column2: Grain marketq developed an easier undertone today, largely in sympathy with securities and the failure of Europe to show any anxiety in regard to the Treasury's decision to end its gold sterilizing policy.

A State prison sentence of twenty years to life was imposed by Judge Koenig in General Sessions yesterday on former Mounted Patrolman Arthur H. Chalmers, 34 years old, on his conviction April 6 of seconddegree murder in the shooting of Miss Irma L. Pradier, 42, a hospital domestic.

A. Bernard Leckie, special agent in charge of the Philadelphia office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that one of every twenty-five persons in the United States has a criminal record. Crime increased 6.2 per cent during the last seven months and in March a slaying occurred "every thirty-nine minutes," Mr. Leckie told an advertising club.

Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, published statistics today listing 1,379 priests and members of religious orders allegedly slain by government forces in Spain. The newspaper said that the figures, supplied by the College of Propaganda of the Faith, did not include secular priests "who have been killed by the hundreds."
The perjury conviction of Louis Luckman in connection with the Samuel Drukman murder case was reversed yesterday in a 4-to-1 decision by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn; a new trial was. ordered.

Brooklyn College, champion of the Intercollegiate Chess League, took a 2-1 lead in the intersectional match with Wayne University of Detroit in last night's second round at the Marshall Chess Club. The visitors led by 2 1/2-1 1/2 in the first round, with one game adjourned.

Sales tax receipts for the first three months of the year, received up to and including April 18, totaled only $9,681,515, as compared with $10,760,579 for the same period last year, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, reported yesterday.

A group of leading rayon weavers will soon become members of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., it was indicated yesterday, when G. H. Conze of Susquehanna Silk Mills, who was re-elected president,

The Rev. Dr. P. H. Murdick, former Elizabeth (N. J.) pastor, died of a heart ailment this morning at his home here. His age was 58. He had been pastor of the Methodist Peace Temple here for four years.

A three-cornered investigation of the activities of Burco, Inc., an investment trust, control of which recently passed to a Canadian-controlled group, was under way yesterday after the New York Curb Exchange had suspended dealings in the common and preferred shares and warrants of the company.

George Whitney took the witness stand here today to be questioned for the first time in public concerning the sustained insolvency of Richard Whitney Co., which landed his brother Richard in Sing Sing a week ago to serve five to ten years for appropriating customers' securities.

The application sent to the War Department by Patrick A. Powers to construct a wharf for a $100,000 amphitheater here will be "pigeonholed" for the time being, it was learned today from Colonel J. F. Mayo, military assistant to Colonel E. L. Daly, head of the North Atlantic Division of the War Department, in New York City.

The Cenwest Corp. J. Brill, press, now the fee owner of the 17-story apartment which covers the block on Central Park West from 70th to 71st Sts, has entered Into an agreement with the Empire Trust Co. as trustee, and the holder of the 5 1/2% Prudence certificates, agreeing that the mortgage thereon is confirmed to be $3,500,000, and is extended to Jan. 1, 1943,

The New York University tennis team turned back St. John's, 6 to 3, yesterday at the Fleet Hollow Courts. The Violet gained four triumphs in the singles and two in the doubles. It was the team's second victory in three starts.

Investors appear to have renewed their interest in business properties in the commercial and industrial center on the lower West Side of Manhattan, according to S. Earl Honig, president of William S. Sussman, Inc.
The international stock market indices for April 16, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

The Treasury procurement division today invited bids as of April 21, to be opened April 28, on 128,900 yards of textiles for shipment by May 20 to various places in Alabama. The invitations are as follows:

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Russell Grace of Great Neck, L. I., on April 12 at the Doctors Hospital, this city. Mrs. Grace is the former Miss Ann Shilton McDonnell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward McDonnell of Mill Neck, L. I. The child will be named Ann Shilton.

Organization of the "World Trade Service," at 76 Beaver Street, to supply weekly and monthly reports on international developments affecting import and export trade was announced here yesterday by Harry Tipper, former vice president of the National Foreign Trade Council.
John W. Marder, consulting industrial engineer and public accountant, died in a hospital here last night.

Joseph Vogt; president of the Schueler Brass Foundry Company of Newark, died yesterday this home after a brief illness. He was 69 years old and had been a lifelong resident of Newark. Mr. Vogt was treasurer of the Bergen Building and Loan Association and chairman of the board of managers of the Irvington Lodge of Elks.

Now that Anschluss is a few weeks old, an optimistic view prevails in Trieste of the probable development of trade between this port and what used to be Austrian territory. Recently this trade has constituted about one-third of the total traffic of the port.

Not long ago we received a letter from a man who said he had been bass fishing in the Carolinas and landed a strange fish. He didn't know what it was, but the natives called it a bowfish. From his description we thought it was a "bowfin," a member of the sturgeon and gar family.

The Old Dutch Brewers, Inc., Louis Hertzberg; president, has taken title to the Knickerbocker Ice Company's property at East Forty-second Street and Glenwood Road, Brooklyn, which it has occupied on a lease since 1934, it was announced yesterday. The cash consideration was not revealed.

With the exception of a small group of specially summoned guests, wearing numbered gray uniforms and looking unhappily out of place, New York enjoyed what might be termed an absolutely perfect opening of the 1938 baseball season at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Receiving the award of merit presented annually by the Park Association of New York City, Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, urged the association last night to "continue its work as a defender of the city parks" and to "organize and galvanize public opinion to demand their extension as the needs of the city for recreation grow."

Mr. and Mrs. W. R. Ames of Claflin, Kan., have announced the approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Verda Ames, to Ralph B. Praeger. The ceremony will take place in the Cadet Chapel at West Point, N. Y., on June 15.

The Coast Guard reported late tonight that the coal freighter David H. Atwater and the fishing schooner Orion had been in collision twentyfive miles south by east of Five Fathom Bank Lightship but that both vessels were proceeding under their own power for Cape May.

Luigi Barzini Jr., Italian newspaper man, was arrested by Japanese last night at Kupeh Pass on the Manchukuoan border. Signor Barzini, a survivor of the bombing of the United States gunboat Panay last Dec. 12,

The New York Credit Men's Association, which last week brought to a successful conclusion a twoyear campaign for enactment of the Pitcher bill empowering the Controller of New York State to require payment bonds on State, public works,

It is a pleasure to report that the 1938 Dodgers tonight are in a tie for first place. Before a crowd of 10,000, at least 8,000 under the Baker Bowl capacity, the men of Burleigh Grimes romped away with the season's opener by beating the Phillies, 12 to 5. They collected fifteen hits for a total of thirty-one bases.

Opposition to President Roosevelt's $5,000,000,000 relief and recovery program took on more definite form today as legislative efforts to bring. relief to business through tax revision continued to bog deeper in a conference committee of the Senate and House.

Monte Weaver pitchsu six-hit baseball today and the Senators took their second consecutive game from the Athletics. The score was 9 to 2. Washington drove eleven hits off two pitchers. Wright and Lewis hit triples and Travis, Ferrell and Myer smacked doubles.

Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday at 10.175 to 10.22 cents a pound c. i. f. European base ports. This compared with 10.05-10.10 cents on Monday. Domestic copper was unchanged at 10 cents. The volume of business done in the export market was heavy.
The Czechoslovak Kozeluh brothers will meet California's Richard Skeen and Johnny Faunce tomorrow in the semi-finals of the Pinehurst professional tennis tournament.

Announcement has been made by the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Edward Schofield Travers of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Travers, to Burrows Sloan Jr., son of Mrs. Burrows Sloan of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Sloan.

Miss Zelina Therese Clark and Donald Peabody Blagden, whose engagement was announced last week, have chosen June 8 as the date for their marriage. The wedding will take place in St. James Church and the ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee

Baseball struck a snag even before the opening game of the local season at the Polo Grounds yesterday in the form of labor trouble. Hours before the New York Giants and the Boston Bees began their initial clash of 1938, the special guards who have policed the grounds for years surrounded the park with a picket line that would have paraded all day were it not for the arrival of Mayor La Guardia.
A son, their fourth child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin J. Butternwieser of 17 East Seventy-third Street on Saturday at the Doctors Hospital. Mrs. Buttenwieser is the former Miss Helen Lehman,

Louis S. Cates, president of the I Phelps Dodge Corporation, esti- b mated net income for the first quar- t ter of 1938 at $1,700,000, or about 34 cents a share, at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday. The present monthly rate of production is about 50 per cent of the best month of 1937, he added.

In the first sale of bull hides in about three months packers yesterday sold 26,500 at 7 1/2 cents for native bulls and 6 1/2 cents for branded bulls,. and it was said that this cleared out the bulk of packers' stocks. Calf skins also were active yesterday, with sales of 15,000. February take-off 91/2 to 15-pound skins.

Frank Thompson Bruno, advertising sales representative of This Week, Sunday magazine of The New York Herald Tribune, died yesterday in his home here after an illness of several months. His age was 42.

The Spanish Government filed with the League of Nations Council today a request that may embarrass seriously French and British plans for a Mediterranean peace with Italy. Foreign Minister Julio Alvarez del Vayo asked the Council to place
Reflecting the large increase in inventories of gasoline and fuel oil in the Atlantic Coast territory, the tanker charter market is reported to be the lowest in several years.

Colonel Yves Picot, president of the "Gueules Cassees" (cracked faces), an association of French war veterans wounded in the head or face, died this morning in the Chateau de Coudon near Toulon at the age of 76.

Contributions totaling $100,380 toward a $263,990 goal set by the committee for planned parenthood to carry out an extensive program to democratize birth control information were announced by Mrs. William C. Potter, chairman, at a meeting of the women's division held in the Cosmopolitan Club yesterday morning.

Secretary Wallace declared in an address here today that "pump priming" must and will continue until government has assurance that business is ready to replace government spending with a flow of capital.

Miss Alice Popham Durant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence N. Durant, was married this afternoon to Dr. Jeremiah Evarts Greene, son of Dr. and Mrs. D. Crosby Greene of Newton Center, Mass. Mgr. Edward L. Buckey, pastor of St. Matthew's Church, Washington, D. C.,

Mrs. Margaret Belknap Farmer of 4 East Ninty-fifth Street, wife of James A. Farmer, an attorney associated with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness.

With prices for cotton in Liverpool advancing little yesterday when trading there was resumed after the Easter holidays, they moved lower on the Cotton Exchange here and ended with net losses of 13 to 15 points.
Interest in virtually all sections of the bond market diminished noticeably yesterday in slower trading on the New York Stock

Kayo Morgan, 31-year-old Detroit southpaw, gained a ten-round decision over Sixto Escobar of Puerto Rico, bantamweight champion of the world, in a non-title fight tonight. Morgan weighed 120 pounds, two pounds over the bantamweight limit, while Escobar scaled 124.

Atlantic Beach Amusement Park at Atlantic Highlands, N. J., has been leased to a group of amusement park operators, headed by John T. Fitz Gerald, president of the Bartenders School, it was announced yesterday by Fred H. Ponty, New York broker, who negotiated the deal.
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a radio speech to Great Britain under the auspices of the British Broadcasting Corporation attacked John L.
President Roosevelt expressed approval today of the agreement between Britain and Italy because of its "proof of the value of peaceful negotiations."
Covici, Friede reports that John Steinbeck's new novel will be finished about July 1. Its locale is Salinas, Calif., and the tentative title is "L'Affaire Lettuceburg."

Robert Perkins Bass, former Governor of New-Hampshire, and Mrs. Bass formally announced here yesterday the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joanne Bass, to Marshall Field Jr., son of Mrs. Diego Suarez of this city and of Marshall Field, banker and sportsman, of New York and Chicago.

Much of the financial derangement, social distress and political unrest "which has plagued the world during the last twenty years" is traceable "to a vast revolution in the prices of raw commodities," according to the results of a study by Dr. Melvin T. Copeland,

The marriage of Miss Flora Brady Garvan; daughter of Mrs. Francis P. Garvan and the late Mr. Garvan, to Francis Dana Winslow 2d of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., will take place on Saturday at the home of her mother in Wheatley Hills, L. I.

Mr. Paul Boepple, conductor of the Dessoff Choirs, is to be congratulated upon the originality and the artistic enterprise he showed in the selection of the choral program that he directed last night in Carnegie Hall.

Plans of the architectural profession for an attack on the problem of adequate housing for urban dwellers in the $30 per month rent class were revealed today before the American Institute of Architects.

Trainer Earle Sand expressed satisfaction with a workout today by Maxwell Howard's Kentucky Derby eligibles, Stagehand and The Chief, who were kept in check all the way while clocked in 0:26 for the quarter, 0:52 1-5 for the half, 1:19 for six furlongs and 1:43 3-5 for the mile.

Thomas F. Jeffress, president of the King Cotton Mills Corporation of North Carolina, died today in his home, Meadowbrook Manor, Chesterfield County. He was 78 years old. Mr. Jeffress was chairman of the board of the Wortendyke Manufacturing Company and a member of the board of directors of the Bank of Commerce and Trust of Richmond.

Mr. and Mrs. Forsyth Wickes of 4 East Seventy-second Street have announced the engagement of their third daughter, Miss Kitty Wickes, to Ralph H. Poole Jr., son- of Mr. and Mrs. Poole of Lake Forest, Ill.

The marriage of Miss Jessie McClelland Hutcheson, daughter of Mrs. Mary Hutcheson of Brooklyn and Johnstone, Scotland, to John Carlon Tattersall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Tattersall of Fort Monroe, Va., and Springfield,
The growing safety of air travel was strikingly marked yesterday by the presentation of the second annual Aviation Safety Awards to four of the nation's airlines by the National Safety Council.

The International Art Exhibition in Venice, Italy, which has been held biennially for more than forty years, will have this Summer a representation of American art lent by many American museums and collectors.

Mayor La Guardia appealed to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night to use its influence in obtaining legislation and constitutional revision to curb the spending power of the courts, limit their interference with the police powers of the city and institute widespread judicial reforms in the interest of economy, and efficiency.

Czechoslovakia recognized Italian conquest of Ethiopia today, it was reported here. The Czechoslovak Minister to Rome, Dr. Frantisek Chvalkovsky, notified Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano of Italy that the Prague government now considered him accredited to "the King of Italy and Emperor of Ethiopia."

A part of the railing from the balcony of the old Federal Hall on which George Washington rested his hand during his inauguration as first President of the United States in 1789 was used again yesterday.

The decision upholding price cuts on radios in view of the "collapse" of price maintenance under the Feld-Crawford act in that industry, handed down on Monday by Supreme Court Justice Patterson at White Plains, will be appealed and a jury trial sought,
The Administration's $1,156,000,000 naval expansion bill was taken up by the Senate today with every indication that it will be passed by a substantial majority.

Sixteen bridge teams qualified last night at the Hotel Ambassador for the knockout rounds which start tonight in the annual contract team of four championship for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup. Of the group A seeded teams only one failed to qualify, that of Charles Goren, Mrs. Ralph Young, Charles Solomon and John Crawford.

An average monthly price of $2.40 a hundredweight to dairymen supplying the New York City market is contemplated under the proposed Federal marketing order, Homer S. Rolfe, president of the Metropolitan Cooperative Milk Producers Bargaining Agency, disclosed today.

Jackie Coogan filed an affidavit in Superior Court today charging that his mother, Mrs. Lillian Coogan Bernstein, "has made a number of inconsistent and contradictory statements under oath" in her deposition given in his suit for an accounting of his earnings.

On the ground that information reported by it as required in registration statements is being used by its competitors and that the expense of continued listing is not proportionate to the advantages derived, the Lima Cord Sole and Heel Corporation has filed an application with the SEC for permission to withdraw its $1 par value common stock
Premier Edouard Daladier intends to build up France's national morale before going ahead with plans to borrow money from the people.

About 500 high Chinese Government leaders gathered today to honor the memory of Dr. Herman Liu, president of the American Mission Shanghai University, who was recently murdered in Shanghai, apparently because of his refusal to participate in the Japanese puppet government.

T. O. M. Sopwith, twice unsuccessful challenger for the America's Cup, sees no prospect of Britain challenging again for the famous international yachting trophy for many years. "Under no circumstances will I make another attempt with Endeavour II," said Sopwith on his return from New York today.

About 900 striking truck drivers continued to shackle heavy hauling and delivery throughout Rochester tonight while officials of both union and warehousemen's organizations tried to arrange an armistice to end the five-day walk-out.

" If there is any definite trend in steel business, it is downward," The Iron Age says this week. "Not only have sales during the first half of April failed to increase over the March rate, but in some instances they are lower, the losses on a tonnage basis ranging from slight to as much as 25 per cent.

Electric power production declined last week, running counter to seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index has dropped to 91.0 from 92.9. The figure was 106.8 for the week ended April 17, 1937.

KINGS BLOCH, DELPHINE (Dec. 26, 1937). Gross assets, $38,397; net, $36,359. To husband, Joseph Bloch. Chief assets, real estate, $7,500; stocks and bonds, $16,122; mortgages, notes. cash and insurance, $14,389; miscellaneous property, $375. Abraham Wieler, attorney, 220 Broadway, Manhattan.

The Hungarian Reference Library, on the third floor of the Berkeley Building, 19 West Fortyfourth Street, was officially opened yesterday afternoon by John Pelenyi, Hungarian Minister to the United States, who referred to the library as an "important bond between the cultural lives of Hungary and the United States."
The White Sox beat the Tigers today, 5 to 4, scoring the tying and winning runs in the seventh and eighth innings without the benefit of a base hit.

The Dodgers were blown rudely out of their brief tie for first place on the wings of a ninth-inning wild pitch by big Max Butcher today and Burleigh Grimes's blood pressure went up as rapidly as his Dodgers went down to a 6-5 defeat by the Phils.
The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for 131,955 shares of $1 par common stock of the Lincoln Mortgage Company, Newark, N. J.

Frederick Bristol, American pianist, who has appeared frequently on the local concert platform during the last decade, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. According to his long-established custom, Mr. Bristol devoted his program to compositions by the moderns.
Sir Henry Newbolt, author of many popular historical poems and books, died today at the age of 75.
One woman aerialist was killed and another gravely injured when they fell from the top of a ninety-six-foot ladder during practice for a carnival act last night. Hurled to the ground when
Banks in what formerly was Austriahave changed all bookkeeping, accounts and documents from schillings to reichsmarks, said a report from Vienna made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Rallying in the ninth for four runs, the Princeton baseball team administered the first defeat of the season to Rutgers, 7 to 4, before 1,000 fans on Neilson Field today. Bob Riddle, who relieved Lefty Farber for the Tigers in the fourth, was credited with the victory, Princeton's fifth in nine starts.

A nationwide survey of the medical and dental needs of the indigent will be made under the joint sponsorship of the American Dental and American Medical Associations, according to an announcement by Dr. J. Ben Robinson of Baltimore, dean of the Maryland School of Dentistry and a trustee of the American Dental Association.

Turpentine firm, 23c; sales, 69 barrels; receipts, 420 barrels: shipments, 827 barrels; stock, 30,250 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 771: receipts, 1,352; shipments. 4.463; stock, 75,095. Quote-B. $3.45: D, $3.65; E, $3.65-70; F, $4.50-60; G, H, I, $4.60: K, $4.60-621/2; M. $4.65-70; N, $5.10; WG, $5.95-$6.00; WW, X, $6.40.

The Czechoslovak Kozeluh brothers, Karel and Jan, will fight it out in the final of the Pinehurst professional tennis tournament tomorrow. Karel, national pro titleholder, won his semi-final match easily today, eliminating Richard Skeen of Burbank, Calif., 6-1, 6-2, 6-1. Jan won by default after his adversary, Johnny Faunce of Hollywood. Calif., injured his right ankle and could not resume play.

The Polo Grounds was still picketed yesterday by the special guards formerly employed there despite an attempt by Nathan Frankel, the Mayor's labor adviser, to settle the trouble between representatives of the guards' union and the ball park management.

Henry. S. Morgan's new yacht Djinn today won handily in the first contest of the series of four for the Prince of Wales Trophy. The United States craft took the lead halfway down the first windward leg and was not caught subsequently in this race for six-meter craft sailed in a fresh southwesterly breeze.

Cortlandt W. Handy, president of Handy Harman since 1927, was elected chairman yesterday to take office on May 1, and G. H. Niemeyer, vice 'president, was elected president of the internationally prominent dealers in silver and gold.

Although the brooks from the mountains are still high with snow water, the streams are clear in Vermont, and thousands of anglers are chafing impatiently, counting the days until May 1, when they can go after the trout.

Joe DiMaggio's hold-out siege against the Yankees terminated abruptly and without much dramatics yesterday, when it was announced that the American League's home-run champion and so-called "wonder player" had notified Colonel Jacob Ruppert from his home in San Francisco that he has accepted terms.

Secretary Wallace is the latest spokesman of the Administration to champion the President's new spending program. An Associated Press dispatch quotes him as saying in an address at Omaha that the present decline of business followed a too sudden curtailment of Government expenditures, and as arguing from this premise that the expenditures must be increased.

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today exemptions from the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 to the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company and William G. Mather, Cyrus S. Eaton and Edward S. Greene, voting trustees, and to the Cliffs Corporation and William G. Mather, S. Livingston Mather and G. G. Wade, voting trustees.
Mayor La Guardia, Commissioner Valentine and other officials of the Police Department headed a procession of 700 patrolmen yesterday morning at the funeral of Patrolman Humbert Moruzzi.

Howard S. Palmer, president and a trustee of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, presented today a dismal picture of the financial outlook of that system to the stockholders at their annual meeting, at which seventeen directors were reelected.

Two more children of United States Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy sailed yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan to join other members of the family in London. They are Rosemary, 19 years old, who has been at Marymount Convent, Tarrytown, and Eunice, 16, a student at the Sacred Heart Convent. Noroton, Conn.
The Rev. Charles Llewellyn Bilkey, former Cleveland pastor, died here from a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday at the Queen of the Angels Hospital. He was 61. A son of the late

State Controller Tremaine seventh thinks business men should write to Senator Pat Harrison, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, to continue his fight to prevent restoration of the undistributed profits tax by amendment of the Senate Tax Bill.

Cooperation of three retail millinery organizations as the first fruits of the campaign under way to line up support of the syndicates for elimination of purchases from sub-standard shops was announced yesterday by Nathan Spector, manager of the Millinery Workers Union.

Joseph L. Donovan, State Senator, a Democratic leader in the upper house of the Maryland General Assembly and candidate for nomination for Congress, died today at his home in Marriottsville in his sixty-third year. Mr. Donovan had been State's

World boxing champions henceforth will receive formal, world-wide recognition of their titles as a result of action taken by the World Boxing Conference, which closed today. The conference established a world championship committee, representing virtually all the professional boxing governing bodies,

Acceptance by thirty-eight business leaders of new key positions in the campaign of the Greater New- York Fund for $10,000,000 to aid private welfare and health agencies was announced yesterday. The fund will make its appeal to corporations and their employes next month.

A proposal for a constitutional declaration of milk as a public utility was considered tonight by. "liberal" elements, who discussed introducing a measure in the Constitutional Convention to authorize placing the product under supervision of a body similar to the Public Service Commission.

Rioting at Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street, where the German-American Bund, Nazi organization in this country, was staging a celebration of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's 49th birthday, resulted in the injury of at least seven men last night, and the calling of police reserves to protect the meeting.

The tragic odyssey of fifty-one helpless Jews from two villages 'in the Austrian Burgenland, described in yesterday's TIMES, is heartbreaking enough in itself. For six weeks these bewildered people, arrested and robbed when the Nazis took possession of Austria, were held prisoners.

Mrs. Ruth C. Warren, the second divorced wife of George C. Warren Jr., wealthy vice chairman of the Republican. State Committee and president of the State Fish and Game Commission, today lost her suit to set aside their Reno divorce of 1935. At the conclusion

Judge Frederick W. Fosdick issued warrants today for the arrest of former Representative Robert Dinsmore of east Boston, and Harold Simpson, a broker, on charges of conspiring with Edmund L. Dolan, former City Treasurer, and J. Walter Quinn to bribe Suffolk County jurors scheduled to try Dolan, Quinn and Edward J. Supple on several indictments. al indictments.

Carroll E. Gray Jr., former president of Burco, Inc., and Ralph Rushmore, a statistician recently employed by Burco, were examined privately yesterday in Attorney General Bennett's Inquiry into circumstances that caused the Curb Exchange to suspend dealings in the shares of the investment trust on Tuesday.

Greetings from President Roosevelt, who wrote that he would have liked to attend "but alas, I must stay here working in my shirtsleeves"; from Chief Justice Hughes and from Justices Cardozo, Reed and Stone were read last night at a reunion dinner of alumni of the Columbia University Law School at the Hotel Astor.
Soviet children were authoritatively advised today to disobey parents who attempt to send them to church next Saturday with the traditional Easter cake and cheese for priestly blessing.

Flooring his opponent eight times, Nathan Mann, young New Haven heavyweight, knocked out Hans Haverlick, Austrian champion, in the third session of their scheduled ten-round feature bout at the Hippodrome last night. The finish came after 2:54 of the stanza had elapsed as Referee Arthur Donovan called an end to the one-sided proceedings.

It was learned here today that Germany will denounce as from June 30 the agreement between the Austrian Federal Railways and neighboring systems regularizing charges for the transport of freight goods.

Immediate repeal of the undistributed profits tax and modification of the capital gains levy, in line with the Senate bill now deadlocked in conference, were the major recommendations for relief of the "critical" unemployment problem contained in a surprise report issued today by the special Senate Committee on Unemployment and Relief.

Shareholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at their annual meeting yesterday threw their full support behind the management and policies of the $5,000,000,000 organization in its conflict with the Federal Communications Commission and denounced the recent "one-man"
Pedro Groppo, Finance Minister, announced tonight that Argentina had floated in Europe two loans totaling approximately $17,150,000.
The State of Massachusetts awarded yesterday an issue of $1,674,900 of notes to Whiting, Weeks Knowles on their bid of an interest rate of 0.14 per cent plus $20.

Harry C. Kane as referee approved yesterday the acquisition by the Celotex Corporation from the Phoenix Securities Corporation of 109,360 common and 9,496 preference shares of the Certain-teed Products Corporation, for which Bord Celotex will deliver to Phoenix 43,744 common shares of its own stock and $569,760 in cash.
Efforts of a New York bondholders' group to have Fort Lee give Special consideration to its claims will be opposed by the State Muncipal Finance Commission.

Nathan L. Amster, president of the Manhattan Railway Company, said yesterday that the company had not asked the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan or filed with that body a formal application for one.

Police Superintendent Samuel Gearhart of Lower Merion announced some time ago that he would buy special shoes for his men at about $14 a pair to keep them from getting flat feet. This letter came from a London shoe firm:

The index of daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas increased in March by 5.9 per cent over February, 'allowance being made for seasonal factors, the Department of Commerce announced today.
A British mission to study the possibilities of purchasing military aircraft in the United States and Canada left held Southampton aboard the liner Queen Mary today.

Boris Maruchess, long known in the garment industry here as a labor-relations conciliator and for nearly fourteen years labor manager of the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange, 22 East Seventeenth Street, died of a heart attack on Tuesday night at his home, 115 West Eleventh Street. He was 50 years old.

Renewed rumors of former Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's transfer to a concentration camp were denied again today in official circles. Despite the fact that the Nazi guard has been withdrawn from the Belvedere Palace, his home, it was stated thathe was still there, guarded by detectives.

Governor Earle of Pennsylvania was charged here today by the GuffeyLewis leaders in that State with having written a letter to Secretary Ickes, designating Matthew C. McCloskey, Philadelphia contractorpolitician, as Pennsylvania's representative before the Public Works Administration.

Irving Rossi, new president of the Reynolds Investing Company, sent yesterday a letter to stockholders saying he had been advised by counsel that the deal involving the purchase of the stock of the Fiscal Management Company, Ltd., was illegal.

James (Jeff) Burkitt, who was arrested here Saturday night because he attempted to make a speech without a permit, personally served a subpoena on Mayor Hague today requiring the latter's presence as a defense witness at Mr. Burkitt's trial on a disorderly conduct charge Friday.
Mrs. Helen Wills Moody headed back to the scene of her last big tennis match yesterday when she sailed on the United States liner Manhattan for England to launch her comeback campaign.
Napoleon B. Fairclough, who retired three months ago after fiftysix years in the coal business, died yesterday in his home here.
Collection of dummy $19,654,309.98 in alcoholic beverage taxes in the first nine months of the fiscal year ended March 31 was announced today by Tax Commissioner Graves.
Boston at New York--Shoffner vs. Hubbell. Brooklyn at Philadelphia--Pressnell vs. Passeau. Chicago at Cincinnati--Carleton vs. Derringer. Pittsburgh at St. Louis--Swift vs. C. Davis.

Columbia University conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Letters upon Dr. Celestin Bougle, director of l'Ecole Normale Superieure of the University of Paris, at a convocation yesterday afternoon in the trustees' room of the Low Memorial Library.

The nation needs 1,500,000 to 2,000,000 new homes and has the money to build them, Ormond E. Loomis, assistant to John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, told the American Institute of Architects today.

Seventy- five- year- old Herman Hecht, revered by thousands of Jews in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn for his unceasing efforts to aid the oppressed, was found murdered yesterday afternoon in his home at 1,849 Prospect Place, Brooklyn.

Operations of the National Biscuit Company in the first quarter of this year resulted in a net profit of $2,660,570 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges but before surtax on undistributed earnings, according to a report issued yesterday.
Jess Halsted, secretary of the Chicago Stock Exchange for seven years, has resigned to return to the practice of law, it was announced today. The board accepted his

1:00-1:45 P. M.--Advertising Club Luncheon; Donald Flamm, President of WMCA-WMCA. 1:30-2:00P. M.--"Finances of the State," Governor Lehman, at Merchants Association Luncheon, Hotel Pennsylvania-WEAF. 4:30-5:00P. M.-General Federation of Women's Clubs Program; Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming, and Others-WJZ. 8:00-9:00 P. M.-Vallee Varieties: Scenes From Stephen Vincent Benet's Play, "For Future Reference," with Arthur Byron-WEAF.
Stocks improved and closed steadier and mixed after early weakness; airplane shares, with gains of fractions to six points, were the feature; total turnover, 777,540 shares.
The International League, boasting a well-distributed array of fresh talent, will open its fifty-fifth season today with the circuit's four northern teams visiting their southern rivals.

The Cash-O-Way Safe Company has been formed to market a new, compact type of store and office safe specially designed to meet such hazards as daytime hold-ups and night-time burglaries. The new safe has a money slot, making it unnecessary to open it to deposit bills.
The new Wages and Hours Bill encountered another obstacle today in the form of a dissenting report by Representative Ramspeck of Georgia, ranking majority member of the House Labor Committee.

A medical service that reaches every member of the community is the first essential in a general program "to socialize the psychopath," Professor David Kennedy Henderson, psychiatrist of the University of Edinburgh, Scotland, told the New York Academy last night.

Supreme Court Justice Parton Swift granted today a permanent injunction terminating operations of Huff Haskins, Inc., local dealers in securities. Justice Swift's action was taken with consent of the defendants, the Securities Merger Corporation, a subsidiary organization, and John W. Huff and George C. Haines, officers of the firm.

The outlook for better driving and safer pedestrian habits was pictured as more promising than at any time since the invention of the automobile yesterday at the Greater New York Safety Council in the Hotel Astor.

The Senators blanked Philadelphia by. 3 to 0 today as Dutch Leonard fluttered his knuckle ball past the Athletic batters. Making his first start in the American League, Leonard held the Athletics to seven hits. He came to the Senators from Atlanta. Today's victory was the Senators' third in a row over the Athletics.

Favorite teams with the exception of that headed by P. Hal Sims survived the first knockout round played last night at the Hotel Ambassador in the national contract team-of-four championship for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup. The Regency Club team of Sims, John Mattheys, Walter Malowan,

With the supplementary inquiry into the Whitney affair, before the Securities and Exchange Commission at Washington, the episode has seemed to the general public to have become more and more involved. Testimony last Thursday and on Monday has aroused inquiry as to how securities and cash of the Stock Exchange gratuity fundabout $1,250,000 in all-should have been in the private possession of Richard Whitney Co.

The largest piece of public utility financing since mid-February will reach the market today with the public offering of $60,000,000 of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., 3 1/2 per cent ten-year debentures at 101 3/4 by a banking syndicate composed of sixty-four underwriting houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.

A subsidy to assist the construction of a church seating 2,000 in Bubenic--a new Prague suburb-has been granted by the National Defense Ministry. The subvention will be employed for building a huge bombproof shelter beneath the church on the most up to date lines.

The Police Athletic League, which spells "PAL" to 75,000 boys and girls of this city, made public yesterday its annual report on the relations between the "cop" on the corner and the small "kids" who play on the sidewalks of New York.

Three residential properties on Congress Street, in Jersey City Heights, N. J., have been sold through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker. Edith Brignola bought the two-family house at 18 Congress Street from the American Homes Building and Loan Association, Adele Knaub sold the two-family house at 103 Congress Street to T. Rocco, and C. Arantine bought the one-family dwelling at 192 Congress Street from Julia Murphy.

A revival in the foreign demand for North American cash wheat and unexpected strength in Liverpool were factors largely responsible for an upturn of around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade here.

Advertising can and should play an essential part if the country is again to attain or exceed the 1929 figure of $80,000,000,000 national income, Gilbert Kinney, vice president of the J Walter Thompson Company, de clared today in accepting the post of chairman of the board of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

The first session of the auction sale of furnishings of the James A. Burden residence, 7 East Ninetyfirst Street, under the management of the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., brought $6,776 yesterday afternoon. The sale is being held by order

Andrew Carnegie Whitfield, 28year-old nephew of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, who has been hunted by the police of eight States since he took off in a power glider from Roosevelt Field last Friday and disappeared, left his home on Thursday night after a quarrel with his wife, his brother, John H. Whitfield, disclosed yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Mary Rothschild, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans S. Rothschild of New York and Port Chester, to Frederick William Mayer, son of Mrs. J. H. Mayer of Mamaroneck, took place here this afternoon at Green Gables, the country place of the bride's parents.

Attached to the staff of the United States Embassy in London "to study conditions and practices in British and other foreign security markets," Lunsford P. Yandell of the Securities and Exchange Commission sailed for Europe yesterday on the liner Manhattan.

Czechoslovakia will adhere strictly to her laws safeguarding minorities, but will resist any challenge to her democratic form of government, Vladimir Hurban, Czechoslovak Minister to the United States, said yesterday in an address to business men and bankers at the offices of Calvin Bullock, 1 Wall Street.

George Benneyan, promotion manager of Newsweek, has been appointed head of the research and promotion department of the bureau of advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, William A. Thomson, director of the bureau, announced yesterday.

The State Department received by mail today a request from the House Foreign Affairs Committee for comment on the resolution of Representative Scott of California for the United States to name governments that have violated treaties.

The Census Bureau reported today that flaxseed crushed in the quarter ended on March 31 totaled 180,918 tons, compared with 228,904 in the corresponding quarter a year ago. Linseed oil produced totaled 125,587,390 pounds, compared with 156,877,263.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey accused "a vast number of responsible citizens" of undermining the jury system by their reluctance to serve in a speech broadcast last night over municipal radio station WNYC.

In the absence of an authentic demand for ransom since March 1 and hoping to learn the fate of his son, Peter, Murray Levine, New Rochelle lawyer, offered a reward of $25,000 yesterday for the return of the boy alive. If the boy is dead the father will pay $5,000 for information leading to recovery of the body.

The standards of the merchant marine with respect to safety in ship construction, upbuilding of personnel relations and the handling of cargoes were criticized yesterday by speakers addressing the marine section of the Greater New York Safety Council, at the Hotel Astor.

The five-story building at 46 East Fifty-seventh Street has been leased for use by Parish-Watson Co., Inc., on behalf of William Randolph Hearst, for the display and sale of a large part of the vast Hearst art collection.

Properly manipulated tariff rates can be made to serve the dual purpose of helping stabilize domestic economy and of curbing the price fixing which anti-trust laws have failed to meet, Dr. O. M. W. Sprague, Professor of Banking and Finance of the graduate school of business of Harvard University, said yesterday at the seventeenth
Sensational results marked the fourteenth round of the United States chess championship tournament of the National Chess Federation last nigh at the R. C. A. Building, Rockefeller Center,

WHEREVER they play it, the opening game of the season is just one of 154 ball games that the fellows in flannels have to play before the curtain goes down on the major league pennant campaigns. But, just the same, the opening salvo has added attractions in the way of sight and sound.

The German people-both the 75,000,000 within the borders of the expanded Reich and many additional millions either adjoining its borders or scattered throughout the world but united under the terms of the National Socialist racial ideology-joined hands today to pay renewed homage to Chancellor Adolf Hitler on the occasion of his forty-ninth birthday.

Premier Mussolini's campaign for more Italian babies has got results this year. The Official Gazette today published figures for the first three months of 1938 showing a total of 281,629 births, compared with 257,030 for the same period last year.

Albert Bledsoe Herrick, inventor and an associate of Thomas A. Edison at Menlo Park, N. J., died on Monday of a heart ailment in his home in Charlottesville, Va., according to word received here yesterday. He was 76 years old.

The outlook for the automobile industry during the remainder of the 1938 season is regarded as far from brilliant by various members of the steel industry, who do not expect any important steel buying to develop from that source until models for 1939 are put into production. By that time, they believe,

A capacity crowd is expected at Squadron A Armory tonight to see the opening of the three-day Squadron A Spring horse show, which has attracted a large number of the leading campaigners in this vicinity. More than 600 entries have been received.

In an attempt to formulate a citywide health program for the public school system an experimental survey of the physical conditions of the students at Seward Park High School, on the lower East Side, has been undertaken under the joint auspices of the Board of Education, the Department of Health and Progressive Education Association.

President Roosevelt conferred with Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and William O. Douglas, chairman, and John W. Hanes, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, on equipment loans to utilities as a means of stimulating business recovery.

Mrs. Alice Clarke, for more than n a decade head of the department of food production, supervision and service of the Frank G. Shattuck Company (Schrafft's), and the wife of Arban Clarke, an executive of the General Foods Company, died Tuesday in Brooklyn Hospital after a long illness.
Sir Mohammed Iqbal, Indian Moslem poet, philosopher and politician, died here at the age of 62.

Paul Mantz, air service operator, said today that, so far as he and his clients knew, an airplane that figured in a Neutrality Law indictment here was intended for the use of Colonel Roberto Ferrero of Mexico City. The plane is one of four that Fritz Bieler, resident of Mexico, is accused of having bought in this country and having shipped to the Spanish Loyalist Government via Mexico.

A representative of the French Ambassador will present to James Sullivan of Newport, R. I., a Croix de Guerre with Palms at the annual Spring dance of the Seventyseventh Division at the Hotel Roosevelt Saturday night, almost twenty years after the act of heroism that earned the award, it was announced yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia has sent to the Board of Estimate his veto of its recent resolution authorizing the issuance of $600,000 in tax notes to raise funds for payment of expenses of the Transit Commission and salaries of its employes for the first half of 1938, it was announced yesterday just before the Mayor left for his ten-day tour of the Middle West and Southwest.

The marriage of Miss Lucille Niemeyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav H. Niemeyer of New York and Westport, Conn., to William Harmon Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Hart of East Orange, N. J., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 817 Fifth Avenue.

A troupe of 300 actors and 120 head of livestock reminiscent of Western frontiers, constituting an "American Cavalcade" to depict leading events of American history, was suggested last night as the contribution of the Sons of the American Revolution, Empire State Society, to the World's Fair.

In Generalissimo Francisco Franco's radio speech yesterday, which for him was unusually long and vehement, there was not only a note of triumph, not only a warning to his enemies that a day of reckoning was drawing near; there was also a glance into the future when the civil war is finished and the task of reconstruction and reuniting Spain begins.

Two wardens and eight vestrymen, to serve-for one year, were elected at a meeting on Tuesday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, Tenth Street and Second Avenue. Those elected are:

Miss Carolyn Keyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonhard A. Keyes of Maplewood, N. J., has completed plans for her marriage to Thomas Sidney Cadwallader 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Augustus Cadwallader of Yardley, Pa., which will take place the night of June 18 in the Prospect Presbyterian Church, Maplewood.

No other country of comparable size can boast of such complete records of human evolution as those that are found in Java. While engaged in a study tour to all sites bearing on the geology and archeology, of early man, my party, consisting of Dr. P. Teilhard de Chardin, Dr. and Mrs.

Unseasonably warm weather continued yesterday as the mercury climbed to 81 degrees at 3 P. M., 7 less than the record high for the date, established in 1927. The average temperature, 70 degrees, was 19 above normal. The low of 59 was recorded at 6:50 A. M.
Dr. and Mrs. Walter A. Calihan announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Anne Calihan, to George Hollister Spencer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Spencer.

Horace Russell, who resigned yesterday as general counsel of the Home Owners Loan Corporation after Representative- Church, Illinois Republican, had called the attention of the House to franked letters sent out by Mr. Russell recommending his former assistant, Judge O. B. Taylor, invited newspaper men to his office this afternoon and answered questions.

Dr. William J. Flannery, a surgeon in New York for more than thirty years, died on Tuesday this home, 238 Arlington Avenue, Brooklyn, at the age of 61. He was born in New Britain, Conn., and was graduated from Yale Medical School in 1901. He served in the City

The net income of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and its subsidiaries for the year ended on March 31 amounted to $23,497,054 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other deductions. The net was equal after

Sports celebrities gathered tonight to. pay tribute to Bill Dinneen, retired baseball umpire, at a testimonial dinner. Dinneen retired at the end of last season after twenty-seven years as an umpire and thirteen as a pitcher.

Organized, constructive efforts in alleviating the distress of refugees from totalitarian States, rather than "mere characterizations of their plight," were urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, foreign secretary of the Federal Council of Churches.

Frederic McLaughlin, owner of the Chicago Black Hawks, world hockey champions, announced today that Paul Thompson, left winger, had been appointed assistant manager for the 1938-39 season. He also will act as coach. Thompson will

A plan for the reorganization of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad, which has filed bankruptcy proceedings in Federal court, was presented today to Judge William Clark by George S. Hobart, counsel, and signed by G. Walsh, secretary of the railroad.
It looks as if Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean didn't change anything except his uniform after his leap from the Cards to the Cubs in exchange for $185,000 and three players.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has bought the screen rights to "On Borrowed Time," at a price not yet disclosed. The deal is particularly interesting, since John Hay Whitney, who owns the dramatic rights and is the principal backer of the stage production, is head man at SelznickInternational.
Philanthropic organizations received a smaller share of the national income in 1936 than in any year since 1925, Charles V. Vickrey, president of Golden Rule Foundation, reported yesterday.
Word has been received here of the death yesterday in a Stamford (Conn.) hospital of Henry Berg of Darien, former hat manufacturer and onetime Police Commissioner of this city.

The Harvard varsity and freshmen lacrosse teams scored impressive victories in their opening games today by downing teams from Tufts. The varsity score was 9 to 4 and the freshman count 11 to 1. Hammond, outside home, scored six goals for the Crimson varsity.

BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions SWORD STEAMSHIP LINE, INC., 76 Beaver St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $336,713 and assets of $1,071,926, including six steamships operated in coastwise trade.

A program of ancient Chinese shadow plays was presented last night in a ballroom of the Ambassador as a benefit for the American Bureau for Medical Aid to China. Puppets, manipulated from bamboo rods, comprise the "cast" for the plays which originated many centuries ago.

Paced by Arky Vaughan and Al Todd, each with three hits in five times at bat, the Pirates smothered the Cardinals today, 9 to 4. Five pitchers tried ineffectively to stop the 20-hit attack. No Pittsburgher went hitless.
Governor Philip F. La Follette dedared in a radio address tonight that the National Administration could have prevented the current business slump through a carefully worked out program.

Applicants for small business loans to. be issued by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation under the Glass-Steagall law continued yesterday. to ask the assistance of the special bureau opened in the Hotel New Yorker on Tuesday under the auspices of the Smaller Business Association for the New York District.

Questioned on the proposed $300,000,000 government fund to finance the purchase of railway equipment, Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, said yesterday: "We don't need equipment."

Miss Helen Katharine Young, daughter of Mrs. William Christopher Young of Germantown and of the late Mr. Young, was married at noon today to George H. Frew Jr. of this city and New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Frew of New York.
President Roosevelt expressed his interest in National Music Week, May 1 to 8, in a letter received yesterday by C. M. Tremaine, secretary of the music week committee. The letter is as follows:

The program of the benefit concert for Austrian refugees to be given Wednesday in Carnegie Hall by Jascha Heifetz, violinist, and the NBC Symphony Orchestra, under Dr. Artur Rodzinski, was announced yesterday by Countess Mercati, chairman of the executive committee.

The Commodity Credit Corporation, the government agency that makes crop loans to facilitate the orderly marketing of agricultural products, will offer on Monday $200,000,000 of its notes maturing in not less than eighteen months. This will be the first step by the corporation in financing its own activities since Congress provided for the guarantee of its notes by the government.

Postmaster General James A. Farley ridiculed tonight reports of serious dissension within the Democratic party and struck out at Wall Street as the source of "propaganda" intended to picture President Roosevelt as seeking dictatorial powers to make this a Fascist nation.

Renewed devotion to "the American way" of life, with freedom in citizenship and of enterprise preferred to "regimented efficiency" or an "elusive security born of false economics and visionary theories,"

Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean's debut as a Cub was just a six-inning armloosening chore for the former Cardinal loud-speaker today, the "great one" coasting to a 10-to-4 victory over the Reds on the impetus of a nine-run splurge in the second. It was the second straight victory for Chicago over Cincinnati.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 18: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Brittain, T. B., Naval Academy; to command the Shaw. Champion, C. .C.; Jr., VP-16, the Teal; to Naval Academy. Dupree, M. M., Naval Academy; to command the Mugford. Pollard, L. K., granted sick leave 2 months: to await orders at Portsmouth, Va.
Fritz Kruse of the Hamburg-American Line, master of the flagship New York, was announced yesterday in a cable message received at the New York offices of the line from the main offices in Hamburg.

Employers who fail to pay taxes under the Federal Social Security Act face confiscation of their property under liens, and the government, which has begun a drive to round up delinquents, is prepared to proceed on that basis, it was revealed yesterday.
Peace prevailed here today after two days of disorders brought about by the picketing of Fisher Body No. 1 plant of General Motors Corporation by the United Automobile Workers of Amerida.

As City templated under Manager Paul Morton of Trenton ordered today that any one refusing private employment be taken off relief, Governor Moore disclosed plans to "use some sense" in reduring relief rolls throughout the State.

Bomb throwing, which is again a daily occurrence in Jerusalem, and rumors afloat here this morning that curfew was being resumed, did not prevent an enthusiastic crowd from filling Edison Hall for Toscanini's fifth concert of the season with the Palestine Orchestra.
More than 250 persons were dead or missing today as the result of a severe earthquake in Anatolia. There were thirteen shocks between 1 P. M. yesterday and this morning. Some were extremely violent.

A bondholders' committee has been formed to act on behalf of holders of first-mortgage serial 6 per cent coupon gold bonds of the 103 East Fifth-seventh Street Building (Ritz Tower Apartments), due serially through Nov. 10, 1941, following default in payment of interest due to the successor trustee and an assignment of rents by the present owner of the property to the Continental Bank and Trust Company. James A. Beha heads the
Shopping in the Istanbul bazaars will soon lose much of its traditional charm as a result of a new law that will require every merchant in Turkey to have one price and stick to it.
The Second Annual Art Show of works by members of the Town Hall Club is being held in the North Dining Room of the club, 123 West Forty-third Street, through April 30.

The Honduran legation here emphatically denies there is a revolt in Honduras. Airplane passengers had reported a revolt headed by General Filiberto Diaz Zelaya and Rufino Solis, who, they said, had gained control of the north coast, where several American fruit companies have large holdings.

RETAIL CLASSIFIED BY OFFICE Arkwright, Inc., 128 W. 31st BALTIMORE-Brager, Eisenberg Co.; I. Schindler, men's clothing, hats. BOSTON--Gilchrist Co.; Miss S. Lieberman, basement, misses', junior dresses, samples, jobs, cotton dresses, negligees, house coats.
Home T. Ashbaugh, State news editor of The Associated Press at Sacramento, died today after a month's illness of stomach and in testinal disorders.

Prices of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday with railroad issues particularly weak. Only in the United States Government obligations and in some scattered foreign dollar loans was any strength apparent, although the volume of trading increased to $5,406,125, compared with $4.941.000 on Tuesday.

With England represented by five experts and France, Austria, Czechoslovakia, Finland and Latvia by one each, the annual international chess masters tournament opened today under the auspices of the Easter Congress of the Kent County Chess Association at the Grand Hotel, Cliftonville.

Theodore G. Montague, president of the Borden Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the company's stockholders in Jersey City that an increase in Federal taxes might be expected this year. He said also that
With her twin sons, both Harvard Law School graduates, acting as her attorneys, Mrs. Mary Murtagh, widow of Thomas Murtagh, former chief of the Eighth Battalion of the Fire Department, won from

The Joint Congressional Committee named to investigate the Tennessee Valley Authority and its relations with private utilities, will meet Friday and organize. Senator Donahey of Ohio, who is slated to become chairman, called the meeting today and said he hoped the committee would decide upon preliminary plans.

More than 1.000 persons attended a memorial service for the Rev. Dr. Samuel S. Drury, late rector of St. Paul's School in Concord, N. H., yesterday afternoon at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

The end of the island-wide port strike tomorrow was indicated tonight as the strikers -were ordered to return to work by the Governor's arbitration board. Steamship company and labor representatives agreed to appear before the arbitrators tomorrow.
MRS. S. MALCOLM REID Mrs. Ingeborg Morten Reid of White Plains, wife of S. Malcolm Reid, employee of the American Bank Note Company, died on Tuesday in the Presbyterian Hospital at the age of 56.

Richard W. Mott, retired vice president of the Bank for Savings, died on Tuesday at his home, 200 West Seventieth Street at the age of 85. Until his retirement in 1934, Mr. Mott had served with the bank for forty-six years.

Governor Lehman left Albany today for a fishing trip to Florida, and before he left, he declined in a press interview to give any indication of his future political plans. His sole answer was "no comment" to questions as to whether he intended to run again for Governor, or for the United States Senate if Robert F. Wagner should accept the Gubernatorial nomination, or whether he was through with politics for good.
Congress put aside pressing problems of taxes, relief and national defense for a brief period today to participate in memorial services for members who died in the past year.

The Sword Steamship Lines, Inc., operators of a coastwise freight and passenger shipping service, filed a petition in Federal Court yesterday for permission to reorganize under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act.

Sargent's home run to deep right field in the seventh inning enabled the Lafayette nine of Easton, Pa., to beat Army today, 4 to 2. After each team had scored twice in the opening frame the pitchers settled down, but Lipscomb was first to weaken.
Mr. and Mrs. James A. Jackson of 778 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss George-Ann Jackson, to Jonathan Slocum, son of Dr. and Mrs. C. Jonathan Slocum of Beacon, N.Y.

The stock market here suffered from allaround profit-taking today and most sections were set back. Gilt-edge issues were inactive and prices fell off, but among the foreign bonds Austrian, German and Czechoslovak loans improved.

Yesterday was a muggy day and eyeglass lenses clouded easily. But a drastic application of the handkerchief made no difference. There it stood at the top of our split page: "WPA Fights Schoolyard Erosion." It was not schoolyard evasion, which makes sense.

The Iron Guard's abortive plot to march on the capital is taking on increased importance following the seizure of the organization's documents and letters. It is now apparent that the widespread plans had reached the stage where it was only a question of days before a serious attempt would be made to overthrow the regime.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has purchased paintings by three New York artists to add to its colelection of contemporary art. All the canvases will be placed on exhibition today in the gallery devoted to recent American paintings.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Between those who want to cure depression by a sharp rise in governmental spending and those who want a balanced budget lies a middle course. It yields to the demands for more borrowing, larger debt, increased bank deposits, renewed "pump-priming."

Officers and members of the National Arts Club presented a colorful Viennese ball last night in their clubhouse at 15 Gramercy Park. A setting reminiscent of ballrooms in old Vienna was designed for the party. The walls of the main

The Commonwealth of Virginia today asked the State Corporation Commission to prevent the Virginia Public Service Company from paying certain charges for services and from paying any dividend on its common stock pending an investigation of charges made by the State.

Mr. and Mrs. Clifford W. Michel gave a dinner last evening in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Mrs. Michel's sister, Miss Muriel Bache Richards, and her fiance, Francis Warren Pershing, whose, marriage will take place tomorrow in St. Thomas Church.

A message will be sent to the Cuban Congress by President Federico Laredo Bru recommending that the present profits tax on sugar mills be replaced by a tax per bag of sugar manufactured, the Cabinet decided tonight.
Recognition has been accorded by the State Department to foreign consular offices In the United States as follows: J. Gus Lallande, as honorary consul of Hungary at San Juan, P. R.

So as not to conflict with the War Admiral-Seabiscuit race, the date of the annual meeting of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds has been changed to May 28. Originally it had been set for May 30, which is the date of the $100,000 match at Belmont Park.

Miss Doris Marie Carroll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Leo Carroll of this city, was married to Irving Monroe Bailey, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Monroe Bailey, in the rectory of St. Brendan's Church today. The Rev. Edward Donnelly performed the ceremony.

Assailing all forms of dictatorship as making for the destruction of the creative life and for the enslavement of man, Governor Herbert H. Lehman declared in an address last night that it was the paramount duty of Americans to defend their heritage of freedom, which in many parts of the world was lost, and elsewhere was sorely threatened.

Front St, 193, 20.2x76; Selma R. Block and Charles R. Goldsmith to Exchange Estates, Inc. 292 Madison Ave, care A. N. Geller; mtg $16,500. Walker St, 39-41, 48x106: James M. Grady to John J. Cray, trustee for certificate holders of Bond and Mortgage Guaranty Co, 141 Broadway; consideration $1,000, foreclosure.

The imprisonment of Corneliu Codreanu and the round-up of hundreds of members of the Iron Guard, charged with a plot to march on Bucharest and overthrow the Government, is only another episode in the Rumanian struggle that led to the establishment last February of what is virtually a royal dictatorship. The King acted at that

One day in 1914 Bill Brown, the boxing commissioner, said publicly, "If I ever see another boxing glove I'll eat it." He thereupon closed his gymnasium and departed for his health farm at Garrison, N. Y.

Leon Trotsky, former Bolshevist leader in exile here, issued a statement today saying that he and his political friends were entirely for the Chinese in their "fight for independence against the Japanese militaristic bandits." He asserted Japan's

An "'inside-out" structure of polished stainless steel will be erected at the New York World's Fair to house exhibits of the United States Steel Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation. The building, which
Percy H. Manners, secretary of the Thomas W. Dunn Company, gelatin manufacturing firm, died yesterday in his home, 210 Sixth Avenue, after a long illness.

While showing substantial declines from last year's levels, the reports of the first five railroads to publish March earnings indicated that, as a group, they would not show an operating deficit for the month. Net operating income

Mayor La Guardia left yesterday on an eight-day Western trip. Tomorrow he will take part in the Oklahoma Day celebration in Guthrie, Okla. He will speak at Wichita Falls, Texas, on Tuesday and address the St. Louis Chamber of Commerce the following day.

I. A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks-Fifth Avenue, predicted that "the next big step" in advertising would come from the use of color in a talk last night at the advertising course conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES in the Times Annex.

John s J. Cunningham, for forty years until his retirement in 1932 an examiner for the New York State Insurance Department, died here today at the Sunny Rest Sanitarium after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

Dr. Rose Hoffman, retired dentist and wife of Dr. B. Hoffman, columnist of The Jewish Daily Forward, who writes under the pen name of Zizion, died yesterday morning at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 64 years old.

Cigarette jobbers in the city will be permitted to apply the one-cent relief tax stamp on each package of cigarettes by metering machines as an alternative to the decalcomania method first proposed, under regulations announced yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.

Speakers for two important conventions, those of the Association of National Advertisers and of the Advertising Federation of America, were announced here yesterday. The national advertisers will meet at -the Westchester Country Club, Rye, on May 4 to 6, while the federation will convene in Detroit, June 12 to 16.

The annual banquet of The Columbia Law Review, monthly student publication of the Columbia University Law School, will be held at 7:30 o'clock this evening at the Hotel Ambassador. Speakers will be Justices Bernard L. Schientag and Ferdinand Pecora of the New York State Supreme Court; Dean Charles

The supply of strictly good, choice and prime steers and yearlings today was the largest of the week. Numerous loads sold at $9.50 upward, strictly prime weighty steers reaching $10.50 and 991-pound yearlings $9.85 on a market that was 10 to 15 cents lower; weighty butcher hogs held up. The lamb trade was fairly active, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

William N. Fink of El Paso, Texas, the American mining engineer who is in prison in Chihuehua, Mexico, on charges of complicity in murder, has petitioned the courts in habeas corpus proceedings, and a ruling is promised on April 28, the State Department was informed today.

Terence P. Cook, traffic manager of the Barber Steamship Lines, was elected president of the Foreign Commerce Club at its annual meeting last night at the Hotel Astor. He succeeds Charles E. Dougherty, vice president of the stevedore firm of Carter Weekes. Mr. Cook

The engagement of $5,800,000 gold in Japan for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This brought the total of gold shipped here from Japan since Feb. 24, when the current movement started, to $33,500,000.

Sabu, the lad who won acclaim in "Elephant Boy" last season, has been engaged by RKO for one of the principal roles in "Gunga Din," which is expected to get under way next month; the comedy element will be expounded by Jack Oakie.

In his address on Tuesday night before the Association of the Bar of the City of New York Mayor La Guardia informed his audience that the courts in New York City were costing nearly $4,000,000 a year more than the entire Federal court system.

Information which has accumulated recently that government and business groups at last are sincerely seeking ground for a mutual effort to combat the recession led this correspondent today to circulate a private questionnaire.

Five members of the Newark Housing Authority were appointed here today at a meeting of the Newark City Commission. City Commissioner Vincent Murphy, director of finance and revenue, has asked the Federal Government to earmark $6,000,000 for slum clearance in this city.

Trading was again slow in most classes of fresh meats. A few steer cuts were lower, otherwise beef prices were mostly unchanged. Other classes were weak to lower. Owing to the Jewish holidays beginning at sundown Thursday, kosher slaughtering was extremely light today while tomorrow will wind up the kosher kill for the week, as reported by the United State Department of Agriculture.
The old Schieren properties, in the heart of a section known for many years as the "hide and leather district" of Manhattan, are to be rehabilitated.
With the traditional business moving day, May 1, a little more than a week off, commercial leasing continues active, with midtown locations predominating in the lists submitted yesterday.

Colonel Duncan Ferguson Dempster Neill, yachting expert who aided Sir Thomas Lipton in the design and sailing of all five of his Shamrocks with which he challenged for the America's Cup, died here today at the age of 69.
The American Federation of Labor, following the example of the rival C. I. O., entered politics on a national scale today by forming an organization to back selected candidates for public office.
Robert W. (Bob) Feller, back in the form that made him the American League's strikeout champion, shut out the Browns with a single hit today while Cleveland's artillery swung into action to win, 9-0.

Future scholars will regard the attitude of the present American leaders of large corporate enterprises as "one of the most amazing phenomena in the history of capitalism," Eduard C. Lindeman declared yesterday.

The French Government today started wholesale deportation of undesirable foreigners, a move designed chiefly to stamp out espionage. Two hundred and twenty foreigners were ordered to leave France immediately and both national and local police were told to make a thorough clean-up throughout the country. The government said the

More than 300 alumni of the Columbia University School of Engineering, celebrating their sixtyninth annual reunion last night with a dinner at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street, were invited by Dean Joseph W. Barker to support the new engineering buildings and laboratories proposed recently by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

Sanitary police here are putting up a gallant fight against the hoof-and-mouth disease among cows, which is spreading from one section of the city to another. There are about 800 dairies with their own cows on premises distributed in all sections of Berlin, including those heavily populated.

The six-story apartment house at 39-30 Fifty-ninth Street, Woodside, L. I., was sold by the Apex Realty Corporation to an investing client of Walter Samuels, Inc., broker in the deal. Sale was subject to a first mortgage of $164,500 held by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.

Arthur N. Bachrach, president of the Bachrach Company, will be tendered a testimonial dinner in the Hotel Biltmore on April 28 by the men's neckwear division of the campaign of Joint Distribution Committee and the United Palestine Appeal.

The Navy Department was advised today of the death yesterday at his home in San Francisco of Captain Walter Hinds Allen after an attack of coronary thrombosis suffered while playing golf. His age was 63.
Mexico's distribution of lands among peasants again culminated in bloodshed yesterday, when eleven persons were killed and several wounded at three places, according to press reports.

Scores of physicians in the city have refused to attend the annual dinner of the Long Island College of Medicine Alumni Association on April 30 in the Columbus Club, Brooklyn, because Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City was scheduled as a speaker, it was learned yesterday.

The interclub matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Long Island section will start on May 2, it was announced yesterday. The contests, for Class A and Class B players, will be held on Mondays and Fridays during May, with the concluding tests on May 23.
Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Romanesque Period: Minor Arts," Harry D. M. Grier, 11 A. M.; collection of paintings (general tour), 2 P.M.

United States patent letters covering an electronic device said to be capable of almost directly converting any form of electric power into any other form, or of "manufacturing" radio waves from light socket current with a minimum of other apparatus requirements,

Still balked at Tortosa, the Insurgents pushed their lines southward yesterday and reported capturing Albocacer, Loyalist field headquarters for Northern Castellon Province. At the French frontier they took two more mountain passes, thus getting control of nine out of twelve routes into France.
The new government clean-up of the rear guard, given impetus by recent Insurgent advances, brought death sentences for three more men in popular courts today, raising the week's total to fortyfour.

City Collector William Reid announced yesterday that since April 1 a total of $95,418,986 had been received, in real estate taxes, against $89,885,908 for the same period last year. The taxes for the first half of the year were due April 1.

The Chinese abandonment of the town of Lini following successive Japanese assaults was announced here last night by a Chinese military spokesman. Lini, an important city in Southwest Shantung, had been a bone of contention between Chinese and Japanese for more than a month.

Stephen A. Kroner, an assistant editor of a Slovak language newspaper, and one of ten men and two women on trial in General Sessions Court for the $2,060,000 land frauds at Slovak Manor, near Babylon, L. I., was freed yesterday after appearing on the witness stand in his own defense.

BARMANN-Benjamin F., beloved husband of Sarah S., dear father of Joseph, and Beatrice M. Silverberg, brother of Arthur, Irving, and Mrs. Carrie B. Silver. Funeral services Thursday at 1 o'clock, Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

The Census Bureau reported today the cotton spinning industry operated during March at 101.1 per cent of capacity on a single shift basis, compared with 98.9 per cent during February this year and 148.3 per cent during March last year.
James P. (Red) Wilson, former army telegrapher who flashed the first word along allied trenches anbouncing the signing of the armistice, died here Tuesday at the age of 52.

Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's Tiger pulled up lame after a workout today and Trainer Bob McGarvey said it probably would be tomorrow night before he could judge whether the brown colt would have to be withdrawn from training for the Kentucky Derby.

IF at the moment you are city-ridden and sick of it, perhaps you will find relief in one or the other of two new books*: Edwin Valentine Mitchell's "American Village" and Henry Tetlow's "We Farm for a Hobby." Mr. Tetlow's is full of cheering advice. What it reports, in effect, is that any family with
