Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Encour aged by warm. weather, the vanguard of billions of blossoms in the New York State fruit belt appeared today, two weeks ahead of schedule. Farmers from the Hudson River. to the Niagara frontier kept anxious eves on their thermometers,

Colonel Wyndham Torr's Lassitude II, with Jack Skinner up, had only to parade to the post to receive the honors today in the Rose Hill three-mile timber race as the Middleburg hunts meeting closed. All other entries in the feature were scratched.

The combination of the veteran Tom Healey and his son Jack, who did so well with Tatterdemalion on the closing clay at Tropical Park, brought off another victory in the featured Devon Handicap at Jamaica yesterday when Black Look was home first at 8 to 1. It was a race of six speed horses over the six-furlong route and the son of Whichone was first by a neck, outgaming Great Union in the final drive.

A set of The Annals of Sporting and Fancy Gazette, in the rare original issues published in London, 1822-28, including the issue for June, 1828, was bought by Gabriel Wells for $3,100 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at the

The Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City will be the site of the world championship welterweight fight between Barney Ross and Henry Armstrong on the night of May 26, it was -announced yesterday by Promoter Mike Jacobs of the- Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

George Jamerson, 27, pleaded guilty today before Louis L. Hicks, justice of the peace, of stealing $2 from a gasoline filling station. Cautioning Jamerson he could expect leniency only because it was his first offense, Mr. Hicks said:

Columbia University's tennis team vanquished Fordham at the latter's courts yesterday, 8 to 0. Chauncey Steele captured the No. 1 singles match from Jeff Hogan by 6-1, 6-0, then paired with Leo Hayes to score in the doubles against Hogan and Henry Jaeger, 6-3. 6-2.

More than 950 athletes, representing sixty-four high and prep schools, will compete in the thirtieth annual interscholastic track and field meet at Ohio Field Saturday. The meet will begin at 2 P. M. and is sponscored by New York, University.

Commemorating the diamond jubilee of the founding of their alma mater, more than 600 Manhattan alumni also paid tribute to Cardinal Hayes, who was graduated from Manhattan fifty years ago, at their annual dinner last night at the Hotel Biltmore.
Linnie Marsh Wolfe, secretary of the John Muir Association, has edited for Houghton Mifflin the unpublished journals of Muir. They will be released on May 10 under the title "John of the Mountains."

Engineering education and the new industrial South, especially the pulp and phosphate businesses, were the chief topics as the Spring convention of the American Society of Civil Engineers opened here. Delegates this afternoon viewed the historical restoration work being done by the Carnegie Institution of Washington at St. Augustine, the oldest city in the United States.

In Flint, Mich., pickets of the Automobile Workers of America blocked the entrances to the Fisher Body No. 1 plant and refused to allow any nonunion worker or any union worker to enter the plant unless he paid his union dues up to date or could show a receipt that he had done so. Men and

The 1938-39 season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society -- its ninety-seventh-will open Thursday evening, Oct. 20, and will continue for twenty-eight subscription weeks, closing Sunday afternoon, April 30, it was announced yesterday by the society. John Barbirolli
Louis L. Walters was elected president of the Saratoga Springs Foundation, Inc., at its annual meeting, held last night at the Hotel McAlpin, Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway.

The Class I railroads had 5,825 freight cars on order or being reconditioned in their own plants on April 1, the Association of American Railroads reported yesterday. This compared with 46,439 on April 1, 1937, and 13,562 on April 1, 1936. Steam locomotives on order or being rebuilt on April 1 numbered eighty-four, against 359 on April 1, last year, and fifty-two on the same date two years ago.

Under a combination of foreign selling and liquidation of May contracts in advance of notices on next Tuesday, prices on the Cotton Exchange here lost 1 to 4 points yesterday. A late show of strength in the stock market brought an upturn of almost 10 points at one time, but reselling by room traders ran quotations back in final
Washington's Governor and Lieutenant Governor raced across the country to a photo finish today in a scramble for a few critical minutes of the State's executive power.
Miss Mary Margaret Huntington, daughter of Mrs. Henry Arthur Huntington of Windsor, has chosen April 30 for her marriage to R. Dunham Braman, son of Mr.. and Mrs. Sidney R. Braman of West Hartford.

Operators were active yesterday in deals involving houses in Brooklyn. Charles Walzer sold 500 St. John's Place, a six-story self-service elevator apartment building for 112 families assessed at $450,000. The building, which contains 335 rooms, occupies a plot 225 by 165 feet and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $375,000. Samuel Finver was the broker.

Gustav A. E. Ackerman, on Orchard Drive in the Milbrook section of Greenwich, Conn., from Henry M. Stevenson; Prince Ripley, brokers. John Rutherford, residence of Mrs. Cornelius E. O'Connor Jr, in Laurel Hollow; Charles V. Graham, home of Mrs. Henry C. Taylor in Lloyd Harbor, Huntington; Mrs. Vladimir L. Littauer, renewal on Marston house, In East Norwich; L. I. rentals by Talbor J Taylor Jr, in association with Butler Baldwin.

A plate-glass window. of the Chappaqua National Bank, on Greeley Avenue, was shattered by a rock early today and, although the State police listed the incident as an attempted burglary, the New Castle town police insisted it was only a "prank by a drunken man."

Fifteen of the fifty-one Austrian Jews whom Czechoslovak frontier guards rescued from a breakwater in the middle of the Danube on which they had been left marooned by Austrian Nazis are now aboard a French tugboat.

A proposal for specifically defining the boundaries of a "defensive sea area" which the navy "shall maintain inviolate against any foe" was advanced as an amendment to the administration's $1,156,000,000 Naval Expansion Bill today by Senator Bone, Democrat, of Washington, a member of the Naval Affairs Committee. He will ask for an early vote, perhaps tomorrow.

With Hal Schumacher judiciously interspersing his famed sinker ball with his newly perfected slow one, and Johnny McCarthy sinking a well-timed home run into the upper right tier in the fourth inning with two comrades aboard the bases, the Giants were moving serenely along at the Polo Grounds yesterday to their second straight triumph of the season, when something went wrong.

Grouped in eight "battalions," the flags of fifty-one military ororganizations in the metropolitan area will be massed tonight in the Hotel Astor at the annual military ball of the United Spanish War Veterans, Department of New York.
Prince de Broons, who also has the title of Marquis Charles d' Espinay de Durtal, and is a cousin of the French pretender, Duke de Guise, today married an American, Mrs. Jean Harris.

Andover blanked St. Mark's today, 9 to 0, behind the five-hit pitching of Joe Phelan, scoring six runs on four scattered hits off Palmer in the first eight innings, and bunching four more blows in the ninth for three runs. Harrison batted
AMERICAN VILLAGE, by Edwin Valentine Mitchell (Stackpole, $3), A series of essays on bygone American manners and manufactures. BARNEY BARNATO, by Richard Lewinsohn (Dutton, $3).
A prematurely gray-haired lieutenant colonel, who commands two-thirds of the Catalan ront army, pointed at the territory west of Lerida on his war map today and said, "We will have that back soon."

Rain, which the citizens downtown complained about as they sloshed about their duties, flattened down the waters of Cayuga Lake tonight and delighted the oarsmen of another Cornell navy who are starting the latest of the chapters in the tradition-studded history of rowing here at the college on the hill.

Mrs. Adelaide Moffett Brooks, widow of David Brooks, who died two years ago when he fell from the window of his apartment on the fourteenth floor of Mayfair House, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal Court listing liaabilities of $9,691 and assets of $1,800.
The Reichsbank's statement as of April 19 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Captain Albert Francis Cronhardt, He who was within the brokerage firm of J. R. Williston Co., 115 Broadway, and had served in the finance division of the army during the World War, died Tuesday in New York Hospital after a short illness at the age of 58.

A moderate rally in the late trading yesterday in which aircraft issues figured prominently, materially reduced the earlier declines but did not prevent the stock market from closing irregularly easier.

Pulitzer Prize awards in letters the and journalism for 1937 will be announced by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, at the silver anniversary dinner of the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism on Monday evening, May 2,

Continuing his search for a recovery formula President Roosevelt turned today to the electric utility industry and in a conference with administrative aides sought ways to stimulate the utilities' buying of equipment through loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

If the police of the Beach Street station see a family of eight trudging past their door at 4 o'clock some morning, they will probably do nothing at all about it-except, may be, call the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.
Miss Sylvia Lazarus, 27 years old, who has been missing from her home at 993 Park Avenue for nearly two weeks, was brought back from Chicago in company of a doctor and a detective yesterday.

The Conemaugh Sanitary Manufacturing Company, Blairville, Pa., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 132,500 shares of $1 par value common stock of which 105,000 shares are to be offered by the issuer,

James Roosevelt, son and secretary to the President, said tonight at a delayed Jackson Day dinner that experiments with public works showed government spending was the way to a balanced budget. "When we taper off, your income goes down and we go farther away from a balanced budget." he added.

The Securities and Exchange Commission learned today that it was the legal opinion of John W. Davis that prevented J. P. Morgan Co. from replying to a last-minute call for rescue from Richard Whitney.

Employment discrimination against Negroes because of prejudice was deplored today by Vice Chancellor John 0. Bigelow when he refused to issue an injunction to restrain a Negro organization from picketing a department store that allegedly had refused to hire a Negro saleswoman.
Pipe lines made of sulphur instead of steel were described to the American Chemical Society today as a new step in the "brimstone" business, one of the major industries of the Southwest.
Mrs. Adelaide Kent Bowker, wife of Horace Bowker, chairman of the board of directors of the American Agricultural Chemical Company, died here this morning at her home. She was 59 years old.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended April 9 totaled 307,556,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with figures of the previous week, this total represents a decrease of 681,000 barrels, comprising a decrease of 722,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude and an increase of 41,000 barrels in stocks of foreign crude.

Brooklyn College's baseball forces triumphed on their home field yesterday, routing the Savage School nine, 13 to 2, in a wildly played game that resulted in the first setback in four contests for the visitors. The encounter was limited to eight innings by agreement.

Edward L. Parke of Norristown, Pa., and Donald G. Herring Jr. of Princeton, freshman athletes, have qualified for the exceptional award of major letters, it was announced today by Burnham N. Dell, '12, chairman of the university council on athletics. Parke, a swimmer,

Michaels-Stern Co., Inc., Rochester, which for many years have offered several price brackets in their men's clothing line, yesterday announced a policy of specialization for the Fall season. Only one price range, $35, will be sold and will include one and two trousers suits, overcoats and formal wear.

Canada's export trade in the fiscal year ended on March 31 was the largest since 1930, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. Domestic exports totaled $1,070,217,328, compared with $1,060,181,906 a year before, an increase of $9,035,422, or 0.9 per cent.

Federal Judge Francis J. Caffey yesterday heard an outline of allegations and pleadings in the suit brought by the government against the Aluminum Company of America and its subsidiaries for alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

Word was received here today that Stanley V. Platt, a district superintendent of the F. W. Woolworth Company with headquarters at Charlotte, N. C., had been killed last night in an automobile accident at Westminster, S..C. He was 48 years old.

Helen Keller presented a medal for "outstanding service to the blind" yesterday to Walter G. Holmes of Jackson, Tenn., editor of the Matilda Ziegler Magazine for the Blind since its establishment in 1907. The ceremony took place at the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Alessandro Pallavicini of Rome are at the Croydon. Mrs. Pallavicini is the former Miss Margaret Roosevelt. Mr. and Mrs. W. Henry Williams of 7 East Sixty-third Street, sailed yesterday on the Aquitania for England. They will return in several weeks to go to their Summer place in Newport.

Miss N. May Karff of Boston continued her winning streak last night in the women's championship for the Hazel Allen Trophy under National Chess Federation auspices at Rockefeller Center by defeating Mrs. Adele Rivero, twice winner of the trophy, in the ninth round.

Investment buying of houses yesterday featured realty activity in Manhattan. An investor bought from Dr. Hans J. Schwartz the four-story dwelling at 50 East Fifty-third Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, assessed at $53,000.
An attack today by armed Arabs on Tel Amal, a Jewish settlement in the Beisan Valley of Northern Palestine, resulted in the death of five brigands.

With a brave show of his old "Black Jack" manner, General John J. Pershing came to New York yesterday for his son's wedding. He disdained a wheel chair, posed for photographers and saluted in characteristic fashion, but it was obvious that the commander of the A. E. F. had not fully recovered

Mayor La Guardia, his voice ringing with pride, offered yesterday to match New York's detective division with Scotland Yard. "Our publicity might not be as good, but our bureau is," he declared at a luncheon of the Police Captains Endowment Association at the Hotel Commodore. At an impressive ceremony the

Further purging of collectivized peasants and wholesale expulsions of peasants from collective farms were peremptorily ordered stopped today in a blistering decree of the Council of People's Commissars and the central committee of the Communist party.
William J. A. Rowe, 1936 Olympic hammer thrower and former Rhode Island State College athlete, died here yesterday morning in the PostGraduate Hospital after a long illness.

A Federal grand jury today indicted Ray Scruggs, former Oklahoma City School Board treasurer and vice president of the First National Bank and Trust Company here, on sixty-five counts charging violation of Federal banking laws. Federal Judge Edgar S. Vaught set bond at $100,000.

Holy Cross shelled three pitchers for eighteen solid hits and scored an easy 12-4 victory over Fordham before 2,500 fans at Fitton Field today. It was the Maroon's first defeat of the season after four straight triumphs.

Federal Judge Francis J. Caffey yesterday heard an outline of allegations and pleadings in the suit brought by the government against the Aluminum Company of America and its subsidiaries for alleged violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

Special meetings of shareholders of the Canadian Industrial Alcohol Company, Ltd., will be held here on May 20 to consider a compromise arrangement under which the A voting shares and B non-voting shares, other than those held by or for Hiram WalkerGooderham Worts, Ltd., woul be exchanged for stock of the latter company.

Less than twenty-four hours after Mayor La Guardia had threatened to "dim the light's in Brooklyn" if salary increases for various court employes in that borough were upheld, Justice Thomas C. Kadien handed down two decisions yesterday allowing additional pay for twenty-one employes of the Brooklyn Supreme Court and also directing the Controller to provide salaries for three newly-created positions and one recently filled vacancy.

The War De apartment released the following orders today, dated April 19: COLONELS Lincoln, R. B., Air Corps, 2 months' leave, July 8, with permission to, visit foreign countries. Burtt, W. B., Inf., retired on own application, May 31.

Canada's export trade in the fiscal year ended on March 31 was the largest since 1930, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. Domestic exports totaled $1,070,217,328, compared with $1,060,181,906 a year before, an increase of $9,035,422, or 0.9 per cent.

Word was received here today that Stanley V. Platt, a district superintendent of the F. W. Woolworth Company with headquarters at Charlotte, N. C., had been killed last night in an automobile accident at Westminster, S..C. He was 48 years old.

Miss Irene C. Gilhooly, niece of Mrs. William J. McDonnell of this city, was married to William J. Waters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Waters of Derby, Conn., yesterday in the Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Carroll, assistant pastor.

Art judges flipped 390 plaster models today and picked a design for a new nickel showing Thomas Jefferson on the "heads" side and his Monticello home on the "tails." Which design won may not be announced for a day or two. There is a $1,000 prize for the winning artist.

Hearings were called today by the Federal Power Commission on interlocking directorate applications involving fifty-eight officials of three large utility company systems and each has been asked to make
George E. Cummings, retired advertising man and former resident of this city, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at Rockledge, Fla., where he had been living. He was 68 years old.

The preview of the "World of Tomorrow," scheduled for a week from tomorrow, will have a real World's Fair setting," Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair Corporation, announced yesterday following an inspection of the area set aside for the preview activities.

The five-story apartment at 1,844 Crotona Avenue, the Bronx, figured in two quick resales yesterday. A client of Joseph Howard, Katz bought the property and then sold it to a client of Irving H. Stolz, who in turn sold it to Louis Finkelstein.

MANHATTAN Gross assets, $207,552: net, $202,-280. To Gertrude E. Anderson, daughter, one-half residue; Carl H. Fraenckel, son, $15,000 and one-half residue; Johanna von Passow, sister, $45,000 in trust, remainder to residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $198.045. Ellery O. Anderson, attorney, 25 Broad St.

It is encouraging indeed to observe the growing interest in this State in Arbor Day. This annual event, dedicated to the planting of trees, and to renewed appreciation of their importance both in the economics of modern life and in verities of beauty and of peace,

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 20: COLONELS Smith, T. J., Ordnance Dep't, four months and eleven days' leave, April 20. Commiskey, A. F., Cav., Batlimore, Md., to retirement, July 31.

Lieut. Gen. Sir Talbot Hobbs died today on board the liner brama at the age of 73. He was en route to France to attend the unveiling July 1 of the Australian War Memorial, at which the King will take part.

OPENING Day for the Yankees, the big fellows of baseball. World champions. The aristocrats of the diamond, "the glass of fashion and the mold of form, the observed of all observers." But once upon a time Well, once upon a time they were known as the Highlanders and in some seasons they were the laugh of the league.

Power Memorial Academy's nine, defending city C. H. S. A. champion, began its Manhattan-Richmond. Division drive with a 4-0 victory over St. Ann's Academy at Farmers Stadium, Glendale, yesterday. Joe Maher gave only two hits and struck out fourteen.

Due to the increased number of applicants for small loans to make possible the extension of business enterprises under the Glass-Steagall law, the special committee of the Smaller Business Association for the New York District was compelled to remove its temporary headquarters yesterday' from the Hotel New Yorker.

Oklahomans celebrating 89'er day to-morrow will have Mayor La Guardia as a guest and before the day is done he will have an Indian name and war bonnet. Two tribes, the Cheyennes and Arapahoes will adopt the New Yorker.

A request for a judicial inquiry into the' guardians management of the Dionne quintuplets has been filed with the Ontario Attorney General's Department by Henri St. Jacques, Ottawa barrister, acting for Oliva Dionne, father of the children.
Anderson, Josephine Annenberg, Lillian R. Black, George H. Bochner, Betty Bray, John M. Burnhauser, George Byrne, Mary L.
Announcement has been made in Paris of the engagement of Miss Amecie de la Grange, daughter of Baron and Baroness Amaury de la Grange of that city, to Marquis Aymard de Nicolay, also of Paris.

With the total entry above the 600 mark or approximately double last year's figure, the second annual Squadron A Spring horse show, first major three-day exhibition of 1938, opened last night at Squadron A Armory: before large crowd.

Senator Smathers of New Jersey asked Congress today to make a sweeping revision of the banking laws. He introduced a bill to substitute an insurance bureau for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and to overhaul the office of the Controller of the Currency.

For some time Warners have sought a vehicle in which Edward G. Robinson could be seen in a similar role to that which he played in "Five Star Final." Today the studio announced "Murder for Two Cents," an original by Jerry Wald and Richard Macaulay, as its choice for the picture to follow "Thousand Dollar Window."

Camilo Saenz, twelve rooms and five baths in 141 E 72d St; Leo Klaber, in 2 W 86th St; Madeline Perretta, in 230 Riverside Dr; Apartment Renting Co, Inc. agents. Henry Bruere. duplex ten rooms and four baths in 925 Park Ave, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, for Payson McL. Merrill Co.
Premier Fumimaro Konoye, who has been ill for three weeks, resumed his official duties today. His first action was a meeting with the Japanese press.
Telegrams are being received by hundreds of anxious and impatient anglers this week, and most of them are only four words long:

Appointment of an advisory committee in connection with the New York Curb Exchange's current reorganization study was announced yesterday. The committee is to receive suggestions from members and others interested in the Exchange and to advise the original committee on organization and administration of the trading body.

Princess Elizabeth on her twelfth birthday for the first time received congratunations and greetings in official form from the dominions and the colonies. For the first time, too, she assumed a public office, president of the Children's League of
The first President of Ireland under the new Constitution will be 78-year-old Professor Douglas Hyde, the country's most distinguished living Gaelic scholar.

The third annual Yale-HarvardPrineeton- Conference on Public Affairs will. open-here tomorrow- afternoon, preceded, by a luncheon which will be briefly 'addressed by President' Seymour of Yale. Two sessions will be held Saturday.

At Bellevue Hospital yesterday, 2,000 children, crippled and ailing, chorused approval as the circus came to visit them again. It was the thirty-second annual show the Ringling Brothers Barnum Bailey circus has given at the hospital.

The general level of wholesale prices rose in the week ended on April 16, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 78.6, compared to 78.5 on April 9 and 87.6 on April 17, 1937. A sharp upturn in wholesale prices of agricultural commodities accounted for the increase.

The stock markets here suffered from lack of business today and a number of sections fell off. Gilt-edge issues and foreign loans generally were steady. Transatlantic shares were supported and United States Steel and International Nickel had a good tone.

An English student named Brown-bridge, sent here by the Bradford Chamber of Commerce, just escaped being tried for high treason because of a remark about Chancellor Hitler appearing in a letter to a friend.

Passenger traffic on the Interborough Rapid Transit Company's lines, including the subway and elevated divisions, in March was 86,062,447, a decrease of 5,987,823, or 6.5 per cent, compared with the same month last year,

A plan for compilation of statlstics on production and on inventories of raw materials on hand on a weekly basis was developed at a meeting. of the board of directors of the Radio Manufacturers Association at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday.

The management of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a plan for reorganization of the railroad which would reduce capitalization from approximately $45,000,000 to $15,000,000 and cut fixed charges from about $630,000 to $240,000.

Adolf Dehn has been by no means inactive since 1932, yet not since that year has he held a one-man show. In 1932 it was his lithographs, just .as the season before it had been his drawings, that attracted visitors to the Weyhe Gallery, 794 Lexington Avenue, where is installed, scheduled to remain until May 7, a group-of the artist's recent water-colors.

Mayor La Guardia's veto of a Board of Estimate resolution appropriating $600,000 for the expenses of the Transit Commission for the first half of this year split the Board of Estimate into two camps yesterday,

Mrs. Alice Lorenson, Keansburg invalid, who was shot three--times early. Tuesday- evening in her home as she knitted and talked with a neighbor, died in Riverview Hospital here at 4:45 o'clock- this morning-as a result. of -the bullet wounds. She was 71 years old.

Fearful of restrictions on their independence, many private welfare organizations are opposed to the proposal of the State Board of Social Welfare that it receive regulatory power over philanthropic agencies not receiving public funds, it was learned last night.

Charles R. Parmele, retired president of the Parmele Pharmacal Company, manufacturers of medical preparations, 47 West Street, died yesterday at his home, 33 Central Avenue, St. George, S. I. Mr. Parmele, who had been in ill health for about a year. was 78 years old.
The Treasury procurement division today invited bids, to be opened April 29, on a total of 8,364,000 yards of textiles for delivery by June 30. as follows:

It was small wonder that the Scherzo from the- Mendelssohn String Octet, as scored for orchestra, was repeated by general acclaim when John Barbirolli and the Phllarmonic-Symphony Orchestra played it" last night in Carnegie Hall.

Tonight's major events: Anna Schramm, soprano, Town Hall; "Barber of Seville," Hippodrome Opera Company. Auditions for entrance in the free choral school of the Metropolitan Opera Association will take place next week. Young vocalists with a reading knowledge of music are eligible.

Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, who winters his horses in New York and feels that he can get them ready as swiftly as those who go to warmer climes, saddled his seventh and eighth winners of the metropolitan season at Jamaica yesterday and thereby added strength to his conclusions.
The Orioles opened their 1938 International League season today by defe-ting Rochester, 11 to 4, before 10,500 fans, including Mayor Lester: Rapp of Rochester and State offlcials.
French Communists vigorously applauded King Gustaf of Sweden and shouted "Long live the King!" f when the monarch visited the Paris "Red belt" today.

In an effort to promote consideration for the city's pedestrian public and to correct certain practices of the canine population, eight little girls and eight little dogs paraded yesterday afternoon in the amateur dog show benefit given for the Outdoors Cleanliness Association.

Wheat futures advanced today around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade here, largely in sympathy with Liverpool and on reports of further export sales of domestic cash wheat to the United Kingdom and Europe.
Opponents of the Administration's $1,156,000,000 Naval Expansion Bill held the Senate floor for more than five hours today in an effort to

Combining his customary craft and patience, commodities of which his supply seems inexhaustible, Carl Owen Hubbell launched his personal inaugural at the Polo Grounds yesterday by wearing the Boston Bees to a frazzle and squeezing the Giants across the wire while 8,403

The clash on Wednesday night be- A tween Nazi sympathizers and a group of men who wore American Legion caps at the Yorkville Casino, where seven men were beaten, was continued, yesterday in the courts.

The third arrest in connection with Attorney General Bennett's investigation of J. T. Connor Co., a brokerage at 2 Broadway, was made yesterday when James J. Connor of 2,494 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, a partner, was taken into custody.

Mrs. Louise Beebe Wilder of 11 Beechwood Road, Bronxville, N. Y., C one of the nation's leading writers s on horticulture and a foremost ex- d ponent- of rock gardening, died on Wednesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center here of a heart ailment after a four-month illness. Her age was 60.
The heads of. city departments were frankly despondent yesterday about the possibility of adapting WPA projects under their jurisdic tion to the new cost formula devised in Washington.
Miss Margaret Jackson, librarian at Hoyt Library, died at her home in Kingston today after an illness of twenty-four hours.
To nine college graduates have been granted Charles A. Coffin Fellowships, totaling $5,000 by the General Electric Company, for use in advanced scientific research the coming year.

Honorary membership in the United Spanish War Veterans was conferred on President Federico Laredo Bru and Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff, in a ceremony at the Presidential Palace today, the fortieth anniversary of the United States' declaration of war against Spain.

Robert M. and Madeline T. Crowley sold to Exclusive Home Builders, Inc., the dwelling at 4 Foster Court, South Orange, N. J., through Martin Weis, Inc., brokers. The New Jersey Realty Title Insurance Company will insure the title.

Restoration of the system of selling on discounts instead of net was announced yesterday by five wool goods producers for their women's wear fabrics, following similar action earlier in the week by Botany Worsted Company.

An order opening for committee inspection the tax returns of all persons summoned before the Senate Lobby Committee was revealed today to have been issued by President Roosevelt under an Executive order dated April 18, and by a Treasury order dated April 9, the day after the House recommitted the reeorganization bill.

This morning at about 1 o'clock Jean Charles Legrand, a lawyer, who last year was suspended by the French bar and who has recently formed a political league called Le Front de la Jeunesse [the Front of Youth],

Charles T. Pennington, former employee for twenty-five years of the New York jewelry firm of Black, Starr Frost and secretary of the company when he. retired five' years ago, died yesterday of pneumonia in the White Plains Hospital at the age of 78. Born at Aldershot, England, Mr. Pennington came to this country forty-three years ago.

The Durham-Duplex Razor Company, which last Fall bought a onestory plant in Mystic, Conn., has added to its manufacturing facilities there 'by leasing a three-story building of standard mill-type construction.

After being hesitant for a time, Germany's opinion-directing organs are now proclaiming. President Roosevelt's relief-spending program to be proof that his policies have failed. The Deutsche Allgemeine has the following to say:

TROJAN INCIDENT, based on Homer and Euripides and adapted by Professor Philip H. Davis. Score by Wallingford RieggerStaged by Harold Bolton and TamirisScenery by Howard Bay. Produced by Dillard Long for the Federal Theatre Project. At the St. James Theatre.

Dr. Francis E. Townsend, old-age pension advocate, called on President Roosevelt today to express his thanks for the Executive pardon given to him on Monday as he awaited commitment to the District of Coumbia jail to begin a thirty-day sentence for contempt of a House committee that investigated his Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd.

The Society of Friends is now cooperating with the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and the Council for German Jewry in England in an effort to aid Jews in Austria, it was announced yester- e day by the Joint Distribution Committee.

Obeying an order of the arbitration board headed by Chief Justice del Toro, the stevedores and,clerks who had been on strike since Monday returned to work this afternoon and were warned by the board that another unauthorized strike during the arbitration negotiations would be ground for the board to terminate its efforts to reach a new labor agreement.

Amerlean shipyards- increased their production in 1937 to the highest volume since the completion of the building program fostered by the Merchant Marine Act of 1928, according to H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Association of American Shipbuilders, who submitted his annual report at a meeting yesterday.

Two British soldiers were killed this morning by a gang of armed-Arabs. The victims, Privates C. Hayes and D. Harris, belonged to a detachment camping at Um el Fahm, a village near Jenin in Northern Palestine.

Myron C. Taylor, who retired as chairman of the United States Steel Corporation on April 5, is planning to devote a substantial part of his time henceforth to the study and development of his theories on industrial peace and other management problems.

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will be a guest and chief speaker at a dinner which the Association of Stock Exchange Firms will give on May 20 for Carle C. Conway and his associates on the committee for the study of the organization and administration of the New York Stock Exchange.

Sixty-four high and prep schools have filed 954 entries for the thirtieth annual interscholastic track and field meet to be held at Ohio Field tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by New York University, sponsor of the meet.

Andrew Carnegie Whitfield, 28year-old nephew of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, showed no signs of despondency and gave no indication that he contemplated suicide the night before he disappeared in his power glider from Roosevelt Field a week ago, Inspector Harold King of the Nassau County police Was informed yesterday.

MANHATTAN BURKE. ANNIE (April 8). Estate, less than, $400. To Mary V. Lynch, executrix, 454 W 27th St. DIAMONDSTEIN, LEVI (March 25). Estate, $2,365. To Bertha Hacker, 415 Broad St., Valley Fall, R. I., Nathan Diamond, 3,830 White Plains Ave., Bronx; Gussie Lewis, 984 Tinton Ave., Bronx, and Jacon Diamond, executor, 1,744 Clay Av., Bronx, about $500 each. Abraham H. Sarasohn, 33 Riverside Dr., executor.

Seventy-six of the 118 deaths in industry during March occurred in New York City, according to Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner. He said that the March total was six less than for March, 1937, but thirteen more than in February, 1938.

After allowance for seasonal changes, business in the Pittsburgh district remained approximately unchanged last week, according to the Bureau. of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Nevertheless, there-were fairly wide changes in some of the major lines of economic activity.

General John J. Pershing, convalescing from his recent serious illness, remained secluded yesterday in his suite in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria but will emerge today to attend the wedding of his son, Warren, to Miss Muriel Bache Richards at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church.

Yesterday was the first anniversary of the death of Edward J. Smith's wife, Margaret. At about 8:30 A. M. Smith, 42 years old, who aft was treasurer of the Strand Theatre; Broadway and Forty-seventh Street,

The Bank of Canada's statement for the week ended yesterday, issued today, showed that $4,000,000 had been advanced to the Dominion Government. This is a normal development in the first month of the government's new fiscal year pending the receipt of tax payments.

The age-old breach within the Church of England was widened tonight by the Anglo-Catholics, who favor alliance with Roman Catholicism, when a manifesto was issued by the "Catholic Advisory Council" criticizing the Church of England's 'Bishops and complaining of repeated violations of church principles of faith, order and morals.

Jacqueline Cochran, woman flier who won the Bendix Trophy as the outstanding woman flier of 1937, received the trophy yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue. The presentation was made by Howard Welsh, vice president of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, in behalf of Vincent Bendix, the donor.

Cotton Summer clothes of charm and character, designed in America after peasant costumes imported from Sweden, were presented by Franklin Simon at a luncheon yesterday at the Kungsholm restaurant, 142 East Fifty-fifth Street.

The housewife who buys "not wisely but too well" was the object this week of a report by the United States Department of Agriculture and of a radio address under sponsorship of the Consumers Service Division of the New York City Department of Markets.
The Tigers scored their first victory of the new American League season today, defeating the White Sox, 9 to 3, behind Elden Auker's sevenhit pitching.

Despite the influence of President Roosevelt's message to Congress, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices dropped onehalf point to 80.6 on Wednesday, the lowest it has been since June 16, 1936. A week before the index stood at 81.1 and a year ago it was 94.2. The greatest declines were in livestock and meat prices.

The management of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway appealed today to stockholders through H. F. Lohmeyer, secretary, to give it additiona' proxies representing 9 per cent of the outstanding stock to provide a quorum at the railroad's adjourned annual meeting on May 10 in Richmond, Va.

The American International Corportion reported yesterday net assets of $14,631,170 as of March 31, equal to $1,463.11 for each $1,000 of debentures and -to $4.63 a common share, compared to $17,453,422, or $1,745.34 for the debentures and $7.45 a common share on Dec. 31.

Following a long hearing Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the Federal court, Brooklyn, decided yesterday that a plan for the reorganization of the Prudence Company, Inc., had been "duly filed" by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Postmaster General James A. Farley said last night that postal receipts thus far in April were up to those for the corresponding period a year ago,

The principal exponent of the New Deal and one of its severest critics -will face each other across a White House luncheon table next week when, amid growing Congressional opposition to his $5,000,000,000 spending and lending program for recovery, President Roosevelt will go oyer business conditions with Henry Ford of Detroit.

All unit of government should exercise careful restrain in expanding public funds, considering existing economic conditions and the uncertanity of the business future, Governor Lehman declared yesterday, addressing a luncheon meeting of the members' council of the Merchants Association, held in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Treasury will put the $1,400,000,000 of gold ordered desterilized last week as part of President Roosevelt's recovery plan into the nation's credit structure at the rate of $50,000,000 weekly, reducing the national debt by that amount, it was announced tonight after the closing of the New York market.

Captain William Wickes Stephens, long a captain and owner of fishing excursion boats docked at Sheepshead Bay and a member of an old Brooklyn family, died on Wednesday at Raquette Lake, N. Y. Recently he had been living on a farm at Camillus. N. Y.. His age was 55.

Winston Guest's New York Optimists qualified tonight for the right to meet the New York Athletic Club in the open final of the national indoor polo tournament by defeating the Chicago Ramblers, 15 to 7.

The conferees of the Senate and House, deadlocked for more than a week on differences in their respective versions of the revenue bill for 1938, will resume their conferences tomorrow after a recess since Monday.

Japanese forces have launched a sweeping counter-offensive in South Shantung, which has brought some forces already to the outskirts of Tsaochwang and Yihsien. The latter town had been beleaguered by Chinese forces for many days.

Through a drizzling rain that drenched the course, Paul Leslie, 22-year-old Louisiana State University captain, breezed to a convincing triumph today in the qualifying round of the fourth annual Southern intercollegiate golf tournament.

Appointment of Miss Mary L. Gibbons of New York as First Deputy Commissioner fe in the Department of Social Welfare, to succeed Frederick I. Daniels, resigned, was announced today by Welfare Commissioner David C. Adie.

Survivors of the earthquake Tuesday and yesterday,, which is now known to have wiped out fifteen villages and devastated a huge area in Central Anatolia, bring reports tonight that 50,000 persons have been rendered homeless. The deaths are variously estimated between 300 and 800.

Max D. Steuer, chairman of the local campaign of the American ORT Federation, announced yesterday that two groups, one of lawyers and one of dentists, had been organized here to seek $200,000 as the city's share of the nation-wide fund to provide technical and agricultural training for the Jews of Eastern and Central Europe.

Nearly 900 registered and practical nurses, attending two sessions yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of the New York State Nurses Association, learned that the actual. deadline beyond which they cannot practice their profession without licenses in this State would be July 1, 1940.
Professor Adhemar mailhiot, dean of L'Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal and a noted geologist, died suddenly today at his office at the age of 55.
Judge Charless L. Bartlett, a familiar and stormy figure in Congress for years, died here today at the age of 85.

A constitutional amendment which would remove present restrictions against the State setting up a compensation plan to care for persons injured on the highways was proposed today by Abbot Low Moffat, Republican delegate at large to the Constitutional Convention.
Transfer To take effect 8 A. M., April 22. PATROLMAN James J. Falihee, from 14th Precinct to Police Academy, for duty in Technical Research Laboratory.

United States Government bonds cot rose yesterday to new high levels for the year and longer, in the most active trading on the New York Stock Exchange in eight months, or since Aug. 20, last year. Net gains ranged from 2-32 to 17-32 point on a turnover of $3,174,375, against sales of $622,125 on Wednesday.
Columbia's tennis team- scored its fourth consecutive victory by defeating St. John's, 8 1/2 to 1/2, on the South Field courts yesterday.

The National Labor Relations Board today ordered the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., of Santa Monica, Calif., to reinstate forty-five sitdowners who participated in a strike at the plant in February, 1937. The company, was also ordered to disestablish the Aircraft Workers Union, Inc., alleged to be favored by the company.

Contracts were signed at the United States Housing Authority today assuring $30,000,000 in Federal funds for two large low-cost housing projects in New York City. Alfred Rheinstein, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, and Nathan Straus of the USHA signed the papers.
The Insurgents are striking with sudden force at the weakened defenses of Madrid and have driven back the government lines in the western outskirts of the long-besieged city.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Leroy Finch are among-those who hate reserved tables for the Butterfly Ball dinner dance to be held this evening in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Pinch is chairman of the E. G. event, which will benefit the House of Rest at Spring Ridge, Yonkers, a hospital for the treatment of tubercular patients.

Yesterday workmen were tearing down the walls of the Grand Opera House. The bronze horses are perhaps stabled in some junkyard. Disembowelment had preceded demolition. o Where shall one go now to look for the faded splendors of seventy years ago?
Realty interests .are hoping that the efforts of Federal agencies to expand business credits will result at least indirectly in expansion of financing facilities for large-scale realty deals.

Miss Helen Warren Buchanan, daughter of John R. Buchanan of this city and Mrs. Ruth Lester Buchanan of Washington, was married to William Standley Stokes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. W. S. Stokes of Berwyn, Pa., today in St. James Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. Arthur B. Kinsolving 2d of Garden City, L. I., an uncle of the bride.

In a contest that needed more than two and a half hours to complete seven and one-half innings, New York University's baseball team gained a 10-to-4 triumph over its metropolitan rival, City College, yesterday at Ohio Field.

Death Announced Retired- Fireman John M. Bray, formerly a member of Engine Co. 93, residing at 134 West 166th St. Manhattan, died April 21. Funeral will take place from his late residence, at 10 A. M, Saturday, April 23. Interment at Woodlawn Cemetery., The deputy chief. of the 5th Division shall detain one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen, as funeral escort.

BACKSTAGE WITH ACTORS, by Helen Ormsbee (Crowell, $3.50). . .An account of actors past and present. BIOLOGY AND MARXISM, by Marcel Prenant (International Publishers, $2.50). A Marxist view of scientific problems.

A star fell in the midst of the Brooklyn pitching corps today and the countenance of Burleigh Grimes, so dour last night, was one big beam as he took his troupe back home to tackle those hated--Giants at-; Ebbets Field tomorrow.

Reporting themselves "swamped' by the number of salesmen offering goods in response to the advertisement offering "to buy up to $100,000 worth of first-quality merchandise at a price," the three buying representatives of the Read Drug Company of Maryland, Wow at the Hotel Vanderbilt, said yesterday the results of their trip here were "beyond their expectations."

The drive for greater home rule for cities in this State opened today when Harold Riegelman, chairman of the Committee on Cities of the Constitutional Convention, made public a proposed amendment, sweeping in nature, which he will introduce when the convention reassembles next Monday night.

Another lease emphasizing the growing importance of Fifty-seventh Street as an art center was announced yesterday when the Metropolitan Art Galleries, Thomas W. Weitmeyer, president, rented the store at 37-39 West Fifty-seventh Street from the Bainbridge

The sixteenth annual Front Page Ball of the New York Newspaper Women's Club will be held tonight at the Hotel Astor. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, it was announced, will be the guest of honor. Mrs. Roosevelt will present the awards of the club's second annual story contest.

Success- again crowned the efforts of Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, chess champion of the world, representing France in the internal tional tournament of the Kent County Chess Associations in the second round at the Grand Hotel, Cliftonville, today.
Walter James Raybold, paper manufacturer, died of pneumonia tonight at the House of Mercy Hospital. He was 73 years old.

Jehiel Weintraub, first general secretary of the Workmen's Circle and founder of the Bailystoker Center and Home, 228 East Broadway, was killed in an automobile accident in West Warren, Mass., on Wednesday, according to word received here yesterdays He was 56 yers old.
Attorney General Bennett's investigation of causes that led the New York Curb Exchange to
James Speyer, banker and philanthropist, received the annual gold medal of the Hundred Year Association at the tenth annual dinner of the organization last night in the Savoy-Plaza Hotel.

Allen St, 35, 25x87.6: Rachel Sackin to Harris Sackin, 35 Allen St. 59th St, 440 E, 20x100.5; Albert and Leon Loeb to 440 East 59th Street Corp, 440 E 59th St; mtg $6,000 ($1).. 109th St, 124 E, 18.6x101; Metropolitan Savings Bank to Mary Bozovic, 245 E 110th St ($3.50); she gave mtg for $2,500, 3 years, 6 per cent, to Hyman H. Rubin.

Toddle On, making her first start since she annexed the Maryland Futurity at Laurel last October, gained a photo decision over E. D. Shaffer's Evening Shadow in a thrilling finish that marked the running of the Sudbrook Purse today.

Mr. Floyd Caves Herman, once a distinguished performer of Flatbush, slashed a double down the first-base line with the bases full in the tenth inning today to make the Jersey City International League opening at beautiful Roosevelt Stadium the artistic success sit deserved to be.

A rise in member bank excess reserves of $760,000,000 to a total of $2,490,000,000, the largest since the first part of August, 1936, was reported in this week's Federal Reserve statements, issued yesterday. The gain reflected to the extent of $690,000,000 the reduction by 13 1/4 per cent in reserve requirements of the member banks that was put into effect by the Federal Reserve Board last Saturday.

The appointment of Joseph A. Brandt present director of The University of Oklahoma Press, to succeed Paul G. Tomlinson, '09, as director of The Princeton University Press was announced today by the board of trustees of The Princeton University Press.

Mr. and Mrs. William H. Siebrecht of this place celebrated the sixtieth anniversary of their marriage with a tea given at their home this afternoon by their daughter, Mrs. Harry H. Lorenz of Boonton, N. J., and three sons, Henry B. Siebrecht, George C. Siebrecht and William H. Siebrecht Jr., all of Chappaqua.

Many of the mental ills of the present day can be traced to the fact that people have not been educated for living and that much of the, energy of our educational system is expended in imparting knowledge without really educating, according to Dr. C. Charles Burlingame, psychiatrist in chief of the Neuro-Psychiatric Institute of the Hartford Retreat.

Mrs. Pleasants Pennington entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the cottage of Hampshire House for Mrs. G. Palen Snow, Mrs. Robert Rand, Mrs. Thomas K. Finletter, Mrs. Ethelbert Warfield, Mrs. Morin de Linclays, Mrs. Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Mrs. William Francis Gibbs, Mrs. Phillip D. Wilson and Mrs. Tuckerman Draper.

Mrs. Payne Whitney's Gangplank, preparing for the Kentucky Derbly, covered a 'mile handily in 1:422-5 at Churchill Downs today: The bay colt by Dis Donc-Conge, was clocked in 0:244-5, -0:501-5 "and' 1:16 3-5 at the quarter posts.

The Republican Club of the Fifteenth Assembly District, Manhattan's "silk stocking" area, refused last night, after two hours of debate, to adopt a resolution condemning the appointment of Communists to public Office.

The Camp of National Unity was purged today of its extreme right wing, which is Fascist and anti-Semitic when General Stanislas Skwarzynski, the camp's new chief, dismissed Jerzy Rutkowski, leader of the Union of Young Poland with
New York University's tennis team gained its third victory in four matches by blanking Brooklyn College, 9--0, yesterday at the Fleet Hollow Courts in the Bronx.
-Karel Kozeluh of Czechoslovakia clowned through three sets today in winning the Pinehurst professional tennis singles championship from his brother, Jan,- 6-3, 6-2.
CONDEMNED WOMEN, from a story and screan play bt Lionel Houser; directed by Lew Landers; produced by Robert Siak for RKO Radio. At the Riaito.

A deck of cards was cut to decide a village election tie here last Tuesday, it became known today. At the annual election in March James J. MacGilvray and Charles Kerr each polled 113 votes as candidates for a village trusteeship.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES is quite right in questioning whether the theory of overproduction can explain the causes of the present depression. I do not agree; however, with the conclusion in the editorial "The Theory Behind Spending" in the issue of April 18: "AS the President's diagnosis is wrong, so the remedies he proposes are wrong."

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today to the Philadelphia Stock Exchange unlisted trading privileges in odd lots of $5-parvalue common stock of the Atlas Corporation, which is listed in the New York Stock Exchange, and in the $10-par-value common stock of the Niagara Hudson Power Company, now listed on the New York Curb.

Louis Sperandei, for thirty-five years a French horn player in symphony orchestras in New York and formerly a member of the board of governors of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, died of pneumonia Wednesday at his home, 27-27 Erickson Street, East Elmhurst, L. I., on his sixty-fifth birthday.
Superior Judge Emmet H. Wilson saw to it today that there would be no "exploitation" of child actors unless at least half of their salaries were put in trust for them.

The National Cash Register Com pany and subsidiaries reported yesterday that the net profit for the twelve months ended on March 31 amounted to $3,710,978 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges.
The House approved the non-military appropriation bill of the War Department today, which carried $220,634,725 for rivers and harbors improvement and flood-control works.

More than 100 members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, here for their annual convention, talked "off the record" tonight With President Roosevelt. By mutual understanding, neither questions nor answers at the informal conference were to be disclosed outside.

Wheater to call J. P. Morgan as a witness at the hearings into the failure of Richard Whitney Co. is a question which has developed a sharp difference of opinion among the members of the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was learned today.

A search of Iron Guard archives today brought to light a document written and signed by Corneliu Zelea Codreanu providing evidence that his organization had very close relations with certain foreign polit-. ical groups. 'The document formed the basis of a report presented to the Cabinet.

As a further sign of the advance solo of Spring, the Boys Club of New York deserted the indoor setting of the doughnut-dunking and baby beauty contests with which it whiled away the Winter and moved to the roof of its clubhouse at Avenue A and Tenth Street for the pet show yesterday.
Stressing the importance of foreign commerce to the prosperity of this city, Mayor La Guardia yesterday urged all citizens to participate in the activities of Foreign Trade Week, May 22 to 28.

Forty-three newly promoted cadet officers of the Reserve Officers Training Corps at New York University will be presented to their commands this afternoon in the first regimental parade of the year on Ohio Field at University Heights.

Preparations are being made at Pine Camp Military Reservation for the opening, May 23, of a two-week training period for 1,200 army regulars from the First Division Machine Gun and Howitzer School. The division headquarters is at Fort Hamilton.

Maurice W. Spear, secretary and treasurer of Spear Co., furniture dealers of New York and Pittsburgh, died on Wednesday night in Elizabeth Steel Magee Hospital in Pittsburgh after a short illness, according to word received here yesterday. He was 56 years old.

Registration of $68,334,000 in securities, excluding $878,000 reserved for the conversion of other securities, became effective in March under the Securities Act of 1933, bringing the total on that basis for the first quarter of the year to $333,822,000, a new low quarterly figure for three years, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Dr. Thomas McBurnie of 1 Westminster Road, Baldwin, L. I., president of the State Board of Optometry Examiners, died yesterday morning of a heart ailment in Adelphi Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 60 years old.
Marse Joe McCarthy celebrated his fiftieth birthday by hopefully conducting an experiment at Fenway Park to day.
The Pirates swept their opening series with the Cardinals by taking the third and final game today, 6 to 5.

Light weather boats came into their own today in the second Prince of Wales Trophy race when the new Nicholson-designed sixmeter Solenta and the 8-year-old Viking, both flying the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club burgee, took first and second places in an eight-mile westerly breeze.

Boris Romanoff has been engaged as choreographer and ballet master of the Metropolitan Opera Association for the season 1938-39, it was announced yesterday by General Manager Edward Johnson. As has been announced, the ballet next season will be developed as a part of the opera ensemble. Mr. Romanoff will be at its head.

Thirty-six savings banks comprising Group V of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York announced yesterday that they were prepared to invest $100,000,000 in housing loans to spur a revival of the building industry.

Securities purchased in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the the week ended on April 16 exceeded those sold by 13,871 shares; the wo Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. This was with the price trend, which on the basis of THE NEW YORK TIMESs averages for fifty stocks showed a net advance of 2.37 points. The statistics follow:

Governor Philip F. La Follette, who has split with President Roosevelt over methods to bring the nation out of the recession, told a radio audience tonight that able-bodied men and women must be put to work at productive enterprises to insure the return of better times.
Meeting, Patriotic Luncheon Club; of the American Patriots, Hotel Iroquois, 12:30 P. M. "Red Flag Over Albany," Senator John J. McNaboe.

The adult of 45 years and beyond is the pedestrian most liable to traffic accidents in New York City, according to statistics quoted yesterday at the closing session of the Greater New York Safety Council in the Hotel Astor.
Paul Derringer limited the Cubs to four hits today while his mates garnered thirteen off Tex Carleton to win, 6 to 2, for the Reds' first victory the 'season.

President Rooseveit is considering a short fishing trip in the Caribbean Sea starting about May 1 from Charleston, S.C. It was indicated, however, the President would make the trip only if the Congressional situation permitted.

Thomas H. McInnerney, president of the National Dairy Products Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders that the company's sales in the first quarter of this year were about 1.2 per cent less than a year before, but that operations were "in the black."

The 1938-39 season of the Metrobolitan Opera Association, Edward Johnson, general manager, will begin Monday evening, Nov. 21, and that will continue for sixteen weeks, according to announcements sent yesterday to opera subscribers.

Mount Holyoke College juniors and their escorts will dance in Chapin Auditorium tomorrow night at the opening event of the annual Junior Promenade week-end. The festivities will be resumed Saturday with tea dances and another formal.
The Electrical Trades Union protested today to the Office of Works against what it charged was employment of nonunion projectionists at a private film showing for King George at Windsor Castle.

Circuit Judge Thomas Brown denied late today the application of Raymond Dawson, counsel for the Friedrich Krupp Aktiengesellschaft of Germany, for an order requiring officers of the Pan-American Securities Corporation of New York to appear

For the first time in-recent years more men are applying for teaching licenses than are women. Fortyfive hundred candidates, 2,500 of whom are men, are taking teacherin-training examinations in fourteen general high school subjects, for which 118 positions are available.

In the course of his interesting discourses before the New York Academy of Medicine Professor David K. Henderson of the University of Edinburgh paid his respects to the genius among other psychopathically afflicted persons.

Of the New York City firms, Bonbright Co., Inc., led all underwriters in the amount of security issues managed, $73,195,000. Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., was second with $34,500,000, and Stone Webster and Blodget, third with $3,618,000 in the first quarter of 1938, according to an analysis made public today by the SEC.
Colonel Marcuswell Maxwell, whose pictures of wild animals he stalked in broad daylight are considered unsurpassed in hunting photography, died today in a hospital here.

The White Construction Company 'has been awarded the contract for alterations to the bakery of the National Biscuit Company at 69-75 Ninth Avenue, according to Brown's letters, Inc. Louis Wirtsching Jr. prepared the" plans.

New fluorescent lumiline lamps, which provide any desired tint of white and colored lights while remaining cool, were demonstrated before an audience of nearly 1,000 persons last night at a meeting at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 -West Thirty-ninth Street.

Behind the six-hit pitching of Johnny Gee, 6-foot-9-inch southpaw and the first Syracuse boy ever chosen to pitch an opening game here, the Chiefs got off to a flying start in the International League campaign with a 3-to-1 victory over Montreal today.

The compilation of awards for engineering construction in the current week reveals a slackening in private work which-brings the total of all awards 11 per cent below the 1937 figure for the same period, according to The Engineering NewsRecord.

The Robert Steiner-Leona Heyert Stavis melodrama; called "Escape This Night," or murder in the Public Library, relights the Fortyfourth Street Theatre this evening. It is Robinson Smith's pleasure to present the same, with Arnold Korff and Francesca Bruning at the top of a large cast which Mr. Steiner has directed. 'Curtain at 8:40 P. M.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Doris Baumann Wechsler, daughter of Ralph V. Wechsler of 575 Park Avenue and the late Mrs. Wechsler, to Jesse Freidin, son of Mrs. Sidney J. Freidin of this city and Miamo, Fla., and the late Mr. Freidin.

London tra vociferously hailed its first demonstration of American pro hockey replete with power plays and with an overtime period thrown in for good measure as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 4, at Earl's Court tonight.

A total of eleven and a half years of life has been provided to vital human and animal organs in the artificial "life--chamber" designed by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Dr. Alexis Carrel, according to a report made by Dr. Carrel today before the annual meeting of the American Philosophical Society.

The Treasury on Monday bought its first silver from Mexico since the announcement, effective April 1, that the United States had abandoned its agreement to purchase 5,000,000 ounces monthly from the Mexican Government, Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference today.

Newark's. Bears, virtually scrapped after. they had romped off with the International League championship and the little world series last Fall, resumed their winning ways today as the 1938 pennant race was launched at Ruppert .Stadium before a chilled gathering of 15,298 fans.

On the eve of the biennial convention of the Young Women's - Christian Association. of America, 'officials estimated that 8,000 delegates and visitors would attend, to make this the largest gathering in the history of the organization. The program, based on the topics of Christianity and democracy, will continue through next Thursday.

The following Reserve officers recently released to the 1st Military Area, are assigned as indicated: 389th Infantry-2d Lt. Daniel C. Nolan 3d, Inf-Res., 350 Hoslck St., Troy, N. Y. 391st Infantry-2d Lt. Olen B. Garrison, Inf-Res., 109 Summit Ave., Ithaca, N. Y. 41st Infantry-2d Lt. Robert E. Knapp, Inf.-Res., 916 Westcott St., Syracuse, N. Y.

Sandy Herd, former.British open champion, who will be 70 years old next Sunday, shot a sensational 67, six under par, over the Moor Park west course today in the $5,000 Rickmansworth open golf championship.
A less than seasonal increase was registered in-lumber production last week and the . adjusted index dropped to 58.6 from 60.3. It was 84.1 for the week ended April 17, 1937.

The United Spanish War Veterans of the Department of New York held their annual military ball last, night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor. Alfred J. Kennedy, commander in chief, and Mrs. Mary A. McCauley, national president of the women's auxiliary, both--New Yorkers, were the guest of honor.

More than 1,500 persons were at the . Pauline Edwards Theatre, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, last night for the initial performance of "In the Groove," satirical musical revue produced by the City College Dramatic Society as the annual varsity show to celebrate the golden jubilee of the college's oldest undergraduate club.

A throng of approximately 1,500 taxed the capacity of the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for a preview supper dance arranged in behalf of the philanthropic work conducted by the Cooperative Committee of Big Sisters.

Negotiations between representatives of public utility holding companies and the Securities and Exchange Commission on application of provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 are expected gradually to evolve to the point where utilities will find a more receptive market for the flotation of their securities.

Paintings and sculpture by five American artists have just been bought by the University of Nebraska at Lincoln. The purchases are "Mahone Bay," oil by William, J. Glackens; "Abandoned Farm House," water-color by Charles Burchfield; "Winter, Pittsburgh," oil by Ernest Fiene; "Wandering Three," bronze by Heinz Warneke, and "Dolphins," bronze by Gaston Lachaise.

Secretary Ickes today declined to confirm a report that there was a letter in the files of the Public Works Administration which designated Matthew H. McCloskey Jr., Philadelphia political leader and contractor, as Pennsylvania representative before the PWA.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that in nine of the ten countries in which it has telephone operations, 28 per cent more telephones were installed in the first three months of 1938 than in the first quarter of 1937.
Lyn Lary's double with the bases full in the eighth gave the Indians a 4-3 victory over the Browns today. Cleveland won the series, 2-1.

Award of. the $2,000 McKim fellowship in architecture, a $1,500 university fellowship and an exchange scholarship in the University of Rome was announced yesterday by Dean Leopold Arnaud of the Columbia University School of Architecture.

A minority on the House Interstate Commerce Committee filed a report today with the House criticizing the Copeland-Lea Pure Food and Drug Bill which was favorably reported last week by a majority of the.committee.

Full support of the Republicanapproved revised Wages and.Hours Bill recently voted out of the House of Representatives Labor Committee, was voiced last night by Representative Bruce Barton, a member of the committee, at the annual meeting of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club, 122 East Eighty-third Street.

Expenditures by the church on foreign missions while it is "hardly ably to touch the fringes here" among foreign elements, Negroes, and - the underprivileged, were scored .last night by the Rev. Mark A. Dawber, executive secretary of the Home Missions Council, an. interdenominational body.

Although the 1938 major league campaign was officially opened in Washington and Boston ;last Monday and the Giants started the ball rolling at the Polo Grounds Tuesday, New -York' - first big- moment of the new-born season will not arrive until this afternoon.

Herbert Kruttschnitt, local Director of Revenue and Finance, and Feist Feist, Newark real estate firm, announced today that the thirtytwo-acre Ollemar tract, near this town's business center, had been sold for $1,500,000 to an undisclosed New York syndicate,

Mrs. Jerome Monks, the daughter of the late Major Orlando Jay Smith, founder of the American Press Association, died yesterday morning at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a brief illness.

Joseph Stalin has a habit which must be very uncomfortable, to put it mildly, for his loyal subordinates. Every once in a while he rounds them up and punishes them publicly and severely for carrying out his orders.
While Samuel Reshevsky, United States titleholder, was held up in an adjourned game with Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, Reuben Fine defeated George N. Treysman in

A Vatican news service reported today that Pope Pius had delivered a forty-minute speech, the longest with possibly one exception since his grave illness of more than a year ago. He was talking to 150 Italian diocesan presidents of Catholic Action youth about their official duties.

Education discussed its relation to business today when sixty-three representatives of forty-nine educational institutions attended the annual meeting of the American Association of Collegiate Schools of Business. Government came in for criticism at the opening session, which dealt with cooperative research in three phases:

Hitler's birthday celebration in Berlin had for one of its features a military parade. It was short but representative, according to our correspondent, Mr. Tolischus. It showed that the guiding principle of the' new German Army is tempo.

Miss Grace Livingston Furniss, author, playwright and a member of an old New York family, died here yesterday at the Colly Convalescent Home after an illness that resulted from a fall. Miss Furniss, who lived at 64 and Orchard Avenue, was 74 years old.

Maurice Schwartz's production of "Brothers Ashkenazi" will end its stay at. the Parkway, Brooklyn, Sunday night, resuming its tour in Philadelphia the next night. The Parkway's next tenant, opening Monday, will be "Schlemiele," the Yiddish operetta which moves from the Second Avenue.

Stressing that "nothing in Mexico's Constitution can affect the right of the British Government to protest against action regarded as unjustifled and request the restitution of properties of the Mexican Eagle Oil Company as the only practical house means of avoiding serious injury ot extensive British interests," the British Government today added support to its previous note to Mexico.

HELL hath few furies like a reader who has been persuaded by an injudiciously enthusiastic review to spend from two to five dollars on a book he finds he doesn't like at all. Particularly if the book is allegedly humorous. So perhaps one had better just say that "Bowleg Bill,"* by Jeremiah Digges, is not, oh decidedly not, unentertaining. And let it go at that.
On May 17 Dodd, Mead will publish "Mural for a Later Day," a novel dealing with the founding of the first Swedish colony in America. The author is Kathleen Pawle.
John H. Pardee, utility industrialist, died on Wednesday evening in his home, 1,088 Park Avenue, after a short illness. His age was 71.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Gloria Gucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry John Gucker of this city and Centerport, L. I., to Richard Anderson Hoefer of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Hoefer of Chicago, took place last night in Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Saxon performed the ceremony.

The Southern Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to sell $14,000,000 of its equipment trust certificates to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in connection with the purchase of 5,000 freight' cars and four small Diesel-electric passenger units.
The annual Caledonian games, highlight of Princeton University's intramural sports program, were annexed by the Tiger freshmen, with the juniors, seniors and sophomores following in that order.

Rowland St (15-3973), w s, 40 ft n of Westchester Ave, 60x127; Loray Realty Corp to Reuben H. Brown, 415 W 151st St; mtge., $45,750. 195th St (12-3282), s s, 121 ft w of Decatur Ave, A. Bird, 309 E 119th St; mtge., $11,000.

The auction of the furnishings of the James A. Burden residence, 7 East Ninety-first Street, which was completed yesterday under the management of the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., brought a total of $31,591.50, at three sessions.
The navy told a House committee today that legislation to deny government contracts to violators of the Wagner Labor Act probably would hamstring the fleet construetion.
Dr. Donald C. Hoffman, an associate medical director of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Rye, N. Y. He was 39 years old.
Miss Junia Culbertson will sing at a musicale tomorrow at the Mayflower Hotel, to which her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William S. Culbertson, have invited their friends.

Total loans and investment of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose ??82,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to their conedition statement issued yesterday.
Of the 2,500,000 foreigners resident in France, 11,467 are from North America, according to 1936 census figures examined today by the French Cabinet.

The Italian liner Roma will sail today for Mediterranean ports with 573 passengers. Those on board will be Mr. and Mrs. M. Baroni, Mr. and Mrs. James. O'Brien, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Loebs, Edward Georges, Samuel Levy, Paul Henkel, Mr. and Mrs. Morris O. Alprin, George Tucker, the Rev. Leo Madden, Dr. and Mrs. George E. Eversole, Dr. and Mrs. B. H. Pillsbury, J. C. Blackwell and Mr. and Mrs. S. Cardamone.

Senator Wheeler. informed a joint committee representing railway managements and the standard railway unions-today that it would be possible to put through Congress at the present session an emergency railway relief program, but that a long-range, permanent program was out of the question.

Although there was room- for alibi in one instance, Hal Price Headley's hopes for victory in the sixty-third renewal of the Kentucky Deby took a decided setback today as both Menow and Dah He, his chief reliances, lost.
Miss Julia Kingsland Macy and W. Cary Potter will have twentyfour attendants for their marriage on June 11, which will take place in St. Mark's Church, Islip, L. I.

Four Americans have been desig nated by the board of trustees at Manhattan College as recipients of honorary degrees as part - of the diamond jubilee celebration to be held next Tuesday, it was announced by Brother Patrick, president.

A number of big manufacturing companies have achieved success with guaranteed wage plans, Harold B. Bergen of McKinsey Wellington Co.. New York, told the American Management Association conference here today.

Delivering the seventeenth anniversary address at Hampton Institute today, Mrs. Franklin D. roosevelt told the students of the Negro school of their obligation in preserving a democracy. Her theme was "Seeking a Place in a Community."
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders to, day, dated April 19: COMMANDERS Mitchell, E. A., the Shaw, to instruction Naval War College, Newport, R. I., June 4.

A new venture in Federal housing plant in New York City got under way this many week when President Roosevelt approved a $30,000,000 loan, made through the United States Housing Authority, for the projects in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn and at bring Queensbridge, Long Island City.

The New Jersey Council, created last year to advertise the State's advantages, received a letter today from the New Jersey Taxpayers Association urging that the State's favorable tax status be emphasized in its publicity program.
The new minimum basic agreement between the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union and the League of New York Theatres is now being generally distributed. Some random notes thereon:

The marriage of Miss Virginia' Mallory Peyton, daughter of Mrs. Nathaniel M. Wagner of Starrs Plain, this city, and of Donald Chambers Peyton of Hollywood, Calif., to Charles Vincent Wynne of Reading, Pa., son of Mrs. Katharine G. Wynne of Cleveland, took place here at noon today in the rectory of St. Peter's Church. The Rev. John J.

Dickerman Hollister will give a dinner tonight in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Honour R. Dickerman and her fiance, James Oliver Brown, who will be married next month. Miss Dickerman is the daughter of- Mr. and Mrs. William Carter Dickerman.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for numerous small homes in Queens and Brooklyn. In Manhattan, plans were filed for a taxpayer near Pennsylvania Station and several alterations.

Making a sweep of first places in the fifteen events contested, the Brooklyn College track and filed team crused Hosfstra College, 103 1/2 to 30 1/2, today in a meet that dedicated the home team's new track. Irgo Storojeff paced the visitors' scoring. He captured four events, the pole cault shot put, javelin and discus throw.

The Treasury's decision to apply some of the proceeds of the desterilization of its $1,400,000,000 of inactive gold funds toward the retirement of outstanding bills at the rate of $50,000,000 a week will put some of its conservative critics in an awkward spot.

The International Seamen's Union, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, has been designated as the bargaining agency of the unlicensed personnel employed by the American Range Lines, it was announced yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board.

Driven from the mound by Holy Cross yesterday, Gene Bowe pitched Fordham to a three-hit, 14-0 victory over Boston University before 1,500 fans on Nickerson Field today. It was Bowe's second shutout of the season.
