Miss Nancy White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. White, has completed plans for her marriage to Clarence J. Dauphinot Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence J. Dauphinot of Forest Hills, Queens, which will take place here at the White home on the afternoon of May 7.

William F. Bleakley of Yonkers was chosen unanimously late today by members of the executive committee of the Westchester County Republican organization as their candidate for county executive, popularly known as President, under the new county charter, which will become operative Jan. 1. Endorsements by the committee have been tantamount to election for many years.

According to plans for the Salzburg Festival, issued today, all operatic performances excepting the new staging of "Tannhaeuser" will, take place as originally scheduled, but the conductors 'and many singers will differ from the original list. Neither Arturo Toscanini nor Bruno Walter will conduct, and several non-Aryan singers have been excluded.

MUNICIPAL X-RAY TECHNICIAN-Salary: $1,200 per annum to $1,500 per annum; pension; fair sick leave. Vacancies: Four in Health and Hospital Departments. Requirements: High school graduates preferred. Candidates must have had one year's recent, full time. paid experience in the field, or equivalent training or education.
Morris Goldfarb, florist, died ?? terday at the New York Hospital after an illness of three months. He was 65 years old and had lived at Miami Beach, Fla., and at 215 West Eighty-third Street.

As with us, the only certainties of life for the British are death and taxes. But they handle their levies on a more equitable and successful basis, and, contrary to the general impression, British taxes in the higher brackets are not so likely to a prevent a Duke of the Realm from

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve for the New York bank also reached a new high point for the year.
Mayor La Guardia endorsed the campaign of Beekman Street Hospital for an additional $90,000 to finance its work for 1938 yesterday in a letter to Howard S. Cullman, president of the hospital.
President Roosevelt reminded 4,000 Daughters of the American Revolution today that they and he were descendants of "immigrants and revolutionists."

Although liquidation of May contracts continued as the outstanding development in trading on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday, less foreign selling combined -with reports that rains were delaying planting in the Southeast brought about an improvement of 8 to 11 points.

Poultney Bigelow, who comes home at this time- every year with his head full of ideas about affairs in Europe and the state 'of man saw generally, returned on the North no German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday, running true to form.

Postoffice officials said today that they would ask Horace Russell, resigned general counsel for the Home Owners Loan Corporation, to pay about $280 in postage charges for letters he sent out under the franking privilege, praising the legal- abilities of 0. B. Taylor, a former HOLC attorney.

Two four-story tenement houses at 339-343 Christopher Street, in East New York, have been purchased by the Quincy Housing Corporation. The buildings stand on a plot 62.6 by 100 feet, and contain thirty-two three and four room suites.

C. K. Boettcher of Denver, Colo., failed of re-election as a director of the Alpha Portland Cement Company yesterday when stockholders, by a vote of 459,216 shares to 70,007, with 15,872 negative votes disallowed as being defective reduced the number of directors from ten to nine. All the other directors were re-elected.
Instructions are being sent tonight to Juies Blondel, Charge d'Affaires in Rome, regarding the course he should take in his conversations with Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano.

The two favored teams in the national championship knockout team of four contract bridge championships, the Four Aces and the Cavendish Club combination headed by Waldemar K. von Zedtwitz, won their way to the semi-final round last night at the Hotel Ambassador.

Richard Whitney's assorted methods of borrowing $100,000 without security were passed in review here yesterday when the Securities and Exchange Commission questioned eight brokers who had lent to him and five who had not.

The building at 672 Eighth Avenue, between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets, will be converted into a two-story taxpayer as the result of its purchase by the Annbrec Realty Corporation from Mrs. Margery W. McNally.

Bank clearings of the twenty-two leading cities throughout the country amounted to $4,759,234,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represents a decline of 18.6 per cent from the $5,849,518,000 reported for the corresponding week last year.

The Rev. S. O. Rusby, retired pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Centur Church of Woodrow, S. I., died on Wednesday night at his home in Pleasant Plains, N. Y., after a long illness. He was born eighty-one years ago in Nutley, N. J.

Business in the wool goods. market this week showed signs of picking up and more orders were written on Fall men's wear suitings than in any similar period since the 'beginning of the season, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Thomas W. Palmer, counsel for the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in charge of its Latin-American legal business, was elected president of the New York Southern Society at its annual. meeting last night at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.
For several months a special committee of the Senate has been holding hearings on problems of business and employment. One member of this committee now says in his report:
The C. I. O. affiliated United Automobile Workers extended strikes to six additional Detroit plants today and brought their disputed "dues-collectibn" picket line manoeuvre to this city.

Fed steers sold steady today, but the market was slow. Choice and prime kinds such as showed up earlier in the week were absent. Special interest followed the sale of fed lambs at 15-25c lower, top falling to $8.35. Hogs showed strength, according to the United States Department of Agriculture report.
For several months a special committee of the Senate has been holding hearings on problems of business and employment. One member of this committee now says in his report:
The C. I. O. affiliated United Automobile Workers extended strikes to six additional Detroit plants today and brought their disputed "dues-collectibn" picket line manoeuvre to this city.
President Roosevelt addressed the Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution and tonight addressed the American Society of Newspaper Editors in an "off the record" talk at the White House.

Fed steers sold steady today, but the market was slow. Choice and prime kinds such as showed up earlier in the week were absent. Special interest followed the sale of fed lambs at 15-25c lower, top falling to $8.35. Hogs showed strength, according to the United States Department of Agriculture report.

Mayor La Guardia's charge that the justices of Kings County Supreme Court were guilty of extravagance in the granting of salary increases for court employes was disputed in an affidavit that was part of the record on which Justice Thomas C. Kadien handed down two decisions Wednesday allowing additional pay and providing salaries totaling $20,240 for sixty-six employes of the Brooklyn tribunal. The record was made public yesterday.
A fashion show was held last night in behalf of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children at Bergdorf Goodman, 754 Fifth Avenue.

A thrilling dash by air to bring a supposedly rare serum from London, Ont., to an ill woman at 241 Central Park West, turned into a mystery yesterday when the bearer of the "serum" disappeared suddenly after paying $7 for a taxi ride from Newark Airport to the Central Park West address.
The Chamber of Commerce- of the United States announced awards tonight in its 1937 'city health conservation contest, conducted in cooperation with the American Public Health Association.

The Cardinals rallied for four runs in the ninth inning today to defeat the Cubs, 6 to 5, and score their first victory in four starts this season. Chicago was leading, 5 to 2, going into the ninth. An error placed Mickey Owen on base, then Bill Lee weakened.

Timothy J. Horrigan, president and treasurer of the Kingsbury Construction Company of Hudson Falls and one of the best-known construction executives in this section of the State, died today at his home here. Death was caused by thrombosis. He was 65.
Joseph Stalin, "First Deputy of the Soviet Union" by virtue of his unanimous election to the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. last December, is again a candidate for office.

Clearing the hurdles in flawless fashion, the well-matched bay geldings, Boer and Remsen, last night scored an impressive victory to put the New York Police Department team in front in the three-phase military jumping competition at the Squadron A Spring Horse Show.

The task of checking up on the money Jackie Coogan earned as a movie star today caused the court to postpone until May 2 further action in his suit for an accounting against his mother and his stepfather.

Although there have been minor changes in schedules, the running time of several trains between stations having been reduced, the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company announced yesterday that there would be no drastic changes in its schedules when the Spring timetable becomes effective on Sunday morning.

Olga Treskoff, actress who was associated with Russell Janney in the production of many operettas, died Thursday night at her home in the Essex House, 325 East Fortyfirst Street. She was 36 years old.
The Texas Pacific Railway reported a profit-and-loss surplus of $16,668,444 on Dec. 31, against $14,790,729 a year previously. Total assets were $209,451,280, against $206,862,922.

Twelve thousand alumni of the University of Notre Dame will commemorate universal Notre Dame night on Monday at dinners, meetings and other affairs in scores of cities throughout the United States and in many foreign countries.
A sixpoint program of principles, including abolition of the teachers' oath, was adopted unanimously by the State Federation of Teachers Unions, which ended its annual convention tonight.
Walter Borden Tallman," who retired in 1928 as a vice president of the Irving Trust Company, died on Wednesday night at his home, 780 Riverside Drive, after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

2d Lt. Armistead P. Booker, Cav.-Res, 35 Woodland Ave., Woodbury, N. J., is ordered to active duty for six months, effective April 25, at Headquarters Trenton District, CCC North Olden and Breunig Aves., Trenton, N. J., for assignment and duty in connection with. CCC activities. Date of rank: April 20, 1937.

Army engineers have informed a House Appropriations Committee that they planned to spend $1,655,800 for maintenance of twenty-two river and harbor projects in New York State during the 1939 fiscal year.

Flanked by a capacity gathering of 31,154 enthusiasts, the majority of whom would gladly have laid down their lives to have brought about a different result, the Dodgers made a noble bid to crown the opening of their championship baseball season at Ebbets Field with success yesterday.

When the Seamen's Church Institute of New York was established Richard a Henry Dana was about to sail for the California coast on the brig Pilgrim, Herman Melville was a pale-faced clerk, steam at sea was still a novelty, and, in short, the romance of seafaring life, with its hardships and dangers, was at its height.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows. British stocks, 1,239,000 bales, against 1,213,000 a week ago, 1,190,000 two weeks ago, 1,203,000 three weeks ago and 979,000 a year ago; of which American 818,000 bales, against 815,000 a week ago, 794,000 two weeks ago, 797,000 three weeks ago and 979,000 a year. ago.
Pennies totaling $17.15 were donated to pay the $6 fine of J. Haskell Bethurum, arrested when he asked two policemen why they were driving their patrol car without lights.

Alexander W. Crandall, a Civil War veteran who passed his sixteenth birthday within the walls of a Confederate prison, died today at his home in Buskirk at the age of 89. He served with Company H, of the Sixty-ninth New York Infantry during the war, and was discharged in 1865.

The dream of a National Theatre-a project that has been under way for nearly half a century and that has split the English theatrical world from the top to the bottom-was partially realized today when the deeds of the National Theatre site were publicly accepted by George Bernard Shaw.

Harry Chancer, president of the New York and Brooklyn Cloak and Suit Trucking Association, was found guilty yesterday, of conspiracy and coercion in the clothing trucking industry and was remanded to the Tombs without bail by Justices William R. Bayes, Max Salomon and John V. Flood at a Special Sessions term held in the County Court House.

Holders of dollar bonds of the German Atlantic Cable Company have been placed in a position, by a recent decision of the German Government, to receive a substantial part of their interest, according to Jacob S. Chaitkin, their attorney.

The New York Chinese Hand Laundry Alliance will ship to China today five ambulances, valued at $10,000, according to an announcement yesterday by James Lee, president of the alliance. The money for the ambulances was donated by 1,500 Chinese laundrymen in the metropolitan area.

The Albanian and Italian Governments have settled differences arising from the former's failure to observe the conditions on which the semiofficial Italian organization S. P. E. A. (Society for' the Promotion of the Economic Reconstruction of Albania) failed to pay regularly its interest or amortization annuities, the arrears reaching 69,900,000 gold francs.

Charles S. Howard, owner of Seabiscuit, said today his stake star may not be entered in the Dixie Stakes at Pimlico in Maryland May 11, as originally planned. "It all depends on how he stands the trip East," Howard said.

A rare military ceremony, that of an enlisted men's review for the officers of their regiment, was held last night by the non-commissioned officers and enlisted men of the 107th Infantry (Old Seventh Regiment), N. Y. N. G., at the regimental armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
The Chicago White Sox and the St. Louis Browns battled through thirteen innings today before the Sox got the run needed to win, 4 to 3, and spoil the home opening of Gabby Street's team.

Miss Dcrothy Grace Mechling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Franklin Mechling of Orchard Lane Farm, Flourtown, was married this afternoon to Donald Dodge of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kern Dodge of Ingleside, Germantown. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Nathaniel B. Groton in St. Thomas Church, Whiternarsh.

Winning for the third time, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris assumed undisputed lead in the third round of the international masters' chess tournament today at the Grand Hotel in Cliftonville. The world champion defeated H. Golombek of London, one of the five British representatives.

Before retiring tonight New Yorkers should turn their clocks and watches forward one hour. Daylight saving time will become effective at 2 A. M. tomorrow and continue until Sept. 25, when the lost hour of sleep will be regained.

Complaints by jobbers and merchants of flour and other foodstuffs that they were forced by unions to hire public loaders at excessive costs at railroad and steamship terminals and public warehouses were made yesterday at a hearing called by William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets.

Miss Ruth Adeline McCreary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. B. A. McCreary of Norfolk, Neb., was married here yesterday morning in the Second Presbyterian Church to Lawrence E. de Neufville of this city and London,

Something was bound to happen when Acting Mayor Newbold Morris and Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx agreed. And yesterday, when the two members of the Board of Estimate were stanch allies for fully twenty minutes, thereby delaying the opening game at the Yankee Stadium, more than 20,000 fans, not at all concerned with problems of political expediency, booed them quite roundly.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 22 unless. specified: Babbitt, at Guantanamo Bay. Bushnell, at Survey Area. Chaumont, at San Diego. Charleston, Charleston to Guantanamo Bay, April 21.

In response to a direct appeal to President Roosevelt, an investigation was ordered tonight into Pennsylvania's bitter Democratic primary, specifically into charges that. Senator Joseph F. Guffey is "coercing" WPA workers in this State.

By a decree published today in the Official Journal, France made operative the international accord regulating the production and marketing of sugar signed in London on May 5, 1937. The accord still must be ratified by the French Chamber of Deputies and the Senate, but its provisions are effective immediately in view of the Cabinet's decree powers.

Miss Honour R. Dickerman and James Oliver Brown, whose mare rage will take place next month, were guests of honor at a dinner given last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria by Dickerman Hollister.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 16 amounted to 537,585 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 15,607 cars, or 3 per cent, more than for the preceding week, but 208,938 cars, or 28 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 105,072 cars, or 16.3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Plans to found two new children's museums, one in Greenwich Village and the other in the Kings Highway section of Brooklyn, were revealed yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Auxiliary of the Brooklyn Children's Museum in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Senator Copeland pledged his support today to efforts to restore to a War Department appropriation bill $3,250,000 cut from funds for deepening the New York State barge canal.
A banking group headed by Estabrook Co. obtained yesterday $2,600,000 of refunding, general improvement and school bonds of Hartford, Conn., on a bid of 101.618 for a fixed rate of 1 3/4s.

Mayor F. H. La Guardia of New York City donned cowboy boots and a ten-gallon hat here today, rode a white horse in a parade celebrating the forty-ninth anniversary of the opening of the Oklahoma Territory

Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes has contributed to the land and building fund of Barnard College for the purchase. of Riverside Quadrangle, a block at 120th Street and Riverside Drive bought last year by the college, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday at the executive meeting of the Fiftieth Anniversary Fund.

The Yankees got off to a false start yesterday as they opened the 1938 season at the Stadium, were recalled, righted themselves and then jammed through an inaugural that was the epitome of perfection.

Emotional and mental activities of everyday life play an important role in physical disease, and in extreme cases may actually induce changes in the structure of the human body, according to six of the nation's neurologists and psychiatrists who yesterday took part in a symposium on neuropsychiatry at the Academy of Medicine.

Graduation exercises at the United States Military Academy will be held on June 14. The tentative program for June Week includes daily full dress parades, an athletic review, an equitation demonstration in the Riding Hall, alumni exercises and the distribution of diplomas.

No photographs may be taken in a courtroom during sessions of the court or during recesses between sessions, and court proceedings may not be broadcast, the Appellate Division ordered yesterday in a "special rule" on the "improper publicizing of court proceedings."
Mayor La Guardia is now a member of two of the fightingest Indian tribes in our history. Yesterday at Guthrie, Okla., he was adopted by the Cheyennes and the Arapahoes.

In a careful historical argument before the annual meeting of the Amerlean Association of Collegiate Schools of Business today, which brought together educators and business men in an exchange of friendly criticisms, Dean C. E.

The Interstate Commerce Commission closed its hearings today on the reorganization proceedings for the Chicago North Western Railroad after refusing to consider exhibits dealing with a proposed consolidation of the North Western with the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific.

After announcing that it would close after tonight's performance, "A Doll's House" decided yesterday to continue at the Broadhurst for another week. That leaves as tonight's only closing "Brother Rat," which will end 575 performances and on Monday will go over to Brooklyn for a visit.

Featuring an elevated highway more than half a mile long, to be known as the "road of tomorrow," and modern in architectural conception to symbolize the advances America may expect in transportation, details of the Ford Motor Company's building for the New York World's Fair of 1939 were revealed yesterday.

The choice of the patriarch of the Gaelic revival movement to be the first President of Ireland has a fitness both symbolic and real. It is symbolic because if Eamon de Valera is right in believing that you can't have a nation without a national language--though the Irish seem to have done pretty well
The State Banking Department's weekly bulletin announced today that Twentieth Century Fox Employes Credit Union, 444 West Fifty-sixth Street, New York, had received an authorization certificate.

The Legislature adjourned today after killing Governor Quinn's income tax plan, a series of constitutional amendments backed by the Democratic administration, and bills which would have allowed the voters to pass on the question of continued horse-race betting this Fall.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 21: COLONELS Commiskey, A. F., Cav., three months and ten days' leave, April 21. FitzGerald, S. W. (Lt. Col.) (Air Corp), General Staff Corps, one day leave, April 23.

The annual luncheon of women or all Protestant denominations active in missionary work will be held on May 3 at the Hotel Commodore. The principal speaker will be Dr. Mildred Allen McAfee, president of Wellesley College. This will be her first address in New York since her inauguration.

Eighteen persons were injured, five of them firemen, at 4 P. M. yesterday when Hook and Ladder Truck 149, going north on Seventh Avenue, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, collided with an eastbound Bay Ridge Avenue street car filled with passengers.

The mystery surrounding the disappearance from Vienna of Baron von Ketteler, Colonel Franz von Papen's confidential aide and secretary since the latter's appointment as Chancellor Hitler's special envoy to Vienna, has not yet been cleared up.

The Levine kidnapping case was believed to be establishing a record for the arrest of ransom chiselerss" as an eighth man was held in Chicago yesterday for an alleged attempt to obtain a $30,000 ransom from Murray Levine, father of 12-year-old Peter, who vanished in lew Rochelle on Feb. 24.

Suspension of social security payments to release a billion and a half dollars immediately through private channels for re-employment was urged here tonight by Colonel Frank Knox in an address attacking President Roosevelt's new recovery program.

Playing before a record Detroit crowd of 54,500, the Detroit Tigers lost their opening home game of the American League season to the Cleveland Indians, 4 to 3, today. Mel Harder went the route for the Indians, allowing eight hits.

Although there is comparatively little in the way of new corporate bond financing on the horizon, the apparent re-entrance of commercial banks as an important factor in the distribution of new securities has strengthened the hopes of investment bankers materially

West Broadway, 241-243, 37.7 1/2xl00.1 Irreg; Wusner Mfg Co to Billings Estate Corp, 274 Madison Ave ($1). 128th St, 34 W, 25x100; 1/2 interest, Paul Tsagos to Georgianna Coke, 34 W 128th St, deed dated last Sept. 21. 133d St, 220 W, 16.8x100; Viola and Joseph L. Rogers to Albert Boris Leasing Corp. 1,819 Broadway, care I. I. Steinman, mortgagee ($1).

Evidence was introduced yesterday before the Securities and Exchange Commission that George Whitney, a partner in J. P. Morgan Co., had been notified formally that his $1,175,000 loan at 2 per cent on Jan. 8, 1937, to Richard Whitney was "to be used as capital of Richard Whitney Co."

Miss Norma Duke Sherow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alonzo B. Sherow of Mahwah, N. T., was married here today to Thomas B. Kennedy, son of Mrs. Norman S. White of Short Hills, N. J. The ceremony was performed at Christ Episcopal Church here by the rector, the Rev. Charles P. Bispham. A small reception followed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden B. Hewitt at Mahway.

Winning his adjourned game from Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, unfinished in the fifteenth round, Samuel Reshevsky, national titleholder, regained undisputed possession of the lead in the biennial tournament of the National Chess Federation at the Marshall Chess Club last night. The game lasted 53 moves.

WITH a cigar wedged firmly between his teeth, Clark Calvin Griffith, the silverhaired owner of the Senators, gazed out of a hotel window about noon yesterday and remarked cheerfully: "Well, it's clearing up. That's fine. I was afraid I was-going to miss the funeral."

Designs submitted in a national "Drive. Safely" poster contest will go on exhibition in the seventh floor galleries of La Maison Frangaise in Rockefeller Center on May 11, the Devoe Raynolds Company, sponsors of the contest, announced yesterday. Open to all artists, professional or amateur, the competition closes on April 29.
Governor Philip F. La Follette issued a call tonight for a meeting of "liberals" in Madison next Thursday night which may be The forerunner of a national third party.

Discovery, by means of improved solar photography, of three new distinct forms of startling celestial fireworks on the surface of the sun, one of them shooting up sprays of flaming hydrogen atoms to heights of 150,000 miles,

A verdict of $116,000 was returned yesterday by a Supreme Court jury in favor of James C. Van Siclen and C. Walter Randall, former reorganization trustees of the Bush Terminal Company, against Irving T. Bush, president of the company.

The American Society of Newspaper Editors voted unanimously today to "carry on a constant campaign" for popular support for a free press. "Unfortunately, all citizens do not think through the meaning of a free press," said a restatement of the society's aims and ideals, adopted at its annual convention.

Judging from advance repercussions in the German press, the party congress of Konrad Henlein's Sudeten Germans opening in Carslbad, Czechoslovakia, tomorrow is likely to prove the beginning of a final showdown between German and Czechoslovak ideas regarding the solution of the Sudeten problem that may well involve the fate of Czechoslovakia herself.
Spanish Government troops, separated from their comrades by the Insurgent drive to the Mediterranean, surrendered today to Generalissimo Francisco Franco's forces on sea and land.

For the fourth year in a row Miss Helene Mayer, former Olympic champion, won the women's national fencing championship at the Fencers Club last night. Miss Mayer was victorious in all her matches although she had a close call in the one with Miss Dorothy Locke, titleholder in 1932 and 1933.

Because of repeated protests that city public works contracts, under the rules adopted by the Board of Estimate in January, afford no protection to subcontractors, material and supply men, a survey of the situation is being conducted by' William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigations, it was disclosed yesterday.

Prince Bernhard of The Netherlands returned home today from a month's vacation that had given rise to reports of a rift in the royal family. The Prince, husband of Crown Princess Juliana, drove up to the royal palace in a new Italian automobile purchased at Cannes, France.

Mrs. Julian S. L. Humphrys gave a luncheon yesterday at the SavoyPlaza for chairmen of the committees for the American Merchant Marine Library Association's book drives, which will open here on May 19.
Samuel J. Bond, an employee of the New York Telephone Company for the last nineteen years, died Wednesday at his home, 182 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, in his fifty-second year.

With retailers' inventories cut by last-minute Easter demands, wholesale volume this week was expanded by replacement orders and the decline from a year ago was reduced to 8 to 22 per cent, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

Two stockholders of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company, known as Mokan, brought suit yesterday in Supreme Court to compel the officers and directors of the company to allow its stockholders to take up rights held by Mokan to subscribe to 80,000 shares of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company's stock at $25 a share.

A six - story elevator apartment house will be erected in Flatbush where a site in East Fourteenth Street, between Avenues O and P, was purchased by a Brooklyn builder. The property consists of a plot 160 by 100 feet improved with four one-family dwellings known as 1,555, 1,561, 1,565 and 1,571 East Fourteenth Street.

H. H. Doehler, chairman of the board of the Doehler Die Casting Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that sales in the first quarter of this year were $1,652,928, compared with $3,301,331 in the similar period of 1937.
Seven candidates for queen of the Ulster County Apple Blossom Festival to be held in Kingston on May 6, 7 and 8 called on Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair Corporation,
Twenty-five days hence the new governing board of the New York Stock Exchange will face the task of selecting a paid president.

William M. Lawson has sold to Mrs. Rea Lembke a tract of more than two acres on Cornwell's Beach Road, Sands Point, L. I., for improvement with an all-year residence. Henry R. Tibbitts, Inc., was the broker.

Mr. and Mrs. Wright Barclay will entertain with a buffet supper tomorrow night at their home 1,165 Park Avenue. Dr. Gilbert H. Grosvenor, president of National Geographic Society, and Mrs. Grosvenor of Washington are at the Waldorf-Astoria.
H. F. Broadbent, Australian aviator, today clipped 13 hours and 54 minutes of the Australia to England solo flight record estab-, lished by Jean Batten, New Zealand woman flier.

The Very Rev. Jose Maria de Jesus Isasi, Provincial of Catalonia, Spain, for the Discalsed Carmelite Order, will by special invitation of the Rev. John E. Burke, the pastor, preach tomorrow evening and the following two Sunday evenings in the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, "mother" parish of the Paulist Fathers, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

The twenty-one story Crystal Building, on the southwest corner of Second Avenue and Forty-third Street, was bid in yesterday at auction in the Vesey Street salesrooms by the New York Trust Company, plaintiff, as trustee, for $1,000.

The board of directors of The Associated Press yesterday presented a life annuity for herself and her 5-year-old son to Mrs. Helen Nolan Neil, widow of War Correspondent Edward J. Neil Jr., who died of wounds suffered last New Year's Eve while covering the Insurgent offensive in Spain.

Fixed indebtedness of the RadioKeith-Orpheum Corporation and subsidiaries, which was reduced $4,216,356 between July 1, 1934, and the end of 1936, was further lowered to the extent of $2,232,010 in 1937, according to the sixth report of the Irving Trust Company, trustee in the company's reorganization proceedings.

The Rev. Adrien Gabriel Morice, author of about thirty books on the history of Western Canada, died in a hospital here yesterday at the age of 79. The noted missionary, anthropologist, historian, musician, explorer and publisher was stricken with apoplexy Tuesday night.
Attorneys for Horace E. Dodge disclosed today that he had filed suit for divorce from Muriel Sisman Dodge, to whom he was married in London in 1928.

The British freighter City of Salisbury lay tonight on The Graves, shoals at the eastern entrance to the harbor, having grounded earlier today as the climax of a jonah voyage from Calcutta, marked by cannibalism in her deckload of snakes and escapes by a bear and twenty-five monkeys included in the cargo.

Cotton-mill activity declined more than seasonally last week and the index dropped to 87.7 from 90.6. It was 135.5 for the week ended April 17, 1937. Sales of gray goods, although in smaller volume than in the previous two weeks, were estimated at about 100 per cent of the curtailed
The Utilities Investing Trust, Boston, has filed an application under the Holding Company Act for an order by the SEC exempting it and its subsidiaries from the act.

A. G. Knebel, widely known Y. M. C. A. executive, died today of heart disease at the age of 63. General secretary of the Y. M. C. A. here, he formerly served as head of the Y. M. C. A. Eastern region, with offices in New York.

The Treasury's announcement last Monday that "the inactive gold account has been discontinued" obviously meant that imported gold, which had been bought by the Government with borrowed money since Dec. 21, 1936, would be returned to the money market.

About 300 teachers and students of public speaking heard an attack yesterday on those teachers in all fields of education "whose concept of their function appears to be that of training students to have a superior predatory advantage in society."

St. Michael's Greek Orthodox Church, loft in 327 W 43d St; Walter Samuels, Inc, brokers. Zip-O-Hat Co. children's headwear, In 1,214-16 Broadway; Lesner Brothers, furs, in 214-18 W 28th St; Alex Coopehik, furs, in 134-40 W 29th St; M. L. Hess, Inc, brokers.

The Pirates warmed the spirits of 20,500 opening-day fans today by beating Cincinnati, 7 to 4, for their fourth straight National League triumph and their nineteenth in a row over the Reds at Forbes Field.

Melvin Gibbon, 27 years old, of New York was detained for further examination by Japanese authorities today after being released earlier when questioned about his suspected connections with China's "Flying Foreign Legion."

A strong possibility that President Roosevelt would defer until June 30 enforcement of the rule limiting total expenditures on WPA white-collar projects to $1,000 a year for each employe was indicated in WPA circles here yesterday.

Following the arrest here and in Pittsburgh last night of George (Bugs) Moran, prohibition gang leader, and eight others, raiding squads from the State's Attorney's office today sought a printing shop which had turned out hundreds of thousands

Building projects for which plans were filed yesterday include a ninestory hospital costing $2,750,000 for the Department of Hospitals in Brooklyn and an alteration to cost $120,000 in East Seventy-second Street, Manhattan.

The United States liner President Roosevelt, arriving today from Germany and way ports, has on board Myrtle Leonard, Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip, Commander Theodore E. Chandler, assistant naval attache at the United States Embassy in Paris; H. I. Babes, press attache of the Rumanian Legation in Washington, accompanied by Mrs. Babes; and Dr. H.E. Hasseltind of the United States Public Health Service, accompanied by his wife.
Exports of tobacco and tobacco products from the United States increased materially in the first three months this year, the Deapartment of Commerce announced today.
Williar M. Hargrave, 32, of New York City, fell to his death today from the window of his eleventh-floor hotel room to a second-floor court.
The annual directors' meeting of the S. S. Kresge Company was held at the office of the company today and the following officers elected:

Senator Borah's proposal for enforcing the anti-trust laws through Federal licensing of corporations assumed new importance tonight in the light of a statement by President Roosevelt that he and Mr. Borah were in substantial agreement on the monopoly issue.

The Senate and House conferees on the $5,300,000;000 Revenue Revision Bill agreed today on a compromise by which the undistributed profits tax will be retained in modified form and the present system of taxing long-term capital gains as ordinary income abolished.

State Senator John J. McNaboe, speaking yesterday at a testimonial luncheon given in his honor by some 100 members of the American Patriots at the Hotel Iroquois, 49 West Forty-fourth Street, referred to Supreme Court Justice W. Charles Poletti; American Labor party spokesman at the Constitutional Convention, as "Communistic Charlie."
The Daughters of the American Revolution, as their congress continued today, were warned that "eternal vigilance still remains the price of liberty." In a series of addresses

The Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., has launched its first advertising campaign through its new agency, J. Stirling Getchell, Inc., in newspapers of major cities throughout the country, it was announced yesterday.

A new figure was brought yesterday into Attorney General Bennett's investigation of Burco, Inc., an investment trust suspended from the Curb Exchange on last Tuesday, when Howard Hansell, a securities broker of 2 Rector Street, was sought for questioning.

Ernest Hemingway's play about the Spanish civil war, "The Fifth Column," has been bought by Joseph Losey, who will produce it some time before Oct. 15. At that time Scribner will publish the play in book form.

The Mortgage Commission and Title Guarantee and Trust Co assigned to Clinton Trust Co, as trustee for certificate holders, a mortgage for $30,000 on 181 1st Ave. A mortgage for $262,000 on 121-125 E 60th St, held by Metropolitan Life Insurance Co from Professional Offices, Inc, Robert H. Halsey, president, was extended to March 1, 1943, 4 1/2 per cent.

Directors of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of $1.50 on the 6 per cent first preferred stock and a dividend of $1.75 a share against arrears on the 7 per cent second preferred stock. Both are payable on June 1 to stock of record of May 13.

The New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company announced yesterday the withdrawal of the steamship Oriente from its service between New York and Havana and an indefinite lay-up for the Yucatan, which has been in the line's Mexico service.

Trading in round lots by members of the New York Stock Exchange for their own account in the week ended on March 26 fell off to only 14.50 per cent of the total volume, the lowest percentage since the Securities and Exchange Commission

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mr. Kaempffert and Miss Perkins have recently presented in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine the social problem which industry has created by its discrimination against employes in the older age brackets.

Dr. Charles J. Pick, one of the first New York physicians to specialize in the administering of anesthetics, died yesterday at his residence, 47 East Eighty-eighth Street, after a year's illness, at the age of 63.

Village Boy Pegasus, a white and liver pointer dog, owned by L. F. Sampson of Swampscott, Mass., and handled by A. C. Biggi, today was named the winner of the Open Junior All-Age Stake. It was the leading number of the initial card of the eleventh annual Spring meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club.

Enactment of a wages and hours bill providing for adjustment of standards over a three-year period was urged upon Congress today by the House Committee on Labor as an essential move -toward business recovery and a means of decreasing relief payments.

Benjamin F. Judd, a Civil War veteran, who often recounted witnessing the assassination of President Lincoln and the surrender of General Robert E. Lee, died today at 43 New Street, where he made his home with Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Howard. He would have been 104 years old May 24.

Arthur de Souza Costa, Minister of Finance, announced today that Brazil is not considering any modifiction of its present exchange policy. Elucidating press reports released here concerning a statement by Mario de Pimentel Brandao, Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, made in landing at Miami, and quoting him as saying that Brazil would grant exchange

Paced by a record crowd of 54,500 at Detroit's remodeled Briggs Stadium, the second half of baseball's opening-day program drew a total of 151,798 fans to six games yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

J. W. Y. Martin's Battle Jack annexed the Pagebrook Purse, today's feature race, but he lost prestige as a Preakness candidate. The son of John P. Grier had to be given a "million dollar" ride by Sonny Workman to eke out a neck decision over Bar Fly, E. R. Bradley representative.

Turpentine firm, 23 1/4c; sales, 57 barrels; receipts, 292 barrels; shipments, 50 barrels; stock, 30,694 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 175: receipts, 1,644: shipments, 10; stock. 77,866. Quote: B. $3.45; D, $3.70; E, $3.75; F. $4.55; G, H, I. K, $4.75; M, $4.80; N. $5.10-.20; WG, $6.05; WW, X, $6.40.

Following a plea by counsel for Albert J. Marinelli, former County Clerk of New York County, that Marinelli is too ill to appear in court to answer an indictment charging him with harboring Charles Falci while the latter was a fugitive from justice,

Livestock trade both in cattle and hogs was dull today and prices on the latter were weak to lower, according to the United States Department of Agriculture, and bearishness was still the keynote in both branches of the trade in so far as the attitude of buyers was concerned. Lambs, however, strengthened, this improvement being due in a large measure to expanded shipping demand.

To Henry Ford was awarded today the James Watt International Medal by the Council of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers. This award, established in 1936 on the centenary of Watt's birth is made biennially for outstanding achievements in the field of mechanical engineering.

A record entry of 954 athletes representing sixty-four high and prep schools will compete in the thirtieth New York University interscholastic track and field meet at Ohio Field today. Twelve individual and four relay tests have been carded. In addition, there will be a one-mile relay race for metropolitan colleges.

Mrs. Lena McIntire David, society editor of The Miami Daily News and sister o, Dr. Ross T. McIntire, President Roosevelt's physician, died today at the age of 53. She had undergone an emergency operation for a stomach ailment two days ago.

TRANSFERS IN THE BRONX Westchester Ave (15-4164), s w cor of Buhre Ave, 99x120; Allerad Realty Corp to Margaret M. Murray, 333 E 176th St; mtg $75,000. 176th St (11-2861), s w cor of Jerome Ave, 103x138: S W Jerome Avenue and 176th Street Corp to Northpel Realty Corp. 391 E 149th St.

Bequests exceeding 1,000,000 are contained in the will of Wistar Wallace Braxton, who died April 9. The bulk of the estate consists of securities which Mr. Braxton accumulated during his service as an executive of the British-American Tobacco Company. Cash bequests included $100.000 each to four sisters.

A terrific explosion in the Red Jacket Coal Company mine eight miles east of this village just as the night shift was going on duty late yesterday afternoon killed at least eight men and trapped an estimated fifty.
Somewhere between the White House and the Department of Agriculture,-about a mile away, a sheaf of important papers has been lost, with the result that President Roosevelt cannot for some time

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Clara Bissell, daughter of Mrs. Eugene Bissell of this place and the Jate Mr. Bissell, to Willard Roper, son of Mrs. Charles H. Roper of Belmont and the late Mr. Roper, was announced today at a luncheon given by her mother at -the Brae Burn Country Club, West Newton.

The recodification of the fish and game laws, with many important changes, is now an actuality, and the hunters and anglers of New York State have reason to be happy at the simplified laws which are the outgrowth of this measure.

With inquiries coming from all sections of the country concerning modifications which it proposes to try out to facilitate and make less expensive the registration of issues of securities under the Securities Act of 1933

Tommy Forte of Philadelphia tonight scored a technical knockout over Izzy Caplin of Baltimore.- Dr. W. B. G. Terry refused to let Caplin come- out for the eighth round because, he said, one of Caplin's teeth was knocked out.

Sixteenth annual convention of the New York State Title Association, Roosevelt Hotel, 10 A. M. Luncheon 12:30 P. M. Address by Louis H. Pink. Meeting of the Albany Club of New York, State Office Building, 80 Centre Street, 12:15 P. M. "Must We Have Depressions?" Dr. Ralph B. Wynn.

K. R. Burke, general superintendent of the tar and chemical division of the Koppers Company, has been elected a vice president of the company. The Chase National Bank has invited tenders for the sale to it of Central States Edison, Inc.,

Columbia had to use three pitchers to halt Penn in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game at Baker Field yesterday, the trio. allowing only three hits as the Lions triumphed, 4 to 2, in a tense battle. The Quakers had the bases filled and only one out in the ninth but could not move a man over the plate.

A party of more than 200 wine dealers sailed on the Italian liner Roma yesterday for a visit to the wine districts of Italy, Sicily and Tripoli. The entire tour, which will be-joined in Boston today by fifty New England dealers, will take thirty-one days.
Nedayr, considered by Willis Sharpe Kilmer his best 3-year-old hope in many years, heads the field of eight named for the Stuyvesant Handicap, which will feature the racing at Jamaica this afternoon.

Shortly before the Star class owners sat down last night to their annual Spring dinner in the Building Trades Club, 2 Park Avenue, the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association, through George W. Elder, president, and Sampson Smith, international secretary, issued the racing number 1,650.

The recent expulsion of Austrian Jews from Burgenland is reported to have been carried out on orders from the Berlin Gestapo [secret police]. It appears the order was issued that. all Jews be expelled from a thirty-mile zone along the border between Czechoslovakia and the Austrian province of Burgenland and already 400 have been deported.

Reductions of $5 a ton in bag kraft were made yesterday by several leading paper manufacturers, and the selling basis on wrapping paper kraft was changed by elimination of the functional discount. The cut was the fourth in various types of paper in the last two weeks.

Ellis A. Gimbel Jr., executive head of Gimbel Brothers, New York store, yesterday announced the following promotions: Walter Haims, buyer of hosiery, will also buy knit and rayon underwear; Rose Finkel, buyer of girls' wear, will also buy infants' wear; Mrs. Catherine Lincoln, formerly buyer of sportswear, blouses and skirts,

A continuance of the demand for properties in Harlem was indicated yesterday in sales of houses in that section. Dr. Harold A. Collins bought from the Title Guarantee and Trust Company the five-storyapartment house on a lot 25 by 99.11 feet at 223 West 135th Street.

The Broadway Association, in conjunction with the Department of Sanitation, is conducting an intensive Spring clean-up drive against litter. This week, representatives of the two agencies are making daily surveys on Broadway from Thirty-fourth to 125th Street, ing merchants to cooperate.

By winning her adjourned game with Miss Elizabeth Wray from the ninth round of the tournament for the women's championship. of the National Chess Federation and the Hazel Allen Trophy at the Marshall Chess Club last night,

Daylight Saving Time Department clocks shall be advanced one hour on April'24. At 1:59 A. M., April 24, one round of test signal will be transmitted on the primary alarm circuits, as a preliminary warning, followed by one round on the escondary alarm circuits. Upon receipt of the first tap on the secondary alarm circuits, clocks shall be advanced exactly one hour, from 2 A. M. to 3 A. M.

Four thugs invaded the office of Charles Weiss, 31 years old, editor of an anti-Nazi magazine, Uncle Sam, on the third floor of 130 Flatbush Avenue, near Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, shortly before 8:30 o'clock last night.

Temporary Assignment PATROLMAN--Names A. Sheridan, from 19th Precinct to office of the bookkeeper, assigned to clerical duty, for 15 days, from 8 A. M., May 1. Leaves Without Pay CAPTAIN-Daniel McGlinchy, Traffic P, for 6 days, from 8 A. M., Aug. 27.

A wild shuffling of the leaders resulted from the third race of the six-meter series for the Prince of Wales Trophy today, when Ray Hunt of Marblehead, Mass., sailed his chartered yacht Indian Scout flawlessly to take first place.

Vice President Garner broke silence today on the reported differences between himself and President Roosevelt over government policies. Speaking at a luncheon given by Mayor Burnett Maybank in observance of Charleston's annual azalea festival,

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and wholly owned subsidiaries, in the quarterly statement for the period ended on March 31, reported yesterday net income of $9,060,602, subject to year-end adjustments, after depreciation, obsolescence,

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Helene Pagenstecher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albrecht Pagenstecher of this city and Huntington, L. I., to Charles Augustus Frank Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank, also of New York, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.
Florendale Beau's Nan, a white and orange English setter bitch, annexed the third annual junior allage stake today in the field trials being sponsored by the English setter association near here.

Miss Doris Bothwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Ewing Both well of this place, was married this afternoon to Henry Evans Heydt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Heydt of this place and Westport, Conn., in Christ Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Harold F. Hohly, the rector, performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Bronxville Women's Club.
One hundred years ago today the steamship Sirius, a 178-foot Britishowned vessel, steamed up the bay to the Battery, the first passenger steamship to arrive in New York from the British Isles.

Refinancing for five years of the $30,000 first mortgage on the one-story taxpayer at 31-79 Steinway St. Long Island- City, has been arranged by Wm. A. Krahe Son, Inc.. broker. with a private investor.

Pleas of not guilty were entered yesterday by Miss Julia Cullen, kindergarten teacher in Public Schools 36 and 147, Brooklyn, and James H. White, teacher of health education in the Theodore Roosevelt High School, before a trial committee of the Board of Education on charges of "conduct unbecoming a teacher."

Miss Elizabeth Claire Rowe, daughter of Mrs. E. Eddy Rowe of New York and of Samuel Davis Rowe of Barrington, Ill., was married this afternoon to James Edward Hosac, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wirt-Edward Hosac of Bronxville, N. Y., at Graymar, the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Graham B. Grosvenor.
Paul V. McNutt, United States High Commissioner to the Philippines, today denied reports he would resign and return to the United States before Oct. 1.

The Estonian Republic this weekend will open a new chapter in its political life designed to reintroduce constitutional government along democratic lines after a long interval of a semi-dictatorial regime.

Low Sunday, as the first Sunday after Easter is known in .the ritualistic calendar, will be observed tomorrow in the churches which follow the Gregorian calendar, while Easter .itself will be celebrated in Eastern orthodox churches, which follow the Julian calendar.

CURTIS MARY (April 7, 1937) Gross assets, $48,797; net, $45,623. To Marie R., Lyons and Susan T. Lyons, nieces, $28,042 each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $26,391. Susan T. Lyons, attorney, 16 E. 96th St.

The stock market advanced briskly yesterday, with leading issues up 1 to 3 points in the second largest turnover of the month thus far. The volume on the Stock Exchange was 1,116,000 shares, compared with 595,000 on Thursday; the record total for April

Fire of unknown origin destroyed three of six four-stozy buildings of the old North Mianus Woolen Mills this afternoon, the-damage being estimated at $75,000. Machinery, tools and dyes were also ruined.
Farmers received $572,000,000 in March from the sale of agricultural products and from government benefit payments, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated today. In March, 1937,

The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners authorized here today the discontinuance of twenty-six trains on the Central Railroad of New Jersey and fifteen trains on the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad, a subsidiary of the Erie Railroad.
The game of golf has produced many brilliant putters, but today Tommy Barnes of Georgia Tech was "king of-the greens."

In a seven-page letter sharply replying to the recent charge of Senator John J. McNaboe that the psychiatric division of Bellevue Hospital was a "cesspool of inefficiency," S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, asserted yesterday that an investigation "impartially made" would show the division to be "a credit to the City of New York."

The Volksblatt of Graz several days ago printed an article that is only now attracting attention here. It is alleged that, among 300 foreign correspondents in Vienna before Anschluss, only twenty "had clean hands," all others being in the pay of the Schuschnigg regime.

The French franc had a severe sinking spell in the foreign exchange market yesterday as rumors of plans to reduce its value and of other developments unfavorable to the French situation were circulated in financial quarters.

The New York area lacks 44 per cent of the three-inch anti-aircraft guns necessary for its proper defense, and not a single anti-aircraft regiment in the country has its "full quota of weapons," Louis Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, declared last night.

Bells tolling the beginning of the Puritan Sabbath at sundown, 6:39 o'clock, tonight in all the towns of the original New Haven Colony. including Milford, Branford, Guilford and New Haven, and also Southold, L. I., marked the beginning of a six weeks' tercentenary celebration of the landing of the pioneers here April 25, 1538.

Philip H. Gladstone, former vice president of J. D. Konover, Inc., and Lewis E. Raines, former partner of the Triboro Painting Company, have organized GladstoneRaines, Inc., with offices at 204 East Forty-first Street. They will specialize in interior decorating and painting.

Trading showed some improvement yesterday, although most salesmen reported business considerably below normal for a Friday. Except for a few steer and fresh pork cuts which were lower, the markets showed little change from Thursday. On account of the Jewish holiday there was practically no slaughter of those classes generally dressed kosher. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture. follow:

The "naval frontier" proposed by Senator Bone was attacked today by Secretary Swanson in a letter to the Washington member which declared that adoption of such a policy for peace time would hamper efficient operation of the navy in time of war.

The opening of churches as meeting places for organizations now allegedly barred from other meeting places in Jersey City is commended in the annual report of the Social Service Commission of the Newark Conference, Methodist Episcopal Church.

Today, the second Saturday of the new college rowing season, brings with it the second regatta on the Harlem River, where the eights of the United States Naval Academy and Columbia will go over the oneand-three-quarter-mile course along the Speedway wall in a three-race event.

While the Yankees were downing the Senators in their home opening yesterday, Joe DiMaggio, Colonel Jake Ruppert's spectacular outfielder, was speeding to this city. DiMaggio is scheduled to arrive this morning at 7:30 o'clock at Penn Station, completing a crosscountry trip started last Wednesday when he formally notified the club he would accept a contract for $25.000.

Charles Whitcombe, captain of the British Ryder Cup team, won a $5,000 open golf tournament at the Moor Park Club today with a 72-hole score of 276. finished two strokes ahead of his 24-year-old nephew, Eddie Whitcombe, and Alf Perry, former British open champion.

Continued rains over a large area of the Cotton Belt have caused further delay in planting, and prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced 10 points at one time yesterday and ended with net gains of 2 to 6 points.
The resignations of John E. Zimmermann and Edward Hopkinson Jr. from the board of directors of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey was announced yesterday.

TAXES AND RECOVERY Among the numerous proposals of a Senate Committee on Unemployit and Relief the most significant ?? the recommendation for adopting Senate Tax Bill repealing the undisuted-profits tax and drastically difying the capital-gains tax.

A vigorous advance by domestic corporation bonds in their heaviest turnover of the year to date shared the limelight with a continued adverse in United States Government obligations in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Butterfly Ball, one of New York's most popular Springtime fetes, took place last night in the main ballroom and Oval Restaurant of the Ritz-Carlton. It was again given as a dinner dance, the committee having decided a few years ago to hold the ball earlier in the evening.

Toolin Co., a New York Stock Exchange firm, proposes to dissolve on May 14. Waller Cecil Hardy retired from Winthrop, Mitchell Co. on April 15, when the estate of Woodward Babcock, a general partner, became a limited partner.

President Roosevelt conceded today that although the Neutrality Act was intended to prevent American discrimination or partiality toward foreign combatants, the United States cannot always be sure that arms and munitions shipments. to third powers may not be destined -for a faction or nation engaged in civil or international war..

The Distinguished Flying Cross was awarded today to Lieut. Col. Robert Olds for his achievement in commanding the flight of six Army Air Corps "flying fortresses" from Langley Field to Buenos Aires and return from Feb. 15 to 27.

Sentences to die in the electric chair in the week beginning May 30 were imposed by General Sessions Judge Nott yesterday on five youths who had been convicted by a jury eight days before of first-degree murder in the shooting of Detective Michael J. Foley of the Fifth Street station.

Dr. Henry Goddard Leach, former president of the Scandinavian American Society, was the recipient last night of the Order of St. Olaf following a dinner of the members of the society in the Hotel Plaza.

During the eighteenth-century wars Laurence Sterne traveled through the French countryside scarcely aware of the hostilities going on between France and Britain. There was no shortage of food or men. The peasants and the leisure class were little disturbed, save where armies passed.
Dick Siebert, Cardinal infielder, who is reported to be asking that he be ruled a free agent, has been granted an interview next Sunday with Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis.

Robert McKean Barry, member of a distinguished Maryland family and a descendant of the Earl of Barrymore and Dalhousie, died here yesterday. Mr. Barry, before entering the insurance business here, was assistant treasurer of the Metropolitan Street Railways of New York.

The Rev.-Robert M. Gibson, 51 years old, of New Brighton, S. I., was found dead this morning in a bathroom of the Imperial Hotel. Father Gibson arrived yesterdayand intended to return today. Among his personal effects was a physician's certificate showing he had been under treatment for cardiac trouble.

Preparations for a protracted state of hostilities in China as well as a scarcity due to military demands are evident in further economic restrictions just announced. The pressure is felt primarily on metals and other imports of military value such as rubber, hides and leather.
Deapartment store sales as reported by the Federal Reserve Board for the week ended on April 16 showed an increase of 8 per cent over the same week one year ago.

The Front Page Ball, the sixteenth annual party of the New York Newspaper Women's Club, was held in the Hotel Astor roof last night. Many celebrities from the literary, theatrical and motion picture fields attended.

Hundreds of athletes from twenty-one universities, thirty colleges and a dozen junior colleges converged on Lawrence tonight for the sixteenth Kansas relays tomorrow. Interest centered on the special mile race involving Glenn Cunningham, Archie San Romani, Don Lash and Gene Venzke, with a new world record considered a possibility and a new meet record a probability.

Dr. Robert A. Millikan (shown on the left in the picture), Nobel prize winner for scientific research, received the Ulster Irish Society Medal at the society's annual dinner at the Hotel Astor last night. The presentation was made by Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College.

About the first thing that the medical student hears in school is the oftquoted dictum that medicine is an art as well as a science. Indeed, some medicos are prouder of being artists than scientists. What we want in diagnosis and therapy is less art and more science.
Many Canadian industries have reduced production this Spring, but steel, mining and allied industries are active, the Bank of Montreal reports.

A fight for possession of the Dionne quintuplets and control of their fortune of $600,000 tonight found Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, country doctor who saved the babies' lives, nnnnsing Oliva Dionne, their father.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor today signed a two-year lease for the Chateau la Croe; Cap d'Antibes, at 16,000 annually. The rental includes the use of the twenty-carat gold bathtub in that part of the house reserved for the Duchess's apartments.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Anne Carrington, daughter of Mrs. Ellsworth Torrey Carrington and the late Mr. Carrington of this city, and Robert Hurtin Halsey Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Hurtin Halsey of New York, took place this afternoon in Trinity Cathedral here.

An investigation of alleged "ambulance chasing" and other unethical practices by attorneys in Westchester County has been ordered by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Departmeit, it was learned here today.

Achievement of good character through a broad public policy was urged upon industry today by W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the Union Pacific Railroad, in addressing the open session of the twenty-first annual convention of the American Association of Advertising Agencies here.

Nothing that the State Constitutional Convention can do can alter the fact that something more than half the population of the State resides in Greater New York, and that Greater New York has many problems and interests that do not closely concern the rest of the State.

Not as a prophet but rather as a hopeful designer President Conant of Harvard takes a peep in Harper's for May at "The Future of Our Higher Education." The swarms of students into colleges and universities will soon be checked.

COUNTRY LIVING: PLUS AND MINUS, by Charles Morrow Wilson. (Stephen Daye Press, $2.) A guide to the pleasures and pitfalls of living in the country. DAUGHTERS AND SONS, by I. Compton-Burnett. (Norton, $2.50.) A novel showing the relationships of three generations.

In her first concession to the screen, Maude Adams arrived today to discuss with David O. Selznick the possibility of a film career, the initial step of which will be as the wealthy dowager in Selznick International's "The Young in Heart," adapted from the I. A. R. Wylie story, "The Gay Banditti."

A homeless, unemployed man dived into the East River yesterday afternoon to rescue a 4-year-old boy from drowning, and the child's grateful parents, themselves in straitened circumstances, repaid him by offering the hospitality of their tenement flat until he can find employment.

A little more than a week after Great Britain and Italy ended their three years' quarrel, an agreement will be signed at 10 Downing Street next Monday afternoon calling off the still longer feud between Britain and Ireland.

The nation's architects have joined the widespread discussion of possible means of bringing home ownership within the grasp of more American families. They agree with the experts who believe that high costs are blocking building recovery.

Should Joe Louis fail to go through with his scheduled heavyweight title defense against Max Schmeling in June he will be stripped of the championship, the newly formed World Boxing Commission decided today.
Eli Gledhill, woolen goods designer and manufacturer, died in the Lawrence Hospital here yesterday of a heart ailment after an illness of a month. He was 71 years old and lived in Yonkers.

Alf M. Landon called upon "an articulate citizenry" today to make it clear to Congress that the "huge appropriation" proposed in President Roosevelt's new recovery program must be met by adequate tax provisions.
Weakness in wheat in Winnipeg today more than offset relative strength in Liverpool and the general upturn in other commodities and securities as a market influence on the Board of Trade here.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at her home in Redondo Beach, Calif., of Mrs. Adele P. Blauvelt, widow of William H. Blauvelt, former general manager of the Semet-Solvay Company of Syracuse, N.Y. She was born in Chestnut Hill, Pa., about seventy years ago.

The Soviet Union increased its exports of merchandise from $271,820,800 in 1936 to $347,726,800 in 1937, the Commerce Department announced today, while imports in the Union dropped slightly from $270,507,000 to $268,251,000.

The American Institute of Graphic Arts opened its exhibition of Fifty America. ?? with a preview last evening in the gallery of the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, where, beginning today, the work will be on public view through May 7.

Cleveland was selected for the next joint session of the National Open Hearth Steel Conference and the blast furnace and raw materials committee of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at their joint session here. L. F. Reinartz of Middletown, Ohio, was re-elected chairman.

Declaring that the small plant was the answer to considerable industrial difficulty, Henry Ford said today he was planning to open a small factory in South Sudbury to make a certain part for his automobiles.

Louis H. Egan, president of the Union Electric Company of Missouri, told the Missouri Association of Public Utilities yesterday that the industry does not want Federal loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Net asset value of the International Mining Corporation on March 31, last, was $6,117,410, equal to $11.69 each on the 523,273 shares of common stock outstanding in the hands of the public.

Estate, about 300. To Stephen J. Sabo, friend, executor, 508 E. 78th St. DODD, MAYNARD (April 10). Estate, more than $10,000. To Gilbert Dodd, brother, Craigowarr, Skelmorlie, Ayrshire, Scotland, fourteen thirty-seconds of residue Robert Dodd, brother.
The Interstate Commerce Commission suspended today, pending an investigation, proposed increases in West Shore ferry rates between Weehawken, N. J., and New York City.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 20: COMMANDER Harper, J., Med. Corps, Naval Hospital, Washington, D. C., to Naval Medical School, Washington, D. C.; orders Feb. 12 revoked.

Relatives of Andrew Carnegie Whitfield, who disappeared from Roosevelt Field in his plane on April 15 after a quarrel with his wife, yesterday called off the personal search they have made for him for a week and announced the belief that he "has gone off by himself."

Although lacking the services of Bill Winslow and Al Martin, who rank second and third, the Princeton varsity tennis team kept its record clean by blanking Cornell, 9--0, today. The Tigers have not been scored on and have dropped only three sets in three contests this season.

Dr. Richard M. Dingelstedt, physician, of 63 Sherman Place, this city, died early today of apoplexy in Christ Hospital. His age was 65. He was stricken in his office at 68 Hudson Street, Hoboken, late yesterday afternoon and was taken to the hospital.

The marketing of $60,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent ten-year debentures of Consolidated Edison Company of New York lifted the total of new bond financing this week to $76,048,500, the largest in more than six months, or since the period ended Oct. 8 last year, when $113,224,300 in new loans were offered. This compares with only $1,313,000 in bonds offered last week, but with a total of $96,682,000 marketed during this period last year.

IT was all because they would not raise their right hands. Since they are "Aryans" that symbolic gesture of submission would have saved them from losing various things-a pleasant house in Cologne, an excellent income, a commanding position, a career. Everything--except the integrity of their own beliefs.

The marriage of Miss Muriel Bache Richards to Francis Warren Pershing, only son of General John J. Pershing, Commander in Chief of the A. E. F. in the World War, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas Church.

Light snow has continued to fall during the past twenty-four hours, reducing the visibility and ceiling to zero. The temperature has risen from ten below zero to sixteen above with a light south wind.

A permanent exhibit of the History of the Recorded Word that may be visited by the public five days a week was formally opened yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES on the tenth floor of The Times Annex, 229 West Forty-third Street.

Miss Rosamund Hodges, a debutante of this season, was married yesterday afternoon in St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, to Stirling S. Adams of New York. The Rev. Dr. James A. Paul, associate rector, performed the ceremony in a floral setting of forsythia and other yellow Spring flowers.

James (Jeff) Burkitt, Mayor Frank Hague's long-time political foe, went on trial in First Criminal Court today on a charge of being disorderly person and just about dominated the proceedings with his unorthodox court conduct.

It became known in the Criminal Courts Building yesterday that the day before the New York County grand jury had dismissed a charge of suspicion of felonious assault against Peyton Murray, 30 years old, a Harvard University graduate,

With only the feminine role remaining unfilled, RKO today completed the cast of principals for "Gunga Din" with the acquisition of Victor McLaglen as the hard-boiled sergeant. Shooting will start early in the month with Sabu, the lad in "Elephant Boy," Cary Grant and Jack Oakie. Another RKO venture which will start Monday is "Care Free," with Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers.
Unemployment among non-agricultural workers, last month was 2,450,000 greater than in March, 1937, it was announced today by Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor.

Condemnation of the Neutrality Act, coupled with a call to Americans to boycott the goods of aggressor nations, particularly Japan, were among recommendations adopted last night by the united lay and ministerial session of the 139th annual New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, meeting at Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

The Rev. Dr. Edwin Field Frease, retired Methodist Episcopal missionary, who passed forty-four years abroad for his church, died yesterday at his home in Canton, Ohio, after a long illness, according to word received by the church's board of foreign missions here. He was 75 years old.

President Getulio Vargas made it clear today that Brazil is not a Fascist country. He declared that his recent decree forbidding foreign political propaganda in Brazil should dispel whatever doubts may exist abroad as to the character of the Brazilian regime.

Payment of taxes was pictured as an "alibi" for the "comparatively small" amounts contributed to philanthropies in the United States in a statement issued yesterday by Charles V. Vickrey, president of the Golden Rule Foundation.

Three persons were injured seriously at 8:30 A. M. today in an accident on Route 4 here, about a quarter of a mile from the George Washington Bridge, which involved a passenger bus, a truck and five automobiles.

Although the stock markets here were quiet today, the general tone was firm. Gilt-edge issues eased slightly, while in foreign loans German and Brazilian issues declined. Transatlantics were irregular, with United States Steel and International Nickel showing small advances.

Hereafter cautious men will pay cash for all the books they need. According to the authors of "Escape This Night," which reopened the Forty-fourth Street Theatre last evening, our revered Public Library is one of the most homicidal places in Gotham. The authors are Leona Heyert,

Liquidation in bankruptcy of the Prudence Company, Inc., for which many of the creditors. of that concern have been clamoring, was deferred and possibly avoided yesterday in two rulings by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Federal Court, Brooklyn.

The fresh dynamic forces of a "new orthodoxy" were urged today as a means of averting some form of fascism in the United States, at the annual convention of the Y. W. C. A.'s of the United States, opening here today.

Revised plans for the vast Queensbridge and Red Hook housing projects, incorporating new ideas in building layout and simplification of structural details, will bring the unit cost of these apartment communities well below the maximum expenditure a room permitted under the Wagner-Steagall act, and will permit rents much lower than originally contemplated, it was learned last night..
Anna Schramm, New York soprano, who made her local debut in a recital at Town Hall last night, disclosed a voice of rare natural beauty. There was, moreover, a secure grasp of style,

The production of alcoholic liquors, particularly of whisky, fell off matereally in the nine months ended March 31 as compared with the corresponding period in the previous year, the Treasury Department announced today. Withdrawals for sale also declined to a lesser degree in the same period.
John M. Landon, father of Alf M. Landon, suffered a heart attack today and was taken to Menorah Hospital, where he was placed in an oxvygen tent.
Dr. William J. Steele, physician, banker and educator, died late yesterday at his home, 55 Merrick Road, following a short illness of pneumonia. A He was 71 years old.

The Four Aces the defending champions, and- a Cavendish Club team led by Waldemar K. von Zedtwitz, last night won their way to the final round of the National Knockout Team of four contract bridge championships for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Trophy.

The Arkansas Natural Gas Company, Shreveport, La., a subsidiary of the Cities Service Company, has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

New York's Court of Appeals worked itself right out of a job today. After a two-week session-the shortest term in years-the seven Jurists of the State's highest tribunal found there were no more cases to be argued

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for April 15, issued today, shows that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation increased from 118.81 per cent on March 31 to 119.69 per cent on April 15.

To Sport Editor of The New York Times: I do not know if the following idea has ever before been suggested, but, if it hasn't, I am taking this opportunity to write to you, as I believe it has considerable merit. Baseball is our national game, yet few of its followers are thoroughly familiar with the rules.
Names of the designers and engravers of three new regular series postage stamps which are to go on sale in the next few weeks were given out today by the Postoffice Department.

William Wellington Atwood, veteran railroad man and former president of the B. M. T. Employes Benefit Association, died yesterday at his home, 461 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, in his eighty-sixth year.

Heavy Japanese reinforcements were rushed down- the Tientsin-Pukow Railway today in the second stage of the new Shantung offensive already launched at Lini, seventy miles to the east. The fresh troops, accompanied by tanks and artillery, arrived at Tenghsien, sixty miles north of Suchow, and started working their way southward and eastward

The prospect of a preliminary Italo-French agreement within a brief period of time was seen today after a half-hour conversation between Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano and Jules Blondel, French charge d'affaires.

Otis Skinner was elected president of the Episcopal Actors Guild at its annual meeting yesterday afternoon in the Hudson Theatre, 141 West Forty-fourth Street. He succeeds George Arliss, who had been president for fifteen years and who was elected an honorary president.

The three-story business building at 4,125 White Plains Road, northwest corner of East 230th Street, the Bronx, was sold by Miss Eliza R. Greenwood to an investing client of the Herman A. Acker Corporation, broker in the transaction.

Miss Stella A. Glass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Glass of this place, was married tonight to William A. Roos 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Roos of New York, in Christ's Episcopal Church, Lynbrook, by the Rev. John V. Cooper, the rector.

Collecting a total of fifteen hits, the Barnard School for Boys nine began its northern division, Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools, schedule yesterday by overpowering Lincoln School, 18--3, at Van Cortlandt Park.
Plans for a new medical library here to house what he regards as the greatest nucleus of medical incunabula and manuscript sources in the world were endorsed today by President Roosevelt.
The affairs of one of the leading British companies operating in Insurgent Spain was revealed tonight in the publication of the Rio Tinto Copper Company's report for 1937.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There is a better tone in the wool market. It is not especially broad nor especially intensive and prices have not responded particularly as yet, although there is a disposition on the part of holders of wool to ask more money for their stocks, and this has stopped some business which might have been done.

Revised plans for the vast Queensbridge and Red Hook housing projects, incorporating new ideas in building layout and simplification of structural details, will bring the unit cost of these apartment communities.well below the maximum expenditure a room permitted under the Wagner-Steagall act, and will permit rents much lower than originally contemplated, it was learned last night..
