Stocks advanced 1 to 3 points in second heaviest day's trading of the month; turnover, 1,116,200 shares. Bonds generally higher in largest turnover of month; domestic bonds strong and United States Government obligations higher; transactions, $9,748,625.

One of the gravest international incidents of the Chinese-Japanese war, the sinking of the United States gunboat Panay, was closed officially today when Japan gave the United States a check for $2.214,007.36.

A report by Medical Examiner Thomas Gonzales revealed yesterday that Charles and Henry Wagner, two of four heirs to a $7,500 house at 25-32 Twenty-first Street, Astoria, Queens, had been poisoned by arsenic, and that their sister, Elizabeth, who is also an heir,
Miss Junia Culbertson, daughter of the former Ambassador to Chile and Mrs. William Smith Culbertson, made her musical debut at a musicale given by her parents here today at the Mayflower.

The three-story business building at 4,125 White Plains Road, northwest corner of East 230th Street, the Bronx, was sold by Miss Eliza R. Greenwood to an investing client of the Herman A. Acker Corporation, broker in the transaction.
Names of the designers and engravers of three new regular series postage stamps which are to go on sale in the next few weeks were given out today by the Postoffice Department.

The existing demand for older one and two family houses can be greatly increased by employing the modern methods of merchandising, Thomas J. Clark of the Clark Realty Company told the members of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board at a meeting last week.

The Merritt Parkway grand jury, which is believed to have drafted secret indictments to be handed up to the Superior Court next week, was today nearing the end of its three months' investigation of the spending of $6,176,000 for the parkway right of way.

With competition in the Brooklyn, Manhattan-Richmond and BronxWestchester Divisions of the C. H. S. A. A. already under way, the annual city senior high Public Schools Athletic League championship baseball tournament will join the parade this week when the schedules of two of the four divisions in that loop will be begun.

A color scheme of rose and blue was carried out in the gowns of the bride and her attendants at the marriage of Miss Adelaide Duff Whittemore to Charles Sanford King 2d, which took place here this afternoon' in the Hitchcock Memorial Church.

The Grace Line announced yesterday that combination gravity fall and electric hoist lifeboat winches had been installed on six of its ships at a cost of about $50,000. The new equipment is designed to provide maximum safety and efficiency in the lowering of lifeboats, it was said.

Buttressed by huge iron ore deposits essential in the construction of armaments, China, after nine months of hostilities, stands on firm economic ground, while Japan has had to lean more and more on the United States, Great Britain, Holland and France for raw materials.

The Pirates gained a tighter hold atop the National League today by taking a 6-to-2 verdict from the Reds. It was the fifth consecutive victory in the current campaign for the Bucs. Johnny Rizzo, Pittsburgh rookie left-fielder, drove 450-foot triples to the center-field fence in the first and fifth innings.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gustav A. Schwenk of Scarsdale, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elsie Schwenk, to Walter A. Fullerton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fullerton of Saratoga Springs, N.. Y. The announcement was lade at a luncheon given today at the Norwich Inn.

On five New York State reservations, 171 young Indian men and women are preparing themselves to bring Indian culture to boys and girls in camps this Summer. Most of these students in the National Youth Administration course for Indian counselors are employed during the day on NYA projects,

In a wild and woolly ninth inning that saw a. total of eleven runs tallied, Harvard edged out Princeton, 14 to 13, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League -baseball game today that had the official scorers groggy and on the ropes at the finish.

Stocks eased slightly and closed moderately lower in slower trading; turnover, 410,950 shares. Corporate bonds higher with rails leading; United States Government issues a shade lower and quiet; transactions, $4,226,075.

Premier Edouard Daladier today, with the franc quoted at 166 to the pound sterling on the London market, found it necessary to issue an emphatic contradiction to rumors that have been circulating here and abroad during the last few days that there is dissension within the Cabinet over measures that must be taken to restore the financial situation.

The coldest region on earth is the Republic of Yakutsk in the remote stretches of Eastern Siberia. A temperature of 94 degrees below zero has been recorded. Yet even in the coldest months water gushes forth over the thick surface ice.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, announced yesterday the addition of twenty new courses in nine departments of the College of Liberal Arts and Science for the 1938-39 academic year. Nine single semester courses were expanded to a full year.

TORONTO.-Canadian children stand a better chance of reaching threescore years and ten than do American or English children of the same age, according to findings of the Dominion Bureau of Statistics at Ottawa.

The sharp turn in British foreign policy from one of collective security to the one of realistic negotiation which marked the accord with Italy inevitably is forcing the United States to a re-examination of its foreign-policy methods. The results will not be immediately apparent, there will be no haste, but gradually, it can be expected, there will be many modifications.

With all the strategy of a Hollywood screen idol, Joe DiMaggio came back to New York, the Yankees and baseball yesterday and jumped right into the limelight. The Coast ace, last of the major league hold-outs, arrived on schedule, but disappointed reporters and photographers assembled at Penn Station to greet him when he left the train at Newark.

Salvia, the Scarlet Sage, long a standby of the Summer garden, has been developing new colors that belie the name. Now we may plant purple flowering Salvia of the Splendens type, or pink or white ones. The most famous pink is Welwyn.

OFFICERS and directors of the 1938 National Motor Truck Show, Inc., were elected recently at the annual meeting of the board of directors. Those who will play a major part in the fifth annual truck show to be held in Commerce Hall, Port of Authority Building,

ON May 1 an improved highway extending from Bellevue to Arco, Idaho, will finally give easy access to Idaho's one national monument, the fantastic Craters of the Moon. This little-known national monument in a volcanic region was long neglected by tourists, partly because of the more celebrated and accessible Yellowstone National Park to the northeast and Crater Lake National Park to the west.
More than [pound]57,000,000 has been spent by the London County Council on slum clearance in recent years, involving the erection of approximately 86,600 houses and flats housing 385,000 persons.

Plans for the twenty-ninth season of the Princeton Summer Camp, student-operated establishment for underprivileged boys from the crowded sections of New York City and Princeton, were annouced today by the Rev. Laurence Fenninger, '09, director of the StudentFaculty Association of Princeton University.

Civic Symphony, under the direction of Eugene Plotnikoff; the soloist is Katherine Bacon, English. pianist, and the commentator is Leonard Liebling, editor of "Musical Courier"; WNYC. 1:30-3 P. M. Overture "In Bohemia" ..... Henry Hadley Symphony No. 4 in A major (Italian).

Representative and Mrs. Robert Low Bacon and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Woods Bliss celebrated tonight their wedding anniversaries with a dance at Dumbarton Oaks, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Bliss, in Georgetown.

Before the compromise - was reached by the Senate and House members of the joint conference committee on the new Revenue Bill, late last Friday, reports were current that the House members had offered to yield to the Senate's modification of the capital-gains tax if the Senate members would consent to the restoration of the House's undistributed-profits tax.

WITH short-wave stations linked from coast to coast, Mexico has been heard of late between 11 and 12 midnight, Eastern standard time, sending special Sunday programs over a national hook-up. Tuned to this so-called "Hora Nacional"

Mrs. Thomas Gibb of Oxford, England, has announced here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Isabella Gibb, to Duncan Chaplin Lee of Chatham, Va. Miss Gibb attended schools in Scotland and also went to Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford University.

The New York University golf team defeated Boston C.ollege, 3 1/2 to 2 1/2, on the Maplemoor course today. Fred Fiore and Ed Milton scored for the Violet in twosomes play, while Captain Irving Richland and El Milton turned in a best-ball triumph.

Four Yale athletes answer "Yes, Dad," to the calls of a quartet of coaches these days in an unprecedented number of father-coach and son-athlete combinations. The four athletes are Joe Wood, son of Smoky Joe Wood, baseball tutor; Jim Hinchcliff, whose dad, B??l, is tennis coach; Maurice Grasson, whose father, Bob, is fencing instructor, and DeLaney Kiphuth, son of Bob, swimming mentor.

Yale scored a 7-1 victory over the University of Pennsylvania today in an Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball game. A crowd of .3,500 attended. Monroe Jubitz and Paul Wargo, the Eli battery, were the stars of the game. Jubitz held the Quakers to eight scattered singles, being particularly effective with men

The Kremlin's concern over abuses to peasants-concern shown for four years in a series of measures designed to win the peasantry to collectivization after -a large proportion of them had been alienated by the early rigor with which the collectivization program was carried out in many regions-was shown again yesterday in editorial comment.

LONDON. HAROLD NICOLSON was born in 1886 at Teheran, while his father, the late Lord Carnock, was Brit- in ish Minister to Persia. On leaving Balliol, he entered the Foreign Office himself and from 1909 to 1929 he held diplomatic posts in many countries.

SYDNEY, Australia. - Between $70,000,000 and $75,000,000 will be spent on defense by Australia this year, and because world conditions have alarmed the Federal Government the new budget will step up taxation to make this large expenditure possible.

Miss Virginia Drabell Casey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Edwin Casey of Thistledhu, this community, and formerly of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, was married in the Methodist Episcopal Church of the Glen at Netcong this afternoon to Wilfred George Snyder, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Philip Snyder of West Orange.

Twenty young women college graduates have been selected for the "interneships" which the New York branch of the American Associtation of University Women has devised as an experiment in bridging the transition between college and industry.

ANABASIS. By St. J. Perse. Translated by T. S. Eliot. 75 pp. New York: HarcourtBrace Co. $1.25. ST. J. PERSE (Alexis Leger) has, as Eliot points out, used the word "Anabasis" in the same literal sense in which Xenophon himself used it.

NO one was in a position to wrangle at the Critics Circle meeting last Monday afternoon. All save one of the sixteen voting members had saluted "Of Mice and Men" with a broadside of praise after it opened last December; and when,

The Nicaraguan Government has made a contract with the American firm of contractors, Pablo Dambach R. C. Gautier, Ltd., of New York, for additions to the national palace now under construction. The additions will cost more than 300,000 cordobas.

Edward J. Agnew, president of the Apartment House Owners Association and Chief of Police at Long Beach, L. I., reports that rentals of apartments facing the ocean have been more numerous at this season

The crews of Williams College today took a slight lead in the first day's racing for the new Henry A. Morss Trophy, emblematic of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association's second annual dinghy championship. The races were held on the Charles River basin under the auspices of the M. I. T. Nautical Association.

Miss Judith Carolyn Strempel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. R. Strempel of Washington, formerly of Scarsdale, N. Y., was married today to James L. Washburn of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. C. Washburn of Marion, Ala.

The income of the Continental Can Company, Inc., for the year ended on March 31, as reported yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange, amounted to $12,859,279. Deduction of $4,497,254 for depreciation and Federal income taxes, left net earnings of $8,362,025 available for dividends.

Inshore, a veteran steeplechaser, won the Grand National point-topoint race today for the third successive year and gained for his owner, J. W. Y. Martin, a Maryland sportsman, permanent possession of the Gold Challenge Cup put up fifteen years ago.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Carol Decker, daughter of Professor Floyd Fiske Decker of Syracuse University and Mrs. Decker, to Burton Benjamin Corwin, son, of Mr. and Mrs. Roswell Corwin of Brooklyn and Aquebogue, L. I., took place here this afternoon-at the home of the bride's parents.
IN John Dos Passos there is combined the dramatic impetus of a novelist, the perception of a remarkable correspondent and the vigorous, independent curiosity of the great travelers of the past.

Winning for the fourth time in succession in the international tournament of the Kent County Chess Association at the Grand Hotel, Cliftonville, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris today widened the gap over the three rivals who are pressing him the closest for the lead.

Appropriation of $5,000,000 for the support of a Federal travel bureau has been urged by Thomas D. Green, president of the American Hotel Association, in identical letters to Senator Copeland of New York and Representative Lea of California. The two legislators are sponsoring a bill setting up such a bureau.
Forty-five charred bodies were taken today from the depths of the Keen Mountain mine of the Red Jacket Coal Company, set afire yesterday by dust explosions which trapped the night shift.

Champion drum and bugle corps in junior and senior divisions from various parts ofthe East will com pete on May 15 at Madison Square Garden in a demonstration and contest sponsored by President- Borough of Manhattan Post 84 of the American Legion, it was announced yesterday.

Plans for expansion of boys' club activities in certain areas in upper Manhattan and the Bronx, which are "taking over both the aspects and the problems once typical of the lower East Side," are announced in the eighty-fifth annual report of the Children's Aid Society.
With impressive ceremonies, the Daughters of the American Revolution inaugurated their newly elected officers today, and adjourned their annual congress at noon.
WILL HAYS will tell you that people go to the movies to be entertained, and no one can dispute him on that point. For the screen as we know it, at least, is primarily an entertainment medium.
Displaying more strength in the hurdles and field events, Temple University defeated the Manhattan College track team at the Owls' stadium today, 88-47.

Construction of new buildings on the campuses of two New England colleges, Connecticut and Williams, will soon be in progress. The Frank Loomis Palmer auditorium at Connecticut College will be started early in the Summer. It is the gift of the late Miss Virginia Palmer of New London,

Visibly disturbed by the wars in Spain and China and the German march into Austria, the American student peace movement, convening Wednesday morning on 500 college and high school campuses, is split over the question of isolation versus collective security.

To develop trained leadership in the field of nature study, Massachusetts State College will hold its first Nature Guide School from June 18 to Aug. 12 in the Otter River State Forest at Winchendon, Mass. Buildings of a discontinued CCC camp will be used.

Thirty-four Philharmonic - Symphony scholars have received positions with American major orchestras since last September, and of these there are eight at first-desks, according to the report of the Committee on Ensemble Musical Training and Scholarship of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York.

ENGLAND'S practice of converting the old-style portrait stamps into the more modern pictorials is gaining momentum, with Fiji Islands the latest to join the procession. Fiji's "new reign" set is the colony's first picture series and comprises eleven values.

Homer H. McKeehan, who was president of the Cleveland Bar Association in 1916 and 1917, and had practiced law here for forty-six years, died today of a heart attack at his Winter residence in St. Augustine, Fla. He was born in Hillsboro, Ohio, sixty-eight years ago.
THE miracle of barren desert soil bursting into bloom is adding impetus to repair work on roads and bridges damaged in the recent California rains.

Amid settings depicting in striking motif the architecture and various modes of transportation of the future, the Junior League of New York in cooperation with officials of the New York World's Fair will present the Ball of Tomorrow on Friday night in the recently-completed blue and orange neo-classic Business Administration Building on the fair grounds.

Nugym's Mohawk Sport captured the all-age stake in the third annual field trials of the English Setter Association held near here today. He is a white and black sette-, owned by Frank Quarella of Landisville. He ran only a fair ground heat, but he was perfect in bird work. He located a pheasant, which he handled brilliantly, and was steady to wing and shot.
The most celebrated rugged individualist in American business said last week: "I am going to give the President a chance to look at somebody who doesn't want anything. I shall not give any advice."

Next to the encounter between Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, and Albert C. Simonson in the tournament of the National Chess Federation at Rockefeller Center, which served to break the latter's winning streak, the meeting between Reshevsky and Isaac I. Kashrdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, provided the big moment in the biennial competition.

What makes the sun and the stars glow? Physicists find the answer in atomic energy. There are two theories. According to one protons and electrons collide, neutralize each other. A splash of radiation and all is over. Since there are almost countless protons and electrons it would take billions of years for the sun to become a mere cinder. But there is no supporting evidence of any such Process.

IN anticipation of steadily increasing traffic, the New Jersey State Highway Commission is rapidly improving heavily traveled routes and building new links in all parts of the State's metropolitan area.

Inquiries from many foreign nations looking to the purchase of planes, heavy guns, coast artillery, men-of-war and all types of munitions and equipment are being received by American manufacturers at probably a faster rate than at any time since the World War, it became known yesterday.

THIS compact and well illustrated volume offers a guide to the principal ballets of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries and will be welcomed by a large public which has needed just such a reference book as this.

Three gold medals will be presented next month to New York public officials for "outstanding contributions for the betterment of the city's children," it was announced last night by Uncle Robert, founder of Parents Day, Stay-on-the-Sidewalk movements and children's clubs bearing his name.

Ten students now enrolled in New Jersey, Pennsylvani, New York and New England high schools were named today as recipients of Irving S. Upson Memorial Scholarships, the highest awards of their kind made by Rutgers University. They will enter the university in the class of 1942 next Fall.

Champion Blakeen Juna Frau, a standard poodle owned by Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of the Blakeen Kennels of Katonah, N. Y., won the best in show ribbon at the first annual competition of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey for the benefit of the Northern Valley Chapter of the American Red Cross tonight.

The way was prepared today for negotiations in a favorable atmosphere in an effort to reach a satisfactory solution of the controversy caused by the expropriation of American oil properties in Mexico.

Mr. and Mrs. Homer Root Turner of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Everest Turner, to John Tallman Brainard, son of Dr. and Mrs. C. Brewster Brainard of West Hartford.

One of the perplexing problems which, in the past, often confronted Summer home-owners was where to put the unexpected guest who dropped in to spend a few days in the mountains, at the farm. or at the beach.

Retention of the present constitutional limits of 2 per cent plus debt service on real estate taxation and 10 per cent of assessed valuation on municipal indebtedness is essential for the protection of property and should be guarded jealously by realty interests, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, declared last week at a meeting of Management Division of the board.

Justice Mitchell May in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, reserved decision yesterday on an application of the Associated Flour Haulers and Warehousemen, Inc., of 79 Kent Avenue, Brooklyn, for an injunction. The group seeks to restrain the officers of Local 308 of. the International Brotherhood of

Six victims of the trolley-fire truck crash in Bay- Ridge, Brooklyn, on Friday were still in hospitals yesterday. The motorman of the car was paroled until May 24 on a third-degree assault charge. Police sought a 10-year-old boy as the one who sounded the false alarm which summoned the fire apparatus.

Mayor La Guardia of New York arrived here today from Oklahoma City. He was escorted from the Oklahoma-Texas State line by highway patrolmen of both States. He is a guest at the home of an old friend, Dr. O. B. Kiel, with whom he served on the Italian front in the World War. ld War.

Miss Gloria van Wart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Franklin van Wart of this place, was married to Clarence Preston Scoboria Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Preston Scoboria of Brooklyn and Bedford, N. Y., here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.
Protestant churches in France have announced a meeting to take place at Lyon starting Monday that is expected to result in the union of all the principal Protestant sects in the country.

On the basis of returns from seventeen companies, sales of household refrigerators in March totaled 162,139, compared with 327,922 in the same month of last year and 247,647 in March, 1936, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.
At the end of a day devoted to tests of horsemanship, Miss Muriel Arthur, a student at Marymount, was judged the champion. rider of the Spring competition at the Kenilworth Riding Club today.
A sophomore stood on the mound on Rose Hill yesterday and knew the thrill of a lifetime as he hurled himself into the college hall of nohit, no-run fame.

The following Foreign Service changes since April 15 were announced by the State Department today: Reginald P. Mitchell of Jacksonville, Fla., third secretary of the legation at Dublth and now in the United States on leave, assigned to the Department of State.

Turpentine firm, 23 1/2c; sales 357 barrels; receipts 395 barrels; shipments 36 barrels; stock 31,053 barrels. Resin firm; sales 235; receipts 2,016; shipments 15; stock 79,867. Quote: B, $3.50; D, $3.75; E, $3.80; F, $4.60; G, H, I, K, $4.82 1/2; M; $4.85; N, $5.25; WG, $6.05; WW, X, $6.40.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J.-Conventons will hold the center of the stage in this city for the next two weeks. The New Jersey State Hotel Association convention and exposition, opening Tuesday for four days at the Hotel Ambassador, is expected to draw hotel men from throughout the East and with $250,000 worth of exhibit.
INTERPRETATION: Members of the American Labor party last week listened to a British interpretation of the New Deal philosophy. The interPreter.

The prize winners in the annual Spring exhibition of the Academy of Science and Fine Arts, Richmond Va., were announced yesterday. First and second prizes for oils went respectively to Carson Davenport of Danville, Va., for "Wild Ponies at Chincoteague" and J. Stanley Collins for

James' F. (Jeff) Burkitt, who for the last ten years has been one of the leaders in political campaigns and crusades against Mayor Frank Hague's Administration, was sentenced this afternoon to serve six months in the county penitentiary after he was found guilty by Judge Anthony Botti in the First Criminal Court of being a disorderly person.
William A. Eddy, president of Hobart College, told the American Society of Newspaper Editors today that the United States was the only great nation which still had a truthful press.
Miss Ellenor Brigham Colgate chose a decorative scheme dominated by white for her marriage yesterday afternoon to Benjamin Loring Young-Jr., which took place in St. John's Church, Flushing.

Miss Nancy Krementz and John Monks Starr Hutchinson were married here this afternoon in Trinity Church, where Easter lilies and dogwood formed a decorative background. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Robert Lee Bull Jr.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's birthday has probably become an annual event on the National Socialist calendar, which best demonstrates the manner in which Hitler's totalitarian State has given back to essentially monarchical Germany the old institutions and instinctive viewpoint of a monarchical society.

The Sino-Japanese war is aiding lily culture in America. For years America's Easter lilies have been coming to our florists and seedmen in Japanese refrigerator-equipped vessels. The lily has been, like silk, one of the chief sources of revenue in Japan.

When the New York City public schools close two months hence, the 1,250,000 eager boys and girls, released from the discipline of the classroom, will find awaiting them one of the most progressive and extensive Summer programs ever attempted here.

The West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association announces the closing of the first of a series of mortgage loans to home builders at Alden Estates, Portchester, Westchester County. Dr. Herman L. Reis, president of the association, is cooperating with John W. Fries, general manager of the Westchester development in analyzing the needs of prospective home buyers here.

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, in Federal court, Brooklyn, yesterday adjourned until Thursday the trial of Albert Marinelli, former County Clerk of New York County, on an indictment charging him with harboring Charles Falci while the latter was a fugitive from justice charged with violation of the Election Laws.

Condemning Great Britain's dealings with Italy and Germany, Sherwood Eddy, author and lecturer, addressing a luncheon meeting yesterday of the League for Industrial Democracy at Town Hall Club, urged "genuine neutrality" for the United States in "the coming world war," predicting that Germany and Japan would collapse economically in the event of a prolonged conflict.

The Eastern Polo League, which has revived interest in low-goal polo on a large scale during its two-year existence, is planning to have two circuits this season, it was made known yesterday by Jack Blake Quisenberry, chairman of the organization. One circiut will be made.

Dagmar Godowsky, daughter of the noted pianist, Leopold Godowsky, arrived on the Britannic today from New York, with a black handbag as her only luggage. She explained that the vessel sailed while she was saying goodbye to the pianist, Josef Hofmann, and Mrs. Hofmann.
Miss Grace Breadon, director of nursing and nursing school principal for nine years at General Hospital, died today at the age of 54. She recently had undergone an operation.

Transfer from North American Aviation, Inc., to a new corporation-Eastern Air Lines, Inc., Captain E. V. Rickenbacker, president-of air mail contracts between New York and New Orleans, New York and Miami, Chicago and Jacksonville and New Orleans and Houston, effective at midnight on April 22, was announced today by Postmaster General Farley.

The motion picture, radio and television rights to the title "Ziegfeld Follies" have been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer from Lee Shubert, producer, and Miss Billie Burke, widow of Florenz Ziegfeld, it, was revealed yesterday.

In a sensational finish, Tommy Barnes of Georgia Tech won the Southern Intercollegiate golf championship today. The 22-year-old senior defeated Bert McDowell, sophomore from Louisiana State University, 1 up, on the twenty-first hole of the final.

Part 2 of the library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop will be sold at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., tomorrow afternoon and evening and on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings.

The ever spectacular and swiftmoving Penn Relay carnival will usher in the major track season along the Eastern Seaboard on Friday and Saturday when some 3,000 athletes from 500 schools and colleges compete in the forty-fourth annual renewal of the first relay race ever held on this continent.

Rutgers University's chapel choir of forty-five will present a vesper service in the Gould Memorial Library chapel at New York University on May 1 at 3:30 P. They sing under the direction of Professor Howard D. McKinney, head of the Music Department.

Although post-Easter sales brought a good response, retailers placed few reorders. They continued t clean out Spring stocks and bough Summer merchandise with caution, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buy ers.
A home run by Rookie Ken-Richardson with the bases full in the fourteenth inning broke up a thrilling battle today and gave the Jersey City Giants an 11-to-7 victory over Toronto.
The five Turnesa brothers of New York defeated the five Fry brothers of California in a telegraph golf match today by a net margin of twelve strokes and a best-ball net of three strokes.

With the business structure- utterly stagnant, a weak tone but no evidence of drastic declines in commodity prices, and inventories lower, but still heavy in numerousmanufacturing plants, definite opinions are scarce among purchasing agents concerning the time when an improvement in business volume may be expected,

Since its opening five months ago, the Jules S. Bache art collection has been seen by more than 20,000 persons, its custodian, Mrs. Mary Duggett Benson, reported last week to the board of trustees. Her report was made public yesterday.

The Shandon Farm's Dickerville virtually eliminated himself from Kentucky Derby consideration by finishing last for the second time during the Keeneland Park meeting in the Elmendorf Purse today, and the Milky Way Farms' Mountain Ridge showed little to warrant enthusiasm while finishing fifth in the Ben Ali Handicap.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has registered a new low for the year and back to the week ended Oct. 13, 1934. With only one component higher, the index has broken to 77.1 for the week ended April 16, which compares with 78.2 for the preceding week and 107.2 for the corresponding week last year.

While Francis Warren Pershing and his bride were leaving from Newark Airport yesterday on their wedding trip, General John J. Pershing, father of the bridegroom, was resting well at his suite in the Waldorf-Astoria,
A new 37 mm. anti-tank gun, which fires a shell at such velocity that it can penetrate more than an inch of armor at more than 1,000 yards, is now being tested by the army.
Steve Vasillakos, the White House peanut vendor, popped off today about Henry Ford's impending luncheon with President Roosevelt set for Wednesday. "These Mister Fords," he asked "make the autos?"

The American Institute of Architects and the Producers Council, Inc., in convention here, agreed yesterday to cooperate to reduce costs of planning, building and furnishing homes, but expressed fears that poorly constructed houses would result from haste, to get relief programs under way.
BECAUSE of the financial success of Joris Ivens' "The Spanish Earth" the attention of some of the citizens has been directed toward documentary films as a practical method of expression.

The Silurians will hold their annual Spring dinner at the Hotel Lafayette on Saturday at 7 P. M. The Silurians are an association of 200 or more men who were New York newspaper men at least thirty years ago.

With the pre-marital examination law now part of New York statutes, to become effective July 1, advocates of a greater unity in State marriage laws have found new encouragement in their aim to lessen the wide diversity that now exists throughout the country.

MODERN Norwegian art and craftsmanship will be richly represented on the new motor liner Oslofjord, scheduled to put in its appearance here in the harbor the middle of May, a little in advance of its first transatlantic sailing.

Justice Owen J. Roberts and Mrs. Roberts of Washington and Kimberton, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth R. Roberts, to Charles A. Hamilton of Fellowship, Greens Farms, Conn., son of Mrs. Florence Wildes Hamilton of New York and of the late Burgoyne Hamilton.

Rarely heard songo will be sung when representative groups ranging from anthracite miner of Pennsylvania and West Virginia to New York sailors and lumberjacks from Wisconsin and Michigan participate in the National Folk Festival, to be held at Constituton Hall in Washington on May 6, 7

Another crisis in a war that is fast becoming one of the greatest of Japan's gambles is forecast by dispatches from China. Stung by recent reverses and by her profitless months of hammering at the east-west Lung-Hai Railway line, convinced at last by mounting casualty lists and the increasing effectiveness of the Chinese guerrillas of the quality of Chinese resistance,
Albert Heilbronn,a former Brooklyn department store owner and long a leader in civic affairs, died Friday in his apartment at the Hotel Granada after a week's illness. He was in his sixty-ninth year.

FELIX WOLFES, widely experienced German director of opera, has been engaged as assistant conductor of the Metropolitan Opera Association. Follow ing an uninterrupted career as opera leader in Germany from 1912, Mr. Wolfes, as a non-Aryan, found it advisable to leave that country at the start of the present Hitler regime.

The University of Vermont will hold the forty-fifth annual celebration of Founder's Day next Saturday when students and faculty will hear Professor Henry F. Perkins, '98, speak on Ira Allen, founder of the university, and witness the induction of new members into honorary societies.

MANUFACTURER has at last answered the amateur movie maker's prayer for a device that will quickly and simply make enlarged negatives and pictures from 16 mm. movie film. The device is particularly valuable to the photographer who lacks facilities for making enlarged stills from his reels, for it offers a means of making a series of negatives in rapid succession and eliminates the need of immediate processing.

The captain and ten men of the crew of the freighter Canadian, under charter to the Grace Line, today forcibly put down what they described as a mutiny. Two sailors were seriously injured in an exchange of revolver fire. The disturbance was said to have been started by a drunken sailor returning from shore leave.

Figures which showed that salaries paid to women teachers in private schools in the city and vicinity varied from $460 to $4,000 were presented yesterday at a meeting of 200 teachers in such institutions.

The marine division of the Police Department came out yesterday with some new fashions for Spring (as well as for other seasons) in the form of two sleek patrol boats that cost $11,005 each. The boats took to the open waters for the first patrol trip without much fanfare. There was no christening ceremony with traditional bottlebreaking.

Drs. A. C. hardy and P. S. Milne (department of Zoology and Oceanography, University college, Hull, England) write to Nature, the British scientific weekly, that ever since 1932 they have been studying the way insects are blown by breezes.

Because the French Government had his name misspelled, Private James J. Sullivan of the 306th Infantry, Seventy-seventh Division, received his croix de guerre with palms only last night. It was presented to him at the annual Spring dance of the Seventy-seventh Division Association, in the presence of several hundred guests at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated today that, despite production of the largest cotton crop on record, the growers' income in the 1937 calendar year amounted to only $863,970,000, or $41,109,000 less than in the previous year,

THIS book proves that the long fight against Com stock's successors was worth making: It convinces that Ernst's court briefs and Mencken's showy gestures and Broun's many columns. all spent in the effort to make the facts of common speech printable, were not in vain.

A drastic "Fifth Column" clean-up has been under way in Barcelona, Valencia and other cities in Loyal territory under the new rule of "iron law and discipline" established by Dr. Juan Negrin; the Premier and National Defense Minister. Houses are beling visited at night when their occupants are at home.

The writer of the following communication was Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, March, 1931-February, 1932, serving thereafter as Under-Secretary until May, 1933. Previously he was an advisory counselor on taxation to the Treasury, Solicitor General of Internal Revenue and an adviser of the Joint Congresssional Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation.

Prospective brides are now making their final preparations for several weddings which will take place here during the coming week. Although fewer notable marriages are scheduled for the immediate future: than transpired during Easter week, those in prospect also concern families long identified with society here, in near-by cities and also abroad.

INCREASED attendance at national contract bridge tournaments was predicted when the previous warring associations were united as the American Contract Bridge League last October. The two championship tournaments now in progress have borne out that prediction.

EXHIBITIONS of fine, oldtime wallpapers are important factors in the excellence of present-day designs. These reminders of an artistic past are often considered worthy of exact reproduction, while in other cases they serve as inspiration for new patterns.

Trinity College will start a series of programs designed to bring the college into touch with the cultural life of the community. A series of broadcasts will be given, presenting the college to the listeners in a novel way.
St. Louis, which cradled the organization at its birth nineteen years ago, is welcoming today the vanguard of delegates to the thirteenth convention of the National League of Women Voters.

Long Branch High School turned in its sixth consecutive victory in the sixth annual Long Branch relay carnival today, rolling up a total of 25 points against 11 for Perth Amboy and 10 for Toms River, nearest of the forty-two schools which took part.

TELEVISION Station W2XBS, atop the Empire State Building, and linked by co-axial cable with the studios at Radio City, is now operating on the following schedule: Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday afternoons from 3 to 4 o'clock still pictures and charts of "no entertainment value" are telecast.

The Jonah jungle freighter City of Salisbury, which grounded yesterday in a dense fog on the Graves Reefs, broke apart and sank at noon today. A live cargo of 40 pythons, 40 cobras, 300 monkeys and 20 crates of rare birds were safely ashore but the rest of her varied freight of tea, jute, rice and sugar went down with the ship at the entrance to the harbor, a total loss estimated at $2,000,000.

A group of members of the William Alexander Jr. Chapter, United Daughters of the Confederacy, will leave Greenwich, Conn., by chartered bus Tuesday for a pilgrimage to Philadelphia, Washington and the Robert E. Lee memorial home in Stratford, Va., returning Thursday night.

The Rutgers lacrosse team scored four times in the first quarter and then stood off a desperate last-half rally by the Army to win its fourth victory of the season, 4 to 3, and remain undefeated, before 1,000 persons on Neilson Field today.

King George today led the Knights of the Order of St. Michael and St. George in the annual St. George's Day service at St. Paul's. The King wore a deep blue silk robe as sovereign of the order. Queen Elizabeth, still confinedWindsor Castle. with a cold, was unable to accompany the Monarch.

EYE ON THE SPARROW-Tuesday evening at the Vanderbilt Theatre. Herewith a comedy by Maxwell Selser, with Catharine Doucet, Edgar Stehli, Edward Fielding, Katherine Deane, Barry. Sullivan, Dorothy Francis, Philip Ober, Stiano Braggiotti. Francesca Lenni and Montgomery Clift in the cast.

M. I. T. hit a new rowing high today when it swept a regatta on the Charles to give the new coach, Cedric Valentine, a rousing send-off. At the same time Boston University made its varsity crew debut, but finished fourth in the feature race over the Henley distance.

AIRPLANES are solving the vacation problem for many whose limited holidays have in the past made outings in the Far West impracticable. Today increased flights and new airports enable one to reach almost any desired western spot in hours instead of days. Besides, lower fares have brought air travel within the range of the slender purse.

Jackie Coogan's mother, stating "I'd go through fire and water for the boy," obtained permission today to alter or amend the deposition she made Monday in the suit filed by her son for an accounting of the money he earned as "The Kid" of the silent screen.

Executives of two out of three deapartment stores here which have launched book club plans on the 30 per cent discount basis have found results only "fair," with the third declaring results "satisfactory."

The first in a series of events arranged for the coming year to bring the work of the Girls Service League to the attention of the publie will take place on Tuesday, when the thirtieth anniversary dinner of the organization will be held at the Plaza. Speakers will include Mrs.

A production of shadow plays, one of the most ancient forms of Chinese drama, will be given on Wednesday afternoon at the Cosmopolitan Club as a means to raise funds for the Art Workers Club for Women.

Holy Cross defeated Dartmouth, 4 to 2, in a well-played game today. Art Kenney allowed the Indians only two hits and struck out six. The Crusaders registered seven safeties off Hal Wonson. With the score knotted at 2-all in the seventh and one out, Bartolomeo reached first on an error, and Kenney grounded out.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 21 COMMANDERS Fife, J. Jr., Submarine Division 12, to Submarine School, Submarine Base, New London, Conn., May 30 as officer in charge. Hart, H. D., Med. Corps, Dover, N. J., about April 30, to home, relieved all active duty.

With all the golfers in the United States straining their eyes in scanning the newspapers for the allimportant publication from the United States Golf Association of the personnel of the 1938 Curtis Cup team, it is the purpose of this department to give readers an idea of just how this team is selected.

A Colonial type home on a plot of three acres in Croton Falls, Westchester County, has been sold by Miss Harman-Brown to Mrs. Elizabeth Cassidy of Hempstead, L. I. who intends to occupy the place as her permanent home.
A regular meeting of the Board of Education will be held on Wednesday at 4 P.M. in the board headquarters, 500 Park Avenue. Action on the appointment of several high school principals is scheduled.

Two small monkeys, which escaped from the Cadwalader Park Zoo, here, this afternoon while a keeper was cleaning the cage, were shot and killed just before dark tonight after a three-hour chase through the park by police and a crowd of almost 1,000 visitors.

Edwin Markham, poet and author of "The Man With the Hoe," celebrated his eighty-sixth birthday yesterday at his home, 92 Waters Avenue, Westerleigh, S. I. Although visibly affected by the death of his wife, Mrs. Anna Catherine Markham, last Sunday, the poet appeared to be in excellent health and cheerfully greeted many callers.

With several members of the cast planning to pursue careers on the professional stage after graduation, the Pennsylvania Players of the University of Pennsylvania are rehearsing their Spring production, Maxwell Anderson's "High Tor."

THE rugged beauty of the Pacific Northwest coast is attracting an increasing number of tourists. Several steamship lines, both American and Canadian, are now catering to this traffic, most of the steamers making their southern base at Seattle or Vancouver and going up the British Columbia and Alaska coasts
Princeton's golfers beat Navy today, 8 to 1, sweeping the three foursome matches. Helfrish saved the Navy from a shut-out by winning from H. Jones, 3 to 2, in an individual match.

The Administration's "pump -priming" program was denounced today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, which urged instead a "non - spectacular, inexpensive program" which would have as its theme the restoration of public confidence.

Amid all. the shouting and tumult in Washington for the last few months, emanating from the lifeand-death struggle between the President and his new-found opposition over control of Congress, there is one development which only recently has claimed the notice to which it would seem entitled. This is the almost desperate attempt of the Republicans to reestablish themselves as the recognized front-line resistance against the policies and legislative proposals of the New Deal.

Paul Dean, who did all right in his only Texas League start this season--except for a little trouble getting the other side out-admitted with characteristic Dean modestly today that he and his brother Dizzy come high. "That 185,000 smackers and a fourth of a dozen players for Ole Diz was okay," Paul said,

Thomas E. Colleton completed his third year as New Jersey State Director of the Federal Housing Administration on Tuesday, April 19. During his regime New Jersey has taken its place among the leading States of the nation in FHA activity.

Only one-third of the nation's aged are able to maintain themselves through current earnings, pensions, savings or other resources accumulated during their active years, according to a survey by Marjorie Shearon of the bureau of research and statistics of the Federal Social Security Board.

Abraham Lincoln High's formidable nine gained its seventh successive triumph by conquering the City College junior varsity, 6-2, yesterday. Nick Chellima gained the distinction of being the first Lincoln moundsman to go nine innings this season.

Merger of all labor unions into one large union was urged today by Charles P. Howard of Indianapolis, president of the International Typographical Union. Addressing the Empire Typographical Conferencee , he discussed the objectives of the A. F. of L., the C. I. O.

PROMINENT gallery events of the week have included the opening of the Architectural League's fifty-second Annual, which is likewise, by virtue of a much broader representation, its First National. But before entering that maze it will be appropriate briefly to record here two prominent straight news events:

With the dedication of the new $115,000 wing to the Dudley Peter Allen Memorial Art Building this week, Oberlin College will have completed the first unit of the campus architectural group. In addition to the Art Building, this architectural group will include the proposed million-dollar Hall Auditorium and an outdoor theatre.

Although that perennial plague, the Japanese beetle, will not be in visible evidence for some weeks yet, he is already at his nefarious work--at this season of the year just underneath the sod. Gardeners who are now making new garden beds or lawns frequently discover the white grubs below the surface, where they are busily engaged in destroying the grass roots.

Lack of the art and skill in the application of paint presents the main obstacle to the progress of paint science and the fullest use of paints by the public, declares A. L. Zinser, paint chemist of the Texas State Highway Department.

Mgr. William Quinn, who resigned in 1936 as national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, died here today in St. Agnes Hospital, after two years' illness, of heart disease. He was 51 years old.

Three educational courses dealing with real estate appraisal problems will be given during the Summer at the University of Chicago under the auspices of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers with the cooperation of the School of Business of the Chicago University.
The Turnure Trophy, in competition today for the first time, was annexed by Russ's Seaview Rex, a white and liver pointer dog, owned and handied by Russell Gardner of Middletown, N. Y.
The new West Side Institutional Synagogue and its adoining Community Center, 122 West Seventy-sixth Street, will be dedicated next Saturday morning and the following Sunday afternoon.

YURIY HERMAN is Moscow's latest literary discover. Only six years ago he was an unknown beginner. Today he is one of the best known and most frenziedly discussed Soviet authors. In itself that would not necessarily mean much: the Soviet Parnas.
New York State unemployment Insurance checks will go to workers who acquired benefit rights by employment here but now live in other States under a procedure outlined

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Frances Harris, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rosslyn Philip Harris of this city, to Ralph Waldo Earl Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl of Morristown, N. J., took place here tonight in the First Parish Church.

In discussion at the meeting of the American Association of Collegiate Schools of Business here today it was the consensus that a certain amount of flexibility in setting up the standards of the association would give better promise than a too-particularized formula.

AND SO TO WAR. By Hubert Herring. 172 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $2. By WILLIAM MACDONALD MR. HERRING is convinced that the United States is headed for war. The conspicuous leader of the crusade is-President Roosevelt, whose "quarantine" speech at Chicago on Oct. 5, 1937, was interpreted by overseas Foreign Offices as "in effect"

The police are watching ports and airfields, and mails for the United States are being searched following the daring theft early today of five old masters valued by some experts at [Pound]100,000 from Chilham Castle near Canterbury, Kent, the home of Sir Edmund Davis, financier.
THE story is told of George Luks, the painter, that once at an art exhibition he spent his entire time following a wealthy lady about. Everywhere she went, there was Luks right behind her.
The celebration of the Russian Easter--the bar's holiest day for the Greek Arthodox Church-began tonight in e score of churches that are all at remain at pre-Bolshevist

A proposal that the new Constitution do away with the "three-day" messages- of the Governor, which are designed to speed legislation, was completed today by Irwin Steingut,. minority leader in the Assembly, for presentation to the Constitutional Convention.
The National Labor Relations Board ordered today David E. Kennedy, Inc., Brooklyn tile manufacturer, to disestablish a company union and reinstate three employes with back pay.

Representative J. J. O'Connell, Democrat, of Montana, said today that a conference of liberals at Madison, Wis., next week would provide "a very excellent opportunity" for the group to endorse President Roosevelt for a third term.

Callan Brothers, builders and developers of Wyngate at Great Neck, L. I., will hold a dual celebration on May 1- to commemorate their thirty-fourth year in the home construction field and their second year at Wyngate.

The first ten railroads to report showed a decrease of 79 per cent in net operating income in March compared with March, 1937. This compared with a drop of 83 per cent disclosed by the first five companies to report.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. D. Herbert Hostetter Jr. of Pasadena, Calif., of the marriage of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ruth Hostetter, to Captain Charles Thomas Irvine (Pat) Roark of London, internationally known polo player.
Buoyage changes in several popular. metropolitan waterways have been made this month and will be continued early in May by the Lighthouse Service.

Furnishings of the Gilbert W. Keech residence, 4 East Seventyninth Street, will be offered at auction by the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., on Tuesday and Wednesday, partly at the galleries and partly at the residence.

Installation of modern heating plants in homes under the FHA modernization credit plan now is about three times the volume recorded for this type of work prior to revival of Title I of the National Housing Act early in February, according to A. R. Herske, vice president and general manager of sales for the American Radiator Company.
A ninepound boy, Walter, born this morning in the Villefranche Maternity Hospital is the first offspring of the United States Navy squadron on the current tour of duty in Mediterranean waters.

Nova Scotia's annual Annapolis Valley Apple Blossom Festival has been set for May 28-30, inclusive. Miss Gladys Harris, queen of last year's festival, departed today for Winchester, Va., to be the guest of honor at the Shenandoah Valley Blossom Festival.

Cardinal Hayes is among the honorary patrons for the concert to be given on next Saturday afternoon at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York by the glee clubs of the College of New Rochelle and Georgetown University. Miss Iris Bohan, president of the College of New Rochelle glee club, is in charge of the arrangements.

A remedial reading project, started with the aid of WPA teachers in fifteen high schools, helped 6,000 pupils advance in their studies last year, according to a report made public by Frederic Ernst, Associate Superintendent of Schools.

Daniel Breck, president of the SeldenBreck Construction Company and an associate of the firm for the last thirty-three years, died of a heart ailment at a St. Louis hospital last night. His age was 75.

Declaring that "we have protected the employee from the political domination of every employer in the United States except one," Representative Barton, Republican, of New York, stated today that he would offer a bill on Monday to amend the Corrupt Practices Act so as to prevent the government from exercising such "domination."

MANDALAY. TRAVEL in Burma is still an adventure. Even in Rangoon, the lively export harbor for teakwood, rice and oil, nature will still provide the unexpected. On the evening when we boarded the train for Prome, clouds of green insects descended on the city.

Mr. and Mrs. Noble Crandall of 124 East Seventy-first Street and Pepperell, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie Crandall, to Dr. Sydney L. Harris of New Rochelle, son of Mrs. Donald J. Harris of Ottawa and the late Mr. Harris.
Developers and builders in and around the Forest Hills section of Long Island report that construction activity is at a higher peak than has been experienced for several years.

A wild pitch by Dowd of -Columbia in the tenth inning of the Lions' diamond battle with Army today gave the Cadets a victory by a score of 10 to 9. Three Army runners were on base when Dowd's misplay came and Weinnig raced home with the winning tally.

Permits for the sale of cigarettes required by the new 1-cent tax which becomes effective May 1 will be ready for distribution to the city's 50,000 shopkeepers tomorrow, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, announced yesterday. The permits will be distributed by-the jobbers...

DURING an extensive career in the theatre Frank Craven has been adequately celebrated both as an author and as an actor, but above all-as a cursory survey of old theatre programs and reviews will disclose-as a personality.

A strike involving 20,000 union men in automobile factories here has been voted by members of the United Automobile Workers of America employed by Buick and Chevrolet, it was announced today by officials of the union, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization.
Miss Marian Clark Lokes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Clark Lokes D of this city, was married tonight to Henry Brock Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Mount Vernon, N. Y.

Rudolph J. Schaefer's new oceanracing yawl Edlu II was launched yesterday at the Nevins shipyard in City Island amid one of the largest gatherings ever to attend the maiden dip of a .yacht except that of an America's Cup sloop.

Albert Max Butcher, right-hand pitcher of the Dodgers, yesterday was fined $500 and suspended indefinitely for "violation of training rules." The announcement of the action, which was signed by Manager Burleigh Grimes,

Stressing the need for "a better understanding and a more sympathetic attitude on the part of store management toward the toy department, not only for its direct profit possibilities but its value in building good-will and traffic for the store as a whole,"

FICTION "MAY FLAVIN." Myron Brinig. (Farrar Rinehart.) June. "THE LENIENT GOD." Naomi Jacob. (Macmillan.) May. "YOUNG MAN WITH A HORN." Dorothy Baker. (Houghton Mifflin.) June. "THE BLACK ARROWS." Francis Beeding. (Harper.) June. "DEATH IS SO FAIR." Louis Lynch D'Alton. (Doubleday, Doran.) June.
The Brown baseball team collected fifteen safeties off Michel and Stott of the Amherst nine today and won by 10 to 3.

Retail trade fell below 1937 in most districts last week, and the volume was sharply below the previous week. Where gains were shown, they were spotty, with several lines in poor demand. Stores in a number of districts were ordering promotion merchandise, and were cutting prices on unsold Easter goods, for quick clearance.

EDSON, WILLIAM RUSSELL (April 14). Estate, less than $10,000. To Natalie A. Edson, widow, executrix, 2 Beekman PI., residue. FINNEGAN, JULIA (April 11). Estate $4,800. To Jennie Poppo, sister, executrix, 430 pearl St., residue.
The London correspondent of The Journal of the American Medical Association reports that after a search lasting eight years eight milligrams of radium in the form of needles have been recovered.

The first of three news seminars on "Germany and Her Neighbors" will be opened tomorrow at the Crestwood Library lounge by the Westcheter Federation of Women and the Westchester League of Women Voters. Mrs. J. L. Stolz of Bronxville and Mrs. Frank Hawley of Scarsdale are in charge of arrangements.

Prides on the Cotton Exchange held within a 5-point range yesterday, but the closing prices were 2 to 5 points lower than Friday. Although most of the trading was at slight advances in quotations, active liquidation of the May contract toward the close of the session counterbalanced the effects of foreign straddle-buying,
The marriage of Miss Caroline Turner of East Orange, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey N. Turner, to Harry MacDonald Broughton, son of Mrs. Mary L. Broughton, also of East Orange,

The Highland Lakes development near Stockholm, Sussex County, N. J., will celebrate its first anniversary today. The community was opened a year ago to individual site purchasers fter eighteen months of engineering and development operations.

Baseball - Johnny McCarthy's seventh-inning homer with two on the bases enabled the Giants to beat the Dodgers, 8-5, yesterday at Ebbets Field. The Senators downed the Yankees, 7--4, at the Stadium. Hank Borowy pitched a no-hit game as Fordham defeated Rutgers, 7-0.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Kathryn Chatten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon A. Chatten of this city, to Stuart M. Hoyt, son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Hoyt of Pennington.

The two-day plenary congress of the Sudeten German party opened today at Carlsbad, at which Ernst Kundt, the party's chairman, declined even to consider the proposed. minority statute as outlined in conversations between Premier Milan Hodza and a party representative.
The Shawmut Association reported yesterday that its net asset value on March 31 was $13.52 a share, compared with $15.56 on Dec. 31 and $22.97 a share on March 31, 1937.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended April 20, which included five business days in some of the reporting cities, aggregated $7,627,000,000, or 17 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 19 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

The thirty-eighth annual meeting of The Associated Press will be held tomorrow and the fifty-second annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association will be held from Tuesday to Friday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Stimulated by recent events in Washington, obligations of the United States Government had in the seven bond-trading days ended on Friday their sharpest advance in many months and reached their highest levels of the year and longer.
FROM the Great Plains westward stretches a vast area that again this year will be the destination of millions of travelers. The 1938 tourist season is about to begin in the Far West.

At the season of cleaning up old and planting new lawns, home owners frequently discover grubs destroying the grass roots. Along the Connecticut shore and in the towns and suburbs of the State, grubs of Japanese, Asiatic Garden, Oriental and Ochrosidia Villosa beetles are prevalent, according to the State Experlment Station at New Haven.

Several hundred Austrian political refugees are reported to have asked the Interior Department for funds to come to Mexico under the terms recently offered by President Lazaro Cardenas in support of President Roosevelt's appeal in behalf of minorities.

A conference of New York suburban community chests and councils, comprising about thirty-six such agencies in Westchester, Connecticut, Long Island and New Jersey, will be held Tuesday at the Hotel Roosevelt. The meeting will begin with a luncheon and will continue into the afternoon.

A few weeks ago we commented on that section of the Rockefeller Foundation's last annual report in which the erection of international barriers to the pursuit of science by the totalitariancountries was deplored. Now comes a communication in Science from Dr. Otto Struve, director of Yerkes Observatory, in which he expresses his concern at- a disintegrating trend in astronomy so far as international cooperation is concerned.

Lake Shore Mines reports production for the three months ended on March 31, the third quarter of the fiscal year, at $2,142,860 with gold at $20.67 an ounce (approximately -$3,628,452 at $35 gold) from treatment of 233,055 tons of ore for an average recovery of $9.19 ($15.56 at $35 gold).

The Columbia Jester was adjudged the best American college comic magazine for the second time in three years yesterday by the American Association of College Comics at a meeting in the Hotel Lincoln. The judges were Ik Shuman of The New Yorker and Jack Shuttleworth of Judge magazine.

Marano and R. R. Bogie tied at 48 for the high scratch cup in a skeet event at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. On a toss, the trophy was taken by Marano. J. White, shooting for targets only, broke 49. In a handicap shootoff the winner was L. D. Ward. J. E. Connelley Jr. finished second.
BRAERMAN--TRACHTENBERG--Mrs. A. Trachtenberg announces the engagement of daughter, Doris, to Dr. A. Braverman of Brooklyn. The wedding will take place in June.

Vandals who invaded historic St. David's Cemetery on a nocturnal tour of destruction and left behind damages which police estimated 'would total thousands of dollars were the object of a concerted search today.

Bar associations of the State should vigorously oppose the transfer of automobile personal injury cases from the jurisdiction of the courts to a board or commission that would treat them like workmen's compensation cares, Justice William F. Hagarty of the Appellate Devision, Second Department, declared last night at the annual dinner of the Westchester County Bar Association in the Hotel Biltmore.

In recognition of his war record and his "services in the interests of war veterans," Colonel Julius Ochs Adler received a scroll from Newsdealers Post 1,169 of the American Legion at its second annual military ball at the Hotel Center, 108 West Forty-third Street, last night.

One of the less known, but potentially important phases of TVA activity is the campaign of its health section, in cooperation with State and local public health agen??es, to eliminate malaria from the TVA lakes and reservoirs, bring it under control throughout the Southeast, and set an example for its handling elsewhere if "TVA's" eventually are established in other regions of the country.

To simplify its real estate transactions and perhaps eliminate any future criticism of favoritism, the city has adopted a new procedure for leasing space and purchasing property for use of municipal agencies.

DESPITE sporadic labor troubles which have slowed production in various plants during the past week, the impetus of increasing sales carried the output approximately 2,000 units above the previous week for a total of about 66,500 units.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago has been called for May 20, when authorization will be asked by the directors for the issuance of additional mortgage bonds. No definite program has been formulated, the announcement said, because further steps will depend on money-market conditions.

Seven and one-half per cent of Pennsylvania's 10,000,000 population depended upon--the State for assistance during March, the Department of Public Assistance reported today. The State's rolls carried 772,629 persons,, including 605,371 on Unemployment relief; 93,337 obtaining old age assistance; 61,628 granted aid for dependent children, and 11,295 in blind pensions.

Underwriting the health needs of young business women of small income, the Medical Service Club is working to preserve esprit among a gallant group who would not willingly avail themselves of a charity clinic.

On the way to Hawaii from Norfolk by way of Panama, the United States Steel Company's 400-foot freighter Ensley City, with thirty-five officers and men on board, was reported today floundering helplessly at sea with a broken tail-shaft.

Europe this week continued the uncomfortable process of adjusting itself to the dynamic outward pressure of Nazi Germany. It was a "quiet" week with no violent changes except the hammer blow of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's armies against Catalonia and the dramatic counterblow struck by King Carol against the Iron Guard in Rumania.

The Danubian congress which, under the auspices of Fordham University, was to have been held March 31 and which was postponed because of the Austro-German anschluss, will be held from May 6 to May 8, it was announced at the university yesterday.
Indiana University's two-mile relay team set a new national collegiate record of 7 minutes 38.1 seconds today in a quadrangular track meet won by Michigan. The new figure bettered Georgetown

Leslie Hore-Belisha, the first British Cabinet member to visit Rome since Anthony Eden in June, 1935, at the height of the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, called on Premier Mussolini at the Palazzo Venezia this afternoon and conversed with him for forty minutes in the presence of Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano.

Miss Elizabeth Louise Good, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John-Good of this place, was married here this afternoon to Edward Lowndes Rhett, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Rhett of Garden City, in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Advent by the rector, the Rev. Richard D. Pope.

THE object of attack in Henry de Montherlant's new book is, he says, love as women understand it. And on this theme he has written a clear-cut, merciless, provocative novel, hard and brilliant like sharp steel.

IT'S almost- midnight and the bay Windows of our hotel room are wide open. There's a gentle current of air like perfumed balsam. This place is almost too good to be true. Abject platitudes in description, such as paradise on earth, seem perfectly inadequate.
Professor Irvir T. Mohme has been decorated by Chancellor Adolf Hitler with the service cross of the German Eagle, Second Class.
Federal and State conciliators succeeded late today in their efforts to bring truck owners and the American Federation of Labor Teamsters and Chauffeurs Union back to the council table.

Four stakes will be contested during the annual field trial meeting of the Sport and Conservation League to be held on the McNeeley farm in Middleton, N. Y., Friday, Saturday and Sunday. This will be the concluding event for the pointing breeds in the section near New York City.

WHAT is probably the final stamp with its value expressed in an Austrian monetary term, the groschen, is an Anschluss adhesive released in Vienna on April 8 in connection with the plebiscite held two days later. This postal item supplements the German 6-plennig dark green Anschluss stamp described in these columns last Sunday.

In an unusual experiment that proved highly gratifying to the pupils but probably less so to the teachers, New York City school children were allowed to grade their instructors in terms of teaching ability, knowledge of subject, fairness in the classroom and personal characteristics.
New York Pan-Hellenic --Annual tea, Hotel Beekman Tower. New York State Federation of Temple Sisterhoods-Convention, Temple Beth Elohim, Brooklyn.

New Jersey yachtsmen and boating interests are giving their support to three bills in the Legislature, one by Assemblyman Wickham and two by Senator Scott, according to Commissioner Harold L. Jones of Glen Ridge, member of the Board of Commerce and Navigation.

With the final session of the American Association of Collegiate Schools of Business over yesterday and the conference on the problems of higher education in the State of Illinois opening tomorrow, the small city of Urbana, in the midst of the corn prairie 126 miles south of Chicago, has a new disclosure to make to its visitors.
Good food in ample amount im. proves the minds of sick children Dr. I. Newton Kugelmass, New York specialist in children's diseases, reported to the Therapeutic Society at its annual meeting.

British agriculturists, fruit farmers and floriculturists are in despair. The driest Spring in 150 years opened with a freak Summer that brought out flowers over a month before their time and almost ruined the growers under glass.

" The great battle before us now is to preserve the American dollar and its purchasing power from the rosy promises of pump-priming which a few years ago seemed to be so assuring," Harold A. Stonier, executive manager of the American Bankers Association,

AS the Spring tide of transatlantic voyaging moves toward its flood, one of the major lures for those who trip up the gangplanks these days is, as always, the succession of visits to the famous restaurants of the Old World. Tradition still holds that the finest in cuisine lies 3,000 miles east of New York.

The compromise agreement on the two major issues of the 1938 Revenue Revesion Bill appeared acceptable today to most Congressional leaders, although Senator Vandenberg, Michigan Republican, declared that the retention of the undistributed profits tax principle would become an issue in the November elections.

Yale today won its annual Rugby football game from Harvard, 18 to 11, largely through the successful try and three conversions of Hesketh. He was the only Eli to score in the first half, which closed with the count tied at 3-all. Scott's try for the visitors in this chapter was brilliantly executed.
Sharp evidences of a rising demand for fine homes in many of the choice suburban centers of New Jersey were indicated last week in the announcement of several large residential sales.

Does the sudden concentration of strikes indicate that the nation is heading into a wave of labor trouble? That was the question uppermost in the minds of many employers when the headlines flashed word of the strike vote of Buick and Chevrolet union workers in Flint, the disputes in a dozen other Michigan plants,

PORTRAITS OF A LIFETIME. By Jacques- Emile Blanche. Translated and edited by Walter Clement. Introduction by Harley Granville-Barker. With illustrations chiefly from the author's paintings. 305 pp. New York: Coward-McCann, Inc. $4. J. E. BLANCHE has been brushing up against celebrity ever since he was knee high to a grasshopper. Indeed, he is somewhat of a celebrity himself, as painter, as writer, as critic, as teacher. His connections and concerns are cosmopolitan.

One of the chief matters for discussion at the fourth annual Alumnae Leaders Conference of the Associate Alumnae of New Jersey College for Women, which will take place here on Saturday, will be a plan for the reorganization of the Associate Alumnae which will allow for wider representation on the board of directors.

WHILE John C. Wilson's office says no plans will be made until mid-June, there comes a likely sounding report that "Operette," Noel Coward's musical play of Edwardian England, will be trying its luck here next August.
Heavy police reinforcements were rushed to . Piccadilly Circus tonight to break up a sudden, riotous fascist demonstration which snarled traffic at the height of the theatre rush hour.

Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, approved yesterday the model showing the general exterior design of the Bell Telephone System Building at the New York World's Fair in 1939, planned for an exhibition of the latest- developments in telephony.
An open meeting and tea on May 2, at the home of Mrs. Sol M. Stroock of Ossining, will open the celebration of Children's Week by the Westchester County Children's Association.

Four additional national organizations of small business are listed in the second news letter on independent small business, issued by the Division of Applied Exchange of The School of Living, Suffern, N. Y., of which Ernest H. Gaunt is director. The four organizations described comprise Independence, Inc., St. Louis, Mo.;
Lieutenant Governor Victor A. Meyers lost today by a Supreme Court decision his battle to call a special "relief" session of the State Legislature against the wishes of Governor Clarence D. Martin.

After four months of investigation, students in Yale College have established the Yale Community Council, a bureau of twelve who seek to be informed on opportunities for social work throughout the city Under the leadership of David W. Williams, '39, of Washington, Conn.,

LONDON. LEET STREET, which ought to know, thinks the old-fashioned political house party is coming back. Lady Astor's recent series of weekend parties at Cliveden, the palatial Astor home on the Upper Thames, indicates the trend.

The French frano slumped afresh today amid hectic dealings in the foreign exchange market here. At one time it seemed that the rate would touch a new low record against sterling, and it actually reached 166 3/4 francs to the pound, against 167 in March.

Reuben Fine, second in the keen competition for he United States chess championship behind Samuel Reshevsky, the titleholder, defeated Arthur .W. Dake of Portland, Ore., Pacific Coast champion, in the sixteenth and semi-final round in the assembly hall. of the R.C. A. Building yesterday.

The archiepiscopal pallium, made from the wool of lambs and symbolic of centuries-old ecclesiastical prerogatives will be conferred Wednesday on the Most Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, first Archbishop of the newly created Archdiocese of Newark.

A special committee on the Constitutional Convention has been appointed by the Real Property Council of New York, announces Robert Daru, president. The council was formerly known as the Mortgage Council of New York, of which the late M. Morgenthau Jr. was president.

IT is ten years since he died, but not so long, since we visited the workroom where there were so many talks. It was part of a little house and yard on a quiet street in Cambridge, Mass. There was an old table on which he composed, with music paper, in meticulous order, upon it. The very modest furniture, consisting principally of several ramshackle chairs, would hold together.

The annual Spring gambol and ball of the Lambs, theatrical club, was held last night-Pt the WaldorfAstoria. More than 1,000 persons attended the gambol, the receipts from which will be used for the benefit of the Lambs Memorial Relief Fund.

The Detroit Red Wings and Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League battled to a 5-5 tie tonight in their second exhibition game in England. Two fights marked the lively game as the Red Wings came from behind twice to send the game into a scoreless overtime period.

The Kent first crew defeated the M. I. T. sophomore shell by five lengths today in the first race of the season on the Housatonic River. After getting away to a good start, the Kent oarsmen rowed smoothly, with M. I. T. trailing for the whole distance of one mile.

FANTASY AND FUGUE. By Marina Wister. 108 pp. New York: The Macmillian Co. $2. THESE poems by Marina Wister bring a refreshing note of individuality of reaction to objective things, and in the more reflective pieces there is generally something of originality of interpretation.

The steps recently taken by the Treasury and the Federal Reserve authorities to increase the reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System were based upon the theory that increases in bank reserves tend to result in an expansion of outstanding bank credit.

STRUGGLING against the Laocoon coils of Hollywood is a favorite indoor sport among the better people of thatmegalopolis. Whether it's a Fredric March, a Sylvia Sidney, a Walter Connolly, a Franchot Tone, an Elissa Landi or a Wallace Ford, they all have moments of fond nostalgia for the legitimate stage, and return to it for better or for worse-frequently for worse.

The foreign exchange market here yesterday was dull, with activity at a minimum and quotations carried over from abroad. The franc, after opening at 3.02 3/8 cents, up 1/8 point from the previous close, gained slightly and then settled back to close at its opening rate.

Pointing out that hundreds of partially blighted residential neighborhoods have been successfully rehabilitated, Seward H. Mott, chief of the land planning section of the FHA, declares that the service rendered to owners of partially developed subdivisions is equal in importance with the review of plans for new subdivision developments.
