THIS is one of those honest human documents that tell more about its period than some of our most hifalutin' or widest-read literature. It may be more valuable half a century from now than anywhere from a dozen to a gross of average "proletarian novels."
It would be interesting to have Henry Ford cite chapter and verse for his statement that the old Yankee farmers found they could live on a single acre of land.

A report terming "tyranny of State over individual as in fascism" as "most sinister" was adopted today by the Troy Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church. The report, by Jackson Townsend, a Hoosick Falls layman, was made to a united session of ministers and laymen.

Miss Nancy Lyle, Wightman Cup player and daughter of Sir Leonard and Lady Lyle of Greystoke, Canford Cliffs, Bournemouth, was married Wednesday to Captain Philip F. Glover, R. N., son of the late John Bri W. Glover and Mrs. Howard Kingscote of Liphook, Hampshire.

In memory of Amelia Earhart, a one-day commission to fly air mail from Rye to the Newark airport has been issued by the Postoffice Department, it was announced today by Mrs. Theresa Ball, postmistress here. It will be the first time that mail has been flown from Westchester County.

A threat by Police Chief Walter Leibert of Clarkstown Township to arrest the owner of the Cardinal Lunch for violation of the Building Code caused the cancellation of a meeting of the German-American Bund of Rockland County tonight after 150 members of the Bund had entered the restaurant.
The Bronx Board of Trade has been informed that the city will complete the work on the new Westchester Avenue bridge over the Bronx River toward the end of Summer.

ROADCASTING as a performance largely supported by commercial activities goes up and down on the business Index curve. When at the prosperity peak, high-salaried stars of the entertainment world festoon the wave-lengths. Broadcasting booms.

Sponsored by the Department of Parks in cooperation with R. H. Macy Co., Inc., the eleventh seminar annual model sail and motor boat regatta will be held on May 14 of Conservatory Lake, Central Park The event is open to boys and girls 18 years old or younger residing in New York City.

More than 30 per cent of the total expenditures of the Danish Government are now being used for social relief, the aggregate used for that purpose during 1937 being $84,590,000, as compared with $81,400,000 in 1936, the American commercial attache at Copenhagen has reported to the Department of Commerce.

Both faculty members and students at Union College are increasingly reaping benefits. from the system of honorary fellows established by President Dixon Ryan Fox to keep the college in close contact with the "outside world."

Cough his performance sagged toward the close, Sophomore Woell pitched the unbeaten U. nine to its seventh victory ??ay as the Violets conquered Sattan College, 11-8, on the late diamond. It was the Jaspers' setback of the campaign.
Mr. and Mrs. Hazen L. Hoar of Bristol, R. I., formerly of Providence, have announced the engageerta Laura Hoar, to John Theodore Vester of Jerusalem and New York.

THERE has come to climax in the Far East a kind of moral transvaluation which is still only a by product of the war between Japan and China, but will emerge at the end as the principal enduring consequence of the war.

WASHINGTON.--Long envious of the subway that carries Senators in comfort and dispatch between their office building and the Capitol, members of the House have under consideration a plan for a moving sidewalk to connect the House wing Of the Capitol with the two office buildings.

How is tuberculosis actually produced? The medico points to the tuberculosis germ. That is not enough. How does the germ act? Chemically, there is reason to believe. Some experiments made by Drs. Florence R. Sabin and Austin L. Joyner of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research indicate that this is indeed so and that it may be possible both to produce and to check tuberculosis by chemicals alone.
The Insurgent Government today announced a new press law placing newspapers and periodicals under strict Cabinet control. Bureaus were established in each province to enforce the measure.

E. O. Shreve, vice president of the General Electric Company, who stressed the necessity of greater cooperative action in meeting the housing needs of the country at the convention of the American Institute of Architects in New Orleans last week,

In connection with reorganization of the Scott Stamp and Coin Company, as announced last week; it was pointed out yesterday on behalf of the firm that the new set-up involves a separation of the stamp merchandising and publication departments.

MY BROTHER, A. E. HOUSMAN: Personal Recollections, Together With Thirty Hitherto Unpublished Poems. By Laurence Housman. mustrated. 286 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $3. By PETER MONRO JACK IN the two years since his death more has been written about Housman than during his entire lifetime.

Susquehanna University's AllMaster Band Festival will attract 175 young musicians from thirty or more Central Pennsylvania high schools. Percy Grainger will be the guest conductor at the annual festival on the campus May 5, 6 and 7.

Miss Eleanor Sophia Stevens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Tuttle Stevens of this place, was married in the Westhampton Presbyterian Church this afternoon to John Millens Burt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Millens Burt of Forest Hills.
" We are going to fight this decision to the end," Donald Douglas, president of Douglas Aircraft Company, said in reply to the NLRB decision in the C. I. 0. sit-down strike of February, 1937.
WITHOUT as yet the customary ballyhoo attending such events, the Hawaiian Room of- the Hotel Lexington is rapidly nearing its first anniversary on June 21, and therein lies a saga of night clubdom.

A demonstration against the "dictatorial methods" of Dean Tristram Walker Metcalfe, head of Long Island University. was being planned yesterday by members of the United Student Action Committee for the reopening of the institution tomorrow after the Easter holiday.

Facing the huge task of perfecting what, subject to the voters' approval at the general election next November, will be the fifth Constitution under which the people of New York have lived since the State became a free Commonwealth, the 1938 Constitutional Convention this week
A brief political quarrel which flared up between King Farouk and Premier Mohammed Mahmoud Pasha over Cabinet appointments ended today in the Premier winning his point.

None of the larger agreements which the British Government has made or seeks to make in the effort for European appeasement will give greater satisfaction to English-speaking people everywhere than the accord with Ireland.

" Foam" glass is the latest development in acoustical insulation for keeping unwanted noise and sound from entering rooms and buildings, as disclosed in a patent (No. 2,114,546) granted to Games Slayter of Newark, Ohio.
Miss Roberta Ray Chace, daughter of -Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Charles Chace of New York and Mystic, Conn was married to Gustav George Freygang 3d of 'Philadelphia yesterday afternoon at the Plaza.

With the object of providing the home builder with a better plumbing system, a program of research in piping design and installation and the operation of plumbing fixtures is under way at the institute of hydraulic research at the State University of Iowa.
After almost two full years, Spain's civil war seems to be coming to an end. The "quick showdown" that both sides had expected at the opening of the conflict became, instead, a long terror.
The reported confession of Melvin H. Gibbon, 27-year-old New York airman, that
German diplomats are to be put in uniforms. The cut and insignia will exclude any chance of mistaking the government that they represent.

Austria's Nazi chieftains today started a purge of proscribed "non-Aryan" volumes in the Austrian National Library, ranked among the world's finest. Lists were sent to the chief librarian of books to be removed and burned from among the 1,200,000 volumes housed in the magnificent Hofburg, once home of the imperial Habsburgs.

The marriage of Miss Madeleine Adele Pascual, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Vincent Pascual of Brooklyn and Bellport, L. I., to Arthur Scranton Gibbons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melville G. Gibbons of Tampa, Fla., took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 108 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn.
Pennsylvania opened its sixty-first intercollegiate rowing season by defeating Manhattan in all four races on the wind-swept Schuylkill River course today. Rough water handicapped the oarsmen.

With educators directing their teaching toward the individual's development in the family setting and in relation to the community home economics is attaining a new importance not only as a field of interest for girls and women, but in the education of boys and men, Mrs. Kathryn VanAken Burns, president of the American Home Economics Association, said yesterday.
A man describing himself as Charles Norris Veaoh, Emperor of the Realm of Tangible Dynamics, somewhere in-the South Seas beyond the dimensions of the earth, called today at the Treasury.

A NEW type flying boat, revolutionary in its smallness, recently underwent successful tests at a bay near here. The boat looks like a miniature China Clipper except that it has only one engine. It carries two persons.

The staff of the psychiatric department of Bellevue Hospital unanimously adopted yesterday a resolution protesting against the charge made last Tuesday by Senator John J. McNaboe, chairman of the Legislative Committee on Law Enforcement, that the department was a "cesspool of inefficiency."

The free public library is as American as corn on the cob. The trouble seems to be that this fact has not yet been fully realized. Even in such great and wealthy cities as New York.and Chicago the library has an uphill fight to get enough new books and replace old books as they wear out.
When Premier Fumimaro Konoye returned to his post on Thursday after a twentyday illness the nation heaved a sigh of content and a huge gas balloon of political speculation at once collapsed.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list of holders of license for service as teacher of business training in junior high school, as of April 20, 1938, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:
Andover Academy's Ted Harrison beat Joe Wood Jr. of the Yale freshmen, 1--0, in a pitching duel today. Each made fourteen strikeouts, with the Yale cubs getting four hits and Andover five.

THE ADMINISTRATION OF JUSTICE FROM HOMER TO ARISTOTLE. Volume II. By Robert J. Bonner and Gertrude Smith. of. Chicago, Ill.: The University of Chicago Press. $3.50. A study of legal practice and procedure of this period.
The Faucett Aviation Company, one of the oldest independent airlines in Latin America, will take over the local operations of Aerovias Peruanas, a subsidiary of Pan-American Grace Airways.

Led by Joe Vigna, who annexed two individual titles, the Twentythird Street Branch won team honors in the New York City Y. M. C. A. gymnastic championships in the gymnasium of the victors last night. The home squad rolled up 20 points to lead the Flushing branch by a three-point margin.

ALEXANDER--Mr. and Mrs.- Irving Alexander (Edith Ann Levy) joyfully announce the arrival of Linda's brother on April 19 at the Sydenham Hospital. APPEL--Mr. and Mrs. Alfred, a daughter, Elizabeth, April 20. Doctors Hospital.

Sydenham Hospital will give, a dinner tonight-at the Hotel. Waldorf-Astoria to raise money to meet the - hospital's 1937 deficit- for free care to the needy sick. There will be a charge of $25 a plate and more than 500 persons are expected to attend.

" JEFFERIES' ENGLAND" (Harper Brothers, $3) will come as a release to city dwellers at this season. It will push back the walls of their captivity and enable them to breathe keen air cleansed by the touch of salt water, to see in imagination the first gilding of willow wands,

Elizabeth Wagner, 22 years old, confessed yesterday that she had poisoned two brothers, Charles, 14, and Henry, 21, in the home at 25-32 Twenty-first Street, Astoria, Queens, they had inherited from their paternal grandmother.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick is conducting a survey of the daily turnover of betting and of the business methods of the bookmakers at the Jamaica and Aqueduct race tracks as a possible source of new revenue for emergency relief, it was learned yesterday.

The Woonsocket Association of Manufacturers announced today that it was considering reducing wages in textile plants here, effective May 2, with the hope that lower operating costs would stimulate activity and increase employment in the industry. The new wage scale will be announced next week.
Mohandas K. Gandhi, who has led India's millions along the troublesome road toward political autonomy, has predicted his own early death.

A series of ceremonies on Tuesday, beginning with the dedication of the Cardinal Hayes Library and closing with the awarding of four honorary degrees, will mark the celebration of the seventy-fifthanniversary of Manhattan College and the golden jubilee of the graduation of Cardinal Hayes.

Enactment of State legislation making compulsory the Torrens system of land title registration, a system whereby title searches are made by State agencies, likely would be harmful to the "State and the public," Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, said yesterday.

Director, American Institute of Public Opinion DURING the last three years the American Institute of Public Opinion has interviewed hundreds of thousands of American voters, composing a true cross-section of the population in all walks of life.

Penn State defeated Army at golf today on the links of the Storm King Golf Club at Cornwall, 6 to 3. The summaries: Twosomes-Stevens, -Penn State, defeated Lynch, 3 and 2; Mahaffy, Penn State, defeated Johnson, 3 and 2; Clifford, Army, defeated Gross, 4 'and 3: Hebda, Penn State, defeated Garrett, 3 and 2; Miller, Penn State, defeated Penny, l up; Moore, Army, defeated. Clingsmith, 4 and 3.

The marriage of Miss Edith Adelaide Quinlan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Quinlan of Scars dale, N. Y., to Edson Bly Snow, soh of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Edson Snow of New York and Jamestown, N. Y., took place here yesterday afternoon at the Plaza.

Ben Howe, chairman of the City Fusion party, joined yesterday in criticism of the speech of John R. Davies accepting re-election as president of the National Republican Club, in which Mr. Davies declared against any further alliance with Socialist, Communist and other groups as in last year's Fusion movement to re-elect Mayor La Guardia.

Providence College.and C. C. N. Y. engaged in a free-hitting game at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday and after. three hours and sixteen minutei' of play the Friars prevailed by 16--11 for their second victory in as many starts during their metropolitan tour.
Columbia's tennis team, Eastern intercollegiate indoor champion, scored its fifth consecutive triumph by defeating Pennsylvania, 5 to 4, on the South Field courts yesterday.

A larger number of firms are preparing separate midsummer dress lines this year than in any of the past five years, Morris Kolchin, executive director of the Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc., declared yesterday.

A group of conservative ministers, led by the Rev. Christian F. Reisner, pastor of Broadway Temple, gained control yesterday afternoon of a stormy session of laymen and clergymen of the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church and forced the tabling or amendment of many of the liberal sections of the report of the State of the Country and Social Service Commission.

THE national defense plan for an independent Philippines in 1946 presumes an air corps of sufficient speed and sustained striking power to deliver a crippling blow at an approaching naval enemy equipped to land troops.

Forty years ago on Monday the United States declared war on Spain and embarked on a policy that involved her heavily in the Far East. From April 25, 1898, dates the policy that brought us the Philippines, Puerto Rico and Guam and stretched our lines of interest far to the east.

More than half the 8,000 jobless young men and women who applied for aid to private non-profit vocational guidance agencies in the last year found permanent jobs with their assistance, the vocational guidance committee of the Welfare Council reported yesterday. The report was submitted to the Greater New York Fund, which next month will appeal for $10,000,000 to supplement the finances of private welfare and health organizations.
OPERA, according to its historians. is now 340 years old. Of the making of many books about it there is no end. But here is a book about opera that makes a fresh approach to its subject.

There were several interesting features in the markets fast week. Spurred by the injection of the erstwhile desterilized gold into the credit stream and the change in bank reserve requirements, trading in United States Government bonds was the heaviest in nearly a year and all issues touched new highs for 1938 or longer.
" Dodsworth" will be succeeded at the Palace on Tuesday by the long-heralded "Countess Maritza," a new version of the Hungarian musical comedy by Emmerich Kalman.

The Hershey Chocolate Corporation, after a long period of strife with the Committee for Industrial Organization, agreed here. today before the National Labor Relations Board to withdraw recognition of and "disestablish" the Independent Chocolate Workers Union, a reported company union.
A SERIES of educational broadcasts, described as "embodying a new concept of learning through radio," has been announced by the Adult Education Board of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

With the exception of the overture to Weber's "Der Freischuetz" all the numbers presented at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli in Carnegie Hall, consisted of modern compositions.

WASHINGTON. IN eagerness the nation's philatelists await tomorrow and the newest offering of Postmaster General Farley, who has brought the Dexter Fellowes touch to the stamp business. That offering is a one-cent green gummed label decorated with the bust of General Washington in right profile.

WASHINGTON.--Including over head, it costs Uncle Sam $8,458 annually for each midshipman's education at the United States Naval Academy. According to estimates recently placed before the House Appropriations Committee,

The American team of Al Crossley and Jimmy Walthour came from behind in a last-hour surge tonight to win Pittsburgh's six-day bicycle race. The winners clinched the title by taking eleven of the last twentyseven sprints.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Monteith of 1,225 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Inez Rita Montieth, to George Brenton Leddy, son of Mrs. Mark Leddy of this city and the late Mr. Leddy.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. White of Larchmont, N. Y., have announced the engagements of their daughters, Miss Irene Dolores White to Francis Leigh Connors of Detroit and Miss Patricia Theres to Everett Le Moult of Larchmont.

The New York Rapid Transit Corporation and the Brooklyn Queens Transit Corporation told the Supreme Court today that New York City "politics" was responsible for enactment of a 3 per cent gross income tax on utilities to aid the unemployed.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Rudolf Brown of this city, formerly of Short Hills, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Hughes Brown, to John Warner Field of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Field of Bridgeport, Conn.
An important issue will soon be laid before Congress by President Roosevelt in a message calling for the taxation of income from government securities.

Eight new records flashed from the gloomy setting of the sixteenth annual Kansas relays today, but missing from the list was a mile mark expected to be dug up by the spiked shoes of Glenn Cunningham, Archie San Romani, Don Lash or Gene Venzke.

THE new art of finger painting presents such unlimited possibilities that it is transforming blase modern adults into enthusiastic hobby-enthusiasts. The reason for the growing popularity of finger painting as a hobby is perhaps to be found in the fact that its devotees consider it more a medium of artistic self-expression than a hobby like stamp collecting.

TOMMY RIGGS, whose vocal chords harbor that popular little radio star "Betty Lou," has a difficult time explaining his double identity to inquisitive people who write after hearing the act on the Vallee show, on which he has been appearing for thirty-eight weeks.

Hugh Gingras of Rockledge, Fla., bettered his own world speed record for four-liter hydroplanes today with an officially timed dash at 73.701 miles an hour. He set the old mark of 73.544 miles an hour here last March 21. Gingras drove the Gray Goose, owned by Jerry Cannon of New Rochelle, N. Y., in which. he the old mark.
Bourbon King, Hal Price Headley's bay colt, flashed to prominence as a Kentucky Derby candidate today with a smashing victory in the $15,000 added Chesapeake Stakes at odds of more than 8 to 1.

A bill broadening the definition of army officers eligible for duty with the general staff was signed by President Roosevelt today. Under the law previously in effect only officers actually in command of combatant troops were eligible for general staff duty.

The British Government's "serious misgivings" regarding Egypt's increased tariffs on cotton piece goods and yarns were expressed in a note handed to the Egyptian Government at the British Embassy today.

President Getulio Vargas today definitely lifted the veil of reticence he had maintained since Nov. 10, 1937, when he set up the new regime, and revealed to more than forty Brazilian and foreign correspondents the administrative program that the government wishes to achieve and what it aims to accomplish in the way of economic reconstruction.
Winston Guest scored seven goals tonight to lead his New York Optimists to a 12-7 victory over the New York Athletic Club and the open championship of the national indoor polo tournament.

Miss. Lucretia Van Horn, daughter of Brig. Gen. Robert Osborn Van Horn, U. S. A., and Mrs. Van Horn of Fort McPherson, Ga., was married here this afternoon in All Saints Episcopal Church to Lieutenant James Yeates Adams, U. S. A., son of Colonel Emory S. Adams, U. S. A., and Mrs. Adams, also of Fort McPherson.

ROLLING toward Louisville early next month will be dozens of special trains and more than a score of private cars carrying thousands to Churchill Downs for the sixty-fourth running of the Kentucky Derby on May 7.
The secret court of espionage and high treason today sentenced four men to death, three of them soldiers charged with attempting to desert to France and the fourth- a robber.
An interesting little booklet, "A Fishing Directory of New York State," has just been published by the Conservation Department, and should prove of great value to the New York angler.

Pierce Moore, former NEW YORK TIMES pressman, died in the United States Veterans Hospital here today. He was 41 years old and had been in the hospital since April 4. He enlisted in the army on June 6, 1916, and was discharged on April 7, 1919.

UNFORTUNATELY for our joust with Howard Dietz last Sunday, we were unable to bring "Test Pilot" and "To the Victor" into the arena with us. But they so perfectly illustrate the points we raised in contrasting foreign films with Hollywood's that we cannot resist introducing them now.
Mrs. Henry R. Caraway will end her third term as president of the Women's National Republican Club with the annual meeting on Thursday at 2 P. M. at the clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Six delegates will represent the New York branch of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom when the annual convention opens in Minneapolis on Friday. Mrs. Alfred C. Intemann of New York City will head the delegation. Meetings will continue through Saturday, Sunday and Monday.

Nearly nine hundred students and their friends will attend the "Faculty Frolics" of the College of Mount St. Vincent, in Riverdale, on Wednesday. Faculty members will entertain with a program of skits, songs, dances. and melodrama in the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium.

Child deportees from Austria-orphans of those who have committed suicide or have been carried off to an unknown fate since the German annexation-are reported arriving at the Czechoslovak frontier station of Breclay.

Patrolman Joseph Allen, a member of the Police Department for more than ten years, was dismissed by Commissioner Valentine yesterday on charges related to the Queens ambulance-chasing racket. Allen, attached to the Ozone Park Precinct, was accused of accepting fees of $3 to $5 for recommending

Judge John J. Freschi of General Sessions handed down a decision yesterday denying a motion of counsel for a man awaiting trial on a first-degree murder indictment, in the hold-up slaying of a policeman, for a fingerprint examination of a pistol in the possession of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey that is suspected of having been used in the shooting.

The international scope of the Scandinavian Gold Cup six-meter yachting series next August was extended yesterday when it became known that two more nations, Finland and Sweden, had entered the picture by filing challenges with the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Scoville Clarke, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. T. Wood Clarke of this city, to Edward Hartigan O'Hara of New York and Norwich, N. Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred H. O'Hara of Norwich, took place here this afternoon in St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

Herman N. Matzen, sculptor, who executed many public monuments, most of which are to be seen in Cleveland, died here late last night after a brief illness. Born in Denmark seventy-six years ago, he had lived in the United States since boyhood.

French authorities arrested 135 more Neodestour leaders today in a drive to break up the nationalist group which has been ordered dissolved. Those taken into custody included Tahar Sfar, who was described as the last of the party leaders at liberty.
The validity of an order of Mayor La Guardia to his department heads not to reinstate dismissed employes without his consent was challenged in a suit filed yesterday in the Supreme Court.

The following information is from a competent informant who has just come from Austria: More than 3,000 Jews in the province of Burgenland were expelled from their homes last week by local Nazi organizations.
One thousand person attended a reception last night at the Hitchcock Memorial Church here in celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the church and the work in Scarsdale of the Rev. Dr. George

Doubts as to whether second quarter business will be perceptibly benefited by the "pump-priming" program are expressed in a survey of trends in major industries by Fenner Beane, Stock Exchange members.
Co-Sport turned in the fastest Derby workout of the season today, but it stood just long enough for Stagehand and The Chief to get out on the track.

Each successive wave of increase a the percentage of homes ownerccupied in the United States has een matched with an increase in he proportion of the country's total savings Investment which was set side for home financing, points out he United States Building and joan League.

Near Hamburg is Bad Bramatadt, much frequented by sufferers from rheumatism. In Bramstadt lives Dr. Paulus, who thinks that his rheumatic patients will do better if they promenade on elastic ground. At his suggestion a sidewalk has been built, about 100 yards long, which takes the jar out of walking.

A judgment embodying a penalty of more than $5,000,000 for failure to pay $15,000 in stock transfer taxes was filed yesterday by Attorney General Bennett with the New York County Clerk for collection from A. Dudley Phelps, a securities broker of 29 Broadway.

Titles on two different fronts. were at stake in Scottish soccer today but only one was decided. A disappointed crowd of 78,000 saw Kilmarnock and East Fife battle to a 1-1 tie in the cup final at Hampden Park, while Celtic clinched its nineteenth league championship at Paisley by defeating St. Mirren, 3-1.
The annual Spring Washington Square Outdoor Art Show will be opened on Friday, May 13, it was announced yesterday. The show will continue until May 22 and this Spring prizes totaling $200

THE engagement by Stadium Concerts, Inc., of two young conductors--Massimo Freccia of Italy and Macklin Marrow of this country--who will make their stadium debuts during the coming Summer season will surprise no one who has followed the organization's practice in the last decade or so.

Behind the effective pitching of the veteran southpaw, Lefty Grove, the Red Sox today ruined the Athletics' home opening by winning, 10 to 4, before a crowd of 10,895. Within five minutes after Governor George Earle tossed out the opening ball the slugging Red Sox chased Edgar Smith from the mound to give Grove a three-run lead on Joe Vosmik's double,

Miss Madeline Negreen, daughter of Mrs. Joseph F. Negreen of Forest Hills, was married yesterday morning to Henry Charles Kessler Jr. of York, Pa., in the Church of St. Nicholas of Tolentine, Flushing.

James Breath, who retired in 1924 as general manager of the Seaboard branch of the New York Life Insurance Company at 217 Broadway, died yesterday at his residence, Hudson View Gardens, 183d Street and Pinehurst Avenue, at the age of 83. No members of his immediate family survive.

AT the break of watery dawns for over a century the Fulton Fish Market has been conducting its noisy business at Fulton Street and the East River. An old-timer that has served the city for almost 300 years in different waterfront locations, it is stubbornly oldfashioned.

Behind the brilliant pitching of Claude (Duke) Walck the Montclair State Teachers College vanquished Panzer College of East Orange, 10 to 4, today. Waleck allowed only seven hits, striking out ten and walking two. The Montclair Teachers pounded two Panzer hurlers

From its flexibility and elasticity Dr. Eugene Guth of the University of Notre Dame infers that rubber is composed of curved molecules. He outlined his hypothesis before the American Chemical Society at Detroit recently.
MANY of the facets of the highway Safety Problem were turned to the light during the ninth annual Convention of the Greater New York Safety Council in session here last week.

Mrs. Mabel M. Bowes discovered nearly $5,000 in an unclaimed Canadian National Express package which she bought last week for $1. The money was tucked in the toe of one of the hiking boots which she bought.

The many personal friends of Mrs. Louise Beebe Wilder and the host of gardeners who knew her through her extensive and always delightful writings on horticulture were grieved to learn of her death last Wednesday in New York. For twoscore years Mrs. Wilder had filled a unique niche in American

At a total cost to the four responsible agencies of considerably more than $1,500,000, the New York World's Fair of 1939 is being provided with a water gateway and boat basin where three excursion steamers and as many as 150 small pleasure craft can moor at one time.

The new building of The Cloisters, a branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art devoted to medieval art, is to be open to the public soon. For several years visitors at Fort Tryon Park, Washington Heights, have watched the construction of the Romanesque-Gothic building, which is a gift to the museum by John D. Rockefeller Jr.

Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association, made public yesterday a letter sent to all members of the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives, urging them to vote against the Wages and Hours bill as reported by the House Labor Committee.

Four new types of galactic systems, each consisting of tens of thousands of galaxies, giving the first faint outlines of the all-embracing universe, were described today before the an nual meeting of the American Philosophical Society by Professor Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard University Observatory.

William Sturgis Linnekin, senior partner of the real estate firm of Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc., of New York for more than forty years, died last night in the North Country Community Hospital at Glen Cove of pneumonia. His age was 62.

Miss Laura Christina Ekengren, daughter of Mme. Wilhelm A. F. Ekengren and the late Minister of Sweden to the United States, was married today to Richard Hays Hawkins, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hays, Hawkins of Pittsburgh and a grandson of the late James McCrea, one-time president of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Three concerts by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, two conducted by Eugene Ormandy, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, and one by Jose Iturbi, pianistconductor, will be given at the second annual Silvermine (Conn.) Guild Symphonic Festival, Aug. 18 to 21, it was announced after a meeting of the festival association.

In keeping with its policy of individual attention to. students Mount Holyoke College is developing a study clinic, designed primarily to assist freshmen who find difficulty in adjusting themselves to new tasks and responsibilities.
Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Aronson of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Aileen Aronso., to Peter Meyer, son of Mrs. Otto-Meyer of Scarsdale and the late Mr. Meyer.
The outdoor training season opened here today with the arrival of more than 200 reserve officers, who will participate in a mimic battle for possession of the supply base tomorrow.

With airplane and engine orders already on hand totaling more than $150,000,000, and tentative orders provided in pending Army and Navy Bills, plus the increasing demand for airplanes abroad, the United States aviation manufacturing industry has prospects of reaching production capacity this year, according to a review of company reports and an industrial study by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. August Egerer of Kensington, this place, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Claire Egerer, to Michael Edward Kuh, Son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kuh, also of Great Neck.

Mrs. Ferruccio Vitale of 17 East Ninety-sixth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nina Vitale, to Leonard Brooks Elms, son of Mrs. Leonard E. Elms of East Orange, N. J., and the late Mr. Elms.
The Independent Artists showed pride yesterday as they prepared for their tweny-second annual exhibition in Grand Central Palace.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish.

Mr. and Mrs. Colin F. Macdonald of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabel Dick Macdonald, to Lawrence A. Fernsworth. The announcement was made at a tea given here yesterday by Mrs. Theodore B. Stubbs and Miss Catherine Stubbs.
A large amount of activity in the residential field was reported yesterday by two governmental agencies having interest in housing developments.

Miss Margaret Frances Roosevelt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Lay Roosevelt of this city, was married to George Frederick Mullen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Mullen of New Haven, in St. Peter's Episcopal Church here this afternoon.

The thirty-six leading bridge masters of the country started play yesterday afternoon at the Park Central Hotel for the individual master's championship and the Steiner Trophy. B. Jay Becker is the defending champion.

A demonstration of recent advances in the science of. regional anesthesia was given at Mount Alto Veterans' Hospital here today, incident to the annual meeting of the Post-Grad uate Association of Regional

CONGRATULATIONS are in order more or less all around over the healing of the breach in the Ballet Russe, which will unite Leonide Massine and his newly organized company now playing in Monte Carlo with the de Basil Ballet Russe.

A memorial to Amelia Earhart in the form of a scholarship was unanimously endorsed yesterday afternoon at a meeting of District Three of Zonta International at the Hotel Roosevelt, Zonta is an organization of executive business and professional women and Miss Earhart was a member.

An eight-year experiment in cooperative housing, designed to lighten the financial burden of needy students of high scholarship and character, is considered so successful by Massachusetts Institute of Technology officials that, as a result, the M. I. T. student house will move into a new and larger home in the Fall.

We print on this page today a letter from Arthur A. Ballantine, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, criticizing the recent proposal by David Cushman Coyle and other writers that the Government's statements, following the practice of business corporations, should separate "investment" from its "spending" and put the former down as "assets."

Wheat futures on the Board of Trade here declined around 1 cent a bushel early today as the result of a forecast for rain over the greater part of the leading producing States at the week-end and a report from the Bureau of Economics of the Department of Agriculture predicting an Winter wheat crop of 750,000,

Under the direction of Charles A. Ward, who will make his debut as an orchestral and choral conductor, Westchester will hear for the first time on Saturday night the recently organized Westchester Bach Society at a benefit concert in Daniel Webster School, here. Miss Leonora Gorton is secretary of the society.

Nettled by the departure of a British air mission to purchase American-built war planes, British operators and manufacturers are flooding the newspapers with charges that their work has been snarled by the Air Ministry's "muddle and delays."

The Friday Assemblies, an annual series of subscription dances which have been conducted since 1926, are now being planned for the season of 1938-39. The directing commniittee has announced that several changes will be effected for the new series.

The colonial and early Federal furnishings of Gadsby's Tavern at Alexandria, Va., which is reputed to have numbered George Washington, Lafayette and John Paul Jones among its guests, were sold yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries for $11,037.

Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator, and about twenty city Commissioners and officials conferred yesterday at City Hall regarding the impending changes in rules governing whitecollar projects.

THE LONELY DEBATE. By Houston Peterson. 310 pp. New York: Reynal Hitchcock. $2.75. EVERY now and then one comes across a critical work with a novelty of approach, an incisiveness of manner and a persuasiveness of subject-matter which sets it off instantly from the rank and file;

Alex Rose, State executive secretary of the American Labor party, yesterday characterized the attack made by State Senator John J. McNaboe upon Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti and himself as "ravings."
Seven persons today were reported killed and many injured in clashes between Christians and Moslems in the Djezireh region of Eastern Syria.
James F. Egan, Public Administrator, announced yesterday that James P. Blue, who had served that department as chief clerk for more than fifteen years, will become assistant public administrator,

More than six thousand musicians on the WPA's Federal Music Project rolls will take part during the week of May 1 to 7 in National Music Week programs in forty-two States. There will be 123 symphony and concert orchestras, seventy bands, twenty-one chamber-music ensembles and twenty-nine opera and choral groups, all composed of persons on relief.

A new arrangement of Shakespeare, containing many of the poet's greatest scenes and charac ters and requiring two evenings to perform, will be produced by Orson Welles, director of the Mercury Theatre, under the title of "The Five Kings."

Planting time having come on with a rush, the home gardener finds several duties pressing for attention. He is apt to go at them hastily, without due deliberation. His redesigning, provision of fresh effects and transplanting generally are likely to be unsatisfactory unless -he checks' his eagerness and proceeds with cautious forethought.

An effort will be made this week, it was learned yesterday, to rescue the Continental Securities Corporation from bankruptcy through filing of a suit for approximately $3,000,000 on charges that the investment trust was "milked" of that sum.
The new Strength Through Joy vacation cruiser Wilhelm Gustloff is a ship of sadness today with a full list of vacationing workers as passengers.

Beethoven's Ninth symphony, musical apotheosis of the imperishable ideal of human brotherhood, with its final chorus chanting the lines from Schiller's "Ode to Joy," has been chosen as the one fitting climax of the pre-view festival program of the New York World's Fair, to be heard in the completed Administration Building of the Fair next Sunday evening, May 1.

Dr. N. P. Neilson of Stanford University became president of the American Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation today. Other new officers announced by the governing board to the closing general session of the association's forty-third annual convention here included Dr. Dorothy B. Nyswander of New York, vice president for the health section, and Grover W. Mueller of Philadelphia, vice president for the physical education section.

Marching to the French military song "Sambre et Meuse," members of the Old Guard, the city's oldest military organization, passed in review yesterday at City Hall Plaza before Colonel Edward Havemeyer Snyder, re-elected commander for the twenty-first year, a delegation from the Grand Army of the Republic, National Guard and army officers.
The New York Stock Exchange has been notified by the Anchor Hocking Glass Corporation of a proposed increase in its authorized common stock from 1,000,000 to 1,500,000 shares.

The tall apartment building at 895 Park Avenue, corner of Seventyninth Street, is now fully rented, according to Douglas L. Elliman Co., agents. The building contains suites of eleven to fifteen rooms.

The former Philadelphia plant of the David Lupton Company, at Tulip Street, Alegheny Avenue and Westmoreland Street, has been sold in an all-cash deal to the Fair Shopping Center, Inc., through Frank G. Binswanger, Inc., broker.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has assembled a History of the Recorded Word, a permanent collection showing the progress of that word from the dawn of writing to the present day. The exhibition, installed in a special museum in the Times Annex, 229 West Forty-third Street, will be opened to the public tomorrow.

S0NS AND DAUGHTERS. By I. Compton-Burnett. 320 pp. New York: W. W. Norton Co. $2.50. IN English fiction George Bernard Shaw-itis has apparently become a recurrent disease. But while it is continually breaking out afresh, it seems to have chosen one especial human relationship as its favorite point of attack; that which exists between parents and children.
Thousands of mutilated World War veterans--men whose faces were disfigured by bullets or shrapnel-followed the body of their leader, Colonel Yves Picot, through the city today in a funeral parade.

Another season of spectacular International speed-boat regattas seems indicated, according to plans made at the International Motor Yachting Union headquarters in Brussels and relayed yesterday to American drivers through George W. Sutton Jr., former president of the American Power Boat Association and now chairman of its International Affairs Committee.

WAY OUT WEST: Ned Hillyard lives near Pomerene, Ariz. Folks near by say he's one of the best cowboys in that part of the country. He's 100 years old, or so he claims. Last week the Department of the Interior granted him a three-year grazing lease on the public domain.

PARIS.-The American reader under the impression that France is in a turmoil of political, social and labor conflicts might be somewhat surprised if he could drop down in Paris and find himself at the Lunatics' Ball.

Because they are less influencedby financial sentiment and political developments than big organizations and in order to improve their competitive position,. small and medium-size companies in most lines of business are launching programs of modernization,

THE vanguard of vacationing America already is on the move, lured by flowering redbud and dogwood in the East and by the last of the Winter sports in the Western national parks. Judging by pre-season reports, last year's amazing record of 15,000,000 visitors to the various units of the Federal park system (50 per cent over 1936) is destined to be far exceeded.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in relatively small volume, consisting largely of small lots of foreign securities. Payment dates were nearly all for later months, but there were a few small amounts of municipal securities added to the list for payment this month.

Admiral Farragut Academy conquered St. Peter's High of New Brunswick, N. J., today in a dual track meet, 49 to 22, and made a 5-to-0 sweep of a tennis match. In tennis, Gary beat Barr, 2-6, 6-1, 6-1; Reeve downed Harkin, 3-6, 6-3. 7-5;
Supply contracts valued at $2,133,973 were awarded in the week ended on April 21 by twelve Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

Fifty-two real estate men who have completed the second annual course in real estate appraising recently conducted at New York University jointly by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers and the university's Division of General Education will receive certificates Wednesday at a dinner at the Hotel Belmont Plaza in honor of the faculty of the course.
A consent judgment f or $2,160 against Lenore Ulrich of 254 West Seventy-fifth Street, actress, was entered yesterday in the New York County Clerk's office, Supreme Court Building.

Fuller L. Austin, 46, Superintendent of Public Schools here since June, was found dead in the garage at the rear of his home, South Main Street, at 7:30 o'clock today. Death was caused by inhalation of carbon monoxide, according to Medical Examiner W. D. Hoffecker.

Miss Hester Marie Laning, daughter of Rear Admiral Harris Laning of the United States Naval Home and of Mrs. Laning, was married this afternoon in St. James Church to Dr. Dickinson Sergeant Pepper of this city, son of Dr. William Pepper of Melrose Park and of the late Mrs. Pepper.

A LITTLE-KNOWN legend dating from the era before the Spanish conquistadors vanquished the peoples of eastern and southern South 'America will be given philatelic significance when Colombian Republic shortly releases a series of stamps commemorating the founding of Bogota, the republic's capital city, by Gonzalo Jimenez de Quesada, four centuries ago.
Problems of consumer relations will engage the attention of the women's advertising clubs at their second Eastern Conference on Saturday and Sunday, opening with luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore.

Annual communion breakfast of the New York Fire Department Holy Name Society, Hotel Astor, 8:15 A. M. Speakers: Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, the Rev. Patrick F. O'Connor, the Rev. Joseph A. Daly, John F. Ryan, John J. McCarthy.

Hilary Holmes of Princeton, Ind., a junior at Columbia College, has been elected president of the college debate council for 1938-39, it was announced yesterday. Charles H. Schneer of fount Vernon, N. Y., a sophomore, is the new manager of the group.
THOUGH this town is off the beaten path, it has become a popular Summer rendezvous. The town has no more than 250 year-around residents. But when Summer comes in the population numers about 1,000.

WASHINGTON: TELEVISION fans would always know the exact time while viewing a tele-broadcast according to the invention of a "television time system" for which a patent (No. 2,114,500) has been granted to Alexander McLean Nicolson of New York.
Treasury experts ended their search today for more revenue to meet heavily increased rearmament and other costs in the fiscal year which began April 1.

Only seven out of sixty-five divisions of local department stores scored sales increases in March, while fifty-five sections had inventories on hand ranging up to 33 per cent under the same month a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The sales showing was affected by the later date of Easter this year.

THIS may not square with the big dictionary but a big dictionary lugged on the sports field Would be about as range a sight as a big batting cage installed in a public library. In defiance of the lexicographers, therefore the following definitions are set forth:

NEW ROADS, La. - Almost forgotten for seventy-seven years, James Ryder Randall, author of the verses of that stirring war song of the Confederacy, "Maryland, My Maryland," will be honored in Louisiana for the first time when a bronze tablet is.dedicated on Tuesday in front of the oak he made famous.

At a special meeting yesterday of the directors of the Northern States Power Company of Wisconsin, a unit in the Standard Gas and Electric Company system, E. H. Cotton, J. S. McMillen, Albert Smith and J. G. Felton were elected to the board to fill vacancies caused by the resignations of H. E. Young, Henry Grenacher, T. D. Crocker and J. J. Molyneaux.

The engagement of Miss Mary Janet Kraus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Richard Kraus of Cleveland Heights, to Clark Tryon, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Tryon of South Orange, N. J., has been announced by her parents.
That portion of the United States Navy that is propelled by racing sweeps has yet to take the wash of another boat as the college rowing season moves past its second weekend of competition.

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred L. Fawcett of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Fawcett, to William Elder Robertson, son of Mrs. John L. Robertson of Baltimore and the late Dr. Robertsor.

THE highland snow in the Rockies is melting now and the cowhands of the ranch country are patching up horses and saddles in anticipation of the biggest flock of Summer dudes since dude ranching began half a century ago.

Mr. and Mrs. John Hodgins of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Georgina Hodgins, to Robert Avery Whitney, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Boardman Whitney of New Brunswick.

Miss Margaret Macomb Simmons, a granddaughter of the late Admiral David P. Macomb, was married here this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church to Dudley Guilmette, son of Charles E. Guilmette of Yonkers and the late Mrs. Guilmette.

Jesse James, popular light-heavyweight from Los Angeles, will meet Kimon Kudo, Japanese ju-jitsu expert, in the feature wrestling attraction at the Hippodrome tomorrow might. James will substitute for Jim Londos, who withdrew yesterday because of an injured left leg.

Mrs. Ethel Pangborn Kepple of 175 West Seventy-third Street, New York, widow of Ernest P. Kepple, for many years Supreme Court reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES, died this afternoon in the Yonkers General Hospital of heart disease after an illness of ten days. She was 57 years old.

HYMAN--STOLLER--Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Stoller, 131 Riversid Drive, announce the marriage of their daughter, Lucille, to Mr. Nathan Edward Hyman, son of Mrs. Sadie Hyman of this city, Saturday, April 23.

ASCHHEIM-Amelia, widow of Alexander and devoted mother of Joseph H. Funeral services at the West End Funeral Chapel, 200 West 91st St., today at 10:30 A. M. BASS--Samuel A., beloved husband of Sophie and father of Irving and Harvey Bass Services at Rosenstock's, 138 Norfolk St., Sunday, 10 A. M.

Myers Y. Cooper, former Governor of Ohio, explained the beneficial results of the real estate taxrate limit enacted a few years ago in Ohio to the members of the real estate taxation committee of the National Association of Real Estate Boards at their recent meeting in Chicago.

Three plays, "The Nursery Maid of Heaven" and "Highways Cross," e by Thomas Wood Stevens, and "The Dear Departed," by Stanley Houghton, are now being rehearsed by Wigs and Cues, the dramatic societs at Barnard College, for presentation Friday, April 29, as the annual Spring productions of the club.
Engineering students at the University of Rochester are spending their Spring vacation arranging elaborate exhibits for the annual Engineers Club open house scheduled for next Friday and Saturday.
The Dionne quintuplets, who struggled to get into the dentist's chair all at once, today were told by three specialists that nothing was wrong with the 100 teeth which the girls share evenly.

Miss Sandra Martin, former secretary of Simone Simon, French fil actress, was arrested today by District Attorney's investigators, who maid that she confessed spending thousands of dollars withdrawn from the actress's bank account to buy herself jewels and clothing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The suggested constitutional changes in our judicial system contained in the report of a special committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York are food for thought. All of the suggestions are admirable in their purposes.

Delegates to the Socialist party's national convention today adopted an anti-war resolution declaring "Roosevelt liberalism, like Wisconsin liberalism, is a prelude to war, part of a system to charm the workers by a few concessions to lay down their lives for capitalism."
The Rutgers University track team won nine out of fourteen first places today to defeat Lehigh, 93 to 33, on Nellson Field.

The twelve-story office building at 135-37 Broadway, corner of Cedar Street, formerly the main offices of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, will be sold at auction on Wednesday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

A veteran, Jose de Capriles, member of the last American Olympic team, and a newcomer, William Randall, senior at Yale and current holder of the junior title, ified last night for the final of the national epee championship on the strips of the New York Athletic Club.

After four days of blasting the economic policies of both the Democratic and Republican parties, Wisconsin's Governor, Philip F. La Follette, was busily at work this week-end preparing a public manifesto which is expected to summon liberals in all camps to join with him in establishing a national third party.

President Roosevelt's program of pump-priming and gold desterilization has given a fillip to the agitation-supported by a section of the Liberal party-for a similar policy in Canada. The Ottawa Government, it is learned; has something in the pumppriming line under consideration, but on a scale so small as hardly to merit comparison with Washington's program.

Extra-curricular. activities for the 1,200 lower freshmen of Hunter College have been set in motion with the organization of thirteen departmental, religious, and discussion clubs at the Thirty-second Street building of the college.

Despite reductions in four major paper products in the last two weeks, strong resistance to pressure for reductions in other types has continued and, because of steady trading and small stocks in the hands of distributors, traders said yesterday that most lines will not be changed during the current quarter.
HOLLYWOOD won't be glorifying Thomas E. Dewey after all, for the District Attorney served notice on the studios last week that his name was not to be mentioned in connection with any film stories.

More than 100 delegates to the annual convention of the State branch of the American Federation of Labor refused to go through a picket line this afternoon to attend the meeting. Some days ago the A. F. of L. State headquarters was moved to the Strand Building.
This city is threatened with isolation from its main traffic artery as a result of landslides and washouts on railroads from a fortnight of daily rains along the Magdalena River.

OBERLIN COLLEGE announces that it will dedicate this week its $115,000 addition to the Dudley Peter Allen Memorial Art Building, with appropriate ceremonies including a meeting of teachers of art in the Midwest, a symposium with distinguished speakers, and special exhibitions.
A considerably larger than seasonal increase in residential building permits was recorded in March, Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, announced today.

Miss Florence Colt Brigham, daughter of Henry D. Brigham and a great-granddaughter of James Dennison Colt, an eminent Berkshire lawyer who was an associate justice of the Massachusetts Supreme Court from 1868 until his death in 1881, was married to John Wallace Wales. this afternoon at the Wen-. dell Avenue home of her father and stepmother here.

Ridden by her owner, Captain Frank DeK. Huyler of Rye, the German-bred chestnut mare Moesta was awarded the open jumper championship at Squadron A Armory last night, while the famed and consistent brown gelding Hexameter looK the hunter crown in the closing session of the squadron's second annual Spring horse show.

The House of Commons will be crowded Tuesday afternoon to hear Sir John Simon make his first budget speech. The Chancellor of the Exchequer will be able to claim, if he wants to, a melancholy distinction, for it is in his first budget that the expenditure of the British Treasury goes above [pound]1,000,000,000, a figure never before reached except during the war and its immediate aftermath.

Doubles and the distance chaminonships of the New York A. C. were decided at the Travers Island traps of the organization yesterday. In the doubles, the winner was Roger Fawcett, who broke 88 out of 100. C. W. Phellis, victor last year with 97. finished in a tie for third place with a card of 86.

A report just presented to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board by the St. Louis Chamber of Commerce indicates, states the bank board, that a great market for new homes exists in most, if not all, American cities.

A discussion of distribution costs will feature a meeting sponsored by the Society for the Advancement of Management at the Seymour Hotel on Tuesday. The discussion, which will be preceded by a dinner, will be led by Dr. Frank M. Surface.

The American Friends of Russian Children in Exile, a committee organized here last year to aid children of impoverished Russian emigres, will give a small supper dance on Thursday at the Montparnasse.

Despite a slight sales upturn in some lines, collections since the start of this month have continued very slow and credit men are checking all accounts carefully, they reported here yesterday. The Spring season has been a disappointment in most merchandise lines, it was said,

Signs numbering each exit from express highways in the city have been installed by the Department of Parks. Grand Central Parkway Extension exits begin with 1 at Triborough Bridge and run to 11 at Kew Gardens. Interborough Parkway exits start with 4 at Pennsylvania Avenue, Brooklyn, and end with 11 at Kew Gardens.

All six officials of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League, 20 West Forty-seventh Street, will apply for pistol permits if Federal action is not taken against American Nazi strong-arm tactics, J. H. Steel, executive secretary of the league, announced yesterday.

ANOTHER big saving in time has been accomplished in South America by aviation. Recently one of the twin-engine planes of the Condor Peruana Aviation Company soared up from the ancient Incan city of Cuzco and headed northeast over unknown territory of the Peruvian mountains on a 190-mile trial flight to the isolated river port of Maldonado, reachable overland only by a tenday passage of dangerous mountain trails and the descent of rockstrewn rivers.

Joey Fontana, East Side protege of Tony Canzoneri, outpointed Jimmy Lancaster of Wilmington, Del., in the main bout of eight rounds at the Ridgewood Grove last night. The victor weighed 131 pounds and his rival 130 1/4. In the six-round semi-final Matt Perfetti, 128, Amsterdam, N.Y., conquered Jerry Mazza, 129, Bensonhurst.

NASSAU, Bahamas.-Bimini in the Bahamas lays claim to having the smallest newspaper in the world. Just recently, launched, The Bimini Bugle is a fortnightly of sixteen pages, each measuring 5 1/2 by 4 1/2 inches.

FACED with the costs of heavily taxed gasoline foresighted motorists are turning to ways and means of keeping the car's gas bill within bounds. In this process of keeping upkeep down automotive engineers stress the importance of driving practices.

For the third consecutive year the number of exhibitors at the Knitting Arts Exhibition, which will open tomorrow, will establish a new all-time record, according to a statement issued yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manu-. facturers.

Asserting that a "balanced stomach" is more important at the moment than a balanced budget, Postmaster Geieral James A. Farley expressed confidence last night that American business would cooperate with President Roosevelt's five-billion-dollar recovery program and that the people of the United States thereby would "find their way to a new level of prosperous and contented living."

Generalissimo Fiancisco Franco's forces launched a new drive over a wide front south of Montalban today, capturing thousands of prisoners and conquering a large area of mountainous territory in Teruel Province.

Scattering eight hits, Johnny Allen pitched Cleveland to a 6-to-3 victory over the Tigers today, enabling the Indians to remain deadlocked with Washington and Boston for first place in the American League. Whistling Jake Wade, Tiger southpaw, who pitched the first four innings, was charged with the defeat.

Mrs. Albert J. Pitkin, widow of a former president of the American Locomotive Company, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of Presbyterian Hospital at the age of 74. Mrs. Pitkin, who was born in Philadelphia, had lived for several years at 1 Fifth Avenue.

Edith Barrett and Vincent Price, members of the cast of the Mercury Theatre's production, "The Shoemakers' Holiday," were married yesterday morning in the chantry of St. Thomas Church here by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks.

Debutantes of former seasons and their escorts attended the third and final Knickerbocker Assembly of the season last night. in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. A midnight supper was served in the Oval Room of the hotel..

THE book trade has lost something of its humility. There had been anxious days- last month when the sober-minded were asking how it would be possible for the market to absorb the fabulous riches of the Cortlandt Field Bishop library.

STATION KNX, Los Angeles, key station of the Columbia Broadcasting System On the Pacific coast, will celebrate the opening of new $1,750,000 Hollywood studios in an all-day, broadcast beginning at 6 A. M. on Saturday. The site at Sunset Boulevard and Gower Street, has been named Columbia Square.

The wedding of Miss Martha Janet Smith, daughter of Mrs. James Smith of Montclair and the late Mr. Smith, to Robert Dick Stoddard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren J. Stoddard of East Orange, took place this afternoon in St. Cloud Presbyterian Church, West Orange.

ALONG mountain passes between snow-capped peaks 11,000 feet high Canada is building what is described as North America's most spectacular scenic highway, that connecting Banff and Jasper on the AlbertaBritish Columbia boundary.

Establishment of minimum construction requirements for the areas served by fifty-nine of its sixty-five insuring offices has been completed by the Federal Housing Administration, Howard P. Vermilya, director of the technical division, announced yesterday.

Miss Neill James, American author, has emerged from Arctic Lapland, where she spent the whole Winter. She will now return to New York. Clad in a Lapp costume of reindeer pelts and with scarcely more luggage than a toothbrush and an eiderdown sleeping bag, Miss James lived with the Lapps in their tents in the snow, sleeping on the frozen ground and subsisting entirely on Arctic food.

Hunting for the truly human I looked for the true man And saw an ape at the fair With the circle still to square. Learning Breeds its own ignorance. Fame and power Demand a rush and pounding. Those who rush through rush through and who Are they but those who rush through? Yet truth resides in contemplation And comprehension of contemplation Not necessarily of Plato.

Approval of the apartment lease form recently prepared by the committee on law reform of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York has been made by the special committee on tenant-landlord relations of the Real Property Council of New York, of which Simon Dovne is chairman.
Vice President Garner today laid the keel of the new 1,500-ton destroyer Roe at a ceremony marking .the second day of Charleston's annual azalea, festival.

Miss Dorothy Marion Mack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Dwight Mack of this place, was married to Eugene Russell Jr., son of Dr.,and Mrs. Russel of Tarrytown, this evening at the Hawthorne Dutch Reformed Church here.

Buck Newsom, stalwart right-hander, pitched and batted the Browns to a 5-to-4 victory over the White'Sox today, breaking the St. Louisans' three-game losing streak and putting his club even with Chicago in the series.

Many a gardener has found some decorative use for the rocks scattered over his soil or dug up from it in leveling or planting operations. He has put them into walls to be overgrown with ivy; into borders for low-growing plants to creep over and into rock gardens.
The freshman nines of Columbia and Princeton battled to a 5-to-5 deadlock at Baker Field yesterday. The game was called because of darkness, after 13 innings of play.

There have been other ages of the world when civilization seemed to be going to pieces. One of them was the latter part of the sixteenth century, during which there flourished near Bordeaux a quiet country gentleman of literary tastes, named Michel de Montaigne.

A somewhat common practice among home builders of moderate circumstances, points out an official of the FHA, has been to erect a story and a half or a two-story house and leave the top floor in an unfinished condition, the idea being that as the space was needed and money to carry out the work could be obtained the home would be completed.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today that the income from dairy products had been nearer the pre-depression level than that of any other farm product this Spring. In March, for example, the bureau estimated that the income from dairy products was only 7.5 per cent below the 1924-29 level.

Senator Alfred E. Reames, 68-yearold Democrat from Medford, Ore., was taken to -the Naval Hospital last night suffering from bronchial pneumonia. Physicians said his condition was "good, considering the fact that he has pneumonia." He was sworn in Feb. 11 as the first Democratic Senator from Oregon since 1921.

What to do about a collective bargaining agency for employes of the Daniel Reeves grocery stores was puzzling the State Labor Relations Board yesterday. An election among 1,582 Reeves workers showed a majority in favor of representation by some union, but the votes were so split between a C. I. O. and an A. F.

Exports of motor cars and trucks from the United States in the first quarter of 1938 were virtually double those in the 1937 period from the standpoint of their relation to total output, although numerically the total of cars shipped whole or for assembly abroad declined slightly.
HOT SPRINGS, Va.-The State of Virginia is now at the height of its Spring glory, and its floral beauty will be celebrated with many fetes during the coming week.

DEATH IN THE INNER OFFICE. By Natalie Wright. 246 pp. New York: Phoenix Press. $2. UPON one subject the girls in the correspondence department of Loring, Jolie Epstein are in complete agreement. They do not like Mrs. Root, the office manager.

In brief address to an unusually large number of persons including more than 2,000 newly married couples, crowding today's public audience, Pope Pius expressed his horror a the wars that are tearing the world apart both in East and West.

Blood tests for all freshmen entering Colgate University next Fall was proposed today by the student senate after a conference with Dr. Linn C. Beebe, university health officer. University authorities have urged students for some time to take tests for disease.

In a meet which saw seven records shattered and three others equaled, the Evander Childs High School athletes carried off team honors for the third straight year at the thirtieth annual New York University interscholastic track and field meet on Ohio Field yesterday.

The New York State Department of the American Legion last night honored its commander, Jeremiah Francis Cross, at a dinner at the Hotel Astor. Public officials, including leaders in the recent fight for the vetoed McNaboe bill, for which Mr. Cross campaigned vigorously, hailed his stanch patriotism and courage. About 500 persons attended.

The marriage of Miss Flora Brady Garvan, daughter of Mrs. Francis Patrick Garvan and the late Mr. Garvan, to Francis Dana Winslow 2d, son of Mrs. Herbert Reed Lawrence of New York and Tuxedo Park and of the late Kenelm Winslow, took place this afternoon at Roslyn House, the home of the bride's mother in this community. Because of the death in November of the bride's father, only relatives and close friends were present.

Only "some" of the thirty or more interstate and intrastate bus operators directed by Mayor La Guardia to file applications for city franchises authorizing them to operate within city limits have complied with the order.
Ferdinand Pecora, New York Supreme Court justice and one-time New Deal investigator, today warned that liberty was endangered-unless the Constitution was "construed in the liberal tradition."

As the problem of relief for the unemployed takes the national spotlight again a nation-wide survey conducted by the American Institute of Public Opinion indicates a majority of Americans think persons on relief are already getting "as much as they should."

After more than eighteen hours of deliberations yesterday and today, the . State committee of the National Municipal League, holding a constitutional conference at Union College, adopted a program for submission to the Constitutional Convention in Albany.

TRADE volume slipped into its usual post-Easter decline last week. Comparisons with last year were again affected by the holiday date. Clearances were in full swing a year ago and family budgets had been replenished for the buying.

Bitter feeling has beer aroused here by the movement in Brazil to make all schools Brazilian and by other attempts of the Vargas government to interfere with the development of an organized German minority training its children as Germans and looking to Berlin for its ideology and cultural inspiration.

A third place in the final race today made Indian Scout, chartered by Ray Hunt of Marblehead, Mass., the third United States yacht in the last seven years to win the coveted Prince of Wales Trophy. In conditions strongly reminiscent of Long Island Sound, with .alight northerly blowing between four and six miles an hour when there
President Roosevelt left on the Presidential yacht Potomac today for a week-end cruise on the Potomac River and Chesapeake Bay. He planned to return late tomorrow afternoon.

The Distinguished Service Medal, was awarded today to Captain Frank N. Roberts, Assistant Military Attache in China, for his services during the bombing of the United States gunboat Panay by the Japanese on the Yangize River on Dec. 12. 1937.

MISS KNIGHT'S experiences in her brief newspaper career seem in outline hardly enough to fill adequately 374 pages. The parade of newspaper "I" books has been long and competition for attention has sharply increased since that fresh morning when the appearance of Vincent Sheehan's "Personal History" set so many worn portable typewriters clacking.
Leonor F. Loree, retired president of the Delaware Hudson Railroad and national figure in railroad circles, celebrated his eightieth birthday today by visiting Bowwood, his estate here.
The Massachusetts State baseball team handed Williams its third successive setback today on Weston Field, 18 to 4.

SOON the thunderstorm season will begin. Magnificent cumulus cloud formations will come marching from behind the Jersey Palisades, bringing lightning and swiftly changing cloud patterns for the photographer to capture.

Freshmen at Wheaton College :have started preparations for the production of three original one-act plays, a project which involves their work in writing, art and speech. Advanced classes will help to direct the plays.

Paralleling the situation which developed in 1930 and 1931, the decline in home furnishings volume has become a major problem of the current recession, store executives here reported yesterday. Failure of the housing movement to gain headway,

VINELAND, N. J. A SMALL boy of 8, crippled and crosseyed and wistful, sits in a high chair at a table in a classroom at the Training School at Vineland with a disk of pegs and a pile of cardboard cylinders before him. Spectacles give his face a gravity strange for his years.
One of the last songs composed by George Gershwin is to be used as an anthem-march for the New York World's Fair, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corportion.

A Socialist charge that the Police Department and the Communist party had formed a united front to deprive Socialist May Day marchers of their "traditional right" to Union Square was termed "so much poppycock" yesterday by Israel Amter, State organizer of the Communist party.

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey will be the principal speaker at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore on May 11, under the auspices of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and the New York County Lawyers Association.

Even a person whose gardening experience ends with pansies and radishes can be intrigued and inspired by the new garden tools and gadgets in the shops now. Some of the garden equipment departments are dressed up to look like rustic tool sheds.

Although in most recent years wholesalers have completed. their buying of both wool and part-wool blankets by the middle of March, the volume booked this season to date is not only well behind that of last year but represents less than half the reduced requirements of the jobbers, selling agents reported yesterday.

FOR the final concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra's season, to be given this Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall, Eugene Ormandy, who will conduct, has arranged a program featuring Hans von Buelow's three great musical B's-Bach, Beethoven and Brahms.

Strategical advances upon which the Japanese high command obviously places the greatest importance have been recorded on the Shantung front, where at one point the Japanese claim to be only fifteen miles north of the tracks of the Lung-Hai Railway.

Four hundred women's clubs throughout the State are contributing a book apiece to the library of Westfield Farms, the former Bedford Reformatory for Women, but the gift will not include Ernest Hemingway's "To Have and Have Not."

Above the din of Congressional debate that has greeted President Roosevelt's $5,000,000,000 spending and lending program for recovery and relief many citizens have been asking themselves the question: the pump-priming method failed before to bring about lasting prosperity, why should it now be relied upon to produce the same result?
Ambassador and Mrs. Joseph Kennedy were guests of the Council of the English Speaking Union at a dinner at Daryouth House with the Marquess of Willingdon presiding.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Carlin of this city gave a luncheon today at the Essex House, Newark, at which they announced the engagement and coming marriage of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Dolores Carlin, to Richard Lang Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lang of New York, formerly of Nutley.

Overnight news of the details of the compromise agreed on by the Senate-House conferees on the taxrevision bill did not prevent profit taking as the aftermath of Friday's sharp advance, and the stock market close irregulaly lower yesterday.

Home construction is possible under very favorable conditions this year, points out Paul S. Collier, secretary-manager of thee Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association, with headquarters at Rochester, N. Y. Financing is available on easy terms; he states, and lumber and building material costs in general are less than the commonly accepted 1926 normal rate.

Transfer To take effect 8 A. M., May 1: PATROLMAN-Bernard J. Halpin, from 7th Precinct to Telegraph Bureau. Temporary Assignments SERGEANT--Francis T. Hickey, from 48th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Bronx, for 1 day, from 4 P. M. April 19.

BEYOND DARK HILLS. A Personal Story by Jesse Stuart. With Six Decorations by Ishmael. 399 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton Co. $3.50. By J. DONALD ADAMS JESSE STUART has written three books that spring straight from the American earth.

THERE has been considerable discussion of late by educators, film producers, Will Hays and even by spokesmen for the patient public concerning the use of motion pictures in the advance of visual education.

SLEEP IN PEACE. By Phyllis Bentley. 554 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $2.50. By PERCY HUTCHISON IN "Sleep in Peace" Phyllis Bentley has done another splendid novel of that region she knows so intimately, the West Riding of Yorkshire.
Dr. Wilbour E. Saunders, headmaster of the Peddle School, announced today the awarding of highest scholastic honors for March to fourteen boys, as follows:
Brock Pemberton, Broadway producer, attacked theatre unions yesterday as hampering production and tending to cut down the number of jobs available.
Louis Edward Frith, one of the oldest member of the Union Club, died on Friday at his home, 277 Park Avenue, at the age of 93.

BARON-Mr. and Mrs. Irving Baron announce the bar mitzvah of their son. Richard, on Saturday, April 30, 9:30 A. M., at the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 West 76th St. Reception at home, 350 Central Park West, on Sunday afternoon, May 1, from 2 to 6.

TIME was when the last thing that any Western city cared to be reminded about was the fact that just a little while ago it used to be a fur-trading post or a mining camp or a "cow town." But today that attitude is completely changed. Oklahoma City and Denver have erected statues of cow hands on bucking broncos and placed them in the most conspicuout spots available.

Sporting goods equipment, sales of which started off slowly this year, has begun to move more rapidly, manufacturers reported yesterday and while the figures for last year will not be reached, the decline will be smaller than in many lines.
