Danno O'Mahoney, 225, Ireland, and Gino Garibaldi, 225, St. Louis, wrestled to a draw in an exhibition interrupted by the 11 o'clock curfew at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night.
A total of 242 letters was granted to members of seventeen teams at Syracuse University's annual Block S dinner tonight in Archbold Gymnasium.
More than 300 persons attended the "Cruise to Georgia" supper dance, the annual Spring entertainment of the Georgia Society of New York, which was held last night in the main ballroom of the Pierre.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, opening the Girl Scouts' "better homes" week at their national Little House today, planted a Norway spruce in the memory garden, autographed a copy of her autobiography for the library and watched a series of home-making demonstrations.

Consul generals and consuls of foreign nations in New York City will be the guests of the executive committee of the New York Foreign Trade Committee next Thursday- at the Rockefeller Center Luncheon Club. The purposes of Foreign Trade Week, May 22 to 28, will be explained.

The Narcissus Show of the Westbury Horticultural Society, in cooperation with the Horticultural Society of New York, will be held at 598 Madison Avenue, New York City, on Tuesday and Wednesday. .. . On Thursday and Friday there will be-a Daffodil Show given by the Massachusetts Horticultural Societv at Horticultural Hall, Boston.

FOUR interesting and very diverse exhibitions of watercolors were among the exhibitions opening last week and remaining current until the end of April or longer. The artists in question are Winthrop Turney, showing at the Fifteen; Alice Judson, at Babcock's; Arthur K. D.
THE jacket picture of Hilda van Stockum's latest book--a white-washed cottage with its peat pile by the wall, purple hills in the distance, children, dog and geese-unmistakably suggests Ireland;

Love, not based on emotion; but on the law of God, is what is most lacking. the the world today, Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein said yesterday at the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 West Seventy-sixth Street.

A strong finish enabled Howard Oxenberg, Park Central A. A. ace, to annex the New York State 220-yard free-style championship, his second within a week, at the A. A. U. swimming meet in the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. pool last night.

Copper plays an important part in the proper equipment of a home, points out the Copper and Brass Research Assqciation of this city. Convectors made from the metal it is explained, can be built into. walls and used as insulation, and shields of copper are being used widely as a protection against termites.

North Dakota voters have been asked to decide at the primary election. June 28 whether they want to continue to have village, town and city elections or prefer to have all municipal officers, elective and appointive, chosen by a commission composed of three State. officers, the Governor, Lieutenant Governor and Attorney General.

PLONSKY, EZEKIEL (Sept. 17, 1936). Assets, $70,867; gross, $66,746 net. To Federation of Hebrew Charities of Manhattan, $1,000; niece, Jennie Lipshutz, $1,000; niece, Pauline Frankel, and niece. Irene Frankel, $1,5000 each;

THESE are busy days for the Sea Scouts, young men 15 years of age, who as members of the Boy Scouts of America take to the waterways of the nation instead of to the woods and mountains. Many are using their Spring school vacations and week-ends to put their craft into shape for the cruising season.

Doubt and assurance were present in about equal measure among the thousand farmers, extension agents and AAA committeemen here this week to attend the launching of the "all risk" crop insurance program.
Colonel Bill Terry's Giants made it two straight over the Dodgers yesterday at Ebbets Field by the official count of 8 to 5.

THE vocal portion of The New Friends of Music series consists of one selection each from the composers engaging the society's attention. In Victor Album M-430, on four ten-inch disks, is the first complete recording of Schumann's "Liederkreis"

Mrs. Della Rozen, 37, one of the three persons seriously injured in a crash involving a truck, a bus and five pleasure cars on Route 4 in Fort Lee yesterday morning, died tonight in Englewood Hospital. Mrs. Rozen lived at 150 Rockwood Place here. Her husband, Jerome Rozen.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Geller Duncan, who returned recently from their wedding trip, will give a reception this afternoon at their home, 108 East Ninety-first Street. Mrs. Duncan is the former Miss Janet St. Clair Mullan, daughter of the late Justice and Mrs. George V. Mullan.

The recently organized Bach Products, Inc., headed by Oscar B. Bach, metal crafts designer, will conduct commercial experiments in the construction of low-cost housing of colored stainless steel along the lines of a process developed by Mr. Bach.

Official Summer will not arrive in New York until June 21, but it came to Central Park last week with the opening of the Park Department's annual campaign to protect the lawns and flower beds from children, dogs and picnickers-offenders in the-order named.

The Commodity Credit Corporation, the government agency which makes loans on crops, will use approximately $100,000,000 of the receipts from the $200,000,000 of its notes to be offered for it on Monday by the Treasury to repay its indebtedness to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and if it needs more money in the future will obtain it by additional note issues instead of borrowing from the RFC.

Miss Betty Washington Peyton of Staunton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Peyton, and William Grosvenor Davis of New York were married this afternoon in historic Trinity Episcopal Church, which was decorated with ferns and Madonna lilies.

With the veteran Bob Seeds and Rookie Catcher Clyde McCullough pacing a twelve-hit bombardment, the Newark Bears scored their second victory over the Buffalo Bisons today, 6to 4. Seeds and McCullough gathered three hits apiece, the former blasting a home run in the fifth inning with Charlie Keller aboard to send the Bears into a lead they never relinquished. Seeds also batted.

Lieutenants R. Antrim, C. Werts, J. McCormick and Ensign Rice, naval officers stationed at Lakehurst, N. J., arrived here last night with a story of how they landed in a balloon in the Tug Hill wilderness of Lewis County and then walked twenty miles.

Changes in the membership of the Young Women's Christian Association, as well as in nominees for its national board, restricted until a ruling four years ago to those of the Protestant faith, were reflected in reports made to delegates attending the organization's convention here today.

Laws have recently been passed in twenty-four States, according to a survey released yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which will materially strengthen the efforts of that board and its various agencies to establish a sound national system of home financing institutions.

Spurred by a clear day and the cheers of 10,180 fans, the hustling Bees officially opened the National League baseball season in Boston today by turning back Philadelphia, 3 to 1, and starting Pitcher Lou Fette on the victory path again.

" MA che grazia!" (What grace!) "Che freschezza di melodia!" (What freshness of melody!) "Che cose deliziose!" (What a delightful work!)-typical remarks heard last week at the Teatro delle Arti during an intermission of Pergolesi's two-act opera buffa, "IL Maestro di Musica," produced in the adaptation of Richard Falk and under, this conductor's direction, with a brilliant cast.

The report of the Boston Edison Company for the year ended on March 31, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $5,210,544. after all operating expenses, taxes and charges. This was equal to $8.44 each on the 617,161 shares of capital stock outstanding, compared with a net of $5,360,388, or $8.69 a share, in the year ended on March 31, 1937.

Exhibiting thirty-five canceled checks, Governor Earle gave a public accounting today of his personal financial relations' with Matthew H. McCloskey Jr., Democratic party leader and building contractor.

The business depression has "leveled out" and "we will be on the road to better things in a few months," says Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation. Mr. Watson, who is here for the annual dinner of the I. B. M. Country Club, also asserted that he felt "very much encouraged"

When the school girls wind their May poles again this Spring on the greens in the city parks, not the least interested spectator will be Miss Elizabeth Burchenal, who started the folk-dance movement in this city thirty-three years ago.

A. Aguilar Machado, Secretary of Public Education of Costa Rica, has taken a stand in favor of classical music in the public schools and has declared war against the rumba, carioca, tango and all forms of "popular" music. Music teachers have been informed that promotions are only for those who teach classical music.

A CAPE HORN passage, particularly if it were from east to west, in the teeth of the prevailing westerly winds, was one that was always dreaded by deep-water sailors, masters and crews alike. For that reason its successful accomplishment was a matter of deep satisfaction.

AN acute and stinging revue, "Nine Sharp," by Herbert Farjeon, is filling the Little Theatre for the good. reason that there are brains behind its satirical fooling. One of its most entertaining turns is a skit on what in England is called continuous revue, which does indeed deserve to be satirized.

New Yorkers, in common with many millions in other. parts of the country, are observing daylight-saving time today. Effective at 2 A. M. Eastern standard time, most persons were expected to have turned their clocks and watches ahead by one hour on retiring last night.

Nedayr lost and Fighting Fox won. That tells the story of the two highly discussed Kentucky Derby eligibles who made their seasonal debuts in separate races before 18,000 persons at Jamaica yesterday.
The trustees of Princton University at their Spring meeting announced nine appointments to endowed chairs and the introduction of two undergraduate courses in religion.

The Greenport Basin and Construction Company announced today that it had delivered to the United States army a seagoing crash, or aircraft rescue boat, built at its plant here. The seventy twofoot streamlined craft went under its own power to the Brooklyn port
For the sixth straight year Yale defeated Pennsylvania in a dual track and field meet at Franklin Field today, 86--49,

WITH the playing of this afternoon's program the Philharmonic- Symphony begins its final week of the current season. Soloists today are Eugene List and Harry Glantz. On Thursday and Friday Marjorie Lawrence and Charles Kullmann will appear with the orchestra in a program devoted to works of Beethoven and Wagner.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson, who never has looked upon political campaigns as pink teas, has been dubbed the "hatchet man" of the Senator Guffey-John L. Lewis alliance by Governor Earle, his rival for the Democratic Senatorial nomination.

A new transcontinental record from west to east for military planes was established by Lieut. Col. Robert Olds of the Army Air Corps when he set his plane down at Langley Field at 4 o'clock this morning.

Declaring they were undaunted by Governor Lehman's veto last week of bills appropriating $850,000 for improvement of the Cross-Country Parkway in Westchester, members of the Westchester County Park Commission discussed today with a special committee of county supervisors a proposed parkway expansion program for which State and Federal aid would be sought.

WHEN Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo climbs ashore from his Spanish exploration vessel this week to see the changes which 400 years have wrought on the coast of California he will behold things which not even the dreamers of his own era Let the could envision.

The Huguenot influence in American religious life has been of great importance and must be preserved, the Rev. Dr. Thomas J. Lacey, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer, Brooklyn, said yesterday in his sermon at the afternoon services at the French

A proposal for the settlement in Palestine of 100,000 Jewish refugees annually for the next five years under the direction of an international commission was made here today-at a national emergency conference of the United Palestine Appeal.

Olyve White Norman, colorature soprano, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall under the auspices of St. Ambrose Church. The program opened with "Voi che sapete," from Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro," which was followed by "Addio! del Passato,"

James G. Blaine, chairman of the campaign committee of the Greater New York Fund, announced yesterday the appointment of twelve officials of the American Federation of Labor to serve on the labor advisory committee of the campaign.

The New York Drama Critics Circle took to the air at 10:30 o'clock last night to broadcast the honors it had voted last Monday to "Of Mice and Men" and "Shadow and Substance"-respectively the best new American play and the best theatrical importation of the season,

Installation of air - conditioning equipment in buses, a strong sales argument used by railroads, will be promoted in forthcoming advertising campaigns of various bus lines, plans for one system indicate. The Santa Fe Trailways, Wichita, Kan., has launched a campaign, which is double that of any previous drive, to announce the acquisition of fifty air-conditioned buses.

The American Heart Association, Inc., announced yesterday that an international broadcast on rheumatic heart disease affecting children would be held on Monday evening, May 2, over the network of the National Broadcasting System in connection with the observance of National Child Health Day.

John Maillot, a novice representing the French Sporting Club, scored his first victory in road competition by capturing the St. Anselm's A. C. thirtieth annual sixmile Metropolitan A. A. U. open handicap run yesterday.

The Most Rev. Bartholomew J. Eustace, who was consecrated Bishop on March 26 in St. Patrick's Cathedral, sang his first Pontifical mass there yesterday at the invitation of Cardinal Hayes. As a further mark' of high esteem, the Cardinal invited the new Bishop to occupy his throne during the ceremony. According to church officials, Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, was the last dignitary previously to whom the New York prelate yielded that honor.

Declaring the prevalence of suicide in America to be one of the nation's most alarming problems, Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell prescribed yesterday the peace which comes with faith in Christ as anantidote for the skeptical pagan attitudes and materialistic views which drives men in despair to selfdestruction.

In a protest against the seizure of all "non-aryan" books in the Vienna National Library for burning, a small group of Williams Col-lege students sent a cablegram to the chief librarian of the internationally famous library today offering to purchase all these books.

Ways in which household workers might apply collective action to obtain higher standards of wages and working conditions were discussed at a meeting tonight of the industrial delegates to the fifteenth annual convention of the Y. W. C. A.'s of the United States.
A proposal for settling the twelveday strike of 900 warehouse employes at four mid-city stores was drafted by union leaders today for presentation to a joint conference of employers and strikers.

Three Austrian professors, now refugees,- have accepted invitations to join the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science of the New School for Social Research, known as the "University in Exile," it was announced yesterday by Dr. Alvin Johnson, chairman of the faculty.
Governor Lehman has proclaimed the week of May 22 to May 28 as Foreign Trade Week, the executive offices said today. The Governor is on a Florida vacation.

A scientific monograph by Dr. Alexis Carrel and Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh describing their method for the cultivation of human and animal organs, which Dr. Carrel discussed before the annual meeting of the American Philosophical Society last week, will be published in June by Paul B. Hoeber, Inc., the medical book department qf Harper Brothers.

A world organization to transcend the internationalism of the League of Nations was advocated by W. Edwin Collier, leader of the Philadelphia Ethical Culture Society, in an address before the New York society yesterday morning at the meeting house, Central Park West at Sixty-fourth Street.
The assumption of charge of the Spanish Loyalist legation here by Romero Ortega, Mexican charge d'affaires, has created another problem for the Foreign Office.

Such evidence as has accumulated in the last week indicates that British trade still tends to contract. Foreign 'trade summaries tended to confirm this, while railway receipts, building activity and bankers' clearings all point to some slowing down.

Extraordinary precautions against a repetition of the noting that marked the celebration of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's birthday at Yorkville Casino last week were taken by the police yesterday as New York and Westchester residents of Nazi leanings joined in the observance of German Day at White Plains.
While dealings in corn futures on the Board of Trade here were in considerably restricted volume last week, relatively active business was done within a narrow range of quotations.

The great one, Dizzy Dean, poured it on his old mates today. The big righthanded pitcher, for whom the Cubs paid $185,000 and sent three players to St. Louis eight days ago, shut out the Cardinals, 5 to 0, with a four-hit hurling masterpiece. It was his second victory as a Cub in as many starts.

Governor Blanton Winship left for Washington today by plane. He said he would attend the House of Representatives Rivers and Harbors Committee meeting Tuesday as well as look after island legislation pending in Congress.

Medals were presented to Police Sergeant Otto Kafka and Acting Sergeant Joseph W. Forsythe of the Police Department Aviation Bureau yesterday by the Marine Parkway Civic Association in ceremonies at Floyd Bennett Airport, Brooklyn.

Forty-six Princeton University undergraduates have received awards for participation in intercollegiate fencing and squash racquets during the Winter season, it was announced today by R. Kenneth Fairman, '34, acting graduate manager of athletics. The awards brought the total for the Winter to 188 in seven sports.

Miss Alice Gertrude Beekley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Waldron Cheyney Beekley of this city, and Robert Crampton Ackerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Crampton Ackerman of New York, were married here last evening in St. James's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. George G. Guinness.
Prime Minister Eamon de Valera of Ireland was warmly greeted on his arrival here today to sign the Anglo-Irish agreement settling some of the major points of difference between the two countries.

Gates W. McGarrah, treasurer and chairman of the distributing committee of the United Hospital Fund, made public yesterday a list of hospitals throughout the city to which funds have been allocated from the total raised last Fall in the joint campaign of the hospital fund organization and the Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association.

The undefeated Pirates beat Cincinnati, 2 to 1, today in a sparkling pitching duel between Jim Tobin and Ray (Peaches) Davis. It was Pittsburgh's sixth victory of the new National League season and to its twentieth over the Reds since early last year.

The life work of George Foster Peabody, philanthropist, was cornmemorated in two addresses yesterday afternoon at a service of music and religious devotions at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn. Mr. Peabody died last month.

Egypt's constitutional- crisis deepened today when Premier Mohammed Mahmoud Pasha submitted his resignation in a quarrel with King Farouk over the formation of a "party Cabinet." The young monarch neither accepted nor rejected the resignation.

The Yankees won their first d series of the year by beating the Senators at the Stadium yesterday on a daring, speedy bit of baserunning before the largest crowd the Bronx ballyard has held this I season.

Retailers, concerned largely with clearances of Easter merchandise, ordered sparingly in the wholesale markets here last week, but there was a fairly active response to special offerings of such goods as pe could be used to attract customers.
President Alberto Enriquez conferred last week with John K. Roosevelt, vice president of All America Cables, Inc., concerning revision of the company's concession in Ecuador.

There were few fancy pedigrees among the sixty dogs and cats that romped around in the improvised show ring in the Hotel Roosevelt ballroom yesterday. Many were just "plain" dog or cat, and some of the animals even snapped at the hands that were trying to award them ribbons.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 81, which compares with 81.1 a week ago, 80.9 two weeks ago, 81.2 three weeks ago and 81.9 four weeks ago.
Members of the Maritime Association own, or represent the owners, of more than 15,000,000 tons of shipping, according to the sixty-fifth annual report of the directors, which was published yesterday.

A statement insisting that the Protestant Episcopal Church "cannot with integrity enter upon or encourage efforts toward Christian reunion except such as are based upon the terms presented in the 'Lambeth Quadrilateral'"
Hiker's June, white and orange English setter, owned by Lippincott Colket of Villanova, Pa., and handled by Austin Heckscher of Stratford, Pa. near hee, today.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,392,878,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.

Crowds of bathers along the south shore, including several En hundred Americans, watched a rare sight today--a whale chase. At 6:30 this morning whales were sighted close inshore and the Southampton whaling crew, who have been attempting to revive the old whaling industry for the past six or seven years, promptly put out their boat.

An overhead footbridge, erected with WPA assistance after a small girl lost her left leg under the wheels of a freight car in Pulaski Park here, was dedicated this afternoon at ceremonies attended by city, WPA, Erie Railroad and National Safety Council officials.

Trading in soy bean futures on the Board of Trade here last week was largely in the way of liquidation by holders of May contracts. Much of the business was in spreading between the May and July futures.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Louise F. Hatry, daughter of Mrs. Howard W. Blake of 565 Park Avenue and of Harry A. Hatry of 907 Fifth Avenue, to George Jellenik Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Jellenik, also of New York.

Hornblower Weeks have opened an office in the Eastern Trust and Banking Company Building, Bangor, Me., under the management of James H. Freeland, formerly manager of the Bangor office of Wrenn Brothers Co.

Sarah Lawrence College of Bronxville will inaugurate its second decade with a dinner tomorrow night at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventyfirst Street, for parents of present and former students, alumnae and their husbands and friends. James H. Perkins will preside.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Frida Kondrup Frazer, daughter of Mrs. Randolph Leigh of this place and of Laurence S. Frazer of Nashville, Tenn., to W. Thacher Winslow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Nickerson Winslow of Boston.

The economic factors of supply and demand dominated the American wheat markets last week. Prospects for larger European purchases during the balance of the season were offset largely by continued favorable reports of the weather and the crops.

Emmanuel M. Cohan, trustee of Series K, State Title and Mortgage Company, announced that he is sending today to 400 certificate holders checks representing a payment of 2 1/2 per cent on the principal of the issue.

One run was scored in the second inning of the Giants-Dodgers' series finale at Ebbets Field yesterday and the 35,078 chilled fans saw not another runner cross the plate. Since Mel Ott, the mighty little man, accounted for that all-important tally by banging a Van Lingle Mel Mungo pitch over the scoreboard and screen, the Giants today are bringing a four-game winning streak into the Polo Grounds against the Phillies.

The program for the 1938 conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, to be held on Mav 4 to 6 inclusive in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, was announced yesterday. Henry R. Kinsey, president, will open the conference with an address setting forth "The Mission of Savings Banks."
Percy A. Robbins, mining engineer, economist and traveler, died today in his home in Highland Park after a year's illness. He was 64 years old.

The special committee of the Senate which has been investigating the problem of relief has recommended certain changes in the policies of the National Government, but strongly endorsed the basic principle of continuing a Federal program of work relief.

The awarding of the national.. championships 'to the St. Paul Figure Skating Club of St. Paul, Minn. for the first time was among the leading developments of the annual meeting of the United States Figure Skating Association, which came to a close at' the Hotel Lincoln yesterday. The title event will be held' late in January or-early in February, in conjunction with St. Paul's "City Week" carnival.

The New York Central Railroad Co sold to Isaac L. Gibbs and Bertha Meth, who reside at 659 W 131st St. the parcel at that address for a consideration indicated as $19,000 and they gave back a purchase money mortgage for $12,000, payable five years hence at 5 per cent, and gave a third mortgage to Sadie Alperin for $2,000.
Financial circles here are rather disturbed about President Roosevelt's new "reflation" policy, first because such a measure has not been very successful in the past.
The 1937 junior hurling championship was won by Cork yesterday at Innisfail Park where 1,500 fans saw Galway bow by 4 goals and 2 points (14 points) to 4 goals (12 points) in an interesting game.

Five minutes after the first showing of the film "The Spanish Earth" began here this morning the picture died out, the theatre went dark and a voice from the rear said calmly: "Gentlemen, there is an air raid alarm."

Only eleven gunners reported at c the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. O. Agathon won the scratch trophy by breaking 95 out of 100. The handicap prize went to C. T. Jackson, who had a card of 94-4-98.

Imports of gold received here last month amounted to ??28,829,197, compared with [Pound]37,575,901 in March, 1937, and they made the aggregate for the first three months of this year [Pound]56,372,632, against [Pound]91,116,165 a year before.
Toy military gear upon which the children of the violent nations cut their second teeth constitutes less than 1 per cent of the toys at the American Toy Fair opening today at 200 Fifth Avenue.

The restoration fund for Stratford Hall, the birthplace in Westmoreland County, Va., of famous members of the Lee family, will be the beneficiary of an exhibition of paintings to be given tomorrow afternoon at River House by Mrs. Arthur A. Ballantine.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Initiative in British financial markets is being stifled temporarily by the imminence of the government's budget. With the large intensified armament program immediately ahead, the budget becomes even more difficult than usual to forecast, and the City wisely has abandoned the attempt.

Despite a resumption of the Reich's export surplus after two 'months of deficit, trade figures for March cannot be considered altogether favorable. The seasonal increase in exports, which in 1937 was 56,000,000 marks, dropped to 42,000,000 marks this year.

Seventy manufacturers will join in presenting new designs to furniture dealers from all parts of the United States in the semi-annual Jamestown Furniture Market to begin Wednesday at Jamestown, N. Y. An attendance of 1,000 dealers is expected at the market, which continues through May 7.

BALTIMORE-A. G. Clothiers; R. Goldberg. ready-to-wear, accessories; 225 W 34th (T. Epstein). BALTIMORE-Brager-Eisenberg, Inc.; J. C. Fenton. notions. leather goods, jewelry. bathing accessories; A. Howlett, silks.. wash goods, linens, domestics; J. Block. men's furnishings; M. Frieman,

Assessments levied by Newark in 1935 against five properties of the Prudential Insurance Company in the center of the city have been reduced by $3,519,400 by the State Tax Board, it was disclosed today.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in a Montreal hospital of Robert W. Boissevain of Westport, N. Y., former president of the United States Navigation Company, operators of freighters and agents for foreign shipping lines. Mr. Boissevain, who was about 60 years old, had been ill with stomach ulcers for three weeks.

The Associated Telephone and Telegraph Company, in its annual report for 1937, shows net earnings of $566,873 after expenses, taxes, interest and amortization. The net was equal to $7.07 each on 80,161 shares of 7 per cent and $6 first preferred stock outstanding.
The New York PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conductor, completed the twenty-seventh and penultimate week of its current season with its concert at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.
A master key to the cosmic ray puzzle has been discovered by Dr. Robert A. Millikan, head of California Institute of Technology, and his coworkers, it was reported here tonight.

The Greek Catholic Church celebrated Easter yesterday throughout the world while in New York special services and processions marked the observance which is in accordance with the Greek Catholic calendar.

ONE more letter from Denver and it will be necessary to take steps. Perhaps Postmaster General James A. Farley will come to the rescue of a beleaguered citizen who is being bombarded through the mails. Or it might be stopped if the big-league officials would obligingly rip Rules 44 and 50 out of the baseball code.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Lewis Campbell of 930 Park Avenue, this city, and of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Robertson Campbell, to Donald Howes Gleason, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bemis Gleason of Newton, Mass.

Topping a field of thirty-six pointers and setters, including a number of the big circuit performers, Inspector Bimpkins today carried off first money in the open all-age Stake, leading number of the threeday meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club.

The color scheme for the 1939 World's Fair, the result of two years' work by experts, was disclosed yesterday by Grover A. Whalen,- president of the fair corporation. The-main exhibit area will be of rainbow hue.

Cardinal Hayes presided and made an address yesterday at solemn high mass in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eightyfourth Street, at the annual school commemoration of the Feast of St. Ignatius Loyola, the founder of the Society of Jesus.

Stocks rallied, but failed to recover all losses of week; turnover, 4,328,700 shares. United States Government bonds up 1 to 2 points in largest weekly trading in a year, with corporate and foreign loans also higher; transactions, $38,142,175.

Plans for altering the two fivestory apartment houses at 161-63 East Ninety-fifth Street were announced in connection with-the sale of the buildings by the Bowery Savings Bank to a client of Nathan Friedman, attorney.

Mayor La Guardia of New York swapped yarns with a World War buddy here today while th resting from activities of his Southwestern tour. He was the guest of Dr.O. B. Kiel, who served with him on the Italian front and whose skillful treatment when Mr. La Guardia was wounded was credited with saving his life.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mayor La Guardia's expose of the waste in our Municipal Court system should be taken seriously by the citizens of this city and at the same time be a reminder to citizens of other cities to subject their municipal expenditures to greater scrutiny.

Official reports set the stock of bread cereals in the Reich on April 1 at 1,100,000 tons more than on the same date a year ago. The total, it is estimated, will cover consumption until the new harvest and leave a surplus.
An order to cease and desist from an alleged attempt to discourage membership in the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen, of North America, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor,

Guiga Bahri Ben Hamoda, Tunisian nationalist leader, was arrested here today on a charge of conspiracy against the republic. Guiga Bahri fled French-governed Tunisia following recent riots there in which thirteen persons were slain.

The Sudeten German party congress, at which Konrad Henlein proclaimed today his public allegiance to the National-Socialist ideology and served on the Czechoslovak Government eight demands, is being followed in Germany with intense interest.

Progress ever carries with it the loss of picturesque figures. Thus the old style of whaling disappeared when kerosene replaced whale oil in lamps and steel was found as good as whalebone for reinforcing ladies' foundation garments. Whaling came back, but it is now disgustingly mechanized.
The last week of April not only finds more than a score of exhibitions on the art calendar but among them a number of events of signal interest.

The Indians moved into the undisputed lead in the American League by beating the Tigers, 9 to 4, today as Bobby Feller held the Bengals scoreless in all except the final inning. The loss dropped Detroit to last place.

New York City spent $343,021,882 in the first quarter of this year and collected $364,454,040 through revenues and borrowihgs, according to a report yesterday by Almerindo Portfolio, the City Treasurer. At the close of the period the city had cash bank deposits of $113.551.030.

Business in rayon woven fabrics for the week ended April 16 was featured by a "crystallization of the many inquiries for cloths in the staples and linings field," according to the report issued for publication today by the National Rayon Weavers Association.

" New fangled ideas" will not plague members of the Police Department in the next four years, Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday at a rally of the Holy Name Society for the Boroughs of Brooklyn and Queens in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

An entertainment entitled "La Revue Directoire" will serve to open the St. Regis Roof on the night of May 3 for the late Spring and Summer season. The occasion will be a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Vincent Astor is acting chairman.
The General Headquarters Air Force is to move May 1 to the defense of New England in an imaginary war in which the United States is being attacked by a coalition of "Asiatic and European powers."

Germany's wholesaleprice index is 105.6, unchanged from last week. In the first months of this year the hghest point reached by the German wholesale price index was 105.8 on March 2. It remained at that figure until March 30.

The production of basic chemicals was higher in March than at the beginning of the year, while the general level of industrial output remained virtually unchanged in the first quarter, the Guaranty Survey, the monthly review of Guaranty Trust Company, reports.

The minority of the Senate's Special Committee to Investigate Unemployment and Relief issued today a preliminary report supporting the majority's preliminary report of Wednesday in its attack on the undistributed-profits tax and request for modification of the capital-gains tax.
The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company has reported for the twelve months ended on March 31 net earnings of $11,328,918 after charges for depreciation, amortization, contingencies and Federal income taxes.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Reuben Mord of West Brighton, S. I., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rosalie Faith Mord, to Dr. Henry Litinsky of New Dorp, S. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Litinsky of Brooklyn.

Second thoughts on President Roosevelt's spending plans have induced caution and doubts here that were absent in the first flush of excitement. These proposals generally have been examined here as a whole rather than individually, and the verdict is that permanent prosperity cannot spring from them unless they are accompanied by action that will restore the confidence of business men.

The cotton market here was on the te quiet side last week. Prices fluctuated from day to day, but the changes were somewhat erratic and net changes were advances of 1 to 3 points. In early trading the market showed a disposition to improve, owing to traders' expectation of inflation from the Administration's "pump-priming" proposals.

Mayor La Guardia will be among the speakers at the 155th convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Ybrk, which will open at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on May 10, it was announced yesterday.
The most widely held appraisal here concerning trade in the United States is that the current levels will continue through the Summer.

Charles Sumner Hamlin, first governor of the Federal Reserve Board, died today after a long illness. He was 76 years old. At his death he was special counsel to the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System.
" The Hundred Days," that spectacular moment in history between Napoleon's escape from Elba and his banishment to St. Helena, is to be filmed by Warner Brothers. The idea was initiated as a short,

John Quincy Adams, prominent for many years in New Jersey Masonic activities, died last night at his home here after a long illness. His age was 80. Born in New York, Mr. Adams came here in 1872. He retired from the banking business thirty years ago. A member of Century Lodge.

With its highly regarded forward wall functioning smoothly throughout the contest, the undefeated Queens Rugby Club triumphed over the Harvard University Rugby Club, 6 to 0, at Alley Pond Park in Douglaston, Queens, yesterday. The victory was the seventh in as many starts for Queens this season.

Following a five-week vacation from competition, the army of golf professionals will return to action on May 12, when the thirty-first annual metropolitan open championship starts a three-day run at the Fresh Meadow Country Club at Flushing.
The first outdoor informal match in preparation for the 1938 polo campaign was staged today at Preece Field, with the Whites conquering the Reds. 6 to 3.

Opposition to any proposal which would involve the Court of Appeals in reapportionment of the Legislative and Congressional districts of the State was voiced tonight by Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane of the court, who is also president of the Constitutional Convention.

Out in McPherson College, Kansas, is Professor J. Willard Hershey, maker of real diamonds. They are not exactly Kohinoors, these gems. A jeweler would not even dignify them as "chips." The largest, a colossus in Professor Hershey's eyes, weighs only a thirtieth of a carat.
The Athletics pounded four Red Sox rookie pitchers for fourteen hits, including home runs by Dario Lodigiani and Bob Johnson, to gain their first victory of the season, 10 to 4, today.

The laughter of a bridal party turned to screams in a photographer's studio today when flames enveloped the girls' flimsy frocks, burning two bridesmaids to death. The bride and six others in the party of fifteen were burned seriously.

After nine years of service in the field of improved housing standards, the Multiple Dwelling Law Committee has. been dissolved, it was announced yesterday, after an exchange of letters between Harold Riegelman, counsel to the group, and Lawson Purdy, chairman.
Frank G. Wisner, president of the First National Bank of Laurel, Miss., and long active in the national and Southern lumber industry, died here today of pneumonia. His age was 66.

American tire manufacturers have spent $55,000,000 on research in the last ten years, Walter J. Geldard, chief chemist of the Fist Tire Company, reported here today. This has brought the United States leadership in the world tire market, he said.

World peace, now threatened by ambitious Fascist and Communist nations, can 'only be attained through widespread acceptance of Christian principles, the Right Rev. Dr. Benjamin M. Washburn, Episcopal Bishop of Newark, declared yesterday afternoon at the St. George Day Service at the Cathe dral of St. John the Divine.

A banking syndicate headed by Estabrook Co. will offer formally today a new issue of $2,600,000 of city of Hartford, Conn., 1 3/4 per cent bonds dated May 2, 1938, and maturing serially on May 1, 1939 to 1953. The bonds are to be priced to yield from 0.35 to 1.75 per cent, according to maturity.

Stopford William Wentworth Brooke, former Unitarian minister at the First Church in Boston, died yesterday at Cranleigh, Surrey, at the age of 79. Mr. Brooke, who was the son of Stopford Brooke, the famous Unitarian minister, had lived in the United States for eighteen years.

Mrs. Duryee de Saint Phalle of 157 East Seventy-second Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alix de Saint Phalle, to William Cornelius Hall of New York and Newburgh, N. Y., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Bernard Hall.

Lord Britain, 8-year-old chestnut gelding from Mrs. Edgar Mayer's May Top Stables in Port Chester, climaxed a brilliant day by winning the hunter championship at the annual horse show today of the Hutchinson Riding Academy. Reserve honors went to the 9-year-old gray gelding Dancing Partne, owned by Mrs. Dorothy White of Port Chester.
Beachcombing is having a revival in this area and thousands lined the shores to- pins day to scramble for pieces of cargo from the wreck of the British whiz freighter City of Salisbury.
Miss Phyllis Jones was married here this afternoon at the home of her mother, Mrs. Fisher Jones, to Charles Townsend Letson, son of Mrs. Charles T. Letson, also of Metuchen, and the late Mr. Letson.

Cotton prices were little changed last week. The buying enthusiasm which followed the announcement in the previous week that the Federal Government was embarking on a spending and easy-money program, was greatly modified. On the New York Cotton Exchange, active contracts at the close on S.aturday were unchanged to 4 points down from the previous week.

Tendencies on the Bourse here this week were influenced chiefly by the foreign-exchange market's trend. Foreign currencies were offered in large volume onTuesday and Wednesday and readily absorbed by the market, especially for commercial needs, while francs, were purchased to facilitate operatoins in stocks. By Thursday, however,

George Lyttleton Upshur, a son of the late Rear Admiral John Henry Upshur and believed to have been the oldest surviving descendant of Martha Washington, died yesterday of heart disease at his residence, 110 West Fifty-fifth Street, at the age of 82. His widow, who was Minnie Milliken at their marriage fifty-three years ago, survives.

Wearing the war-time uniformsofwornen's groups that aided the A. E. F. in France,members of the New York unit, Women's Overseas Service League, held a memorial service yesterday .afternoon in Corpus Christi-Roman Catholic Church, 529 West i21st Street, for members who have died. More than 350 persons attended.
The general trade outlook in Continental Europe has improved somewhat lately because of the better political atmosphere, and further amelioration is expected toward Autumn.

Mrs. Phoebe Elsen Carter, daughter of Professor Joseph Elsen, violin teacher who led the Military Academy Band at West Point for forty years, and widow of Henry Carter, a Newburgh (N. Y.) florist, died at her home here yesterday at the age of 72. She was a niece of Brig.
North Texas Teachers and Michigan State will have the favored pole positions in two races each at the forty fourth annual University of Pennsylvania relay carnival Friday and Saturday.

" WIND OVER WISCONSIN,"* by August Derleth, who was recently awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship, is good reading. It belongs in the same galley as "Gone With the Wind," "Drums Along the Mohawk" and "Northwest Passage." Mr. Derleth's patience is not as great as the first author's, his hand not as steady as the second's, his future not as assured as the third's (Kenneth Roberts, after years of merely local fame,

Religious enthusiasm tends too often to pass with the Easter season, the Rev. Dr. Merle H. Anderson, pastor of North Presbyterian Church, 525 West 155th Street, dedared in his morning sermon yesterday.
Gains of 1.1 per cent in March employment by retail stores in New York State and 0.4 per cent in payrolls over February were reported today by the State Industrial Commissioner, Elmer F. Andrews.

Mrs. Charles Morgan Jr. of 132 East Ninety-fifth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Camilla Morgan, to Remsen Ditmars Donald, son of Mrs. George Donald of 1,220 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Donald.

Harry W. Mack, formerly for several years Republican leader of the old Fifteenth Assembly District, New York, and recently chief counsel to the New York law firm of McCauley, Spiegelberg, Davis Gallagher of 70 Pine Street, Manhattan, died here last night of a heart attack at the home of George B. Bernheim, where he was a visitor. His age was 77.
Leonard Crawley, generally recognized as the finest amateur golfer in England, Is favored to win the thirteenth English amateur championship at the Moortown Golf Club, starting tomorrow.
Samuel L. Rothbard, Ne Wark attorney, announced today that he would file an appeal tomorrow in Hudson County Common Pleas Court from the Police Court conviction of James F. (Jeff) Burkitt,
Herman Fink, Buffalo righthander, pitched six-hit ball before a crowd of 17,400 persons to hand Jersey City's Little Giants their initial defeat of the season today, 7 to 2.
A single by Merrill May in the tenth inning that scored Les Scarsella from second base gave the champion Bears a 3-to-2 victory over Toronto today. It was their third straight triumph.

The United Box and Lumber Company of Belleville, N. J., has purchased one and one-half acres at Clifford Street, Wheeler Point Road and Delancey Street, Newark, N. J., from William Rubin for improvement with a one-story building.

The uncertainty prevailing in the financial mind is sufficiently illustrated by the markets. Stock market averages, having advanced 12% points in the first half of April, declined 6 points in last week's earlier days, then recovered more than 5 before the week was over.
The Votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the only important roll-call in Congress, during the period from April.16 to 22, are given in the. following tabulation:

James P. Lardner, 23 years old, second son of the late Ring W. Lardner, American author, quit today as a war correspondent to enlist in an international brigade fighting with Spanish Government forces.

The "moral failure" of the Amer can people, evidenced in their increasing consumption of liquor, was held responsible last night for the economic depression now facing the country by Fred A. Victor, State Superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League.

For the second successive day and the eighth time in ner career, the white standard poodle bitch Champion Blakeen Jung Frau, tonight captured a best-in-show trophy to conclude the second annual Union County Kennel Club all-breed exhibition at the Elizabeth Armory.

Varied reports on the state of business over the country and of sentiment toward the New Deal were given yesterday by some of the nation's leading newspaper publishers as they arrived in New York City.

An appeal for the annihilation of all "subversive groups" active in New York City was made yesterday by Abraham Cohen, who was reelected county commander of the Kings County Council, Jewish War Veterans of the United States, at the annual convention held yesterday at the Jewish Community Center, 661 Linden Boulevard. Brooklyn.

Music that ranged from the classics to the popular Flamencos of the Andalusian gypsies was performed by Vicente Gomez, young Spanish guitarist, at his first American recital giver last night in Town Hall.

The Eastern Athletic Club Basketball League held its annual dinner last night at the Crescent A. C. in Brooklyn with the election of officers featuring the event. Albert Sturcke of the New Mooners was chosen president for the second year while Edward Russell, New York A. C., and Dave Lawrie, Newark A. C., were elected vice president and secretary-treasurer, respectively.
Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday the posthumous award of the Department Medal of Honor to five members of the Police Department who were killed in the line of duty in 1937.
Philippine customs officials said today they would ask the imposition of a fine against any Japanese fishing vessels found to have refueled within the insular threemile limit the night of April 10.

Fascist authorities today suppressed an issue of the newspaper Popolo di Roma containing an article considered to reflect on the character of the Spanish people. Entitled "The Spanish Panorama," the article attributed the Spanish civil war to racial char-' acteristics "of indiscipline and anarchy" of the Spanish people.

The engagement of Miss Mary Meredith Nichols, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Osgood Nichols of Short Hills, N. J., and Onteora Park, N. Y., to Florus Marcel van der Does, son of the Honorable Lady Wilhelmien van der Does of Scheveningen, Holland, and the late William Charles van der Does, has been announced by her parents.

Mr. and Mrs. George M. Schlee gave a dinner last night at their home, 114 East Seventy-eighth Street, to celebrate Russian Easter. Their guests included the Grand Duchess Marie, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bull, Mr. and Mrs. Robert De Vecchi, Prince and Princess Paul Chavchavadze, Mr. and Mrs.
The Rev. Edward H. Ford, honorary canon of the Episcopal Cathedral Church of St. John in this city, died at his home today after a short illness. His age was 72.
A traffic light system has been adopted by the Southern Rhodesian Parliament to control the length of the speeches of its members.
Cyril Kissane, former managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, died suddenly at his home, 3555 the Eightieth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, yesterday of a heart attack. He was 46 years old.
H. G. Wells, British author, today expressed agreement with "that clearheaded, original American, Henry Ford, when he said 'history is bunk.'"

Negotiation of the Italian-French accord will be held up until the Italian Foreign Minister, Count Galeazzo Ciano, returns next Thursday from the wedding of King Zog of Albania and Countess Geraldine Apponyi.

A "wholesale" Chinese retreat in Kiangsu Province was reported tonight by Japanese military authorities, who said that the withdrawal enabled their fighters to push nearer the vital east-west Lung-Hai Railway, long a Japanese objective.
As an aftermath of the airing of Governor Earle's financial relations with Matthew H. McCloskey Jr., building contractor and Democratic party leader,

Josephus Daniels, Ambassador to Mexico, and Mrs. Daniels will celebrate their golden wedding anniversary here on May 2. The reception at Wakestone, the Daniels home, will be attended by all the Raleigh friends of the couple and their children.
Philadelphia at New York-Passeau vs. Hubbell or Lohrman. Brooklyn at Boston-Pressnell vs Turner. Chicago at Pittsburgh-Bryant vs, Bauers. St. Louis at Cincinnati-Welland vs. Derringer.

The report of the Bank of France dated April 14 shows a further increase in its advances to the State amounting to 580,000,000 francs, so that the government's borrowing margin has been reduced to less than 2,000,000,000 francs, to which must be added 10,000,000,000 in authorized new advances.

Professor Frank Justus Miller. Classical scholar and Emeritus Professor of Latin of the University of Chicago, died last night at the Norwalk Hospital after a brief Illness. He was 79 years old. He wrote many books and articles on the classics.
A union jurisdiction dispute threatened tonight to cut off the country's $45,000,000 annual Alaska salmon pack as well as the jobs of 20,000 men and 80 per cent of Alaska's revenue.

Chicago carried off its first national soccer championship yesterday as the well-balanced Sparta eleven triumphed over the St. Mary's Celtics of Brooklyn, 3-2, in a thrilling encounter witnessed by an overflow crowd of 10,000 at Stara three-point advantage, gained last week in the Windy City, Sparta captured the crown on the total-goal basis by 6--2.

Holyrood Protestant Episcopal Church, Fort Washington Avenue at 179th Street, observed a double anniversary yesterday morning at a special choral eucharist service. The Rev. Dr. Gustav Arnold Carstensen, rector emeritus, returned to the pulpit to deliver congratulations to the rector, the Rev. Arthur P. S. Hyde, and to give a sermon on the meaning of the resurrection.

Sermons were preached and varied religious services held in all the towns of the original New Haven colony today in commemoration of the 300th anniversary of its settlement. The tercentenary celebration will be in progress for six weeks.
Lewis H. Stanton, son of Edwin M. Stantion, secretary of War in President Abraham Lincoln's Cabinet, died today of a heart attack at his home here. His age was 78.

Mrs. Boulton Dixon Saltus, wife of R. Sanford Saltus, a real estate and investment broker, died yesterday after a long illness. Her age was 45. Mrs. Saltus, who lived in Viilanova, was the daughter of William Boulton Dixon and Mrs. Lana Jones Dixon and was the widow of Morris W. Stroud Jr. She was a member of the Acorn, Gardeners and Valley Forge Gun Clubs.

Polish political circles were aroused tonight by reports that a Polish balloon had been fired on by Czechoslovak frontier guards and the balloon's two occupants arrested when they landed in Czechoslovakia.

Senator Wheeler asserted today that the government's efforts to lend and spend the nation out of depression would "in the long run" mean either a "general liquidation" or inflation with disastrous results.

Figures issued this week by the Bank of the Netherlands reflect clearly the alleviation in Europe's political anxiety and a complete return of confidence in the guilder. The bank's stocks of gold are constantly increasing again and have reached a new high level of 1,480,000,000 guilders (at the old parity) against 670,000,000 before devaluation.

Foreign trade of The Netherlands is holding up remarkably well. Its imports for the first quarter of this year amounted to 358,000,000 guilders, compared with 406,000,000 in the last quarter of 1937 and 336,000,000 in the first quarter of 1937.

Charles G. Dawes, former Vice President of the United States, underwent an operation in Roosevelt Hospital last night. Dr. Henry W. Cave, who attended him, declined to disclose the nature of the illness or his condition after the operation, but said a bulletin would be issued by the hospital this morning.

The marriage of Miss Cynthia Hymanson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Hymanson of 1,225 Park Avenue, to Dr. Jules D. Gordon, son of Mrs. Jennie Gordon, also of New York, and the late Samuel I. Gordon, took place yesterday afternoon in the Italian Garden of the Ambassador Hotel.

Directors of the B. M. T. will consider at their next meeting a new pension plan for the company's 12,000 employes, to become effective July 1. The new plan, to replace the existing pension and welfare arrangements, will be formulated on an actuarial basis.

By the terms of a new decree promulgated in Brazil, effective April 13, it has been declared, in effect, that subsoil deposits of petroleum, natural gas and rare. gases are the property of the government, the American commercial attach at Rio de Janeiro has reported to the Department of Commerce.

Going ahead with his assignment despite the fact that his foster father had just died of a heart attack; Danny MacFayden, the Bees' curve-ball artist, pitched a three-hit game today and led Boston to a 2-0 victory over Philadelphia. It was the home team's second straight triumph over the Phillies.

The Federal Symphony Orchestra, under Edgar Schenkman, was heard last night at the WPA Theatre of Music in a program comprising the Fourth symphony and "Tapiola" of Sibelius, Berlioz's . "Benvenuto Cellini" overture and the Schumann piano concerto with Joseph Battista as soloist.

The Rev. C. F. Derstine of Kitchener, Ont., Bishop of the Mennonite Church of Canada, spoke on "Thrills Over the Living God" yesterday morning at the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 114th Street. Bishop Derstine said that David shouted about God.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry N. Matthews gave a tea at their home here today at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Matthews, to Francis G. Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Jackson of Westwood.

The Official Gazette today published a decree threatening a year's imprisonment for any one who helps to camouflage Jewish ownership of a business establishment. The same punishment was provided for those who conducted any legal business for a Jew without making it clear that they were acting for a "non-Aryan."

Prominent figures of the theatre, church and politics, including former Governor Alfred E. Smith and Postmaster General James A. Farley, were among the 1,000 guests paying tribute to George M. Cohan at a testimonial dinner sponsored by the Catholic Actors Guild at Hotel Astor last night.
While the sailing dinghy season was supposed to have ended last weekend, the temptation of fine weather brought out nine of the one-design B craft today at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

Count Karol Romer, 53 years old, Foreign Office Chief of Protocol, was found dead, shot in the head, at 6 o'clock this morning, on his Inwald estate south of Cracow. According to an official statement, Count Romer was killed accidentally while handling his gun in his bedroom.

Without referring by name to his recent attack on Life magazine for its publication of the birth-of-ababy pictures and his ban on the sale of the April 11 issue in the Bronx, District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx defended his action yesterday with the assertion that "my ideas are Catholic ideas and American ideas."

The comparatively new profession of social work, which has come to the fore in the last few years, has been of such nature that it is rapidly becoming "indispensable" to modern life, Walter S. Gifford president of the Charity Organization Society of the City of New York, -declared in the fifty-ninth annual report of the society, made public yesterday.

Mrs. Breckinridge Long, wife of the former United States Ambassador to Italy, left the Ambassador hotel yesterday for Laurel, Md. Robert Mills McClintock, vice consul of the United States Legation in the Dominican Republic, and Mrs. McClintock will return from Europe this week and will be at the Savoy-Plaza.

What rural electrification means in terms of a higher standard of living and opportunities for profitable farming in sections that never had electric power until it was supplied by the Tennessee Valley Authority is shown by the experience of the North Georgia Membership Corporation.
Sir Guy Dawber, prominent architect and an ardent campaigner for the preservation of rural England, died, at his home in London today at the age of 76.
Dr. Louis von Cotzhausen, a retired physician and physiotherapist, died at Hahnemann Hospital today at the age of 84.

A ghost of a theory and or the man who expounded it haunts the ruins of Spanish towns and the bomb-cratered rubble of Chinese cities these days. For the late General Giulio Douhet, Italian apostle of victory by air, died too soon to see his theory written off the books of history by the indomitable spirit of the Madrilefios, by the persevering pertinacity of Chinese coolies.

Differences between the highest and the lowest rates on Jan. 1, 1937, for stated quantities of electricity in communities of like populations in New York State ranged from 104.2 per cent to as high, in one case,

In sermons by a Jewish rabbi and a Congregational clergyman preached yesterday morning from the pulpit of Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, made famous by the antislavery sermons of Henry Ward Beecher, Christians were challenged to apply the principles of Christ in the economic and political life of, the nation.

George Grey Barnard, who spent a lifetime recapturing the spirit of the Renaifsance in a modern age and whose statues grace the great galleries of the world, died yesterday of a heart ailment in the Harkness Pavilion at the Medical Center at the age of 74.

The Austrian National Bank announced today that it will cease purchasing gold and foreign currencies as of tomorrow. Effective on Tuesday, it is to delegate this function to the Reichsbank, which will apply the official rate-that is -pproximately 27 per cent less than the amount now paid by the Austrian National Bank.

Nation-wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated at 33 per cent of capacity, a one-point decline from the rate in the, two preceding weeks and slightly less than one point under the average rate in March, which was the high month since last November.

The crews of the M. I. T. Nautical Association came back strong today in the final racing for the new Henry .A. Morss Memorial Trophy and captured the second annual dinghy championships of the Intercollegiate Y. R. A., held under Tech auspices in the Charles River basin.

As indicated in this column last Tuesday, "I Married. an Angel" will open on Broadway the week of May 9, coming probably to the Broadhurst, Shubert or Winter Garden. Since the Dwight Deere Wiman musical is a heavy scenic production, the chances favor the Winter Garden, which also has a cooling system.

The leader of Britain's organized munitions workers demanded today that all profits from armaments be turned over to the national Treasury.
The meeting of the British and French Ministers, which has been arranged for London for Thursday and Friday of this week, will have an importance even greater than the public knows.

Forum and luncheon, Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Hotel Commodore, 10:30 A. M. Women's National Republican Club. "My Chinese Holiday Under Fire," Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., 11 A. M.; "New York State Constitutional Convention," Jane H. Todd.
In Liver a New Jersey northern zone registered shoot today Dr. A. T. Vickers took Class A honors. J. D. Rake, J. D. Rowland, P. Holloway and L. Pagliughi tied for second.

Malcolm W. Schuler, formerly for ten years president of the Chapaqua School Board, died at his home here today after an illness of four months due to a nervous breakdown and a cardiac ailment. Born in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., fifty-one years ago, he attended the Bradley Polytechnic Institute and later was graduated from Teachers College, Columbia.

Artisans worked through the week-end to erect ten altars in the Essex House here for the use of Archbishops and Bishops coming to Newark for the installation on Wednesday of Archbishop-elect Thomas J. Walsh and other church ceremonies this week.

The Long Island University baseball team ended 'its southern trip by losing to the Penn A. C., at the Phillies park today, 9--5. First Baseman Abraham Abramo witz of the Blackbirds injured his right shoulder in a collision with Catcher Freddy Barnes of the home team in the second inning.

The 116th anniversary of the birth of Ulysses S. Grant was observed yesterday at his tomb on Riverside Drive at 123d Street. More than 1,000 persons participated, including several hundred uniformed members of junior and senior patriotic organizations, who marched to the exercises along the Drive.

Once more the books are to burn. Once again German Kultur will assure its continuity, this time by purging the Vienna National Library and disposing of all that is of "non-Aryan" origin or otherwise proscribed. As the flames feed on these volumes from the Hofburg, they will cast queer,

The Russian Easter observed. today by many thousands of remaining devout was marked-whether by coincidence or design-by an announcement of the wholesale arrest of religious persons, headed by a Moscow Archbishop,
David L. Podell, New York lawyer, yesterday was unanimously elected president of the Council of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations of the New York and Brooklyn Jewish Federations of Charities.
Nothing could seem more innocent than the refreshing ice cream cone. Yet within its cool depths lurk potentialities for crime undreamed of by those who have not succumbed to its sinister enticements.

John Wesley and Methodism would never have been known to modern Christians if it were not for the changed lives his teachings wrought, the Rev. Dr. Charles Wesley Flint, Bishop of the Atlanta Methodist Area, Ga., declared yesterday in his sermon at Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Reports from Innsbruck indicate that the inhabitants of South Tyrol had ceased their passive acceptance of Italian authority there. Swastikas have been hoisted and the Hitler salute is employed among them despite the prohibition of the authorities.

National Challenge Cup Sparta of Chicago 3, St. Mary's Celtics 2. National Junior Cup Senate Boys of Harrison 3, Bay Ridge Hearts. New York State Cup Brooklyn Germans 4. Gjoa 3. New York State Junior Cup GJoa Juniors 0, New York Germans Juniors 0 (overtime).

John P. Alexander, a sales engineer for the General Electric Company for the last twenty-five years, died at his home, 469 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, yesterday at the age of 62. He had been ill for a year.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks:

Street car and bus service was resumed here at noon today following settlement of a strike. Members of the Amalgamated Association of Electric Railway and Motor Bus Employes Union, an A. F. of L. group, approved a proposal to end the strike,
Regent Konstantin Paets today was elected the first President of the Estonian Republic under the new Constitution with 219 votes against an opposition of 19.

Dr. R. H. Ecker Jr., with 490 1/2 points, took the lead at the end of the fourth session of twenty-eight boards played last night at the Park Central Hotel in the competition for the individual masters championship.

A special performance of Bizet's "Carmen" was given by the Hippodrome Opera Company last night at the Hippodrome in aid of Haarlem House of New York. The presentation, which was sponsored by a committee headed by Mrs. Fiorello H. La Guardia and Commissioner of Public Welfare Edward Corsi, attracted a large and appreciative gathering.

The stock market reopened after the Easter holidays on a dull trading pace, but with a confident undertone which was maintained all through the week. Sharp advances were registered by certain industrial equities and specialties, but the general pieture was irregular.
One of the largest striped bass caught in the vicinity of Atlantic City, N. J., in years was taken on Thursday by Ralph Chevalier of the Atlantic City Tuna Club. The striper weighed 42 3/4 pounds.

Commodore Sir Arthur T. Harris, British Army Aviation Service; Air Commodore James G. Weir, Commander Caspar John, Squadron Leader Charles E. Horrex and Lord Ventry are due to arrive today from England on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

Konrad Henlein delivered his much-heralded speech on Sudeten German demands at the conference of his Sudeten German party in Karlsbad today. It was uttered in terms so strong that in government circles it is considered to have postponed indefinitely the hopes

Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau, on behalf of the Commodity Credit Corporation, the government agency which makes crop loans, offers for subscription tomorrow through the Federal Reserve Banks $200,000,000 of the corporation's...

The Minister of War has appointed General Eberhardt Bohnstedt to be director of El Salvador's military academy and has transferred a number of high officers serving in the capital to provincial regiments.

Strength in cottonseed oil furnished the bullish incentive in the lard market last week. Buying of lard against sales of cottonseed oil by speculators who misjudged the situation a while ago resulted in lard closing 5 to 10 cents for 100 pounds higher

In a surprising finish to some seven hours of fencing, Dernell Every of the New York A., C. and Frank Righeimer of the Lake Shore A. C. of Chicago gained the final round of the national foils championship yesterday at the N. Y. A. C. as both Joe Levis and Hugh Alessandroni, titleholders for the last seven years, yielded the crown to their fellow Olympians.

Eddie Cantor, the comedian, was obliged to call off a preview rehearsal at the Coluinbia Broadcasting System studios last night as well as his regular broadcast tonight because of an attack of influenza.
ADAMS--April 23, 1938, at his residence, 370 Purrell Ave., South Orange, John Quincy, beloved husband of Christine Degen Adams. Private services at convenience of the family. Kindly omit flowers.

Declaring himself against armament expansion contemplated under the $1,156,000,000 naval bill pending in Congress, Senator La Follette warned today that "if the United States gears its productive machinery to an expanding armament program,

The sweeping character of the demands presented to the Czechoslovak Government by Konrad Henlein has shocked public opinion here. It is generally felt that it would be better for the Czechs to surrender the Sudeten district to Germany outright than to consent to a process of cantonization that probably would end in the complete break-up of the country into different nationalities.

There are several ways of looking at the Tax Bill that has finally emerged from conference. If we compare it with existing tax provisions, it is a very substantial improvement. Though it retains the "principle" of the undistributed-profits tax, that tax has become the merest shadow of its former self.

George Austen, a prominent resident of Albermarle County for thirty years, died here today at the age of 89. At the age of 16 he went to the Philippines and was associated there with the old Boston shipping firms of Russell, Sturgis Co. and Peel, Hubbell Co., returning to the United States in 1882.

After breakfasting on bread and milk bought at his own expense to supplement the rice and sour plums of prison fare, Melvin H. Gibbon, New York. aviator, faced a resumed examination by Sergeant Tokutaro Hasegawa this morning.

If leaders in Congress can keep their colleagues to tentative schedules two important measures will be acted upon this week. Opponents of another major bill, that on wages and hours, were reported planning an attempt to bury it in the House Rules Committee by a campaign of delay.

Democracy, which came with the tide of Christianity, must strengthen itself by observance of spiritual principles, the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox declared in a sermon yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. The Cadet Choir of the United States Military Academy, West Point, sang at the service.

Roseate reports of Austria's industrial reanimation, which promises increased profits -to her Reich-owned undertakings, have influenced favorably this week's business sentiment. To this also contributed Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's article foreshadowing credit expansion for development of the new province.

Last night's dance fare was nothing if not varied, with Veloz and Yolanda initiating the dignified podium of Carnegie Hall to the frivolities of exhibition ballroom dancing, while the American Dance Association was presenting three solists in a joint program at the Guild Theatre,

Madison Ave. e s, 49 ft s of 28th St, 24.8 1/4x100; John R. Brook to City Bank Farmers Trust Co, as trustee will of Virginia Hamersley Field; consideration $50,000; foreclosure.

The famous exchange variation of the Ruy Lopez, by means of which Dr. Emanuel Lasker conquered Jose R. Capablanca to win the international tournament at St. Petersburg in 1914, was utilized by Abraham Kupchik to hold Samuel Reshevsky to a draw in the semi-final round of the United States championship tournament at Rockefeller Center.

With an investment of $500,000 W. R. Grace Co. are erecting on their Paramonga sugar estate in the Pativilca Valley 110 miles north of Lima a paper manufacturing plant designed to turn out 4,000 tons a year. The estate is served by the port of Supe.
Some 10,000 property owners from all Je parts of the island staged a demonstration- here this morning asking the government to approve legislation to scale down mortgages on property.

Miss N. May Karff of Boston, sixth prize-winner at Stockholm last Summer and participating in a tournament here for the first time, emerged undefeated from a field of eleven yesterday when she won her last game in the eleventh round at the R. C .A. Building, to gain the Women's National Chess Federation championship.

Mr. and Mrs. Livingstone E. Jones of Chellowe, Chestnut Hill, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Peyton Bolling Jones, to Dr. W. Emory Burnett, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. W. Emory Burnett of Spartanburg, S. C.

Geraldine Apponyi, the half-American little Hungarian Countess who will become Queen of Albania this week,. will find herself more than a figure in a fairy tale. According to her friends and relatives in Vienna and Budapest, she is carried away by the romance of the adventure and feels like a fairy-tale princess.

The French general wholesale price index on April 16 stood at 619, against 618 on April 9 and 617 on April 2. The gold index for raw materials on April 16 was 41.3, against 40.7 on April 9 and 41.0 on April 2.

Insurgent troops operating in Teruel Province under General Jose Varela continued their advance rapidly today. The immediate objective of the drive, begun yesterday with the capture of Aliaga, about thirty miles northeast of Teruel,
Robert C. Heinze, Mrs. Sandra Goddard, John L. Scheuing, Max Wille, Patricia Deming, Ernest J. Clark, Walter Coogan Robert B. Watts, in London Terrace; William A. White Sons, brokers.

At the end of the Easter recess the Stock Exchange opened in a favorable mood. The signing of the AngloItalian agreement, and the strikers' evacuation of the factories at home, coincident with improvement in Wall Street following the announcement of President Roosevelt's reflation program, gave rise to a strong advance on the Bourse among French and foreign securities.

The Ford Brotherhood of America, Inc., a union organization which claims a membership of 21,400 workers employed by the Ford Motor Company, made public today a proposal for a collective bargaining contract under which each member of the union would agree to buy a Ford car within six months.

George Austen, a prominent resident of Albermarle County for thirty years, died here today at the age of 89. At the age of 16 he went to the Philippines and was associated there with the old Boston shipping firms of Russell, Sturgis Co. and Peel, Hubbell Co., returning to the United States in 1882.

After breakfasting on bread and milk bought at his own expense to supplement the rice and sour plums of prison fare, Melvin H. Gibbon, New York. aviator, faced a resumed examination by Sergeant Tokutaro Hasegawa this morning.

The Ford Brotherhood of America, Inc., a union organization which claims a membership of 21,400 workers employed by the Ford Motor Company, made public today a proposal for a collective bargaining contract under which each member of the union would agree to buy a Ford car within six months.

James F. (Jeff) Burkitt, veteran political foe of Mayor Frank Hague on this city, will go on the rock pile at the Hudson County penitentiary, Secaucus, tomorrow, to begin servicing his six months' term. Burkitt was sentenced Saturday afternoon by Police Judge Anthony Botti after a two-day trial.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 20: A decrease of $38,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, and an increase of $51,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities;
Lady Rankeillour, prominent English Roman Catholic, died in her home here today at the age of 65.

Plans for a national advertising campaign designed to replace an estimated 59,000,000 auto tires which are smooth or will become so during 1938 were announced yesterday by the tire division of the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Such a replacement program would result in more than $500,000,000 of sales if new tires were purchased to replace all old ones, the association said.

Czechoslovakia, in a semi-official statement, rejected the Sudeten demand that she give up her alliances. The Henlein domestic program was said to be so lacking in clearness that it gave no basis for negotiation.
