The effort to weld all newspaper elements together for a concerted promotion of newspapers as a national advertising medium is now an "accomplished fact," William E. Thomson, director of advertising of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, declared yesterday at the afternoon session of the annual convention of the National Newspaper Promotion Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Jesse W. Ehrich, a lawyer, with offices at 347 Madison Avenue, died suddenly on Sunday of a heart attack at his home, 173 West Seventythird Street, in his sixty-fourth year.

In the truest sense of the phrase, George Grey Barnard followed a flaming ideal. He was a mystic; his watchword, service. With devotion that seemed to burn always at white heat; with singleness of purpose that, in its unswerving contempt for compromise, may be deemed not a stranger to fanaticism;
The city of Yonkers,N. Y., will be in the market on May 4, with a new issue of $1,665,000 of general, water and local improvement

Arthur Mace, formerly with the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., and A. Parnell, formerly with the Oceanic Sprinkler Company, have formed the Mace, Parnell Realty Company, Inc., with offices at 291 Broadway.
A renewed downturn in the wholesale commodity price level took place last-week, according to the index compiled by The National Fertilizer Association.

The $200,000,000 of 3/4 per cent notes of the Commodity Credit Corporation offered by the Treasury has been oversubscribed about seven times on the basis of preliminary reports, Secretary Morgenthau announced at his press conference this afternoon.

Encouraged by heavier consumer buying, distributors of grocery products are optimistic about the possibilities of good business through next month and June, the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly survey of grocery conditions.

It is expected that Melvin Gibbon, the American aviator held by Japanese police, will be released in time to sail for San Francisco Thursday. Mr. Gibbon is said to have admitted flying in the Chinese air force.

Miss Mary Angela McDonnell and Miss Catherine McDonnell are cochairmen of the flower committee for the luncheon and card party to be held today at Sherry's -to assist the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ora Sears Webster of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Sayles Webster, to Henry Erben Gaillard of Cleveland, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. B. Gibson Gaillard of New Rochelle.

President Roosevelt proposed in a message to Congress today that it pass "a short and simple statute" abolishing privileges that now prevent reciprocal taxation of Federal, State and municipal securities, and, as well, the salaries of all government employes.

Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Doubleday gave a dinner last night at the American Museum of Natural History. The party was the latest in the series of "natural science evenings" in the interests of the tenyear development program of the museum.
A plot of ground which had been held in the same family for more than a century was involved in one of the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday.
A fashion show of Spring and Summer apparel will be held today at the Maison de Linge, 290 Park Avenue, in aid of the Bargain Box, a permanent thrift shop at 1,175 Third Avenue.

Charles J. Margiotti, State Attorney General, today accused heads of the Democratic organization in Pennsylvania of demanding "kickbacks" totaling $1,200,000 from architects on projects sponsored by the General State Authority.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt disclosed today that she had seen, but not at the White House, the much-discussed film "The Birth of a Baby." A showing at the White House was originally scheduled for last Monday night, but on finding it was a seven-reel picture Mrs. Roosevelt was obliged to cancel it for lack of time, she said, and had since seen it elsewhere.

Premier Mussolini today founded the new town of Pomezia, fifth and last rural center in what were once the Pontine marshes, the redeeming of which will be completed when the new town is inaugurated Oct. 29 next year.

Konrad Henlein's speech in Karlsbad on Sunday gives the measure of the change that has taken place in the attitude of the dissident Germans in Czechoslovakia since the occupation of Austria. It definitely and deliberately lowers the sword suspended over the Czech republic.

The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on removing tax exemptions from governmental securities and salaries: The Sixteenth Amendment to the Constitution of the Unitdd States, approved in 1913, expressly authorized the Congress "to lay and collect taxes on incomes from whatever source derived."
Premier Edouard Daladier's plan for national regeneration was approved by the Cabinet today without dissent and the first "decree laws" aiming to put it in force will be issued May 3.

Today's windfall of a ??10,000,000 payment from Ireland will simplify the task of Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in submitting the annual British Government budget to the House of Commons tomorrow.
A "cat burglar" visited the Neuilly home of Baroness de Neuflize, the former Lor Eva Barbey, last night, carrying off jewelry valued at $40,000 while the Baroness slept.

In a broadcast from Rome, through the facilities of the National Broadcasting Company and man Station WJZ, Marchesa Cristina as " Marconi and her daughter, Maria Elettra, sent a greeting to the American radio audience yesterday He on the sixty-fourth anniversary of and the birth of her late husband, Guglielmo Marconi.
In an effort to increase trade between the United States and India the Indian Trade Commission will for the first time open an office in New York in July at 38 East Fifty-seventh Street.
The Bomar Stable's Little Shaver and the Belair Stud's Isolater recorded the first dead heat of the Maryland season in the Conowingo Purse before 8,000 today.

The report of the. Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and its affiliates, for the first quarter of this year, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses and charges of $15,417,643.

The Treasury's net gold acquisitions in the first quarter of this year amounted to $34,390,000, according to a quarterly announcement today. Of the total, $38,230,000 was newly mined domestic gold, $3,830,000 was miscellaneous (secondary and other), and there was a net Ibss to foreign countries of $7,670,000 on the basis of imports and exports.

Twenty thousand alumni and present students of the University of Notre Dame met in scores of communities throughout the United States and in eleven foreign countries last night to participate in the fifteenth annual Universal Notre Dame Night.

Reports current abroad that the Reich is contemplating the expansion of her naval building plan beyond the ratio stipulated in the 1935 AngloGerman pact met categoric denials in official naval quarters today.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken commercial space throughout the city was the Erie Meter Systems, Inc., of Erie, Pa., which leased quarters for its New York offices on the twenty-fourth floor of the Time and Life Building in Rockefeller Center. The firm will take occupancy May 1.

The week-end certainly brought out the fishermen, and for every man who was on the streams after trout there seemed to be ten on the water after flounders and striped bass, particularly in New Jersey.
Benjamin J. Badger, Carl F. Brown, Edward W. Dettmann, Edward M. Gallagher, B. T. Gordon, Kai Holm-Hansen, Milton P. Jacobs, J. Howard Johnson, James E. Maddock, Joseph F. Ordas,
A second ana decisive step was taken today to force all the Protestant clergy in Prussia to take the civil servants' oath of personal obedience to Chancellor Adolf Hitler.
Everett Woodruff Wilson, who retired in 1924 as president of the American Distilling Company of Pekin, Ill., died yesterday morning in his apartment in Essex House after a six weeks' illness.

A million dollar mortgage on 300 Park Ave, held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co from the New York State Realty and Terminal Co, R. E. Dougherty. vice president, was extended for ten years with interest reduced from 6 to 4 1/2 per cent, $50,000 to be paid off semi-annually beginning next Nov. 1.

Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller dismissed yesterday a writ of habeas corpus obtained by Samuel Leibowitz, attorney, in an effort to obtain an immediate trial for Robert Irwin, a sculptor who is under indictment for the murder on March 28, 1937, of Veronica Gedeon, her mother and a boarder in their home. The court asserted that District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey had not unreasonably delayed the trial.

The possibility of legalized horse racing and pari-mutuel betting in New Jersey was advanced today when Attorney General David T. Wilentz advised the Legislature that constitutional amendments could be subemitted to the voters oftener than

The San Carlo Opera Company, Fortune Gallo, director, will open its season at the Center Theatre on Thursday night, May 5, with a performance of "Aida." The cast will be headed by Bianca Saroya as Aida, Maru Castagna as Amneris, Charlotte Bruno as the priestess, Aroldo Lindi as Radames, Mostyn Thomas as Amonasro and Harold Kravitt as the high priest.

Sharply better trading in leather was reported by tanners yesterday, and prices were advanced from 2 to 3 cents a pound. The better buying followed the rising trend which developed in hides two weeks ago and has continued since then.

What is announced as David Warfield's first stage appearance since he played "The Merchant of Venice" on tour in 1924 will take place on May 3 at Madison Square Garden in the Greater New York Fund show.

THE extraordinary thing about H. G. Wells is that he won't stay down. Various sorts of people, pious and impious, reactionary and radical, have been throwing him overboard at more or less regular intervals since 1900. But without much success; Mr. Wells comes back every time, cheerful and apparently refreshed by the experience. His incorrigibility is magnificent.

Dr. William Beebe and three members of his six months' expeedition to the west- coast of Latin America returned yesterday aboard the Santa Clara of the Grace Line with a vest-pocket specimen as their prize find, a young sailfish only an inch and a half long.

Mr. and Mrs. Drelincourt Mathews Martin of 163 East Seventy-first Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Martin, to Dr. John Lawrenee Pool, son of Mrs. J. Lawrence Pool of Rye, N. Y., and the late Mr. Pool.

Compulsory grading of meats is neither excessively costly nor unfeasible, B. F. McCarthy, senior market specialist for the meat-grading service of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, told a group of consumers yesterday at the offices of Wilson Co., Forty-fourth Street and First Avenue.

Joseph Buerckel, a non-Austrian, the National Socialist party Commissioner in Austria, received dictatorial powers under a decree issued here today. He will be responsible for his rule in Austria solely to Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

Charles C. Hull was re-elected president of the Brooklyn Free Kindergarten Society, Inc., 287 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, at its forty-seventh annual meeting yesterday. Mr. Hull reported that since 1891 the society had been providing pre-school education for children between the ages of 2 and 5 years in thickly populated areas of the borough.

Franklin St, 185, 20x70; Paulbert Realty Corp, Paul Hansen, treasurer, to Albert Hansen, Flagtown, N. J.; mtg $20,000. 123d St, 114 E, 25x100.5; Moses Koch to Cora Realty Corp, 450 Audubon Ave; deed dated March 26, 1930.

The first reaction to the new agreements between Ireland and Britain here tonight is one of extreme relief that the economic war is ended coupled with the rejoicing of farmers in the twenty-six counties that the unrestricted British market once more is thrown open to them.
Stocks sagged and closed moderately lower in third slowest trading of year; turnover, 395,880 shares. All groups of bonds generally lower in dull trading; transactionn. $4.831,050.
Fifty-second annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association will open at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria at 10 A. M. Morning, afternoon and evening sessions through Friday.

Whatever else happens we are promised a colorful World's Fair. There should be pretty general applause for Mr. Whalen's statement that "we are taking off our gloves and are plunging both hands deep into paint pots." A few two-handed painters can do wonders to liven up architecture and take people's minds off troubles.
Lord Macgregor Mitchell, rector of St. Andrews University and chairman of the Scottish Land Court, died today at the age of 63.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today issued a statement of itg administrative policy governing financial statements, and this put the commission on record for the first time concerning its attitude toward conflicts in accounting procedures such as that which recently developed in the current Missouri Pacific case.

After having sailed almost 30,000 miles in the last thirteen months, A. Thornton Baker of Princeton, N. J., took steps today to have his fifty-ton schooner yacht So Fong, built at Hong Kong, brought permanently under United States registry.
Two trainloads of Jaipur State troops left today to reinforce Lieut. Col. Sir Henry Beauchamp St. John, Premier of Jaipur, in his operations against the rebellious Rajah of Sikar.

Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro, who is charged with conspiracy in the garment racket and extortion in the bakery racket, pleaded not guilty yesterday to both accusations when he was arraigned before Justice Ferdinand Pecora in Supreme Court.

Slow declines characterized yesterday the security and commodity markets although final prices, as a rule, were up somewhat from the day's low levels. The turnover on the Stock Exchange amounted to only 395,000 shares, representing the third slowest trading of the year to date, Saturdays excluded.

Class freight rates between Western trunk-line territory and southern territory were reduced on the average between 7 and 10 per cent by a decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission handed down today.

Longshoremen at Sydney and Melbourne refused today to load scrap tin for shipment to Japan on the ground that the metal could be used for munitions. The Sydney longshoremen also refused to load tallow for Japan on the ground that it could be used to manufacture glycerine.

The Eastern Steamship Lines, Inc., receive $800,000 from the Federal Government in settlement of claims arising out of cancellation of mail contracts between New York and Boston and St. John, N. B., and Yarmouth, N. S., the Maritime Commission announced today.

It is generally felt here that the United Kingdom's treatment of Ireland in the Anglo-Irish agreement has been quite generous. Officials, however, were unwilling to comment pending a statement tomorrow by Viscount Craigavon, the Prime Minister,

Both the Syracuse Herald and The Syracuse Journal have announced increased rates for their daily ediLions, effective next Monday. Both papers are increasing their weekly rate for editions delivered to homes from 18 to 20 cents and their street sale rate from 3 to 5 cents.

The Engineers Golf Club, where one of the greatest links duels in history, the famous struggle between Chick Evans and Francis Ouimet in the final round of the 1920 national amateur, took place, was the scene today of the inaugural event of the local golf season.

The denial by Premier Edouard Daladier of France over the weekend of rumors of dissention within his Cabinet on currency matters and his announcement yesterday of a plan of economic rehabilitation based on stimulation of production and the tourist-trade, balancing of the budget and retention of a free exchange within the tripartite agreement, brought yesterday a swift rally in the franc.

With the beginning of daylight saving time, the Outdoor Sculpture Show, at Park Avenue and Thirtyninth Street, will now remain open evenings until 8 o'clock. More than 19,000 persons have visited the show since its opening on April 12. Demonstrations by exhibiting sculptors are given every afternoon, except Sunday, at 2:30 o'clock.

With Senator Jacob H. Livingston of Brooklyn asserting that "prison psychosis" was "tommyrot" and that psychiatrists should be "less c scientific and a little more practical" in diagnosing criminal patients,
The engagement of Miss Charlotte Eliot Leo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norton B. Leo of this place, to David Seabury Henkel of New York has been announced by her parents.
The Utilities Power and Light Corporation, which has been in bankruptcy since late in 1936, has a present value of $49,000,000 to $58,000,000, against the original $250,000.000.

The Japanese-dominated "reformed government" of China at Nanking announced today it would not recognize the transfer of the China Merchants Steam Navigation Company's properties, valued at $25,000,000, to the American concern of William P. Hunt Co.

Dr. R. H. Ecker Jr. won the individual bridge master's championship and the Steiner Trophy yesterday at the Park Central Hotel. Dr. Ecker made 610 match points on 140 boards played against thirtyfive of the country's leading players.

Mrs. Merretta Filkins Kirby, widow of John Kirby Jr., former president of the National Association of Manufacturers, died here this morning. Since the death of her husband in 1925 she had made her home at 2,600 Hudson Boulevard, Jersey City, N. J., but had spent much of her time in Dayton. She is survived.

Mr. and Mrs. Austin Potter of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoria Potter, to William Henry Lewis-Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis of Mountain Lakes, N. J. Miss Potter was graduated from the Beaver Country Day School in Brookline and was introduced to

Today's major events: New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, Antonia Brico conducting, in the Verdi Requiem, at Carnegie Hall in the evening; Harold Kohon, violinist, evening, Town Hall; Alfred Nano, violinist, and Longina Weglarz, soprano, evening, Steinway Hall.

General Pershing arrived here late this afternoon from New York and went immediately to Walter Reed Hospital, the army medical center, where he will undergo an examination to determine his condition after his recent illness in Arizona.
Count von Kageneck, another secretary of Franz von Papen, who had been reported executed, announced tonight that he was very much alive. Also denying reports that he had fled Germany,

Federal Judge Charles B. Davis authorized today Berryman Henwood, trustee of the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railroad, to omit payment of $400,000 interest due on May 1 on $20,000,000 of the road's first mortgage bonds.

Miss Barbara Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Allen of 97 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, has completed plans for her marriage to Richard Zellner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl P. Zellner, also of Brooklyn, which will take place the afternon of June 4 in the First Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn.
Mrs. Alfred Willstatter, twelve rooms, through Brown. Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., in 911 Park Ave; M. MorgenthauSelxas Co. Inc. broker.

Huge De Matties, 34 years old, of 229 West Twelfth Street, was convicted in Special Sessions yesterday on the charge that he had threatened to disclose confidential records of the business owned by his brother, with a $500,000 yearly turnover, to one of its principalcustomers.

Only those newspaper readers who have the misfortune to be old know what The Associated Press has done for them and the country. At a time when a press association, not to be confused with the one that now bears its name, was trying to get into its hands mastery of the collection and distribution of the news,

The Carolina, Clinchfield Ohio Railway and its lessees, the Atlantic Coast Line and Louisville Nashville Railroads, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to borrow $14,150,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation with which to pay off a like amount of first-mortgage bonds of the Carolina, Clinchfield Ohio due on June 1.

C. S. Maginnis, who started working for the Fair store thirty-five years ago at $7 a week, will become president of that organization tomorrow at the annual stockholders' meeting. Having been a vice president and director for the last six years. he will succeed D. F.
Gordon H. Russell, who successfully negotiated for the first eight-hour day to be obtained by a typographical union, died yesterday at the age of 77.

In the first race for the King Edward VII Trophy, presented to the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club by the American, Sherman Hoyt, who won it in the Jamestown regatta many years ago, William Miller's Viking, Bermuda representative, demonstrated her speed off the wind and came back to beat the champion of the United States invaders, Indian Scout, when the dice were loaded heavily against her today.

Representative O'Toole, Democrat of New York, asked the Department of Labor today to investigate morals charges made in court in New York City against Severin Winterscheidt with a view to deportation. He identified Winterscheidt as the chief propagandist of the GermanAmerican Nazi Bund in this country.

EVERY so often a jury is summoned to weigh and consider the worth of an arm or a leg, but if any twelve good men and true, sittingin accordance with "statoot made an' perwided," ever priced an arm at $185,000 and three human chattels to boot, this observer must have been out of hearing when the foreman spoke up to the judge.

Nineteen railroads failed in the Supreme Court today in their attempt to enjoin the Interstate Commerce Commission from enforcing an order reducing rates for the transportation of coke from Birmingham, Chattanooga and Wise County, Va., to Illinois, Indiana, Ohio and the lower peninsula of Michigan.

Lefty Ostermueller of the Red Sox, an old Washington jinx, routed the Senators today, 7 to 0. Ben Chapman, former Washington outfielder, led Boston at bat with three hits, two of them doubles. Jimmy Foxx and Joe Cronin also made doubles.
When a large section of the European world is turning upside down, a hospital bed on a Swiss mountain top is not a bad spot from which to take a longrange view of the proceedings.
The entire German propaganda apparatus swung into action today to back the demands served on the Czechoslovak Government yesterday by Konrad Henlein, leader of the Sudeten German party,

Alfred Rheinstein, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, told the City Council housing committee yesterday that about $1,000,000,000 would be needed to make a substantial improvement in slum elimination and the construction of new low-cost housing.

Dick Gallagher allowed no hits and no runs in pitching Bishop Loughlin Memorial High to a 3-0 triumph over Cathedral Prep in a Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. game at the Parade Grounds yesterday. He struck out twelve and issued seven bases on balls.

A BOOK OF BIRDS, by Mary Priestley. (Macmillan, $2.50.) An anthology of quotations about birds. CONNECTICUT: A GUIDE TO ITS ROADS, LORE AND PEOPLE, by workers of, the Connecticut WPA Federal Writers' Project.

MANHATTAN ALLEN, ELIZABETH RODNEY (Aug. 13, 1937). Gross assets, $32,341; net, $28,926. To Mary Ella Dixon, sister, and Frank D. and Albert E. Rodney, brothers, one-third each. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $20,455. John L. Class, attorney, 156 5th Ave.

Retail advertising linage in newspapers of eighty major markets dedined 9:8 per cent for the week ended April 16 under the correspending period of last year, Advertising Age reported yesterday. The volume was 287.919.932 lines,
John W. L. Forster, dean of Canadian portrait artists, died today of injuries suffered when knocked down by a motor car on Thursday night. The distinguished painter was 85.

Arthur Myles of Moore Schley was elected chairman of the advisory committee to the Committee on Organization and Administration of the New York Curb Exchange at its first meeting yesterday afternoon. Theodore V. D. Berdell of Berdell Brothers was named vice chairman.

President Roosevelt's proposal that existing reciprocal immunities from taxation of Federal, State and municipal securities and salaries be in abolished brought expressions of ap- In proval from both sides of the Capi- in tol today. Opinion was divided,
Several years ago the court refused to permit Rosika Schwimmer, a Hungarian, and Douglas Act C. MacIntosh, a Canadian, to become citizens. Each had refused to promise to bear arms.
The veteran George Lott was forced to call upon his vast experience to escape elimination by Captain Val Yavorsky, Greenbrier professional, today in the United States open tennis tournament.

An independent resolution condemning racial oppression and backing President Roosevelt's efforts to care for exiles was accepted without opposition yesterday morning by clergy and laymen of the Methodist Episcopal Church attending the fifth and final session of the 139th New York annual conference.

Conversational flashbacks to those vigorous and colorful days when votes for women were more possible than probable, monopolized attention in the "city where the National League of Women Voters was born nineteen years ago, as delegates arrived for the convention of the organization, opening tomorrow.

Marina Yurlowa presented a program of Spanish dances at the Town Hall last night, assisted by Addi Prohaska at the piano. As has been noted in her previous appearances here, her temperament is Slavic rather than Hispanic, and the flavor of the type of dance she has chosen to present quite naturally eludes her, in spite of a certain amount of skill in its performance.

The Royal Academy, which, despite its reputation as the most august body in British art, has been involved in many disputes in past years, today lost one of its most famous members when Augustus John resigned in protest against the academy's rejection of Wyndham Lewis's portrait for its annual exhibition, opening on Monday.

At least one important tax proposal has been made by the Administration to which Wall Street does not throw up its hands in horror. This is the proposal that the income from future issues of Federal, State and local bonds be made taxable by the respective taxing authorities.

David B. Ditz, 47 years old, of ??,995 Webster Avenue, the Bronx,. ignored ten summonses and oper??ted an automobile under a false registration, because he feared that ??is name would be stricken from the relief rolls if it were known he owned an automobile, he testified yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year a consolidated net income of $4,209,332 after interest, depreciation and other charges. This is equal to 47 cents each on the 9,023,138 capital shares outstanding.

A tea will be given tomorrow at the home of Mrs. Shepard Fabbri, 7 East Ninety-fifth Street, for members of a committee arranging the performance of Bach's "Passion According to St. Matthew" to be given on the afternoon and evening of May 5 in the nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Pleas of the New York Rapid Transit Corporation and the Brooklyn and Queens Rapid Transit Corporation for reconsideration of the recent Supreme Court decision upholding New York City's 3 per cent gross income tax on utilities for unem-

The Lycee Francais de New York, school of secondary education in French, was hailed last night by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler and Count Rene Doynel de Saint-Quentin, the French Ambassador, as another of the intellectual bonds binding France and the United States.

The Mortgage Commission of the State of New York has sold to Brown Shenker the six-story apartment house at 3,204 Holland Avenue, on the northeast corner of Burke Avenue, the Bronx, for cash above a first mortgage of $225,600. The deal involved negotiations which lasted nearly a year, according to Edgar P. Goodwin, broker.

Hurling three-hit ball, Paul Derringer inflicted a third successive shut-out on the hapless Cardinals today, Cincinnati winning, 5 to 0, to shove Frankie Frisch's men into the National League cellar all by themselves.

Toys in higher price brackets attracted most attention and most active buying at the opening yesterday of the American Toy Fair, at the McAlpin Hotel and in manufacturers' salesrooms here. The fair, which will continue for two weeks, attracted slightly over 600 buyers, and it was estimated that this was an increase of about 5 per cent over the first-day registration last year.
A special British commission that arrived here today to negotiate purchases of American military aircraft will be able to buy these under the same conditions that apply to all foreign powers.

A report of the Social Service Commission of the Newark conference of the Methodist Episcopar Church, at which Mayor Frank Hague and other Jersey City officials were criticized for alleged violations of the right of peaceful assembly and free speech was upheld today at the final session of the annual meeting of the conference,
An indefinite sustaion for Rollie Herself, catcher was threatened today by C. C. Slapnicka Indians' suspended night as Chicago, $250 for gneral manager.

John Henry Schwarting, vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Advertising Corporation, died suddenly Sunday night while driving his car in Queens. Mr. Schwarting, who was 49 years old, was stricken with a heart attack at Sunrise Highway and Rockaway Boulevard.

A proclamation signed by Mayor La Guardia was issued yesterday asking the citizens of New York City to cooperate in the preview of the New York World's Fair 1939 on Saturday, just a year before the scheduled opening.

The Federal government's first step toward acquisition of 342 acres of land adjacent to the United States Army air base at Mitchel Field, Long Island, was disclosed yesterday when Assistant United States Attorney Frank Parker in Brooklyn announced the purchase of a four-acre tract for $50,000
Although Michael Todd had thought of holding over "The Man From Cairo" to next season, he has now decided to bring it in next week. It will arrive at the Broadhurst on Wednesday, May 4.

Another significant move to strengthen the unitary regime set up by President Getulio Vargas last Nov. 10 was made today in the appointment of Adhemar de Barros as federal interventor of Sao Paulo, replacing Cardoso de Mello Netto.

The time has come for business to "prime its own pump," in the opinion of Allen L. Woodworth, president of United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation, who declared last night that that corporation's advertising yesterday for $5,000,000 worth of merchandise is a practical step in that direction.
Members of the Board of Estimate received four bids yesterday for the operation of the city's Foreign Trade Zone on Staten Island.
The condition of Charles G. Dawes (former Vice President) was reported as satisfactory yesterday at the Roosevelt Hospital, where heunderwent an appendix operation Sunday night.

According to the building plans filed yesterday in Brooklyn the Department of Parks will construct a recreation building at a cost of about $285,000 at 694 to 752 Hopkinson Avenue, a playground in East New York,

Protesting against the recent decision of the Board of Education in dismissing W. C. Cook, Physical Education Instructor, after a trial on charges of insubordination, about 1,100 of the 1,800 students in the high school here took a holiday today and staged a parade on foot and in automobiles.

Deliveries of rayon woven fabrics, in the greige, to the consuming trade during March, 1938, were approximately 10 per cent greater than for February, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc.

Sherman M. Fairchild, president of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, said yesterday that the company had sold to Canadian interests for about $250,000 its holdings of 40,000 shares in Fairchild Aircraft, Ltd., of Canada.
The two-story building owned by the Kattermann-Mitchell Silk Corporation, at Cornell and Ten Broeck Streets, Kingston, N. Y., has been leased to the Barclay Knitting Mills, Inc.,

Exports of merchandise from the United States in the first quarter of the current year exceeded the value of imports by $320,737,000, a reversal of the situation which existed in the first quarter last year when imports exceeded exports by $113,271,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Mrs. of the Agnes Pyne Bacon obtained a di- Penns vorce here today from Robert backs' Ogden Bacon Jr., son of the former Ambassador, on grounds of cruelty. Custody of a daughter was arranged by agreement.

Joe DiMaggio formally signed a contract with the Yankees yesterday, a legally binding document by which Colonel Jacob Ruppert agrees his "club will pay the player at the rate of $25,000 salary to start when the player is in condition to play," and forthwith the Coast slugger became eligible to play with the world champions.

Although outhit, the champion Bears chalked up their fourth straight International League victory today, conquering Toronto, 5 to 2, behind steady pitching by Nick Strincevich, rookie from the Norfolk farm.

In a story-book climax to a game which he appeared to have lost in the box in the first inning, Ray Volpi stepped to the plate in the seventh with two out and the bases loaded and lifted the ball over the fence yesterday as Manhattan defeated St. John's University on Manhattan Field. 8 to 3.

Five hundred employees. of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, members of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainrmen and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, have voted to strike in support of wage demands presented by their unions and rejected by the company.
The Big Show opened its bag tricks yesterday morning for the exclusive pleasure of the greatest circus audience that ever was and ever will be-children.

When the little House group of Wisconsin Progressives voted against the Reorganization Bill, despite much pressure from their long-time Administration allies to take a contrary course, some observers suspected more than a wish to set an impersonal limit on Executive power.

Seabiscuit, hope of the West in the $100,000 special race against War Admiral, joined his rival at Belmont Park yesterday when he was led off a special car just after midday and subsequently stabled at the old A. C. Bostwick barn.

Major Gen. Eben Swift, retired, veteran of Indian campaigns and an active officer from 1876 until 1918, died here today in his apartment at Stoneleigh Court. He would have celebrated his eighty-fourth. birthday anniversary on May 11.

Three proposed constitutional amendments, looking toward the writing into the State's fundamental law the principiles of "integrated relief" were sponsored tonight by Edward Corsi, chairman of the committee on social welfare of the Constitutional Convention, as the convention met.

J. W. J. Merris, a traveling salesman from Nottingham, scored one of the biggest upsets in the history of the English amateur golf championship when he eliminated Cyril J. H. Tolley, twice winner of the British amateur title, 2 up, in a first-round match today.

The passenger list of the HollandAmerica liner Statendam, leaving today for the Channel ports, includes Dr. Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the Associated Hospitals Service; Dr. H. A. Van Coenen-Torchiana, consul general of The Netherlands at San Francisco;

Sixteen promotions of high-ranking army officers, including the creation of four major generals and of eight brigadier generals of line, were made today by President Roosevelt. The nominations were sent to the Senate for confirmation.

Mayor William E. Kane today abandoned a plan to cage "drunks" after "America's first plebiscite" in which the city electorate voted against it, but overwhelmingly expressed confidence in his administration by approving other proposals.

Catholic, Jews and Protestants joined at meetings yesterday afternoon and evening to "dramatize" the need for adequate support of religious, educational and charitable institutions and to observe Brotherhood Day.

FARM MANAGER, $2,900 a year, ASSISTANT FARM MANAGER (DAIRYING), $2,300 a year, Bureau of Prisons, Department of Justice. Applications must be on file not later than May 19, if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idanho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming, and not later than May 16 from all other States.

Two rivals of long standing, Norman Armitage of the Fencers Club and Dr. John R. Huffman of the New York A. C., gained the title round of the national saber fencing championships last night on the strips of the Winged Foot Club.

As one who never fails to "come up smiling" after a reception, regardless of the number of hands shaken in the process, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt disclosed today her personal "system" for greeting however many thousands of guests.
A man who gave his name as Richard Brent, 21 years old, of Chicago, was jailed today when he tried to steal an airplane at Bendix Airport.
Frank E. Langley, publisher of The Barre Daily Times, died today after a long illness at the age of 74. Mr. Langley long had been prominent in civic and political affairs.

Belief was growing on Capitol Hill today that the Wages and Hours Bill was dead for this session of Congress. With Speaker--Bankhead reiterating: his prophecy, that. Congress will quit by- June 1, thus leaving only five weeks for additional legislation, Representative O'Connor of New York, chairman-of the RulesCommittee, announced" that his group would begin hearings Thursday on whether to grant a rule for floor consideration of the bill.
Broadening of the base of selection of student delegates to future Y. W. C. A. conventions was voted today at the organization's national convention.

Paul Lee, 125 1/2, Indianapolis, furnished an upset by outpointing Vince Dell'Orto, 129, Italy, in the main attraction of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night before 1,500 fans. Pat Mulcahy,

The 'city will sponsor a body of trained civil servants in city-supported colleges by permitting selected students to do research -work in the policy-forming departments of the municipal government, William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, announced last night.

Frank B. Noyes retired yesterday as president of The Associated Press after having served continuously in that capacity since the inception of the organization in its present from thirty-eight years ago.

Mrs. Elizabeth Graham Lewis, who has a large investment in racing from which she has taken a comparatively small return, had the satisfaction yesterday of victory in the featured Bridgehampton Handicap that attracted only three starters at Jamaica. Little Miracle,

The series of Coffee Dances was concluded for this season last night with a Spring dance given at the Cosmopolitan Club. Following the custom from which the entertainment derives its name, many subscribers gave dinners before the event and later took their guests to the club for coffee and dancing.

Acting on- the initiative of The Daily Princetonian, campus newspaper, Lawrence Heyl, head of the acquisitions department of the Princeton University Library, communicated with the Library of Congress tonight to inquire if it would be possible to obtain

Dr. Katherine L. Storm, 81 years old, a well-known physician of East Rock Hill Township, Bucks County, was killed near here tonight when the automobile in which she was riding went out of control and struck a pole.

William 0. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, reported to President Roosevelt today that there had been some rather tangible signs that some members of the public utility industry were accepting the Public Utility Holding Company Act and working under it.

Miss Frances Talcott Stanley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Bartholomew Stanley, has completed plans for her marriage to John Deming Stout Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Stout of Hartford, which will take place on the afternoon of May 20 at the Stanley- home here on Shuttle Meadow Road.
The foreign policy of the United States is "to meet the foreign policy of any other nation whose policy is against the United States," Senator Lewis of Illinois said in the Senate today.

Steel operations in the United States this week are scheduled at 32 per cent of ingot capacity as against 32.4 per cent last week, a decrease of 1.2 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports. One month ago the rate was 35.7 per cent.

Charles S. Hamlin embodied in many respects the older school of American public finance. He had served as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury during President Cleveland's entire second Administration, and had occupied the same office during a year before the war.
Bill Bonthron, erstwhile Princeton track luminary and captain, is planning a comeback. He is pursuing a program of light workouts in Palmer Stadium.

The report of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 1, issued yesterday, shows holdings of $10,153,628 in cash and marketable securities at the year end, including $2,680,827 balances in Great Britain and Dominions, and $110,678 in other foreign countries, compared to $10,782,172, of which $3,300,154 was held abroad, on Jan. 2, 1937.

A huge program of low-cost housing financed by building and loan organizations was suggested yesterday as the remedy for the present depression in this country, by Sir Harold Bellman, chairman of the British National Association of Building Societies and managing director of the Abbey Road Building Society.

Belfast Celtic defeated. Derry City, 3-1, today to win the Irish Football League championship for the third successive year. (Canadian Press).-Millwall jumped to the top of the English football league's: third division, southern section, today by halting Bournemouth, 4-0. In the northern loop Hull City: went ahead with a 3-1 verdict over York City.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Meyer D. Siegel, Maxwell Shapiro and Moses Polakoff of New York City were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 514-The United States and Interstate Commerce Commisison, applts., v. Pan American Petroleum Corp. et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana,

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: PATENTS 38.9--Willaim S. Ellis v. William H. Maddox. Opinion by Judge Bland. Decision of the Board of Appeals is affirmed.

The House today reversed two earlier votes and approved a $2,613,000 appropriation to start construction on the Tennessee Valley Authority's Gilbertsville Dam in Kentucky. the item is in the conference report on the Independent Offices Bill. The vote was 159 to 152. vote was 159 to 152.
Achille Bloch, a Mason for nearly sixty years, died Sunday at his home, 40 Argyle Road, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 85 year old.

The Panama Pacific Line completed its withdrawal from intercoastal service yesterday morning when the liner California docked at Pier 61. North River, with about 650 passengers, arriving from the Pacific Coast by way of the Panama Canal.

A Spring tour of city gardens and landscaped penthouse terraces will take place on the afternoons of May 5, 8 and 10 under the auspices of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, which endeavors to rid the city streets of unsightly litter.
Van Lingle Mungo, ace of- the Dodger pitching staff consulted a Philadelphia physician today about his right arm, which has not been functioning in. the real Mungo style since last June.

Chinese declarations that the Japanese Array in the Yangtze' Valley area was experiencing a shortage of manpower were contradicted yesterday by news of hostilities on a large scale on the north bank of the Yangtze between Nanking and Wuhu.
Carl Henry Kappes, former partner in the firm of Seiter Kappes, New York lithographeres, died at his home here last night after a brief illness. He was in his seventy-third year.

Jimmy Caras of Wilmington, Del., world pocket-billiard champion, defeated Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, 128 to 112, in sixteen innings in the opening block of their 1,000-point challenge match at the Strand Academy last night.

With trumpet and drum, the eighth annual Eastman School festival of American music was inaugurated tonight in the Eastman Theatre. The Eastman School symphony band, Frederick Fennell conductor, gave the concert.

A Pan American Airways plane flying between Santiago, Cuba, and Kingston was forced down and sank in the Caribbean Sea off the east end of Jamaica this afternoon. The passengers and crew were rescued by the Elders Fyffes The Rad steamer Cavina and were landed at York at 9: Bowden, Jamaica, at 6:30 o'clock this evening.

For the first time in many weeks the motorists within the city limits went through an entire week-end last week without a single fatality, figures made public yesterday by the Safety Bureau of the Police Department showed.
Southern Senators will ask Congress this session to establish a free government classing service for the entire Cotton Belt.

Funeral services for George Grey Barnard, noted American sculptor, who died in the Harkness Pavilion at the Medical Center on Sunday, will be held at The Monastery, 698 Fort Washington Avenue, adjoining a the sculptor's home, at 10 A. M. to- h morrow.
Underwear and hosiery manufacturers from all over the country began to gather here today as the thirtyfourth annual Knitting Arts Exposition got under way at the Commercial Museum. This year's show.
The Textile Color Card Association will hold its twenty-third annual business meeting and election of officers on Thursday at its offices, 200 Madison Avenue.

The National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin, conductor, closed its season at Carnegie Hall last night with a concert that was designed to demonstrate "the various educational phases" of its work.

Sales of Sears Roebuck Co. in the four weeks ended April 23 are estimated at 8 to- 9 per cent less than in tVhe 1937 period, Lessing J. Rosen wald, chairman of the board, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

Successful until today, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, representing France in the international masters tournament of the Kent County Chess Association, met defeat in the fifth round at the Grand Hotel, Cliftonville.

Loomis J. Grossman has purchased the six-story Chatsworth apartment building at 20 East Fourth Street, on the corner of South Third Avenue, Mount Vernon, Westchester, from a client of Bedford, Pavitt Company. The latter firm cooperated with Low Gross, Inc., as broker.

Meredith Nicholson, United States Minister to Venezuela, and Mrs. Nicholson, who arrived yesterday on the Santa Paula, are at the Waldorf-Astoria before going to Washington. Mrs. Harold Brown has left the Savoy-Plaza for her home in Newport, where she will pass the season.
Three decisions of import to the New Deal who were handed down by the Supreme Court today as the justices returned from a two weeks absence from the areas bench.

James G. Blaine, chairman of the Greater New York Fund, told fifty members of the Employes Endorsement Committee, representing 75,000 employes, yesterday that he knew of no other country in the world "where Catholic, Jew and Protestant could work together as we are doing in this fund drive."
The President's proposal to put an end to the issuance of tax-exempt securities is not a new idea, or a radical idea, or a sudden happy thought of the Roosevelt Administration.

The engagement of $4,350,000 gold in Japan for shipment to this country was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This consignment lifted the total of gold shipped here from Japan since Feb. 24, last, to $37,900,000, and made the total of gold engagements from all sources in the last two months $84,900,000.

A squat, stockily built youth from the sidewalks of San Francisco, one Dario Lodigiani, who up to now has been commanding such attention as he could gain from the fact that he once went to the same school with Joe DiMaggio and lives only a block from the "wonder player," carved a little prominence in his own right today.

The State Motor Vehicle Bureau warned holders of one-year driving licenses today that they must- be renewed by May 31. Persons who last year renewed their permits for three years will not be affected.

Manfred Goldman and Victor S. Riesenfeld have been elected president and chairman of the board, respectively, of Cohen, Goldman Co., clothing manufacturers, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Goldman succeeds his brother, the late William Goldman, as president.

Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the Yankees, was confined to his home last night under the care of his physician, Dr. Otto Schwerdtfeger. The owner of the Yankees was suffering from an inflammation of the veins in his left leg. The condition of the baseball magnate was said not to be serious. Dr.
Fiscal officials of the Federal Government started conferences today at the request of President Roosevelt in an effort to work out uniform bank examinations without legislation.

The Rev. Isaac W. Goodhue, lawyer and Baptist minister, died here today in the Barnert Memorial Hospital after a nine-day illness during which he underwent an operation.. He was born in Boston seventy-five years ago.

Mrs. Arthur W. Bingham Jr. of New York City and Mrs. Sidney A. Cook of New Brunswick, N. J., are the two nominees for the presidency of the Smith College Alumnae Association, to succeed Mrs. Hollis T. Gleason of Cohasset.

The widely discussed high visibility yellow baseball will be put into play for the first time on record tomorrow when Columbia opposes Fordham at Baker Field, it was announced yesterday. Frederic H. Rahr, New York color engineer and consultant, developed the pew ball.
Embattled government forces struck furiously to turn the tables today on the Insurgent offensive in Eastern Spain.
