There are no hopes at present of peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, according to William -Green, who presided today at the Spring meeting of the feder-' ation's executive council.

Nearly 1,000 persons attended the fifth annual "Gift Horse Party" yesterday afternoon -in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event was arranged to aid the New York Exchange for Woman's e Work at 541 Madison Avenue.
Sir Robert Williams, friend and business associate of Sir Cecil Rhodes and one of the African empire builders of the old school, died today at his home here. His age was 78.

An unsigned letter to President Roosevelt asserting that a large Detroit corporation, alleged author of a previous "chain telegram" drive on Congress, is broadcasting petitions against the President's recovery program to be signed and sent

A bill to clarify and liberalize the Ship Subsidy Act received right of way to the House floor from the Rules Committee today. Chairman Bland of the Merchant Marine Committee said one major change would allow ocean carriers to obtain construction subsidies by putting up in cash 25 per cent of the foreign building cost of ships.

Mrs. publisher William S. Vare, widow of the Republican organization leader of Philadelphia, died of a heart attack today at the Cynwyd home of her and son-in-law and daughter, Dr. and Mrs. John J. Shaw, where she had been visiting. Her age was 67.
Mrs. Rosa M. Hoots, Osage Indian woman whose horse, Black Gold, won the Kentucky Derby in 1924, died here yesterday at the age of 70.

The bitter factional fight within the ranks of the United Automobile Workers of America which has as its objective the ouster of Homer Martin as leader of the auto workers' union flared into the open again at the concluding sessions of the newly created C. I. O. State Council.
The world heavyweight championship fight between Joe Louis and Max Schmeling, scheduled for June 22, will be held at the Yankee Stadium, it was learned yesterday.

Doubleday, Doran has signed a contract with Dan Williams for a biography of the late sculptor, George Grey Barnard. Mr. Williams, who formerly was on the staff of The New York World and later of The World-Telegram, was a close friend of the sculptor and had access to family records. He has been gathering material for three years.

The work of the Crippled Children's After Care Committee, which supports a physical therapy department at the New York PostGraduate Hospital and maintains clinics and workshops to assist handicapped children in several

The average daily sales of chain drug stores in March were 7 per cent below the same month last year, according to preliminary statistics of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce made public today. The decrease from February was d 1.8 per cent.

Representative Chandler of Tennessee introduced a bill today to expedite railroad reorganizations by providing for a railroad commissioner to handle problems of insolvent rail lines independently of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Beethoven's Ninth symphony will be presented on the opening program of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival for the inauguration of the new music shed at Tanglewood on Aug. 4, it was announced yesterday.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended April 21 dropped-to the loweat number for any week this year, totaling 226, compared with 278, in the week preceding and 191 in the corresponding period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet. Inc.

" Edgemont," historic Albemarle County (Va.) estate with a house designed by Thomas Jefferson in 1806, has been sold to Graham Clark of Englewood, N. J., a student at the University of Virginia Medical School, who plans to restore it to its original beauty, it was learned yesterday. The sale price was not disclosed.

Despite reports to the contrary, Postmaster General James A. Farley has not made any attempt to displace Representative Christopher D. Sullivan as leader of Tammany, it was learned yesterday from an authoritative source, and will make r1o such move before the State election next November.
Sen ator La Follette said in an interview here today before returning to Washington that he and his brother, Governor Philip La Follette, are jointly backing formation of a national third party.
Charges of misrepresentation of facts in litigation with the Federal Power Commission were filed today in the Supreme Court by Solicitor General Jackson against six Eastern utility concerns.
Wilkinson Ave, s w car of Robart Ave, 100x 100; Patrick J. Hayes, Archbishop of New York, against Henry J. Lowe: due, S15,952; taxes, etc, $7,881; to plaintiff for $1,000.

The Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations sent members of its legislative committee to Albany yesterday to protest against the proposed constitutional amendment to give to cities in the State new powers, including that of fixing the salaries of teachers.

One woman was killed and a woman and a man were seriously injured at 1:45 A. M. today when the automobile in which they were riding south on Fifth Avenue got out of control at Thirty-ninth Street and mounted the curb, shattering two shop windows before it came to a halt.
Thomas Oliphant Connett of Washington, who had been associated with the United States Maritime Commission for several years, died here yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness.
Dr. William Frederic Moore, a pioneer in the field of bronchoscopy and esophagoscopy, died of a heart attack today at his home here in his fifty-eighth year.

Did James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, speaking for the President, express the opinion that Maryland should defeat Senator Tydings and send a representative to Washington "whose mind would go along with Roosevelt's"? New Deal and conservative Democratic leaders and voters here are asking themselves.

John Henry Lewis of Phoenix, Ariz., defended his world lightheavyweight title by knocking out Emilio Martinez, Denver, in- the fourth of a scheduled fifteen-round bout tonight. Lewis weighed 174 3/4, and Martinez 174.

Taxing powers should be used e' solely for revenue and not for punishment, Maxwell E. McDowell, head of the tax department of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, declared yesterday afternoon in a talk on
The Buffalo Bisons scored four runs in the first three innings as the result of erratic play on the part of the Jersey City Giants' infield today to take the second game of the series, 5 to 4.

J. F. Fogarty, president of the North American Company, told shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday that the North American system was not greatly inter- la ested in the prospect of borrowing money from the RFC.

The British and Irish Governments ended their disastrous six-year tariff war to- b day with the help of a ?10,000,000 n lump sum payment by Ireland and e the abandonment by Britain of the last vestige of her control over the soil of the twenty-six counties.

The Rev. John Ewing Steen, assistant minister of Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, at South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, was elected Moderator of the BrooklynNassau Presbytery yesterday afternoon and inducted into office at the Arlington Avenue Presbyterian Church at Elton Street. Brooklyn.

As a result of Jackie Coogan's suit to recover $4,000,000 he says he earned as a child movie star the parents of three film juveniles announced in a joint statement that they were taking steps to protect their children's earnings.

A new sit- "1. A new sitdown strike closed two Detroit tax and plants of Gar Wood Industries, of tax-ex Inc., today. Five hundred employes were involved in the strike at the "2. Just plants, named for the famous speed should tr boat driver. The U.A.W.A.,

The tori Wilson Bennett Manufacturing ver Company, makers of steel containers, today announced the election of Harry M. Gustafson as president of the company. He succeeds Stevens A. Bennett who has been named chairman of the board and general manager.

A charge that Monroe J. Berliner of 1,288 East Eighth Street,.Brooklyn, had conspired with Martin (Buggsy) Goldstein and Seymour Magoon, Brooklyn gangsters, and sixteen contractors to maintain a $1,500,000 monopoly of painting and decorating contracts in Brooklyn and Queens public schools, was dismissed yesterday in Special Sessions Court; Brooklyn when -Dep uty Attorney General Bernard'Bienstock 'informed the court that an investigation showed the defendant had had no actual connection with the alleged conspiracy.

Samuel Reshevsky, who successfully defended his title as chess champion of the United States in the tournament concluded at Rockefeller Center Sunday night, divided the first and second prizes with Reuben Fine in a rapid-transit tournament for a fund donated by

Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and publisher of The Houston Chronicle, said in an interview at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that there were unmistakable signs of business improvement for the Summer and Fall.

As a prelude to Wednesday's wedding of King Zog and Countess Geraldine Apponyi a series of festivities took place in this capital today. In the early morning a salvo of twenty-one guns announced the opening of the three-day celebration.
The address of Paul Bellamy of The Cleveland Plain Dealer at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria follows:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In commenting on a Senatorial remark as to a "lack of ideas" among business men you have produced a list of suggestions for governmental reform to show that the criticism is not just. Certainly a major problem of American life is that of business management.

Parliament will return from its Easter vacation tomorrow to face serious difficulties with the budget. Professor Fernand Baudhuin in his report on the financial situation said that the deficit would probably reach 2,000,000,000 francs. Finance Minister Henri de Man had previously estimated it at 1,000,000,000 francs.

A sixteenth century French manuscript Book of Hours-a masterpiece of illumination and calligraphy--brought $18,000, the top price, last night at the sale of Part 2 of the library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

Samuel Goldwyn and Mary Pickford returned yesterday on the Queen Mary from England, where they formulated plans with Alexander Korda and Douglas Fairbanks for the reorganization of the opereating policy of the United Artists Distributing Corporation, of which they and Charlie Chaplin are the owner-producers.

Mrs. C. Douglass Green was a luncheon hostess yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Edward Wyckoff Harris, who has returned from Florida. Other guests were Mrs. Edwin H. Denby, Mrs. Warner M. Van Norden, Mrs. Charles Astor Bristed, Mrs. John J. Watson, Mrs. Edward L. Tinker, Mrs. Joel Ellis Fisher, Mrs. du Pignac Thompson,

Final liquidation of May contracts, preparatory to appearance of the notices this morning, was the source of a large volume of business on-the Cotton Exchange yesterday and in caused losses of 9 to 11 poinnts at the close.
A three-day sale at the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop, 705 Second Avenue, which is being held to raise funds for the support of seven welfare organizations of New York and Brooklyn, opened yesterday.
Automobile production declined last week, with the seasonal factor unchanged, and the index dropped to 51.1 from 52.3 in the previous week and compared with 112.2 for the week ended April 24, 1937.

Many reservations have been made for the Spring card party and bazaar -for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery Thursday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Daniel Daney Miller heads the bridge committee and Mrs. William Gage Brady is chairman of the group in charge of the arrangements for the bazaar.

A $100,000 first mortgage loan at 4 1/2 per cent for five years on the recently completed six-story apartment house at 161 E 206th St, Bronx, has been arranged by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc, and Pease Elliman, Inc., as co-brokers, for the 206th Street Realty Co, Inc. The New York State Teachers Retirement System is the mortgagee.

The third short to be expanded into a feature was announced today by Warners, who revealed that'"Declaration of Independence" will be filmed late in the Summer with John Litel in the leading role of Patrick Henry.

Two four-run explosions enabled the Pirates to defeat the Cubs today in the first meeting of the two clubs this season. The score was 8 to 6, Pie Traynor's unbeaten team thus recording its seventh straight victory.

Miss Barbara Baird, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon C. Baird of this city, became the bride of John Robert Parker Jr. son of Mr. and Mrs. Parker of Schenectady, this evening in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. George E. Norton officiated.
The Tigers, in a batting slump since the start of the season, uncorked a mighty attack in the opening game of their series with the Browns today and won easily, 10 to 1.

The United Biscuit Company has called for redemption at 105 on June 1 $136,000 of its 5 per cent debentures, due April, 1950, which have been drawn by lot for payment out of the purchase fund for these bonds. The drawn bonds will be paid on and after the redemption date at the office of Goldman, Sachs Co.

Philip Meise defeated Howard Bergman, 125 to 134, in 30 innings, and Seymour Prince conquered Hugo Doob, 125 to 89, in 38 frames, in the twenty-second annual Poggenburg Memorial 18.2 balkline competition at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night.

The pound sterling cheapened in the foreign exchange market yesterday on the news of Britain's new budget of about $5,000,000,000 and the higher tax rate which it calls for. Selling of sterling hit the market as soon as the budget proposals were placed before Parliament by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir John Simon.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Herman Silverman of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 921-William H. Neblett, Vernon Bettin et al., petrs., v. Samuel L. Carpenter Jr., Insurance Commissioner of California, et al. Motion for leave to file brief of Josiah E. Brill and Samuel H. Maslon, as amici curiae, submitted and the motion denied.

The Shandon Farm's Burning Star gave a speed demonstration today in his first start since two dull races in Florida last Winter. The Burning Blaze colt outclassed four opponents in the Riderwood Purse at a mile and a sixteenth.

Business in general will be normal by Fall and the recession is about to turn now, William H. Gosch, retiring president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, predicted at that organization's annual meeting at the Commercial Museum today in connection with the annual Knitting Arts Exhibition. Hosiery, he added,

Subscribers to the three performances of the Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, "H. M. S. Pinafore" and "Trial by Jury," to be presented by the Blue Hill Troupe tonight, tomorrow and Friday nights at the Heckscher Theatre, are arranging several dinner parties to precede the performances.

The inquiry by Attorney General Bennett into circumstances that caused the New York Curb Exchange to suspend trading recently in the shares of Burco Inc., investment trust, was continued yesterday. William H. Robinson Jr., secretary to Howard F. Hansell,

With Franco-Italian diplomatic talks just getting under way, these two nations are preparing to take one of their disputes before the Hague Court. The Permanent Court of International Justice today fixed the opening of hearings on the Morocco phosphate question for next Monday.

Colonel Jacob S. Clinton, city assessor, and veteran of the SpanishAmerican war, the Mexican border expedition of 1914 and the World War, died of a stroke yesterday at his home here. He was 58 years old. He had commanded companies of the 105th Infantry, National Guard, both in peace and war.

Daily average gross crude oil production - in the - United States last week was 3,440,100 barrels, compared with 3,385,400 in the previous week, an increase of 54,700, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 78,400 barrels more than the calculation of 3,361,700 daily for April by the Bureau of Mines.

Governor Lehman of New York got his revenge today. On his first day at this resort yesterday he hooked a tarpon estimated to weight 55 pounds. During the battle a huge hammerhead shark swallowed tarpon, hook, line and sinker, then snapped the line.
Co-Sport was sent over the full Kentucky Derby route today, the first nominee to be given that long a workout at Churchill Downs this season. He covered the mile and quarter in 2:113-5.
Two paintings by Sir Frederick Banting, discoverer of insulin, will be seen in the first annual exhibition of the American Physicians' Art Association in June in San Francisco.

State libraries in Austria will segregate those books with anti-Nazi tendencies or written by prominent "non-Aryans," which will be placed in special rooms, together with Socialist works eliminated previously by the Schuschnigg regime.
Minister of Justice C. M. J. F. Goseling, who is a Roman Catholic, is much criticized by the Left for having given first place to loyalty to his church even before the requirements of his office.

The Museum of Modern Art opened with a preview last evening its exhibition of "primitive" art, called "Masters of Popular Painting"-a title that seems to have been adapted for English use from the French "Maitres Populaires de la Realite," employed by the Grenoble Museum as a banner under which it marshaled, last Summer at the World's Fair in Paris, a battalion of naivetes. In fact,

Goldman, Sachs Co. and Eldredge Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $407,000 of bonds of the town of Riverhead, L. I., on their bid of 100.569 for 2.20s. The bonds, which will mature from 1939 to 1958,

The Greenbrier open tennis tournament moved to the quarter-final round today, with the favorites, including Karel Kozeluh, George Lott, Bruce Barnes and Richard Skeen, still undefeated. Herman Peterson, Fishers Island, N. Y., had little trouble in his match with Al Chapin, New York,

George H. Mead, president of the e Mead Corporation, said at the annual meeting of stockholders in Dayton, Ohio, yesterday that indications were that business in April and May would continue the upward trend which began in January. In June and July, however,

Edward Baruch, an attorney in Brooklyn for thirty-three years, died of a heart ailment yesterday at his home, 988 St. John's Place, after a brief illness. Mr. Baruch, whose office was at 16 Court Street, was 59 years old.
Pedro Montanez of Puerto Rico, one of the outstanding contenders for the lightweight crown, will meet Frankie Wallace of Cleveland in the ten-round feature bout at the Hippodrome tonight.

Nazi spokesmen in Berlin predicted today that Konrad Henlein, leader of the Sudeten Germans, would demand early in June that they be permitted to vote on whether they desire to remain a part of Czechoslovakia or be joined to Greater Germany.

Edgar Silver, 43, former New York-city broker who came here a year ago for his health, was found dead in his room in the Newton Falls Hotel late yesterday, suspended from a coat hook with a heavy cord about his neck.

Pulitzer prize awards in letters and journalism for 1937 will be broadcast over the WEAF network next Monday at 9 P. M. when they are announced by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, at the silver anniversary dinner of the Columbia School of Journalism at the Men's Faculty Club, Morningside Drive and 117th Street.

The steam freighter Malamton ran ashore on Southeast Point near the lighthouse on Block Island, R. I., at 8:30 tonight, in a heavy fog. The Coast Guard station keeper at Block Island telephoned that Coast Guardsmen there had gone to the assistance of the vessel, which is five miles from the station.
A loan of 5 cents was made here today by Charles D. Dickey, a partner in J. P. Morgan Co., who testified before the SEC concerning the failure of Richard Whitney Co.

There is great indignation here regarding reports appearing in some American newspapers under Innsbruck and Vienna date lines to the effectt that the German-speaking minority in what was once South Tyrol and is now-Upper Adige has been becoming increasingly restive since Anschluss.

The body of Mrs. Alfred Snively, aged 51, wife of a Whittinsville Episcopal clergyman and a Welleslay graduate, was found today by Coastguards in a boat in Meadow Creek, a quarter of a mile from her Summer cottage, from which she disappeared early yesterday.
Leave of absence for 10 days, effective on or about May 11, 1938, with permission to leave the continental limits of the United States, is granted 1st Lt. Alfred C. Nicholas, F.A.-Res. (3d M.A.).

Thomas W. Lamont of J. P. Morgan Co. defended himself before the Securities and Exchange Commission here today for saying nothing to anybody about supplying $1,082,000 for the restitution of securities which he knew Richard Whitney had used last November "unlawfully."

Sales of the May Department Stores in the fiscal quarter, Feb. 1 to May 1, were running approximately 7 1/2 per cent below the similar period last year, Nathan L. Dauby, vice president, stated yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

Deaths Announced Retired Captain William H. Holmes, formerly a member of Engine 224, residing at 30 Elm Rd., North Caldwell, N. J., died April 3. Retired Lieutenant John J. McMahon, formerly a member of Engine 62, residing at 3,325 Decatur Ave., Bronx, died April 22.
BULLINGER BOUND AND OTHER POEMS, by Leonard Bacon. (Harper, $2.) A long narrative poem and a miscellany of shorter pieces.
Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange continued listless as values again drifted irregularly to slightly lower levels. Apparently because of pending tax legislation,

Adolf Hitler, in brown-shiftea effigy, disappeared suddenly from the Williams College campus this evening as a group of pro-fascist conservatives made off with an image of Der Fuehrer which had been prepared for destruction at the stake.

Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, earmarked $55,000,000 today for nineteen cities, including $2,900,000 for Bridgeport and $900,000 for Montclair, N. J. The day's earmarkings increased to $310,998,000 the reservations thus far made for seventy-seven communities in twenty-three States and the Territory of Hawaii.

Smarting under "discourteous treatment" from Mayor La Guardia and Council President Newbold Morris, Councilman Abner C. Surpless told his colleagues yesterday that he would bolt the La Guardia coalition unless he was treated more politely by both officials.

Delivery of 17,000 bales of cotton mon on May notices here and in New Orleans, coupled with a decline in the stock market, brought yesterday losses of, 5 to 9 points in prices on the Cotton Exchange. Throughout the first hour the market held relatively steady and it improved at one time.
Clubs and baseball bats were hurled tonight in a brief clash between rival unions at the General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet plant here. Two men were injured and a third was arrested.
The average citizen in these parts is no Lord Chesterfield, but he is reasonably polite under most circumstances. He stands patiently in line to buy tickets to a motion-picture show or a ball game.

Modification, for a three months' trial period, of the rule forbidding persons -to stand in buses operating through the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority. A maximum of ten now will-be allowed.

With the Rev. John Boland, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, presiding and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey as a witness, a new collective-bargaining agreement was signed yesterday between Local 302 of the Cafeteria Employes Union, A. F. of L. affiliate, and the Affiliated Restaurateurs, Inc., in the board's offices, 366 Broadway.

The growing popularity of salt water fishing was never more clearly illustrated than during the Metropolitan Miami Fishing Tournament which will reach its formal conclusion tonight with the presentation of awards to seventy anglers.

Having suffered his first and only defeat in the fifth round yesterday, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris made amends today with a brilliant victory over E. Book, the young Finnish master, in the sixth round of the International Chess Masters Tournament at the Grand Hotel, Cliftonville.
Henry Morgenthau Sr., former Ambassador to Turkey, expressed optimism over the future of this country at the observance of his eighty-second birthday yesterday at his home, 1,133 Fifth Avenue.
Twenty-three new members were admitted last night to Macy's "Twenty-five Year Club" at the annual dinner of the organization held in the restaurant of the store.

The negotiations that Sir Robert L. Craigie, British Ambassador, has been conducting with the Japanese Foreign Office regarding the Shanghai maritime customs are new within measurable distance of success.

Miss Florence A. Grant, who has been a member of the American Woman's Association for twelve years, received the Anna W. Porter memorial medal at the annual meeting and election at the clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, last night.

Governor Earle was called upon from two sources today to retract charges he made against the American Viscose Company in a radio address last night in his campaign for the Democratic Senatorial nomination.

The German Ambassador at Washington informed the State Department yesterday that Germany had decided to withdraw from participating in the New York World's Fair of 1939 because of financial difficulties.

Dr. John R. Huffman, assistant Professor of Chemical Engineering at New York University, won his fifth national saber championship last night, while two of America's leading swordsmen for several years achieved their first national indoor crowns on the strips of the converted salle d'armes in the New York A. C. before a large gathering.

House and Senate conferees reached agreement today on the new revenue bill after a four-hour session. The measure, containing drastic modifications of the present law, including compromises on the undistributed profits tax principle and capital gains levies, is expected to reach the Senate floor late this week.

Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, in response to the Scott resolution asking for specific information on treaty violators, has advised the House Foreign Affairs Committee that the United States considered the Italian and Japanese Governments as having failed to carry out their obligations under the Kellogg-Briand pact.
The Senators defeated the Red Sox, 6 to 4, today, largely because Pete Appleton was stingy with hits in the pinches and had them to spare when he went to bat.

In replying today to the second British note on the expropriation of British-owned oil properties in this country, the Mexican Government asserted that British shareholders could not legally invoke their government's protection because such persons were considered Mexican.

THE Italian word novella is once more thrust beneath our noses with the publication today, of "The Flying Yorkshireman," a collection of five . . . of five ... well, of five "novellas," I guess we'll have to say, sparing the italics.. Each of the five is by a different author, and the entire lot appeared at one time or another in the pages of the magazine Story.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 23: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Mattox, R. H., Yorktown, Va., to continues treatment Norfolk Naval Hospital, Portsmouth, Va., and when discharged ordered to treatment Naval Hospital, New York, N. Y.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated April 25: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Andrus, C., F. A., General Staff Corps, two days' leave April 28. Eichelberger, R. L, Inf., Adjutant General's dept., General Staff Corps, 10 days' leave, April 25.

President Roosevelt called Representative O'Connor of New York, chair-' man of the Rules Committee, to the White House today to urge favorable action by the committee on the pending Wages and Hour Bill.

The first thirty-seven railroads to report for March showed a decrease in aggregate net operating income of 80.1 per cent from the total for March, 1937. This was an improvement compared with February, when the companies showed an operating deficit.

The Federal Government receives $97,855 from the estate of James Reuel Smith, Yonkers historian and writer, "to be applied toward redemption of Liberty bonds issued in 1918," according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

The idea that the living pattern of the metropolitan area of New York could be controlled and reshaped was first set forth in detail a decade ago when the Committee on Regional Plan of New York and Its Environs began publishing its monumental report.

By far the best national recovery plan that has come to the notice of this department is the projected La Follette third party. Reasoning purely by analogy, we recall that the last time there was a La Follette third party, in 1924, it was followed by five years of great prosperity. To be sure,

Burdened with a bumper crop of 2,000,000 bales of cotton, Brazil is being subjected to terrific pressure by Germany to increase the volume of aski mark trade with that country, Nicholas Moreno of the export department of Fairbanks, Morse Co., told members of the Export Managers Club'of New York, Inc.,
The Right Rev. Edward A. Pace, vice rector emeritus of the Catholic University of America, died this morning at Providence Hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

The experiment of Dr. Herbert E. Ives of the Bell Telephone Laboratories with an "atomic clock" which verifies the existence of ether in space is the most direct proof yet brought forth in support of the theory of relativity, Dr. Albert Einstein declared tonight. In an interview at his home, 12 Mercer Street, he said:
Otis - Harlan, veteran of stage and screen, today was in Hollywood Hospital in a critical condition from a stroke suffered while rehearsing for an appearance with Al Jolson.

Pitted against twenty-four opponents in an exhibition of simultaneous play at the Marshall Chess Club last night, Arthur W. Dake of Portland, Ore., chess champion of the Pacific Coast and a member of the United States international team, won eighteen games and drew six. .

I. B. Tigrett, president of the Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad, received $30,120 compensation in 1937, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday. F. M. Hicks, executive vice president, received $15,090; J. N. Flowers, general counsel, $17,090, and G. P. Brock general manager. $11,000.
Clear indications were given today that the first problem to be dealt with on the floor of the Constitutional Convention will be revision of the anti-gambling clauses of the present Constitution.

In his first tic public appearance since he explained his resignation as Foreign Secretary to his constituents on Feb. 25; Anthony Eden tonight said that Britain must not forget her chief contribution to the world"the art of self-government by a free people."

Boynton Ave. (14-3741), e s, 284 it s of Westchester Ave, 150x100; Manufacturers Trust Co., trustee, to A. B. Sey Real Estate. Inc., 551 5th Ave; mtg $194,000. East Kingsbridge Rd. 58 (11-3177); Mard Realty Corp to Leon Goldenthal, 2,703 Webb Ave: mtg $11,700. Quincy Ave, 236 (18-5591): Jacob K. Javits, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp.

An unnamed banker, convicted of violating the Securities Exchange Act, has informed the Bureau of Prisons that he thinks the prison at McNeil Island, Wash., would be a far pleasanter place than Leavenworth Penitentiary.

The Travelers Aid Society in 1937 aided more than 50,000 travelers, and next year, with the New York World's Fair, it expects much greater problems, according to the annual report made yesterday afternoon at the society's annual meeting at the Cosmopolitan Club.

Blanked for six innings, Cincinnati overcame a seven-run disadvantage today and, with rallies in three frames, nosed out the Cards, 8 to 7, in the tenth to take fifth place in the National League race.

Commercial film companies are aiming at a $10,000,000 volume this year, Frank Tripp of the Gannett Newspapers declared yesterday at the afternoon session of the American Newspaper Publishers Association convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
The need for a city college on Staten Island was recognized in a resolution adopted last night by the Board of Higher Education meeting held last night at the City College School of Business.

After deliberating for eleven hours, a Federal Court jury last night found John M. Kelley, former general counsel for the Ringling Brothers-Barnum and Bailey combined circus, and two former Internal Revenue agents, not guilty under two income tax conspiracy indictments, but convicted them under two other indictments charging them with aiding and counseling the preparation and filing of false and fraudulent income tax returns.

The program for immediate railroad relief recently submitted to President Roosevelt for the Interstate Commerce Commission virtually was assured of Congressional approval at the present session by developments here today.

Nehring Brothers, Inc. have arranged a 10-year, 5 per cent, first mortgage of $35,000 on the property at 128-36 West New York Post Road, White Plains, for Sterpost, Inc. An investing client of Samuel Hurwitz bought the first mortgage of $4,000 on the 3-story apartment and store building at 253 Floyd St, Brooklyn.

The entire livestock market pepped up some today. Both lambs and cattle sold strong to higher and hogs, after an early lower opening. reversed the trend with a large measure of the early break regained, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

President Roosevelt made it clear today that his Administration would not be represented at the conference of liberals called by Governor La Follette and Senator La Follette at Madison, despite the attendance of Adolph A. Berle, Assistant Secretary of State.
The card party, fashion show and tea in aid of the scholarship and building fund of Marymount College in Tarrytown will take place this afternoon at the Marymount School, 1,028 Fifth Avenue.

Ousting of fifty-eight teachers holding positions only in the evening schools in order to make room for a similar number holding day school positions was directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller. Twenty-three substitutes who have been teaching in the evening schools are also to be displaced.

However much its real significance may be camouflaged with declarations of mutual confidence and professions of faith in the spirit of the Entente Cordiale, it is secretly admitted here that there is much tragedy in the visit to London that Premier Edouard Daladier and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet will begin tomorrow.

The construction of two of the largest icebreakers in the world--named the Joseph Stalin and the Lazar Kaganovitch -is nearing completion in Leningrad shipyards. After tests of the engines, winches, pumps and other mechanical parts, the icebreakers will make brief sea tests and then go to the relief of icebound Soviet ships in the Arctic Ocean.
The Reichsbank's statement as of April 25 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Fair trade laws do not foster monopolies nor do they weaken the anti-trust laws, State Senator A. Spencer Feld, co-author of the FeldCrawford act, said last night at the fair trade mass meeting held in conjunction with the annual convention of the New York Pharmaceutical Council, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Lammot du Pont, a director, said at the annual stockholders' meeting of the General Motors Corporation today that "corporations must pay high salaries to keep their successful executives."

Today's major events: "The Sun Dance." New York Light Opera Guild, Broadway Theatre, evening; Clarinet Ensemble, Town Hall, evening; Madrigal Singers and Forum String Quartet, Federal Music Theatre, evening.

Signal honors will be paid to Seaman Dean Leroy Blake of the U. S. S. Raleigh, father of the first baby born to a member of the United States Navy squadron stationed at Villefranche on Spanish war duty.

A. F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, announced today that he had authorized a strike of Hudson Manhattan Railroad workers in New York "unless a satisfactory settlement is made."

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions MANHATTAN RAILWAY CO., 165 Broadway-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of upward of $50,000,000. including a funded debt of approximately $45,000,000, and assets of $130,617,778. The corporation. which operates the El lines in Manhattan and Bronx, is capitalized at $60,00,000.

Only twice before in the history of this Administration has any action been taken by business leaders comparable to that announced today by John W. Hanes, member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

William Loeb Jr. of New York, who announced a month ago that he was soliciting proxies in an effort to reorganize the Reo Motor Company, failed in re-election to the company's board of directors today, and a threatened "battle of proxies" did not materialize. To succeed Mr. Loeb,
Britain's hard-pressed taxpayers were thunderstruck tonight to learn that they must bear crushing new burdens to help pay for the rearmament program.

The first of the Westchester interclub matches of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association will be held on May 13 at the Century Country Club, according to an announcement made yesterday by Mrs. I. M. Wheeler, team captain.

Furnishings of the residence of Gilbert W. Keech, 4 East Seventyninth Street, together with property of his estate, were sold for $17,456 at two auction sessions yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. A white ermine wrap with Hudson Bay sable trimming went to a private buyer for $625.

O. C. Stanton and L. W. Francis Jr. of Heights Casino were among the first-round winners in the Mixsell Cup squash tennis doubles tournament at the Heights Casino yesterday. They defeated L. H. Sonneborn and C. F. Weidlich of the Yale Club, 15-9, 18-17, 18-16.

The University of Rochester baseball team made it two in a row with a 5-4 victory over Syracuse University today. The Yellow Jackets fought an uphill battle, tying the game in the seventh and gaining their one-run margin in the next frame. Pitcher Bob Ulreck held the losers to six hits while striking out ten and walking four men, all in the third inning, in which Syracuse made three runs without a hit.

The world's apparent use of tin in the first two- months of this- year was 26,400 tons, or 5,100 less than in the corresponding period of last year, the International Tin Research and Development Council reported yesterday. In the first two months of 1938 world production was only 1,500 tons smaller, at 26,800 tons.

The Bureau of New Plays, sponsored by seven motion picture companies to encourage embryo playwrights in colleges and universities, has surrendered to the Dramatists Guild in the matter of contractual relations with the new authors it might discover, it was announced yesterday.

Price reductions of from $40 to $92 on all automobile models now being produced by Graham-Paige Motors Corporation were announced today by Storrs J. Case, advertising representative, who described the action as a deliberate attempt on the part of the company and its dealers to stimulate business. The new prices,

A chemical model which imitates in many important respects the behavior of the mysterious invisible fluid wall surrounding all living cells and gives the "appearance of 'perpetual motion' that can go on for months," was described today before the National Academy of Sciences.

A possibility that a trace has been found of the missing Russian Arctic plane of Sigismund Levanevsky and his crew of five, who left Moscow for Fairbanks, Alaska, on Aug. 12, 1937, was reported to the War Deapartment today by Master Sergeant Stanley Morgan, veteran signal corps operator at Point Barrow Alaska.

Broadway will go through a "dolling and cleaning up" in the next year to prepare for the millions of visitors to the World's Fair, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor given by the Broadway Association to the secretaries of other civic organizations.

Urged by advisers of President Roosevelt to enter the primaries in opposition to the renomination of Senator Tydings of Maryland, a critic of the New Deal, Dr. H. Clinton Bird, president of the University of Maryland, declined today to make the race.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Kennelly of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Kennelly, to William C. Sandy 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. William C. Sandy Jr. of Harrisburg, Pa.

After spending six weeks in jail awaiting trial on a charge of attempting to kidnap his two daughters from his former wife's care, Forrester Scott of Philadelphia was freed today when the court decided the former Mrs. Scott's Reno divorce was invalid under British law.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday reached the thousand mark for the first time in two months. The total was also well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. Last week the arrivals were 1,028, as against 663 in the previous week and 818 in the same period last year.
Mr. and Mrs. Max Bache of 1,035 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maxine Bache, to Maurice R. Forman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Forman of Rochester, N. Y.

Although American democracy is not immune from the European plague of autocracy, a dictator could hardly capture all the sections of this country because of their divergent interests, William Allen White,

Frank Nasmith, president-elect of the Textile Institute, Manchester, England, and J. R. S. Goodall, chairman of the institute's diplomas committee, will visit the United States the last week in May as representatives of the organization, with a view to developing closer cooperation with similar American groups interested in testing and research.

By the time they are 7 or 8 years old, Dr. Dafoe announces, those five hard-working young ladies in Callander, Ont., will be able to retire for a while from the motion-picture business. They will then have accumulated about a million dollars.

A boycott of Japanese goods, lifting the embargo on Loyalist Spain and opposition to "compulsory" military training in colleges are included in a five-point "minimum peace action" to be demanded today by students in their annual demonstration against war. The other points are opposition to the Navy Armament Bill and the meas ure to end war profits.

A horse that has won the only race of his life, H. E. Morriss's Pasch, tonight was established a 3-to-1 favorite for tomorrow's running of the Two Thousand Guineas, first of the season's classics for 3-year-olds.

Clinton St, 129, 25x100; Charles Wilfred Hunter and wife to 129 Corp, 33 W 42d St. care B. A. Theeman (50 cents). Norfolk St, 76, 25x100; Maxwell Lustig to Central Savings Bank; consideration $13,000, foreclosure. 31st St, 110 W, 20.10x98.10; Julian L. Marx to same; holding mtgs, $42,000.

Seth C. Avery, free on bail of $10,000 on a charge of violating the Federal impersonation statute, was found dead yesterday in his threeroom apartment at 226 Lexington Avenue, near Thirty-fourth Street.

Charles T. McCarthy, executive in the plant of the United States Rubber Products Company here, died in the Waterbury Hospital yesterday after a brief illness. He was 70 years old. Mr, McCarthy was graduated from Dartmouth in 1888 and captained the college baseball team.

The Nationalists [Insurgents] have inaugurated a new passenger airline joining Seville and the Canary Islands, with calls at Larache, Spanish Morocco; Ifni and Cape Juby, all of them North African points in Generalissimo Francisco Franco's possession.

For the first time in its 153 years The Times of London published today a thirty-six-page issue--largely, it is understood, as a result of a rush of late advertisements following the budget speech in the House of Commons yesterday. The largest issue hitherto was thirty-two pages.

Fifty years ago Professors Michelson and Morley cross-examined Nature. Is there an ether-or not? The question was put in the form of a searching experiment. Light had a known velocity. Also it was conveyed by the hypothetical ether.

Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Steamship- Owners Association, told a group of 200 shipping men yesterday that legislation would be sought to provide tax exemption for funds set aside by all ship lines for new construction.
Extra-hole victories by Frank Pennink, defending champion, and Harry Bentley, German amateur champion, featured second-round matches in the English amateur golf championship today.

Ben Jonson's own copy of the first edition of Montaigne's essays, published in 1580, brought $3,900 last night at the auction of Part 2 of the library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries. Inc.

Operators and investors figured yesterday as the buyers and sellers of houses in scattered sections of Manhattan. Rosenstock Bacharach bought from the 50 Central Park West Corporation the six-story apartment house for eighteen families at 503 West 122d Street, between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway.

A man who said he was Prince Rospigliosi, 30 years old, and gave his address as the Hotel Weylin, 40 East Fifty-fourth Street, was arrested last night in Queens and released in $500 bail on a charge of leaving the scene of an accident.

Frank Key Green, a member of the Supreme Court staff for nearly fortyfive years and marshal of the tribunal for almost a quarter century, died in his home here today at the age of 61. Soon after the court met for its regular session at noon, it adjourned in respect to his memory and after Chief Justice Hughes paid a tribute from the bench to the veteran officer.

Fordham's freshman baseball team handed the New York University cubs their second defeat in as many starts this season by routing the Violet, 9 to 4, at Ohio Field yesterday. Ed Leighton, Ram pitcher, yielded eleven hits, but proved effective in tight spots in the fifth and ninth innings.

Jimmy Caras of Wilmington, Del., defending the world's pocket billiard championship against the challenge of Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, made it three blocks in a row yesterday at the Strand Academy and his advantage soared to 384167 in the eight-block, 1,000-point match.
Lady Henrietta Diana Finch-Hatton, youngest daughter of the Earl and Countess of Winchilsea and Nottingham, was married to Peter Frank Tiarks to-day in St. Ethelburga's Church, Bishopsgate, London.

Erwin R. Hilts and J. Paul Lynch, members of the New York Stock. Exchange and partners in the recently dissolved member firm of Prentice Brady, were found guilty yesterday by the governing committee of the Exchange of "conduct inconsistent with just and equitable principles of trade."

Associate Justice Cardozo, absent from the Supreme Court bench since Dec. 3 because of illness, left here today to spend the Spring and Summer with Judge and Mrs. Irving Lehman at Port Chester, N. Y. He was associated with Judge Lehman on the New York Court of Appeals before coming here in 1932.
Wiping out three early Chicago leads, Cleveland's first-place Indians batted out a 10-to-6 victory over the White Sox in the delayed opener of a series today for their sixth straight triumph.

Commissioner Richard H. Ackers of the Federal Court of Claims heard a Justice Department attorney charge today that a major airline paid $3,000 in 1930 to a son of the late Senator Fess of Ohio for two days' activity on Capitol Hill.

Former Kaiser Wilhelm's barber, Francois Haby, died here today at the age of 77. Fifty years ago he devised the famous imperial mustache worn by the former Kaiser and trimmed it himself for a quarter of a century before the monarch went into exile
Tribesmen, soldiers and diplomats crowded this tiny capital tonight for the wedding tomorrow of King Ahmed Zog and a Hungarian Countess with Virginia blood.

Lou Conway, president of Local 54 of the Building Service Employes Union, also known as the Service Employes in Amusement and Cultural Buildings, expects to open negotiations soon with the League of New York Theatres for a contract covering the cleaning staffs, matrons and watchmen in theatres.
Postmaster General Farley scoffed here tonight at charges that the Roosevelt Administration was unfriendly to business and that the President was inclined to seek a dictatorship.

Four more earthquakes during the last twenty-four hours were reported in the Kirshehir district, the scene of the recent disastrous earthquake, and eleven dead were added to the long list of victims as further destruction was wrought.

Bernie Friedkin, 133 1/2, Brownsville, gained the decision after a keen battle with Orville Drouillard, 134, Windsor, Ont., in the feature eight-rounder of the Broadway Arena boxing card last night. After the bout it was announced that Friedkin and Drouillard had been rematched for May 10.

Representative Snell of New York, the House Republican leader, proposed today a formal inquiry by Congress into the authenticity of a letter addressed to President Roosevelt, which said new propaganda against the government spending program was about to deluge Congress.

Thirty-two persons were killed and forty-eight were injured yesterday, according to trustworthy estimates, when police fired into a crowd variously estimated at from 500 to 25,000 at Viduraswatham in the Kolar district of Mysore State.

The emergency relief bureau of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children was the beneficiary of a luncheon and card party held yesterday at Sherry's under the auspices of the advisory board of the Shelter. Many luncheon parties were given at the benefit.

The Columbia and Fordham nines will meet today at Baker Field in a game that will serve as a test for the new yellow baseball. The sphere is the regulation National League ball except for color, which is said to be of "high visibility" and will be used for the first time on record.

Jaily Aaverage sales of grocery chain stores in March were about 4 1/2 per cent below the dollar volume for the same month last year, when these sales were higher than for any month since June, 1931, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Savings banks were among the sellers of properties in Brooklyn reported under new control in deals yesterday. An investor bought from the Bowery Savings Bank the five-story apartment house for sixteen families at 1,794 Pitkin Avenue, which occupies a plot 37.6 by 100 feet and is assessed at $34,000.

Public spending is "out or dateas a way toward recovery and would prove a serious obstacle, according to the monthly survey of business in the current issue of Banking, the official publication of the American Bankers Association.

The marriage of Miss Christina Whitehouse Boardman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Boardman of 57 East Eightieth Street and Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., to Julian Gerard Buckley of this city took place yesterday afternoon in St. James Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Paul and the Rev. Lyman C. Bleecker.

An appeal for conservatism in the size of newspaper headlines as a means of preserving freedom of the press was voiced by Arthur J. Sinnott, editor of The Newark Evening News, at a luncheon of newspaper and advertising executives today in the Ayer Building.
New Jersey banks will go on a five-day week during July and August each year if Governor Moore signs a bill sent to him today by the Legislature.

Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt and a group of high government officials attended funeral services in St. John's Episcopal Church today for Charles Sumner Hamlin, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in the Cleveland and Wilson Administrations and first governor of the Federal Reserve Board, who died Sunday.

Unless the nation's citizens use their rights of petition and do what they did when the Supreme Court Bill and the Reorganization Bill came up in Washington, the same formula of spending, "right or wrong," will be followed by the national Administration, De Witt Emery of Akron, Ohio, founder and president of the National Small Business Men's Association, said yesterday.

Mrs. Herbert Noble gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's. Her guests included Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius, Mrs. John C. Juhring, Mrs. Charles King Morrison, Mrs. Fielding Lewis Taylor, Mrs. William H. Judson, Mrs. William O. Rogers, Mrs. Joseph P. McComas, Mrs. Charles H. Willard,, Mrs.

Wearing adhesive tape on his palms and thumbs and cloth gloves as protection for his blistered hands, Joe DiMaggio yesterday went through a brisk two-hour drill in the deserted Yankee Stadium as he resumed his exclusive training campaign to condition himself for an early return to action. DiMaggio,

The "natural science evenings" at the American Museum of Natural History were continued last night with a dinner and meeting at which Mr. and Mrs. Shepard Krech were hosts. Later in the evening Dr. Harold E. Anthony, curator of the Department of Mammals, showed motion pictures and lantern slides of Shiva Temple and the party afterward visited various exhibition halls of the museum.

Prime Minister Eamon de Valera returned to Ireland this evening, and in good spirits stepped ashore to be greeted with enthusiatsic cheering for his conclusion of an Anglo-Irish agreement. Before he left the ship several members of his Cabinet and deputies of the Government party went aboard to tender their congratulations.

The new channel of the Harlem River ship canal, which was cut through the Spuyten Duyvil peninsula, has been completed a full year ahead of the contract time. Dredgers broke through the cofferdam holding back the water from the new channel a week ago and in another week the waterway will be complete and turned over to the Federal Government.

Verdi's Requiem was performed by the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, of which Antonia rico is conductor, and a quartet of soloists and 285 voices from the horses of Greater New York assisted last night in Carnegie Hall this was a moving and eloquent in terpretation.

The Brooklyn College netmen handed the University of Newark tennis team an 8-1 setback at the Brooklyn courts yesterday. Nathan Goldstein and Co-captain Bob Keefe starred for the winners, taking the first and second singles respectively, in straight sets, and then teaming to win the first doubles match, again in straight sets.

Americanization Day will be celebrated in Brooklyn today with a rally on Borough Hall steps at noon under the auspices of Brooklyn Council, Ladies Auxiliary, Veterans of Foreign Wars. A street parade will precede the rally.

Predictions that the present quarter will bring one of the most active periods they have enjoyed in several years were made here yesterday by exporters on the basis of inquiries received from customers abroad. Heavy foreign buying, they predicted, will develop soon on manufactured as well as other goods as a hedge against possible inflation resulting here from the Federal spending program.

Reports from the United States that the British mission of air experts was already negotiating for the purchase of large numbers of American aircraft were discounted in the House of Commons this afternoon. Earl Winterton, Under-Secretary for Air, on behalf of the government declared the mission was "concerned solely with exploratory inquiries."
Opposing the passage of the Administration's $1,156,000,000 Naval Expansion Bill, Senator Borah of Idaho asserted in the Senate today that the United States had all the national defense it required.

The report for 1937 of the Socony--Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $56,808,264 after charges, taxes, depreciation, depletion, minority interests and undistributed Federal profits taxes of $1,924,946, equal to $1.82 each on the 31,151,071 capital shares outstanding in the hands of the public. This compares with $42,

Along about 5:20 this afternoon a sigh of relief went up in this sedate metropolis that almost blew off William Penn's hat and one needs scarcely to be told that Marse Joe McCarthy was chiefly responsible.

A letter is being sent to some 60,000 retail druggists throughout the country by the American Druggists Syndicate asking them to vote on these questions: "Are you in favor of government loans to deserving retailers?" and "Can you use profitably additional capital?"

The New York City metropolitan region leads the rest of the world in planning organization and achievement, the Regional Plan Association, Inc., reported in its second four-year report of progress, released yesterday.

Banking officials of the Federal Government agreed today that bank examinations should be made uniform and ordered their technical staffs to proceed with drafting a uniform examination to be adopted by the three Federal agencies which examine banks.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner' Queen Mary, leaving today for Southampton via Plymouth and Cherbourg, includes Mr. and Mrs. Forsythe Wickes, Sir Arthur Sutherland, Professor Caroline Spurgeon, Captain C. A. W. Wrightson, Lady Hardwicke, Paul Vincent Carroll, Robert E. Sherwood, Mrs. Erno Rapee, Edward Klauber, C. Ross Somerville, Lord Davies, the Hon. Michael L. Astor, Lady Wise,

Theatrical agents licensed by the Actors Equity Association have revived the Theatrical Artists Representatives Association to seek adjustment of the Equity rules governing actors' representatives and otherwise protect their interests, it was announced yesterday. The agents met Monday night in the office of Briscoe Goldsmith, 522 Fifth Avenue.

Represented by the largest group of stockholders since 1931-more than 61 per cent of the ote of the share owners-the Cities Service Company decided this afternoon in annual meeting here to reduce the stated value of its stock and exchange the common stock on a basis of one share for ten. By today's vote,

The Four Aces, Oswald Jacoby, David Burnstine, Howard Schenken and M. D. Maier, had a lead of 1,260 points against a Cavendish Club team of Waldemar K. von Zedtwitz, Theodore A. Lightner, B. Jay Becker, Charles Lochridge and Edward Hymes Jr. after thirtysix boards had been played last night at the Hotel Ambassador.

In a second attempt by Commander I. Schlossbach to make a survey flight over Ellesmere Island, Canada, John Johnson tonight suffered a fractured arm when he slipped while trying to turn the propeller.

MANHATTAN BAUMANN, CLIFTON KINSLEY (Oct. 16, 1936). Gross assets, $61,010; net, $55,118. To Emily G. K. Baumann, mother. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $44,872. Milbank, Tweed Hope, attorneys, 15 Broad St.
A total of eleven properties in scattered sections of Manhattan changed hands yesterday at auction sales held in the Vesey Street salesrooms.
Henry Ford left today for the widely heralded business conference tomorrow in Washington with President Roosevelt. Before boarding his special railroad car, Mr. Ford genially told questioners:

The Most Rev. Thomas J. Walsh will be installed as Archbishop of the newly created Archdiocese of Newark and Metropolitan of New Jersey here tomorrow in a ceremony to be witnessed by one of the greatest gatherings of the Catholic hierarchy in this country since the Eucharistic Congress.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, will head the educational institutions division in the $10,000,000 campaign of the Greater New York Fund, according to an announcement yesterday by J. A. Brown, chairman of the fund's committee of employes.

Manhattan 140th St. s w cor of Lenox Ave, 25x16.2; for 1-story comfort station; Department of Parks, City of New York, owner; Aymar Embury 2d, architect; cost, $4,000. Alterations Pike St. 26; to 5-story tenement and stores; 26 Holding Corp, 1,775 Broadway, owner; G. G. Miller, architect; cost, $15,000.

President Roosevelt's version of the first year and a half of the New Deal is given in a further collection of White House press conference notes made public today. These notes, which duplicate in time and to a certain extent in topic the first series published in mid-March, form a sort of primer of objectives as he conceived them then, together with comment by way of his answers to questions at the press conferences.

Criticizing what she said were recent pronouncements by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt on divorce and on the motion picture "Birth of a Baby," Mrs. Charles Feehan, president of the League of Catholic Women, today said:

A few days ago a Washington dispatch to THE TIMES reported that President Roosevelt had issued an Executive order opening for committee inspection the tax returns of all persons summoned before the Senate Lobby Committee. This is the committee over which Senator Black presided before his appointment to the Supreme Court.

A number of small residential parcels figured in the Bronx realty deals announced yesterday. A client of Smith Stanley sold, through Ernest T. Bower as broker, the three-story private house at 1,010 Faile Street, adjoining the corner of Aldus Street, to Aaron Weiss.
The Temple University tennis team conquered Fordham University, 5-4, on the Maroon's courts yesterday. In the outstanding singles match, Jeff Hogan, Fordham captain, subdued Henry Yaskin, s 6-3, 6-3.
H. W. Warley, vice president of the Calmar Steamship Company, was re-elected president of the Maritime Association at the annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Maritime Exchange Building,
The engagement of Miss Florence Perlow, daughter of Mrs. Esther Perlow of 55.Central Park West, to Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag of this city was announced yesterday by her mother.

James G. Stahlman, publisher of The Nashville (Tenn.) Banner and resident of the American Newspaper PublishersAssociation, opened the fifty-second annual convention of the association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday by callng on the smaller newspapers to join in the fight to preserve freedom of the press.

Collecting six of its seven hits to score four-runs in the upper half of the eighth, the St. John's Prep nine downed St. Francis Prep, 5--1, in a Brooklyn C. H. S. A. A. contest at the Prospect Park Parade Grounds yesterday.

Today was budget day and its influences restricted business on the stock market here, but the tendency of most sections was cheerful. Gilt-edge issues were steady, and among the foreign bonds German loans advanced. Transatlantic securities were in some demand and International Nickel went ahead.

The hockey rivalry between West Point and the Royal Military. College in Canada will provide the background for Robert Taylor's next film, to follow "Give and Take," which goes before the cameras tomorrow.

A mortgage for $2,000,000 on the Broadway Claridge Hotel, southeast corner of Broadway and 44th St, held by the Chase National Bank, as trustee, from Broadway and Forty-Fourth, Inc, Florence C. Anderson, president, leasehold and fee owner, has been extended to Nov. 1, 1944, at 3 to 4 per cent, the- principal to be reduced annually in instalments increasing, from $10,000 in 1938, to 40,000 in 1943, and $30,000 in 1944.

John Klein of 627 West End Avenue, a retired newspaper man who was a correspondent for The New York Herald in the Boer War, died yesterday in the Misericordia Hospital. Born in Liverpool, England, he came to the United States as a youth and joined The World as a reporter.

The subjoined tale shows the amount of income tax and surtax, if any, payable on earned incomes under the new schedule announced today. In each case the applicable personal and marriage allowances and the allowances for children and earned income have been deducted. The figures, in dollars, are calculated at $5 to [Pound]1. ADESSA-Marguerite Nancy, beloved wife of Henry P., devoted mother of Theresa Funeral Wednesday, April 27, 10 A. M.. from residence, 33-17 82d St., Jackson Heights N. Y. Service 11 o'clock, St Joan of Arc Church. AHRENS-Carrie (nee Regensburg), on April 25, wife of the late Max J. Ahrens, devoted mother of Jerome M. Ahrens. Services at the Universal Chapel, 597 Lexington Ave., on Wednesday, April 27, at 10 A. M.
Steel ingot output declined last week against a rising seasonal factor, and the adjusted index dropped to 42.2 from 44.3. This compares with 120.3 for the week ended April 24, 1937.

Mrs. Eleanor Cuyler Walker of 164 East Seventy-second Street, daughter of Mrs. Thomas De Witt Cuyler of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Mr. Cuyler, was married here yesterday afternoon in St. James Lutheran Church to Robert StrauszHupe of this city.
Clarence M. Britten, president of Britten-Fenton Company, has been appointed State group chairman of the butter, egg and cheese industry for the American Federation of Little Business, Inc.

Edward Blood Sr., retired Philadelphia manufacturer, died Sunday at his home in Ventnor, near here. His age was 84. Since moving to the shore eighteen years ago, Mr. Blood had been vice president of a local battery and electrical company and chairman of the Chelsea

Robert McLean, president of The Philadelphia Bulletin, was elected president of The Associated Press yesterday to succeed Frank B. Noyes, president of The Washington Star, who retired on Monday after thirty-eight years in the office.

On the eve of President Roosevelt's conference with Henry Ford, sixteen men representing billions in industrial investment and employing power throughout the country, filed with the White House today a pledge of their fullest cooperation with the government in bringing about recovery.

Methods used by some Westchester County organizations in soliciting funds for "charity," with little of the proceeds actually going for that purpose, were condemned today in a presentment handed up to Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich by the March Grand Jury. Remedial legislation was recommended.

The opening yesterday by SaksFifth Avenue of a new $500,000 store in Beverly Hills, Calif., according to a statement by Adam Gimbel, president of the store, signifies the company's "complete confidence in future business" and its belief in "the rapid development of the Southwest as a shopping center."

Plans have been completed by Miss Joan P. Lusk, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. William B. Lusk of Ridgefield, Conn., for her marriage of Charles Henry Tenney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Gleason Tenney of 630 Park Avenue, which will take place May 14 in St. Stephen's Church, Ridgefield. The ceremony will be performed by the prospective bride's father, rector of the church.

Governor Moore received word today from United States Senator John Milton that President Roosevelt had approved an appropriation of $50,000 for the construction of a therapeutic pool in the A. Harry Moore School for Cripple Children in Jersey City which will surpass the pool at Warm Springs, Ga., in modern design and usefulness.

The humanitarian technique used by the Girls Service League of America should be applied in adjusting international relations, Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick declared last night at a dinner commemorating the thirtieth anniversary of the organization at the Plaza.

Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., State Health Commissioner, said today that the new sanitary code regulation prohibiting importation, breeding or sale of birds of the psittacine or parrot family would become effective June 1.

Leopold Geiger, composer of symphonies and an operetta and long a teacher of violin, died on Monday at his home, 27 Lawrence Street, Yonkers, after a brief illness. His age was 86. Born in Czechoslovakia, he attended the Prague Conservatory of Music and came here as a violin teacher in 1888.

Jackie Coogan's mother, Mrs. Arthur Bernstein, today surrendered to the receiver in her son's $4,000,000 accounting suit, a 17-carat diamond set in a platinum ring, purchased by Jackie's father, the late John R. Coogan, for $25,000, and presented to her.

Grote St. 790, 3-story dwelling, 68.10x 114.1; East River Savings Bank against Patsy Polvere; due, $20,975; to plaintiff for $6,000. By DANIEL GREENWALD Jerome Ave, 1,868, 3-story tenement, 18.7x 98.3 irreg; East River Savings Bank against George D. Ebermayer; due, $12,317; to plaintiff for $5,000.

Elden Auker, the submarine right-hander, pitched the Tigers to a 7-1 victory over the Browns today. It was his second triumph of the season. The battle was hot until the Detroit half of the fifth, when a brief display of temper by Pitcher Oral Hildebrand trimmed the Browns'

Herbert Hoover appealed to politically minded women tonight for a fight against what he termed "a moral recession" in American government. Loss of morals in selfgovernment paved the way for the rise of European dictatorships, said the former President.

The victory of Kho Sin Kie of China over H. G. N. Lee of England, finalist a year ago, was the only real upset today in the British hard courts tennis championships. He scored, 6-1, 6-4, 6-1. Bunny Austin reached the quarter-finals with a 6-4, 4-6, 6-0, 6-3 triumph over F. J. Piercy.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher-in-training in day secondary schools, other than junior high schools, in the subjects indicated, be issued, as of the dates indicated, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore.

Herman Philips's Scrooge and W. F. Morgan's The Fighter took the two divisions of the Syosset Handicap that featured yesterday's racing at Jamaica, where an unusually large week-day crowd watched the six events.

This week witnessed an impressive ceremony when 600 newly trained sergeants just graduated from the military academy here took the oath of loyalty to Generalissimo Francisco Franco's scarlet and gold flag.

To beat or not to beat the Bees may have been a burning question when today's proceedings started, but all the fire was taken out of the query by Jim Turner and the rest of Casey Stengel's men, who set back the Grimes crew rather easily by a 4-1 score.

In a unanimous decision the three justices of the Bronx Court of Special Sessions ruled yesterday that pictures in the April 11 issue of the magazine Life depicting the birth of a baby were not indecent and acquitted Roy E. Larsen, publisher of the weekly.

The Vienna edition of the Voelkischer Beobachter publishes an article today declaring that Jews must be eradicated from this city by 1942. The Berlin edition of the Voelkischer Beobachter is Chancellor Adolf Hitler's organ.

Ambrose Goulet Grandpre, engineer and builder of Loop skyscrapers and theatres, died on Sunday in his home here at the age of 53. Mr. Grandpre was a member of an old French family which settled more than 100 years ago at Bourbonnais, near Kankakee.

Mayor F. H. La Guardia of New York made an appeal today before the West Texas Chamber of Commerce for closer cooperation of labor, business and government to work out a permanent solution to the business recession.

After passing most of more than thirty suggested rules of fair practice for the automobile industry at a conference before Charles H. March, member of the Federal Trade Commission, about 800 members of the National Automobile Dealers Association, at the first session of their annual convention today, applauded a speech by Representative Withrow of Wisconsin, taking their part in relations with the manufacturers.

Convinced "it is not practicable to utilize department stores as an agency of consumer cooperative action in this country at the present time," Flint Garrison' has resigned as executive vice president of the Consumer Distribution Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

The alternative Konrad Henlein offers the Government at Prague is autonomy for the Sudeten Germans, with whom he imperially associates all the national minorities, or autonomy for the Czechoslovak State. There cannot be independence for both if the claims he puts forward are accepted.

Generalissimo Francisco Franco today ordered the fleets of planes concentrated at his Majorca base to support General Miguel Aranda's army, which has encountered stubborn government resistance in the Albocacer-Alcala de Chivert coastal sector.

And now it is the British public that is being asked to tighten its belt. The reason is at bottom the same as that in the authoritarian countries-the world armament race which those countries have initiated. The Government's expenditures in the coming fiscal year will go above a billion pounds for the first time since 1922.

Theodore C. Hovey, assistant vice president of the New York Trust Company since 1921, died of a heart attack this morning in his home here. He was 60 years old. Born in Troy, Pa., he went to work as a clerk for the Liberty National Bank of New York forty years ago, and remained with it until its merger in 1921 with the New York Trust Company.
The Atlantic Monthly Press announces its fifth $5,000 non-fiction contest, with May 1, 1939, set as the closing date. The winners of the four previous non-fiction contests were: In 1929,

Regional officials of the Home Owners Loan Corporation disclosed ,yesterday that they have been investigating the high cost of foreclosure fees collected from government funds by referees appointed by State Supreme Court justices.

Leo A. Lanigan of Chicago was elected yesterday a director of McKesson Robbins at the annual meeting to succeed Merrill P. Northington, deceased. Edward A. Crone and Sheldon M. Ward have joined Lord Widli, who have opened a municipal bond department.

In the annual elections today in Port Chester, the largest incorporated village in the State, the Democratic party elected its Mayoralty candidate and a trustee, to gain control of the village board for the first time since 1935.

The annual card party and garden bazaar for the benefit of Savea-Life Farm in Nyack, N. Y.; will take place the afternoon of May 3 at Sherry's. Miss Frances Coleman heads the committee in charge of the arrangements, and associated with her are Mrs. Albert

Trading was mostly fair. The beef market was about steady, veal mostly unchanged, lamb strong to higher, fresh pork cuts somewhat uneven. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef and veal to be about steady and lamb higher. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

The markets continued dull and lower yesterday. Stocks drifted downward after a firm start and the leading issues closed with losses of from fractions to about 3 points. Transactions on the Stock Exchange totaled 444,000 shares, compared with Monday's turnover of 395,000. Bonds finished irregularly lower in comparatively light trading.

Frederick P. Kapper, secretary to the Kings County Commissioner of Jurors and son of former Justice Isaac M. Kapper, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 1,729 Caton Avenue. Brooklyn. He was 47 years old.

Dressed in brand new, natty gray uniforms made especially for the occasion, movie camera men and news photographers selected by the Nazi Propaganda Minister left for Italy today as the advance guard of Germans attending the Hitler - Mussolini conversations next week.

Net resources on March 31 of Incorporated Investors, based on market quotations of investment securities, amounted to $41,695,408, equal to $14.01 each on 2,976,708 shares of capital stock, according to the quarterly report published yesterday.

An exhibition of home-run meeting came late yesterday to relieve the monotony of a three-hour skirmish in which the Giants stretched their winning streak to five straight by downing the Phillies. The count was 12 to 8.

The names of 112 retailers who were reported as having made "unjust returns" were read before a joint conference yesterday afternoon between the grievance committee of the National Association. of Blouse Manufacturers and the Blouse Industry Stabilization Board in the association's offices.

Chile's frozen credits with different countries will continue to be reduced as far as possible in the early future, and the aim will be to clean. the slate before the yearend, the government announced today.

BALDWIN, LYDIA P. (April 1). Estate, more than $10,000. To William M. Baldwin, husband, 40 E. 88th St., life estate in two-fifths residue; Dorothy B. Buel, daughter, 10 E. 85th St., $2,500, threetwenty-fifths residue and remainder in two-twenty-fifths residue; John C. Baldwin, son, Maguabo, Puerto Rico, life estate in three-twenty-fifths residue and succeeding estate in two-twenty-fifths residue; Ruth Baldwin Alexander,

William H. Purdy, who won amateur championships as a walker nearly sixty years ago and as late as last September put on an exhibition running sprint, died on Monday in his home, 189 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, after a six months' illness. His age was 79.

The LegisLature adjourned today for the week without the Senate acting on the princeton local government survey ills passed by the Assembly for tate control of municipal spending r the Assembly considering the esolution for a constitutional amendment to permit pari-mutuel getting at race tracks.

The markets continued dull and lower yesterday. Stocks drifted downward after a firm start and the leading issues closed with losses of from fractions to about 3 points. Transactions on the Stock Exchange totaled 444,000 shares, compared with Monday's turnover of 395,000. Bonds finished irregularly lower in comparatively light trading.

Frederick P. Kapper, secretary to the Kings County Commissioner of Jurors and son of former Justice Isaac M. Kapper, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 1,729 Caton Avenue. Brooklyn. He was 47 years old.

Dressed in brand new, natty gray uniforms made especially for the occasion, movie camera men and news photographers selected by the Nazi Propaganda Minister left for Italy today as the advance guard of Germans attending the Hitler - Mussolini conversations next week.

Net resources on March 31 of Incorporated Investors, based on market quotations of investment securities, amounted to $41,695,408, equal to $14.01 each on 2,976,708 shares of capital stock, according to the quarterly report published yesterday.

An exhibition of home-run meeting came late yesterday to relieve the monotony of a three-hour skirmish in which the Giants stretched their winning streak to five straight by downing the Phillies. The count was 12 to 8.

The names of 112 retailers who were reported as having made "unjust returns" were read before a joint conference yesterday afternoon between the grievance committee of the National Association. of Blouse Manufacturers and the Blouse Industry Stabilization Board in the association's offices.

A temporary injunction restraining Joseph D.
