McGoldrick, Controller, and the Board of Water Supply from awarding $32,000,000 worth of contracts for construction work in connection with the city's Delaware water supply project was granted yesterday by Justice Mitchell May in Brooklyn Supreme Court on the ground that the wage schedules involved were exorbitant and would defraud the city's taxpayers of about $5,000,000.
The Atlantic Monthly Press announces its fifth $5,000 non-fiction contest, with May 1, 1939, set as the closing date. The winners of the four previous non-fiction contests were: In 1929,

Your laughter glancing in the air today, Weaves me in meshes of substantial gold, And yet I am afraid and look away Seeing this moment's life gone suddenly cold: This solid-pillared place, for all its. strength, Heaving up skeleton rafters at the sky, And fallen pillars measuring their length Among dry grasses: and no feet go by.
William Miller's six-meter yacht Viking today captured the King Edward VII Gold Cup, defeating Raymond Hunt's American craft, Indian Scout, for the second time in a row.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The President demands retention of the capital gains tax and undistributed profits tax. He gave no indication of his attitude while Congress was debating and forming the new Tax Bill, but waited until it was up before the conference committee to bring his pressure to bear.

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS-To take effect 4 P. M., April 25: Patrick Sullivan, from 6th Precinct to 15th Division, assignment changed. from desk duty to supervisor of plain clothes patrolmen.

Mike Belloise, 127 1/4, the Bronx, outpointed Pete Scalzo, 126 3/4, West Side, in the main bout of eight rounds at the boxing show at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 13,582 saw Scalzo lose his first bout in thirty-eight starts since turning professional.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation declared yesterday for the first quarter of 1938 the full preferred dividend of $1.75 a share, payable on May 20. The deficit before dividends was $1,292,151, hence the disbursement of $6,304,919 voted will leave a deficit of $7,597,070 charged to earned surplus, which was $280,356,144 on Jan. 1.

An agreement that is expected to permit the tearing down of the entire Sixth Avenue elevated line within a few months has been reached between the city and the controlling financial interests of the elevated lines after nearly twenty years of intermittent negotiations, it was announced at Mayor La Guardia's office in City Hall yesterday.

A pinch home run by Al Smith in the ninth inning with Frank Reiber aboard, gave the Toronto Leafs a 6-to-5 victory over the Newark Bears today. It was the first triumph of the year for the Canadians and Newark's initial reverse in five starts. Smith's blow came off Xavier Rescigno, Smith Falls rookie, who relieved Hiram Bithorn in the seventh.

After a long debate last night, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York approved six, defeated one and deferred action on five of the proposals recently advanced by its special committee on plan and personnel of the State Constitutional Convention.

A distinguished audience is expected to gather at Carnegie Hall this evening for the benefit concert for Austrian refugees which will be given by Jascha Heifetz, violinist, and the National Broadcasting Company Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Artur Rodzinski.

Harold Kohon, young New York violinist, a recent student of Georges Enesco in Paris and of Mishel Piastro under a Philharmonic-Symphony scholarship, gave his first local recital last night at Town Hall. The lad had his courage with him, for he played a program that would have given pause to one three times his years.

Special reductions. on railroad fares and on gasoline charges for the benefit of foreign tourists in France this season have been approved by the new French Cabinet, it was announced yesterday by Henry d'Ornano, director of the French Government Tourist Bureau at 610 Fifth Avenue.
Miss Mollie Swid, a lawyer and organizer and former president of the Jersey City Business and Professional Women's Club, died of pneumonia last night at her home here. Her age was 35.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended April 21 declined in three out of five trade groups compared with -the corresponding week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Dr. Paul D. Bartlett, 30-year-old assistant professor on the staff of Harvard University, will receive this year's $1,000 prize in pure chemistry awarded by the American Chemical Society. The prize will be presented at the ninetysixth meeting of the society in Milwaukee next September.

William Gay Spalding, former Vice Consul in Aix-la-Chapelle, and later a leading Democrat here, died yesterday in the Lockport Hospital of a hip fracture suffered in a fall recently. He was 68 years old. Mr. Spalding devoted twenty-eight years to public service.

Japanese fighting southward toward the vital railroad junction at Suchow broke through Chinese lines today at Hsiaowang, a village southeast of Yihsien, but the Chinese swiftly counter-attacked and temporarily plugged the hole.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Mrs. Jane Benson Smith Weadock of this city, daughter of the late Edward Smith, to Edwin Clay Merrell, United States Vice Consul at Hamilton, Bermuda, which took place on Thursday in the Fort Meyer (Va.) Chapel. Chaplain Ora J. Cohee performed the ceremony.

Funeral services for Mgr. William Quinn, former national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, were held here today in St. Gabriel's Church. Five hundred friends, including many clergymen, were present. Monsignor Quinn, a resident here, died last Saturday in the White Plains Hospital.

The improved financial condition of the Cunard White Star Line was reflected in an announcement today that it had decided not to accept the [Pound]250,000 loan it arranged with the government last year with which to make the final payment on construction of the Queen Mary and to start construction of her sister ship, the Queen Elizabeth.

An investing client of Henry Shapiro Co. has purchased from the Milsin Development Corporation, for cash above a first mortgage of $28,000 held by the East River Savings Bank, the one-story taxpayer on the northwest corner of 159th Street and Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.

Rollie Stiles, veteran righthander, turned in a six-hit pitching performance at Roosevelt Stadium today and Jersey City's Little Giants, as a result, salvaged the. final game of their three-game series with Buffalo, 2 to 1.

Wheat prices declined 1 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel early in the trading today, with the May selling at a new low level for the season and since 1934. Liquidation by holders of May contracts on the Board of Trade here and at Winnipeg, combined with rains on both sides of the line in the Northwest, furnished the bearish incentive early. Prices here,

Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club yesterday announced the prices and other details- for the heavyweight championship fight in which Joe Louis will defend his title against Max Schmeling at the Yankee Stadium on June 22.
Manager Oscar Vitt of the league-leading Indians sighed with relief today as Rollie Hemsley rejoined the Cleveland club with another promise to behave.

Housewives in search of new recipes, gardeners looking for latest horticulture hints and school children on the trail of "pretty pictures" to paste in school "project" notebooks were some of the reasons the Brooklyn Public Library frantically appealed yesterday to its readers to "be merciful" to the library's books.

Robert McLean, yesterday chosen president of The Associated Press, is, like his predecessor, Frank Noyes, a newspaper man by inheritance. William McLean, his father, was for thirty-six years president of The Evening Bulletin of Philadelphia, a journal now well on toward its hundredth year.

About 2,000 women staged a nearriot last night in Arcadia Hall, Halsey Street near Broadway, Brooklyn, in a stampede to get their 25-cent admission fee back after a squad of police had raided a bingo party being held in the hall for the benefit of the James A. McKenna Post, Veterans of Foreigu Wars, which has a clubhouse on Broadway near Marion Street.

The answering of questionnaires, the preparation of detailed reports and the submission of voluminous data of all kinds to Federal and State authorities are costing the Texas Corporation about $500,000 annually, T. Rieber, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.

Dr. and -Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer have returned from Palm Beach to 563 Park Avenue. Mrs. William T. Hildrup Jr. of the St. Regis will leave tomorrow to pass several weeks in Washington. Mr. and Mrs. P. Schuyler Church of Dayton, Ohio, are at the RitzCarlton.

Eric S. Paternoster, 42-year-old master mechanic in charge of operating and maintenance of the central power plant and distribution system at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, received class honors in industrial electricity last night at commencement exercises of the evening division of Pratt Institute, Brooklyn.

The official line-up for the World's Fair preview motorcade on Saturday, and the judges who will present trophies for best window displays in connection with the preview, were announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.
Dr. Charles Van Ronk, Philadelphia osteopath, said today Van Lingle Mungo, Brooklyn's ace righthanded pitcher, would be able to take his regular turn on the mound Thursday.

Jo. C. Guild Jr., president of the Tennessee Electric Power Company, in his 1937 annual report to shareholders, issued yesterday, hoped a satisfactory conclusion can be reached in the negotiations between the Tennessee Valley Authority and the private utility in the projected purchase of the utility's properties by the Federal

An echo of the contentions which have marked the division between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization was heard today in the Assembly chamber, where the Constitutional Convention held its second sitting for the week, when labor's proposed new "Bill of Rights" was submitted to the convention in fifteen- proposals sponsored by John J. Dunnigan, temporary President of the State Senate.
The deposition of the gypsy king, Janusz Kwiek, who was elected last Summer to be a democratic, law-abiding ruler, was voted today by the council of elders of the gypsy nation in Poland.
President Roosevelt discussed the railroad problem with Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC, and wages and hours legislation with Representative O'Connor, chairman of the House Rules Committee.

Two hospitals here, Holy Spirit and Sebastian Hospitals, have adopted regulations excluding Jews from treatment. Wiesbaden and Badschandau have been added to the list of German medicinal spas from which Jews are excluded. Steps have also been taken to drive Jews from the wine trade.

The Pirates bowed today for the first time in the young National League season, but it took the hard-hitting Cubs ten innings to earn their 5-to-3 triumph. The Cubs crammed two triples and a-single into the extra chapter to account for two runs

After a general indictment of recent Supreme Court tactics as "a subtle and growing menace to American democracy," Robert F. Cushman, Professor of Government at Cornell University, proceeded in an address before the convention of the National League of Women Voters this afternoon to specific identification of those members of the tribunal whom he considered adequate in tolerance.
The sale of part 2 of the library of the late Cortlandt F. Bishop was completed last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., bringing a total of $209,287.50.

D. B. Robertson, president of the Brotherhood of Firemen and Enginemen, issued today a statement in which he said that the Interstate Commerce Commission had "saddled on the public more than $3,000,000,000 of bonds" of railroads which now are in default and suggested that a Presidential board investigate the commission to determine why this had been done.

Several differences of opinion still exist among members of the bars newspaper publishers and newspaper editors as to what restrictions should be placed upon publicity of court proceedings, the committee representing the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday to the publishers' annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Blue Ridge Corporation--As of March 31: Net assets of $21,752,970 after deducting all bank loans, is equal to $53.06 a share of preference stock outstanding. On Dec. 31, 1937, net assets were $28,652,267, or $69.47 a share of preference stock and 78 cents a share of common stock outstanding.

Percy Avery Rockefeller, industrialist, who died a resident of Greenwich, Conn., left a New York estate of $476,881, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday by his son, Avery Rockefeller of 52 Wall Street, ancillary executor of his estate.

The Philharmonic-Symphony will give the last Thursday evening concert of the present season tonight at Carnegie Hall, presenting a Beethoven-Wagner program. Marjorie Lawrence and Charles Kullmann, both of the Metropolitan Opera Association, will be soloists.
Soviet Russia tonight announced a deadlock in efforts to compose troubled relations with Japan in the Far East.

William F. Bleakley, Republican Gubernatorial candidate in 1936, advocated in a speech tonight before the county Republican organization the nomination of a straight party slate in the coming Fall elections, and opposed fusion with any other political group.

Lawrenceville's baseball team overpowered Peddle, 13 to 1, today. Led by Pitcher Doug Bournique, who allowed three hits and collected as many for his team, the Laurentians knocked out twelve safeties.

Harold B. Butler, British director of the International Labor Office, will announce his resignation tomorrow to the governing body at the opening of its Spring session. John G. Winant, American assistant director, is being prominently mentioned to succeed him.

Regulations for the establishment and operation of common trust funds under a law enacted by the Legislature last Summer were issued yesterday by the State Banking Board through its chairman, William R. White, Superintendent of Banks. The regulations, Mr.

Scoring four runs in the first inning, the City College of New York defeated Upsala at Viking Field today, 6-4. The visitors used four passes by Schade and two hits to net their quartet of runs in the opening session.
Word was received here today of the death of Mrs. Julia L. Vigoroux at her home in St. Petersburg, Fla., aged 78. She was the widow of Emile V. Vigoroux, a retired importer of linens.

Michael Selwyn, stage manager for the late Oscar Hammerstein and for many years associated with his half-brothers, Edgar and Arch Selwyn, in theatrical productions, died here last night at the Mayers convalescents home, 614 Webster Avenue.

Gross operating revenues of the Duquesne Light Company for twelve months to Feb. 28 amounted to $30,596,856, compared with $28,340,137 for the year ended. Feb. 28, 1937, the company, a unit in the Standard Gas and Electric Company system, reported yesterday.
M. V. Atwood, associate editor of the Gannett newspapers, urged today that readers insist on freedom of the press "even in the face of abuses of freedom, at times, by a small sector of the press."

Senator Wheeler plans to introduce next week, probably on Monday, a bill which would establish a "railroad reorganization court" to take over allay roads now in bankruptcy and formulate reorganization plans for them.

" Frozen magnets" brought up from the bottom of the sea which can be used to determine the shift of the earth's magnetic pole during several thousand years were described at the annual meeting of the American Geophysical Union by Drs. A. G. McNish and E. A. Johnson of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

Dissatisfaction over yesterday's budget was so widespread today that the Conservative party headquarters asked Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain to take steps to prevent the loss of the Parliamentary seat for Lichfield, Staffordshire, in a by-election to be held there May 5.
MANHATTAN HAY, ALBERT V. (Jan. 22, 1938). Gross assets, $15,186; net, $12,944. To Anna C. Hay, mother. Chief assets, real estate, $8,590. Richard Steel, attorney, 61 Broadway.

Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General in New York, was the guest of honor at the thirty-seventh annual luncheon of the Graham Alumnae Association of this city, which was held yesterday at the Pierre.

The Indians suffered their first defeat today since opening day as the White Sox fell on Mel Harder for four runs after two were out in the seventh inning and won, 6 to 3. The Indians had annexed six straight games.

G. G. Gale, president of the Gatineau Power' Company, told shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Montreal that primary power deliveries this year p, should be increased by 56,000 horsepower, and that the company expected an increase in 1939 of 66,000 horsepower.

A dinner was given by Mrs. Charles L. Riker last night at the American Museum of Natural History. The occasion was another of the "natural science evenings" being observed at the museum, in the interests of the institution's tenyear development program.

MANHATTAN ABERT, ISAAC (March 22). Estate, more than $20,000. To Minnie Abert, widow, executrix, 230 Riverside Dr., household effects, one-half residue outright and onehalf residue in trust; Theresa Abert, daughter, same address, remainder in onehalf residue.

A decidedly firmer undertone ruled in the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange despite a further curtailment in trading activity to the second smallest turnover of the month. Sales amounted to only $4,478,600, compared with $5,004,775 on Tuesday.

The Royal Bermuda Yacht Club team defeated the United States group today in the second race of the Cubitt trophy series, 19 to 17 1/4, and with the final contest scheduled for tomorrow, trails by only one and a half points. The Americans captured the first race on Tuesday, 19 1/4 to 16.
The BancOhio Securities Company of Columbus and associates submitted the successful bid yesterday for $2,776,000 of bonds of the Muskingum Watershed District, Ohio.

Charles B. Wrightsman, who will lead a team in quest of the British open polo title in June, sailed yesterday for England on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. Wrightsman's four, which will be known as the Texas Rangers, includes himself as No. 1; Cecil Smith, No. 2; Aidan Roark, No. 3, and Eric Tyrrell-Martin, back.
More than 1,000,000 bushels of corn were cleared from Chicago yesterday for Canadian ports, and it was reported that boats were loading a like amount today.

May will be the big publication month of the Spring season for Harper. On May 11 the firm will publish "Flames Coming Out of the Top," by Norman Collins. The publishers think so' well of the book that they have sealed the last third of it and are offering to return the price of the book to any reader who is not interested enough to break the seal when he comes to it.

The Japanese Army has launched a vigorous campaign in Northwestern China within 100 miles of Outer Mongolia, which is under protection of the Soviet Union, and neutral authorities here believe the drive may endanger the land routes by which considerable Russian war supplies have reached the Chinese armies.

Joseph A. 'Padway, general counsel of the American Federation of Labor, accused the National Labor Relations Board of "bias and prejudice" today in testimony before the House Judiciary subcommittee at a hearing on the pending Wagner-Healey bill.

Mayor La Guardia works hard, often too hard. He recuperates by playing hard. His rest is largely motion. Again he has had the time of his life. He has made himself at home in tumultuous and sympathetic Oklahoma.

A concert, brilliantly successful, was given last night in Carnegie Hall for the benefit of Austrian refugees. The NBC Symphony Orchestra, Jaseha Heifetz, as soloist, and Artur Rodzinski, conducting, were the performers.

The steel business now is 10 to 25 per cent smaller than it was a month ago, although ingot production for the industry as a whole remains at last week's average of 32 per cent of capacity, Iron Age reports in its weekly summary.

Jack I. Straus and Edwin I. Marks, vice presidents of I. H. Macy Co.. Inc.. have relinquished their directorships 'in La Salle Koch of Toledo and the Davison Paxon Company of Atlanta, as well their supervisory activities of these stores from New York, It was announced yesterday.

Executives of three big advertising agencies, invited to speak at the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association for the first time in its history, told the publishers yesterday how they thought the agencies and newspapers might cooperate in strengthening the position of newspapers as a national advertising medium.

Two Rockland County housewives, who have been worrying about rising living costs and the future of their children, were deluged today with inquiries over a "Women's Rebellion," which they started, as individuals, against government spending.

After an incredibly long time in the doldrums, the world champion Yankees finally succeeded in drawing abreast of the .500 mark for the first time this season today and, as Marse Joe McCarthy hustled back to New York tonight, he felt more convinced than ever that might, coupled with a good righthander, must invariably triumph.

The defending singles champions, Senorita Anita Lizana of Chile and Henry Wilfred (Bunny) Austin of England, led a parade of favorites into, the quarter-final round of the British hard-court tennis championships today.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, indorsed in an address before the National Automobile Dealers Association's convention today many of the principles of relationships within the industry advocated during the sessions.

Miss Christina Aitchison MacDougall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James MacDougall of Canoe Brook Farm, this place, was married here this evening in her home to Murdoch MacLeod of Skye, Scotland, and Arlington, N. J., in a Scottish ceremony. The Rev. D. A. DeBeer, pastor of the Christian Reformed Church, Passaic, officiated.
The new yellow ball with the red seams made its debut at Baker Field yesterday and for eight innings Columbia wondered whether its greater visibility had not been slightly exaggerated.

Grenville Clark, a member of the law firm of Root, Clark, Buckner Ballantine, told the members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that they must insist on free speech not only in the press, but also in the radio, movies and all other forms of expression and must fight all abuses of governmental power to the limit.

The Delaware Hudson Company's $11,000,000 investment in the New York Central, last of the financial' coups scored by L. F. Loree who retired from the presidency of the D. H. on March 31, is due for liquidation, it was disclosed yesterday. The holdings gave the D.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today, Morris M. Miller and Harold Stern of New York were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 782-Fred G. Zerbst, Warden, etc., petr., v. Sherman Kidwell.

Duplicating last year's score, Yale and Long Island University today played a 3-3 Rugby draw. Walter Cohen made a brilliant try for the visitors midway in the first period and George Hasketh, who starred for Yale throughout, tied the count in the closing minutes on a penalty kick.

Governor Philip La Follette indicated in an interview at the Executive Mansion tonight that he would lay before the nation a comprehensive plan for solving its economic problems at a mass meeting here tomorrow night.
Formation of a $5,000,000 investment trust to be known as Delaware Fund, Inc., was announced yesterday by William Stix Wasserman, president of the Investment Corporation of Philadelphia.

With their run-making matching the alleged unlucky number that Manager Burleigh Grimes wears on his back, the Dodgers today snapped their losing streak and buried the Bees beneath a 13-2 score for an even break in the abbreviated series.

Continuing its policy of reducing funded debt, the Great Northern Railway Company will pay with its own funds $3,625,000 of Willmar Sioux Falls Railway first 5 per cent bonds when they mature on June 1, W. P. Kenney, president, said in his report for 1937, issued yesterday.

The executive committee of the Greater New York Fund announced yesterday that 279 private welfare and health agencies had been admitted to participation in the fund, which will open on Monday an appeal to business establishments and their employes for $10,000,000 to supplement the finances of the private social agencies.

The deficit whereby Richard Whitney Co. will fail to meet their obligations to those who dealt with the firm was established today by accountants for the Securities and Exchange Commission at $2,655,000.

Representatives Tabe of New York and Michener of Michigan assailed today the insertion in the Congresionasl Record of the anonymous letter to the President accusing a big Detroit corporation of planning a. propaganda drive against the Roosevelt pump- priming recovery program.

Bernard Baruch recently pointed out before a Senate committee that though in New York State the income tax rises as high as 85 1/2 per cent, the highest it goes in Great Britain is 66 1/4 per cent. Yet there are good grounds for thinking that even the British rate is too high for satisfactory results.

Miss Eleanor Ryan, daughter or Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Ryan of Lawrence Park, was married this afternoon to Norman R. MacEvilla Prouty, son of Mr. and'Mrs. Carll R. Prouty, also of Bronxville, at the home of her parents.

Although the Anglo-Irish agreement will make Ireland responsible for her own protection, British experts and British war material are expected to play an important part in building up Dublin's defense forces.

British Admiralty is having built at Dartmouth a non-magnetic 650-ton ship, which is only the second of its kind to be designed for magnetic survey work and which will replace the American vessel Carnegie, destroyed by an explosion off Samoa in 1929 after twenty-five years of service in the study of magnetic variations.

Floyd (Arky) Vaughan, 1935 National League batting champion, unwound his big bat for a home run with the bases loaded in the seventh inning today and brought the Pirates a 6-to-5 triumph over the Cubs.

Home mortgage loans of the direct-reduotion type made by the ninety-two insured savings and loan associations in New York State in the first quarter of this year increased from $75,000,000 to $77,800,000 a gain of $2,800,000, Nugent Fallon, general manager of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, announced today.

Four bids submitted last Monday to the special committee of the Board of Estimate on the foreign trade zone were discussed by the committee yesterday after Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler had submitted an analysis on them.

The plan for the city's purchase of the Sixth Avenue elevated line for $12,500,000, as negotiated by Mayor La Guardia and his transit aides with a committee representing holders of the 4 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Manhattan Railway Company, was denounced as a "crackpot invention" yesterday by Nathan Amster, president of the Manhattan company.

The twenty-five-room apartment in 660 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Sixty-seventh Street, which was designed -originally by John Russell Pope, the architect, for Mrs. Graham Fair Vanderbilt, has been leased by Seton Porter to a client of Mrs. Edward Stout, Inc.
Richard M. Learned, former editor of The Syracuse Post Standard, died today of pneumonia in an Auburn (N. Y.) hospital, where he had undergone an operation. His age was 58.
Andover met its first reversal today when the Brown freshman baseball team won a 7-3 victory. The visitors made two hits more than Andover.

Reaffirming his faith in the organization and its work, Samuel Untermyer, lawyer and philanthroUntermyer announced his resignation yesterday as president and chairman of the board of the NonSectarian Anti-Nazi League to Champion Human Rights, Inc., of which he was a founder.

Members of the Housing Committee of the City Council were warned yesterday that new housing developments must take into consideration the fact that more than one-fourth of the city's population cannot afford to pay more than $30 a month rent.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., May 1: THIRD-GRADE: DETECTIVE-Bernard E. Shandley, from 18th Division, 14th Detective District, to 75th Precinct, designation as third-grade detective revoked.

A third attempt will be made today. by committees representing the steamship operators of Atlantic and Gulf ports and the National Maritime Union to effect an agreement covering the unlicensed personnel of the lines.
Secretary Wallace is planning to store wheat with an eye to an evernormal granary, meaning a stabilized output

Army bombed two New York University pitchers for fifteen hits today and sent the Violets down to their first defeat of the season, 7--4. The cadets turned their big guns on Kashata, the opening New York pitcher, and in the fifth inning shelled him for four hits, two of them triples.

Miss Frances Hall Rousmaniere, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Easton Rousmaniere of 115 East Sixty-fifth Street, was married to Richard Salter Storrs Jr. of this city yesterday afternoon in St. James Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lyman C. Bleecker of St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., who was assisted by the Rev. James Paul of St. James.

Miss Anne Bush MacLear, Professor of History at Hunter College, New York, died yesterday in the Mount Vernon Hospital, after a D three weeks' illness, at the age of 65, She is survived by a sister-inlaw, Mrs. Walter MacLear, with whom she resided at 118 Cottage Avenue, Mount Vernon.

The State Department of Public Works announced today acceptance of a site on Main Street, Babylon, on which the Long Island headquarters of the division of highways will be built. Construction of a $150,000 building will be started soon.
R. G. Casey, Australian Treasurer, introduced a bill today at the opening session of Parliament authorizing the borrowing of up to [Pound]10,300,000 for national defense purposes.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders to-, day, dated April 25: CAPTAIN Van Auken, W. R., orders of Feb. 9 revoked, to continue duty with Naval Examining Board, Navy Dept., Washington, D. C.
A new light opera, "The Sun Dance," by William F. Hanson, Professor of Music at Brigham Young University, received its New York Premiere at the Broadway Theatre last night.

There is one point in the statement addressed to President Roosevelt by a group of business leaders which deserves all the emphasis that can be given to it. "Wide but honest differences of opinion exist as to ways and means," say the signers of this statement, "but surely no one can doubt that the goal which every citizen
A crowd of 3,500 farmers from Central Illinois counties and areas in four adjacent States assembled here tonight and pledged their opposition to government control of their crops.

King Zog and Countess Geraldine Apponyi were married this morning amid great popular rejoicing. Early in the morning thanksgiving services were held in all Albania's churches and mosques. The divine blessing was invoked for the roval couple.
William H. Fallon, independent candidate, apparently was elected Mayor over John J. McDonough in yesterday's municipal election by a margin of 471 votes.
Eugene Olsen entered the select circle of schoolboy pitching aces yesterday when he twirled a no-hit, no-run game as the Rhodes School baseball team downed Drake Prep, 8 to O, at Central Park.
Jim Deren, the fishing panjandrum of Kirtland Brothers, just returned from a few days on the Broadhead, up in Pennsylvania, and says the big trout are taking dry flies with considerable abandon.

The State of New Jersey, through its Joint Legislative Appropriations Committee, declined today to accept as a park site the 800-acre estate of the late Arthur Brisbane at Allaire, in Monmouth County.
Though the center of government is anything but a beauty parlor, it is yet a fact that earmarking and face-saving are two of the chief considerations hereabout just now.

Athletes of the past and of the present, the gray-haired veterans and the sinewy-muscled youngsters of the New York Athletic Club, gathered in the gymnasium at the Winged Foot clubhouse last night for the seventh annual all-sports dinner. There were 1,000 present, something of a record for these affairs.

Grand Rabbi Osheah Rabinowitz, president of the United Grand Rabbis Association of the United States and Canada, generally recognized as the dean of Chassidic rabbis, died early yesterday morning at Mount Sinai Hospital after a month's illness. He was 78.

B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., head of the investment banking group that last month bought a large block of revenue bonds from the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission, reported yesterday that progress was being made in the consummation of plans to finance the turnpike, which is to be a 162-mile highway piercing the mountains between Harrisburg and Pittsburgh.

The paintings by Edwin Dickinson, currently shown at the Passedoit Gallery, will continue on view until May 7. The exhibition of paintings by E. Madeline Shiff and of sculpture by Lilian Swann at the Karl Freund Gallery has also been extended and will be-current until May 11.

After a meeting of the directors of the Lehigh Valley Railroad today it was announced that the New York Stock Exchange would be notified that interest on the company's general consolidated mortgage bonds, due on May 1, would be paid in full.

The list of the Italian motorship Conte di Savoia, due today from Mediterranean ports, includes Mr. and Mrs. Mark Brown, Count Visconte di Modrone, Lorenzo Alvari, Mr. and Mrs. John Meyer, Mr. and Mrs. George Gardner, Colonel Giovanni Ferrando, Kenneth Kean and Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Moreland.

On the ground his client might not get a fair trial in Suffolk County because of "strong Nazi propaganda," Alexander Mayper, attorney for Morris Coopersmith, a Jew, asked today for a change of venue in Coopersmith's trial for grand larceny.

1:15-2:00 P.M.--James G. Stahiman, Publisher Nashville Banner, and Others, at Advertising Club Luncheon--WMCA. 3:00-3:15 P.M.--Town Hall Luncheon, Hotel Astor: David Sarnoff, President RCA; Anne O'Hare McCormick of the Editorial Staff THE NEW YORK TIMES; Dorothy Thompson, Writer--WJZ.

The Cities Service Company having informed the New York Curb Exchange that an amendment to the company's certificate of incorporation had been filed with the Secretary of' the State of Delaware providing for the reduction of common shares outstanding in the ratio of one for ten, the Exchange announced last night that the new issue would be admitted to unlisted trading today at 11 A. M.
Many reservations have been made for the annual luncheon bridge of Auxiliary No. 6 of Stony Wold Sanatorium, which will be held today in the roof garden of the St. Regis.

With only three blocks remaining, Jimmy Caras of Wilmington, Del., defending the world's pocket billiard championship against the challenge of Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, boosted his advantage over his rival to 632-405 as they divided the fourth and fifth blocks yesterday at the Strand Academy.

At 8 o'clock last evening the Society of Independent Artists opened its twenty-second annual exhibition with a preview for the artists and their friends. The show, installed as usual on the fourth floor of Grand Central Palace, opens to the public today and will continue until May 18.

Facts are more important than adjectives in writing good advertising copy, Berenice Fitz-Gibbon, publicity director of the John Wanamaker store, said yesterday in a talk to the retail advertising class conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES at the Times Annex, 229 West Fortythird Street.
Bob Carpenter, 20-year-old Jersey City right-hander, making his first International League start, gave only three hits today to defeat Rochester, 5 to 0, in the opener of a four-game series.

The decline in electric power production last week, which was counter to both seasonal and longterm trends, caused the adjusted Index to drop to 89.7, a new low for the year, and also the lowest since the week ended Nov. 3, 1934.
Mrs. Gretchen Wilson Hearst obtained a divorce today from John Randolph Hearst, son of the publisher. She won the custody of their 4-year-old son, John Randolph Hearst Jr.
Two hours of conversation with President Roosevelt did not change Henry Ford's belief that the nation's present economic ills arise mostly from governmental causes.

Miss Muriel Bowden entertained with a dinner last -evening in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. Her guests included Professor William Lyon Phelps, Professor and Mrs. Harry Morgan Ayres, the Rev. and,Mrs. William Walsh, Professor and Mrs. Stephen Bayne; Mrs. Joseph Kirchoff and M. Edward Dann.
The price of a package of cigarettes will be increased 1 cent as a result of the penny stamp tax for emergency relief which becomes effective Sunday, it was learned yesterday.

Henry Lewis Bullen, one of the foremost authorities on the history of printing and curator emeritus of the Typographic Library and Museum started by the American Type Founders Company in Jersey City, died yesterday in his home, 42-44 Judge Street, Elmhurst, Queens. His age was 80.
Manager Gabby Street shook up the Browns' batting order today, Buck Newsom hurled well despite eight bases on balls and the result was a victory over the Tigers, 7 to 2.

William H. Tammen, for more than forty years Baltimore correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died suddenly at midnight at his home. He was 81 years old. For sixty years Mr. Tammen had been engaged in newspaper work this city, where he Was born.
The Reich Treasury's fiscal year ended March 31. A preliminary official report today showed tax . revenue reached 13,958,000,000 marks. The preceding fiscal year the figure was 11,473,000,000 marks.

In the presence of high dignitaries of the Roman Catholic Church the Apostolic Delegate to the United States placed on the shoulders of Archbishop Thomas J. Walsh in the Sacred Heart Cathedral here today the pallium of woven lamb's wool, ancient symbol of archiepiscopal authority and jurisdiction.

The threatened strike of operating employes of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, ?? for 5 A. M. today by the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, was postponed yesterday for twenty-four hours while negotiations were being continued for an agreement on the union's demands.

Dollar volume in the retail furniture industry is off 10 to 20 per cent compared with a year ago, with the drop reaching as much as 30 per cent in some of the larger population centers, Roscoe R. Rau, managing director of the National Retail Furniture Association, said here yesterday.

Savings banks continued yesterday to dispose of realty holdings in scattered sections of Manhattan. The Bowery Savings Bank sold for cash to the E. X. Realty Corporation the five-story building containing- sixteen apartments and two stores on a lot 24 by 100 feet at 82 Avenue D.
With an unfavorable 'weekly weather summary and rains still persisting in the Southwest, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday recovered 10 to 14 points, or 50 to 70 cents a bale.

David F. Lilienthal, director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, reported to President Roosevelt today that ne??stations for purchases of private utility properties in the TVA area were going on and that no insurmountable obstacles to early consummation were foreseen.

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, speaking tonight before the Yale Club of Washington, predicted that an administration of the affairs of the New York Stock Exchange truly sensitive to its public responsibities will be worked out under the new leadership soon to take office, and said the commission was prepared to lend its support.

Great Britain and Pdland today signed a naval agreement along. the lines of the 1936 Naval Treaty of. London, providing-limitations for individual warships and for the exchange of naval building information.

A bill pending before the Legislature would create locally the island's first New Deal alphabetical agency--the PRlWRA, the Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority. This administration measure-in which, the newspaper Mundo says, Secretary of Interior Harold L. Ickes is interested-would create a public corporation as a governmental instrumentality of the people of Puerto Rico.
Rutgers came from behind with two runs in the sixth inning to defeat the University of Pennsylvania nine, 6 to 5, on Neilson Field today before 1,000 fans.

Seven men died today and ten were seriously burned in the nation's second major mine disaster in less than a week. An explosion, attributed to gas, shook the St. Clair Coal Company's anthracite workings in a slope four miles from this Eastern Pennsylvania hard coal center.
According to visitors from Vienna, the persecution of Jews has assumed a much more violent form since Easter than in any previous period.

In the midst of Pennsylvania's bitter Democratic primary campaign, Governor Earle this afternoon dismissed his Attorney General, Charles J. Margiotti, who is a candidate for the party nomination for Governor, for refusing to present evidence to support his bribery charges against three prominent members of the Democratic organization.

President Roosevelt had as his luncheon guests Henry Ford and Edsel Ford; he conferred on his forthcoming message on monopoly with Attorney General Cummings and Robert Jackson, Solicitor General, and discussed Tennessee Valley Authority affairs with David Lilienthal.

Dramatic indeed was the opening event of the eighteenth annual Newark Horse Show, which began a four-day session tonight in the Essex Troop Armory. The class was for open jumpers and more than thirty of the star performers of the East competed.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses clashed yesterday with James J. Halleran, Queens Public Works Commissioner, accusing him of furthering his own real estate interests in Queens by asking for a twoweek adjournment on a zoning change involving Whitestone Parkway.

Washington recorded its second straight victory today, beating the Red Sox, 5 to 2. Jimmy DeShong pitched effectively for the Senators until the ninth, when he put two men on bases with none out. Elon Hogsett relieved him and held the Sox at bay.

John M. Landon, father of Alf M. Landon, the 1936 Republican Presidential nominee, died in a hospital here today. He was 81 years old. Last week he suffered a series of f heart attacks while visiting at a club in Kansas City. His son, the former Governor of Kansas, was at the bedside when he died.

An unusual incident took place in the Supreme Court today when the justices refused for lack of jurisdiction to hear the appeal of the International Ladies Garment Workers against an injunction preventing the union from picketing the Donnelly Garment plants in Kansas City in an effort to organize the factories.
Aratoma Ledge, the twenty-fiveacre estate of the late Mrs. Frank Hunter Potter, on the Hook Road, Bedford, Westchester, has been sold to Fifield Workum.

The celebration of May Day this year will find the ranks of those who observe labor's international holiday in this city divided. Locals of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, which in past years supplied the largest contingents in the parade arranged by the United May Day Committee, let it be known yesterday that they would not participate this year.

Demand for steer hinds and ribs, veal hindsaddles and lamb was fairly active. Trading in fresh pork cuts Was fair to slow. The lamb market was higher and other classes of hon-kosher meats mostly steady. The kosher markets opened about steady with Tuesday's close.
New delays of as much an three weeks in the payment of State unemployment insurance benefits to 162,000 jobless persons were officially admitted yesterday.

Joseph E. Elliot, superintendent of the Sequoia National Forest, said today a ground crew reached the wreckage of an airplane which vanished with four Visalia residents Monday, and that all were dead.

Appointment of the Rev. Dr. Charles Wilford Sheerin of Chattanooga, Tenn., to the second vice presidency of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church in America was confirmed yesterday by the council on the second day of its quarterly meeting, now in session at the Church Missions House, 281 Fourth Avenue.
The program of the fifty-second annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria will continue this morning with a meeting at 10 o'clock.

Before 91,710 persons at Hampden Park tonight, East Fife booted two overtime goals to defeat Kilmarnock, 4 to 2, for the Scottish Football. Cup and became the first second division club to win the trophy since the junior league was formed in 1922.

A warning against the misuse of radio for propaganda purposes, "especially by any dominant political interest," is made in the report of the radio committee of the American Newspaper Publishers Association to the annual publishers' convention. It was one of sixteen committee reports.

The Administration's policy of maintaining an embargo on arms to Loyalist Spain was assailed from two quarters here today. Fifteen outstanding members of the National Academy of Sciences, now holding its annual meeting here, sent to President Roosevelt a petition urging him to lift the embargo.

Eastern shippers and order buyers bought well--finished steers and yearlings actively, paying firm prices. Strictly prime weighty steers and yearlings actively, paying firm prices. Strictly prime weighty steers went to $10.65, several loads selling at $10-$10.50. There was a mild upturn in hogs, while lambs held steady, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.
The engagement of Miss Joan SkewesCox of this city to Adrian Halsey Malone of New York has been announced by her parents.
Major T. J. Oakley Rhinelander will give a dinner tonight in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for his granddaughter, Miss Le Brun Rhinelander, in celebration of her birthday.
Mrs. Helen Wills Moody; full of confidence and loaded down with twenty-five racquets, arrived today and prepared to practice at Wimbledon tomorrow.

Defending Champion Frank Pennink today entered the fourth round of the English amateur golf championship by defeating T. Day, 2 up. Gaining the third round were G. Illingworth, who defeated Brig. Gen. A. C. Critchley, noted sports promoter, 1 up, in twenty-one holes;

With sunny skies outside of the Capitol lending moral support to insurgency, the Constitutional Convention was the scene today of the first "rebellion" against the ironclad rule of its president, Chief Justice Frederick E. Crane.

Brown today defeated Yale, 15 to 8, in a three-hour game marked by ineffective pitching and fielding lapses in the sixth inning, during which Yale scored six runs, and in the eighth, when the visitors registered seven.

The release of Melvin Gibbon; American aviator held by the Yokahoma police, is expected today. The prosecuting authorities say they have found no charge on which Mr. Gibbon can be indicted and no evidence to support a case if a charge could be made.

George Zengaras, East Side lightweight, registered a surprise triumph over Frankie Wallace, veteran Cleveland campaigne, at the New York Hippodrome last night. The New York boxer scored a clean knockout in twenty-one seconds of the seventh--round of the scheduled ten-round main event.

The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation announced yesterday the award of two fellowships, in addition to fifty-eight awards previously announced, for 1938-39. The recipients are Lloyd K. Garrison, dean of the Law School of the University of Wisconsin, and Marvin Chauncey Ross, associate curator of medieval- art at the Walters Art Gallery Baltimore.

The Constitutional Convention may take steps to suspend the veto power of the Governor over legislative and Congressional reapportionment measures. The Congressional reapportionment now in force was enacted in 1911 by a Legislature controlled by Democrats.

Mrs. Mamie vaughn Patterson Winchester, widow of John Maxwell Winchester of this city and Natchez, Miss., died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital of complications-arising from arteriosclerosis. She was born seventy-three years ago in Nashville, Tenn., a daughter of General Michael Vaughn.

Army romped over Swarthmore to an 18-to-1 victory at lacrosse today. The visitors were unable to follow the close shifting of the cadets, who began rolling in the goals after the first few minutes. Bollard led the cadet attack with four goals. Swarthmore's only point was scored by Krattenmaker.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it has aocepted a proposal of the Staten Island Edison Corporation, a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Eleotrio Company, to -put into effect reductions in charges for electric service which, it is calculated, will save customers about $500,000 annually.

A net profit of $2,353,002 for the first quarter of 1938 was reported yesterday by Standard Brands, Inc., after deductions for expenses, minority interest, Federal and foreign income taxes, but before profit and loss items and Federal surtax on undistributed income.

The adoption of a resolution asking Bishop William T. Manning of the Episcopal Diocese of New York to relinquish his exclusive control of the "faltering and dying" missions of Westchester County and permit a local archdeacon to build them into full parish churches was announced here today by the Episcopal archdeaconry of the county.

Off-price merchandise, usually in relatively small lots, is freely available in such lines as smokers' articles, stationery, leather' goods, household merchandise and electrical goods, but sharp price reductions are absent in ready-to-wear and dry goods lines, according to the experiences of two chain organizations who advertised this week for immediate offerings.

Creation of a committee of retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers to analyze and disseminate to the public information on fair trade to offset attacks by opponents of price maintenance was urged yesterday by H. L. Brooks, president of the Toilet Goods Association, in an address yesterday at the convention of the New York Pharmaceutical Council at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Early Gothic Period: Minor Arts," Harry D. M. Grier, 11 A. M.; American Wing (general tour), 2 P. M. Luncheon, Advertising Club of New York, 23 Park Avenue, noon. James G. Stahlman, guest of honor.
Gustavo Ross, former Finance Minister, has decided to enter next October's Presidential elections as the candidate of the Right Wing parties. Pedro Aguirre Cerda,

Captain Jim Salsich converted three times to pace the Princeton Rugby Club to a 21-6 victory over Hofstra College today. Ralph Pierce averted a Blue and Gold shut-out by pushing over two tries in the last five minutes.
Every one's peace now hangs on Czechoslovakia, and the gamble there seems the hardest and riskiest since 1914 for all the. players and bystanders.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that it had paid out $169,767,047 in benefit payments to farmers and for administrative expenses during the July-March period of the current fiscal year.
The War Deapartment released the following orders to- day, dated April 26: COLONEL Brown, E. 1., Eng'rs., Richmond, Va., about Aug. 15, to home and await retirement; previous orders revoked.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, are recommended as suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private schools. The list follows:
J. Edward McDermott, in 25 E 83d St; G. Norman Farquhar. in 136 E 36th St; Mrs. Eugene S. Taliaferro, in 1,040 Park Ave; Mme. Henri Goiran, in 505 E 55th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, brokers.

Several large and well-known Manhattan business properties were bid in by the plaintiffs in auction sales held in the Vesey Street salesrooms yesterday. The fourteen-story office building at 135-37 Broadway, on the northwest corner of Cedar Street, was awarded to the Mutual Life Insurance Company on a bid of $100,000.
The United States Steel Corporation's earnings for the first quarter of 1938, and its action on the quarterly dividends, had been awaited with much interest.

Theodore H. Steinblinck, a suspended patrolman who was a star witness in a Sullivan Act case in General Sessions recently, was convicted yesterday by Justices William R. Bayes, Max Salomon and John V. Flood in Special Sessions of second degree perjury.

Despite the fact that they experienced a smaller increase in national advertising volume last year than other media did, newspapers continued to lead by a substantial margin in national copy, according to the annual report of the Bureau of Advertising of the A. N. P. A., presented yesterday.
Albert B. Anderson, for twentyseven years a Federal judge in the Indiana District Court and the Circuit Court of Appeals at Chicago, died here today. He was 81-years old.
Without the loss of a set the New York University tennis team shut out Fordham, 9 to 0, yesterday at the Fleet Hollow Club courts. It was the fourth victory in five starts for the Violet.

The final liquidation of Jewish property in "Great Germany" was initiated today when Field Marshal Hermann Goering, as Commissar for the Four-Year Plan, issued a decree ordering all Jews in Germany, including those of foreign citizenship, to report to the government by June 30 of this year all their possessions if these exceed 5,000 marks.

Septuagenarian and octogenarian graduates of the Old Fifth Street School gazed reminiscently at their alma mater for the last time yesterday and hundreds of youngsters shouted in delight as a demolition sledge hammer fell on the centuryold structure.

The Giants took almost five hours to dispose of the Phillies yesterday in the season's first double-header at -the Polo Grounds, but, like most of the 21,829 midweek guests present, they considered the time well spent.
The Tomara Stable's Teddy Weed led throughout the running of the Shenandoah Valley, a 3-yearold race at a mile and seventy yards that featured the mid-week program at the Harford County track today.
A proposal for a reciprocal trade agreement with Great Britain to increase American hosiery exports was placed before the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers today.
After a fortnight of discussions And consultations between the Palace and Premier Mohammed Mahmoud Pasha, the latter has reshuffled the Cabinet as follows:

Reaction to the budget news caused an early setback in the stock-market today but prices improved during the afternoon and most sections closed higher. Gilt-edge issues fell sharply; among the foreign bonds, however, German and Chinese loans did well.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederic S. Doremus of Indian Harbor, Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clarissa Doremus, to Robert E. Clift Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clift of Belle Haven, Greenwich.

IT is, as has been observed several million times before, a queer world we live in. The amiable philosopher--it's too bad his name doesn't come to mind at the moment; he deserves wider recognition-who stated that "Life is short, Nature is hostile and Man is ridiculous" scored a direct hit.
Gotham Equities Corporation (Joseph K. Alliger and Hyman Ratner) have purchased the two-family house at 1,836 Seventy-fifth Street, Brooklyn, from a client of Bulkley Horton Company.

Chairman Alfred Rheinstein of the New York City Housing Authority believes that he can cut previously estimated costs on the Queensbridge and Red Hook housing projects, for which the United States Housing Authority has just contracted to provide loans and subsidies.
A prediction that Czechoslovakia's 3,500,000 Germans soon would demand "inevitable" union with Germany was fnade tonight by a German official of Cabinet rank.

The Federal Communications Commission denied today an application by the principal telegraph companies for a 15 per cent increase in domestic rates. Five commissioners voted to deny the increase while two favored the granting of an increase for one year.

Under the spur of a few critical sentences uttered by G. Lyle Belsley of Chicago, the National League of Women Voters this afternoon decided overwhelmingly to expand its scope but rejected as too rigid his estimate of $250,000 as an adequate operating budget, and empowered a committee not yet appointed to submit the financial platform on which its future operations will be based.

General Jose Varela's Spanish Insurgent troops suddenly smashed through government defenses north of Teruel today and seized Escorihuela in the Pobo Mountains, which command important Teruel. [A map covering yesterday's operations is on Page 10.]

Lon Warneke pitched three-hit ball today, garnered as many at the plate and otherwise helped the rejuvenated Cardinals win, 5 to 0, from the Reds for their second victory of the year and their first in five starts.

The International Paper Company, a subsidiary of the International Paper and Power Company, had a consolidated net profit of $9,220,520 in 1937,- according to the annual report, which will be forwarded today to shareholders.

President Roosevelt's views about newspapers find expression in his excerpts from White House conference notes which were made publie today. His views are expressed in the partial transcript of a conference held on Dec. 27, 1935, for faculty members of schools of journalism.

My theme is the relation of the press to the maintenance of American civil liberty. I wish to discuss this question: What can the American press best do at the present time to safeguard and perpetuate our basic civil rights?

The World's Fair will be a dazzle of architecture, a cocktail of color, a burst of glory, brilliantly fountained and lighted by night, terraced, lawned bushed, treed and flowered by day, a symbol of beauty and progress of which this city and the whole country may well be proud. But what about the way out?

Broadway, s w cor 4th St, 80.5 1/2x110; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp to Frederick W. Dau, trustee, 52 Vanderbilt Ave. reorganization plan. Broadway, 710. 25x137.6; Mortgage Commission to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee, deed dated Dec. 12, 1935; same prop. Mortgage Commission Realty Corp to Frederick W. Dau, trustee. 122d St, 214 W, 15x101; same to same, deed dated March 22, 1936.
A statement by Elizabeth Wagner, 22-year-old Queens girl arrested on a charge of poisoning her two brothers, was issued yesterday by Robert Molinari of 21-01 ThirtiethAvenue, Astoria, her counsel.

Jack Inglis of 147 West Forty-seventh Street, former vaudeville and musical revue comedian, died on Tuesday in Bellevue Hospital after a long illness. He was 56 years old. He appeared in "Good News," "Strike Me Pink" and "Follow Through."

Opponents of the Naval Expansion Bill, in an attack on its provisions for three 45,000-ton battleships, blocked an attempt by Administration leaders today to limit debate and speed a vote on the $1.156,000,000 measure.

COMEMCIAL PAPER Yesterday Tuesday For the best names 1% 1% The quotations are for four-six months' paper. Toy Buyers Reach 1,400 While the average of orders placed so far at the Toy Fair here continued under a year ago, the buying pace quickened somewhat yesterday.

William Dieterle, the movie director, is casting rather hopeful eyes on Broadway. As soon as he finishes Paul Muni's next film for Warners (it may take time, though, for the story hasn't been selected), he will be coming East to look over the ground.

Miss Mary Lewis, long recognized for her outstanding promotional and merchandising work for Best Co., Fifth avenue specialty shop, has severed her connection with that store, it became known here yesterday. Miss Lewis, who has been affiliated with Best's for nineteen years, resigned last Monday.

Canada's external trade during. the fiscal year ended on March 31 was valued at $1,883,870,944, compared with' $1,746,119,786 in the previous fiscal year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. This was the highest point reached since 1929-30, when the total trade was $2,393,211,652.

Yankees vs. Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, Bronx, 3:15 P. M. Dodgers vs. Phillies, at Ebbets Field, Bedford Avenue and Sullivan Place, Brooklyn, 3:15 P. M. Newark Bears vs. Montreal Royals, at Ruppert Stadium, 262 Wilson Avenue, Newark ............3 P. M.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's projected mammoth assembly hall in the center of Berlin, it is now announced, is to be eleven times the size of the Reichstag Building, which was long the chief monument of the German capital after the Imperial Palace.

The issuance yesterday by the State Banking Board of its regulations governing the establishment and operation of common trust funds completed a long series of steps which have been taken by Federal and State authorities to clear away the obstacles that formerly prevented bans in this State from mingling the funds of small trusts and estates.

Several residential parcels in Hoboken figured in the New Jersey real estate transactions reported yesterday. Charles Rivara bought from Commissioner Thomas J. McAleer- the dwelling at 210 Fifth Street, which he will alter to accommodatec two families. The broker -in the .del, J. I. Kislak, Inc., also reports the following sales:

Echo Pl, 221 (11-2810); Benjamin H. Leibman to Echo Properties, Inc. 565 5th Ave. Paulding Ave. 1,851 (15-4127); Abraham D. Levy, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp. Bryant Ave, 1,492 (11-3000); Maurice Downing, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp. .

The California Packing Corporation announced yesterday that it had arranged to sell at par to an institutional investor a new issue of $6,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent nonconvertible debentures, redeemable at the rate of $1,000,000 annually to June 1, 1939, to 1944.

Their zeal undiminished by their division into rival groups, one emphasizing collective, security, the other isolationism, thousands of undergraduates poured out of the classrooms of the colleges and universities of the city at 11 A. M. yesterday to take part in the fifth annual "student strike for peace."

Nature did not intend that the vocal organs should be used as such and what we use for speaking and singing are organs originally shaped for other purposes, Victor E. Negus, prominent London laryngologist, said today in a talk before the American Laryngological, Rhinological and Otological Society in convention here.

With all reports continuing to indicate that the House Rules Committee is standing eight to six against reporting a rule for consideration of the Wages and Hours Bill at this session, the committee will meet tomorrow with pressure upon it increasing.

H. M. Woolf's handsome bay colt Lawrin worked a mile today in a trial for the Kentucky Derby that amazed veteran turfmen. He was clocked in 1:38 flat, said to be the fastest time ever made in a Derby prep at Churchill Downs.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: 1st Lt. George S. Schuyler, Inf.-Res., 3d M. A., Nov. 12, 1938.

Exports and imports of the United States by classified groups of merchandise during March, as announced by the Department of Commerce, are compared herewith with those of February, 1938, and March, 1937.

The student leader of Berlin University, Guenther Lemke, today renewed his. campaign against so-called free students. These are students belongig formally to the National Socialist organization but who are not active except when they cannot avoid it.

A plan for the eradication of leprosy throughout the world "within a very few generations" by means of sterilization was outlined yesterday in an interview by Perry Burgess, president of the Leonard Wood Memorial for the Eradication of Leprosy, who has just returned from a tour of lepresaria in all parts of the world.
The Board of Education, at its meeting yesterday, elected two principals to head the new Andrew Jackson High School in Queens and to fill a vacancy at Flushing High School.

The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association announced in its twentyfifth annual report yesterday that it was "in the midst of a campaign to build a newer and stronger organization through the wide expansion of membership."

A message from Perpignan, France, says the Bishop of Perpignan, acting on special Vatican authority, yesterday administered Catholic baptism, as well as first communion, to the two daughters of the British charge d'affaires to Barcelona, John H. Leche, and his American wife, the former Helen Morris Janney of Philadelphia.

E. H. Little, who has served as vice president in charge ot sales and advertising of the ColgatePalmolive-Peet Company since 1933, was yesterday elected president. The action was taken by the directors immediately following the annual stockholders' meeting in Jersey City.
BLUE MASK AT BAY, by Anthony Morton. (Lippincott, $2.) A mystery novel. CROOKS IN CLOVER, by Percy J. Smith. (Lippincott, $2.50.) Accounts of international criminals and confidence men.
A total of $116,744 in the campaign of the Committee for Planned Parenthood for $263,990, has been contributed, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. William C. Potter, chairman of the committee.

Visitors to Japan are surprised by the peaceful atmosphere they find. If they were about the city in the early hours they might meet a string of ambulances crawling from railroad station to hospital with the badly wounded, or in the suburbs at any hour they might see small procession escorting to some temple graveyard a white box with the ashes of a soldier.
Karel Kozeluh of Greenwich, Conn., the defending champion, and Joe Whalen of New York reached the semi-finals of the annual Greenbrier open tennis championships today.
The General Motors Corporation in its report for the three months ended on March 31 shows net earnings of $8,234,017, compared with $44,814,166 for the first quarter of 1937.

William McC. Martin Jr., chairman-designate of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, has invited his fellow-unopposed-nominees to the board to an informal dinner at the Yale, Clubon May 5.

Pearl S. Buck, whose novels often have appeared on lists of best sellers, appealed yesterday for an end of regular listings of fast-selling books. "I wish to heaven that we could do away with the best-seller list entirely," she said.
The bargain art exhibition and sale arranged by the Joint Distribution Committee at the Studio Guild Galleries has enlisted not only the support of artists but of the buying public.

Hope that a peaceful agreement would be reached in the controversy between Robert R. Young, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, and the Guaranty Trust Company for control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway was expressed yesterday by Earle Bailie of J. W. Seligman Co. Mr. Bailie was proposed by the Guaranty Trust as one of three directors for the Chesapeake Corporation, which holds 30 per cent of C. O. control.

Dropping down a peg or two from the top notch sprinters he trailed in the Paumonok Handicap on opening day, William H. Gallagher's Rudie found himself in more suite ble company at Jamaica yesterday and he captured the Parole Handicap, at a mile and a sixteenth. The event featured a fine mid-week program.

The Brooklyn Trust Company was rebuked yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler for alleged laxity in performing its duties as trustee for Series N-75 first mortgage participation certificates issued and guaranteed by the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company.

If all the cruising boats and International one-designs that are expected to participate appear on the scene, the Larchmont Yacht Club will have quite a regatta to open the big-time yachting season on the Sound on Saturday and Sunday, May 14 and 15.

Declaring that newspaper promotion as a whole is "entirely too competitive," Colonel Julius Ochs Adler, vice president and general manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, urged the National Newspaper Promotion Association yesterday to "declare war on obscure linage claims, on trick circulation charts and on all autobiographical material which is of no interest to any one except other publishers."

The 369th Infantry of New York City, the only Negro regiment in the State National Guard, is to have Colonel Benjamin O. Davis, also a Negro, as its colonel. The regiment was created by a special act of the Legislature some years before the World War as a Negro unit.

The Four Aces' steamroller slackened its pace yesterday afternoon in the final thirty-six boards of the annual knockout contract team-offour championship for the Vanderbilt Cup played at the Hotel Ambassador.

Mayor Frank D.Livermore, whose announcement several months ago that he was looking for an applicant with a college education to fill a vacancy on the local police force attracted wide attention, disclosed today that he had been successful in his search.

The Itanan authorities, in cooperation with a vast contingent of German police, have been adopting a number of very severe measures to insure Chancellor Adolf Hitler's safety when he comes to Italy next month. Most noteworthy is the arrest of all persons who might for any reason bear a grudge against the German dictator.

H. E. Morriss's Pasch thrust himself prominently into the Epsom Derby picture today when he kept a perfect record intact with a victory in the Two Thousand Guineas, first of the British season's classics for 3-year-olds.

As the French Premier and Foreign Minister arrived in London last night for talks that mat lead to an Anglo-French alliance and world-wide coordination of the two nations' foreign policies, Czechoslovakia loomed as the knottiest problem facing the conferees.

Pease Elliman, Inc., announce the resignation of Edwin W. Ryan, who has been with the concern for many years. The board of governors of the St. Nicholas Club, which will occupy its new quarters at 379 Park Avenue on May 1, has invited the members to a tea and inspection of the quarters to be held this afternoon.

Texture designs in axminster rugs hive outsold all other patterns by a wide margin, according to preliminary figures revealed yesterday by the style trend council of the Instiute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, Inc., at a luncheon to newspaper and magazine representatives at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Commodity Exchange Admlnistration said today it had preferred charges against Burke Co. of Sioux Falls, S. D., grain and stock brokers, and two of their officers for alleged violation of the Cornmodity Exchange Act.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, opened an exhibition in the university's Low Memorial Library yesterday afternoon commemorating the thirtieth anniversary of the death of Edward MacDowell, American composer, who was the first Professor of Music at Columbia and head of the music department from 1896 to 1904.

Shipments of Seville green olives to the United States slackened in April, although shippers had hoped to sell larger quantities in New York to aid the Franco Government's efforts to bolster its finances with dollars.

Two freighters met in a heavy fog at the entrance to Delaware Bay early today. The York of the Merchants and Miners Transportation Company was left with a gaping hole at the water line and was beached on a shoal a quarter-mile from shore. It was bound from Philadelphia to Southern ports.

Jackie Coogan, who is waging an accounting suit against his mother and his stepfather, learned today that even if he wins all they have, he will get only $535,923 of the millions he says he earned as a child actor.
The German Government announced here today that the invitation to exhibit at the 1939 World's Fair in New York would not be accepted because a return commensurate with the cost would be unlikely.

In the medieval atmosphere of a twelfth-century monastery the body of George Grey Barnard lay yesterday in a flower-draped coffin as 200 sculptors, other artists and friends paid tribute to the man whose statues adorn galleries the world over.

Public interest in the films adapted from the writings of Lloyd C. Douglas caused Warners today to purchase "Forgive Us Our Trespasses." Some seasons ago Universal made "Magnificent Obsession" and Warners have filmed "Green Light" and "White Banners" on the minor schedule.

Essex Liodcaster, Inc, of Detroit, in Time and Life Building, Rockefeller Center; George F. Briegel, Inc, publishers of music for educational institutions, in RKO Building, Rockefeller Center. Ryan Sullivan, Inc, advertising, in 342 Madison Ave;

Now that the war is believed to be nearing its end arid military activity has shifted to Southern Spain, Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime has decided that the time has come to undertake a resumption of tourist traffic in Northern Spain, which is remote from the war zone.
Twenty-five years ago Robert G. Fowler, pioneer American aviator, made the first nonstop flight from the Pacific-to the Atlantic in a biplane with an eighty horsepower motor and temporary pontoons.

The half-way mark has been passed in the $400,000 campaign being conducted here by the women's division of the Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, it was announced yesterday after a luncheon of the division at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, said today that Ambassador Francisco Najera of Mexico had assured him that Mexican tariffs would be materially reduced, probably on May 1. Tariffs were increased in January, in some cases as much as 200 per cent.

Establishment of a "tax reserve" system to stabilize State revenues was urged on the constitutional convention today in a pamphlet sent to all the delegates by the Merchants Association of New York City.

Parties in Holland hold an unexpired option to purchase Anticosti Island in the Gulf of St. Lawrence from the Consolidated Paper Corporation, L. J. Belnap, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here today.

An entertainment known as an "Afternoon in Old China," featuring the Red Gate Players, was held yesterday at the Cosmopolitan Club to aid the Art Workers Club for Women. The beneficiary, located at 152 West Fifty-seventh Street, provides a homelike meeting place for women artists and models.
A single by Jim Gleeson in the ninth inning with the bases loaded capped a four-run rally and enabled the champion Newark Bears to defeat the Montreal Royals today, 6 to 5.

Market closed steady and generally higher after reducing earlier gains; turnover, 425,070 shares. United.States Government bonds recovered- Tuesday's losses and closed higher; other groups irregular in second slowest trading of month; transactions, $4,478,600.

The British commission to study the partition of Palestine arrived tonight accompanied by two special detectives and M. S. Harris of the Palestine Government, who will be attached to the commission during their stay here.

Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, world chess champion, continued in the lead today at the annual Easter congress of the Kent County Chess Association, the seventh round of which was contested at the Grand Hotel, Cliftonville. The champion drew with one of his nearest rivals, Rudolph Spielmann of Austria, the only one of the ten competitors who is undefeated.

About 9,600 telephones will be transferred to new addresses in this city as a result of the Spring moving activity, which is expected to reach its peak next week, the New York Telephone Company estimated yesterday.

The Illyrian spring is very beautiful in Albania, a half-mythical mountain kingdom on the Adriatic which the currents of Mediterranean conquest and the sweep of Balkan wars have hardly changed since the twilight of the Greeks.
The Marquess of Lothian today denied the existence of a "Cliveden set," of which he is reputed to be a member. Much political play has lately

The Warehousemen's Protective Committee, representing, operators of fifty-nine warehouses in the Port of New York area, filed today a brief urging the Interstate Commerce Commission to find illegal the contract under which the Erie Railroad pays $196,000 annual "rent" to the Seaboard Terminal and Refrigeration Company for services in connection with its, $4,000,000 warehouse in Jersey City.

The voice of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was added to "the library of talking books for sightless readers" yesterday when she read from the first chapter of her recent book, "This Is My Story," for the American Foundation for the Blind, West Sixteenth Street.

THE first installments of the much-debated "Public Papers" of Franklin D. Roosevelt appear today in five large and handsome volumes.* They are, compared to the average collection of official documents, of extraordinary general interest. This is due to the spirit of the documents themselves and to the admirable way in which they are presented.
An attempt by thirty-five typographical workers to pass through American Newspaper Guild picket lines at The Duluth Herald and News-Tribune plant was blocked by 120 pickets this morning.

Police Commissioner Valentine, speaking yesterday before more than 600 past and present police lieutenants at the seventh annual luncheon in the Hotel Commodore of the Lieutenants Benevolent Association, exhorted his men always to be "Public Friend No. 1."

The contract for the general construction of the new out-patient building of the Hospital for Joint Diseases, at 41-59 East 123d Street and 52-8 East 124th Street, has been awarded to. M. Shapiro Son, according to Brown's Letters, Inc.

" America must preserve civilization if it is to be preserved at all," declared the author, Hendrik Willem Van Loon, yesterday at the Astor Hotel at a luncheon of the Philharmonic-Symphony League of New York, attended by 700 league members and their guests.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The President proposes to remove tax exemptions from government securities and salaries, not by constitutional amendment but by reciprocal legislation. The same method was suggested by me in a letter published in THE TIMES on Sept. 23, 1933.

Former Mayor George J. Zimmermann, held in contempt of court yesterday for failure to appear at a hearing in connection with a lawsuit, was attacked and knifed by marauders the previous night, Dr. Edward J. Zimmermann, his brother, reported today.

The Palestine Partition Commission, before holding open sessions, will spend a fortnight acquiring personal knowledge of the country by tours. Any persons or organizations desiring to express views will be heard.
