President Roosevelt is considering the creation of an "inner council" of business men to study and make recommendations on economic problems, some of his more conservative advisers said today.
Corporation reports for the year ended Dec. 31 last, made available by the Securities and Exchange Commission, disclose the salaries paid to some of the country's leading industrial executives.

Each year one of the Eastman School American composers' concerts is included in its festival. Tonight the fiftieth concert in this series was played by the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, Dr. Howard Hanson conducting, in the Eastman Theatre, where, in 1925, the first concert was played.

Dr. Elzy Dee Jennings, dean of Southern Methodist University, died here today after a long illness. His age was 58. He became ill while attending the international convention of Rotary clubs at Nice, France, last year.

The Rev. Frank Dean Gifford, chairman of the Episcopal Archdeaconry Council of Westchester County, expressed "strong disapproval of the implications" of the report of the meeting at White Plains on Wednesday of the archdeaconry published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

A new house on South Howell Avenue is for sale, but the robins now in possession will not have to worry about eviction. Inspecting the property, L. E. Stanton, president of the construction company, discovered that the birds were nesting on a window ledge and expecting a newcomer.
Raymond Vaude, 35-year-old fugitive from a penal colony in French Guiana, has returned to France, a free man-but he had to dive overboard and swim ashore at St. Nazaire to do it.

Winning two more matches today, Frank Pennink, the defending titleholder, entered the quarter-finals of the English golf championship. After disposing of J. H. Wales, 1 up, when Wales missed an 18-inch putt on the last green, Pennink crushed F. Haughton, 8 and 6, in the fifth round this afternoon.

James L. Miller, 60, fish and game editor of The Rome Daily Sentinel; his wife, Julia, 59, and Stuart.C. Lambert, 23, a poultry dealer, were killed late today when cars driven by Mr. Miller. and Mr. Lambert were in collision near here. Mrs. Mildred Lambert, riding with her husband, was critically injured.
Robert T. Bowman of Trenton will suceeded Walter Kidde of Montclair next week as president of the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce, it was announced by the organization here today.

A bronze bas relief--portrait of the late Rev. Dr. Archibald R. Mansfield, superintendent of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York for thirty-eight years until his death in 1934, was unveiled yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of Our Saviour, in the institute building, 25 South Street.

Simultaneously with the communication of a communique from Berlin announcing Chancellor Adolf Hitler's journey to Italy and giving a list of the important personages who will aocompany him, the Italian press today launched an energetic campaign to stir the very distinctly lukewarm Italian people to some measure of enthusiasm over the impending visit of Premier Benito Mussolini's fellow-dictator.

The council of the International Sugar Conference received today the report of its statistical committee, with revised estimates of the requirements of the free market for the quota year ending on Aug. 31.

Death Announced Fireman 1st grade Herbert J. Wolfe, of Engine Co. 38, died April 27. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 2,141 Starling Ave., Bronx, at 9:30 A. M., Saturday, April 30. Interment at St. Raymond's Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 7th Division shall detail a lieutenant and twelve firemen, who, together with six members from the off platoon of Engine Co.

The Board of Estimate authorized yesterday Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick to issue $300,000 in tax notes to provide funds to meet salaries and expenses of the Transit Commission for the period ended on July 1.

The hope that the United States would conclude reciprocal trade agreements with all Latin-American countries was expressed in an address tonight by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, at a dinner of-the Pan-American Coffee Bureau;

The Board of Estimate cleared the way yesterday for the Rockaway Beach improvement by approving acquisition of the property involved at an estimated cost of $4,753,100 and voting the necessary changes in the city map.

Share prices held lower during most of yesterday's session, meeting increased pressure in the final hour that sent many issues to the lows of the day at the close. Leading stocks were down 1 to more than 3 points.

Professor Edmund Husserl, noted German philosopher, died on Tuesday in Freiburg in Breisgau, Germany, it was learned here yesterday. He was the founder of the so-called phenomenological school, generally considered as representing one of the important German philosophical movements of this century. His age was 79.

Paul R. Vervoort of the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company has been nominated for president of the Bank Credit Associates of New York for the coming year, it was announced yesterday by Edward Adams Jr. of the Grace National Bank, retiring president of the group.

Jockey Charles Kurtsinger, suspended by his contract employer, Mrs. Dodge Sloane, owner of the Brookmeade Stable, has been restored to good standing and is eligible to accept mounts immediately. He will have the leg up on Pasteurized in the Wood Memorial tomorrow at Jamaica and will ride the Brookmeade Stable's Handcuff in the Pimlico Oaks on May 7.
Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller approved yesterday the fornation of a society with the avowed purpose of attempting to limit any individual to two terms as President of the United States.

The Coordinating Committee for Employment, formed on Lincoln's Birthday to break down discrimination against Negroes In the public utility and other industrial fields, announced yesterday at its headquarters, 132 West 138th Street, that the Consolidated Edison Company had agreed to employ more Negroes in white-collar jobs.

With Bill Lee pitching air-tight ball for eight innings, the Cubs easily outclassed the Reds, 12 to 5, today in the first of a two-game series. The Cubs pounded Gene Schott, Ray Benge and Lloyd Moore for fifteen hits, including a homer by Augie Galan, who drove in five of the Chicago runs.

Now that the German Government has withdrawn from the World's Fair, what disposition is to be made of the space allotted to its building? "The World of Tomorrow" is the general to theme of the fair. That world is being fashioned even now in the scientific laboratories.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today the following proceedings were had: 915--Federal Power Commission, petr., v. Metropolitan Edison Company, et a.l. Petition for writ of cert. the Third Circuit Court of Appeals granted and case assigned for argument on Monday, May 2 next, Justice Roberts not participating.

The Society of Photographic Illustrators, Inc., 230 Park Avenue, representing leading illustrators producing photographs for advertising purposes, has drafted a "Code of Ethics" for its membership "to correct some extremely bad practices in the profession, detrimental to the interest of both the agencies, whom we serve, and the photographic illustrator," it was announced yesterday by Grancel Fitz, president.

Following is the text of the prepared speech of Governor La Follette announcing formation of the Progressive Party of America All over the world principles fox which Americans have fought and died are under attack.

Declaring the city hospitals faced a growing burden, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, in transmitting yesterday his annual report to Mayor La Guardia, said the best means of relieving the pressure would be through extension of the voluntary group hospitalization plan.

Paintings from the collections of Mrs. Sonia Norris of London, the late Carl Schoen of Rumson, N. J.; Henry Jordan of New York and White Plains, and other properties brought $27,810 last night at auction at the American Art AssociationAnderson Galleries, Inc.

Indefinite suspension of the social security contributions of both employers and employes as a means of releasing funds for re-employment was advocated last night by Colonel Frank Knox, publisher of The Chicago Daily News.
Lyn Lary's home run at the start of the game set the tempo for the 2 1/2-hour contest the Cleveland Indians won from the St. Louis Browns today, 11 to 6.

President Roosevelt signed today an order which suspended the restrictive regulations adopted in connection with his silver nationalization proclamation of Aug. 9, 1934. The Executive order did not affect the Treasury's domestic silver buying policy, but was a formality necessitated by changed conditions, Treasury officials said.

William McC. Martin Jr., soon to become chairman of the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange, was in Washington today and called on W. O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Commissioner John W. Hanes, Mr. Douglas had not met Mr. Martin before.

Directors of the Diamond Match Company declared yesterday three quarterly dividends of 25 cents each on the common stock, payable on June 1, Sept. 1 and Dec. 1, and a stock dividend of onetenth share of capital stock of Pan American Match Corporation for each Diamond Match common share, payable on June 1.

Almost in view of some of the statues that added to his fame, George Grey Barnard, American sculptor, was buried in Pennsylvania's capital today. It was in accordance with his wishes that the man who carved the symbolic marble groups flanking the main entrance to the Capitol was returned here after his death Sunday in New York.

With the 1939 World's Fair preview scheduled to open tonight at the Junior League Ball of Tomorrow and fashion show in the Administration Building in Flushing Meadow Park, Fair officials announced last night that elaborate preparations were being made by traffic agencies to handle the flow of visitors- to the ceremonies on the site tomorrow.
The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad reported a profit and loss surplus of $143,316,167 on Dec. 31, against $144,304,246 a year previously. Total assets were $682,104,284, against $673,564,835.

A second attempt to bring a minimum wages and maximum hours, bill to the floor of the House through a petition requiring the signatures of 218 members was under serious consideration by its advocates, it was learned tonight.

Isaac Wolfe, former judge of the Superior and Common Pleas Court and, since his retirement from the bench, a State referee, died today in the Hospital of St. Raphael after a major operation. His judicial services had covered a period of thirty-one years.
Japanese forces continue to advance toward the east-west LungHai Railway, but Chinese reported today that the invaders' power was spent.
Prospects of one of the greatest Metropolitan open championships in the history of golf have been brightened lately by the caliber of entries received by the M. G. A.

President Roosevelt conferred 'on his forthcoming anti-monopoly message with Attorney-General Cummings, Robert H. Jackson, Thurman Arnold and Benjamin V, Cohen, signed an- order suspending restrictive regulations on the holding of silver and appointed Lowell Mellett as director of the National, Emergency Council.

The decree that Field Marshal Hermann Goering issued yesterday ordering Jews, not merely German but also of foreign citizenship, to report their property in Germany exceeding 5,000 marks to the German Government in preparation for its utilization in the interests of German economy precipitated something like a storm in diplomatic quarters here today.
1.The ownership and control of money and credit, without qualification or reservation, must be under public and not private control.
Bonds on the New York Stock Exchange turned irregular yesterday in dull trading. The turnover was down to $4,455,825, compared with $4,478,600 on the preceding day.

The statement of Parke, Davis Co. and subsidiaries for the March quarter, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $2,303,750 after depreciation, pension payments, Federal income taxes and other charges, but before any provision for surtax onundistributed income.

Skeleton machinery, by which, in the event of war, the government can place every inhabitant of the United Kingdom on rations with overnight control of food distribution to regularize quantities and keep down prices, has been already established.

Sale of a New York Stock Exchange seat for $62,060, down $1,000 from the price on April 14, was-reported yesterday. Wrenn Brothers Co. propose to retire as Stock Exchange members tomorrow, when Warner J. Banes and Samuel A. Anderson will retire.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended April 27 were announced today: Jordan, Lt. Cmdr. B., the Campbell, effective upon return from leave of absence about Oct. 20, assigned to the Defoe Boat and Motor Works, Bay City, Mich., in connection with construction of Cutters Nos. 72 and 73.

The Ford Motor Company, in an affidavit filed in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today, charged that the National Labor Relations Board was improperlyly influenced by extraneous considerations, political and otherwise" in handing down its order against the firm to require compliance with the Wagner Labor Act.
Joseph H. Nuelle resigned today as president and manager of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company and as president of the Lehigh New England Railroad Company, effective May 15.

Urging business to "forget politics and Washington" and concentrate upon the job of meeting the every-day needs of the country's population of 130,000,000, Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said that if "business men determine to have good business they can have it."

The Sir Andrew filly Anaflame, bred and owned by William Woodward, chairman of the Jockey Club, gave further evidence of speed over a distance when she was easily first in the Ariel Purse which featured yesterday's program at Jamaica.
Stock markets, although quiet today, were generally firm and most sections advanced. Gilt-edged issues made small improvement, while among the foreign loans German bonds had a good tone.
Five patents at the Trenton State Hospital for the Insane escaped at about 8:30 o'clock tonight after overpowering an attendant in a ward and stealing his keys.

Eskimos who thought they saw an airplane that might have been carrying Sigismund Levanevsky and his five Russian companions in the Arctic last Summer probably saw only Robert Randall's plane searching for the Russians, Randall declared today.

Miss Doris Ellen Weeks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus S. Weeks of Larchmont, was married to Alexander MacConnell Scott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott of New Rochelle, tonight in the Salem Baptish Church here on the thirtieth wedding anniversary of the bridegroom's parents. The Rev. Fred Bennett Ford officiated.

Under the sponsorship of the Committee on How to Combat AntiSemitism in America, "Through Gentile Eyes: A Plea for Tolerance and Good Will," by John Haynes Holmes, minister of the Community Church, will be published today, according to an announcement yesterday by George Gordon Battle, chairman of the committee.

The American Federation of Labor's executive council opened a new chapter today in its warfare with the Committee for Industrial Organization by chartering the Progressive Miners of America as a rival to the United Mine Workers of America in the hope of destroying or reducing to impotence the chief prop of the C. I. O., led by John L. Lewis.

Sears, Roebuck Co. reported today a decline of $3,256,342, or 7.5 per cent in gross sales for their third period (March 28 to April 23), compared with a year ago. The sales totaled $40,156,151, compared with $43,412,493.

Dr. Preston Pope Satterwhite is leaving 960 Fifth Avenue today for a visit in Louisville, Ky. He will return late next week to pass the Summer at Preston Hall, his country home at King's Point, Great Neck.
The Supreme Court consented today to review a legal fight between the Federal Power Commission and six subsidiaries of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, setting the arguments for Monday.

Israel Grief, 55 years old, a drugist, was struck and killed at 12:10 o'clock this morning as he was crossing Third Avenue, Brooklyn, after locking up his store at 8,201 Third Avenue, on the corner of Eighty-second Street,

The tendency of many large buyers of underwear to take advantage of present conditions to "chisel ruthlessly" for lower prices was roundly condemned here today by Ralph N. Jones of the Utica Knitting Mills, Utica, N. Y., in his annual address as president of the Underwear Institute.
Stockholders of Aluminium, Ltd., at a special meeting in Montreal yesterday, approved a by-law empowering the directors to declare dividends on common stock of the company.

There is not and has not been in two years any substantial lack of capital available for industrial expansion, but many . companies which could have used new capital profitably for expansion were deterred from seeking it because of the lack of confidence in the economic and political outlook and burdensome taxes, according to conclusions drawn from a survey of the capital needs of small manufacturing enterprises conducted by the Investment Bankers Conference,

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has bought from the collection of William Randolph Hearst some of his finest antique English silver and furniture for installation in the Governor's Palace at Williamsburg, colonial capital of Virginia, which has been restored by Mr. Rockefeller.
Robert R. Young said tonight that he had refused today to give a final answer to a peace plan proposed by New York banking interests in the struggle for control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad.

Charles Pinnell, general sales manager of the Merrimack Manufacturing Company, was re-elected president of the Textile Color Card Association at the annual meeting of the organization held yesterday at its headquarters here. Other officers were also re-elected, and W. R. MacIntyre of Joseph Ban croft Son and Brainerd Pidgeon of the Stunzi Sons Silk Company were elected to the board of directors, succeeding Philip Johnson and Godfrey Conze.

James G. Stahlman, publisher of The Nashville Banner and president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, told his fellowpublishers and some 200 others attending a luncheon yesterday at the Advertising Club of New York,
About 500 salmon were taken from the waters of Sebago Lake last week-end, as scores of New England and New York anglers took advantage of the weather to get in their first fishing of the season.

The staff organization of the psychiatric division of Bellevue Hospital sent telegrams yesterday to Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia saying that "an impartial and scientific investigation" of the division would show that "we are working against the overwhelming
The national income in the first quarter of 1938 was 5.4 per cent less than in the same period last year, statisticians of the Department of Commerce estimated today.

Dizzy Dean wouldn't believe Joe Medwick called him the kind of a guy who starts fights and then runs away until he called him on the telephone in Pittsburgh tonight. But Medwick, his former team-mate now with the Cardinals in Pittsburgh, admitted it, Dean said.
The preliminary designs for a Russian battleship, believed to be the largest in the world, have been, or are being, prepared by Gibbs Cox, naval architects of 1 Broadway, it was learned yesterday.
Following is the text of provisions of the decree affecting Jewish-owned property issued by Field Marshal Hermann Goering yesterday under date of April 26:

The Council of Foreign Bondholders, London, and the League Loans Committee, London, have notified Speyer Co. and the National City Bank that they remain of the opinion that both the original and present offer of the Greek Government to pay 40 per cent of the coupons on its external loans is wholly inadequate.

CLOSE, ARTHUR A. (April 23). Estate, more than $10,000. To Eula Close, widow, executrix. DUMONT, JEROME FRANCOIS (Jan. 20, 1920). Nuncupative will. Estate, $10,000. Helen Powers, 315 W, 79th St., petitioner, entire estate. MARRONE, SALVATORE (March 9). Estate, $2,895. To Caesar A. Cirigliano, executor. 1,128 45th St., Brooklyn.
Repeating its late uprising of Monday against St. John's, Manhattan pulled another ball game out of the fire yesterday at the expense of Brooklyn College on Manhattan Field.

A fast track and a star-studded field of athletes left the weather the only worry of officials tonight as they made ready for the fortyfourth University of Pennsylvania relay carnival tomorrow and Saturday.

Admiral Sir Morgan Singer, director of naval ordnance during the greater part of the World War, died in Winchester today at the age of 73. From Aug. 19, 1914, to the early part of 1917 he was responsible for the Admiralty's entire supply of guns, torpedoes and mines.

Miss Gayle Reese, daughter of Mrs. Adams Reese of Miami, Fla., and of John Evan Reese of Atlanta, Ga., was married to Abbot Southall of this city yesterday afternoon in Grace Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Felix Kloman.
The House passed tonight a bill designed to aid the merchant marine, regarded as one more important item on the legislative "recovery program," and sent the measure to the Senate.

Committees of the American Steamship Owners Association and the National Maritime Union agreed late yesterday afternoon on a wage and working contract, governing unlicensed personnel, for about sixty ship lines operating from ports on the Atlantic Coast.

Dr. Walter Russell Newton, professor emeritus of Rutgers University, died at his. home here today after a long illness. He was 82 years old. A member of the faculty of Rutgers for twenty-nine years, Dr. Newton was presented with the Rutgers University award in June, 1934, and was named professor emeritus.

Surrogate Edward G. Rogan decided today that living children of Andrew N Brady, utilities executive, each should receive one-fifth of the remaining $50,000 of his estimated $80,000,000 estate, and that off spring of deceased children should receive the fifth to which each of their dead parents would have beer entitled under the will.

In the week ended on Wednesday the Treasury spent $107,000,000 of the deposits in the Federal Reserve Bank which it had acquired through the recent desterilization of gold. The money was used to the extent of $50,000,000 to retire maturing Treasury bills and, to the remaining extent, for the general needs of the Treasury.
The Wellesley Verse Speaking Choir will present in Alumnae Hall tomorrow evening a program illustrating the place of choral speaking in the educational scheme.
Stocks continued depressed and closed lower, with leaders off 1 to 3 points; turnover, 537,260 shares. United States Government issues steady, other bonds irregular; transactions, $4,455,825.
The last Thursday concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony season of 1937-38, which comes to an end on Sunday afternoon, took place last night in Carnegie Hall.
The American Newspaper Publishers Association adopted of its fifty-sedonc annual meeting at the Hotel Wardsorf-Astoria yesterday.

The furniture industry last year earned a net profit of 6 3/4 per cent on invested capital, compared with 6 per cent in the preceding year and less than three-fourths of 1 per cent in 1935, according to the eighteenth annual survey of industry condition released yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants.
A group of advisers has been designated by the Textile Foundation to plan and place under way a scientific research program, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May signed an order yesterday in Brooklyn appointing Irwin Steingut and James A. Martin temporary receivers of the Russo-Asiatic Bank in litigation concerning a judgment obtained by the National City Bank and assigned to Herbert J. Grant on April 1, 1933, by Supreme Court Justice John H. McCooey. The order also permits the receivers to submit a new answer regarding, the judgment.

The Delman Shoe Salon in the Bergdorf-Goodman building at 754 Fifth Avenue is expanding its quarters by taking over the lease in the building of Mosse, Inc., linen shop, which recently leased the store at 659 Fifth Avenue.
The Duchesu of Atholl, one of the Scottish Conservative members of Parliament who have taken an active part in bringing Basque refugee children to Great Britain,

1st Lt. Earl R. Baublitz, Ch.--Res., now on active duty at Headquarters Trenton District, CCC, Trenton, N. J., and detached service with CCC Co, 2214, Camp SP-47, Peekskill, N. Y., is continued on active duty with the CCC until May 8, 1938. Date of rank: March 2, 1935.

The guardians of Alice B. Berle, an infant, assigned a $50.000 mortgage on 39 Beaver St to John T. Javasile, who assigned it to the John Hancock Life Insurance Co. A mortgage for $35,726 on 1,125 6th Ave was assigned by Beatrice Bishop Berle to Mr. Javasile,

Tax returns under the old-age insurance title of the Social Security Act for the first quarter of 1938 must be filed, with remittance, before midnight tomorrow, James J. Hoey, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second New York District, warned yesterday.

A liberal share of today's lamb crop comprised shorn offerings that sold strong at $7.85 down. Woolskins reached $9. Hogs and lower grade steers and she stock tended lower, but the market remained active and firm to higher on strictly grain-fed steers. No strictly choice steers arrived, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.
Funeral services Stephen Merritt's Chapel, corner 22d St. and 8th Ave., Saturday afternoon. AMER--Suddenly, on April 28, Frank B., of the Hotel Hargrave, 112 West 72d St. Interment private.

Charles S. Morris, retiring president of the New York Rotary Club, was guest of honor at the weekly luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Commodore. Mr. Morris, who has served for a year, will be succeeded by Andrew J. Haire. The election occurred on April 5.

Expecting a quiet May Day, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine issued orders yesterday calling upon the police throughout the city and particularly in Manhattan for a "suitable and adequate" distribution of forces during the May Day week-end and outlining the police arrangements for the May Day parade and rallies to be held tomorrow.

Payrolls of the American steel industry rose 13 per cent in March to a total of $51,386,000 for the month, compared to $45,599,000 in February, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. This compares to payrolls of $90,863,000 in March, 1937.

Members or member firms of the New York Stock Exchange were advised yesterday to make and save for twelve months all "short sale" orders exempt from application of the new rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Seth B. Carkin, for the last thirteen years president of the Packard Commercial School, 253 Lexington Avenue, died suddenly yesterday in Preston, Ont., according to word received here last night. He was in his fifty-third year.
The Pirates bowed in defeat for the second time this season today, losing to the Cardinals, 5 to 3, and dropping into secondd place in the National League race.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Debevoise entertained with a dinner last night at one of the series of "natural science evenings" being given at the American Museum of Natural History in the interest of the ten-year development program of the institution.

The management' of the Hotel McAlpin will be taken over on May by the Knott Hotels Corporation, it was learned yesterday. John J. Woelfle, who has acted as general manager of the property since 1932, will continue in that capacity, the Knott interests announced.
Harold B Butler informed the governing body of the International Labor Organization this morning of his desire to relinquish the post of director toward the end of the year.

A strike of operating employes of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, serving some 200,000 commuters between New York and New Jersey, which was to have gone into effect at 5 A. M. today, was averted shortly before 4 o'clock this morning when the company and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, which had called the strike, reached an agreement.

Hunter Estates, Inc., Jack Ferman, president, resold to the Roosevelt Central Realty Corporation of 260 East 161st Street, New York City, the five-story, thirty-family brick flat at 531-537 Thirty-fourth Street southeast, corner of Roosevelt Street, Union City.

The Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union's newest honorary member, John Golden, the producer, has donated $500 to the union as a loan fund for members in temporary distress, it was announced yesterday.

Louis Palermo, 33 years old, known - in the underworld as "Shorty the Wop," pleaded guilty in General Sessions Court yesterday to a first-degree assault charge in a shooting linked to a gang feud in 1935 that reached a climax with the murder of Arthur Flegenheimer (Dutch Schultz) of the beer and policy rackets.

The Ball of Tomorrow, first large entertainment to be presented on the site of the New York World's Fair, will take place in the Business Administration Building on the fair grounds tonight, the eve of the fair's elaborately planned preview.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New. York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:
Blyth Co. Inc., headed the successful banking group yesterday in the purchase of $3,000,000 of relief, public works, general improvement and land purchase bonds of Nassau
FIGHTING FOOLS, by James E. Edmonds. (Appleton - Century, $2.50). A plea for American preparedness. FLATTERY'S FOAL, by Peter Shiraeff. (Knopf, $2.50). A novel about horses and horsemen.
Lumber production declined last week, against a rising seasonal factor, and the index dropped to 57.2 from 58.6. For the week ended April 24, 1937, the figure was 84.4.
The text of the address delivered last night by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey at the dinner of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association follows:

Mrs. Charles P. Bispham and Mrs. Charles L. Hulswit the Rockland County (N. Y.) housewives who have started a " woman's rebellion" against government spending, outlined their movement to a sympathetic audience of 200 women at a meeting of the "S. O. S." (Save Our System) meeting here this afternoon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of Arthur A. Ballantine and the editorial in THE TIMES of April 24 may help to bring to a focus in the public mind the economic distinction between capital and the. consumption expenditures.

Mrs. Gertrude Ross Grant, for many years active in women's clubs in Montclair, N. J., and wife of Robert L. Grant of the investment firm of Charles Pratt Co., died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital after an illness of two months. She was 50 years old.

The "Deutschland-Lied," like the Horst Wessel song, the German national anthem, has been lengthened by an "official" fourth verse, glorifying Austria's union with the Reich, it was disclosed here yesterday. It reads in translation as follows:
The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended April 27 Were announced today: COLONEL Moses, E. P., San Diego, Calif., to advanced course, Naval War College, Newport, R. I., June 1.

Tomorrow is the last day on which real estate taxes for the first half of the year may be paid without penalty, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, warned yesterday. The penalty for late payments will be at the rate of 7 per cent per annum, starting on Sunday.
A dark-horse contender for the Kentucky. Derby at Churchill Downs May 7 developed here today when Elooto, from the Blue Ridge Stable, ran a mile in 1:38 4-5.
A fifty-year weather record toppled yesterday at 3:10 P. M. when the official city thermometers reached 85 degrees, marking the hottest April 28 in Weather Bureau history.

It's not only the temperature-it;s the question whether or not shorts shall be permitted on the public streets, and bathing, suits without tops on the public beaches. When this issue arises we can confidently predict that Memorial Day will arrive in about a month and the Fourth of July five weeks after that.

The hold-up of a clothing store this morning resulted in the death of two gangsters and the wounding of the proprietor. The assailants entered the store of Alexander Ayub when he was opening for the day's business.

The board of directors and nominating committee of the National Automobile Dealers Association this afternoon re-elected the present officers and directors for an interim period of perhaps six months,

In pursuit of a pigeon that had alighted on the ten-foot fence surrounding the Central Park Reservoir about 7:15 P. M. yesterday, James Holden, 9 years old, of 749 Columbus Avenue, climbed the fence at a point near West Ninetythird Street, lost his balance,

Francis L. Kraus, Hobart College athletic director, announced today the appointment of John E. (Bing) Miller, former assistant to John F. (Chick) Meehan at Manhattan College, as assistant football coach at Hobart.

Brig. Gen. Walter C. Sweeney, commander of the Sixth Infantry Brigade at Fort Douglas, Utah, who was designated recently for promotion to major general, was assigned by the War Department today to command the Third Division with headquarters at Fort Lewis, Wash.

A battle over reunion of Northern and Southern Methodists, split in 1844 by slavery, opened today with disagreement among Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, meeting here to consider merger with other groups in the denomination.

During the week ended April-27 member bank reserve balances increased $114,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $6,000,000 in money in circulation, $107,000;000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $5,000,000 in non-member .deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and increases of $3,000,000 in reserve bank credit,

Reorganization Petitions WINDBOR LAMP MANUFACTURING CO., INC., 6-8 W. 18th St.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Baukruptcy Law, lifting liabilities of $18,500 and assets of $21,286. Petitions Filed--Against LOUIS LINDENBAUM, as Lindy's Mattress and Bedding Co., 2,018 3d Ave., by Charles Comiter Co. for $175: Alan Dick, $500: David Raider Son. Inc., $196.
Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers, "challenged" Henry Ford today to discuss with him the latter's statement that Ford employes were "not interested" in unionism.
M. W. Clement was the highestpaid railroad president -in the country in 1937, according to figures the Pennsylvania Railroad reported yesterday to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Awards of seven gold honor medals and two certificates for heroism to nine Boy Scouts who saved the lives of others were announced last night by Daniel Carter Beard, chairman of the Boy Scouts of America. The awards were made by the national court of honor of the Scouts.

Borough President Harvey of I Queens is suing the city for $2,500 pay which he claims is due to him for deductions from July to December last year after expiration of the emergency law under which citywide pay cuts were made.

A form of government censorship of broadcasting, "all the more severe because it is undefined," threatens the conduct of the radio industry under private auspices, David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, declared yesterday in a nation-wide broadcast.

Coddington Ave. 3,017, dwelling, 26,1x67.6 irreg; Home Owners Loan Corp against Francesco Larocca; due, $7.261; to plaintiff for $500. By HENRY G. WALTEMADE White Plains Rd, 2,168-72, 100x100; Frank L. Well et al, trustees, against Golran Realty Corp: due, $142,219: to plaintiff for $1.000.

Tonight's major events: Thomas Negro Composers Study Group, Town Hall; "Samson and Delilah," concert version, Federal Music Theatre. Claudio Frigerio and Carmela Ponselle, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera Association;

The marriage of Miss Mary Anne West, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Winfree West of Maplewood, to Robert Nelson Davie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Davie of. Norfolk, Va., will take place the evening of May 27 in Prospect Presbyterian Church here.

Lowell Mellett, former editor of The Washington Daily News and chief of the Scripps-Howard. Newspaper Alliance, was appointed by President Roosevelt today as director of the National Emergency Council. Mr. Mellett succeeds Frank Walker of New York, as head of the council, of which Eugene Leggett has been acting director for several years.

A proposal which would permit municipal or Federal officials to run for legislative offices without resigning their jobs will be introduced Monday night at the Constitutional Convention by Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat, Republican delegate at large.
Executives of the 142 major railroads of the country will meet here tomorrow morning to consider an emergency program for meeting their pressing financial problems.

Mrs. Marjorie Howard Mears of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Edward Howard, was married yesterday morning to Francis Stillman Hyde of Watertown, Conn., in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.

Beekman St, 28, 21.8x85.2; Helen K. Fash, Elizabeth W. Gardner, Alice H. Ripley and Alexander C. Postley to Charles H. Hastings, 333 Madison Ave. (The executors of the will of Frank B. Highet quitclaim) ($31).

Thomas J. Boyle, until his retirement in 1930 principal of Junior High School 69 at 125 West Fifty-. fourth Street and president of the Junior High School Teachers Association, died yesterday at his home, 146-25 Thirty-fifth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, after a short illness. His age was 77..

Prices of wheat fluctuated erratically today within a range of 1 cent a bushel. They declined early with the May selling at a new low for the season, but rallied later on firm Liverpool cables and strength at Winnipeg, only to ease again toward the close.
Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, New Fla., who defeated Bobby Riggs at Chattanooga Tuesday, moved successfully through the third round the Hot Springs Spring invitation tennis tournament today.

Dr. Robert Woodhouse Fowler, for forty-two years connected with publie health work in New York, died yesterday at his home, 118-02 Eighty-fourth Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, after a six weeks' illness, at the age of 64.

Methodist clergymen and laymen were told today that the "dove of peace" will not "nest on the point of a bristling bayonet." The combined annual report of district superintendents, read at the annual session of the Wyoming Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, said:

The Merritt Parkway grand jury, reporting to Judge Kenneth Wynne in the Superior Court this afternoon, returned several secret indictments and recommended the immediate removal from office of John A. MacDonald, State Highway Commissioner.

Mrs. William Henry Hays, elected yesterday president of the Women's National Republican Club, called upon the women of the nation to unite to end the New Deal and elect a Republican President in 1940. The election and annual meeting were held at the clubhouse, 3 West Fiftyfirst Street.

Net international payments by the United States on trade and service accounts in 1937, on the basis of preliminary data, amounted to only $49,000,000, compared with $160,000,000 in 1936, according to the annual studies of international payments by Dr. Amos E. Taylor, made public today by Secretary of Commerce Roper.

Three hundred airplanes could turn the tide in the Spanish war and rescue Loyalist Spain, according to General Santiago J. Philemore of Mexico, who is in Paris after collaborating with the Madrid and Barcelona defendera for over a year.

Robert Lax of Olean, N. Y., a senior in Columbia College, has won first prize in the 1938 poetry contest of the college's Boar's Head Society, it was announced last night at the annual poetry reading of the group in John Jay Hall.

The Annalist index of wholesale commodity prices dropped on Wednesday to 80.3, the lowest point since June 2, 1936. A week before it was 80.6 and a year ago it stood at 94.1. A new decline of seventenths of a point, the Annalist said, would send commodity prices through the support points of 1985-36 and- into the lowest territory since the latter part of 1984.
As a Summer resident of Redding, Conn., Jascha Heifetz will appear tomorrow evening at the Norwalk (Conn.) High School Auditorium in a recital for the benefit of the Saugatuck Valley Association.

Joseph Buerckel, Reich Commissioner for Austria, is taking energetic action to halt violent anti-Semitism by certain groups in Vienna who are described officially by Nazis as "elements which do not belong to the party."

New orders for structural steel equipment placed in March totaled 83,977- gross tons, the best since December, compared to 54,996 tons in February, to 79,874 tons in January, and to 206,321 tons in March, 1937.

The Rev. Charles C. J. Carpenter, rector of Birmingham's Church of the Advent, early today was elected Bishop of the Alabama diocese of the Episcopal church. He received a majority of lay and clerical votes over seven others also nominated to succeed the late Bishop W. G. McDowell.

Positive proof that Paul Redfern, United States aviator lost ten years ago on a flight over South America, had crashed and died was held tonight by Theodore J. Waldeck, New York sportsman who led an expedition into the hinterland of British Guiana in search of the long missing flier.

Warren Wright's Bull Lea broke the track record for one mile and a furlong at Keeneland today by two and three-fifths seconds to win the Blue Grass Stakes and gain the honor of being the "horse to beat" in the Kentucky Derby May 7.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows. the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Benjamin Geismar of the Essex House Hotel, salesman for Eagle Clothes, 79 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday at the Beth David Hospital at the age of 54. A native of Rochester, N. Y., Mr. Geismar had been connected with the clothing business for thirty years.
Importers' purchases of foreign next goods for Summer delivery have been the smallest in two years, according to executives of the larger trading houses.

Turpentine firm, 23 1/4c; sales, 75 barrels; receipt, 546 barrels; shipments, 761 barrels; stock, 31,296 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 154; receipts, 3,460 shipments, 2,642; stock, 84.130. Quote: B, $3.50; D, $3.75; E, $3.85; F, 4.50; G. H, $4.82 1/2; I, K, M, $4.85; N. $5.25; WG, $6.05; WW, X, $6.40.

Sir. Gerald Campbell, British consul general, expressed the hope that a trade treaty between England and the United States "may top off the recent fine achievementsof the English Prime Minister in accomplishing pacts with Italy and Ireland," in an address yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York Financial Advertisers Association of New York at the Lawyers Club.

The Rules Committee of the House of Representatives now has before it the question of deciding whether privilegedstatus shall be given to the revised Wage-and-Hour Bill. This measure, unlike its predecessors, imposes a single minimum standard on the whole country regardless of sectional consequences.

The New York University tennis team routed a metropolitan rival, City College, 8-1, yesterday on the Fleet Hollow Courts in the Bronx. The Beavers made their point on a default when Alter Milberg and Irving Storch failed to return to the courts after their singles triumphs to play Herbert Mescon and Kiaghan in the concluding doubles test.

Thomas W. Warner Jr. and Mrs. Jean Macdonald were married here tonight. Mr. Warner gave his age as 23 and his bride's as 24. His father, a manufacturer, was named defendant in a damage suit brought at Los Angeles by Mrs. Pearl Antibus, a private detective.

Retail authorities here expressed L marked concern yesterday regarding what was felt to be a "new definition of interstate commerce that may vitally affect retailers" in the powers granted the Secretary of Labor by the pending Wages and Hours Bill, which was before the Rules Committee of the House in Washington yesterday.

Henry Ford made a two-sentence speech to more than 1,500 newspaper men and their guests last night at the seventeenth annual dinner of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Action by the Board of Estimate to begin proceedings for recapture of the Culver Line of the B.'M. T., at an estimated total cost of $20,679,100, so that by Oct. 1, 1939, it may be operated as part of the city's.Independent Subway System, is recommended in a report submitted by the Board of Transportation and made public yesterday.
The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on 7,150,350 yards of textiles in two lots, as follows: DATED APRIL 28, TO BE OPENED MAY 6--For delivery July 8:

Grote St, (11-3100), s s, 100 ft w of Southern Blvd, 66x114; Samuel J. Joseph, referee, to East River Savings Bank. Bronx Ave, (16-4543), e s, 350 ft n of King St, 50x90; John I. Bradley Jr., to Gustave Talcsik, 2,918 Lurting Ave.

A complaint filed several weeks ago against Herman Waker, vice president and treasurer of the United American-Bosch Corporation, William Boedecker, American I sales manager of the corporation, and William Featherstone, metropolitan sales manager,

Henry Ford, whose determined industrial individualism has become to millions a symbol of American initiative, submitted yesterday to a mass interview by newspaper reporters in which he gave his belief that every man should be his own leader.

A residential landmark in the midtown section of Manhattan which figured for many years in the social and diplomatic life of the city will make way for a modern housing improvement when wreckers begin to demolish the former home of the late Chauncey M. Depew.

The Rev. J. F. Sollier, former pastor at Our Lady of Victories Church in Boston and founder in this country of the Marist Missionary Sisters, whose mother home is at Bedford, died today at the rectory of Our Lady of Pity Church in North Cambridge.
A successful "enemy" air raid on San Francisco despite opposition of defending forces was described in an official announcement as the fleet came home today from its war games in the Pacific.

In the case of Gerald M. Loeb et al., charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with manipulation of the stock of Auburn Automobile on the New York Stock Exchange, the commission has denied motions by the respondents for a further bill of particulars and examination before hearing of certain information obtained by the SEC in the course of its investigation.

S. N. Petchers heads a syndicate which has bought for investment the five-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 2,314 Crotona Avenue, the Bronx. There are forty-nine apartments in the building,

THERE was some scientific excitement the time they smashed the atom in the Princeton laboratory. It was a Princeton triumph of some kind. But up in Boston recently an Armenian pastry cook exploded a myth and Princeton, in the repercussion, was thrown for a loss. This requires a little explaining.

" It has been a long time since you could get a good sirloin steak for what it costs now," one meat dealer said the other day. "People should buy more of them." Although he failed to mention the rest of the "sizzling platter" family, or the juicy, tender roasts of beef that now are selling for so little, he could easily have done so.

America's Good-Will Union ceremonies commemorating the inauguration of George Washington at Washington statue in Wall Street, noon. Speakers: The Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, Frederick H. Cone, Rear Admiral Reginald R. Belknap.

Mrs. Murray Dodge the Benjamin Low Property on Broad Brook Rd, Bedford, Westchester: Geoffrey Platt, the Edward K. McCagg residence on Sarles St, Mt Kisco: Robert Jordan Jr., the Dr. Ransom Hooker Property at Bedford: T. Wilson Lloyd, for Mrs. William May her dwelling on Cantitoe Rd, Bedford: Beatrice L. Renwick, Inc, broker.

A sentence of thirty days in jail has been given to C. G. Muller, a prominent local horse owner, for attacking an American finish judge, Milton Horter, at the Juan Franco track after an eyelash finish was decided against his horse, Patsy Clifford.
Senorita Anita Lizana of Chile, American singles titleholder, was the victim of a major upset inthe British hard court tennis championship today.

The list of the Hamburg-American liner New York, due from the Channel ports today, includes Mr. and Mrs. Hans von Luttitz, Mr. and Mrs. Gottfried Priester, Dr. Hermann Karnbach, Mr. and Mrs. C. C. Moore, Reginald Barker, Miss Marion Ganter, Mr. and Mrs. A. R. Hauschel, Walter Philipps Lots and Miss Margaret D. Koopmann.

The Court of Errors and Appeals granted permission to the Newark City Commission today to appeal from a Supreme Court order setting aside the commission's action in assuming control of all municipal departments.

Secretary Morgenthau today described as "completely justified" the criticism of certain large cement manufacturers of the bid form prescribed by the Treasury's Procurement Division for taking the bids which the Treasury rejected within the past week.

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Bowman of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Eleanor Bowman, to Richard Wentworth Pentecost, son of Captain Ernest Harvey-Pentecost, Royal Navy, retired, and the late Mrs. Pentecost.

Great Britain moved today toward an annual vacation with pay for her millions of industrial workers. A special committee under the chairmanship of Lord Amulree unanimously recommended that emplayers grant at least a week's paid holiday annually to their help.

An ironclad defensive alliance between Great Britain and France became a reality in all but name tonight after seven hours of momentous discussions between the Prime Ministers and Foreign Ministers of the two countries.

Engineering construction work, as reflected in the contract awards for the current week, continues the recent tendency toward levels lower than in the corresponding period of 1937, according to The Engineering News-Record.
The war Department released the following orders today, dated April 27: BRIGADIER GENERAL Sweeney, W. C., Fort Douglas, Utah, to command Third Division, Fort Lewis, Wash., June 1.

The "Heartbreak House" that Mr. Shaw built some eighteen years ago will be open again tonight, this time at the Mercury Theatre, whose repertory it now joins. In its cast are Orson Welles (who has also staked it), Mady Christians,

The efforts of low-cost housing and slum clearance advocates to increase the United States Housing Authority's emergency "pump-priming" authorization above the $300,000,000 requested by President Roosevelt were challenged today by Chairman Woodrum, of an appropriation subcommittee.

Germans in Poland have their Konrad Henlein in the person of Senator Kurt von Hasbach, a former officer in the Imperial Prussian Guard, and a landowner In Pomorze Province who is seeking to unite all German organizations in Poland under his leadership in a single party with a National Socialist program.

National Music Week will be celebrated in this city from next Sunday through May 7, with a large number of highly varied programs. The great diversity in the offerings is in line with the basic purpose of Music Week, namely, "to stimulate the desire for variety of activity which will increase the public's enjoyment of music;
J. P. Morgan was on an airplane flight from his estate here to New Haven, Conn., and back, today, it was learned. It is believed to have been the first trip by air he has ever made.

Harold Kingsmill, vice president of the Cerro de Pasco Copper Corporation of Lima, Peru, has leased an apartment in the building under reconstruction at 320-30 Park Avenue after longdistance negotiations with Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted the application of St. Anthony Gold Mines, Ltd., to withdraw its $1 par value common stock from listing and registration on the New York Curb Exchange.
The Albert Goldman Community Chest will open its second annual appeal for funds on Sunday to about 17,000 employes of the New York Postoffice in Manhattan and the Bronx.

" That's Life," the annual New York University Varsity Show, will be presented tonight at the Royal Windsor, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street. More than fifty men and women students of the University's Washington Square College, School of Education and School of Commerce, will take part in the production, a musical satire on picture magazines and their coverage of current world events.
Buddy Lewis's bat and Wes Ferrell's strong right arm combined to give the Senators their fourth straight victory over the Athletics today,- 7 to 2, before a ladies' day crowd of 9,100.

Hedda Hopper, in Hotel Savoy-Plaza. Charlotte Smith and Dorothy Gardner, also Victor Andrews, in 355 E 86th St; Duff Conger, Inc, brokers. Mrs. Mary I. Nicholson. In 1,045 Park Ave; Alfries Realty Corp. agent.

The Queensboro Corporation has sold, through George Campbell Updike and Frank J. Haas, acting as co-brokers, a plot 12 by 95 feet on the southeast corner of Thirty-seventh (Polk) Avenue and Seventythird Street, Jackson Heights,

Unemployment decreased slightly in March, according to the monthly report of the National Industrial Conference Board. The number of unemployed persons for the month was estimated at 10,408,000, a drop of 142,000 from the 10,550,000 reported for February.

Largely due to the heavy transactions reported by New York, which showed, the first increase since the week of Oct. 20, 1937, total bank clearings for the current week rose sharply from the preceding week, but were -smaller than the corresponding period last year for the twenty-fourth consecutive time.

Norah Hoult, Irish novelist from Dublin, has written her fifth book. It is called "Coming From the Fair" and Covici, Friede will publish it on May 20. It is a novel of life in Dublin from 1908 to 1933.

Magistrate Jacob Eilperin in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, refused yesterday to send a defendant to the Kings County Hospital for a mental examination because he did "not think the psychiatric division of the hospital is functioning properly."
Wall Street is beginning to realize that the name of the New York Stock Exchange's acting president is possibly of more immediate importance than that of its first paid president.

The nine major private agencies concerned with family welfare work in this city served 36,150 families, including 127,300 men, women and children, last year, the family service section of the Welfare Council informed the Greater New York Fund yesterday.

Scientific studies of the electric eel, the living "dynamo" said to 'generate power strong enough to kill a horse, provide a large-scale model for the study of the minute electrical impulses involved in the nervous activity of all animals, including man, a meeting tonight of the International Scientific Radio Union.

An analysis as to quantity, quality and price of construction covering the model home now on exhibition at Fifth and Lowel Streets, New Hyde Park, L. I., will be available at the home and at the Long Island National Home Show,

Major T. J. Oakley Rhinelander gave a birthday dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis in honor of his granddaughter, Miss Le Brun Rhinelander. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Mr. and Mrs. Huntington Hartford, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sanford Jr., Mr. and Mrs. H. Whitfield Carhart Jr., the Misses Virginia French, Mimi Villa, Lesley Bogert and Peggy Stevenson;

Max Butcher came back to the fold in good standing yesterday, and though all he got out of the Dodgers 6-3 victory over the floundering Phillies was a slap on the back, a handshake from his boss and possibly the glow of satisfaction that may come of doing a good deed, he probably welcomed these more than credit for the victory.

United line, but States Attorney John J. Quinn verified today report that evidence would be presented to the Federal grand jury in Newark next Tuesday pertaining to a charge by the American Civil Liberties Union that its mail had been tampered with in Jersey City last Winter during the height of its controversy with Mayor Frank Hague.
The Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is investigating whether the Weymouth fisherman who killed a monster shark Monday with his pocketknife should be hailed into court.

State home relief rolls were cut by 6,067 between March 1 and April 1, according to figures made public today by David C. Adie, commissioner of the State Welfare Department, who declared that the reduction indicated a definite upswing from the recession.

The State Labor Department plans extension of unemployment insurance to 1,000,000 workers in small businesses as soon as a practicable system of administration can be devised for presentation to the Legislature, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews disclosed yesterday.

The Rev. David Garrett Smith, for forty-five years a Presbyterian minister, died in his home at Holland Patent yesterday at the age of 73. He retired from his last charge, at Southampton, L. I., a year ago.
Because it permitted bingo games, yesterday from the premises at 2,661 Third Avenue, which it has occupied since it was chartered in November, 1887.

None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low position for the year, but the ratio of reserve at the New York bank was at the high point of the year to date.

While the dollar value of sales on all registered securities exchanges in March amounted to $1,023,667,334, an increase of 28.9 per cent over February, the total was more than 70 per cent below March, 1937, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Speeches on the freedom of the press are apt to be a little vague and virtuously declamatory. John Peter Zenger's acquittal, Jefferson's pardon of the persons convicted under the Alien and Sedition Laws, are piously commemorated.

Growing resentment among Czechs against the Nazi threat of the Henlein movement and a fear that Premier Milan Hodza's Government is making too many concessions found expression today in the distribution of many thousands of leaflets at the Charles University here and at factories and offices, demanding a "strong democratic government."

Investments in direct and fully guaranteed obligations of the United States by the 5,256 active national banks throughout the country, and in Alaska, Hawaii and the Virgin Islands on March 7, the date of the recent call for statements of condition, amounted to $8,092,162,000.

Like a diary of events more than 2,000 years ago, some 1,200 coins that old were placed on exhibition yesterday for a preview by experts in the hall of the American Numismatic Society, Broadway at 156th Street.
Terming as "reprehensible" parents or educators who do not teach children the facts of motherhood, Dr. Howard W. Haggard, Professor- of Applied Physiology at Yale University,

Net profit of the United Aircratt Corporation for the March quarter was $1,072,298 after taxes, depreciation, provision for minority interest of profits of subsidiary company and other charges. No provision was made, however, for Federal surtax on undistributed income.
David H. Haughey, formerly a partner of Farr Co., has become a general partner of Lawrence Turnure Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

Business activity in the Pittsburgh district registered a further decrease in the week ended April 23, according to the bureau of business research, University, of Pittsburgh. The bureau's weekly index fell from 65.2 per cent of the 1923-25 average in the week ended April 16 to 63.8 last week.

Robert Caterson, 78 years old, of 132 West Second Street, here, a tombstone maker, was found dead in his place of business at 64 South Fifth Avenue, Mount Vernon. Near his body police found notes indicating despondency over the fact that the business which he founded fortythree years ago was to be sold by the marshal.

Queen Elizabeth's 20-year-old niece, Miss Anne Ferelith Bowes-Lyon, was married to Viscount Anson here today. The Queen and the Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret Rose attended the white and silver wedding at St. Margaret's Church, Westminster, close to Westminster Abbey.

American newspapers and especially those which do not support the New Deal policies of the Roosevelt Administration were assailed in the Senate late this afternoon by Senator Minton of Indiana, a friend and supporter of the President.

Governor Moore signed today the bill making Saturdays in July and August legal holidays for banking purposes. The law will give bank employes a full day off instead of the customary half day during those two months.
The veteran George Lott fell today before the steady play of Jan Kozeluh in the feature match of the Greenbrier open tennis tournament's quarterfinal round. The score was 6-4, 2-6, 7-9, 6-2, 6-2.
James Fitzgerald, retired police lieutenant, died of heart disease early yesterday in his home, 153-49 Eighty-ninth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens. He was 64 years old.
Blasting three home runs, the Bears maintained their place on top of the International League by defeating Montreal, 4 to 2, today.
While awaiting decision on Maude Adams, Selznick-International has engaged Billie Burke for the role of Mrs. Carleton in "The Young in Heart" based upon I. A. R. Wylie's "The Gay Banditti."

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation earned 53 per cent of its quarterly preferred dividend requirements of $1,867,774 in the first quarter of 1938, it was announced yesterday after a meeting of the directors. The net income after all deductions was $994,908, compared with $4,253,329 in the fourth quarter of 1937 and with $8,293,833 in the first quarter a year ago.

The Royal Bermuda Yacht Club's Spring regatta ended today with the last race for the Cubitt Cup, in which the Bermudians subdued the American fleet of six-meter craft, 21 1/4 points to 15, giving them a total point score of 56 1/4 to 51 1/2 for the series.

Operations of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana were "in the black" for the first quarter, although; profit was less than that in the corresponding period in 1937, Edward G. Seubert, president, said today before the annual stockholders' meeting in Whiting, Ind.

Delegates from sixteen Eastern universities and colleges will meet on the campus tomorrow and Saturday in the first Eastern Intercollegiate Republican Club conference arranged by the Stephen K. Little Republican Club of Princeton.

The Interstate Commerce Commission should find that New England Greyhound Lines, Inc., has insufficient capital assets to justify granting of its application to acquire certain equipment and operating rights of the New England Transportation Company and two subsidiary lines, Frank A. Clifford, examiner of the Bureau of Motor Carriers, said today in a report recommended for adoption by the commission.
Jimmy Caras led Andrew Ponzi, 880 to 716, at the end of yesterday's play in the 1,000-point world pocket billiard challenge match at the Strand Academy.

At the suggestion of some of the registered utility holding companies, among them United Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted a new rule under which holding companies and their subsidiaries may submit for its approval investment programs covering both utility and non-utility securities which they would be permitted to acquire with idle surplus funds.
Senator Wheeler of Montana said today that "although many people seem to think the President will run for a third term, I can't conceive of any man doing it or winning if he tried."

Premier. Hepburn declared today that a judicial investigation of the affairs of the Dionne quintuplets was unwarranted and that none would be made. Oliva Dionne, father of the five little girls, requested an inquiry last week through Henri St. Jacques, an Ottawa lawyer.

Department store sales last week, as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank, turned below last year again following the Easter buying. The week's volume for St. Louis was 23.7 per cent below last year and for the district they were 23.6 per cent below.

The fifteen-story apartment house at 310-18 West Seventy-second Street was sold to the Brooklyn Trust Company, the plaintiff, as trustee, on a bid of $1,000 at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.
In recognition of his bravery in saving the life of a horse during the- recent stable fire at 238 Cherry Street in which more than 100 animals were -burned to death,

Holding that organized labor as well as employers must respect reasonable contracts, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals today denied a petition of the National Labor Relations Board to force the Columbian Enameling and Stamping Company of Terre Haute, Ind., to re-employ 250 workers discharged during a strike in March. 1935.

The new variety program which started yesterday at Loew's State Theatre is headed by Buddy Rogers, conducting his orchestra. His company also includes a large aggregation of performers. Among them are Marvel Maxwell, Jack Douglas, Frank Payne, Bob Hannon, the Three Nonchalants, Linda Moody and Bob Du Pont.

Mrs. Caroline Knox Kimball of this city and Rumson, N. J., widow of Dr. Reuel Baker Kimball of New York, was married yesterday noon at her home here, 142 East Seventyfirst Street, to Paul Harrison of Montclair, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John Gass, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, this city.

The general level of wholesale prices remained steady in the week ended on April 23, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, continued at 78.6, the same as on April 16, compared with 87.5 on April 24, 1937.

The marriage of Miss Marie Gavin, daughter of John H. Gavin, Surrogate of Hudson County, and Mrs. Gavin of this city, to James Bowen Jr. also of Jersey City, took place here this morning in St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. John Farrell performed the ceremony.
William Aitken of Toronto, a nephew of Lord Beaverbrook and son of J. M. Aitken, married Miss Penelope Maffey today in St. Peter's Church, Eaton Square, by the Rev. Arthur Fuller.

A writer of nearly 2,000 published poems in the course of thirty years has been selected as "The American Mother of 1938," it was announced last- night by the Mother's Day Committee of the Golden Rule Foundation, 60 East Forty-second Street.

President Roosevelt today acted to abolish the former Austrian immigration quota and to merge it with the German, thus taking one more step in the de facto recognition of Austro-German Anschluss. The combined quota precisely equals the sum of the two.
With the exception of heavy rain at a few stations in Texas, weather in the Cotton Belt was the most favorable this season and prices on the Cotton Exchange lost 8 to 9 points yesterday.

PAUL DE KRUIF'S most famous collaborator has just returned to the ivory tower where he wrote his last novel. Mr. de Kruif remains among the undefeated. His newest book, "The Fight for Life,"* is a stirring and heart-warming narrative of great campaigns that are still being fought in the heat of the day.

A House elections committee voted today to unseat Representative Jenks, Republican, of New Hampshire, whose election was contested by Alphonse Roy, Manchester, N. H., Democratic nominee for the House in the last election.
Louis Ludington, Genesee County Welfare Director, said today that he was advising all unemployed automobile workers with less than two years' seniority in their plants to' leave Flint.

The mystery Surrounding the system by which Colonel Bill Terry continues to attain amazing results in the National League was still beyond solution, so far as Professor Casey Stengel and his Bees were concerned, on this afternoon of midsummer heat in the Hub.

The whale boat Surprise, missing since yesterday, and hunted by two cruisers, returned safely to port here late this morning. The crew, all well, reported that they had harpooned a whale at 9:30 A. M. yesterday and were towed until 4 P. M. during which time they unsuccessfully attempted to bomb the whale.

The report of the Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries, not including those in receivership, for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after operating expenses taxes and fixed charges,

MANHATTAN BARDON, ISABELLE (June 16, 1937). Gross assets, $753; net a deficit. Hooker I Coggeshall, attorney, 170 Broadway. CAMPBELL, JOHN J. (March 23, 1934). Gross assets, $162,209; net, $23,436. To Josephine B. Campbell, widow. and Ruth Campbell, Patricia M. Marsh. Marie C. Sinclaire and John J. Campbell Jr., children, specific bequests and inetrests in residuary income. Chief assets, real estate, $124,600. Jesse Watson.

Max Schmeling is certain to repeat his victory over Joe Louis in their battle at the Yankee Stadium June 22, in the opinion of Joe Jacobs, his American manager, and Ste ?? Dudas, latest knockout victim of Schmeling. This was disclosed yesterday on the arrival of Jacobs from Germany on-the North German Lloyd liner Columbus.

Under the auspices of the American Friends of Russian Children in Exile, a supper dance was given last night at Montparnasse. Mr. and Mrs. Serge Jurenev were among those entertaining, their guests including Grand Duchess Marie and Princess Nina.

The first exhibition by members of the New Hudson River Group of Painters and Sculptors will open on Sunday at-the Southern Colonial House, River Road, Scarboroughon-Hudson, and will continue for one week.

In the presence of the largest and most distinguished gathering of the clergy this city has ever seen, the Most Rev. Thomas Henry Mc. Laughlin became today the first Bishop of the newly established Roman Catholic Diocese of Paterson.

Before 5,000 cheering home folk and a sizable group of visitors from other States, the La Follettes, "young Phil" and "Bob," sons of a bolter of an earlier day, unfurled a new political banner here tonight and promised to fight -for a new economic order, based on tried and true methods of old-time Americanism.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in this city rose $24,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $7,705,000,000, according to the condition statement of the banks, issued yesterday.

President Roosevelt's coming message to Congress on monopolistic practices will recommend expanded Federal powers to end price-fixing, despite previous indications in official sources that he would only state the problem and suggest an intensive Congressional study of alternative remedies.
A proposed amendment to the bylaws of the New York State Medical Society, submitted to its House of Delegates for action, has resulted in much discussion and considerable opposition medical circles.

Premier Edouard Daladier rolls his ownand it has got to be his own. As he left the French Embassy this morning for Downing Street he discovered he had run out of his supply of the French brand of tobacco he nolls into cigarettes; to be without it might prejudice the success of the vital meetings with British statesmen.

Administration support for legislation extending Home Owners Loan Corportion mortgages to twenty-five years from fifteen years, as at present, and a reduction in its interest rates from 5 to 3 1/2 per cent was sought today by Mayor Edward T.

Discussion and debate on the items to be supported by the National League of Women Voters during the ensuing two years led to relatively few changes in the organization's program, in its convention here today

Through the purchase of two plots St from the Dime Savings Bank and Hermina Sanders, the G R Oprating Corporation has assembled a parcel 120 by 100 feet on the northwest corner of Fifteenth Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street,

Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, world champion, virtually clinched the honors in the Easter congress of the Kent County Chess Association at the Grand Hotel, Cliftonville, today by capturing his eighth and semi-final round match. He defeated the women's titleholder, Miss Vera Menchik of Czechoslovakia, retaining first place by a one-point margin.

Mrs. Abbeline C. Harriss, wife of Robert M. Harriss of the cotton brokerage firm of Harriss Vose, 60 Beaver Street, died yesterday afternoon at her home, 160 Greenway North, Forest Hills, L. I., after a long illness.

Demand for wool goods this week continued spotty, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Some mills booked a satisfactory amount of business, while others made no progress in their efforts to obtain orders and start up machinery for Fall.
Charles J. Margiotti, ousted yesterday as Attorney General of Pennsylvania, accused Governor Earle tonight of trying to "buy off" his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes. in francs:

Consolidation of five national organizations, now active in relief work for China, into a central body to be known as the United Council for Civilian Relief In, China was announced yesterday by Theodore Roosevelt, national chairman of the new council.
Elwyn Gibbon, flier, of Seattle, Wash., was released from jail today by Japanese police who had detained him six days for questioning in connection with his activities with the Chinese are force.

Senator La Follette of Wisconsin charged in the Senate today that the $1,156,000,000 naval expansion bill was designed to implement the foreign policy of the Roosevelt Administration and that the "final responsibility" for it lay with the President.
Barcelona at last is beginning to feel the hardships of war which besieged Madrid has known for a year and a half. The pinch has come with weeks of war on Catalonia's border.

Dr. R. Fait McKenzie, sculptor, physician and J. William Wright research professor of physical education at the University of Pennsylvania, died of heart disease tonight at his home here. He was 70 years old.

Both as a warning and as a guide to business, the Department of Justice henceforth will give full publicity to its attitude toward and policies upon business practices forming the basis of anti-trust prosecutions, Thurman W. Arnold, newly appointed assistant attorney general, disclosed last night in an address.

Miss Barbara MacGay Leggett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Cox Leggett of 402 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, and Redding Ridge. Conn., has completed the plans for her marriage on June 3-to Dr. Otto Emile Billo of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Billo of Glen Ridge, N. J.
Viscount Rothermere, writing in The Daily Mail a few days after his return from-the United States, says:
The German, Supreme Court ruled today that divorces obtained abroad by temporary domicile are illegal. Many Germans have gone to Latvia to obtain divorces refused in Germany.

The German-American, Bund announced here yesterday that its meetings, devoted to the propagatiori of Nazi philosophy in America, no longer will be decorated with the German national flag-the black swastika in a white lozenge on a field. of red, made official by Chancellor Hitler.
Revised gas rate schedules, adding May and October to the period during which the reduced "Summer rate" will be in effect, were filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission.
The French franc underwent another abrupt sinking spell yesterday as the conversations between, representatives of the British and French Governments began in London.

The Bach Society of New Jersey performed Bach's Mass in B minor tonight at the Mosque Theatre before approximately 3,000 persons. Many in attendance had journeyed to the concert from Bethlehem, Pa., where the work also is presented annually.

A double by George Myatt today climaxed a ninth-inning rally and gave the Jersey City Giants a 5-to-4 victory over Rochester in the second game of the series. It was the third straight victory for the Giants.

J. Arthur Hull of Bronxville has sold his seven-room dwelling at 23 Smith Avenue, White Plains, Westchester, to Edward Miller, owner of the Miller Dyeing and Cleaning Establishment of White Plains, through Chauncey B. Griffen, broker.

The question whether intercollegiate football, engaged in by State universities, is an essential function of the States or merely a commercial activity was asked of the Supreme Court, both by the Federal Government and the State of Georgia, in arguments today.

The National Distillers Products Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year a net profit of $1,445,223 after depreciation, Federal income taxes, interest and other charges.

The Commonwealth and Southern Corporation of New York has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application with respect to the company's organization and conduct of business as a subsidiary service unit of the registered holding company system of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation of Delaware.

William Kennedy, builder, died yesterday in his home at 18 Montgomery Place, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 72 years old. Mr. Kennedy was president of the William Kennedy Construction Company of Brooklyn, which erected many notable buildings.

Declaring that every WPA worker may vote as he pleases regardless of demands or threats by politicians, Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, said today that he would give this message to the 2,542,978 workers soon over a national radio hook-up.

One more important sign of a possible rapprochement between Government and business is the very conciliatory speech which Chairman William O. Douglas of the Securities and Exchange Commission has just delivered regarding the mutual attitude of the commission and the reformed Stock Exchange.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 26: LIEUTENANT COMMANDEERS Abbott, R. W., Navy Yard, New York, to the west Virginia as navigating officer, June 1.

Thirty senior members of the New York University varsity baseball, basketball, football and track teams were presented with special awards last night at a dinner held in the gymnasium of the New York Athletic Club. The affair was sponscored jointly by the N. Y. U. Board of Athletic Control and the university's Letter Club.

Franklin Henry Hooper, editor of the Encyclopedia Britannica for forty years, has retired to become editor emeritus of the 170-year-old publication. His retirement was announced last night at a dinner given in his honor by close friends and business associates at the University Club. E. H. Powell,

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, who for the last two years have been living at Long Barn, Sevenoaks, Kent, plan. to move at the end of May to the small island off the coast of Brittany that the flier recently purchased.

Marse Joe McCarthy shook up his Yankee batting order yesterday and the.Red Sox, getting the idea much too quickly, proceeded to shake up the Yankees.
