The Bostonians pounced on the offerings of Lefty Gomez with considerable relish and the New Yorkers found Lefty Grove something of a problem as the Sox made off with the ball game rather easily, 6 to 1.

A lecture yesterday on trading in metal futures, by Martin H. Wehncke, treasurer of the Commodity Exchange, was the final in a series of eleven conducted weekly since Feb. 17 under the auspices of the Commodity Club of New York and sponsored by six leading commodity exchanges in New York and Chicago.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operation of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before provisions for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.- Figures in many cases are subject to final adjustment:
Jules Siegfried, chairman of a research committee studying Franco-American relations, told the American Club today that the committee had found relations between the two countries difficult to study.

The flow of WPA workers into private jobs has enabled the WPA in this city to add 7.000 openings for home-relief recipients to the 20,000 new jobs created in the last two months by an expansion in the quota of the Federal work-relief agency. Lieut. Col. Brehon B.
Nature intended man to be seen and not heard, but, as usual, he had his own ideas on the subject. This is the opinion of Dr.

Demand for steer hinds and ribs and lamb continued fairly active. Trading in veal hindsaddles showed a tendency of slowing up at some points. Some fresh pork cuts were very active and others continued to move slowly. The lamb and fresh pork loin markets were slightly stronger,
Following is the text of the four resolutions adopted at yesterday's session of the American Newspaper Publishers Association's annual meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria:
The completion of the new Spuyten Duyvil channel for the Harlem River ship canal is another reminder of the rapid fashion in which the physical face of New York City is changing.

The American Association of Advertising Agencies has joined the list of associations and individual companies which are making efforts to explain the usefulness of advertising to the American people, it was announced yesterday.
Mrs. John Hugh Nolan of New York was elected president of the National Society, Daughters of the British Empire in the United States of America, at the convention of the society today.

Pensioned On their own applications: to take effect 12 midnight, April 30: PATROLMEN--Valentine Standing, 8th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 28, 1907. Joseph F. Horan, 22d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 22, 1896. Michael McGowan, 52d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sent. 29. 1905.
Among the administration attitudes toward business which many persons feel have tended to destroy confidence are certain Treasury practices in collecting taxes.

The raising of an emergency fund of $5,000,000 for Chinese civilian relief during the next year will be discussed by the Committee on Relief in China of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America at conferences next week, it was announced yesterday.

In an effort to stem the "rising tide of consumer resentment against advertising," the American Association of Advertising Agencies has started to establish a ConsumerAdvertiser Council, according to John Benson, president. Mr. Benson first outlined this plan at a closed session of the agency's annual convention in White Sulphur Springs last week.

The decisions taken in London are momentous. Seven weeks ago we were saying that the annexation of Austria, the first drive of Germany beyond her own borders, rang the curtain on the Europe the Great War created and trumpeted the overture for the next war. Whether the struggle to come
Edward Fuller, author, playwright and retired newspaper editor, died in Jefferson Hospital here today after an illness of several months. He was 77 years old.

Most foreign exchange rates held steady yesterday with trading at a reduced volume. The pound sterling held in a narrow range and closed unchanged at $4.98 3/4. The French franc sold at 3.06 cents, a loss of 1 3/8 points, while the guilder, belga and Swiss franc advanced, the latter 2 1/4 points.

Kho Sin Kie, Chinese Davis Cup player, beat Nigel Sharpe, British veteran, 7--5, 6--2, 6--4, in the semi-final round of the British hard court tennis championships today. Miss Peggy Scriven eliminated Miss Kay Stammers in an all-British women's semi-final, 6--2, 6--3.

Frank Pennink, defending titleholder, reached the final round of the English amateur golf championship today. After putting out E. H. Moss, 3 and 2, in the morning, Pennink won his semi-final round match from G.: Stretton-Cox, 7 and 6.

The marriage of Mrs. Hope Wilson Rasch, daughter of Mrs. Edward Conover Wilson of Jackson Heights, Queens, and the late Mr. Wilson, to John Arthur Bruner, also of Jackson Heights, son of Mrs. Albert M. Bruner of Bloomington, Ill., and the late Mr. Bruner, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

THERE was a discussion of triple plays in baseball and Manager Joe Cronin of the rich Red Sox was in on it deserved He knows how those things are done. He cooperated with James Emory Foxx in finishing off the Yankees with a triple play in the ninth inning the other day at the Stadium.

Lord Thomas has been appointed to handle the Schenley Red Label and Black Label whisky accounts, relinquished yesterday by Brown Tarcher, Inc. The latter agency also discontinued handling the Old Quaker account, for which no new agency has been named as yet. Brown Tarcher, however,

THE Scandinavians build novels as soundly as they build ships. At least that is the impression one gets from most of their novels that reach these shores. They have, these novels, a. depth and a full-roundedness--and a certitude about them that is admirable--and a way of going. on and on and on that is not necessarily a mark of enormous merit.

" It looks as if the executives are not satisfied with what they can get out of the government and now they are trying to get it from the workers," J. A. Phillips, president of the Order of Railway Conductors, declared today in commenting on the action of the American Association of Railroads to serve notice of a 15 per cent pay cut for all classes of railroad labor.

With reorders for Spring merchandise starting to slacken and little future buying evident, estimated wholesale volume this week dropped 3 to 20 per cent below the same period last year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., declared yesterday in its weekly review.

The Stuhler boys seem to be doing all right by themselves this year. Only a few days ago, Bob, 19-yearold amateur, and his brother, Frank, who is pro at the Idlewild Club, captured the honors in the Long Island P. G. A.'s opening event on the year's schedule for metropolitan district golfers.

Probably the largest mechanized procession that the city has ever seen will pass through sixteen miles of New York City streets today as the main feature of the preview of the World's Fair of 1939 opening a year from this date.

The fifty-first annual exhibition of student work, representing classes in all fields of art and craft endeavor at Pratt Institute, will open today to the public in the galleries of the International Building Radio City, instead of being held in the school galleries of the Brooklyn institution, as has been the custom in other. years. A preview and reception took place last evening.

Current loans by chartered banks in Canada on March 31 were $15,353,584 greater than at the end of February and $58,241,130 higher than on March 31, 1937, according to the monthly report to the Finance Minister, made public today.

Davega-City Radio, Inc., which was recently ordered by the New York State Labor Relations Board to reinstate two employes who had been discharged allegedly for union activities, filed suit yesterday in Federal court to enjoin the board, Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag, the Attorney General and Governor Lehman from enforcing provisions of the State Labor Relations Act.

L. F. Loree, who resigned as chairman of the Kansas City Southern Railway on Dec. 31, 1936, received a pension of $22,500 from the company in 1937, a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday.

The first official inspection of Bethlehem Steel Corporation's new consumer-goods facilities at Sparrows Point, Md., was held yesterday afternoon, when several hundred members of the Association of Iron and Steel Engineers visited the new wire, rod and bar mill.

Nine men, two of whom are awaiting trial in the so-called Secord-Vanderpoel mail-fraud case, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of port rigging the market in the sale of stock of the Hidalgo Gold Mines, Inc., which were allegedly pushed by C. G. Blackwell Co. in Denver, Col., in 1935 and in a branch office operated in this city at 42 Broadway.

From The Herald Tribune (Ind. Rep.) Let us pass over for the time being the political implications of Governor La Follette's program for a National Progressive party. Only time can say whether the practical results will be large or small.

The Dail Eireann this evening, after a day of dramatic debate, approved the pact of friendship with Great Britain without division. James Larkin, Dublin labor leader, alone dissented because the pact involved the compromise, as he called it, of a [Pound]10,000,000 payment to Britain.

Member trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on April 2 represented 16.88 per cent of the total volume, compared with 14.50 per cent in the previous week, when the percentage was the lowest since the Securities and Exchange Commission began the publication of such data in October, 1936.
Ackman Co. Inc. has arranged a first mortgage of $56,000 running five years, with interest at 4 1/2 per cent, for the 188 East 75th St Realty Corp on the six-story apartment at 188 E 75th St.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The volume of new bond financing this week dropped sharply to a total of $7,913,000, as compared with $76,048,500 in new issues placed on the market last week. During this week last year a total of $21,069,000 in new bonds were marketed.

The Rev. John J. Fagan, curate of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Pacific Street and Vanderbilt Avenue, Brooklyn, was killed yesterday when a light monoplane in which he was flying alone crashed at Floyd Bennett Field.
The House Rules Committee dealt a severe blow to the prospects of wages and hours legislation at this session by voting today, 8 to 6, against a rule by which the new bill could be voted upon.

Miss Marguerite Sykes, daughter of Mrs. Walter H. Sykes of 30 East Sixtieth Street and the late Mr. Sykes, was married to Walter P. Chrysler Jr. of 856 Fifth Av and Great Neck, L. I., yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The Rev. Dr. George P. T. Sargent, the rector, performed the ceremony.

" For sheer adventure and thrills the Russian Arctic flights easily took first place among the world's exploits in the air during 1937," according to the 1938 Aircraft Year Book published yesterday by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America. It is the twentieth annual edition of the aviation industry's reference and guide book. It was edited by Howard Mingos.

3d Av, 41, 23x70; Alfred E. Smith Jr. to David Schwartz, 107 6th Ave, Brooklyn; consideration $5,000, foreclosure; Same property, David Schwartz to Sunset Property Corp, 565 5th Ave, care A. J. Bernstein ($7.50).

A note in a whisky bottle washed ashore near here revived speculation today of the fate of the motorship Nunoca, hissing since July 4, 1936, when she sailed with twenty-two persons aboard from Grand Cayman Island for Tampa.

Edward M. King, in 2 Rochambeau Rd. Scarsdale, from Zenas Potter; Robert E. Farley Organization, broker. Charles H. Borne, in 21 Vanderbilt Rd. Scarsdale; Paul E. Stohel, in 180 Lyons Rd; Chauncey B. Griffen, broker.
Managemients of the 139 railroads voted here today to ask their 925,000 union employes to take a 15 per cent wage reduction, effective on July 1.

Drawing a distinction between orders placed here subject to acceptance outside the State and orders accepted here subject to filling from outside the State, the Appellate Division, in a four-to-one decision, ruled yesterday that Sears, Roebuck Co. was liable for New York City sales taxes on so-called "ship direct" sales in which the merchandise to fill an order is forwarded directly to the consumer from warehouses in New Jersey, Massachusetts or Pennsylvania.

The Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway increased equipment owned in 1937 for the first time in many years, the annual report showed yesterday. The company, which is in bankruptcy, inherited much old equipment when it was reorganized in 1920. It is controlled by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway.

The Columbian Enameling and Stamping Company of Terre Haute, Ind., employed 600 workers. Five hundred of these were eligible to become members in the A. F. of L. union at the plant, and of these about 485 belonged.

The North New York Congregational Church, East 143d Street near Willis Avenue, the Bronx, gave a reception in honor of its new pastor, the Rev. J. Charles Pelon, and his wife, last evening in the parish house.

Pierre C. Cartier was elected president of the Alliance Frangaise de New-York, 4 East Fifty-second Street, at-its annual meeting yesterday afternoon. James W. Gerard, William L. De Bost, Frederic R. Coudert Jr. and Pierre Claudel were named vice presidents; Pierre C.

MANHATTAN BEGGI, FRANK (March 21, 1938). Gross Assets, $12,008; net, $10,553. To nine children, $1,150 each. Chief assets, real estate, $8,800 Wallace A. Kroyer, attorney, 17 John St. BEVERLY, BELLE FREEBORN (Oct. 25, 1937). Gross assets, $16,239; net, $13,865.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 27: COMMANDER Bowman, D. O., Med. Corps, to duty at Naval Academy, when discharged from treatment, Naval Hospital, Washington, D. C.
Mgr. John C. McClary, chancellor of the Newark Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church, was appointed today vicar general of the new Archdiocese of Newark by Archbishop Thomas J. Walsh.

D. W. Brogan, author of "Government of the People," has accepted the editorship in chief of the Dictionary of National Biography for its next volume covering the period 1931 to 1940. The dictionary is under the supervision of the Oxford University Press.

In response to a plea that "a situation of grave and .serious moment exists in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania," the Dauphin County Court ordered a grand jury inquiry today . into Democratic primary campaign charges of bribery and coercion,

A new theory according to which the heavy electron found to constitute the major component of the cosmic rays at sea level also arises within the nucleus of the atom and supplies the cosmic force which holds the universe together,

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt arrived here today with a declarationn that recent criticism of her attitude on divorce must have resulted from a "misunderstanding," but she reiterated her stand that divorce was an accepted fact of American life.
A fiftymile barbed wire barrier to keep out armed Arab bands is to be constructed along the PalestineSyria frontier according to The Daily Telegraph.

Tonight's major events: Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall; American Committee for Birobidjan, benefit concert, Town Hall. The- second annual music. festival of "The Schools-on-the-Hill,"Riverdale-on-Hudson, will be held this evening at Fieldston School.

Edison Ave (18-5378), n w cor of Dudley Ave. 105x25: The Alwell Realty Co to Frank T. Warburton, trustee, 67 Lafayette P1, Greenwich, Conn.; mtge, $20,000. Belmont Ave (11-2945), w s, 95 ft n of 175th St, 49x105; Isaac Hellman to Isana Realty, Inc.
The Department of Commerce and those it serves will be lucky to have Colonel Richard C. Patterson Jr. as Assistant Secretary, a post to which the President yesterday named him.

Property of the Seneca Copper Corporation will be offered at public auction on May 4 to liquidate a receivership which began in 1931. The property includes 2,800 acres of mining land, tenements, power houses, plants, equipment, shops, and interests in copper mills and railroads.

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the Federal court in Brooklyn signed yesterday an order directing all creditors of the Prudence Company, Inc., to show cause before him on May 13 why $500,000 in cash held by the company should not be distributed.

G. F. Powell, British Social Credit expert, who came to Canada to advis the Alberta government and is serving a six-month jail term for publishing defamatory libel, was paroled today by Justice Minister Lapointe.

The New Jersey Women's Golf Association's first one-day tournament of the new season was won by Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, whose card of 39, 42-81 led home a large field of sixty-three players over the Echo Lake Country Club course today.

After he had read a prepared statement accusing District Attor ney Thomas E. Dewey of perse outing him, Harry Chancer, former president of the New York and Brooklyn Cloak and Suit Trucking Corporation, was sentenced yester

About 900 Sanitation Department employes whose names were dropped from a promotion list because they answered too many questions in a Civil Service examination were ordered restored yesterday by the Appellate Division.

That the La Follettes and their allies believe the time to be ripe for an open break with the Roosevelt Administration and an attempt to launch a new party is a fact of unmistakable political significance. They may be wrong in their appraisal of the present situation. They may be sharply disappointed

Supreme Court Justice Algeron I. Nova, who filed an affidavit in the Brooklyn Federal Court recently indicating that he owed a total of $381,000, was ordered-to pay $5,000 c annually instead of $2,500 of his $25,000 yearly salary to two of his creditors in a ruling handed down yesterday by Justice James T. Hal- F linan in the Brooklyn Supreme Court.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 29, unless specified: Norfolk to New York: J. F. Talbott, Texas, Barker, Manila, to Southern Philippines. Charleston, Puerto Cabezas, to LaCetha, Honduras.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions ROBIN REDBREAST HOSIERY CO., INC., operating chain of retail stores.--Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $534,878 and assets of $717,543. The corporation operates directly and through affiliated operating companies retail stores in Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland,

Your correspondent entered Lerida today. It's not very hard to do. All you have to do is keep your legs moving steadily and control a slight tickling sensation between your shoulder blades and the base of your neck as you cross the railway yard and come under machine-gun fire from a tower 500 yards away.
Receivers of the Wabash Railroad had authority today from United States District Judge Charles B. Davis to withhold payment of $847,275 in interest due May 1 on the road's first mortgage bonds.

Z. H. Rubenstein, managing editor of The Day, sent a telegram to Senator La Follette yesterday asking the significafice of the cross as the emblem of the new Progressive party, adding that as the editor of a Jewish newspaper he was very much interested.

Without comment, the Appellate Division affirmed yesterday a decision of Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin upholding the ouster of about 126 pushcart peddlers from stands along Ninth Avenue between Thirty-ninth and Forty-second Streets, in Paddy's Market. The court also vacated a
Representatives of many patriotic organizations, military and naval groups joined yesterday in commemorating the inauguration of George Washington.

The 2,000 peppercorns paid to the city as advance rental on Bowling Green for the next 2,000 years at the recent celebration of the historic little park's restoration have been duly audited by the Controller and are now in the safekeeping of the Museum of the City of New York, where they will soon be placed on display.

The final Kentucky Derby test for several widely discussed thoroughbreds will be applied this afternoon at Jamaica when a capacity crowd is expected to turn out for the $20,000 added Wood Memorial, which has attracted nine 3-year-olds

At a mass meeting here today 900 members of Local 118 of the United Automobile Workers of America, comprising employes of the Chevrolet and Fisher Body plants of the General Motors Corporation in North Tarrytown, authorized the local's executive board to conduct a strike vote if the international union consents.
Bob Feller wasn't the puzzle to the Browns that he was ten days ago, but his team-mate, the rookie third baseman, Ken Keltner, was quite a problem as the Indians won, 3 to 2.

The expectation among business men that the country will right itself through natural causes was attacked yesterday by Kenneth M. Goode, author of numerous advertising books, in an address before the advertising and marketing forum of the Advertising Club of New York.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today supplemented its control of the over-the-counter market by adopting a rule which made applicable to it and to the seven exempted Securities Exchanges provisions identical with those contained in Section 9 (a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, which declare unlawful certain manipulative practices.

Magistrate Anthony Savarese in Queens traffic court yesterday refused to permit withdrawal of a charge of leaving the scene of an accident against Prince Gerolamo Rospigliosi, 30 years old, of the Hotel Weylin, 40 East Fifty-fourth Street, Manhattan.

President Roosevelt nominated Richard C. Patterson Jr. of New York today to be an Assistant Secretary of Commerce to take the post vacated by Ernest G. Draper, recently appointed a member of the Federal Reserve Board.
Charles Whitney Tillinghast Barker, prominent in civic, philanthropic, educational and church circles here, died today after a short illness. He was 56 years old.
With favorable weather in almost all parts of the Belt, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined again yesterday to end with losses of 4 to 9 points.

When the coxswains in today's intercollegiate rowing races give the order to let their shells run at the close of the day's events, every major crew in the country, with the exception of Yale, will have felt its first taste of competition in the new season.

Former Police Lieutenant Charles P. Vosburgh, who retired on Sept. 16, 1937, when the rule for retirement of policemen above the age of 63 was enforced, died Thursday night at his home, 4,349 Barnes Avenue. the Bronx.

SECOND MILITARY AREA So much of Paragraph 5, Special Orders 54, dated April 22, 1938, as pertains to the following prospective graduates of.. the R. O. T. C., University of Alabama, University, Ala., is revoked: 2d Lt. Anton Lattal Jr., C.A.-Res., 735 Carson Ave., Perth Amboy, N. J.

A Federal grand jury, delivering what Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, described as the severest blow ever dealt to traffickers in marijuana, yesterday indicted sixteen alleged members of a, hempproducing and distributing ring that until recently operated in Minnesota, Iowa, Chicago and New York City.

Applicants for licenses to practice medicine in Puerto Rico must hereafter be American citizens, and not even the Board of' Medical Examiners may waive the required examination or grant courtesy licenses to foreigners, according to legislation that today awaits the Governor's signature. Foreigners, however, may obtain- licenses for medical research.

Dizzy Dean, for whom the Cubs paid $185,000 plus three players, returned to the "sore-arm brigade" today after starting his third game but Chicago defeated the Reds, 6 to 4, to sweep the two-game series.
A client of Hy. D. Agar, Inc., brokers, has purchased for investment the two four-story apartments at 47-29-31 Thirty-seventh Street, Sunnyside, Queens, from the Amalgamated Equities, Inc.

Hearing on the appeal from the conviction of James (Jeff) Burkitt, political opponent of Mayor Frank Hague, was postponed today by Common Pleas Judge Robert V. Kinkead here until next Monday afternoon at 2 o'clock.

Shifting of the American Henley rowing regatta from the Schuylkill River at Philadelphia, where it has been held for the last thirty-four years, to the Charles River basin on' May 14, was announced tonight by Forrester A. Clark, president of the Union Boat Club.

Dr. Robert R. Williams of New York was honored tonight by the Chicago chapter of the American Chemical Society, which awarded to him the Willard Gibbs Medal, given annually to the scientist "adjudged to have made an outstanding contribution to chemistry."

The Department of Commerce reported today that United States imports of Mexican silver in the week ended on April 22 were valued at $480,991. The shipments included 709,497 ounces of refined bullion and 426,843 ounces of ore and base bullion.

The National Press Club is getting ready for the first mobilization of the famous and far-flung Kentucky colonels. The occasion for this muster will be the annual outdoor soiree of the club, which also includes a baseball (sic) game between members of Congress and reporters.

Starting on Tuesday, retail trade on men's wear in other sections of the country started to improve steadily, out-of-town buyers visiting the local market reported yesterday. The warmer weather in many areas was given as the chief reason for the pick-up. In Southern and Pacific Coast regions,
Cotton-mill activity registered a greater than seasonal decline last week, and the index dropped to 83.7 from 87.7. For the week ended April 24. 1937, the figure was 134.5.

Home work will be prohibited after Monday in the artificial flower and feather industry, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reminded workers and employers yesterday. The "no homework" rule- was issued last March 11 and is the third such to be promulgated by the State Labor Department.

Most of the President's long-awaited message on monopoly unfortunately reads more like a general defiance of critics of his policies than a serious study of an unusually difficult economic problem. He seems to be saying, in effect: "My Administration had nothing to do with this depression.

The Treasury reported today that cash subscriptions for the offering of $200,000,000 of 3/4 per cent, eighteen-month notes of the Commodity Credit Corporation aggregated $1,839,000,000 and had been allotted 8 per cent, but not less than $1,000 on any one subscription.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 28. MAJOR GENERAL Gibbins, H., the Quartermaster General, one day's leave, April 30. COLONELS

During their stay in London, M. Daladier and M. Bonnet (French Premier and Foreign Minister) had a certain number of conversations with the Prime Minister (Chamberlain), Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs (Viscount Halifax) and other British Ministers, in the course of which they discussed the principal questions presently affecting the maintenance of peace in the spirit of mutual confidence which inspires the relations between their two countries.

Hans Mueller, a 21-year-old German stowaway, arrived yesterday on the Hamburg American liner New York in the ship's hospital recovering from a self-inflicted bullet wound. He shot himself after being -discovered hiding in a lifeboat on April 23.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 23 amounted to 523,767 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The writer has seen the Giants under all its various managers, Jim Mutrie, John M. Ward, George S. Davis, Bill Joyce and the rest, up to John McGraw. Not one of these men, with the possible exception of Davis, ever displayed the sports-' manship that Terry consistently has shown.

Fire of undetermined origin last night did considerable damage to the library and offices of the rectory of the Fordham Methodist Episcopal Church, at 2,543 Marion Avenue, the Bronx, on the corner of Fordham Road. The Rev. G.

The former residence of Lord Duveen, celebrated art dealer, at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Ninety-first Street, has been placed on the market for sale. It is one of the finest town houses in the city and is said to represent an investment of. about $1,000,000, including the value of the land.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Adelaide Michel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Michel of Brooklyn, to Joseph Preston Searing Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs; Joseph Preston Searing, also of Brooklyn, took place last night in the Chapel of the Packer Collegiate Institute, Brooklyn.

Mrs. Emma B. Roe Johnson of East Patchogue, who died on Dec. 29, left an estate valued at more than $6,000,000, it became known today when a hearing was held before Surrogate Richard W. Hawkins of Suffolk on a discovery action brought by a relative. Mrs. Johnson had lived also in Bronxville.
The Chinese air force scored its biggest victory of the war during an air raid this afternoon-over Hankow, the temporary capital, and near-by cities by thirty-nine Japanese lanes.

Before an audience of 2,500 persons, New York University undergraduates last night presented their annual Varsity Show at the Royal Windsor, 69 Wrest Sixty-sixth Street. The production, entitled "That's Life," was a musical satire of picture magazines and their coverage of current events.

Henry Ford's two-sentence speech on Thursday to the advertising group of the American Newspaper Publishers Association plainly disappointed his expectant hearers. An extensive exposition, in a formal speech, of his attitude toward public questions had been anticipated.

A. Leroy Ellis, associate of Professor Elihu Thomson, scientist and former assistant director of the Thomson research laboratory at the General Electric plant in Lynn, died today at his home in Swampscott.

North Bridge Estates, Inc., of which Charles Walzer, operator, is president, has sold the six-story apartment building at 1,400 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, after a brief ownership, through Joseph Goldsmith and Ernest L. Reichfield, cobrokers, to an investing client of Max J. LeBoyer, attorney.

United States Government obligations resumed an upward course yesterday under the impetus of a further large increase in excess reserves as disclosed in the weekly Federal Reserve statement. Gains ranged from 1/32 to 8/32 point for most of the Treasury issues. Several, on the other hand, eased off 1/32 to 5/32 point.

Miss Ruth Mary Burdett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert U. Burdett of this place, was married this afternoon to Anson Boulton Herrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Newbold Lawrence Herrick of Woodmere, L. I., at St. Paul's Episcopal Church here.

A warrant of deportation against Mme. Marie Rasputin Saloviff, who says she is the daughter of Rasputin, the "mad monk" of the Russian Czarist regime, was issued yesterday by Rudolph Reimer, Commissioner of Immigration, at Ellis Island.

If favorable weather prevails, 20,000 crosscountry racing enthusiasts will gather on the hillsides of J. W. Y. Martin's Snow Hill Farm, in the ir Worthington Valley, tomorrow to witness the forty-fifth running of the Maryland Hunt Cup.

Death Announced Retired Fireman William J. Horne, formerly a member of Eng. 268, residing at 65-24 78th St., Middle Village, Queens, died April 28. Funeral will take place from George Werst Funeral Parlors, 71-41 Coper Ave., Glendale, Queens, at 9:30 A. M., Monday. May 2 Interment at Pinelawn

Despite threats of secession, delegates to the Quadrennial Convention of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, voted today for union of the whole denomination in the United States, split into northern and southern divisions by the Negro slavery dispute before the war between the States.

William S. Wilson, formerly a resident partner here in Stein Brothers Boyce, will be admitted to general partnership in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Montgomery, Scott Co., coincident with the retirement of Stuart R. Stevenson from the firm and the withdrawal of Robert L. Montgomery from general partnership to become a limited partner.

President Roosevelt accepted today the offer of aid of sixteen industrial and financial leaders made early this week, and invited them to submit suggestions as to what should be done to end the recession in business.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Justice William F. Hagarty of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn is reported as being opposed to the adoption by the Constitutional Convention of a provision conferring upon the State Legislature the power to enact new laws providing a system of compensation, similar to workmen's compensation, for personal injuries and loss of life caused by automobile.

Financial authorities of the Province of Buenos Aires, Argentina, in reply to representations of the Bondholders Corporation concerning the 4 1/2 percent bonds of 1910 of the province, have issued a statement showing that amortization payments are well ahead of schedule and. that full compliance has been made with all commitments, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.

Professor Charles E. Merriam of the University of Chicago, frankly admitting resentment at defeat of the Reorganization Bill, of which he was part author, predicted today the ultimate adoption of this or a similar measure.

James Caras of Wilmington, Del., retained his world pocket billiard title by vanquishing Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia in the concluding block of their 1,000-point match last night. Caras won, 120 to 95, thus

Christian Kreider Binkley, author and educator, died yesterday in Berkeley, Calif., at the age of 67, according to word received here last night by his son, Professor Robert C. Binkley of columbia University.

Two of the five old masters stolen Saturday from Chilham Castle, Kentish home of the financier Sir Edmund Davis, were recovered today by detectives. They--"Pitt" and "Lady Clarges," by - Gainsborough -were found wrapped in a newspaper in a London office. George Owens,
The application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing the $25 par value common stock of the Fairbanks Company has been granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Oakley Canal Company, Oakley, Idaho, an irrigation project, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $212,500 of 4 per cent first-mortgage serial coupon bonds to be sold to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation at 100.

Prices in most sections of the stock markets here showed small declines in quiet trading today. Gilt-edge issues were slightly lower, but foreign loans were quietly firm. Transatlantics were dull and United States Steel and International Nickel weakened.

The running twins from North Texas Teachers, Wayne and Blaine Rideout, turned in twin achievements of superlative worth in the opening session of the forty-fourth annual Penn Relay Carnival at wind-swept Franklin Field today.
James B. Rowley, a lumber and coal merchant here, died yesterday at the age of 49 in Roosevelt Hospital, New York. He was long active in the Middletown Chamber of Commerce.

The Prudential Insurance Co. took from the 5th Ave. 37th St. Corp., Hyman Schroeder, president, a mortgage for $1,500,000, payable Oct. 29, 1943, on the northwest coiner of 5th Ave and 37th St. The Fifth Madison Corp., Wallace Greene Arnold, president, gave to the Title Guarantee Trust Co., a trust mortgage for $1,

The stock market was off to a poor start yesterday and held lower until late in the session, when prices rallied moderately. Final prices were off irregularly on the day, however. The turnover on the Stock Exchange was 543,000 shares, compared with 537,000 on Thursday.
A $142,000,000 ten-year construction program to supply the needs of the Federal Government here was recommended to President Roosevelt today by his public building program committee.

Miss Mary A. Denneen, daughter of Mrs. Charles A. Denneen of West Islip and the late Mr. Denneen, was married to Cecil Early Johnson of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Early Hurt Johnson of Columbus, Ga., here this afternoon in St. Joseph's Church.

Mr. and Mrs. Irenee du Pont have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucile Evelina du Pont, to Robert Flint. Miss du Pont attended Tower Hill School and is a graduate of the National Cathedral School at Washington, D. C. She made her debut in 1934.

The report of the Bank of Canada for the week ended on Wednesday, issued today, shows the ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities as 54.58 per cent at the end of the week, against 54.69 per cent a week before.

Pensioned On his own application-To take effect 12 midnight, April 30: LIEUTENANT--Charles A. Shanley, 79th Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed March 25, 1912. Transfer To take effect 8 A. M., May 1:
President Roosevelt asked Congress today for funds to start two more battleships in the current fiscal year. With two battleships which

Foreign Minister Rudolf Holsti denied today a Rome report that the Finnish charge d'affaires had informed the Italian Ministry that Finland had recognized the Ethiopian conquest. No decision regarding recognition has been made.

The railway labor unions will resist to the utmost any effort to reduce wages at this time, according to George M. Harrison, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association, who told President Roosevelt today that labor found the wage-cut proposals indefensible at a time when the nation was seeking to find the road to recovery.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of a new issue of $192,000 of refunding bonds of St. Joseph County, Ind., on a bid of 100.904 for 2 1/4s. The bonds, to be dated June 1, 1938, and maturing on June 1, 1939 to 1948, were reoffered to yield 0.70 to 2.30 per cent, according to maturity.

G. M. P. Murphy Co. announce the withdrawal from the firm of Gerald Constable Maxwell, a general partner resident in London, who will join the partnership of Williamson, Fawcett Stirling, members of the London Stock Exchange. The London office

Holy communion will be celebrated tomorrow in virtually all the denominational churches as well as the ritualistic, it being the first Sunday of the month. Pre-Mother's Day sermons will be preached by some pastors, next Sunday being annual Mother's Day.

Dr. Charles P. Lane, dean of the University of Detroit School of Dentistry since 1934, died yesterday of pneumonia in Detroit, according to word received here by the Greater New York Bureau for Dental Information. His age was 54.

Drawing the last game of his schedule after an eventful encounter with C. H. D. 'O. Alexander of London, in the course of which a number of ticklish situations arose, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, chess champion of the world, representing France, emerged winner today of the international masters tournament at the annual Easter Congress of the Kent County Chess Association at the Grand Hotel, Cliftonville.

Four runners from Rice Institute of Houston, Texas, driving their legs into the cinders with the precision of pistons, set a short-lived American record in the opening session of the Drake Relays today.

Department store sales for the week ended April 23 were 13 per cent lower than for the same week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Sales for the four weeks ended April 23 were 4 per cent lower as compared with the same period in 1937.

After an absence of twenty-three years Berdell Brothers, members of the New York Stock Exchange, are returning to the address where the firm's first office was located. In 1908, when the organization was formed, quarters were taken in the Hanover Fire Insurance Building, at 34 Pine Street, and occupied for seven years.

A fresh impulse to the British plan to produce 1,750 first-line aircraft with full war reserves by next March was given tonight by the appointment of a "supplies committee" under the chairmanship of Earl Winterton to insure that the fullest use shall be made of the manufacturing capacity.
A contract for construction of four steel cargo vessels by the Tampa Shipbuilding and Engineering Company will be signed tomorrow by the Maritime Commission, Chairman Land said today.

Plans for expanding a large notion and dry goods business on downtown Broadway were . announced yesterday when Simon Blechman, head of the enterprise bought from the Hawley family the property at 557-59 Broadway, extending through. the block to 128-130 Mercer Street.

A "young people's" garden party will be held at the White House next Tuesday. For the sons and daughters of members of Congress between the ages of 10 and 18, too old for children's- parties and too young for the formal entertainments given annually during the season, Mrs. Roosevelt has added to her "little season" schedule a party especially for these young "Congressionals."

Largely because of an increase in purchases by British Empire countries, Canada's domestic exports during the 1937-38 fiscal year rose to $1,070,228,609 from $1,061,181,906, a gain of more than $9,000,000, according to a summary issued today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

The 150,000 shares of General Foods Corporation cumulative preferred stock of no par value that will be marketed next week by a banking group headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Lehman Brothers will carry a dividend rate of $4.50, according to an amendment filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following additional applications from New York City for registration as brokers or dealers in the over-thecounter market:
In three hours and twenty-four minutes, or twelve innings, the Dodgers beat the Phillies, 5.to 4, at Ebbets Field yesterday in a game they should have won in the regulation number of innings.

Miss Milla Wood Jenkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. V. Clement Jenkins of Ridgefield Park, N. J., was married to Roy Edward Babcock of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Dean Babcock of Oneida, N. Y., yesterday noon in the chapel of the Riverside Church.

The Federal Trade Commission today ordered Justin Haynes Co. of 347 Fifth Avenue, New York City, to cease representing, through the use of the word "aspirub" or any other word simulating aspirin, that its embroactory product is aspirin or accomplishes substantially any of the beneficial .therapeutic effects of aspirin.

Intensive anti-diphtheria campaigns have been started by the Health Department in several health center districts of the city where diphtheria was most prevalent in 1937, it was announced yesterday by the city Bureau of Health Education.

Richard H. Regan, Assistant State's Attorney and war veteran, died tonight of pneumonia in St. Anne's Hospital. Mr. Regan, who was 43 years old, had been a prosecutor's aide for five years. He participated in many

Mrs. Marcus Daly Jr., Mrs. Carolyn Lawson, George Pinckard, John T. O'Brien, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, agents. Dr. Samuel Irgang, in 160 Riverside Drive; I. V. Hest, in 139 E 82d St: J. Kisburg, in 41 W 70th St; Paul Warhaftig, in 58 W 72d St; Apartment Renting Co, Inc, agent.

Deals in which operators figured as principals in sales of walk-up apartment houses in the Bronx were announced yesterday. Henry Goelet sold to the Harwid Realty Corporation the five-andone-half-story walk-up for sixtythree families at 2,121-25 Harrison Avenue, near 181st Street.

A last-minute rush of buying of cigarettes was expected to develop today in anticipation of a 1-cent stamp tax on each package, which goes into effect at midnight. The revenue is for emergency relief.

In a four-to-one decision, the Appellate Division affirmed yesterday a lower court ruling that Christadora House, at Avenue B and Ninth Street, was wholly exempt from New York City real estate taxes. The city contended that it was liable to taxes on that part of the structure which was 'used for "residential club" purposes.
Emperor Hirohito celebrated his thirtyseventh birthday today with the customary review of his - troops but without much of the ceremony that marked similar observances.

A high temperature of 80 degrees and an average for the day of 71 yesterday marked the continuance of New York's unseasonal warm spell. It was relatively cool compared with the record-breaking high of 85 degrees Thursday.

The annual report of the American and Foreign Power Company for 1937, which will be forwarded today to shareholders, shows a consolidated net income of $6,153,093 from operations after all expenses, taxes and charges but foreign exchange adjustments, an increase of $1,092,646, or approximately 20 per cent over 1936.

Model sail and motor boat races for boys and girls 18 years old or younger will be held by the Park Department at Conservatory Lake, Seventy-second Street and Fifth Avenue, Central Park, today at 1:30 P. M.

The move to reduce wages made yesterday by the railway managements was in line with expectations. The wages of unionized railway men are about 7 per cent above the 1929 levels, increases having been granted last Fall.

A program of ballets and solo dances ended the Eastman School Music Festival here tonight. The dancers were from the studio of Thelma Biracree, choreographer and soloist,--assisted by several guest artists.

The solution to fatal tenementhouse fires lies in finding a way to get property owners to remove violations on their buildings and bring them up to legal standards, Harry M. Prince, Deputy Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, told the Housing Committee of the Council yesterday at a public hearing.
All bulls in the Valencia stockyards are to be sold in view of the recent ban on bullfights. Valencia's provincial council today decided to sell the animals to stock farmers or slaughter houses.
New York Aquarium officials confirmed yesterday the revelation made by Dr. Christopher W. Coates in Washington Thursday that shocking-events are taking place in the fish house down by the Battery.

The tercentenary of the Collegiate School of the Collegiate Reformed Dutch Church, the first to undertake the teaching of children here, was observed last night at the Hotel Plaza. The school is at 241 West Seventy-seventn Street. It was founded in the Dutch colony of New Amsterdam.

Henry J. Ripperger, receiver for the United States Electric Power Corporation in Federal Court proceedings in Maryland, filed suit here yesterday in Federal District Court against twenty-three former directors of the corporation, charging mismanagement and misconduct.

The State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance, official guardian of the interests of emplayers, employes and the public, moved yesterday to end the secrecy that has enabled relief chiselerss" to find refuge in the records of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department.

Three productions will depart the Broadway scene tonight. After threatening to do so last Saturday, "A Doll's House" vacates the Broadhurst with a record of 141 performances, and on Monday starts a two-week engagement at the Forrest Theatre, Philadelphia.
Due to the fact that May 1 falls on a Sunday, the opening of the trout season in the Province of Quebec was advanced one day in order to give prospective anglers a full week-end.

Military training was praised as a means of inculcating good manners in the youth of America by Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, N. Y. N. G. (retired), speaking yesterday at the annual Spring review and reception of the Knickerbocker Greys, crack junior military unit, at the 107th Infantry Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

The Federal Government found itself owner of a knitting, mill yesterday when a public auction of the property, the first seized for failure to pay taxes under the Social Security Act, failed to produce. any one else willing to pay the amount of the delinquency and the costs of the sale.

An assertion that if a tendency of the National Labor Relations Board to assume jurisdiction never contemplated in the Wagner act was- continued, compulsory arbitration by government decree would have become a reality was made in a report to the executive council-of the American Federation of Labor today by Joseph A. Padway, federation counsel.
The League of Nations received yesterday from Haile Selassie a check for 10,000 Swiss francs (about 6,500 gold francs) in token payment of Ethiopia's back dues, totaling 117,000 gold francs.

The National Steel Corporation reported yesterday a net income of $1,088,635 for-the first quarter of 1938 after all charges except provision for surtax on undistributed profits, equal to 50 cents a share on 2,167,877 shares of capital stock, compared to $5,695,819, or $2.63 a share, earned in the first quarter of 1937.

N. Y. unassigned, is attached for training only to the 581st Engineer Company (D. T.) (not eligible for assignment, active duty of promotion). Capt. Melvin W. Fischbein, Dent. Res., 612 W. 178th St., New York, N. Y., recently promoted, is assigned to the 18th Surgical Hospital.

The Ball of Tomorrow was staged last night by the Junior League of New York in cooperation with officials of the New York World's Fair in the blue and orange neoclassic Business Administration Building on the fair grounds.

State Senator John J. Dunnigan, assistant minority leader of the Constitutional Convention, announced today that he would submit "in the near future" a proposal to amend the Constitution to permit pari-mutuel betting at horse-race tracks in the State.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, and the Rev. Dr. Ralph H. Long, executive director of the National Lutheran Council, will attend a meeting of the executive committee of the Lutheran World Convention, of which Dr. Knubel is vice president, in Upsala, Sweden, on May 20-25.

Dr. George Rothenberg, 37 years old, of 186 Midland Parkway, Jamaica Estates, was cleared yesterday of a charge of performing an illegal operation by a jury before County Judge Charles S. Colden in Long Island City.

Premier Antonio de Oliveira. Salazar today announced to the National Assembly that Portugal soon would recognize the Franco government, because there was discipline in the Insurgent territories of Spain that the Barcelona- government apparently was unable to maintain.

With ranks split by factional differences, left wing labor forces in this city will celebrate May Day ?? two outdoor demonstrations today Communists and their sympathizers, together with a large number of rank-and-file union and in dependent groups, will march under the banner of the United May Day Committee.

Eastern shippers came into the hog market today and bought 170 to 240-pound butchers more actively than any day this week. The top held at $8.35. Efforts to break the weighty butchers were unsuccessful. No choice steers arrived but the undertone remained firm while all other classes of cattle sold slow and weak.

62d St, 8 E, 5-story dwelling, 25x100-5 Seamen's Bank for Savings against Guaranty Trust Company; due, $123,143; to plaintiff for $90,000. Ridge St, 54, 6-story tenement and stores 25x100; Margaret G. McConaughty against Lee-har Realty Co, Inc: due, $31.092:

Two Brooklyn boys received bronze medals from the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission today. To James Pettas, 13, was awarded a posthumous medal. He drowned while attempting to save Thomas R. Keeshan, 11, who dropped into ten feet of water while wading in a pool May 29, 1937.

Richard Rosenbaum and Rose Low have proposed the formation of the new New York Stock Exchange firm of Richard Rosenbaum Co. The committee on quotations and commissions will ballot on the matter on May 12.

Preservation of the American form of representative government and opposition to all efforts to extend the power of the executive should be the keynotes of the Republican drive to return to power, Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, former Governor General of the Philippines, said here today at a conference of Eastern collegiate Republican clubs.

Germany proposes to purchase immediately as much raw materials and foods in the world markets as her financial resources will permit, even if her trade balance should run into deficits, according to the Deutsche Volkswirt, the organ of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank.

Storm signals for May Day are increasing in the German Sudeten districts. A proclamation by Rudolf Sander, propaganda chief of the Sudeten party, to be issued tomorrow, is similar to proclamations issued by Nazis in Austria before their open revolt against the Schuschnigg regime.

MANHATTAN COHEN, LESTER B. (April 23). Estate, less than $10,000. To Grace Bloom, $3,000; Doris S. Leerburger, niece, residue. Charles Hollander, New. Rochelle, N. Y., executor. GOLDING, MARY. also known as Mary Goulding (Feb. 3). Estate, more than $10,000. To Margaret Foley, niece, 2,206

Miss Jane Andrews, daughter of Frank L. Andrews of this city, was married to William A. Kirmse, son of Mrs. George Kirmse of Los Angeles, yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold F. Lemoine.

Great interest in the proposal of Governor Philip F. La Follette for a new party wes expressed by political leaders here yesterday. The consensus was that the proposal, regarded by some as premature, was designed to take the sup port of progressives from President Roosevelt and that it might work to the advantage of the Republican party in the Presidential campaign of 1940.
Miss Yvonne Navello and Leonard M. Thomas Jr. were married here at noon today in St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frank L. Vernon.

Mrs. Edward Jackson Brundage of Lake Forest, Ill., and East Falls Church, Va., has announced to friends here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Germaine Brundage, to Dr. Kennedy Creevey, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Mason Creevey of 40 East Sixty-third Street, this city.
The text of President Roosevelt's monopoly message to Congress today was as follows: Unhappy events abroad have retaught us two simple truths about the liberty of a democratic people.

Real estate taxes totaling $127,737,114 for the first half of the year had been paid up to the close of business yesterday, William Reid, City Collector, announced. This compared with $116,466,692 for the same period last year, when the basic tax rate was $2.64 as against $2.80 this year.
Turpentine firm, 23c; sales. 90 barrels; receipts, 423 barrels; shipments, 52 barrels; stock, 31,667 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 624: receipts, 2,705; shipments, 301; stock.. 86,534.

The Jersey City Giants gained a 4-to-2 decision over Rochester today to stretch their winning streak to four games in a row. Although Johnny Meketi, young right-hander, stopped the Red Wings with five hits, the wildness of Rochester's Bobby Bowman really gave the Little Giants the game.
Mrs. Robert Livingston Clarkson returned yesterday from Concord, N. H., and is at the Ritz Tower. Colonel and Mrs. Wyndham Torr of Washington are at the Gotham.

At a luncheon of the Greater New York Fund, which will seek $10,000,000 from business, at the Bankers Club of America, 120 Broadway, yesterday, James G. Blaine, chairman,. speaking to about 150 divisional leaders, said:

Virginio Gayda, writing in the Giornale d'Italia today, protests against the "hostile f manifestations against Italy that have been going on in the United States for some time" and declares "that owing to their frequency they have lost the character of a mere episode and have assumed that of a system."

The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday for the quarter ended on March 31 a net income of $2,080,170 after depreciation, estimated Federal normal income taxes and deduction of $196,408 blocked foreign net profits and other charges, but before provision for surtax on undistributed profits.

Vital Spot, a 7-year-old brown gelding owned by the Audwill Stables of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kennedy of Southboro, Mass., tonight won the Hunter Stake, the first of the rich cash events of the eighteenth annual Newark Horse Show in the Essex Troop Armory.

Robert Shannon, vice president and general manager of the RCA Manufacturing Company, was elected yesterday a member of the board of directors of the company, it was announced by David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America and chairman of the board of the manufacturing unit.

The National Consumer News, which changes its name to The American Consumer with the June issue, has devised-a sampling plan whereby manufacturers in the food and grocery industry can have their products examined by consumer education groups.

On his arrival here yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner New York from the Fourth International Leprosy Conference at Cairo, Egypt, Dr. H. W. Wade, head of the leper colony at Culion, P. I., said that one of the most heartening results of the meeting was that 100 delegates from all parts of the world departed with the full realization of the importance of international cooperation in fighting the disease.
Teachers agreed yesterday that there is no ideal teacher. They discussed it at a round table meeting between faculty members and students of the Cooperative School for Teachers at 69 Bank Street.

President Roosevelt asked the Social Security Board today to study methods of improving the Social Security Act, including liberalization and extension of the old-age benefit system, and the board, responding quickly to his request, announced that it would have recommendations ready before Congress reconvened in January.

Prices of farm products are going down while the cost of things farmers buy remains unchanged, the Department of Agriculture reported today. In terms of the pre-war level, the farm products price index had dropped on April 15 to 94, the lowest figure in four years, the department said.

The first ladies' day in the fifteenyear history of the Yankee Stadium was celebrated yesterday by an attendance of 4,903 guests of Colonel Jake Ruppert,. who brought the total gathering for the day to 12,395.
Withdrawal of all American Federation of Labor unions from affiliation with the American Labor Party was recommended today by the executive council of the State federation.

Bill Werber pulled a Frank Merriwell stunt today and stole home with the winning run in the ninth inning to give the Athletics a 7-to-6 triumph over the Senators. Washington tied the score with a run in its half of the final frame.

The tax bill of the private utility companies operating in the United States amounted in 1937 to $330,000,000, an increase of $44,000,000 ?? 1936, the Edison Electric Institute has reported in its annual statistical bulletin.
How many people would expect offhand, to look in the dictionary and find a dame or a skirt for a lady friend,

The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided to call J. P. Morgan, senior partner in J. P. Morgan Co., in its public inquiry into the failure on March 8 of the firm of Richard Whitney Co., it was learned here tonight.
Mr. and Mrs. Frank T. Sage of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Sage, to James Beach Platt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Platt of Baltimore.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The better tone which was noted in the wool market last week continues. Pulled wools are a shade dearer, but for the greasy wools of territory or bright fleece type it is hard to get any advance over last week's levels, although not too difficult to sell modest weights at those levels.
Henry Ford paid a flying call on J. P. Morgan at the latter's office at 23 Wall Street yesterday forenoon, causing a furor in financial circles when the fact became known. Widespread interest in the

Speaking of ideologies-and who doesn't ?--the ideology of the most hopeful epoch in recent history was thrown overboard with a resounding splash yesterday by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Lord Halifax, apparently with the full accord of the Premier and Foreign Minister of France.

Losing no time after his announcement at Madison last night that a new political party had been born, Governor Philip F. La Follette came here today to try to win the liberals of this Corn Belt State to his cause, which involves an effort to whittle away the left-wing strength of President Roosevelt's New Deal.

A contest of almost six months' duration for control of the United Licensed Officers Association, a union of licensed deck and engineer officers employed on American merchant ships, was ended yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo issued an injunction barring Captain John F. Milliken from the presidency and use of the name of the association.

Further increases may be expected in the excess reserves of the member bank Federal Reserve System as a result of the expenditure by the Treasury of the large balances in the banks created by the desterilization of gold, according to the monthly review of credit and business conditions prepared by the Federal Reserve Bank of the Second District.

Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, Fla., moved into the final of the Hot Springs invitation tennis tournament today by defeating Harris W. Everett of Jacksonville, 6-4, 6-0. He will meet Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., who eliminated Bernard Coghlan of Santa Monica, Calif., 6-3, 6-1.
HEARTBREAK HOUSE, a revival of the George Bernard Shaw play; setting by John- Koenig; directed by Orson Welles; produced by the Mercury Theatre. At the Mercury Theatre.

Having purchased nearly 3,000 items from the offerings of 953 sellers in three days, the United Cigar Whelan Stores Corporation will ad vertise for additional off-price mer chandise next Tuesday, Frank M Head, merchandise sales director said last night.
Postmaster General James A. Farley blamed the business recession today on the fact that some phases of President Roosevelt's recovery program were defeated.
Governor Wilbur L. Cross requested and received today the resignation of John A. MacDonald as Highway Commissioner and named as his successor Professor William J. Cox of Yale University.

Today's issue of The Art News contains a copyright article that says Charles M. Schwab, steel executive, has sold one of his important paintings, Rembrandt's "The Accountant," to the Boymans Museum in Rotterdam, Holland.

The New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals, highest tribunal in the State, upheld today the conviction of Henry C. Steneck and George W. Steneck, officers of the defunct Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken.

Manhattan 120th St, 535-41 E; 106x100; for 3-story offices and garage; City of New York, 125 Worth St, owner; F. B. McDuffee, architect; cost, $150,000. 22d St, 515-41 E, and 23d St, 516-34 E; 39x27; for 1-story gas station and sales room; Yellow Taxi Corp, 1,775 Broadway, owner; Charles M. Schultz, engineer; cost, $8,000.

The Official Gazette published today the final figures in the first Great Germany plebiscite and Reichstag election of April'10. They show that in the old Reich territory the total number of registered voters was 45,150,443; the aye votes 44,451,401, the nay votes 442,981, the invalid 69,846. The election participation was 99.59 per cent. The aye votes in the percentage of total valid votes totaled 99.1.

Diverse views were expressed here today by political leaders on the formation of the National Progressive party. One group held the opinion that the major parties and the lesser political units already offered the voters a wide opportunity to register their varying opinions.

The indications are for generally fair and cooler weather today. Tomorrow will be partly cloudy with little change in temperature, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock Eastern standard time last night.

Fifteenth semi-annual convention of the Commercial Education Association, Hotel Pennsylvania, 10 A. M. Luncheon at 1. P. M. "Place of Commercial Education in the Full-Time Vocational School," Commissioner Paul J. Kern.

The dispute between the Rajah of Sikar and his overlord, the Maharajah of Jaipur, which earlier this week threatened an armed clash, was reported settled today after an agent of the Governor General had intervened.
The Tigers drove John Rigney from the mound in the seventh inning today when they tallied four runs, to defeat the White Sox, 5 to 1. Cletus (Boots) Poffenberger scattered seven Chicago hits.

Russ Seaview Rex, a pointer dog owned and handled by Russell Gardner of Middletown, again came through by a wide margin to annex the open gun dog stake of the Sport and Conservation League field trial meeting today. There were fortyone dogs in action and the event was not completed until 7. P. M.

The Royal Academy held its private view today and so by tradition opened-the London social "season." Quite naturally, in view of the events of the last year, pictures of the coronation and royal family were featured among the 1,587 pictures, sketches and sculptural.. pieces shown.

More than 600 graduates of the New York University College of Dentistry attended-an Alumni Day reunion yesterday, elected new officers and honored thirteen of their associates who have, in past years, received the Alumni Federation Meritorius Service Awards, at the College of Medicine Building, 209 East Twenty-third Street.
Setting all the pace, Sir Hugo Cunliff-Owen's Rockfel today defeated nineteen other fillies in the 1,000 Guineas Stake, second of the English turf's classics for 3-yearolds.

The Thomas Negro Composers Study Group, Blanche K. Thomas, director, presented a program depicting the "Evolution of the Negro Through Music," last night at Town Hall. The group, now in its sixth year, consists of some forty nonprofessional singers, mostly of school age.

Sir Auckland C. Geddes, chairman of the Rio Tinto Company, Ltd., told stockholders at the annual meeting in London yesterday that in 1937 the company was able to export from Spain with difficulty about 1,200,000 tons of pyrites and about 200,000 tons of iron ore.

Declaring that the Anglo-French entente had never been so cordial and firm as now, Premier Edouard Daladier and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet returned to Paris this evening from their two-day visit to London.
A total of $1,888,950 was loaned last month on home mortgages by 111 members of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations, the group announced yesterday. Projecting these actual

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,255,000bales, against 1,239,000 a week ago, 1,213,000 two weeks ago, 1,190,000 three weeks ago and 985,000 a year ago, of which American 828,000 bales, against 818,000 a week ago, 815,000 two weeks ago, 794,000 three weeks ago and 412,000 a year ago.

" Hans Brinker or the Silver Skates," one of the most popular child's stories of a quarter-century ago, is to be brought to the screen by Principal Productions with Bobby Breen as Hans and Irene Dare, 5-year-old figure skater, as Greta. Incorporated with the Mary

Myron C. Taylor, former chairman of the United States Steel Corporation; Mrs. Taylor, Colonel and Mrs. Marston T. Bogert, Count Antonio Barberis, Mr. and Mrs. G. R. B. Blodgett, Colonel and Mrs. L. A. Bradley, Dr. and Mrs. D. M. Balsam and Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Hilles are due to sail today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian motorship Conte di Savoia.
A "stringer" yesterday became recognized as a legitimate member of a Japanese ship's crew and by his creation a grave international situation was probably averted in Brooklyn.

Dr. Henry Guelman, attending dermatologist at Fordham Hospital, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home at 2,174 Bathgate Avenue, the Bronx. He had been formerly with the staffs of Lebanon, Lincoln, Columbus and Polyclinic Hospitals and St. Bartholomew's Clinic.

Behind airtight relief pitching by Phil Page in the last four and onethird innings, the Bears today scored their seventh victory in eight starts, getting an even dozen blows for a 10-7 decision over Montreal.

Canadians are the most talkative people in the world and they are getting even more so. Apart altogether from the wordy briefs presented to royal commissions and the 4,000,000 to 6,000,000 words spoken in the House of Commons, telephone statistics award the laurel of talkativeness to Canadians.

This city's 9,000 employes, including school teachers, will not receive pay checks due them tomorrow, it was announced today by Commissioner Vincent Murphy, Director of Revenue and Finance. The municipal payroll totals about $1,300,000.

President Roosevelt sent his long-awaited message on monopolies to Congress today. In it he called for "a thorough study of the concentration of economic power in American industry and the effect of that concentration upon the decline of competition," and an extensive investigation by Congress directed toward remedial legislation.

Officers of the American ?? Manufacturers, Association took issue today with charges of critics that-feudalism existed in the Southern textile industry. W. M. McLaurine, the secretary, told the association the Southern textile mills have a keen sense of principles governing a sane industrial relations policy and pay labor 35 per cent of its manufacturing income, against 18 per cent, the average for the United States.

President Getulio Vargas issued a decree today giving control of all oil refineries in Brazil to Brazilians. Whether the recent oil expropriation measure in Mexico was reflected here cannot be determined, as Brazil has no oil of her own and depends exclusively on imports.
National League Brooklyn at New York-Mungo vs. Hubbell. Boston at Philadelphia--MacFayden vs. La Master. Chicago at St. Louis--Carleton vs. Macon.
The Federal Reserve Board made public today two interpretations dealing with technical questions arising under its Stock Exchange margin regulations.

All deliveries of wheat futures sold below 80 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade here today for the first time since May, 1934. Liquidation by holders of May contracts who feared they would be forced to pay for cash grain and continued favorable crop reports were responsible for the decline.

Owing to the large amount of stock of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in the hands of brokers, the unusual difficulties encountered by the corporation in getting in touch with the real owners and the importance of the matters to be decided at the general meeting to be held on May 5, the committee

Representatives of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen and the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company started drafting late-yesterday afternoon the details of the agreement which averted a strike of operating employes of the Hudson Tubes that had been called for 5 o'clock yesterday morning.

The marriage of Miss Cornelia Esther Edwards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Holmes Edwards of this city, to Dr. Paul Harper, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Harper of Watertown, took place here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church. The Right Rev.

Prestdent Roosevelt left all office routine d behind him tonight and left Washington for an undetermined voyage on the Atlantic off the Florida coast in the hope of getting as far away a as possible from visitors, telephones and the press.

Caroline Babcock was selected by the students of Barnard College yesterday afternoon to receive the $1,000 fellowship raised by the undergraduates to send a graduate abroad for study in a foreign university. Dorothy Colodny was selected as alternate.
Thomas F. Reilly, a Brooklyn newspaper man for more than fifty years, died yesterday at his home, 180 Lenox Road, Brooklyn. He was 75 years old.

The police guarding the Hudson County poll and registration books, which had been withheld from the Young Assembly committee for more than three months, stepped aside this morning to permit the removal to court of the records of the Twenty-fifth district of the Tenth Ward of Jersey City, as ordered by Judge Robert V. Kinkead.

William Allen White, editor and author, will be the principal speaker at the fiftieth anniversary dinner of the Jacob A. Rlis Settlement on Tuesday night at the Hotel Plaza, according to an announcement yesterday. The event will "celebrate a half-century of progress in housing and in social attitudes."

PLANT IN THE SUN--This evening at the Bayes Theatre. The Ben Bengal play and "Transit," an adaptation by Philip Stevenson of Albert Maltz's "Season of Celebration," for Sunday night performances through May.

Miss Dorothy Jayne Dow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay L. Dow of East Orange, was married this evening, the twenty-fifth anniversary of her parents' marriage, to Robert Charles Mervine, son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Mervine, also of East Orange.
The north tube of the Lincoln Tunnel under the Hudson River will be "holed through" soon after noon tomorrow, weeks ahead of schedule, according to the Port of New York Authority.

The campaign of the United Hospital Fund will begin on Oct. 25 and end Thanksgiving Day, it was announced last week at the annual meeting of the Women's Activities workers in the American Red Cross building, 315 Lexington Avenue.

Preparations have begun for May Day, the week of May 14, at Skidmore College. Events start Friday afternoon with a song contest. On Friday and Saturday nights the dramatic group will present "First Lady."
Liquidation was under way in the grain markets in the early trading today, but it quickly ran its course after May nd July wheat futures aad sold at new low prices for the season.
AMONG the outstanding events at Jasper this Summer will be the thirty-third annual camp of the Alpine Club of Canada, July 16 to 30, at the foot of the Athabaska Glacier, in the Columbia Icefield.

Problems of taxation, public welfare and representative town meeting government will be discussed at the third conference on current governmental problems at Massachusetts State College May 13 and 14.
The Finance Ministry issued an order tonight that all foreign credits held by Germans or persons domiciled in Germany, not including Austria, must be reported to the Reichsbank by May 20.

Forty-five coal miners have been killed in an explosion in a Buchanan County mine and attention is focused once more on the fact that Virginia has no standard compulsory rock-dusting law. West Virginia, Pennsylvania and other major coal-producing States have such laws.

Mr. and Mrs. Sumner Brown, Whitney of Summit, N J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Whitney, to Alvin B. McClelland Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin B McClelland of Elizabeth, N. J.

William C. Potter, chairman of the Guaranty Trust Company, denied in a statement to stockholders made public yesterday that Guaranty Trust had been seeking to vote Chesapeake Corporation stock pledged with it to control the Chesapeake Ohio Railway for special benefit.

Mayor La Guardia is no going along with Governor Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin at the present time in the latter's proposal for a new political party, it was learned yesterday after a conference between the Mayor andAssistant Secretary of State A. A. Berle'Jr. at City Hall.
Music Hall of the Air symphony orchestra, with Erno Rapee -conducting, and Viola Philo, soprano; Grover Whalen, president of World's Fair, will discuss "World-of-Tomorrow": WJZ. 12:30-1:30 P. M.

Johns-Manville's National Housing Guild program was awarded honorable mention last week in the annual Howard G. Ford award competition for "outstanding achievement in sales management." It is said to be the first time that a building industry representative was selected for these honors.

Attacks on Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City and pleas for better housing, more jobs and adequate relief featured a peaceful May Day march of 3,500 C. I. 0. unionists down Broad Street here today. The marchers, assembled in Military Park, heard speakers plead for A. F. L.-C. I. O. unity to strengthen the labor movement.

The trolley lines of this city suffered the worst breakdown of their history today when a burned-out coil in the main generator, believed to have been caused by a short-circuit, put the main power house out of commission at daybreak.

Pursuit, attack and bombardment units of the G. H. Q. Air Force will depart from their home stations tomorrow to participate in the manoeuvres in the northeast section of the United States during May to be held under the direction of Major Gen. Frank M. Andrews, commander of the G. H. Q. Air Force, the War Department announced today.
The Real Estate Board of New York at its April meeting added sixteen new members, bringing to 238 the number of memberships added since Sept. 1, the beginning of its fiscal year.
Cottage rentals in and around Long Branch, N. J., for Summer occupancy, have shown considerable activity during. the last two weeks and brokers report a stronger demand than last year at this time.

According to General Superintendent Allyn R. Jennings of the New York Department of Parks, his office has asked the War Department to consider dredging the mud flats known as Bronx Kills, which separate Randalls Island from the mainland. to provide an important short route with a six-foot depth between the Harlem River and Long Island Sound, thus obviating passage via Hell Gate.

As inevitably as night follows day, the burgeoning buds of the Spring are accompanied by post-season statistics, complete and complex, on the activities of one or another of the important phases of the town's musical life; the which are duly transcribed to the local music columns.
PITTSFIELD, Mass.--Berkshire vegetation is nearly two weeks ahead of its average status for May 1. With a continuance of favorable weather, the apple trees will be in bloom by another week.

The gray granite edifice at 122 West Seventy-sixth Street, which for many years was the site of St. Andrew's Methodist Church, began the second phase of its existence yesterday, as the West Side Institutional Synagogue.

Sweeping the six singles and three doubles matches, Army's tennis team defeated Fordham, 9--0, yesterday on the Fordham Field courts. Only one match went into an extra set, McCutchen conquering Schmitt, 6--3, 3--6, 6--3.

Annual communion breakfast of the New York Postoffice Holy Name Society, Hotel Astor, 9 A. M. Speakers: Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, Mgr. J. Francis McIntyre, Postmaster General James A. Farley, the Rev. James M. Gillis, the Rev. John J. Kiernan, Justice John Matthews, Edward Cunningham.

Bruce Barnes, former University of Texas intercollegiate tennis star, now turned professional, overpowered Karel Kozeluh, defending champion, to win the Greenbrier open singles title today. The scores were 5-7, 6-1. 6-4. 3-6. 6-4.

Three Kent crews scored a clean sweep over Manhattan College oarsmen today on the mile course. Kent's first crew left the jasper 150-pound shell five lengths behind, crossing the finish line in 5 minutes 18 seconds.
