Construction activities throughout the country were less during the has first quarter of this year than during the similar. periods of 1937 and 1936, according to E. M. Craig, executive secretary of the National Association of Building Trades Emplayers.

Colonel Fulton Q. C. Gardner, commanding officer of the Harbor Defenses of Sandy Hook at Fort Hancock, N. J., will be promoted to brigadier general today, and tomorrow at 5 P. M. will be honored with a parade and review in which all the troops at Fort Hancock, including the Seventh Coast Artillery (Harbor Defense) and the Fifty-second Coast Artillery (Railway), will participate.
The AngloIrish Relations Treaty which Premier Eamon de Valera signed in London this week carries a significance which the mere reading of the text does not disclose.

This department, which for the past several Sundays has been recording the growing awareness of the Administration that it must move in a way to reassure industry and capital, finds in the events of the present week nothing but confirmation of that record.

ROME. THE Italian Government has decided to resume the excavations of the ancient city of Ostia. The plans, which must be carried out in time for the inauguration of Rome's World Fair in 1941, call for digging over an area of about fifty acres of earth under which lies what in Republican and Imperial times was one of the busiest sea towns of the Mediterranean.
Citizens of the District of Columbia registered an overwhelming desire for the right to vote in early returns from an unofficial referendum today.
A smart looking black and white foxterrier owned by Thomas W. Bevan of Andover, Mass., took best in show honors at the ninth annual exhibition of the Manchester Kennel Club today.
Increased enrollment at Middlebury will necessitate the breaking of a century-old tradition in June, when commencement exercises will be held for the first time in Mead Chapel on the campus.

Declaring that "within the next few weeks" the nucleus of a State organization of his National Progressive Party will emerge in Iowa, Governor Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin urged cooperation tonight at a dinner here attended by Farmer-Labor leaders of this State and Minnesota.

Two New Jersey National Guard armories, one in Englewood and the other in Hackensack, will be sold at auction next Saturday by the New Jersey State Military Board. Joseph P. Day will be the auctioneer. Both sales will be- on the premises, the former at 2 P. M. and the latter at 3:30 P. M.

Surmounting no end of difficulties which included a downpour of rain that forced a thirty-minute interruption at the close of the seventh, Carl Hubbell, with the help of a ninth-inning lift from Dick Coffman, silenced a hostile section of 31,723 fans who openly avowed allegiance to Flatbush, and thrilled the remainder of the spectators by turning back the Dodgers, 3 to 1, in the opening clash of a threegame series at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

The silver service of the old armored cruiser Brooklyn, which has been for years in the custody of the Brooklyn Museum, will be formally presented to the new light cruiser Brooklyn at 4 P. M. next Friday.
Coney Island of 1910 will be depicted in miniature form at Le Coq Rouge on the night of May 17 when a benefit entertainment will be given for the West Side Hospital and Dispensary.

The cat that Konrad Henlein, the Sudeten German chief, let out of the bag last week-end continues to flutter the diplomatic dovecotes of Europe. In Czechoslovakia nobody was surprised at the nature of the beast;
Present and former city and State officials were among 2,500 persons who attended the annual dinner and dance of the First Avenue Boys last night in the Hotel Commodore. Among those present were:

NOW and then the question arises whether any discussion of the philosophy of poetry is valuable other than in a theoretical way; whether the reader's appreciation of poetry, or the author's ability to create it, has ever been improved in even the slightest degree by all the painstaking analyses of the nature, function and psychological import of the poetic act and impulse.

Consultations between the United States and Britain to decide on the size of the new super-battleships each will build have reached a deadlock, officials said today. Britain insists on a limit of 42,000 tons. The United States insists that, in the present state of uncertainty as to the exact nature of Japan's intentions, no limit should be set.

EACH year flower festivals become more important in the American travel scene, with thousands of tourists visiting well-known centers as seasonal blossoms reach peak beauty. Washington's long-famous cherry blossoms share honors with the dogwood of Greenfield Hill, Conn.; the apple blossoms of Nova Scotia's Annapolis Valley, the rose parades of Portland, Ore., and Pasadena, Calif.

Representative Frank J. Dorsey, Democrat of Philadelphia told the Eastern Seaboard Conference of the United Typothetae' of America today that government reorganization still is ahead because it will be fought for by public demand. The conference closed tonight in the Hotel Traymore.

Guided by carefully studied experiments in a dozen schools embracing thousands of pupils over a decade, New York City's high school officials are ready to start a program of differentiated courses which they believe will more effectively meet the educational needs of their 250,000 pupils.

All four entrants of Stuyvesant High current team champion, made their way into the semi-final bracket along with fourteen others as the preliminary round of the annual Public Schools Athletic League individual fencing championship competition was held on the strips of the Washington Irving High School yesterday morning.

Cornell collected twelve hits, including home runs by Mike Stehnach and Jack Lozier, to defeat Columbia, 12--7, today and continue undefeated with three victories in as many Eastern Intercollegiate League starts.

The study of microchemical analysis, a new and recent technique in chemistry which was introduced into the City College curriculum two years ago, will be aided by the recent acquisition of a microchemical balance capable of weighing loads of from three to five milligrams with an accuracy of a millionth of a gram.

An incessant downpour from leaden skies cut short yesterday the most elaborate parade ever planned in Queens County. Close to 100,000 marchers had mobilized in the Corona section to participate in the borough demonstration at the World's Fair preview in the Flushing Meadows. But only 25,000 filed past the reviewing stand on the fair grounds.

The arrests of clergymen and their followers in the past year, culminating in the announcement last Sunday (the Russian Easter) of the arrest of at least twenty-five religious practitioners on treason charges, focused attention once more on the status of religion in the Soviet Union.
The National Industrial Conference Board's regular monthly survey of wages, hours and employment in twenty-five manufacturing industries indicates there has been no general reduction in wage rates.

The Akron, Canton Youngstown Railroad contemplates the purchase of three or four locomotives, according to Railway Age. The Warrior River Terminal has ordered a 900-horsepower oil-electric switching locomotive from the American Locomotive Company.

rending announcement of the French Government's financial decrees, the franc was steadier today in a quiet foreign exchange market here, closing unchanged at 162 13/16 points to the pound. The dollar was firmer at $4.98% to the pound, but the belga and the Swiss franc were easier.
Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia defeated Miss Florence Le Boutillier of Westbury, L. I., in the women's final of the annual

The Manhattan College baseball team defeated Columbus Council, 12--0, in a five-inning game yesterday at Manhattan Field. The contest, called because of rain, was the fifth victory in six starts for the Jaspers.

Through the generosity of Mrs. Margie A. Smith, widow of Dr. Edgar Fahs Smith, $5,500 has been added to the endowment of the Edgar Fahs Smith Memorial Library of Chemistry at the University of Pennsylvania, it is announced by Dr. Thomas G. Gates, president of the university.

Two of the most popular symphonies in the repertoire were presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, at the final students' concert of the season given last night in Carnegie Hall.

Many persons are finding that a quiet study room for children is conducive to good marks in school. A child is easily distracted and if there are sounds such as a whistling radiator, kitchen noises, adult conversations or radio programs to be heard while a child is studying his lessons, his school work will doubtless be inferior.
The baseball game between the Columbia freshmen and Scarborough was called because of rain at the end of six innings at Baker Field yesterday after each team had scored three runs.

SALUDA, N. C.--Who will keep the Morris fire going when bachelor William Morris, 77 years old, passes on? William Morris laid down his fiddle and looked at the bright fire. "Well," he said, "I guess me and the fire will go out together."

Dr. Franz Weidenreich of the Cenozoic Laboratory, Union Medical College, Peiping, China, who now is in this country lecturing on the Peking Man, upsets some cherished notions about the origin of man and the effect of environment in evolution.

The marriage of Miss Beatrice Louise Savage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel G. Savage of Orange, to Edward Brennan, son of Mrs. Margaret Brennan of West Orange, took place this morning in St. John's Church here. The Rev.

The United States has now received favorable replies from twenty-eight of the twenty-nine countries that Secretary Hull and President Roosevelt appealed to for a cooperative effort to facilitate the emigration of political refugees.
A total of 326 PWA projects costing $240,204,578 can be started immediately upon notification of fund allotments in Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts.

Ralph E. Smith, Pittsburgh Postmaster since June, 1936, was dismissed today. He announced immediately that he would contest his removal. No general shake-up was indicated as Inspector Thomas C. Cargill and two other inspectors began a general examination of the office's affairs.

The Securities and Exchange Commission's public hearing in the case of Richard Whitney Co. at which J. P. Morgan, senior partner in J. P. Morgan Co., will appear has been set for Tuesday morning in New York.

Construction activities throughout the country were less during the first quarter of this year than during the similar. periods of 1937 and 1936, according to E. M. Craig, executive secretary of the National Association of Building Trades Emplayers.
For improvement with English and Colonial style dwellings, a large tract of land, comprising 147 building lots, in Hollis, L. I., has been purchased by Mrs. Lea Warshauer, builder.
The coming visit of Adolf Hitler to Italy will give a final polish to the axis around which he and Benito Mussolini expect the affairs of Europe to revolve.

FROM a naval officer wearing a Scotch outing cap it was "Fire when you are ready, Gridley!" in the early morning of May 1, 1898forty years ago today. Before noon we had won the Battle of Manila Bay, that glamorous victory suited to the national mood of the hour, for which Commodore George Dewey was hailed as a wondrous hero.

WHEN the author of the abstruse "Experiment With Time" starts fooling with the animal kingdom almost anything may be expected. Here is a farcical extravaganza about some fabulously talented lions of Borneo who landed, of all places. in the hitherto quiet and very English Puddleboro Zoo.
Revenue from the sale of manufactured and natural gas in February amounted to $77,805,300, against $79,382,600 in February, 1937, a decrease of 2 per cent, the American Gas Association has reported.

Jules Blondel, French Charge d'Affaires, conversed with Foreign Minister i Galeazzo Clano for an hour this afternoon. According to the French Embassy, "favorable progress was made toward an accord that may be concluded about the middie of next month." It is uncertain whether, as first reported, a prrlirinary agreement will be concluded before the League Council meeting May 9.

The former Marietta Neff estate, consisting of a large Colonial-style house with seventy-five acres of land at Shaftesbury, Vt., has been purchased by Henry Hopkins Jr., New York attorney, reports Previews, Inc. George M. Hawks of Bennington, Vt., acted as broker in the deal.

Dr. and Mrs. Eduard C. Lindeman of High Bridge, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Lindeman, to Robert Gessner of this city, author and son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Gessner of Escanaba, Mich.

The annual Mission Day of the College of New Rochelle will be held on the campus next Saturday, under the general chairmanship of Miss Mary Lavelle of Astoria, L. I., with the aid of the 734 students of the college.
National Vaudeville Artists Post 690, American Legion, will hold its annual Spring frolic Tuesday night at the Manhattan Opera House, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue.

Baseball--Joe DiMaggio, playing his first game of the year with the Yanks, and Joe Gordon, second baseman, were hurt yesterday as the New York team beat the Senators, 8--4. The two collided attempting to catch a fly ball and suffered head injuries.

WILD geese caused the suspension of training flights by Trans-Canada Air Lines in the region of Grant's Lake in Manitoba recently. Conservation authorities objected because the noise of the planes was diverting the northbound migration from its customary stopping place, and pilots were considerably concerned because the geese, seeming to enjoy prior rights, did not observe the airway traffic rules, according to C. D. B. Colyer, technical chief of the new operating company.
Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, appealed yesterday for a broader educational foundation for all times in public employment.
Thirtyeight-year-old Ted Lyons, veteran of sixteen seasons with the White Sox, yielded nine hits but didn't allow the Browns to pass second base today as he gained his first 1938 victory, 3 to 0.

JOURNALISM, books and the stage have their Pulitzer prizes. The theatre has the New York Drama Critics Circle award. The screen is knighted annually by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Radio as an art has no such citation.

Miss Peggy Marshall heads a junior committee working on arrangements for the preview opening of the St. Regis Roof Tuesday which will serve as a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund. Her aides include the Misses Edith Gould, Ruth Young, Elaine Frueauff, Catharine B. Gamble and Elizabeth Irion.

Maryland dropped Rutgers from the ranks of the undefeated lacrosse teams today, defeating the Scarlet, 11 to 9, on Neilson Field before 1,500. The victory was the twenty-first in a row over collegiate opponents for the Terrapins.

" In all of this," said President Roosevelt on April 14 when recommending his renewed program of government outlay for economic recovery, "government cannot and should not act alone. Business must help. I am sure business will help."

The crack Eighteenth Infantry, one of the famous units in the regular army, will celebrate its organization day on Wednesday with a variety of ceremonies at one of the two posts it garrisons, Fort Wadsworth, on Staten Island.

Another sure sign of Spring is the Aueue of yachtsmen visiting the New York field station of the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey and coming away with armfuls of cruising charts, tide and current tables and other publications which every well-trained skipper has on his bridge.

Bullion valued at $8,013,494 was produced by Ontario's gold mines in March, according to the monthly bulletin of the Ontario Department of Mines, establishing a new record monthly production in the Province's history.

Prospective home buyers in Queens and adjacent parts of Long Island will have exceptional opportunities this week of inspecting the latest home types in all price ranges and also studying building improvement methods and new equipment devices.

With trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday the dullest since Sept. 4, last year, prices moved in an extremely narrow range. Sales amounted to only $2,187,000, against $4,226,075 on the preceding Saturday.

AS firmly as it can without specifying penalties, a clause in the contract between the League of New York Theatres and the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union forbids "ice"--i. e., the sum paid by a broker to a box office in excess of the printed price of a ticket.

If Professor Frederick A. Saunders of Harvard is given time and money enough he may lay down principles which will make it possible to duplicate in a departmentstore violin the tonal quality of the best Stradivarius.

Mr. and Mrs. Griswold A. Thompson of 375 Park Avenue sailed on the Paris for their annual visit to France nd England. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Ramee of 53 East Sixty-sixth Street sailed on the Conte di Savoia to pass the rest of the Spring in Italy. They will return to East Hamp'on, L. I., for the- Summer.

IT doesn't matter what board you spring from--the modern bathroom, housing, radios, railroads, chairs--you can, if you are so minded, take a header into questions of esthetics. Or starting with esthetics, a science all civilization has been engaged in trying to explain, you can swim around in benign ethical, moral, symbolic, religious, gastronomic, climatic, economic circles and without the least strain arrive back at the modern bathroom, housing, radios, railroads, chairs.

Kenneth A. MacDonald of Quinc Mass., was elected president of the Dartmouth Outing Club and chai man of the executive committee that body today. He succeeds Wa ter Averill, who is recuperatin from a serious skiing accident his home in Poughkeepsie, N. Y The club also elected John L. Steel of Chicago as secretary and Win: low Hatch of the biology depart ment as faculty adviser.

Following the seizure by Mexico at midnight on March 18 of the $450,000,000 of foreign-owned oil properties, which Ambassador Daniels termed "a bolt from the blue," diplomatic negotiations were soon under way seeking the return of the expropriated properties.

The fortieth anniversary of the battle of Manila Bay tomorrow finds no officers who participated in it on the active list. The twenty-seven surviving retired officers who fought under George Dewey, then commodore, in vanquishing Admiral Montojo's Spanish squadron were:
The cue to the German press apparently has been to belittle the result of the British-French conversations and express virtuous surprise that the

An outstanding health year for the United States is indicated by the low mortality rate recorded among 17,700,000 industrial policy holders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in the first three months of 1938, it was announced yesterday by the company.
The engagement has been announced to friends here of Miss Alma H. Carvill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl A. Carvill of Boston, to Trentwell Mason White of New York.

Like many another custom of Republican days, now all but forgotten, the political handshake under the New Deal has undergone a metamorphosis, and when glad-handers of the old school read this week an account of Mrs. Roosevelt's frank remarks on the planned economy of greeting she habitually practices, there was a deal of portentous wagging of the head.
Tirana, capital of primitive and pastoral Albania, is a city of mosques and gardens. There are electric lights, a few paved streets, a royal palace with coffee-colored walls and a red roof.

The Social Security Board rejected today a request by the Oklahoma Public Welfare Commission to be made eligible for Federal public assistance grants. The board cut off the Oklahoma board from Federal funds on March 2 on the ground that it had failed to comply with the Social Security Act.

" The Nazi seizure of Jewish property is a sign that Germany's economic structure is steadily weakening and that the collapse within the Reich may come earlier than expected," Rabbi Louis. I. Newman said yesterday in his sermon to Congregation Rodolph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

One of the singular results of the civil war is that Franco Spain has become for the time being an exporter of wheat. The explanation is that Republican [Loyalist] Spain, containing the three largest Spanish cities, embraces the principal industrial zones and hence is a consumer of wheat, while Franco Spain, mainly agricultural, is a producer of wheat.
Henry Shippey, 17-year-old son of Lee Shippey, novelist and newspaper columnist, is missing and his parents fear he has encountered some misfortune.

HUNGARY'S promised series to commemorate the "XXXIV Nemzetkozi Eucharisztikus Kongresszus" (Thirty-fourth International Eucharistic Congress), at Budapest from May 25 through 29, will bring two newcomers to philately's gallery-Blessed Margaret, nun, and St. Maurice, monk and writer, both of whom were identified with early Christianity in the Magyar country.
A change in the conditions of the national sculpture competition for sculptures for the United States Government Building at the New York's World's Fair was announced yesterday.

MAUDE ADAMS, who has stubbornly resisted many Hollywood offers since her retirement from the stage in 1918, has finally given in to Selznick-International and is on the West Coast undergoing screen tests for the role of a wealthy dowager in "The Young in Heart," the I. A. R. Wiley story, otherwise known as "The Gay Banditti."

THE country club era of airplane travel in Europe has arrived. Deck chairs, collapsible card tables, Scotchand-soda are all evidence of it. The time has passed when the majority of air travelers carry bulky briefcases and have urgent business to transact.

Turpentine firm, 23c: sales, 87 barrels; receipts, 563 barrels; shipments, 268 barrels; stock, 31,962 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 563; receipts, 2.215; shipments, 2,425; stock, 86,324. Quote: B, $3.45; D, $3.70; E, $3.75; F, $4.25; G, $4.55; H, $4.60; I, $4.60; K, $4.60; M, $4.62 ; N, $5.05; WG, $5.80; WW. $6.30; X, $6.30.

TWO important salons that will be of interest to the advanced worker have been announced. The Chicago Camera Club, 137 North Wabash Avenue, Chicago, Ill., is preparing the Ninth Chicago International Salon of Photography and will welcome entries.

The marriage of Miss Mignon Wright Vroom, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. H. Vroom of Port Richmond, S. I., to Charles Roger Pollock, also of Port Richmond, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Richmond, S. I.

RADIO-TUBE musical instruments, including the latest de velopments of electronic pianos and organs, will be demonstrated on Thursday evening at Town Hall under -the auspices of the League of Composers.

The German Government news service, in a dispatch sent from Washington, warmly applauds the press law bill sponsored by Senator Minton of Indiana, by which editors would be taken into court if charged with a failure to print facts.
The Greater New York Fllnd will open its appeal for $10,000,000 to supplement the finances of private welfare and health agencies at a dinner tomorrow evening at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BACH'S "St. Matthew Passion" will be given by the Oratorio Society of New York in the nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Thursday night. Complete opera and concert programs of the current week follow:

IT is most appropriate that Tay Garnett should direct a picture titled "The Joy of Living," because it fits him to a T. Indeed, it is doubtful whether there are many folks around who have had as much fun and pleasure out of life as Mr. Garnett.

This is the particular time of a particular year when national thought naturally turns to politics. A little more than six months from now-on Nov. 8 to be exact-voters of the United States will go to the polls to elect 435 Representatives in Congress, 32 Senators, a goodly number of State Governors and many hundreds of local officials.

The Fourth Degree Knights of Columbus assemblies of the Second New York District, comprising New York, Richmond, Bronx, Westchester, Putnam, Orange, Greene, Dutchess and Sullivan Counties, will hold a military ball. and entertainment next Wednesday night at the Hotel Commodore.
The Yale polo team opened its outdoor season today by defeating the Giant Valley Club of Mount Carmel, 10--4. Captain Woolley and Alan Corey scored three goals each for Yale.

As a result of the Students Organization election held recently, Miss Dorothy Lamberton, 39, of Westfield, N. J., was chosen by the student body of Goucher College as president of its organization for the coming year.

Brown University will dedicate its new $10,000 boat club at the head of Narragansett Bay Saturday as a feature of the Intercollegiate Dinghy Racing Association regatta sponsored by the Brown Yacht Club. Sixteen boats from eight colleges and universities are expected to compete.
Mrs. Roderick O. Williams heads a junior committee, whose members will act as manikins for a fashion revue to be held on Thursday at Hampshire House for the benefit of the Hartley House Music School.

NEW YORKERS had a preview of their World's Fair yesterday. They are favored a full year ahead of the rest of mankind, whose invitation won't be good at the gate till April 30, 1939. Even at this early time they behold wonders wrought and waiting amid the shapes of greater wonders still to come.

Edward M. Anderson, a founder o the bookbinding firm of Anderso Priggs at 12 Vestry Street, NeN York, died here yesterday at hi home, 291 Harrison Avenue, after long illness. He was 70 years old Mr. Anderson, who had been pres dent of the firm for many years was a life member of Daniel Car penter Lodge, F. and A. M., of New York.
No matter how or when the war in Spain ends there will be children on both sides of the present fighting line who will be in need of milk, medicine, hospital care and other essentials to health.

THE Spring and Summer motor season is rapidly getting under way, and rebuilt high ways and new links are now available to those planning short week-end trips to mountain resorts, the seashore and other popular points in the metropolitan area.
Opinions on Germany's actual fiscal condition varied widely among bankers and traders last week as a result of the Reich's announcement of withdrawal from the New York World's Fair.

TO make the Westchester music festivals an expression of local culture is the avowed aim of Hugh Ross, director of these annual events. Mr. Ross contends that festival programs in smaller communities of this country differ from those in the larger centers in that they constitute a wider manifestation of indigenous culture.

More than 500 persons were present this afternoon at the annual luncheon, bridge and fashion show of the business women's division of the Westchester County Women's Republican Club at the Westchester Country Club here.

The American Union for Democracy announced yesterday that it had started a national campaign to arouse popular interest in the first ten amendments to the Constitution, commonly called the Bill of Rights.
WITH the bricks of their old homes flying about their finally convinced heads, Los Angeles Chinese are on the move.

Hollins Nicholas Randolph, member of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission and a descendant of the former President, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 2,230 California Street, N. W., at the age of 66. He had been ill several months.

AT the beginning of his book on country living Charles Morrow Wilson makes a statement which may be charged to either the plus or the minus account: "A good time in the country rests upon a foundation of plain, personal discipline, which is definitely and tangibly attainable."

A receiver was appointed yesterday for the trust fund estimated at $1,200,000 which Basil Allen Ryan, a grandson of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, utilities and traction official, is to get when he becomes 30 years of age next July.
Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Charles M. Monagas of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Maria Monagas, to Norris Joseph Horn of Philadelphia.

The almost deserted port of Tacoma, which normally handles about $131,000,000 worth of goods a year, was closed today by employers because of a dispute between rival Atlantic and Pacific Coast maritime unions.

Study of "brown snowfalls" at Ottawa and Huntsville leads government experts in Ottawa to the belief they had their origin in the United States Dust Bowl. The snow, which fell March 5, brought down with it an amount of solid matter sufficient to produce a brownish discoloration.

B. Ovid Musselman, who overcame the handicap of paralysis to work for a quarter of a century as a newspaper mna, died today at the age of 62. Mr. Musselman set up his own "editorial room" in his bedroom when an illness left him paralyzed and almost blind.

Mr. and Mrs. George Burdick of this city, formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eunice Burdick, to Richard Glenn Gettell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond G. Gettell of Berkeley, Calif.

LONDON. IF any one knows how to create a lovable character in fiction, it is surely the author of "Good-bye, Mr. Chips." But when The Star asked James Hilton to reveal his secret, he could only reply that there was none.

Breaking a 6-6 deadlock in the eleventh inning, the Trinity freshmen defeated the Choate baseball team, 9-6, today. Gordon, hurler for the victors, went the route as the home team's play was marked by seven errors.

IT would require a hardy soul, indeed, to recommend attendance at the WPA production of "Trojan Incident" at the St. James Theatre, for, truth to tell, it is only the dances of Tamiris, supported by the admirable musical score of Wallingford Rieggaer,

NEW YORK seems all at once aswarm with "primitives." And since there are so many of them, and since there will not be time today to delve far into speculation upon what a "primitive" really is and what he is not, from this point on let the quotes be dropped.

Dr. and Mrs. John C. A. Gerster of 18 East Seventy-eighth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Fox Gerster, to Thomas Kirby Schmuck Jr. of 164 East Seventy-second Street, son of Mrs. Kinsey Schmuck of New York and of Mr. Schmuck of New York.

For the first time in many years, both manufacturers and retailers are taking seriously promotion of Father's Day, the volume of orders appearing in the New York market last week indicated. The aim of making the day a "second Christmas," as far as gifts for the country's fathers are concerned, is taking hold in the industry and the promotion this year will be on a nation-wide basis, it was said.
Presi dent Manuel L. Quezon placed Bulacan Province under control of the army to preserve order today as 5,000 tenants and landowners came to grips over rents.

A Department of Agriculture submarginal land project of 10,290 acres in Eastern Connecticut is being turned over to State management for ninety-nine years, Connecticut accepting full responsibility for the protection, maintenance and proper use of the area.

Lefty Moe Jubitz of Yale gave a fine pitching performance today and the Elis defeated Dartmouth, 4--1, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball game. Jubitz, who held Dartmouth to seven hits, was opposed by Harold Wonson, sophomore hurler.

The recent movement to have the large residential area north of Hillside Avenue, between 150th and 170th Street, Jamaica, changed from a small-home district into an apartment house zone presages a radical change in the development of that section, says Edwin J. Dunn, manager of the Jamaica office of the Bulkley Horton Company.

Young Republicans were counseled. here tonight by John D. M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, to join the party organization and to work within it for whatever reforms they felt necessary. Only through party discipline, he told students from seventeen Eastern colleges and universities, delegates to the first Eastern Intercollegiate Republican Club Conference, can party unity and party strength be attained.

TOKYO. WHEN Perry summoned Japan to open her doors, in 1853, he was backed by armaments 200 years in advance of anything Japan could oppose to them. If an American squadron came to Tokyo Bay today it would meet armaments equal to its own. In the span of one long lifetime the Japanese Fleet has risen from the sailing-junk era to the third position in the world.

Nine counties are joining this year in promoting the eighth annual Western New York Apple Blossom Festival at Le Roy on May 21 in connection with the State-wide campaign to promote consumption of New York State apples.
Domestic producers of bonded whiskies expect to offer more severe competition to imported liquors in this market shortly through the introduction of bottles holding a fifth of a gallon.

Circular rooms designed to insure against obsolescence are being provided in the two buildings which are replacing the former home of Marshall Field at 3 East Sixty-ninth Street and 4 East Seventieth Street. Builders usually shun such rooms and all but straight connecting stairways in duplex suites because of the expense involved in such construction.
Stocks firm and mixed in smallest Saturday's trading since Sept. 1, 1934; turnover, 147,770 shares. All groups of bonds irregular in dullest session since September; transactions, $2,187,000.
Postmaster General Farley, concluding a swing through the Southeast, said here today that "the business spiral downward has been stopped."
THE first film Julien Duvivier made was financed by a mustard manufacturer of Bordeaux. That was in 1919. It was a one-man job and Duvivier was the man. He wrote it, directed

In another week or two-perhaps even today-pleasure boat skippers will pull up to a yacht-service station, spread a wide smile as they ask for their first 1938 tankful of gas, and then cast off their dock lines and lay a course for the season's first cruise.

More than two thousand parents and friends of Manhattan College are expected to attend the sixth annual Campus Day fete arranged by the members of the Junior Class this afternoon on the campus of the Riverdale institution.

Real estate as an investment medium is faced with destruction unless a more equitable system of taxation can be found, in the opinion of Nathan Ottinger and Maxwell C. Katz, attorneys, who propose as a remedy a method of levy which stresses income as a better basis for taxes than assessments.

Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons! revealed in explaining the new defense program to the House of Representatives that on completion of the defenses [pound]10,000,000 will be required annually to maintain all services compared with f6,000,000 at Desent.

THE National Automobile Dealers Association, at its convention in Detroit last week, put itself on record for a new set of rules to govern the relations of automobile merchants with each other, with the manufacturer and with the public.
General P. E. Dybenko, one of the most romantic figures of the Bolshevik revolution, has been removed as commander of the strategically important Leningrad military district.

Social implications of magnitude are involved in women's cooperation with the State Department of Labor in making effective the new minimum wage regulations for laundry workers, according to Miss Frieda Miller, chief of the women's division of the department.

A definite trend to reducing the number of styles and price brackets in the lines of leading tire manufacturers will get under way before the end of this year, an executive of one of the leading companies predicted here yesterday.

IT was 9 A. M. hard by Battery Park. The great motorcade for the World's Fair Preview was massing for the start. Floats, floats and floats. Brass bands, jazz bands, fife and drum corps, gendarmes, firemen, soldiers and merry villagers.

Word just received from Chincoteague, Va., indicates that the sea trout fishing is just about the best in years down there and almost too good for some of the anglers. You get a bit worn out after taking forty or fifty of these fish and what to do with so many is a problem.

Without benefit of a single yachting cap or the faintest sort of "heave-ho," about 150 yachtsmen, ranging in age from 4 to 18 years, matched craft and seamanship on the alternately "slick" and choppy waters of the Conservatory Lake in Central Park- yesterday in the fifteenth annual renewal of the Parks Department Spring regatta.
Price trends likely to influence furniture quotations for the balance of this year will be revealed to furniture buyers tomorrow when the mid-season market of the furniture industry opens in Chicago.

Republican leaders in the constitutional convention have decided to write into the preamble of the State Constitution a clause which will define the State's sovereignty and will in effeet criticize the course of the National Administration.
OSLO. UNDER the banner "Vi Kan" (We Can), a Crafts and Industries Exhibition opens in this Norwegian capital on May 12 to continue throughout the Summer.

Twenty-five years of concentration on problems affecting the welfare of the family, and the advancement made in this field during the last quarter century provide the members of the Home Makers' Forum with a fund of reminiscence as their silver jubilee approaches.

President Roosevelt was urged tonight to take the leadership in summoning another Hague conference. The advice was given in an address here by Jan Hostie, former adviser to the Belgian Foreign Office, before the American Society of International Law.
GIVE the lady a circus-ring, and she will set the show afire. Give her a play full of art and she will strangle in the tapestries. So the quip went of Beatrice Lillie.

As a feature of annual house party week-end, the Princeton University Theatre Intime and the Finch Junior College of New York will collaborate in presenting "The Beaux' Stratagem," eighteenth century comedy, in McCarter Theatre on Friday and Saturday evenings.

A BENEFIT for the Elinor Wylie Poetry Fellowship (in association with the Academy of American Poets) will be held next Wednesday evening, May 4, at the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman Beecher Stowe, 1 Beekman Place, New York City.

BLOSSOM time has come rushing again, taking long chances, wasting no shining hour, impetuous in the business of reclothing the dull earth with beauty and eager to start the annual task of perpetuating the plant species while yet the year is young.
Fifteen children got lost at the World's Fair preview yesterday afternoon, giving fair police a preview of what may happen next year in "The World of Tomorrow."
Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hunt of 145 Central Park West have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Geraldine Marion Hunt, to Dr. Jerome S. Coles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Cohen of this city.
Announcement has been made by Paul Occhipinti of Mount Vernon, N. Y., of the engagement of his niece, Miss Erminia Occhipinti, to Anthony J. Graziano of New York.

The police tonight disbanded the Nazi Organization headed by Professor Kantartjeff. Last night it staged violent anti-Jewish demonstrations, smashing shop windows. The organization sponsored several weeks ago demonstrations against lectures oy Professor Popoff, who attacked Chancellor Adolf Hitler's racial theories.

About 100 deaths a day from cholera are reported from Hardwar, in the United Provinces. Fires are burning night and day to cremate the bodies of the victims of the epidemic, which broke out at the conclusion of the Kumbhamela Fair.

Regarded as a model of completeness in annual reports for companies in the retail field, thus setting something of a precedent in that respect, the financial report of the City Stores Company, issued during the week, attracted considerable attention.
Two girls received minor injuries when rival factions clashed as the tail-end of Toronto's May Day parade neared the Queen's Park bandstand, end of the parade route, today.

During many weeks of the year the neat appearance of a formal garden or of border planting depends to a large extent upon the sort of edging plants used. In Spring and early Summer low-growing varieties along the outer line enhance the effect of exuberant, blossoming beds.

His fifteenth best-in-show award was gained by Champion Nornay Saddler, James M. Austin's smooth foxterrier, when he captured premier honors tonight in the ninth annual show of the National Capital Kennel Club.

With the temperature vagaries of a very erratic Spring apparently over, and the weather, at least for the present, a bit more settled, gardeners are hastening to finish their early planting, and are putting in some of the "tender" seeds.
The gasp that swept the House of Commons when Sir John Simon announced his increase in the budget was figuratively echoed throughout the country.

A father and son were arraigned yesterday on charges of violating the lottery laws, after Patrolman Robert Smith of the Police Commissioner's office had arrested them and had seized 2,000 books with chances for a $25,000 drawing purported to be offered by "Our Lady of Victory Home of Charity" at Lackawanna, N. Y.

The effects of the military and economic agreement reached last week in London between Great Britain and France are being ?? keenly in all European capitals. The first results are discussed in the two dispatches which follow.

NOTHING much has happened in the field of poetic drama this season. Although it is important to the serious theatre, it is not prospering just now. Maxwell Anderson wrote this year's "The Star-Wagon" in prose.

Exactly one year before the official opening date of the World's Fair of 1939, visitors who thronged the fair site in Flushing Meadows Park yesterday found preparations advenced to such a stage that a sizable exposition could be held in the buildings already approaching completion.

2d Lt. Arthur L. Keiser Jr., FA -Res., 95' Cedarbrook Road, Plainfield, N. J., 307th Field Artillery, is ordered to active duty effective May 1, at headquarters Elizabeth Reserve District, Postoffice Building Elizabeth, N. J., for training.
Congressional debate on the Naval Expansion Bill and the Army Appropriation Bill has verified the President's assertion that the country is full of "amateur strategists."

The English Football Cup rests in Preston North End's clubrooms today after a lapse of fortynine years. The famous Lancashire team, one of the originals of the football league, won the trophy for the second time today, vanquishing Huddersfield Town, 1-0, in the most exciting finish to a cup final ever seen at Wembley Stadium.

An agreement that will run until March 1, 1939, was signed last night by officials of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company and of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, averting a strike by employes of the.Hudson tube line.

Virgil D. Giannini, younger son of A. P. Giannini, board chairman of the Bank of America, died here on Thursday at the age of 33. A native of California, Mr. Giannini was named vice president of the Bankitaly Company of America, a former Transamerica Corporation subsidiary, in 1930.
Army's varsity polo quartet scored in every chukker to defeat Princeton, 9--2, on rain-swept Devereux Field today in the opening outdoor contest for both teams.

Miss Dorothy Snare, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Snare Jr. of this place, was married to Beverly Walden Warner, son of Mr and Mrs. Frederick Warner of Hackensack, N. J., this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Carl H. Elmore, pastor, and the Rev. Wilhemus B. Ryan of Princeton.

MORE than 500 participants from twenty-nine States will gather in Constitution Hall, Washington, D. C., this Friday for a three-day folk festival announced as the most complete ever staged in this country.

The governing body of the International Labor Organization closed its session today by deciding, after a long secret discussion, to defer its decision on the resignation of Harold B. Butler, the director of the International Labor Office, until its next session on May 31. Worker and employer groups were ready to accept it, but most government delegates desired time to consult their governments.

The League of Nations published today the Swiss Government's memorandum requesting from the May meeting of the Council a "declaration that the traditional neutrality of the Confederation is consistent with the Covenant's provisions."
Prominent medical men from all sections of the country will attend the annual meeting of the Congress of American Physicians and Surgeons, which opens Monday in Chalfonte Haddon-Hall.

All hope that any advantage would be taken of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's visit to Rome to explore the possibilities of peace between the Nazi regime and the Catholic Church came to an end today when Pope Pius left the Vatican and retired to the seclusion of his Summer residence at Castel Gandolfo, about twenty miles south of Rome.

The eighth annual directory of savings, building and loan associations and cooperative banks is being issued by the United States Building and Loan League. Associations in all the States and in the territories of Alaska and Hawaii are listed if members of the national organization.

Tibwin White Sister, a points, owned by George C. Haas of M Kisco, N. Y. and handled by A. O. Meredith of Trinity, N. C., won the open derby in the Sport and Conse vation League's field trials today. This merry working pointer rs an exceptionally good ground her and had two nice finds in the bil fields.

Paris will celebrate May Day tomorrow without newspapers, without taxis and without some of its varied amusement facilities. But most of the essential services will operate and no disturbances are expected.

IT is not easy for even a professional interior decorator to create a fine effect in a room when a client insists on retaining there all his collector's pieces, whether they happen to fit in or not. The usual principles of selection then became unworkable.
Mr. and Mrs. Clement D. Cates of 48 East Sixty-eighth Street and Winterport, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Ann Cates, to Herbert G. Monson of New York.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 29: COLONELS Kromer, L. B., Cav., retired on own application, with rank of major general, effective June 30.
Edward Esmond's Phbaos today won the Victoria Cup by a head from C. T. Applewhaite's Over Coat. Sir George Bullough's Daytona was another head back in third place.
Dividend declarations in April aggregated $164,896,038 for 721 companies, compared to $203,626,918 declared by 1,272 companies in March and to $232,449,421 voted by 806 corporations in April, 1937.

New York City and the metropolitan area will be well represented next Friday and Saturday in Richmond, Va., at the Central Atlantic regional conference of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
Oriskany Falls will have a public library to be known as the Charles W. Clark Memorial Library under the terms of Mr. Clark's will, probated in Surrogate's Court here this week.

New silver and copper coinage, in denominations of from 1 to 50 cents, is being issued here, under a decree of President Rafael L. Trujillo Molina, and the national currency of 1897 as well as United States silver, nickel and copper coins are being withdrawn from circulation.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday a proposed amendment to the State Constitution that would give the State and New York City wide powers to provide for low cost housing, slum clearance and rehabilitation of neighborhoods, including provision for adequate streets, boulevards, parks, parkways, recreational and other facilities.

Real estate in and around Madison, N. J., is witnessing something like its former active state, reports W. Kelton Evans, Madison broker, who announces the recent sale of three houses, twenty building lots and a four-acre tract.

The Oslofjord, new flagship of ?? Norwegian American Line, will ?? her sea trials Tuesday and er speed trials Saturday prepara?? to sailing June 4 from Oslo New York on her maiden transtlantic voyage, it was announced yesterday.

Samuel T. Hoag, for more than sixty years publisher of The Pine Plains Herald, died Thursday in his home at the age of 96. Mr. Hoag retired several years ago. His wife died last November at the age of 93, soon after the couple had observed their seventy-second wedding anniversary.

WITH radio broadcasting revolving along what is called "an axis of ideas," a new trend in court decisions promises to weaken century-old precedents which denied to a mere idea the status of a property right, according to Louis Nizer, New York lawyer, in The Law Review of Columbia University Law School.

The World's Fair preview celebration yesterday gave operators of the city's transportation facilities a foretaste of the extra burdens they must care for when the fair opens a year from now. Cancellation of the evening program because of inclement weather eased a test that was expected, but the railroad, subway and bus lines expect to operate at full capacity today.

Mayor La Guardia and welfare organizations in this city are asked to reconsider their opposition to the legalization of residence clubs in an appeal by Nathan Lidsky, president of the Residence Club Owners' Association, Inc.

Miss Virginia French heads the Alumnae Committee active in the plans for the presentation of the Spring plays by students of Miss Hewitt's classes which will be given Tuesday night at the BarbizonPlaza for the benefit of the Babies Hospital.

The Supreme. Court's decision in the Kansas City stockyards case last Monday, which impelled the National Labor Relations Board today to move toward reopening its Ford Motor Company case and to consider similar action in its muchpublicized Republic Steel and other cases, scored another Federal agency for issuing an administrative order without a full and fair hearing.

Christoffer Hannevig Jr. of Norway, who had large shipping lines and shipbuilding interests in this country prior to the entrance of the United States into the World War and controlled, among others, the Pusey Jones Shipbuilding Company, arrived here today to press claims he has long asserted against the United States for indemnification for his interests, which were requisitioned by the United States when it entered the war.

Class I railways, excluding switching and terminal companies, reported 939,017 employes at the middle of February, the total being 156,953, or 14.32 per cent less than a year previously, the Interstate Commerce Commission announced today.
WITH the completion of two major underpasses at Williamsburg, Va., the Colonial National Historical Parkway now extends from Yorktown to within a mile or so of Williamsburg.

Texans of this Mexican border region, long used to the creak of leather and the hard-riding "yellowlegs" of the army's cavalry of yesterday, got a glimpse of the cavalry of tomorrow during the past week, when 1,400 men of the First Cavalry Division commenced important manoeuvres throughout this area.

Commercial and industrial real estate will be greatly benefited by the Glass-Steagall bill authorizing the RFC to use $1,500,000,000 of its available capital for loans to business and by the new regulations of the Federal Reserve Board and the Securities Exchange Commission,
Government lotteries, pari-mutuel betting and State aid for parochial schools were opposed today by the Northern New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.
Yale registered a sweep today in its tennis match with Cornell by winning the singles, 6--0. Rain halted play in the doubles.

The modern store building being erected on the site of the old Brick Presbyterian Church at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street has been financed by a loan of $1,500,000, it was announced yesterday.

More than 250 undergraduates of Barnard College and their escorts attended the Spring Dance held last night in Barnard Hall on the campus for the benefit of the Undergraduate Land and Building Fund. Proceeds from the dance were added to the fund for the construction of the new building to be erected on Riverside Quadrangle, a plot of ground recently acquired by the college at 119th Street and Riverside Drive.
WE of the United States know less of South American history than we should, but most of us have heard of the war which nearly wiped out Paraguay at about the time of our own Civil War.

Four soloists will be heard during the coming Summer season of Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts of the Goldman Band, to begin in Central Park on June 15. They are Leonard Smith, cornetist, who made his debut with the band two seasons ago;

More than 400 organizations used the placement and information services of the Children's Welfare Federation last year, Dr. Shirley Wynne, president, reported at the federation's annual meeting last week.

Results of a nation-wide poll taken on favorite radio programs of clubwomen, and the presentation of an award for the outstanding achievement of the year in radio are features of the annual luncheon of the Women's National Radio Committee, scheduled for Wednesday at the St. Regis Hotel.
Charlie Grimm's Cubs continued to show little respect for the Cardinals today and gave them a sound spanking, 11 to 5, on the return of the Gas House Gang to its own park.

WESTERNERS and Easterners, too, are rapidly becoming conscious of a vast new outdoor playground area, centering around Boulder Dam. Some 700,000 visitors saw its development last year; the number this year will probably be much larger.

Maurice John Leonard, American vice president of the Punta Alegre Sugar Corporation, died this morning in the Anglo-American Hospital following an operation. His age was 50. Mr. Leonard, a native of Lynn, Mass., had resided in Cuba for the last twenty-five years.
TO congratulate Paul de Kruif on another splendid book is not enough. Something should be done about it, first to spread its gospel and then to fight its fight. It is more

While World's Fair enthusiasts and Communists were marching in other sections of the cify, still another parade was in progress on East Thirtieth Street between the East River and theSecond Avenue elevated line.

Mexico's prohibitive tariff will be reduced somewhat at midnight tonight in accordance with the decree issued by President Lazaro Cardenas on Dec. 31. The tariffs on most articles, however, will be far higher than the 1937 levels.

Ten women golfers are accorded scratch status in the handicap list released by the Women's Eastern Golf Association. Among those who enjoy the highest rating are Miss Jean Bauer, Mrs. Marion Turpie, Mrs. Jonathan Thorne and Mrs. Sylva Annenberg, all well-known in the Greater New York area.

Diet and the part it has played in the physical growth of the Dionne quintuplets will be one of the interesting fields to be explored by the New York State Dietetic Association at its annual meeting, which opens in Syracuse on Thursday morning. Miss Emma L.

When the North German Lloyd liner Columbus sailed at 5 P. M. yesterday from Pier 86, Hudson River, for the channel ports with 965 passengers, Mr. and Mrs. C. Kamermeier rushed to the gangway carrying a 3-months-old baby.

The basic question in European politics just now is this: Can Great Britain make a deal with Germany satisfying Nazi aspirations sufficient to insure a peaceful solution of all European and colonial problems without conceding to the Reich that complete hegemony over Europe that most observers believe to be Germany's ultimate aim?
Even with the best of care in digging a large part of the root system is destroyed when any tree or shrub is transplanted. Therefore the top should be pruned to restore the balance.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Large-scale agitation for National Socialist Christianity and a "National Church" will be resumed here May 28 after a three-year pause. The government has again placed the Berlin Sportpalast at the disposal of the National Church and the German Christian [Nazi] movement.
Aside from a brief flurry during the last two days, no great stock ing up on cigarettes by the public in anticipation of the tax which goes into effect here today was noticed by leading retailers.

After thirty-five years of research du Pont engineers announce that they have succeeded in developing a "sink-and-float" process which makes it possible to remove slate from coal cheaply and thus promote even waste to the highest grade of fuel.
Members of the Buick division of the United Automobile Workers of America voted tonight to withdraw from Local 156, the parent body of the U. A. W. A. in Flint, and form their own local.

Consumer groups and advertisers should cooperate to aid in business expansion, according to representatives and officials of various national advertising organizations who addressed the Second Eastern Conference of Women's Advertising Clubs yesterday in the Hotel Biltmore.
Convicted last December of "stealing a railroad in broad daylight," Joseph Gemma, 38 years old, of this city, must pay the penalty, the Rhode Island Supreme Court ruled today.
NORTHWEST RIVER, one of Labrador's chief fur-trading settlements, will, according to radio flashes, soon celebrate the arrivel of Spring in the Far North.

Use of unapproved methods of firing a blast was responsible for the death of forty-five men at the Red Jacket Coal Company's mine at Grundy, Va., April 22, the United States Bureau of Mines reported today.

HOLLYWOOD. SIDNEY HOWARD'S valid and searching treatise on the history of man's battle with yellow fever has passed beyond the boy-meets-girl stage at Metro and this week was in the middle of the boy-loses-girl phase, with the studio anticipating that the cameras will focus on the boy-gets-girl denouement within a few days.

A battle for possession of Tancheng, in Southern Shantung, twenty miles north of the Lung-Hai railway, today threatened supply lines of a Japanese advance guard that was reported only five miles from the railway.

IN answer to many inquiries from motorists regarding the probable dates on which the various blossoms in the Bear Mountain Park area of the Hudson Highlands, located west of the Bear Mountain Bridge, will appear, Mr. Adolph, chief forester of the park, has furnished the following information:

THE Federal Theatre Radio Division, a project of the WPA, which has become one of the most active drama-producing units on the air, is celebrating its second anniversary by planning a more ambitious series of plays.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 28: COMMANDERS McMorris, C. H., Newport, R. I., to staff, commander Scouting Force, as operations officer. Taylor, W. D., New Orleans, La., to treatment, Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, N. Y.

The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus began packing up to leave Madison Square Garden at 9 o'clock last night, when the sideshow performers and the exhibition animals were through for the night.

With more than 2,000 buyers from all sections of the country registered, the results of the first week of the Toy Fair surpassed earlier expectations, James L. Fri, secretary of the Toy Manufacturers .of the United States of America, said yesterday.

THE Three Choirs Festival will be held, Sept. 4-9, at Worcester, England, under the direction of Sir Ivor Atkins. The London Syphony Orchestra will assist and the soloists will include Benno Moiseiwitsch and Norman Tucker, pianist; Albert Sammons, violinist, and twelve prominent English vocalists.

To upset what Nazis term "the expanding sphere of United States influence in Brazil" after the induction of Oswaldo Aranha as, Foreign Minister, the press released this week an apparently inspired Berlin dispatch branding the TJnited States "a democracy of noise."

The tenth annual Spring dinner of the Silurians, an association of present and former newspaper men, who have completed thirty years' active work on a newspaper, was attended by fifty persons last night at the Hotel Lafayette, University Place and Ninth Street.

Dr. James Jackson Minot, founder and honorary president of the Boston Tuberculosis Association, died today in his home here at the age of 85. Until his retirement a few years ago, Dr. Minot was connected with the Massachusetts General Hospital.

Mrs. Robert C. Clothier was reelected president of the Woman's League of Rutgers University at the annual meeting of the league held today in Jameson Auditorium at New Jersey College for Women. The members named Mrs. L. G. Schermerhorn to succeed Mrs. Norman C. Miller as recording secretary and Mrs. A. R. Johnson to succeed Mrs. John W. Shive as treasurer.

Symons Galleries, one of the old antique concerns in the country, will open its new quarters this week in the six-story building at 12 East Fifty-third Street, which it has leased for a long period from the Mutual Life Insurance Company through Harold W. White. broker.

Launching his third year as a Yankee in his first game today, Joe DiMaggio, the celebrated holdout, played a part in a victory for the McCarthymen over Bucky Harris's Senators, 8 to 4, to give the champions the distinction of passing the .500 mark for the first time this season.
Settlement of the twelve-day strike at the seven Detroit plants of the Bohn Aluminum and Brass Company was announced tonight.
Trainer ?? Sande cut loose with the Chief, his second barrel for next Saturday's renewal of the Kentucky ??, in the Daniel Boone Purse in today's opening card at Churchill towns.

Hank Borowy, Fordham's sophomore pitching sensation, received credit for a two-hit victory over N. Y. U. yesterday at Fordham Field when the umpires stopped the ball game after a shower fell and the Violets had been retired in the first half of the seventh inning.

Keith H. R-pp, 29-year-old resident of Bakersfield, Calif., was ordered held in default of $25,000 bond today on a charge of threatening the life of President Roosevelt. United States Commissioner Featherstone ordered Rapp's immediate removal to California for trial.
Kho Sin Kie, Chinese Davis Cup player, dethroned Henry Wilfred (Bunny) Austin of England as British hard court tennis champion today in an upset. 6-4. 6-4, 3-6. 6-3.

A TLANTIC CITY, N. J.--Tons of turf have been spread on the floor of the Municipal Convention Hall and all is ready for the arrival of thoroughbreds from all sections of the country to compete in the Atlantic City Horse Show, May 10 to 14.

The Kansas Electric Power Company, Lawrence, Kan., a subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, has filed a declaration under the Public Utility Holding Company Act covering the sale of $1,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds and 7,000 shares of no par value common stock.

Aerial photographs of Germany's $5,000,000 "Strength Through Joy" cruise ship, the Wilhelm Gustloff, forerunner of a fleet of twenty similar ships, have aroused considerable speculation here whether these craft with their long upper deck, obstructed only by a funnel, could quickly be converted into aircraft carriers.

Dr. Harold I. Lillie of the Mayo Foundation, Rochester, Minn., was elected president of the American Laryngological, Rhinological and Otological Society at its forty-fourth annual meeting in the Hotel Claridge here this week.

The Legislature adjourned early today without voting on the Administration's "Little TVA Bill" to create a Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority with a proposed $10,000,000 insular government corporation.

The Hapag Lloyd has ordered a ew 36,000-ton liner for its Hamurg-New York service to meet the challengee of the Holland America Aine luxury flagship Nieuw Amterdam, which sails on her maiden oyage early in May. The new.Gernan ship will also compete with he projected flagship of the United States Lines, which will have about he same tonnage.

Two stained glass windows, the gift of an anonymous donor, were installed this week in the main foyer of Dinand Library at Holy Cross college. The windows were designed by Charles J. Connick of Boston, and are dedicated to the memory of the Rev. Edward Joseph Fitzgerald, '88, and the Rev. Michael Earls, '96.

WARNING against the danger of tying up the future usefulness of radio in a strait-jacket made effective by too much regulation, David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, at the recent Town Hall luncheon, discussed radio's role in the preservation of democracy.

The Long Island National Home Show, which opened yesterday in the Jamaica Armory, 168th Street near Jamaica Avenue, and will continue throughout this week presents displays from more than 100 exhibitors in home construction, planning and equipment.

Rudy York's home run with two on base in the first inning gave the Tigers the nucleus of a 5-3 victory over the Indians today. The Tribe remained in first place despite the defeat, its third of the season against eight victories.
After months of desultory engagements and holding offensives, the army (with the help of the WPA and a 450-gallon spray) has finally launched a major offensive against invading foreign hordes.
THE Hopi are the most remote among all the Pueblo Indians from white civilization and they are the only ones who still live "in the land where the great apartment houses flourished in the past."
Former Mayor George J. Zimmermann, awaiting trial on bribery charges, was in a coma in his home tonight, victim of a mysterious attack of illness tentatively diagnosed as uremic poisoning.

The $35,000,000 housing development planned by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company on the Catholic Protectory site in the Bronx is described as an example of "judicious spending" by I. Jerome Riker, president of Riker Co., Inc,

The "court camarilla" played the decisive role in persuading King Carol to launch his personal dictatorship in Rumania. according to Charles A. Davila, Rumanian Minister to the United States from 1929 until last December.

LIMA. LUFTHANSA of Germany has completed plans to begin during May a regular weekly airplane mail and passenger service across South America from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, to Lima, Peru. The flying distance of about 2,812 miles will be covered in a two-day flight, with ten to eleven hours flying each day.

Bryan Untiedt, who was a national hero at 12 years and a guest of President Hoover at the White House, was in jail at 18 because of his inability to pay a $7 fine for driving a truck without a license.

TODAY is May Day round the world. The pageantry of traditional ceremonies or the marching feet of workers, or both, will mark the day which, since the industrial revolution, is also Labor Day. Parades through the streets, fervent speeches, sometimes riots, have overshadowed the songs that greet the May morning and dancing round the Maypole.

Expressing the opinions of business on means of combating the depression, in a statement issued preparatory to an annual session here next week, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today contradicted practically every proposal put forward yesterday by President Roosevelt in his anti-monopoly message.

A two-run rally in the seventh and last frame enabled the City College junior varsity nine to top Newtown High, 6--5, yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. Catcher Balkin's double to center, which drove Weiser and Schlichter across decided the honors.

Although trade for the country was well under a year ago last week, a few districts began to show gains. Admitting that the figures of the post-Easter period a year ago were easier to beat, there was the opposite factor of the record vacation buying which began very early last year.

TODAY is Child Health Day and President Roosevelt in proclaiming it called on all children "to celebrate the gains they have made during the year in health and strength and to do their part in the year-round effort to promote the health of the nation."

New clubrooms will be opened tomorrow for the New York branch of the American Association of University Women in Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street. The suite will afford double the space which the branch has heretofore occupied in Rockefeller Center.

Another attack on bureaucracy--that "strangling parasitic growth" which Soviet leaders have recognized from the first as one of their greatest internal enemies--was made yesterday in a Kremlin decree greatly reducing the number and complexity of

Miss Grace Elizabeth Lullmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lullmann of this city, was married to James Milton Pike, son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Pike of Newnan, Ga., yesterday morning in Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street.

Three events will mark the silver jubilee of the Hunter College Menorah Society, which will be celebrated for two weeks, beginning May 9. The organization was founded twenty-five years ago by Dr. Dora skowith, now an instructor in the Evening and Extension Division of the college.

The question of the married woman worker is a live issue in Massachusetts. Stormy legislative hearings have been held both last year and this on Beacon Hill on a bill, promoted by the Women's Political Club, providing for a survey of the extent of such employment of married women and its effect on the public relief rolls.
The Holy Cross baseball team defeated Brown, 5 to 2, at Aldrich Field today, squaring the one setback it had received this year.

Despite the offering of the largest single issue of bonds since June, 1937--$60,000,000 of Consolidated Edison of New York 3As-flotations of new securities in April were in the smallest volume for that month since 1933.

Although it has several important unfinished cases on hand, the local field staff of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, largest in the nation, will be reduced by half in May and June because appropriations have been exceeded.
GOLDBERG--Mr. Harry Goldberg announces the bar mitzvah of his son, Jack, at West Side Institutional Synagogue, 76th St., between Amsterdam and Columbus Aves., Saturday morning, May 7.

Playing in driving rain, the Queens Rugby Club defeated Yale on Alley Pond Field today, 11-3. It was the eighth successive victory for Queens, which ended its schedule with this match. The victors played one hand short, using only fourteen men.

Former President Hoover said here today that he favored a revision of the anti-monopoly laws, but that the preceding investigation. should embrace. "the methods of government competition with private enterprise."
From 1,000,000 to 2,000,000 persons turned out yesterday in Manhattan and Queens to see the preview of the New York World's Fair in 1939, which will be officially opened a year from now.
IN the halls of Congress weighty affairs of state are by no means the only sub jects of debate. All manner of topics are brought up for discussion.

BECKERIAN--Dr. and Mrs. Louis Betkerman (nee Bertha Stein) announce the arrival of their son, April 25, 1938, at Woman's Hospital. BERGERON--Mr. and Mrs. Edmond, announce birth of a son, April 27, 1938- at Polyclinic Hospital.
Native iris species have been found useful in the shaded rockery. Iris cristata grows wild in rich woodlands from Maryland to Georgia and westward through the Ohio Valley.

A new plan was announced today at Harvard under which selected national scholars, now being chosen from fifteen Western and Southern States annually, will have their four-year awards extended for work in the graduate departments of the university.

Labor's Leftists celebrated May Day with divided ranks, but there was no disorder even when the rival groups stood within 100 yards of each other. The police pronounced the day one of the quietest since the first observance of the workers' international holiday fifty-two years ago.

The festivity of the maiden voyage of a new transatlantic liner is manifest in plans for a spectacular flower and fashion show arranged for the afternoon of May 20. It will be held aboard the new flagship of the Holland-America Line, the Nieuw Amsterdam, a day or two after the arrival of the liner on her first trip here. The event has been arranged for the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

When the new board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, which will take office on May 16, gets down tq the study of listing problems as recommended by the Conway Committee, it is expected that two changes in procedure will be made.

Princeton's football players who have become adept at rugby beat Harvard, 11 to 6, today in a hardfought game. Harkness scored first for Harvard, but Scott failed to convert, and Salsich of the Tigers equalized before intermission.
GENOA. EXIT from Monte Carlo yesterday in the late afternoon, amid confused whispers of hotel porters and station clerks about a new World War,

Arthur Pitt of the Swiss Turn Verein, a member of the last Olymbic team, took the Metropolitan A. A. U. men's senior gymnastic Championship last night at the rwenty-third Street Y. M. C. A. with an all-around score of 367.8 points.

Setting at rest all doubt as to his ability to carry on, Fighting Fox yesterday smashed home a dominant winner of the $24,450 Wood Memorial at Jamaica after he had been made an odds-on favorite by a crowd that closely approached 20,000.
Supreme Court Justice Joseph B. Perskie signed today the final statutory order approving Asbury Park's $10,735,199 amended refunding plan.
Southern Methodism's sanction of union with other branches of the denomination was attacked as improper and illegal today in arguments before the church's "supreme court."
THE cost of gasoline to the consumer varies between localities for the same reason that the cost of other commodities varies.

Flunking is expensive at the University of Oklahoma, where the board of regents recently levied on students a fee of $3 for each hour failed. Officially the enactment is known as the "Fee for Repeating Instruction." Students, however, have other names for it.

Construction of a wholesale railroad terminal at the Bronx Terminal Market will be started by the city within ten days, according to information transmitted to Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx the Board of Trade, by Carl W. Kimball, Deputy Commissioner of Public Markets, Weights and Measures.
There's no recession in so far as the golf world is concerned, judging by the list of tournaments appearing on the 1938 schedule of the Metropolitan Golf Association.
Fourteen thousand spectators sitting in the warmth of a bright sun saw eight meet records go tumbling into oblivion in the finals of the twenty-ninth Drake relay carnival today.

Little striped garter snakes, harmless enough in meadows where they belong, are terrorizing the housewives in a Fort Dodge neighborhood by appearing in attic staircases, under basement wash benches and underfoot outdoors, almost anywhere over an entire block.

Although lower quotations prevailed abroad, prices on the Cotton Exchange here developed resistance yesterday and closed with gains of 1 to 4 points. Weekend covering and mill completion of May contract obligations steadied the list, with May moving up within 3 points of July.

BERLIN. THE long-drawn-out war between energetic and ambitious little Japan and the ancient, tattered, giant China naturally turns the attention of Europe as well as of America more than ever toward those Far Eastern countries. And literature likes to find new themes in places that hold the interest of the world.

In this green month of May two colleges for women will recall the past of education in America at celebrations of their anniversaries. On Thursday, Friday and Saturday of this week Flora Stone Mather College of Western Reserve University will observe its fiftieth anniversary.

A "sociable" game of stud poker which wound up with two.players striving for a pot of $340,000 in I. O. U.'s and checks, had repercussions today in court action, an investigation by the District Attorney's office and a bodyguard for Harry T. Clifton, wealthy 37-year-old English globe trotter, who lost the pot to Lew Brice, former song and dance man and brother of Fanny Brice, the- comedienne.

The thirty-first annual convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers will be held in Milwaukee June 20 to 23, inclusive. Taxation will be the major theme of the program, with Wingard Miller of Seattle leading the discussion.
William Cogger, Washington attorney, was elected president of the Fossils, Inc., a club of former amateur journalists, at its thirty-fifth annual reunion dinner at the Hotel Astor last night.

The local ticket agent of the Lackawanna Railroad was held up and robbed of $330 this afternoon by a nervous thug who escaped in an automobile. The robber entered the station about 2:30. There was only one other person in the waiting room and the intruder waited until he had left.

The annual observance of May Day-the traditional labor demonstration the world over and one of the two great Soviet festivals-was launched today with an unusually strong manifesto issued by the Communist International from its headquarters here.
May Day will be just another Sunday in Italy. Premier Mussolini linked May Day with the anniversary of the founding of Rome celebration April 21.

Demolition of cell blocks in the old Westchester County Jail' on Martin Avenue will be begun next week, the Board of Supervisors announced. The building will be remodeled for the storage of seldomused records belonging to the County Register and County Clerk. The low bid on the work is $12,100 and a contract will be awarded on Monday.

THE late President Goodnow of Johns Hopkins University once wrote that Chinese life was so intimately linked with agriculture that the country had a vegetable civilization. Dr. Buck's monumental survey portrays how true this is: the roots of the Chinese do go deep into the earth, an earth which is often none too good.
The board of governors and the executive committee of the New York State Association of Young Republican Clubs met here today to adopt a report of the platform committee of the association.

Harvard cleaned up its Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League series with Princeton today, winning, 4 to 1, on Soldiers Field behind righthander Ed Ingalls, who allowed the Tigers only four hits and held them scoreless until the ninth inning The Crimson collected six safeties off left-hander Dawson Farber.

Edward Tuck, American philanthropist and one of the most notable friends of France, died today at Monte Carlo at the age of 95. He had been a resident of France for nearly half a century and was one of the best-known Americans here.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Haines Perry of Dover and Nahant, Mass., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Agnes Nicholson Perry, to Nicholas Conover English, son of Mr. and Mrs. Conover English of Summit, N. J.
