As the end of the week coincided with the end of the month, a few exact comparisons on recent trading in the markets are afforded. According to THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks, the market was off 4.65 points on the week, the poorest showing for a week since that ended on March 26.
??up to the close of business yesterday totaled $224.784,975, or $5,841,221 more than was collected up to April 30 last year, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, reported last night.

In the hope of providing facilities for the largest number of men and women in the history of the school of The Seeing Eye at Morristown, N. J., plans are now being made for the New York membership enrollment next Autumn.

The lightweight crews of Columbia and Cornell divided two races over the Henley distance on the Harlem River yesterday. Cornell's varsity 150-pound boat came from behind in the last quarter mile to win by a deck in 6:16.8 after trailing the Lions by a length at one stage of the mile-and-five-sixteenths race.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's plans for rebuilding the city of Munich, along the lines of the Berlin reconstruction project, were made public today. The Munich transformation will include more palatial Nazi party offices, new subways running north and south and east and west,
Substantial savings to investors and the speeding up of mortgage reorganizations are being achieved by the State Mortgage Commission under a new method of handling certificated issues in its care.
In hundreds of filing cases and desks of Washington officialdom lies the evidence of a new American indoor sport--evolution of plans "to end the depression."

The annual celebration of Parents Day will be held, weather permitting, at 3 P. M. on the Central Park Mall next Sunday, it was announced yesterday by Uncle Robert, philanthropist and originator of the S. O. S. (stay on sidewalk) safety campaign in the city's schools, who will act as master of ceremonies.

WITI the start of strenuous Spring and Summer sports, action pictures have returned to vogue. Baseball, tennis, track, rowing, horseback riding are all popular subjects and present photographic activity about the playing fields indicates that New York photographers are not overlooking any of these possibilities.

Fred A. Cauchois, of Kew Gardens, L. I., one of the best known gunners of the metropolitan district, won the trapshooting championship of the New York A. C. at the Travers Island traps of the organization yesterday. He broke 196 out of a possible 200 on rounds of 97 and 99. Tracy H. Lewis, who won the title last year. had 191.

Students from New York and New Jersey attending Georgian Court College comprise the majority of appointees to the committee of the junior class annual Spring prom, to be held May 6 at the Hotel McAlpin, Manhattan.
Frederie loyse died on the guillotine at awn today for the torture-muder if his 5-year-old illegitimate son, Maurice.

Backing for a third party, if the New Deal is repudiated, was pledged by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, at a May Day rally held by three locals of his union at the Hippodrome last night.

Dr. J. C. Steinberg and D. W. Farnsworth of the Bell Telephone Laboratories photograph the vocal cords at the rate of 4,000 pictures a second. On the pictures the cords separate and move upward simultaneously much like lips puffed out by the breath.

Today Long Island Women's Cornell ClubTea, home of Mrs. Charles M. Reed, Hempstead. Monday A. A. U. W. (Queens Branch)-Annual May dinner and election. Dr. Margaret Schlauch, speaker, 6:30 P. M., Beechwood Yacht Club.

LOUISVILLE. THE annual pilgrimage to Kentucky--"horse heaven"-- has begun, and by Derby Day, next Saturday, Churchill Downs will look from a distance like a field of straw ripening in the breeze, so great will be the bobbing of new hot-weather hats.

Behind the superb pitching of Larry Shea, who allowed the opposing batters a scant two hits in eight innings of play, the St. John's University baseball team overwhelmed the City College nine at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, 11 to 0. Rain caused the game to be halted at the end of the eighth.
THOSE who read "The Affair of the Searlet Crab" will probably remember Huntoon Rogers, the Professor of English who doubles as a sleuth.
UNIQUE support has been given both by artists and the public to the exhibition and sale arranged- by the Joint Distribution Committee and current throughout this week at the Studio Guild Gal'leries.

Jose Maria Cantilo, Argentine Foreign Minister, accompanied by a considerable retinue, arrived in Chile today for a four-day visit. He expressed a desire for closer friendship between Chile and Argentina.

TWENTY-FIVE new laws affecting motor vehicles were enacted at the last session of the Legislature which ended on April 18, when Governor Lehman completed work on the thirtyday bills. Of this number fifteen will go into effect on July 1, the remaining ten being now in operation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This is an attempt to appraise the current American situation in terms not of group or sectional needs but of the national interest. It proceeds from the premise that beneath the clash of conflicting demands and more immediate concerns labor, industry and government have fundamental interests in common.

Voting down claims by representatives of Cuba for an even larger cut, the International Sugar Council today decided to reduce total quotas by 5 per cent, as it is empowered to do by the international sugar convention signed last year.

Younger members of society headed by Mrs. Quincy S. Cabot will serve tea at the annual bridge and garden bazaar in behalf of Save-A-Life Farm, which will be held Tuesday afternoon at Sherry's. Mrs. Cabot's aides include Mrs. Daniel...

MANHATTAN IMcCORMICK, MARGARET F. (April 7). Estate, more than $10,000. To Mary McNany, executrix. 2,305 University Ave., Bronx. $4,000; Ann McNany, same address, $2,000; Catherine McLaughlin. 43-36 193d St., Flushing, $2,000; Mary Touhy, 445 W. 49th St., and Annie Dhew, 21-46 Hazen St., Queens, $1,000 each; six minor bequests.
The first tangible consequence of the London conversations will be a joint FrancoBritish representation to Berlin and Prague in the interests of a peaceful settlement of the Sudeten question.

Ten detectives and ten patrolmen from Emergency Squad 4 spent several hours yesterday searching for Marie Bucci, 10.years old, who was reported by her father, John Bucci, as missing from her home at 522 East Eighty-fourth Street since early Thursday morning.

Miss Sally Ann Atwood and David Hamilton Smith had twenty-five attendants for their marriage here this afternoon, which took place in the Cathedral of St. John. The ceremony was performed by the Rt. Rev. Granville Gaylord Bennett, who was assisted by the Rev. Arthur H. Beaty, rector of the cathedral.

THE New York World's Fair will fire a double-barreled gun in the second day of its preview today. The proceedings, which come under the general heading of a May Day Music Festival, will be divided between a pageant and program of folk and contemporary art in the afternoon and a formal concert in the evening.

In the Eighteen Seventies, when horse-cars were the main reliance of commuters between the Battery and Harlem, citizens protested against the prospective noise and unsightliness of proposed elevated lines.

A SIMPLE flared metal horn designed as an aerial to project radio's micro-waves in a desired direction in much the same way that a horn beams sound, has been developed by Dr. Wilmer L. Barrow in the communication laboratories of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

A decision in the suit of stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation to restrain the directors from asking at the annual meeting on next Thursday approval of cancellation of the company's management stock ownership plan, is being held in abeyence by Justice Pecora, it was disclosed yesterday, pending a ruling by Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum, whether the action should be brought in the United States District Court.

William A. MacLaurin of Victoria, B. C., has won first prize for an architectural plan in a competition among graduate students of the Columbia University School of Architecture under sponsorship of the New York section of the Illuminating Engineering Society, it was announced yesterday.
Honorary degrees were conferred yesterday by the University of Richmond upon Ellen Glasgow, author, and Charles Hoffbauer, artist, in recognition of their contributions to literature and art.

Reports from many of the lake areas in the metropolitan section indicate that the coming season will reveal more activity in Summer home occupancy and new construction than has been seen for several years.
The entire question of transit unification for New York City is scheduled to appear as an issue in the State Constitutional Convention.

The Washington Heights Town Club, which has been in existence as a social and cultural organization for four years, yesterday afternoon opened its first art exhibition at its headquarters, 807 Riverside Drive.

Completing the program for their twenty-third annual convention to be held in St. Louis May 23 to 26, officials of the National Association of Purchasing Agents announced yesterday that a new feature on the agenda this year will be a convention session devoted entirely to the discussion of business conditions in all sections of the United States and Canada.
Greystone, the estate of Samuel Untermyer in Yonkers, will be opened to the public next Saturday as part of the garden day tours program, sponsored by the Westchester County Children's Association.

Harvard's formidable tennis team was leading Columbia University's unbeaten netmen, 4--2, yesterday at the South Field Courts when rain caused the match to be halted with three doubles still to be contested. The Blue and White had previously won all its seven team matches.

THE lot of an understudy is not a happy one. Abnormally healthy, as a rule, Frank Nugent, this department's leading man, two weeks ago contracted a deliberate and highly selective form of disability; he arranged to undergo a throat operaation during a time which, in the most charitable spirit in the world, we can only describe as an off period in the cinema. Now, as Mr.
The jinx that usually follows a medalist held no terrors for the Stuhler brothers, Bob and Arthur, in the invitation four-ball golf tournament at the Lido Country Club today.
Miss Frances Lathrop Chapman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Burr Chapman of this city, became the bride of Tohn R. Hollister of Beverly, Mass., this afternoon in St. Mary's Cathedral.
J. L. Garvin, resuming his weekly review in Viscount Astor's Observer, says that "a deep difference" still lies between Britain and France over Czechoslovakia.

MILITARY transports from the principal bases of the United States Army Air Corps were shuttling in and out of Mitchel Field during the last week bringing supplies and personnel for the manoeuvres which will concentrate on the protection of New England from a hypothetical enemy during the next two weeks.
The Outdoor Cleanliness Associatibn, headquarters at the Barclay, will hold an exhibition of city gardens on the afternoons of Thursday, Sunday and Tuesday, May 5, 8 and 10.
In a letter to THE TIMES, published last week, an excerpt of ghost-writing which differed from the familiar type was produced.

Navy had an excellent day in its major sports today, with the baseball team rallying strongly to defeat Pennsylvania, 9 to 5, and then the crews adding one more clean sweep in a brilliant regatta as they turned back the eights of Cornell and Syracuse in the freshman, junior varsity and varsity- events on the rain-swept Severn River after the sternest sort of fighting.

Economies effected by architects, builders, building materials manufacturers and heating and ventilating engineers have cut down the consumption of coal by home owners, according to a recent report of the National Bituminous Coal Commission.

Addressing his remarks to that group of persons who are neither 'to the left or to the right," Representative Bruce Barton, who spoke yesterday at the twentyfourth annual Spring luncheon of the Theatre Assembly at the Hotel Astor, said that what was needed was strong faith in the United States and not a "short view." More than 600 members, including guests, attended.

Miss Dorothy May Luckman Garside daughter of Alston Hill Garside and the late Mrs. Garside, was married here this morning at the home of her father to Joseph Chandler Robbins Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Robbins of White Plains.

Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Earle King of Meriden have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Whitcomb King, to Lieutenant Enrique D'Hamel Haskins of the United States Navy, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. A. Haskins of Brooklyn.

The marriage of Miss Hilary Vincent Stanyer, daughter of Mrs. John Frederick Stanyer of New York and the late Mr. Stanyer, to William Georgi Rodgers, son of Mrs. Georgi Rodgers of Elizabeth, N. J., and of Earle Vincent Rodgers of Cranford, N. J., took place yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension.

Ten vice admirals and rear admirals have been moved to allow a change in the high command in China after sixteen months of fighting. The changes are so arranged that Vice Admiral Kiyoshi Hasegawa receives what is regarded as a handsome promotion.

IN a changing world of theatrical entertainment, with living people taking a secondary place to mechanical reproductions, one branch of stage production goes on very much as it did twenty-five years ago--grand opera for the masses.
Radio broadcasting of Argentine and foreign national anthems, except in special cases, was forbidden in Argentina today. The ban prohibited broadcasting of foreign hymns,

Dr. Lauge Koch, the Danish explorer, departed by seaplane today for Spitsbergen, a group of Norwegian Arctic islands, to start a polar expedition to determine whether firm land exists between Spitsbergen and North Greenland.

Arthur Henderson, British Labor Member of Parliament, has given the press his impressions. of his interviews with political leaders here, saying he was delighted to come to Czechoslovakia, a country that had remained faithful to democracy.

SALVADOR'S promised set commemorating the United States Constitution reached New York last week. Comprising two values, an 8-centavo for regular postage and a 30c for air mail, they are identical in design except that a plane is shown on the 30c.

The boys' basketball team of the Lewis and Rivington Streets Playground, Manhattan Borough champions, won the city title yesterday afternoon when they defeated the team of Highland Park Playground, Queens champions, in the final game of the Park Department's annual tournament at Roosevelt Playground. Chrystie and Hester Streets.

Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's radio broadcasting station, WHAZ, is ending its sixteenth year with perhaps a thousand alumni engineers scattered over the world who are "immune to microphone fright and whose task of getting on in the world is probably helped more than they realize by the hours they spent in the studio."

The appointment of a special committee to investigate relations between unemployment insurance and relief agencies, announced here Friday by Professor Herman A. Gray, chairman of the State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance, led William Hodson, Commissioner of the Department of Welfare, to express the hope yesterday that the committee investigation would result in quick action.

To aid their Adoption Nursery, which has placed more than 900 babies since it was founded in 1911, members of the Spence Alumnae Association will give their annual dinner dance on Wednesday on the St. Regis Roof.

Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Bradish of Bronxville, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Bradish, to Henry Wadsworth Raye, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Wesley Raye of Eastport, Me.

Gordon S. Braislin, former president of the First Madison Corporation, has formed his own real estate firm, Gordon S. Braislin, Inc., with offices at 551 fifth Avenue and at 188 Montague Street in Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday.

A passenger plane bound from Tirana, Albania, to Rome, was believed today to have crashed near Formia, Italy. The airline office here neither confirmed nor denied that the plane had crashed, but a reliable source said it was certain that disaster had overtaken the craft, which was equipped to carry nineteen passengers, including the crew.

" The Fall of the City," written in 1937 by Archibald MacLeish to encourage American poets to experiment with verse plays for radio, will have its first production at Smith College in dance drama form, as part of the commencement activities.

President Roosevelt's most recent message to Congress, suggesting an allembracing study of the monopoly question, represents a new approach to a problem as old as the activities of commerce and industry.

GROUP and one-man shows, old masters and new abstractionists, oils, water-colors, sculpture and pastels, all played a part in the score or more exhibitions opening last week and remaining current as April turns to May.
The Hershey Chocolate Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on March $1 a net profit of $1,390,187 after charges and Federal income taxes.

Tom Sharkey, one of the famed figures of earlier day boxing and once possessor of a fortune of $250,000, today became an inmate of the Laguna Honda Home-San Francisco's haven for the aged, infirm and destitute.

Sir George Ernest Schuster, British banker, and Lady Schuster; Dr. and Mrs. Hanns Oertel, Mrs. Charles R. Petrie and Hugo Stinnes are due today from the Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

Spurred on by its captain, Alex Northrop, who turned in a 4:17.6 mile to feature the individual competition, the Harvard track team today dominated the second annual New England relay carnival by capturing four other varsity events, including two team races.

Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Loeffler of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carleen Elizabeth Loeffler, to Clarence Conaway McClaine, son of Mr. and Mrs. William W. McClaine of Washington.

All components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity declined for the week ended April 23 and the combined figure has fallen to 75.4. This is its lowest level since the week ended May 6, 1933. The decline was from 77.1. A year ago the index was 107.4.
Official orders disclosed today that the army had started cooperating with the navy in preparing a new air-defense outpost far out in the Pacific at Midway Island.

The one-year suspension of Herbert G. King from the New York Stock Exchange took effect yesterday. The Securities and Exchange Conlmission, it will be recalled, ordered the suspension as a result of its findings in the trial of Mr. King, Norman Stern, C. C. Wright and others for manipulation of the stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd. Mr.

The word axis has in recent months taken on new and diplomatic meaning. It serves as a substitute for entente--a friendly but often informal understanding between nations, a willingness to aid and support one another's aims and policies.

So great has been the rush of early entries for the Morris Essex Kennel Club's show at Madison, N. J.. May 28, that the prediction already is being made that America's biggest dog show will be bigger than ever before. A record was established last year, when 4,104 dogs were benched.

Previews, Inc., reports that two large properties in Connecticut have been sold. One is the sixtyfive acre farm with a ten-room house, formerly owned by Eugene B. Lequin at Woodbury, which was purchased by L. V. Clark of Waterbury. The house is of the Colonial style and was erected in 1774. It has recently been modernized.

The average discounts at which weekly offerings of Treasury bills were awarded last month stiffened in the first half of the period and then fell sharply to the lowest level in the history of Treasury bill financing as the effects of the government's new credit-easing policy took effect.

A resolution "asking for the appointment of a committee to consider the whole question of the present archdeaconry system" of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will be submitted at the coming diocesan convention, it was announced yesterday at the office of Bishop William T. Manning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, who will conduct the Boston Symphony Orchestra at the Berkshire Symphonic Festival, Aug. 6, 7, 11, 13 and 14, will visit Tanglewood, near Lenox, Mass., tomorrow, to inspect the music shed being built to house the festival events.
Charged with disorderly conduct, Anthony Muscolina, 19 years old, of 102 East 123d Street, was arraigned before Magistrate Louis Brodsky in Night Court.

WASHINGTON JITTERS--Tomorrow evening at the Guild Theatre. The dramatization by John Boruff and Walter Hart-plus an assist by Tom McKnight-of Dalton Trumbo's novel of early alphabet days under the New Deal in Washington. Among the Players are Fred Stewart, Helen Shields, Will Geer, Harry Shannon, Bertram Thorn, Robert Porterfield, Francis Pierlot, Forrest' Orr, John O'Shaughnessy and Rose Keane.

Vested with full authority to administer the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 under the mandate of the recent Supreme Court decision upholding the constitutionality of the registration features of the statute, the Securities and Exchange Commission finds itself faced with two major undertakings in its projected regulation of the $15,000,000,000 electric power and light industry.

The marriage of Miss Kathryn Eleanor Kalix, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Kalix of Hartsdale, to William Gustav Hollrock Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hollrock, also of Hartsdale, took place here tonight in the Hitchcock Memorial Church. The Rev. Dr. George Smyth, rector, performed the ceremony.

From Wasco (Calif.) comes the news that the Continental Oil Company has driven a well to 15,004 feet (about 2 5-6 miles), now the world's record. No oil was found at that depth. Hence the casing had to be perforated higher up. Oil began to flow at 13,100 feet, which also is a record.

Norman Thomas, national Socialist leader and his party's candidate for President in 1936, was twice deported from Jersey City last night by Mayor Frank Hague's police in the only May Day disturbance in the metropolitan district.

After a long postponement due to production difficulties, "Rovina," by John C. Baines, will be tried out by John C. Wilson, Noel Coward's partner, in a repertory players' production at the Aldwych tomorrow.

Miss Antoinette Perry, chairman of the American Theatre Council's committee of the apprentice theatre, will be honored at a testimonial dinner on May 23 at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton. for her work in aiding young performers to win recognition in the theatre.

The Reds broke the longest jinx in the National League with a 2-to-0 shutout of the Pirates today. It was Cincinnati's first victory over the Bucs since Memorial Day last year, a record of twenty straight defeats.

A cold rain that descended as the final sections of the motorcade were passing the reviewing stand caused the official. announcement to be made by the fair press department at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon that the outdoor entertainment and fireworks scheduled for last night had been put off until next Saturday night.

SUNDAY having been added to London's television schedule, the program planners have decided to avoid jazz and the "musichall" type of entertainment. The big Sunday item is to be drama, opera and ballet, also an interesting personality talking on a major topic of the day.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in substantial volume, contrasted with the small lots of issues called in recent weeks. Except for a few small municipal calls for May, however, the calls were all for later months, particularly June and July.

A long-threatened relief crisis became a reality today for nearly 75,000 indigent Cleveland residents. Food orders for the first two weeks of May were not mailed last night as the customary distribution deadline Dassed.
The United States was the largest purchaser of Nicaraguan products during the first quarter of 1938, buying two-thirds of all of Nicaragua's exports.
With nineteen hours of broadcasting provided by fourteen programs, the new Pacific Coast headquarters of the Columbia Broadcasting System was opened today.

The coming visit of Adolf Hitler to Benito Mussolini presents a large problem to the authorities in Germany and Italy who are responsible for the safety of the dictators. The precautions taken to guard both Hitler and Mussolini against attempts Upon their lives are described in the following articles.

An inherent weakness of the income tax as a revenue raiser is its failure to produce a uniform flow of income to the taxing power. While so-called reasonable rates in normally good times may provide an ample revenue, in times of stress the same rates are likely to produce an inadequate revenue.
The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, as the general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, under date of Friday, sent the following letter to more than 1,000 Protestant pastors:

Dr. and Mrs. Henry F. Standerwick of 310 Convent Avenue, this city, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Denison Standerwick, to Gerald W. Brown of Montreal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald H. Brown of Ottawa.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry JUstice Kenderdine of Boston have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Wright Kenderdine, to Dr. Theodore Judson Abernethy, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. William S. Abernethy of Washington, D. C.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will give a lecture in Syracuse Friday evening for the benefit of the Harriet May Mills Memorial Fund of the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts. Proceeds will go to the museum for thp fund for its new building.

IN a circle of chairs around an old-fashioned, plainly furnished doctor's office in New York's Criminal Court Building sit five men, all in ordinary business clothes. Four are expert probers of the human mind.

A program on significant forces at work in the world today; with specific attention to the Far Eastern situation, has been planned for the annual convention of the Eastern Federation of Delphian Chapters, to be held on Friday at the Hotel Biltmore.

Los ANGELES. TO take advantage of the growing export market, the Vultee aircraft division of the Aviation Manufacturing Corporation at Downey, Calif., last week embarked on a policy of heavy foreign advertising, expansion and redesigning of its singleengined attack-bomber which today flies in the service of China, Russia, Brazil and several Near Eastern nations.

The Shandon Farm's Burning Star, prominent figure in 1937 stake competition, ran a smashing race today to be eased to the wire in winning the twenty-sixth running of the $10,000 added Philadelphia Handicap, closing-day feature at this plant.
Trading in stocks on the New York'Stock Exchange in April was on a smaller scale than in the preceding month. The daily volume on April 7 dropped to 330,850 shares, the smallest since Sept. 4, 1934.
The New York University freshman nine dropped a 15-13 decision to Manhattan College's yearlings yesterday at Ohio Field in a freehitting contest.
In trade reports from Tokyo there are new indications of that JapaLese economic crisis which has been redicted since the Japanese Army et out on its great campaign in china.

Oliva Dionne, who four years ago thought he "ought to be shot" for becoming the father of the only living quintuplets in recorded history' but later changed his mind on this important point, made another attempt this week to obtain control of his now famous daughters. Like many of his previous efforts it failed.

The Merchants Association of New York has filed with the Senate Committee on Education and Labor a memorandum opposing Senatbr Wagner's bill to extend the National Labor Relations Act to all private employers except those to whom the Railway Labor Act applies.

The average American was accused of racking appreciation of the rights for which his forefathers fought by Rear Admiral Reginald R. Belknap, U. S. N.. retired, at the eleventh annual meeting of the Daughters of the Defenders of the Republic at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va.--The finals of the Spring invitation tennis tournament are being played this week-end. The first rounds were postponed from last Monday to Wednesday, because so many of the contestants were playing in the finals of the Chattanooga tournament, which was delayed by adverse weather conditions.

Charles J. Margiotti, former State Attorney General, charged here tonight that "martial law" was declared in Johnstown and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's plant, closed last Summer by Governor George H. Earle, at the "request of Senator Guffey, John L. Lewis and others."

The National Labor Relations Board has taken steps to reopen its inquiry into the labor practices of the Ford Motor Company, acting after counsel for the company had sought to take testimony from members and aides of the board to sustain its charge that the company had not had a full, fair and open hearing,it became known yesterday.

CROCKFORD'S CLUB, once the most widely publicized bridge club in the country, the meeting place of bridgeplaying celebrities and socialites, as well as the leading champion players of the day, will pass out of existence tomorrow.

Many farms in Monmouth County, in the heart of New Jersey's agricultural belt, are being purchased by city residents who are modernizing and converting them into profitable vacation and yearround living Quarters. Thomas G.

Home runs by Gene Moore and Pinch-Hitter Harl Maggert with the bases loaded helped the Bees hand the Phillies their ninth straight defeat in a 16-11 slugfest today. Moore's homer came in the third inning and Maggert, batting for Niggeling in the seventh, also cleared the bases.

The junior group representing the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery is making final arrangements for the annual Bassinet Dinner Dance to be given Friday in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton to raise funds for the nursery, which is situated at 444 West Twenty-second Street. Well-known entertainers will present a program of divertissements during the evening.
Fifteen thousand persons atched the public burning tonight f books written by Jews and anti?azi propaganda published during le regime of Chancellor Kurt chuschnigg.

The Bronx Board of Trade and the Bronx Joint Committee have renewed their campaign for early action on construction of the Bronx easterly approach to the Triborough Bridge, states Roderick Stephens, president of the board and chairman of the committee.
William N. Fink, United th States mining man, was conditionally freed today on charges that he was implicated in the bomb assassination of Mayor Jose Borunda of Juarez.
GENEVA. -- Because Germany's industrial regions do not "black out" successfully against air attacks, Czechoslovakia has been having all the excitement and trouble over its German minority.

Alfred E. Smith Jr., son of the former Governor, told Supreme Court Justice James T. Cross today that he was virtually penniless and could not make alimony payments of $200 a month to Mrs. Bertha Gott Smith of Syracuse, who obtained a separation decree last year.

Bernie Miller of Harlem won the decision over Jimmy Fantini, Fordham, in the main bout at Rockland Palace last night before a capacity crowd of 3,500. The contest was limited to six rounds because Miller is under 21. The winner weighed 134' and Fantini 136.
Women golfers in the metropolitan district will open their 1938 season officially this week when the New Jersey, Long Island and Metropolitan associations hold their first one-day tournaments.

A demonstration of the rapidity with which a home can be constructed by means of the Tim-BoLok prefabrication method was presented last week in Bergenfield, N. J., on a tract on Vreeland Avenue near Prospect Street under development by the Model Homes Builders, Inc., headed by Elmer Blomkvest.

That marvelous bit of running machinery, OP John Woodruff, turned in two more extraordinary performances in the sunshine, shadows and showers of Franklin Field today as his long, gazelle-like stride carried the University of Pittsburgh to the major honors of the forty-fourth annual Penn Relay Carnival.

The Federal Administration's use of labor legislation to gain political ends at "painful cost to labor" was denounced yesterday as a fundamental cause of present economic ills at a meeting of the platform committee on labor and industry' of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs at the Town Hall.

The executive committee of Southern Californians, Inc., adopted a resolution today asking Congress to abolish the National Labor Relations Board. A mass meeting of members and guests of the organization Monday will be asked to endorse the resolution.
Cavity brick walls, used extensively in Europe, are becoming increasingly popular in this country, according to Myron L. Matthews, writing in the Dow Service Daily Building reports.

Robert Edison Fulton, a pioneer in the automobile industry and former president of the Mack International Motor Truck Corporation, died today of a coronary thrombosis at his home here at the age of 59. Born here, he attended the College of the City of New York and began his business career with the Beechnut. Packing Company.

30.-Plans have been completed for the annual horse show to be held here June 3 and 4 for the benefit of local charities. Mrs. David Wagstaff, president of the Tuxedo Horse Show Association, held a meeting of her committee this week to complete final details.

AIready Vassar seniors begin to feel themselves thrust out into the wide, wide world for room drawing is afoot and every knock on their doors portends juniors, anywhere from one to a dozen of them, picking quarters for next Fall. Like each senior class, 1939, after spending its first three years scattered in seven or eight halls, will move into Main Building.

Joaquin Irrarazaval, executive vice president of the Nitrate and Iodine Sales Corporation, which controls the Chilean industry, denied yesterday that it was planned to close numerous nitrate refining plants in northern provinces to withdraw from these provinces 25,000 Leftist workers before the Presidential elections.

A GREAT international highway, stretching through scenery of rugged grandeur in the hinterland of British Columbia, in Yukon Territory and deep into Alaska, will link the modern highway system of the United States with Fairbanks, just under the Arctic Circle.

That non-agricultural students, faculty and the public may become more familiar with agricultural education and research, a Rutgers University undergraduate club will sponsor a field day next Saturday. The event is expected to draw several thousands to the college farm campus.

Another son of Man o' War, the 9year-old Blockade, owned by Mrs. E. Read Beard, won glory on the turf today when he led all the way to capture the famed Maryland Hunt Cup amid the cheers of a crowd of 20,000.
Among the many wild plants which gardeners like to attempt to tame none is more fascinating than the ground-pine. Unfortunately, few so successfully resist "bringing in."

President Roosevelt was on the high seas tonight, somewhere off the southeastern coast and headed in the general direction of the Virgin Islands, aboard the new light cruiser Philadelphia for a week of fishing and relaxation after nearly a month in Washington charting his new-recovery program and the Administration's anti-monopoly drive.

The New York State Labor Relations Board has notified representatives of the White Plains Publishing Company, publishers of The Daily Reporter, and the White Plains Typographical Union, Local No. 585, of the International Typographical Union, A. F. of L., that the board will hold a hearing on collective bargaining at the Westchester County Court House, White Plains, at 10 A. M. on May 9.
LOAN: Before the SEC last week Charles D. Dickey, J. P. Morgan partner, testified. Also present was Dean Acheson, special counsel of the New York Stock Exchange.

When Governor Clarence D. Martin crossed the Columbia River and went into Oregon for half an hour several days ago, people here on the border wanted him to hurry back before Lieutenant Governor Victor Aloysius (just call me "Vic") Meyers called the Legislature into special session.

Alex Rose, State executive secretary of the American Labor party, denied yesterday the charge of George Meany, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, that the Labor party was designed as an instrument to advance the cause of the C. I. O.

A movement was begun among German exiles here yesterday to arrange a "Germany-in-Exile" exhibit at the World. air, which would interpret "the old culture of the true Germany," and would encourage Germans now in exile to "continue to help make their contribution to world art."

A BORN storyteller, Mr. MacManus has made out of the first thirty-odd years of his life a delightful story and probably his best book. Coming hard on the heels of Sean O'Faolain's recent collection of stories, "A Purse of Coppers,"

Colonel Joseph F. Taulbee of the Army Quartermaster Corps, who was on leave of absence pending retirement, died in the Station Hospital at Fort Sam Houston. Texas, yesterday at the age of 61, the War Department has been informed.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Ernest Schreiber of this city, formerly of South Orange, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Richardson Schreiber, to Eugene C. Gerhart, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Eugene Gerhart of Madison, N. J.

AFTER a postponement caused by the death of Mme. Homolka, Karl Capek's "Power and Glory" has appeared in an English version by Paul Silver and Ralph Neal. As a plea for peace, it will certainly be contrasted with "Idiot's Delight."
Nine cadets from the -United States Military Academy visited the Marshall Chess Club yesterday for a return match with New York University experts, who had defeated them at West Point by 71/2--21/25.

Don Bradman served notice today that he had lost none of his batting skill by hitting a double century in the opening match of the Australian team's English tour. The antipodean captain made 258 runs of his team's 474 for six wickets against Worcestershire.
The Earl of Clarendon, who was one of the closest friends of King George V, was appointed yesterday to succeed, the Earl of Cromer as Lord Chamberlain of the King's Household.

The All Union Fish and Oceanographic Institute of Moscow is telling the world that it is freezing live fish, transporting them, reviving them, then eating them. Some day anabiosis-resuscitation after apparent death-may become of practical value, hopes Professor P. J. Schmidt, scientific secretary of the Leningrad branch of the institute, the man who is conducting the Soviet experiment.

A tentative draft of a rule suggested by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the purpose of which would be to safeguard the capital of commission houses from impairment and restrict general partners of such firms from buying securities on margin for their own account when their firms carry margin
Lumber and building supply dealers from all over the country will meet in Washington, D. C., May 10, and 11 for the annual convention of the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association.

GINSBERG--STORCH--Mrs. Frances Storch to Dr. J. L. Ginsberg, to take place May 1 in Chicago. HOLTMAN--HORVATH--On Friday, April 29, at St. Paul's Lutheran Church, 1,986 Crotona Ave., by Rev. George C. Koenig, Olga L. Horvath to Robert A. Holtman.

The marriage of Miss Alma Allis, daughter of Mrs. Ora M. Walker of Bloomfield, to Arthur William Eriksen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Eriksen, also of Bloomfield, took place this afternoon in First Presbyterian Church here.

Cool Summer lingerie in the shops now is so attractive that it promises to be one of the joys of hot weather. Some of it is charmingly demure, and some is positively glamorous. Almost all of the lingerie mentioned here is moderate or inexpensive in price.

Italy has a very considerable stake in Albania. Apart from large sums of money lent to the Albanian Government she is interested in a number of enterprises in Albania, which represent a very large capital investment and play a not inconsiderable part in the Italian effort to attain self-sufficiency.

The seventeenth annual book drive in New York City of the American Merchant Marine Library Association will be conducted this year from May 19 to 28, under the combined leadership of Thomas J. Watson, Mrs. LeBrun Rhinelander and Mrs. Henry Howard, president and founder of the association.
THE camera never lies" is an old saw. But no one nurtured on the motion picture would ever believe it. The movie's most fundamental job--that of putting reality on the screen--has been neglected.

The marriage of Miss Florence Mooney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel John Mooney of 29 Washington Square, to Arthur Joseph Halleran, son of Mrs. Thomas Augustus Halleran of Flushing, L. I., and the late Mr. Halleran, took place yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph, Washington Place and Sixth Avenue. The ceremony was performed by the Most Rev. Raymond A. Kearney, who was also the celebrant of the-nuptial mass that followed.
Teachers desiring sabbatical leaves must file their applications before May 14, Superintendent of Schools Harold G. Campbell announced last week.
Complete tranquillity prevailed throughout the country tonight as voters prepared to go to the polls to morrow to elect a President to succeed Dr. Alfonso Lopez, whose four-year term ends Aug. 7.

About 1,500 guests, representing every branch of the industry, are expected to attend the Summer Millinery Fashion Show to be held Tuesday evening at the Astor Hotel, Walter K. Marks, chairman of the trade promotion committee of the Millinery Stabilization Com mission, said yesterday.

Dr. Lewis Webb Crigler, surgeon director and secretary of the board of surgeons of the Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital, died suddenly yesterday afternoon of a heart attack in his office at 653 Park Avenue. He was 61 years old.

The Spring primaries and the elections to follow promise to keep politicians and the public in some Statesmore particularly the closely contested ones--in turmoil over accusations and counter-accusations involving politics in the WPA.
The Merritt Parkway land situation "cannot happen again" in Connecticut, Governor Cross told the biennial convention of the State FederaLion of Democratic Women today.

Hannibal, Mo., dethroned Williamsport, Pa., as the basketball title-holder tonight in the international Y. M. C. A. championships, defeating the Pennsylvanians, 57 to 48, in the final. The wrestling title went to Baltimore with 10 points.

Harvard made a happy start in its 1938 rowing season today, all four Crimson crews capturing their races in the second annual Rowe Memorial Regatta against Rutgers and M. I. T. Prevailing by steadily increasing margins, the freshman, junior varsity, varsity 150-pound varsity eights rowed to victory over the Henley distance on the Charles River.

Czechoslovakia took extensive precautions today to prevent possible disorders in tomorrow's celebrations of May Day. The government announced that an order forbidding political parades would be enforced strictly.

Eugene S. Burke of 20 Franklin Street, former postmaster and active in civic and religious affairs of this community, died today in All Souls Hospital. His age was 86. Mr. Burke was born in Morristown, a son of Thomas W. and Mary Elizabeth Cogan Burke. His father, who came to this country from Ireland in 1840, had a farm outside of Morristown. In 1882 Mr.

The rev curbside parking meters here will be operated Sundays as well as weekdays, beginning in May, according to an announcement by Mayor Charles D. White.
" VICTORIAN CRITICS OF DEMOCRACY" should appeal to a wide audience among that small but constantly growing minority who regret the gradual passing of the good book and the private buyer.

Mr. and Mrs. F. Starr Collins of Sunset Farms, West Hartford, have announced the engagement of Mr. Collins's daughter, Miss Josephine Toy Collins, to Bradford S. Tilney of New York, son of Mrs. Sargent Tilney of Simsbury, Conn., and the late Robert F. Tilney.

Very young members of St. James Church will participate in, as well as enjoy, the Spring fete and bazaar which takes place Thursday afternoon at the Plaza. Not only have a wide range of divertissements been planned for their amusement but one of the features

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended April 27, aggregated $7,976,000,000, or 5 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week, which included five business days in some of the reporting cities, and 9 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

A May Day bicycle breakfast party will be held today under the auspices of the New York Wellesly Club. Starting at 10:30 A. M. from 100th Street and Central Park West the cyclists, under the leadership of Mrs. Ivy Lee Jr., will ride through the park to Armando's in East Fifty-fifth Street, where breakfast will be served after a program of tandem riding, races and costume stunts outside the restaurant.

For a week Barnard College students have been participating in making a movie to record the academic and extra-curricular life of the college. Scenes of classes in session including shots of microphotography in the physics laboratory,

Miss Anne Johnson, superintendent of nurses at Queens General Hospital, will be inducted as president of the Business and Professional Women's Club of Queens County on Wednesday evening at the Jamaica Y. M. C. A. Mrs. Harry Harvey Thomas, parliamentarian of the State Federation, will officiate.

In observance of National Music Week, beginning today, a series of five free lectures on music has been arranged by Dorothy Lawton, chairman of the libraries' committee, Municipal Art Committee, to take place at the music library, 121 East Fifty-eighth Street. The lectures follow:

A. H. Ginman, president of the Ianadian Marconi Company, said Yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Montreal that firstuarter profits were above last ear, but that he did not care to omment on the future.
William H. Vanderbilt has announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor of Rhode Island. The announcement was made at a meeting of the Portsmouth Republicans.

A constitution, which will lead to a union of the principal Protestant sects in France, was adopted at the Protestant Assembly held this week at Lyons. At the close of the meeting a message from the delegates was addressed to all the pastors of these sects giving notice that the Union of Protestant Groups will go into effect on Jan. 1 next year.

The American Agents Plate Glass Insurance Company, New York City, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 2,500 common shares of $100 par value to be offered at $200 a share. , Proceeds will be used for capital and surplus. No underwriter was named.

Miss Jane Dahl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George V. Dahl of Chicago, was married to Russell W. R. Powell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell W. R. Powell of New York, today, the twenty-fifth wedding anniversary of the bride's parents.

Period furniture, Brussels tapestries, decorations, and objects of art, including property of Mrs. James P. Donahue of this city and other owners, and of estates, will be sold at auction at the ParkeBernet Galleries on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Six of the seven high-school teams entered in the championship series of the Interscholastic Chess League of Manhattan and the Bronx played in the first round at the rooms of the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday.

The following Foreign Service changes since April 22 were announced by the State Departmen today: Charles E Bohlan of Ipswich, Mass., sec ond secretary of the embassy at Moscow assigned as consul there to serve in dual capacity.

The retirement of Waiter W. Kohl after forty-three years of service with the International Mercantile Marine Company and its predecessor, the Atlantic Transport Company, was announced yesterday by Basil Harris, vice president. The retirement will be effective today.

FANNY BURNEY'S "Diaries" are one of the great chronicles of social England during the last half of the eighteenth century. Not so wide in scope or so animated in expression as Horace Walpole's "Letters," they yet present a picture of scores of people worth knowing from the hand of one who knew them all.

WASHINGTON.--The more than 1,300,000 holders of United States Savings Bonds, otherwise known as "baby bonds," the most widely distributed single security in America, are not satisfied with financial participation in government affairs but, like stockholders, seek continuously to guide the Administration by a large volume of letters.

Five out-of-State officials of the Columbia Gas and Electric system pleaded innocent today to indictments charging the local subsidiary with fraud by diluting natural gas it sold. The five appeared without notice and posted bonds of $2,000 each.

With the spread of the "garden center" movement during the past few years to almost every State in the Union, there came discussion among metropolitan gardening enthusiasts as to why New York had no such center.

The second in a series of three news seminars on "Germany and Her Neighbors," conducted jointly by the Westchester Federation of Women and the Westchester League of Women Voters, will be held tomorrow at 10 A. M. in the Crestwood Library Lounge.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Edward Flannounced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Elizabeth Flanders. to Dr. William Whitney Ballard of Hanover, N. H., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Ballard of Greenfield, Mass.

A VERY kind reader, in a letter too long to be reprinted here, asks, apropos of last Sunday's account of certain compositions and theories of the late Henry F. Gilbert, how any composer, or writer, for that matter, can seriously suggest the development of our native musical art based upon so-called "American" folk-music.

Mr. and Mrs. James F. McClelland of Greenwich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Kearny McClelland, to Julian Shumway Barrett, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Felton Barrett of Rye, N. Y., and North Egremont, Mass.

THOSE who point out in these days of forceful national expansion in Europe and Asia that the war which was to "make the world safe for democracy" bred only a nest of dictators, fail to consider that out of that war's devastation also grew a new

In the Anglo-French military defensive alliance, announced Friday in London, resides the strongest factor for the preservation of peace in the Old World. In the pooling of the forces, land, air and sea, of the two great European democracies, force is aligned vis-a-vis the force upon which the dictator nations have been depending for the furtherance of their purposes.

New Yorkers went officially World's Fair-conscious yesterday and in a city brightened with myriad blue, white and orange banners almost a million men, women and children watched the sprawling motorcade wind toward the exposition's preview.

Although outhit by eight to six, Long Island University's baseball team defeated Brooklyn College, 6--3, at Dexter Park yesterday. It was the second triumph for the Blackbirds over the Kingsmen this season.

Encouraging reports of improvement in the real estate market throughout the country supplemented by increasing loans by savings and loan associations for new home construction were presented to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board by the presidents of the various Federal loan banks at their recent semi-annual conference in Washington, D. C.

Belgium's Tennis Federation will support the suggestion to hold the last two Davis Cup tennis rounds biennially instead of annually. The suggestion will be made at a meeting of the Davis Cup nations in London this June.

The police of Branch Brook Park found today the body of Charles I. Korb, 55 years old, one of the great European jockeys of two decades ago, in Branch Brook Lake between Bloomfield and Park Avenues. He had lived at 71 Orchard Street.

What is believed to be a new hormone that is concerned with the normal transport and utilization of fat by the body has been isolated from fresh beef and calf pancreas in the laboratories of the University of Chicago.

THERE is a crack train out of Boston to New York today called the Puritan. When I used to come here from Boston years ago I traveled on the Puritan, but she was a boat. Her sister ship on the Fall River Line was Priscilla.

A campaign to explain the residential and recreational advantages provided by Sussex County, N. J., is being launched by the Board of Freeholders and other interests in the county. Among the sponsors are R. D. Ayers, J. R. Roe and A. B. Rude, members of the Board of Freeholder;

A new gallery for the exhibition of decorative and architectural products will be opened next Fall in the International Building at Rockefeller Center by the Permanent Exhibition of Decorative Arts and Crafts, which has leased the major portion of the mezzanine floor and a large part of the third floor.

Plans are going forward rapidly for the entertainment to be known as an "Anti-Jinx Party," arranged for the benefit of the Women's Auxiliary of the social service committee of the Knickerbocker Hospital, which will be held Friday night, May 13, at the formal opening of the roof garden of the Montparnasse Restaurant.

The 1-cent stamp tax on packages of cigarettes, effective today, will produce a net gain in revenue for emergency relief of from $4,500,000 to $5,000,000, as compared with the original estimate. of.$3,000,000, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, predicted yesterday.

The New York Public Library announced yesterday that henceforth it would issue monthly bulletins which will list the library's exhibits each month. These broadsides are intended for posting on bulletin boards or for information of publishers.

Not everything is totalitarian in this totalitarian world after all. Here in China, behind the lines in Hankow, you have the perplexing and exilarating spectacle of Germans and Russians fighting on the same side.

Faced with a greater than seasonal decline in advertising linage during the coming months, many types of advertising media laid plans last week to combat reductions of promotional budgets during times of business depression.

Congress's aversion to doing much about anti-trust or other controversial matters at this session became increasingly manifest today and Administration leaders concentrated on whipping President Roosevelt's lending - spending program into shape for an early vote.

Eleven persons required medical aid in Queens yesterday after having participated in one way or another in the World's Fair preview. Two were girls who rode to the site on the prize-winning Florida float.
THESE five bulky volumes cover less than a decade in the life of their author. In volume of writing alone they bulk greater than the life work of many a professional literary man.

HOW to preserve the genetic quality of the American people is the theme of Messrs. Fritts and Gwinn. They lyrically recommend farm life. Civilized living, say the authors, is promoted by farm life and discouraged by modern city life.

Ben Altheimer, retired banker and philanthropist, died at his home, 28 East Sixty-third Street, yesterday morning, after a brief illness. He was 88 years old. Mr. Althelmer was identified for many years with civic movements and he was widely known for his work in making Bundle Day a national movement.
THE Bible has always been the best seller among printed books, and it is safe to assume that it enjoyed that distinction even in the age of manuscripts.

A TRAGIC destiny has pursued Ypres, the one-time capital of Western Flanders. The Niobe of Belgian cities! Except for intermissions devoted to peace and progress, to serve as a battleground for nations has been its sacrificial role.

KINGSTON, N. Y. -- Ulster County, birthplace of constitutional government in New York State, home of the McIntosh apple and center of the Hudson Valley apple-growing industry, will hold its first Apple Blossom Festival next Friday to Sunday.

Six companies of the Knickerbocker Greys, boys' cadet regiment, marched yesterday in review on Governors Island, lunched in the messrooms of the Sixteenth Infantry quartered there, and later captured four machine-gun emplacements in a sham battle fought on the open terrain of the polo field.

The Cooper Union team won the annual metropolitan intercollegiate mathematics contest conducted by the Brooklyn College Chapter of Pi Mu Epsilon, national honorary mathematical society, according to an announcement yesterday.

Challenging the traditional "piecemeal" method of teaching English in the high schools of this country, a national committee of educators, after a two years' study, has prepared a new program intended to make this subject more interesting and dynamic to the hundreds of thousands of students who take it.

Fordham honored its athletes last night. Ninety-seven Maroon standard bearers in football, baseball, basketball, track, swimming, crosscountry, tennis, golf and rifle shooting filed to the dais to receive major or minor F's from Earl W. (Zev) Graham, toastmaster of the tenth annual Block F dinner, then heard their accomplishments praised by an outstanding group of six speakers while a crowd of 400 filled the dining room of Keating Hall on the university campus with applause.

A method whereby the light of the rising and setting sun is made to serve the purpose of a super-stratosphere balloon rising thirty-five miles, nearly three times as high as the actual stratosphere balloon, was described today before the closing sessions of the American Physical Society.

Joseph M. Coldwell, Rhode Island members of the Socialist party executive committee, challenged Governor La Follette today to prove his recent statement that Socialist party philosophy "proposes to reward work and achievement on the same basis regardless of individual contribution."
Forecasts made previous to the start of Spring activity in Westchester County were borne out last month by reports of sales and the opening of new developments.

W. Hall Harris, who served as postmaster of Baltimore in the administration of President Theodore Roosevelt, died last night at the age of 85. Until a week ago, when he suffered a serious stroke, Mr. Harris had been an active partner in the law firm of Harris Thompson.

Black eyes and other bruises can be electrically cleared up in twentyfour hours if treated at once, Dr. Harold A. Abramson reported to the recent American Congress of Physical Therapy. He drives a curing drug, histamine, into the bruise. Blood plasma does the rest.
Manhattan's varsity crew registered its first triumph of the season yesterday by defeating . the Washington and Lee eight over the Henley distance on the Harlem.

The new Article 5 of the State Insurance Law modernizing title insurance as an underwriting operation gives better assurance to the purchasers of title insurance and will encourage companies in this State with a combined capital and surplus of about $30,000,000 to engage fully in the unguaranteed mortgage business, according to Henry J. Davenport, president of the Home Title Guaranty Company.

Sir Auckland Geddes, former Ambassador to Washington, gave the shareholders of the Rio Tinto Mining Company yesterday his forecast of the situation in Spain if General Francisco Franco sweeps the country.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, will receive the fourth annual medal of the New York Academy of Public Education next Thursday evening at the academy's annual dinner in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The medal is awarded for "distinguished service to public education."

The latest apartment building, known as the Curzon House, to be erected in Kew Gardens, L. I., was opened for inspection last week. It occupies a well-elevated site at 118th Street and Curzon Place, and the suites range from three to seven rooms with one to three baths.

When additional wall space is needed for furniture, recessed radiators help to solve the problem. When so placed, tables or low desks or chairs may be arranged in front of the grilles without interfering with the heating of the room.

Miss Beryl Partridge, younger daughter of Captain H. F. Partridge, late of the Eighth Hussars, and Mrs. Partridge, was married in Bath Abbey a few days ago, to Eric Hyde Lord Sexton, elder son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lord Sexton of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and Belfast, Me.

A collection of fine American furniture and decorations which was sold yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries realized $14,030. The principal owners represented were Mrs. J. T. Smith of Beverly Hills, Calif.; the late Hermine Cromwell and L. Denis Peterkin of Andover, Mass.

Because South Africa is calling back her native sons, S. H. de Montille, with his wife and three small children, is returning to the land of his birth. An engineer, Mr. de Montille has been on relief here for two years.

Miniature "country" landscapes, set high on apartment buildings and in backyards of private houses in this city, will be on exhibition here this week and next in two series of garden tours to be conducted under the auspices of several organizations working in the Interests of philanthropic service and civic improvement.

The University of Delaware baseball team defeated Rutgers today, 6 to 2. Loose fielding in the first two innings enabled Delaware to score five runs. The game was halted at the end of the sixth because of rain. The box score:

THE only woman polar explorer in the United States will sail from New York in two days on her sixth trip to the Arctic, and if the ship-news men discover her this time it will be the first occasion on which she has attracted their attention when going north.

An embryo paleontologist and a budding taxidermist were named yesterday as New York City's healthiest boy and girl after several months of preliminary examinations conducted by the Child Welfare League of America, 130 East Twenty-second Street.
Dr. Channing Lefebvre, for the last sixteen years organist and choirmaster of Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, will give his 1,000th recital on its organ Wednesday at 12:30-P. M.

At last there comes the welcome news that horticulture is to be represented at the New York World's Fair in a way commensurate with its importance and in keeping with the other arts, sciences and industries which will go to make up an exposition of the "home of tomorrow."

Mr. and Mrs. Hamlin Foster Andrus of Yonkers, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Dyckman Andrus, to Frederick Franklin Moon Jr., son of Mrs. Frederick Franklin Moon of Syracuse, N. Y., and the late Dean Moon.

Miss Margaret Whaley Howe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Jenkins Howe of this city, was married this afternoon to Nelson Tillinghast Saunders, son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman B. Saunders, also of Mount Vernon, at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev.
The Commodity Credit Corporation, through April 28, had made advances on 5,337,286 bales of cotton from last year's crop, it was announced here yesterday through the New York Cotton Exchange.
Efforts to assay the influence of New York and Washington on Australian and world markets dominate the annual financial and commercial supplement of the Sydney Morning Herald, recently received here.

The President has recommended to Congress that it put up to the Supreme Court of the United States the question whether present-day economic circumstances call for revision by the court of the established constitutional doctrine-long ago announced by that court- and since often reaffirmed-that bonds and the income therefrom of Federal and State governments are reciprocally immune from taxation of the other government.

THE untimely death of Winifred Holtby deprived contemporary literature of a writer who was a salty, witty critic of life, a warmhearted humanitarian and a novelist who, in "South Riding," proved herself capable of fictional conception and execution on the grand scale.

Mural paintings of abstract design, done by thirty-five advanced students in the Fine Arts Department to symbolize "The Activities of Teachers College," have been installed as a semi-permanent wall decoration on the main floor of the college's Russell Hall.

The Seventy-eighth Division Association held a reunion in the Top Hat Hotel here tonight to commemorate the twentieth anniversary of the sailing of the "Lightning Division" for France to participate in the World War.

Myron C. Taylor, former chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, was appointed by President Roosevelt today to be the American member of the inter-governmental committee which will facilitate the emigration of political refugees from Austria and Germany.

The New England Power Association reported yesterday net income in 1937 of $5,728,587, or $1.87 a share on common stock, against $5,704,222, or $1.85 a common share in 1936. Gross revenues were $55,026,816, against $54,171,676.

NOVELS portraying the South during the Civil War and Reconstruction periods are as many as dandelions in June, but few among them are as interesting or as well balanced as Gwen Bristow's new story of Louisiana, "The Handsome Road."

Gilbert Clark Wagner of Leonia, N. J., a sophomore in Columbia College, has been elected manager of the Columbia University Glee Club for 1938-39, it was announced yesterday. Three juniors named to the managing board are Stuart D. Robinson of Montclair, N. J., student adviser, Hilary H. Holmes of Princeton, Ind., and Fabio N. Piccirilli of New York, associate managers.

The situation of European Jewry today will be analyzed by a number of speakers at a luncheon which the American Women's ORT is sponsoring on Wednesday at the Hotel Astor. The event will mark the opening of a campaign which the division is sponsoring to raise its quota of $50,000 for the continuation of its work abroad.

Miss Clara Victoria Nance, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Herndon Nance of Bellerose, was married here tonight in St. Thomas Church to George William Kay Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kay of Garden City, by the rector, the Rev. John Williams.

Mr. and Mrs. Percy Hollister Whiting of Montclair, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Polk Whiting, to Thielo Gray Howland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel J. Howland of Bayside, Queens.

Calling attention to pressure on the Federal Housing Administration to lower its standards in order to increase the volume of housing, the American Institute of Architects has adopted a resolution urging that this tendency be "strongly resisted" as contrary to public policy. A copy of the resolution has been sent to Stewart McDonald, FHA Administrator.

A desire to develop technique and composition in the modern dance has inspired fifteen women students at Swarthmore College to organize a dance club under the direction of Miss Alice Gates of the Women's Athletic Department. Symposiums have already been given with

Through educational forums held during the club year, the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs has become convinced that education has not met the challenge of the depression, according to Mrs. Andrew J. Noe, president of the organization.

The Peddie baseball team defeated Poly Prep, 5-2, in its first Eastern Private School League encounter of the season at Hightstown today. Three of Peddle's five runs were scored in the first inning, when Allen, Cronin and Hail crossed the plate. In the fourth Ferris of Poly hit a home run. The game was called at the end of the sixth on account of rain.

THE journey to Manaos was part of a one-man scientific expedition. Earl P. Hanson was sent to South America by the Carnegie Institution in 1931 to make a survey of the earth's magnetism along a route in the northern interior and on the west coast.

AN exhibition of painting and sculpture will be held in Wood stock beginning on May 6, as part of the Ulster County Apple Blossom Festival. Two juries, one for painting and one for sculpture, will judge the work submitted and the same juries-will award the two cash prizes. On the jury for painting are Eugene Speicher, Henry Billings and Judson Smith; for sculpture, Carl Walters and Robert Davidson.

Among the American compositions to be performed at the Silvermine Symphonic Festival, which will be held in Silvermine, Conn., Aug. 18-21, one will be accorded its world premiere. The work so honored is to be chosen at a competition just announced, which closes July 15.

Mayor La Guardia brought his son, Eric, with him to the reviewing stand to see the World's Fair preview parade yesterday. Asked by camera men to hold up the child to be photographed, the Mayor asked the lad if he wanted his picture taken. Eric said, ",No."

Federal Judge Moinet today sentenced Wesley Earl Gray, 22, of St. Louis, to serve seven years in the United States Reformatory at Chillicothe, Ohio, for sending an extortion note to Henry and Edsel Ford last November.

AN ancient Chinese walled city with its quaint dwellings, markets, shops, theatres, cafes and tea gardens will be reproduced at the 1939 Golden Gate Interriational Exposition on San Francisco's Treasure Island.

Delegates from clubs throughout Connecticut will attend the State's first triennial convention of the Federation of Women's Clubs, opening on Tuesday at the Bond Hotel, Hartford, Conn. Miss Florance L. Sutton of Greenwich, as head of the organization, will preside at the sessions, which will close on Wednesday with the election of new officers.

Championship competitions brought to a close the eighteenth annual Newark Horse Show tonight in the Essex Troop Armory. First of the title events was that for three-gaited saddle horses and it was a foregone conclusion that the rosette would go to the lovely chestnut mare Dixie Maid of the Fair City Stable of Mr. and Mrs. L. Victor Weil of Elberon, N. J.

A consultation service for the benefit of prospective home builders is maintained by the Construction Industries Association, 101 Park Avenue, an association of designers, engineers, contractors and surveyors.

BRAUNSTEIN--BERGER--Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Berger, 771 West End Ave., announce the engagement of their daughter, Selma, to Mr. Irving B. Braunstein. COLES--HUNT--Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Hunt of 145 Central Park West announce the engagement of their daughter. Geraldine Marion, to Dr. Jerome S. Coles, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Cohen.

ONE evening in 1846, Jesse Little, wide-hatted, longbearded and clothed in black, called at the home of Federal Judge Kane in Philadelphia. He was an elder of the Mormon Church and had stopped over on his way to Washington to discuss asking government aid for the Latter-day Saints in their projected trek across the continent.

Although mail orders in the wholesale markets here last week were slightly lighter than in the previous week, there was some increased activity on Summer merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

Production of school plays in integrated cycles instead of in unrelated performances, to give students a better grasp of particular subjects, was suggested yesterday by Emmet Lavery, playwright and national director of the play department of the Federal Theatre Project.
Colonel Lindbergh will apparently make his permanent home in France. It is on a small island off the Breton coast,

Louis Lasher Lorillard died toda at his home here at the age of 6He had made his home in Pomfrl since 1916. Born in New York, Jan. 3, 187.5 he was the .son of the late Loui Lasher Lorillard and Katherin Beekman Lorillard. He attende.

ALTHEIMER--Benjamin, beloved father of Selma A. Well, at his home, on April 30, 1938, in his eighty-ninth year. Private services at convenience of family. Kindly omit flowers. Interment at St. Louis. ALTHEINIER--Ben. The Trustees of Congregation Emanu-El record with deep sorrow the death of Ben Altheimer.

The engagement of Miss Charlotte Phillipson, daughter of Mrs. Brainerd F. Phillipson of 440 Riverside Drive and the late Mr. Phillipson, to Harold Gray Hencken, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hencken of Greenwich, Conn., was announced last night by her mother at a dinner given in Sherry's by Mrs. Phillipson and Mr. and Mrs. Hencken.
Editor The New York Times Book Review: MAY I comment briefly on Dr. Michael T. Florinsky's review of my book, "The Plough and the Sword," in THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review of Feb. 27, 1938?

HARRIET HASSELL is a girl of 26 who last year won Story Magazine's national short-story contest, and this is her first novel. These facts are mentioned at the beginning of a review of her book because they are of pertinent interest.

John W. Davis, Walter Sherman Gifford and Dorothy Thompson will receive gold medals, conferred annually by the National Institute of Social Sciences for "distinguished services to humanity," at the annual dinner of the institute at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on Thursday night, it was announced yesterday.

MR. ADAMS has written a story of politics, labor rackets, gangsters and civil war in the United States in 1940. He shares the current worry over dictatorship in the land of freedom, and he makes future history just about as fantastically horrible as some of the incredible news coming from warring lands today.

The Lincoln School of Teachers ,College, Columbia University, one of the first experimental progressive high schools in the United States, will celebrate this week the twentieth anniversary of its establishment "as a protest against formalism and tradition" in education.

Miss Mary Hyde Clarke, daughter of Mrs. S. Beach Cooke of Springfield Center and George Hyde Clarke of Cooperstown, was married today in St. Mary's Church, Springfield Center, to Kenneth Henser Paton, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Crawford Paton of Flushing, L. I.
Mrs. Lillian C. Patterson, president of the Catholic Big Sisters, was selected last night as the outstanding woman civic leader of the Bronx by the Soroptimist Club at its annual award dinner.

There are times when no news is big news and these days in Catalonia furnish a good example of such a time. Things at the front are so quiet that the trips we have made in the last few days have turned into picnics.

NEWS comes from Berlin that Adolf Hitler's birthday, April 20, was commemorated with a 12 plus 38-pfennige semi-postal stamp, steelengraved in sheets of fifty, with a picture of the Fuehrer adapted by Professor Richard Klein of Munich from a work by Heinrich Hofmann, the official photographer of the National Socialist party.

WASHINGTON has had its famed cherry blossoms, Virginia its glamorous Garden Week and all around the Empire State various communities have celebrated many types of floral displays. Now New York comes into its own with the great Apple Blossom Festival of Ulster County.

The Westchester County Park Commission urged the County Board of Supervisors at a joint session today to approve a proposal that the State be asked to build and assume control of a Sprain Brook Highway, to link the Bronx River Parkway Extension at Hawthorne and the Bronx River, Cross County and Saw Mill River Parkways in Southern Westchester.

A formal declaration of the government's war program was issued here this evening after having been drafted by a Ministerial Council. Intended as a Spanish declaration of independence, it was addressed to Spaniards and to the world so that the Loyalists' aims and ideals should be known in this critical period.

Despite a cold, damp day, 40,000 fans cheered the opening of the 1938 New England racing season at Suffolk Downs today and watched Panther Creek, the H. and H. Stock Farm's entry, easily take the $5,000 added Plymouth Rock Handicap from Higher Cloud and the favored Clocks.
Students of Bryn Mawr College will hold their celebration of "Little May Day," Monday. "Big May Day" at Bryn Mawr is the Elizabethan pageant held once every four years.

GIANT prints, columnar slimness, Wedgwood daintiness, corseted waistline, rhumba ruffles, strapless-shoulder allure, tailored dinner chic--what more diversified spread of ideas could one desire? All are present in evening clothes.

WITH a remarkably short time elapsed since its recording and only three years after its first performance, Victor gives domestic release to Vaughan Williams's symphony in F minor, played by the British Broadcasting Orchestra under the composer's personal direction (Album M-440).

Officials of the FHA offer the following suggestions for the construction of a satisfactory nonsmoking fireplace: Determine the size of the opening desired and then select a flue lining that has an area equal to onetenth of that opening.

Mrs. Freeman Clarke Allen gave a dinner at her home here tonight, at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Allen, to Robert Ayres Messler 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin E. Messier of Montclair, N. J.

Miss Agnes Helen Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Brown of Brooklyn, was married to John Joseph Drummond, son Of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Drummond, also of Brooklyn, yesterday morning in the Church of St. Therese of Lisieux, Troy Avenue and Avenue D, by the Rev. Joseph P. Lamb.

" Cornell Day," the spectacular feature of the university's persistent effort to attract qualified students and maintain national representation on campus, will be observed here next Saturday, with 600 secondary school pupils as invited guests arriving Friday evening.
Eclipses of both the moon and the sun will occur this month, according to an announcement yesterday from the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History.

Because of a Supreme Court decision, the National Labor Relations Board is "seriously considering" the rescinding of orders against the Republic Steel Corporation and the re-opening of the Republic and several other cases under a modified procedure, the board's general counsel, Charles Fahy, disclosed today to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are April 30 unless specified: Arctic, San Francisco to San Pedro. Babbitt, at Nassau, Bahamas. Blackhawk, Manila to Southern Philippines. Charleston, at La Ceiba, Honduras. Edsall, at Chefoo. Erie, at Guayaquil, Ecuador.

With $505,816.30 already pledged toward the $1,150,000 fund for the new home of the Boston University College of Business Administration, students, alumni and friends of the institution are looking forward confidently toward a speedy climax of the campaign begun only seven weeks ago.
FOR the American conception of Bayrische Gemuitlichkeit und Wiener Frohlichkeit, East Eighty-sixth Street between Second and Third Avenues retains, ism riots or no, much of its after-dark charm.
