HRARDY travelers are beginning to discover the color of the organ pipe cactus country as a result of the setting aside of a 330,000-acre tract by Presidential proclamation last year as Arizona's thirteenth national monument. Eventually the area will be made accessible to the less adventuresome.
Three generations of the reigning house of Orange today appeared before cheering Netherlands throngs in celebration of Crown Princess Juliana's twenty-ninth birthday.

The School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University has announced the award of nine scholarships to graduates and undergraduates for Summer study in this country and abroad. The following have received $500 grants:

The Bears made a clean sweep of their four-game series with Montreal with a 7-2 victory today, their eighth in nine league starts. The game was called on account of a heavy downpour in the last of the eighth inning.

To provide real "stock" training for promising high school actors and to furnish a practical laboratory for high school teachers coaching in ??, Syracuse University will conduct its third Summer training course form July 5 to Aug. 12 under the general direction of professor ?? Wyer Falk.

Prospects for the 25,000 children kept in day nurseries throughout the country while their mothers work look brighter with the ?? last week of the Association of day Nurseries in New York and the National Federation of Day Nurseries, effected after months of reparatory discussion.

LAST Thursday the literary output of Presidents of the United States was increased by five volumes. Franklin D. Roosevelt's latest contribution to library shelves raises his production as an author to an equality with Calvin Coolidge and to one more title than Herbert Hoover.
Mrs. Clara Blanche Simmonds, wif of Frank W. Simmonds, senior deputy manager of the America Bankers Association, died today the Tarrytown Hospital after an ill ness of several weeks.
Fielding H. (Hurry Up) Yost, who made the University of Michigan one of football's strongholds, observed his sixty-Seventh birthday today. He made-it clear that he has not thought of retirement.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Tammany leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District, was lauded last night as a long-time and loyal friend of labor by Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, at the annual dinner and dance of the Grover Cleveland Democratic Club at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Rochester Red Wings snapped Jersey City's winning streak at four today, outslugging the Little Giants, 11 to 7. The game, played in a slow drizzle from the third inning on, was featured by a six-run uprising by Jersey City in the seventh which knotted the score at 6-6.

IN principle one may agree with all that Robert M. Coates says about the spirit and accomplishment of the WPA Federal Art Project, and yet may feel that his foreword in the catalogue prepared for the current oil and water-color show of the New York City easel division at the Federal Art Gallery does not too happily fit the occasion.
IN the dwindling ranks of Broadway's musical comedy actresses Ethel Merman is just about what Cole Porter once classified as "the tops."

Stewart McDonald, FHA administrator, reports that the actual net loss on home mortgages insured by the FHA through March 31 has been only $13,229 on 220,475 premium paying mortgages for $902,634,417 insurance. This represents barely a little more than one-thousandth of 1 per cent.
When one head of a government meets another on an officially festive occasion their diplomatic advisers have been busy long beforehand preparing the program of formal conversations.

It would be as hard for this nation to recapture the mood in which it heard the news of the Battle of Manila Bay as for a middle-aged man to recover his boyhood appetite for strawberry shortcake or to live again the innocent rapture of his first love.

SOME pick-up from the postholiday slackening in retail trade was reported here and there through the country last week. The gains were slight in most instances and offset by further losses in some sections.

Attracted principally by the expanded powers of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to make longer-term loans, extending to five years, smaller retailers have already begun to make applications for loans, with indications that many more will do so.

The Treasury's analysis of personal income taxes for 1936 alarms the Council of Executives of the Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery. Not because we are earning less than we ever did but that we are apparently giving less to good causes.

The marriage of Miss Beatrice G. Park, daughter of Dr. John Edgar Park, president of Wheaton College here, and Mrs. Park, to Robert Leland, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Leland of Rye, N. Y., took place this afternoon in the Wheaton College Chapel.
Imports of $27,673,300 gold, the largest for any month since last October, were received here in April, according to the daily reports of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
As suming the role of European political leaders, eight Hobart College freshmen will defend their policies in the George Gordon Hull Extemporaneous Speaking Contest to be held tomorrow.

Justice Jacob Panken of the Domestic Relations Court struck at the "full faith and credit clause" of the Constitution yesterday in announcing a ruling through which he refused "from a social point of view" to permit his court to be "perpetually paralyzed" by the court of another State.

The United Gas Corporation, including subsidiaries, which is controlled by the Electric Bond and Share Company, reported for 1937 a net income of $11,396,172, against $11,051,706 in 1936. Gross was $30,144,368, against $28,496,849.
The public schools of New York were praised by the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and 175th Street, the Bronx, in his sermon yesterday morning.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 32 per cent of capacity; 1 point lower than the week before and almost 2 points under the average rate in March.
Returning to New York from a week of travel in which he covered more than 4,000 miles, Postmaster General James A. Farley reported yesterday that "we seem now to be emerging" from the recession.

Hearings on President Roosevelt's $4,500,000, 000 recovery and relief program will end tomorrow before a House Appropriations subcommittee. The witnesses scheduled to appear are Mayor La Guardia of New York, John L. Lewis of the Committee for Industrial Organization and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

With daily business on the Stock Exchange repeatedly running less than half a million shares-pretty nearly a pre-war figure-last week's averages declined 5 or 6 points, though they did not reach the lowest of April, or of the year to date.

The Summer theatre season that reaches its peak in July will begin tonight, when the Cumberland Hills (Rhode Island) Playhouse revives "The Warrior's Husband," by Julian Thompson. The engagement will be for six days, with Elissa Landi in the role created by Katharine Hepburn.
Two of three eel fishermen were drowned here last night after one of them capsized a borrowed rowboat by standing up land losing his balance.

A newly dedicated processional cross of silver and gold was borne before the marching column of more than 150 Knickerbocker Greys as they left St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church shortly after 5 P. M. yesterday, following the junior cadet organization's annual church parade.

No reductions in woolen piecegoods prices can be made as a result of the wage cuts recently announced, as present prices have "more than discounted" the wage revisions, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, says in a statement issued for publication today. Mr.

Re-dedication to the ideals of democracy as. represented by the American flag, liberty, justice, freedom and humanity, was made by more than 300 members and guests of the State Sons of Veterans and their auxiliaries this afternoon at the annual exercises at Grant Cottage and Lookout Point, Mount McGregor, in memory of Ulysses S. Grant.
Five races were held today in the weekly dinghy sailing series, with Edward Maxwell's Tu Yung Tu the winner and Commodore H. R. Kunhardt's Paralysis second.

Deals involving three industrial properties in the Newark area were announced by Louis Schlesinger, Inc., broker in the transactions. The Kent Feather Company leased the three-story factory at 35-37 New York Avenue from the Nathan Lewitt estate.

Mrs. Anna Walcket, 49 years old, and her daughter Madeline, 22, of Delaware Gardens, near Camden, were burned to death at 10 o'clock this morning when an automobile driven by August Walcket, 51, the woman's husband, was in collision with a car driven by Steve Shwetz of Baptistown at the intersection of State Highways 12 and 30 here.

Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, made public yesterday a letter sent by him to Senator John J. McNaboe, chairman of the legislative committee investigating the administration of the psychiatric division of Bellevue Hospital, asking the Senator to place on record letters written by Dr. Goldwater last year directing the division to give full cooperation to the Police Department and District Attorney.

The Stock Exchange moved rather irregularly this week. Although French industrial shares are steady, investors and speculators in general are not showing much inclination to buy French securities until they know the government's financial plans.
The report of the Commerce Department on our foreign trade for March and for the first quarter of 1938 portrayed some striking contrasts with last year.

OF this morning's two books,* one was written by a man who, though he died as recently as 1934, used to take walks with Henry Thoreau, play games with Bronson Alcott's children and hug Nathaniel Hawthorne. He grew up in Concord when that little Massachusetts town was the wonder of the new world.

Field Marshal Hermann Goering's recent order for the registration of Jewish property has caused the greatest consternation in Jewish circles here. The Neue Freie Presse printed a dispatch today from its Berlin correspondent outlining the Reich point of view in answer to American queries regarding the position of American Jewish citizens living in Germany.

Brig. Gen. Fulton Q. Gardner, commanding officer of the Harbor Defenses of Sandy Hook at Fort Hancock, N. J., yesterday became the army's newest general officer when he was sworn in at 12:01 A. M. by Major Edward G. Cowan, post adjutant.

The seventh annual fund appeal of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn to further diocesan charitable activities was begun yesterday with a tea given at the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, by the women's division of the Bishop's Lay Committee for Charity.

Miss Katherine Rawls of the Miami Beach (Fla.) Swimming Club had to break a national record and tie another to retain her titles in the 300-yard individual medley race and the 100-yard breast-stroke in the 1938 women's national swimming championships tonight.
Arthur Hendrix of Lakeland, Fla., won singles honors in the Hot Springs invitation tennis tournament today, defeating Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., 6-4, 6-4 6-4 Cooke was the 1937 winner.

Mrs. Marion H. Spielmann, writer of many children's books, died today at Uplands, Folkestone, at the age of 75. She is survived by her husband, Shakespearean authority and writer on art, and one son, Dr. Percy E. Spielmann, a chemist.
President Getulio Vargas marked international labor day today by signing a decree creating regional commissions charged with establishing minimum wages for all workers.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, gave its last concert of the season yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. An all-Wagner program, with Marjorie Lawrence, soprano, and Charles Kullmann, tenor, attracted a large audience which ndisplayed its approval lavishly after each of the numbers.

ALTHEIMER-Benjamin, beloved father of Selma A. Weil, at his home, on April 30, 1938, in his eighty-ninth year. Private services at convenience of family. Kindly omit flowers. Interment at St. Louis. ALTHEIMER-Ben. The Trustees of Congregation Emanu-El record with deep sorrow the death of Ben Altheimer.

With the exception of lining taffetas, looms operations in every fabric group declined during the week ended April 23, according to the report issued for publication today by the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc.
The New World's first proletarian army marched here today in military units and uniforms--about 100,000 strong--as Mexico celebrated May Day.

A variety bill of the sort which, in the pre-double-feature days, made the Palace Theatre the goal of every worthy torch singer, hoofer and ad libber, was presented last night by Billy Rose at his Casa Manana. Drawing liberally on tried and true artists who were of the two-a-day during its heyday, Mr. Rose has put together an offering which should delight all those who still have a warm spot in their hearts for vaudeville.
The New York Stock Exchange firms of Hubbard Brothers Co. and Berg, Eyre Kerr have combined under the name of Hubbard Brothers Co. and today will open new offices at 60 Beaver Street.

Dr. and Mrs. Wilbur A. Sawyer of this place have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Margaret Sawyer, to Wallace Carroll. The wedding will take place on May 25 in Geneva, Switzerland.

We publish on this page today a letter from Borough President Harvey of Queens, taking issue with our recent editorial recommending that some action be taken with regard to the messiness visible on the way from New York City to the World's Fair grounds.

Opposition to a proposal to provide for State compensation to victims of motor vehicle accidents in the State Constitution was expressed yesterday by former Magistrate David Hirshfield in a letter to Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane, presiding officer of the Constitutional Convention. Mr. Hirshfield,

Salvatore Princiotta of the home club led a field of sixteen In the weekly handicap road run of the St. Anselm's A. C. over a nine-mile course in the Bronx yesterday. With a three-minute allowance, he scored by almost fifty yards over his teammate, Al Holden, who was second. Princiotta's actual time was 49:56.

Ever since the date set for Hitler's visit, the municipalities of Rome, Naples and Florence have been engaged in furious house cleaning. The polishing-up process to which Italy has been subjected during the busy fifteen years of the fascist era has reached a climax in these six months.
Supply contracts valued at $2,469,458 were awarded in the week ended on April 28 by eight Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor has announced.

A crowd of 4,379, a record for amateur cup soccer play, saw the Ponta Delgadas of this city capture the national amateur soccer championship by defeating the Heidelberg, Pa., F. C., 2-1, at Bigberry Stadium today.

Mr. and Mrs. William Parfitt Baird of 47 East Eighty-eighth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alys Phyfe Baird, to Robert Beverly Falk, son of Mrs. Nils Falk of Bay Shore, L. I., and the late Mr. Falk.

Despite showers and a cold wind, a large gathering of workers demonstrated at the May Day meeting in Vincennes today, which was dedicated to demands for maintenance of the Popular Front program and aid for Republican Spain.

The Institute of Pacific Relations recently published "Propaganda from China and Japan: A Case Study in Propaganda Analysis." Written by Bruno Lasker and Agnes Roman, the book attempts to show how elements of propaganda may be recognized in the information sent out from two Far Eastern countries, now at war, to influence American public opinion.

The Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, meeting on Saturday in the Federal Court House here, un nimously approved a program of "Safety-at-Sea" legislation, according. to an announcement yesterday.

A government-owned mortgage bank, which is managed by the German Consul, Baron von Hundelhausen, and which controls the sale of aski marks, is making advance payments on coffee, henequin and sugar for export to Germany.
The Reds made it two straight over the Pirates today, already surpassing their last season's mark of one victory over the jinx team. The score was 4 to 1.

In faintly historical mood, the Theatre Guild and the Actors Repertory Company combine this evening to present publicly the postponed "Washington Jitters," adapted by John Boruff and Walter Hart (with an assist by Tom McKnight) from Dalton Trumbo's novel of the same name.

A last-inning homer by Les Scarsella--his second of the game-with two mates aboard and two out, gave the Newark Bears a 9-to-7 victory over the Rochester Red Wings in the nightcap of a double-header today, and a sweep of the twin bill. The Bears won the opener, 12 to 8.

Mrs. Morris Aron, recently retired president of the Crippled Children's After Care, Inc., was guest of honor last night at a testimonial birthday dinner given by her friends and associates at the Croyden Hotel, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street.

Howard R. Handy, vice president of Pottery, Glass and Brass Salesman, a trade paper published in Manhattan, died yesterday at the Staten Island Hospital at New Brighton, S. I., after a brief illness. He was 60 years old and resided at 33 Central Avenue, St. George.

The award of twenty-three scholarships was announced today by Wesleyan University. These include the appointment of six Olin scholars, two regional Thorndike scholars from the Middle West and fifteen regular Thorndike scholars.
The announcement of twenty-year license agreements by Claude Neon Lights, Inc., with General Electric Company and Claude Paz et Silva of Paris was made today in the annual report of Claude Neon.

Although the American- Museum of Natural History received last year $669,797 in various types of gifts and contributions,-the institution is now in a more critical financial condition than it was in 1936 when it embarked on a campaign to raise- $10,000,000 for a ten-year development program.

Probably some 80 per cent of Czechoslovakia's population today either took part in political marches and demonstrations or watched others doing so. The writer motored from Prague to Reichenberg to stand on the platform beside Konrad Henlein and to hear him address 43,000 followers.

With men's straw hats scheduled to make, their appearance in about two weeks, advertising campaigns are now being prepared by leading manufacturers. The Hat Corporation of America will break halfpage ads for Knox, Dobbs and Dunlap during the week of May 16, deDendinz on the weather.
A large body of armed police raced from Kingston at noon today to reinforce a small party that was holding 1,000 armed strikers at bay on a sugar cane estate owned by Tate Lvle near here.

The week's stock market here was predominantly lower, there being a sizable recovery only on Friday. The Jewish property ordinance, talk of changes in bank personnel, and the rumor, since denied, that the Reich railroads' preferred equities would be called in, all affected Boerse sentiment unfavorably.

The general opinion in financial circles here is that the inflation plan of President Roosevelt and the increase in public expenditures may induce some improvement in the United States markets. This, however,

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York made public yesterday the text of a letter it has sent to all members -of the United States Senate, opposing the Pettengill bill and particularly its provision to repeal the long-and-shorthaul clause of the Interstate Commerce Act.

Three former employes of the St. James Street branch of Jenks Gwynne Co., New York stock brokers, are scheduled to appear in Arraignment Court tomorrow on charges of theft of about $100,000, conspiracy to defraud and falsification of books.

A statement opposing government pump-priming unless it is accompanied by "governmental policies that will permit business to accept the priming and go forward" was issued yesterday by the board of directors of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Ever since Earl Sande arrived from California with Stagehand, the Kentucky Derby favorite, and the rest of Maxwell Howard's string, there has been a rumor going the rounds at Churchill Downs that the trainer wasn't expecting to win next Saturday's renewal of the Derby with Stagehand at all.

More than 1,500 persons attended the twenty-sixth anniversary dinner of the National Council of Young Israel at the Hotel Commodore last night and heard speakers challenge the assertion that Jews were less worthy Americans than others.

The Cash Office of Foreign Credits at Budapest, Hungary, has announced through its central paying agents in New York, the Schroder Trust Company, that it will redeem coupons dated May 1, 1938, on the following bonds at the rate of $8.75 a coupon detached from a $1,000 bond:

United States Senator Royal S. Copeland heads a group of wellknown men who are serving on the executive committee for the annual Charity Ball in behalf of the Community Hospital, at St. Nicholas Place and West 150th Street. to be held tomorrow night in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

May Day was celebrated as German Labor Day in an address last night by Dr. Hans Borchers, German Consul General, at Schwabenhalle, Brooklyn, in which he expressed a hope for better GermanAmerican relations.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

Bob Sall, Paterson veteran, made a clean sweep of the 1938 inaugural A. A. A. auto races today, breaking three records on the Ho-Ho-kus half-mile track. He won the threemile match race in 2:46.25. the fivemile qualifying test in 4:39.38 and the fifteen-mile feature in 14:38.95, all bettering previous performances on the local track.

Mr. and Mrs. Guy Hunter of Eastlook, this place, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Jane Hunter Partridge, to Longley George Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Walker of Summit, N. J.

Patrolman Arthur R. Erickson of the Old Slip Station was shot in the left shoulder shortly after 2 o'clock this morning by one of three men, Negroes, whom he had accosted in Battery Park near the Bowling Green Station of the I. R. T. and asked to give an account of themselves.

The first shocks to the market of what was described generally as a grim budget were overcome with surprising, almost suspicious, rapidity. Security quotations, momentarily sharply depressed, have recovered or more than recovered their lost ground; moreover, the appearance of cheerfulness in the market is even more marked than before the introduction of the budget.

The Spring benefit bridge party and fashion show of Colony House, 297 Dean Street, Brooklyn, will take place today at the Plaza. Proceeds will provide days in the country for children affiliated with the organization.

The first factory in Australia for manufacture of axminster rugs is now being built in Sydney, with machinery and equipment and expert operatives to come from England, the Commerce Department reports.

In most of the latest British index figures there is certain but not pronounced evidence that the trade recession is continuing. Railway receipts are falling and recent declines have almost eliminated the gains shown earlier in the year.
Belford Forrest, playwright and former film comedian, died today at a Hollywood hospital. His age was 60. Mr. Forrest was known as Fenton Ford when he played in Hal Roach silent screen comedies.

The Economist's index number of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 73.3 on April 27, compared with 74 a fortnight before, 74.1 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Mgr. Eugene Murphy, rector of St. John ,the Baptist's Catholic Church in Manayunk for forty-seven years and friend of Pope Pius XI, died today in Misericordia Hospital, just three weeks before he was to have celebrated his golden jubilee as a priest. His age was 75.

The third annual interclub golf tournament for the Arthur Lehman Memorial Trophy, sponsored by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, will be held at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains on Sunday, June 19, it was announced yesterday by Herbert A.
Charles Headley Guerin, founder of Rubeck Guerin, formerly manufacturers of novelty furniture in New York, died yesterday at his home here after a six weeks' illness. His age was 71.

A program to combat the depression and to "promote national progress through the traditional business system" will be advanced by representatives of nearly 1,000,000 American business men, large and small, who will meet for four days, beginning tomorrow, in the twentysixth annual convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Though Jimmy Foxx crashed two home runs over the left field wall his first two times up, four Red Sox pitchers failed to hold Philadelphia in check today and the Athletics walked off with an 8-to-6 victory in the postponed series opener before 17,200 fans.

Although marked by a slight slowing down of activity from a year ago, the traditional Spring moving day this year furnished some examples of speed in the transfer of desks, files and other office equipment without interfering with the usual routine of business.

A resolution urging Congress to take action toward the immediate enactment of legislation establishing minimum wages and maximum hours was adopted by 5,000 members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers at a meeting in the Hippodrome, Sixth Avenue and Fortythird Street, yesterday.

Senior singing, Princeton's oldest undergraduate custom, will start its '179th season tomorrow night when the students gather on the steps -of Nassau Hall to. sing old favorites and traditional campus songs. Programs will be held nightly, except Sunday, and will continue until June 20.

Professor Irving Fisher's index, number of average commodity prices last week, based on' 100 as the average for 1926, was 80,6, which compares with 81 a week ago, 81.1 two weeks ago, 80.9 three weeks ago and 81.2 four weeks ago.
Hall Ruckel, Inc., 241 Thirty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, in a complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission, is charged with unfair competition in selling X-Bazin, advertised as a depilatory.

The Girl Scouts announced yesterday that five members of the organization from various parts of the country had been selected to attend the international encamp ment of Girl Scouts and Girl Guides in Switzerland from Aug. 11 to 29.

The Atlantic Elevator Company has acquired the good-will, name, patterns, drawings, patents, and service facilities of the Gurney Elevator Company and will continue the operation of this company, according to announcement issued for publication today by B. F. Mechling, president of the Atlantic Company.

Two mortgages held by the Bank for Savings from Cherry Pinkard Ball on 130 E 62d St. were consolidated as a single lien for $30,000 and extended to June 1, 1940, at 412 per cent. When Kathleen Downey bought 333 E 92d St from the Central Savings she gave back a purchase money mortgage for $8,000, due five years hence at 4' to 5 per cent.

Otto G. Innes, in 930 Park Ave.; S. Maurice Salomon, in 480 Park Ave.; Carlisle S. Griffin, in 424 E. 52d St.; Mrs. Ruth B. Lipper, in 10 E. 85th St.; Mrs. Helen Kirkpatrick, in 321 E. 54th St.; Pease Elliman, Inc.. brokers. Abraham Hecker, in 300 Central Park W. Hortense Bleker, J. F. Nelson. Milton F. Flynn, George N. Cole, Harry Lee Fassett, in London Terrace:

Acting Police Captain Henry B. Hill, No. 4 on the promotion list, killed himself with his service pistol yesterday. He died in Fordham Hospital at 3:15 P. M., about five hours after his wife found him on the floor of their garage, wounded in the right temple.

The marriage of Miss Sara Pickett Woolsey, daughter of Mrs. T. Salisbury Woolsey of this city, to Kenneth MacLean, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles Chalmers MacLean of Batavia, N. Y., will take place in the Woolsey home on May 14. The ceremony will be performed by the bridegroom's father.

The board of directors of the Merchants Association of New York, after long deliberation, has reached the conclusion that the bicameral Legislature, in existence in this State without interruption since the colonial period, has outlived its usefulness and should be supplanted by a unicameral body, with its members elected under a proportional represensation plan.
The offensive the Nationalists [Insurgents] launched a week ago in the Teruel and Castellon sectors has been held at a virtual standstill during the last four days by poor weather.

Miss Ann Louise Whitlock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Palmer Whitlock Jr. of 20 Scotland Road, will have eight attendants at her marriage to James H. Harris Jr., also of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harris, which will take place here on May 28 in Westminster Presbyterian Church.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Garfield Buell of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Jane Buell, to Vincent Strong Mulford Jr. of 55 Park Avenue, New York, and Montclair, N. J.

Almost 700,000 persons attended the May Day demonstrations in Vienna, which became an attempt to win the working class to National Socialism. The outward aspects of the celebration took on the character of a country fair.
Following the recent fluctuations in the franc, capital repatriations have ceased, and it is felt here that the success of the next national loan depends on currency stabilization.

Weekend visitors here were spectators at a general-alarm fire that damaged the two top floors of the Fredonia Hotel, six-story brick structure on Tennessee Avenue near the Boardwalk, early this morning.
Joe DiMaggio deserted his hospital cot today and parked his first homer of the year in the distant left-field bleachers. But the blow was struck in a lost cause.

The sudden departure for Washington today of Speaker Miguel Angel Garcia Mendez is causing much speculation, chiefly because he introduced the "little TVA" bill, whereby the administration sought to set up the Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority.

Nineteen persons were killed and about $1,000,000 worth of jewelry was destroyed yesterday afternoon when soon after 2 o'clock an Italian seaplane of the Ala Littoria line, flying from Tirana to Rome, crashed on Mt. Maranola, about three miles from Foggia, and burst into flames.

Patrons of art and other prominent residents of Westchester County attended today the first annual exhibition of the New Hudson River Group of artists and sculptors in a new Colonial country house on River Road in this village, which had been opened by Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip.

Wilder Ave (17-4984), e s, 312 ft a of Edenwald Ave. 37x100; Eastchester Savings Bank to Alexander D'Aloia, 1,826 Bussing Ave. Washington Ave, 2-459-61 (11-3042); Charles ki. Grambow to Dominick Claffa, 2,251 Bassford Ave.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and James H. Perkins, chairman of the board of the National City Bank of New York and the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, joined tonight in a radio discussion of ways in which the government and the flanks can cooperate in extending credit no create employment and stimulate business.

New York City has a population of about seven and a half million people. During the coming year two million of them will need some kind of help from private social welfare agencies. They will need things that a public social welfare agency cannot give.

About 100,000 persons attended May Day meetings in the Greek capital. General John Metaxas, the Dictator, proclaimed the day a national holiday, and he delivered a speech in which he stressed the necessity for harmony between employers and workers.

Formal announcement of plans for the fiftieth anniversary program of the Child Study Association of America will be made Thursday afternoon at a tea and private showing of the Bache collection of art at the residence of Jules S. Bache, 814 Fifth Avenue.

Ernest A. Turner, a New York real estate broker who was also manager of the Hotel Irving, 26 Gramercy Park, Manhattan, died here suddenly at noon today of a heart attack in his Summer home at 285 Old Lake Street, which he had opened for the season yesterday. He was 66 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur La Chapelle have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna E. La Chapelle, to Dr. Paul Edgar McMaster. The wedding will take place in the gardens of the La Chapelle home on May 28.

" Religion, to be effective, must be a deeply- personal, internal possession, not just a social heritage or an external label," the Rev. Howard D. McGrath, pastor of the Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, 131 West 104th Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

The imposing list of collaborators who are accompanying Chancellor Hitler on his visit here, among whom is Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop, indicates quite clearly that the meeting between the two dictators is not merely a show staged to impress the world with the solidity of the Rome-Berlin axis, but is also an Italo-German political conference in which the broad lines of the two countries' foreign policies will be discussed.

A method to solve the problem of a legislative reapportionment, overdue by eleven years, was put forward yesterday by the City Club of New York in a report prepared by Richard S. Childs, its president.

Distriet Attorney Carl B. Shelley of Dauphin County indicated today that he would resist any attempt on the part of the Earle administration to have him superseded as prosecutor in the coming grand jury investigation of charges made by Charles J. Margiotti, former Attorney General.

It has long been a custom of the financial community here to follow rather than anticipate events in its reactions to European politics. It is thus casting anxious eyes toward Czzchoslovakia but taking no pronounced views on what is likely to happen under German Dressure.

The first wave of army air corps planes and personnel reached East Coast airports from their bases at Langley Field, Va., and Barksdale Field, La., today as mobilization began for defense manoeuvres along the northeastern seaboard from Massachusetts to Maryland.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase will announce today that, because of "increasing operation costs" and "improving educational services," New-York University will raise its student fees at the end of the current academic, year.

Herbert Hoover, in a betweentrains interview, said today that Governor Philip La Follette's proposed third party might be the wedge for returning the Republican party to power. The former President is en route to Oklahoma City and Chicago.

Dr. Wade Hampton Frost, Professor of Epidemiology and former dean of the School of Hygiene and Public Health, Johns Hopkins University, died early yesterday at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, where he had been a patient for several weeks. His age was 58.

The German wholesale price index on April 20 stood at 105.6, unchanged from the week before. In the first three months of this year the highest point reached by the German.wholesale price index was 105.8 on March 2.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks:

Cotton prices weakened further last week on discouraging mill conditions in this country and abroad and the general domestic business situation. The price trend was downward through most of the week's trading. sessions.

The money market continues stringent, and with the approach of the monthend, day-to-day funds advanced late this week to 2 1/2 to 2 3/4 per cent. The market's tendency, however, was better than at the beginning of April.

President Roosevelt was about 700 miles southeast of this port aboard the cruiser Philadelphia tonight on a Caribbean vacation trip, headed in the general direction of the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico.

Ram Gopal, a youthful Hindu dancer, made his New York debut last night at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre and came through the ordeal with flying colors. He is a slender, pictorial young man who does not look the twenty-two years accredited to him; and, truth to tell, his dancing is at present equally slender, equally young and equally pictorial.
The Greater New York Fund made public yesterday a proclamation by Mayor La Guardia setting aside the period beginning today and continuing through June 2 as "Greater New York Fund Month."
New strength in the end and tackle slots has been the main advantage gleaned from Tad Wieman's six weeks of Spring drill with an enthusiastic group of Princeton football recruits.

The first Great Germany May Day and the fifth May Day since Chancellor Adolf Hitler came to power mobilized about 1,000,000 persons today in the Lustgarten before the former Imperial Palace and in Unter den Linden. The decorations used during Premier Benito Mussolini's visit were employed.

James E. Sheridan, a member of the New York Stock Exchange and of the brokerage firm of Griffen Sheridan, 20 Broad Street, died suddenly yesterday morning of a heart attack at his home, 91 Central Park West.

A Pastime Athletic Club athlete, Samuel Scott, won the ten-mile handicap road race sponsored by the Walkers Club of America yesterday. He had an allowance of minutes and an actual time of 1:38:43. Robert Simpson of the St. Anselm's A. C. was second and his team-mate, Arthur Hall, third.

The Rev. Brother Florentius, director and principal of the Central Catholic High School in Lawrence, Mass., and former director and principal at St. Ann's Academy, New York City, and Mount St. Michael, the Bronx, died today at Lawrence, Mass., at the age of 49.
Bishop William T. Manning officiated yesterday morning at the service of institution for the new rector of Christ Episcopal Church, Riverdale-on-Hudson, the Rev. Gerald V. Barry.

The Oratorio Society of New York will sing "The St. Matthew Passion," by Johann Sebastian Bach, on Thursday evening in the incomplete nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.

A message of greeting from President Roosevelt on the occasion of the fortieth anniversary convention of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, to be held in New York from May 13 to 16, was made public yesterday by William Weiss, national president of the organization. The message read as follows:

Extremely favorable crop conditions prevail in North America, with the possible exception of some delay in seeding in the Canadian Northwest due to wet weather, but the additional moisture is going into the subsoil, and taken as a whole the prospect, at the present time, is for a large wheat crop.

Two persons were seriously wounded here today when a bomb exploded in the main square of the Jewish quarter, a few minutes before the Jewish Socialist May Day procession was due to pass. The police arrested several members of Fascist organizations.

A celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Architects Samples Corporation will be held this afternoon in the showrooms of the company in 101 Park Avenue under the auspices of the New York Building Congress. Kenneth Murchison and Daniel T. Webster will speak.

Major Karl C. Schwinn, U. S. A., for several years Professor of Military Science and Tactics at City College, died yesterday in Fitzsimmons General Hospital, Denver, according to word received here. His age was 46.

Because fifty-eight Berea College students are convalescing from attacks of measles, blood will be taken from them tomorrow for use in the manufacture of serum needed in New York City where stocks are low.

Frank H. Krebs rode an airplane yesterday as an unwilling "stowaway"astride the fuselage. It happened at the Munipical Airport as Lieutenant Lewis J. Connors of the Army Air Corps took off with James K. Hutton for St. Louis.
Wadyslaw Talun of Poland and Chief Sanooke, Oklahoma Indian, two of the largest wrestlers among the topflight grapplers, will exchange holds in the feature at the Hippodrome tonight. Talun,

Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Thorne will return to the Ambassador today from Claremont, their home in Columbia, S. C. Mr. and Mrs. Donald S. Stralem will give a dinner on Thursday in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria.

The new cigarette stamp tax to raise relief funds went into operation yesterday with little confusion. Although in the future the stamps will be affixed by the jobbers or wholesalers, retailers yesterday transferred the decalcomania tax stamps to the stocks they had on hand.

The art season in New York, even with the opening of May, shows as yet little sign of slowing down. About twenty-five exhibitions are on the calendar for the week and a diversified lot they prove to be. One-man shows predominate.
Parading the new swastika flag of the German-American Bund, the New Jersey organization held a May Day celebration in honor of national labor at its Camp Nordland this morning and this afternoon.

Professor Gerhard Colm, formerly head of the economics department of Kiel University, Germany, and since 1933 Professor of Public Finance in the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science in the New School for Social Research (the University in Exile), has been elected dean of the faculty, it was announced yesterday.

WPA workers are not considered unemployed by the State Labor Department and cannot apply for State unemployment insurance benefits, thus eliminating the prospect of any cut in the Federal relief rolls from that source, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, disclosed yesterday.

A fashion and animal show will be given in connection with a tea dance on May 12 at the opening of the St. Moritz Sky Gardens. The party has been arranged under the auspices of the Chinese Women's Association to raise funds for the shipment of clothing to Canton for Chinese civilian refugees.

Americans should not lose- their moral indignation at the horrors of war nor their resentment against war-makers, or else they will also lose their moral standards and become participants in equally bloody wars, the Rev. Dr. Harry F. Ward, Professor of Union Theological Seminary, declared in a sermon yesterday at the Seminary's James Memorial Chapel, Broadway at 120th Street.
According to the Commerce Department, China imported approximately $68,541,000 worth of goods in the first three months this year, or a decrease of 14 per cent from the same period in 1937.
Republic Pictures will make thirty-one features, twenty-four "Westerns" and four serials, during the 1938-39. season, according to announcement here yesterday.
Hiram Lister Kilborn of Waterbury has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Lois Hall Kilborn, to William Torres of Chicago, formerly of Waterbury.

Representatives of Sweden's armed forces, its government, the church, learned professions, science, education, labor, agriculture and other phases of social activities will be among the fifty persons who will accompany Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf and Crown Princess Louise of Sweden to the New Sweden Tercentenary celebration in the Delaware Valley in June,

Loaded with curios and tales of adventure on the high seas, the schooner Yankee, a former Dutch pilot boat, sailed into this port today from her second 35,000-mile cruise of the world. She had sailed Nov. 1, 1936, after a similar voyage in 1933-35.
Secretary Morgenthau made public today the second of the monthly trust fund investment, account reports which he instituted last month in answer to inquiries.

Charles McLennan, racing secretary at the Pimlico track, announced today that Nedayr, second choice for the Kentucky Derby in the Winter future books, would be shipped here for the Preakness instead of to Louisville.

More than 1,100 dogs took part today in the third annual show sponsored by the Baltimore County Kennel Club at Pikesville, with Champion Nornay Saddler, a black and white foxterrier, winning the award of best in show at the evening session.

The cotton market here was quiet last week with liquidation of the May option the principal development. This selling caused moderate declines in the near month, while distant positions, particularly in the new crop, ruled steady.

More than 500,000 men, women and children passed through the grounds of the New York World's Fair yesterday as the preview for the 1939 opening was devoted in its second day to a music festival on a grand scale.

The Dodgers tossed a gathering of 40,248 highly partisan spectators into a turmoil yesterday, knocked out one of their own men with a mask and shook the historic ?? Grounds right down to its foundation in a tremendous effort to smash the Giants' amazing winning streak.

Bror G. Dahlberg, president of the Celotex Company, his wife and two lawyers and their wives were held up late tonight by three bandits on Lake Shore Drive and robbed of more than $20.000 in jewelry and cash.

Hugh Mulcahy limited the Bees to two hits today as the Phillies nicked Jim Turner, Boston pitcher, for eleven to pocket a 5-1 victory. The victors ended a Phils' losing streak which had reached nine in a row.

Well-known skippers of the merchant service--ordinarily, aboard their own ships, monarchs of all they survey-will salute the quarterdeck of the battleship Texas this morning and report to Captain Fred F. Rogers, commanding, for two weeks of active training duty.

William Burston will become buyer for the liquor department of L. Bamberger Co., Newark, on June 1. He will take this position along with his other duties as buyer for the grocery and candy departments.

Descendants of early settlers of New Amsterdam, forerunner of New York, took part last night in a tableau celebrating the 283d anniversary of the founding of the Spanish and Portuguese Congregation, Shearith Israel, Central Park West and Seventieth Street, the oldest Jewish congregation in the United States.

A concert of choral music, performed by leading choirs of various religious denominations of the city, will be given tonight in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of the Municipal Art Committee. The Edvard Moritz Chamber Orchestra will be heard tonight at Town Hall.

Stocks continued to slump for the second consecutive week and erased half of the earlier monthly gains; turnover, 2,494,530 shares. United States Government issues higher in less active trading; other bonds irregular and quiet; transactions, $25,957,750.

The rising tide of anti-Semitism' in Europe today, which has deprived more than 6,000,000 Jews and nonAryans of a birthright, may some day sweep across the United States if Christian: America does-not aggressively challenge the menace, the Rev. Dr Conrad Hoffmann Jr. declared yesterday morning. Dr.

Luncheon, Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 12:30 P. M. "A Creed for Republicans," George E. Sokolsky. Dinner, Masons of Queens County, in honor of Emile E. Rathgeber and George F. Gausman, Hotel Astor, evening.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "Premise for Debate" you dismiss with justified contempt "the theory so popular with some of the Administration's critics, that the President really does not desire business to prosper;

The Browns rallied in the ninth inning today to defeat the White Sox, 7 to 5, and gain an even split in the two-game series. Buck Newsom and Julio Bonetti held the Chicagoans to five hits, but a homer by Mike Kreevich and nine bases on balls kept the Sox in the game. Newsom,

(Figures in parentheses indicates par) Bayside (71)--F. H. Korff made a hold-in-one on the 150-yard fourteenth with a No. 7 Iron while playing with Steve Hall and C. H. Wilkinson. Brookville (72)--Match play handicap against par, Class A: Joe McGough,

Twelve of every thirteen residents of the District of Columbia want the right to vote for President and members of Congress. Seven of every eight would like to have a voice in selection of local officials.

A revival of the principles of the NRA was advocated today by Mgr. Francis J. Haas of Catholic University, who was a member of the original National Labor Mediation Board, at the opening of the fourday National Catholic Social Action Conference.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ludlow Fowler of Oatlands, this place, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Angela Fowler, to Craig Wylie, son of Mrs. K. V. H. Wylie of Washington.

With Godfrey and Terence Preece hammering in all but two of their goals, the Reds subdued the Whites, 8-7, at Preece Field today in a tune-up contest for the forthcoming outdoor polo tournament season.

Men-of-war costing from $2,000 to $5,300 a ton; merchant ships varying between $380 and $694 a ton; such are the astronomical figures which the shipbuilding world has displayed to the somewhat startled gaze of the country recently.

The Montreal Royals snapped their losing streak at six games before 25,811 fans today by coming back to win the second game of a double-header, 7 to 3, after the Jersey City Giants had taken the opener, 8 to 5.

Reports on progress in coordinating the work of advertising women with the interests- of consumers were heard by more than 100 delegates to the second annual Eastern conference of women's advertising clubs at a breakfast in the Administration Building at the New York World's Fair grounds yesterday morning.

Miss Mary Margaret Huntington, daughter of Mrs. Henry Arthur Huntington of Windsor, was married to Royce Dunham Braman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Royce Braman of West Hartford, yesterday afternoon in the home of the bride's mother.

Liquidation developed last week in the lard market on the Board of Trade. While the trade had reports that both England and Germany were to accumulate reserves of fats, there was no evidence of an improvement in the foreign demand for lard.

Average daily sales of chain men's-wear stores were 33.5 per cent lower in March, 1938, than in the same month a year ago, the Commerce Department reported today. Last year Easter fell in March, but came in April this year, which is considered to have some bearing on sales volume.

Wang Keh-min, Premier of the Provisional Government in Peiping arrived in Tokyo yesterday by military airplane from Shanghai to speed relief plans for the farmers and workers in war-ravaged North China.
The New York Americans were eliminated by the Irish-Americans of Newark from the American Soccer League championship finals before a crowd of 2,000 at Starlight Park yesterday. The score was 5 to 4.

Beattie Ver Eecke have announced that they are now specializing in odd-lot municipal bonds. The New York Hanseatic Corporation has moved to 120 Broadway. A. D. Braham Co., Inc., are at 40 Exchange Place.
The Missing Persons Bureau at Headquarters sent out a general alarm yesterday for Leah Deutsch. 25 years old, who disappeared after arriving here from Palestine on Thursday on the Conte di Savoia.

About forty decree laws relating to the budget, production and credit will be submitted to two Cabinet meetings tomorrow and will be promulgated Tuesday. This will be the first of a series of decrees.

Although the regular shooting season at the New York A. C. has closed, fourteen gunners took part in a full program of 155 targets at the Travers Island traps of the organization yesterday. Harry Thoens set the pace in the scratch competition. with 97 out of 100.

Stores continued their cautious buying policies last week, but increased activity was noted in placing of orders for Summer merchandise in the apparel, accessory and other lines. In the dress market there was strong demand for chiffons, marquisettes, printed sheers and spectator sports types.

Miss Eleanore Davis, daughter of Mrs. Edward Parsons Davis of this town, formerly of New York, and the late Mr. Davis, will be married to Pemberton Hutchinson Lincoln of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Lincoln of Elkhorn, W. Va., on June 3 in St. James's Episcopal Church here.

Corn futures held within a range of 1 1/4 cents a bushel last week, with hedging sales offsetting a liberal export demand. The close on Saturday was at the low point and in new low ground since the middle of March, showing net losses of 1 1/4 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel for the week.

New York's greatest need is not a new gospel but "fresh methods to take the old gospel to those who do not know it," the Rev. Dr. Don O. Shelton, president of the National Bible Institute, declared yesterday in an address at the thirty-first anniversary exercises of the institute at 340 West Fifty-fifth Street.

" Hold your nose and shut your ears" must now be the motto of prudent and reasonable persons in Pennsylvania. The air is darkened with charges and counter-charges. "Lies" are "hurled," only to be "hurled" back. Political dignitaries have lost their temper and their dignity.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,342,861,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.

A new first mortgage of $25,000 has been placed for Emile G. Hantsche Jr. on the five-story apartment house at 333 East Thirtieth Street by William Cruikshank's Sons, brokers. J. Brion Foulke Jr. was associate broker. It replaces a first mortgage of $12,000 which was given by Mr. Hantsche when he bought the house two years ago through the Cruikshank organization.

The Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg, preaching yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, scored present-day followers of Luther, Calvin and Knox for their disregard of Mary as the mother of Christ. He urged Catholics to be untiring in their devotion to her, especially during May, which ecclesiastic tradition has decreed to be "her month."
Germany increased her share in Brazil's import trade in 1937 over the preceding year, while the share of the United States declined fractionally, the Pan American Union reported today.

An exhibition of letters and sketches illustrating the life of the late Frank Julian Sprague, "father of rapid transit," will be placed on view today in the New York Public Library. The exhibition marks the fiftieth anniversary of the opening of the first successful electric railway under Sprague's guidance.
The Wagner Labor Relations Act declares that in hearings before the Labor Board or its examiners "the rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling."

Miss Dorothy Borcherdt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter O. Borcherdt of this community, was married this afternoon at the home of her parents to Eugene G. Krause of New York, son of Mrs. Emma Krause of Hamburg, Germany, and the late Franz Josef Krause.

Accompanied by an imposing diplomatic and military retinue, Adolf Hitler will leave Berlin today for his visit toRome. Its composition indicated the coming conversations were to be a counterfoil to the Anglo-French accord.
Calculation by the Bankers' Magazine of the prices of 365 representative securities on April 19 shows the extent of their recovery from the severe depression of March.
Twenty thousand persons marched in Brussels today in a May Day demonstration that passed without an incidentals

Described in a message from Helen Keller as "another milestone on your record of intelligent, instructive work," the new $500,000 home of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind was dedicated this afternoon at a ceremony attended by 500 persons.

The net profit of the United CigarWhelan Stores Corporation for the period between July 17, 1937, the reorganization date, and the end of the year was $200,716 after all charges. Included in this figure is $145,974, representing excess of face value over. cost of the company's own 5 per cent sinking-fund bonds which it purchased, less Federal taxes on them.

The Swiss Government has agreed to issue tomorrow special League of Nations and -International Labor Organization postage stamps, thus partly granting a long-standing request from those organizations.

Wyatt St, 1,125 to 1,135 (15-3906); Wyatt Street Realty Co to Philip Schoenfeld, 636 Empire Boulevard, Brooklyn: due July 29, 1939, at 6 per cent, $110,000. Astor Ave, 1,466-1,468 (16-4389); Patrick O'Rourke to Railroad Federal Savings Loan Association. 441 Lexington Ave, extends mtgs to May 1, 1943, at 5 per cent, $28,500.

Kerry won the divisional Gaelic football championship at Innisfail Park yesterday, defeating Kildare by 2 goals and 2 points, or 8 points to 5, before 3,000 fans in a replay of their 4-to-4 tie of two weeks ago. Kerry will meet Fermanagh in the the final next Sunday.

The immediate practical question raised by the monetary-spending program recently announced by the government is whether it is welltimed to help business upward, the National City Bank says in its current monthly letter.

Apparently undisturbed by the much evident coolness to his plans for building the Progressive party of Wisconsin into a national party, Governor Philip F. La Follette returned- to his home here today after a trip to Iowa, where he received pledges of support as individuals from representatives of the powerful Farmer-Labor party of Minnesota and of its feeble off-shoot in the State where the tall corn grows.

Hudson St, 422; 21.11x59.6: Alexander F. Hehmeyer to Mutual Life Insurance Co, consideration $5,000, foreclosure. 37th St, 339-343 E; 75x90xirreg; 335 East 37th St Corp, R. B. Knox, vice president, to City of New York, consideration $59,500. 33d St, 341 E; 20x98.9; George A. Molleson to Montslope Realty Corp, 12 E 41st St, care B. Cohen ($1.50).
At its final meeting for the season yesterday at the Hotel Astor the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., elected the following new officers:
Thomas Mann, self-exiled German-born- author and lecturer, said in an interview today he would apply for American citizenship in New York late this week.
If broken china means lUCK, Grand Duchess Kira of the Romanoffs and Prince Louis Ferdinand of the Hohenzollerns should have plenty in their wedded life.

Don Gutteridge's fumble of a grounder was a major factor in the Cardinals' 6-to-5 defeat by the Cubs today. After Frank Demaree singled to start the Cub second inning, the St. Louis shortstop muffed Joe Marty's blow on what appeared to observers an easy double play chance. Then the former Yank,
A subcommittee headed by Senator O'Mahoney will submit to the Senate Judiciary Committee tomorrow its version of the Bankruptcy Revision Bill which passed the House in August.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the only important roll-call in Congress, during the period from April 23 to 29, are given in the fol. lowing tabulation:
William Gillette, the actor, left an estate valued at $113,178.33, including his stone castle at Hadlyme, equipped with a three-mile model railroad.
A May Day mass for Catholic judges and lawyers was held in the Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Paul here today with Dennis Cardinal Dougherty as the celebrant.

International Labor Day was observed today by workers' organizations throughout Cuba with demonstrations and mass meetings. No newspapers were published and transportation workers halted traffic for ten minutes beginning at noon.

Miss Eleanor Wynne of New York gained the unusual distinction of capturing first place in both the Good Hands class and the Alfred V. Maclay Trophy competition in the eighth annual horse show at the Kentucky Riding Stables today.

Sir Percy Bates, Major Gen. -and Mrs. John J. Phelan, John W. Riddle, former United States Ambassador to Russia; Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Coudert, Sir George Frederick Davies, M. P., and Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Morris are due today from Europe on the French liner Normandie.

St. Mary's Celtics 3. Brookhattans 2. Irish Americans 5, New York Americans 4, National Amateur Cup Final Ponta Delgada (Fall River, Mass.) 2, Heidelberg (Pa.) F. C. 1. Eastern Junior Cup Final Lighthouse B. C. (Phila.) 4, Senate B. C. (Harrison, N. J.) O.
" Of Mice and Men" will have an extra performance next Sunday night for the Stage Relief Fund. Prices: $2.50 (no tax) and down.

Norman Thomas, national Socialist leader, through counsel of the Workers Defense League, moved yesterday for Federal prosecution of Jersey City police who twice deported him after an attempt to make a speech.
The peace of mind that Jewish communities in Moslem countries in the Near and Middle East, except Palestine, have enjoyed for more than a century is now being threatened.
Virginia R. Boy, white and liver pointer owned and handled by Dr. Driggers of New Brunswick, N. J., won first place in the open all-age stake of the Sport and Conservation League today.

More than 11,000 seamen, constituting one-fifth of the unlicensed personnel of the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico ports and San Juan, P. R., are without employment, according to a survey conducted by the National Maritime Union, C. I. O. affiliate.

A fashion show entitled "Twice In a Lifetime" will be held in conjunction with a luncheon tomorrow in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Girls Vacation Fund. Young women of society will act as manikins.

The twenty-first annual award of the fifteen prizes in journalism, letters and arts established by the will of the late Joseph Pulitzer, the recipients of which already have been selected by the advisory board of the Pulitzer School of Journalism, will be made today by Dr. Nicholas Murray Bulter, president of Columbia University.

William J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company, who was with Henry Ford in a White House conference with President Roosevelt last week, said in a radio address tonight that "government's best service to economic life is to preserve a state of tranquillity in which public confidence flourishes."

A number of prominent Republican delegates to the Constitutional Convention will hold a conference here tomorrow afternoon at which they will establish a "policy" committee to act in an advisory nature concerning proposals at present and hereafter submitted to the convention, it was learned today.

Chauffeurs' licenses are renewable beginning tomorrow at any issuing office of the Motor Vehicle Bureau, it was announced today by Commissioner Charles A. Harnett. The renewal period ends May 31, and this deadline will be adhered. to, it was stated, although last year there were extensions until July 10.

The Voelkischer Beobachter today published an article advocating the confiscation of the thirteen castles and 20,000- acres of forests belonging to Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, former Vice Chancellor of Austria.

Scholastic, the American high school weekly, which annually awards $10,000 in money and scholarships for literary, artistic and musical accomplishments by high school students, announced yesterday its awards for this year. There are forty-five New York students among the winners.
The Western Pacific Railroad Corporation, holding company for the Western Pacific Railroad, reported yesterday a net loss of $509,263 in 1937, against a net loss of $501,640 in 1936.
The International Amateur Athletic Federation accepted Elroy Robinson's 1:49.6 as a world half mile record a few months ago. 01 John Woodruff of Pitt will break it in the very near future.

Eight hundred parents crowded the Fordham University campus yesterday for the second annual freshman parents' day ceremonies. A seven-hour program designed to acquaint visiting parents with every phase of their sons' scholastic and extra-curricular life was carried through.

France's wholesale price index, which was 619 on April 16, is reported as standing at 620 on April 23. The gold index of raw materials was 41.3, unchanged in the week and comparing with 40.7 two weeks ago.

The National Council of the Jewish Welfare Board held its annual meeting yesterday at the Young Men's Hebrew Association, Ninetysecond Street and Lexington Avenue. -About 800 Jewish leaders from many sections of the United States and Canada, representing 300 Young Men's Hebrew Associations, Young Women's Hebrew Associations and Jewish Community Centers, attended.

Mr. and Mrs. Clifford D. Mallory entertained a large company at their annual jonquil tea this afternoon. Mrs. Mallory's Spring gardens are now at their height, and many guests have viewed them in the last few days.
Because of the Reich loan flotation, month-end credit demand exceeded normal but the market was stimulated by repayment of the Gold Discount Bank's promissory notes.

Patrick A. Moynahan of 249 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, a retired realty broker who had long been active in Irish-American societies, died Saturday night of pneumonia and heart disease in St. Peter's Hospital, Brooklyn, at the age of 73. A native of County Kerry,
Fourteenyear-old Willis Dysart of Tift County, who has had only two years of formal schooling, did a few sums in his head for the professors this week-end and left them goggle-eyed.
About 3,000 persons attended the sixth annual campus day fete yesterday at Manhattan College, Spuyten Duvvil Parkway and 242d Street.

The recently organized Westchester Bach Society, under the direction of Charles A. Ward, appeared last night in a program of works by Bach at the Daniel Webster School. Assisting the chorus and string orchestra were Alexander Harsanyi and George Bennett, violinists, and Thomas Richner, pianist.

The three candidates for directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway backed by the Guaranty Trust Company in opposition to Robert R. Young, chairman of the Alleghany Corporation, issued yesterday an appeal for proxies from C. O. stockholders to be used at the adjourned meeting called for May 10.

Repeating his victory of a year ago, Champion Royal Kid Regards was judged best of breed in the fourth annual specialty show of the Boston Terrier Club of Westchester before an enthusiastic gallery at the Westchester County Center tonight.

More than 1,000 men and boys from American Legion posts and squadrons in six States will participate in a drum and bugle contest in Madison Square Garden on Sunday, May 15. Details of the event were announced yesterday by the President Borough of Manhattan Post 84, under whose auspices the contest will be conducted.

Exceeding even his superlative efforts of last Fall, Runyon Colie of M. I. T., intercollegiate yachting's premier dinghy helmsman, led his team to an overwhelming victory in the fifth semi-annual series for the Boston Dinghy Club intercollegiate challenge cup on the Charles River basin.
Despite a hard rain, which broke the drought from which London has been suffering for more than a month, a record crowd went to Hyde Park to celebrate May Day today.

The Soviet staged another great military show for its May Day observance, and 1,000,000 workers also poured through Red Square in Moscow. No new types of armament were shown, but improved artillery, tanks and planes were-on view. Stalin appeared as fit as. usual, remaining, with other leaders, for hours in the rain. [Page 1.]

A series of addresses yesterday afternoon completed the three-day dedication services of the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 122 West Seventy-sixth Street. The building formerly was occupied by St: Andrew's Methodist Episcopal Church.

Charles H. Mayo Jr., former Long Island amateur golf champion, and Ralph Trost, representing the home club, today won the Lido Country Club's four-ball tourney, first invitation event of the metropolitan season.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Arthur Whisler of Chicago have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Millie Whisler, to the Rev. Oscar Raymond Lowry of this place, son of the Rev. Oscar Lowry of Chicago.
Donald McBride, hotel manager in the Broadway version of "Room Service" since its opening last year, will arrive this week at RKO to continue his role in the film version with the Marx brothers.
Before the theft of 990 women's hats valued at $600 had been reported to the police, Detective Edward Miller of the West Thirtieth Street station had recovered the hats, it was revealed yesterday.
Akron tonight faced a breadless Monday as the result of a strike vote by members of the bakery drivers' union, following expiration of their contract with employers last night at midnight.

On the business situation in the United States German comments are either non-committal or unfavorable. Writers of bank reviews dwell for the most part on the failure of raw-material and foodstuff prices to recover, and in this connection it' is emphasized that the most important commodities -cereals,. metals, cotton and oilremain weak. This is regarded as an unfavorable sign.
Because of the Reich loan flotation, month-end credit demand exceeded normal but the market was stimulated by repayment of the Gold Discount Bank's promissory notes.

Patrick A. Moynahan of 249 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, a retired realty broker who had long been active in Irish-American societies, died Saturday night of pneumonia and heart disease in St. Peter's Hospital, Brooklyn, at the age of 73. A native of County Kerry,

Ninth inning relief pitching by Al Milnar, a Cleveland sandlot product, helped the Indians to a 4-to-3 triumph over the Tigers today before 23,782 spectators in the Municipal Stadium, the Tribe's home on Sundays and holidays.
Mrs. Helen Swett Artieda, educator, author and social worker and daughter of John Swett, organizer of the California public school system, died today at her Oakland home.

Total production of electric energy for public use in the United States in March aggregated 9,191,000,000 kilowatt-hours, compared with 8,440,000,000 in February, an increase of 8.9 per cent, the Federal Power Commission has reported.

Executives of foreign-owned oil companies operating in Brazil have refused to comment on Friday's decree nationalizing Brazil's oil.industry. However, it is obvious that the move has caused considerable uncertainty.

Dr. Francis E. Townsend, old-age pension advocate, criticized labor Unions today for what he said was a "selfish" attitude. He spoke at a meeting of the Townsend Unions Club of Chicago, an organization of American Federation of Labor groups.
About 6,000 persons gathered for May Day celebrations at Queen's Park here yesterday after the annual parade. Leaders had expected 25,000 to attend.

Dr. Charles F. Bolduan, director of the Bureau of Public Health Education of the Department of Health, announced last night that Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler had signed a certificate of incorporation for the New York Diabetes Association.

The newly appointed council of the National Unity Camp held its inaugural meeting yesterday in an atmosphere of confusion and uncertainty caused by the withdrawal from its ranks of three Radical Nationalist Deputies.

Former members of Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, were Lincoln once sat to hear Henry Ward Beecher preach in a pew now marked with a brass plate, returned yesterday to attend an annual anniversary communion.
It was revealed today by the Department of Justice that there are 558 duly established unions in Colombia. The total membership was put at 31,062 men and 3,374 women.
The total of 13,958,000,000 marks collected by the Reich in tax revenue in its financial year ended March 31 almost reached the official estimate of 14,000,000,000 marks.

Mrs. M. Louise McAlpin of 775 Park Avenue died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center following a brief illness. Mrs. McAlpin, the widow of William W. McAlpin, was a lifelong resident of New York City.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Herman Suter of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alice Van Zandt Owens, to Richard Tomfohrde Kennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace C. Kennett of West Medford, Mass.

Intensification of road building was announced today by Ricardo Pacheco, the Minister of Public Works, particularly on the section of the Inter-American highway between Cartago and Santa Maria, now under construction with the cooperation of the United States.
It is said that what America needs to swing it out of the present economic tailspinis a new industry.

Although active buying of specialties continued as a feature in the week's stock market, the list generally was depressed, with even home bonds losing their resiliency. Neither domestic nor foreign developments encouraged any bullish sentiment.

Kent School will send a crew to the Henley Regatta again this year, which will mark the 100th anniversary of the famous races on the Thames. It will be the sixth time that Kent oarsmen have gone abroad to row over this course.

In the town square, a beautiful colonnaded eighteenth century rectangle, Salamanca celebrated yesterday the announced intention of Portugal to recognize General Francisco Franco's government. Many uniforms added color to the scene.

John Curry Barlow, retail hardware dealer, died today at his home here after an illness of three months. He was 68 years old. Born in Ossining, Mr. Barlow was president of Barlow Co. of Ossining, a firm founded by his grandfather, John Barlow, in 1844.

Mayor La Guardia has rejected the Transit Commission's request for his cooperation in drafting a proposed constitutional amendment under which city corporate stock or serial bonds used to purchase privately operated rapid transit lines would be exempted from the debt limit.

The idea underlying the annual rally of the Brooklyn Citizens Patriotic May Day Celebration Committee seems to have "caught on at last," in the words of the chairman, James M. Golding, for the response yesterday exceeded that of any year since 1920.

George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, made public yesterday a letter to Alfred Rheinstein, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, strongly protesting against the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for a frame building at 83-75 118th Street, Kew Gardens, for use by the Soviet Private School now located at 810 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn.

Marked progress in disposing of disputed claims for State unemployment insurance benefits, 68,485 of which were received in the early weeks of the insurance program, was reported today by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner.

German manufacturing industries are active, but there is again a pronounced shortage of natural raw textiles, cotton stocks at Bremen having fallen. Certain finished textile articles are unobtainable at retail.
In memory of Henry S. Chatfield, one of the original members of the Union County Park Commission, a garden and bench were dedicated at Warinaco Park here this afternoon.
The AngloFrench. "super alliance" is moderately welcomed in League of Nations circles as a wrong step in the right direction or at worst the lesser of- two evils.

Robert S. Mann, an associate editor of Editor and Publisher, died suddenly of a heart attack at his home here today. Born in Kansas City, Mo., about fifty years ago, he was graduated from the University of Missouri in 1910.

Nomination of Richard W. Lawrence to succeed Winthrop W. Aldrich as president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York was announced yesterday. If elected on Thursday, Mr. Lawrence will become the forty-sixth president.

THAT standard greeting of "How are ya hittin'?" among ball players is no empty social gesture or idle query. It is packed with meaning and full of importance. In baseball, they pay off on hitting. That was why Frankie Crosetti and Lou Gehrig, to pick a couple of notable examples, were such mournful-looking gents as they went about their chores at the Yankee Stadium recently. They weren't hitting.

The Most Rev. William A. Griffin was consecrated as Auxiliary Bishop of Newark today at a pontifical mass attended by 5,000 persons in Sacred , Heart Cathedral. An estimated 3,000 more sat or stood outside.

Mr. and Mrs. Somers Marshall Rutledge of South Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Winifred Hazeltine Rutledge, to Alfred Joseph Sillery, son of Mrs. Thomas Moran of Union City.

Worms do turn sometimes. So do dragons. When the dragon is the symbol of 450,000,000 people, and it not only turns but snaps like a rattlesnake, the spectacle is challenging. China, after years of patient or supine prostration, has turned on Japan.

Elaine Wilson, incubator baby who weighed only a pound and fourteen ounces on Feb. 2 when She was rushed to Atlantic City Hospital, has grown to 5 1/2 pounds and has been allowed to go home. The daughter of Mr.

A new world record at skeet has just been chalked up by S. Odis Walding of Los Angeles, Calif., who made a run of 452 consecutive targets during the month of March. The record is now official, according to the National Skeet Shooting Association.

The Social Democratic Federation, "right-wing Socialists," celebrated May Day yesterday with a meeting in the Debs Auditorium, in the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street, where speakers attacked communism and fascism as enemies of freedom of thought, liberty and action.
The International Danubian Commission will hold its annual meeting May 10, when it will discuss the problem of the Sulina Canal, at present the main channel for navigation in the delta district.

The statement made by Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, that the psychiatric division of Bellevue Hospital gave full cooperation to the police when they were seeking Robert Irwin for the Gedeon murders was contradicted yesterday by Senator John J. McNaboe, chairman of the legislative committee investigating the division, on the basis of testimony at the resumption of the committee's hearings in the Supreme Court Building.

Cardinal Innitzer's office announced today that Governor Arthur Seyss-Inquart had prohibited the consecration of marriages between "Aryans" and Jews and that therefore, pending new regulations, these marriages must be postponed.
The Virginia Public Service Company filed today a blanket denial with the State Corporation Commission that it had "milked" away any of its operating assets.
Thornton Wilder now has won Pulitzer awards in two fields, for ten years before his "Our Town" received the drama prize his "The Bridge of San Luis Rey" won the award for best American novel.

Five firemen were injured and eighteen persons were driven from their homes by fire yesterday at 3 A. M. at 42-65 Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, Queens. Miss Ella Tighe, 60 years old, sounded the alarm.

" Roosevelt luck" failed the President today as choppy seas "with white caps all around" forced cancellation of a scheduled barracuda hunt and forced him to remain aboard the cruiser Philadelphia throughout the day.

The new headquarters of the German Railroads Information Office at 10 East Fifty-seventh Street was officially opened yesterday by Dr. Wilhelm Prins, representing the general director of the State-owned German Railroads.

The final details of an arrangement whereby foreign obligations secured by Chinese martime customs are to be covered were agreed upon tonight by Sir Robert Leslie Craigie, British Ambassador to Japan, and the Japanese Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs.
