Secretary of the Treasury Morganthau announced today the final subscription and allotment figures of the $200,000,000 of 3/4 per cent series C notes of the Commodity Credit Corporation, which were oversubscribed approximately seven times.

A headon collision between the American Federation of Labor and the Mexican Federation of Labor at the coming meeting of the International Federation of Trade Unions in Oslo, Norway, late this month, was indicated when Vicente Lombardo Toledano, secretary-general of the Mexican labor group, announced his plans here today for the I. F. T. U. parley.

William Reid, City Collector, announced yesterday that the total sale of the new cigarette tax stamps through yesterday's business was $470,427. This total, Mr. Reid said, included $403,769 for 1-cent stamps, $13,458 for 3cent stamps and $53,200 for meter certifications for stamping machines.

STUDENT NURSE, St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Department of the Interior. Applications must be on file not later than May 26 if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming and not later than May 23 from all other States.

Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, will receive the Mendel Medal from Villanova College for outstanding work in science, the Very Rev. Edward V. Stanford, president of Villanova, announced today.

In a two-to-one decision, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday upheld an order signed by the Federal Trade Commission, directing the . Biddle Purchasing Company and others to cease violating the Robinson-Patman Act by accepting commissions from sellers and passing them on to buyers.

A plebiscite of the Jews of America, "for the purpose of creating a united democratic front' against anti-Semitism" in Eastern and Central Europe, was announced yesterday - by the American Jewish Congress at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore.

Mrs. Gertrude E. Fox, widow of Dr. Frederick John Fox, who died on the Waldeck Expedition into the Amazon jungles, got her first letter from the survivors yesterday at her office at 425 Fourth Avenue.

After nearly two years of legal manoeuvres and technicalities the Samuel Drukman conspiracy case went on trial a second time in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday with the completion of a blue-ribbon jury before Justice Erskine C. Rogers. For the first time in the many proceedings the jurors were permitted to go home.

The engagement of Miss Margaret Elizabeth Griffin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Griffin of this village, to Dr. Arthur J. Manske, instructor of history in the Peekskill High School, has been announced.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler's departure for Rome this afternoon was made the occasion for a noisy send-off, and in its exuberance it ran yesterday's May Day festivities a close second.

Louis Shoneman of Kresge Department Store, Newark, N. J., was elected president of the American Toy Managers Association at its annual meeting last night at the Hotel McAlpin. The following district vice presidents were elected: C. W. Benzow, Adam, Meldrum Anderson Company, Buffalo, first district;

Members of the New York Curb Exchange, more susceptible to the jitters in these days of slack markets than in more normal times, have come down with them again. They are bothered by the suggestion that the Curb be absorbed by the Stock Exchange, with the implication that the former has outlived its usefulness.

J. P. Morgan is to be questioned here today by the Securities and Exchange Commission concerning the relations of J. P. Morgan Co. with Richard Whitney and the Whitney brokerage firm, which collapsed March 8.

Two of the American members of the International Olympic Committee, William May Garland of Los Angeles and Frederic R. Coudert of New York, arrived here yesterday on the Normandie of the French Line. They attended the meeting of the I. O. C. in Cairo in March.
Attorney General Bennett ruled today that the workmen's compensation law covers all employes in the State Labor Department's Division of Placements and Unemployment

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals in a unanimous decision upheld yesterday the Board of Tax Appeals in its ruling against the Commissioner of Internal Revenue in the latter's attempt to collect $130,410 from the Kensico Cemetery as unpaid income taxes and penalties for the years 1926 to 1932 inclusive.
Because he is a layman, Dr. Frans Ericsson, acting president of Upsala College, here, is no longer a candidate for the presidency of the institution.

" Meadowland," the former country estate of the late Edmund A. S. Clarke, on the northwest corner of Hartshorne Lane and Ward Avenue, Rumson, N. J., has been divided into five. tracts and sold through the office of William H. Hintelmann, broker of that town.
H. E. Morriss's Pasch, winner of the Two Thousand Guineas, today remained the favorite for the Derby in a callover at the Victoria Club. The colt was backed at 5 to 2 for the Epsom Classic June 1.

The collection of general property taxes in the average city continued in 1937, for the fourth consecutive year, its rise from the low point of the depression, according to a survey on tax delinquency for the eight-year period 1930 to 1937, inclusive, just published by the municipal service department of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Lawrence Marx, president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New YQrk City, died at New Rochelle Hospital tonight at the age of 51, following injuries received a little more than a week ago aboard his yacht.
The Securities and Exchange Commission concluded this afternoon its hearing

Quite a bit of excitement in Fiftyseventh Street yesterday centered in the opening of the new German Railways information bureau. The railroad opening is one that does not fall within the province of this department.
New York University and St. John's played a remarkable ball game at Dexter Park yesterday, with its most distinctive feature its length.

Mr. and Mrs. David Samuel Gamble of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Gamble, to Heckscher Tweed, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Tweed. The wedding will take place in August at Madison, Conn.

The New York Chapter of Kenwood Alumnae, which aids the blind, will give a flower and fashion show during the luncheon hour at Chatham Walk of the Hotel Chatham on May 21, when the sidewalk cafe will be opened for the Spring and Summer.

Mr. and Mrs. Marcus D. Richards of Hubbard Woods, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Fidelia Richards, to William Winston Roper Jr., son of Mrs. William Winston Roper of Chestnut Hill and the late Mr. Roper.

Alabama, Florida, Indiana and South Dakota hold primary elections today. In Alabama Senator Hill, elected in April for the rest of Mr. Black's term, will be unopposed for the full term beginning in January, 1939.

In the face of protests that the constitutional guarantee of the freedom of the press was violated, the Supreme Court today, without comment, upheld the validity of the Arizona law imposing a license fee and a privilege tax on the publication of newspapers.

The Central Maine Power Company and the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, both subsidiaries of the New England Public Service Company, have filed applications for exemption from requirement for filing a declaration covering issuance of securities to be used for payment of bank loans and other purposes, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Rudie Marshall, 158 3/4, Stamford, Conn., fought an uphill battle to gain a draw with Walter Woods, 163, East Side, in the feature bout of eight rounds before 2,800 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Thomas Mann, German author in exile, will be the guest of honor at a dinner at the Hotel Astor next Monday, it was announced yesterday by a committee headed by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University.

Fourteen-year-old Deanna Durbin has earned $165,000 from the movies and radio, it was disclosed today in a court case involving an agent's commissions. Judge Joseph Vickers awarded $4,139.86 paid by Jack Sherrill and Frederick Falkin, Deanna's agents, to Rita Stanwood Warner, former wife of H. B. Warner, veteran film actor.

The award to The Edmonton Journal of a special Pulitzer Prize in the form of a bronze plaque for public service and of engraved certificates to the five other daily newspapers and the weeklies was regarded in this Canadian Province today as recognition and reward for a long uphill battle to preserve the freedom of the press against governmental control, censorship and intimidation.

Arthur T. Vanderbilt, president of the American Bar Association, was consulted yesterday by representatives of the Workers Defense League on whether civil liberties had been violated in the forceful deportation of Norman Thomas by Jersey City police when the Socialist leader attempted to address a rally in Journal Square Saturday night.
The Treasury today received a money order for $100 from Fred Hohner, an unemployed mechanic of Newark, N. J., in payment for "shelter" he received in 1935 from "the government."
The University of Newark tennis team chalked up its third straight victory of the season by trouncing Fordham University today, 6 to 3. The Bombers scored four singles and two doubles victories.
Minimum salaries for workers, including farm hands and domestic servants, went into force today under a decree signed by President Getulio Vargas yesterday in commemoration of Labor Lay.

A decision by a Federal Court sitting in Minneapolis, holding unconstitutional the Minnesota Unfair Trade Practice Act requiring all types of food stores under one ownership to charge identical prices regardless of varying business costs, is likely to have a substantial bearing on legislation of this type in twenty-one other States, George J. Feldman, of counsel for the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company said yesterday.
The Coca Cola Company declared a dividend of 50 cents a share on its common stock, payable on July 1 to stock of record of June 11. A similar amount was paid on April 1.
In heavy crosswinds that sent scores soaring in many instances at the Garden City Country Club today, two teams finished in a deadlock for top honors in a Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro tournament.

James J. Caffrey yesterday succeeded Ernest Angell as regional administrator of the New York office of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Caffrey, former chief of the Boston office, met representatives of the financial press yesterday but was noncommittal, indicating an intention to continue the policies of his predecessor.

Racing returned to the Chicago area today as 10,000 fans jammed the Fox Valley Jockey Club track for the season's opener. The 10,000, who bet $150,000 through Aurora's new totalisator, saw a little of everything during the course of the seven-race program.

The associated boards for the thirteen Christian colleges in China held their annual dinner last night at the Hotel Roosevelt. It was attended by 200 trustees of the colleges, by faculty members, and by thirteen Chinese graduates who are ir this city for advanced studies.

Anticipating that the Winter wheat crop this year will be the largest for any year except one, the railroads have begun preparations to- move it Without delay or interference with other traffic, the Association of American Railroads has reported.

After a shutdown since last Wednesday the Chevrolet and Fisher body plants here resumed operation today, giving employment to 2,500 men. The layoff was attributed to overproduction and another may be ordered within a few days, it was announced at the plants.
Consumer views concerning proposed ordinances taxing super-markets in Bridgeton and Hamilton Townships will be aired at public hearings to be held by town councils in both townships tomorrow.
John O'Neill Jr., 8 years old, of 242 Bergen Avenue, was fatally injured at 7:30 o'clock tonight when he was struck by an automobile while crossing Bergen Avenue near his home.

MAN'S affection for error seems to be one of his chief qualities. Born an ignoramus, he learns with difficulty, and then most quickly the wrong things. It was only about 200 years ago, for example, that a Bavarian named Stahl sold everybody on the idea of phlogiston.

Dominlon, privinclal and municipal financing in Canada for April amounted to $66,330,300 and consisted principally of $60,000,000 of Treasury bills, according to a compilation by Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd.

The report of the Northern States Power Company of Delaware and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued today, shows a net income after interest, amortization, minority charges and other expenses of $6,057,067, compared with a net of $5,217,090 in the twelve months to Feb. 28, 1937.

By a vote of 33 to 25, the Assembly adopted after long debate tonight a resolution proposing a constitutional amendment for pari-mutuel betting at race tracks. If adopted by the Senate, as is generally expected, the question will be submitted to the electorate this year.
The Board of Higher Education approved last night a resolution providing for voluntary Wasserman tests as a part of the usual medical examinations at Brooklyn and City Colleges.

Mrs. Beeckman J. Delatour and Mrs. Ellinger Warwick head a group of women in charge of a dinner dance benefit for Huntington House, which will mark the formal opening of the Garden of the Ambassador tonight.

The British House of Commons delivered a salute to Premier Mussolini as Chancellor Hitler was on his way to Rome, ratifying the Anglo-Italian treaty, 316 to 108. Praise of Italian good faith by Prime Minister Chamberlain brought furious attacks from Labor and Liberal leaders.
More than 20,000 employers in Manhattan failed to file Social Security tax returns for the last quarter, due last Saturday, it was announced yesterday.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 27:

The British partition commission began its tour of inquiry this morning, driving from Jerusalem to Jaffa and Tel Aviv. It encountered the first signs of a complete Arab boycott at Jaffa, where not a single Arab met them.

If Norman Thomas, or any one else, had lingering doubts as to whether freedom of speech exists in Jersey City they were removed last Saturday night. Mr. Thomas was also removed--once by ferry and once by the Hudson Tubes.

William Randolph Hearst Jr., in 447 E 57th St; Edward Morris, in 1,150 Fifth Ave; A. E. Shea, in 300 W 23d St; James F. Ryan, in 15 E 48th St; Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc, broker. Thomas Jones. in 226 W 97th St; Morris Wolf, In 575 West End Ave; Abraham Hecker, in 300 Central Park W; Bernard Prager, in 441 West End Ave; George J.

Senator Minton of Indiana-successor to Mr. Justice Black as chairman of the Senate Lobby Committeehas introduced a bill which would subject to a heavy fine and a compulsory prison sentence the publisher of any newspaper, magazine or other periodical circulating in interstate commerce, "in which is published as a fact anything known to said publisher or his responsible agent to be false.

William H. Smith, noted metallurgist, pioneer of the automobile industry and whom William S. Knudsen credited with "giving me my start in America," died tonight after a week's illness. His age was 65.
The National Labor Relations Board asked the Federal Circuit Court today for permission to withdraw the NLRB order finding the Ford Motor Company guilty of Wagner Act violations.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 2, unless specified: At San Pedro, May 1: Arctic, Utah. New London to Norfolk: Dickerson, Leary. At Shanghai: Isabel, May 1: Oahu. At Makassar: Canopus, Pigeon, S-36, 37, 38. 39 and 41.

The Protestant clergy, who are opposing State domination of the church, announced their willingness today to take the oath of obedience and loyalty to Chancellor Adolf Hitler. Their Confessional Synods, however, in a formal announcement added two conditions.

Trading was mostly fair in local markets yesterday. The lamb market was stronger, veal weak, other non-kosher meats steady. Early kosher business indicated beef and lamb to be about steady, veal weak. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

The Adjutant General released the following orders today: These officers, having qualified, are placed on duty: Eaton, Lieut. Comdr. Ernest R., Medical Corps, is to report to the Commanding Officer, N. Y. N. M., for assignment to Headquarters as Brigade Surgeon.

Radio stations of the Columbia and Mutual Broadcasting Systems and the blue network of the National Broadcasting Company will rebroadcast a description this afternoon of the arrival of Chancellor Adolf Hitler in Italy for his meeting with Premier Benito Mussolini.

Still only "No. 552" so far as her builders are concerned, the new Cunarder, Queen Elizabeth, presented an unforgettable sight today as thousands of workers put the finishing touches to the hull of the liner that is to be a larger, finer and-one may assume-faster version of the Queen Mary.
More than 700 persons attended a testimonial dinner last night at the Commodore Hotel for Mgr. Martin A. Fitzpatrick, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Sorrows, Corona, L. I.

Using the entire main-floor exhibition hall at Grand Central Palace, Hearns Department Stores today win open a two-day sale of 66,000 blankets, representing the entire stock of Cannon-Leaksville Woolen Mills, Leaksville, N. C. Regular and extra salespeople will be at the exhibition hall for the sale, which will be concluded tomorrow.
A new low point in the current recession in wholesale commodity prices was registered last week, according to the price index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association.
Dr. Ross V. Patterson, for the last twenty-two years dean of Jefferson Medical College, died tonight in Jefferson Hospital after an illness of a month. His age was 60.
The thirteen-story office building at 80 William Street figured yesterday in one of the rare recent deals involving realty in the financial and insurance district.

The President's letter to Mrs. Norton, expressing the hope that "the House as a whole can vote on the Wage and Hour Bill--either by reconsideration of this action by the Rules Committee itself or by the petition route," gains much by the reasonableness of its argument.
Mayor La Guardia of New York is the "type" of Presidential candidate to be selected in the future, according to William Allen White, editor of The Emporia (Kansas) Gazette.

Josephus Daniels, United States Ambassador to Mexico, and Mrs. Daniels were greeted today by friends from many States and from Mexico as they celebrated their golden wedding anniversary at Wakestone, their home here.

Thirty-eight varsity letters and six medals "for distinguished service" were presented to members of the N. Y. U. women's field hockey, basketball, fencing, tennis and swimming teams last night at the fourteenth annual dinner of the N. Y. U. Women's Athletic Association at the Hotel Brevoort.

Hope for early demolition of the Sixth Avenue elevated was strengthened yesterday by remarks made by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson during a hearing on the application of the Manhattan Railway Company for-permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act.
Paced by Ival Goodman with two home runs and Billy Myers with a double and two singles, the Reds scored an 8-6 victory over the Pirates today to sweep a series of three games.

With the leasing of the store and basement in 95 Madison Avenue, the National Mineral Company, manufacturer of chrome furniture and beauty-parlor equipment, now occupies three times the amount of space formerly occupied.

James W. Trihy, a retired lieutenant of the New York Fire Department, died today at his home, 7,006 Ridge Crest Terrace, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. Mr. Trihy was born seventy-two years ago in Ireland and came to Brooklyn when he was twenty.
Unemployment in the film industry is more acute now than at any time since the 1933 bank holiday, Jack Holen, chairman of a studio labor conference, reported today.

General issimo Francisco Franco hurled his Teruel army against the Spanish Government lines south of Aliaga today during a let-up in the rains, but government advices said he failed to gain appreciably.
Net earnings of the Coca Cola Company in the first three months of this year were $5,945,995 before taxes, compared with $5,130,289 in the March quarter of 1937.

Colonel Bill Terry's swashbuckling Giants were winging westward last night toward Cincinnati on the momentum of an eleven-game winning streak, thanks to the still futile, though ever furious, battling of Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers, who emerged on the short end of a 7-4 count in the series finale at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Dr. Eduardo Santos was elected President of Colombia without opposition in yesterday's balloting. He will be inaugurated Aug. 7. Fifty years old, he was educated as a lawyer, but turned publisher with his purchase of the newspaper Tiempo twentyfive years ago.

The discovery that yeast may serve as an effective substitute for liver or dried stomach extracts in the treatment of pernicious anemia was reported today before the annual meeting of the American Society for Clinical Investigation by Dr. Maxwell M. Wintrobe of the Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore.
Mary Roberts Rinehart, who is recovering from a serious illness, has corrected the proofs of her new mystery novel, "The Wall," which will be released on July 5 by Farrar Rinehart.

Common Pleas Judge Robert V. Kinkead reserved decision this evening on an appeal from the six-month penitentiary sentence imposed on James (Jeff) Burkitt for using abusive and indecent language on April 16, when the police blocked his attempt to speak in Journal Square at the point where Norman Thomas tried to speak Saturday night.
Dr. Harry F. Ward deplores our indifference to human mass suffering. The world is losing its capacity for moral indignation.

Miss Sibyl H. Levy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy W. Levy of 1,120 Park Avenue, was married to William Theodore Golden, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Herbert Golden of 1,235 Park Avenue, yesterday noon at the home of her parents by the Rev. Dr. Ira Eisenstein of this city.

A suspected bank robber was shot and killed, a Federal agent and a son of the dead man were seriously wounded and another officer slightly hurt today when officers raided a hideout near Armstrong, II1.

The Jersey City Giants made it two out of three in their series with Montreal today, when they annexed the third game, 9 to 2. The Little Giants pounded Americus Polli and Ed Chapman for sixteen hits, driving Polli out of the box with a five-run uprising in the second inning.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 30: COLONELS Brandt, A., Inf., to retirement. Sultan, D. I., Eng'rs, Washington, D. C., to Ft. Logan, Col., to sail from New York about Sept. 9, for San Francisco, Calif.

Sir Percy Bates, Bart., of Hinderton Hall, Neston, Cheshire, England, who arrived on the Normandie, is at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Alton B. Parker, who returned here recently after passing the Winter and early Spring in St. Petersburg, Fla., has gone to her country home in Esopus, N. Y., for the Summer.

In the Court of Claims of the United States today the following proceedings were had: J-861--Aluminum Company of America; findings of fact; plaintiff entitled to recover, but entry of judgment suspended awaiting filing of report of Commissioner of the Court showing amount due.-Opinion by Judge Williams, Judge Whaley dissenting.

Retired Engineer of Steamer John B. Sullivan, formerly a member of Engine 247, residing at 73 89th St., Brooklyn, died April 22. Notice The following notice from the Municipal Civil Service Commission is promulgated for the information of the members of the uniformed force:

The annual Tip Top Ball, sponsored by Auxiliary 5 of Stony Wold Sanatorium, will be held on Friday evening at the Plaza. Proceeds will be used to care for young women and girls of the tubercular sanatorium at Lake Kushaqua in the Adirondacks.

Dr. Elias Compton, father of Dr. Arthur H. Compton, University of Chicago physicist, and Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died today at the age of 81. Dr. Compton was Professor Emeritus of Philosophy at Wooster College. He retired from teaching in 1928.

Jackie Coogan emerged victor to day in the preliminary battle to regain his childhood earnings where Judge Emmet H. Wilson overrules demurrers to his accounting suil against his mother and stepfather and confirmed the appointment of a receiver.
Mackubin, Legg Co. have moved to 42 Broadway. Pugh Co. are now at 50 Broadway. Berdell Brothers have moved to 30 Pine Street. Elliot Wolfe have moved to 52 Broadway.

Joe DiMaggio hit his second home run of the year today, Lou Gehrig smacked his first Washington single of 1938, Frankie Crosetti snapped one of the most depressing hitless streaks of his career when he struck a double and the Yanks, shaken up almost beyond recognition, sneaked through with a victory over the Senators, to the dismay of a big Monday crowd of 10,000.

The previous winners of the Pulitzer Prizes in letters and their prize-winning works are listed below. The prizes have been awarded annually, based on the best work in each field in the preceding year.

Dwellings of varied types, including apartment houses and two and one family homes, together with a number of business properties and vacant plots, figured in the realty dealings in the Bronx reported yesterday.

With a decline in Liverpool where quotations failed to meet Saturday's improvement here, and a trend to lower levels in the stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased yesterday to end with net losses of 9 to 11 points.

In the Supreme Court today, Joseph Prendergast, Benjamin Schenker, Samuel Rosenzweig, Morley S. Wolfe, Edward F. Huber, and George J. Banigan of New York City were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

Alfred Rheinstein, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, announced yesterday that an application of the Soviet Private School to occupy a building at 83-75 118th Street, Kew Gardens, Queens, as a school,. had been denied because the building did not comply with the :code for schools.

The "wooden" anniversary of Thrift House, charity rummage shop, will be celebrated tonight with a party and midnight supper at the Commodore Hotel. Admission is by invitation, extended to those who make donations of salable merchandise.

Air mail service between Juneau and Fairbanks, Alaska, will. start today, it was announced yesterday by Pan American Airways in New York. The new service will reduce the time for transporting mail between the capital of the Territory and its principal inland city from nine days to four and one-half hours.

A breathing spell of two or three years "during which both government and business can consolidate, modify and assimilate what already has been done" was proposed here tonight by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, as a means for bringing lasting economic recovery to America.

The Queens Central Y. M. C. A. won its way into the final round of the senior National A. A. U. softball water polo championship by defeating the West Side Y. M. C. A., 24-15, at. the New York Athletic Club last night. The winners will meet the N. Y. A. C., the defending titleholder, in the Winged Foot pool tomorrow night.
The Jeanette MacDonald-Nelson Eddy musical, "The Girl of the Golden West,"

James T. Burke, 32 years old, an attorney of 61 Berry Street, aided in the rescue yesterday of Dana C. Cochrane, 37, of 270 Bowery, who fell off Pier 52A at the foot of Gansevoort Street in the Hudson River. Both were carried downstream by a swift tide and later pulled out, along with a third man, by a tugboat captain.

Dan Carmichael, ace cub hurler, hit a sixth-inning streak of wildness that gave the Princeton varsity an 8-2 victory over the Tiger freshmen on University Field today after Hugh Green had set the regulars down without a hit for four frames. The varsity collected five passes off Carmichael to net six of the inning's seven runs.

The marriage of Miss Genevieve Marian Heide, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Louis Heide of 210 Riverside Drive and Monmouth Beach, N. J., to Edward John McCrossin Jr. of this city will take place on May 25 in the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 150 West Seventy-first Street.

Mrs. Margaret V. Cray, widow of the late Police Inspector Patrick J. Cray and sister of the late Charles F. Murphy, former Tammany leader, died Saturday at her home, 309 East Seventeenth Street. She was the last of her generation of her family.

A Spring Church Choir Festival of different churches and denominations was held last night in Car" negie Hall. Music of the Jewish, Catholic, Protestant, and Russian Greek Churches was heard. Eight choirs of churches and synagogues of Greater New York participated, with their conductors.

Net income of the Solvay- American Corporation for the year ended on March 31 amounted to $2,609,810 after Federal income taxes, $1,197,300 loss on realization of investments and undistributed profits taxes.

Exports of raw sugar from Cuba in the first quarter of the current year amounted to 678,610 Spanish long tons, compared with more than 800,000 long tons in the first quarter of last year, according to a report from Havana made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Alarmed by the increase in traffic on Westchester County highways and the prospect of further congestion when World's Fair crowds arrive next year, the County Board of Supervisors voted, 31 to 7, today to ask the State and Federal Governments to finance parkway improvements costing $24,663.000.

The Indians took to the warpath today in a manner befitting a first-place club. In one inning, the fourth, they shelled three pitchers for nine hits and ten runs. They went on to beat the Tigers, 11-3.
A further temporary modification in the service on the outstanding dollar bonds of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia was announced yesterday by Constantin Fotitch, Yugoslavian Minister to the United States.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler, exponent of the airplane and automobile, will return to the horse and buggy era when he arrives tomorrow on his state visit.

A solemn mass of requiem was celebrated yesterday morning for the Rev. John J. Fagan, at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Pacific Street and Vanderbilt Avenue, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Lawrence H. Bracken, police chaplain in Brooklyn.
Miss Anne White Stuyvesant, of the ninth generation in descent from Peter Stuyvesant, Dutch Governor of New Netherland, died yesterday at her home, 2 East Seventyninth Street.

Steel operations for the week beginning yesterday are scheduled at 30.7 per cent of ingot capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This represents a decrease of 1.3 points, or 4.1 per cent, from the 32 per cent rate of last week.

Two persons were burned to death and two others rescued from flames by firemen shortly after 2 o'clock this morning when a fire destroyed a two-story frame house known as. the Sixteenth Street Hotel, across the street .from Steeplechase Park, near the Boardwalk at West Sixteenth Street, Coney Island.

Appointment of Dr. William I. Myers, Governor of the Farm Credit Administration, to head the Department of Agricultural Economics and Farm Managemeat in Cornell University's College of Agriculture was announced today.

The Maryland Jockey Club's stake-a-day program provided a thrilling feature event as a twelve-day session opened at Pimlico today. The Millsdale Stable's Infantry took the Baltimore Spring Handicap, a $2,500 added sprint of six furlongs, after the judges had consulted the photograph.

WASHINGTON JITTEUS, a comedy in two acts by John Boruff and Walter Hart, based on Dalton Trumbo'S novel of the same name. Staged by Mr. Hart and Worthington Miner; settings by Lawrence L. Goldwasser; produced by the Actors Repertory Company; presented by the Theatre Guild. At the Guild Theatre.

Colonel Walter H. Frank, former commandant of Mitchel Field, now chief of staff at Langley Field, Va., will return here tomorrow to take part in the approaching air corps defense manoeuvres along the Eastern seaboard, to be held from May 12 to 17 with this field as the base af operations.

Everything is set tonight for the arrival in Italy tomorrow of the German Chancellor, who throughout a week-long demonstration is to signify to the world his attachment to his fellow-dictator in Italy.

10th St, 368 E, 25x92.3; Eugene Lebohl and wife to Emigrant Bank, which holds a mtg for $16,000 thereon. Broadway, s e cor 102d St, 75x100; New Idaho Realty Corp to'Nameloc Securities Corp, 363 7th Ave. .

Estate, more than $50,000. To Maud D. Benedict, widow, Hotel Barbizon-Plaza, $10,000 and residue in trust; Alice G. B. Seligman, 1,125 Park Ave., and Edith M. B. Wurts, 244 Cedar St., Englewood, N. J., sisters, remainders in residue. P. Jay Wurts, 244 Cedar St., Englewood, N. J., executor.

John E. Zimmerman, president of the United Gas Improvement Company, told shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday in Philadelphia that "if nothing unforeseen happens" the utility will be able to continue its present dividend rate of $1 a share on the common stock to the close of the year.

The seventh annual field day of the Municipal Bond Club of New York will be held at the Lakeville Club, Lake Success, Great Neck, L. I., on Friday, May 20, according to F. Kenneth Stephenson of Goldman, Sachs Co., chairman of the committee. Those aiding Mr.

In a statement signed by Luis M. Altamirano y Bulnes, titular Archbishop of Blja and secretary of the Episcopal committee in which all Mexican Bishops and Archbishops are represented, the episcopate today approved the contribution of funds by Catholics to the government for the payment of seized oil property.

President Roosevelt has thrown his influence behind the Wages and Hours Bill again. In a telegram to Representative Norton, chairman of the House Labor Committee, he endorsed her decision to seek action on the bill at this session by resorting to the petition method to take it from the hands of the Rules Committee and force it to the floor.

Lighning struck the four-masted British barkentine Cap Pilar and knocked down a man at the anchor chain as the ship arrived here last night, homeward bound from a cruise around the world. Neither the man nor the ship was seriously injured.

There were 4,774 fewer cases in the five traffic courts of the city during April this year than in April, 1937, but the month brought an increase of $31,077 in fines paid in the same courts over the corresponding period last year, it was reported yesterday by Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. at his chambers, 300 Mulberry Street.

The American Trust Company and the Bankamerica Company, both of San Francisco, bought yesterday an issue of $3,582,242 of registered warrants of the State of California on a 0.75 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $921.43. The warrants will be dated May 15, 1938, and are to mature on or about Aug. 31, 1938.

With thirty merchant marine deck and engineer officers and fortyfour enlisted men aboard, the battleship Texas left from the Navy Yard in Brooklyn shortly before noon yesterday for Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

Wheat futures dropped to new low levels for the season today. Liquidation induced by excellent crop reports from the Winter wheat belt and further good rains in the Northwest was persistent on the Board of Trade here.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 29: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Dillon, W. M., staff, Commander of Cruisers, Scouting Force, in June, to Naval Operations, Washington, D. C.

Charles J. Margiotti, ousted State Attorney General, whose charges of bribery and coercion against Democratic leaders and members of the Earle Administration led to the calling of a grand jury inquiry at Harrisburg, turned over today to directors of the investigation additional information on "graft and bribery."

The American Red Cross, opening its annual convention here, was pictured today by speakers as.a force for peace in a world where war's destruction had increased and added to the peril of the Red Cross worker's task.

Although Mexico City was violently shaken by an oscillatory earthquake lasting several seconds at 8:15 this evening, knocking plaster off walls and ceilings and frightening residents into praying on their knees wherever they happened to be, the observatory at Tacubayo, serving the capital, denied under government orders that a quake had occurred.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial on the President's message on the subject of monopoly is admirable.
Turpentine firm, 23c; sales, 146 barrels; receipts, 434 barrels; shipments, 31 barrels; stock, 32.365 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 552; receipts, 1,380; shipments, 265; stock, 87,439.

More than 1,500 persons prominent in banking, business and professional circles in New York City attended the dinner opening the drive of the Greater New York Fund, Inc., and heard various speakers stress the need for cooperative action to finance private welfare and health organizations.

Two persons were killed and six hurt during political clashes yesterday in the resort town of Cuernavaca. The fight took place when the Governorelect, Elpidio Perdomo, tried to take possession of the State Capitol and his opponents in the recent election tried to stop him.
Trading in listed bonds on the New York Stock Exchange came nearer to a complete standstill yesterday than it has in almost twenty years.

Due to the week-end dullness in Wall Street, there was an easier tendency in most sections of the stock market here today. The gilt-edge list was a firm exception, while among the foreign bonds some Chinese issues improved in anticipation of a settlement of the customs question.

At the very time when the Administration is seeking to strengthen the antimonopoly laws, Justice Black sharply criticized the Supreme Court majority today for two decisions which he said "will inevitably result in a sweeping expansion of this the statutory boundaries constitutionally fixed by Congress to limit the scope and duration of patent monopolies."

The north tube of the Lincoln Tunnel under the Hudson River, between Manhattan and Weehawken, N. J., was holed through at 1:10 P. M. yesterday. Owen Roarthy, sandhog of the New Jersey gang, pushed through the muck and grinned as the New York force cheered.

Miss Elizabeth Rogers Roberts, daughter of Justice Owen J. Roberts of the Supreme Court and Mrs. Roberts of Washington, D. C., and of Kimberton, Pa., will be married to Charles A. Hamilton of Greens Farms, Conn., son of Mrs. Burgoyne Hamilton of New York and the late Mr. Hamilton, on June 4 at Bryncoed, the country place of the bride-elect's parents in Kimberton.

Tonight's major events: Philadelphia Orchestra, evening, Carnegie Hall, and the Branscombe Choral, evening, Town Hall. Victor Chenkin, character singer, will appear in recital at Steinway Hall tonight for the benefit of the Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade.

The articles of association of Governor Philip F. La Follette's new National Progressive party, made public here today with the names of the founders deleted, bar it from ever adopting principles or taking action that would be "repugnant to the Constitution" and pledge it to defend freedom of speech, press and assembly.

Charles H. Meyer, authority on stock exchange law, formerly of Guggenheimer, Strasser Meyer, and Ira Skutch and Lee H. Burton, constituting the firm of Feiner, Skutch Burton, announced yesterday the formation of a partnership for the general practice of law under the firm name of Skutch, Meyer Burton.

Leading stocks closed slightly firmer but lower in second slowest trading since Feb. 4, 1935; turnover, 354,010 shares. United States Government issues higher, other bonds irregular in smallest trading for a full day in twenty years; transactions, $3,597,450.
Stagehand, Trainer Earl Sande's Cinderella horse, will get a chance tomorrow to show the hardboots why he is the No. 1 candidates for Saturday's renewal of the $50,000 added Kentucky Derby.

Raymond L. Korndorfer, broker, and Thomas V. Tozzi, attorney, have been elected to fill vacancies on the directorate of the Bronx Board of Trade. They will serve until the annual meeting of the board in December.

Burgess Whitehead, convalescing second baseman, will be lost to the Giants indefinitely, it was revealed tonight by Manager Bill Terry as the National League champions passed through here on their way to Cincinnati, where they open their first Western invasion tomorrow.
Another shipment of $5,800,000 gold has been dispatched to this country by Japan, according to information received by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.
Another empire exhibition which, like that at Wembley in 1934 and 1935, will present British products from the four corners of the earth, will be opened tomorrow by King, George and Queen Elizabeth.

St. Agnes Ave (17-5133), w s. 175 s of Central Ave, 50x100; Joseph E. Marx Co., Inc., to Lillian Grotz, 2,854 E 196th St. Rochambeau Ave, (12-3335), e s s of Van Cortlandt Ave, 160x100; Bekler Realty Corp to Emile Realty Corp, 22 E 105th St, mtg $161,500.

Ceiling, an improving gelding, stepping up from claiming races to Class C handicaps, justified the confidence of his trainer at Jamaica yesterday by winning the Polydor Handicap at six furlongs for his third straight victory of the meeting.
Foreign Minister Jose Maria Cantilo and other members of the visiting Argentine delegation were guests of honor today at army headquarters.

Offering will be made today by Leigh Chandler Co., Inc., of 9,000 shares of capital stock of Major Marketing Company, Inc., New York, at $1.50 a share. The stock, which will be offered by means of a prospectus as a speculation, marks the initial public financing of the company. Proceeds of the sale will be used for working capital.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Color in Painting," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; Egyptian Collection (general tour), noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Design in Dress Fabrics," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Oriental Puppets and Plays," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 4P. M.

The American Federation of Labor's executive council today revoked the charters of six more unions of the Committee for Industrial Organization, leaving in the ranks of the federation, of all the C. I. O. unions, only the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, of which David Dubinsky is president.

Carole Lombard has renounced comedy for the moment and will return to melodrama. SelznickInternational today announced that she had been cast in "Made for Each Other," adapted from Rose Franken's "Of Great Riches."

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended April 28 totaled 278, compared with 226 in the preceding week and 183 in the same period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Prince Louis Ferdinand of the House of Hohenzollern and the and Grand Duchess Kira of the House of Romanoff were married in civil ceremony in Cecilienhof Castle this morning.

General Amasa Junius Parker, widely known lawyer, soldier and statesman, died today, just four days before his ninety-fifth birthday. Funeral services will be conducted privately at his home on Wednesday with military honors at the Albany Rural Cemetery.

The union of real estate interests to oppose high taxes and legislation "inimical to property owners," proposed during March, is becoming an actuality, it was disclosed yesterday at a meeting of more than seventy representatives of realty and civic organizations at the Hotel Commodore.

Information that a warrant for his arrest as a material witness in an espionage case had been issued by Federal Judge Vincent H. Leibell caused Lutz Leisewitz, official of the North German Lloyd Line, to cancel plans for returning to Europe last night aboard the liner Europa.

State Auditor Walter R. Darby reported today that New Jersey municipalities were in an improved financial position because of continued activities in refunding. However, eight cities, fourteen boroughs and nine townships were in default in the payment of principal and interest on their debt service on March 31.

A DICTIONARY OF SLANG AND UNCONVENTIONAL ENGLISH, by Eric Partridge. (Macmillan, $12.50.) Second edition, revised and enlarged. JAMES I OF ENGLAND, by Clara and Hardy Steeholm. (Macmillan, $3.75.) A biography.

The International Labor Organization today opened its tripartite technical meeting to consider reducing coal mining hours while taking into account economic and social factors. Its purpose is to facilitate action by the organization's, conference in June.

Gross assets, $155,409: net, $148,662. To Mary F. McParlan, sister, $148,662. Chief assets, real estate, $153,084. Nicholas A. Donnelly, attorney, 20 Vesey St. POSNER, DAVID H. Nov. 6, 1934). Gross assets, $69,701; net, $31,257. To Mary M Posner widow, $1,257. Chief assets.
Glenn S. (Pop) Warner, veteran football mentor, who is coach at Temple University, was the guest speaker at a meeting of the Temple University Club of New York at the Hotel Astor last night.

Automobile production declined sharply last week, when there was registered a small easing in the seasonal trend, and the adjusted index slumped to 43.3. It was 51.1 in the previous week and 118.6 a year ago.
A six-run attack in the sixth enabled the Manhattan freshman baseball team to defeat George Washington High, 8--5, at the George Washington Stadium yesterday.
The Senate debated the Naval Expansion Bill, received the Nye resolution for lifting the embargo on arms to Spain, and recessed at 5 P. M. until 11 A. M. tomorrow.
The Philadelphia Inquirer will announce tomorrow morning an increase in the retail price of the paper from two cents to three cents a copy, effective next Monday.

A group of young women will serve as ushers at the recital of original monologues by Mrs. Francis Rogers and songs by Earle Spicer, baritone, which will be given tomorrow afternoon in the Embassy Room of the Ambassador to assist the Prosperity Shop.

The following dispatch is from a correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES who has visited the vital battle front in South Shantung, where the Japanese and Chinese have been locked for weeks in a major struggle. His revelations bear out reports that the second Japanese offensive has been checked:
Great Britain told Czechoslovakia today that her first proposals for satisfying Nazi demands and preventing another armed move in Middle Europe were not sufficient.

An import-permit requirement for wheat flour was placed in effect yesterday by the Brazilian Supervisory Board for Flour Trade, according to a cable from the United States commercial attache at Rio de Janeiro and made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Mrs. Madeline Force Astor Dick Fiermonte, filed suit for divorce here today from Enzo Fiermonte, charging extreme cruelty. No mention was made in the papers filed of a $125,000 settlement which she was reported to have made on him when he sailed for Europe recently.

Making one of her infrequent appearances in a full-length play. Cornelia Otis Skinner, the disease, will open a week's engagement in "Romance" on July 18 at the Ogunquit (Me.) Playhouse. Miss Skinner, who played "Candida" on the Summer circuit in 1935 and 1936, will have the role made famous by Doris Keane in the revival of the Edward Sheldon play.

Seventeen persons pleaded guilty today in Federal court on charges of conspiracy in connection with what officials described as the "biggest organized lottery ring in the East" and were fined a total of $10,500.

In the Customs and Patent Appeals Court of the United States today the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4121-American Import Co. v. the United States. Opinion by Judge Bland. The United States Customs Court judgment affirmed. Judge Garrett dissents.

The split within labor's ranks, as emphasized last week by the advice. of American Federation of Labor leaders that its unions withdraw from the American Labor party, has spurred political manoeuvring within the Constitution Convention.

A "tribute" dinner to the blind, believed to be the first event of the kind in this city, was held last night at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn. Awards of bronze medals were presented to four men and one woman who cannot see, "in token of their outstanding achievement."

The New York University freshman baseball team scored its second victory of the season by defeating the College of Paterson, 11 to 10, yesterday at Ohio Field. Joe La Manna starred at the bat for the Violet, hitting a home run in the first inning with the bases loaded and also had a double and single in four trips to the plate.

The Wolverhampton Wanderers wrested the lead from Arsenal in the English Football League today by defeating West Bromwich Albion, 2 to 1. If the Wolves are successful at Sunderland, Saturday, they will win their first league title.

Thomas H. Hagerty of 46 College Avenue died at St. Peter's Hospital shortly before midnight last night after a short illness at the age of 64. He was attorney for the city of New Brunswick for the last twenty-three years and was one of the Democratic State Committeemen.

Maj. Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, returned to this city yesterday aboard the Normandie of the .French Line after a three-week trip to Europe. The commissioner declared that his visit was worthwhile from the standpoint of finding some uniform method of governing international boxing.

Margaret Rawlings, dramatic actress, received a probationary divorce (decree nisi) today from Gabriel Toyne on grounds of adultery. Her suit against the actor-producer was not defended. Decree nisi may be made final in six months.
Celebrating the silver wedding anniversary of the President of Peru, a reception was given last night at his country residence, "La Perla."

Across the footlights of the Vanderbilt Theatre this evening Broadway will put the eye on "Eye on the Sparrow," or Maxwell Selser's comedy of the financially embarrassed in Park Avenue and Greenwich Village.

All Moscow is celebrating tonight the gayest and most carefree holiday in the Soviet calendar-the day after May Day. May Day itself was exhausting, with its parade of 1,000,000 or more, who had stood in. line all morning for the brief sprint past Soviet leaders in Red Square.
Edvard Moritz, Swedish-born conductor and composer, made his American debut at the head of his newly organized. ensemble, known as the Edvard Moritz Chamber Orchestra, at the Town Hall last night.

August Bohn has purchased from Mayfair Homes, Inc., the onefamily dwelling on the north side of Thirty-eighth Avenue, fifty feet east of 211th Street, Bayside, Queens, for occupancy, through Edward J. Farrell, attorney. The house is on a plot 50 by 80 feet.

Brig. Gen. Fulton Q. C. Gardner, retiring commander of Fort Hancock, was honored here today by a parade and review of the entire garrison. He leaves the coast defense post to take a temporary assignment in Washington.
The Manati Sugar Company announced yesterday that interest due on May 1 on its new twenty-year 4 per cent bonds is now payable at the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.

Heavier retail advertising last month because of the Easter promotions reduced the loss in linage of eight newspapers here under March, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records reports.

A dinner and dance will be given at the Pierre tonight by the League of Young Russia in aid of the league's general welfare fund. The philanthropic work of the organization is conducted principally among children of Russian emigres in this nation and other countries.
A seven-week season of grand opera opened at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, tonight with the performance of Mozart's "Magic Flute," conducted by Sir Thomas Beecham.

The division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Department of Labor made known yesterday a unanimous decision of the Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board to the effect that thousands of persons who perform factory work in their homes for outside employers are insured employes as defined by the New York unemployment insurance law.

The Board of Estimate, meeting in special session last night in Mayor La Guardia's office at City Hall, voted an appropriation of $9,144,000 to pay the expenses of unemployment relief in New York in the month of May.

Hard, dry wickets resulted in high scores in first-class cricket matches today. Led by Don Bradman's 258 on Saturday, the Australians completed their first innings against Worcestershire for 541 runs. The Sauce County made 268 in reply and, going in a second time, scored 74 for one wicket.

Real estate taxes collected since April 1 for the first half of 1938 amounted to $9,580,727 more than collected for the same period last year, it was announced yesterday by William Reid, City Collector.
The Red Sox hammered Harry Kelley, Edgar Smith and Almon Williams for thirteen hits and as many runs in the first three innings today to rout the Athletics, 13 to 1.

The National Spring Home Furniture Show opened today at the American Furnature Mart, with more new samples on exhibition than in many previous seasons. More than 800 buyers attended the first of the sixday meeting, and about 2,000 are expected to register before the end of the week.
The Senate voted an amendment into the Administration's $1,156,000,000 Naval Expansion Bill today, which qualified the approval by Congress of projected 45,000-ton battleships.

With the Constitutional Convention entering upon its fourth week, the Republican majority tonight indicated clearly that it is prepared to keep in its hands control of the convention assured by the party majority at the polls.
The St. John's University tennis team gained its fourth victory in six starts by defeating Brooklyn College, 7-to-2, at the Boulevard Garden courts in Jackson Heights yesterday.

Miss Anna Frances Frear, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wright Frear of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to Lieutenant William Campbell Gibson Church, the Engineer Corps, United States Navy, which will take place here on June 25 in St. Paul's Church.

When the Emigrant Bank sold to the 237 Realty Corporation, Jacob Lipschitz, 236 E 82d St, pres, the parcel at 237-39 E 29th St. 50 ft wide, for a price shown as $43.000, it took back a p m mortgage for $42,688 and a building loan for $6,000, both due on demand.

Sometimes time does turn backward in its flight-and with good results. This is the case when we put trees back on ground where trees ought to grow. This week Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne was able to announce that with the aid of the CCC boys the State was well ahead with its Spring planting of 13,000,000 trees.

I do not think it will be necessary for me this afternoon to delve very deeply into past history. At the same time if we are to obtain a proper consideration of the agreement [with Italy] I think it is an essential preliminary that I should say something about the conditions which prevailed.before it was signed.

Marking the close of the three-day preview of the New York World's Fair 1939, forty-nine automobile couriers started from the fair grounds in Flushing Meadow Park yesterday afternoon for a "good-will tour" of the entire country.
Plans were filed yesterday in the Queens office of the Department of Housing and Buildings for a sixstory apartment house in Long Island City, the cost of which is estimated at $500,000.
The sharpest decline in President Roosevelt's popularity in any month since early 1934 was registered in April in the Presidential 'index of the American Institute of Public Opinion.
Police had to fire on an armed crowd of strikers on the Tate Lyle sugar estate in Westmoreland this morning. Three persons were killed and nine injured.

Amalgamation of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O. unit of unlicensed seamen, and the Inland Boatmen's Union, a group of employes-on barges, tugs and similar craft, was considered yesterday afternoon at a meeting at the N. M. U. hall, 126 Eleventh Avenue.

Wladyslaw Talun 300-pound Pole, tossed Big Chief Sanooke, Cherokee Indian, who weighed 380, in the main wrestling bout at the Hippodrome last night. A crowd of 2,000 saw the 7-foot-tall winner score in 2:11 with a crotch hold and body slam.

The management of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway issued yesterday to its stockholders an appeal to withhold proxies from a committee backed by the Guaranty Trust Company which seeks to place three new members on the C. O.'s board.

Dean Sage Jr. and Malcolm P. Aldrich were elected to the board of trustees of the American Museum of Natural History last night at the annual meeting of the board. Mr. Sage led the West China expedition for the American Museum in 1934-35, and succeeded in making extensive collections of mammals and birds from that region. Mr.

New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company sold to Estelle Goldman the nineteen-family flat at 361 Danforth Avenue, Jersey City, on a plot 43 by 131 feet. The bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $41,500.

The Nassau County Board of Supervisors heard today a 1938 version of the theme "Woodman, Spare That Tree" during a hearing on the adoption of road maps showing property to be acquired for the repair and realignment of Hicksville-Farmingdale road.

North Carolina's tennis stars defeated Williams, 7-2, today for their third victory over the Purple this Spring. Al Jarvis, of Williams, New England intercollegiate champion, won the No. 1 singles and teamed with Pete Shonk, sophomore star, for a victory in the doubles.

Six firemen were injured, four of them seriously, at 1:15 o'clock this morning when Fire Rescue Squad 3 and Engine Company 48, answering separate alarms in their apparatus, were in collision at 188th Street and Valentine Avenue, the Bronx.

A single by Merrill May that scored Les Scarsella in the eighth inning and capped a four-run rally, enabled the champion Bears to gain a 12-to-l1 decision over Rochester today. It was the seventh straight victory for Newark.

A special session of Congress to deal with a permanent recovery program was suggested today by Mayor La Guardia of New York, who appeared as a witness before a House subcommittee which is writing legislation for the President's $4,500,000,000 relief and recovery program.

The Rev. James A. Hobson, rector of St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church here for the last five years, died last night in St. Mary's Hospital at Orange of burns received on Saturday when a cigarette he was smoking ignited his pajamas. He was 52 years old.

The engagements of Miss Frances Pierpont Kopper and Miss Patricia Burton, two young women of the Montclair, N. J., district who made their debuts together in 1934, have been announced simultaneously by their respective parents.

All grades of fed steers were under pressure on a very slow, weak to 25 cent lower market. Prime light steers sold up to $10.40, but bulk of crop went at $9.25 downward. Hogs lost a little price ground, but lambs held about steady, fed woolskins selling up to $9 and clippers $7, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

Despite three Chicago home runs, the Cardinals beat the Cubs, 6 to 3, today with a 4-run, eighth inning rally featured by Joe Medwick's circuit blow. It was the Cardinals' fourth victory of the season.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Waldo Emerson MacGregor of Crestwood, Roslyn Estates, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Irene Damon MacGregor, to Raymond J. Mathewetz, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Mathewetz of Ashland, Wis.

The strapless evening dress became a leading item in the formal evening group during April, doubling its volume of March, when it first received general consumer recognition, according to the monthly statistical report issued yesterday by Lord Taylor.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association officially opened the season with the Long Island interclub team matches as 130 players representing 26 clubs fought for supremacy in the Class A and B divisions at Queens Valley in Forest Hills yesterday.

The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York will hold its annual convention this year in the form of a cruise to Nassau in the Bahamas. The cruise will be made on the Kungsholm of the Swedish American Line, leaving New York on Oct. 21 and returning on Oct. 27.

A $3,500,000 mortgage loan at 4 per cent on the forty-eight-story Continental Bank Building at 30 Broad Street has been made by an undisclosed mortgagee through the Paul Hammond Company, and Gettner, Simon Asher as co-brokers.
Radio was at its best last evening, when the voices of Lord Horder, chairman of the Empire Rheumatic Council; Dr. William J. Kerr, president of the American Heart Association; Dr. T.

The year's awards of the Pulitzer Prizes in letters and journalism were announced last night by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, at the annual dinner of the alumni of the Graduate School of Journalism, which was held at the Columbia Men's Faculty Club.

Using the full powers granted to him by Parliament last month, Premier Edouard Daladier today issued, in accord with his Cabinet, his first series of decrees tending toward economic recovery and stimulation of production. All State taxes, direct and indirect, were raised 8 per cent.

Benny Spiller and Jesse Jacobs, members of the vice ring headed by Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania, were sentenced yesterday to five to ten and ten to twenty years' imprisonment, respectively, by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

Announcement of a plan whereby the $35,000,000 Hercules Life Insurance Company will be sold by Sears, Roebuck Co. to the Washington National Insurance Company of Chicago will be made this week, well-informed insurance circles indicated today.

Widespread public approval of the adoption by the Constitutional Convention of a proposal which would bring gambling into the-open-and permit lotteries to be operated under State regulation, with revenues so derived to be used for relief purposes, was expressed in many letters received here today by Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Lewis, Republican, and chairman of the convention's Bill of Rights Committee.

The net railway operating income of Class 1 railroads, of the United States dropped 86.9 per cent from $147,514,808 in the first quarter of 1937 to $19,276,663 for the first quarter of the current year, the Interstate Commerce Commission and Association of American Railroads announced today.

Religious education was discussed at the Spring meeting of the New York Junior League at its clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, last night. A dinner preceded the meeting, at which the Rev. Dr. Theodore F. Savage, secretary of the Church Extension Committee of the Presbytery of New York, presided.
The State Education Department announced today that applications were now being received for admission to the October class of the State Merchant Marine Academy at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx.

Belief that the present business outlook is essentially favorable was expressed today by Howard W. Dunbar, president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association, at the opening of its thirty-sixth annual Spring convention here.

If the Supreme Court, like so many other arms of the government, had a publicity agent, eight days would not have passed before the importance of its decision in the Tompkins case became known. Though Justice Brandeis delivered this transcendently significant opinion a week ago yesterday, it has generally eluded public notice.
The annual luncheon of the alumnae of the Sacred Heart will be held tomorrow at the Convent, 1 East Ninety-first Street. Mrs. Carl Doelger is chairman of arrangements.

New York City last week passed through its second successive weekend without a traffic fatality, it was announced yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Department in making public the weekly tables covering accidents, deaths and the number of persons injured in traffic. The tables are compared with those of similar periods a year ago.

Those of you who are planning to do any salt-water fishing in New Jersey this season will be interested to learn that the State Fish and Game Commission has published a booklet called the "Salt-Water Fishing- Guide," which covers the coast from Atlantic Highlands to the Delaware Bay, and very completely.

Draped models, with short and sometimes lower quarters, featured the advance Fall style showing of the Shoe Fashion Guild at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday, where twenty-seven manufacturers showed their new lines to about 400 buyers.

During the coming week-end the metropolitan district will become the amateur golf capital of America as members of the United States Walker Cup golf team assemble before sailing for England and the biennial international matches.

It is officially announced that the Italian Government has adhered to the Montreux Convention of 1936 regarding the Dardanelles, with certain reservations "dictated by the fact that Italy has withdrawn from the League of Nations." The exact nature of these reservations has not been made public.

Jeremiah Tyner, 31 years old, of 16A Clendenny Avenue, Jersey City, killed himself with a shotgun after wounding his sister and another woman in view of a crowd of factory workers here just after noon today.

Harry O. Ferester, for the last twenty years New York sales agent of the Royal Weaving Company of Pawtucket, R. I., recently liquidated, has formed the Harry O. Ferester Company, selling agency for silks, rayons and novelty fabrics. Temporary offices are at 350 Hudson Street.

The elimination of James V. Ryan of the Brooklyn Handball Club, seeded first, by Otto Schmidt of the home club featured the start. of play in the national A. A. U. fourwall hardball handball championship at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. yesterday.
Organizers of the recently formed National League to Oppose a Third Term for President met yesterday in the law office of Bennett E. Siegelstein. 535 Fifth Avenue.
Continued support of President Roosevelt by the American Labor party was pledged here tonight by Nat M. Minkoff, legislative leader of the party, in a speech delivered at a local Labor party meeting.

The shortest-priced favorite of the meeting was the easiest sort of a winner at Jamaica yesterday, when John Hay Whitney's filly Inhale, winner last year of almost $25;000, was first at the end of the six furlongs of the Trance purse.
E. Stanley Perkins, an authority on leather manufacturing, died yesterday at the Germantown home of his sister, Mrs. Thomas Appleton Cope, after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

Lawrenceville's polo champions scored their fifth straight victory of the year over the Princeton freshmen by overwhelming the cubs, 13--4, on Devereaux Field today in the opening outdoor contest for both teams.

Accompanied by five House members from New York and New Jersey, Representative Barry of New. York arranged today at the White House for an engagement with'President Roosevelt next Wednesday at which the. delegation Will press for 'either legislative or Executive action to check foreclosures by the Home Owners Loan Corporation.
The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today the acquisition by the Bethlehem Steel Corportion of all the properties of the Williamsport Wire Rope Company for $3,300,000 last June.

The Rev. Dr. Ivan Lee Holt of St. Louis and the Rev. Dr. William Walter Peele of Greensboro, N. C., were elected Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, today on the first ballot of the quadrennial conference, in session here.

Despite the civil marriage and Orthodox Church consecration in Potsdam yesterday, Prince Louis Ferdinand of Prussia and the Grand Duchess Kira of Russia are still considered unmarried, according to the austere Lutheran views of the head of the Hohenzollern family, whose members gathered here today.
Ken Keltner, rookie third baseman, pounded out two home runs and drove in six tallies today to help the league-leading Indians defeat Washington, 10 to 9, before a crowd of 10,000.
The failure of the air mail to function on schedule caused a mix-up today on bids for a new air mail contract between Wichita, Kan., and Pueblo, Col.
This city will name a street after the late American philanthropist, Edward Tuck, it was announced today by Rene Failliot, president of the Paris Municipal Council.
The American Artists Congress will open its second membership exhibition with a private view this evening (to the public tomorrow) in admirably arranged galleries on the fifth floor at Wanamaker's.

Despondent over the delay in getting his check from the State Unemployment Insurance Fund, William J. Shea, 50 years old, of 414 West Fifty-third Street, hanged himself with a bedsheet in his apartment yesterday. The check arrived about two hours later. It was for $7. Shea's sister,

The body of Angelo Yamarone, 84 years old, was found today in a well in the yard of his home, at 3 Midland Place, here, by a daughter, Miss Josephine Yamarone. Police said Miss Yamarone told them her father had been in poor health. Dr.

Representatives of seven trade and civic associations met yesterday with members of the Real Estate Board of New York to formulate "a consolidated plan" for the rezoning of certain midtown sections of Manhattan preparatory to the presentation of proposals to the City Planning Commission.

Mrs. Clover Boldt Morrissett, in 320 E 72d St; J. C. Bull, in 2 Beekman P1; Albert B. Ashforth, Inc, broker. Captain Harvey A. Delano, through Douglas Gibbons Co, Inc, in 1,065 Lexington Ave; John N. Thorp Jr., in 277 Park Ave; Fred Hansen, in 176 E 71st St; Carl E. Pihard, Arthur O. Ernst, in 6 E 37th St; Sylvester Weaver Jr., in 36 E 40th St; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, broker.

Mrs. Laura Rood Rowlahd of Watertown and Adrian Van -Sinderen Lindsley, also of this place and Hartford, were married yesterday in the Church of the Redeemer, Bryn Mawr, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Ernest E. Earp.

The twenty-four large apartments in a building on the upper West Side will be broken up into seventytwo small suites at a cost of about $125,000, it was learned yesterday when announcement was made of the sale by the Harlem Savings Bank of the twelve-story and penthouse structure at 140 West Seventy-ninth Street.

Chinese reported today that the second Japanese offensive in Southern Shantung Province, the pivotal front of the war, was on the verge of collapse. The crushing of the first drive last month was the most disastrous defeat of a modern Japanese Army.

Federal Judge William Clark ordered here today the removal of Ellis H. Parker, former chief of Burlington County detectives, and his son, Ellis Jr., to Brooklyn, N. Y., to answer a Federal grand jury indictment charging them with the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel in an aftermath of the Lindbergh case.

The fiftieth anniversary of the Jacob A. Riis Settlement at 48 Henry Street was celebrated last night with a dinner at the Plaza Hotel at which speakers paid tribute to the late Mr. Riis as the first American to realize the problem of the city slums and called on the present generation to carry on his work.
While Adolf Hitler was making a triumphal entry into Rome the French Government disclosed plans tonight for the State visit from the British King and Queen at the end of June.

A temporary injunction restraining the Gold's Drug Stores of Jersey City from selling Calvert whiskies at prices below those provided in the company's fair-trade contracts has been issued there by Vice Chancellor Fielder, the company announced yesterday.
The mysterious disappearance of a Queens policeman was disclosed last night in a teletype alarm sent out from Police Headquarters to. all precincts.

Media Records, Inc, newspaper statistical office, in 354-60 4th Ave; M L Hess, Inc, and Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers. Mary Kropatkin and Eleanor Medcalfe, jewelers, in 130 Fulton St; Albert. Greenfield Co, brokers.
A comprehensive and authoritative world picture of money and banking was given today by publication of the annual Monetary Review of the League of Nations.
The Official Gazette announces that the state of overcrowding in Gibraltar, due to the number of Spanish refugees, continues to be a grave concern. a grave concern.

Three candidates of the Fair Play Committee, promising economies in school operation, were elected today as trustees of School District 1 of the town of East Chester, according to unofficial returns. The winners were P. Leonard de Salvo, Carleton J. Everett and Richard M. Pott. Walter D. Burke and Frank Grogan, incumbents, and John E. Weber were defeated.

Police investigations of the disturbance at a Nazi meeting in Yorkville on April 20, which ended in a clash with American Legion members, and of the assault on Dr. Charles Weiss, editor of an antiNazi publication on April 22, are being pushed at the direction of Mayor La Guardia, a committee of the United Anti-Nazi Council was informed at City Hall yesterday.

An appeal for labor support for the reciprocal trade agreements program was made to John L. Lewis today by Secretary Hull. Mr. Lewis, invited to the State Department for a conference, referred all inquiries to Secretary Hull, who said the trade agreements program had been discussed but gave no details.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I agree with Borough President Harvey that the Queens authorities have done a good job in preparing their borough for the World's Fair visitors, and. that to go farther by doing work on private property would be too much like regimentation.

The Syracuse Chiefs got an outfielder and a pitcher today in a deal with the Cincinnati Reds, but lost Outfielder Arnold Moser to the Montreal Royals. President Jack Corbett announced that Ted Kleinhans, left-hander,

Ira A. Hards, retired theatrical producer, died yesterday at his West Norwalk home. He was in his sixtysixth year.. In recent years Mr. Hards had been interested in the Westchester Playhouse at Mount Kisco, N. Y.,
A contra-seasonal decrease in steel ingot production last week caused the adjusted index to drop to 40.7 from 42.2. This compares with 121.3 for the week ended May 1, 1937.

Mayor La Guardia is of the urban type from which future Presidents will dome, in the opinion of William Allen White. Henceforth the city boy is bound to have the edge over the country boy, for the reason that the whole nation has shifted from rural to urban. Even the rural sections, said Mr.

Grove, the Red Sox's 38-year-old .ace, became the eighth major league pitcher in history to pass the 2,000strike-out mark today when he fanned six Tigers while gaining the 260th victory of his 15-year American-League career.

Twenty-five college and university swimming coaches from all parts of the nation were appointed to committees of the College Swimming Coaches of America Association today by Neils Thorpe,- swimming coach at the University of Minnesota and president of the- national organization.

Vander Pool, a sensation on the American turf in 1930 and 1931 with fifteen straight victories to his credit, was involved in a lawsuit today filed by Mrs. Agnes Allen of New York against Secretary Woodring and the War Department.

Ernest Lemenon, Paris attorney, concluded today a speech, begun yesterday, in which he sought to prove that phosphates were discovered in Morocco by French citizens -several years before the arrival of the Italian claimants in the case now before the Permanent Court of International Justice.
Albert F. Free, president of F. R. Tripler Co., haberdashers, has been appointed State group chairman of the men's wear industry for the American Federation of Little Business, Inc.

The newly extended powers of the Reconstruction. Finance Corporation to make loans to business enterprises "will interest many small retailers," as in addition to giving the RFC discretion to allow long-term credit, the amendment also eases the security requirements somewhat, according to an analysis issued yesterday by the bureau of smaller stores of the Na-. tional Retail Dry Goods Association.

The Rev. Thomas V. Wingate, pastor of St. John's Episcopal Church, Salem, N. J., was nominated for the office of district governor of the 184th District, Rotary International, at the final session of the district organization here today.
The Government Bank and the commercial banks have an excess of Aski marks [German controlled exchange credits] for which there is no demand.

Mrs. Hannah Woodruff, centenarian and friend of President Lincoln, is dead at her home here from injuries suffered in a fall at her home two weeks ago. Widowed at the age of 26, Mrs. Woodruff never remarried.

The principle of exchange fellowships has been applied for the first time to the four-room Hill Public School here, near the Babylon and Huntington boundaries, and as a result its roll of pupils now includes twin Tennesseans, 12 years old.

The Federal Power Commission announced today that it had postponed until June 15 the hearing-scheduled for May 9 on the interlocking directorate applications of the following officials in the Standard Gas and Electric Company system:

Viscount Astor's Cave Man, a 3-year-old colt by Mannamead, from Miss Cavendish, today won the Chester Vase, feature of opening day. Cave Man, starting at 8 to 1, defeated the Aga Khan's Sadruddin by a length and a half,...
The Julius Rosenwald Fund has awarded fellowships to thirty-four Negroes in continuance of its program of furthering the cultural and sociological development of the American Negro.

Many luncheons were given at Sherry's yesterday before the card party and garden bazaar in aid of Save-a-Life Farm which was held later in. the, afternoon at the same restaurant. Miss Frances Coleman,

JosephBuerckel, German Commissioner for Austria, today. appointed the head of the German Press Chamber, Max Amann to the same post in Austria pending the extension of German press laws. Herr Amann has already decreed the "Aryanization"

Counsel for the Young Assenibly Committee sent to the Hudson County counsel, J. Emil Walscheid, today a copy of a brief asking the Court of Errors and Appeals to reverse a ruling by Vice Chancellor Henry T. Kays that the resolution creating- the committee was unconstitutional.

With an estimated attendance of more than 5,000 customers yesterday, the blanket sale being staged by- the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., in the Grand Central Palace gave every indication of being a "sell-out" by tonight, it was stated last night by Leonard Ginsberg, president of the company.

The annual baby health contest of Colony House was held yesterday in the settlement building at 297 Dean Street, Brooklyn. The contest this year had added significance because the institution is celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding.
