Twentytwo persons, charged by the government with participating in an eight-State lottery ring, received suspended prison sentences and fines ranging up to $2,500 when they pleaded guilty today to conspiracy and interstate shipment of lottery tickets. Two others,

Conditions paralleling those of 1932, when imports of manufactured goods touched the lowest levels in twenty years, threaten importers in the coming Summer and Fall unless some radical change in domestic business conditions occurs, customs brokers and importers conceded here yesterday. Shipments are al.

A scrawled letter warning Governor Charles F. Hurley that "Your dogher will be missing one week from today" tonight sent State police and Federal agents on a widespread search for the sender, who signed himself "The Black Hornet."

In an unheralded move the Republic Steel Corporation obtained from the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today an order restraining the National Labor Relations Board. from "taking any steps or proceedings whatsoever" before May 13 in its case against the corporation.

Paul Felix Warburg, whose grandfather, the late Jacob H. Schiff, maintained a residence at 965 Fifth Avenue, will occupy an apartment in the building now under construction on the site of the Schiff residence, it was announced yesterday.

In an effort to make soldiering more appealing as a permanent career, Leslie Hore-Belisha, the Secretary of State for War, announced tonight new regulations holding out a guarantee of twenty-one years' enlistment with a pension at the end.

Describing the White House conference of last Wednesday attended by Henry Ford as an informal and friendly affair at which there was no discussion of a financial or economic nature relating to government, Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today denied as "entirely false" reports that he and Henry Ford "discussed and differed with references to governmental policies."

A novel "Les Halles" party, beginning with a midnight supper and continuing to a dawn breakfast, will be given tonight as a benefit for the Bide-a-Wee Home for Animals. The .supper will be held at the Longehamps Restaurant in East Fify-ninth Streete.

Charging widespread inefficiency in the administration of emergency relief taxes under the previous administration, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday a complete reorganization of the bureau of emergency taxes.

A three-year-old Pennsylvania law giving Negroes the right to be served in public places was declared valid today by the Dauphin County Court, which refused to quash an indictment against a hotel manager accused of violating the law.

The Federal Trade Commission has served a complaint against the American Flange and Manufacturing Company, Inc., of New York and Chicago, charging violating of the Federal Trade Commission, Clayton and Robinson-Patman acts in the manufacture and sale of certain mechanical parts used as closures for metal containers, it was announced today.

The: Madison Square Boys Club, whose membership attacks annual features with a gusto that makes them seem unprecedented, tried cooking again yesterday and produced an 11-year-old Hungarian goulash champ, ne Italian.

The proposal of the United States Steel Corporation to offer $100,000,000 of debentures next month indicates that the company plans to pay as it goes by the medium-term financing of its heavy construction program, now in process of completion.
Twenty-two members of the senior class at Barnard College have been elected to the New York Delta Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, the. honorary society.

Funeral services for Lawrence Marx, president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of NewYork City, will be held in Temple Emanu-EI, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, at 2 o'clock this afternoons Dr.

Florida Democrats renominated United States Senator Claude Pepper in yesterday's primanry, approving his pro-Roosevelt policies in the face of charges by opponents that he was the President's "rubber stamp."

May Day in the Soviet Union was evidently celebrated with a demonstration worthy of the best tradition of the revolutionary holiday Millions of workers from factories and offices marched before the granite tomb of Lenin under the crenelated walls and turrets of the Kremlin.
North Carolina's tennis team won from Harvard today, 5 to 4, taking five of the six singles, while Harred won all three doubles engagements.

The Independence Shares Corporation, Philadelphia, an investment trust, has filed a registration statement finder the Securities Act of 1933 covering 9,955,319 Independence Trust Shares to be offered at the market for estimated cash proceeds of $22,665,020. Proceeds will be used for investment.

Edward Joel Cornish, chairman of the board of the National Lead Company, died suddenly at 2:30 yesterday afternoon at his desk in the offices of the company on the nineteenth floor of 111 Broadway. When his body was discovered by his secretary a doctor was summoned,

Miss Helen M. Farrelly, daughter of James Tully Farrelly of Rye, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Farrelly, has completed plans for her marriage to S. Richard Hall of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Hall, which will take place the morning of May 14 in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. James E. Goggin.
Even in Twelfth Street the dear God will not forget you, according to the author of "Eye on the Sparrow," which opened at the Vanderbuilt last evening.

President Mildred McAfee of Wellesley College disputed yesterday the charge of critics of the country's colleges that graduates take with them from the campuses a godless or an irreligious attitude. Lack of interest in home town church services, she asserted frequently demonstrates less a moral backsliding than a normal reaction. of improved esthetic and intellectual tastes to "dum-de-dum" hymns and inferior sermons by theological seminars recruits.

Plans have been completed by Miss Jean Mabel Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hurst Martin of Rye, N. Y., for hei marriage to Thomas Burnett Dorman'Jr. of Upper Montclair, N. J., which will take place on June 4 in the Presbyterlan Church of Rye.

Official confirmation of the agreement to sell the Hercules Life Insurance Company, now controlled by Sears, Roebuck Co., to the Washington National Insurance Company of Chicago was made today by Hercules Life.

Playing under ideal weather conaltions, Miss Marion Turpie, women's metropolitan champion; topped the largest field ever to take part in an opening one-day-tournament of the Women's Metropolitans Golf Association when she carded 38, 44-82 to win the low gross honors over the North Shore Country Club course yesterday.

The entire exhibit space of 13,046 square feet in the Cosmetics Building of the New York World's Fair has been taken over under contract for $168,032 by Perfumery and Cosmetic Exhibits, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporatlon.

A block on Henry Street, on the lower East Side, will be transformed next Sunday evening into an open-air theatre, where sixtyfive young men and young women will present the premiere of an original pageant called "Youth on Parade" as part of the East Side Youth Day.

Walter Gordon Merritt, counsel for the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, became witness and attorney for-himself yesterday in opposing charges of contempt of court pressed by Frank P. Walsh, counsel for Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, in the injunction suitbrought by the manufacturers against the union.

Germany has Informed the International Danube Commission that Austria's membership in the commission has ceased with its entrance into the Reich. Germany herself withdrew from the commission in November, 1936, when she issued a declaration reassuming "full sovereignty" over all German water courses.

Mrs. John Sloane gave a tea yesterday at her home, 48 East Ninetysecond Street, for Ernest Schelling, director of the Young People's Concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony. Orchestra, and in honor of the members. of the orchestra who were soloists last season.
William Beebe,who returned recently from an expedition in South American waters, will deliver to Harcourt, Brace within the next few days the manuscript of his new book, "Zaca."

Plans for a luncheon, fashion show and tour of historic gardens and houses, of Greenwich Village for the benefit of the Judson Health Center, GreenWich House and the Little Gardens Club were announced yesterday at a joint luncheon of the three organizations at 1 Fifth Avenue.
In this space yesterday an attempt was made to explain the purport and importance of the recent Supreme Court decision in the case of the Erie Railroad Company v. Harry J. Tompkins.

Finding the Pirates moving unhappily down the toboggan of a losing streak, the Dodgers today gave them a few. energetic shoves and won the opening engagement of their first Western trip, 7 to 2, to make it five in a row the recently high-flying Buccaneers have dropped.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City and one of his severest critics, Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, nearly met face to face in Federal court here today when both arrived unexpectedly on separate legal errands having to do with the handling of the "radical" situation in Jersey City.
Adam Richetti, last of "Pretty Boy" Floyd's deadly band, was condemned to Missouri's lethal gas chamber by the State . Supreme Court today for the Kansas City Union Station massacre of 1933.

William M.Eberhardt, Erie County Sheriff, one of a list of past or present publie employes indicted in the Buffalo and Erie County investigations, won acquittal today in his trial on charges of perjury.
Stocks of burlap in the hands of Calcutta mills at the end of April-established an all-time high, according to cables received last night by C. E. Rockstroh Co., here.
Sir Maurice Abbot Anderson, noted physician and botanist and a leader in the movement for the preservation of rural Britain, died today of pneumonia at the age of 77.

For the first time since 1929, Australia is seeking new money in the London market. The Commonwealth tonight advertised for [Pound]7,000,000, with interest at 33/4 per cent, the obligations to be issued at 99 and to be redeemable in 1952-56.
Four bills sponsored by the Princeton Local Government Survey for State Control of Municipal Finances were ready tonight to be sent by the Legislature to Governor Moore.

Although business in the stock market here was on a small scale today, the tendency in most sections was firm. Giltedge- issues were well supported, while among the foreign bonds Chinese loans made further gains and Austrian 7s fell off.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night overwhelmingly rejected a recommendation of its committee on the State Constitutional Convention for abolishing the- County Courts and Court of General Sessions and establishing one superior court of general jurisdiction.
Pittsburgh will offer for sale on May 24 $1,500,000 of school district bonds. The issue will mature serially from 1939 to 1963.
Jackie Kid Berg, 145 1/2, London, defeated. Ray Napolitano, 143 3/4, Brooklyn, in a fast eight-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night before 4,000 spectators.
The Duke University tennis team opened its northern trip yesterday by crushing Brooklyn College, 8-1, on the Kings Community Club courts. Captain Robert Merchant
The war Department released the following orders today, dated May 2: BRIGADIER GENERAL Bryden, W., Ft. George G. Meade, Md., to command 13th F. A. Brigade, Ft. Bragg, N. C.
The Brown Shoe Company declared yesterday a 25-cent dividend for common stockholders. Previously it paid .75 cents quarterly.
Transfer of money due foreign holders of Austrian Government, municipal or private loans was banned today and the prohibition made retroactive to April 30 by a government decree.

The Federal deficit mounted to $1,270,670,707 in the first ten months of the current fise 1 year, compared with $2,154,685,287 for the same period of the last fiscal year, the Treasury Department reported today.

Fairfield Ave (13-3409) e s 440 ft n of 232 St, 222x245; Cajorco Realty Corp to Manufacturers Trust Co; 1 year, 6 per cent; $465,000. 180th St, 780-82 E (11-3109); Leboro Construction Co to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtg to March 1, 1943, at 4 per cent; $44.200.

The Brooklyn College women's swimming team, dedicating the new seventy-five-foot pool, scored a 29-24 victory over Hunter College as a triumph in the relay decided the issue last night at Brooklyn College.

James Harry Westcott, an oil analyst with New York offices at 25 Broad Street, died at his home here on Sunday at the age of 65. Mr. Westcott was a graduate of Lehigh University and for thirtyfive years traveled extensively for large oil corporations and analyzed their Properties and products.

Best steers stopped at $10 on a araggy, weak to 25 cents lower steer trade today which closed dull at the decline. Fed heifers held steady and waterfalls were a big feature in the fat cattle market. Hogs also fell of their own weight in a dull market.

East Houston St, 328, 23x81.11; Louis G. Fooler to Gordon Memorial Chapel, Inc, 341 E Houston St, mtg $7,500 ($3). 11th St, 404 E, 25x94.8; Betty Burak to Harry and Sam Wasserman, 3,002 W 28th St, Brooklyn ($3.50).
Both factions of organized labor rallied vigorously to the support of the Wages and Hours Bill today, but, despite this, Congressional observers expressed private opinions that the bill was doomed.
Net borrowings of members of the New York Stock Exchange on collateral carried here at the close of business on April 30. aggregated $466,766,529, compared with $521,116,919 on March 31.

Mrs. Frank L. Patterson Jr. was elected yesterday as chairman of the Young Women's Organization of the Women's National Republican Club to succeed Mrs. Donald L. Bigelow, who was elected vice chairman and treasurer. Mrs. William Henry Hays, president of the club, was elected honorary chairman.
By a vote of 117 to 37, the House today approved a bill designed to decrease congestion in Federal District and Circuit Courts by providing twentyfour new judgeships.

Trading was fair to slow. Steer beef sold steady. Veal weak to lower, lamb steady to weak, fresh pork cuts steady to lower. Early trading in- kosher meats indicated most classes to be weak to lower. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Losing only two singles matches, Yale today defeated the Columbia tennis team, 7-2. Columbia's stars were Steele and Persinger, who took singles engagements, Steele later pairing with Hayes to give Yale's top pair, H. and M. Stephens,- a hard fight before succumbing, 3--6, 6-3, 13-11.

Senator and Mrs. Pat Harrison learned yesterday morning that their daughter, Miss Catherine Harrison, had been married in Frederick, Md., to Dr. Irvin T Miller of Colton, Calif., and today they sped the couple on their wedding trip with their blessing and good wishes.

Manhattan Alterations 54th St, 342 E; to 3-story bathhouse; Department of Parks, City of New York, owner; Aymar Embury 2d, architect; cost, $130,000. 55th St, 2 W; to 21-story hotel and stores; Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, 1 Madison, Ave, owner; D. E. Wald, architect;

The number of out-of-town buyers reported in-town during the week ended yesterday was slightly ahead of the preceding week but considerably above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

Whether C. L. Bradley and Frank B. Bernard would be re-elected directors of the Alleghany Corporation at the annual meeting in Baltimore today was a subject of speculation in Wall Street yesterday. Robert R. Young, head of the syndicate that controls Alleghany,

The Maritime Commission opened bids from nine shipbuilding plants today for the construction of twelve steel cargo vessels and found them in the aggregate several million dollars below- bids the commission rejected April 10 on eight of the same group of vessels on the ground that' they were so high it would have been impossible to operate the ships successfully as a commercial venture.

It was erroneously stated in a Washington despatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES, printed today, that Ferdinand Gutman Company, Inc., won in the Supreme Court yesterday by a vote of six to one over the Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc.
The bodies of two women and two children have been recovered from buildings in Iguala in the State of Guerrero which were badly damaged by last night's earthquake. It is believed more are dead. `
Market closed with best gains in more than a week; turnover, 472,470 shares. United States Government issues steady and mixed, other bonds generally higher and dull; transactions, $4,238,100.

Miss Honour Redifgton Dickerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Carter Dickerman of New York and Dune Dee, East Hampton, L. I., has completed plans for her marriage to James Oliver Brown of this city, son of William E. Brown of Rochester, Pa.,

The annual dinner of the Flatbush Real Estate Board will be held in the Half Moon Hotel, Coney Island, on Saturday evening. Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, and Lee Thompson Smith, head of the -Real Estate Bureau of the Board of Estimate, will be the principal speakers at the seventeenth annual dinner of the West of Central Park Association tonight in the Hotel Biltmore.

Natica, Lady Lister . aye, who passed the Winter and early Spring at the Ambassador here and in Washington, D. C., will sail today on the Normandie for her home in London. Mrs. John W. Alexander of 277 Park Avenue has gone to Ogunquit, Me., where she plans to remain until October.

Educational officials defended yesterday the activity program now under way in the New York City school system. Scoffing at the charges of "atheism" and "communism" recently made against the program, educators in the system said these attacks were "pure nonsense."
Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, was today appointed chairman of the United States delegation to the sixteenth international Red Cross conference in London from June 20 to 24.

Mrs. David Rumsey gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for Mrs. Harris. Fahnestock. Other guests were Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw, Mrs. Charles Astor Bristed, Mrs. Thomas. Jefferson Mumford, Miss Constance Curtis, Mrs. Henry Leroy Finch, Miss Virginia Murray, Mrs. Martin von Dehn,
The two-story building at 558 Broadway through to 94-96 Crosby Street has been leased by the Charles F. Noyes Company for Cross Brown, agents, to Riback Mantis and Schwartz Zuckerman.

The House Postoffice Committee reported favorably today a bill by Representative Barry which would give Queens County, N. Y., a two-cent postage rate on all first-class mail transmitted within its borders.

The Branscombe Choral, a women's group conducted by Gena Branscombe, gave its annual Spring concert last night at Town- Hall. John Gurney, bass-baritone of the Metropolitan Opera Association, assisted as soloist.

A memorial address to the late President of the Czechoslovakian Republic. Thomas G. Masaryk, one of the world's outstanding exponents of democracy, has been published by the University of California Press under the direction of Samuel T. Farquhar, university printer.

The ownership of a large part of the Salisbury Country Club property at Salisbury Plains, L. I., reverted to the certificate holders of Series B M 171,038 of the Bond and Mortgage Guaranty Company today When the trustees bid in 824 acres comprising eight parcels of land for $588,000.
Turpentine firm, 23c; sales 91 barrels; receipts 529 barrels; shipments 4,832 barrels; stock 28,062 barrels. Resin firm; sales 461:-receipts 2,067: shipments 7,218; stock 82,288.

ON Wednesday, April 20, of the current baseball season there occurred in the fair" city of Cleveland, Ohio, an incident that brought bitter criticism from many outraged onlookers. Billy Sullivan, a miscreant wearing the uniform of the St. Louis Browns, beat out a bunt.

Social, political and artistic conditions in Italy today are not conducive to the development of mural painting or the inspiration and feeling necessary to the best progress in the art, Referee Edmund McCarthy declared yesterday in a report filed in Supreme Court. Mr.

A capacity attendance filled the St. Regis Roof Garden last night at a preview opening of the rendezvous for the late Spring and Summer season. The occasion was a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Vincent Astor is acting chairman. Many dinners ane supper parties were given.

A new effort to encourage continuity in advertising and to effect economies for both advertisers and agencies has been started by fiftyfive newspapers in Illinois and Iowa, the plan to become operative June 1. An organization,

Rumors that the French Government had made inquiries in London and Washington to learn whether a further substantial reduction in the value of the franc would bring about the break-up of the tripartite agreement caused yesterday a renewed decline in French exchange. The franc fell 4 1/2 points to 3.01 7/8 cents.

While the dates have not been fixed, theboard of directors of the Newport Country Club has decided that the club will hold its annual. invitation golf tournament this Summer and a special committee has- been apnointed to handle the event.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized George D. Brooke to hold the positions of a director of the Erie Railroad Company and the Chicago Erie Railroad Company or any other offices with the railroads named.

One thing certain about the appreaching Congressional campaign is that unless there is a phenomenal business recovery during the Summer the Democrats will not use the slogan "Are you better off today than you were a year ago?"

Triple damages amounting to $21,980.069 and also costs and "reasonable attorneys' fees" are sought in the United States District Court here by Ben Williamson Jr., trustee of the Kentucky Fuel Gas Corporation, a Delaware corporation, in a declaration filed today against the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, charging monopoly in violation of the Clayton Anti-Trust Act.

Australia's hard-hitting cricketers started their tour of the United Kingdom with a victory over Worcestershire by-an innings and 77 runs in a match concluded today. The home players were no match for the Antipodeans, being dismissed for 268 and 196 after the tourists had led off with 541.
Merry Caroline, the veteran mare that races in the colors of Paul Kelley of Preston, Iowa, scored her fifth victory of the year in the best of fering at Aurora today.

Two aspects of Premier Daladier's first series of economic decrees deserve special attention because they bear so directly on our own situation. The French Government's main hope to stimulate production, apparently, is to stretch the forty-hour week to include a greater number of working hours; "but within the framework of the 1936 social legislation."

A "militant" Masonry, conscious that of its' social responsibility and always ready to extend "a helping hand," especially to the young, was urged yesterday by Jacob Charles Klinck, Grand Master of Masons in this State.

A new mortgage for $1,650,000 was given by the Thirty Broad St Corp, Hyman Schroeder, president, to the Mutual Life Insurance Co, and this has been consolidated with two prior mortgages to form one lien for $3,500,000 on the Continental Bank Trust Co Building, a 48-story structure on the south side of Exchange Place. running from New to Broad St.

The Athletics jumped into sixth place in the American League today by beating the White Sox, 7 to 2, behind the five-hit pitching of Buck Ross. A six-run outburst in the third inning that sent Sugar Cain to the showers won the game for Phila-

The strike of workers on Jamaican sugar plantations was broken today by armed policemen. Some strikers returned to work. The government said it would take steps to prevent agitators from inciting workers to riots. it ordered an inquiry into the Westmoreland riots.

Eight persons in the Arverne section of the Rockaways who have been bitten by a dog in the last few days were notified by the Health Department yesterday that they would be required to take the Pasteur treatment for rabies.

The work of the Catholic Youth Organization in providing wholesome recreational facilities for young men and women was praised last night by speakers at a dinner at the Hotel New. Yorker in honor of Edward J. Dwyer,

The executive council of the American Federation of Labor will urge the Senate (La Follette) Civil Liberties Committee to investigate charges that Los Angeles employers are trying to deprive workers there of labor rights, William Green, president of the A. F. of L., said today.

" Gentlemen Need a Shave," the Ben S. Gross-Charles Washburn farce, which had been announced to open here next Tuesday evening, has been deferred until next season. The decision was reached last night after the first tryout performance in Baltimore, where the play will close on Saturday night.

J.P. Morgan voiced approval yesterday of the loan of $1,082,000 made by his partners, Thomas Lamont and George Whitney, to enable George's brother Richard to cover up a misuse of customers' securities last November.
Two BrooklynCentral Y. M. C. A. players and two unattached entrants reached the semi-finals in the National A. A. U. senior fourwall hardball handball championship at Brooklyn Central last night.
For the first time since the war, capital punishment for spies may be resumed in 'France as a result of the rapidly growing number of spy cases. One of Premier Edouard Daladier's new decree laws,

New York University's tennis team scored its third shut-out victory of the season yesterday when it turned back Manhattan, 9 to 0, at the Fleet Hollow Club courts.' It marked the sixth straight triumph for the Violet.

Announcement was made here last night by the Methodist Board of Foreign Missions of the death on Monday in Greencastle, Ind., of Professor William Austin Shelly, retired educator and missionary who served for twenty-eight years in Chile until his retirement in 1983.

Commercial and industrial failures for the week ended April 28 increased in all five groups, compared with the corresponding week last year, according to a compilation made by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and issued yesterday.

The Yankees' first stand against the West was begun yesterday under cloudy skies in a penetrating drizzle. But as the afternoon wore on the skies cleared, the sun peeped through, the Yankees started banging the ball and, at the finish, everybody in the Stadium was happy -- everybody except Gabby Street and his St. Louis Browns.

On the thirty-sixth anniversary of its first run, June 15, the Twentieth Century Limited, newly streamlined from locomotive to observation car and containing rooms instead of open berths, will make its first run between New York City and Chicago on a schedule of 960 minutes for the 960 miles, officials of the New York Central Railroad announced here yesterday.

The University of San Marcos, the oldest in the Americas, has just founded a chair of Quechua, the language of the primeval Inca race. It is proposed to raise this old Indian dialect to the rank of a vehicle of culture.

A client of Hirsch Islon, attorneys, sold- to Charles Walzer, operator, the six-story apartment house at 726 Ocean Avenue, on the northwest corner of Beverly Road, Brooklyn, for cash above a first mortgage of $134,500.
Henry A. Eagle, pioneer wagon and carriage manufacturer of Peru, died of pneumonia, which developed after a fall a week. ago in which he fractured his leg. His age was 87.

The incidence of measles, which had been rising steadily in this city since early in January, declined for the first time during the week ended last Saturday, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, city health commissioner.

For the second time since the trial began last Wednesday, Common Pleas Judge Robert V. Kinkead refused to grant a mistrial in the case of John R. Longo, 24 years old, of 500 Montgomery Street, Jersey City,

Full compensation for American and other foreign oil wells seized in Mexico by the Cardenas government may be expected, in accordance with Mexican law, Vicente Lombardo Toledano, president of the Mexican Confederation of Labor, declared yesterday on his arrival in New York en route to Oslo,

Today's major events: -Down Town Glee Club and Golden Hill Chorus, Carnegie Hall, evening; Music School Settlement Spring concert, Town Hall, evening; "Mile. Modiste," Light Opera Guild, Venice Theatre, evening.

How red are the Reds? On the answer to this question a great deal in the future of China depends. The Communist Army-the Eighth Route Army, or the Eighth Army Corps, as it is more properly called is fighting in Shansi Province as an integral and indispensable adjunct to the forces of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.
James A. McKeown, president of the John O'Brien boiler works, was appointed today temporary receiver of the Hamilton-Brown Shoe Company by Circuit Judge William S. Connor.

The proposed sale of the United Shipyards, Inc., to the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, will be submitted to a meeting of the stockholders of the United on May 25, it was announced yesterday.
Shortly after 11:30 A. M. Saturday we swept across a corner of Manhasset Bay and watched Port Washington fade beneath us as the Imperial Airways' Cavalier took to the air.

Average daily crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,396,150 barrels, compared with 3,440,100 in the previous week, a decline of 43,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

President Roosevelt and his party aboard the cruiser Philadelphia were steaming in leisurely fashion tonight toward the northern coast of Puerto Rico, on the way to Sombrero Island, where the ship is due early tomorrow morning.

Inclusion of windbreakers, lumber jackets, work and. other short coats, blanket-lined and similar coats, and mackinaws in the requirement for wages of 37 1/2 cents an hour or $15 per forty-hour week, with 10 per cent tolerance for-learners and for -substandard workers,

Dr. Charles P. Messick of this city, chief examiner and secretary of the State Civil Service Commission, was named today by Chancellor Luther A. Campbell as a State director of the Prudential Insurance Company to succeed the late Judge Edward J. Mills of Trenton, who died in March.

Brilliant defensive play, featured by a triple play and a pair of double plays in successive innings, helped Manhattan College defeat Seton Hall today,6--2. Caruso, Sarullo and McKenna, of the Jaspers collaborated on a double play in the second.

Maxie Berger, 141, Montreal, outpointed Eddie McGeever, 141, Scranton, Pa., in the eight-round feature before 9,000 persons at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night. Berger, . the aggressor throughout, piled up a long .lead with his left.

Prize awards td three seniors at Columbia-College, to be presented on Class Day, May 31, and the electionof nineteen students to undergraduate offices for the next academic year-were announced yesterday at the college.

Last May some decisions of the Morningside prize court, especially its choice of the novel and the play, were sharply attacked. Had the judges no minds of their own? Why did they meekly follow the popular opinion? These criticisms and all others made from year to year, often reaching the point of "abusing the court," are welcome and healthful signs.

With quotations in Liverpool at the lowest levels since. Jan. 3 and a continuation of favorable weather in producing sections, prices on the Cotton Exchange here opened 10 points lower yesterday only to meet resistance and end with losses of 1 to 4 points.

Eighteenth annual conference, National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, will begin at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria at 10 A. M. and continue to May 6. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Sculpture: Distortion or Realism," Edwin L. M. Taggart; collection of Roman art (general tour), 2 P. M.

An active campaign by the Schenley Products Company to get a large share of the bonded bourbon market is expected by the liquor industry with the introduction Saturday of the company's new line of Bonded Belmont whisky,
The trustees of Series F-1 mortgage certificate issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company bid in two large Bronx apartment houses at auction yesterday for $1,000 each.

Word has been received here from London of the approaching marriage of Miss Nadia A. J. Fortingto daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Fortington of the Isle of Jethou, Channel Islinds; to Graham Charles; Master of Kinnaird, elder son of Lord and Lady Kinnaird ;of Rossie Priory, Inchture, Perthshire, Scotland.

William Frederick Thomas, 52 years old, of Queens Boulevard and Eighty-second Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, was burned to death in the. cab of his truck this afternoon when it was struck by an eastbound train of the Long Island Railroad on a grade crossing at Bayside Avenue, near Roosevelt Memorial Park here.

In testifying before a House Appropriations subcommittee yesterday David Lasser, president of the Workers Alliance of America, urged establishment of a minimum wage of $40 a month and 30 cents an hour for WPA workers as against $21 a month and 15 cents an hour, the present minimum.
Charges made against the Supreme Court of California by Thomas J. Mooney are absolutely false, that State asserted today in opposing a review of Mooney's case by the Supreme Court.

Appointment of Merchant Hall of Oneida Castle, Livingston Platt of Westchester County and William J. Kuczwalski of Manhattan as members of the committee headed by former Governor Alfred E. Smith to honor the memory of Elihu Root,

Louis Hallett, a leader of the conservative movement in the Actors Equity Association, was reprimanded yesterday by Equity's council for criticizing its actions and describing it as "Communist-controlled."

The Jamaica High. School nine, P. S. A. L. city champion, won its second Queens Section B victory yesterday when Pitcher Joe Dooley struck out nineteen batters to enable his team to defeat Far Rockaway, 11 to 3, at Jamaica Stadium.

Possibly as a counter-blast to charges of backwardness and inefficiency, the Air Ministry released tonight some details about its low-wing, single-seater Hawker Hurricane fighter, which recently flew in a night gale from Edinburgh to London,
Defying officials of their international union, members of the United Automobile Workers of America took possession of the Chevrolet parts

James Fenimore Cooper, retired Albany lawyer and banker and grandson of the author, died at his home today in his eightieth year. Funeral services will be held Thursday afternoon at Christ Church, Cooperstown. Burial will take place in the churchyard.

Marie E. Singer has sold her fifty-acre farm on Bullet Hole Road, in Paterson, Putnam County, to M. Shalet of Long Island City. The property includes a ten-room Colonial dwelling, barns, chicken houses and other outbuildings and has a long frontage on the road.

The Constitutional Convention witnessed today its first partisan flurry on the floor when Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti of New York City, a Democratic delegate at large, protested against the publicity methods of the Republican majority.
The Bomar Stable's Benjam annexed the fourteenth running of the Rennert Handicap, a dash of six furlongs for 3-year-olds that featured' today's Pimlico program.

The United States Steel Corporation will file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the near future covering a proposed issue of $100,000,000 of ten-year debentures, it was announced yesterday by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the board.

Twenty or more leading publishers have acted or will act shortly on the elimination of loopholes in the "book club" clause in their fair trade contracts to be issued for the Fall season about July 1, it was reported in the trade here yesterday.
Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn awarded yesterday $24,000 for land taken for the city's development of a public beach system along the Brooklyn and Queens ocean fronts.

About a year after its erection the six-story apartment house for forty-two families at 2,229 Valentine Avenue, the Bronx, has been bought by the Dorn Realty Corporation for cash over a first mortgage of $118,000. Max Weinstein was the broker and Samuel K. Beier, attorney, represented the seller.

Two women and' fourteen men who were recently indicted with seventy-two others as members of an international ring that smuggled narcotics into the United States on ocean liners pleaded guilty yesterday in advance of a trial scheduled to begin May 9.

Four thousand dollars has been allowed to Mrs. Rebecca Palumbo by Surrogate George A. Wingate of Brooklyn for the loss of her son, Robert, in the fire that took eight lives in Lum's Chinese restaurant, Fifty - ninth Street and Lexington Avenue, on Feb. 12, 1936, it was announced yesterday.

From 3,000 newspaper men of all countires who applied for permission to report Chancellor Adolf Hitler's visit to Rome, Premier Benito Mussolini singled out Jules Sauerwein, foreign editor of the Paris Soir and for years a contributor to THE NEW YORK TIMES, as undesirable. undesirable.

At least 750,000 persons on both sides of the lines in Spain are in serious need of help, William Allen White, Emporia (Kan.) editor, said yesterday at a tea in his honor at the home of Paul D. Cravath, 36 East Seventy-second Street. Mr.
The Old-Timers of the Ninetysecond Street Young Men's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street, will hold their annual dinner tonight at the association headquarters.

Stuyvesant High School, 1938 team champion, qualified three of its four contestants for the final of the annual P. S. A. L. individual 'fencing championship as the semi final round was completed on the strips of the Washington Irving High School last night.

The Senate passed the $1,156,000,000 Naval Expansion Bill and the $21,658,578 Legislative Appropriation Bill, received the Truman bill to authorize the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to make employment and equipment loans to railroads and recessed at 6:03 P. M. until noon tomorrow.

At the outbreak of a war involving the United States 10,000 of the nation's industrial plants immediately would be converted for production of war supplies, Louis Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, told members of the National Machine Tool Builders Association at their convention today.

A serious rift in the engineering department of the National Maritime Union which led to the appointment of a committee to investigate charges of mishandling of funds developed yesterday on the first anniversary of the formation of the union.

A campaign to persuade consumers in the Bronx to complete their shopping Saturday nights and permit.retail grocers and fruitmen of the borough to keep their establishments closed on Sundays will be discussed tonight at a meeting of a committee of twenty-five. retailers in the headquarters of the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, Inc.

After several contentious weeks over the selection of her next vehicle, RKO and Katharine Hepburn today agreed to the dissolution of the star's contract. The settlement was described as amicable and it is understood that no money was paid Miss Hepburn for the cancellation.

BARNARD, GEORGE GREY (April 24). Estate, more than $20,000. To executors for the erection of "Rain-Bow-Arch," to be dedicated to the Gold Star Mothers of America. Monroe Barnard, son, 700 Fort Washington Ave.; Stephen C. Clark, 46 E. 70th St., and Frank Aydelotte, Swarthmore. Pa.. executors.

Great Britain could clear the way for the work of the international body summoned by President Roosevelt on the refugee problem by lifting the restriction on Jewish immigration into Palestine, Senator Robert J. Bulkley of Ohio declared last night.

A summary of numerous transactions by officers, directors and principal stockholders in equity securities in March as well as some delayed reports for earlier months was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Paddy's Market, like so many other simple, pleasant institutions, has been adjudged in the path of progress Progress in this case is the Lincoln Tunnel,

Amid memories of the two great dictatorships of the past, in the Rome of the Caesars and of the medieval Popes, the two outstanding dictators of our own time met tonight to demonstrate their unity of purpose in building for their people new empires, each according to his lights. It is a reunion that the whole world is keenly observing and it has been made a spectacle to remember.

Anthony Carcich has purchased for investment through J. I. Kislak, Inc., brokers, the three-story apartment building at 558 Twelfth Street, West New York, N. J., from the Hudson Trust Company. The house contains six apartments of four and five rooms.

Mme. Gisa Bergmann, Viennese soprano and former member of the Theatre An Der Wien, will give her American debut recital this evening in the Embassy Room of the Ambassador Hotel. She will be accompanies at the piano by Fritz Kitzinger.

Passengers sailing for Europe today on the French liner Normandie include Baron Silvercruys, Belgian Minister to Canada; Count de Montale, Consul General for Albania in New York; with Countess Montale; Dr. Alexander Silverman and Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse.

A nation council of independent unions will be formed as a result of meetings held here in the last few days, according to Frank Bow, counsel for the Central Council of the Republic Steel Corporation, who was temporary chairman.
Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, although continuing exceedingly dull, managed to lift itself out of the stalemate of the preceding day.

The South Georgia Railway- Company today applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $154,000 of first mortgage, twenty-year, 6 per cent bonds to be exchanged for $154,000 of preferred stock or sold-at not less than par, the proceeds to be used for retirement of the preferred stock.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Cheney Farley of 238 East Forty-ninth Street and Manchester, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Cheney Farley, to Henry Robinson Palmer Jr. of Stonington, Conn.

Charles D. Orth of this city has announced the engagement of his stepdaughter, Mrs. Kathryn Knight Dunscombe, to Carl F. Boker Jr., also of New York. Mrs. Dunscombe is the daughter of the late Mrs. Orth and the late William Knight, and is a sister of William Knight Jr.
Manufacturers and their agents bearing huge bouquets visited Arnold Constable Co. yesterday afternoon as soon as they learned that a woman was acting president.

Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn rendered a decision yesterday in favor of Mrs. Edith Liggett of 708 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, in her $25,000 libel suit against The Daily Worker, Communist party daily newspaper published at 50 East Thirteenth Street, Manhattan; Clarence Hathaway,
George Sellew captured the low gross prize at Plandome today in the first of a series of four golf tournaments to be staged by the Advertising Club of New York.

L. B. Dailey and F. H. Merrill of the Princeton Club and 0. C. Stanton and L. W. Francis of Heights Casino scored second-round victories in the Mixsell Cup doubles squash tennis tournament at Heights Casino in Brooklyn yesterday.

The membership forum of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, afternoon and evening sessions of which were held last Monday, will be resumed next Monday evening at the Hotel New Yorker.

Senators voted themselves 20 cents a mile today for traveling expenses to and from their homes for the current session. Senator Borah proposed that this time-honored allotment, totaling about, $222,000, be forgotten since a travel allowance was voted for the special session.

The increased death toll from 'motor accidents was termed "one of the appalling problems of our time" by President Roosevelt in a message read for him tonight at the convention dinner of the American Red Cross.

Making her first start of. the 1938 season,"Tom Heard Jr.'s Be Blue galloped howe an easy, winner by two lengths and a half in the Danvers Purse,. today's six-furlong feature at Suffolk Downs. before a crowd' of 12,000.

Under a new plan about to go into effect in Brooklyn's forty-nine public and private hospitals, every expectant mother in the borough may receive full medical attention whether she can pay for it or not.

Eari Sande played his other ace today as The Chief took the measure of seven other Kentucky Derby eligibles, including his famous stablemate, Stagehand, with a track record-equaling performance in the Derby Trial Stakes at Churchill Downs.

Wheat futures dipped in the early trading to new low levels for the season on the July and September deliveries but there was no material pressure after the first half hour and toward the last covering by shorts developed and disclosed a lack of offerings.

After hearing the report of Major Gen. John J. Phelan, who attended the recent world boxing conference in Rome, theNew York State Athlet-. ?? Commission went on record yesterdayas opposing many of the regulations proposed there.

Dizzy Dean won his third game of the season against no defeats as the Cubs-defeated Philadelphia, 5 to 2, today, but the pitcher whose high-priced right arm has all baseball talkingand guessing-was in the showers at the finish.

Robert R. Young of New York, who is engaged in a dispute with the Guaranty Trust Company of New York over control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, was elected today a director of the Pere Marquette Railroad.
Mechanized Spanish Insurgent units slashed deep into government territory east of Teruel today, capturing three towns and advancing to within striking distance of the Sagunto highway.
The Treasury Procurement Division today announced the awards of contracts for a total of 128,900 yards of textiles for shipment by May 20 from bids opened on April 28, as follows:

Another type of voluntary chain group in the men's clothing field, the second to be publicized in a month, was announced yesterday when the Trimount Clothing Company, Boston, made known a plan of cooperation with retailers under the name of the Clipper Craft Plan.

Edward V. McGovern, a contractor, was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer to pay the city $66,533 for delay in completing plumbing work at the Rikers Island penitentiary for which he received a contract.

Experiments on three families of white rabbits at the Henry Phipps Insti- from tute, Philadelphia, have helped produce some conclusions that tend to substantiate studies of tuberculosis in human beings and may open an entirely new approach in prevention and treatment, according to Dr. Max B. Lurie of the institute.

Value of Canada's imports in the 1937-38 fiscal year ended on March 31 reached the highest level since the 1930-31 fiscal year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. The total was $799,069,918, compared with $671,875,566 in 1936-37 and $906,612,695 in 1930-31.

Miss Rosamond Harris Seidel will be the only American woman not connected with official life to be presented by Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy, wife of the Ambassador to London, at the first royal court on May 11.

Net profit of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation for the twelve months ended on March 31 amounted to $4,907,289, after interest, depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes, subsidiary preferred dividends, minority interest and other charges, according to a report issued yesterday.

While other passengers watched in horror an Atlantic City chiropodist slashed his throat with a razor twice on a shore-bound bus which left from the city today, according to police. At West Jersey Hospital here physicians said they feared the man, Harry E. Swetzel, 45 years old, would not recover.

To protect children in time of war the League of Nations Advisory Committee on Social Questions proposed today the "creation in every belligerent country of neutral zones in which children might be brought together,
The Rochester Red Wings slugged three Newark pitchers for a total of fourteen hits, including three home runs, and whipped the Bears, 10 to 6, to salvage the fourth game of their series today.

Nelson Ave (11-2876), w s, 125 ft n of Brandt PI, 50x100; Mae Wohlgemuth to 1,695 Nelson Ave Corp, 230 Grand Ave, Secor Ave (17-4943), w s, 150 ft s of Conner St, 30x95; Eastchester Savings Bank to Joseph Lammanna, 2,469 Crotona Ave.

The Senate passed the Administration's $1,156,000,000 Naval Expansion Bill this afternoon by a vote of 56 to 28. The majority favoring the bill was made up of forty-nine Democrats and seven Republicans, while the opposition was comprised of seventeen Democrats, seven Republicans, two Farmer-Laborites, one Independent and one Progressive.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals threw out yesterday the reorganization plan of the Ritz Carlton Restaurant and Hotel Company of Atlantic City on the ground that it was not fair to first-mortgage bondholders.
Two home run balls cost Lou Fette a pitcher's duel with Bill McGee today as the Cardinals defeated-the Bees 3 to 2. Herb Bremer cloued the first homer in the second and the Cardinals led, 2 to .0.

Officials representing twenty- three Nassau County villages gave their unanimous approval this afternoon to a resolution condemning the solicitation of funds by any police organization offering subscribers courtesy cards "or any other token of good-will."

The Most Rev. Bartholomew Joseph Eustace, Bishop of the newly created Catholic Diocese of Camden, was greeted by a crowd estimated by police at 25,000 when he arrived late today for his installation services, scheduled for 10:30 tomorrow morning.

Webster J.- Oliver of New York was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be assistant attorney general in charge of customs at New York. He is to fill the vacancy caused by the appointment of Joseph R. Jackson to the Court of Customs and- Patent Appeals.

Retired Lieutenant James W. Trihy, formerly a member of H. L. Co. 134, residing at 7,006 Ridge Crest Terrace, Brooklyn, died May 2. Funeral will take place from his late residence at 9:30 A. M., Thursday, May 5. Interment at St. John's Cemetery. The'Deputy Chief of the 10th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

The financial reports of the country's railroads for the first three months of the present year do not make pleasant reading. The net railway operating income of the Class I railroads has dropped from $148,000,000 in January, February and March a year ago to $19,000,000 this year.

Less than a day after the start of its $10,000,000 drive for private health and welfare agencies, the Greater New York Fund listed yesterday a group of large contributions totaling $870,000. The announcement was made through Winthrop Rockefeller,

The net income of the Kennecott Copper Corporation in the first quarter this year was about 32 cents a share on the capital common stock, Stephen Birch, chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday. He said the company was earning its dividend, having paid 25 cents a share in the first quarter.

Three thugs who shot it out with the police during a hold-up in a wholesale tobacco store in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn at 5 P. M. yesterday. fought a losing battle. Two were killed and one was wounded seriously.

George Grey Barnard, sculptor, who died on April 24, left his estate to his executors to complete his "Rainbow Arch," on which- he labored nearly twenty years and which he considered to be his greatest work. The monument is to be dedicated to the Gold Star Mothers of America.

Large, wide-brimmed hats will take the fashion lead this Summer, with interest about evenly divided between the flat sailor of the Spring season and a new type of "manipulated" high crown hat, it was indicated by styles shown last night at the Summer Millinery Fashion Show sponsored by the Millinery Stabilization Commission at the Hotel Astor, as a preliminary to National Summer Millinery Week, May 16 to 23.

A measure placing the control of production and sale of goats' milk under jurisdiction of the State Department of Health "butted" its way to passage by a bare majority, in the New Jersey Assembly today after a good deal of "kidding."
Dean William R Inge, the one time "gloomy dean" of St. Paul's, had characteristically gloomy things to say about democracy today.

Harry A. Laird, traffic manager of The Chicago Tribune and widely known as an authority in the field of transportation, died today at his home in Evanston. Mr. Laird, who was 54 years old, had been ill for six weeks with coronary thrombosis.

Lt. Col. Brenon B. Somervell, Corps of Engineers, having been detailed for duty with the Organized Reserves,. Second Corps Area, in addition to his other duties at New York, N. Y., by paragraph 2, Special Orders 14, W. D., Jan. 18, 1938, is assigned to duty as Assistant to the Executive Officer, Second Military Area, New York. N. Y.

Dr. William Lathrop Love of 857 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, former State Senator from the Eighth District of Kings County, was named in an indictment handed down yesterday by the Federal grand jury to Judge Clarence G. Galston in the United States District Court in Brooklyn.

A correspondent of THE TIMES who made his way through the shuttling armies gave us yesterday a vivid glimpse behind the lines in Southern Shantung, where the Chinese seem to have taken the offensive in a battle that may develop into one of the major engagements in the Far Eastern war.
Scotiand's fervent loyalty to King George and his Scottish Queen was demonstrated anew today at the colorful opening of the great ??10,000,000 empire exhibition.

The House of Commons tonight approved Sir John Simon's proposal that the tax on tea be increased from 8 to 16 cents a pound. The measure was passed by a vote of 227 to 129 after an attempt by .the Laborites to strike out the increase. Sir John, defending the tax,

Y., by paragraph 2, Special Orders 14, W. D., Jan. 18, 1938, is assigned to duty as Assistant to the Executive Officer, Second Military Area, New York. N. Y.

Dr. William Lathrop Love of 857 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, former State Senator from the Eighth District of Kings County, was named in an indictment handed down yesterday by the Federal grand jury to Judge Clarence G. Galston in the United States District Court in Brooklyn.

The semi-official Prager Presse says that although no sensationalresults are expected from tomorrow's conference of the Little Entente - Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Yugoslavia-in Sinaia, Rumania, important questions will be discussed, the principal one being the situation resulting from the union of Germany and Austria.

Governor Blanton Winship of Puerto Rico arrived here from Washington yesterday with word that Federal funds soon may be granted to finance slum clearance in San Juan.. - Governor Winship said he had discussed plans in Washington with Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority.
Japan estimates 'that Soviet planes supplied to China number 500 and that 200 Russian pilots and mechanics are serving the Chinese forces.

Mr. and Mrs. Reginald L. Whitman of this city and Glen Head, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Whitman, to Clarence Whitman 2d, son of Mrs. C. Morton Whitman of 1,088 Park Avenue and Katonah, N. Y., and of the late Mr. Whitman.

A ration -wide banking group headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Lehman Brothers and including Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; the First Boston Corporation; Kidder, Peabody Co. and Smith, Barney Co., will offer today to the public a new issue of 150,000 shares of $4.50 cumulative preferred stock of the General Foods Corporation. The stock will be priced at $101 a share.
A radio dispatch from the liner Hikawa Maru in the Pacific today reported Jigoro Kano, Japan's member of the International Olympic Committee, had died of pneumonia. His age was 78.

More officers and men arrived here and at near-by Roosevelt Field today to take part in the air. defense manoeuvres to be held along the store Eastern seaboard from May 12 until May 17 by the United StatesArmy Air Corps.

After a conference with representatives of the over-the-counter industries, the Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended until July 1 that portion of a rule adopted last Friday which made applicable to over-the-counter transactions,

For several years business men have been urging upon the Government the wisdom of a "breathing spell" in-the enactment of new legislation. On one Occasion, in the Summer of 1935, the President not only agreed with them that it would be desirable to give the country time to catch its breath-"the
St. Louis at, New York-Hilldebrand vs. Beggs. Cleveland at Washington-Feller vs. Leonard. Detroit at Boston-Poffenberger vs. Wilson. Chicago at. Philadelphia-Dietrich vs. Caster.

After having deftly polished off the best the East had to offer, the-Giants made an excellent clearance of the Alleghenies today, effected a neat three-point landing and immediately set ogt for fresh worlds to conquer-

After a delegation from "Paddy's Market," on-Ninth Avenue between Thirty-seventh and Forty-second Streets, had visited City Hall yesterday and failed to get another extension of the ouster order by William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, two peddlers appeared at the corner of Ninth Avenue and Fortieth Street with their pusheart.

Mrs. Charles Gilmore Kerley of 10 East Eighty-first Street was elected president yesterday for a term of three years of the Woman's Auxiliary, New York Diocese, of the National Council of the Protestant Episccopal Church.

The New York Central Railroad held $7,891,250 (par value) of Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad capital stock at the end of 1937, a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday.

The Bankers Trust Company, as trustee for Power Securities Corporation collateral trust 6 per cent bonds, announced yesterday that it will redeem on June 1 at 101 and accrued interest $24,300 of these bonds.

Amendment of the State Constitution to give the Legislature power to provide financial aid to parochial schools was sought in a proposal submitted to the constitutional convention today by James J. Heffernan, Brooklyn Democrat.

National Summer Millinery Week, to be held from May 16 to 23, will be a big selling force provided both reail an manufacturer branches give it unqualified support, speakers said yesterday at the luncheon meeting of millinery buyers and merchandising executives, sponsored by the trade promotion committee of the Millinery Stabilization Commission at the Hotel Astor.

A Congressional investigation of the effects of the National Labor Relations Act, with a view to removing "a formidable barrier to enduring business recovery," was demanded in a resolution tentatively adopted by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States at its annual convention here today.

The city will start today to advertise the public sale of tax liens totaling $5,310,000 that it holds against the street-car companies owned or controlled- by the Brooklyn and Queens Transit Corporation, a B. M. T. subsidiary, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

The nation's twelfth G-man to be killed in line of duty, William R. Ramsey Jr., 34, a special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, died this morning from four gunshot wounds suffered in a battle yesterday with a former convict near Armstrong, Ill.

Dr. David B. Pindar of 1,100 Bloomfield Street, Hoboken, N. J., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Rosalie Agnes Pindar, to Francis William Magovern, son of Mr. and Mrs. William I. Magovern of South Orange, N. J.
The Reichsbank's statement as of May 2 shows the - following changes from the preceding week in thousands of marks:

The report of the American Water Works and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the first three months of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $440,567 after all operating expenses, taxes and charges.
The suicide rate is 53 per cent higher among American coal miners than the average for American workers, A. D. Lewis, brother of the C. I. O. lead-
Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Elite Guard, in its organ, the Schwarze Korps, today warns Jews that it is time for the last of them to flee Germany.

Parallel bills authorizing the relaxation of requirements for loans by the RFC to railroads as a step to stimulate employment were introduced in the Senate and House today by Senator Truman and Representative Steagall, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee.

Mrs. Anna S. Wambaugh, wife of Dr. Eugene Wambaugh, professor emeritus of the Harvard Law School and mother of Miss Sarah Wambaugh, expert on plebiscites, died yesterday after a long illness. She would have been 80 on June 19.

The Better Business Bureau of New York will undertake a community-wide campaign in the Fall to extend its services to business and the public, it was announced yesterday at the sixteenth annual meeting of the bureau, held at its headquarters here yesterday.

David H. Coolidge, well known as a landscape architect, died early today in a hospital here in his seventy-fifth year. Born in Boston, Mr. Coolidge was graduated from Harvard University. Many fine estates in New England and the vicinity of New York City were designed by him.

DELIVERED of their annual duty, the. Pulitzer judges are now in retreat. When the committee on novels emerges again, the first thing it ought to do is to look at Rose Wilder Lane's "Free Land,"* published today.

The Sales Executives Club of New York held a Spring sports luncheon yesterday. at the Roosevelt Hotel, with Christy Walsh, chairman of the sports committee of the World's Fair, presiding, and prominent figures of sport making short talks to the gathering of more than 600.
Britain already is laying plans for future pump-priming, Sir Kingsley Wood, Minister of Health, revealed yesterday when speaking at a luncheon celebrating the Manchester centenary.

According to information in banking circles, the first big public loan of Great Germany, for which subscriptions Close tomorrow, is already well over-subscribed and the total issue will be raised from 1,000,000,000 to 1,250,000,000 marks. Official announcement of this increase is expected tomorrow or Thursday.

The National Socialist Governor of Wuerttemberg Wilhelm Murr, has publicly demanded the resignation of Bishop Johann Baptist Sproll of Rottenburg, head of the Catholic Church in Wuerttemberg, because he failed to vote in the Anschluss plebiscite and Reichstag elections. The demand appears in the local party organ, National Socialist Kurier.

The purchase of a site for a large apartment house in Forest Hills, Queens, was announced yesterday. K. V. B. Building Corporation, of which Morris Brecher holds a controlling interest, has acquired a plot fronting 105 feet on Queens Boulevard, with a depth of 137 feet on Seventy-second Avenue, being the southwest corner, and containing a total area of 16,000 square feet.
Roy Joiner, veteran southpaw making his first start of the season, hurled the Jersey City Giants to a 5-to-1 victory over the Montreal Royals, in the final game of a fourgame series today.

The gleeful shouts of a multitude of youthful yachtsmen displaced the comparatively dull routine of the classroom at Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon as Regatta Day again arrived.

Several hours after they were thrown to the street when two Fire Department vehicles collided in the Bronx early yesterday morning, Fire Captain Joseph A. Tracy and Fireman James M. Hughes died in Fordham Hospital.

A definite formula for the handling of unjustified returns in the popular-price dress industry is expected to be worked out shortly, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of representatives of the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Associa-

Although public opinion had been hoping for National Unity on a broad' basis following the speech last week by Finance Minister Eugen Kwiatkowski, in which he invited the Opposition to cooperate with the government and to which Ignace Jan Paderewski responded from his voluntary exile, these hopes were shattered today by M. Kwiatkowski himself.

Some manufacturers of quality shoes will make reductions averaging about 5 per cent in their Fall prices, it was reported at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday, where the Fall showing of the Shoe Fashion Guild is in progress. Retailers,

The Better Business Bureau of New York will undertake a community-wide campaign in the Fall to extend its services to business and the public, it was announced yesterday at the sixteenth annual meeting of the bureau, held at its headquarters here yesterday.

Official announcement of this increase is expected tomorrow or Thursday.

The National Socialist Governor of Wuerttemberg Wilhelm Murr, has publicly demanded the resignation of Bishop Johann Baptist Sproll of Rottenburg, head of the Catholic Church in Wuerttemberg, because he failed to vote in the Anschluss plebiscite and Reichstag elections. The demand appears in the local party organ, National Socialist Kurier.
Stewart MacDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, announced today that mortgages accepted for insurance on small homes by the FHA during April numbered 14,400 with a value of $63,250,000.

Unbeaten in competition since 1932, the New York A. C. team retained the national A. A. U. water polo soft-ball championship last night by defeating the Queens Central Y. M. C. A. of Jamaica, 12 to 11, at the Winged Foot pool.

No reversal of the downward trend in pig iron or steel ingot production is yet in sight, The Iron Age says this week, finding that "orders and inquiries for various steel products are either barely-holding at recent level or are declining."

Tommy Farr, holder of the British Empire heavyweight championship, left these shores for his home in Wales yesterday on the Normandie of the French Line. Accompanying him were Joe Gould, who will act as his manager, and Abe Feldman, who will serve as a sparring partner.

Continuance of the Tripartite Monetary Agreement on the same basis as heretofore was announced jointly late this afternoon by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. and Count Rene Doynel de Saint-Quentin, the French Ambassador.

Carl von Ossietzky, pacifist writer, who was imprisoned by both the republican and National Socialist regimes and who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1935, died in a hospital here this afternoon at the age of 48.

A third marriage service for the Grand Duchess Kira of the House of Romanoff and Prince Louis Ferdinand of the House of Hohenzollern was performed today at the home of the bridegroom's grandfather, former Kaiser Wilhelm of Germany.
Mr. and Mrs. John W. Delafield will give a dinner tonight in the St. Regis Roof for Miss Phyllis I. R. Gillespie and Alan T. Schumacher, who will be married this Summer in Newport.
President Roosevelt's Caribbean vacation cruise may go down in history as a contribution to the science of navigation, if observations already made are borne out by subsequent investigations.

House supporters of the Wages and Hours Bill said tonight that they were assured of 198. signatures to a discharge petition as soon as itwas placed on the Speaker's desk for signature, and expected more.
Mrs. Clothilde Douai Egbert, chairman of the Music Department of Hunter College High School, New York, died at her home here last night at the age of 65.

Marietta College will not meet Rutgers and Manhattan in the regatta to be held on the Harlem Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Herbert M. Kopf, director of athletics at Manhattan. The Ohioans were forced to withdraw from the Dad Vail Trophy competition because of a curtailed Spring practice program, J. Ellis McDonald, Marietta coach, informed the Jasper authorities.
The British Embassy said today F. L. O'Hara, 38 years old, manager of the British Royal Insurance Company, had been arrested secretly yesterday at Yokohama on a charge of espionage.

Most sections of the stock market here were firm today, although the volume of business continue small. Gilt-edged issues- showed strength. Among the foreign bonds Australian issues were steady on the announcement of a new ??7,000,000 loan and Chinese issues made further gains.

A. O. Fulton of the Wheelock-Lovejoy Company, Cambridge, Mass., was yesterday elected president of the American Steel Warehouse Association at the organization's annual meeting held at the Waldorf-Astoria.

A chorus of more than 400 and a sixty-piece orchestra performed Bach's "St. Matthew Passion" yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The performance, given by the Oratorio Society of New York under the direction of Albert Stoessel, was a dress rehearsal for the formal three-hour presentation tonight.
A run--off in Alabama's Governor--ship race appeared certain tonight as chances faded for a clear majority for the leading candidate in the Democratic primary yesterday.

Senator Harrison, chairman of the Finance Committee, announced, today that the new draft of the Tax Bill could not be completed before Monday. Under the rules the Senate must act first on the conference. report, and the House afterward.
An open attack on the New Deal, as represented by the slum-clearance program presented to the Constitutional Convention by Senator Wagner, came today from the Republican side.

A divorce suit brought by Phyllis Fellowes Waid, member of an English family, against her 75-year-old husband, Dan Everett Waid, architect of Greenwich and New York, was withdrawn from Superior Court today.

Reporters assigned to City Hall sent Mayor La Guardia a written question 'yesterday, asking why the city had waited until today to advertise for sale its tax lien of $5,310,000 against the street car companies of the B. M. T. system. The answer came back on a sheet of yellow paper.

Approximately 2,000 persons, including hundreds of standees, filled Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon for the funeral services of Lawrence Marx, president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies.

Methods to achieve greater efficiency in advertising campaigns and to reduce coats were discussed by 100 members of the Association of National Advertisers, holding their Spring meeting today behind closed doors at the Westchester Country Club. Paul B. West, president of the association, reported that members. would consider different ways to spend their advertising money so that the best results could be achieved.
The Senate voted today to speed up payment of subsidies on the 1937 cotton crop and to increase by 2 per cent the quotas for several types of tobacco under the Crop Control Act.
Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Late Gothic Period: Minor Arts," Harry D. M. Grier, 11 A. M.. Collection of paintings (general tour), 2 P.M.

Daniel Carter Beard, a founder of the Boy Scouts of America, received the grand master's medal awarded annually by the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York at yesterday's business session of the 157th annual meeting, held in the lodge rooms at 71 West Twenty-third Street.

Tailer Robinson, a New York Stock Exchange firm, will be dissolved on May 7. On May 9 William C. Cooke and Phillipse E. Greene will form the Stock Exchange firm of Cooke Co., with offices at Delafield Delafield.

Initial steps in developing a procedure to prevent misrepresentation in violation of the recently enacted Wheeler-Lea law were taken yesterday at the first meeting of a committee of twelve retail representatives and toilet goods producers, held in the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Organizing to carry on in New York City the "Women's Rebellion" against government spending started by two housewives in Suffern, N. Y., last week, a committee of volunteers opened offices at 542 Fifth Avenue yesterday and began the distribution of 50,000 circulars urging Representatives to "stop the spending spree."

During a hearing today before Charles Moore, examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, on an application by the Lima Cord Sole and Heel Corporation for permission to delist 112,600 shares of common stock from the Cleveland Stock Exchange,

The appointment of Dr. Albert B. Newman as professor and head of the Department of Chemical. engineering of the School of Technology at City College was announced yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president.

In sharp contrast to the high cost' of food a year ago, the feeding of a family now can be done at the lowest prices in almost four years. A survey of wholesale and retail markets disclosed today puts wholesale prices of important foodstuffs
Hicks St, 308; alteration in 10-family brick house; Giuseppa Passalaqua. premises, owner; O. Silverstone, architect; cost, $10,000. Plymouth St. 202-14; alteration in 1-story

Plans for the marriage of Julian D. Steele, Negro social worker, and a Boston University graduate, age 27, and recently a teacher in a private school in Providence, were revealed today when Steele's resignation from Robert Gould Shaw House in Roxbury, was made public.

Using more than 100,000 miles of. wire to reach more than 10,000 employes of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, Raymond C. Kramer, one of three trustees in charge of the reorganization of that company, telegraphed yesterday a message of optimism regarding the future.

The Spence Alumnae Society presented its annual silver spoon dinner dance last night in the St. Regis Roof to aid the maintenance of the Spence Adoption Nursery. Since its foundation in 1911, the beneficiary has been the established philanthropy of the Spence School graduates. Many formed dinner parties for the event.

An exhibition of the works of John Vanderlyn, an early American artist and former resident of Kingston, will be opened Friday at the old Senate House at Kingston, it was announced by the State Conservation Department today.

The. first of two symposiums by members of the American Artists Congress will be held tomorrow afternoon at 2:15 o'clock in conjunction with their second annual exhibition, which opens today in the art galleries of John Wanamaker.
Wheat futures closed unchanged to 1/4 cent a bushel higher today on the Bdard of Trade here after holding within a range of about 1 cent a bushel most of the session.

The sixth circuit Court of Appeals was asked today by the Ford Motor Company to set aside an order of the National Labor Relations Board against the company. Ford lawyers declared the order Was based on proceedings which "ignored the basic rules of justice."

Earl Baldwin was selected president of the Marylebone Cricket Club at its annual meeting today. The former Prime Minister succeeds J. J. Astor. Formed in 1787, the famous club has become the parliament of cricket and is recognized as the governing body of the sport throughout the world.

On the eve of the League of Nations meeting, Foreign Minister Julio Alvarez del Vayo, who will be the principal Spanish spokesman, announced today the government's determination to carry on its batties, on the international diplomatic front as well as on the home military fronts to an ultimate victory.

Several recommendations by social welfare groups calling upon the Constitutional Convention to write into the new State Constitution a general statement of principles which would make it the duty of the State to provide for the "physical, mental and moral" welfare of its residents were under consideration today by the Social Welfare Committee of the convention.
Harry Townsend Rounds of this place, textile designer and former president of the Fabrics Finishing Corporation of New York, died yesterday in the Lawrence Hospital here at the age of 64.

Thomas Hackett, 56-year-old patrolman who had been on the police force for twenty-five years, was killed yesterday when his foot became entangled in the rear bumper of an automobile as it careened for forty feet after being in collision with a truck. Hackett was dead when aid reached him.

Vegetable corsages will be worn at the market party which will be given tomorrow night between midnight and dawn on the Pennsylvania Produce Terminal Pier, West and Hubert Streets, for the benefit of the Bide-a-Wee Home for Animals.

Cessation of hostilities between the government and business, notably the utilities, divorcement of politics from banking and vice versa, and return to the gold standard were among the outstanding proposals advanced by speakers at the eighteenth annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Senator Burton K; Wheeler of Montana, running mate of the late Robert M. La Follette on the Progressive party's Presidential ticket, in 1924, summed up today the outlook for Governor Philip La Follette's new progressive movement.

The Peninsular Copper Company of Grand Rapids, Mich., organized by bondholders of the Seneca Copper Corporation, was the successful bidder today in a special master-in-chancery sale of assets of the Seneca company.

The executive committee of the American Jewish Committee will meet next Wednesday afternoon at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street. One of the subjects of consideration will be the plebiscite announced Monday by the American Jewish Congress, with which the committee has differed on questions of policy for many years. An adverse vote is expected.

Nat Litfin, clever featherweight from the Bronx, scored an upset victory over Sixto Escobar, bantamweight champion of the world, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the - New York Hippodrome last night.

Ontario and Quebec newsprint manufacturers will confer here soon to discuss prices. The $50 per ton price, despite the strong support of Premiers Hepburn and Duplessis, has not been maintained, one large mill having already broken away.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's foreign policy will be once more submitted to a portion of the British electorate tomorrow, when the constituency of Lichfield will elect a new member of Parliament to replace the late J. A. Lovat Fraser, Government member.

A copy of the first essue of the first edition of Mark Twain's "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" went to the Chaucer Head Book Shop for $1,050 last night at the ParkeBernet Galleries at an auction of the library of the late Gilbert W. Keech and other properties.

Murray Levine of New Rochelle, father of the missing 12-year-old Peter Levine, saved a youth in General Sessions yesterday from a long State prison term when he urged clemency for the prisoner, who had attempted to extort $30,000 from him under the pretext that the boy would be returned.

The twenty-family apartment house at 1,046 DeKalb Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to an investing client of the Mastrow Realty Company for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $30,000.
