Registering its fourth straight victory, Yale defeated the North Carolina tennis team, 7-2, today. It was Yale's first triumph over the Chapel Hill array since 1935 and was accomplished with the loss of but two singles matches.

Eleven 3-year-olds, forming the smallest but the best balanced field in many years, are expected to fight it out in the sixty-fourth running of the $50,000 added Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs on Saturday.

Oil acquired by the Mexican Government through the seizure of foreign-owned wells in that country is being routed through New York to Germany and other European nations, according to statements made yesterday at the monthly roundtable conference of export credit men held at the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

It was fifty years this week since the settlement house. which bears the name of Jacob Riis was founded. The anniversary celebration on Tuesday evening seemed to show that his warm heart had never stopped beating, though it is long since he wrote his last newspaper story and delivered his last speech.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, are endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers- and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

The National Labor Standards Committee, with offices at 156 Fifth Avenue, yesterday addressed an open letter to Congress pleading for the adoption of the minimum wage and maximum hours bill as essential to recovery and the maintenance of conditions necessary to the promotion of the national welfare.

Stocks gained in final hour and closed higher; gold shares leaders on news of devaluation of French franc; turnover, 550,600 shares. All groups of bonds generally higher in quiet trading; transactions, $4,921,025.

" Mystics" who have made winedrinking "a mysterious process to be enjoyed only by a select few" were criticized last night by Alfonse Wile of the Schenley Import Corporation, an authority on wines, in a talk inaugurating the Wine and Spirits Academy at the Wine and Liquor Club, 1,560 Broadway. Mr.

Mrs. Emil Denemark's War Minstrel, shortestpriced favorite of the current meeting at even money, finished fourth behind Hall and Warrender's Natty Boy, Miss Doris Letendre's Mansco and Mrs. F. C. Dunn's Wise Player today in the Suffolk Downs feature event.

Ogden Phipps's Teufel, who is destined to become a steeplechaser, temporarily delayed his transfer to the cross-country sport yesterday when he scored an easy victory in the Sunnyside Purse at a mile and a sixteenth at Jamaica. It was his second triumph of the season in the colors of his new owner.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders, dated May 2: REAR ADMIRAL Dennis, J. B., Med. Corps., detached as President Naval Retiring Board, Board of Medical Examiners, Naval Examining Board for Officers of Medical Corps. Washington, D. C., June 15, and ordered home, relieved all active duty.

Captain David R. Brandon, commander of Company L (formerly the Eleventh Company) of the Seventh Regiment, New York National Guard, received a gold medal last night in commemoration of twenty-five years of active service with the company.

Miss Sallie Loraine Mellon and Darragh Anderson Park Jr. were married yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas Church. Palms and dogwood provided a setting for the ceremony, which was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks.

The Commonwealth Edison Company is expected to file next week a registration statement for $33,000,000 of firstmortgage bonds, the proceeds of which will be used to retire $30,000,000 of 5 per cent bonds which will mature in 1953 and 1954. It is expected also to file a registration covering an issue of convertible debentures, the amount of which is uncertain.
Lawrence D. Bell, president of the Bell Aircraft Corporation, Buffalo, has been elected a director of Air Investors, Inc., to fill a vacancy on th board.

Judge Juiian W. Mack of the United States Circuit Court, New York, has won for 1937 the Gotthei Medal, awarded annually by the Zeta Beta Tau fraternity to the American who has done the most for Jews, it was announced yester day.

" Look!" our host. exclaimed, pointing across the Yangtze from his balcony. "If the Japanese planes come again, they will bomb that spot right here." Our host was a necromancer. His prescience was almost ominous.
Chinese reported today continued "rapid progress" in their counter-offensive on the center of the thirty-mile Shantung front, where the fate of 100,000 Japanese troops daily becomes more uncertain.
Exports of coffee are at new high levels and sales of futures this year, according to the statistics issued today by the National Coffee Department are more than 500,000 bags a month above last year.

Rookie Dutch Leonard pitched the Senators to a 1-to-O victory over the league-leading Indians today in thirteen innings. Fluttering his knuckle ball with deadly effectiveness, he allowed only six hits, struck out five and did not pass a batter.
The United States liner Washington started her sixty-fifth round voyage in the transatlantic trade yesterday when she sailed at noon with 726 passengers for Cobh, Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg.
A threat of economic reprisals against the Netherlands unless that country curbs press attacks on Germany was made this morning by the newspaper Voelkischer Beobachter.
The nation does not need a "breathing spell" so much as it needs "cooperation" of business, government and labor, Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference today.

Charging discrimination through a nation-wide movement to double cash deposits required in the purchase of beer in bottles, manufacturers of glass containers yesterday began a check of the effects of the State Liquor Authority's recent order requiring consumer deposits of 2 cents rather than 1 cent on bottled beer.

Liabilities of $1,546,240 and assets of $596,096 were listed in bankruptcy schedules filed yesterday by the Broad Street Hospital. The schedules list a mortgage of $250,000 to the Chase National Bank, with unpaid interest of $48,766;
Dr. Tuley F. Huntington, author and printer of fine books, died of a heart attack at his home hire today. He was born near Barrington, Ill., and was graduated from Cornell College, Iowa.
Governor Hurley's belief that a kidnap threat against one of his three daughters was "the work of a crank" failed to slow up tonight. a hunt for "the Black Hornet."

Sir Harold Bellman, managing director of the second largest building and loan society in England and a member of .the British Government's Housing Advisory Committee, will be the guest of honor and principal speaker at a luncheon jointly sponsored by the Citizens Housing Council, the New York Building Congress and the Merchants Association at the Hotel Commodore on May 16.

Although it is more an English than an American custom to eat fish for breakfast, we followed the Roman rule yesterday while waiting for Captain Christianson and Louis Mowbray to appear at the Newstead Dock.

Deaths Announced Captain Joseph A. Tracy of Engine Co. 48, died May 3 in discharge of duty, from injuries sustained while responding to Station 3192, at 10 A. M. Funeral will take place at his late residence, 3,232 Hull Ave., Bronx, at 9:30 A. M., Saturday, May 7. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, The following funeral honors are ordered:

The Advisory Council on Social Security, is of the opinion that no reduction in the current tax rates affecting the old-age insurance system should be made at this time, according to a letter sent to Senator Vandenberg today by A.J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board.

Trading was fair to slow. Salesmen were holding steer hinds and ribs at stronger prices due largely to a downward price trend on kosher chucks and plates. The lamb market was lower and some steer and fresh pork cuts lower. Cow and bull prices were weak. Non-kosher veal sold weak to slightly below recent declines.

Robert J. Murray has been nominated for president of the New York Wool Top Exchange by the nominating committee, it was announced yesterday. He will succeed Frank J. Knell, who was recently nominated for president of the New York Cotton Exchange. Max W.

A daring bit of base-running by Dom Principeas he carried home the. winning run in the ninth brought Fordham a 9-8 victory over the Temple nine yesterday-at Fordham Field, six, errors by the Rams and three by the Owls failing to detract from the general interest in the thrilling encounter.

Public hearings in connection with the affairs of the American General Corportion, a subsidiary of the Equity Corporation, will be started here on May 16, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Ogden Doremus Budd, a retired stock broker, died yesterday at his residence, 100 West Eightieth Street, at the age of 76. He was born in this city, a son of Dr. Bern L. Budd and Katherine Fowler Gallaudet Budd.

Amid every evidence of public interest, a Senate committee began today another effort to find a solution for Canada's pressing railroad problem--the greatest burden on federal finances after unemployment relief.

Appropriations of $900,000 for the upkeep of the New Jersey National Guard for the fiscal year beginning July 1 were rescinded today by the Joint Legislative Appropriations Committee in executive session.

The advertising executive, in making study of retail advertising media, should prepare his own case-histories, Paul Hollister, executive vice president and publicity director of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., said last night in a talk on "Study and Comparison of Retail Advertising Media" to students in the retail advertising course conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES at the Times Annex, 229 West Forty-third Street.
Theodore Steinblinck, a suspended patrolman who was convicted last week in Special Sessions of perjury, was sentenced yesterday to an indeterminate term in the penitentiary.

Lewis St. 25, 25x100; Sarah Sperber et al to Weincer Realty Corp, 135 William St, care Amend Amend. 6th St, 312, 25x97; John Dwyer to trustee will of Thomas Franklyn Manville, care Fifth Ave Bank; consideration $9,000, foreclousure.

Another European challenge for the Scandinavian Gold Cup. has been received by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, it was learned yesterday. This one is from Denmark, from the Royal Danish Yacht Club, and brings the number of foreign nations that will be represented on Long Island Sound next August to six, with the United States in the defender's role.

James C. Ashley of Brattleboro, Vt., bought himself another railroad today and paid only $14,000 for it. Mr. Ashley, who, with his wife, now operates a small branch of the former Boston Maine system in Brattleboro, acquired from the New.

New Jersey van men, who carry loads of furniture to New York City or pick up loads there for shore points are subjected to a "shakedown" on every load by members of a racketeering union, the Monmouth and Ocean County Van Owners' Association charges.

George M. Harrison, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association, announced today that the -union officials would demand a Congressional investigation of the Interstate Commerce Commission on the ground that it had "failed to protect the public against the floating of worthless railway securities."
In the face of "secession" threats, the Judicial Council of the Methodist Episcopal Church South ruled valid today a conference-approved plan to unify American Methodism.
The Automotive Daily News, in its midweek survey today of motorcar factory activity, placed this week's assemblies at 60,140 units, compared with 53,591 last week and 139,099 a year ago this week.

Army, in its top baseball stride of late, added Yale to its list of victims today, taking the Elis into camp by a 7-to-3 score. Andy Lipscomb let the Blue down with five hits and struck out seven. All of Army's tallies were scored off Humphrey, Crosby, his successor, holding the cadets scoreless in the last two frames.

Ground for the Red Hook housing project in Brooklyn will be acquired in condemnation proceedings before Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood tomorrow, Commissioner Alfred Rheinstein of the New York City Housing Authority said yesterday.

An amendment to the State Constitution which would permit cities to issue bonds, outside the debt limit, in order to. establish a reserve for accrued liabilities for pension and retirement systems not now on actuarial basis was introduced today by Harold Riegelman, chairman of the Committee on Cities.

Opponents of a Federal Government subsidy of the arts won a unanimous victory yesterday in a debate that enlivened the annual luncheon of the Municipal Art Society at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Since there are no laboratory tests for distinguishing between virgin wool and reworked wool fiber in a fabric, then there can be no enforcement, and there can be. no advantage to the consumer in attempting to make a distinction, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, told a subcommittee of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today.
The Charles Hayden Foundation has made a gift of $450,000, its largest benefaction to .date, to the Madison Square Boys Club for a new clubhouse.

The first one-day tournament of the Long Island Women's Golf Association today found Mrs. Ray M. Torgerson of Queens Valley in a great scoring mood as she won the low-gross honors over the beautiful Meadow Brook course by carding 35. 41--76.

Richard Whitney's counsel, Randolph Mason, appeared before the Securities and Exchange Commission here yesterday, with permission he had obtained by mail from his former client in Sing Sing to tell all he knew of the Whitney crash.
A report of the birth of six girls and one boy to Senora Rafaela Casanova Corrias, a white resident of Cayama, near Bayamo, in Oriente Province, reached Havana this afternoon.

A series of deals that started fifteen years ago ended yesterday with the purchase by Frederick A. Jambes of the four-story building on a lot 20. by 100 feet at 38 West Seventy-third, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue. The buyer now has assembled a 100-foot plot at 30 to 38 West Seventy-third Street, which he intends to improve with a twelve-story apartment house.

Gold and lace hangings and carved furniture valued at. thousands of dollars were destroyed or damaged last night by a fire in St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church at 141st Street and Convent Avenue, the religious center of a parish that was formed more than 120 years ago.

Hal Wonson, Dartmouth's second relief hurler, smashed a mighty home run beyond center field in the ninth inning to score Joe Pyrtek ahead of him and give the Big Green a startling upset victory over Brown today, 4-3.

Warren David Secord, last surviving Civil War veteran here, died last night at his home at the age of 87. Honored for many years in Memorial Day parades, he had planned to take part next month in New Rochelle's 250th birthday celebration.
Provident Institution for Savings sold to Jose Pardo the ten-family flat at -102 Wayne Street, Jersey City. The bank taking back a purchase-money mortgage for $9,900.

Alumni of the Lincoln School of Teachers College, one of the first experimental progressive high schools in the nation disagree strongly on the value of progressive education, the issue now dividing New York educators in the controversy over the city school system's activity program.
Government troops retreated slowly in the Mora de Rubielos sector east of Teruel today as the Insurgents increased the pressure of their offensive in Eastern Spain.

A Maypole supper dance was given by Miss Elsa Maxwell last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The party, attended by several hundred of Miss Maxwell's friends in society and artistic circles, was a pre-opening fete for the roof garden, which will be opened tonight for the late Spring and Summer season.

Robert Strasser, in building under construction at 160 E 89th St; Morgenthau-Seixas Co, Inc., brokers. Ignatius M. Wilkinson, in 1,001 Park Ave; Roy C. Guinn, in 141 E 88th St; Thomas H. Allen, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc. in 400 E 59th St; Joseph G. Mogab, through J. H. Taylor Co. in 315 E 68th St; Douglas Gibbons Co. Inc. broker.
Three patriotic and two educational institutions were named among the legatees of Miss Mary Martin, who died on April 19, in her will filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
The House of Commons today-had one of its best laughs in months--although over a situation that may mean British loss--when a member charged Japanese exporters with "sharp practices."

A warning that the Federal pumppriming program for spending billions of dollars on public works Would cause only a temporary business revival, followed by another depression, was sounded yesterday in a report made public by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

More than 150 newspaper men, publishers, magazine editors and automobile club executives met yesterday at the sixth annual "Motor to Canada" luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore. Canadian Pacific hotels hold the luncheon annually to stimulate interest in Canada as a vacation land for the American motorist.

Dizzy Dean, the $185,000 addition to the pitching staff of the Chicago Cubs, will be lost to the team for at least four weeks. For that period he must not pitch. For at least two weeks he must not even try to throw a ball.

Outhit, the Princeton baseball team capitalized on every scoring chance to upset a strong N. Y. U. contingent 7-5 on University field today. Bill Fallon led the Tigers at bat, connecting for a homer, double and single in four trips to the plate.

The Boersen Zeitung, which the Foreign Office uses occasionally as a mouthpiece, today charges that the United States is responsible for the action against Germans in Brazil by the government of President Getulio Vargas.
The Administration's pump-priming bill will be taken up by the House Tuesday, it was decided today, with ten hours of general debate to be followed by reading of the measure for amendment.
On the first day after Chancellor Hitler's arrival in Rome Papal. opinion of the demonstrations over him here has been expressed by the Pope himself and in no uncertain tones.
Britain's twenty-four best amateur golfers will play four rounds over the Old Course tomorrow and Friday to decide who will face the United States Walker Cup team here June 3-4.

Once more the franc is to be devalued. Until September, 1936, its parity was 6.63 cents. In that month, under cover of an international monetary agreement with Great Britain and the United States, that parity was formally abandoned, but no new parity was ever definitely fixed.

Miss Monnie Douglas of Greenwich won the upper school championship and Miss Barbara Blackwell of New York carried off the Equites Trophy in the Rosemary Hall horse show at the Round Hill Stables today.

Often there are so many confused elements, local issues, personal and political quarrels in a primary campaign that "the voice of the-people" is not so clear as the victors proclaim it. In Florida the point to be decided in the main contest was simple.
The administration and the New Deal have had so many setbacks lately that their success by proxy in the Florida Democratic primaries has attracted attention beyond the normal importance of the event.

George L. Bard and Rosalind Mia Copping, assignees of rights to the Hungarian play "The Star of the Circus," written by Ladislaus BusFekete, filed a suit for an accounting yesterday in Federal court, alleging that Billy Rose's "Jumbo" was a plagiarism of that work.

One hundred and forty-five shares of the capital stock in the Forty Fifth Avenue Corporation, representing ownership of Apartment B on the fourth floor of the cooperative building at 40 Fifth Avenue by former Supreme Court Justice Joseph F. Crater, were sold at auction yesterday in the exchange salesroom at 18 Vesey Street on a bid of $800.
Dr. Irving Langmuir, Nobel Prize winner and associate director of the General Electric Research Laboratories, today assailed radio broadcasts of "scientific jargon to fool the people."
Police Commissioner Valentine caused a flutter among his associates at police headquarters yesterday morning by announcing suddenly by telephone that he was leaing on a short vacation.

The Pirates shattered their five-game losing streak, the Dodgers and Burleigh Grimes's temper at practically the same time today by starting a tremendous forward movement in the fifth inning and going on to win, 9-5.

The New York University women's tennis team defeated Fieldston School, 3 to 2, in the initial match of the season for both institutions on the Arrowhead courts yesterday. The Violet women won two of the singles and one of the doubles engagements.
The French-frane yesterday fell swiftly in the foreign exchange market here toward the level at which Premier Edouard Daladier is expected today to announce a new defense point.

Senator John J. McNaboe, chairman of the joint legislative committee to investigate the administration and enforcement of law, called upon District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey yesterday to direct a grand jury investigation into the death of Mrs. Angeline Guidi in the psychiatric division of Belleviie Hospital last Monday.

The engagement was announced today. of Miss Martha Jayne Rullman, daughter of Mrs. Charles P. Rullman of Hempstead and Stony Brook, L. I., and the late Mr. Rullman, to Ferdinand Joseph Chesarek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Chesarek of Detroit and Calumet, Mich.

Seven Hunter College students have been elected to Alpha Chi Alpha, college honor society of the Department of History and Social Science, it was announced yesterday. Elections to the organization are based on scholarship, character and personality.

Daniel G. Cone, 19-year-old junior page of the New York Stock Exchange, today becomes "president" of that institution in the annual Boys' Day. Charles H. Kerr, 23 years old, will become the Exchange's first chairman of the board, for the post will not be filled in actuality until May 16, when William McC. Martin Jr., 31 years old, takes office;

Members of the United Automobile Workers local, an affiliate of the C. I. O., halted production today at the Allis Chalmers Manufacturing- Company in a two-hour sit-down which, union leaders said, was an unauthorized protest against the company's refusal to meet union demands..

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The State Teachers Association andorganized teacherdom in the metropolitan district seem to be unanimous in demanding that there be no change in our State Constitution's wording with respect to public education.

Bonds pushed ahead further in trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. While the gains were not sizable, the entire list exhibited a strengthened background that brought some new buying into the market. Trading continued at a-mild pace, with total sales of $4,921,025, compared with $4,238,100 on Tuesday.
In an unexpected move, Jacob Silverman pleaded guilty in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday to conspiring to obstruct justice by "fixing" the Samuel Drukman murder case. He was continued in $1,000

AS OTHERS SEE YOU, by Dr. Henry J. Schireson. (Macaulay, $3.) The story of plastic surgery. THE DECK CHAIR READER, edited by Harford Powel and Brandt Aymar. (Greenberg, $2.50.) An anthology for travelers.
The renomination of Senator Pepper of Florida in yesterday's primaries was hailed by President Roosevelt's followers today as signal endorsement of the President's record and policies.

The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor declared today that the basic aims and objectives of the federation committed it to private initiative and the protec,tion of private property.

It was alleged and denied here today that a supplemental agreement was made between the Steel Workers 'Organizing Committee and' the United States Steel Corporation granting concessions to the latter.

Samuel Weiss and David Goldberg, officials of Donnie Frocks, Inc., of 254 West Thirty-fifth Street, were found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of conspiracy in filing an allegedly false income tax return for 1936 which concealed income of about $80,00.

The administration has decided to throw its support behind the resolution of Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota for lifting the arms embargo against Spain. The prospect is that the legislation will be passed before adjournment of the present session.

Mrs. J. W. Cannon Sr. of Concord, N. C., widow of the founder of the Cannon Mills, died at her home this afternoon after a lingering illness. Her age was 80. Mrs. Cannon was noted for her benefactions.

As the program arranged by Premier Benito Mussolini for Chancellor Adolf Hitler proceeded successfully today,. behind the public demonstrations conversations between German and Italian statesmen took place. These included two' talks between Hitler and, Mussolini.

As a method of overcoming the havoc wrought by "parasites" who copy shoe designs, Harry Rosenthal, president. of Shoecraft, Inc., proposed a label to be used on all shoes manufactured by members of the Shoe Fashion Guild, at a luncheon attended by about 400 retailers and sponsored by the Guild at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.

Of the interested bystanders watching the imperially staged meeting of the dictators against the incomparable background of Rome, probably the most curious and concerned is Mr. Neville Chamberlain of London.
Mrs. Dorothy Bailey, 35 years old, of 35-83 Eighty-third Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, was found dead last night in a courtyard at the rear of the biuilding in which she lived.

Big Bill Michell of Amherst pitched a no-hit, no-run game today in stopping a favored Massachusetts State nine, 5-O, on Pratt Field. The victory was the fifth for the Jeffs this season and ended a twelvegame winning streak for State.

Mr. and Mrs. F. H. Daniels, Bruce G. Daniels, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert I. Finch, Mr. and Mrs. James D. Benedict, Mrs. Beatrice Kerr, Mr. and Mrs. W. S. Gilman, Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Ring and J. J. Mundet are among the passengers due to arrive from Mediterranean ports today on the Italian liner Vulcania.

Dr. Rufus Cole, director of the hospital of the Rockefeller Institute, New York, since 1909, received today the George M. Kober Medal for distinguished service to medicine from the Association of American Physicians.

John Sloane, president of W. J. Sloane, was made a member of the French Legion of Honor last night at a dinner in his home, 48 East Ninety-second Street. The award was made by-the French Ambassador to the United States, Count Rene Doynel de Saint-Quentin.
The Phillies subdued the Cubs, 6 to 4, today when the Chicago team handed the lowly Philadelphians the two runs which gave them their margin of victory.
A total of $127,281 has been contributed in the campaign of the Committee for.Planned Parenthood to raise $263,990 it was announced yesterday by Mrs. William C. Potter, chairman of the committee.

Dr. and Mrs. Pascal Brooke Bland of Bala, Pa., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Harrison Bland, to William Cramp Scheetz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Scheetz of Cynwyd, Pa.

The problem of frozen commercial credits in Mexico has become acute, it was learned today, when authoritative sources revealed Mexicans were not meeting about $7,000,000 currently due for payment of machinery and other imported articles.
William A. McKay, last surviving Civil War veteran of Franklin and last commander of Mays Post, G. A. R., died here this morning at the age of 89, He had been ill two weeks.

The International Tin Committee announced tonight that henceforth there would be two world tin quotas if the governments participating in international tin control accept a plan to set up a buffer stock.

Accused of interfering with an anti-Nazi meeting at Ninety-second Street and. Broadway, two men were fined $25 each in Night Court last night on charges of disorderly conduct, with the alternative of 10 days imprisonment.

Frederick J. Barnes, treasurer of James McCreery Co, since 1909, will retire on June 1, it was announced yesterday. He will be sueceqded by Charles D. Marsh, who has been treasurer of the J. N. Adam Co., Buffalo, since 1933.

Frank Page -Cheesman of 1,321 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, president of the Cheesman-Elliot Company, paint manufacturers, 639 Kent Avenue, Brooklyn, died yesterday in the Brooklyn Hospital of arteriosclerosis.

" Once Is Enough" will play its last Broadway performance a week from Saturday night, by which time it will, have had an engagement of 105 performances at Henry Miller's Theatre. It will not tour in this country, but it is understood Gilbert Miller plans to present it in London in the late Summer -- with or without Ina Claire, whose vehicle it has been here.

Fair-haired 18-year-old Walter Leiste Jr., who was born in Germany, but has lived most of his life in the Bronx, found yesterday that his brief encounter with politics, on the night that American Legionnaires and German-American Bund members clashed in Yorkville Casino, April 20, would keep him in the city-for some time.
Indictment of six persons,including the State's agent and three women, for Merritt Parkway land frauds was disclosed today by Lorin W. Willis, State's Attorney.

The Grace Line announced yesterday that the three steamships operating the sixteen-day cruises to the Caribbean will have radio pratique instead of their having to stop at Quarantine for examination by a United States Public Health officer.

In a two-hour ceremony in the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, with many of the ranking clergymen of the American Catholic hierarchy present, the Most Rev. Bartholomew Joseph Eustace was installed today as Bishop of the newly created Catholic Diocese of Camden.

Recommendation was made today by the three trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad system that the lease of the Providence Boston Railroad, an integral part of the main New YorkBoston line, be rejected and no further payments be made.
Yugoslav authorities today fought with difficulty to stem-a run on the nation's banks inspired by the demand of autonomy from Croatian Nationalists.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $4,006,305,904 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on May 1 was $25.15, compared with $22.32 at the beginning of April.

Windt Chemists, Inc, floor in 30-32 W 24th St; David H. Faber, metal ornaments, jewelry, etc., floor in 133-35 W 19th St; D. F. Newfield Co, Inc, in 245 5th Ave; Ben S. Loeb, houseware and cutlery, Philip Hano Co, Inc, stationery, in 1,107 Broadway; estate of Thomas Hedley, cosmetics, through Dwight, Voorhis Helmsley, Inc, floor in 26 E 22d St; Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc. broker.

Unwanted showers in parts of Texas offset effects of a more favorable weekly weather report and most of the trading on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday took place at slight advances in prices. Weakness in French exchange, however,

The New York CentralRailroad obtained today authority from the Interstate Commerce Commission to pledge and repledge from time to time to and including June 30, 1940, as collateral security for short-term notes,

The site of Benjamin Franklin's original printing shop, where he turned out Poor Richard's Almanack, was marked today by a bronze tablet, cemented into the sidewalk in front of a building at 135 Market Street. In Franchise's day it was 51 High street.

THE MAN FROM CAIRO, a comedy in three acts, adapted by Dan Goldberg from the French of Yvan-Noe. Staged by Harry Wagstaff Gribble settings by Frederick B. Fox; produced by Michael Todd. At the Broadhurat Theatre.

The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today an exemption from the necessity of filing a declaration under the Public Utility Holding Company Act to the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation in connection with the issuance and sale of a 4 per cent serial note for $2,000,000 to the Chase National Bank, the proceeds to be used to discharge obligations for construction already completed and for future construction.

Representative Reilly, acting chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, at a hearing today on an amendment to the Housing Act which would increase the working capital of the United States Housing Authority from $500,000,000 to $1,000,000,000 dollars, declared that the government's program was putting slum dwellers in homes "better 'than the homes of 75 per cent of the people of the United States."

BORGIA, JOHN (Feb. 5, 1938). Gross assets, $24,452; net, $10,845. To son, James M. Borgia. Chief assets, real estate, $22,735; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $616; miscellaneous property, $116; transfers, $1,286. Burchard Dutcher, attorney, 22 E. 40th st., Manhattan.

By HENRY G. WALTEMADE Essex St, 153-7 (Stanton St, 113-5), 75x92.1; 4 5-story tenements and stores; Margaret Folsom Corp, against Moleh Holding Corp.; due, $117,177; taxes, etc., $14,285; to plaintiff for $60,000.

Premier Milan Hodza presided at a conference of the Cabinet's political committee today and informed the Ministers concerning the reports submitted by Dr. Stefan Osusky, Minister at Paris, and Jan Masaryk, Minister at London, in which the respective views of France and Britain were discussed and analyzed.

The Inland Steel Company asked the United States Circuit Court of Appeals today to set aside the order of the National Labor Relations Board that it recognize the Committee for Industrial Organization as the sole bargaining agency for its employes and sign work contracts with the employes whom the C. I. O. represents.

John J. Dietz, former New York City Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, and former Tammany leader of the Eighteenth Assembly District, South, Manhattan, died here today in his home at 109 Mamaroneck Road after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., May 5: LIEUTENANTS-Robert E. Quinn, from 84th Precinct to 4th Division, assignment changed from desk duty to supervisor of plain clothes patrolmen. Samuel A. Pinnell, from 87th Precinct to Motorcycle Precinct 2, assignment to desk duty continued.
The Tigers, teeing off against Right-hander Jack Wilson, made at least one hit and had runners left in every inning today, when they stopped the Red Sox, 4 to 1, to deadlock the series at one-all.

Although outhit, City College's baseball forces scored a 9-to-7 triumph over Brooklyn College on the latter's field yesterday. The visitors moved ahead in the first inning, slid behind at 7 to 4 as. Brooklyn College staged a five-run rally in the fifth, and then came from behind for victory.

With what was for the French public, at least, an unexpected suddenness, the franc fell today to a new low level of 33.93 to the dollar and 169.75 to the pound sterling, and the question of its fixation at a new rate is tonight in debate.

The Down Town Glee Club of 200 men's voices and the Golden Hill Chorus, composed of the same number of women singers, joined forces for the first time in a concert given last night at Carnegie Hall, under the direction of Channing Lefebvre.
The Senate tonight approved a petroleum bill that sets up a national reserve and provides regulations for the industry. This measure was passed by the House of Representatives last February.
The promotion of 209 students to noncommissioned officers in the Reserve Officers Training Corps at New York University was announced yesterday by Colonel F. V. S. Chamberlain.

Seeking to comply with the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, Ebasco Services, Inc., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission declarations on behalf of itself and its wholly owned subsidiary,...

Mannfried Hauptmann, the 5-yearold son of Bruno Richard Hauptmiann, was struck by an automobile yesterday and his leg was broker when he ran into the street while playing in front of- his home, 2,977 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, near 201st Street.

Edward G. Robinson was signed today by Selznick-International for the leading role in "Earl of Chicago," by Brock Williams, and Lewis Milestone was announced as director. The satirical story involves an American gangster in London society. The screen play is being written by Gene Fowler and Charles De Grancourt.

Acting at the request of the special grand jury, which has been investigating Philadelphia vice and crime conditions since October, the May grand jury returned today 203 true bills of indictment naming 107 persons.

Plans have been completed by Miss Jean Watson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Ellsworth Watson of New Brunswick, N. J., for her marriage to William Bryan Moses Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses of Portland, Me., which will take place on May 28 in the Second Reformed Church, New Brunswick.

The basketball team representing the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, which has been having great success in a tour of South America, arrived here today on the Santa Lucia of the Grace Line from Valparaiso, Chile.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Loughran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charlemagne Loughran of Kew Gardens, Queens, to George Taylor, son of former Controller of the City of New York and Mrs. Frank J. Taylor of Brooklyn, took place yesterday morning in the St. James Pro-Cathedral, Brooklyn.
The Bees and the Cardinals battled through five innings today to a 3-3 tie and then were chased from Sportsman's Park by a drenching rain storm.

A community center unique in scope was- projected last night with the announcement at a dinner at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's Hebrew Association that the property adjoining it on Lexington Avenue, south to Ninety-first Street, had been acquired as a new home for the Young Women's Hebrew Association, now at 31 West 110th Street.
Colonel Fulgenclo Batista today announced the suspension Of his much-publicized Three-Year Plan until a constituent assembly, to provide the nation with a new Constitution, can be held.

No military pomp or display marked the election of the first Presient of Ireland here today. The only outward indication of the event were the crowds that awaited outside the government buildings for the arrival of Dr. Douglas Hyde.

The Waterview Realty Co, Inc, Rudolph H. Trebitsch, president, bought from the Metropolitan Savings Bank the northwest corner of Lewis and 7th Sts. giving back a purchase money mortgage for $16,000, due seven years hence at 4 per cent.

A proposal for modification of the proposed plan of reorganization for the New York Title and Mortgage Company has been developed by stockholders, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler was informed yesterday.

Many persons entertained parties at the dinner dance last night which formally opened for the season the Pierre Roof. Among the guests of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Tew were Mr. and Mrs. Longstreet Hinton, Miss Lucy Truesdale, Carroll Cavanagh and Joseph R. Truesdale.

Dr. Alonzo G. Grace, professor at the University of Rochester, was elected Commissioner of Education for Connecticut-today by the State Board of Education to take the place of Ernest W. Butterfield, who resigned. Dr. Grace is now directing a survey in Washington State.

The fed steer market continued to seek lower price levels today, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. Strictly grain-fed weighty steers and yearlings lost another 15 to 25 cents to make the rank and file 25 to 50 cents lower for the week. Hogs showed a little strength.

The perennial answer in France to financial difficulties seems to be further devaluation. Since Premier Leon Blum took the plunge in September, 1936, and finally removed the franc from gold, its course has been one of successive depreciations.
Dr. George Edwin MacLean, clergyman and educator, died here yesterday afternoon at his home in his eightyeighth year.

The Senate passed and sent back to the House a bill appropriating $227,000,000 for the non-military functions of the War Department, passed a bill for redistribution of unused cotton acreage allotments, sent to conference a bill for creating twenty-four additional Federal judgeships and recessed at 3:46 P. M. until noon tomorrow.
The Eighteenth Infantry, organized as a part of the United States Army on May 4, 1861, and since credited with distinguished service in four wars, celebrated its seventyseventh anniversary yesterday

While classess were changing yesterday morning at Erasmus Hall High School in Brooklyn, a student monitor was stabbed in the chest. The stabbing followed a Negro youth's refusal to follow school traffic rules in trying to ascend a staircase, it was said.

James G. Conway, president of the New York Towboat Exchange, urged the War Department yesterday to withhold permission for construction of a foot bridge between Manhattan at 103d Street and Wards Island pending the outcome of tests to determine the effect of the structure on the East River tides.
Yale's polo quartet today outscored Farmington Valley, 15--4. Collister Johnson and Alan Corey of the Elis led the scorers with five goals apiece.

The Phaidon Press, for fifteen years centered in Vienna, has moved to Zurich, Switzerland, according to word received by the Oxford University Press, agent in this country for the Phaidon Art Books. The Viennese publisher, Dr. Bela Horovitz, who visited New York a few months ago, had laid plans for the transfer of his business out of Austrial some time prior to the Nazi invasion.
Washington Ave (11-2910), e s, 123 ft n of 169th St, 38x104; 1,308 Washington Ave Corp to Wesko Realty Corp, 11 W 42d St; mtg $28,000.

The first orchids from- Hawaii ever to be exhibited at the annual orchid show here were delivered yesterday after a 5,200-mile flight from Honolulu. The rare blooms, made up of the choicest varieties grown by fanciers in the terri:toral islands, were unpacked at 782 Sixth Avenue by L. Edward Dupuy, president of the Florist Club of New York.

President Roosevelt's proposal to put an end to tax-exempt securities, while a "logical and sound" plan, should be worked out on a reciprocal basis whereby the Federal Government would not tax interest from State and municipal securities higher than the States tax interest from Federal securities, Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, declared last night.

In the twelve months ended on April 1 exports by the United States to the sixteen trade-agreement countries increased 68.6 per cent over the average for the calendar years 1934 and 1935, compared with an increase of only 50.5 per cent in the export trade with non-agreement countries, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Inspired by the abounding patience of Carl Owen Hubbell, the Giants virtually started two runs behind scratch today, but finally succeeded in overhauling the stout-hearted, though hard-headed, Reds to down Ray (Peaches) Davis, 3 to 2.

PILE in, ladies and gentlemen, and we'll go for a little trip. Edith J. Lyttleton, alias G. B. Lancaster, is the guide. The vehicle is a gaudy affair called "Promendae." Lo, New Zealand! And here, la, leaning on the rail of a sailing ship fresh from England, is a giddy young filly named Darien Vibart.

The National Labor Relations Board, by a vote of two to one, today ruled that a craft union election should be held in a Schenley, Pa., distillery plant despite a closed shop agreement with an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization.
The valuation of the properties of the local subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company was ordered increased from $1,417,857 to $3,259,976 for assessment of direct taxes.

In order to compete with current advertising on oil burners, anthracite dealers of a number of cities in the East have banded together to conduct large-space, long-time cooperative advertising campaigns for stokers and water heaters in newspapers.

The escape and subsequent recapture of Frederick Mangieri, 34 years old, of 540 Ninth- Street, Brooklyn, one of the four men who were seized last Fall in connection with the theft of $20,000 worth of furs and jewelry from wealthy women, was revealed yesterday.

The presentation of an award to America's Town Meeting of the Air as "one of the outstanding achievements of. the year in radio" and the results of a nation-wide poll conducted among- twenty-five national women's organizations on their favorite radio programs were announced yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Women's National Radio Committee at the Hotel St. Regis.

Echoes of the Administration's unsuccessful fight for the Reorganization Bill were heard today in reports that several House members are receiving back as undeliverable a number of letters which they wrote to persons who assailed the measure by letter or telegram.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway paid $21,741 to the Guaranty Trust Company for trustee's services and $138,013 to J. P. Morgan Co. for fiscal agents' fees in 1937, a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday. The Guaranty Trust Company is backing a proxy campaign to place three of its candidates on the board of the C. O.

In the first three months of this year the Standard Oil Company of California and its domestic subsidiaries earned a net profit of $7,130,486 after taxes and charges. This is equivalent to 55 cents a share on 13,014,753 shares outstanding.
In an open letter addressed to the President, an organization of young men and women known as the First Voters League expresses its opposition to the Administration's pump-priming plan.

Five-hit pitching by Bill Dietrich gave the White Sox a 4-to-1 victory today over the Athletics and evened the series at one game each. Two walks, Steinbacher's triple, Walker's single and an error by Hasson accounted for three Chicago runs in the fourth inning.
A fashion show, presented as a "preview of Summer from the feminine point of view," was given yesterday afternoon at the B. Altman . Co. store at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
Democratic leaders backing the State Committee ticket were reported to be planning a court move designed to halt the Dauphin County grand jury's investigation of bribery and coercion.

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May in Brooklyn reduced yesterday from $540,031 to $338,499 the condemnation awards made by him in 1933 for eight parcels of land under water taken by the city for its Marine Park development in Queens County,

The city's efforts to sell at public auction on Aug. 5 its tax lien of $5,310,000 against street car companies of the B. M. T. System will be contested and may result in an accounting which will show that the city owes money to the companies, according to a statement issued last night by William S. Menden, president of the B. M. T. System companies.

Exeter won a close game from the Tufts freshmen, 5 to 4, on the diamond today after taking a 4-1 lead in the third inning. Eric Franzen, who pitched effective ball for the winners, increased the lead in the sixth when his blow to left field took. a lucky hop for a home run.

The most spectacular display of fireworks New York has seen in thirty years was promised yesterday by World's Fair authorities as a climax of the entertainment and show to be held on the fair grounds in Flushing Meadows. Park Sunday afternoon and evening.

The Yankees were having a time of it yesterday at the Stadium trying to beat Oral Hildebrand and the rest of Gabby Street's Browns until Bill Dickey stepped into the picture. Then, with one devastating stroke of his bat, the Arkansan settled the issue.

The Association of Foreign Press Correspondents in the United States will celebrate its twentieth anniversary tomorrow night at a dinner at the Hotel Lombardy, D. de Roussy de Sales, president of the organization and correspondent of ParisSoir, announced yesterday.

Of the eleven bids submitted for the general contract for construction of a new grade school in Sayville, L. I., the estimate of John Clausnitzer Associates, Inc., was the lowest, with $247,880, according to Brown's Letters, Inc.
Electric power production last week declined a little less than seasonally, but the long-term rise eased the adjusted index to 89.6 from 89.7. It was 107.4 for the week ended May 1, 1937.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City accepted at his City Hall yesterday, with complete composure, a C. I. O. subpoena that will require him to lay the whole issue of his so-called Jersey City "dictatorship" before Federal Judge William Clark in Newark next Thursday.

GOVERNOR'S ISLAND 2d Lt. Melvin I. Bookman, Inf.-Res., 1,306 Findlay Ave., New York, N.Y., 18th Inf., is ordered to active duty, effective May 8 at Ft. Hamilton, N.Y., for training. Date of rank, April 24, 1938. He will revert to an inactive status on May 18.

A few words murmured behind prison walls brought back into the spotlight tonight an unsolved crime. J. M. McCauley, State Penitentiary warden, said Mrs. Mary Ellen Smith, 73, had confessed that she and her convict son, Earl De Casto Mayer, killed James Eugene Bassett,. 35, a former naval officer.

Banished from their rescue work of generations in the Alpine snows, the pack of Saint Bernard dogs from the famous Swiss monastery of that name sailed today from Marseilles to begin life anew in the Himalayas of Tibet.
Characteristics of the ideal parent were outlined yesterday by Dr. Edmund E. Day, president of Cornell University, at a Better Parenthood Week luncheon at the RitzCarlton Hotel.

The offer of the Government of 50 Yugoslavia and the Mortgage Bank of Yugoslavia to pay 45 percent of the face amount of bond coupons was characterized yesterday as unsatisfactory by the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc.

Robert R. Young of Cleveland strengthened his control of the Alleghany Corporation, top holding company of the one-time railway empire of the Van Sweringens, by the removal today of Charles L. Bradley of Cleveland from the board of directors.

The United States has suffered a direct loss of more than $150,000,000 in the first ten months of the Japanese invasion of China, and contingent and potential losses will raise that amount to a much higher figure, according to O. O. Gallup, secretary of the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc.

Mayor La Guardia paid a half hour visit yesterday afternoon to the outdoor sculpture show at Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street. The sculptors, who were on hand to meet him, found him unexpectedly candid.

BATT--Jessie, wife of the late Samuel, T. Batt. Services at the Stolzenberger Chapel. 450 East 162d St., Friday, May 6, at. 8 P. M. BERLIN--Dorothea, wife of the late Dr. Frederick Berlin. Reposing at the Stolzenberger Chapel, 450 East 162d St., until Thursday, May 5, 11 A. M.

The bondholders' committee for the 5 per cent collateral trust bonds of the Beauharnois Power Corporation, Ltd., announced yesterday in a letter to holders of the bonds that at a special meeting called for May 27 consideration would be given to reorganizing the capital structure of, the company and its operating subsidiaries.

John Knewistub Maurice Rothenstein, formerly on art staffs of the universities of Kentucky and Pittsburgh and more recently a director of the Sheffield Galleries, has been appointed director and keeper of the Tate Gallery in London. He succeeds James B. Manson, retired.

Colonel Lewis- Landes, attorney for Gennaro Caputo, one of twenty-five defendants who went on trial yesterday in Federal Court as alleged members of a narcotic smuggling and distributing ring, was fined $50 by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert when he refused-to obey the court's order to sit down.

Charles J. Hardy Jr. was elected president of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday at the annual meeting at the Lunch Club, Wall Street. He succeeds Darwin P. Kingsley Jr., who had served two terms.

A transaction near the Catholic Protectory site, which has been selected for a $35,000,000 housing development, was completed yesterday when the one-story taxpayer at 1,300-18 Castle Hill Avenue, corner of Westchester Avenue, was sold by John J. Reynolds, broker, for Maurice Goodman, attorney, to an investor.

Announcement by the United States Steel Corporation of a proposed issue of $100,000,000 bonds is interesting chiefly as a temporary change of policy by the company, due to the change in surrounding circumstances. In the prosperous days of 1929 the company retired $265,455,000 of -its own bonds, practically canceling all the funded debt established at the outset in 1901 and 1902.
It appears from Prime Minister Chamberlain's statement in the House of Commons that men may come and men may go,

A proposed scale of uniform prices for drinks served at bars in this State is based on a minimum price of 15 cents for a drink served in a glass of one and a quarter ounce capacity, John J. Daly, president of the New York State Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association, Inc., sponsors of the move, disclosed here yesterday.

New York University's, varsity track team easily defeated Rutgers today, 88 to 47, The Violets captured all first places in the track events with the exception of the 220-yard dash, which was won by Vio Hurst in a close finish with his team-mate, Ernie Baxter. Jim Herbert, Violet middle-distance ace, breezed through his event, the quarter mile, in easy fashion.

Five of the major airline companies operating in and out of New York had before them yesterday a proposal to unite their business and ticket offices in a union terminal to be erected by the Bethlehem Engineering Corporation at Forty-second Street and Park Avenue.

Following the two-day private sales on Monday and Tuesday, the leading specialty shops here began their joint clearances of seasonal merchandise yesterday. While the clearances stimulated consumer attendance, it was noteworthy according to John-B. Swinney, managing director of the Uptown Retail Guild, that interest tended to center more on the purchase of new Summer merchandise than on seasonal woolen suits or dresses.
Julio Alvarez del Vayo, the Spanish Government's Foreign Minister, gave a party today to keep a promise made nearly a month ago when foreigners said the Spanish civil war would end in a few days.

Further complaints from organized business against policies and practices of the New Deal administration were met today with a warning from Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, that the banking system must more adequately meet credit needs if it expected to remain in private hands.
Postmaster General Farley barred from the mails today all copies of the May 5 issue of Ken, semimonthly publication, on the ground that it contained obscene matter.

Louis Hallett, Actors Equity conservative, who was reprimanded Tuesday by Equity's council for issuing "unfounded" statements criticizing the council, submitted his resignation yesterday as Equity deputy of the "Prologue to Glory" company.
The Chase National Bank, the First Boston Corporation, Geo. B. Gibbons Co., Inc., and Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.,
Merle Oberon's damage suit resulting from an automobile accident March 16, 1937, emerged from the maze of a three-day lawsuit today with her chauffeur unexpectedly owing her a lot of money.
A meeting of Little Entente Foreign Ministers began here today under not particularly favorable auspices as far as Czechoslovakia was concerned.

Nassau Pen and Pencil Corporation, 116 Nassau Street, New York, has entered into a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission agreeing to discontinue certain misleading representations complained ?? by the commission, it was announced here today.

Max D. Steuer, chairman of the Greater New York ORT campaign, praised yesterday as the most effective means of relief yet devised, the - system of training Jewish refugees in various European countries: in, technical schools, helping them to help themselves.

Two fellowships and a scholarship have been awarded by Columbia University for graduate Study in medicine,, geology and government in the next academic year, Dr. Nicholas Murray-Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday.

Appointment of Walter F. Wright as vice president and general sales manager, succeeding F. R. Valpey, who has resigned, was announced yesterday by J. B. Graham, president of the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation.

Richard J. Cullen, president of the International Paper and Power Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders in Boston yesterday that operations in the first quarter were at only 50 per cent of capacity. "Operations are continuing at that rate," he continued, "but are showing some upward press trend.

High school children spend too much of their spare time listening to the radio and show very little discrimination in the type of program they enjoy, according to the results of a radio survey carried on in the New York City school system, made public yesterday.

Eighteen thousand persons filled Madison Square Garden last night to hear Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, debate with Frederick J. Libby, executive secretary of the National Council for the Prevention of War, on whether the United States should join in concerted action against the Fascist States.

A resolution asking Governor Lehman to rescind an order by the State Adjutant General forbidding the use of the words "naval" and "militia" by boys' organizations was. adopted last night at a meeting called by the New York Junior Naval Militia and attended by about 200 persons, including representatives of veterans' organizations and about 100 boys in uniform.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-By LAWRENCE CIOFFI, inspector, 201 E. 116th St.-Liabilities, $48,912, partly contingent obligations; no assets. JOSEPH DIAMOND, foreman, 1,877 Daly Ave.--Liabilities, $4,606; no assets except insurance.

Major Gen. Frank M. Andrews, chief of the United Sates Army air force, will arrive here at noon tomorrow to take charge of preparations for the air defense manoeuvres and war games along the Eastern coast from May 12 to May 17.

Seven young men known to the police as the "baloney bandits" because they almost always ordered bologna just before holding up a delicatessen or grocery store proprietor; were sentenced yesterday by Kings County Judge William O'Dwyer, five of them receiving prison terms ranging from ten to sixty years and two others receiving indeterminate terms in Elmira Reformatory.

MANHATTAN BERGH, WILLIE C. (May 1). Estate, mote than $20,000. To Alfred Polk Bergh, Phelps Dr., Brightwaters, L. I., and Roland Christian Bergh, Ocean Ave., Woodmere, L. I, sons, executors, personal efforts and one-half residue each, also contingent interest in a trust; Henry Bergh, nephew, executor, 219 E. 71st St., contingent interest in a trust.

Dr. Hugh Cabot of the Mayo Clinic, speaking tonight before the Group Health Association of Washington, urged group practice of medicine as the best means for bringing adequate medical care within the reach of the majority of the population and characterized the present claims of organized medicine to sole control of medical practice as "pure fascism of the Italian type."

Alfred M. Lilienthal, president of the First Voters League, made public yesterday a letter to President Roosevelt protesting against further Federal "pump-priming." American youth, he declared, does not want additional Federal debt piled up that it will have to pay off in years to come.

THE political writers may overlook this, but it's a hot topic in tennis circles. Part of the Davis Cup program is turning on what the foreign correspondents called the Rome-Berlin axis. What is Herr Hitler going to do about it? What are Benito Mussolini's views on this important matter?

With Germany increasing miners' hours and France, Belgium, Poland and the United States reducing them, the International Labor Organization preparatory coal conference was faced today with the question of whose leadership should prevail.

Acceptance by Robert E. Blum, secretary of Abraham Straus, of the chairmanship of the department store division of the Greater New York Fund campaign in Brooklyn was announced yesterday by Charles A. Gorman, general chairman in that borough.

Flinging her arms above her head with the despairing cry of "I can't go on," Lotte Lehmann, prima donna, tonight electrified -the audience of Covent Garden Opera House by walking off the stage in the middle of a passage during the first act of "Der Rosenkavalier."
The French liner Lafayette was destroyed by fire last night and early today. When the fire began the vessel was in drydock for an overhauling prior to departure for New York May 17.

Chinese, jubilant in hopes or a second major victory on the Shantung front, reported their legions today were continuing to sweep back Japan's front lines. Thrusting through the center, the Chinese said they were approaching Szechuchen, eighteen miles north of Pihsien, in Southern Shantung Province.
The House Interstate Commerce Committee reported favorably today a Senate bill to bring over-the-counter dealers in securities under Federal control.
Many reservations have been made for the fourth annual Tip Top Ball, which will be held tonight in the ballroom of the Plaza under the auspices of Auxiliary 5 of-Stony Wold. Sanatorium.
Harold Stewart Birkby, formerly with the Esso Marketers, has been appointed sales manager of Hodges Carpet Company, Indian Orchard, Mass.

The House Steering Committee working for passage of the Wages and Hours Bill announced tonight that "more than enough pledges" had been made to sign by tomorrow a petition to discharge the Rules Committee from further consideration of the measure and bring the bill to the floor.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided to hold public hearings in regard to the affairs of seven investment trusts concerning which a preliminary private investigation has been conducted in New York.

The scene of the entertainment of Chancellor Hitler and the counselors he has brought from Germany shifted today to the Bay of Naples, the most beautiful of all European harbors. Here the Italian fleet was displayed for the Chancellor in a series of demonstrations unique in naval history.

Plans for Maude Adams's screen career have been altered at Selznick-International, it was learned today, and the noted actress will not be used in "The Young in Heart," adapted from I. A. R. Wylie's "The Gay Banditti," but will be seen in a future production which will be given over entirely to her. It was learned that David O.
The first fistic outbreak at Fenway Park a baseball crowd has witnessed in eighteen years incited the Tigers to come from behind and defeat the Red Sox, 7-5, today in the series finale.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission notified yesterday the twenty-three unsuccessful candidates for the $11,000 post of examiner in the Board of Education who appealed from the ratings of the examining committee that a special appeals committee on manifest errors had upheld unanimously the passing of only one man, a private school teacher.

The Catskill Mountain House, noted resort and landmark at Beachview, N. Y.,. has been leased for ten years by the Andron Hotel Company, New York hotel operators. The rental agreement, which contains an option to purchase, calls for extensive alterations and improvements to be made by the lessee.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

An order dismissing a petition of the Seneca Nation of Indians of New York to intervene in the proceedings on an application by the Niagara Falls Power Company to divert an additional 275 cubic feet a second of Niagara Falls water was issued today by the Federal Power Commission.

Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals, retiring president of the Congregation Emanu-EI, and his recently elected successor, Lewis L. Strauss, partner in the banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co., were guests of honor last night at a dinner of the congregation in the Isaac M. Wise Memorial Hall of Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

The United States Circuit Court heard argument and reserved decision yesterday on the appeal of Robert R. Young and the Alleghany Corporation from the refusal of Judge Alfred C. Coxe to enjoin the Guaranty Trust Company from voting 780,100 shares of Chesapeake Corporation stock pledged as security for a bond issue payable in 1944.

Following an unsuccessful effort to have proxies representing 2,071,811 shares of stock declared invalid, the J. Paul Getty interests, owning some 24 per cent of the outstanding stock, withdrew yesterday from the annual meeting of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, threatening to take some legal action.

The Senate approved- today a House joint resolution creating the Saratoga National Historical-- Park, which will include the site of the Battle of Saratoga. The bill has already been approved by the House.
A number of Spanish Insurgent officials and aristocrats held a meeting here today which was attended by a number of Gibraltar's prominent residents.

Demand for wool goods this week was slow, but sentiment improved. following reports of better response to Fall clothing lines, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

The National Labor Relations Board won the right today to vacate its order against the Ford Motor Company and thus regain jurisdiction of the case for elimination of issues as to validity of its procedure.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Appleton Warren of this place and Kingston, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth-Anne Warren, to Lieutenant Glenn C. Thompson, Air Corps, U. S. A.

While complete agreement has not yet been reached on a number of problems, "strengthened" fair trade contracts applying to the 1939 lines of radios will be used by leading manufacturers, reports here yesterday indicated.

Bank clearings of the principal cities throughout the nation amounted to $5,448,674,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total represents a decline of 17.6 per cent from the $6,613,905,000 reported for the corresponding week last year and makes the twenty-fifth consecutive week in- which a loss has been shown.

Sales of furniture in the. first quarter of 1938 were 31.3 per cent below a year ago, according to the quarterly bulletin of Arthur Fertig Co., auditors, issued yesterday. In 1937, first quarter sales represented 20.29 per cent of the total for the year.

Operations last year of the Humble Oil and Refining Company and subsidiary, affiliated with the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, resulted in a net profit. of $46,924,001 after Federal income taxes, depletion, depreciation, interest and other charges, according to the annual report for 1937, issued yesterday.

Doubt that stockholders who have invested hundreds of millions of dollars have any equity left in some of the railroads now in receivership was expressed yesterday by speakers at the eighteenth annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

In view of the fact that such long hitters as Jimmy Thomson and Lawson Little have entered the metropolitan open championship, to be played Thursday, Friday and Saturday of next week at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Flushing, L. I., Mark J. Stuart, chairman of the tournament committee of the M. G. A., announced yesterday that a driving contest will be a feature of the event.

George W. Perkins has been elect- er ed president of the recently. established New York Presbyterian Foundation. Announcement of his election and of the personnel of the laymen of the board of directors was made yesterday at the office of the Presbytery of New York in the Presbyterian Building, 156 Fifth Avenue.

House parties, highlight of the Spring social season at Princeton University, will be held here by the eighteen Prospect Street eating clubs tomorrow and Saturday.evenings, with 696 feminine guests in attendance.

Eight members of the board of directors of the Stock Clearing Corporation resigned yesterday. Three remained, and William McC. Martin Jr., soon to become chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, and Harry K. Smith of Shearson, Hammill Co. were elected.

6th St, n s, 225 ft w of 1st Ave, 25x90.9; Irving Levy to James E. Willing, admr of Louise Lee Willing, West Brook, Conn; consideration $9,000; foreclosure. 25th St, n s, 150 ft e of 2d Ave, 50x98.9; Taro Holding Corp to Rumax Realty Corp, 2,117 Southern Blvd, Bronx.

The Senate sent back to committee today the proposed constitutional amendment guaranteeing equal rights for women. On motion by Senator Borah the Senate returned the amendment to the Judiciary Committee on a voice vote.

Representatives of consumers' organizations and officials of the New York City Department of Markets met at 139 Center Street yesterday afternoon for a final rally among supporters of the compulsory meatgrading bill, which will come up for public hearing before the City Council's committee on general welfare at 2 o'clock this afternoon. Councilman B. Charney Vladeck, one of the sponsors of the bill, was present.

The Annalist reported yesterday that for the seventh consecutive week its index of wholesale commodity prices had declined, reaching on Wednesday 80.1, the lowest level since May 19, 1936. A week before the index was 80.3 and a year before it was 93.3.

The New York Stock Exchange membership of the late Leopold Newborg has been transferred to Eugene F. Canavan, with offices at Henry Morgan Co. The committee on admissions will ballot on May 19 on transfer of the membership of Charles F. Nichols to Frank A. Hardy; that of J. Paul Lynch to Edward Rose, who will become a general partner of Shufro, Rose Co., and that of W. T.
Tompkins, E. R., QMC., from Washington, D. C., to Army Transport Service, Fort Mason, Calif. Sterrett, R., QMC., from Chicago, Ill., to Washington Quartermaster Depot, Washington, D. C.
Being no respecters of that noble principle of never hitting a man when he is down, the Yankees toppled the hapless and last-place Browns for a clean sweep of their series at the Stadium. yesterday.

Early gifts ranging from $25,000 ed to $150,000 from corporations indicate that the Greater New York Fund's campaign goal of $10,000, 000 this month will be reached, James G. Blaine, president, declared yesterday.

The engagement of Miss Grace Hayward, daughter of Mrs. Charles Burton Hayward and the late Mr. Hayward, former Mayor of Englewood, to Lewis Mack, son of Mrs. Lewis Charles Mack and the late Mr. Mack of Somerville,, Was announced today by Mr. Hayward.

John W. Davis, former Ambassador to Great Britain and former president of the American Bar Association; Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and president of the Charity Organization Society of New York,

The 1938 British Mount Everest Expedition, arrivingsafely after an uneventful journey from Darjeeling and Gangtok, has established its base camp near the snout of the Rongbuk Glacier, twelve miles from the goal of its adventure. The seven members of the climbing party and all our porters are well.
Market closed steady and mixed after showing small gains; turnover, 687,220 shares. United States Government bonds lower, second-grade rails higher, other issues irregular; transactions, $5,256,400.

What Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain called his "act of faith" in settling Britain's long-standing differences with Ireland was endorsed by the House of Commons tonight when it approved, without division on the second reading, the bill to implement the financial terms of the AngloIrish agreement.

Pig iron production in April, according to The Iron Age, was 1,376,141 gross tons, against 1,452,487 tons in March. The daily average last month was 45,871 tons, against 46,854 tons in the preceding month. Not since 1934 has the production of pig iron fallen so low.
I am going to speak to you on the dangerous road for democracy. I wish to speak to you not as Republicans but as citizens. For these things reach to fundamentals far deeper than party labels.

Frank Gabler, former National League hurler, made a successful debut in the American League ranks today with a seven-hit performance as the White Sox hammered three Philadelphia pitchers for seventeen hits and a 10-to-4 victory.

Judge Harland B. Howe in the Federal court here today appointed George E. L. French of Rutland as receiver for the Rutland Railroad. He also granted an injunction preventing creditors from interfering with operation of the line.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O. affiliate of unlicensed merchant seamen, announced yesterday that it would be sponsor of a march on Washington by labor groups from all parts of the country to express support of President Roosevelt's recovery program.

Dr. John Russell Carty purchased from the HomeOwners Loan Corporation the one-family house at 71 Livingston Street, and E. J. McLaughlin bought the dwelling at 29 Whitson Street, Forest Hills, Queens, from the East River Savings Bank, George Campbell Updike acting as broker in both transactions.

Representatives of veterans' organizations called upon citizens of Jersey City last night to turn out in large numbers at a huge "patriotic" rally planned for tomorrow night in Journal Square in an effort to overwhelm and overawe a test meeting called by the International. Labor Defense at which two Representatives in Congress are scheduled to speak.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Celanese Corporation of America has been called for June 3 to consider a proposed issue of not more than $20,000,000 of debentures or other obligations of an unsecured nature, at such times and upon such terms as the directors may determine.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Mary Jeanne Stourton, youngest daughter of the late Major Herbert Stourton, O.B.E., and the Hon. Mrs. Stourton of Chelsea, to the Hon. Ralph Robert Watts. Sherman Stonor, only son and heir of Baron and -Baroness Camoys of Stonor Park, Oxfordshire.

For the better part of a week, until its adjournment yesterday, the annual convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States has served as a forum for the discussion of policies of the Roosevelt Administration from the point of view of business men.
Murray Levine made a nationwide appeal yesterday for the return of his 12-year-old son, Peter, kidnapped in New Rochelle on Feb. 24, and extended his offer of a $25,000 reward until June 15.

Miss Phyllis I. R. Gillespie and Alan T. Schumacher, whose marriage will take place this Summer in Newport, were guests of honor at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. John W. Delafield last night in the St. Regis Roof, which was formally opened for the season.

Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews told the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs today that the navy's goal is "to select, train and maintain the fighting personnel of officers and men of the fleet to the highest pitch in the world-not to second, but first, in comparison, with all navies of the world."
Secretary Morgenthau this afternoon invited bids on the Treasury's current weekly bill offering of $50,000,000, which will be sold to the highest bidders on the usual discount basis.

No one is likely to be surprised to learn that in reply to the question put to voters in all sections of the country in the last few weeks, "Are you better off today than you were a year ago?" a substantial majority replied that they were not.

A trial effort by leading figures of Broadway to further popularize New York and its major amusement street, as a prelude to next year's World's Fair, will be made at 5:30 P. M. today. It will take the form of an hour's program entitled "This Is New York" to be auditioned for the benefit of potential radio sponsors at the Columbia Radio Theatre, 242 West Forty-fifth Street.

A minority report, signed by the seven Republicans and one Independent on the House Interstate Commerce Committee, attacking the Lea bill which would set up a Federal civil aeronautics authority to regulate all aviation, was submitted to the House today.

Hudson Advertising Company, in 21 West St; T. C. Corwin Co., investment securities. William G. Kuss, purchasing agent, in 30 Broad St; Pyramid Corp, in 24 Stone St: Cushman Wakefield, Inc, brokers. Mildred Kuttner, hosiery, etc, in 60 Nassau St; Cornelius Ferris, in 314 Pearl St; Adolph Apter, in 52 Catharine St; Samuel Feigenbaum, fruits and produce, in- 197 Reade St; Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc, broker.

THE two big fights in prospect certainly have the fistic fans going about muttering to themselves. They can't seem to decide. Armstrong or Ross? Louis or Schmeling? Some fight followers, encountered on a Tuesday, are loud in their assertions that Hammering Hennery Armstrong will put it all over Barney Ross and that Shufflin Joe Louis will spread Herr Schmeling on the canvas.
Vice Admiral Kiyoshi Hasegawa, who returned to Tokyo today, received the Emperor's thanks and objected to the press headlining his return as a triumph. "I am making no triumphal return," he said.
Nearly 16,000 fans turned out to watch the Buffalo International Leaguers overcome an early Newark lead and fashion a 12-to-9 victory over the Bears today. The game opened the Bisons' home season.

The United Auto Workers Union demonstrated last midnight at the plant of the Michigan Steel Casting Company, which is being operated on a curtailed basis by about thirty men being housed and fed in the plant.

Action on a recommendation by a special committee of the Board of Estimate that the city's foreign trade zone or "free port" at the Stapleton piers on Staten Island be leased to the New York Foreign Trade Zone Operators, Inc., headed by Harry C. Shanks, president of the Manhattan Lighterage Company, was held up temporarily yesterday by James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx.

ARNOLD, WALTER C. (Sept. 3, 1937). Gross assets, $304,066; net, $283,626. To Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, $10,000; Edward Werring, cousin, $7,000; Dr. Arthur M. Shrady, Mabelle Lebolt, $2,000 each; Dr. Leonard Rau, $7,000; Tessie Arnold, $5,000; five varying bequests; Irene E. Snellenburg and Horace K. Horner, specific personalty and one-half residue each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $275,596. Hays, Wolf, Kaufman Schwabacher, attorneys, 30 Broad St.

The long-awaited La Guardia proposal for greater home rule for New York and other cities is now before the Constitutional Convention, although the Mayor's sponsorship of the measure is known to few of the delegates.
Purchases in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on April 30 exceeded sales by 58,125 shares, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The seventeenth anniversary of the Mother's Milk Bureau, which since its foundation has distributed 48,000-- quarts of frozen mother's milk to delicate or premature babies, was celebrated yesterday afternoon in the bureau's central station at Thirty-fourth Street and Ninth Avenue.
