As a step toward carrying out President Roosevelt's anti-monopoly program, Senator O'Mahoney introduced today a joint resolution which would authorize wide investigation of business practices.
Secretary Morgenthau plans to decentralize the entire revenue system before the year is out. In the future instead of emissaries of a distant Washington, the tax collectors will be just home folks.
The Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria was formally opened last night for the coming Summer season. The capacity of the garden was taxed by the many dinner and supper parties.

The mortgage for $35,500 on 1,125 Sixth Ave, held by the Bank of Savings from the executors of the will of Cortlandt F. Bishop was extended to April 27, 1943, at 4 1/2 per The Emigrant Bank extended for five years at 5 per cent a mortgage for $43.000 on 464 W 152d St. held from the A C Falk Realty Co., Inc.

Mayor La Guardia's views Those do not often coincide with Aztec those of the Sons and Murals Daughters of the Revolu lution. On the subject of modernist art there does seem to be agreement. Several residents of Richmond Hill have expressed much distaste for a mural depicting the original settlers of that pleasant suburban community.

Dartmouth defeated Yale in a closely fought lacrosse. contest today, 5-4. The Elis made a valiant rally after trailing by 4-1 at-the half, but a second-half goal by Kenny, a Dartmouth substitute, proved the deciding factor. Molloy and Reiter shared scoring laurels' .for the Green and the Blue, respectively, with two goals each.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

No easy or automatic victory" is in prospect for Democratic Congressional candidates in November, Postmaster James A. Farley declared here tonight in a speech in defense of the Administration's policies on recovery and relief.

Canada's foreign trade in chemicals last year ran close to sixty million dollars. A little over threefifths of the value consisted of imports, but the growth of the export trade was proportionately the greater.

The dearth" of Democrats and the absence of talk about the Civil War are among the "up North" first impressions of Guy and Gertrude Bates, 12-year-old twins, who recently arrived here as exchange pupils from Memphis, Tenn.

' Trial races to select a team of four six-meter yachts to represent the United States in the biennial British-American Cup contests will begin on Thursday, July 28, and will be followed by another series from which will emerge the defender of the Scandinavian Gold Cup.

A remarkably accurate forecast of -the way the World War actually started, made in 1912 by Sir Edward Grey, as Foreign Secretary, was revealed today in the publication of the tenth volume of a monumental compilation of British documents on the origins of the World War.

The cost of fuel oil for house heating in New York City is only slightly higher than in Philadelphia, which has the lowest cost for automatic oil house heating in the United States, according to the results of a survey announced yesterday by the Oil Burner Institute.
Lumber production declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index dropped to 54.4 from 57.2. For the week ended May 1, 1937, it was 86.0.
Three young men set out from the Battery early last evening in an eighteen-foot canoe bound for Yonkers, and, six months hence, Nome, Alaska.

Was this the face that launch'd a thousand ships and burnt the topless towers of Ilium? Alas! no, Mr. Marlowe. This was the face that Hollywood chose out of the world's loveliness and threw upon a thousand--nay, many times a thousand--screens.

The directors of the Chrysler Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, payable on June 14 to stock of record of May 16. This was the first payment ordered in 1938.

Convention, New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, Hotel Astor, 10 A. M. Address by Frank G. Arnold. Afternoon session, speakers: Dr. Stephen S. Bayne, Roma Gans, Kenneth D. Benne, Dr. Charles Russell.

Japan's grievances against the Soviet Union continue to be kept prominently before the public. Following up Tuesday's statement regarding Russian assistance to China, the Foreign Office here issued an account last evening of recent negotiations in which Japan's efforts to solve outstanding disputes were deadlocked by Soviet "insincerity."

The names of 449 applicants for admission to the bar will be sent to the various Appellate Divisions as a result of the State bar examinations which were conducted by the Board of Law Examiners oh March 15 and 16.
Five associate professors, nine assistant professors and ten instructors were announced today by President. Charles Seymour in the following faculty promotions in the Yale School of Medicine:

Trading was fair in most classes of fresh meats. Some bull sales were lower and some fresh pork cuts higher. Otherwise prices were little changed from Wednesday on non-kosher meats. All kosher meats were lower during late trading Wednesday. Kosher business was confined mostly to sales of carried-over meat at weak prices. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

John Henry Lewis, Pittsburgh Negro, who holds the world light-heavyweight boxing championship took an easy decision from Domenico Ceccarelli of Italy, the European titleholder, in a ten-round non-title bout tonight. Lewis stayed under.

Hallie Flanagan, national director of the Federal Theatre Project, and Bennett A. Cerf, president of Random House, announce that contracts have been signed whereby Random House becomes the official publisher for the Federal Theatre plays.

2d Lt. Eric H. Drexler, AG-Res., 205 Pleasant Ave., Englewood, N. J., AG. Section, Hq. 78th Division, is ordered to active duty, effective May 15, at Headquarters Newark Military District, Postoffice Building, East Orange, N. J., for training. Date of rank: May 15, 1938. He will revert to an inactive status on May 28.
Four unidentified men tonight kidnapped Felipe Rivero, publisher of a weekly magazine, Jorobemos, took him to the outskirts of the city and forced him to drink a large bottle of castor oil.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Campbell, Phelps Co., Inc., obtained yesterday $437,000 of funding, improvement and water bonds
A son, their second child, was born to Lieutenant David Wagstaff Jr., U. S. A., and Mrs. Wagstaff of Fort Riley, Kan., and Tuxedo Park, N. Y., yesterday at the Doctors Hospital, this city.

During the week ended May 4 member bank reserve balances decreased $157,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $108,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks,
George A. Bowman, for many years a real estate broker here, died yesterday morning in his apartment in the Great Northern Hotel, 118 West Fifty-seventh Street. He had been ill for several months.

The warning that the banking system must more adequately meet the credit needs of the country if it. expects to remain in private hands, which Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, uttered in Washington on Wednesday before the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, was met yesterday by Wall Street bankers with the statement that banks cannot lend if borrowers will not borrow.
The annual miracle of Spring went on formal exhibition yesterday afternoon in several gardens in the east midtown area.
In order to permit medical authorities to study the case and to verify the report that septuplets had been born to Senora Rafael Casanova Corrias at Bayama in Oriente Province Sunday,

By ROBERT FISHEL 121st St, 315 W. 5-story tenement, 25x 100.11; Frank L Well, trustee, against Land Estates, Inc, due, $23,960; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Twenty-seven students, including seven girls, will be inducted tonight into the New York University Washington Square College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, it was announced yesterday by Provost Rufus D. Smith, acting dean of the college.

Walter Huber, 20, fatally injured in a baseball game in which he represented his employer, was held by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court today to have been in the employ of his firm when the accident occurred.

The Cabinet's political and economic committees have been considering today Ambassador Stefan Osusky's report. The political committee further considered a report by Minister of the Interior Josef Cerny on the May Day celebrations and the situation in the Sudeten German area. Measures of economic assistance for the German area also were considered.

Dumping of ashes and refuse in Jamaica' Bay, as proposed by the Department of Sanitation. will cause real estate values in the vicinity to depreciate $100,000,000, it was charged by Councilman Albert D. Schanzer, Brooklyn Democrat, yesterday before the committee on rules of the City Council.

William C. Wright, former postmaster here, died today in a Stamford, Conn., hospital following an illness of several years. His age was 78. He had been clerk to the Board of Education here for twenty years.

Charlotte Girl, Elwood Sachsen maier's 2-year-old daughter of Cohort and Virginella, registered her sixth straight victory today at Pimlico in the first running of the Masquerader Stakesof .four and a half furlongs.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today clarified a ruling of April 12, 1937, in a decision restraining the Kellogg Company from using the name "shredded wheat," making the "pillow shape" type of wheat biscuits and using the trademark "Two - Biscuits - in - a - Dish."

Federal Judge William Clark will sign warrants here Monday for the removal of Ellis H. Parker Sr. of Mount Holly, suspended chief of Burlington County detectives, and his son, Ellis H., Jr., for their transfer to Brooklyn, N. Y., to face a Federal indictment charging them with the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, former Trenton lawyer.

With its 1938 fund-raising campaign well past the half-way mark, the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army announced yesterday at its final report meeting at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, that $201,148 had been solicited since March 22 by Workers under thirty divisional chairmen.

Santangelo, architect; cost, $5.000, Bronx Part of property bounded by Cromwell Ave, N Y Central Railroad right-of-way, McCombs Dam Bridge and U S Bulkhead Line, 150th St and Exterior St; 1-story

Tazio NuvoTazio Nuvolari, Italian auto ace, today announced he would not race in the 500-mile classic at Indianapolis on Decoration Day. He said he has not recovered.. sufficiently from injuries sustained recently in a race at Monza.

Once more the yearning to see for myself what lies within the areas that are now only blank white spaces on the maps has proved too strong for me. On Aug. 13 I shall leave New York on my fourth expedition to Antarctica, hoping to map from the air the largest unknown territory anywhere in the world, the Enderby Quadrant of the Antarctic continent.

This country needs more babies from healthy, intelligent parents, and fewer from those of mentally and physically weak stock, it was asserted by speakers at the annual meeting of the American Eugenics Society, at the Town Hall yesterday.

Staving off a last-period rally by the Reds, the Whites rode to a 10-9 victory in the opening practice polo match of the season on Schiff Field today. Dominating the play, the Whites had a 10-5 lead going into the last chukker,
BLACK CHRONICLE, by William Edward Hayes. (Crime Club, $2.) A mystery novel. THE CAIRO GARTER MURDERS, by Van Wyck Mason. (Crime Club, $2.) A mystery novel.

It a home run into the back yard at the home of Mrs. Charles Herman, 55, that caused trouble for the Nomidomi mushball team. When Ray Kimko, 20, went in the yard to retrieve the ball he was told by Mrs. Herman that she was going to keep it.

The board of governors of the League of New York Theatres, organization of producers and managers, decided yesterday at a meeting in its office, 234 West Fortyfourth Street, to renew its campaign for amendment of the State Liquor Laws so that bars might be installed in theatres.

We sat on the aquarium wharf early this morning and waited for the wind to die down. When we heard a hammering on our door, shortly after daylight, there was hardly a breath of wind, but we had cycled only half the seven miles to Coral Island when it began to blow.
Banks continued yesterday to unload realty holdings in Manhattan. The activity was marked by a demand for housing and business parcels in scattered sections of the city.

Employes of the emergency revenue division of the city's Finance Department who privately represent and advise taxpayers in preparing and filing tax returns were severely criticized yesterday in a presentment handed up by the December Kings County grand jury,

A heated argument in court last Wednesday between Federal Judge Murray Hulbert and Colonel Lewis Landis, defense counsel in the trial of twenty-five men and women accused of being members of a nationwide narcotic smuggling ring, resulted yesterday in a mistrial.

George Bainton Watts, 35 -years old, sales manager of the Canadian Division of Calvin Bullock, investment brokerage concern in New York, died today at his home here. His widow, the former Elizabeth Ball of Pelham, N. Y., told police he suffered an accidental injury on Tuesday while returning from a business trip in the West.

The liquor industry at present is afflicted by "too much bickering and too many disputing factions," and unless a unified force for betterment of industry conditions develops, there is danger of "a stampede back to prohibition," Senator James J. Crawford warned about 1,000 members of the industry at a dinner last night at the Hotel Astor.

Factional strife among Democrats in State offices was emphasized today with a formal demand by F. Clair Ross, State Treasurer, that Attorney General Guy K. Bard investigate the unemployment compensation division of the Department of Labor and Industry.

As part of Yale University's contribution to New Haven's tercentenary celebration, four lectures have been arranged at the Yale Gallery of Fine Arts. The first of these, given yesterday by Theodore Sizer, discussed the painters of New Haven. The second lecture,

Claude T. Barnes of Salt Lake City, Utah, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Kathleen Barnes, to Eugene M. Zuckert of Stamford, Conn., and this city, an attorney on the staff of the generaI counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission here.

" The Little Entente once again has proved its vitality and will continue to work in the cause of peace." In these words Foreign Minister Nicolas Petrescu-Comnen of Rumania summed up the conference to the foreign press when it closed today.

The Chevrolet small parts plant here, closed Tuesday by what officials of the United Automobile Workers termed a "wildcat" strike, reopened today, and E. S. Wellock, plant manager, reported that all except 280 of the 1,100 employes returned to work.
Crossing the frontier on his return trip by special train at noon today, Jose Maria Cantilo, Argentine Foreign Minister, brought to a close a successful five-day visit to Chile.

A general seamen's strike threatens to tie up this port over the dispute between the liner Champlain's officers and crew, which, although announced as settled early this morning, again arose after the vessel had been made ready to sail for New York ten hours late.
" Spring Fever" is the name given to this year's annual supper dance of the Junior League of Brooklyn, which takes place tomorrow night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.
The Marine Corps announced the following changes during the week ended May 4: BRIGADIER GENERAL Putnam, R. B., appointed paymaster, Marine Corps, rank o brigadier general for four years from May 1.

Miss Jane Preston, daughter of Mrs. George Hyde Preston of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Preston, was married to Lloyd Westbrook, son of Mrs. Richard Ward Westbrook, also of New Canaan, and the late Mr. Westbrook, yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's aunt, Miss Adeline G. Wykes, at 205 East Sixtyninth Street.

Comparison of the awards for engineering construction made in the four weeks of April this year with the five weeks of April, 1937, reveals a gain, on a weekly average basis, of 11 per cent this year, according to The Engineering NewsRecord. The 1938 total was $193,

None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low position for the year. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."

Wilfred boel Hughes Fritts, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home at 135 Belmont Avenue. His age was 33. He had been a member of the brokerage house of E. Lowitz Co., 29 Broadway, New York, since 1935.
The poker game in which Lew Brice won -$150,000 from Harry Clifton turned out today to have been profitless.

France today agreed to reimpose international control along the Franco-Spanish frontier to prevent the passage of men or materials into Spain as soon as two commissions arrive to supervise withdrawal of foreign "volunteers" in the fighting forces.

Reports from the Yugoslav frontier today indicate that forty-three Austrian Jews, stripped of all possessions, were sent to the frontier to the triangular patch of no man's land between Austria, Hungary and Yugoslavia near Murska Subota, on Yugoslav territory. There they were crowded into a small Alpine hut above the snow line.

Mr. and Mrs. Grover Loening have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Palm Beach. Mrs. Amos L. Beaty is returning today to 30 Sutton Place from Houston, Texas, where she passed the Winter and early Spring. Mr. Beaty will join her-later in the month.

Holding that recent actions of the Labor Board were tantamount to public admissions that its proceedings had not been fair and impartial, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today demanded repeal or drastic modification of the National Labor Relations Act.
On his own application, to take effect 12 noon, May 16: PATROLMAN--Luie C. McMahon, 13th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Nov. 4, 1909.

Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker refused today to interfere with the plan of the city of Newark to sell $1,606,000 in bonds to reimburse current funds by that amount spent last year for relief.

All political eyes in Britain were turned today toward Lichfield, a large parliamentary constituency near Birmingham, as 80,000 Britons were registering their attitude on Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's policies.
J. A. Perkins, acting Minister of Customs, introduced a tariff schedule in the House of Representatives today increasing the duties on eighteen items.

The marriage of Miss Jean Armstrong Ryder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Herbert Ryder of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., to Dwight Hummel Holbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hurd Holbert of Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y., will take place on May 28 in the Church of the Mediator, kingsbridge. The ceremony will be performed by the rector, the Rev. Charles Flint Kellogg.
The Copper Range Company operated at a slight profit in the first four months of this year, F. W. Paine, treasurer, said at the annual meeting held in Boston yesterday.

The Maritime Commission has accepted bids for the construction of eight of twelve steel cargo ships for operation in the foreign trade. The bids were made by the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Kearny, N. J., and the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Chester, Pa.
President Getulio Vargas. issued a decree today allowing foreigners who are in the country illegally 120 days to appear before immigration officials and have, their immigration papers recorded.
Mrs. Otto Hahn, for many years president of the Home Makers Forum, presided yesterday at the luncheon at the Hotel New Yorker celebrating the silver anniversary of the group.

Notwithstanding New York's "hands off" policy toward the newly-formed International Boxing Association, working machinery has been set in motion to bring about the closest approach to universal pugilistic control since punch-tossing was legalized anywhere.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are May 5 unless specified. Arctic, at San Diego. Babbitt, Nassau, Bahamas. to Norfolk. Canopus, Makassar to Bali. Dunlap, at Navy Yard, New York. Edsall, Chefoo to Tringtao. Nitro, at Navy Yard,. Mare Island. Peco, Southern Philippines to Manila. Pigeon, Makassar to Bali. Quincy, at Navy Yard, Mare Island, April 30.
Baseball's Baseball's one and only Dizzy Dean worked out like a lowly rookie today, with his $185,000 arm just so much excess baggage.
Earle Martin, former editor of several Ohio and Indiana newspapers, died tonight after several months' Illness. His age was 63.
Repercussions of the disciplining of Luke Hamlin were heard through the Dodgers' camp today while Burleigh Grimes's Brooklyn crew went about losing a ball game to the Pirates by a score of 4 to 2.

A warning to the dictator-controlled nations of the world that democratic countries might some day get enough of their provocations and resort to war was sounded here today by Secretary of War Woodring, speaker at the annual convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Life Insurance payments in the United States and Canada totaled $2,854,771,623 in 1937, The National Underwriter reported yesterday. New York led the States with $495,000,000, a per capital payment of $38.26.

A decrease of $3,938,000 in the deposits of chartered banks was shown today in the statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday. Dominion Government deposits decreased by $6,869,000, while note circulation increased by $771.000.
Johnny Stone banged out a home run with the bases loaded today as the Senators beat the Indians, 8 to 6. The victory gave Washington the series, two games to one.
Princeton handed North Carolina's powerful tennis team its second defeat in two days by setting back the Tar Heels, 5-4, on the Church courts today.

In another demonstration of tremendous batting power the touring Australian cricketers today declared their first innings against Oxford University after scoring 697 runs for seven wickets. Last week in their opening match the visitors defeated Worcestershire by an innings and 77 runs, hitting 541.

Judge Walter J. McIntire in Second Criminal Court here issued warrants today for the arrest of 'William A. Alberts, Paramus recorder and justice of the peace, on a charge of embezzling $2,900 in State's motor vehicle fines.

In a "warming up" drill before the start of the air manoeuvres in defense of the Eastern seacoast next Wednesday, the United States Army Air Corps will "strafe" Army ground forces tomorrow for target practice at four points in New York State.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Burkhard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marion G. Burkhard of this place, to Robert E. Snowden Jr., also of Garden City, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Snowden, will take place the morning of May 28 at Christ's First Presbyterian Church, Hempstead. The Rev. Frederick M.
Henry J. Topping Jr., heir to a fortune, filed today divorce action against Jayne Shadduck, 22year-old actress, in Superior Court, charging, intolerable cruelty.

The Associated Gas and Electric System announced yesterday that additional changes have been made in its program of corporate simplification. The latest moves have brought to 358 the total of companies in the system, the separate existence of which "it has been found possible to do without."

Even when his own life did not matter to him any longer, William H. Lindeman, 55-year-old animal dealer, thought of his wire-haired dachshund, Mr. Snookums, before turning on the gas in the kitchen of his apartment at 63 West Eleventh Street.
The announcement by Premier Edouard Daladier of France of a new exchange value for the franc was received in the foreign exchange market here yesterday with the utmost calm.

A six-run outburst in the sixth frame enabled the Bryant High nine to beat Grover Cleveland High, 8 to 3, in a Section A,. Queens P. S. A. L., battle at Bradley Oval yesterday. The victory was the first in four league starts for Bryant.

Negotiations are pending for the purchase by the Bethelehem Steel Company of the old W. A. Fletcher drydock plant in Hoboken from the United Shipyards. The property is located on the east side of Hudson Street, extending from Twelfth to Fourteenth Streets, and from Hudson Street out into the Hudson River to the exterior line for piers.

CHARLES DARWIN shook the world. You would not expect that of such a mild man. Yet the world has probably never been quite the same since that small, green, monkey-haunted and strangely revolutionary book, "The Origin of Species," was first published nearly eighty years ago.

Attributing the success of the life insurance business in the past to "the American agency system," 0. Sam Cummings of Dallas, Texas, president of the National Association of Life Underwriters, said that the encroachment of government in this field would be "a detriment to the American people."

Delegates to the annual convention of the Pennsylvania Dental Society were told today that soil erosion was indirectly responsible for increased tooth decay among the American people. Plants growing on impoverished soil, said 'Dr. Fred Miller, president of the society, were deficient in calcium, phosphorus and other minerals necessary for sound teeth.

The Coast Guard announced the following changes for the week ended May 4: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER H. H. Curry, Headquarters, to Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Co., East Pittsburgh, Pa., in connection with inspection and construction of machinery.

Executors of Elizabeth H. Stanton's estate and holders of securities of the Jersey Coast Ferry Company today asked the Supreme Court to review a decision of the New York Supreme Court denying them, they said, the return by New York City of certain securities.

The Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce, which has had its appropriation reduced to less than half what it was in 1932, is ready and able to advise the Administration on dangerous economic trends and to suggest corrective measures, Dr. Alexander V. Dye, director, said today.
It was officially announced today that King Leopold of the Belgians has accepted Crown Princess Juliana's invitation to be one of the godfathers at the christening of Princess Beatrix here next week.

Junior employes of the New York Stock Exchange were in the saddle yesterday, discussing the striking of low-priced issues from the list, arguing over possible reduction of membership and overruling the appeal of a customer from a decision of the business conduct committee.

The list of the Holland-America liner Veendam, sailing today for the Channel ports, includes OssianLong, Count Giovanni Gregorini Bingham, Baroness M. E. M. van Heeckeren, Baroness W. M. van Heeckeren, John Brey, Mrs. G. M. Bodvin,,Miss Edith W. Cooper, Alfred G. Gumpel, Professor and Mrs. A. A. Hayes and Miss Jacqueline Gibbins.

Operations in the world wheat markets were restricted considerably today, resulting in erratic price changes. Liquidation by holders of .old crop futures in Winnipeg had a depressing effect on domestic markets, closing trades on the Board of Trade here showing net losses of 1/2 to 7/8 cent a bushel, the latter on the May.

The campaign of Markets Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. to rid the streets of itinerant peddlers received a set-back yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler ruled that the department could not Withhold licenses solely on the ground that the commissioner believed itinerant vendors constituted a health and traffic menace.

Asserting that Newark, with its port and airport, had been "slighted" in literature advertising the New York 1939 World's Fair, the Newark City Commission urged the State of New Jersey yesterday to return the slight by "advertising at the Golden Gate International Exposition in San Francisco in 1939 rather than at the New York World's Fair."

The franc stabilization move acted like a hypodermic today on the Bourse, which had its liveliest session for a long time. Rentes gained from 2 to 4 francs and domestic stocks rose rapidly as the first exported capital came back to France upon the government's promise that the franc would not be allowed to drop below 179 to the pound sterling.

Making his first appointment of the meeting after a rest from his Florida. campaign, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's 6-year-old Chilean horse Caballero II ran an impressive race at Jamaica yesterday to capture the Fayette Handicap at six furlongs and defeat a small field of good ??.
The average furniture business being done at the midseason market in the Merchandise Mart, which was opened on Monday for a week's run, was reported today as level with that in May, 1936.

The committee convoked by the League of Nations Assembly last September to consider reorganizing and widening the League's financial and economic organization began work today by finding that recent events had practically eliminated all hope of obtaining German and Italian cooperation.
Domestic corporation bonds moved irregularly higher in somewhat more active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

A possoble clue to the causeof epidemics of uch diseases as diphtheria, influnza, cholera and yellow fever was indicated here today in a report on the peculiar activites of a small organism known as micrococus etrageenus.

William Duncan Green, former president of William Green, Inc., New York printing house, died of a heart ailment yesterday at his home here at the age of 50. For the last three years he was associated with the Kalkoff Press of New York.
Edward Ralph Henry Grueriewald, president of the Alaska Chemical Corporation of North Bergen, N. J., rind New York, died at his resort home last night after a brief illness. His age was 58.

Mrs. Grace Noll Crowell, poet laureate of Texas and the "American mother of 1938," urged modern mothers today to recognize their moral responsibilities and instil religion in their children "from the cradle up."

Reports that the Mexican Secretary of Finance, Eduardo R. Suarez, was resigning were persistent today despite semi-official denials. It is expected that a decision regarding his continuance in the Cabinet will be made tomorrow.

Raoul E. Desvernine, a member of the law firm of Miller, Owen, Otis Bailly or its predecessor firm for twenty years, has been elected president of the Crucible Steel Company of America, it was announced yesterday by F. B. Hufnagel, chairman of the board.

Plans for a three-year maintenance and extension fund of $200,000 to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary program of the Child Study Association of America were disclosed yesterday at a meeting and tea held at the Bank of the Manhattan Company, Madison Avenue at Sixtyfourth Street.

Mrs. Jean E. Poletti, president of the New York State League of Women Voters, said today that she would disassociate herself from the Constitutional Convention, to which her husband, Charles J. Poletti, State Supreme Court Justice, is a delegate at-large.
In a Washington dispatch appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning, statements made by Secretary Roper at his press conference yesterday were erroneously attributed to Secretary Morgenthau.

Carl von Ossietzky died in Berlin while two dictators were conferring in Rome. The later years of his career were one long irony. He fought for peace and democracy as Central Europe swung again into the goose-step.

Dismissal of the complaint of Representative Arthur W. Mitchell of In Chicago, only Negro member of Congress, charging that the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway in April, 1937, failed to provide accommodations for Negro passengers comparable with those provided for .white persons, was urge upon the Interstate Commerce Commission today in a report by Examiner William A. Disque.

Replying to the attack made on industrial unionism yesterday by W. S. Knudsen, president of General Motors Corporation, Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, asserted today that it was "quite natural" for Mr. Knudsen to suspect the union of having "strong-arm squads."

Mr. and Mrs. Victor Charles Gilpin of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoria Ruth Elaine Gilpin, to Donald Glenn Neilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Andrew Neilson, also of Brooklyn, formerly of Buffalo.

The Senate Lobby Committee broadened its investigation of alleged "propaganda" against Roosevelt policies today by summoning Maurice V. Reynolds of Chicago, publisher of The Rural Progress, to testify tomorrow about material printed in his magazine.

To promote the organization of more Boy Scout troops for Jewish youths, the Jewish Advisory Committee for Boy Scouting in GreaterNew York was organized yesterday afternoon at a meeting in the office of Kuhn, Loeb Co., 52 William Street.

More rapid progress might have been made in effecting railway economies by cooperation between the Canadian National and the Canadian Pacific, S. W. Fairweather, director of the Canadian National's bureau of economics, testified today before the special Senate committee on railway conditions in Canada.

The Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York and Vicinity by vote of its delegates last night, ordered its affiliates to withdraw support from the American Labor Party as the New York State branch of Labor's Nonpartisan League.

Mayor La Guardia, who has hitherto appeared in public as an orchestra conductor, will make his debut as a music commentator on..a symphonic program to be broadcast by radio station WNYC from the WPA Federal Music Theatre, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street, on Sunday at 1:30 P. M., it was announced yesterday.
Count Rene Doynel de SaintQuentin, French Ambassador to the United States, yesterday assailed "certain American newspapers" for distorting the news from France.
Emil Dickman, for forty years a practicing lawyer in New York and Brooklyn, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 942 East Ninth Street, Brooklyn. His age was 64.

Countess Haugwitz-Reventlow, the former Barbara Hutton, established two- trust funds with total assets valued at $2,251,189, for her former husband, Prince Alexis Mdivani, on Jan. 2, 1934, about seven months after their marriage, it was -disclosed yesterday in a. transfer tax appraisal of the Prince's estate.
Wall Street's prognostications occasionally go astray, but seldom, if ever, have they erred so considerably as in the case of the Chrysler Corporation's first-quarter results.

Emanuel List, basso of the Metropolitan Opera, will sail on the Vulcania'tonight.- He will visit Budapest and-then-go to Prague, where he will sing in "Tristan und Isolde," "Die Entfuehrung des Serail" and "The Magic Flute."

Members of seven Winter sports teams of the United States Military Academy won awards, upon recommendation of the athletic board, according to special orders published today. A total of 131 cadets received athletic insignia in basketball, boxing, fencing, -gymnastics, polo, hockey and swimming.
The French Government fixed the minimum rate for the franc today at 179 francs to the pound sterling, equivalent to 2.79 cents, or 35.8 francs to the dollar.
Jim Bruen, big, plump youngster who won't be 18 until Sunday, loomed tonight as Great Britain's new Walker Cup golf hope.

Miss Helen Strype, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Culver Strype of this place, was married here at noon. today in the Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel to Lieut. Comdr. Victor A. Link. U. S. N. R.,

Giuseppe Scullio, 20-year-old newsboy, had $100 saved up and decided to bet it on the favorite horse in the feature race at Suffolk Downs. He bought a ticket, using the position number given on a scratch sheet instead of the official program.

First prize of $5,000 for a streamlined four-lane elevated highway was awarded last night to Hazelet Erdal, consulting engineers of Chicago, in the elevated highway design competition sponsored by the American Institute of Steel Construction. The second prize went to Madigan- Hyland,
Three dwellings, a taxpayer and a community center and school are among new buildings planned for sites sold yesterday in the Bronx.

A special courier delivered a pouch of White House mail to President Roosevelt, aboard the cruiser Philadelphia, at anchor off el Morro at the entrance of San Juan harbor at 7 o'clock this morning, more than two hours before the President awoke.

While Chancellor Hitler is implementing his political triumph by his spectacular visit to Italy, the government announced today an almost equally spectacular triumph when it raised its latest public 1,000,000,000-mark loan by almost half the original amount to a total of 1,450,000,000 marks in order to meet the large oversubscription and to satisfy the "urgent demand" for its bonds.
Head Coach Ed Leader supervised a final rowing practice on the Housatonic today and then selected the varsity crew for the regatta in Philadelphia Saturday with Columbia and Pennsylvania.

Outlays by the Standard Gas and Electric Company system for construction, renewal and replacement purposes during 1937 amounted to $33,092,715, and in the current year the corporation expects to utilize $33,979,000 for capital expenditures. These figures are contained in the 1937 annual report, which was mailed yesterday to security holders.

Eight members of the junior class at Manhattan College have been appointed to the staff of the 1939 Manhattanite, senior yearbook, it was announced yesterday by David Lawrence, editor. They are James F. McDonald Jr., managing editor; Daniel C. Furst Jr., sports editor; Peter S. Carberry,

Hunts Point Ave (10-2762), n e cor of Lafayette Ave. 154x86; Manufacturers Trust Co to Abraham S. Genvert, 444 Central Park West. Arnow Ave (16-4761-4525), s e cor of Pearsall Ave, 25x100; Arnow Ave, s w cor of Thropp Ave, 25x100; Irving P. Pavis to John J. Talcsik, 3,210 Perry Ave.

Dog lovers everywhere will have a kiss. We read with mixed emotions our dispatch Have we announcing the exile of one of the most the tide pas famous packs of dogs in the world has grown u from the Great St. Bernard pass to the has faded a

Johnson Johnson of New Brunswick, N. J.; the Kendall Company, Walpole, Mass., and the Bay, Company, Bridgeport, Conn., the three companies manufacturing approximately 85 per cent of the national production of medical supplies such as-gauze bandages, bandage rolls, cotton sponges, napkins, pads and adhesives, have been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with unfair competition through a pricefixing agreement, the commission announced today.

Henry Armstrong weighed 142 pounds as he started training at Pompton Lakes, N. Y., yesterday in preparation for his world welterweight championship bout with Barney Ross over the fifteen-round route in the Garden Bowl on May 26.

Two non-union taxicab drivers were beaten and about twenty-five empty taxicabs were damaged in a series of widely separated incidents yesterday, which the police attributed to the efforts of the Allied Taxicab Company, a combination of five independent companies, to operate with non-union drivers.
Octavian Goga, who for fiftythree days headed an anti-Semitic Government in Rumania, was stricken with apoplexy at his estate in Transylvania last night.

Installment sales at retail in March declined 42.3 per cent below March of last year and for the first quarter of 1938 dropped 33 per cent under the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by A. W. Zelomek, economist for the International Statistical Bureau.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today he would define the position of the State Department definitely with regard to the resolution of Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota for lifting the arms embargo against Loyalist Spain in a communication soon in response to one from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee asking for an expression of opinion.
The La Follette third-party movement was more likely to retard, if not to wreck the cause of liberalism in this country than to advance it, Secretary Ickes asserted today.

Another sharp break in the French franc precipitated further selling on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices lost 5 to 8 points. With the dollar buying about 35 francs, investments here were reported being returned to France.

Starting in the Summer of 1939, the school system of this city will get between $1,250,000 and $1,500,000 each year in the form of additional State aid, George H. Chatfield, director of the bureau of attendance, disclosed yesterday.

The Senate took another step today toward complete elimination of double liability of stockholders in closed banks. It voted to amend the deposit insurance section of the Federal Reserve Act so that stockholders of banks which are closed in the future will not be subject to double liability claims by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
Ray Volpi, Manhattan's ace hurler registered his fourth triumph of the season as he shut out Long Island University, 7 to 0, at Dexter Park yesterday.

The Foreign Ministers of Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Yugoslavia, as they meet in the mountain resort of Sinaia, must look back sadly on the good old days when the reunions of the Little Entente virtually dictated the policies of Central Europe.
The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders dated May 3. CAPTAIN Goodhue, E. E., detached Portsmouth, N. H., to Navy Yard, Boston, Mass

First in the drug field to take up the cudgels for proprietary laxatives against the competition from bran cereal products, the Schering Corporation, Bloomfield, N. J., makers of Saraka, a bulk laxative, will launch an anti-bran campaign in drug trade papers, using full pages.

Mrs. Marion R, Earl, in 18 E 65th St; John W. Ahearn, in 21 E 66th St; Dr. Charles V. Morrill, in 157 E 72d St; Benjamin g. Fincke, in 55 e 86th St; Harold P. Kurzman, in 108 E 91st St; Mary K. Murtha, in 130 E 94th St; Robert C. Hardy, in 1,150 5th Ave; Thomas M. Russell, in 1,331 Madison Ave;

Mayor La Guardia resubmitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday with his veto the action taken by the board last week approving a project of Park Commissioner Robert Moses to acquire land on the northerly side of East 103d Street at the East River for a park and eventually the terminus of a footbridge over the Harlem River to park areas that are being developed on Wards Island.
Representative Crawford, Republican, of Michigan, today offered a bill appropriating $173,000 "to meet the crisis" in the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the Justice Department.

Stagehand, the future book favorite, was withdrawn today from the sixtyfourth Kentucky Derby by his owner, Maxwell Howard. The official announcement from Trainer Earl Sande reduced the prospective field to ten, the smallest in twenty years, and left Fighting Fox the probable public choice for Saturday's $50,000 test.
Business in the Pittsburgh district fell to new low levels for the year last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

The fire on the liner Lafayette will cost Lloyd's of London nearly $2,000,000, it was learned today. Since the ship was insured for about ??700,00, of which about half was held here, the fire may prove to be the costliest disaster that underwriters will have to face during the first half of this year.
At the organization meeting yesterday of directors of the Consolidated Coppermines Corporation, Boudinot Atterbury was elected president and Philip L. Carret a vice president.

Miss Lisa Lawrence Renshaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Renshaw of 120 East End Avenue and New Canaan, Conn., has chosen May 28 for her marriage to Charles Henry Mills Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mills of Dongan Hills, S. I. The ceremony will take place in St. Mark's Church, New Canaan.

The general level of wholesale prices dedined in the week ended on April 30, according to an announcement today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, was 78.3 compared with 78.6 on April 23, and 87.4 on May 1, 1937.
Miss Margaret Cotter's veteran jumper, Rocksie, carried off two events today at the opening of the Washington Horse Show at Mead Brook in near-by Maryland.

Odds against H. E. Morriss's Pasch winning the Derby June 1 were shortened to night at the Victoria Club callover when the Two Thousand Guineas winner was quoted at 9 to 4. In the last callover Monday the colt was backed at 5 to 2.

The Cubs presented rookie Paul Epperly with twelve runs in the eighth inning today, but the 20-year-old pitcher up from Moline of the Three-Eye League did not need them to defeat the Phillies, 21 to 2, in his maJor league debut.

A resolution condemning the government's public works program as a measure likely to cause ultimate serious impairment of national credit, and calling for the revision of such "harmful" measures as the undistributed profits tax and the "inequitable" National Labor Relations Act, was adopted unanimously yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at its annual meeting.

A bill authorizing President Roosevelt to bestow medals on four British naval officers for "courageous action and cooperation" in aiding the survivors of the U. S. S. Panay, which was sunk by the Japanese in the Yangtze River, was passed today by the Senate.

"' Better dead than the Habsburgs,' was the Austrian National Socialist slogan during the fateful days following the Berchtesgaden interview and Hitler's final triumph," announced Upper Austrian Nazi leader August Eigruber in a speech at Steyr yesterday.

Frank Carmen, 35 years old, of 167 West Twentieth Street, Bayonne, N.-J., was sentenced today by Common Pleas Judge James R. Erwin, sitting in Common Pleas Court here, to serve two to ten years in State's prison after pleading guilty to a charge of bigamy.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, received the medal awarded annually by the New York Academy of Publie Education for "distinguished services in the field of public education", at a dinner last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Debreczen customs officials recently received orders not to shave their mustaches. Several of them refused to obey the order, but it was disclosed that a law, passed in 1890, prohibits shaving mustaches. The officials are asking the Minister of Finance to repeal the law.

J. J. Lordi and J. W. Callaghan of the New York A. C. subdued Vincent Furno and F. J. Podesta of the Columbia Club, 16-17, 15-12, 15-13,, 15-12, in a quarter-final match of the Mixsell Cup squash tennis doubles tournament at the Heights Casino yesterday.

State's Attorney Lorin W. Willis announced tonight that Mrs. Nellie M. Joyce had informed him through counsel that she would leave Florida to return north and surrender for arrest here on bench warrants based on two grand jury indictments of common law conspiracy to defraud the State on Merritt Parkway land sales.

Higher price items continue to show sharp declines under a year ago in retail trade and their dollar volume will be a major factor in the late Summer results when August sales are held, retail executives here said yesterday.

The fed steer and yearling market strengthened today when the run dwindled to starvation proportion, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. The killing condition, however, was better and the general opinion was that any improvement today was not a reflection of the undertone to the trade. Hogs and lambs sold weak to lower on moderately increased supplies.
Dr. Joseph F. Thorning, Professor of Sociology and Social History at Mount St. Mary's College, Emmitsburg, Md., will sail for Europe tonight on the Vulcania of the Italian Line.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your issue of April 30 carried a letter from I. Maurice Wormser opposing provision by the Constitutional Convention for an automobile accident compensation plan on the lines of the Workmen's Compensation Law.

Dr. William Lathrop Love, a physician and former. State - Senator from Brooklyn, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Judge Marcus B. Campbell in Brooklyn Federal Court to an indictment charging him with having sent scurrilous and defamatory matter through the mails. He was released in $1,000 bail for trial May 24.
Mrs. John- N. Ledbetter Jr., president of the Junior Auxiliary of the Silver Cross Day Nursery, gave a luncheon at her home here today before the annual meeting of the auxiliary

Breaking with other Westchester County Republican leaders, David S. Murden, Republican chairman of the town of Cortlandt for the last nine years, wrote today to County Chairman Charles H. Griffiths that William F. Bleakley of Yonkers was a "meddler" and should not have been endorsed for County President.
Senator Minton, Democrat of Indiana, said today that he would not press for action on a bill he introduced last week to penalize- newspaper publishers who printed as fact material known to be false.

JOY OF LIVING, based on a story by Dorothy and Herbert Fields: screen play by Gene Towne, Graham Baker and Allen Scott; music by Jerome Kern, with lyrics by Dorothy Fields;'directed by Tay Garnett for RKO Radio. At the Radio City Music Hall.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson denied yesterday the application of the Manhattan Railway Company for an injunction restraining the city from further advertisement of Its proposed sale of a tax lien of $9,722,000 against the company's real estate and special franchises.

Herbert Hoover told a "grass roots" convention of Oklahoma Republicans tonight that "despite every alibi" the present depression was the result of government actions, warned that the New Deal had been "following that dangerous road for democracy that led to disaster in Europe," and recommended eleven immediate steps that "would at least be a start on a saner and more cheerful road."

BRENNER, ANNIE (April 26). Estate, more than $10,000. To St. Joseph's School for the Deaf, Eastern Blvd. and 177th St.; Catholic Institute for the Blind, Paulding Ave., both Bronx, and the Rev. George Watkins, Sanford, N. C., $1,000 each; Church of St. Francis Xavier and St. Vincent's Hospital, $50 each; two specific bequests. Ethel Annie Klenk, 136 W. 13th St., residue. executrix.

Ontario Paper Company, subsidiary of The Chicago Tribune, announced here today that the official opening of the company's new mill at Baie Comeau will be held June 11, with leading Canadian public men invited to the event.

Financial newspaper men of New York City will give a dinner to Charles R. Gay, retiring president of the New York Stock Exchange, at the Hotel New Yorker on May 18. Indications are that between forty and fifty will attend.
To John Russell Thompson of Bronxville, N. Y., managing editor of The Yale Daily News, was awarded today the Clare Fellowship, which provides a two-year course of study in Clare College,
An amendment to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation Act broadening the power of the RFC to make loans to railroads was reported favorably today to the Senate by its Banking and Currency Committee.
Voters of 177 municipalities located in thirty-six States approved during April municipal bond issues aggregating $12,502,390, compared with $12,132,590 in March, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.

The entire conception of "the Cliveden set," which many Britons picture as a pro-Nazi and pro-Fascist group influencing British foreign policy at country week-ends on the upper Thames, is "a myth," according to a letter written by Viscount Astor, the owner of Cliveden, published in The Times of London yesterday.
Melio Bettina of Beacon, N. Y., knocked out James J. Johnson of Harlem in the feature bout at the Hippodrome last night. It was the closing show of the season at the Sixth Avenue arena.
Twenty-nine events have been scheduled for the closing days, beginning tomorrow, of the fifteenth season of the Music Education League, it was announced yesterday by Isabel Lowden, president.

Replying to a demand by Senator John J. McNaboe that District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey investigate the death of Mrs. Angeline Guidi of 542 East 139th Street in the psychopathic ward of Bellevue Hospital, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, made public yesterday a report of an inquiry made by a special committee from the Bellevue Hospital medical board.

Some of the insiders in the frequently stalled negotiations between the Tennessee Valley Authority and the public utilities operating in its territory have begun timidly to express the belief that an early settlement is possible.

Johann Sebastian Bach's "Passion According to St. Matthew" was performed by the Oratorio Society of New York, under Albert Stoessel, yesterday afternoon and evening in the nave. of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where it was heard with rapt attention by an audience of some 4,000 persons.
Maurice Cohen, vice president of the management division of E. Osborne Smith, Inc., has been appointed to the Bronx section of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement.

Darmy Riordan, a sandy-haired lad of 12; prize-winner in a letterwriting contest on why the midtown section of Manhattan should have open-air pools, appeared before the Board of Estimate yesterday with a petition bearing -10,000 names and read his $5 letter.
The National Executive Committee of the British Labor party today cast a damper on Leftist agitation for an all-party anti-Chamberlain alliance by refusing flatly to join any kind of popular front.

The Bees swarmed on rookie Max Macon and veteran Guy Bush for nine hits, one a homer, in the fifth and sixth innings today to take the final game of their first series of the season with the Cardinals, 5 to 2.

The government obtained permission yesterday from Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe to bring foreclosure proceedings in admiralty court against four steamships owned by the Munson Steamship Company, now in receivership.

Representatives of five European countries will open a three-day discussion of Central European affairs tonight at the Danubian Congress at Fordham University. The congress will investigate the possibilities of a political and economic rapprochement among the Danubiam States and the consequences of Austro-German Anschluss.
Following are textual extracts from the resolutions adopted by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States at the end of its annual meeting today:

Business properties formed the bulk of realty in Brooklyn reported yesterday under new control as the result of sales and leases. The Kings Highway Savings Bank sold to a client of William Liss and William Rankell, brokers, the twostory building at 2,925 Avenue P, northwest corner of Nostrand Avenue.

The uniform bank examination, on which the three Federal bank examining agencies have been working several weeks, will be submitted to State bank supervisory officials with the hope that for the first time uniform bank examinations may be used throughout the country, Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury said today at his press conference.

United Shipyards, Inc., had a net loss of $665,441 last year, according to the annual report to stockholders published yesterday. Listed as contributing to the loss were a wage increase of 11 per cent, a port-wide strike of shipyard and ship repair employes for ten weeks in midSummer, a write-down of inventory and losses sustained on the construction of two naval destroyers and three municipal ferryboats.

Although public opinion still does not favor the New Deal theory of spending our way out of depression, there has been some increase in sentiment for Federal pumppriming since President Roosevelt's fireside chat April 14.
The arrest of all six officials of the corporation operating the Nazi Summer camp at Yaphank, L. I., was ordered yesterday on complaint of the Disabled War Veterans of America.
Large shifts in their loans and investments were reported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, in their condition statement issued yesterday.

Retired Engineer of Steamer William J. O'Brien, formerly a member of Engine 47, residing at 414 West 124th St., Manhattan, died May 4. Funeral will take place from funeral parlors of W. J. Dargeon, 954 Amsterdam Ave, Manhattan, at 9:30 A. M., Saturday, May 7. The deputy chief of the Fourth Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

The Giants were fighting the Reds tooth and nail today when something happened that practically knocked all their teeth loose at a single blow. With the score 2-all in the eighth, two out and two pairs of Redlegs on the bases, Melvin Ott; of all people, made a wild throw that was both tremendous and devastating.

Pennsylvania Republicans, as yet hardly exemplars of brotherly love, are chuckling over the row among their Democratic brethren. Whether their hopes are justified or not, they may be more substantial than the registration figures for this year collected by The Associated Press. According to these,
War Minister Leslie Hore-Belisha announced today he would raise an army of women as part of the British war machine he is rebuilding.

George Pullman Lowden, son of Frank Lowden, former Illinois Governor, married Grace Darling Cook, formerly of Chicago, now of Augusta, Ga., today. Probate Judge James Parker performed the ceremony immediately after issuing the license.

Dana B. Hellings, Buffalo attorney, was elected and installed yesterday as Grand Master. of. the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York as its 157th annual communication drew to a close.

Before a crowd of 13,000, Blind Eagle and Finance, stake hopefuls from the stable of Mrs. Emil Denemark of Chicago, today warmed. up for important engagements with contrasting. results in the Newton Purse and the Cambridge Purse--Co-features at Suffolk Downs.

Opera came to Rockefeller Center last night when the San Carlo Opera Company, directed by Fortune Gallo, opened a short season at the Center Theatre with "Aida." A large audience, drawn not only by Verdi's hardy perennial but by the subdued sumptuousness of the theatre, attended the performance.
Edgar B. Landis was elected president of the honorary business fraternity, Beta Gamma Sigma Alumni of New York, at the group's annual meeting last night at the George Wahington Hotel.

Creamy cheese in-crocks, crusty cheeses in tinfoil, loaves and cakes of red and yellow and white cheeses, all have come out of their showcases for display and sampling in outstanding cheese shops of the city. It is what the merchants describe as the opening of the "1938 Summer season."
Leonard Moore Davis, noted painter, died here yesterday at the age of 74.
Stimulated by a sharp advance in the stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved by almost $1 a bale yesterday to end with net gains of 12 to 13 points.

The House Ways and Means Committee today favorably reported a bill by its chairman, Representative Doughton of North Carolina, to increase the amount of long-term government securities that may be outstanding at any one time.
An audience which completely filled the Salle d'Iena tonight tumultuously welcomed the young dancer Antonia Cobos, who made her Paris debut in an elaborate program of Spanish dances.
An auditor gave evidence before Judge Maurice Tetreau today that accounts of the Montreal office of Jenks, Gwynne Co., New York Stock Exchange brokers, showed a shortage of $97,954.
Behind the seven-hit pitching of Joe Sullivan the Toronto Maple Leafs blanked the Jersey City Giants for the second successive day, defeating the visitors, 5--0, today.

A reorganization of the WPA en gineering division, intended to cut administrative costs by $30,000 a month, increase "efficiency and eliminate "creaking of the machinery" in the assignment of 120,000 relief workers on construction projects, was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator.

A pumppriming recovery measure embodying President Roosevelt's recommendations, but making appropriations direct to the agencies affected.instead of following the former lump-sum appropriation and reallocation method, was completed today. by a House Appropriations Subcommittee.

The Northern Pacific Company.. expended $952,756 under the Railway Pension Law in 1937, or about what its own pension plan would have cost in that year, Charles Donnelly, president, said in his annual report issued yesterday.

Salwyn Shufro, Edward Rose and Guilliam B. Demarest, the last as a limited partner, have proposed formation of the new New York Stock Exchange firm of Shufro, Rose Co., to begin business on May 19. The Exchange will consider their application on that date.
Mrs. Henry Morgan Tilford has returned from Palm Beach and is at the Waldorf-Astoria before going to Woodland, her country home in Tuxedo Park.

The wheat market was dull today, with speculative interest at a minimum. Prices held within a range of about a cent a bushel, declining early on professional selling induced-by further precipitation over part's of the Winter and Spring grain areas, only to rally late in the session on short covering in sympathy with the strength in securities.

The junior class of Hunter College vill hold its promenade at the Plaza Hotel this evening. About 200 girls arid their escorts are expected to attend. Beatrice Rosenblum and Selma Gendell are cochairmen of the dance.
The House approved without a record vote today the $484,000,000 FederalAid Highway Bill, authorizing appropriations of $238,000,000 a year for 1940 and 1941.

Foreign and expatriated capital and hoarded foreign banknotes and gold continued to pour into Paris today in great volume, although the official and unique rate of exchange was lower by 50 centimes in relation to the pound sterling.
Retirement of C. R. MeDonald, vice president in charge of manufacturing of the International Harvester Company, after forty-three years of active service, was announced today by the company.
Formation of the Wine and Spirits Market Research Group of the American Marketing Association was announced yesterday.
Colyer, Robinson Co. received the award yesterday of $1,606,000 of emergency relief bonds of Newark, N. J., taking $1,596,000 of the issue on a bid of 100.64 for 4s.
Opportunities for the sale of American-made merchandise in overseas markets are included in reports received here this week from-representatives of the government stationed abroad.

With Mayor La Guardia, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott another Fire Department officials present a solemn high requiem mass was celebrated yesterday for Fireman James F. Hughes, who was killed in a collision of Fire Department vehicles.
The necessary 218 signatures to force the Wage and Hour Bill out of the Rules Committee have been obtained and the House will doubtless vote on the measure at this session.

Because they broke a court rule barring newspaper interviews, two New Zealand women--hotel and store hostesses, respectively--have been informed by the Lord Chamberlain's office that they cannot be presented at court.

Gold medals were presented tonight by Leslie Joy, general manager of radio station KYW, to the four persons who took part in the first broadcast from the field at Lakehurst following the explosion of the dirigible Hindenburg last year.

DERBY Day. That certainly calls for some comment, beginning with the admission that the ignorance of horse racing in this corner is abysmal What follows is based entirely on hearsay evidence, with the exception of any reference to Fighting Fox, the favorite in the big race.

Expressing the belief that the complainant did not want to tes tify, General Sessions Judge Donnellan yesterday dismissed the extortion indictment returned nearly a year ago against Mrs. Betty Randolph Sweinhart, former musical comedy performer.
Stevedores and harbor policemen kept their "fingers crossed" today while cages holding 1,000 monkeys, part of a cargo lowered from the freighter City of Hereford, rested in terminal sheds.

Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring captured the low gross honors in the second one-day tournament of -the New Jersey Women's Golf Association with a card of 38, 42-80 over the Glen Ridge Country Club course today. A field of eightytwo players competed.
When the passion to gobble up one's neighbors is so strong, it is a comfort to think of men bent merely on winning honor and prepared to face extreme hardship and even death in the pursuit of it.

Keystone Utilities, Inc., a subsidiary of the NY PA NJ Utilities Company, a sub-holding company of the Associated Gas and Electric System, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application

The financing of two more properties in the extensive real estate holdings of William Randolph Hearst was revealed yesterday with the filing in the Register's office of a $500,000 mortgage on the Hearst Publications Building at 220 South Street and the printing plant at the southeast corner of Walton Avenue and East 149th Street, Bronx.

Because of the admission of a new partner by Heidelbach, Ickelheimer Co., private bankers at 49 Wall, Street, New York, the State Banking Department has, authorized the firm to continue business with a capital of $2,000,000.

Miss Kate Hardy, sister of Thomas Hardy, bought his old home, Max Gate, for [Pound]2,250 at an auction here today. Mr. Hardy was originally an architect, and his ancestors were builders. He put his best skill into his house and garden, which the novelist and his wife loved.
The unit of the Newark Newspaper Guild at The Daily Courier of the Oranges and Maplewood, published here, went on strike today to seek reinstatement of five members dismissed in the last two weeks.

So the destruction of the Sixth Avenue Elevated draws nearer. Why must "everybody" damn the shabby old concern? When Sixth Avenue abounded in prosperous shops and we got off at Twenty-third Street for the Studio or at Thirty-third for Parker's, did we have any unkindly thoughts of our carrier? Once to strangers the elevated roads were among the wonders of the town.
Municipal Court, Judge Utley H. Crane died today of a heart attack after collapsing in a theatre shortly after 3 P. M. His age was 53.

A group bf California sportsmen, including Donald Budge, world amateur tennis champion, and Joe DiMaggio of the New York Yankees, today demanded the immediate release of Baron Gottfried von Cramm, Germany's No. 1 tennis star, from a Nazi concentration camp.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn unanimously affirmed yesterday the right of George A. Wingate, Kings County Surrogate, to' raise the salary of his chief clerk,.Percy T. Stapleton, from $10,500 to $15,0001 but Mayor La Guardia said later that the city could not pay the increase.
Hexameter, owned by Alvin Untermyer of Greenwich, Conn., won the Admiral Cary T. Grayson Memorial Cup today in the Washington Horse Show.
Mike Stehnach fielded two Columbia sacrifice bunts with neatness and dispatch in the third inning of the Cornell-Columbia Eastern Intercollegiate League battle at Baker Field yesterday.
Gilbert F. Davis of Windsor, Vt., an expert in financial law, died today at the New England Baptist Hospital, following an operation for intestinal disorders. His age was 61.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor MacLeod, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Murdoch Douglas MacLeod of New York, to Dr. James Alanson Moore of Boston and Mooresville, N. C., took place here last night in the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas,

Henry F. Woelfle, manager of the tower apartments of the WaldorfAstoria and who made his home at the hotel, died Thursday. night at St. John's. Hospital, Long Island City, of injuries suffered when his car was in collision with a truck at Skillman Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, Long Island City, earlier in the evening.

Mr. and Mrs. Edgar L. Heermance of this city today announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Heermance, to Halsey Munson Hicks, son of Mrs. Arthur W. Hicks and the late Mr. Hicks of Summit, N. J.
The City Commission, fearful of competition, adopted a resolution today protesting the proposal tobuild a large convention hall in Washington with Federal funds.

The National Labor Relations Board in Washington intervened yesterday in the prolonged labor struggle in the fur industry in this city when it instructed Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the board here, to investigate charges filed by the International Fur Workers Union.

Among those listed to sail today on the Cunard White Star liner Carinthia for Liverpool via Glasgow and Dublin are: Colonel M. F. Day, Miss Mary Barton, Herbert Greenwood, Miss Janet P. Fisher, G. H. Rogers, Mrs. G. B. Pease, Miss Asa Thomas, Mr. and Mrs. A. W. Wilson, Miss Frances E. Hall, Mr. and Mrs. L. deS. Duke and Miss Cherry Kennedy.

Opponents of the bill for meat grading and licensing of butchers declared yesterday at a hearing before the City Council's committee on welfare that the bill would not stop fraud; that it would force on consumers higher prices for better grades of meat and would "hamstring" the industry with regulations.

A process using copper-chromium oxide as a catalyst, by which 1,500,000 tons of lignin now discarded annually in the United States can be converted into useful chemicals, was announced last night by Professor Homer Adkins of the University of Wisconsin at a symposium on catalysis sponsored by the New York section of the American Chemical Society at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Harry Sherman of Dorchester, Mass., described by government attorneys as the ringleaderr" f an eight-State lottery ring, was sentenced by Federal Judge Frank Cooper today to five years in prison and fined $25,000.

The drop in cotton-mill activity last weekly was more than seasonal and the adjusted index- eased to 82.3 from 82.8, the revised figure for the previous week. This compares with 139.4 for the week ended May 1, 1937.
Activity stimulated by the proposed $35,000,000 housing project on the site of the Catholic Protectory in the Bronx continued in that section yesterday.
Mrs. Julian Wilson of 1,040 Park Avenue, who will leave tomorrow for the Greenbrier, White Sulphur Springs, entertained with a luncheon yesterday at her home.

While we were in Bermuda we missed the Metropolitan championship at the new grounds of the Valhalla Skeet Club, and worst of all, we missed seeing Douglas P. Jones of Stamford, Conn., take the Metropolitan open all-bore title with a 98 out of 100.

Surplus stocks of rayon yarn at the end of April showed virtually no change from the month before, as production of the yarn in the United States for the month continued about equal with the consumption demand, according tofigures issued yesterday by the Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. Producers' stocks of yarn on April 30 amounted to 3.5 months' supply.

The ninth Duke of Devonshire, towering master of one of England's greatest feudal families, died today within the historic walls of his principal seat, Chatsworth House, where Mary Queen of Scots once was imprisoned. His age was 69.

Percy Kemper Crocker, for nearly forty years. a newspaper and retail advertising man, died yesterday in the Queens General Hospital after a long illness at the age of 60. Mr. Croaker lived at 87-12 Seventyfourth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 30 totaled 543,075 1 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Secretary of Interior Ickes moved his new first assistant, E. K. Burlew, today into the suite of offices long assigned to Charles West, undersecretary. The installation was regarded as the final development 'in the rift between Mr. Ickes and Mr. West.

In the second by-election since Anthony Eden resigned as Foreign Secretary over the question of negotiating with Premier Mussolini and the first since the government reached an accord with Italy, Labor today captured another seat in the House of Commons, although only by a margin of 826 votes.
Turpentine firm, 23c; sales 48 barrels; receipts 324 barrels; shipments 388 barrels; stock 29,160 barrels.

Relief seekers crowded this city's six district relief stations today, crying "We want food." Cleveland was battling another of its recurrent welfare crises which have occurred at intervals for the last two years, in the face of official estimates indicating that from one-third to one-fourth of Cuyahoga County's 1,200,000 population was dependent on some sort of public aid.

North Carolina's tennis team routed New York University yesterday, wining all nine matches on the Fleet Hollow courts in the Bronx. It was the eighth contest of the year for the Violet netmen, who have lost only two engagements.

The annual Hunter College Sing, interclass song competition, held yesterday afternoon at the Center Theatre, Radio City, was won by the junior class, whose chief song portrayed Satan taking a holiday. The seniors, with sports as their theme, placed second.

Mrs. Esther Root Adams of Weston, wife of F. P. A., former newspaper columnist, won her front lawn back from the town of Weston in Superior Court today after a twoyear fight. Judge Edward J. QuinIan gave her a permanent injunction restraining the town and its Selectmen from entering her property.
Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., has signed a long-term lease on a factory at South Bend, Ind., for production of the Bendix home laundry, Don O. Scott, president, announced here yesterday.

The C. I. Os Steel Workers Organizing Committee announced today the signing of its "most unusual contract," an industrial union agreement with the Union Railroad Company, which makes provision for a half-dozen shop crafts.

A life expectancy of seventy years within a few years was predicted today by W. Howard Cox of Cininnati, president of the Union Central Life Insurance Company, in an address to 800 insurance men at the annual meeting of the New York StateLife Underwriters Association in the Hotel Utica.

In a relatively quiet market on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on April 9, member trading in round lots for their own account rose to 20.14 per cent of total volume, compared with 16.88 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association. Inc.:
Ernest L. Nye of Freeman Co. was elected yesterday a director of the Brill Corporation to succeed William M. Hager. Other directors were re-elected.

Mrs. Octavia Goodbar, president of the New England Women's Press Association, was elected today president of the National Federation of Press Women. Mrs. Goodbar succeeded Mrs. Douglas Malloch of Chicago, who organized the federation last year.
Department store sales during the week ended April 30 were 15 per cent below those of the same week one year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The American Chicle Company authorized an extra dividend of 50 cents a share to its stockholders together with the regular quarterly distribution of $1.

AUDRAIN, MARY E. (Feb. 26). Estate, more than $20,000. To Josephine Russell, Bayside L. I., Stephen B. Brigham, 356 Owen Ave., Radburn, N. J.. $5,000 each; Ralph V. Brigham, 358 Arleigh Rd., Douglaston Manor, L. I., $3,000;

The 500-piece silver service, presented to the historic armored cruiser Brooklyn in 1897, valued at $10,000 then and at $30,000 now, was presented to the new cruiser Brooklyn before several hundred persons at the navy yard yesterday.
Following Great Northern's action in setting newsprint prices at $48 a ton for the second six months of the year a similar price cut of $2 by Quebec producers is looked for.
Foreign trade figures for April showed that for the first four months of this year the unfavorable balance amounted to about 6,220,000,000 francs.

West St, 258, 25.1/2 x111; 1/2 interest; Vera Strejcek to Marie Hyjek, 192 Claremont Ave; mtg $13,000 ($3). Cherry St, 218, 37.71/2/164x irreg; Ida Cohen, et al, to 218 Cherry Street Corp, 1,360 48th St, Bklyn, care B. Cohen (50 cents).

BAUMANN, CECILIA (July 27, 1937). Gross assets, $142,467; net, S89,592. To Temple Emanu-El, $3,000; Lillie Engel, Lizzie Hess, Elizabeth Tuscano, Ruth Segal, Beatrice Baumann, Jessie Baumann, Edna Baumann, Frances Baumaun, Elizabeth Reiss, $2,000 each;

The Ralph Beaver Strassburger Prize for journalistic contributions to Franco-American amity this year was awarded to Pierre Lamure, New York corresponded for Le Jour-Echo de Paris. M. Lamure has lived in the United States since 1926.

John r. Longo, 24-year-old political opponent of Mayor Frank Hague, was found gui.ty last night by a jury of Jersey City citizens of violation of the New Jersey election laws following a trial in which the policies of the Hague administration were made the main issue by the defense.

Denouncing gambling as a deeper curse than drink," Dr. Robert W. Searle, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, told members of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice yesterday that gaming was a serious problem throughout the nation.

Leaving a note in which she said that her act had been committed in the hope of "helping other girls" and attributing her straying from home and good influences to the separation of her parents, an unidentified young woman, about 25 years old, killed herself by drinking a poison at 9:10. o'clock last night in a rest -room at the Midtown Bus Terminal, 150 West Forty-fourth Street, according to the police.

Public utility, shares, long neglected, led the advance in the stock market yesterday that culminated in a buying rush in the final hour. Gains for the day ranged from fractions to 3 points, and the turnover on the Stock Exchange was 1,021,000 shares, largest since April 22.

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an application by the Federal Water Service Corporation for permission to acquire from the Chase National Bank, New York, 5,000 shares of $6, cumulative, second preference stock of the West Virginia Water Service Company, a subsidiary.
Two teams tied for the qualifying medal. today in the first annual Rock Spring Club invitation golf tournament.

Miss Beverly Waring, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Waring of this place, was married to E. Newton Cutler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle N. Cutler of Morristown, N. J., this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church, this city, by the Rev. H. M. P. Davidson of St. George's School, Newport, R. I., assisted by the Rev. Harry J. Knickle, rector of the church.

Chancellor Hitler's declaration that human and political rights, were denied to Germans in neighboring States was challenged in regard to the Sudeten German minor ities by Brackett Lewis at the threeday Danubian Congress that opened last night under the sponsorship of Fordham University in eating Hall on the campus::

Molding that it is now virtually! impossible to rid the school system of "mentally and physically unfit teachers," Dr. Emil- Altman, chief medical examiner of the New York City schools, recommended yesterday that sweeping revisions be made in the set-up, of the retirement board.
