Mayor Wilson and Sheriff Hamilton today became co-defendants in the Apex Hosiery Company's $1,750,000 damage suit against the County of Philadelphia as the result of sitdown strike disorders at the plant last May.

The Pope once again has showed his indignation at what ecclesiastical circles call the "Nazi invasion of Rome" by sending orders from his Summer residence at Castel Gandolfo that the Vatican museums are to remain closed until Monday-in other words, till the day following Chancellor Hitler's departure for Florence.

Paul H. Coughlin, for ten years with Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., has been appointed Eastern division sales manager of Hiram Walker, Inc., effective Monday. Natalie. Carpenter has been named fashion adviser to the ac cessory group at L. Bamberger Co., Newark, succeeding Jean Schmolze.

Period furniture and decorative objects belonging to Mrs. James P. Donahue of this city brought $13,900 yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., making a total of $27,008.50 for the first two of three auction sessions.

Willlams College undergraduates have voted in favor of retaining compulsory Sunday chapel by 319 to 268. Although a majority voted for continuation, The Williams Record stated editorially that "less than one-tenth of the undergraduates are satisfied with the present Sunday service."

Miss Mignonne Voigt Pelz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald H. Pelz of this place, was married this evening to William Stevens Spring, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Spring of Hartford, Conn., in Christ's Episcopal Church here.

Wholesale volume this week continued at about 8 to 20 per cent below the corresponding week of 1937, with most of the activity provided by quantity buyers seeking off-price merchandise for Summer promotions, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
The College of William and Mary here will confer the degree of Doctor of Fine Arts upon Georgia O'Keeffe, the artist, at exercises at the Phi Beta Kappa Memorial Hall here tomorrow.

Dr. Robert L. Hutton, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agent, in 1,088 Park Ave; Valentine W. Herbst, in 41 5th Ave; Thomas F. Malone, in 33 E 22d St: George D. Di Belius, in 260 S 2d Ave, Mount Vernon, Westchester; Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.
A new wave of suicides among non-Nazi intellec tuals and Jews has broken out here during the last few days.

Living costs in Japan continued to advance during April, the Cabinet Bureau of.Statistics Index showed today, with an increase of 1.1 points over March. Clothing led the advance, with prices rising 3.1 points.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and low; for the last three days:

The "Women's Rebellion," a movement organized-by two housewives. in Suffern, N. Y., ten days ago against further government spending and\ "the way politicians are running the country," moved along a new front yesterday.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull vigorously defended Administration foreign policy at an unusual press conference today,' when he clashed with Drew Pearson, co-author of a newspaper column entitled "The Washington Daily Merry-Co-Round."
Rensselaer Polytechnic's track team today continued its winning streak with an 80-to-46 victory over C. C. N. Y.

Hope of a revival in the capital markets was increased today when Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., of New York' City filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 77,873 shares of $100 par value cumulative convertible preferred stock, Series A, the first large issue of equity securities registered for some time.
Divergent consumer attitudes toward chain stores precipitated a lively debate yesterday among/delegates to the 106th convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor.
In the March quarter, this year, the United Air Lines carried passengers 31 per cent more revenue miles than correspondingly in 1937, W. A. Patterson, president, announced yesterday.

Walter Geoghagen, art director of Calkins Holden, was yesterday elected president of the Art Directors Club, succeeding Deane Uptegrove of Alley Richards Company, at the club's annual meeting held at its headquarters here. Mr.

World refined lead production in March was 151,113 tons, compared with 146,951 in February, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Production in the United States in March was 35,129 tons, against 33,555 in February.

Jock McAvoy, British middleweight champion, knocked out Marcel Lauriot of France in the second round of their twelve-round fight on the stage of the Royal Theatre tonight. McAvoy floored the Frenchman with a right

Although stewards aboard the French Line freighter Wyoming refused today to join the strike of the line's ship crews and the Wyoming was able to sail for Antwerp, Belgium, the conflict that is tying up the company's major ships here is no nearer settlement.
Three rowing courses will carry the wake of varsity eights this afternoon as the season turns into the month that annually sees middle-distance racing rise to its peak.

A circular building, emblematical of the endlessness of life, will house the Christian Science exhibits and reading rooms at the 1939 World's Fair, Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, announced yesterday.

Annual Mother's Day will be celebrated tomorrow in churches of all faiths and today in synagogues. In Methodist churches there will be sermons on "Mothers of Methodism" and especially of Susanna Wesley, mother of John Wesley, the bicentennial of whose "heartwarming" which led him to found, the Methodist Church is being observed.

Unlawful fixing of prices and discounts, in violation of the Federal Trade Commission Act, was charged today by the commission in a complaint issued against seventeen manufacturers of paper, pulp and wooden dishes or trays used principally by groceries, delicatessen stores and meat markets as containers for food products.
The naval, military and aerial re-views staged with stupendous realism to entertain Hitler in Italy give fresh point to the questions everybody is asking and nobody is able to answer with confidence.

That the silver song of "Boots and' Saddles" will not vanish from the army's repertory, that the creak of leather tightly cinched and the galloping crescendo of hoof-beats at the charge are still, and will remain, a part of the military life, is amply shown by recent campaigns.

The 28,000-ton liner Stockholm, which will enter the transatlantic service early next year as flagship of the Swedish-American Line, will be launched on May 29 at the Cantieri Riuniti shipyard, Trieste, according to official word here yesterday.

The plea made yesterday by John W. Hanes, SEC commissioner, in an address before the Western Pennsylvania group of the Investment Bankers Association of America, for cooperation between the public utilities and the Federal Government was credited in part by brokers for the strong market for securities of the major utility companies.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,215,000 bales, against 1,255,000 a week ago, 1,239,000 two weeks ago, 1,213,000 three weeks ago and 940,000 a year ago; of which American 820,000 bales, against 828,000 a week ago, 818,000 two weeks ago, 815,000 three weeks ago and 417,000 a year ago.

Mis Frances Howell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Howell of Baltimore and Charleston, W. Va., was married in Trinity Church here this afternoon by the Rev. Arthur Lee Kinsolving to Thomas Ferguson Locke, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Allen Locke of Williamstown and Wilton, N. H. A reception followed at the Country Club in Brookline.

Two police sergeants were notified yesterday that they had passed the State bar examinations and were eligible for admission to the bar. They are Sergeant Daniel A. Sweeney of the Legal Bureau at Police Headquarters and Sergeant David A. Fay of Troop C, Mounted Squad 1, assigned to duty in Manhattan. Both men- intend to remain in the-Police Department.

Samuel Seabury has been nominated for the presidency of the New York Law Institute. Other nominees were William Nelson Cromwell, Henry W. Taft and Frank L. Polk, for vice presidents; Albert W. Putnam, for treasurer, and William West Shaw, secretary..

Trading was good to slow in local markets yesterday. Steer hind and rib prices were somewhat firmer, although some sales Thursday were weak to somewhat lower. Steer cuts sold unevenly. Lamb and fresh pork cuts were steady to lower, bull prices higher, other classes mostly unchanged.

Production of "quick frozen" or "frosted" foods is expected to reach a new high level of 480,000,000 pounds in 1938, according to an estimate made public today by the Foodstuffs Division of the Bureau of For-. eign and Domestic Commerce, on the basis of a survey prepared by C. Roy Mundee, chief of the Foodstuffs Division, arid Frances C. Porcher.

A bitter deadlock ushered in the eleventh month of undeclared war between China and Japan today. On the main front in Southern Shantung Province, Japan's modern army was halted in its tracks for the second time in six weeks. It had been forced back from its farthest advances in other provinces.

A competent and thoroughly enjoyable performance of Puccini's 'Madama Butterfly" by Fortune Gallo's San Carlo Opera Company last night formed the second offering. of that organization's current season at the Center Theatre.

Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation told interviewers today that the future of business did not look good, but expressed the opinion that "things can't get much worse,"

A nation-wide broadcast on "Retailing and Recovery" will be sponsored by the National Retail Dry Goods Association over the red network of the National Broadcasting Company next Thursday night from 11:30 to 12 o'clock, Eastern daylight-saving time.
Dizzy Dean, who has played a noisy part in many a turbulent salary conference, participated in one of the most harmonious of his colorful career today. .

Registration under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 necessitated changes in the accounts of the United Gas Improvement Company, John E. Zimmermann, president, said in his quarterly report issued yesterday. Mr.
An "intensive study of the waters of the entire Hudson-Mohawk River area, from the viewpoint of coordination and full utilization" was urged today by the State Planning Council.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel G. Craig of Princeton, N. J., editor of Christianity Today, a national Presbyterian monthly representing the conservative element in the denomination, will hereafter edit the periodical as a quarterly. Dr..Craig formerly was editor of The Presbyterian, a national weekly, published in Philadelphia, and he remains a director of the Presbyterian Publishing Company.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that Frank P. Walsh, designated on April 2 to succeed Mark t Eisner on the Board of Education, would not be able to accept the appointment. The Mayor announced r Mr. Walsh's appointment when the t latter was in the West.

A campaign to stop peddling in Central Park was opened yesterday by Jacob-Gould Schurman Jr., Chief City- Magistrate, with the circulation to twelve magistrates of a memorandum informing them that during the Summer months they alone would be assigned to preside at Yorkville Court.
Education looked ahead today in many fields as 400 leaders gathered here for the twenty-first annual meeting of the American Council on Education.
The International Casino, the sizable night club at Forty-fifth Street and Broadway, reopened its doors last night with a show which consisted entirely of skating, some of it by recognized champions.

By B. HOLLANDER SON 207th St, W, s s, 150 ft e 9th Ave, vacant, 201.11x90.6x irreg; Cecilia Gannon against H. J. Butler Bro, Inc; due, $86.512; taxes, etc, $12,167; to plaintiff for $5,000. By DANIEL GREENWALD

Store leases involving a variety of retail businesses accounted for many of the commercial rental contracts announced yesterday. Several haberdashers took ground-floor space, and furniture dealers and interior decorators also appeared inthe lists.
Millions in the nation will observe Mother's Day tomorrow. In the metropolitan area the day will be observed in special religious services and commemorative exercises to be held today and tomorrow.

Four indictments charging two ticket selling concerns and six individuals with failure to keep proper records of the sale of tickets and with failure to file proper returns to tax authorities, were voted yesterday by a Federal grand jury.

With the defection of "Gentlemen Need a Shave," next week will find just one new show reaching Broadway, and that the musical number called "I Married an Angel." Based on an Hungarian original, it has words and music by Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, and in the cast are Dennis King, Vera Zorina, Vivienne Segal, Walter Slezak and Audrey Christie.
Meeting of the New York Principals Association, Waldorf - Astoria,. 9:30 A. M. Luncheon in honor of President Henry C. Turner, 12:30 P. M.

Dan Fellows Platt, archaeologist, art collector, author and former Mayor of Englewood, died this morning in his home at Booth Avenue and Lydecker Street, here, after a month's illness.- He was 65 years old.
An all-time record Agricultural Appropriation Bill well above the billion-dollar mark won approval today of a Senate appropriations subcommittee.

Goldblatt Brothers announced today that an expedition of thirty-one buyers and store executives would leave on Sunday for New York, where "millions of dollars worth of new merchandise would be purchased for the star event in the Goldblatt calendar--Nathan Goldblatt Week."

Retail road prices of food rose in the month ended on April 12, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1923-25 average, was 79.4, compared with 78.6 on March 15 and 85.6 on April 13, 1937.

Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority and honorary chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, will be guest speaker at a dinner sponsored by the real estate division of the appeal tomorrow night at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Tom Lynch, one of the best-known figures in the circus world whose contact with the "big top" dated back to personal acquaintance with P. T. Barnum, died last night at his home here. He was 82 years old and had spent sixty-two seasons "under canvas."
The golfer who has a tendency to slice or hook the ball, or has other faults in the game which he has difficulty overcoming, will have the opportunity, beginning May 16, of having science aid him.

Dr. Adolph Frederick Bechdolt, for nearly fifty years an educator in the West and Middle West, died suddenly yesterday at Carmel, Calif., according to word received here last night. He was in his ninetieth year.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a tenement to cost $100,000 in the Chelsea section of Manhattan and numerous small houses in Brooklyn. The plans follow:
Rookie Enos Slaughter led the Cardinals to a 4-to-3 victory over the Phillies today and drove in the winning run in the ninth.

The Federal Board in its May bulletin today estimated industrial production in April at 78 per cent of the 1923-25 level, showing a further slight decrease from the average for the first three months of the year. For January the percentage. figure was 80 and for February and March it was 79.

Joan Crawford has signed a fiveyear contract with Metro-Go1dwynMayer studio, M. C. Levee, her representative, said today. It is understood the- deal involves $1.500,000, or three picture a year at $100,000 a picture, The studio confirmed the signing.
Among the things that impress the foreigner in- Spain are. the role of the aristocracy in the war and the changed attitude of many of its members toward social reforms.

The government today announced the appointment of a new Ambassador to Germany, replacing Dr. Constantine Youreneff, who was implicated in charges of. treason by witnesses in the Moscow trial of two months ago.

Delay beset the issuance of State unemployment insurance checks for the third time yesterday as the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department confronted its third major test. This was provided by a change in the computing system.

Despite the definite signs of a revival of activity In the new-issue market apparent during the past few days, the volume of new bond financing this week dropped to $4,515,000, and for the second consecutive period was confined exclusively to tax-exempt Issues.
The transcript of Secretary of State Cordefll Hull's press conference today, in which the Secretary defended aspects of the foreign policy of the United States, is as follows:

James G. Sheridan was right when he ruled the Queens County Democratic Executive Committee had not. ousted him as leader, but he was wrong when he refused to accept a petition from the antiSheridan faction for a special meeting later, Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May held In two decisions handed down yesterday in Brooklyn.

The fourth annual Tip Top Ball was given last night in the ballroom of the Plaza under the auspices of Auxiliary No. 5 of Stony Wold Sanatorium. The party is given each Spring to assist the sanatorium on Lake Kushaqua in the Adirondacks, which provides treatment and care for young women afflicted with pulmonary tuberculosis.

The war Department released the following orders today, dated May 5: COLONEL McDonald, D. C., F. A., relieved from detail in the Bureau of Insular Affairs, Washington, D. C., and ordered to the Hawaiian Dept., to sail from New York about Sept. 1.

Ten, the smallest number in many years, were named through the entry box for the sixty-fourth Kentucky Derby to be run tomorrow before an expected crowd of 50,000 drawn from all corners of the country for what has become America's best known horse race.
Four women members of the Findlay Country Club reported today that the all drew perfect bridge hands in one deal. The four players and the suits they were dealt were:

It became known today that the United States Circuit Court of Appeals issued an order yesterday directing that the National Labor Relations Board file with the court a record of the Inland Steel Company proceedings.

An electrical contractor installing street lights in Shore Road, Brooklyn, was ordered off his own job by Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, and forbidden even to drive along the public thoroughfare with his wife, according to testimony yesterday in the injunction suit against the union.

A group of railroads operating in Pennsylvania filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a petition asking for an investigation and order fixing such rates on intrastate shipments of anthracite coal as would prove not discriminatroy in connection with the recent decision of the I. C. C. granting an increase

Frank Dan Waterman, fountain pen manufacturer, philanthropist and one-time Republican candidate for Mayor of Now York, died of pneumonia yesterday morning at his home, 655 Park Avenue, at the age of 68.
Arrowsmith Co. will move to 48 Wall Street, where they wil clear transactions-through the Stock Exchange firm of Riter Co., beginning on Mond-y.

Walton Ave (9-2346), s e cor of 149th St, 185x131; also property in New York County; New York Evening Journal, Inc, to Equitable Life Assurance Society, 393 7th Ave. installments, 5 per cent; $500,000. Marmion Ave. 2,017 (11-3107); Lind Realty Corp to Cornelia K. Livermore, 410 E 57th St, installments, 3 to 4 per cent; $17,000.
SERGEANT-Lewis Colton, from 112th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in District Attorney's office, Queens, for 1 day, from 4 P. M., May 3.
Legless but smiling, Sir Abe Bailey, 73-year-old gold rush pioneer and South Africarn magnate, sailed for England today to see one of his horses, Golden Sovereign, run in the English Derby, June 1.
In accordance with the stabilization plan, the buying rate for pounds and dollars was lowered slightly today and the rapid flow of capital into the country continued.

Displaying decided superiority in batting and bowling strength, the touring Australian cricket team overwhelmed Oxford University by an innings and 487 runs today for its second successive Victory on English soil. In their opening match the visitors defeated Worcestershire by an innings and 77 runs.

The completed Henry Hudson Bridge, part of the traffic link by which motorists may drive from Canal Street to the city line at .Van Cortlandt Park along landscaped areas without traffic stops in twenty-six minutes instead of through the traffic-jammed streets in sixty-eight minutes, will be openedd today. Mayor La Guardia will speak.

The marriage of Miss Jean Gairdner Moment, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John J. Moment of 815 Park Avenue, to Walter Spalding Douglas of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Douglas of this city, took place tonight in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church.
Great Britain and France decided today to make a quick effort to ease Czechoslovakia's minority trouble and get Europe away. from the brink of possible war.
Press comment here today indicates satisfaction with the outcome of the Little Entente conference, with particular interest manifest in the Entente's relations with Hungary.

Today's major events: Frelhelit Gesang Farein, Carnegie Hall, evening; "Faust" afternoon, "Trevatore" evening, Center Theatre; League of Music Lovers, Town Hall, evening; "Rigoletto," Hippodrome, evening; "Hansel und Gretel," Heekasher Theatre, 11 A. M.; "We the Children," concert, Federal Music Theatre, 11 A. M.

The Rev. William Sherman McAleer, librarian and a member of the faculty of the Immaculate Conception Catholic Seminary at Huntington, L. I., died Thursday night at his home, 538 Beach Nineteenth Street, Far Rockaway, after a long illness. His age was 40.

Works by contemporary Americans, including fifty-one paintings by 'forty-two artists, have been seelected by the Wildenstein Galleries to constitute an exhibition at their London gallery to be held from May 25 to June 25.
A system of clinics for delivery of "free" babies to families who cannot afford proper care for the mother was proposed today as a means of reducing Pennsylvania's maternity death rate.

If American opinion is coming gradually to recognize the fallacies of "economic self-sufficiency," credit is due largely to the efforts of a half-dozen earnest missionaries of the Roosevelt Administration. Secretary Hull, of course, is the most important member of the group.
Stocks closed strong and active, . with gains of fractions to 3 points, public utilities leading; turnover, 1,021,990 shares largest since April 22.

The Catholic Boys Brigade of the United States, which has a membership of 40,000 throughout the country, will be the beneficiary of a dinner dance to be held tonight in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis.

Colonel Lewis Landes, attorney, who was held in contempt of court last Wednesday and fined $50 by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert when he insisted upon renewing objections to government testimony at the trial of the so-called Maceo-Vallone ring' of narcotic smugglers, won the right yesterday to appeal from the court's ruling.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: May I attempt to correct what appears to be misinformation -(not deliberate, I am sure) given by Mr. Kieran in his column to the effect that. counting the one he participated in at the Yankee Stadium recent, Joe Cronin has been in two triple plays, the other being one in Boston in which he was one of the victims.
It is pleasant to see eugenics rallying to the democratic idea. Justly or not, the science of the "well-born" became
Italy gained a lead of two matches to one in Davis Cup tennis play against Ireland today, winning the doubles.
Henry Goddard Leach of 170 East Sixty-fourth Street gave a dinner last night at his home for Robert Woods Bliss, former United States Minister to Sweden and Ambassador to Argentina.

Business volume in April as represented by the turnover in checks at 194 clearing houses of the.country totaled 24,013,408,874, a loss of 4.9 per cent from the turnover in the preceding month, and 16.7 per cent under April last year.
Representatives of farm organizations urged the House Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve the Truth-in-Fabrics Labeling bill.

President Roosevelt realized one of the aims of his Caribbean cruise today when, after a long fight, he landed a twenty-pound barracuda off Caicos Island to carry off first honors as the ranking fisherman of the party.

Although the number of patients and the cost of their care increased, the New York Hospital was able to reduce its deficit last year for the third successive year, according- to the 166th annual report of the Society of the New York Hospital, made public yesterday.

" The Beaux Strategem," third annual collaboration of the Finch Junior College Dramatics Art Department and the Princeton University Theatre Intime, opened tonight in McCarter Theater before a house party audience of 900.

A better and sounder mortgage structure is being built out of the experience with past mortgage difficulties, John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said yesterday to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks at the closing session of its eighteenth annual conference at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Band Order The members of the Department Band shall be directed to report to Capt. Julius A. Unrath, at the Twelfth Regiment Armory, Columbus Ave. and 62d St., Manhattan, at 4 P. M., Sunday, May 8.

British investors responded half-heartedly today to the floating an Australian loan of [Pound]7,000,000 ($35,000,000), the first Australian "new money" loan since 1929. Underwriters had to take up about 66 per cent of the amount offered.

Julius Kulkin, New Utrecht High captain, captured the P. S. A. L. form fencing championship at the Commerce Building of City College last night. Kulkin topped a field of eight with a form average of 7.02. The runner-up was Arthur Friedman of Erasmus Hall, with 6.95. Third place went to Charles Steinhardt, New Utrecht, with 6.69.

The breach between the State Federation of Labor and the American Labor party widened yesterday when Alex Rose, the party's State executive secretary, charged in effect that George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor, was trying to deliver the labor vote to another political party. Mr. Rosen said:

Deals involving industrial properties in near-by communities in New Jersey featured realty activity in the State yesterday. Plans for the removal from New York City of the plant of the Standard Refining Company were announced when the concern leased from the Paulus Hook Corporation the factory buildings at the northeast corner of Palisade Avenue and Bowers Street, Jersey City.
Several residential parcels changed hands in the Westchester realty deals announced yesterday. Samuel Hooper, manager of the New York branch of the Woodstock Typewriter Company,

Still sorely nettled over the manner in which they had blown that odd game in Cincinnati yesterday, the Giants tore into the Pirates with such grand fury today that they virtually bowled over the amazed Corsairs before the latter had a chance to set themselves for the encounter.
Prices at least 10 per cent below those of a year ago, and in some cases showing slightly greater reductions, were quoted yesterday on women's wear fabrics for Fall by leading producers.

John W. Hanes, a member of the SecuriLies and Exchange Commission, said today that he would make an everlasting endeavor" to dissuade government officials from saying "publicly or privately" that business is the "enemy of government."

The New York Advisory Committee of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations announced yesterday that it had recommended that all metropolitan Jewish reform temples, for the first time in the history of reform Judaism in New York City, be united in one federation.

Claire Trevor, Who during her five years with Twentieth Century-Fox appeared in twenty-eight pictures, today gained her release from the studio and will join Warners, where she will make two features a year. Until her association with "Dead End" she had been identified almost entirely with B pictures.

Steel production in April declined slightly from March levels, amounting to 1,925,166 gross tons, as compared to 2,012,406 gross tons in the previous month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

The 1,373 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange,. aggregating $48,279,224,071 par value as of May 1, had a total market value of $42,398,688.128, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday.

The parents and grandparents of Helaine Judith Colan, 5 weeks old, -were debating tonight whether to submit her to an operation which medical men say means total blindness, or spare her the operation--a course which the medical men say means certain death.

Senator Thomas C. Desmond accused the Department of Labor today of faulty administration of the unemployment insurance law. Senator Desmond said: "Of , the several State departments, the Labor Department, headed by Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews, is surely one of the most lax and inefficient.
Premier Mussolini showed his land forces to Chancellor Hitler yesterday in an impressive display in Rome. The German leader was cordially but not enthusiastically cheered.

A local section of the American Press Society has been formed in Pittsburgh, it was announced here yesterday by officials of the association. The Pittsburgh section adopted a local constitution within the framework of the national constitution of the American Press Society.
Spanish Insurgents advanced on Eastern Spain's southern front today while Government forces gained-high in the Pyrenees Mountains on the north.

Miss Elsbeth Davies and Miss Dorothy Colodny, seniors at Barnard College, have received the two special graduate fellowships made from the George Welwood Murray Fellowship for 1938-39 this year, when Miss Jaqueline Dawson, original recipient of the fellowship, declined the honor, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday.

The annual May Festival of the students of Sweet Briar College opened this afternoon with the May Day Horse Show in the -college riding ring. A dinner dance in the evening was followed by a program of Latin-American music given by Irma Goebel Labastille and the formal May Day dance.

Virginio Gayda, Fascist editorial spokesman, declared today that comments such as those in Washington yesterday by Secretary of War Harry H. Woodring on aggression by dictator nations "could not long continue without provoking most fateful and necessary reactions."

When the Emigrant Bank sold to Minnie Ohmer the building at 305 E 80th St for $21,500 she gave back a purchase money mortgage for $21,191 and a building loan mortgage for $10,600, both due on demand. In an agreement between Brewster Properties, Inc, Jesse H. Barkin, president.

IT would be hard to underestimate Mr. Nabokoff's love for his characters. He loathes them. But he takes a mannered and sardonic pleasure in writing about them that has an unintended artlessness about it. This is a variant on the very tough guy with the very soft heart.

The military prosecutor today charged Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, Iron Guard leader, with treason for possessing documents of vital-State interest. Among them, it was reported, were several relating to the manufacture of airplanes and the location of auxiliary ammunition factories.

A socail worker in the Boston Welfare Departmnent was declared tonight by John F. Stokes, captain of the State police detectives, to have admitted he sent the crudely printed letter received Tuesday by Governor Charles F. Hurley, threatening a daughter.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is an ironic phase of the Tompkins decision which perhaps may not have come to your attention, and will, I feel sure, interest and amuse you.

Aaron M. Orange, described as an "agitator, educator and lecturer," of New York,, was named as candidate for Governor last night by the Socialist Labor party at-its State convention at the Hotel Cornish Arms. Jacob Berlin of Brooklyn was nominated for Lieutenant Governor.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders to-day, dated May 4: COMMANDERS Carr, T. D., Naval Academy, to the Davis and in command when commissioned.

The Docterman interests, owners of the eight-story warehouse at 135 West Fourteenth Street, have extended their plottage at that point by purchasing the adjoining fivestory business building on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 133 West Fourteenth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.
Old Pete Appleton pitched and hit the Senators to a 4-to-3 victory over the White Sox in thirteen innings today. He came into the game in the twelfth inning. and hurled masterfully.

Benny Friedman, football coach at C. C. N. Y., is going to conduct a Summer football school for players rather than for coaches, with particular emphasis upon teaching the boy how to avoid injury, it was disclosed yesterday.

" Les Halles," a party patterned after the custom of visiting the markets of Paris, during their rush hour in the early morning, was held last night for the benefit of the Bide-a-Wee Home for Animals.

An Anglo-Canadian rearmament program, under which Canadian factories will make munitions for both countries, is inaugurated with an announcement from the Department of National Defense that a contract had been awarded to the John Inglis Company of Tpronto for the-manufacture of Bren machine guns.

Gerstle Mack, whose life of Paul Cezanne was published by Knopf several seasons ago, arrived here recently from Paris and delivered to his publisher the manuscript of his new book, a critical biography of Toulouse-Lautrec.

A three months' leave of absence granted last January to Dr. William A. Boylan, president of Brooklyn College, has been extended to next September. Dr. Boylan has been suffering from neuritis. Dean Mario E. Cosenza is acting president.

A three months' leave of absence granted last January to Dr. William A. Boylan, president of Brooklyn College, has been extended to next September. Dr. Boylan has been suffering from neuritis. Dean Mario E. Cosenza is acting president.

If it goes through "the financial wringer," the Northern States Power Company of Eau Claire, Wis., may issue $8,000,000 of common stock for refinancing, the State Public Service Commission announced today.

Lawrence Ennis, who learned bridge building in the United States and capped a notable career by having entire charge of the manufacture of the material and erection of the great single span bridge across Sydney Harbor, died here today at the age of 66.

FOUR MEN AND A PRAYER, from a screen play by Richard Sherman. Sonya Levien and Walter Ferris, based on a book by David Garth; directed by John Ford: produced by Kenneth MacGowan for Twentieth Century-Fox. At the Roxy.

Each of the following. graduates of the R. O. T. C., North Carolina State College of Agriculture and Engineering, Raleigh, N. C., Is assigned as a reserve officer to the 1st Division, effective upon acceptance of appointment in the Officers Reserves Corps, as second lieutenant, Infantry Reserve:
Mrs. Barbara O. Clayburgh of New York City received a divorce here today from Albert H. Clayburgh on the ground of cruelty.

Mrs. Harry C. Palmer, Brooklyn clubwoman, suffered a stroke yesterday in the lobby of the Hotel Pennsylvania and died before medical aid could be administered. She was 60 years old and lived at 235 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn. Death was attributed to a heart attack.

The first response to the third devaluation of the franc has been favorable, to the extent that French capital expatriated in recent months through apprehension of reduction in the franc's gold content, which now has happened, has returned to France.
Miss Genevieve Gibbs, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William W. Gibbs of Philadelphia, will be married here tomorrow afternoon to Arthur R. Freedlander, noted portrait painter.

Though Executive Vice President Larry MacPhail last night told them they must take their orders from Burleigh Grimes, the Dodgers found out today that the Reds were their masters, at least for the day. The Cincinnatians made off with the opening game of the series by a score of 10--3.

A general revision of the customs tariff, principally for the purpose of ob taining increased revenue under the provisions of a decree on budgetary affairs, will be undertaken by the French Government, according to a cablegram from the American Commercial Attache in Paris.

The conviction that if even Czechoslovakia had taken a firmer stand when Hitler started to take over Austria, that move might have been averted, was expressed last night by M. W. Fodor, correspondent for The Manchester Guardian and The Chicago Daily News, who was in Vienna before and during Hitler's coup.

Performing in the manner that has earned him a high ranking among the nation's scatter-gun stars, Walter S. Beaver of Conshohocken, Pa., carried off major honors yesterday as the thirty-third annual amateur championships of America at clay targets began a three-day run.

Hearings on the proposed sale of the Sixth Avenue elevated line to the city for $12,500,000, involving the cancellation of the city's tax lien of nearly $9,000,000 against the property and special franchises of the Manhattan Railway Company, began yesterday before Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson.
The Treasury Procurement Division today announced the awards of contracts for a total of 8,351,000 yards of textiles for delivery by June 30. The awards, from bids opened April 29, are as follows:

John Bull, weak and willing in the Walker Cup golf wars these many years, had a chip on his shoulder tonight. He has found a sensational young golfer. His veterans had positively toyed with old St. Andrews. And, for the first time since 1923, he thought his boys could beat the United States when the international matches are played here June 3 and 4.

The general discussion in the International Labor Office preparatory coal conference ended today with a decision to draft a questionnaire with which to consult the governments with a view to shortening hours. This means that there will be no action by them before 1939.

Mayor La Guardia is expected to speak at the dinner of the Presbytery of New York in celebration of its bicentenary to be held on Tuesday evening in the Hotel Astor. More than a thousand persons are to be present. A new manual will contain a brief history of the Presbytery written by the Rev. Dr. Maitland Bartlett, the stated clerk.

Bellevue Hospital, the psychiatric division of which has been under investigation and attack by a legislative committee headed by Senator John J. McNaboe, listed its "outstanding contributions to medical science last year" in a report made public yesterday by Dr. S. S. Goldwater.
Honors almost official in their character were paid today by the French State and municipality to the late Edward Tuck, American philanthropist, who was a "citizen of Paris."

Movements of vessels follow, all dates being May 6 unless specified: Arizona, San Pedro to Navy Yard, Puget sound. Bittern, Manila to South Philippines. Chaumont at Canal Zone. Dunlap at Yorktown. Kewaydin, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. .
Mrs. Grace Noll Crowell, who has just been chosen by the Golden Rule Foundation as "the American Mother or 1938," arrived yesterday from her home in Dallas, Texas, for a week Of honors.

Two indictments alleging grand larceny in the forging of the name of Martin Beck, 'theatrical producer, to $50,000 in checks, and the misappropriation of a $12,000 ring from his daughter, Mrs. Helen Beck Leighton of North Hollywood, Calif., were handed up yesterday by the grand jury against Mrs. Li1lian I. Schrein, 36 years old, secretary-treasurer of the Martin Beck Theatre Corporation.

The Non-Sectarian Anti - Nazi League yesterday started a campaign to boycott the Max SchmelingJoe Louis heavyweight championship fight which is scheduled to take place on June 22 at the Yankee Stadium.

Money in circulation on April 30 was $6,397,325,582, or $49.23 per capital, which' was $41,868,394 more than at the end of March and $29,027,032 less than on April 30, 1937, the Treasury announced today.

Dr. Hugo Eckener, builder and for many years commander of the illfated airship Hindenburg, arrived here from Germany yesterday, the first anniversary of the burning of the huge zeppelin at Lakehurst, N. J.

172d St (11-2967), n s, 67 w Minford Pl, 33x100; also Minford Pl, w s, 34 n of 172d St, 33x67; Harlem Savings Bank to Mary Langfan, 700 W 175th St. Alexander Ave (9-2299), s e cor of 137th, 15x60; Thomas M. Flynn to Agnes J. O'Neill, 214 Alexander Ave.
While the French franc held steady at its new level, other European exchanges were depressed yesterday in the foreign exchange market here.
Rookie Ken Keltner continued his heavy slugging today with a tworun homer that brought the Indians out of their two-game losing slump and clinched a 4-to-1 victory over the Athletics.

The body of Mrs. Donald McGuinness, 31-year-old wife of an electrical engineer of Buchanan, was found late this afternoon in a sedan that had overturned in Anneville Creek, north of here, after plunging from a twenty-foot cliff, twenty feet from a roadway.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes and other charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Miss Jacquette Kilness, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benedict illness of Omaha, Neb., was married to George Kirstein of this city son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis E. Kirstein of Boston, yesterday afternoon, by Supreme Court JusticeSamuel I. Rosenman in, the justice's chambers.
The Red Sox routed the Browns, 7-3, today in a game delayed thirty-four minutes by a heavy shower.
The Wages and Hours Bill was forced to the House floor today by a great rush of signers in support of a petitibn to discharge the Rules Committee from consideration of the bill.

Some 15,000 persons poured in and out of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis of Assisi yesterday afternoon and early last night, when for the first time on the Atlantic seaboard public novena services to Our Sorrowful Mother were conducted.

The silver jubilee convention of the United Synagogue of America began five days of activities in Chicago today. Its aim is to combat what President Louis J. Moss of Brooklyn describes as "the moral recession of the world."
Governor Lehman will hold hearings May 20 on applications for executive clemency in the case of five convicted murderers. The applicants are:

Hunters and jumpers provided the most interesting competition during the first day of the. Spring horse show of the Riding and Polo Club, which will continue through this evening in the club -ring in West Sixty-sixth Street. Entries were light in all divisions.
A spirited advance among the railroad and public utility issues was the feature of more active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Cubs collected only eight hits off six of the Bees' pitchers today but used thirteen bases on balls and four errors to advantage in winning the series opener, 13 to 9.
The New York Produce Exchange announced yesterday the following elections to membership: Raymond J. Barnes, Tidewater Grain Company, Philadelphia;

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Leland Metcalf of Whitinsville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Sawyer Metcalf, to Lieutenant Robert Chambers Jr., United States Marine Corps, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Chambers of this city.

Starvation steer runs featured the cattle trade today, following sharp declines earlier in the week as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture. Hogs drifted lower, top falling to $8.15. Lambs weakened and sheep closed sharply lower as did light veal calves.
C. L. Bradley of Cleveland received $41,000 remuneration as president of the Alleghany Corporation in 1937, a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday.

A $14,000 first mortgage on the 4-story apartment house at 33-14 28th St, Long Island City, has been arranged for the Ely Building and Construction Co. by Joseph F. Holecek, who also reports the placing of a $7,000 mortgage, running for 15 years, on the 2-family house at 87-14 55th Rd, Elmhurst.

The Westchester County Park Commission announced today it would rename the 4,100-acre Poundridge Reservation, in the northeastern part of the county,' the "William L. Ward Memorial Reservation--Poundridge."

Japan's purposes in China were to some extent clarified today by Yosuke Matsuoka, who not only is president of the South Manchuria Railway Company and thus a formative influence on Japan's Far Eastern policy, but he is a member of the Cabinet Advisory Council.

The Senate Lobby Committee refused today to permit Dr Glenn Frank, editor of Rural Progress and chairman of the Republican program committee, to answer charges that his magazine was a propaganda medium financed by "great capitalists."

General Domenico Siciliani, commander of the Rome Army Corps, who was scheduled to lead today's military parade in honor of Chancellor Hitler, died of a sudden illness shortly before the event started.

Italy's emergence as a sea Power of formidable and -growing strength has been one of the more startling manifestations of fascism. The spectacular naval display off Naples reported by Mr. Birchall in THE TIMES yesterday must have convinced those who saw it--and even many of those who read about it-that Rome is rapidly regaining, if she has not already regained, mastery of the Central Mediterranean, that sea once claimed by Roman galleys as Mare Nostrum.
The entire 1923 class of Swedish conscripts, now men of 35 years, will be called up. this Summer and Fall for short periods of training--five days for privates and twelve

In the main ballroom of the RitzCarlton last night the annual Bassinet Dinner Dance was given for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery, 444 West Twenty-second Street, by the junior committee of the beneficiary. A floor show of well-known. dancers and singers featured the party.

Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel denied yesterday a motion made in behalf of three Liechtenstein corporations holding multiple currency -bonds issued by subsidiaries of the Bethlehem Steel Company for a summary judgment directing the Bethlehem Steel Company, as guarantor, to pay them interest in Dutch guilders at the rate specified in the coupons.
' HANOVER, N. H., May 6.-The Dartmouth lacrosse team continued its winning streak in league competition by defeating Williams, 12-3, today in a rough contest.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Advisory Master Dougal Herr in Chancery Court here recommended today a divorce for Mrs. Dorothea Scudder Doeg, who sued John Hope Doeg, former national tennis champion, on the ground of extreme cruelty.

The Nazi movement in this country was under attack on three fronts yesterday as Representative Samuel Dickstein, promising sensational revelations, predicted that Congress would appoint soon a new arid more effective committee to investigate un-American activities.

The Federal Forest Service reported today that the 157 national forests under its supervision earned $3,080,096 from July, 1937, to March 31, 1938, as compared with $3,009,087 in the corresponding period last dear. The receipts were derived principally from timber sales and grazing fees.

Three hundred members of the Chinese customs staff here staged a sitdown strike today in an effort to bring sufficient pressure to prevent the Japanise-inspired Nanking Reformed Government from taking over administration of customs.

The softpedal will be applied to Playland, the county-owned amusement park here, when it opens for its regular season next Saturday, it was announced- today by Herbert F. O'Malley, director of the park.

BERNSTEIN--Mr. and Mrs. Saul Bernstein (nee Mildred Lipke) joyfully announce the arrival of Doris Joan, April 28. BOOSIN--Mr. and Mrs. Walter Boosin announce the birth of a daughter at Hunts Point Hospital. COHEN--Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Cohen (nee Kassln) announce the birth of Bobby's brother at the Polyclinic Hospital, May 7. DIAL--Mr. and Mrs. Nathan, announce the birth of a daughter, May 1, at the Beth David Hospital.

The Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases, Central Park West and 106th Street, will be the beneficiary of the sixth annual show of the Queens County Horse Show Association, on May 22 at Union Turnpike, between 188th Street and Hollis Court Boulevard, Flushing.
Music Hall of the Air symphony orchestra conducted by Erno Rapee; the soloists are Jan Peerce, tenor, and Henriette Schumann, pianist: WJZ, 12:30-1:30 P. M.

A German train steamed last Tuesday morning into the little Italian town of Brennero in the Brenner Pass. Troops were drawn up in the Spring sun, and at the railway station a red carpet was down. Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler had arrived at the historic gateway to Italy.

City Hall Park was cleared of unlicensed bootblacks yesterday after a two-day clean-up by the Police and Park Department officials. At headquarters it was said no special orders had been issued, but it was learned the action had been taken as a routine matter after complaint by a Park Department district foreman.

Calling attention to some of the more important changes which have characterized the history of the lower East Side of the city during the last three centuries, Joseph Platzker, secretary of the East Side Chamber of Commerce, states that tenement house construction began in a large way in that district just prior to the Civil War.

Advice to gardeners in the city on fighting the Japanese beetle, the great Summer menace to flowers, shrubs and lawns, was issued yesterday by the Department of Parks. The grubs of the beetle have been at work on the roots of grass and plants since April.

The many styles and types of roofing now available offer builders a wide variety to select from. Among them are impregnated paper; slatecovered shingles in strips or in single units; wood shingles, composition shingles, cement tiles, terracotta tiles, metal shingles, sheet metal and slate.

Miss Katherine Alberta Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Whitfield Stone, was married to Charles Edward Armstrong of Stapleton, S. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. Orland Benner Armstrong of Adelphi, Ohio, this afternoon in the First-Park Baptist Church here by the pastor, the Rev. Henry L. Bell.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, c., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish.

A committee of home economists, representing public and private welfare agencies, informed the Greater New York Fund yesterday that a family of five in this city should have an income of at least $1,248 a year.
The 1938 Westchester Fete of the women's division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities will be observed by two events in Westchester County next month.

Joseph B. Keenan, assistant to the Attorney General of the United States, said here tonight that although under President Roosevelt "the system of private profit is safe," the country's business was being held back by those who want "profit to the hilt."

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, and John S. Burke and John Thomas Smith, business executives, will be formally invested as privy chamberlains of the cape and sword in the household of Pope Pius XI, on the evening of May- 16 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The teams that Had for the qualifying medal yesterday in the first annual Rock Spring Club invitation golf tournament went down to defeat in the second round today. W. S. Woodhull of Montclair and his Rock Spring partner, J. L. Mac-Withey, were eliminated, 2 and 1, by Bob Lansdell of Hackensack and J. W. Lewis of Rock Spring,

TOSCANINI is not having a good press in Vienna these days. A short time ago he was compared, greatly to his detriment, to Hans Knappertsbusch, who on that particular occasion conducted Bruckner's Eighth symphony--to the best of our knowledge not one of Toscanini's specialties.

THERE are signs that the gold-rush days in this, the country's greatest boom-town, are nearing an end; the fever comparable with that of Forty-nine in the gold fields is beginning to subside and while the asking price for a dozen eggs is still $24 there is little activity in the market. In short, if the swiftly moving events of recent days are indicative, the downward curve of Hollywood's fantastic prices has begun.

Miss Mary Melinda Thompson, daughter of Mrs. William Alexander Thompson of Evanston, Ill., and the late Mr. Thompson, was married to Arthur Robert Meares, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Meares of Mount Vernon, this morning in the Reformed Church here by the Rev. Dr. John H. Powell.
A delegation of 103 WPA teachers and students, sponsored by the New York State FederatiOn of Teachers Unions, came here today to protest threatened relief wage cuts .

Patents granted this week jumped to 800, the greatest number in many months. Among the inventions which won patents, the following are selected for their novelty: A germ shield for the edges of drinking glasses is described in a patent to Willard W. Smithson of Norfolk, Va. Circalar in shape, and made from crimped wax paper, it is slipped over the edge of the glass prior to serving the drink.

Carrying his speed bravely for the full mile and a quarter, Lawrin today won the sixty-fourth Kentucky Derby before 60,000 persons for Herbert M. Woolf, Kansas City department store owner who never faltered in his belief that his colt could do it.

Estates in North Carolina, New York and Florida were reported yesterday by Previews, Inc., as having been sold. Included was the Jackson Springs (N. C.) property of Edward A. Manice, which was purchased by Robin Hood Farms, Inc., of Pinehurst.

Application of a standard accounting system to income property is necessary for estimating future costs of, maintenance and operation, K. Lee Hyder of Milwaukee, president of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, said at the Central Atlantic Conference of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

AFTER months of hearings, revisions and re-revisions the house Interstate Commerce Committee has at last reported a measure providing for the establishment of an "Air Authority" with powers over aviation similar to those exercised by the Interstate Commerce Commission over bus and rail transport.

IT was a happy thought on the part of Mr. McGiffert to select from the approximately 170 manuscript sermons of Ralph Waldo Emerson the twenty-five which for biographical, religious and literary reasons seem best worth publishing.

Statistics compiled by Thomas E. Colleton, FHA director for New Jersey, during the months of March and April, reveal a substantial trend toward new home construction. Mortgage applications in the New Jersey office for April, Mr. Colleton reported,
THE most dignified of His Majesty's subjects are undoubtedly the Judges of the High Court. It is not merely their stately aspect on the bench that entitles them to this distinction.

The Department of Sanitation will open tomorrow bids on a contract to build thirty well-type steel scows to replace the flat barges used for many years in the transfer of ashes and refuse to dumps. The new barges are designed to eliminate the scattering of any refuse in harbor waters.

Admission to this country under special rule of political refugees from other nations would lead to unnecessary increases in the populations of our large cities, according to Mgr. John L. Belford of the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity, Classon Avenue and Madison Street, Brooklyn.

Gale's comet, missing eleven years, has been rediscovered, according to L. E. Cunningham, astronomer at the Harvard Observatory, at a point in the southeastern sky, about ten degrees above the horizon.

Fundamental information in regard to the sensitivity of the body to wheat and cold and the sensory mechanism controlling the internal temperature of the body is reported to the American Physical Society by Drs. J. D. Hardy and T. W. Oppel of the Russell Sage Institute of Pathology.

A new kind of business and economio research more valuable than tons of figures already gathered is envisioned by Dean Ralph C. Epstein of the School of Business Administration at the University of Buffalo.
Although both the Liverpool and Bombay markets failed to meet Friday's late upturn here, prices on the Cotton Exchange ruled relatively steady yesterday to end with losses of 3 to 4 points.

Charles Rosenberg of 187 Anderson Street, this city, died today after a long illness. He was 49 years old. Mr. Rosenberg was organizer and a director of the City National Bank and Trtist Company of Hackensack; vice president of the Englewood Title Guaranty and Trust Company, and a director of the Little Ferry National Bank, the Excell Bank and Loan Company, the Bankers Security, Inc., and the Alliance Security and Realty Corportion.

The New York Physicians Art Club opened last night its eleventh annual exhibition at the New York Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. It contains 170 pictures and about seventy other art objects which range from sculpture and photography to a mahogany grandfather's clock.

The great tuna spectacle will not be confined to Maryland, New Jersey, Long Island and Nova Scotia this Summer, for Maine is going to take advantage of its location and make a bid for salt water angling fame.
Bradford Ellsworth, who said he was a New York broker, reported to police today that $29,500 worth of jewelry was taken from his room at a hotel last night.

The Canadian National joint protective board of the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen of Armerica favors establishment of a minimum forty-hour week throughout the shops of the rail system, effective June 1. The board passed a resolution to this effect in conjunction with the carmen's convention.

NEXT Saturday a nation-wide program, with the double purpose of increasing safety on the highway and stimulating the tire industry, will get under way, backed by advertising in more than 300 newspapers. It is to be called National Tire Safety Week.

The trend of many years toward social science courses has been broken at last at Williams College, according to registration figures for next year. Miscellaneous courses in the arts and letters field show an unusual rise.
Nearly 900 students in the Reserve Officers Training Corps at New York University will participate in the twentieth annual Military Field Day at Ohio Field on Friday afternoon.

Captain Bob Eisner led the Princeton polo team to a 13-5 triumph over the Pennsylvania Military Academy on Devereux Field today. The Tigers scored in every chukker, with Eisner accounting for nine tallies, half of them on long solo charges.

ASHEVILLE, N. C.-Two conventions will be held here this week, attracting more than 1,200 persons from all sections of the State. The North Carolina Association of Insurance Agents, Inc., will hold its forty-first annual convention at Grove Park Inn beginning today.

The parents of Bobby Breen filed an action for declaratory relief today to determine the legal ownership of his film earnings. The parents, Hyman and Rebecca Breen, said they had sought to have the bank where the funds are on deposit appointed trustee of their son's estate, but that the bank had refused until ownership of the money had been determined.
Samuel S. Steinberg, a policeman off duty, shot and killed one bandit and slugged another into submission today in a running gun fight in the West Oak Lane section.

Stating that although it has been in operation in various States for many years the Torrens system has not proved efficient or popular, George L. Allin of the law firm of Allin Tucker, outlines several reasons for this condition..

According to figures made public yesterday by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, whooping cough is responsible for more fatalities among young children than any other communicable disease of childhood.

The German press underlines Chancellor Adolf Hitler's reference to the eternal frontier between Italy and Germany as the most significant element in the exchange of toasts in Rome last night. The Voelkischer Beobachter this morning says:
One of Palestine's most notorious Arab rebel leaders, Issa Battat, was killed late last night by a patrol of armed police in a battle with a small band of Arabs near Hebron.

The growth of Mexican influence in Cuba during the past few months in being watched with interest and some uneasiness by American business men here who are wondering just what effect this new factor will have on the policies of the Cuban Government.

For the "revealing insight, strict integrity and supreme artistry" of her work, Georgia O'Keeffe, exponent of the modern school of painting, was honored today with the Degree of Fine Arts by the College of William and Mary. Williamsburg was her girlhood home and she left to become an art student in New York.

Establishment of the New Hudson River Group of Artists as a permanent organization, designed to foster art appreciation and provide an opportunity for Westchester painters and sculptors to display their work, was announced today.
Two incidents of the: week in Pennsylvania's political strife are illustrative of the extent to which the present chaotic primary. campaign has wrought changes in relationships.

Miss Mary Edith Carroll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Cockrill Carroll of this city, formerly of Pittsburgh, was married here yesterday afternoon in the chantry of St. Thomas Church to Paul Lawrence Grambs of New York and Bismarck, N. D., son of Mrs. Frank G. Grambs of Bismarck and the late Mr. Grambs.

THE Cambridge University Musical Society will hold a festival of British music of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, July 30 to Aug. 6, at Cambridge, England. Boris Ord, general music director of the society, will conduct and Professor Edward J. Dent, president of the society, will lecture on Tudor and Restoration music.

Scoring three runs in the sixth inning of the second game of a double-header, the Jersey City Giants salvaged the final of a four-game series, 3 to 0, after Toronto had won the opener, 3 to 1. Tom Ferrick limited the Maple Leafs to seven hits to break Toronto's six-game winning streak.

For improvement with a one-story building containing a 1,000-seat theatre and stores, the vacant plot, immediately adjoining the proposed Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's apartment house project in the Bronx, has been purchased by the Max-Gor Realty Company, Inc.

Garden "trippers" during the tulip season will be interested to see, in the bulb borders on many fine estates, the increasing prominence accorded the so-called "lily" tulips-a new type which has for some: years been attracting attention at the Spring flower shows.
Supply contracts valued at $6,206,945 were awarded in the week ended on May 5 by ten Federal agencies under the. provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

Legal manoeuvres of the past week in the dispute as to whether the National Labor Relations Board accorded a "fair hearing" to the Ford Motor Company, the Republic Steel Corporation and other employers, and renewed criticism of its activities and procedure,

If the Congressional elections were being held today the Republicans would probably capture their largest bloc of House seats since the elections of 1930, back in the middle of the Hoover Administration. That is the estimate of the -American Institute of Public Opinion following a nation-wide survey of rank and file sentiment.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marvin Nelson of 860 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Katharine Nelson, to James Stanley Richmond, son of Mrs. M. Neely Richmond of this city and Laurel, Miss.

CONCERTS by the NBC Symphony Orchestra currently heard on Saturday nights from 10 to 11:30 o'clock, scheduled to conclude for the season on May. 18, have been extended to June 25. Hans Steinberg, a conductor of the Palestine Symphony Orchestra, will direct the final broadcast.

Plans for a nation-wide "Bowl of Rice" dinner and ball, to be held simultaneously in hundreds of cities and towns throughout the country on the night of June 17, have been announced by Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr., national chairman of the newly formed United Council for Civilian Relief in China.

The Securities and Exchange Commission will take evidence on May 28 at a public hearing on an application by the New York Stock Exchange to strike from registration and listing the $25-par-value common stock of the Pierce Oil Corporation.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler's highly ceremonious tour of Italy has kindled popular imagination in Germany. It has been the one news topic of the week.
In a setting of pleasant weather and bright surroundings, the completed Henry Hudson Bridge over Spuyten Duyvil Creek was opened yesterday.
The' American boy is being discouraged from following the sea, according to the Women's Organization for the American Merchant Marine, by conditions which that group has undertaken to remedy.

Charles H. Walther, a native Baltimorean, who was one of the first exponents of "abstract painting" in America, died today at Union Memorial Hospital of injuries suffered Tuesday in an automobile accident.
FERNAND VANDEREM, in the course of his long career as essayist, journalist and novelist, has come to close acquaintance with the literary world of Paris.

A plan has been perfected by the Institute of Real Estate Management of the National Association of Real Estate Boards whereby individual property managers who meet the requirements set by the institute regarding competency and business standards may be elected to membership and designated by the initials "C. P. M."

Prompt and steady payments of premiums throughqut the depression enabled the life insurance'companies to meet the heavy cash demands of their policy holders without resort to hurried liquidation of securities which would have brought heavy losses to millions of Americans, Joseph C. Behan, chairman of. the National Committee for Life Insurance Education,
Brooklyn College recorded a 15-to12 victory over the Newark University baseball team behind the pitching of Mike D'Ambrosio, a converted outfielder, on the Kingsmen's diamond yesterday.

Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary-of State, speaking tonight at the annual dinner of the New York State Bankers Association, laid the causes of the recession directly at President Roosevelt's doorstep.
Dover celebrated the 300th anniversary of the founding of Delaware today with "open house" and a pageant on the green.

Caballero II, the Chilean horse that runs in the colors of Mrs. Ethel D.. Jacobs, thrilled a crowd of 15,000 at Jamaica yesterday as he drove through the stretch to capture the twenty-first running of the Excelsior Handicap which brought the Spring meeting of the Metropolitan Jockey Club 'to a' close.

New courses for freshmen, a revised counselor system and the housing of all first-year men on the Old Campus are important features of Yale's program designed to meet the difficult problem of the adjustment of the entering class to college life.

Of 104 utility companies queried by the Commercial Electric Cooking Council, seventy-six are planning more extensive sales campaigns this year on such types of equipment, the council announced yesterday.

Miss Marjorie Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Lawson Warner, was married to Charles Woodrow Nielsen, son of Mr. and Mrs. N. Christian Nielsen of Perth Amboy, N. J., last night at the home of her parents, 1,890 Ditmas Avenue, Brooklyn, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William E. Dudley.

Removal of the constitutional provision against gambling to permit cities or the State to raise funds for relief and other public purposes by lotteries was advocated yesterday by George F. Mand, president of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce, in a letter to Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Lewis, chairman of the Committee on the Bill of Rights

NEXT Tuesday will be the one-hundredth anniversary of the birth of a man whose name is familiar to every American. But no one will celebrate his centenary, for he is remembered only as the nation's arch-villain and his name has become a symbol of violence and murder.

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, honorary president of the National League of Women Voters, will be one of the speakers at the annual convention of the Westchester unit, to be held Friday at the Westchester Country Club, Rye.

Extension of the WPA sewing project to provide jobs for 5,000 additional needle workers was urged upon Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, yesterday by a delegation from the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

Philip W. Kniskern, president of the First Mortgage Corporation of Philadelphia, in a recent address said that the real estate cycle is about an eighteen-year period, with 9 long, even swings that can be well foretold in advance.

Two women were killed late today when a seaplane piloted by Bradford Washburn Jr., Harvard geographer and explorer, fell into Lake Union. Mr. Washburn escaped. The victims were Mrs. Ome Daiber and Miss Dorothy Mathews of Seattle. James Borrows,

The German Foreign Office, which speaks semiofficially through the Diplomatische Korrespondenz, issued in that organ today an acrimonious response to Secretary of War Harry H. Woodring's address to the United States Chamber of Commerce charging dictatorships with provoking democracies.

Fred Berry, former president of the Bronx Board of Trade, who is serving as vice chairman, in charge of the Bronx, on Mayor La Guardia's Committee on Property Improvement, announced yesterday that his division is now complete.

Developers of lake-resort properties report a heavy increase in inspections by prospective buyers. Several contracts were signed during the past week for bungalows and plots for improvement with small homes.

As Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini bill and coo to the accompaniment of fullthroated Fascist cheers, those who are running Britain today can breathe a sigh of relief that they have at least taken off the sedge of the totalitarian reunion by making the Anglo-Italian agreement.

The Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association schedule for the coming season, just received from Mrs. Anthony Bassler, chairman of the tournament committee, discloses that there will be ample competition in those sections of the metropolitan district from the opening tourney May 12 to the final oneday meeting Oct. 13.
For the fourth year, Connecticut College students will devote a day at college especially to their fathers when the annual fathers day is held May 14.

The 1938 camping season for New York City Boy Scouts will get under way soon with a series of "camporees," or annual short trips to nearby camping grounds. By means of the "camporees" the boys each Spring rediscover the "game of camping" and prepare for longer

An "honors group plan" which gives to superior students in electrical engineering increased independence and responsibility during their junior and senior years has proved to be one of the most successful educational experiments undertaken in recent years at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

SIXTY-FIVE years ago, when Charles Eliot Norton became the first Professor of Art Appreciation in America, he wrote to Thomas Carlyle from his desk at Harvard that he was undertaking the job because he hoped "to quicken, as far as may be, in the youth of a land barren of memorials of former times, a sense of connection with the past and of gratitude for the efforts and labors of other races and former generations."

Attempts to impose municipal license fees amounting to as much as $10,000 a year on self-service chain food markets, a type of retail outlet new to South Jersey, are being made here and in Atlantic City, Bridgeton and Hamilton Township, near Trenton.

"Tom" Berry, the former "Cowboy Governor" of South Dakota, is now on the trail which he hopes will make him the "Cowboy Senator" of South Dakota. Two years ago he was defeated for re-election to a third term as Governor.

TELECASTERS at Radio City attempted a televised book re view during the past week. On the 7 by 10 inch screen a critic was seen at a desk reading- excerpts from a new book, while the camera was switched to show the illustrations.

Pennsylvania's track team was no match for Cornell if their annual dual meet today as the Red and White recorded sweeps in four events to win, 94 to 41. Jim Pender, sprinter, and Lester Murdock, jump, paced Cornell with doubles while Captain J. Hamilton Hucker,

Gardeners who go in for chrysanthemums have undoubtedly noticed that nursery plants added from year to year are healthier, more vigorous and give more luxuriant bloom than divisions made from their own clumps.

One acre of the International Peace Garden, established between the United States and Canada, will be maintained by the Daughters of the British Empire in the United States, following the approval of the plan at the national convention at Jacksonville, Fla.

Dom Principe tripled down the right-field foul line and subsequently scored on an error by Mike Garbark, Villanova catcher, in the tenth to give Fordham a hardearned extra-inning 4-3 victory over the Wildcats before a crowd of 3,500 at Fordham Field yesterday.

The Hartwick Lutheran Theological Seminary will hold its graduation exercises at 8 P. M. tomorrow at St. John's Lutheran Church, 83 Christopher Street, with eight men receiving diplomas. Five Bachelor of Divinity degrees and four Master of Theology degrees will be given for graduate work.
Most classifications of listed bonds closed moderately higher in dull trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Secondary railroad obligations and certain

The Wages and Hours Bill, forced before the House yesterday by petition of members after it had been blocked by the Rules Committee, follows the Administration's theory that a floor should be put under wages and a ceiling over hours.

"Mother's Day, now accepted as an American institution, is one of America's safeguards for civilization," Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein said yesterday at the West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 West Seventy-sixth Street.

C. I. O. speakers reported to a mass meeting of textile workers on the Common today that the American Woolen Company would pay the same rate of wages as the other local mills. This announcement was hreeted with cheers.

Under a special commission from the Post Office Department, air mail will be carried from Harrison to Floyd Bennett Airport on May 19 in celebration of National Air Mail Week, it was announced today by Mrs. Loretta Patton, postmaster of Harrison.

Arthur Eckstein, who is entering upon his thirty-second year of activity in the Penn zone district, predicts that the renting situation during the coming Summer will approximate that of the Summer of 1937, when there was virtually no desirable space available in the fur district.

MOLLERE, WILLIAM P. (April 26). Estate, less than $10,000. To Mabel Wilson, friend, executrix; 1 Seaman Ave. NEW, HENRY (April 30). Estate, more than $10,000. To. Marjorie New, daughter executrix, 35 E. 76th St., jewelry, household and personal effects and life estate in residue, principal to her issue; Suzanne Unger, niece, 912 5th Ave., $2,500 and contingent interest in 1-3 residuary

Recent strikes which have beset the automotive industry in Southern Michigan are traceable largely to three factors. Foremost is the attempt of the United Automobile Workers of America to hold its membership and to collect dues to support a badly sagging treasury.

Out of discussions of conditions of household work which have agitated groups among both employers and employes, a general shifting of emphasis from legislation to training for greater skill is growing evident.

Moses Phillip Ginzburg, founder and publisher of The Daily Jewish Courier and a leader in the city's Jewish community .for more than half a century, died today in his home at 1,214 South Halsted Street. He was 75 ears old.

Great Britain's young Davis Cup team got off to a faltering start in its opening series with Rumania today, splitting the first two singles matches. Cristea Caralulis defeated C. M. Jones, 6-3, 3-6, 6-2, 8-6, but R. A. Shayes put the Britons back on even terms by routing O. Schmidt, 6-3, 6-2, 6-2.

The annual meeting of the Board of Education will be held Tuesday at 4 P. M. at 500 Park Avenue. Elections of officers will-take place. A luncheon for Dr. Frank J. O'Brien, director of the Bureau of Child Guidance, will be given by members of his staff and representatives of public and private welfare agencies at the Hotel.Plaza on May 21 at 12:30 P. M. William Jansen, assistant superintendent, is chairman of the committee.

Britain's Walker Cup team to meet the Urlited States at St, Andrews on June 3-4 was chosen today, except foi one place to be filled after the British amateur golf championship which starts at Troon, Scotland, on May 23.

ALEXANDER KORDA prefaced his observations on the State of Hollywood versus the foreign cinema by quoting from Lewis Carroll's "Through the Looking Glass" that passage wherein the bewildered Alice, exhausted after running through the chess-board valley, asks the Red Queen to explain why she has not gone anywhere.
The Rev. Charles F. Farrelly, pastor of St. Joseph's Catholic Church in Rensselaer and dean of that county, died today in St. Peter's Hospital following a long illness. His age was 57.

Wladyslaw Talun, giant Polish grappler, will trade holds with Sheriff Tom Hanley of Oklahoma in the main wrestling attraction at the New York Hippodrome tomorrow night. Talun, who stands seven feet tall and scales 300 pounds, is expected to score easily over his Western opponent.

While credit conditions compare unfavorably with those of a year ago in most major lines, there is sharp variation between industries, and a few are finding collections running about the same rate as last year, according to a survey by William Walker Orr, secretary of the New York Credit Men's Association, which will be published in the May 15 issue of Credit Executive.
TRADITIONALLY the rewards of scholars are meager. They do not usually enjoy even the expectation of earthly immortality as compensation for the poorness of their worldly estates.
Following are the texts of the addresses by Premier Benito Mussolini and Chancellor Adolf Hitler at the state banquet at the Palazzo Venezia tonight.

Bob Seeds, 30-year-old big league cast-off who plays center field for the Newark Bears. finished rewriting the International League's home-run record book today as Newark walloped the Buffalo Bisons, 14--8.
