Bowing before superior batting power and steadier pitching, the N. Y. U. baseball team went down to defeat yesterday, 10 to 5, at the hands of Temple at Ohio Field. George Patte, pitching the entire distance for the visitors, yielded ten hits, but put on pressure to get out of difficulties in the second, fourth and fifth innings.

The author of the following article, who is associate curator of geology at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, is conducting research on human origins in the Far East. His expedition, which started last Fall, is sponsored by the Philadelphia Academy and the Peabody Museum of Harvard University, with the support of the Carnegie Institution of Washington and the American Philosophical Society.

Mayor La Guardia and the Transit Commission have agreed, at least in principle, on the procedure to be followed in seeking a constitutional amendment to enable the city to purchase the privately operated B. M. T. and Interborough Rapid Transit System properties with city corporate stock or serial bonds exempt from the debt limit, it was indicated yesterday.

The population of Rome accorded Adolf Hitler this week a reception whose warmth surprised most people witnessing it. The cheering was perhaps not so overwhelming as it has been on some previous occasions but it was enough to convince observers of its spontaneity.

The Memorial Day week-end will serve as in past years to launch the Summer season's activities at various beach clubs and other rendezvous for sports and entertaining on the North and South shores of Long Island.

Mrs. John Gardner Coolidge and Mrs. Richard D. Sears have come from Boston to the Ambassador. Mr. and Mrs. John Hampton Barnes have arrived at the Madison from Philadelphia. Mrs. James-N. Hill has returned from Europe and is at Big Tree Farm,- Wheatley, L; I.

Arthur E. Allen, architect of many homes recently built in Long Island residential centers, calls tention to the fact that while home building during the past two years has seemed very impressive to many observers, the volume actually has amounted to less than 32 per cent of the amount of building per population in 1929.

The Richard J. H. Gottheil Medal awarded annually by the Zeta Beta Tau fraternity to the American who has done the most for Jewry was accepted last night by Dr. Ruth Mack Brunswick on behalf of her father, Federal Judge Julian W. Mack.

Mr. and Mrs. James Robert Werth of this place have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Miss Amanda Bogardus Werth, to Ensign John Nathaniel Boland, U. S. N., son of Commander Micajah. Boland, Medical Corps, U. S. N. (retired) and Mrs. Boland of Virginia and New York.

Eastern Pennsylvania captured all except two of the drill-team awards today at the National School Safety Patrol Convention, which was marked by a parade of 11,000 boys and girls from seventeen States along Constitution Avenue and past a reviewing stand near the White House.

Taking off from San Diego, June 1, Richard Archbold, research associate of the American Museum of Natural History, plans to fly 8,000 miles ,across the Pacific to New Guinea to aid the Museum's exploratory expedition there. The flight is to be made- via Hawaii and Guam.

As never before, men and women are besieging the offices of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, 425 Lafayette Street, attempting to find some means of bringing their relatives from Austria and Germany into this country, Isaac L. Asofsky, general manager, disclosed yesterday.

Mrs. Walter J. Enright of this city and Delray Beach, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Housh, to Henry van Dyke Gibson, son of Hamilton Gibson, former headmaster of the Gunnery School, Washington, Conn., and Mrs. Gibson.

Miss Mary Alice Cahill of Manhattan, a junior at the College of New Rochelle, presided yesterday as queen over the May Day festivities here which about 2,000 persons attended. Miss Mary Lavelle, general chairman of the festival and president of the Mission Club, crowned Miss Cahill as queen.

Better shipping facilities from New York to Puerto Rico have been assured, Governor Blanton Whiship asserted today on his return from New York and Washington. He added that important harbor improvements at San Juan would make it a great Caribbean port.

Life insurance protection, in dollar volume and in the number of persons covered,, reached record "high levels in the United States in 1937, according to the National Committee for Life Insurance Education. Underwriters throughout the country are cooperating this week in transmitting to the public the annual message of life Insurance.
Stocks firm and mixed in slightly heavier trading; turnover, 558,240 shares. All bonds generally higher in quiet trading; transactions, $S,786,675.

SPEAKING last week in London, Dean Inge no doubt did much cheerfully to assist the digestive forces at work in a group of literary lunchers when he prophesied that before long-even, I believe he said, in the dictionary's next edition-it would be thus defined:
GENOESE hotel keys are. tiny little things attached to a neat metal labelette bearing the hotel's name and the room number. Ours remained snugly
The Knickerbocker Greys, boys' cadet regiment, held their annual final

For the first time since "heavy hydrogen," weighing twice as much as ordinary hydrogen, has been discovered by Professor Harold C. Urey of Columbia University, its presence has been made actually visible to the eye by a change of color in a chemical solution, it is reported in the current issue of The Journal of Chemical Physics.

FARRO-ROGOGEN-Mr. and Mrs. Harry Roggen announce the marriage of their daughter, Elsa, to Mr. Ruben T. Farro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Farro of Antwerp, Belgium, on Sunday, May 1. POLLOCK--LAUGHLIN--Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Laughlin of Cleveland, Ohio, announce the marriage of their daughter, Catherine, to Martin Stanley Pollock, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Edward Pollock, New York, May 7.
Life insurance sales in the last ten years 'were less subject to long periods of depression than general business, the trade index Of THE NEW YORK TIMES shown.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Currier of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Esma Currier, to Paul J. Christner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Christner.
Busi ness men are swamping the Reconstruction Finance Corporation with applications for part of the $1,500,000,000 that it has available for lendinz to business.
Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, entertained "the American mother of 1938," '.Mrs. Grace Noll Crowell, poet laureate of Texas, at a tea at her Hyde Park estate this afternoon.

Negotiations for purchase of the Memphis Power and Light Company by the city of Memphis have been recessed again. No date for their resumption has been set. Paul B. Sawyer, president of the National Power and Light Company, who came here to open negotiations on March 30, will return to New York...

About 150 high school students of the metropolitan area filled the air of the North Field of Van Cortlandt Park all day yesterday with tiny aircraft as the fourth annual model airplane championship competitions of the Daniel Guggenheim School of Aeronautics of New York University were held.

SOCIAL welfare people may as well give up hope of ever being able to reclaim the "Dead End" boys for society. Warner Brothers have already cast them in another crime drama ("Chalked Out"--a Warden Lawes story) and the boys only recently completed "Crime School,"

Making his first appearance in big-time competition, a 28-year-old home club representative, Roger Fawcett of New York City, gave the veterans of scatter-gun shooting something to talk about when he captured the amateur championship of America at sixteen-yard clay targets yesterday over the New York A. C. traps at Travers Island.

A single by Cecil Travis that scored Zeke Bonura from second gave the Senators a 5-to-4 victory over the White Sox today in a ten-inning battle. The decision was the fourth straight for the Senators and the third in overtime taken by Washington in four days.

Bonds called last week for redemption before their maturity dates were in somewhat smaller volume than in the preceding period. The announcements, which principally were for future months, involved, for the most part, small sections of issues called to satisfy sinking-fund requirements.

Jobs filled through the State Unemployment Service increased in March for the first time in six months, but the total was still far short of the number of placements in March, 937, according to a report published yesterday in The Industrial Bulletin of the State Labor Department.
Engineers at Westinghouse Research Laboratories today completed the third of a battery of electric furnaces in which steel stretches like taffy when it gets hot enough.

"Daphne," the second of Richard Strauss's new one-act operas, will receive its world premiere Oct. 22 at Dresden. It will be conducted by Karl Boehm, to whom Strauss has dedicated the work. Margarete Teschemacher will sing the title role and the role of Apollo has been assigned to Torsten Ralf.

Many engaged young women in society have chosen June and the countryside of Long Island for their weddings, and the approaching season both on the North and South Shores finds much social activity on the calendar for prospective brides and their attendants.

Relief workers today passed out week-end food orders from the dwindling city relief fund as the city's anxious poor were heartened by Mayor Burton's promise to offer definite proposals Monday for alleviating the critical situation.

Champion Nornay Saddler, owned by James M. Austin of Old Westbury, L. I., was named best in show at the annual fixture of the Bryn Mawr Kennel Club on the grounds of the Philadelphia Country Club today.

Deaths from automobile accidents declined nearly 20 per cent in the nation's leading cities the first four months of this year, the Census Bureau reported today. In 130 cities, motor deaths from Jan. 1 to April 30 totaled 2,536, as compared with 3,138 in the similar period last year.

ROME.--The future of Trieste, which has been affected economically by Germany's annexation of Austria, is one of the most important problems that will have to be solved between Berlin and Rome during the forthcoming negotiations for a new commercial treaty.
It was a Kentucky boy they helped down from this Kentucky Derby winner--a shyly grinning, happily dazed little fellow named Eddie Arcaro.

Visitors returning from Mexico bring back recollections of the flow'ers and plants in pots and jardinieres which are a definite feature of Mexican gardens and patios. Few seem to realize, however, that much the same pleasing effects can be attained in our northern climate.

NOW that the star system has come under adverse critical scrutiny, Hollywood can feel that its cup of hemlock is filled to the brim and waiting to be quaffed. Of course, the potion added by the Independent Theatre Owners Association last week was not as deadly as it might have seemed.

CONSIDERING the vast amount that has been written regarding the poetry of Alexander Pope, one is rather startled to recollect that since Joseph Warton's Essay appeared in 1756 no book-length critical study of the author of "The Rape of the Lock" has been published until the present day.

The Belgian pair of A. Buysse and A. Biliet won the Wembly six-day bike race which ended tonight. They covered 1,950 miles and four laps and gained 1,348 points. The United States entry of Joseph Rodman and Henry O'Brien were eighth with 384 points.

Representative James .M. Mead, Buffalo Democrat, who has been mentioned as a possible American Labor party candidate for Senator, said yesterday that he was "very well satisfied" with his present post and was not a candidate for any other.

Miss Evelyn Young, daughter of Mrs. John Rogers Young, and Lawrence Tremaine, son of State Controller and Mrs. Morris Tremaine, were married this afternoon in the home of the bride's mother. Dr. Albert G. Butzer officiated.

George Beattie, 55 years old, of '1,717 East Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn, and John Helmus, 43, of 660 Broadway, Brooklyn, died on the way-to the Peekskill Hospital here early today from injuries sustained when an automobile, in which they were riding, driven by Leslie Beattie, a son of Mr.. Beattie, failed to make a sharp curve on the Crompond Road and crashed into a tree. Both men died of skull fractures.

Seemingly sympathetic with the injured feelings of Newark over the omission of its airport from the advertising and maps of the World's Fair, Mayor La Guardia moved yesterday to win recognition for the city across the Hudson.

The old notion that blue light or red light is good for the health is shattered by Dr. Herman Vollmer, who has been experimenting with plants and animals in Germany and more recently in Mount Sinai Hospital, New York. He tested lentils, ants, guppies, flies and rats.
Sir Samuel Hoare, British Home Secretary, served notice on dictators today that he believed democracies would flourish by the side of the "juggernaut machines" if the democratic peoples faced facts.

Joseph A. McInerney, president of the Building and Construction Trades Department, American Federation of ,Labor, will be the principal speaker at a luncheon meeting of the New York Building Congress next Thursday at the Hotel Commodore.
The Democratic Junior League of New York will hold its annual bridge, tea and fashion show Saturday on the Biltmore Roof. Proceeds of the event will aid the social service bureau of the league.

Big cities in the United States are having a lot of trouble because the average height of their buildings has increased, whereas the average width of their streets has not. There is vastly mores floor area but not much more street area.

Closing a week's celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of Jacob A. Riis Settlement House, 48 Henry Street, an alumni association-the first organization of its type in the settlement's history-was organized last night at a meeting attended by several hundred persons in the Riis House auditorium.

John F. Dore Jr.; son. of Seattle's former Mayor, discovered today that. the letter which he absent mindedly carried around in his coat for a week contained a check from the Federal Government for $1,241,961.

In observance of National Music Week, which for the past six days has- proclaimed the gospel "Foster Home Talent, ". the NBC Symphony Orchestra under Pierre Monteux presented four American works in last night's broadcast from Radio City By way of contrast, the "Roman Carnival" of Berlioz was the curtain-raiser, while Chausson's B flat symphony concluded the. program.

Repreresentative Wright (One-Bill-at-aTime) Patman, soft-voiced but persistent Texan who fought seven Tears for a bonus bill and got it and then battled eighteen months for the Robinson-Patman antichain-store legislation and got that, too, is hip-deep in another fight, to obtain government ownership of the Federal Reserve banks.

Children representing twentyeight nationalities, all of them actually Americans, but in the costumes of their racial origin, will take part in the celebration. of Parents Day on the Central Park Mall today.

AN opportunity for American photographers to break into print as contributors to the better annual English photographic publications arises with the call for photographs for the 1939 edition of The Photography Year Book.

THOUGH one of a considerable number of illuminating books which have been published in recent years on China and the Far East, Mr. E. R. Hughes's volume will attract the special attention of those who are interested in the international significance of China.

Declaring that the nation's tourists were highly dissatisfied with the present "inadequate and obsolete" system of route-numbering, the American Automobile Association announced today that its affiliated motor clubs over the country were joining in a cooperative effort to bring about improvements.

Closing scores in first-class cricket matches started today: Middlesex 283 (Webster' 76, Elrich 63, Paine five for 53); Warwickshire 56 for five, at Lord's. Somerset 128 (Watts five for 35, Gover four for 37) ; Surrey 202 for three (Gregory 96 not out), at the Oval.

The air of peace departed today from the annual meeting of the American Council on Education. Preceding the arrival of President Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago by. air this afternoon to discuss education and the improvement of society, Chancellor Oliver C. Carmichael of Vanderbilt University had opened the day with what was interpreted as an attack on the philosophy of Dr. Hutchins.

Exhibitors, handlers and all others connected with dog shows hereabout will welcome this week the opportunity once more to get out into the open. The Spring season in and about New York is the most delightful of the year in the exhibition world and some of the most notable of all the canine events are crowded into the two months just beginning.
Chicago's crippled White Sox received another setback tonight with the announcement that their ace relief pitcher, Clint Brown, had a chipped bone in his pitching arm.

Retail prices on over 4,000 branded, patented and copyrighted articles "have been raised about Buy 14.3 per cent on the average" since the passage of the New York FeldCrawford act and the Tydings-Milder amendment to the Sherman act, according to the compilation issued

James B. Hodges, chairman of the Florida State Democratic Execu. tive Committee, died tonight in his office, apparently of a heart attack He was 60 years old. He was the center of a control. versy last Win'er because he criti cized President Roosevelt's policies An effort to unseat him failed a the January meeting of the cornmittee.
Color in plumbing fixtures is not costly and forms only a small part of the total cost of any bathroom, states the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau.

An opera that was written and performed 215 years ago had its first American presentation, if available records are accurate, at Smith College here tonight. The work is "Costanza e Fortezza" by Johann Josef Flux, contemporary of Bach and Handel and highly valued as a composer in this time.

A NUMBER of United States commemorative half dollars are still available to collectors, and the following list has been compiled at the request of many readers: Daniel Boone--Three-mint sets of 1937 are available at $12.40 and also a few Philadelphians at $1.25.

Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Gleason Tenney gave a dinner dance last night in the Cottage Suite of Hampshire House for Miss Joan P. Lusk and their son, Charles Henry Tenney, who will be married on Saturday in Ridgefield, Conn.

IMPROVED trade was reported from numerous points last week and in some cases it was indicated that the declines under last year represented only the difference in prices over the twelve months. For the country as a whole, average dollar volume probably ran about 8 per cent under a year ago.

Among the many gifts illustrative of home craftsmanship and architectural progress recently received by the Cooper Union Museum for its department in the arts of decoration are a number of English tiles with small designs of men and women and several Polish tiles of the eighteenth century.

Modern heating plants, new types of fuel, the growing practice of sending wash to laundries and the increasing number of women going to business are factors contributing toward lessening the necessity for cellars in homes.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 7, unless specified: At Ball: Canopus, Pigeon, S-36, 37, 38, 39 and 40. San Diego to Navy Yard, Mare Island, via San Pedro: Goff. Reuben James. Algorma, at San Pedro.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Condit of Montclair, N. J., 'have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Loraine Condit, to Frederick E. Kneip, son of Mrs. Arthur Powell of Montclair and the late Frederick Kneip.

AFTER five weeks of travel Through the Southwest, the South and the Pacific Coast region, during which he obtained first-hand information as a result of across-the-desk visits with over 300 dealers, H. J. Klingler, general manager of Pontiac Motor Division, has returned to Detroit considetably encouraged over conditions as he found them.

The Police Athletic League of the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department presented a carnival and circus last night at the 165th Regiment Armory, Twenty-sixth. Street and Lexington Avenue. For the adults who witnessed the show it was a demonstration of the recreational activities of the bureau;

IS there an invisible, odorless, tasteless substance, called the ether, occupying all space, or is it a figment of the imagination-something conveniently fabricated by man to assist in explaining the great mysteries of light waves and radio waves?

The acknowledged queen of Fall flowering perennials, the IHardy Chrysanthemum, is enjoying renewed popularity among home gardenai. One cause of this renewed interest has been the development of the splendid Korean hybrids, which can be relied upon to blom even when an early killing frost is experienced and which are' much hardier than many of the older types.

The more or less expert garden enthusiast, with facilities for starting his plants early in windows or cold frames, now has a supply of husky seedlings ready for transplanting, but beginners who are now "making garden"-many of them for the first time-are planting their seeds in the open.

While only' one component was higher in the week, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has advanced. For the period ended April 30 the number lifted to 75.6 from 75.4 in the preceding week and compares with 108.0 for the corresponding week last year.

New jersey's Governor, A. Harry Moore, will be honor guest at the foureenth annual musical of Georgian Court College on May 15. Plans for he event, at which Jessica Dragonette, radio soprano and an alumna of the college, is to be the featured soloist, include a formal reception to the Governor and his staff.

RADIO has no hard and fast rules, simply a knowledge of the art and the application. of good taste and common sense in making its necessary arbitrary decisions on program. subject-matter, Lenox R. Lohr, - president of the National Broadcasting Company, reported at the recent round-table conference of the Chainber of Commerce.

Competition between rail and motor transport in South Africa is controlled by law, and controlled chiefly to protect the railroad. This was easily accomplished because the railroad, the second largest system in the world under one management, belongs to the people.

The deep Blue of Yale ran to the masthead on the banks of the Schuyllkill with the first race of the Blackwell Cup regatta today and it was still flying there in the twilight, for Yale made a clean sweep.

Columbia's varsity tennis team overwhelmed Navy, 9 to 0, to score its eighth victory of the season, on the South Field courts yesterday. In sweeping the six singles and three doubles matches, the Lion netinen were extended to extra sets in only three contests.

THE ageless Will Fyffe, a favorite of the English music halls, refuses, like a coy Hol lywood ingenue in her twenties, to give the year of his birth. His motives, however, are different and have something to do with his resentment against the modern world which dooms a man past the age of 40 to continue in his rut or to disappear into the outer darkness.

Joseph Gilbertson of Vancouver, B. C., fourth engineer of the Freighter Heathcote, was released last. night by authorities at Osaka- after paying a fine 'of 30 yen on a charge of intruding on a fortified naval zone.

St. Peter's College here was named this week by the committee of the Jesuit intercollegiate one-act play contest as the college selected for this year's presentation. It will be held in the Collins Auditorium'of St. Peter's on May 20.

Dartmouth twice came from behind today to defeat Pennsylvania, 7 to 4, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game. Harold Wonson, sophomore right hander, limited Penn to six hits in his second league victory, and was helped by one big inning, the seventh, when the Indians batted Payson Brickley from the box with a five run barrage.

MEMPIS, Tenn. "KING COTTON ON PARADE" is the theme of the eighth annual Mem phis Cotton Carnival, a Spring festival in the bustling river city which is the world's 'largest inland cotton market. The carnival takes place this year from Tuesday to Thursday, inclusive.

A movement to make America independent of France as a source for cigarette paper was seen in the paper trade here last week in the announcement that the Ecusta Paper Corporation will build a $2,000,000 plant at Brevard, N. C., for making cigarette paper.
The top-speed merchants of automobile racing will begin their quest on May 21 for starting places in the annual 500-mile Memorial Day whirl.
A woodchopper's attempt to extract gold from a rock he had found at Pinkham Notch resulted today in the death of his five-months-old son and the serious illness of his entire family.

MOST "comic" histories, no matter how much they may have convulsed their contemporary audiences, make dreary reading in a later age. A notable exception occurs in the work of Gilbert Abbott a Beckett, a distinguished lawyer whose family claimed direct descent from the a Becket.

With the nation in the throes of a new depression which has hit the heavy industries and building labor harder than other sectors, attention is again turning to the hope that a housing boom, or at least a considerable increase in construction, may help us out of our difficulties.

With the exception of Sundays, there have been sculpture demonstrations every afternoon at the outdoor sculpture exhibition at Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street. Each afternoon a member of the Sculptors Guild, which is sponsoring the show, has- modeled or carved for the benefit of visitors.

Enlarging its Philadelphia schedule, the Metropolitan Opera Association will give ten performances, including Wagner's "Nibelungen Ring" cycle of four operas, in this city next .season, according to an announcement by General Manager Edward Johnson.
Postmaster General James A. Farley and A. B. (Happy) Chandler, Governor of Kentucky, headed the list of widely known persons who crowded the Churchill Downs boxes beginning early this afternoon.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--The seventh annual Atlantic City Horse Show will be the center of attraction for visitors here during the coming week. Already visitors are arriving from many parts of the country, to be on hand for the opening on Tuesday night and to remain through the entire five days.

A steady shipment of copper in lots of 500 tons weekly is being made by express steamers to Europe for Czechoslovakia, foreign traders reported yesterday. The shipment of copper itself would attract little attention from exporters, but the fact that express steamers are being used and premiums in the form of higher freight
Princeton and Cornell, which will combine on a competitive track jaunt to England this Summer, practiced up on their team-work today in delivering to Yale a double-barreled sports jolt.

A mission of the League of Nations, making a tour of South American republics to study local conditions in different countries, completed its fourth day of active work here this afternoon with numerous conferences with Chilean experts.

Sunny skies lured a crowd of 28,000 to Suffolk Downs today to see Mrs. Emil Denemark's Finance come back from a bad showing in the last outing by winning the $7,500 added Governor's Handicap, one-mile feature, to pay $4.20 for $2. Finance was timed in 1:38 for the distance.

WITH ski and snow train memories tucked away, the foldboat train now blossoms forth again to appease the appetites of those who seek relaxation and recreation in the open air playgrounds of the countryside.

Orders assigning several wellknown officers in the Second Corps Area to new duties were issued by the War Department last week. Major Joseph N. Dalton, Assistant Chief-of Staff for Intelligence (G-2), was ordered detached from this duty on May 21. Major Dalton will not leave Second Corps Area Headquarters on Governors Island, but will be shifted to duty with the Adjutant General's Department there.

Former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley, candidate for Governor in 1936, and George E. Sokolsky, writer, will be the principal speakers at a dinner for Joseph A. Levenson, veteran Republican leader of the First Assembly District, at the Hotel Commodore on Thursday evening. John R.

A total of 2,496 commitments for residential construction covering $13,533,200 in property values was issued last month by the Federal Housing Administration in New York City and vicinity, it was announced yesterday. This was an all time high and exceeded by about $500,000 the total transactions in the same area for the entire first quarter of the year.

Viewing the mid-season furniture market in Chicago as the most crit ical experienced by the home-furnishings industry in years, manufacturers of rugs, curtains and draperies and all lines of home wares were highly encouraged here last week by reports that furniture

Foreign Mnister Georges Bonnet submitted to the ench Cabinet this morning for its approvall the attitude he intends to ake on the various questions that vill come before the League of Naions Council at Geneva Monday. It is believed here that the meeting wil be one of the most important ever held.

AFTER seventeen months of a public television service on high definition in London, the British Broadcasting Corporation, supposed by the government and the radio manufacturers, has decided to make a fresh start.

The opening for the season of the Terrace Restaurant at Sherry's will take place on Tuesday during the luncheon hour, when a "Town and Country" fashion show will be given to advance the work of the women's auxiliary of the Children's Welfare Federation.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Victoria Rook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Royal Rook of Garden City, L. I., to Chauncey Brewster Garver, son of Ms. John A. Garver of 300 Park Avenue and Wrexleigh, Oyster Bay, L. I., and the late Mr. Garver, took place yesterday noon at the home of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Childe Hassam, 850 Park Avenue.

Inspecting the first harvest of response to his national can for new political action, Governor Philip F. La Follette expressed elation this week at both the scope and quality of public sentiment, as it appears in Madison.
The Westchester Racing Association's Spring meeting at Belmont Park, lasting twenty-four days and presenting nineteen stake events grossing close to $300,000, will get under way tomorrow.

The following is the chart showing how the Kentucky Derby was run at Churchill Downs today: SEVENTH RACE--The Kentucky Derby; $50,000 added; 3-year-olds; one mile and a quarter. Start good; won driving; place same. Went to post 6:32 (New York time), off 6:36 1/2. Winner, b. c., by Insco-Margaret Lawrence. Trainer, B. A. Jones. Value to winner, $47,050; second, $6,000; third, $3,000; fourth, $1,000. Times--0:231-5, 0:472-5, 1:122-5, 1:381-5, 2:044-5.. Weather, cloudy; track, fast.
The New York Power Squadron will finish Its onshore formalities of the season tomorrow night at the Hotel McAlpin and get ready for its Summer afloat.

Discussing the preliminary report recently issued by the committee on the rehousing of tenants of the Citizens Housing Council, which advocated the establishment by the city of a permanent rehousing bureau to assist tenants to find new quarters when forced to vacate buildings about to be demolished, Albert Mayer stressed the importance of rehousing such families whose homes will be razed as the city's housing program and other public works projects get under way.

Cooperation with high schools of the vicinity is one of the policies followed by Skidmore College. During the past week Skidmore has been host to schools on three occasions. Friday night there was a public speaking contest in which students from twelve high schools competed.

Italo Colonello, Italian heavyweight, will trade punches with Tony Lambert of Stockton, Calif., in the star bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace tomorrow night. Lambert, who will be making his first appearance in New York, has a triumph over Jimmy Adamick to his credit.

EASILY the pick of this month's crop is a first recording of Beethoven's scena "Ah, Perfido!" (Op. 65) by Kirsten Flagstad and the Philadelphia Orchestra directed by Eugene Ormandy. This intensely dramatic recitative and aria was composed by Beethoven at 26, even before the First symphony.

The Administration's proposed relief and recovery program for the fiscal year 1939, beginning next July 1, makes possible a deficit of $3,000,000,000 to $4,000,000,000, according to new estimates made public today.

John Strawbridge's chestnut mare Rockicy today easily won the Harston Cup Steeplechase, feature of the Whitemarsh Valley Hunt Club's annual Spring meeting. Rockicy, with Ned Owen up, romped home twenty lengths ahead of Manton B. Metcalf Jr.'s Pete O'Donnell. The victory gave Strawbridge a second leg on the Harston Cup.

INDIVIDUAL designs and articles in the limited-edition class are still obtained through the medium of handicrafts; it is also through handwork that sample patterns are produced for later adaptation to quantity production by machine.

Hope for the passage by Congress of legislation recognizing the merit system in the appointment of postmasters of the first, second and third classes has spurred the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs to renewed activity in rounding out its first year of the operation of asdefinite legislative policy.

United States Government advices from Shanghai report that fourteen privately owned Chinese broadcasting stations voluntarily suspended operations on April 28 as a protest against registration and censorship requirements instituted by the Japanese.

Before the largest crowd to see them in action this year, either on the road or in the Bronx, the Yankees tamed the Tigers yesterday under the punishing influence of the most savage artillery display their bats have thus far achieved in the campaign.

A share of the responsibility for the world-wide trend toward dictatorship and the "disastrous retreat from reason" was laid at the door of educators yesterday by Mark Starr, educational director of the International Ladies.Garment Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, speaking at Teachers College before members of the New York College Teachers Union in a forum on "Democracy and Higher Education. "

Employment on Class I railroads decreased by 1.54 per cent to 913,070 between March 15 and April 15, and the to tal was 19.27 per cent lower than in April, 1937, according to an Interstate Commerce Commission report issued today. All groups except maintenance of way and structures, which showed an increase of 2.57 per cent, had decreases in the period.

A KIND of Spring festival, the simultaneous opening of no less than three. shows of work by Kaethe Kollwitz might be called--though the work of this great German artist is far removed in spirit from any festival mood.

After hearing arguments, Federal Judge John A. Peters today ordered opposing counsel to file briefs in the attempt of a minority stockholders' group of the - Midwest Refining Company, incorporated in Maine and with headquarters in Denver, Col., to set aside action of a stockholders' majority in{ the sale of the company to the Standard Oil Company of Indiana.
The Wakefield and Woodlawn sections of the Bronx will soon be the scene of building activity, predicts James A. Houlihan of D. Houlihan Sons and vice president of the Bronx Real Estate Board.
St. John's College from Brooklyn beat Harvard, 5 to 4, in baseball today. The Crimson had a 4-to-1 lead until the seventh, when "Slim" Curtis passed three batters in succession.

Sponsored by the University of Pennsylvania, the Cultural Olympics project, introduced for the first time in the Spring of 1937, has drawn nearly 45,000 participants this year, according to an analysis made public today by Dr. Frederick C. Gruber, the director.

The American Institute of the City of New York will hold a School Science Fair in cooperation with the American Museum of Natural History for five days at the museum, beginning today. The fair will be the tenth annual one of its kind.

HITLER in Rome, like Hitler in Vienna and Hitler overshadowing Prague, is rather like the moving picture star who steps out of a two-dimensional medium and strides before the footlights in person. Hitherto the National Socialist leader has posed against his own background and played his extraordinary role within fixed boundaries.

Undergraduate members of Phi Eta Sigma, freshman honorary scholastic society at the Pennsylvania State College, announced today that they had selected Dr. Frank D. Kern, dean of the Graduate School and head of the Department of Botany, as recipient of their award for unsubsidized research.

Mrs. James D. Lester of Scarsdale was elected president of the Mount Holyoke College Club at the annual Spring luncheon of the organization at the Hotel New Weston yesterday. She succeeds Mrs. F. A. Whitney of Ridgewood, N. J.

ONLY a few weeks after the Austrian debacle Paris was already agitating the idea of a "French Salzburg," and Jean Zay, Minister of National Education, came out strongly for it in an article in "Paris-Soir." M. Zay, to be sure, made no extravagant or irrealizable plea.

The course of European affairs from the Soviet standpoint never has run worse than it is running now. Soviet political observers are convinced that Chancellor Adolf Hitler's triumphal visit to Rome, as if celebrating a victory over Italy in selsing Austria, can only be the prelude to further fascist aggression, which will give Hitler eventual domination over all the Balkans.

Motion-picture films crack if they are not kept in an air-conditioned vault. Also they burn slowly even if made of fire-resisting cellulose. Hence the importance of the new metal film to which Terry Ramsaye, editor of The Motion Picture Herald, calls the attention of this department.

CARLETON BEALS has always been a scrupulous commentator upon the current events of "America South," and in his previous book by that name he found the Latin Americas admirable, potentially prosperous and generally ailing because of internecine strife plus. the sharp practice of United States capitalists.
In the opinion of his countrymen something more than congratulations are due King Gustaf V of Sweden on his eightieth birthday, which will be celebrated on June 16.

ARTHUR RANSOME upsets all our ideas about books in series, for John, Susan, Titty and Roger, who have already figured as principals in some four volumes, reappear in Mr. Ransome's latest book with the same freshness and reality that delighted us when we first made their acquaintance in "Swallows and Amazons."

Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissionsr of Hospitals since Mayer La Guardian first took office in 1934, plans to retire from city service as soon as the Mayor finds a successor. Commenting on Dr. Goldwater's desire to resign, Mayor La Guar dia said at City Hall yesterday:

I MARRIED AN ANGEL--Wednesday evening at the Shubert Theatre. A musical version (Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart) of a comedy from the .Hungarian, with Dennis King, Vera Zorina, Vivienne Segal, Walter Slezak, Audrey Christie, Charles Walters and others.

Robert Edwards, one of the senior pursers of the Cunard White Star Lines, sailed yesterday on the Carinthia for the last time in that capacity after thirty-seven years of service on the North Atlantic. When the ship reaches Liverpool,

Held to a 3-3 tie in the first half, Hofstra College's rugby team rallied in the second period to score a surprisingly decisive 24-3 victory over the New York Rugby Club at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.
John J. Meenan, Inc., managing agents, report that the nine-story apartment house at 139 West Eighty-second Street is 100 per cent rented. It contains seventy-five suites.
The University of Southern California's undefeated track and field .team today inflicted one of the severest wallopings Stanford has received 'in many years, rolling up a 94 1-6-to-36% victory.

Cigarette sales during the first week of the city tax slumped 20 per cent, with the effect upon dealers so marked that they are planning a strong fight when the levy comes up for re-enactment on June 30, William A. Hollingsworth, president of the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America, said yesterday.

PROSPECTS are that the Metropolitan Opera Association may be on the road next Spring for about six weeks, twice the length of its last jaunt. All visits on its recently completed itinerary will undoubtedly be repeated, and one or two stop-overs may be lengthened. Boston, which enjoyed ten days of opera, has already made known that it wants two weeks next Spring.

A young real estate man who found himself inexplicably on the second floor of a Park Avenue home at about 2 o'clock yesterday morning finished an unusual day in Felony Court, where he heard a lecture on sobriety and paid a $25 fine. Early in the course of his adventures he easily might have been shot.

Miss Helen Marjorie Swanson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Emanuel Swanson of Chicago, was married here this afternoon to Harry Turner Newcomb 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry T. Newcomb of New York, at Holly Farms, the country home of the bridegroom's parents.

Miguel Cruchaga, Ernesto Darros Jarpa, Guillermo Pereira and Luis Barriga, all former Foreign Ministers 1 of Chile, expressed approval of the I agreements reached during the visit here of Jose Maria Cantilo, Argentine Foreign Minister, that arbitration over islands in Beagle Channel be entrusted to Homer S. Cum- c mings, United States Attorney General.
Although residents were unaware of it, New York's capital was theoretically "bombed" from the air today by four planes of the Thirtieth Bombardment Squadron.

All persons intending to import commodities into Austria have been compelled since April 21 to apply in each case for a foreign exchange certificate at the Foreign Office in Vienna, according to regulations issued by that office, the. Department of Commerce reported today.

The stringent requirements of the Federal Housing Administration with respect to ground coverage make it practically impossible for builders and developers in the Bronx and other parts of the city to proceed with large-scale housing programs under Section 210 of the amended National Housing Act, declares Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade.

A definite trend is noticeable toward the construction of homes in the lower-price barckets to meet the increasing demand for reidences in the $3,000 to $5,000 price class, declares Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator.

Broad liberal education for prospective teachers, long impeded by regulations of State boards stressing "how to teach rather than what to teach," will be undertaken in a new five-year training program to be put into effect at Columbia University in 1939-40, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes bf Columbia College announced yesterday.

The unearthing recently in Asia of some ancient documents has revealed that the practice of insuring lives originated in China ages before the birth of Christ. In fact, long before the Code of Hammurabi in ancient Babylon, which provided for various sorts of insurance, it was common practice for the Chinese to take out what corresponds to life insurance policies.

With cash awards amounting to more than $200 in prospect, New York artists are preparing for the thirteenth semi-annual Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit, which will open on next Friday and continue to May 22. A jury will select the prize-winning work on the opening day.

Bronxville Women's Club-Literature department meeting, 3 P. M. Comoedia Matinee Club-Annual luncheon and fashion show, 12:30 P. M., Hotel Astor. D. 4 R. (Mary Murray Chapter)Annual election, Old Guard headquarters.

The outdoor terrace and garden furniture in the shops now is so inviting looking that it makes one long for a place in the country, or even a few square yards of city backyard, to dress up with wrought iron or rattan chairs and tables.

SINCE the signing of the AngloItalian agreement, friendly radio overtures to England have been broadcast from Rome. Recently, during one of the Italian evening talks, now heard at various periods between 9 and 10 o'clock, daylight time,

With Larry Hartmann striking out fourteen and permitting only four hits, the Flushing High nine topped the Columbia freshmen, 6 to 2, at Flushing Memorial Field yesterday. Flushing scored three of its runs in the first and got two more in the fifth and one in the sixth.

Architects were advised in a statement issued yesterday by Ormond E. Loomis, assistant to Chairman John H. Fahey of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, to forget the field of multi-family dwellings and concentrate on one-family homes. Mr. Loomis has just com pleted an extensive study of the nation's housing needs and their relation to the architectural profession.

Three thousand Chinese guerrillas were attacking today the Japanese garrison of 300 men in the streets of Nantungchow, on the north bank of the Yangtze River, sixty miles northwest of Shanghai. This was reported by the American Oil Company's agent, evacuating here by steamer today.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Seidler of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gloria Lucille Seidler, to Bruno Choisnard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marc Choisnard of Paris, France.

Frank McCallister, Southern secretary of the Workers' Defense League said today he was considering the organization of a group of prominent Southerners to investigate civil liberties in Jersey City, N. J. He appended the query:

Sir Harold Bellman of London, managing director of the second largest building society in the world, in a recent address at a dinner sponsored by the United States Building and Loan League, explained that the English housing movement was the result of private enterprise after cooperative home

According to reports from Batavia, Java, some uneasiness has been caused in commercial circles in Netherland India by a campaign in part of the press in the United States against a renewal of the commercial treaty, which expires July 1.

Pensioned On his own application, to take effect 12 midnight, May 6: LIEUTENANT--Thomas J. Hynes, 32d Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed May 6, 1913. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN--Francis A. A. Juchter, from 14th Precinct to 73d Precinct, from 8 A. M., May 9.

The Japanese military machine continued to stall and sputter last week as Chinese guerrilla bands whacked at enemy communication lines and as Chinese mass armies, their strategy directed by German advisers, continued to interpose themselves between the invaders and the Lung-Hai Railway.

How the public schools can best cooperate with other community agencies to promote child welfare will be discussed by educators, parents, physicians, religious leaders, public officials, social workers and newspaper men at the tenth annual conference of elementary school workers Friday and Saturday at Teachers College, Columbia University.

The Bureau of Mines reported today that stored oil stocks increased 5,650,000 barrels in March, rising from 582,579,000 to 588,229,000. During the same period the daily average production of crude petroleum increased from 3,380,800 barrels to 3,438,300, reversing the downward trend of the preceding six months.

Adopting a procedure which attracted industry-wide attention at a wholesalers' convention in Chicago in January, retail grocers, wholesalers and manufacturers will hold a frank discussion of their trade relationships as a feature of the fortyfirst annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers

LAFCADIO HEARN, with his fine independence as a literary critic, declared in The New Orleans Item: With a daily paper the literary department is a news department. It is the medium through which the public is informed as to what good books are for sale and where they may be obtained.

Pinch-Hitter Hal Trosky's single drove in Bad News Hale with the winning run in the eighth inning today as Cleveland defeated the Athletics, 4 to 2. A battle of wits between Managers Oscar Vitt of the Indians and Connie Mack preceded Trosky's appearance at the plate.
THE village used to be the very heart of American life for half our country, roughly north of the PotoEven south of that excellent
Fritz Kuhn, national leader of American Nazis, responded yesterday to the growing opposition to hit movement by requesting Presi dent Roosevelt in a telegram to exonerate the German American Bund.

Glenway Wescott, American author, whose novel "The Grandmothers" was a success ten years ago, returned yesterday on the steamship President Harding of the United States Lines. He had visited London and Paris for five weeks seeking new material for a book upon which he has been working for two years.

More than 87 per cent of the Federal Savings and Loans Associations throughout the country have adopted the code of operations known as "Charter K," approved by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board less than eighteen months ago, the board announced yesterday.

THE Broadway managers have recruited their newest member from England's shires. This newcomer, Victor Payne-Jennings, is, however, no recent runaway from his green fields. For a decade and a half he has been a partner in the largest theatre-operating firm in London.

The Cliffs Corporation reported yesterday a net income of $93,084 for the quarter ended on March 31. This was after charges and Federal income taxes and was equivalent to 11 cents each on 805,734 shares of capital stock. For the corresponding quarter of last year the company had a net profit of $165,415 before Federal taxes, or 21 cents each on the same number of shares of capital stock.

The Nieuw Amsterdam, new flagship of the Holland-American Line, will sail from Rotterdam five minutes after midnight tomorrow on her maiden trip to New York. The ship was turned over to the owners on April 28 by the Rotterdam Drydock Company, her builders, after she had successfully met tests at sea.
THE Atlantic Monthly Press, Boston, Mass., announces its fifth $5,000 non-fiction contest with May 1, 1939, as the closing date. The prize is for the book rights only.

ANY one in search of a hero is respectfully directed to the preface of "Heartbreak House." A hero wrote it; his initials are G. B. S. In 1919, when Shaw was putting his thoughts on paper, the war was over, but the allied nations at the peace tables were already bent on destroying the world they had fought to save on the bloody battlefields.

The engagement and forthcoming marriage of Miss Madeline Heckenbleickner, daughter of Mrs. Ingenuin Heckenbleickner of this place and the late Mr. Heckenbleickner, to Lieutenant Erickson Snowden Nichols, United States Army Air Corps, has been announced by her mother.

The government urges the conservation of fresh water, pointing out that rainfall for February, March and April was less than half of what it was last year. "Many methods maybe resorted to to make the supply go further," says the notice.
A BLOND - HAIRED, youthfullooking gentleman dropped quietly into Washington the other day to chat with old friends. He said that he would be here only a short time,

The marriage of Miss Barbara Phillips of Longwood Tower, Brookline, Mass., formerly of Pawtucket, R. I., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herbert O. Phillips, to Arthur Hunt Willis, son of Mrs. H. Parker Willis of New Brighton, S. I., and the late Dr. Willis, took place yesterday at noon in the Chapel of St. Saviour, Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Rev. Dr. Frederic S.

The New York Curb Exchange has removed from listing and registration Cusi Mexicana Mining Company common stock, 50-cent par value; St. Anthony Gold Mines, Ltd., common stock, $1 par value, and Stutz Motor Car Company of America, Inc., capital stock, no par value.

Continuing cooperation between Germany and Italy, including the vexed question of colonies, is the outcome of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's visit to Premier Benito Mussolini, according to reports reaching London from Rome.

More than 30 pupils carrying placards picketed the Board of Educaton building here this morning to protest the closing of -their grammar school. The board decided to close these school as an economy move and plans to distribute its, 750 students to other schools.

The seventeen-story store and loft building at 257-261 West Thirtyeighth Street will be sold at foreclosure on Friday in the Vesey Street rooms by B. Hollander Son. The action is brought by the Empire City Savings Bank against Morton Kulick and others to satisfy a mortgage judgment of $370,829, with interest from April 7, 1938.

With the opening of children's camps so close at hand, parents are now weighing the many factors of location, personnel, type of program and safety precautions that must be considered in making the decision. This year the trend in camping is back to the simple and primitive.

In its opening track and field meet at home today, Navy won from Duke, 73 to 53, gaining an even break in the first eight track events, winning the mile relay and taking four of the six field contests. The outsanding performer was Don Kinzle of the visitors, with firsts in both burdles and the broad jump.
Governor Jose Refugio Bustamante was suspended from office today in impeachment proceedings by the Morelos State Legislature, which won out over three competing Legislatures.
Members of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, local of the United Automobile Workers, a C. I. O. affiliate, ratified today a settlement of their dispute with the company.

About a year ago Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard University Observatory, reported the discovery of a "cosmic window." This is an opening in the vast cloud of cosmic dust that fills the Milky Way system of which our solar system is an insignificant part, and had thwarted all man's efforts to look through and beyond his own "island universe" toward other universes.

AGENIAL autobiography of the most informal kind, Irving Bacheller's "From Stores of Memory" is a volume of reminiscences, contrasts between past and present, personal opinions and reprints from his most successful writings.

Alumni of Dartmouti College will have a chance to turn back the calendar to their student years this June when the administration will sponsor a graduate college immediately following the commencement activities.

Plans for a two-story bank building to house the Federal Savings and Loan Association at 99 Pondfield Road, Bronxville, Westchester County, have been completed by George F. Root 3d and Frederick J. Hartwig, architects. G. Richard Davis Co. are the contractors.
About the year 1288 an acorn took root in what is now Mingo, W. Va. More than nineteen generations of men, reckoning three to the century, have come and gone since that time.

The 15 to 30 per cent decline in sales of higher price unit items such as furniture, rugs, refrigerators and washing machines is mainly responsible for the drop of a similar amount in department store installment trade, executives here said yesterday. The head of a group of department stores said the proportion of installment sales to cash

The lift given to security prices last week enabled THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks to regain almost all the ground lost the week before and to close about midway between the high and the low for the year thus far. The bond average made the best showing in several weeks and likewise closed about midway between the extremes for 1938 to date.

SQUEEZING a bit of lemon into his breakfast tomato juice, G. Stanley Cochrane, now the Man: Without a Mask, muttered something about Art Fletcher and the baseball schedule. It may have been the lemon that added the touch of acid to his voice. But the black-haired manager of the Detroit Tigers knew that Art Fletcher, the Yankee coach, had nothing to do with drawing up the American League baseball schedule.
The Charlotte Lund Opera Company presented Humperdinck's "Hansel and Gretel" in English before a large and appreciative audience of children and grown-ups yesterday morning at the Heckscher Theatre.

The American people need 1,000,000 new homes to be housed adequately, Myers Y. Cooper, former Governor of Ohio, said here this afternoon at the closing session of the two-day Central Atlantic regional conference of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

The Very Rev. Dr. E. Frank Salmon has resigned as dean of Christ Church Cathedral, Ottawa, to accept a call as rector of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church on Rittenhouse Square here. He succeeds the Rev. Dr. Howard R. Weir, who died last September.

The Thrift Mart, the latest enterprise of the American Jewish Joint Distributionn Committee, at 15 West Fifty-sixth Street, is a special project of the women's division of the committee, which is seeking $400,000 in New York City to be devoted to the rehabilitation and -relief of Jewish persons in Europe.

Miss Virginia Bramble Newbold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene S. Newbold of Glen Rocky, St. Davids, was married this afternoon to John Williams Jr., sort of Mr. and Mrs. John Williams of Narberth. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard H. Gurley,' the rector, in St. Martin's Church at Radnor.
This country's exports to The Netherlands in the first quarter of 1938 totaled 51,276 tons, an increase of 136 per cent compared with 1937. The value, $26,715,159, was 82 per cent greater.
Alix's superb collection will set many Fall fashions. For sports and daytime wear she shows very ample long wool coats matching slim wool dresses.

Frank D. Hall, chief appraiser of the Equitable Life Assurance Society in its New York City mortgage lending, outlined seven keys to value in appraising real estate, at a session in Richmond, Va., on appraisal practice of the America Institute of Real Estate Appraisers.

While every hour aggravated the condition of Helaine Judith Colan, infant victim of a cancerous malady, it was indicated today that a committee of surgeons will be asked to make the decision whether the disease shall be allowed to run its course, with certain death at the end, or medical science shall attempt to save the infant's life, even though it costs her sight.

King Sisowath Monivong, ruler of the ancient kingdom of Combodia, who is reputed to have 200 "dancing-girl" wives, finds that even a golden-crowned potentate in these lean times cannot afford so many consorts.

In a recent survey of many factors indicative of progress in the real estate field by the States Council of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, attention is directed to the increasing interest throughout the country in real estate education.

First real buying of men's clothing for Fall is expected to develop this week, when several buying organizations here hold their conventions, manufacturers said yesterday. Affiliated Clothiers, Associted Merchandising Corporation, Cavendish Trading Corporation and others will look over the new ranges

Reaffirming by. resolution its reliance upon preventive medicine and. its support of the Medical Society of New York in its efforts to keep intact the provisions of the Medical Practice Act, the Women's Medical Society of New York will meet tomorrow for the consideration of professional problems. Many of them are concerned with' public health.
IN this small book of essays, lectures and broadcasts Mr. Wells, having survived the collapse of his idea of a business directorate, adumbrates a new idea for saving the world.

Postmaster General James A. Farley will be the honorary chairman of the second annual State convention of the Affiliated Young Democrats of New York, which will be held in the Park Central Hotel May 19, 20 and 21, Harold R. Moskovit, State president, announced yesterday.

"WITH all his activities, the Chevalier found time to be an amateur botanist, and in the most gorgeous of West Indian flowers, Poinciana Regia, or Flamboyant, is preserved the name of de Poincy, Autocrat of the Antilles," writes George H. King, curator of the museum at St. Kitts, British West Indies.

A "colossal barn dance and box supper" will be given by the Young Women's Organization of the Women's National Republican Club on Friday night in their clubhouse at 3 West Fifty-first Street: The George Washington Assembly Room of the headquarters will become the "granary" for the occasion, with ploughshares, pitchforks and other farmyard implements assembled to create a rustic setting for the party.

Mussolini and Hitler exchanged pledges of continued warm friendship between their countries at a state banquet in Rome last night. The German leader promised the Alpine frontier would remain inviolate. A great warplanes display had to be postponed because of bad weather. [Page 1.]

The National Labor Relations Board gave notice today that it would before the Supreme Court, if necessary, next week in its fight for permission to withdraw- its order against the Republic Steel Corporation so that it might reopen the Republic case.

Far back in the early running, a shifty bay filly named Sketchbook made her move at the right time today to come from behind in the stretsh and win the $7,500 added Pimlico Oaks for 3-year-old fillies by a length and a half.

The Manhattan baseball team scored a 2-0 victory over the New York Athletic Club yesterday at Manhattan Field. Don Phillips, junior, pitched the Jaspers to their eighth triumph in ten hits and striking out seven.
Captain Charles Henry May, former president of the Kings County Grand Jurors Association, died on Friday of a cerebral hemorrhage in his home at 41-88 Forly Street, Elmhurst. His age was 65.
After leading, 2--0, at the end of the first quarter on scores by Rindskopf and Miller, Navy lost to the Mount Washington clubmen, 7 to 4, at lacrosse today.

Miss Margaret McAdam, daughter of Mrs. John V. McAdam of Hastings-on-Hudson and the late Mr. McAdam, was married this afternoon to Robert Hunter Black, son of the Rev. Archibald Black and Mrs. Black of Montclair, N. J., in the Dobbs Ferry Presbyterian Church here.

Arthur Olin, 19 years old, of 110 Seaman Avenue, was taken to Fordham Hospital yesterday suffering from submersion after he had been thrown into East Ohester Bay off Edgewater Camp, the Bronx, by the capsizing of a small sailboat. The hospital reported that his condition was not serious.

James D. Mayne, who retired from the New York Fire Department in 1933, died yesterday after a brief illness at his home, 69 Ives Street, Forest Hills; Queens, at the age of 48. He had been a fireman for nineteen years, last serving with Engine Company 34, in West Thirtythird Street, Manhattan.

THE fourteenth annual Westchester Music Festival will open Friday night with a junior concert at the County Center, White Plains, N. Y. The program will be given by an allWestchester chorus and band, composed of some 400 high school students.

NOT long ago one dietary expert blamed the world's current troubles on the foods that people eat. At a recent peace seminar in Washington a delegate from India declared that only a vegetarian diet was the solution for war. Meanwhile we see food control established in many nations and trade barriers impeding the flow of essential foodstuffs throughout the world.

Some of the city's most charming gardens, in the vicinity of Washington Square, will be shown on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday afternoons for the benefit of Greenwich House, the Little Gardens Club and Judson Health Center.

Marvin Hecht of the Avenue P Playground, Brooklyn, defeated David. Mehler of. the Houston. and First Playground, Manhattan, 14-21, 21-15, 21-19, in the final for players 16 to 21 years at. the interborough handball championships sponsored by the Department of Parks on the Houston and First Playground courts yesterday.

MASTERS'S book is nothing more than a crude restatement of the Van Wyck Brooks theory of 1920 that Mark Twain was a suppressed genius, a potential satirist of the first magnitude, whom greed and uxoriousness and an inability to think things through turned into a clown.

BELMONT--Un Carnet de Bal: Harry Baur, Francoise Rosay.* CAMEO--Lonely White Sail, Russian drama. CAPITOL--Test Pilot: Clark Gable;* The First Hundred Years: Warren William, opens Thursday. CONTINENTAL--To the Victor: Will Fyffe.* CRITERION--Call of the Yukon: Richard Arlen, Beverly Roberts. 5TH AVE. PLAYHOUSE--Moscow Nights: Harry Baur.*

Ostend, small and stout-hearted brown gelding, won the seventeenth renewal of the Virginia Gold Cup Steeplechase before 10,000 persons today, to give Mrs. Frank Gould of New York two legs on the $1,000 trophy.

Dr. Daniel B. Hardenbergh, a physician and surgeon who had practiced in this city for the last fortyfour years, died at his home here on Thursday at the age of 72. Dr. Hardenbergh was born at Port Jervis, March 13, 1866, the son of Henry and Delia Bailey Hardenbergh.
JOSEPH C. ALLEN was a Vineyard fisherman once upon a time, a real fisherman, not just a seeker after sport.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, was one of six Catholic clergymen who pleaded for support of Catholic Summer School of America, Cliff Haven on Lake Champlain, at the annual luncheon of the school's Alumnae Auxiliary Association held in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

MANY of the million or so who suffered sprained ribs and bent fenders while enroute to last week-end's World's Fair preview express alarm over the results of what seemed to be a transportation test. They feel that it would be a shame to draw visitors to the fair from the far corners of the earth and send them home' looking as though they had attended an air raid.

Debate began in the House this afternoon on the Lea bill for the establishment of a Civil Aeronautics Authority having greater powers over air transport than the Interstate Commerce Commission exercises over land transport.
Moving-Up Day, a traditional ceremony at Manhattan College, will be held on Wednesday afternoon on the quadrangle of the campus, it was announced yesterday by Hugh J. Kerins of the Student Council.
Hardly a steamship belonging to the United States Lines arrives now from the Channel ports without having one or more stowaways on board.

The ninetieth anniversary of Blair Academy will be celebrated here next Saturday, the school's alumni day. Numerous alumni and alumnae will return for the day to witness the colorful seven-episode pageant depicting the academy's history.

Mr. and Mrs. John T. Scheepers are opening the gardens of Paradou, their estate on the Northern Boulevard, this afternoon and tomorrow for two garden teas in aid of the auxiliary to the North Country Community Hospital at Glen Cove, of which Harold Irving Pratt is president.

The city was enjoined by Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy yesterday from paying the salary of Simon W. Gerson as assistant to Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President of Manhattan. Mr. Gerson was appointed to that position on Jan. 1 and his title was changed to confidential examiner in the Borough President's office on Feb. 23. He was paid up to Feb. 15 and the decision affects his pay for only eight days.

TWO years ago the Soviet movie director, Vladimir Legoshin, chanced across a newly published novel that moved him to immediate action. The book was Valentin Katayev's "Lonely White Sail." As a youngster, Legoshin's favorite of all novels had been Mark Twain's "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer."

Lawrin, owned by Herbert M. Woolf of Kansas City, won the sixty-fourth Kentucky Derby while 60,000 looked on at Louisville. Well ridden by Eddie Arcaro, Lawrin triumphed by a length over William du Pont Jr.'s Dauber. Third, five lengths farther back, was Myron Selznick's Can't Wait. The favorite, Fighting Fox, finished sixth, with the second choice, Bull Lea, eighth.

Rhode Island swamped Manhattan in a dual track meet today, 88 to 47, Five track and field records were displaced and one was equaled. Manhattan cut a wide swath in the track competition but was help less in the field. Irving Folwartshny was high man with 13 points.

Syracuse defeated Colgate's track team today, 75-60, although Marty Glickman, Syracuse's Olympic sprinter, was beaten by Colgate's sophomore star, Bill Cook, in both in both the 100 and 200 yard dashes. 00 and 200 yard dashes.

HARRY WATKINS, trouper, kept a diary with conscientious care, so that when he should have become one of the most famous actors of his time, and even when he should have died in all his greatness, posterity might know forever how he had followed the path to the bright galaxies of success.
IN celebrating the tenth anniversary of his company, Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker, president'of Eastern Air Lines, last week announced that April was the best month in history.

Members of the faculty and student body of Princeton University yesterday sent telegrams supporting the Nye resolution to -lift the arms embargo against the Spanish Government to President Roosevelt, Secretary ofState Cordell Hull
The King and Queen head the list of subscribers to the International Opera season at Covent Garden which commenced this week with "The Magic Flute" conducted by Sir Thomas Beecham.

A nonpartisan Constitutional Convention was all the cry on Capitol Hill when the present convention first assembled for its sessions early last month. Since then developments here, especially this week, have convinced the leaders of the convention that it would be just about as easy to keep the present gathering nonpartisan as it would be to keep the Democratic party

Or grandmother who had an ape for ancestor and no Huxley retorts savagely that, at any rate, he had never "prostituted the gifts of culture and of. eloquence to the service of prejudice and falsehood." It is in another State than Tennessee that William Jennings Bryan and Clarence Darrow continue an everlasting argument.

O Percy Bright, retired lawyer, suddenly Saturday at his home in Germantown at the age of 75. Born in Wilmington, Del., the son of William and Sarah Bright, Mr. Bright was graduated from Yale in 1885. He then studied law at the University of Pennsylvania Law School, where he was graduated in 1888. He practiced here until his retirement.

THIS year's prospective brides and bridegrooms, figuring where to go on their honey moons, may be fully as sentimental as their predecessors of a decade or so ago, but they are also practical. Come June, the trail of scattered rice and the din of tin cans tied to automobiles will lead, preferably, to a pier where a boat awaits. The modern couple will then embark on a crowded itinerary.

Ignoring orders to put on his company manners when the New York boxing solons came to look him over, Two-Ton Galento mortified his manager today by inviting Major Gen. John J. Phelan to have a workout in the ring with him and then stow away a few beers at Tony's saloon in Orange.

Callan Brothers will open today in their Wyngate development at Great Neck, L. I., a six-room home known as the "Indexed House." At twenty different points in the structure important construction and equipment features have been indexed and classified to show exactly the materials and method of construction used.
Long Island University's varsity. baseball team registered its eighth victory in twelve starts yesterday pounding four City College pitchers for a 10-2 victory at Lewisohn Stadium.
"THIS PASSION NEVER DIES" is the third volume of Sophus Keith Winther's saga of the Grimsens in Nebraska. Possibly it is the concluding volume, for his intention in this respect is not stated.

IF by chance any reader of this review is tired of living in New York--or, for that matter, in Chicago, Pittsburgh, Cleveland or almost any other large American city--he will derive consolation from reading Mr. Sinclair's "human study of London."

Octavian Goga, former Kumanlan Prime Minister, died today at his castle at the age of 58. For the last two days he had been unconscious after suffering a paralytic stroke. The immediate cause of death was pneumonia.

Mrs. Katharine Hurd Cumings of Bradley n Farm, Bedford Hills, N. Y., was married this morning at St. John's Church, Pembroke, to Harold L. Williamson, the United States consul here. The rector, the Rev. Eustace M. Strong, officiated.

Acting, he said, to prevent "bloodshed, violence and perhaps death at the hands of a mob incited to do violence by Mayor Hague," Vito Marcantonio, president of the International Labor Defense, last night canceled a meeting scheduled to be held in Journal Square, Jersey City, to protest against recent acts of the Hague administration.
Three Hunter College alumnae groups met yesterday when the classes of 1878, 1904 and 1928 held their annual reunion luncheons at the Biltmore, Commodore and Astor hotels.

Dr. and Mrs. George Hubbard Blakeslee of Worcester, Mass., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Augusta Blakeslee, to Frank Harmon Patterson, son of Mrs. Frank H. Patterson of Bristol, Conn.

ABOARD the P. O. liner Fort Lucknow, en route from England to Egypt and points East, we find a group of interesting people, one of whom is probably the person who is guilty of a series of mysterious murders in and about Cairo.

Two hundred and eighty orthodox The rabbis urged support of the United award Palestine Appeal in a joint statement made public by the appeal has yesterday. The group seeks $4,500,000 for the settlement in Palestine of European Jews.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph B. Code, Professor of History at the Catholic University of America at Washington, in an address tonight at Cornell University, attacked the proposal for the repeal of the Neutrality Act as a move secretly aimed at aiding

An aggregate net loss of $5,859,949 was incurred in the first quarter of 1938 by twenty-eight steel companies representing a substantial proportion of the country's productive capacity, in contrast to a net profit of $70,676,897 for the same companies in the first quarter of 1937.

Mrs. Anna Brennan Grieve, mother of former Assemblyman William T. Give of Yonkers, an American League umpire, died this morning in her home at 15 Intervale Place, Yonkers. She was the widow of David S. Grieve, formrly associated with the Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company in Yonkers. Born in Newburgh,

Loans by savings and loan associations for construction, purchase, reconditioning or refinancing of homes in the United States during March rose 29 per cent above those for February, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced yesterday.

Governors Island Each of the following Corps of Engineers Reserve officers, assigned to the First Engineers, is ordered to active duty, effective May 27, at Fort DuPont, Del., for training: Captain Wesley F. Malloch, 105 South Rd., Lindamere, Wilmington, Del. 1st Lt. Rollin J. Byrkit Jr., Marshallton, Del. 1st Lt. John A. Hampton, 337 Central Ave., Lawrence, N. Y. 2d Lt. John D. Foley, 4,025 Lowere Pl., New York, N. Y.
House members of the committee named to investigate the Tennessee Valley Authority proposed today that the inquiry be begun quickly by asking detailed statements from each of the three directors.

The New York World's Fair 1939 preview entertainment and fireworks display, held over from last week when a rainstorm forced curtailment of the program, will take place today. World's Fair officials are planning to entertain an even larger crowd than came last week, and in conjunction with the Police Department have made elaborate arrangements.
Mr. and Mrs. David Alper of Beacon, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bertha Alper, to Jack Werber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Werber of Newburgh, N. Y., formerly of Beacon.

The rising tide of protest against the Wagner act, and its agency, the National Labor Relations Board, will doubtless be dismissed in some quarters as merely a new "conspiracy" by business to combat "social legislation." But it would be more profitable, it has, indeed, become urgently necessary, to listen to that protest to determine what is justified in it, and to consider afresh our whole Federal policy toward labor relations.

Magistrate Bernard Mogilesky in Felony Court dismissed yesterday charges against James Clarke, 28 years old, of 96 Bowery, who was accused last Tuesday of having been implicated in the robberies of six physicians in the last four months.

UNKNOWN to most motorists in the New York metropolitan area, a new police radio system, which is 'relieving traffic congestion and reducing accident hazards, is being rapidly developed. Several cities and municipalities in New Jersey and Westchester County have already installed this equipment and extensive tests are being conducted in New York City.

A WEEK of uncommon interest has given London its first knowledge of the work of Maxwell Anderson and a performance of "The Merchant of Venice" of such lucidity and coherence as will give it rank among the greatest and most memorable productions of the play.

Miss Suzanne Capurro, 27 years old, a French woman, arrived yesterday on the President Harding of the United States Lines to testify in Federal court tomorrow at the trial of the New York manager of Marcel Rochas, Inc., 32 East Sixty-seventh Street, who is charged with conspiracy in the alleged smuggling of French gowns into the United States.

A return of confidence and improved economic conditions in Pennsylvania will be followed by a record building boom, according to Freas B. Snyder, president of the Pennsylvania Real Estate Association.

Meet records were shattered during the sixth annual metropolitan Class B track and field championships at Essex Field today while the representatives of Brooklyn College collected 69 1/2 points to take the team crown for the fifth straight year.

The elimination of the 3 per cent excise tax on manufactured furs, effective June 30, will be followed by a widespread revival of activity in every branch of the fur industry, from the trapper to the retailer, United States Senator James P. Pope of Idaho predicted last night at the eleventh annual dinner of the Greater New York Retail Furriers Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

Delegates from eleven colonies in the metropolitan area will be among those attending the silver jubilee convention of the National Society of New England Women, meeting Tuesday to Friday in Charleston, W. Va. Governor and Mrs. Homer A. Holt will entertain the delegates at tea.

Lieutenant Donald R. Hutchinson of the Twentieth Pursuit Group, Barksdale Field, La., escaped serious injury at Roosevelt Field today when his Boeing P26 pursuit ship nosed over after landing. The lowwing fighter was not seriously damaged.

The result of the Democratic Senatorial primary in Florida this week, with its immediate effect of reviving the Labor Standards Bill in the House, should make certain things clear to two groups in this country. One group is made up of the Democratic members of Congress; the other of persons who are honestly alarmed over the electoral power of government spending.
