The Supreme Court will end its term on Tuesday, May 31. Monday would normally have been the final day, but because the thirtieth is a holiday the court will sit Tuesday instead.

WASHINGTON.--Uncle Sam is stepping up production of paper money. About 1,306 tons of paper, or 108,122,000 sheets, wilL be required for currency during the fiscal year beginning July. 1, compared with about 65,000,000 sheets for the present fiscal year.

MELBOURNE. AUSTRALIA has lately provided a spectacular example of the control of a plant pest by means of an insect enemy of the pest. Millions of acres of land that had been covered by prickly pear have been cleared for agriculture and grazing, following the destruction of the pear by a little moth known as Cactoblastis cactorum.

Lee Thompson Smith, head of the Board of Estimate's real estate bureau, disclosed last week that he will make an effort in the near future to relocate some of the city's police and fire stations in an effort to increase the city's revenue from taxes.

Forty players are listed in the squads of the Cavan and Lei Gaelic football Teams which are scheduled to arrive here Thursday on the United States liner Monhattan for a series of three games which start at the polo Grounds next Sunday, with Cavan meeting New York.

Union Costs To the Drama Editor: "The play could have run on and on if not for the salaries of the backstage crew" has long been one of the drearier banalities to assail the ears of the theatre worker whose circulation brought him face to face with those birds of passage known as shoestring producers.

UNABLE to reach an agreement on the choice of a story for her next picture, RKO, and Katharine Hepburn decided the other day to terminate their contract. The studio is said to have sought the cancellation, which was described as "amicable."

Blossom Star, 6-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. Richard C. Kettles Jr. of Glen Head, L. I., and ridden by Mrs. James A. Hewlett of Jericho, L. I., last night won the championship in the three-gaited saddle horse division at the concluding session of the Spring horse show of the Riding and Polo Club in the ring of the clubhouse on West Sixty-sixth Street.

A GRIM old house in Soho which Charles Dickens knew very well is playing a strange part as a result of current events in Europe. This stately mansion, whose garden Dickens transported in fancy to Carlisle House, where lived Dr. Manette of "A Tale of Two Cities,"

Fire Captain Joseph A. Tracy of 3,232 Hull Avenue, the Bronx, attached to engine company 48 in the Bronx, who was killed last Tuesday when two fire trucks collided at 188th Street and Valentine Avenue, received a battalion chief's funeral yesterday morning at St. Brendan's change Roman Catholic Church, 207th Street and Perry Avenue, the trial Bronx. Captain Tracy was 40 years turned old.

United States exports of arms, ammunition and implements of war were analyzed by Secretary of State Cordell Hull at his press conference today to show that they were a negligible factor in the rearmament of Germany.

The American Telephons and Telegraph Company, as the parent concern of the Bell System, issued yesterday for the first quarter of this year a report showing gross revenues of $26,118,082, compared with $27,824,627 in the first three months of 1937.

Miss Diana M. Gerli, daughter of Mrs. Emanuel Gerli of 907 Fifth Avenue, and Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Gerli, will be married in this city on May 27 to Daniel Nelson Adams, son of Mrs. Daniel Crouse Adams of 1,130 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Adams.

BERJOWITZ--Mr. and Mr. Joseph Berkowitz, 1,136 HarrIs St., Far Rockaway, N. Y., take pleasure in announcing the bar mitzvah of their son, Martin Howard, at the Jewish Center of Far Rockaway, N. Y., Saturday morning May 14, 1938.

The dates of several flower shows have been listed by different garden groups in Westchester County. The first flower exhibit will be held on Friday by the garden section of the Manor Club of Pelham Manor. Mrs.

The Greenwich High School will hold a school merchandising fair on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday as a practical method for the development of cooperative employment and business training. Started last year, the fair met with such success that it is being repeated on a larger scale, under the direction of Carl J. Nemetz.

Mr. and Mrs. Perry J. Randolph of West Medford, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pauline Randolph, to Arthur Tenney Hamlin of Cambridge, son of the Rev. Christopher Robert Hamlin of Orleans, Mass.

Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General at New York, will crown this year's Western New York Apple Blossom Queen at LeRoy, May 21. Identity of the queen will not be known until trumpeters sound a fanfare announcing the procession to the throne. She will be chosen from among nine young women.

"Down in Maine we sometimes used to prime the pump, but we never tinkered with the pump during the process," said Representative Ralph O. Brewster in a speech to 400 Chautauqua County Republicans last night.

Now, when the glory of azaleas plays such a prominent role in the Spring landscape, is an excellent time for the garden maker to familiarize himself with the various types. A trip to one of the botanical gardens, or to an ornamental nursery, will enable him to note the kinds which would best suit his own taste and conditions.

George Broderick, general chairman of the State Young Republican Convention, today announced that the slogan of the meeting would be: "Every American recovery has been Republican; let us recover America now."
A campaign to modernize and beautify the Rockaways has been started by the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways, of which Andrew J. Kenny is president.

The direct reduction mortgage with monthly tax accumulation is gradually bringing about a virtual elimination of tax delinquencies on residential properties, while at the same time increasing municipal revenues, according to Newell J. Nessen, president of 'the Quaker City Federal Savings and Loan Association of Philadelphia.

Joe Marty's single with two on base and one out in the tenth inning drove in Billy Herman with the run that enabled the Cubs to defeat the Bees, 5 to 4, today after Boston had rallied to tie the score at 4--4. The victory gave the Cubs a sweep in the two-game series.

Young women will act as manikins in the fashion revue to be held in conjunction with a luncheon Tuesday at the formal opening of the Park Lane Gardens for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.

Governor Wilbur M. Cross and heads of State departments will conduct a round table on "The Proof of the Pudding-Reorganization at Work" at a luncheon on Tuesday sponsored by the Connecticut League of Women Voters at the Stratfield Hotel, Bridgeport.

Czechoslovakia finds herself at the center of the world's most intense political storm. The little republic is in the unenviable position of being surrounded by four countries, two of which, Germany and Hungary, are actively hostile; one,' Poland, is distinctly unfriendly, and the fourth, Rumania, is quite indifferent to her future.

Events in recent weeks have brought into. the open discussions of the need for revising the "administrative tribunal" procedure of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Lawyers who have been concerned with the work of the commission favor elimination of the trial examiners, now appointed from among SEC attorneys. They would have the Federal courts take their place.

Real estate selling prices and rents in New York State at present are about at the same level as they were a year ago, despite the fact that there has been a slight decrease in the volume of realty transactions, according to Frank S. O'Hara, Jackson Heights broker and president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York.

Scoring a total of 45 points, Newtown High won the Queens P. S. A. L. high school novice track and field championship at Jamaica Stadium yesterday. It marked the third time in the last four years that the Elmhurst athletes won the team crown.

ONE hundred years ago Theobald Mathew took the pledge of total abstinence. "Here goes--in the name of the Lord," he said as he appended his signature on April 10, 1838. The centenary of that act by the Roman Catholic priest, who was to become the "Apostle of Temperance,"
THE Big Bend of Texas, the wildest, most isolated and perhaps most romantic remnant of the pioneer West, is about to yield at last in a measure to twentieth-century civilization.

Joseph P. Day, Albert M. Greenfield and William A. White Sons, agents for ten closed national banks in Central and Lower New Jersey, have sold fifty-two properties for a total of $115,450. The results were obtained in a series of separate sales, which started April 22 and closed April 30 at Long Branch and Ocean Grove.

Edward Emery, whose long and distinguished career as an actor fulfilled the tradition of his family, one of the oldest theatrical families in England, died at 7 o'clock last night at the Fifth Avenue Hospital, where he had been undergoing treatment for heart disease. He would have been 77 years old next Friday.

Oliver Pitman Cooke, retired stockbroker, died early yesterday at his home, 425 Riverside Drive, after a long illness. He was 71 years old. Mr. Cooke, born in Norfolk, Va., was associated with the Stock Exchange firm of S. B. Chapin Co.,

THE seven bridge authorities whom Willard S. Karn is suing for $1,000,000 have made their first answer to the summons which he served upon them. Mr. Karn charges that the seven defendants--Ely and Josephine Culbertson, Oswald Jacoby,
When President Roosevelt leaves the capital on one of his ocqasional periods of relaxation, affairs of high Administration policy are taken in hand by an individual known in Washington as Mr. Wild.

Wells College students will introduce the dramatic poem "Samson Agonistes," by John Milton, to the American stage when they present the poem under the direction of Nicholas Nabokoff, head of the Department of Music, next Saturday eveing in McMillin Hall as the final feature of the annual May Day program.

Blood corpuscles-those microscopic "trucks" in the blood stream that carry energy to all parts of the body and fight off germs-are finding a new use in color photography. This is set forth in a patent (No. 2,115,886) granted to Chalmers C. Smith of Glendale and Ray H. Pinker of Los Angeles, Calif.
There was a heavy demand for French francs in the foreign exchange market again today, and one estimate put the amount of speculative capital sent back to Paris today at [pound]10,000,000.

The Alumni Association of the University of Virginia here will send a request to Congress that the $3,000,000 fund available for a monument to Thomas Jefferson be turned over to the university as an "educational, living tribute" to the founder, John S. Chapman, president of the association, announced yesterday.

Archduke Albrecht of Habsburg, 40 years old, was married in a civil ceremony today to Katherine Bocskay, 27-year-old school teacher, in the Archduke's palace here. A ceremonial church wedding was set for Monday in the Benedictine Abbey at Pannonhalma.

Insurgent forces tore a gap through government defenses in Eastern Spain today and advanced five' miles nearer the "lifeline" highway link between Madrid and the Mediterranean ports of Castellon de la Plana and Valencia.

Climaxing the end of the season rivalry Arsenal today gained its fifth English Football League championship. Going into the last day's play the Gunners, 1 point behind the Wolverhampton Wanderers, halted Bolton, 5--0, while the Wolves were defeated, 1--0, at Sunderland.

The Kent School crew was defeated today by the Yale second freshman eight in a rate of one mile on the Housatonic River, The margin at the finish was a half deck length and the winners' time 5 minutes 5 seconds.

Following a violent exchange of blows which, among other things, saw their ace right-hander, Hal Schumacher, shot down from a line smash in the pit of the stomach, the Giants today toppled the Pirates, 6 to 5. That swept the twogame series.
HUBERT SKIDMORE'S first novel, "I Will Lift Up Mine Eyes,"received the Avery and Jule Hopwood Award in 1935. The perspicacity of the judges is justified here.

Since the corporate undistributedprofits tax has been reinserted in the pending revenue bill by the House and Senate conferees, an inquiry into the "principle" of the tax by Dr. Harley L. Lutz of Princeton University, appearing in the April issue of The Bulletin of the National Tax Association, becomes of renewed interest.

Mrs. Velma Capone, 28, obtained a divorce today from Ralph Capone, 32, brother of the former gang leader, Al Capone. Circuit Judge Philip J. Finnegan granted a decree on charges of cruelty, with alimony rights reserved. Her husband was not in court.
Salford won the English Rugby League Cup before 53,000 persons today with a 74 decision over Barrow. The victors led, 4-2, at half time.
The several alternatives before the International dies Garment Workers Union in relation to the Committee

As lawenforcement officers at Harrisburg busily assembled evidence to lay before the Dauphin County grand jury in its investigation of bribery, graft and coercion charges made in the hectic Democratic primary campaign, Charles J. Margiotti, former State Attorney General, directed new charges today against party leaders.

How to conduct international trade without money between totalitarian States whose economic goal is self-sufficiency is the problem-that an Italian economic mission just arrived in Tokyo will explore.

Yankee ingenuity became a byword the world over because of patent laws of unprecedented liberality. Thanks to them, invention flourished. In return for a complete disclosure of his ideas the inventor was granted a monopoly for a limited period, with the result that enormous natural resources were developed by farmers, mechanics, miners and scientists, and that the achievements of Morse, McCormick, Bell, Edison and scores less distinguished made technological history.
A MATTER OF SCENT: In New York arrived last week and Englishman who claimed to be able to smell the approach or non-approach of war. He was Sir Percy Bates,

A British building firm which in the past ten years has constructed more than 10,000 small homes in England has entered the American field and is now developing a tract of land in Queens with ninety-five dwellings.

Under the property improvement credit plan of the FHA, home owners can obtain insured loans up to $2,500 for the erection of new garages and the repair and modernization of similar existing structures.

GERMANY'S decision to absent herself from the New York World's Fair is a sharp reminder that this country is not so friendly as she used to be toward Uncle Sam. The German has not changed fundamentally his mental picture of America; he has changed the way he feels about that picture and his interpretation of its significance.

Miss Anna Jarvis, spinster, founder of Mother's Day, said today she sent no greetings to foreign countries this year because of "war conditions." "I think tomorrow will be the most peaceful Mother's Day we shall see in a long time," said the gray-haired woman of 60, who lives a retired life with an older sister.

A decision, to abandon all active opposition to enactment of the Wages and Hours Bill has been made by Southern leaders in Congress, it was learned today. This decision was reached, it was said, after deliberation over its possible effects. The opposition leaders counted these among the effects:
OTHER operas besides the Metropolitan are apparently not immune to ballet trouble. For the Chicago City Opera next season the Philadelphia Ballet Company, with Catherine Littlefield as director,
A French Franciscan report of the shooting of a priest at Changlo, Shantung province, said three Chinese Catholic sisters, two servants and two girls preparing to become nuns also were killed.

E. Everett Smith, director of the information bureau of the State Mortgage Commission, states that on May 1 the department had interviewed its 81,057th visitor and had received and answered 110,274 letters, indicating the widespread interest in that phase of the commission's work.

Inspectors, after a check-up of the cigarette stamp tax in the outlying sections of the city during the first week of the levy, have reported that no bootlegging of unstamped packages across the city border lines has been found, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, said yesterday.
The status of women in New Jersey is the theme of the three-day convention of the State's Federation of Business and Professional Women, opening Friday at the Hotel Dennis, Atlantic City.

Choirs from several cities in the East will compete in the second biannual choral festival of the Serbian Singing Federation which is being held today in the Stambaugh Auditorium, Youngstown, Ohio. The winning choir will be awarded a cup given to the federation by the late Professor Michael Pupin.

In a complete reversal of last year's tendencies, emphasis In the annual sophomore departmental elections at Princeton University has shifted from the social sciences to the humanities, according to a compilation today by Professor Robert K. Root, dean of the faculty.

Objections to the plan frequently suggested that real estate should be assessed for taxation purposes upon its income basis are presented by H. J. Brachman, Detroit real estate broker and former secretary of the property management division of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, City Controller, who revealed that he was making a survey of betting at the Jamaica and Aqueduct race tracks as a possible new source of revenue for emergency relief, announced yesterday that he had summoned ninety bookmakers OPerating at the Jamaica track to appear next week for questioning on why they had not paid relief taxes under the one-tenth of 1 per cent gross business levy for the last four years.

THE second and final week of the San Carlo Opera Company's season of popular priced opera, at the Center Theatre, will open with "Carmen" tonight. Carmela Ponselle will be heard in the title role. Other events of the week include the final appearance this season of Marian Anderson and the twenty-second anniversary of the People's Chorus of New York.

With more vigor than any French Government has shown for a long time past, Premier Edouard Daladier and his inner Cabinet have set to work to try to cure this country of its maladies, some of which were threatening to become incurable.

In the opinion of Russel Wright, industrial designer, the house of the future will be built with walls of glass-like material sliding back to permit the entrance of fresh air and sunshine. He also predicts that cumbersome upholstered furniture will be replaced with simple pieces of highly Dolished wood and steel.
Herbert M. Woolf was reliably reported to have scored one of the biggest personal "killings" in Kentucky Derby history as a result of the victory of his colt Lawrin in today's big race.
Our astonishing Mayor La Guardia, to whose range of interests and knowledge there is seemingly no limit, made a cryptic reference

ROME. GIAN FRANCESCO MALIPIERO, on a recent visit to Rome, discussed his latest opera, "Antonio e Cleopatra," due to be launched shortly at the Florence festival, a little more than a year after his preceding opera, "Giulio Cesare," likewise after Shakespeare, was brought out at the Teatro Carlo Felice of Genoa. Again this time, the Venetian composer has himself written the libretto (in three acts).

Army won from New York University on the track today, 76 1-3 to 49 2-3. The cadets took nine first places in the fourteen events contested. Herbert was a double winner for the Violet, capturing the 440-yard and half-mile events. Cadets Byars and D'Arezzo were double winners for Army.

THE historical novel has never been in better hands than in G. B. Lancaster's in this story of the colonization of New Zealand. She shows us the age-old primitive civilization of the Maoris struggling against the incursion of a later, more complex, alien way of life;

PHILADELPHIA. THE Naval Aircraft Factory, the only government agency engaged in the building of airplanes, completed last week an order of 185 training planes, in twenty of which were installed engines built by the aircraft factory itself.

Once more the mid-West is the objective for a major convention of women's organizations as Kansas City (Mo.) salutes arriving delegates to the triennial of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, only a matter of days after its neighbor St. Louis, waved farewell to the National League of Women Voters.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dora Goldstone, daughter of Mrs. Morris LI Goldstone of Larchmont, N. Y., and the late Mr. Goldstone, to Abram H. Stockman, son of Mrs. Isaac W. Miller of Freeport, L. I.
Officials of the General Federation of Women's Clubs protested when they learned a prize fight was scheduled for next Wednesday night at the Municipal Auditorium Arena.

The long-anticipated demarche from the British and French Ministers was made at the Foreign Office this afternoon. The British Minister, Basil C. Newton, called at 4 and the French Minister, Victor Leopold Delacroix, an hour later.

Bob (Lefty) Grove held the Browns to four hits today and the Red Sox swept a twogame series with a 7-2 victory. It was the veteran southpaw's fourth triumph in as many starts. Both of the Browns' tallies, made in the first inning, were unearned, due to a pair of errors by Pinky

HOT SPRINGS, Va.--The colony is being left much to its own devices this week. If the present weather continues, as it shows every indication of doing, much time will be spent on horseback, in runabouts or buckboards, viewing the countryside, which is now approaching the height of its Spring beauty.

THERE'S quite a buzz these summery afternoons on the beach, that rent-free haven of vaudevillians to the east of Father. Duffy's statute in Longacre Square. While not to be compared in daily population with musicians row on the southwesterly curb of Broadway and Forty-eighth Street,

Ira A. Hawkins Jr., lawyer of 120 Broadway and Bronxville, N. Y., has accepted the chairmanship of the Plan and Scope Committee, which is directing an appeal for funds to sustain the community service to children and adults by the Greater New York Federation of Churches, the headquarters of which are at 71 West Twenty-third Street.

Warm weather brought better retail sales last week and this resulted in more numerous reorders as stocks were inadequate in many lines, according to a report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

About 4,000 physicians are expected to attend the 132d annual meeting of the State Medical Society at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow through Thursday, according to an announcement made yesterday by Dr. Charles A. Anderson, chairman of the arrangement committee.

Calling attention to the fact that tabulations of pedestrian traffic in certain business or shopping centers may not always be an accurate criterion of rising rental possibilities, Joseph Laronge of Cleveland says that the quantity of traffic means little in itself, as it is necessary to determine not only the buying power but also the buying intent of that traffic.
Henry C. Turner, president of the Board of Education for the last two years, announced yesterday that he would not be a candidate for reelection when his term expires on Tuesday.

The Rev. Dr. John H. Eager, a Baptist minister who had held pastorates in Baltimore, Louisville, and other Southern cities, died yesterday at his home, 55 East Seventysixth Street, in his eighty-ninth year. He was a native of Clinton, Miss., and a- graduate of Mississippi College and the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary. For several years he delivered lectures throughout the South.

THE birds winging their way northward for the Spring nesting season will be greeted this year by a large army of camera fans, lured into the woodlands by the interesting possibilities in nature photography.

John A.Snyder, founder and pres ident of the A. J. Snyder Son Lumber and Material Company a Mariners Harbor, S. I., and firs vice president of the Richmon. County Savings Bank for man years, died on Friday night at hi home, 160 Clinton Avenue, NevBrighton, after two weeks' illnes He was 77 years old.

Amid the resplendent blooms of tulips and lilies and the clang of hoe and rake manipulated by young, but skillful hands, the silver anniversary of the elementary education department of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will be celebrated Tuesday.

Senator Borah, Republican, of Idaho, made public today a telegram to Bertram ,G. Frazier of Philadelphia, in which he offered to sponsor a Senatorial investigation if Mr. Frazier could produce proofs of his charges that a "slush fund" had been raised to support some candidates in the Pennsylvania Republican primary.

"Siam is not playing favorites," declared Luang Pradist Mahudharm, Siam's young, serious and hard-working Foreign Minister, in an interview. "Siam does not, and will not, favor any nation or country in particular," the Minister went on emphatically when asked concerning the rumors of increased friendship with Japan.

Williams won a Little Three track meet from Wesleyan, 88 to 47, today. Schwartz of Williams set a new record of 175 feet 61/2 inches in the javelin throw. Heermans of Wesleyan won both the mile run and the 880. In the latter race he broke past Brown and Griffin of Williams on the last lap and sprinted to the tape to win by a yard.

With pressure strong for holding up retail volume and with manufacturers pushing for new accounts, increasing scrutiny of the system of "preferred resources," which has grown up in merchandising, was indicated here yesterday by prominent buying executives.
Some 6,000 persons, mostly children of the Catholic Youth Association, attended a mass celebrated in Trevor Park here today in observance of Mother's Day.

The method by which American foreign traders who have $1,250,000 tied up in Nicaragua through exchange restrictions there will be paid is expected to be settled in the next few weeks through negotiations between the Nicaraguan Government and T. N. Molanphy, National Foreign Trade Council representative, who sailed Friday for that country.
Miss Jane Pillow Rightor and Frederick Billings Lee were married here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Frank E. Walters.

The winning tribute in a Mothers' Day contest was dedicated to a stepmother. The judges who pored over hundreds of entries agreed today that Mrs. H. C. Waybright's tribute was the best although no mention had been made of stepmothers in the competition.

"Stealthy penetration" of the Communist ideology from Soviet Russia is a source of great concern to Poland, Edward Weintal, former diplomat, who is director of the Polish Information Service, declared last night at the second session of the Danubian Congress at Fordham University.

New York University's School of Architecture and Allied Arts held its annual high school competitions at the Bryant Park center. yesterday and prizes were awarded to high school students in the metropolitan area for their proficiency in seven different phases of art.

Zoning laws in most cities were criticized by Herbert S. Swan, city planner, as being inadequate and incomprehensive in an address last week before the New Jersey Annual State Planning Conference, in Maplewood.

Warship construction of the expanding navy and the Maritime Commission's efforts to re-create the merchant marine have stirred the nation's shipyards into greater activity than they have known since early post-war days, officials said today.
T. A. Crerar, Resources Minister, stated today that the Dominion Government nad adopted further restrictions to conserve the wild life of the northwest territories in the interests of the natives.

MR. MacLEISH'S experiments in the direct and public use of poetry have given us a dance-drama and a radio-play, both in poetic form. Now he collaborates with the photographers to give us a book of emotional intensity that neither his words nor the photographs could have done for themselves.

Fifty youthful editors of secondary school, boys' club and settlement house newspapers in the city pledged support yesterday for the appeal of the Greater New York Fund. At a luncheon in the Hotel Paramount they heard Winthrop Rockefeller, executive chairman of the campaign, assert that in this country youth need not express itself with a "trigger."

After three days of disclosures, involving a mystery of ten years ago, Warden McCauley of the State prison today announced that De Casto-Earl Mayer, a habitual criminal serving a life term, had confessed the murder of James Eugene Bassett, a former army flier.

Plans for the traditional Senior Week activities at Barnard College, to. be held in the week beginning May 27, are being made under the direction of Adi-Kent Thomas, chairman of Senior Week. The plans include an innovation, an allcollege dinner to precede the Step Singing ceremonies which are held on the opening night.

It must be fame and not fortune that the special breed of sportsmen known as outboard drivers will seek when they cast loose from the Albany shore next Sunday morning and make their annual madcap dash through the Hudson's tricky ourrents and tides for 130 treacherous miles.

Although the production of potatoes has increased slightly in the past twentyfive years, employment in this industry has steadily declined, the Works Progress Administration reported today on the basis of a study by its National Research Project.

The marriage of Miss Lydia Evelyn Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Benjamin Martin of 669 Cedar Brook Road, to William Henry Peterson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peterson of Colonia, N. J., took place this evening in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church.

A "country fair" was established yesterday afternoon on New York's midtown East Side to the delight of several hundred children, many of whom never have been out of the city. It was a closing feature of the eighth annual Boys Fair which has been in progress for a week at the Madison Square Boys Club, 312 East Thirtieth Street.

Even the trailer has left its mark upon the school system. In the New York City schools more than 500 boys are taking courses in homemaking and home economics, learning to cook, to use the skillet, to make apple ples or strawberry shortcake.

Patrolman Frank T. Schroeder, 31 years old, of the Bayside Police Station, who was reported missing in a teletype alarm sent from police headquarters on May 3, returned yesterday to his home at 152-14 Thirty-third Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

Many of the canvases shown at the Milch and Downtown Galleries and at the New Art Circle have been seen before but well bear up under reacquaintance, particularly when accompanied by.pictures not previously exhibited.

The annual luncheon and musicale in behalf of the Palestine Lighthouse for the aid of the Jewish blind will take place Tuesday in the ballroom of the Pierre.

Unlike a total eclipse of the sun, however, the moon will not be completely darkened, as only part of the sunlight that falls upon it will be cut off. This will L .-e it a coppery red color.

TO what extent, if any, the public will benefit from the proposed code for automobile retailing approved by representatives of the National Automobile Dealers Association at the recent conference here held by the Federal Trade Commission is a question which students of the industry are attempting to fathom.

The May Day deportation of Norman Thomas, former Socialist party candidate for President, and a group of followers from Jersey City after his attempt to speak at a mass meeting in Journal Square without a permit has thrown the spotlight again on policies of Mayor Frank Hague which have brought many charges of suppression of free speech and other civil right in recent year.

The following WPA Federal Art Projects exhibitions are on view this week: Federal Art Gallery, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street--Paintings from Easel Division. Bureau of Child Guidance, 46 Forsythe Street--20 children's paintings, 10 children's Drints.
Charges that the Senate Lobby Committee had attacked the freedom of the press were "arrant nonsense," Senator Green, Rhode Island, Democrat, declared today.

ADIJER--TRELZIN--Mr. and Mrs. A. StIelzln of Brooklyn announce the engagement of their daughter, Gertrude, to Mr. Harvey Adler of Brooklyn. EIEDELMAN--MIRSKY--Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Mirsky announce-the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Mirsky, to Dr. Harry L. Fiedelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Fledelman.
Seward Park and Benjamin Franklin triumphed for the second time in a row in the Manhattan division of the P. S. A. L. handball tournament on the Macombs Dam Park courts yesterday.

MIDDLEFIELD, Conn.-When Governor Cross crowns the queen of the sixth Middle field Apple Blossom Festival today more than five thousand people are expected to witness this climax of the second day of the annual festival held in the 400-acre Lyman orchard on a series of ridges overlooking the Connecticut River valley near Middletown.

The wheat fields of Kansas and Nebraska are greener and more lush, and cover more ground, than at any time in the last seven years, Every day adds to the probability that they will contribute to the greatest crop produced since the bumper and near-record yield of 1931, which broke the back of . the wheat market. .

Yachtsmen in the Springtime are creatures of habit and likely to steer well-known courses to familiar old haunts and harbors during the shakedown season of May. Trial runs along waterways where every spar buoy, can and nun are well remembered are a heap safer than chancing new routes where navigation is a bit ticklish.

SOME men came out of the World War with a sharp dislike for every kind of lie or illusion and a courteous but powerful determination to spend the rest of their lives doing as nearly what they wanted to do as possible.
The Drama League of New York will give a Spring luncheon in celebration of the twenty-eighth anniversary of the Drama League of America on Tuesday in the-Corin thian Room of the Pierre.

The sale of English, French and Italian period furniture, which was conducted Thursday, Friday and yesterday at the Parke-Barnet Galleries, realized $55,398. Mrs. James P. Donahue of New York was the principal owner.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who has five children, suggested today that something more be done about Mother's Day. than its observance by the sending of flowers, telegrams and silk Stockings.

The primary obligation for dealing with the slum-clearance problem rests with municipal governments, and "municipal bankruptcy" will be the penalty if the committees fail to act quickly, said Louis H. Pink, chairman of the State Board of Housing, today.

An official announcement indicated today that Austria's highest administrative court had been purged by Joseph Buerckel, the Reich Commissioner, nine of its members having been dismissed for political reasons.

After a discouraging start, marked by the damaging of a shell as the freshman race was marred by a foul and ruled off, the Rutgers varsity and junior varsity crews rowed away from Manhattan for substantial victories on the Harlem yesterday over the Henley distance.

Federal Judge John C. Knox of New York City, a Democrat, charged that the nation's economic system is "threatened by the voracious octopus of government" in a speech prepared for delivery tonight before the Broome County Bar Association.
THERE is no doubt that this carefully documented work lives up to its publisher's description; it "is not only a definitive biography; it is a real contribution to American naval history."

Mercersburg, perennial prep school champion, swept to its third consecutive crown in the Princeton interscholastic games at Palmer Stadium today by outdistancing Hill, 44-39. Long Branch carried off the high school laurels by the same margin, scoring 27 points to Evander Childs's 22. Five- meet records fell under the onslaught of the forty-nine schoolboy outfits.

MR. EKINS went to China as a war correspondent last Summer after the war with Japan began, but this book tells less of the war itself than of the background of the war. China's fight for her life in this rendering begins long before 1937. As indeed it did.

The new immigration law setting up rules for the entry of foreigners into Brazil places agrarian immigration on the preferred list. Likewise it removes the barriers heretofore raised against some European agrarian workers who were banned.

Approximately $63,000,000 was made available by private lending institutions to finance the construction or purchase of 14,200 small homes under the FHA plan during April, Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Adihinistrator, announced yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Untermyer's Hexameter topped a large field of qualified or green hunters in the conformation hunters class of the Washington Horse Show at Meadow Brook, Md., today.

The property in the Poundridge section of Westchester County known for many years as the John Gray. farm has been sold by its recent owner, Jack Pegler, brother of the columnist Westbrook Pegler, to Paul L. Tyson, technical director of the General Chemical Company.

The marriage of Miss Betsy Ruth Gerber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Gerber of East Orange, N. J., to Joseph T. Hewitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hewitt of Mount Vernon, N. Y., took place here yesterday Morning in the Church of the Transfiguration.

A London production of "The Women" seems at last to be passing from the realm of speculation to that of reality. Max Gordon now is negotiating for a London management to sponsor the pay-with decision reserved on whether an all-American cast shall be brought over to do justice to the highly localized types.

A joint House-Senate committee approved today the final draft of the compromise Tax Bill. The conferees said they made no changes in the terms of the agreement reached last week, merely approving language of the compromise worked out by the committee.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur A. Ballantine is disturbed at the thought of introducing more businesslike methods into government, for, as he says: "The government is not a business and never will be. * * * The government is not run for profit and cannot proceed as if following rules appropriate for business without getting deeper into trouble."

Charles Edward Lozier, retired steel manufacturer and one of the first manufacturers of automobiles In the United States, died today at, Memorial Hospital at the age of 79. He had made his home here since his retirement from active business in 1924.

The outdoor operetta season at Jones Beach will open on June 25 and that at Randalls Island on June 28, with schedules calling for performances Monday through Saturday at Jones Beach and Tuesday through Sunday at Randall's Island.

The Queens-Nassau Home Builders League has adopted a standard membership sign which will be displayed in model homes in all building projects in Queens and Nassau Counties being developed by members of the league.

Application was made yesterday in Surrogate's Court by Mrs. Lea R. Sachs of 25 Central Park West, widow of Nathan I. Sachs, attorney and member of Lippman Sachs, for an order directing the Manufacturers Trust Company to resume payments of income from her husband's estate.

The marriage of Miss Mary Louise Beakes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Curtis Beakes 2d of this place, to Chauncey Deming Cowles Jr., son of Mrs. Cowles of Buffalo and the late Mr. Cowles, took place here this afternoon in the Second Reformed Church.

The arrest of a man who, it is charged, has been employing high school boys as agents in the distribution of pornographic literature and pictures in New Jersey and other States was announced this evening by the Irvington police. The prisoner, Morris A. Eggert, 29 years old, of 100 Morton Street, Newark, is being held in default of $1,000 bail on a charge of sale and possession of such material.

WITH the first touch of warmth in the air, the cafe tables and chairs come back to the sidewalks of Europe and Spring is here again. Except in London, where outdoor cafes hardly exist, they are Europe's most popular social centers from about 10 o'clock in the morning to 2 o'clock the next morning.

THE National Orchestral Association, with Leon Barzin conducting, will give its annual special concert series for next season, Jan. 28, Feb. 4 and 18, and March 4 and 25, in Carnegie Hall. Rudolf Serkin, pianist, will be the soloist at each of the Saturday afternoon events.

Miss Thelma Eloe, a high school student here, needed information on socialism in order to write a theme. She sent a letter to national Socialist party headquarters asking for pamphlets and received a price list of books and leaflets.

Unfavorable weather conditions in the Southwest, excessive rains falling in parts of Oklahoma, Kansas and Nebraska and a forecast of frost in Western Nebraska, Western and Central Kansas and the Texas Panhandle brought a sharp upturn in wheat futures today.

Foreign exchange experts in Wall Street give the new Daladier frano a life of from two to six months. This somewhat cynical appraisal of France's definitive devaluation springs in part from the disillusionment of a prolonged period of chronic illness in French monetary affairs. In part it is the product of a cold calculation that Premier Edouard Daladier, like his predecessors, has as yet failed to come to grips with what really ails the frano.

More than 11,000 retailers of gasoline who have failed to renew their licenses will be brought up with a short turn soon, the Department of Taxes and Finance announced today. State and local police will be directed to close filling stations where new licenses are not in evidence.

A series of ten Summer symphonic band concerts at various parks and recreational centers of the city will be given during July and August, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday. The concerts were made possible by a joint contribution of Local 802 of the Musicians Union and the Friedsam Foundation, Inc.

Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Edgecomb of BalaCynwyd have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Louise Edgecomb, to Edward B. Tolan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Tolan of Cleveland. Mr. Tolan is a nephew of Clarence Tolan Jr. of Wayne.

The marriage of Miss Nancy White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Justin White of this community, to Clarence J. A varied program of entertainment will be presented at the dinner and dance to be given in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton on May 24 for the benefit of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children. The party will mark the formal opening of the garden for the Summer season.

On an average day in the Winter and early Spring in New York City, 280,000 persons are disabled by illness, another 700,000 suffer from but are not disabled by a chronic disease, and 91,000 others have been affected permanently by congenital defect, previous illness or accident, it was reported last night at a public meeting in, the New York Academy of Medicine.
A model League of Nations meeting on the University of Rochester's river campus "solved" three big international problems today.
Special armament expenditures of 9,038,000,000 francs and increases in the effective of the army, navy and air force are provided in a decree on national defense now in preparation by Cabinet.

At this time next year six lanes of automobiles will glide briskly along a mile and a quarter of glistening concrete connecting the Grand Concourse with the Triborough Bridge. Shrubs and trees bordering the roadway will help blot out memories of the 500 slum dwellings which less than two years ago housed 30,000 persons in that territory.

ROME. -- In the two years that have passed since the annexation of Ethiopia was proclaimed on May 9, 1936, the amount of work that the Italians have performed to prepare their new empire for the exploitation of tomorrow is regarded here as truly remarkable.

A six-year city-wide high school building program which will cost "many millions of dollars" and be a part ot the coordinated city building plan called for by the City Charter for the next six years was announced yesterday by Dr. William E. Grady, associate superintendent in charge of industrial, vocational and continuation schools.

An official denial of press reports from Vienna that 500 Austrian Jews were coming to Mexico as refugees was issued last night by the Press Department in the name of the Interior Department. "There have been no petitions, much less authorizations with respect to the entry into Mexico of a nuclei of Israelite immigrants," said the statement.

A verdict of accidental death was returned today at an inquest here into the drowning of Fred C. Betts, Conservative Member of Parliament or London, Ont. who drowned Tuesday in the Blanche River, in a wooded section of Papineau County.
Probably 6,000,000 families, comprising 20,000,000 persons, are receiving some form of public assistance, Harry L. Hopkins, chief of the WPA, told a House hearing in testimony made public today.

Sharp criticism was voiced at the recent convention in New Orleans of the American Institute of Architects regarding the tendency to use relief funds for the inaccurate restoration of historic buildings.
Foreign Minister Koki Hirota called on the Japanese people today to prepare for "possible extreme personal financial sacrifices" to achieve victory in the Chinese war.
Henry Hufner, city editor of The Shanghai Evening Post, who plunged to his death early today from the sixth floor of the Navy Y. M. C. A., left a self-written obituary for his paper.

The principle that an action which would violate the Wagner act if done by -an employer -on his own initiative is not illegal if done by an employer under pressure from a bona. fide labor union was established in a decision rendered yesterday by Professor Herman A. Gray of New York University, acting as trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board.

ITALIAN East Africa, Mussolini's merger of Ethiopia, Eritrea and Italian Somaliland, has released its first commemorative postal paper-a series recalling the birth of the Roman Emperor Augustus twenty centuries ago.

THE sculpture in the exhibition presented by the American Artists Congress, reviewed above, was being installed at the time of the press view, and numbers had not yet been attached to the pieces. Therefore detailed comment on this work had best not be attempted today.

Retail volume showed some improvement in many sections last week, to the extent that declines from a year ago were smaller than in earlier weeks. Most districts, however, found volume still trailing that of last year! Warmer weather stimulated the movement of Summer items, both in apparel and home furnishings lines.

THE National Council of the Boy Scouts of America, comprising 1,800 men who represent the 536 local councils administering the programs of the movement, will hold its annual meeting in Cleveland next Friday and Saturday. The National Council is the controlling body of the movement, operating under a Federal charter granted by Congress.
MUSIC entered prominently into Mr. Whalen's preview ceremonies of the New York World's Fair. The programs of the May Day festival and concert of last Sunday had a twofold purpose.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Keith Davey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Davey of Evanston, Ill., to Russell Henry Dimmick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Dimmick of Montclair, took place this afternoon in Grace Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Frank A. Hunger, pastor, performed the ceremony.

Marriner H. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, will make the New Jersey Bankers Association's convention here this week the occasion of his first address in many months' on the current economic situation, Fred I. Collins, president of the association, announced today. An important statement is expected.
Dave Smith, veteran Duke right hander, held the Navy to three hits, one of them a home run by First Baseman Wooding, and the Blue Devils downed the Middies, 2 to 1, in a well-played game today.

The climax to society's entertaining during Preakness Week here will be the Preakness b '1 and pageant to be given next Saturday night in the Fifth Regiment Armory.

Under the auspices of the Ladies Auxiliary of All Hallows Institute, a card party and tea Will take place next Saturday in the Rainbow Grill of Rockefeller Center for the oenefit of the institute, an elementary and preparatory school for boys in East 164th Street, the Bronx.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 5: CAPTAINS Riebe, H. B., the Chicago, to Bureau of Navigation, Washington, D. C., June 25. Johnson, L. A., Med. Corps, San Diego, Calif., to Bureau of Medicine and Survey. Washington, P. C., June 15.

Bill McKechnie's Reds gave the Dodgers an even break in the short series today by dropping the going-away contest to Burleigh Grimes's troupe, 7-4, but Wilkinsburg Will was no happier about the whole thing than was Burleigh the day before.

Miss Doris Vandegrift King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Marion King Jr. of Glenside, was married here this afternoon in the Carmel Presbyterian Church to Theodore Stallknecht Corwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Corwin of Orange, N. J.

The New York Society of the Panama Canal, composed of men who worked on "the big ditch" from 1904 to 1914, held its fourteenth annual dinner last night at the Hotel Astor. Nearly 100 men were present.
A record-breaking Harvard varsity crew won the Compton Cup race on the placid waters of Lake Carnegie today, beating Syracuse, Princeton and M. I. T. in that order.

INTROSPECTION is an indulgence for which persons and institutions generally have the time and inclination only dur ing periods of affliction and self doubt. Right at the moment, the American film industry appears to be in the midst of such an interlude-due, in the main, to the general business recession and unsettled conditions throughout the world.

The Sherwood Little Theatre Group of Yonkers won the tenth annual Westchester Little Theatre tournament of the Westchester Drama Association at the County Center here tonight with its performance of Paul Green's "Hymn to the Rising Sun."
Several large corporations paid their officials more money in 1937 than in 1936, reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission showed today.

Great Britain and the United States are approaching an agreement with reference to the status of the disputed islands of Canton and Enderbury in the Central Pacific, with the prospect that an arrangement will be entered into for joint jurisdiction.

An effort to mediate a strike of editorial workers at The Daily Courier of the Oranges and Maplewood here will be made on Monday, when William Hirsch, publisher, and representatives of the Newark Newspaper Guild will meet with Mayor Walter B. Savage.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading citirq for the week ended May 4 aggregated $8,536,000,000, or 7 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 18 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

THERE are many things the business girl has to think about in selecting her Summer trousseau. She is concerned with gaining the admiring approval of her boss's eye and winning the favorable comments of her companions when she is vacationing.

William Gillespie of Scarborough (N. Y.) School and Atlanta, Ga., today scored a clean sweep in the finals of the Cornell interscholastic tennis tournament.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hopkins Paddock of Mount Kisco, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Paddock, to Theodore deFreyne Hobbs, son of Mrs. Edward Hobbs of New Canaan, Conn.

The 1938 B'nai B'irth award will be presented to Mrs. Leo Sulzberger, president of the New York section of the Council of Jewish Women, on behalf of the council, on May 18 at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. New York Lodge 1 of the order will officiate.

A yearly scholarship of the income from a $5,000 fund will be presented to a member of the senior class at Hunter College and judged by a committee made up of the chairman of the Department of Romance Languages, the president and the dean, as having evidenced the highest degree of excellence in the study of the Italian language and literature.

Striking while the iron was hot, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, today boosted the latest German Government loan, originally put at 1,000,000,000 marks, by another 150,000,000 marks to a total of 1,600,000,000.

THE physician who has written this book is nothing if not an enthusiast. He does not only write in praise of honey and in celebration of its age-old history: he would have it brought back into general use instead of sugar and put to a number of special uses as well.
The Phillies tallied two runs in the eighth inning today to blank the Reds, 2--0, in a pitchers' duel between Buicky Walters and Rookie Johnny Vander Meer.
France's semi-Fascist parties, encouraged by the collapse of the Popular Front government, paraded today in Joan of Are Day celebrations.

Serious problems confront the city. as a result of the decrease of its unencumbered debt margin to $73,506,925 as of April 1, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick informed Mayor La Guardia and members of the Board of Estimate in a report made public yesterday.

The Michigan Central Railroad and the Cleveland Union Terminals Company, both of which are headed by F. E. Williamson, president of the -New York Central Railroad,

Some idea of the difficulties that France faces in her efforts to get the national production back on a paying basis is contained in export figures for the automobile, wine and other industries obtained from official sources.

As the finale of judging in twentysix classes at the tenth annual Saxon Woods Hunt Club horse show today on the club grounds in this city, the winner of the hunter championship was announced as being the little chestnut gelding Power Plant, owned by Mrs. Walter Kees of New York and jumped in all the classes by Mr. Kees.
Trading in corn last week on the Board of Trade was not large, and while the market declined in sympathy with wheat, there was good support from houses with export connections on the break.

Max Kaesche of Ridgewood and W. G. Barr of the home club today won the first annual Rock Spring Club invitation golf tournament by defeating Martin Issler of Rock Spring and John Whinery of Essex County, 2 and 1, in an eighteen-hole final.

Despite the absence of "enemy" planes, a mock air raid on Windsor Castle was carried out so realistically today that a window in the Royal Mews was shattered by a firecracker, exploded on the ground to represent a bomb.
Hexameter, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Untermyer of Greenwich, Conn., a consistent blue ribbon performer for three days, was adjudged grand champion hunter of the Washington Horse Show today.

Liquidation by holders of May lard contracts was under way last week on the Board of Trade, the price dropping to $7.90 a 100 pounds, or within 5 cents of the inside figure of the season, established in March. With that exception, the current level is the lowest since August, 1934.

Several hundred school children crowded the Education Hall of the American Museum of Natural History yesterday afternoon to push buttons, throw switches, operate levers and absorb the wealth of information. contained in the 350 displays of the tenth annual School Science Fair of the American Institute.
Dr. Charles M. Culver, retired eye specialist who claimed to be the oldest living participant of the first Intercollegiate Association track meet, died at his home here today after a short illness.
The local office of All America Cables will inaugurate tomorrow a direct radio circuit with Rome through Italian Radio, and follow it on May 16 with a circuit to Berlin.
This week's official decision once again to devalue the- franc was not altogether unexpected here.

Delegates to a conference marking the thirtieth anniversary of the Federation of Polish Jews in America adopted yesterday resolutions protesting against persecution of Jews in Poland and attacking Chancellor Adolf Hitler, nazism and fascism.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 32 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week. This compared with an average of 33.44 per cent in April, when there was only a slight decrease from March, the high month since last November.

Rabbi Solomon Foster, a New Jersey Jewish leader, criticized today as unnecessary and futile the nation-wide plebiscite the American Jewish Congress is to conduct on June 25, 26 and 27 to create a united front against anti-Semitism.

Motorists along Flatbush Avenue and fliers at Floyd Bennett Field watched yesterday as Harry Wesik, 29 years old, an amateur pilot, of 418 West '118th Street, practiced spins in an open cockpit biplane 4,000 feet over the Brooklyn airport.

Twenty-six- feature films and sixteen "Westerns" will comprise the 1938-39 release schedule of Monogram Pictures, according to an announcement made yesterday by W. Ray Johnston, Monogram - president, at the company's annual meeting in-Cincinnati and released here.

DIAL --- Mr. and Mrs. Nathan announce the birth of a daughter, May 1, at the Beth David Hospital. KASDAN--Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kasdan of 141 East 19 th St., Brooklyn, are happy to announce the arrival Richard's sister, Jane Phyllis, on May 1, Israel Zion Hospital, Brooklyn.

Plans for a modern wholesale produce market in lower Manhatton are being developed by the Deapartment of Markets, it was learned yesterday. Because the market would meet a great national as 'well as a local need it is hoped a Federal grant may be obtained to finance its construction, estimated to cost $30,000,000. It would be run by the city as a self-supporting project.
British trade indices continue to point to a moderate business recession. Railway receipts are still failing;

Shown in splendid condition by Harry Hartnett, the handsome veteran Irish setter Champion Milson Top Notcher, from the Milson Kennels of Harrison, N. Y., today captured premier honors in the Trenton Kennel Club's sixth annual all-breed exhibition at the 112th Field Artillery grounds.

There is an unconscious recognition on the part of every individual of a public that may be big or small and that all people play up to, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary declared yesterday befqre the congregation of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Seventy-third Street and Madison Avenue.

The belief in "goodness without God," which he said was prevalent today, particularly among intellectuals, was condemned as thin and superficial by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick yesterday morning in his sermon in the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, where he is the pastor.

An examination of the whole tax structure of the nation by a national, non-partisan commission was recommended to Congress today by the Board of Directors of the National Association of Manufacturers.
More than 1,700 graduate and student nurses attended last night the annual service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in memory of Florence Nightingale and other nurses who have died.

Ketchum Co., wholesale druggists, has leased from the Trinity Church Corporation the building at 50-60 Van Dam. Street, which it plans to equip for one of the largest wholesale drug plants in the city.

Spain and Russia have been destroyed because of the misuse of freedom and liberty, which led to unlawful desires, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray said in his sermon yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner), at 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.
St. John's of Brooklyn halted Providence College's winning streak today with a 14--10 triumph in a game that was called at the end of seven innings because of the 6 o'clock Sunday law.

With the exception of box-loom fabrics, there was an increase in output of rayon cloths during the week of April 30, according to the survey of loom activity for that period, issued for publication today by the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc.

Miss Edith Scott Weed. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Le Roy J. Weed of Garden City, L. I., and Dr. Ralph Frederick Schneider of New York, will be married on the afternoon of June 10 in the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, by the Very Rev. Arthur B. Kinsolving 2d, the dean.
Sixteen New York City firemen who risked their lives in fires and other accidents last year will be decorated for bravery June 1 by Mayor La Guardia.

Fiorello H. La Guardia, modern-art critic, Indian chief and Mayor of New York, made his first appearance yesterday afternoon in still another new role--that of radio music commentator -- and, with characteristic forthrightness, proceeded to tell music critics they had no business saying that "a piece is played too fast or too slow."

While not anxious to become Involved in the competitive battles in which newspapers, magazines and radio are now engaged, producers of direct mail are launching a campaign to clarify the importance of direct mail and to sell agencies and advertising managers on its value.
The German wholesale price index -on April 27 stood at 105.5, slightly off from the 105.6 reported a week before.

A formal protest against the legalization of lotteries and against relaxing anti-gambling laws in this State has been made by the board of directors of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robert Wyckoff Searle, the general secretary, at the federation's headquarters, 71 West Twentv-third Street.

The impatient International Class sloops sailed the first race of the Long Island Sound season today for a prize offered by Earle Hammons, with Frank Campbell carrying off the silverware after winning in Rascal.
Lord Harlech, prominent British landowner and sportsman and father of William G. A. Ormsby-Gore, Colonial Secretary, died today at his home in Oswestry, Shropshire. He was 83 years old.
Forty delegates to the eighteenth biennial Wisconsin Socialist-Labor party convention denounced today Governor La Follette's new National progressive party.
Although they are almost four months off, the second international Tuna Cup matches are coming up for considerable discussion in big-game angling circles.
Now that the question of jettisoning our Neutrality Act and lifting the embargo against Spain is being agitated,

Even in mid-May the waning art season has its share of events. First on the calendar this week is the long-heralded opening of the Cloisters, that veritable museum of medieval art, a branch of the Metropolitan Museum, which will be accessible to the public beginning on Saturday on the rocky height of Fort Tryon Park.
Viscount Halifax, British Foreign Secretary, came to Geneva today to get the League of Nations Council to help Britain recognize the Italian conquest of Ethiopia as legal.

The fourteenth annual Westchester Music Festival will open next Friday evening at the County Center here. For the first time since 1933, a junior chorus will participate. Three hundred pupils from eleven high schools will sing and 100 school orchestra members will form a junior orchestra.

The Bourse reacted vigorously to franc devaluation this week. It is expected that the capitalists who repatriate their money will invest in French industrial securities. These latter and government bonds were particularly firm.

Commissioner Joseph M. Byrne Jr. challenged Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein today to resign from office as he promised on April 27 if the budget for his Department of Public Affairs was not reduced 17 per cent. The Mayor's actual reduction, Mr. Byrne charged, is only 8.9 per cent.

Cotton prices worked slowly downward last week until Friday when a somewhat sharp advance was recorded. On Saturday, however, they lost a part of the previous day's gain. Active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 11 to 17 points for the week.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks:

Governor and Mrs. Lehman, who are Summer residents of Purchase, have bought commemorative half dollars issued in celebration of the 250th anniversary of the founding of New Rochelle next month. They will attend the celebration as guests of honor..

Competent observers in the City are giving especial attention to the currencies of Belgium, Switzerland and The Netherlands, which have depreciated so sharply--mostly on fears that devaluation of the franc may require general revaluation.
The French wholesale price index at the end of April stood at 619, compared with 620 and 619, respectively, in the two previous weeks. The gold index for raw materials was 40.5, compared with 41.3.
Dr. Francis M. McMurray, Fitchburg physician and a close friend of Connie Mack, manager of the Philadelphia American League baseball club, died at his home today after a long illness. His age was 65.

Michael F. Lally assigned to William J. McNulty a mortgage for $13,500 on 333 5th St. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. extended to Dec 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent, a mortgage for $43,450 held from Fannie Vogel on 34 W 35th St.

A group of dealers headed by Eugene J. Hynes Co. will offer today 155,160 shares of 50-cent-parvalue common stock of the Luscombe Airplane Corporation at $1.25 a share. 'The offering will be subject to prior subscription by officers, directors and present stockholders of the company to the extent of not more than 59,997 shares.

" The Italians of New York," first published volume of the Federal Writers Nationalities Group Survey, will be translated into Italian, it is announced by Harry L. Shaw Jr., State director of the WPA Federal Writers Project in New York City.

The American Federation of Actors, which has a closed shop agreement with the Ringling Brothers and Barnum - Bailey circus, announced last night that it would wait a week before moving for a showdown on the issue of whether Frank (Bring 'Em Back Alive) Buck was an actor or a scientist.

Without invalidating the contract between the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes, Local 1,104, an A. F. of L. affiliate; and the Triboro Coach Corporation, operator of bus routes in Queens, the State Labor Relations Board directed yesterday that an election be held by May 17 to determine a collective bargaining representative for the company's employes.

The total .traffic on the city's rapid transit, street car and bus lines for the calendar year 1937, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission, amounted to-3,128,700,000 passengers, an increase of 24,900,000, or 0.8 per cent over 1936.

Counsel for the Ford Motor Company notified the National Labor Relations Board today of the intention to carry to the Supreme Court the fight to prevent the board from regaining jurisdiction of its case against the company.

Miss Jeanne Alexandra Edgar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Edgar of this place, has chosen the afternoon of June 15 for her marriage to Roberts Harrison, son of Harry Waln Harrison of Happy Creek Farms, St. Davids, and of Mrs. Harrison of Pine Cottage, Rosemont. The ceremony will be performed in the Church of the Redeemer here.

This week's chief financial interest here was the repudiation of the transfer of Austria's foreign debt service, which had been conducted satisfactorily since 1935. This event was almost ignored by the home press and was misunderstood abroad.

The firm of Carl Hubbell and Melvin Ott, which has been doing business for all of a decade, put on one of its' old-fashioned two-man shows today to heap a lot of misery .upon 20,835 hardy souls who braved chilblains, a leaden sky and wintry blasts in the hope of seeing something entirely different.
Although this week witnessed numerous dividend increases, the stock market here was inert, featureless and reactionary.

Dr. Charles Lee Bailey of Hudson Falls, N. Y., who gained prominence as an alienist when he testified for the defense in the murder trial of Harry K. Thaw, died today in an Albany hospital after a long illness. His age was 68.
Justice Black, a member of the Supreme Court for only seven months, has been the principal single dissenter at the present term, which will end May 31, preliminary figures showed today.

Gertrude Lawrence said yesterday that her starring vehicle, "Susan and God," would close here on Friday, June 10 (although the closing date announced yesterday by the John Golden office is June 4); that she will sail the next day for a vacation trip (not to Europe, though);

A contribution of $15,000 by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union to the Greater New York Fund, which is conducting a campaign for $10,000,000 for the city's private welfare and health agencies, was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, president, of the fund.

Speakers before the annual meeting of the Jewish Education Association, at which officers were elected for the year, declared yesterday that the survival of Judaism was dependent upon the education of Jewish children in the traditions of their race. The meeting was held in the Hotel Astor.

The firm of Tailer Robinson, members of the New York Stock Exchange, has been dissolved by mutual consent of the partners, it was announced yesterday. F. Sheperd Cornell, Joseph I. Loughlin and W. Guertin Tuttle, formerly with that firm, have become associated with Delafield Delafield.

The outdoor boxing season at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn will start on Thursday, May 19, according to an announcement yesterday by Major Hugh A. Wear, athletic officer at the reservation. Programs will be presented every Thursday night through the Summer.

Officials of the United States and six LatinAmerican countries participated today in the first of a series of international radio broadcasts designed to offset the radio propaganda with which European nations have been flooding South America.
Miss Beatrice Barclay Chard will have two matrons of honor at her marriage to George B. Carpenter, which takes place the afternoon of June 20 in St. Peter's Church, Caze novia, N. Y.

Asserting that "the devil was the first critic" of the Bible, the Rev. Dr. William Hubert Rogers, the pastor, denounced "the marks and menaces of the modernists" in his sermon last evening at the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street.

More than 500 persons, including delegates from twenty-four Eastern colleges and universities, attended the first annual solemn high field mass held yesterday morning on the campus of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, a college for girls at Convent Avenue and West 133d Street.

The Greenwich Exchange for Women's Work will give its annual benefit bridge and tea on the afternoon of May 25 at the Round Hill Club here. Mrs. Walter C. Douglas, president of the exchange; Mrs. George L. Ohrstrom and Mrs. Albert Bradley head the group arranging the party, which this year will also include a fashion show.
The annual five-day session of the Interdenominational Bible Conference opened yesterday morning at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Francis Ouimet, captain of the United States Walker Cup golf team, observed his forty-fifth birthday today by rounding together a lot of knick-knacks he'll need for the team's invasion of the British Isles, the first leg of which starts tomorrow when he entrains for New York.

Jose Iturbi established another record for the Colon Theatre here this afternoon when for the first time in its history the house was completely sold out for a purely symphonic concert without soloists or other side attractions. More than 4,000 persons were present, including all available standing room.

Big words, millennial words, words like eternal, unchangeable, immutable, inviolable for all time, vibrated under the golden. chandeliers of the banqueting hall in the PalazzoVenezia Saturday night as Premier Mussolini and Chancellor Hitler exchanged declarations of undying friendship.

Metropolitan racing will shift tolay to Belmont Park, where the Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association will run twentyfour days to June 4 and will have as its traditional inaugural the for-a ty-fifth Toboggan Handicap at six furlongs, for which eight of the best sprinters hereabouts are lamed.

Victorious in their second encounter at Starlight Park yesterday, as they had been in the first in Brooklyn a week earlier, the St. Mary's Celtics eliminated the Brookhattans from the finals for the championship of the American Soccer League. The game was 1-0.

72d St, 111 W. 23x102.2: Allenhurst Holding Corp to Howgold Realties, Inc. 41 E 57th St ($1). 135th St, 35 W, 37.6x100: Twenty Seventh Management, Inc, to Halkov Realty Corp. both of 989 6th Ave. care H Kovner. mtg $31,000.

William M. Purves of Birmingham, Mich., general sales manager for the Dodge division of Chrysler Motor Corporation, was found dead in his Pullman berth today on a train bearing motor officials here for a district convention.
The National Maritime Union formally reopened yesterday its drive for a national industrial federation embracing all employes in the maritime transportation field.
Two youths who said they had fought with the Loyalist army in Spain, and stowed away on a British collier at Barcelona to get home, ran into trouble today when they fled the ship at East Boston.
The Girls Service League of America needs $230,000 to carry on, according to a pamphlet issued on the occasion of its - thirtieth anniversary and made public yesterday.

Mrs. Chester Clark Boynton and Miss Marie Bradford Trench sail tomorrow for a visit to Italy and France. Mrs. Randolph Barton Jr. and Miss Elizabeth H. Barton have arrived from Baltimore and are at the Berkshire.
The international executive board of the United Automobile Workers Union will meet here tomorrow with factionalism within the union its chief problem, according to union sources.

The North Dakota Non-Partisan League's advisory council, meeting with the organization's State executive committee, today withdrew its support from Representative William Lemke, North Dakota Republican, for re-election.
Austrian German authorities issued a warrant today for the arrest of 20-year-old Archduke Felix of Habsburg, younger brother of Archduke Otto, pretender to .the. non-existent Austrian throne.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company sold to an investor represented by Charles Charak, attorney, the two four-story buildings on a plot 80 by-100 feet at 1,316-24 Nostrand Avenue. Hy. D. Agar, Inc., were the brokers.
New York's Chinese population will take part this afternoon in a parade and celebration in China-town marking the observance of China's National Solidarity Day.

A nation-wide drive for. funds for the Mother Irene Gill Memorial Library, now under construction at the College of New Rochelle here, will close on Saturday, it was announced today. Reports will be made on that day at a series of bridge parties to be held throughout the country under the auspices of the alumnae association.

With Major C. E. Davis supplying the power on the attack and serving as the bulwark on defense, the Governors Island team opened the polo season at Morris Memorial Field in sprightly fashion yesterday by defeating Boulder Brook, 8 to 6.
Fighting Fox, Bull Lea, Dauber, Can't Waitand Menow were en route to Baltimore and the Preakness Stakes today, while Lawrin, Winner of the Kentucky Derby yesterday, remained at Churchill Downs.
The Brooklyn Real Estate Board has moved its offices to 44 Court Street. The contract for erection of the new Fulton Fish Market on South Street, between Piers 18 and 19,

New York City is ready.to-undertake eighty-six PWA projects costing $295,107,200 if Congress appropriates new funds for the Federal Emergency Administration of Public- Works, Colonel M. E. Gilmore, regional director of PWA for the eleven Northeastern States, reported yesterday.

The general sales offices of the Goodall Manufacturing Company, makers of Palm Beach cloth, at 200 Fifth Avenue, have been enlarged and remodeled. Eleanor LeMaire designed the offices, which feature a tropical theme in the contemporary manner.
Jack Wilson, the big-Red Sox right-hander, shut out the league-leading Indians, 5 to 0, with four hits in the series opener today to give Boston its third straight victory.

David Lloyd George, speaking in connection with the 200th anniversary of George Whitefield's arrival in America to spread the gospel- of Calvinism, today described the missionary as the "greatest pulpit orator produced by the English-speaking people."

Using a row of dingy, boarded-up tenements for a background, youths of the lower East Side presented last night an open-air production of "Youth on Parade," a pageant dealing with slum conditions, unemployment and the need for a youth center on the EastSide.

A demand that the Spanish arms embargo be lifted immediately was made to Secretary of State Hull in a letter made public yesterday by William Karlin, chairman of the Social Democratic Federation of New York.
Annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York will begin at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria at 10 A. M. and continue to Thursday. Morning, afternoon and evening sessions.
Samuel A. Ettelson, prominent attorney and former Corporation Counsel of Chicago, died early this morning in Michael Reese Hospital. He was 63 years old.

Maurice J. McCarthy, one of the leading American golf architects, who designed 125 courses scattered throughout the East and Middle West of the United States, died suddenly at 8 P. M. Saturday of a heart attack at his home, 140-56 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Flushing, Queens. He was 63 years old.
Cecil Travis pounded across five runs today to assist the Senators in defeating the Browns, 9 to 7. It was Washington's fifth straight victory and the sixth straight defeat for St. Louis.

The Spring seasonal recovery in German industry is reported to be greater than normal. The number of hours worked in March was 14.7 per cent above March, 1936, but the improvement was confined almost entirely to the capital goods branches.
Jack Mason, a dancer and daning instructor who had been known in theatrical circles here and in London since the early years of this century, died yesterday in- Reception Hospital.

Revived interest in building homes "would go far in easing the ills of the world," declared the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams, in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Henry and Clark Streets, Brooklyn, of which he is pastor.
A Methodist congregation of 500 cheered approval tonight when their pastor was officiaily excused for "playing hookey" from church last Sunday to go fishing..
