135th St. 373 E (9-2298): Siracusa Construction Co to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; $33,639. Ryer Ave (11-3157) n w c of 181st St. 102x 126; Ryecroft Realty Corp to Emigrant to 5 per cent. S195,000.
Loss of the British yacht Lost Horizon, owned by H. P. J. Phillips, by fire in the Bay of Biscay was reported today. All aboard were saved.

The engagement of Miss Marion Magner, daughter of Mrs. Edward F. Magner of 5 Prospect Place and the late Mr. Magner, to James R. Scully, son of James J. Scully of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Mrs. Scully, has been announced by her mother.

France's devaluation of the franc has been cordially welcomed by the City. For the first time in several years, it is felt, France has taken proper and courageous action in dealing with her- economic and financial troubles. Hitherto she has persisted in trying to maintain the franc at an overvalued level.
Bill Werber's single with the bases loaded in the tenth inning gave the Athletics two runs and a 7-to-6 victory over Detroit before a crowd of 10,000 today.

If present prospects of a bumper wheat crop materialize, growers will be asked to make this Fall the most drastic reduction in plantings ever proposed under the government's crop-control programs, officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration said today.

Four times yesterday afternoon the promenaders on Fifth Avenue heard rolling drums and the sound of marching feet as two regiments of the New York National Guard, the Seventy-first Infantry and the 212th Field Artillery, marched to and from the annual church services.

Mrs. Amorette E. Fraser, going on 103 and mother of a daughter over 70, which makes her probably the oldest mother in New York City, assumed last night the pulpit of the Brooklyn Baptist Tabernacle, 241 Gates Avenue, and talked--for six minutes on "Motherhood."

Miss Cornelia Kissam Dickinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Dickinson of Sheffield, formerly of St. George, S. I., is to be married to Everitt H. Pell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. E. Pell of Great Barrington, at Christ Episcopal Church, Sheffield, on the afternoon of June 18. The Rev. Edward K. Thurlow, the rector, will officiate.

Paul Russo of Chicago won the feature five-mile midget automobile race at the Velodrome tonight for the third time this season after taking his time trial and qualifying heat in record times and placing first in his semi-final.
Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Margaret Parkhurst, daughter of Mrs. M. Argue Parkhurst of this city, to Rawson Atwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Desler Atwood of Brooklyn.
Chicago at New York--Gabler vs. Chandler. Cleveland at Boston-Galehouse vs. Rogers. Detroit at Philadelphia--Lawson vs. Thomas. St. Louis at Washington---Hildebrand vs. Leonard.
The shadow of a prospective near record-breaking North American Winter wheat crop over the world market became more pronounced last week.

The Yale Law Journal, in the current issue to be published tomorrow, severely criticizes the American Medical Association and local medical societies for alleged policies of expelling physicians who engage in group practice and outlines the possible legal redress open to expelled physicians.
The Manhattan Council of the American Jewish Congress met yesterday afternoon at the Manhattan Opera House in an effort to create a united democratic front against anti-Semitism.

Opening of a special ramp at Wall Street and the East River today is expected to increase the amount of "commuting by air" to the financial district. The ramp at Thirtyfirst Street and the East River is expected to be ready next week.

Miss Peggy Lashanska Rosenbaum has chosen the afternoon of June 16 for her marriage to Peter Gerald Lehman, eldest son of Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman. The ceremony will take place at Sherry's and the Governor will be his son's best man.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.5, which compares with 80.6 a week ago, 81 two weeks ago, 81.1 three weeks ago and 80.9 four weeks ago.
Both in Albany and in Washington the program for public loans and grants-in-aid of better housing is being attacked, mainly on the ground that it costs money.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll calls in Congress during the period April 30 to May 6 are given in the following tabulation:

Leaders of a Congress looking eagerly toward adjournment, whose members wish to return home to fight their election battles, will try this week to pass or speed toward passage the $5,330,000,000 Tax Bill and the $4,500,000,000 Recovery and Relief Bill.

John Seybold - Morris, Professor of Business English and Public Speaking in the School of Commerce of New York University, died Saturday night in the Homeopathic Hospital, East Orange, N. J., where he had undergone an operation for appendicitis. He was 36 years old.
Three of Canada's major gold-producing tines set new monthly records in April and two others came near to their peaks.

There has been introduced in the Senate and the House a bill which provides, at a cost of some $28,000,000, for the creation of a naval air station at Kodiak Island, Alaska; for increasing seaplanes and drydock facilities in Hawaii, and for establishing an air base at Midway Island, halfway across the Pacific.

St. Paul set forth in the thirteenth chapter of Corinthians a "perfect plan for adult living," the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, the rector, said In his sermon yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

While the recent peace conferences failed to reunite the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, such efforts ultimately will be successful, it was asserted here today by Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, and his associates on the union's general executive board. Mr. Hillman is also a vice president of the C. I. O.

Summing up the views expressed at the three-day Fordham Danubian Congress at the final session yesterday afternoon. Dr. Gabor de Bessenyey, the chairman, declared that a union of 'the Danubian States would restore to Europe the balance lost by the dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian Empire .and would "once and for all remove the powder keg from the middle of Europe before it exploded."
Colonel J. Taber Loree, vice president and general manager of the Delaware Hudson Railroad, believes railroads are "operating on too many miles of track from which there is no profit."

The responsibilities of government, the public and organized medicine in the provision of medical care and such aspects of public health as the control of pneumonia, cancer and syphilis will be among the subjects to be discussed at the 132d annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York, which opens today in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

On evidence. obtained by D. S. Hosbetter, of the United States Bureau of Investigation, Grace Travers, Josephine Hill and M. M. Dunlap of Ketchikan were charged before the United States Commissioner on allegations of white slavery. The arrest of the two women was made by Mr. Hostetter and the Marshal's office and bonds were given.
WITH Max Schmeling due back in this country today to go into training for the big bout with Shufflin' Joe Louis, the anti-Nazi organizations in this area probably will swing into action again.

Mr. and Mrs. John W. Livermore, in 130 East End Ave from the Gresham Realty Co; John A. Vance, in 1,112 Park Ave; Mrs. Ethel Petinot, in 480 Park Ave; Dr. Joseph L. gorse, in 521 Park Ave; Pease Elliman, brokers.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Alice Richardson, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Richardson of this city, to George Mattias Hoffman Jr. of New York and Verona, N. J., son of Mrs. George M. Hoffman of Verona and the late Brig. Gen. George Mattias Hoffman.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Do not fear," said the judge to the trembling prisoner at- the bar, "this court will .do fair. justice by you." "Tha's zactly what. I'm afraid of, judge," mumbled the culprit.

The annual celebration of Parents Day, when school children of the city and their parents join with Uncle Robert, sponsor of the plan, to pay honor to fathers as well as mothers, was held yesterday afternoon on the Mall at Central Park.
Two college classmates were killed and a third was seriously injured today when their automobile smashed into the stone abutment of a railroad underpass on the Hadley-Amherst highway.

Mr. and Mrs. William Hubert Gunther of' 205 Greenway North, Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gloria Rita Gunther, to James Francis Garvey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick James Garvey of Holyoke, Mass.; and Pine Orchard. Conn.

Miss Elizabeth Cooke Alling, daughter of Mrs. Morris Ezra Alling of this place, was married to William Daniel Carter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Clifford Carter of Wakefield, Mass., yesterday afternoon in the garden of the bride's home.

Mr. and Mrs. Walton H. McGean of Cleveland Heights have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Lucile Phillips McGean, to Hermann Scheyhing of New York, son of Christian Scheyhing of Kassel, Germany, and the late Mrs. Scheyhing. The wedding will take place on May 27 in Cleveland.

New York City joined with the nation yesterday in a tribute to mothers. The sentimental note of Mother's Day was heard on the radio, from the pulpits; it was visible in the flower-decked coat lapels, in the bundles containing candy, flowers or potted plants.
The executive committee of the United States Amateur Baseball Congress today banned all semi-pro players from competing for the 1940 Olympic team.

Henry Spaulding Park died here last night at his home, 266 Audley Street, after a fortnight's illness at the age o 67. He was secretary and treasurer of the Read Lovatt Manufacturing Company, silk thowsters, 95 Madison Avenue, New York, with which he had been associated since 1893.

As a market factor, the new budget already has as good as vanished. Gilt-edge securities, far from being depressed by the higher income tax, have been rising, receiving, in fact, their first check through French liquidation following devaluation of the franc.
Though there had been definite intimations a few days before then, Mr. Ruosevelt presented his detailed "pumppriming" program to Congress on April 14.

The Rev. Dr. Charles D. Trexler, pastor for the last eight years of the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, was unanimously called yesterday to the pastorate of Grace Lutheran Church, Forest Hills, L. I. The congregational meeting was held at the close of the morning service.
Charles Hill Coe, a vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 664 Prospect Street. He was a native of Jersey City.

The Citizens Budget Commission announced yesterday its opposition to any amendment of the State Constitution that would permit the issuance of city bonds beyond the present constitutional debt limitation.

Angelo Trulio, competing unattached, defeated Eddie Hahn of the home club, 21-18, 21--19, to gain the semi-final. round in the Metropolitan A. A. U. four-wall handball singles championship at the Pastime A. C. yesterday. Ray Ruddy, Edward Linz and Willie Waxman also advanced.

Dinghy skippers from Massachusetts Institute of Technology today won their third consecutive regatta when they outscored Harvard, Brown, Dartmouth and Princeton on the Charles River. Light winds slowed up all five races.

George Oliver Jr., with four tallies, led the Monmouth County Country Club polo team to an 8-to-6 triumph over Evergreen Farms on the victor's field today. Max Phillips, with three goals, also starred for the winners, while M. Untermeyer Jr. excelled for the losers with three.

THE BLUE BED, by Glyn Jones. (Dutton, $2.) A collection of nine store. DEATH SOLVES NOTHING, by Margaret Sothern. (Sheed Ward, $2.50.) A novel about the conflict between communism and the Catholic view of life.
Seton Hall, aided by a ten-run splurge in the ninth inning, defeated the Penn A. C. at the Phillies park today, 14--4. Fifteen men batted in the big inning.

The efficiency of the Italian air force and army was successively demonstrated to Chancellor Hitler today in highly realistic displays, respectively, by the sea, some forty miles from Rome, and in hilly country inland five miles away from the first demonstration.

A total of 146 undergraduates at the University of Pennsylvania received either varsity or junior varsity awards or freshman numerals for participation in six indoor sports, according to an announcement today by H. Jamison Swarts, chairman of the awards committee.

Dean Charles W. Gilkey of Rockefeller Memorial chapel, University of Chicago, addressing the convention of the United Synagogue of America today, declared that 'the time had come when believers in one God would again be responsible for the preservation of civilization.

Colonel Charles H. Bauer, formerly of the Multiposter Advertising Corporation, has been elected a vice president of Kimball, Hubbard Powel, Inc., according to announce.ment issued for publication today.

" Without religion we sink almost to the level of things," said the Rev. Dr. William H. P. Hatch, Professor of the Episcopal Theological School of Cambridge, in his sermon yesterday morning in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.
Reports that the B. M. T. still was obtaining steel rails from Germany were revived yesterday and denied by a spokesman for the traction company.

The German freighter Frankenwald, after taking on general cargo and bunkers here, dropped down the Delaware River today to Carney's Point, N. J., to load 20,000 aerial bombs, the last of four shipments included in an order sold to parties in the United States" by the Atlas Powder Company of Wilmington, Del.
People often talk as if what we had to fear in this country was some one who had personal aspirations to be a dictator. But this reflects a serious misapprehension of the real cause of dictatorship.

Miss Mary L. Carter, 88 years old, member of a once prominent Newark family, was killed early this morning in a fall from a second-story window of her sixteen-room mansion at 44 Hinsdale Place, where she had lived for seventy years.
The statement of the Bank of France dated April 28 shows that advances to the State remained at 18,050,000,000 francs.
Belgium led the way into the third round of the European zone Davis Cup competition yesterday as Poland, Italy and Yugoslavia gained second-round brackets in week-end matches.
The Yankees said it with homers yesterday before 28,440 highly excited fans at the Stadium, where they served up an appropriate greeting to the White Sox.

Delegates to conventions held in New York now stay in the city on an average of five days and spend an average of $90 during the period, according to results of a study just completed by the Merchants Association of New York and made public yesterday.
Attention in the apparel markets last week centered on Summer merchandise and, while activity in the coat and suit field dropped off, mail orders increased and Summer suits were ordered brisky.

Miss Jean Sinclair, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. A. G. Sinclair of Bloomfield, will be married June 11 in First Presbyterian Church here to Arthur Lincoln Schade of Cambridge, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Schade of West Englewood.

Tanned and invigorated after an eight-day cruise in the Caribbean, President Roosevelt boarded his special train at Charleston this afternoon for an overnight run to Washington, where he will confer tomorrow morning with legislative chieftains and administrative aides on the status of his recovery and relief programs and fiscal and foreign affairs.

Here on Loyalist Spain's "other side" and in a town that is the Rebels' present great objective the impression is that the war still has a long time to go. There has not been the faintest collapse either at the front or in the rear guard, there is sufficient food and the cities and villages are quite orderly.

Although 100,000 jobless workers have complained to the State Labor Department that their unemployment insurance rights were improperly recorded, only fifty-eight cases have been carried to the appeals board of the division of placement and unemployment insurance, it became known last night.
Stocks recovered preceding week's losses in heavier trading; turnover, 3,642,530 shares. Bonds generally higher; transactions, $29,073,450.

It was Durocher Day, but not the Dodgers' day here .this wintry afternoon. Local admirers presented the former Cardinal shortstop with an automobile and some of his former mates tried to give the game to Brooklyn.

The C. I. O. affiliated Cannery Workers and Farm Laborers Union today was certified by the National Labor Relations Board as winner in an election held to determine jurisdiction over Alaska salmon cannery workers hired in Oregon and Washington. Robert M. Gates,

Declaring that the -recession is the result of the "law of retribution," the Rev. John P. Monaghan, director of the Labor School of Fordham University, attacked- yesterday. "selfish individualism which poses as political liberalism and sidetracks measures like the Wages and Hours Bill." Its opponents, he said, must be overcome by a positive and constructive democracy.

Paul Muni has advised Warners that, with certain revisions, the screen play based upon Bertita Harding's "The Phantom Crown" and known variously as "Juarez and Maximilian" and "The Patriot" is acceptable to him for his next picture and it has been placed on active schedule. Bette Davis will be seen as Carlotta and negotiations are still being carried on with Fredric March for the role of Maximilian.

S. Young of Hempstead today vaulted into the spotlight of the New York State bowling tournament by taking first place in the all-events and combining with his partner, W. Hoffman, to climb into the fourth berth of the doubles standings.

Alfred M. Cohen of Cincinnati, international president of B'nai B'rith, declared in opening the fifteenth annual convention of the order here today that few Jews were engaged in the communistic movement.

Although gross income of the Pan American Airways Corporation increased from $10,917,542 in 1936 to $14,729,412 in 1937, net profit decreased from $955,352 to $512,446, Juan T. Trippe, president, said in his annual report.
A fight by conservatives and employers to amend or repeal the Wagner Labor Act was touched off in speeches and resolutions at the annual meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce last week.
Members of the Carpet Workers Union local voted today, at a mass meeting, to resist a wage reduction of 10 per cent announced by the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company to become effective tomorrow.

Life insurance has been tower of strength to America and Americans through the depression, according to Kenneth R. Miller, chairman of the National Committee for Life Insurance Education. From 1930 to 1937 inclusive, he says,

The willingness of the late Father Gerard Donovan, Maryknoll (N. Y.) missioner, to die for his faith is the most recent addition to "the evidence of the centuries that the religion of Christ cannot be overthrown because it is of God," the Rev. Charles O'C. Sloane declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Mayor Frank Hague still was "the law" in Jersey City yesterday as his political foes, defeated in their latest attempt Saturday night to rally his city against him, retired to lay new plans and continue their attacks from other vantage points than Journal Square.

In the United States the recognition is gaining ground that democracy can be preserved only by fulfilling its responsibilities, Nathan Straus, Federal Housing Administrator, said last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The Montreal Royals won both ends of a double-header from the Jersey City Giants today, taking the opener, 5 to 4, in eleven innings, and the nightcap, 3 to 2, in seven.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fiftyfifth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning declared that "an outstanding point of our contemporary religion is the loss of our sense of sin."

Representatives of the Progressive Mine Workers of America, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, scheduled to address a mass meeting, failed to appear today and the hall was immediately taken over by United Mine Workers of America,
Japanese military authorities today reported a smashing victory over a Chinese guerrilla force participating in an apparently coordinated effort to break Japan's hold on North China.

Embree H. Henderson and John A. Edwards are with Jackson Brothers, Boesel Co. Herman Johnson has joined Alexander Eisemann Co. at 499 Seventh Avenue. Alexander H. MacKinnon has been appointed co-manager with Lennox G. Black of the office of L. F. Rothschild Co. in Montreal.

Earnings of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation in the first quarter of this year, reported for publication today, were the largest for any quarter in the history of the company, according to Guy W. Vaughan, president.

The Liberal press charges that Opposition politicians and radical agitators are responsible for the violence of the students' strike here, which has forced police and firemen to use tear gas bombs and fire hose on the strikers.

Miss Hattle Thattle, 60-year-old nurse, was beaten and criminally attacked early this morning by a Negro in the bungalow of Mrs. Harriett Hawkins on Montauk Highway, adjoining the Moriches postoffice.

Mother's Day was recognized by many pastors of the city yesterday in sermons appraising its significance and calling upon worshipers of the various denominations to observe its principles in daily practice.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and womrath's:

Miss Mar Sherman Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Ledyard Mitchell of this city, has chosen June 11 for her marriage to Paul Harvey Deming Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. P. H. Deming of Detroit. The ceremony will take place here in St. Catherine's Chapel of the Church of Saints Peter and Paul.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Grant Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Hyland Jones of South Orange, to Alden J. St ahr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin M. Stahr, also of South Orange, will take place the evening of May 28 in the Episcopal Church of St. Andrew, South Orange.
William J. Stratton, former Secretary of State of Illinois and long a leader in Republican politics, died today at his home in Ingleside. He was 52 years old.
The Treasury's depository for silver bullion at West Point will be ready to receive silver for storage about June 1, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

The Catalan government today received a story of the shooting in Burgos, Insurgent capital, of Manuel Carrasco Formiguera, the head of the.Catalan Catholic party, who had been sent as a Catalan emissary to the Basque country a little more than a year ago.

Miss Adele Wise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Shreve Wise of this city, will be married to Howard Garthwaite Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs., Karl Garthwaite Smith of South Orange, N. J., the evening of June 11 at Muhlenberg College Chapel, Allentown.
It is admitted generally here that this week's official devaluation of the franc will give a spur to France's export trade, which is hampered by the current rise in prices.

The Rumanian American National Committee, meeting at National House today as part of a program commemorating Rumania's independence, adopted a resolution protesting the presence in Cleveland of Charles A. Davila, former Rumanian Minister to the United States, who- heads an opposition party.

Secretary Ickes, who is holding up the -sale of helium to Germany, has' been omitted from the list of guests invited to attend-a dinner at the German Embassy tomorrow night honoring Dr. Hugo Eckener, German dirigible expert.

Fermanagh won the 1937 Gaelic football championship at Innisfail Park yesterday by defeating the Kerry fifteen by the narrow margin of one goal and a point (4 points) to 3 points in a keen battle before a crowd. of more than 3,000.
The unemployed of Hollywood want to work, at their own trades, under WPA sponsorship.. But WPA salaries do not appeal to at least one large group of workers.

Professor Samuel Eliot Morison of Harvard University has won Columbia University's $1,000 Loubat Prize for his Tercentennial History of Harvard,it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia.

A new Stravinsky concerto named "Dumbarton Oaks Concerto in E Flat Major" was played here for the first time today at a musical given at Dumbarton Oaks, a famous Washington estate, for which the composition was named.

On the ground that a grand jury investigation into Democratic primary campaign charges of bribery, graft and corruption would be chiefly a "fishing expedition" threatening interference with the orderly processes of government, the Earle administration will appeal to the State Supreme Court here tomorrow to block the inquiry, ordered in the Dauphin County Court.

A proposal that a course in military training be started in this city's public schools, recently advocated at a meeting of Argonne Post, American.Legion, will be presented to the Board of Education and Superintendent of Schools Ira T. Chapman this week, officers of the post announced today.
A jury of twelve men, nine doctors and three rabbis, was selected today to settle the "death or blindness" question confronting the family of baby Helaine Colan.

Mrs. Carlo Savini, president of the Ladies' Auxiliary, and Mrs. John Pittari, president of the Junior Auxiliary of Columbus Hospital, are among those active in the plans for the Primavera entertainment in aid of the hospital to be held Saturday night at the Biltmore.

With attendance only 9 per cent behind last year's record figures, the Spring National Home Furnishings Show closed its week's run yesterday at the American Furniture Mart. The official count of registration for the week was 2,452.
Reduction by 13 1/4 per cent on April 16 of reserve requirements of member banks resulted during the next two weeks in a rise of $850,000,000 in surplus reserves. The past week's $140.

Official reports indicate that the State Treasury has made claims against Fritz Mandl, former proprietor of the Hirtenberg ammunition factory, for tax arrears of about $70,000, for the satisfaction of which it has seized mortgages that he gave to several firms.
Three Polish heroes who fought on American soil, two to 'help to crate a union and one to. preserve it, were honored yesterday as, 15,000

Miss Mary Washington Hotchkiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Stuart Hotchkiss of East River, will be married here on May 28 in Center Church to Sydney Messer Williams Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams of Wellesley, Mass., and Peterborough, N. H.

Marian Anderson, contralto, gave what was announced as her season's final recital last night at Carnegie Hall before a capacity audience. It was her second appearance there and her fifth in the city this season.

The New England Council reported today that its business index showed a "light but consistent increase in New England's general business activity" for each of the three months in the first quarter of 1988.
Zalmon G. Simmons Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., gained his most important victory in twenty-five years of shooting yesterday at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club.

So far as mortality was concerned, the State's health record for the first quarter of this year was the best in its history, Dr. J. V. Deporte, director of the division of vital statistics in the-State Department of Health, reported today.
The proximity of two large aircraft factories at Farmingdale, L. I., is the reason that community has been selected to be "blacked out" on May 16 during the General Headquarters Air Force manoeuvres.
John Nellis Klock, industrialist, civic leader and publisher, of Benton Harbor, died last night at Presbyterian Hospital in Chicago at the age of 72.
Mrs. Alfred J. Frantz of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janet Birbeck Frantz, to P. W. Murray Threipland of Newhouse, Llanishen, Wales.

Mr. and Mrs. John H. Ehlers of Middletown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Barnhart Ehlers, to Carlton Thompson Merriman, son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Merriman of Bristol.

The Presbytery of New York began a four-day celebration of its 200th anniversary with a united service of worship last evening at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.
La Meri, the American dancer, who first visited Lima ten years ago, gave a recital in the main theatre here last evening and received an ovation. ived an ovation.

The failure to conquer what he termed "this new frontier of idle overhead" has cost the people of the United States at least $200,000,000,000 in lost income since 1929, according to Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator.

While the officially directed German press treated Chancellor Hitler's sojourn in Italy as a sentimental and military demonstration, financial circles here saw the import in its possible bearing on the Czechoslovak issue.

A mortgage loan of $105,000 at 4 1/2 per cent has been placed by Ivor B. Clark, Inc., with the Metropolitan life Insurance Co. on the taxpayer at the northwest corner of 37th Ave. and 81st St., Jackson Heights, L. I. The building was erected by the Polk-81st St. Corp., Ben Gottfried, president.
The first ball Lou Fette served to Al Todd, first man up in the Pirate half of the twelfth Inning, went soaring over the left field wall today and gave Pittsburgh a 2-to-1 triumph over the Bees.

Because the Securities and Exchange Commission has refused to treat as confidential data filed in connection with registration of capital stock now listed on the New York Curb Exchange, the Jonas Naumburg Corporation has announced that this morning it will withdraw the stock from registration.

Major letters were presented to seven members of the New York University basketball team that captured the metropolitan intercollegiate championship and to six indoor track men, it was announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics.

Frederic Behm Taintor of 60 East Ninety-sixth Street, former managing editor of The New York Globe, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital of pneumonia after a six-day illness. He would have been 66 years old on June 18.

Replying to attacks on the National Labor Relations Act, particularly that of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States last week, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the NLRB, defended the act yesterday and-plead ed for "terms of mutual respect" between industry and labor.

The League of Nations Council's 101st session opened this evening with a threehour secret discussion, mainly over whether to admit the Ethiopian delegation when the Council debates the question of freeing League members from their obligation not to recognize the Italian conquest.
Max Lerner, editor of The Nation, was appointed to the Williams College faculty as a Professor of Political Science by the trustees, meeting at the week-end.
The bombing of Suhsien, a small city fifty miles south of this city, last Thursday by Japanese fliers was described here by Dr. Robert McClure of Toronto, Canada,
For the first time in seven weeks, since the expropriation of foreign oil holdings, the Mexican Government today permitted a strike against a major foreign-owned company.

The four-story apartment house at 462 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by the Williamsburg Savings Bank to Manny Solinger and Bertha Seltzer. Sale was for cash. Jeannette S. Dolgin, attorney, represented the purchasers. Kalmon polgin, Inc., was the broker in the deal.
Premier Edouard Daladier's "production" decrees, designed to get France back to work, will be submitted to the inner Cabinet tomorrow.

The Board of Estimate, in a move' to stir the City Council to action, voted yesterday to receive a resoluti6n authorizing the New York City Housing Authority to present 'for approval a bond issue or bond issues to carry out provisions of the State Housing Law for non-Federal housing projects, projects on which the ity is to pay interest and amortization.

The Journal Square Merchants Association of Jersey City; whose business has been brought to a complete stop on two successive Saturday nights by demonstrations for and against Mayor Frank Hague, announced last night that it was sending a delegation to City Hall today to ask that all demonstrators be barred hereafter from Journal Square.

A legendary figure of civil war days, the last survivor of the notorious Antonoff band of insurgents against Red rule in Tamboff Province, has been patiently tracked down by the Soviet Secret Service after sixteen years and executed, according to a disnatch from Tamboff today.

A movement to cut down the number of furniture trade markets held annually by the industry has received endorsement from the National Retail Furniture Association, according to a bulletin sent out by that group yesterday.

More than 1,200 persons attended the second day's sessions of the annual Interdenominational Bible Conference yesterday at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fiftyseventh Street. The conference is being held under the auspices of the Moody Bible Institute of Chicago.
Walter F. Alexander, a shipyard superintendent who was in charge of the reconditioning of the Leviathan after the World War, died here on Saturday at the age of 68.

The 1938-1939 advertising campaign for the Bureau of Milk Publicity, State of New York, was launched yesterday on a scale equal to that of last year and will continue until March of next year, according to Charles S. O'Donnell, account executive of J. M. Mathes, Inc., which is directing the drive for the fourth year.
Another advance in astronomy was recorded today when the Yerkes Observatory announced discovery of what may be the star nearest to the earth.

Trading was generally only fair. Steer hinds and ribs were strong to higher. Old crop lamb and some plainer grades of springers were lower, while good and choice springers were steady. Fresh work prices were steady to lower, veal unchanged.
THE CANADIANS: THE STORY OF A PEOPLE, by George M. Wrong, (Macmillan, $3.50.) A popular history of Canada. CLEFT MOORING, by Lillian Saminsky, (Margent Press, $2.) A first novel.
Alarming reports about the Pope's health, circulating abroad since his arrival at Castel Gandolfo were most emphatically denied here today.

Ottilie Heuer, decorator and home furnishing stylist, has formed Ottilie Heuer, Inc., with offices at 9 Rockefeller Center. Miss Heuer plans to open home furnishing display rooms, showing the products of various manufacturers, at 748 Fifth Avenue in the Fall.

In move to stimulate exports by compiling information relating to this phase of its foreign trade, the National Foreign Trade Commission of Mexico has issued a call to Mexican exporters to register their names and other information, according to a report from Mexico City made public today by the Denartment of Commerce.
Frank Weitenkampf, director of the print department at the Public Library, opened yesterday one of his major. print shows of the year. This Is the title: "Artists of Aloofness--?"

The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to the list Lehigh Valley Coal Company secured 6 per cent notes, Class A, extended from Jan. 1, 1938, to Jan. 1, 1943, and Minneapolis-Moline Power Implement Company common stock $1 par-value.

With five tons of fuel and food for three days aboard, Japan's giant monoplane took to the air at Kisarazu Airport in Toyko Bay at 5:09 A. M. today, intending to remain up seventy-two hours and cover about 12,000 kilometers (about 7,450 miles) to break the world distance record of 10,601 kilometers for a closed circuit. made in France in 1932.

Gratification over completion of lout preparations for the "most realistic ram and strenuous air exercises" ever the held by the General Headquarters Air Force, scheduled to start on Wednesday, was expressed today by Major Gen. Frank M. Andrews, ten chief officer attached to the Army Air Force.
The New York Chapter of the Society of Residential Appraisers will meet at the Hotel Lexingt6n Thursday at 6:30 P. M.
The Ford Motor Company blocked today efforts of the National Labor Relations Board to withdraw from court the record of its case against the company.

Increasing popularity of air conditioning is bringing with it new fire hazards and an increased need for fire prevention, E. W. Fowler of New York, an engineer for the National Board of Fire Underwriters, warned here today at the fortysecond annual convention of the National 2ire Protection Association.
Senate acceptance of whatever Wages and Hours Bill the House may pass will be urged by the Administration in an effort to obtain a speedy adjournment of Congress.

Apparently with the object of ascertaining the effect of its new short-selling regulations during the recent decline in prices on the New York Stock Exchange, the Securities and Exchange Commission has requested the Exchange to obtain from member firms all record and data covering dealings in twenty active stocks between March 21 to April 2, inclusive.

The majority of dry goods wholesalers, it was reported yesterday, have decided to postpone the remainder of their Fall buying until next month. The decision has resulted, it was understood, less because of fears as to prices than because of the unwillingness of jobbers to add to their commitments in a period when their own sales are running well behind those of a year ago.

Voluntary curtailment of production as a means of reviving profitable operations in the coat and suit industry was urged last night by Samuel L. Deitsch, president of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers. Inc.,

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United states for the week ended May 5 was 231 compared with 278 in the preceding week and 177 in the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Employers in the fur industry appealed yesterday to Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissioner Valentine and District Attorney Dewey to intervene to end "the reign of terror" that has marked the general strike of 15,000 workers being conducted by the Fur Workers Union, a Communist-led affiliate of the C. I. 0.

Declaring that the ."essential human content of democracy, and Christianity are the same,"' Thomas Mann, German author and Nobel Prize winner in literature, who last week made known his intention of becoming an American citizen, urged before 1,000 dinner guests at the Hotel Astor last night the necessity of giving new life to their ideals.
Funds aggregating $23,550,000 were ear-marked today for slum clearance and low-rent housing projects in four cities by Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority.
Lehman Brothers headed the successful banking group which won yesterday the award of a new issue of $2,100,000 of sewer, improvement and paving bonds of the city of Cleveland, Ohio.
Increasing support for H. E. Morriss's Pasch today shortened the odds against the colt's winning the Epsom Derby June 1 from 9 to 4 to 2 to 1.

Playing their first matches in the English county cricket championship, Middlesex and Nottinghamshire recorded convincing victories today. Middlesex defeated Warwickshire by nine wickets and Nottinghamshire had an eight wicket margin over Northamptonshire.
Mrs. Stephen H. Philbin will open her home and garden at 174 East Seventieth Street this afternoon for a tea to aid the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York. Inc., 283 Lexington Avenue.

Currency of $50 and larger denominations has been circulating in gradually increasing amounts in recent years. From March, 1937, to March, 1938, for example, such notes in circulation increased $53,000,000 - from $1,520,000,000 to $1,573,000,000.

The City Affairs Committee, through Dr. John Haynes Holmes, its chairman, wrote yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Lewis, chairman of, the Bill of Rights Committee of the Constitutional Convention, opposing the proposal to remove the constitutional provision prohibiting lotteries.

After hearing sharp argument, during which the National Labor Relations Board was accused of planning to "doctor" the record in the Republic Steel Corporation case, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals delayed a ruling today on whether the board should be permitted to withdraw its order against the corporation.

Fabrics for Summer wear were of foremost interest to the converting trade in the rayon greige goods, market last week, Nickel, Barrett, Lieberman Quinn, textile brokers, declared yesterday in its weekly review. Sheer textiles,
The first session of the Cortlandt F. Bishop collection of' postage stamps realized $14,223 yesterday at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries.

Transit Commissioner M. Maldwin Fertig will submit to the State Constitutional Convention today a proposed amendment, with which Mayor La Guardia is in "substantial agreement," to exempt from the city's debt limit sufficient city corporate stock or serial bonds to cover the purchase of the rapid transit properties of the B. M. T. and Interborough systems as part of a unification program.

Industrial operations in Canada in the first part of April were irregular, but toward the end of the month a change for the better was apparent, according to A. E. Arscott, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce.

The 1937 annual report of the American Power and Light Company, which is being forwarded to shareholders today, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses and charges, of $11,448,078, compared with a net of $10,398,806 in 1936, an increase of $1,049,272.
Charles H. Murphy, a former partner ,in the New York dry goods commission house of Ridley, Watts Co., died today at his residence, 20 Highland Avenue, of heart diseae, after, an illness of ten days.

Japan will make no peace with the regime of Chiang Kai-shek, Foreign Minister Koki Hirota again stated today. Instead, the policy of the Japanese Government in pursuing the war in China will be to extend its military operations until the "friendly" regimes in Peiping, Nanking and Shanghai can be consolidated into a new central Government of China. This Japan will recognize.

New salvage operations on the Lutine, which has been lying in the sands at the entrance to Zuyder Zee ever since 1799, probably will. take place, it was indicated today when Lloyds announced they had granted a salvage license to the Billion Point Mining Company of the Hague.

The Bureau or Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 6: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Beard, J. D., the Chester, to Long Beach, Calif., Board of Inspection and Survey, Pacific Coast section.

Borough President Ingersoll officially greeted James G. McDonald, who took office yesterday as president of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, at a reception yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Henry L. deForest, president of the Hackensack Water Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday that the company was completing a ten-year modernization program, involving replacements and additions to property and changes in operating methods and organization.
Adolf Hitler on his way home spent some time in Florence inspecting its treasures of art. Premier Mussolini was- there to

Fresh from his vacation cruise, President Roosevelt returned to the White House early today to enter immediately into a series of conferences with administrative and legislative leaders on foreign affairs, fiscal policies and means of expediting the $2,500,000,000 deficiency bill for recovery and relief.

Three mortgages held by the Metropolitan Savings Bank from Report Realty Corp, Charles R. Faruolo Jr. secretary, have been consolidated as a single first lien for $55,000 on 333-337 E 13th St. 85 ft front, and extended to March 1, 1943, at 3 per cent for the first two years, 3I for the last three years.
President Justice and Mrs. Pelham St. George Bissell have left their home at 270 Park Avenue and will pass the Summer at Wayside, their country place in Merrick Road, Freeport, L. I.

With martial chants and a display of bold banners of defiance, more than 12,000 Chinese marched here yesterday in a Solidarity Day parade as a protest against Japanese aggression, while in the overcast skies an aerial guard of honor was formed by seven Chinese aviators who are training to become war pilots against Japan.

The United States must either adopt a successful "stop and go" system of economic control, such as England typifies, or face the possibility that some type of totalitarian system will be imposed on it, Dr. Joseph E. Goodbar, president of the Society for Stability in Money and Banking, Inc., said here yesterday.

Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, addressing the opening session of the union's twelfth biennial convention today, asserted that wage rates were being maintained in most of the unionized industries largely because 7,000,000 workers were now formed into trade unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization as compared with approximately three million less than three years ago.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator, made public yesterday a list of appointments in connection with the reorganization of the WPA division of operations, which is expected to yield a saving of $30,000 a month. The changes will become effective at various times this month.

Three amphibian airplanes alighted on the East River shortly after 9 A.M. yesterday for the Summer opening of the city's skyport at the foot of Wall Street. Robert Clarkson, broker, was the first to arrive, coming from his home at Oyster Bay, L. I., and nosing his plane up to the dock at 9:15 A. M.

A few hours after he had been returned on the Queen Mary as a stowaway, 13-year-old Robert Stap of 145-10 221st Street, Springfield, Queens, disappeared again, and late yesterday afternoon his mother, Yvonne, was at a loss to know how to keep his yearning to be a sailor within bounds.

The large garden-type apartment house, containing ninetyfive suites, at 115 East Mosholu Parkway North, southwest corner of Steuben Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold to the Burtwane Realty Corporation.

Bunching hits in five innings, the Reds gained a 9-to-4 victory over the Phillies today to even the series. Lacking the punch to convertfourteen men were left stranded on bases-the Reds took advantage of three Philly errors, and aided by Ray Davis's seven-hit performance were able to tally in every inning except the first. sixth and eighth.

One of the classiest fields ever to participate in the tourney is scheduled to set out in pursuit of the Metropolitan open golf championship over the exacting course of the Fresh Meadow Country Club, Flushing, on Thursday.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers, told members of the twenty-four-man executive board at its quarterly meeting today that Richard T. Frankensteen would be removed as assistant president of 'the organization and the office would be abolished.

In record balloting for an unopposed ticket, members of the New York Stock Exchange cast yesterday 924 votes for the new board of governors and chairman of the board which will assume office on next Monday. The polls opened at 10 A. M. and closed at 3 P. M.

President Roosevelt returned from his fishing cruise, discussed pending legislation and plans for- expediting its passage with legislative and administrative leaders, conferred with Secretary Hull on neutrality policies and with Secretary Morgenthau on fiscal policies, and sent to the Senate the nomination of Joseph E. Davies to be Ambassador to Belgium.

Upon petition of the Earle Administration, the State Supreme Court late today called upon the court and District Attorney of Dauphin County to show cause why they should not be permanently enjoined from conducting a projected grand jury investigation into bribery, graft and coercion charges against Democratic party officials.

Fed steers and yearlings closed active at higher prices but the advance was in a measure offset by improved slaughter conditions, the United States Department of Agriculture reports. Other killing classes were also firm to higher. Hogs sold actively at near steady prices, but lambs were weak to lower and sharply off on an increased supply of aged sheep.

IT was either the falling of the raindrops or the standing of the clubs that had Manager Jimmy Dykes of the Chicago White Sox muttering about murder and insanity. Ordinarily, James is a chipper chap. But, as he explained it, things have been happening.

With last-minute penciled insertions virtually giving the President control over all expenditures and projects the Recovery and Relief Bill, carrying $2,515,425,000 in direct appropriations, was introduced in the House today by' Chairman Taylor of the Appropriations Committee.

Members of society from the Long Island Summer colonies, New York, New Jersey, Westchester ind Philadelphia, many of whom Slew from Louisville after the festifes following the Kentucky Derby, yesterday braved the penerating wind and rain that have beome almost traditional at the opening of Belmont Park.

Isidor Bernstein, who for move than forty years had a jewelry store at 143 Sands Street, near the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, died yesterday in his apartment at the Hotel St. George-after a short illness. He would have been 73 years old on July 4.

The to Wagner-SteagaII amendment to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation Act liberalizing the lending policy of the RFC to railroads as part of the President's recovery plan would tend to injure rather than aid railroads in difficulties, according to witnesses who apBanking and Currency Committee.

Westchester County began today the installation of a new type of highway marker designed to give a luminous outline at night to roads for several thousand feet in front of vehicles using full headlights.

It has been pointed out many times that the interests of labor leaders are not necessarily identical with those of labor. But it is pointed out chiefly in connection with labor racketeering and other abnormal developments.
Using little -more than five minutes, the Senate approved today the conference report on the $5,330,000,000 Tax.Revision Bill. A voice vote was taken and no negatives were audible.

Italo Colonello, Italian heavyweight, made short work of Tony Lamaretto, Stockton, Calif., ln the main bout scheduled for eight rounds at St. Nicholas Palace last night before a crowd of 2,000, knocking out his opponent in 2:10 of the first round. 'Colonello weighed 200% and the loser 185.

The membership of the New York Stock Exchange took yesterday the first actual step to ward the reorganization of the institution under the new constitution-an outgrowth of the Conway report-when the unopposed slate for governors and chairman of the board received a complimentary vote of 924, an unprecedented total for a rubber stamp election.

Free marketing and the continuance of the futures trading system of the Winnipeg Grain Exchange were recommended by Justice W. F. A. Turgeon in his report on grain and grain marketing, presented today in the House of Commons by W. D. Euler, Trade Minister.
In an atmosphere of tension centering on the 'belg, Parliament will meet tomorrow to discuss-measures to meet the unbalanced budget and proposals for increased taxation.
The stock market here, bolstered by the improved prices in Wall Street at the week-end, was generally firm today and most sections advanced.

Flashing a powerful attack toward the close, the Hartwick College nine overwhelmed Drew University of Madison, N. J., 10-2, today. The winners accounted for thirteen hits and registered nine of their runs in the last three innings.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler today issued orders that all troops, on the march or at rest, are to give him personally as Fuehrer and commanderin chief of the armed forces the so-called "Deutsche gruss," or Hitler salute, instead of the usual military greeting.
Retired Fireman James Mayne, formerly a member of Engine Co. 34, residing at 69 Ibis St., Forest Hills, Queens, died on May 6.
Maxwell. Howard's colt The Chief cannot run in the Preakness Stakes at Baltimore Saturday because of the same ailment that kept his stablemate, Stagehand, out of last Saturday's Kentucky Derby..

Miss Alma Clayburgh, daughter of Mrs. Alma Clayburgh of the Berkshires and of Albert Clayburgh, also of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to James Hooper Grew, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sturgis Grew of Boston, which will take place here on June 14 in St. Bartholomew's Church.

Thomas A. Dempsey, for the last two years general clerk of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn and for the last fifteen: years Democratic leader of the, Eleventh Assembly District, Brooklyn, died last night at his home, 178 Sullivan Street, Brooklyn, after a year's -illness of a complication of heart and kidney ailments.
John J. Wilson, 68 years old, who operated a drug store at 671 North Avenue, New Rochelle, was found dead this afternoon in his apartment on the Boston Post Road here.

The marriage of Miss. Elsie Burke Foster,. daughter of Herbert Hastings Foster of this place and the late Mrs. Grace Burke Foster, to Stuart Warren Don of Saratoga, N. Y., and Louisville, Ky., took place this afternoon in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church here.

As noted here yesterday, "Julius Caesar" moves from the Mercury to the National next Friday night to open a regular run. And now it appears that at least one factor behind this departure from the repertory scheme is the- added cost of paying actors who appear in only one show.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick has been reading the new city charter and doing a little figuring. His reading of the charter reminded him that it was his duty to place before the Board of Estimate "such recommendations, comments and criticisms in regard to the operations, fiscal policies and financial transactions of the city as he may deem advisable in the public interest."

The New York Public Library, which received by bequest the military note and sketch books of the late Brig. Gen. DeWitt Clinton Falls once commanding officer of the 107th Infantry Regiment, an-. nounced yesterday that part of the general's collection would be placed on public view for the first time on Saturday.

Charles Elmer Bushnell, prominently identified with the oil industry thirty years ago, was found dead yesterday on a New York Central Railroad train en route from Saranac Lake to New York City. He was 80 years old.

A new indication of the Greek regime's friendly relations with Germany was given today, when the German. Legation on Chancellor Adolf Hitler's order, conferred upon Dictator John Metaxas the order of the German Eagle.

Mrs. Evelyn Fahnestock Steele of Rumson, N. J., and William G. Wendell of the Harvard Club obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building. They will be married on Saturday at the Ritz-Carlton.
Paul Cavanagh of the Crescent A. C. and Tony Penna of Dayton combined today to win the opening oneday amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at Timber Point. With Penna,

Columbia University received last month twenty gifts aggregating $147,286, including a fund of $132,000 from an anonymouss donor to support legislative research in the Columbia Law School, it was announced yesterday at the university.

In a record-breaking exhibition of smooth shot-making, Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky.s led a flashy field today to win medal honors in the qualifying round of the twenty-seventh annual women's Southern golf championship.

The Philharmonic--Symphony Society of New York has raised by private subscription a maintenance fund "which, under careful management, will suffice to pay the deficits for the coming two seasons and possibly for part of a third," it was revealed yesterday by the report of Marshall Field, president, at the annual meeting of the society at Steiriway' all.

Mail orders for apparel and other merchandise coming into the local market yesterday were very encouraging, exceeding in volume and variety those of the previous Monday, manufacturers and resident offices reported.

While Japanese leaders here show serenity and apparent unconcern over the seeming stalemate of hostilities in South Shantung and the lack of decided progress on the Shansi and Central China fronts, foreign military observers in Shanghai believe this attitude masks grave concern, bordering on alarm, in the Japanese high command.

Charles Sorenen, general manager of the Ford Motor Company, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen from his annual tour of the company's offices abroad and declared there is "no depression in Europe."

Field Marshal Hermann Goering has ordered another burst of pageantry when Chancellor Adolf Hitler returns tomorrow night. This time he will arrive at the Lehrte station and proceed across Kings Square and the Tiergarten to the Chancellery.

From entirely reliable sources this correspondent learns that the general assumption that the Austrian frontier is now open to Austrians-Jews and non-Jews--wishing to leave the country, is not correct.
After losing extra-inning decisions on two successive afternoons, the Bees, with a revamped line-up came back today to score two runs in the tenth and whip the Pirates, 7 to 5.
Oscar F. Douglas Jr., dean of buyers -of the F. W. Woolworth Company, died on Sunday in his apartment in the Hotel WaldorfAstoria after a three-weeks' illness at the age of 58.

League of Mothers Clubs of the United Neighborhood Houses, meeting of Settlement House Mothers, Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street, 10:30 A. M. Speakers: Commissioner Paul Moss, Linie Ehrich, Pauline Catlin, Mrs. Elizabeth Simpson, Mrs. Jane Shapiro, Mrs. Robert T. Williams, Mrs. Lewis P. Addoms, Mrs. William T. Kennedy, Grace Niles, Eddie Dowden, Morris Traub, A. Pearlman, Betty Shannon.

Funeral services for Frank D. Waterman, fountain-pen manufacturer, were held yesterday afternoon in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street. The Rev. James A. Paul, assistant rector, officiated,

Spendthrift nationalism, however planned, is hard hit as a remedy for depression by the annual report of the Bank for International Settlements, which its president, J. W Beyen, submitted to its General Assembly today. It is much harder on nationalism than on government planning and spending.

Miss Evelyn Menk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Menk of this place, formerly of St. Louis, has completed plans for her marriage to John Young Jr. of Bloomfield, son of John Young of Bloomfield and Lake Mohawk.

In view of local protests by the American -Legion -and by the Knights of Columbus against Nazi parades, the Town Board of Babylon, L. I., will hold a hearing tomorrow on a proposed ordinance to bar parades anywhere in the township in which flags of-other nations are carried.

From Freeport to Montauk they had a real fishing week-end, according to more than a score of reports. Weakfish, pollack and mackerel came in by the thousands, and although the weaks and mackerel ran somewhat small, there was an. occasional big one to keep up the interest.

Several deals in Croton-on-Hudson and vicinity, Westchester County, were reported yesterday by Arnold Krimont, broker, of that-town. Among them was the sale of fortythree acres with a ten-room house on Mount Airy Road, just beyond the village limits.
The Bureau of Mines reported today that crude petroleum runs to stills declined 56,000 barrels in March to 3,093,000 barrels. The total March run, however, was 48,000 barrels more than a year ago.

Samuel Goldwyn today announced plans for the production of "The Exiles," dealing with European oppression. Jascha Helfetz will appear in one of the leading roles, canceling his scheduled "The Great Musical Festival."

The average factory wage in Brazil is approximately $11.05 per month, according to a census covering 21,556 establishments employing 540,013 laborers, said a report to the Department of Commerce from Rio de Janeiro, made public today.
One hundred and eleven ships aggregating 396,430 gross tons are under construction in American shipyards, according to the monthly report of the American Bureau of Shipping, published yesterday.

Melvin Schwartzman of Poly Prep, the defending champion, defeated Eugene Schwartz of Horace. Mann in love sets yesterday as the twentythird annual tournament of the Athletic Association of Private Schools started on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

Three weeks later than usual, Fall buying conventions on men's clothing were launched yesterday by three important resident groups here, with definite indications of conservative purchasing for some months' to come.
With the Walker Cup team scheduled - to leave for England tonight and the metropolitan open championship only a few days away, New York yesterday became the golf center of the.country.

Fair governmental regulation is not opposed by the electric utilities, C. W. Kellogg of New York, president of the Edison Electric Institute, told the insurance division of the American Management Association, tonight in Chalfonte-Haddon Hall here.

Stocks strengthened in final hour and closed active and higher; turnover, 1,018,150 shares. Traction bonds strong, United States Government and secondgrade rail groups higher, other issues mixed; transactions, $7,109,500.

The Senate approved today the 1939 Agricultural Department Appropriation Bill appropriating $758,572,820 of new money, and also giving authority to spend $187,105,000 of unexpended funds appropriated last year.

Directors of the Commonwealth Edison Company authorized today the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed issue of $33,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds and a proposed issue of convertible debentures of not less than $39,083,195, nor more than $42,303,845.

The Yankees and White Sox made an effort to go through with yesterday's scheduled ball game at the Stadium, but the affair was postponed. Both clubs remained in the dugouts until 3:15 P. M., when the umpires took charge.
Old Goldy, a mountain eagle, is playing stepmother to two goslings today, and Thomas Chadderton, keeper at the Edmonton Zoo, where Goldy makes her home, is delighted.
Lord Beaverbrook's Daily Express, ,which recently called for abolition of the Royal Enclosure at Ascot, today came out with an editorial plea for democratization of the royal courts.

Apparently suffering from the delusion that his dancing teacher had been murdered, Charles Costa, 23 years old, of 343 Chauncey Street, Brooklyn, attempted suicide yesterday by leaping from the balcony under the dome at City Hall three stories to the marble floor.

Fred (Red) Cochrane, 139, of Elizabeth, was held to an eight-round draw by Eddie Alzek, 140, of NewYork, in a feature boxing bout tonight. The draw -snapped a winning streak of six straight held by Cochrane.

Miss Tacie Nairn Sergeant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Sergeant of this place, has chosen June 4 for her wedding to Briscoe Baldwin Ranson 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Briscoe Baldwin Ranson of Maplewood.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert, imposing a two-year prison sentence yesterday upon John M. Kelley, former general counsel of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, who was recently convicted of income tax fraud in the preparation of returns for the circus, said that other attorneys convicted of the same crime would receive more severe sentences if they appeared before him.

More than 600 volumes of nine-. teenth-century fiction have been purchased by the Princeton University. Library from what was once the Imperial Library at TsarskoeSelo, Russia, it was announced here today by Lawrence Heyl, acting librarian and head of the acquisitions department. The collection,

The governments of Siam and Switzerland went ahead with plans to participate in the New York World's Fair 1939 yesterday when representatives of Siam signed final contracts for exhibit space in the Hall of Nations and representatives of Switzerland inspected the site for the Swiss exhibit.

On his own application: To take effect 12 midnight, May 7: PATROLMAN-Walter G. Haslan, 120th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 21, 1907. Temporary Assignments SERGEANT-Samuel V. Terranova, from 79th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, N. Y. County, for 1 day, from 4 P. M., May 5.

Wladyslaw Talun, 300, Poland, threw Tom Hanley, 260, Enid, Okla., in 2:09 of the feature match listed for a finish before 2,500 persons at the Hippodrome last night. The winner used a crotch hold and body slam to pin his rival.
The Dartmouth baseball team battled William and Mary on even terms for nine innings today, but fell apart in the tenth, allowing the southerners to score ten runs and win, 12-3.

The captain and crew of the coastal schooner Jane Victoria arrived today aboard the steamship Nerissa from Guadeloupe and told how their; vessel was rammed and sunk last Friday by the French steamship Cantal.
Mrs. Nelle M. Joyce of Miami and Greenwich surrendered today on two bench warrants charging her with conspiracy to defraud the State in Merritt Parkway land sales.

Louise Muldener, an actress who supported many of the great stars of tragedy in her sixty years' asociation with the American theatre, was reported seriously ill at the Lenox Hill Hospital last night.
Continued weakness in commodity prices took the wholesale price index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association last week to a new low point in the recession which began last Summer.

The segregation of the Terminal Tower Building in a separate company is proposed in a modified plan of reorganization of the Cleveland Terminals Building Company, a subsidiary of the Van Sweringen Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Frank R. Bailey, chairman of the bondholders' committee of the Terminal Tower Building.
Joe Stripp, third baseman obtained from the Dodgers last Winter, has agreed to terms with the Cardinals and has been ordered to report immediately, the St. Louis club announced today.

Sidetracking an Assembly-passed bill creating a State board to fix prices for retail sale of' gasoline, the Senate adopted tonight and sent -to the lower house a measure forbidding retailers from selling motor fuels below wholesale cost plus marketing expense.

The Senate gave tentative approval today to a proposal to permit building in foreign shipyards of government subsidized merchant marine ships if their bids were 50 per cent below those of domestic yards.
Senator Harrison of Mississippi, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, offered today a bill requested by the Treasury Department making more flexible the government's borrowing facilities.

Trustees of the $10,250,000 Series Q guaranteed mortgage certificate issue of the closed New York Title and Mortgage Company reported yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler that they had been able to effect annual savings of $18,000 by substituting direct management of real estate owned or operated by the trust for the many agents who previously were in charge.

While most business hereabouts is very slack this Spring, the business of destroying scenic beauty along the Hudson is thriving. Up at Mount Taurus, 'fifty-two miles from Times Square, there is more activity than for years.

Word seldom comes out of the tight little island of Minorca, easternmost of the Balearics, which government forces have successfully held since the beginning of the civil war, notwithstanding its proximity to Majorca, particularly Pollensa Bay, where the Germans recently established a base.

Barring a sudden collapse of both their games, the United States amateur champion, Johnny Goodman, and Ray Billows, whom he defeated in the 1937 American final, will clash in the second round of the British amateur golf championship, which opens May 23 at Troon.

Patrolman Louis A. Drago of 2,303 Belmont Avenue, the Bronx, a member of the Police Department for fourteen years, five of which were spent as a detective, died yesterday in Fordham Hospital at the age of 41. He had undergone an operation for a stomach disorder.

The members of the Greater New York City Lifeguards Association, about 200 strong, refused yesterday to take a civil service examination on the ground that they had already qualified for civil service posts. They won their point.
In a stubbornly contested game the Yale freshmen today defeated Suffield Academy,- 5-2, Dick Ames holding the visitors to seven hits, well distributed. Warren Mozley pitched well for Suffield.

The Junior and Senior Guilds of Colony House, Inc., will hold their annual election today at the settlement, 297 Dean Street, Brooklyn. Mrs. James M. Roche will preside at the Senior Guild's meeting in the morning.

Austrian goods exported to foreign countries are now subject to the existing German exchange regulations governing trade with other countries, according to an official decree cabled from Berlin to the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, Inc., here.
A number of dwellings of both the apartment house and single-family types have recently changed hands in the Bronx, according to reports received yesterday from brokers.

Bel Espoir, carrying the silks of Mrs. Ethel K. Well of Chicago, staged a driving finish today to win, the Montgomery Purse. Bel Espoir finished a length and a quarter ahead of Cardarrone, with Lucky Ducky third.
Charles Heath Bannard of Haverford, a retired banker and lawyer, died in Bryn Mawr Hospital today after an illness of two weeks. His age was 83.

ADTLER- Solomon C, beloved husband of Eva, devoted father of Arthur, brother of Herman, Abner, Robert, Martin and Harold. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., on Wednesday, May 11, at 11:30 A. M.

Sidney Scodes, 10 years old, of 3,147 Broadway, a pupil in Public School 125, La Salle Street and Amsterdam Avenue, was drowned yesterday afternoon when he fell from an abandoned pier at the foot of 134th Street in the Hudson River.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 7: COLONELS Pickering, R. R., Adjutant General's Department, three months and twenty-three days leave, May 8.
Senator George L. Berry declared tonight that his quarrel with the Tennessee Valley Authority over marble leases was started by the TVA after it had "confiscated" his properties.

The first contract in sixteen years for the construction in an American shipyard of cargo. vessels for operation in foreign trade received today the signatures' of officials of the Maritime Commission and the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Kearny, N. J.
A spirited upswing in local traction isues featured otherwise routine trading yesterday in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange.

The first prison term - for evasion of the City Sales Tax was imposed yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, when Samuel Watterman, a shoe store proprietor, of 266 Riverdale Avenue, Brooklyn, received thirty days in the workhouse for failure to file a return for 1937. He owed the city a tax total of. $418.
France's tennis youngsters rallied briskly today to defeat The Netherlands, three matches to two, in their first-round Davis Cup series.
Gus Dugas clouted a homer over the centerfield fence today to break a tie in the ninth and give the Montreal Royals a 5-4 victory, their third straight in the series with the Jersey City Giants.
Representative Welch, Repubican, of California, presented to Congress today a revision on a once rejected proposal that the government subsidize fast intercoastal vessels.

Syracuse scored nine runs in the sixth inning to defeat Penn State's baseball team today, 12 to 10. Penn State tallied in six of the nine frames, profiting by nine Syracuse fielding errors and nine singles. However, Argento, who relieved Kane on the mound in the sixth, held the Lions to a pair of singles.

Acting through Meyer L. Lewis, special representative of President William Green, the American Federation of Labor intervened yesterday in the factional conflict in the International Ladies' Handbag, Pocketbook and Novelty Workers Union. An offer of peace was made,
Automobile production expanded last week, countering the usual seasonal drop, and the justed index advanced to 50.1 from 43.3. The figure was .31.3 or the week ended May 8, 1937.
Samuel Dudley Kelley, retired architect, died today at his home here at the age of 89. He was the last of the founders of the Quaker colony in South Yarmouth.

Preeminent, 6-year-old campaigner, wearing Hal Price Headley's navy blue colors, pulled ahead without effort in the stretch today to beat Sun Egret by four lengths in the $2,500 added Jennings Handicap. A crowd of 11,000 watched the racing under ideal conditions at Pimlico.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Referring to the many confusing proposals to take care of the growing frequency and severity of motor vehicle accidents, which cause so much misery to innocent sufferers because numerous operators are financially unable to meet their responsibilities, I would like to submit a solution which I think is practical and superior to the plans now being discussed.

The Public Utility Act of 1935 directed the SEC, "as soon as practicable after Jan. 1, 1938,"to perform a number of operations on holding companies in the power business by authority of Section 11, which contains the long-contested "death sentencee."

W. K. Rice and E. A. Mays of the Harvard Club entered the final round of the Mixsell Cup squash tennis doubles tournament at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn, yesterday by eliminating L. B. Dailey and T. H. Merrill, Princeton Club, 15-12, 15-11, 15-12.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 9, unless specified: At Southern Philippines, Peary, May 7, Bittern. At Navy Yard, Mare Island, Reuben James, May 8, Goff. Blue, at Norfolk. Brazos. at San Pedro.

Work on six important sections of the Delaware water supply project will start within twenty days, the Board of Water Supply announced last night when they made known that contracts totalling $57,563,306 had been let, in all but one instance to the low bidder.
With water, water everywhere the Bermuda Islands faced an increasingly difficult drought situation today with a shortage of water to drink.

A proposal that the New York Furniture Exchange open its doors for a limited time to the public during the market showing here July 18 to 29, was rejected yesterday at a meeting of the exchange directors.

At noon today at City Hall Mayor La Guardia will present to Albert Torborg, Brooklyn Borough Commodore of the United States Volunteer Life Saving Corps the Mayor's Medal for Conspicuous Service in Life Saving.

While interest in the franc died down in the foreign exchange market yesterday pressure against the Belgian belga increased and indications appeared that the banking world was looking for a change in the status of that currency very soon.

Nine of the eleven towboats operated by the Meseck Towing Company, which are used by many of the large steamship lines for docking their vessels, were tied up yesterday morning at their Jersey City pier by a strike called by the Associated Marine Workers, a branch of the Inland Boatmen's 'Union and an affiliate of the C. I. O.
The Piping Rock women's golf team maintained its lead in the Long Island interclub Class A team matches as play was resumed over the Lakeville Club course today.

Dr. Carl E. Becker, assistant pathologist at Lankenau Hospital for twenty-five years prior to his retirement in 1933, died in the hospital today of injuries received in an automobile accident near Doylestown on Saturday night. His age was 75.

The New York State Conference of Mayors and other municipal officials presented a fifteen-point program to delegates of the Constitutional Convention today, giving full support to Mayor La Guardia's home rule recommendations which were incorporated into a proposal submitted to the convention last week by Joseph Clark Baldwin, Manhattan Republican.

Mrs. Louise Fiske Shannon obtained a divorce today from Porter Clyde Shannon of New York City. They were married in New York on Jan. 14, 1931. Mrs. Shannon got the decree on charges of cruelty. An agreement on a property settlement was made.

Charles Campigiia, 33 years old, of 2,021 Davison Avenue, the Bronx, was sentenced here today by County Judge L. Barron Hill to serve thirty-five to seventy years in Sing Sing prison. His attorney announced the case would be appealed.

Dr. Bernard Lunenfeld, a dentist who had practiced in Queens for nearly: thirty -years, died yesterday at his home, 82-45 167th Street, Jamaica, of a heart ailment which had confined him to his home intermittently for a year. His age was 51.

The church must learn to think in terms of the urban culture now dominant in this country and in terms of a less expensive church establishment, the Presbytery of New York was told yesterday at the second of four meetings marking the 200th anniversary of the presbytery.

Following a long series of secre conferences an out-of-court settle ment of the marital difficulties o. Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, pitcher fo: the New York Yankees, and Junc O'Dea, his actress wife, was reached yesterday.
President Jorge Ubico has approved a law regulating employes, directors, managers and attorneys of banking establishments.
Herbert M. Woolf, owner of Lawrin, 1938 Kentucky Derby winner, laughed at reports today he had won $150,000 in the future books when his big horse came in first Saturday.

Formation of a national nonpartisan committee to work for the re-elecion of Senator Nye of North Dakota was announced here today. The committee will call attention to the "national significance of Senator Nye's record in the Senate," the announcement said.

President Roosevelt conferred with Secretary of State Cordell Hull on the neutrality policy of the United States soon after the President had returned to Washington today, but both the White Hous and the State Department were silent on the result of the conference.

Arthur Altritt, a second lieutenant of the 105th Field Artillery, N. Y. N. G., died suddenly last night of a heart attack at a dinner of the regimental officers in the armory, at 166th Street and Franklin Avenue. Bronx. The officers,
Senator Bone announced today a Senate committee would open hearings Thursday on the proposal to construct and operate a powerful Federal radio station to broadcast to Latin America.
American Federation of Labor officials said today that unemployment had increased to about the level it attained in 1935.
