Chancellor Hitler's week-long visit to Italy came to a close here last midnight when, after having exchanged cordial farewells with Premier Mussolini and Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano, he started back .over a strictly guarded railroad for Germany.

Officials of Knoxville and the Tennessee Valley Authority resumed today negotiations with the National Power and Light Company seeking joint city-TVA purchase of the utility's holdings in and near this city.

Sending across four runs in the opening frame, the New York Stock Exchange baseball team topped St. John's University's freshmen, 6-5, yesterday at Carey Field. Correll's triple which drove in three men featured the victor's first-inning attack.

Persons who complain to the police about boys playing baseball in the street are making "much ado about nothing," Magistrate Sabbatino observed in Flatbush court, Brooklyn, yesterday in dismissing a complaint of disorderly conduct against Alfred Melov, 19 years old, of 519 East Fifty-second Street, Brooklyn.

Supreme Court Justice Charles J. Dodd in Brooklyn reserved decision yesterday on an application by Clarence Hathaway, editor of The Daily Worker, Communist party daily newspaper published at 50 East Thirteenth Street,
Premier Benita Mussolini's newspaper, the Popolo d'Italia, said today it was "very dangerous to speak of and wave the Cross of Christ as if it were a weapon."

Activity in Manhattan realty reported yesterday consisted mostly of deals involving, tenement properties on the East Side. An investing client of Schimmer, Kerner Feder, brokers, bought from Gerard C. Gignoux, as trustee, the five-story house at 451 East 119th Street.

In what the police said was an attempt to rob the Garden Theatre here early this morning, one man was shot and killed and another arrested when detectives entered the building and fired at the intruders.
The Federal Theatre Project's Ithree-ring circus, complete with a street parade and Japino, the elephant, will open its season this evening at Skillman Avenue at Forty-sixth Street, Sunnyside, L. I.

The third annual competitive exhibition for a first one-man show, sponsored by the American Artists Congress, is announced by the A. C. A. Gallery. Artists who have not had a one-man show in New York may submit two pictures or two pieces of sculpture, which should be sent to the gallery, 52 West Eighth Street, on June 13 and 14.

The formulation of a permanent, or at least a long-time, national relief policy based upon careful, nonpartisan study was urged last night by Professor Charles E. Merriam of the University of Chicago at the thirteenth annual dinner of the Welfare Council of New York City, held at the Hotel Commodore.
The final tour in the series of city garden visits being conducted under the auspices of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association will take place this afternoon.

Despite increases in traffic accidents and the number of persons injured in the last few days, the death toll in traffic declined last week and week-end as compared to figures for the corresponding periods yast year,the Safety Bureau of the Police Department announced yesterday.
In a note to the League of Nations- Council China charged tonight that Japan had used poison gas in her undeclared war in the Far East and was intensifying preparations for wider use of gas.

Federal experts who conferred with Secretary Morgenthau this morning did not unanimously agree upon the uniform bank examination worked out by representatives of the Federal bank examining agencies, so Mr. Morgenthau asked them to study the proposal for another week in the hope of winning unanimous approval, the Secretary said at his press conference this afternoon.

HERE is a strange story. About twenty-five years ago, the editor of an Italian radical weekly wrote a series of articles on a certain political turncoat. This-renegade, he said angrily, had committed every crime in the radical lexicon. He had betrayed democracy and socialism.

The Minister of Education opened tonight an Ecumenical Conference at Utrecht attended by fifty-six representatives of thirty church bodies from twenty-one countries. The Archbishop of York presided. The conference will last until Friday.

Carlo Nunziato, whose name was replaced on the city payroll in February, twenty-three years after he lost his leg in the city's service, died yesterday of pneumonia in St. Catherine's Hospital, Brooklyn. His age was 53 years.

In reference to a statement by Senator Minton, chairman of the Senate's Lobby Committee, that the Securities and Exchange Commission had de questioned him about the validity of newspaper reports that the magazine Rural Progress had issued stock debentures, SEC officials said that it was customary to investigate all reports of unregistered security issues which might come under the Securities Act.
The Senators climbed to first place in the American League today, using the cellar-dwelling Browns as a stepping stone.

Edward Strecker, who rose from messenger boy to president of the Union National Bank, died at his home here today at the age of .71. He retired as president in 1935 and became chairman of the board of directors.
Paderewski is giving a recital at Carnegie, but it's the Little Carnegie Playhouse, not Carnegie Hall --a difference of a few yards reckoned one way, a difference immeasurable if reckoned another.

Miss Diana Kissel, a daughter of Mrs. Stephen Hurlbut of 10 Gracie Square and Lenox, Mass., will be married to J. Lawrence Barnard, a descendant of Frederick Augustus Barnard, founder of Barnard College, on the afternoon of.June 3, in St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

Welcomed by President Roosevelt, and acclaimed by Speaker Bankhead as "sleepless sentinels on the frontiers of freedom," more than 1,000 dele gates and guests of B'nai B'rith assembled for its general convention, rededicated themselves today to-protection of- America's heritage of democracy from its "mortal ene mies," communism, fascism and nazism.

A reception was given yesterday at Mayfair House by Mrs. J. Wuertz Edwards, who returned recently from Palm Beach. Among the guests were Mr. and Mrs. Leo T. Kissam, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Nichols, Mr. and Mrs. John A. McVickar Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Edgar We Garbisch, Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Bondy and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Holleran.
With the equivalent of four dollars in American money in his pockets, Max Schmeling arrived from Germany aboard the Bremen of the North German Lloyd Line yesterday.

A resolution urging delegates to the- State Constitutional Convention to preserve for Nassau County all the home rule provisions gained under the new charter that became effective on Jan. 1 was offered to the County Board of Supervisors here today by County Executive J. Russel Sprague.
The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for April 30 showed that the gold reserve ratio to notes in circulation was 118.72 per cent, compared with 119.69 per cemt on April 15.

A warning that "all Jews are fellow laborers in today's battle for the survival of Judaism" was voiced today at the annual meeting of the Women's League of the United Synagogue of America by Mrs. Samuel Spiegel of New York, president of the league.
Miss Ann W. Leisenring, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Leisenring of Ardmore, was married this afternoon to George L. Justice, son of Mrs. George L. Justice of Sorrel Horse Lodge, Villanova.

On the assumption that Congress will give its approval to the President's new spending program, the Budget Bureau estimates that next year's deficit will be in excess of three billion dollars. That will be the sixth consecutive deficit for the Roosevelt Administration. It will establish a Precedent.
A settlement of the strike that has tied up seven ships of the French Line appeared to have been obtained tonight and with it the Normandiets departure on Wednesday seemed assured.

Richard D. Meyer, 31 years old, of 1,518 Liberty Avenue, Hillside, and Joseph Spinola, 19, of 583 South Seventeenth Street, Newark, were arrested today as they were loading allegedly obscene booklets into art automobile in front of a print shop at 17 William Street here.

With her lights glowing across the picturesque River Maas, the Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam began her maiden voyage this morning from Rotterdam, bound for Boulogne, France; Southampton, England, and New York.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Fenno of this city have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Neva Elizabeth Fenno, to Clifton B. White Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. White of Mount Kisco, which took place here yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles O. White.
A possible explanation of mysterious radio broadcasts denouncing the present Soviet regime purporting to come "from the heart of Russia" that have recently been heard abroad was indicated here today.

Authorization for the city to enter into a contract with the New York Foreign Trade Zone Operators, Inc., for operation of the socalled free port at Stapleton, S. I., was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate at a special meeting after bitter debate.
Miss Miriam Ackland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Ackland of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to William A. Johnson Jr., son of Colonel and Mrs. Johnson of Baltimore.

In a unanimous decision the Appellate Division has reversed the conviction of Ralph Holland for allegedly using counterfeit trademarks on radio sets sold in the Holland Radio Stores, Inc., 5 East Fourteenth Street, it was disclosed yesterday.
The City Commission approved its 1938. budget today, placing the tax rate between $4.70 and $4.80, and adjourned until tomorrow at 11 A. M., when it hopes to vote formal adoption.

The Countess of Portsmouth, the former Marguerite Walker of Frankfort, Ky., and Chicago, died today at Morchard Bishop, Devon. She was the wife of Oliver Henry Wallop, the eighth Earl of Portsmouth, who lived many years In Sheridan, Wyo., and became a United States citizen.

A $30,000 mortgage on the recently modernized building at 540 E 149th St, Bronx, has been taken by the North River Savings Bank. The Ironsides Estates, Inc. Charles Peck, president, is the owner of the property. James Boyd acted as broker in the transaction.
Albert Axelrod of the champion Stuyvesant fencing team came through a triple tie to win the Publie School Athletic- League individual foils crown last night at the Washington Irving High School.

Activity in the New York wholesale dress market last week continued at a disappointingly slow pace, with lower price ranges again substantially below expected volume, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by the research department of the joint board, Dress and Waistmakers Union.

The first definite break in the ranks of the Amierican Labor party as the result of the attack upon it by George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor, came yesterday, when George J. Troy, president of Local 32-K, Building Service Employes International Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate, resigned as vice chairman of the Kings County organization of the Labor party.
F. Burton Fisher, assistant manager of the Hotel Plaza, was reelected president of the New York Hotel Sales Managers Association at its annual business meeting last night at. the Park Central Hotel.

Women and children piled Federal rations of cabbage and potatoes into baby carriages and toy wagons to replenish their bare cupboards today, as city officials grappled with the food crisis among Cleveland's 87,000 recipients of relief.

The American Federation of Labor, which has 600,000 members in the city, will open Union Label Week with a parade on Saturday, in which 30,000 trade unionists will march to emphasize "the benefits which accrue from purchasing only those goods produced by American workers under fair, American working conditions."

Michael F. Walsh, recently appointed United States -Attorney for the Eastern District, was sworn in yesterday afternoon in -the Brooklyn Federal Building by Judge Marcus B. Campbell in the presence of 300 friends and relatives.

Federal Judge George A. Welsh opened the way today for intercompany out-of-court agreements to replace the present plan to merge the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company and its underlying concerns into a $100,-235,000 organization under court auspices.
Arnold Kahne, in 21 Gedney Terrace, for Sarah H. Cole; James E. Hughes, in 17 Blackthorne Lane, for Dorothy S. Pitner; White Plains rentals by Chauncey B. Griffen, broker.
A fashion revue and luncheon be held on Thursday at the Rltz Tower to aid the Spring Farm Camp at Greens Farms,. Conn. Mrs. D. Swing Starring, the camp president, heads the committee in charge.

" Birds of the World," an illustrated natural history of all the living families and orders of avian life, compiled and written by local Federal Writers, will be published next Fall by Albert Whitman of Chicago.

In a letter to J. Earle Connelley, Federal Bureau of Investigation chief in New York City, District Attorney Fred J. Under asked today if the former's office had withdrawn from the investigation into the disappearance eleven months ago of Mrs. Alice M. Parsons of Stony Brook.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Triggs of Madison, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Elizabeth Triggs, to Harrington Vose Ingham, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Ingham of Los Angeles.

Although heavily guarded, the Partition Commission today proceeding to Haifa from Jerusalem avoided the regular motor highway, which passes through Arab towns and villages notorious for terrorist activities. Instead, they proceeded to Tel Aviv and then traveled the new coastal road, going through Jewish colonies all along the way to Haifa.
Today's Cardinal-Dodger affair resembled nothing so much as a battle between two wild-swinging boxers, with the outcome depending upon which one was able to survive the many knockdowns.
It was announced today that King Leopold of the Belgians would pay an official visit to The Netherlands court some time this year.
James H. Foster, director of the Child Aid Bureau of the State Social Welfare Department died today. His age was 64. He had served thirty years in the State service.
Culture and the fistic art have met head on here and pugilism-has won. Executives of the General Federation of Women's Clubs have capitulated to a lightweight champion with a contract.

In an admirably lucid lecture which he delivered recently before- the National Academy of Sciences and in which he summarized our present knowledge of cancer, Dr. James Ewing, director of New York's Memorial Hospital, generously concedes the correctness of the contention of certain newspaper science editors that cancer research lags because it is not organized.

The left eye of Helaine Judith Colan was removed today in a swift operation to save her life. The five-week-old glioma victim was hurried into the operating room at Garfield Park Community Hospital a few minutes after a council of ten doctors decided this was her only chance to avert death, perhaps within two months, from the cancerous growth creeping toward her brain.

The Red Sox, on a combination of eleven hits and twelve bases on balls, rode to their second straight victory over the Indians today, this time by a score of 15 to 3. The defeat dropped Cleveland into a second-place tie with the Yankees, who were idle.
A demand that the Republicans cease playing politics in the Constitutional Convention was made from the floor of the convention tonight by Senator Robert F. Wagner, leader of the Democratic minority.

Commander I. Schlossbach, who took off last night on a survey flight over Ellesmere Island, Canada, was forced back after reaching the middle of the island when he encountered low clouds on the other side of the mountains.

Operations in the steel industry are scheduled at 30.4 per cent of capacity for this week, a decrease of 0.3 point, or 1 per cent, from the week before when the rate was 30.7 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Influenced by reports of belowfreezing temperatures in parts of Texas and a strong stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered from an early decline yesterday and ended unchanged to 4 points lower than Saturday's close.
Dr. William Alexander Hammond, who was dean of the faculty of Cornell University, 1920-30, died here Saturday. after a brief illness. He was 77 years old.

Acceptance by Presiding Justice Edward Lazansky of the Appellate Division, Second Department, of appointment as an honorary chairman of the Brooklyn division of the Greater-- New York Fund, was announced yesterday by Charles A. Gorman, division chairman.
A re-enactment of the first night air mail flight in this country is planned for National Air Mail Week, to be observed from May 15 to May 21.
A large proportion of the new leasing contracts announced yesterday involved store space for retail businesses. Several were for Fifth Avenue locations.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Fegeral Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 4:

Formation of a new corporation to liquidate, Continental Shares, Inc., a holding company once capitalized at more than $100,000,000, was directed today in a decree signed by Judge Edwin T. Dickerson in Circuit Court.
Raymond Wilde, 57 years old, identified as a Camden real estate man, committed suicide this evening at Laurel Lake, three miles south of here, according to Coroner Frank Tongue of Cedarville.

Only about 600 tons of recoverable copper remained to be removed from Mother Lode Coalition Mines Alaskan property on April 1, E. T. Stannard, a director, told stockholders at Qtheir meeting here yesterday.

The San Carlo Opera Company presented Puccini's "La Boheme" at the Center Theatre last night before a large and demonstrative audience. The cast was headed by Bianca Saroya as Mimi, Dimitri Oofrei as Rodolfo, Mario Valle as Marcello, Harold Kravitt as Colline, Stefan Kozakeviteh as Schaunard, Leola Turnei as Musetta and Natale Cervi as Bennit and Alcindoro.

Following a decision by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals upholding Federal Judge Mandelbaum- in a ruling which subordinated claims on participating debentures and American certificates of Aktiebolaget- Kreuger Toll, Edward S. Greenbaum, trustee in bankruptcy for that company, said the case would probably be coneluded soon.

More than a third of the new students at fifty-six colleges and universities which make tests for tuberculosis were found to be infected to some degree, according to a preliminary report to the American Youth-Commission on a survey of the health of college students.

A group of twenty German horse men and horsewomen arrived in New York yesterday aboard the Bremen of the North German Lloyd line.- The party, under the direction of Gustav Rau, chairman of the German Olympic Committee for horsemanship, will remain in this country until May 28, visiting lead ing horse centers.

The Sunshine Anthracite Coal Company, operating mines in Johnson County, Ark., filed suit in Federal court today questioning the constitutionality of the National Bituminous Coal Act of 1937. The company has headquarters at Chicago.
Five maritime unions moved 'tonight to vote on closing the port of Seattle as a protest against the ten-day Tacoma waterfront tie-up.

Annual corporation reports made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that H. F. Sinclair, chairman of the execuLive committee, received $200,570 from Consolidated Oil Corporation, New York, in 1937. Mr. Sinclair's 1936 income from the oil company was $200,659.

The movement to buy off-priced goods, either in surplus lots or from manufacturers who have been unable to book near-by production on new products, has spread over a wide number of retail organizations and is likely to continue, according to executives interviewed yesterday.

Present indications are that the President will not yield to pressure to lift the embargo on the sale of arms to Spain. The Administration could hardly adopt a different attitude at this time, by lifting the embargo in advance of changing the law itself.
The international stock market indices for May 7, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

Conferees on the Administration's billiondollar naval expansion bill reached full agreement today. The committee considerably altered the amendment sponsored by Senator Vandenberg, which would have permitted construction of capital ships above 35,000 tons only if some other nation went above the old London treaty limit.

The House of Delegates of -the Medical Society of the State of New York, which opened its 132d annual meeting here yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, turned down proposals by its council and by its special committee on matters pertaining to medical care approving 'the principle of nonprofit medical expense indemnity insurance.

As a result of one of the few successful suits for plagiarism brought in this district, Edward Sheldon and Margaret Ayer Barnes, authors of the play "Dishonored Lady." will receive damages of $587,604 from Metro-Goldwyn Pictures Corporation and other defendants, if Federal Judge John C. Knox approves recommendations filed with him yesterday by Gordon Auchincloss, and if the defendants do not win an appeal to a higher court.

Papers filed in the Town Clerk's office, Greenwich, today reveal the s '- of the estate of the Benedict Realty Company, formerly the property of E. C. Benedict, well-known banker and yachtsman, to Andre Fraser and Anita H. Fraser of Greenwich, for $200,000.

Work on the Cooper River Parkway and the Haddon Lake development, the two principal WPA projects in Camden County, was halted today as 4,200 WPA workers went on a strike called by the Workers Alliance against a new stagger system of employment under which the employes work only four days a week instead of five.

Enlistrdent of the smaller nations of Europe and Russia behind France and Great Britain in their efforts to encircle Nazi Germany, using League of Nations machinery, was proposed tonight by Winston Churchill in a speech at Manchester in which he opened his campaign against the Chamberlain government's present repudiation of the League.

Deliberator, the Florida horse whose last previous race had been six months ago in Maryland, inaugurated the Belmont Park Spring meeting yesterday with a head victory at the end of a bitter drive down the Widener chute with Parmelee T. battling alongside as 12,000 persons watched. Peter A. B.

The-first full-scale tests of the efficiency of production of calcium metaphosphate from rock. phosphate and. phosphorus have shown, the operation to be both successful and profitable, speakers revealed at the annual fire meeting of the Chemical Engineers times Council here today.

Among the properties in New Jersey reported yesterday as having been sold was the Bayonne Opera House, '583-89 Avenue C. It was purchased by the Erie Amusement Company of Erie, Pa., from the Bayonne Feiber Shea Company, Edmund C. Grainger, vice president.

New York Typographical Union 6 applied yesterday in Supreme Court for an order directing the New York City Publishers Association to pay $66,83 to. former composing room employes of the old Brooklyn Times Union in accordance with an arbitration award dated June 26, 1937.

Dutyfree importation of equipment and machinery for installation in an electric lamp factory has been approved by the Technical Tariff Commission of Cuba and awaits only the approval of the President of Cuba, according to a report from Havana made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Operations in the first quarter of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation resulted in a net profit of $586,288, after depreciation, interest and Federal income taxes, but before surtax on undistributed income.

Archduke Albrecht married a commoner today and lost his place in the ancient House of Habsburg. Expulsion of the Archduke from the family dominant in Europe for 700 years was announced shortly after he took for his bride Katherine Bucskay, 27-year-old country school teacher and daughter of a small town mechanic.

Plans have been completed by Miss Lois Augusta Benedict, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Northrup Benedict, for her marriage to Dr. Edgar Eginton Stewart Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart of Great Neck, L. I.

There has been a greater trend recently toward mutual understanding of government and business, which, if continued, will react favorably on the general economic situation, Morris C. Troper declared last night after his re-election as president of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants at its forty-first annual meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Percy L. Elias and George F.. Price of the electrical contracting concern of Hoffman Price pleaded guilty yesterday in the special term of Special Sessions to charges of evadings of State income tax involving about $30,000 in 1936.
Wheat futures closed today 7/8 to 1/4 cents a bushel lower on the Board of Trade here, more because of lack of aggressive support than any material pressure.
Miss Alice Marble, ranking woman tennis player of the country,, had a last workout yesterday before sailing tomorrow on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary with the Wightman Cup team.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. today announced complete elimination of exchange speculation on this side of the Atlantic. He made the statement in discussing the franc crisis that occurred last week.
What Secretary Morgenthau hailed as the lowest interest rate on record for Treasury bills, 0.029 per cent, the equivalent of a price of 99.993, was received on the $50,000,000 offering sold today.

The general prohibition of political demonstrations in Czechoslovakia was canceled Saturday, and as an immediate result there was a general increase in dangerous incidents, apparently mostly provoked by Henlinists [Nazis] in the Sudeten areas on Sunday.

Anthony Fokker, who built the famous Fokker airplanes used by Germany during the war, conferred here today with Defense Department officials. He was accompanied by R. B. C. Noorduyn, general manager of the Noorduyn Aircraft Company, Ltd., of Montreal.
Robert B. Egbert of Jamaica, Queens, a senior at Cooper Union Institute of Technology, has won the A. MacLaren White Award, it was announced yesterday.

COHN, JOSEPH (April 27). Estate, less than $5,000. To Helene Moos, grandniece, executrix. 315 W. 91st St.. residue. FOODEM, SARAH (March 28). Estate, $3,500. To Dora Cohn, daughter, 309 E. 19th St., Brooklyn, Rose Koppman, daughter. Sayyille. L. I.. Anna Kapstein.

The government has decided to stop the entry of refugees into this country in an effort to halt an increase in the number of unemployed. Although the measure was taken for economic reasons no discrimination will be made in favor of a well-to-do person. Only.
The Spanish Government's Central Army today took a wedge of territory from.. no the Insurgent corridor to the Mediterranean on the Valencia or southern side.

Gambling in any form and for any reason, even under the guise of "lotteries" for the raising of parish or relief funds, was condemned yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning-in his address before the 155th convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York at the Synod House, 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

A second successive victory sent Lancashire into the lead in the English county cricket championship today. The Northern county followed a ten-wicket triumph over Warwickshire last week by defeating Hampshire by an innings and 160 runs.

Following an unwonted display of pugnacity during batting practice that almost brought on a fist fight among themselves, the Dodgers later redirected their ire against the Cardinals to such good effect that they walked away with the series final today by a 10-2 score.
The Savage School swimmers defeated the Brooklyn College women's team last night at the Brooklyn College pool, 34 to 19.

Glenn Cunningham, New York Curb Exchange ace, ran an exhibition mile and gave a talk to about 400 students of Poly Prep at Poly Field- in Brooklyn yesterday. Dan Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the National A. A. U., and Joe McCluskey, veteran New York A. C. star. also were present.
The Reichsbank's statement as of May 9 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Department store sales throughout the country declined 3 per cent in April from April, 1937, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board. For the first four months of this year the board reported a drop of 8 per cent from the 1937 sales volume.
The Women's League of the United Synagogue of America ended its annual convention today with the adoption of resolutions dealing with various problems.

Pennsylvania rallied to. defeat Lafayette in their annual lacrosse match on River Field today, 7-3. Coach Hap Middleton started his second Penn team, with the exception of Captain Kermit Gordon, and the Leopards gained a 3-0 lead on two goals by Swede Erickson and one by Jim Link.

To Motor and Pump Operators' School The following members shall be directed to report at the Motor and Pump Operators' School. 32-02 Queens Boulevard. Long Island City, at 10:30 A. M., on the dates specified above their names:

Negotiations tions are in progress for a merger of the Allegheny Steel Company and the Ludlum Steel Company of Watervliet, N. Y. While details have not been worked out, indications are that considerable headway has been made.
The Cloisters, the new branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art at the northern end of Fort Tryon Park, was officially opened yesterday afternoon shortly before 4 o'clock.

Plans were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings for a total of seventy-two dwellings in the various sections o Queens. In Brooklyn, architect also submitted a number of projects for the construction of small homes The Manhattan plans covered al terations to several tenements and business buildings.
A suit for $250,000 was filed in-the County Clerk's office here today by Max Eastman, radical author and lecturer, against The Daily Worker, Clarence A. Hathaway, its editor,

Two gas explosions killed seventy-nine miners and injured more than forty at the Markham coal mine here today. The disaster, which trapped an entire shift in the mine, struck into virtually every home in this little village.

Strictly grainfed steers did not sell nearly as low today as the trade had expected, downturns being mostly 10 to 15 cents, according to the United States Department of Agriculture. The market was active, with a top of $10.50. After hogs weakened the trade became active also. California Spring lambs sold at $8.90 down.
The Bureau of Concord aviation unit resumed Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 7:

The Bacardi Corporation of America today won a permanent injunction against the Treasurer of Puerto Rico restraining his enforcement of a law that would forbid the company's use of the Bacardi label under a license agreement from the Bacardi Corporation of Cuba on rum manufactured in Puerto Rico and also stop its shipment of rum in bulk.

Preliminary estimates place the losses by fire in the United States during 1937 at a total of $285,000,000, according to a report read by Robert S. Moulton of Boston to the fortysecond annual meeting of the National Fire Protection Association here today at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall.
Joseph Salou, 22-year-old sailor, was arrested here today following fires aboard the French liner Champlain this morning.

A deposit of $890,000 posted by the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company in settlement of claims of $7,000,000 growing out of the burning of the Morro Castle on Sept. 8, 1934, has not been distributed, and may not be for months to come, it was learned yesterday.

The Kittredge Players will present their Spring production tomorrow and Friday nights at the Heckscher Theatre for the benefit of the Abbott E. Kittredge Club for Girls, 440 East Fifty-seventh Street. The play will be a mystery drama entitled "The Night of January 16th."
Canberra's wheat harvest in :1937-88 of 181,000,000 bushels is an increase of 31,000,000 bushels over the' 1936-37 yieldand the greatest since 1932-33, when it was 213,000,000 bushels.
The Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam called at Southampton this evening on her maiden voyage to New York. The original plan to dock the vessel there and hold a reception and brief inspection for

The sitdown strike and its attendant seizure of property is illegal, and the Wagner Labor Relations Act cannot supersede a State's right and power to prevent disorder, the Illinois Appellate Court held here today.

The government is anxious to cooperate with and receive cooperation from all forms of business, Clinton Davidson, vice president of Fiduciary Counsel, Inc., said yesterday at a luncheon of life insurance supervisors of New York City in the Hotel Governor Clinton. Mr.

The first in the series of threeday garden tours annually conducted by the School ..Nature League will be held on Monday. For nine years the league has secured permission from the owners of some of the most attractive city penthouse and backyard gardens and country estates to exhibit their gardens to the public.

Rutgers scored five runs on four hits in the fifth inning to pile up a lead big enough to win from William and Mary, 6 to 3, today on Neilson Field as 500 fans looked on. Carl Miller, Rutgers pitcher, allowed eight scattered- hits and struck out nine batters.
The People's Chorus of New York celebrated its twenty-second anniversary with a "Spring Song Festival" last night at Carnegie Hall. L. Camilieri, founder of the organization, conducted.

By the death of his father, Lord Harlech, Sir William Ormsby-Gore, Secretary of State for the Colonies, finds himself transferred to the House of Lords. It is thought probable that, remembering the pother about Lord Halifax's appointment to the Foreign Office, he will resign and there may be another rearrangement of the Cabinet.
The Ocean County election board sat all day in the county courthouse awaiting the returns from a commission election in Harvey Cedars.

A banking group composed of the Bancamerica - Blair Corporation, Hemphill, Noyes Co., C. F. Childs Co., Inc.; Graefe Co., and Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., has obtained $550,000 of water works revenue bonds of Keokuk, Iowa, on a bid of 100.19 for 2 1/2s. The bonds, dated May 1, 1938, will mature serially from May 1, 1939 to 1958, optional on May 1, 1942.

The feud that Mayor La Guardia and Fusion members of the Board of Education have been carrying on with the board's Bureau of Construction and Maintenance approached a climax yesterday when the law committee introduced a resolution at the annual meeting recommending drastic changes in the construction department.

Bitterly complaining of overheated American railway trains and sharply critical of the "expensive food and poor, service" in the dining cars, William Purkis, one of a group of British hotel men on a tour here, limped about the Waldorf - Astoria Hotel yesterday.

John Amory Lowell Blake of Boston, banker and broker, died at his Summer home, Malf Hill, Beverly Farms, last night after a- brief sickness. His age was 59.. He had been vice treasurer of the Provident Institution for Savings, Boston, a week when he died.

THE four gifted Powys brothers--A. R., Llewelyn, John Cowper and T. F.-have each written books "and made a reputation. John Cowper Powys is no doubt the most widely known and the most prolific, a novelist whose "Wolf Solent" and "Maiden Castle," despite their curious self-consciousness and artifice, have found an admiring audience.

New York City's proposals for a constitutional amendment. to exempt from the debt limit city bonds issued to purchase private transit lines were placed before the State Constitutional Convention in Albany yesterday.

Bound for New York with a specimen of. one -of. the world's rarest birds-the flightless rail-the Rev. A. G. Partridge, forinerly in charge of the isolated South Atlantic island of Tristan da Cunha, will sail this Sunday from Southampton, England; on the Red' Star liner Pennland.

Grand Concourse, 2.850-56 (12-3305); Dale Construction Co, Inc, to Corporation Realties, Ltd, 1,450 Broadway; mtg $113,000. Washington Ave (11-3050), n e cor of 182d St, 36x93; Seventieth Management; Inc, to Halkov Realty Corp, 989 6th Ave.

Captain Royal E. Ingersoll, chief of the navy's war plans division, who worked with British naval authorities in evolving a program for bigger battleships, was, promoted today to the rank of rear admiral.

Pride in the part the Bar Association of the City of New York tools in the successful fight to defeat President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the United States Supreme Court was expressed last night by Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State.

Large-scale adoption by drug chains of the movement to purchase manufacturers' surplus stocks for special retail promotions, which already has resulted in arrangements to purchase nearly $1,500,000 worth of goods, will break within the next ten days, it was learned here yesterday.

The Federal Government, through the Tennessee Valley Authority, has under consideration the laying of groundwork for the creation of a vast publicly owned and operated electric power distribution network encompassing the entire State of Tennessee and sizable parts of the States of Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia and North Carolina, it was learned yesterday.

Retired Police Sergeant Joseph T. Dwyer, who was cited three times during his twenty-six-year career in the department, died Monday night in Bushwick Hospital of a combination of diseases at the age of 54.

A sudden rush of imports of German automobiles, which are underselling many models here, is causing concern among British manufacturers, and today the government was asked in the House of Commons whether they w re being subsidized by the German Government.

Six Americans who had served with the WashingtonTLincoln Battalion in the Spanish Loyalist Army arrived here today to seek repatriation at the United States Consulate. Six others arrived a few days ago under police escort from Perpignan.

LIEUTENANTS--Charles V. Meehan, from' 43d Proinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, N. Y. County, for 1 day, from 4 P. M., May 6. Thomas P. Browne, from 46th Precinct to 19th Division, office of the chief inspector, for 16 days, from 8 A. M.. May 16.

Orville Drouillard, 134 1/4, Windsor, Ont., 'and Bernie Friedkin, 133 1/2, Brownsville, battled to a draw in the feature eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night before a crowd of 3.000.

For' the' second consecutive week during this "measles, year" the number of new cases in this city declined for the seven-day-period ended last Saturday, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John .,. Rice, Health Commissioner. There were.
Dr. Friederich Fischerauer, former Austrian Consul General at New York, and Dr. Arno Halusa, former vice consul, have been assigned to he staff of the German Consulate General there.

Suspension for an indefinite time of all construction work; on Princeton's $4,500,000 Palmer Square was announced today by officials of the Princeton Municipal Improvement, Inc., sponsors of the project.

As a forerunner to tomorrow's annual- intersectional team match, in which Westchester will defend the laurels it won last year against Long Island and New Jersey, an 18-hole medal play competition was staged today over the Sands Point links despite the after-effects of the rain.
Another marriage of a Habsburg prince to a commoner was celebrated today in St. Stephen's Cathedral here, the parties being Archduke Carlos and a Hungarian girl, Christa--Satzger de Balvanyos.

The first meeting of the Holland House Corporation of the Netherlands, an organization of Dutch eultural and commercial interests now negotiating for a 50,000 square foot Holland House to be built in Rockefeller Center, was held yesterday afternoon in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. Forty-six members were elected to the board of directors.

The estate of George Dupont Pratt, a son of the late Charles M. Pratt, who founded Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, showed a gross value of $13,714,101, according to a transfer tax appraisal sent yesterday to the Surrogate's Court in Mineola, L. I.

Steel ingot production declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index eased to 40.0, its lowest point in two months. The figure was 40.7 for the preceding week and 121.2 for the week ended May 8, 1937.

Final agreement was reached today among League of Nations members for the establishment of a single autonomous office to aid refugees of all nationalities and creeds The United States will be asked to cooperate with the new office.

Increased government regulation of advertising and selling practices can be expected in the future as the result of management's growing emphasis on distribution rather than production problems, Edwin B. George, economist, of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.,
Cary D. Landis, Attorney General of Florida, died here today. Mr. Landis, who was 65 years old today, had been ill two weeks.

Abolition of the Chorus Equity Association as a separate affiliate of the American Federation of Labor was recommended yesterday in a report by the union's executive secretary, Miss Edith L. Christenson. Her report was accepted by the union's parent body,

Sir Cedric Hardwicke, who portrays Canon Skerritt in Paul Vincent Carroll's play, "Shadow and Substance," at the Golden Theatre, received yesterday the Delia Austrian Medal of the Drama League of New York for "the most distinguished performance of the theatrical season."

We have received a wire from Julian Crandall, the Ashaway (R. I.) man, that gives considerable promise for the future of Buzz Shonnard's Walker Key ' Club, which opened last week. Julian took the season's first blue marlin, a 230-pounder, on Monday.

The promotion of Dr. Henry.Pratt Fairchild; a member of New' York University's teaching staff since 1919 and Professor of Sociology there since 1924, as head of the Department of Sociology in the Grad"uate School, effective Sept. 1,

The fifteenth defendant to be arrested in connection with State and Federal investigations of how $500,000 was obtained by the sale of allegedly worthless securities through the Secord, Vanderpoel Company of 70 Pine Street, now defunct, was taken into custody yesterday.

John A. Elbe, cashier of the Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn, was elected president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking at the annual meeting held last night in the Hotel Victoria.

Gypsy Princess, flashing young bay mare in the string of the Trillora Farm of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Wettach of Shrewsbury, N. J., tonight gained the honor of capturing the first cup event in the opening session of the seventh annual Atlantic City horse show.

A deal involving the southeast and southwest corners of Godwin Terrace and 232d Street, the Bronx, was reported yesterday by David S. Meister, when the operator announced that he had purchased from a client of Sobel Brand, attorneys, the two five-story apartment houses known as 3,136 and 3,155 Godwin Terrace. Sale was for cash above mortgages aggregating $385,000.

Mme. Andre Message; composer of "Auf Wiedersehn," other songs and ballads under the name of Hope Temple, died today at Folkestone at the age of 79. The widow of Andr6 Messager, composer of "Vronique," who died in 1929, she scored a number of successes in the days when the ballad was as popular in the home as in the concert hall.

Chauncey Sparks, runner-up in last week's Democratic contest for GoVernor, announced his withdrawal today, assuring the Governorship to Frank M. Dixon. Complete unofficial returns for the primary gave Mr. Dixon 152,612 votes of the 814,000 cast for five candidates. Mr.
Mitzi Green, about Whose return to the screen there has been some confusion, will be co-featured with Barbara Stanwyck in "The Mad Miss Manton" at RKO., With the cameras scheduled to turn on June 10.

Today's major events: "Lohengrin," San Carlo Opera Company, Center Theatre, evening; concert by Music Department of New York University School of Education, Town Hall, evening; Greenwich Orchestra, Mozart program, Federal Music Theatre, evening; Evangelos Tsamourtiz, polychord player, Steinway Hall, afternoon.

Columbia University dormitory residents on Van Am Quadrangle and members of near-by fraternities who destroyed campus peace and property in a four-hour riot last Thursday night began yesterday to' pay for the transgression. price was 75 cents a man.
America's Walker Cup goimers sailed last night on the Bremen ol the North German Lloyd Line, bound for St. Andrews, Scotland, where on June 3 and 4 they will de fend the trophy against Greal Britain.
In place of the "busy" signal on telephones, a verbal announcement of "Line engaged" is to be made soon throughout the Postoffice telephone service.
Columbia University's campus on Morningside Heights is taking on hues of every shade this week with the bloom of 30,000 irises of fifty varieties, the largest collection in Manhattan.
Delegates to the convention of the B'nai B'rith, meeting tonight with the resolutions committee of the convention in committee of the whole, adopted a resolution empowering the executive committee to

Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, told the House Banking and Currency Committee today that one reason for the delay in railroad reorganizations was because security holders preferred to put off the "evil day."

The Venezuelan Government is endeavoring to foster the development ofg new industries, and in-connection with this program maintains a file of equipment catalogues for the guidance of those establishing plants, according to a report made public today by the Machinery Division of the Department of Commerce.
Wheat futures fluctuated in an erratic manner today, evening up for the domestic and Canadian Government reports, due after the close, furnishing much of the business.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has sold the two-family house at 50-12 Forty-eighth Street, Woodside, to Frank Kotraba. Sale was for cash above a $4,700 first mortgage. Tanner, Sillcocks Friend represented the seller. William Adam Schulz Co., Inc., was the broker in the deal.

Municipal Court Justices John O'Rourke of Queens and Arthur P. McNulty of Manhattan faced possible disciplinary action by the Appellate Division yesterday in connection with a court record that was changed to shield Simon W. Gerson, Communist confidential adviser to Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan, from adverse publicity in a suit brought against him as a rent-dodger.

Charging that the Committee for Industrial Organization had an "undercover man" within the National Labor Relations Board who obtained board decisions before they were made public, Representative Hoffman, Republican of Michigan, offered a resolution today for a $25,000 investigation of the Board's activities by five members of the House.
Premier Koloman Daranyi had an audience today with Regent Nicholas Horthy, after which he conferred with leading-members of the upper house, where the new electoral law began to be debated.

Mrs. Edgar Franklin Romig was elected president of the Woman's Board of Foreign Missions of the Reformed Church of America at a meeting in the Reformed Church House, 25 East Twenty-second Street, yesterday.

The net profit of the Standard Oil Company of Kansas for the first three months of 1938 was reported yesterday as $168,908 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, royalties and leases, interest, intangible development costs, Federal income taxes and other charges.

The voting was heavy as interest ran high in the election of commission governments in nine New Jersey communities yesterday. The most spirited contest. was in Union City, where the five Democratic incumbents found, opposition in a Fusion ticket of four Republicans and one Democrat.

Charles W. Ackerman of 135 East Beech S~reet here, owner of the men's clothing store bearing his name at 224 Fifth Avenue, New York, died suddenly last night in the Long Beach Hospital of a heart attack. His age was 73.

John F. (Chick) Meehan, former Manhattan and N. Y. Ui. football coach, has been appointed football director at Ebbets Field, it was announced. yesterday by Executive Vice President Larry MacPhail of the Brooklyn Baseball Club.

Funeral services were held today in Middletown for Henry S. Spooner, who died Sunday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. J. Albert Smith Jr., in Wallkill Township. He was 88 years old. Mr. Spooner, who was a former hardware merchant in Middletown, was born in Brooklyn,

Major Gen. Frank M. Andrews, commanding general of the army's General Headquarters Air Force, made an aerial inspection of five bases in three States today on the eve of the opening of a mimic war that will make aviation history.

A syndicate managed by C. P. Couch, C. S. McCain and Dillon, Read Co. hold 258,000 of the 260,000 voting shares of the Louisiana Arkansas Railway, a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday. C. P. Couch is the brother of Harvey C. Couch.
Business enterprises of many types figured in the reports of commercial rentals submitted yesterday by brokers. Several full-floor units were taken, as were a number of stores for retail purposes.

As a result of the impression made by the visit of United States military bombing planes to Buenos Aires last February, the Argentine Government has asked the United States to detail a number of army flying officers to that country as instructors.
Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, Minister to Norway, said today that she had bought a loom and learned to weave. In Norway, she said, virtually allwomen are interested in handicrafts.
Foreign tourist traffic in Austria is reported to have fallen to practically nothing since the annextion by Germany.

The Department of Commerce reported today that gold imports for April totaled $71,236,453, compared with $52,947,452 for March. The import figure was far below the total of $215,824,506 for April, 1937. Gold exports for last month were $145,053, compared with $20,065 for March and $13.441 for April, 1937.
More than twenty-four hours after a surgeon had removed her left eye as a means of saving her life, Helaine Judith Colan, 5% weeks old, slept peacefully today at the Garfield Community Hospital.
The Department of Agriculture reported today that conditions on May 1 indicated that this year's crop of Winter wheat would be 754,153,000 bushels, the second largest production on record.

Fourteen process servers, six of whom are World War veterans, brought suit in Supreme Court yesterday to compel District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey to reinstate them to positions they occupied in the prosecutor's officer before he became District Attorney.

Stockholders of Dawes Brothers, Inc., an investment company controlled by Members of the Dawes family, approved today distribution of certain assets looking toward eventual dissolution of the organization.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler was received in his capital tonight on his return from Italy with a turbulence of almost hysterical enthusiasm and a splendor surpassing his reception after his bloodless conquest of Austria.

The Barnard School for Boys nine clinched the Northern Division, Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools, championship yesterday by downing Fieldston School, 9 to 3, on Fieldston's diamond.

Employment in New York State factories fell 2 per cent last month, a sharper decrease than the usual seasonal decline, the State Labor Department reported today. At the same time, payrolls decreased 4.5 per cent.

Passage of the House bill on hours and wages would impose an "unbearable burden" on the cigar industry and would result in disorganization and widespread unemployment , Samuel Blumberg, general counsel for the Cigar Manufacturers of America,

Leading bookmaking establishments today reported brisk wagering on the Derby, to be run at Epsom June 1. Odds against H. E. Morriss's Pasch, winner of the Two Thousand Guineas, were shortened to 7 to 4 from the 2-to-1 price set in yesterday's official callover 'at the Victoria Club.

Realization on the part of executives of utility companies and leading government officials that some solution to the utility problem must be effected before the current business slump can even approach the corrective stage has at last taken definite shape.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,382,350 barrels, compared with 3,396,150 in the preceding week, a decline of 13,800, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

The Netherlands Government has decided -upon further measures to guard against unemployment. Following upon the decision to stem the flood of German refugees, the Cabinet will increase the number of persons employed on public works projects from 53,000 to 75,000.

Plans for the production and distribution of forty feature films by Universal Pictures Company during the 1988-39 season were announced yesterday by Charles R. Rogers, vice president in charge of production.

BAGRY, MIRON (April 21). Estate, $21,-000. To Frances and William Bagry, children, 1,426 York Ave., $8,500 each; Josephine Bagry, widow, petitioner, 1,426 York Ave., $2,000. Edward T. Kruglak, 151 York Ave., executor. BALL, WILLIAM A.- (Oct. 4, 1934). Estate, $500. To Lillian Ball,. widow, executrix. 226 W. 150th St.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, playing in Great Britain for the first time since 1935, and the first time on a hard. court in this country, today defeated Miss Enid Wyard, 6-1, 6-0, in the North London tennis tournament.

Without an opposition vote, James Marshall, Manhattan representative on the Board .of Education since 1935, and its vice president during the last two years, was chosen as president of the board at the annual meeting held yesterday at 500 Park Avenue.

The question of gambling in general and Stateoperated lotteries for relief and housing purposes in particular was debated today at the first public hearing of the Constitutional Convention, held by the Bill of Rights Committee.

The bitter controversy over whether Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City has abridged the right of free speech and assembly in Jersey City had an echo in the White House yesterday. President Roosevelt was asked at his press conference if he intended to take any action as Chief Executive of the nation or as head of the Democratic party.
Attendance was large at the opening sale of the year's third wool auction series today. Offerings totaled 9,069 bales, of which 6,983 ware sold. The domestic trade bought liberally.
Jewish veterans who fought with the French armies during the World War kindled a flame at the Arc de Triomphe tonight on the anniversary of the Battle of Carrency, where many of their comrades fell.

A bolt of lightning struck a parapet on top of the Hotel Majestic,/2 West Seventy-second Street, at Central Park West, during a storm at 3:20 o'clock yesterday morning. Several bricks were dislodged, one of them plunging through the roof of a cab- parked in Seventy-second Street and another breaking the glass in a revolving door in the entrance of the building.

Eight Hunter College student will be installed as members of Theta Beta chapter of Sigma Tau Delta, national honor English fraternity for creative writing, at a formal dinner in the roof garden of the Hotel Barbizon at 6 P. M. today.

What piece -of news this weeK nas interested the most people? Not the progress of the Wages and Hours Bill or the new Federal spending program. Not Hitler's visit to Rome. Not the Spanish civil war. Not Mayor Hague. No, not any one of a hundred stories whose importance now and for the future is self-evident.

The first women's metropolitan one-day tournament to be played in Westchester this season took place today over the Quaker Ridge golf course to the accompaniment of high winds and drenching rain and resulted in a tie for. low gross honors between Mrs. Henry Dietrich of Green Meadow and Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches with respective scores of 40, 45-85 and 41, 44-85.

Abraham Schneider, 32 years old, of. 769 Arnow Avenue, the Bronx, was killed at Eighth Avenue and Forty-first Street just before 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a sedan crashed into his truck and turned it over, pinning him under it.
The wage-hour legislation which New Dealers have succeeded in bringing to the floor of the House for a vote May 23 is one of the most popular measures put forward by the Roosevelt Administration.

Many luncheon parties were held yesterday at the luncheon and fashion revue, "Town and Country" at the formal opening of the Terrace Restaurant at Sherry's, for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Federation.

The Hon. Mrs. Charles Coventry of London is at the Savoy-Plaza. Mrs. David Dows of the SherryNetherland will sail today on the Queen Mary. Mr. and Mrs. Georges de Latour of San Francisco and Beaulieu, Calif., have come to the WaldorfAstoria.
The Syracuse and Rutgers varsity crews will- race here-May 21 on Onondaga Lake over a mile and a-half course, opposite the village of Liverpool, on the east shore.

Miss Mary V. Terwillegar, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Clyde Byron Terwillegar of Steubenville, Ohio, has chosen May 19 as the date of her marriage to Bartram Haines Woodruff, son of Colonel and Mrs. G. Bartram Woodruff of this city. The ceremony will take place in the music chapel of Occidental College, Los Angeles.

Urging a combined effort to "help speed up distribution," the National Retail Dry Goods Association: yesterday issued a "challenge" to its membership in the department, dry goods and specialty store fields to "take eyes off extraneous events and toss aside the stock market columns of the newspapers."

The Belgian National Bank raised today its discount rate from 2 to 4 per cent. The action was believed to be due to an attempt to check the outflow of capital caused by speculative selling of the belga.

Failure of Ohio's General Assembly to make adequate provision for unemployables on relief and Governor Davey's delay in calling a special session to do so have brought the industrial cities of the State to the

Dr. Thomas Louis Fogarty, physician in Brooklyn for the last fortysix years, who had held medical positions under several city administrations, died suddenly yesterday morning at his home, 70 Prospect Park West. He was 70 years old.

Miss Daisy Kohn, 31 years old, a teacher at the James Monroe High School, the Bronx, was discovered hanging in the bathroom of her apartment at the Hotel Tudor, 304 East Forty-second Street, yesterday morning. Detectives of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station listed the death as a suicide.

Adoption of a Federal incorporation or licensing law carrying uniform standards for the protection of investors in corporations engaged in interstate commerce, and the establishment of a central protective agency which would represent security holders in corporate matters, were suggested today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in a report dealing with voluntary reorganizations.

One young woman was killed and two women and three men were injured tonight when the car in which they were riding left the road and turned over several times after a tire blew out at Jacobstown, near here.

There are many new things in the current news, which is not always the case. News of dictators swearing eternal friendship and dedicating themselves to the peace of Europe is not new. It is old stuff, as old as recorded history.

The thirteenth exhibition of work by artists of this city opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Municipal Art Galleries, 3 East Sixty-seventh Street; galleries sponsored by the Municipal Art Committee.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Julie Walcott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Howe Walcott of this place, formerly of Winnetka, to Frederic A. de Peyster 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic A. de Peyster of Winnetka.

In brief exercises attended by more than one hundred guests, Lucius N. Littauer of New York City laid the cornerstone today of the new building to house the Harvard.Graduate School of Public Administratid which he founded with a gift of $2,250,000.
Thirty mentors attended a meeting of the Public Schools Athletic League Basketball Coaches Association at The New York Herald Tribune yesterday.

The principle of "socialized selfcontrol" is needed in the world today, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, dedared yesterday at the opening of the seventy-seventh annual convention of the New York and New Jersey Missionary Society of the Christian Church.
Stricken by a heart attack, Elon Huntington Hooker, father of Mrs. John D.-Rockefeller 3d, died today in his bungalow at the Hotel Huntington, at the age of 69 years.

President Roosevelt asked Congress today for an additional appropriation of $108,000 for the Federal Bureau of Investigation to make up a deficit caused by "unforeseen expenditures" in connection with recent major kidnapping cases. Daniel W. Bell, acting budget director,
The Music Education League will hold its final or interborough contest for vocal soloists tonight in Steinway hall. Advanced vocal students registered in Division XVIII will also be heard.

Miss Margery Osborn, daughter of Mr. arid Mrs. Frederick Osborn of 123 East Seventy-third Street and Garrison, N. Y., has chosen the afternoon of June 17 as the date for her marriage to Josiah Macy Erickson, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Wentworth Erickson of Swampscott, Mass. The wedding will take place in St. Philip's Church, Garrison-onHudson.

When the Emigrant Bank sold to 19 Holding Corp, Samuel Mindlin, president, the parcel at 19 E 108th St, 31x101, for about $30,500, it 'took back two demand mortgages, a p m for $30,332 and a building loan for $16,600.

The Pullman Company in a brief filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Railroad Regulatory Commissions of Idaho, New Hampshire, New Jersey, North Dakota and Utah, was charged with seeking a 10 per cent rate increase to pay dividends.
The barnstorming Montreal Canadiens and the Detroit Red Wings of the National Hockey League dazzled a capacity crowd at Earlscourt tonight, and the Canadiens won the exhibition, 5-4.

Trading in steer hinds and ribs was fairly active and some slaughterers were sold up to Monday's kill. Demand for other classes was fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were strong to slightly higher, lamb lower, fresh pork cuts slightly uneven but mostly steady other classes were mostly unchanged.

Harely L. Clarke will be dropped from the board of directors of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation as the result of orders issuedtoday by Federal Judge William H. Holly authorizing the trustees of two
The State Banking Commission took under advisement today the State's request that the 1938 securities license of H. M. Byllesby Co. be revoked.

At least [Pound]2,500,000 of British gold, it is learned, has been shipped from Paris to Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on the account of the Bank of England or the Exchange Equalization Fund of earmarked British gold in Paris.
Auctioning of the Cortlandt F. Bishop collection of postage stamps was completed yesterday afternoon at the American Art AssociationAnderson Galleries.

The phenomenal success which followed the Woolford Farms through the Florida season and was climaxed with Lawrin's victory in the Kentucky Derby continued unabated at Churchill Downs as Unerring scored narrowly in the Dogwood purse for the stable's second triumph today.

New York University will be represented by a five-man teamin the tenth annual New York State intercollegiate tennis tournament to be held on the Army courts at West Point tomorrow through Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Coach Gerald B. Emerson.

IT started at the luncheon table when Mr. Frank Crowninshield, a veteran explorer in the world of art and literature, interrupted Mr. Jack Doyle, the Sage of Broadway. Mr. Doyle was explaining to a dazed neighbor that War Admiral would run right away from Seabiscuit when Mr. Crowninshield piped up with the remark:

Several residential properties in Westfield, N. J., were reported yesterday by T. B. N. F. Reynolds, brokers, as having been sold. Included was 180 Lincoln Road, which was purchased by G. L. Herrick from the Home Owners Loan Corporation, and 252 Sinclair Place, which was bought by Warren L. Shaub from John I. Thompson.

Enrique A. Berumen of the home club won the veterans' threeweapon fencing championship at the Salle Santelli last night. Berumen finished third in 1936 and was runner-up to Harold Van Buskirk, who did not defend, last year.
The first round 'of elimination play in the twenty-seventh annual Southern women's golf championship was run off today without a casualty, but a couple of the stars had close calls.

Opposition to the Nazi movement continued to spread yesterday as rallies planned by the German-American Bund in Suffern, N. Y., and Lindenhurst, L. I., were prohibited by official action. Today the town board of Babylon, L. I., moved by similar protests, will consider an ordinance to bar parades in which the flags of foreign nations are displayed.

A further vigorou advance in local traction obligations, which, as a group, duplicated their performance of the preceding day, again was the feature of more active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Senate Finance Committee reported today a bill which would remove the $25,000,000,000 limitation from the issuance of Federal bonds. Under the present law the government may not have more than $45,000,000,000 of indebtedness outstanding, of which not more than $25,000,000,000 can be in bonds.

Four members of the United States Wightman Cup team scheduled to face the British women's tennis squad in the international matches June 10 and 11 will sail for England today aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. .

The co-partnership of Goodale Co. has been dissolved by mutual consent. Walter D. Goodale is making his office with M. A. McHale Co., 115 Brdadway. Robert S. Way will continue the investment securities business under the name of Robert S. Way Co. at 115 Broadway.
From the Rover Boys at Camp to the Dead End Kids at San Quentin is not merely a far cry but the two shouts and a holler separating this generation from the last.
Movemente or vessels follow, all dates are May 10, unless specified: At Hampton Roads, May 9: Fanning, Phladelphla. Manila to Southern Phllippines: Parrott, Whipple.

While architects and engineers are busy drawing up the general plan for the vast apartment community which the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company will erect on the former Catholic Protectory site and adjacent blocks in the_ Bronx, realty observers see signs that other large investments in housing and realty will be made shortly by insurance companies.

President Roosevelt disclosed today that he had directed a survey be made of the adequacy of electric power for national defense purposes, and of the possibility of greater coordination of existing facilities in time of war, After a conference on the subject with Basil Manly, vice chairman of the Power Commission, and Louis Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, the President said the study would be the first ever undertaken in this country.

The United States light cruiser Marblehead departed for Amoy, China, this afternoon in response to a consular request for naval protection for Americans under Japanese bombardment in Chinese coastal cities. Carrying a crew of 350 and 30 officers, the Marblehead is expected to reach Amoy about dawn Friday.
The news that Chancellor Adolf Hitler had arrived safely in Berlin and had been received in triumph by his own people brought a sigh of relief from Italian official circles tonight.

Richard E. Berlin gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Mr. and Mrs. Clarence J. Dauphinot Jr., whose marriage took place Saturday in Smithtown, L. I., and for Miss Valerie Lathrop and Bennett Ryan, who will be married here tomorrow. Mrs. Dauphinot is the former Miss Nancy White.
The oil tanker Deroche arrived today carry. ing the sailing yacht Santana, which W. L. Stewart Jr., her owner; will sail in the race from Newport to Bermuda in June.

Angry House Repuplicans, meeting in conference toddy on the Administration's pump-priming Recovery Bill, denounced the program as "another New Deal raid on the Treasury" that threatened to "extend the misery of unemployment" and "plunge the nation into cataclysmic inflation."

The search for assets to repay the creditors of the bankrupt firm of Richard Whitney Co. extended yesterday to the individual assets of Richard Whitney's partners, all of whom likewise have declared themselves bankrupt.

The St. John's University golf team defeated the New York University linksmen, 5 1/2 to 1/2, over the Hillcrest links in Jamaica yesterday. Russell Ebbets and Joe Parillo of St. John's recorded their sixth consecutive success in foursomes competition this season when they defeated Fred Fiore and Ed Milton. 5 and 4.
The twelve-room English-style house at 886 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Philip Gill to William J. Grace. The Bulkley Horton Company, broker, negotiated the sale.

Mrs. Wanda Bergman of the Badminton Club of Westport, Conn., and William Markham of the Old Sixty-ninth Badminton Club, New York, top the respective lists of the women's and men's rankings of the Metropolitan Badminton Association, according to an announcement yesterday.

Mrs. Samuel Seabury of East Hampton, L. I., was elected president of the Garden Club of America without opposition today at the annual ballooting of 1,200 members. The national convention is being held here.

The League of Nations Council, in another secret meeting, deferred tonight until Thursday its public discussion of the Ethiopian question so that Haille Selassie might have time to come here to defend in person his title of Emperor.

ADAMS, JULIA E. (Nov. 2, 1937). Gross assets, $47,586; net, $31,878. To Clara Taylor, aunt, and William L. Taylor. uncle, one-half residue each. Chief assets, real estate, $25,000.' Maurice Nagler, attorney, 36 W. 44th St.

David S. Murden, Republican chairman of the town of Cortlandt and former chairman of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors, announced today his candidacy for county president although his town committee last night endorsed William F.

Lowell Thomas, author and radio commentator, was yesterday reelected president of the Advertising Club of New York at the annual election held at the club, 23 Park Avenue. His election was uncontested.

Tomorrow will be National Hospital Day, the 118th anniversary of the birth of Florence Nightingale, founder of modern nursing. The ninety-two member hospitals of the United Hospital Fund here will celebrate the day, as will many other American and numerous foreign hospitals.
ALLEN'S SYNONYMS AND ANTONYMS, by F. Sturgis Allen. (Harper, $3.) A revised and enlarged edition, edited by T. H. Vail Motter.

The Presbyterians of New York City play a part in its social services out of all proportion to their numbers, and are entitled to the gratitude of the city for their services, Mayor La Guardia declared last night at a dinner at the Hotel Astor marking the 200th anniversary of the New York Presbytery.

Edward Strecker, a leading banker of the Troy area, who had been associated fifty-eight years with the Union National Bank of Troy, died last night at his home here after an illness of four years. His age was 71. Mr. Strecker, a former president of the bank, was chairman of the board of directors at the time of his death.

Clint Brown, ace relief pitcher for the White Sox, underwent an operation today for the removal of a chipped bone in his salary arm. "The operation was very successful," said Dr. Phil Kreuscher, "the bone chip being removed without trouble.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today another opinion by Carman G. Blough, its chief accountant, holding that dividends on a corporation's own stock held in its treasury or in sinking or other special funds should not be included in income.

Sing Sing terms of ten to twenty years each were imposed yesterday by Judge Owen W. Bohan in General Sessions on two Negroes, known as the "torture robbers." They had pleaded guilty to'thirddegree robbery on the complaint of George Bronson of 350 West 118th Street.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 9: BRIGADIER GENERAL Hartshorn, E. S., one month's leave, Mat 12.

Penn State's lacrosse team defeated Cornell today, 13 to 5, for its third straight victory of the season. Although Bob Wiggins scored the first goal for Cornell after three minutes of play, Wuenschel and Snook tallied in. quick succession for Penn State, and the Lions were never again behind.
Members-elect of the New York Stock Exchange's board of governors will meet tomorrow or Friday morning to decide on the name of a president pro term. William McC.

The United States Government has formally protested the application to American citizens of the Reich decree of April 28 ordering Jews of all nationalities to declare their property holdings in Germany.

Holding "it is wiser -to bear with scandal- mongering than to extend the criminal law to become an instrument of oppression." Judge James Garrett Wallace of General Sessions dismissed yesterday three indictments against Robert Edward Edmondson, elderly pamphleteer, which alleged he had libeled Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor;

At the instance of former Governor Alfred E. smith,. leaders of the Constitutional Convention today set July 29 as the tentative date for adjournment. A resolution fixing that date was introduced from the floor by Perley A. Pilcher,

The George Schlegel orchid nursery, reputed to be the third ranking nursery of its kind in the United States, has been sold to Floral Gardens, Inc., for $60,450, according to an accounting filed yesterday in Supreme Court by Louis W. Stotesbury as trustee of a trust created for Mr. Schlegel in 1922.
William Radcliffe, an authority on fishing and its history, died today at Deal, Kent, at the age of 81. His "Fishing From Earliest Times," proved/ one of the best sellers among sports books.
A nine-room Colonial-style home on Chalford Lane in the estates of Cotswold development in the vicinity of Scarsdale, Westchester County, has been sold to Oscar S. Holmgren, a New York attorney.

An $85,000 first mortgage for 10 years with interest at 4 1/2% and 5% has been placed on the one-story business building at.3,413425 Jerome Ave, the Bronx. The Senior Construction Corp. Is the owner of the structure. The Prudential Life Insurance Co. of America is the mortgagee. Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., negotiated the loan.

Changes in the program for the 100-yard dash and the 120-yard high hurdles have been voted by the championship committee for the sixty- second annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. outdoor track and field championships to be held at Randalls Island Stadium June 3 and 4.

Edward Loughran, a plumbing contractor, prominent figure in the Kingston Lodge of Elks and a brother of Judge John T. Loughran of the State Court -of Appeals in Albany, died here Saturday night in Benedictine Hospital, in his fiftyfirst year.

Just when it appeared their winning streak might be stopped at six straight the Senators came from behind to score three runs with two out in the last half of the eighth and edge out the Browns today, 8 to 6.

The Manhasset Stable sent tb the races at Belmont Park yesterday a good colt in Thingumabob, a bay son of Boojum and Refine, who marked his debut by easily taking the Forest Hills Purse at four and half furlongs through the Widener chute in a large field of juveniles.
After firming. up slightly in the forenoon yesterday the stock market was called on to absorb a moderate amount of piofit-taking and the list gave ground gradually and closed irregularly lower.

The gold medal of the Mining and Metallurgical Society of America was awarded last night to Charles Arthur Banks of Vancouver, B. C., for the "application of aerial transportation to the development of remote mining regions."

The total of outstanding dollar acceptances declined $14,034,375 in April :to $278,707,940 at the end of that month, the lowest figure in about twenty-one years, according to the monthly survey issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Traffic through the Panama Canal declined during April, the War Department announced in its monthly report' today.

Yesterday's Government crop report indicates, as was expected, an unusually large wheat crop. The Agricultural Department estimates the 1938 yield of Winter-sown wheat at 754,153,000 bushels, as against 725,707,000 foreshadowed a month ago and 685,102,000 actually harvested in 1937. This, if the.

Dr. Hugo Eckener, an excellent man anal outstanding dirigible expert, is in Washington in an effort to obtain from this government the release of enough helium to put and maintain Germany's new Zeppelin in commission.

Sir Percy Bates, chairman of the Cunard White Star Line; the Earl of Ranfurly, Lord Ventry, Sir George Davies, Claude Graham White, Sir Derrick Wernher, Lady Essendon, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gould, Mrs. Cass Gilbert, Mrs. Lloyd B. Sanderson, Lady Bailey.

The engagement and approaching marriage has been announced of Miss Betty Durrell of Brooklyn and Stratton, Me., daughter of Mrs. Oramendal Blanchard of Stratton, and of Clifton F. Durrell of Wilton, Me., to Jay S. Morris of Paterson, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bower J. Morris of Gouverneur, N. Y. The wedding will take place June 30.

Nicolas Petrescu-Comnen, the Rumanian Foreign Minister, in a talk with Georges Bonnet, the French Foreign Minister, today threatened, according to French sources, Rumania's withdrawal from the League of Nations if the League Council's committee of three-which includes France and Britain-insisted that he appear before it to answer charges made in a World Jewish Congress petition.

Reductions in prices for crude oil were announced yesterday by two companies. The Ohio Oil Company cut the price it will pay for heavy crude oil in the Grass Creek field in Wyoming from 62 to 50 cents a barrel.

Daniel Fitzgerald of Durham, N. H., a former soldier with the Government forces in Spain, who arrived as a passenger on the President Harding on Saturday, received a release from the Department of Security of the Spanish Government in Barcelona and did not escape from Spain with several stowaways on the ship as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES on May 8.
The Athletics today announced the sale of Russ Peters, an infielder, to Atlanta of the Southern Association. The price was not announced.

The Delaware Hudson Company has been managed by two committees of directors since L. F. Loree, its former president, went on indefinite leave last October, E. Roland Harriman, a director, disclosed at the annual meeting yesterday. Mr. Loree's resignations as president and a director recently were announced.
The way things look now, the residents of North Tarrytown might have to spend an indefinite number of Tuesday evenings trying to elect trustees to the local School Board.
