Stirred by the protest of the United Fur Manufacturers Association against the alleged "reign of terror" that has marked the strike of 15,000 fur workers conducted by the International Fur Workers Union, Communist-dominated affiliate of the C. I. O.,

German and Italian propaganda broadcasts to Argentina hinder rather than help attempts of those countries to market goods in the Argentine, Fernando M. Carries, submanager of the Buenos Aires branch of the National City

Louise Muldener, an actress who supported many of the great stars of tragedy in her sixty years' association with the American theatre and who was one of the pioneer members of the Women's Professional League, died yesterday morning at Lenox Hill Hospital, where she had been a patient under the care of the Actors Fund of America. Her age was 84.

The Yankees didn't play yesterday. For the second straight day gloomy skies, pouring forth rain, forced a postponement of a scheduled meeting with the White Sox, piling up two double-headers on the next visit of Jimmy Dykes's clan here June 7, 8 and 9.

Homer Martin, confronted with factional disputes in the United Automobile Workers of America, succeeded today in centralizing in the executive board punitive power to deal with instigators of "wildcat" strikes.

James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, was pictured yesterday as a power behind Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, in testimony intended to show a connection between city inspectors and the union.

James W. Kiernan was elected vice president of Best Co. at a meeting yesterday of the board of directors of the store. He has been with Best's since the latter part of 1930 and has been its assistant superintendent since December, 1931.

The management division of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx will meet Thursday at the East 148th street Restaurant. Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, will be the guest speaker.

After an ownership of over thirty years by the Carlson' family, the heirs of the late Francis A. Carlson have sold to Oscar Rosenbaum the six-story apartient house on the southeast corner of 156th Street and Broadway, known as 3,750 Broadway.

Purchases approximating $200,000 were made yesterday by the buyers of Goldblatt Brothers, Chicago, who are now in the market here to purchase $2,000,000 worth of goods for "Nathan Goldblatt Week," it was stated yesterday by Jack Gordon, general merchandise manager.

President Roosevelt took personal charge today of the controversy over the proposed sale of helium to Germany. He discussed legal aspects of the problem with Robert H. Jackson, Solicitor General, and said at his press conference later that he would pursue the matter further tomorrow with General Malin Craig, Army Chief of Staff; Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations; Secretary Ickes and Mr. Jackson.
The British Government announced in the House of Commons today that it was considering the establishment of an air service across the Pacific Ocean from Canada to New Zealand.

The engagement was announced here today of Yehudi Menuhin, young violinist, who won fame as a mere boy, and Miss Nola Nicholas of Melbourne, Australia, to whom he proposed by telephone from Holland while on a tour there.

An income of $21,150,077 from sales of newsprint and pulp was reported today by the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd. for 1937, compared with $14,662,752 in 1936. Income from power sales increased from $312,134 to $604,704.

Plans to construct about twothirds of the new building of the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany at York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street, adjacent to the New York Hospital, were announced yesterday by Charles H. Russell, chairman of the building fund campaign.

The fortress of Madrid appears as strong today as it has ever been. This correspondent has spent the day in the lines, finding the same troops holding therm in positions better fortified than they were three months ago.

Only War Admiral and Seabiscuit could add more luster to tomorrow's Preakness prelude at Pimlico, the thirtyfourth running of the $20,000 added Dixie Handicap in which fourteen of the country's best handicap
A proxy battle, which preceded the annual meeting of Interstate Department Stores yesterday at the company's offices at 111 Eighth Avenue, drew a record attendance of stockholders.

The semi-annual conference of the Long Island Real Estate Board will be held today in the Garden City Hotel, Garden City. Among the speakers at the luncheon session will be Frank G. Arnold, president of the Nebraska Federation of County Taxpayers Leagues.

Announcing the award of the first contract for an amusement concession at the 1939 World's Fair, Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, outlined yesterday plans for the 280-acre recreation area.

Lashed by a stinging gale that swept off the lake, and chilled still further by the frigid stares from Colonel Bill Terry and his coldly methodical Giants, the Cubs congealed completely today as they dropped the concluding engagement of their two-game series with the front-running National League champions.
Elbert G. Bennett of Ogden, Utah, and Percy J. Ebbott of New York were elected today new directors of the Kansas City SouthernRailway. Both are bankers.

L. R. McGregor, Australian Trade Commissioner in Canada who has been stationed in Toronto since 1930, has been appointed Commissioner General in the United States, a post vacant since 1930 when it was relinquished by Herbert Brookes to effect an economy for

The Federal National Mortgage Association,. whose capital stock is owned by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, will offer on. May 18 $25,000,000 of its 2 per cent notes maturing in five years, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, announced tonight.

An Italian spokesman, Rafaele Montagna, began today the presentation of his government's case in the Moroccan phosphate suit before the World Court here after the French spokesman had concluded his plea.

Miss Elinore Humphreys, daughter of George F. Humphreys of Spring Brook Road, this place, and the late Mrs. Humphreys, was married to Theodore Mercer Emory this afternoon in the rectory of the Church of the Assumption here. The Rev. Gabriel Stone performed the ceremony.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial reviewing the article in the May issue of Harper's by President Conant invites an explanation. Dr. Conant's plea for scholarships for superior students states the matter accurately. That many excellent boys are unable to attend college because they have insufficient funds is not news.

Florence Johns, in 35 Grant Ave, for Mrs. M. Ruesch; R. D. Bribbon, in 30 McKinley Ave. for C. F. Reynolds; White Plains rentals by the Robert E. Farley Organization, broker. James Craig, through Adams Realty Service, in 156 Inwood Ave, Hartsdale; Mrs. Ada Cauzza, in 20 Lee Ave, Scarsdale; rentals by Raymond R. Beatty Management, Inc., broker.
Albert Edward Kennedy, attorney and sportsman, died at his home in Haverford yesterday after an illness of ten days. He was 69 years old.
President Roosevelt discussed legal aspects of the proposed exportation of helium to Germany with Robert H. Jackson, Solicitor General, and the proposed survey of electric power resources of the

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation in April amounted to 501,972 tons, compared with 572,199 tons in the preceding month and 1,343,644 in April, 1937.

Fifteen freshmen in Columbia College have been elected to the Van Am Society, student honor organization, it was announced yesterday by Lloyd Taylor, a junior, president of the group. Election of Arthur Wolfe as undergraduate manager of the Columbia University band for the next academic year was made public by Wallace S. Jones, retiring head.

The four-week strike of warehouse employes of four midcity department stores was settled tonight. The warehousemen will return to their jobs tomorrow morning, along with members of other unions who had refused to cross picket lines during the strike.
Merritt W. Harper, Professor of Animal Husbandry in the "New York State College of Agriculture at Cornell University, died at his home here last night. He was 60 years old.

The Sixth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals denied to the National Labor Relations Board today an enforcement order against the Thompson Products Company of Cleveland, Ohio, and declared that the Board's finding in the case tended to "promote discord among employers and employes.

Dr. Everett Field Darling of. Redding Ridge, Conn,, a specialist -in diseases of the eye, with offices at 17 East Thirty-eighth Street,- died Monday in St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 63 years, after a month's illness.

Stocks receded from fractional gains and closed irregularly lower; turnover, 1,044,140 shares. Transit bonds continued strong, United States Government and other issues higher and quiet; transactions, $7,436,175.

Mrs. Thomas W. Fitzgerald of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marjorie Kenyon, to Richard Channing Moore, son of Mrs. T. Channing Moore of Bronxville, N. Y., and the late Mr. Moore.

Five years ago, if any one had forecast what is taking place at the 101st session of the Council of the League of Nations, he would have been brushed aside as a congenital cynic. Then the ,Soviet Government was deriding the League as a hopelessly bourgeois institution, a closed corporation of capitalist states.
Manufacturers selling trimmings to the cloak and suit trade will strongly oppose any change from a net to a discount basis, which reports indicate is wanted by the
Starting next week, leading radio set manufacturers will begin to introduce new lines and outline their advertising campaigns for the coming season.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States for the week ended May 5 increased in three out of five trade groups, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet. The two groups which recorded declines were wholesaling and commercial service. Detailed comparisons are shown in the following table:
The Reds made hits count today and, led by the four-out-of-five performance of Dusty Cooke, routed Philadelphia, 7 to 3, before a chilled crowd of 1,133.
The Royals made a clean sweep of their International League series with Jersey City by taking the fourth game, 9-4, today, on a ten-hit attack against three pitchers.
Relative steadiness' in foreign markets, with an early improvement in stocks here, stiffened prices on the Cotton Exchange for a time yesterday and the July sold above 8 3/4 cents a pound.

Miss Eleanor Claudia Brennan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Brennan of this city, was married to Richard Justin Leonard, son of Mr; sand Mrs. Daniel J. Leonard, also of Elizabeth, this morning in St. Genevieve's Roman Catholic Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John H. McManus, the pastor.
Cabinet leaders' discussions in two meetings today failed to get decisions on a number of proposals for speeding up French industry and reorganizing national economy.
Town Hall is publishing a pamphlet containing the series of addresses given- at the annual Town Hall Celebrities Luncheon at the Hotel Astor on April 28.

Sixty feature-length "action" pictures will be released by Warner Brothers next season, it was announced yesterday by Gradwell L. Sears, general manager of distribution, at the second session of a three-day convention of Eastern and Canadian sales representatives in the Roosevelt Hotel,
The Westchester County grand jury voted today a first degree manslaughter indictment against Mrs. Genevieve Horton, 39 years old, a practical nurse, of 227 Buena Vista Avenue, Yonkers.

Ralph Thompson Crane, one of the nation's leading investment bankers, who was vice president and a director of the investment banking house of Brown Harriman Co., Inc., 63 Wall Street, New York, died suddenly here of a heart attack this morning in his home at 42 Highland Avenue. His age was 59. When Mr. Crane went to his office yesterday he had seemed in good health.

Dwight Deere Wiman, who likes to bob up in the Spring with a musical, is offering tonight his contribution for 1938-"I Married an Angel." With words and music by Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hartit was they who collaborated on Mr. Wiman's "On Your Toes" (with George Abbott) and "Babes in Arms"-itis- based on a Hungarian play by John Vaszary.

The twenty-one-story loft and store building and the adjoining four-story loft structure comprising the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street were sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. They were bought in by the International Fur Merchants, Inc., for $741,250.
Although the number of visiting buyers reported in. the market during the week ended yesterday was considerably less than in the preceding week, the total was ahead of the corresponding week a year

Dr. Terry M. Townsend of this city was named president-elect and first vice president of the Medical Society of the State of New York at the annual meeting of the society's House of Delegates in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Establishment of a board of three to stabilize labor conditions in the maritime industry and act with very limited powers temporarily for mediation and arbitration of disputes was approved by the Senate today without a record vote in passing an amendment to the proposed new Merchant Marine Act.

Any effort by the railroads to reduce the wages of employes on their marine equipment in the ports of New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Norfolk will be opposed by the Railroad Marine Workers, Local 933-5, it was announced yesterday by Patrick F. Mulqueen, business manager.

The world heavyweight championship battle between Joe Louis, the titleholder, and Max Schmeling, former champion, will be formally signed and sealed today-ready for delivery in the Yankee Stadium on the night of June 22.

The Massie Medal for outstanding work in the restoration, preservation and beautification of Virginia was presented to Mrs. George Sloane of Warrenton at a banquet tonight under the auspices of the Garden Clubs of Virginia, which is holding its annual convention here. Mrs.

Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, Urged today that President Roosevelt call a national conference of leaders in business, labor, finance, agriculture and government to "end the petty bickering over cure-alls" and to use their combined efforts to "lead the nation out of the economic wilderness in which lt finds itself."

Convention, Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 10 A. M. Address by Mayor La Guardia at noon. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Sculpture: Changes in Taste," Edwin L. M. Taggart, 11 A. M.; European decorative arts (general tour), 2 P. M.

Pleasure before business animated the General Federation of Women's Clubs as its triennial convention opened here tonight. Pomp and glitter marked the scene in the new municipal auditorium, where a historical fantasy supplemented the customary welcoming addresses to the many hundreds of women from practically every State in the Union.

The marriage of Miss Sedohr Barbara Rhodes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Travis Rhodes of this city, to Thomas Hendrick Allen, son of Judge William Allen of the Court of General Sessions, will take place on May 28 in the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, this city.

The State Supreme Court today delayed until after the primary election on May 17 the Dauphin County grand jury investigation into campaign charges of bribery, graft and coercion against Democratic party leaders and Earle administration officials.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has acquired since Jan. 1 $984,000 of tenyear convertible 4 1/2 per cent debentures, due on Jan. 1, 1939, at a cost of $844,600, and has reduced its bank loans by $403,485, according to the annual report for 1937,

Colonel Keith Ryan of the Veterans Administration, and Mrs. Ryan of Kecoughtan,Va., have announced to friends here the engagement of. their daughter, Miss Joanne Ryan, to Elbert Chauncey Anderson, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. P. Chauncey Anderson of this city.

Miss Helen Hayes Peffer, managing editor of Refrigerating Engineering, has been elected president of the Advertisnig Women of New York, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Louis W. Rogers, retiring president.
Vera K. Maxwell, in 1,045 Park Ave; Henry Wynkoop, in 192 E 75th St; Mrs. Jean B. Lambrecht, in 220 E 73d St; Wilbur H. Mehlkorn, David Haynes, in 15 E 48th St; Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc., broker.
The Federal Labor Board maintained silence today in regard to the strike at the Ford plant in Mexico City which is expected to continue for a considerable time.

From a point of view which is both disinterested and expert, the Bank for International Settlements has surveyed the course of business in this country and drawn the conclusion that it is "infinitely difficult" to direct the trend of economic life by governmental planning.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent two hours yesterday with four other judges -in selecting the prize-winning 15 from 3,026 "Drive Safely" posters entered in. a national' contest sponsored by Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc.,'in an effort to reduce the highway accident toll.

Miss Helen Hayes Peffer, managing editor of Refrigerating Engineering, has been elected president of the Advertisnig Women of New York, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Louis W. Rogers, retiring president.
Vera K. Maxwell, in 1,045 Park Ave; Henry Wynkoop, in 192 E 75th St; Mrs. Jean B. Lambrecht, in 220 E 73d St; Wilbur H. Mehlkorn, David Haynes, in 15 E 48th St; Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc., broker.
The Federal Labor Board maintained silence today in regard to the strike at the Ford plant in Mexico City which is expected to continue for a considerable time.

From a point of view which is both disinterested and expert, the Bank for International Settlements has surveyed the course of business in this country and drawn the conclusion that it is "infinitely difficult" to direct the trend of economic life by governmental planning.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent two hours yesterday with four other judges -in selecting the prize-winning 15 from 3,026 "Drive Safely" posters entered in. a national' contest sponsored by Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc.,'in an effort to reduce the highway accident toll.

Four new directors of the Missouri Pacific Railroad were elected today at the annual meeting of stockholders here. Eight new directors of a subsidiary, the (New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway, were chosen at a meeting of stockholders in New Orleans.

Before an audience of 16-to-21year-old "corporation" executives, Charles R. Hook, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, defended last night the American system of business endeavor and warned that youth's greatest current--concern was to "avoid throwing away what is rightfully yours--the heritage of opportunity under private enterprise--for something vague that does not really exist."
Great Britain's youthful Davis Cup team just managed to turn back Rumania, 3 matches to 2, in the first-round series of the European zone competition today.

James Laurence McIntosh, 45year-old vice president of the Dictaphone Corporation, 420 Lexington Avenue, at Forty-fourth Street, fell or jumped to his death shortly before 1 P. M. yesterday- from his seventh-floor office. His body landed on a two-story extension roof in the rear of the building.

Miss Helene Marie von Czoernig, daughter of Baron and Baroness Carl von Czoernig of Weltvreten, Radnor, was married this afternoon to Charles Richard Arenschield Jr. of Philadelphia, son of Mr.and Mrs. Charles R. Arenschield of Washington.

Captain Eddie V. Rickenbacker and Richard T. Merrill will fly a modern Eastern Air Lines mail-passengerexpress plane from Newark to Washington in eighty minutes on Sunday afternoon,in celebration of the twentieth anniversary of the first scheduled Air mail in this country which covered the same distance in three hours and twenty minutes, Postmaster General Farlev announced today.

Miss Marjorie M. Lovett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Lovett of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to Chester L. Duff Jr. of Newark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Duff of Syracuse, N. Y., which will take place the afternoon of May 28 in the Old Bergen Reformed Church in Jersey City.

The Literary Digest, which suspended early this year after having been published since 1890, has been sold, and will be merged with the magazine Time, it was announced yesterday by Ralph MeAllister Ingersoll, publisher of the latter weekly.

As a result of the recent weakness in the beiga, shipments of gold from Belgfum to this country were resumed yesterday. A shipment of $896,Q00 of the metal was engaged, according to the Federal Reserve Bank This transfer follows shipments of $6,200,000 to this country between March 22 and April 1.

The last vestige of the control over the Kansas City Southern Railway once exercised by 0. P. and M. J. Van Sweringen has been ended by the resignation from the railway's board of Kenneth D. Steere, a partner in Paine, Webber Co., former brokers for the Van Sweringens.

Edward Holle, 24-year-old mechanic, Of 344 Sanford Street, is being held here for arraignment tomorrow on a charge of murdering Sophie Kujat, 23, whose body, weighted with automobile tire chains, was found in the Passaic River last Saturday, several weeks after she had disappeared from her home at 647 South Seventeenth Street, Newark.

Scoring five runs with two out in the ninth inning, the Newark Bears beat Toronto, 8 to 7, today. The Maple Leafs went into a 3-1 lead in the first inning by driving John Lindell to cover, and were in front until the ninth.

The Yankees had the world's champion heavyweight' fighterJoe Louis, as their guest yesterday at the Stadium, and they made him feel at home by doing some heavyweight hitting to repulse the In- dians, who, were invading the Bronx for the first time this season.

" Palestine Week" is to be observed in Iraq, starting tomorrow, which is a Moslem holiday, as the birthday of the prophet Mohammed. Moslems here are devoting the week to protest against the partition plan for Palestire and the British policy there.

Maximum economies possible through cooperation between the Canadian National and Canadian Pacific Railways were placed today at $10,000,000 a year by S. W. Fairweather, chief of the Canadian National's Bureau of Economics, who testified before the special Senate committee on the railway condition of Canada.

At today's final session of the convention of B'nai B'rith the delegates voted full authorization to its executive committee to carry out "aggressively" during the next three years a program of resistance to democracy's three "mortal enemies," communism, fascism and nazism.
The sale at auction of the Manbattan Towers Hotel at 2,162-68 Broadway, scheduled to be held yesterday, was adjourned by Joab H. Banton, referee, until May 20.

An indictment charging evasion of income taxes and the filing of a false inincome-tax return for 1935 was returned yesterday by the Federal grand jury in Newark against Joseph A. Corio, Common Pleas Court judge of Atlantic County, it was disclosed here today by Assistant United States Attorney William A. Smith.

Fifty African chieftains and tribal leaders in native dress pledged homage and fidelity to Premier Benito Mussblini today at a ceremony marking the second anniversary of the founding of the modern Italian empire.

Constitutional rule has utterly disappeared in many of the dictator-controlled nations of the world, said Senor Dr. Pedro Martinez Fraga, Ambassador from Cuba, in a speech made today at the annual luncheon of the international and comparative law section of the American Bar Association.

Spokesmen for the coat and suit industry, testifying today at a hearing before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Foreign and Interstate Commerce, on the "Truth-in-Fabrics" Bill, declared that the measure, if enacted, would sharply curtail activity in the industry and would react to the detriment of the consuming public.

With 98 per cent of Calcutta's burlap mills signed to an agreement to restrict operations to forty-five hours a week, final action on the pact was postponed yesterday to next Tuesday, according to cables received here yesterday by C. E. Rockstroh Co. The postponement was made,
A four-run drive in# the first inning, featured by Nelligan's triple, marked the 7-5 victory of Williams over Wesleyan in their Little Three battle today.
It was the biggest check the teller had ever seen. It was 5 feet long and 201/2 inches wide, and instructed the Banque Canadienne Nationale to pay Eddy Larivee $150.

Most of the nearly 2,500 employes of the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company here struck today in protest against a 10 per cent wage cut. In holiday mood, union workers, estimated by officials of the C. I. O.-atfiliated Textile Workers Organizing Committee to number nearly 1,000, paraded pant the plant instead of entering the gates at the usual hour this morning.

President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University announced yesterday the aw -d of 170 fellowships and scholarships for 1938-39, with a total value of more than $150,000. Twenty-one alternates were also named.
President Roosevelt decided today that he was powerless to override the judgment of any one of- six Cabinet officers and direct the sale of helium to Germany. Accordingly,

At its last scheduled meeting yesterday, the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange adopted a resolution recording its "gratitude to Charles R. Gay and its respect and warm affection for him."

Herman A. Speh, president of the Drygak Corporation, member of the Binghamton Board of Education, former president- of the local Chamber of Commerce and one of "little business men" called to Washington by President Roosevelt, died here today after an operation for an abdominal infection. He was 55 years old.

A dozen Princeton freshmen spent two hours in Journal.Square, Jersey City, early last evening passing out handbills denouncing Mayor Frank Hague for his alleged violations of the right of free speech, and advertising the antiHague rally to be held on the Princeton campus this evening.

GLORIA APAREL SHOPS, INC., 225 W. 34th St.-Voluntary proceeding under section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $83,019 and assets of $94,475. The debtor through affiliated operating companies conducts stores In Atlanta, Ga.; Birmingham. Ala., and Knoxville, Tenn.

Charles A. Thayer of the R. T. French Company, Rochester, N. Y., was re-elected president of the American Spice Trade Association at the concluding business session of the group's annual two-day conventino in the Hotel Astor yesterday.

A year's deadlock over the selection of a Bishop Coadjutor for the Episcopal Diocese of Central New York ended today with the election of the Rev. Malcolm E. Peabody, rector of St. Paul's Church at Chestnut Hill,

Funds for the administration of unemployment insurance here virtually are exhausted, officials of the division of placement and unemployment insurance- of the State Labor Department reported last night.

May 21 is the new closing date for "Hooray for What!" On Tuesday the show had been announced to end its engagement on June 1. "The Women" apparently can't make up its mind. Scheduled originally to close April 23, the show didn't. Scheduled to close this coming Saturday night; it won't.

Following closely the downward trend in general business and advertising linage, the printing industry in New York has experienced an approximate decline of 15 per cent since the start of year, executives of leading companies reported here yesterday.

The United States Government has suggested that the first meeting of the intergovernmental committee to facilitate the emigration of political refugees from Germany arid Austria be held on July 6 at Evian, France, the State Department announced tonight.
The Federal Power Commission is making a series of court moves in which it seeks to circumvent a judicial short cut frequently used by private utility companies named in the commission's orders.

The Senate today passed without a record vote a bill amending the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 designed to stabilize and stimulate the shipping industry and make it an active agency for national defense.

Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York, addressing the Amalgamated Clothing Workers convention today, emphatically denied that the National Labor Relations Act was onesided and that it discriminated against employers and in favor of labor

Following member of the force is relieved from duty and retired from the police force and is placed on the roll of the pension fund: On his own application-To take effect 12 midnight, May 9: PATROLMAN-Henry J. Coleman, 19th Division, office of the chief inspector, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed OCt. 28, 1912.

Pupils of the Lenox School presented a musical version of "The Pied Piper of Hamelin" last night in the auditorium of the school at 52 East Seventy-eighth Street. The operetta in two acts was composed and directed by Miss Marjorie Otis, head of the music department.

Aided by a triple play and five Philadelphia errors, the Browns today ended an eight-game losing streak by beating the Athletics, 9 to 5. The triple play camen in the second frame after the Mackmen had filled the bases on a single and two passes.

The unions affiliated with the Allied Printing Trades Council of Greater New York, headed by Vincent J. Ferris, let it be known yesterday that they would not permit the Newspaper Guild to encroach upon their jurisdictions by enrolling workers who, though not affiliated with any of the unions in question, are regarded, nevertheless, as potential members and come within the jurisdictions granted to the unions under American Federation of Labor charters.

The Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company told Congress today that immediate legislation was necessary to prevent the concern from being eliminated as a competitor in the foreign radio communications field.

A committee of four experts of the Danubian Commission, after inspectiVg the Sulina Canal on the Danube, has announced that it will be unnavigable in the very near future because mud will prevent ships from passing to the Black Sea.

Glittering with diamonds, including the great Kohinoor, and wearing a gown of silver lame, Queen Elizabeth sat tonight beside King George on a dais in the white and gold ballroom of Buckingham Palace while for two hours they received guests of their first court season.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved a declaration by the Iowa Power and Light Company of the North American Company systern, covering the sale to seven institutional investors, at 1023/4 and accrued interest,
Listing of 350,000 shares of Basic Dolomite, Inc., common stock, $1 par value, has been approved by the New York Curb Exchange.

Quell McKeever, corporation lawyer, senior partner of the law firm of Isham, Lincoln Beale of 72 West Adams Street, Chicago, died early yesterday at his home; 271 Madison Avenue, this city. He was 66.

Thomas Mann, exiled German author, suggested last night at a dinner of the American Guild for German Cultural Freedom at the Town Hall Club, which was given in his honor, that this organization should become an intellectual clearing house for true German culture and that the New York World's Fair should offer an opportunity for its display.

Fred R. Carlson, treasurer of the North Bellmore Fire Department for the last six years, is being held in the Nassau County jail here today pending grand jury action on charges of grand larceny and forgery filed against him last night by-the department's board of trustees.

Four "emergency" resolutions, centering attention of delegates on that many topical problems, comprised the first item of new business as the triennial convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs swung into a business session this morning.

Warren H. Smith has been appointed assistant traffic manager of the Boston-Maine-Central. Vermont Airways, subsidiary of the Boston Maine, Maine Central and Central Vermont Railways. He succeeds J. V. Sheehan, general passenger agent, resigned.

Reliable quarters tonight reported that Ambassador Francisco Castillo Najera was returning from Washington to Mexico with a "conciliatory formula" advanced by the United. States for settlement of the $400,000,000 oil industry controversy.

Five of the thirty-five process servers dropped from the District Attorney's staff when Thomas E. Dewey took office Jan. 1 have been reinstated it was disclosed yesterday when an action to compel the reinstatement of thirteen others came up for a hearing before Supreme Court Justico Salvatore. A. Cotillo. The hearing was adjourned until May 25.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Harrison Kneale- of Oyster Harbors, Cape Cod, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Harrison Kneale, to James Alexander Hetherington 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Fenton Hetherington of Bound Brook, N. J.
The Babylon Town Board adopted today an ordinance that makes it necessary to obtain a permit before any assembly in the unincorporated sections of the township may be held.

Summer is i-cumen in and with it one of the- best musical comedies for many seasons. "I Married An Angel," which opened at the Shubert last evening, perches on the top shelf of the Rodgers and Hart music cabinet.

Welfare Commissioner William Hodson, whose department includes 11:000 city workers, formulated yesterday rules of collective bargaining intended to establish in his department "a sound and progressive employer-employe relationship directly in line with the ideals of the administration of Mayor La Guardia."
A number of leases for quarters in buildings on Broadway were among the - contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday.

A report of T. A. Hamilton and M. E. Miller, examiners for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which takes issue with the findings of an examiner of the Interstate Commerce Commission and estimates future net earnings of the Western Pacific

Samuel J. Weiss of 115 Central Park West and David Goldberg of 241 Central Park West, former officials of Donnie Frocks, Inc., of 254 West Thirty-fifth Street, were sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions to indeterminate terms, not to exceed three years, in the penitentiary for conspiracy and the filing of false franchise tax and State income tax returns.

The gardens at Ikaraaou, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Scheepers, and at Rynwood, that of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Salvage, both -in Brookville, L. I., will be opened to the public on Saturday and Sunday afternoons to assist the Seamen's Church Institute tof New York.

Plana have been completed by Miss Dorcas Brownell Freeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clayton E. Freeman of Glen Ridge, for her marriage to Dr. Harrison Rawlings Wesson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Wesson of Lawrenceville, Va., which will take place the afternoon of June 4 at the home of her parents.
A list of 113 awards to Columbia varsity and freshman athletes, managers and managerial candidates was announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, athletics manager.

Alexander Kerensky, former Russian Premier and leader of the revolution that brought the downifall of the Czarist regime, sailed yesterday for England on the Queen Mary after a three-month lecture tour of the United States.
A Jewish appeal to the League of Nations regarding the treatment of Jews in Rumania has been settled by direct negotiation, it was learned in official quarters tonight.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Johnson of 840 Park Avenue and Palm Beach have announced the engagement of Mrs. Johnson's daughter, Miss Jean MacKinnon, to George Albert Zabriskie 3d of 410 Park Avenue, son of Mr. and--Mrs. Elmer Thomas Zabriskie of Brooklyn and Sayville, L. I.

The trade agreement signed by the Oslo convention States-Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, The Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg-at The Hague in May, 1937, will not be continued in all its provisions beyond July 1, 1938, when it expires.
With buyers repreenting two drog chains prepared to spend a total of $750,000 for promotion merchandise, more tha 500 manugacturers and salesmen stormed the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.
Bowaters Paper Mills; Ltd., one of the biggest British manufacturers of newsprint, has acquired the International Paper Company's Cornerbrook mill in Newfoundland, it was learned today.

In an effort to show city dwellers how bleak back yards may be converted into cool garden refuges, five private gardens in Greenwich Village were opened for inspection yesterday afternoon in the first of a three-day series of garden -visits. The tours are being conducted for the benefit of Greenwich House, the Judson Health Center and the Little Gardens Club.
The Mexican Government cracked down tonight upon the Nazi-inspired antigemitic propaganda campaign, which started again today in the Mexican press.

Arthur Schomburg, curator of the Carnegie Collection of African Arts and Literature, will be the principal speaker at a concert and symposium on "Haiti" this afternoon at 3:30 o'clock in the Federal Art Gallery, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street. Among other speakers will be Maurice Clark and Perry Watkins.
A majority of the members of the Committee on the Bill of Rights of the Constitutional Convention are understood to be opposed to elimination from the Constitution of the present ban on gambling.

Mrs. C. Douglass Green was a luncheon hostess yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton to Mrs. Basil M. Stevens, Mrs. Nina L. Duryea, Mrs. George Rockwood, Mrs. du Pignac Thompson and Mrs. J. Henry Lienau. Luncheon guests in the Oval Room of Mrs. Warner L. Jones were Mrs. Henry G. Gray, Mrs. Charles Morgan and Mrs. George G. Thomson.
Churchmont Estates, Inc., has sold to Charles Walzer, operator, the three-story apartment house, and taxpayer at 80-82 Church Street, Montclair, N. J., for cash' above a first mortgage of $886,000.

Some 750,000 residents of New York State, most of them members of a large salaried class which is unable to meet the extraordinary expenses of severe illness, are subscribers to the "threecents-a-day plan" under which they receive hospital care in semi-private rooms for thirty days with bed and board, general nursing service, X-ray and laboratory examinations.

Felix Frankfurter of the Harvard Law School, Giovanni Martinelli, Metropolitan Opera tenor, and Nikola Tesla, electrical scientist, received scrolls of honor last night from the-National Institute of. Immigrant Welfare as "distinguished citizens of foreign birth who have made significant contributions to American life."

The arrest of more than a dozen clergymen in Leningrad Province on charges of "fascist spying debauchery and plotting against the Soviet regime" was reported today in the atheist newspaper Bezbozhnik.

Refinancing -of a large commercial property in the area just south of Times Square was announced yesterday when a new first mortgage loan of $1,600,000 was placed. for the Raben Holding Company on the land occupied by the Lefcourt-State Building at 1,375-83 Broadway,

This year's grain crops, exclusive of corn, are 24 per cent lower than last year and 19 1/2 per cent lower than the five-year average, according to the third and final estimate by the Bureau of Rural Statistics published today.

I. E. Haight of Montclair, N. J., was instantly killed and his passenger, Frank Austin of Toronto, was seriously injured today when a rear tire on their car blew out in is district, seventy-five miles north of Belleville. Mr. Austin was taken to a hospital in Belleville, where it was found he had a fractured skull.

Harry (Big Harry) Schoenhaus, the only man Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer ever trusted out of his sight with the moneybags, was arrested early yesterday by detectives attached to the office of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey and later held in $50,000 bail by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora as a factor in the policy racket.

With nothing but four-set-backs and a tie to show for its last five starts, the N. Y. U. baseball team batted its way out of the slump with a nineteen-hit attack against C. C. N. Y. at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

A minimum weekly wage.of $16.50 and a maximum work week of forty-five hours for the 16,000 women and minors employed in 8,000 beauty shops of this State were-announced yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, .State Industrial Commissioner.

The appointment of George M. Bohler, trainer at the University.of Mississippi, as head trainer of Princeton University was announced today by Professor Burnham N. Dell, chsirman of the university council- on athletics. Bohler,

The third annual country fair of the Society for Seamen's Children will be held on the grounds of the society on Castleton Avenue, Staten Island, Saturday afternoon. In case of inclement weather the fair will be postponed a week.

New York's "first community party," an evening of music, dancing and speaking, was held last night -in Madison Square Garden by the Greater New York Fund, Inc., before approximately 15,000 spectators.

Establishing contact with Rio de Janeiro by telephone yesterday afternoon, exporters here were assured by spokesmen for business groups that business was proceeding normally in that city and that the Fascist outbreak had been quelled.

Charities which held the Interest of Lawrence Marx during his lifetime were remembered in his will. which was filed for probate here today in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court. Mr. Marx, a textile broker and president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, lived in New Rochelle. He died on May 2.

Trading was fairly active to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were strong to another 50 cents higher, and active at advance. The lamb market showed considerable strength and other classes were mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated all classes to be about In line with Tuesday's close. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of- Agriculture, follow:

Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano returned yesterday from Florence where he had gone to bid Chancellor Hitler farewell, and one of his first acts on returning to his office today was to resume his negotiations with France interrupted ten days ago.

With the Walker Cup team on the high seas, bound for Scotland, to compete in the British amateur and international match.es this month and next, now comes the long-awaited announcement of the make-up of the women's golf team which will meet the British in the Curtis Cup matches at the Essex Country Club, Manchester, Mass., Sept. 7 and 8.

Spring rains and warm weather have saved Western New York's Winter wheat crop, aided hay- plantings and made cash crop outlook "real good," Wilbur D. Chase, regional land bank supervisor, reported today. "It looks as though the dairymen will have another bumper hay crop this year," he added.

The House of Representatives by a vote of 67 to 31 approved today the conference report on the Administration's $1,156,000,000 Naval Expansion Bill. The report now goes to the Senate, where favorable action is expected quickly. The bill will probably reach the President before the end of the week.

Guano production for 1937-38 amounted to 146,000 tons. With the exception of 1933-34 this is the highest recorded in the last thirty years. Production for the coming year, it is estimated, will exceed 150.000 tons.

While cooler weather has tended to slow up the general consumer demand for Summer merchandise during the last few days, active interest has been shown in special promotions at attractive prices, it was reported yesterday by retail executives.
In National Labor Relations Board won today the right to set aside orders issued against the Douglas Aircraft Company and reopen the case to correct possible procedural defects.
This capital buzzed today with rumors of the forthcoming resignation of the Daranyi Cabinet and its replacement by a government headed by the present Minister of Finance, Bela Imredy.

E. H. Clark, president of the Cerro de Pasco Copper Corporation, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting that earnings are holding up and that dividends are being earned before depreciation and depletion.

Restoration of the people's faith in the parliamentary system of democratic government will be the keystone of President Roberto Ortiz's Administration, according to his first annual message, read at the opening session of the new Congress this afternoon.

Charles Berger, 17 years old, a student at Brooklyn Manual Training High School and a member of the rifle team at that institution, was fatally wounded at about 10 o'clock last night in the kitchen of his home at 134 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, by the discharge of his .22-caliber rifle in the hands of a girl who had come to call on him.

A constitutional-amendment is being drafted to facilitate the elimination of twenty-one grade crossings on the Atlantic Avenue line of the Long Island Railroad and the general improvement of the line by the depression of the tracks, Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, disclosed yesterday at a hearing before the City Planning Commission.
Papers in connection with a suit for divorce, alleging intolerable cruelty, were served today on John B. Wright, who is held under $5,000 bonds on charges of shooting Friday at his. wife.

A highly competitive market developed on all grades and classes of fat cattle today, accordingto the United States Department of Agriculture. Steers sold 15 to 25 cents higher. Top was $10.65, with numerous loads at $10 Upward. Lambs was a cleanup supply of old croppers that sold mostly at $8 down. Hogs showed strength.
Lou Ambers, world lightweight champion, earned a unanimous decision over Jimmy Garrison of Kansas City ins ten-round overweight bout tonight. Ambers weighed 136 and Garrison 186w.

Mr. ad Mrs. Harris Fahnestock of 15 East Sixty-sixth Street have announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Faith Fahnestock, to John F. Paine Jr. of 441 Park Avenue. The couple took out their license yesterday at the Municipal Building and said that they would be married this month in the Municipal Chapel.

Threats of a strike in plants of the Chevrolet division of General Motors Corporation were voiced in Flint tonight as a result of additional layoffs which company spokesmen said were made necessary by a "seasonal" decline in sales.

The right to undertake the refloating of the brig Telemaque, which sank near the mouth of the Seine, With a fabulous treasure of fleeing French royalty in 1790, has been granted by the State to a French company.

The rate of 1 per cent for call money on the Stock Exchange was two years old yesterday. The last change in rate was on May 11, 1936, when a charge of three-quarters of 1 per cent, which had been unaltered for six months, was lifted to the-present 1 per cent level as a result. of concerted action by the lending banks.
Chaps and Benjam, two who struggled bitterly in Maryland, were divided by only a head yesterday at Belmont Park, but this time Chaps was first and Benjam was forced to take the place.
University Ave (12-3249), se cor of 197th St. 159x100; Rosevine Realty Corp to 2,800 University, Inc, 527 5th Av; mtg S192,400. Hull Ave, 3,078 (12-3332), Johl Ebner to Amdor Corp, 7865 E 175th St.

In one of the fastest college baseball games of the current campaign Fordham defeated Brooklyn College, 10 to .4, at Fordham Field yesterday. The encounter lasted only one hour and twenty-five minutes as the Rams recorded their fourth straight victory and their tenth in twelve onntests this season.

The baby Princess of The Netherlands, Beatrix Wilhelmina Armgaard, slept peacefully tonight in the palace of her grandmother, Queen Wilhelmina, as the little country over which she some day may rule prepared to celebrate tomorrow the first royal christening in twenty-nine years.

A demand for autonomy for the 4,500,000 Ukrainians in Poland has been made by the National Democratic Union, the largest Ukrainian political organization, which three years ago signed a "normalization" pact with the government, pledged loyalty to the Polish State and canceled its independence program.
Miss Margaret Smith, former actrees and a member of the staff of the Actors Equity Association, died yesterday at her home, 2,020 Broadway, after an illness of two months.

Rear Admiral William Woodward Phelps, former commandant of the Third Naval District and of the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, died at 6:30 P. M. yesterday at his home, 129 East Sixty-ninth Street, after a long illness of heart disease. He was 68 years old.

A plan to provide penniless offenders with first-rate legal counsel, by which it is hoped to eliminate from the criminal courts the "feegouging shysters" who prey on the ignorant and distressed, was announced last night by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey at a dinner for the Legal Aid Society of New York.

A first mortgage of $85,000 has been arranged with the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company through Harry G. Gebhard, Inc., correspondent, on the 52-family apartment at 37-41-5 79th St., Jackson Heights, J. Halperin Co., Inc., and Arthur M. Chinman acting as co-brokers,

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would establish his Summer City Hall in the Arrow Brook Golf and Country Club, about two miles south of the 1939 World's Fair Administration Building and about one-half mile off Grand Central Parkway near Forest Hills.
The Par House Banking Committee approved today a bill authorizing the Recon struction Finance Corporation to make re-employment and equipment loans to financially distressed railroads.

The cooperation of Lord Nuffield, the largest motor manufacturer in Europe, has been obtained in carrying. out the Royal Air Force expansion program, it was disclosed tonight on the eve of the crucial Air Ministry debate in the Houseof Commons.

With only half a point separating the leading teams with one match to come in, Paul de B. Scott of the Essex County Country Club turned in two victories to give New Jersey a triumph in the annual triangular golf match for the Stoddard Trophy at the Sands Point Club today.
The engagement of Miss Betty Waldo Parish, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Parish of .456 Riverside. Drive, to Whitney' Darrow Jr., also of this city, has been announced by her parents.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph -Company, Inc, for the first quarter of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net loss of $1,079,744 after taxes, depreciation and other charges. This contrasts with a profit of $1,444,372, or $1.38 a share, in the 1937 period. Gross revenues were $22,163,665, compared with $25,648.625.

In connection with the minorlties statute on which the Cabinet's political committee is working the Czechoslovak Constitutional Court was reconstituted yesterday under its leading jurist, Dr. Dobroslav Krejci.

William S. Knudsen, president of General Motors Corporation, predicted in an interview today that business would improve next Fall, but that the upturn would not be linked with government or the Fall elections.

Miss Anne L. Greenway, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James C: Greenway of this place, will be married to John Sloane Griswold, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. S.- Grlswold of 883 Fifth Avenue, New'. York, and Black Hall, near Old Lyme, Conn., at Kincraig, Mead's Point, the Greenwich estate of Dr. and Mrs. Greenway, on the afternoon of June 25.

A. Harry Feldman, vice president and active head of United Factors Corporation for the last three years, was elected president of the company yesterday at a meeting of being taken upwith the manufacthe board. Mr. Feldman succeeds the late Lawrence Marx.

Mrs. Vincent Astor was re-elected president of the Musicians Emergency Fund at the joint meeting of the directors and auxiliary board yesterday afternoon at Steinway Hall. Mrs. John Sloane and Mrs. Moritz Rosenthal were named vice presidents and Samuel L. M. Barlow a director.

Comparatively few important building sites in Manhattan remain vacant for any extended period. Despite the fact that quite a few old tenements and other outmoded structures have been demolished within the past two or three years, in some cases to save taxes, there still are only about 2,800 unimproved plots-in this borough,
Prince Giorolomo Rospig Host was cleared yesterday . of. a charge of leaving the scene of an accident by Magistrate Anthony Savarese in the Queens Traffic Court.

Collection ratios on open credit accounts receivable of department stores showed a decrease of 3.6 per cent for March, compared with the same month last year, while a gain of 5.4 per cent from February, 1938, was shown, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce announced toDomestic Commerce announced today.

The San Carlo Opera Company ventured on dangerous ground in attempting to do justice to Wagner's "Lohengrin" last night at the Center Theatre. It made a valorous struggle to cope with the opera and in certain respects the results could be heartily endorsed. Whatever the other shortcomings of the performance, the contributions of certain members of the cast demanded definite commendation.

The increasing possibility of an early peace treaty between the government and utility companies in the Tennessee Valley area caused redoubled efforts today among the leaders of the movement for a common front of government and business in meeting the recession.

Stocks closed higher in slowest trading in a week; turnover, 978,300 shares. United States Government bonds steady, public utility and rail groups strong, foreign issues irregularly lower; transactions, $7,409,450.

Thomas Edward Manning, wellknown Hudson River tugboat captain who during the last fifty years nosed his tug against many ocean liners and guided them to their piers, died yesterday /at his home, 97-25 Eightieth Street, Woodhaven, Queens, after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.

IT is something of a relief to have, on the heels of indignant and denunciatory books about Japan, the dispassionate analysis by Emil Lederer and Emy Lederer-Seidler: "Japan in Transition."* How accurate an analysis it may be is for the experts to decide, but it is obviously fair-minded and conscientious.
Investigation of the changing of a Municipal Court record in an attempt to shield Simon W. Gerson, Communist aide of Borough President Stanley Isaacs, went forward on several fronts yesterday.

Abraham Lincoln High registered its thirteenth straight triumph by vanquishing Samuel J. Tilden, 6 to 2, in a Brooklyn P. S. A. L. baseball game at Tilden Field yesterday. In other Brooklyn P. S. A. L. battles, James Madison defeated Brooklyn Tech, 3 to 0, and Alexander. Hamilton gained an 11to-O decision over Thomas Jefferson.

Turpentine firm, 22c; sales, 53 barrels; receipts, 512 barrels; shipments, 115 barrels; *tock, 30,975 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 547 barrels; receipts, 2,210 barrels; no shipments; stock, 94,198 hbrrls.

Strong measures by President Getulio Vargas of Brazil to suppress the Integralista (Fascist) party have been reported from time to time ever since he set up the corporative State by. his swift coup of Nov. 10, 1937.
The body of former Premier Octavian Goga lies in state in the Palace Athenium here today. The glasstopped- coffin bears but one floral tribute-from Chancellor Hitler.
The annual induction of fifteen juniors into the Pen and Sword Society was the main event at the traditional Moving-Up Day ceremonies held on the campus of Manhattan College yesterday afternoon.
Two magistrates in Brooklyn yes terday expressed sharply contrast ing opinions following their dis missals of charges against a father and son for the possession of lot terv books.
The Nova Scotia fishing season is opening at last, and we had word yesterday from that province that trout fishing in the Musquodoboit and Mooseland areas is excellent.

After a lower opening due to liquidation of foreign straddle accounts, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered several points yesterday and ended with gains of 1 to 2 points on the day. The May fell to within 3 points of 8% cents a pound, but the market met scale buying at that level and fewer contracts appeared after the close of foreign exchanges.

Members of the women's auxiliary of the Stryker's Lane Community Center, 554 West Fifty-third Street, have arranged a "mystery cruise" to an unnamed port on the night of May 20 aboard the S. S. Westchester as a means to raise funds for the children's Summer camp maintained.by the settlement in the Interstate Park hills near Bear Mountain.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 11 (AP)--Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page of Chapel Hill, N. C., the national champion, moved another step today toward a title she has yet to win when she gained the quarter-finals of the women's Southern golf championship.
Here is a summary of the important provisions of the 1938 Revenue Bil as reported today by Senate and. House conferees, and a comparison of these provisioRts with those of the existing tax law:

To the attractive bay mare, Midday Sun, owned by the Trillora Farm of Mr. and Mrs.Fred Wettach of Shrewsbury, N. J., went the honor tonight of winning the first championship of the seventh annual Atlantic City Horse Show. The event featured the second day of the exhibition.

Mayor La Guardia appealed for funds to complete the interior of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine before the opening of the World's Fair in an address yesterday at the 155th convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, held in Synod Hall, 111th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

The real Van Lingle Mungo was back with the Dodgers today. Ignoring the wintry weather and any thought of a sore arm, he fireballed and curved his way to a gaudy shut-out as his mates hammered Tex Carleton for a 7-0 triumph. The victory shoved Brooklyn up one notch into sixth place, displacing the Cards, who bowed to the Giants.

Because of the dangerous condition of surrounding piers, the Waverly Boat Club is being forced to vacate its quarters .at the foot of West 155th Street and the Hudson River; the Dock Department announced yesterday.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, are endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows.

Sir Abe Bailey's Golden Sovereign today won the Newmarket Stakes, important preDerby race, defeating the.Earl of Derby's Greenwich by a length and a half. Colonel-H. S. Follett's Malabar was third'in the field-of six, a short head behind Greenwich.
Mortgages on farm: properties will be insured by the Federal Housing Administration beginning May 16, Stewart MacDonald, Administrator, announced today.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won the award yesterday of $2,000,000- of public improvement bonds of Rochester, N. Y., on a bid of 100.583 for 2s. The bonds, to be dated May 1, 1938, and maturing serially from May 1, 1939 to 1958, were reoffered at prices to yield from 0.35 to 2.10 Der cent, according to maturity.

Philip F. Donohue, for many years treasurer of Tammany Hall, left a net estate of $25,808 when he died on Aug. 15, last, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Insurance policies of $14,484, payable to his children and grandchildren were not included as part of the estate.
Invitations to exhibit and application forms for space were issued yesterday for the 1938 National Automobile Show to be held in Grand 'Central Palace from Armistice Day, Nov. 11, through Nov. 18.
Secretary Hull tonight branded as "absurd and fantastic" a report that he would resign because of differences with President Roosevelt over policy.

Russell. R. Brown, president of the American Commercial Alcohol Corporation, in announcing yesterday the quarterly statement of earnings of the company for publication today, said that the Federal and State taxes which the alcoholic beverage industry was called upon to sustain were increasing constantly.

Senator Barkley will have to stay in Washington for some time. Governor Happy Chandler, his rival, has stolen a march on him. He has done some preliminary work by week-end trips, fuller of handshaking than talk. Now he has gone on the stump, spreading great waves of sound from a sound-truck.

Pompoon, returning to the track where he had finished a scant head back of the great War Admiral in the 1937 Preakness Stakes, ran the finest race of his brililant career today, whipping eleven other turf titans with a track record performance in the thirty-fourth Dixie Handicap at Pimlico.

Juan de Cardenas, former Spanish Ambassador to the United States, declared last night that the Loyalist Government of Spain had been "disloyal" to the Spanish people and that the Insurgent Government of General Francisco Franco stood for "loyalty to-order and human rights."

Covici, Friede will bring out on May 24 "Westward Under Vega," Thomas Wood Stevens's novel in verse. It is the story of two young persons who gave up routine jobs in the Census Bureau in Washington and traveled in an old caracross the continent in search of adventure.

Vincent A. Carlin, chief of the property rating section of the FHA in Washington, will be the gUest speaker at the meeting of the Greater New York Chapter of the Society of. Residential Appraisers this -evenipg in the Hotel Lexington. Mr. Carlin's subject will be the minimum construction requirements of the FHA in metropolitan New York.

In speculating on the reasons for Japan's surprise attack on Amoy Island, far away from the central and northern fronts, where the invading forces are floundering before Chinese resistance, it is not necessary to dwell only on the explanations suggested by military strategy.
The Continental Oil Company has received the American Petroleum Institute's all-department award for safe operations in 1937, it was announced here by the company yesterday.

Boarded-up tenements are in the same category as smallpox signs and an admission of defeat on the part of the owner who allows his buildings to continue in that condi-. tion, William Stanley Miller, president'of the Board of Taxes and Assessments, told the Mayor's Committee on Pxoperty Improvement at a meeting in City Iall yesterday.

A not-guilty plea to first-degree murder was entered in General Sessions yesterday for Chester Carsop, 28 years old, one of three alleged gunmen who, on April 12, shot Patrolman Humbert Moruzzi in the hold-up of the Howdy Club, in West Third Street.

Plans for long-range promotion of the window display as a major advertising medium were under consideration here tonight by the Lithographers National Association, following a symposium meeting in which both users and producers of display material expressed joint interest in the medium's future and pointed to the recently issued report of the Advertising Research Foundation as a logical starting point.
The report of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey for 1937, issued for publication today, shows consolidated net income of $147,993,147 after all charges, taxes and reserves.

It has long been evident that the control of relief expenditures is a source of immense political power. Mr. Garner's remark is often quoted: "You can't beat a government that has four billion dollars to spend as it pleases."

American authorities reported early today that Japanese sailors had captured the important port of Amoy, 600 miles south of. Shanghai, driving the Chinese defenders off Amoy Island, where the city is situated.
The protest of the United States to Germany against the decree aimed at Jewish owners of property in Germany is most emphatic and emphasizes the urgency of the situation.

Sir Percy Bates, chairman of the Cunard White Star Line, who sailed yesterday for England in the Queen Mary, declared that he was more optimistic about the business outlook in this country than when he arrived here ten days ago. He visited Boston, Washington and Chicago in addition to New York.

George H. Davis, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in a letter to members of Congress today urged rejection of, the Barkley Trust Indenture Bill, which would impose restrictions upon corporate financing. Mr. Davis transmitted a copy of a report prepared by a special committee of the chamber.
Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain denied in the House of Commons today that the British Government was trying to prevent the United States from lifting its embargo on arms to Spain.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., made in the first quarter of 1938 a net profit of $10,113,764 after depreciation, depletion, income and franchise taxes and other charges, according to the statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

Mrs. Stuart Duncan Preston sailed yesterday on- the Queen Mary to join her son, Stuart Duncan Preston Jr., in' Paris fol a stay .of several weeks. -On her return she will join Mr. Preston Sr. and members of their family at Miramichi, their placein 'Southampton, for the season.

Government furs sold at auction by the Fouke Fur Company at St. Louis on May 2 brought $160,323, or an average of $22.58 a skin for 7,100 fur seal skins dyed.black; $272,298 for 12,849 seal skins dyed safari brown, an average of $21.19 a skin,

Jacques Brecher of 204 Lewis Avenue, Brooklyn, executive secretary of the Children's Day and Night Shelter, 130 Boerum Street, Brooklyn, died Tuesday night in the Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short illness. His age was 59.

About eighty of the 300 pupils of the high school in District 8 of the town of Greenburgh, near here, went on strike today because the Board of Education had refused to renew the contract of Miss Esther Neubrand, mathematics teacher, for another year.

A 9-tube television set of simplified design that intercepts pictures but not the accompanying sound was demonstrated here yesterday afternoon for more than an hour as it clearly tuned in a test broadcast from the Empire State Building television transmitter. Charles H.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest the letters of I. Maurice Wormser against and of Arthur A. Ballantine for ;a constitutional amendment to authorize the Legislature to create an automobile accident compensation plan along the lines of the Workmen's Compensation Law.

Melvin Schwartzman, defending champion and ranked first in the singles, advanced a round ahead of the field as play in the twentythird annual Athletic Association of Private Schools tennis tournament was resumed on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.
Axel L. Wenner-Gren, Swedish industrialist, arrived from the Pacific through the canal on his yacht Southern Cross today, returning to Sweden after a world tour.

A 700-word letter written by Benjamin Franklin in 1756 was sold yesterday afternoon for $350 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. Written to Governor Lewis Morris of New Jersey, it referred, among other things, to the buying of scalps.

With the home production of pig iron now sufficient, together with Empire supplies, to meet all present and prospective demands, an import duty of 33 1-3 per cent will be restored tomorrow on the foreign product with the exception of certain special qualities.
The, Spanish Government's "lost division" sallied forth from its hidden Pyrenees Mountain stronghold today in new raids on the Insurgents' northern lines.

The United States Consulate here has refused to grant to William Gallacher, lone Communist Member of Parliament, a visa for a visit to the United States, the consulate's explanation being that regulations in America forbade granting a visa.

In the second transfer of the property in six months, the-six-story apartment house at 445 East 166th Street, the Bronx, was. sold by Nuko Estates, Inc., Eva Okun, treasurer, to the Towser Company, Maurice Roche, president.
The FertigLa Guardia transit unification proposal was referred by Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane today to the Committee on Cities of the Constitutional Convention.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has received additional applications from the following in New York City for registration as broker or dealer in the over-the-counter market.
The Tigers, behind the seven-hit pitching of Vernon Kennedy, chased the Senators out of first place in the American. League today, winning, 4 tol.

The Mayors of a dozen or more Ohio cities where the problem of providing for the relief of the destitute has become acute will meet tomorrow in ,Columbus to frame a program for submission to the special General Assembly session which Governor Davey has called for Mon.day.

Acting under direct orders from Governor. Lehman, Abraham S. Weber, the Budget Director, informed State department heads. this week that Summer vacations for all regular departmental employes would be increased this year from three to four weeks, a restoration of the former vacation period.

A nominal increase was registered in total electric power production last week. Daily average output declined, but less than seasonally, and the index advanced to 90.1 from 89.6. It stood at 106.5 for the week ended May 8, 1937.
Tremont Ave, 440-44 E, 4-story office and store 60.8x54.9xirres; United States Trust Co against Marjorie V. Paulsen; due, $95,707: taxes, etc. $2,161; to plaintiff for $65,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Patrick H. Marshall of Lewiston, Me., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Mary Marshall, to Leonard V. Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald H. Murphy of Flushing, Queens.

In a seventeen-page mimeographed "Minority Report on the Relief and Recovery. Program" three minority members of the House Appropriations Commitee put forth today what Representative Bacon of New York, one of the signers, said was essentially a "five-year Republican plan" to "rescue" the country.

Tonight's major events: "Samson et Dalila," San Carlo Opera Company, Center Theatre; Bruce Boyce, song recital, Town Hall. The Society of Professional Musicians will hold a concert this evening in its quarters, at 1,347 Sixth Avenue. Works of Bloch, Trunk, Bach, Liszt and Debussy will be heard.

Joe Louis and Max Schmeling met yesterday under the auspices of the New York State Athletic Commission. The heavyweight champion of the world and the German boxer who hopes to regain the crown now worn by the Brown Bomber encountered each other at the headquarters of the board, but their meeting was of a most peaceful nature.

I have just seen the highest waterfall so far found in the world. Art Williams, American aviator operating an air service in British Guiana, and 'I hopped off from Georgetown last Sunday with the object of flying over the majestic Kaleteur Falls. We camped in the jungle on the riverbank at night on Monday and then moved along to Kaieteur.

WITH deep sorrow it is confessed that there was a ghastly lack of accuracy in the forecast here of the running of the Kentucky-Derby at Churchill Downs. It turned out that complete ignorance of local conditions and atmospheric pressure in Old Kentucky and only a nodding acquaintance with Fighting Fox of the Derby field were insufficient data on which to base Any prediction or even vague hint concerning the order of finish.

General opinion holds that no sustained upward trend in the steel industry may be expected before late Summer or early Fall, according to Iron Age. The magazine suggests that government-sponsored projects, together with what railroad buying may be stimulated by pending legislation in Congress, may prevent production from decreasing much from present levels.

Lack of business gave the stock market here an appearance of gneral dullness today. Gilt edge issues closed steady after early weakness, while among the foreign bonds Brazilian and other South American loans were lower. Transatlantic stocks lost ground; United States Steel and Internatiional Nickel were set back.
Frank Albertson, former screen player who went to New York and appeared in "Brother Rat," has been engaged by RKO for the role of the youthful doctor in "Mother Carey's Chickens."

After having been held by the same family for eighty-six years, the Chelsea property at the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Twenty-first Street, improved with a six-story store and loft building, has been purchased by I. A.-Chelsea, Inc., I. Alper, president, from the Almy Realty Company, a holding company for the Gallatin family.
A $375,000,000 flood control program cutting present requirements for local financial participation by 70 per cent received approval of' the House Flood Control Committe today.

Recent cables from THE TIMES European financial correspondents indicate gratification, on both French and English markets, at Daladier's bold action in devaluing the franc. But both markets warn against reckoning too confidently on a continuing betterment of the French financial situation.

While all preparations for the proposed grand jury investigation of Earle administration officials were being halted at Harrisburg by District Attorney Carl B. Shelley, complying with "spirit and letter" of a Supreme Court order,

The confident prediction that ultimately there would be peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization was made by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labbr, in an address last night at New York University under the auspices of the division of general education in the auditorium at 41 West Fourth Street.
Solid hitting back of effective pitching by John Crosby brought Yale from behind to beat Brown, 11-8, today and the Elis evened the home-and-home series between the teams.

Mayor La Guardia signed a contract yesterday leasing five of the city's twelve piers at Stapleton, S. I., to the New York Foreign Trades Zone Operators, Inc., for operation as a free-trade zone for twenty years.

Several of the world's leading golfers will swing into action today when the 1938 metropolitan open championship, one of the oldest of all tournaments, gets under way at the Fresh Meadow Club, near Flushing, L. I.

Confident of winning the trophy for the eighth successive year, the last contingent of possibly the strongest Wightman Cup team to represent the United States sailed yesterday for England on board the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.
President. Roosevelt conferred with Secretary Ickes, Robert H. Jackson, Solicitor General; . General Malin Craig, and Admiral. William D. Leahy on the sale of helium to Germany.

112th St, 4 and 8 E, 25x89.7 and 25x101; Sophie Swarts to David Roth, 1,181 Grant Ave, Bronx; mtg $15,500 (50 cents). Sheriff St. 56, 25x100; Nathan Julien to Keabro Realty Corp, 565 5th Ave ($2). 17th St, 212 W. 25x92; Charles de Fabre to Donbert Estates, Inc, 35 E 41st St; mtg $13,500 ($4.50).
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 11, unless specified: At Navy Yard, Puget Sound, May 8: Arizona, Mississippi. At Menton: C. axton, Manley, Omaha. Asheville, Swatow to Amoy.

Some enterprising Westerners will seemingly never be satisfied until they have driven tunnels under all the national parks, drained all the lakes and diverted all the rivers. Last year they succeeded in getting authority for a tunnel under the Rocky Mountain National Park, to carry water under the continental divide, and unavoidably to disturb the park landscape with the debris of construction.
Visitors to the New York Stock Exchange yesterday included the economics class of AdeIphi Academy, Brooklyn, under the leadership of Lloytd W. Johnson, principal.

Marcus Lee Hansen, Professor of American History at the University .of .Illinois since 1928, died yesterday in Redlands, Calif., of chronic nephritis. He was 45 years old and. had been ill several months.
George Seymour Lyon, first great golfer developed in. Canada, died at his home here tonight after a lengthy illness. Mr. Lyon won the Canadian amateur golf championship eight times. His age was 79.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petro leum totaled 307,147,000 barrels on April 30, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the figures for the week before, this total represents a decrease of 507,000 barrels,. 407,000 and 100,000 barrels in domestic and foreign crude, respectively.
German low-priced automobiles are being dumped on the British market in the face of a high duty. It was stated
The State Tax Department has collected. $87,706;510.46 from the personal tax on 1937 incomes, of which it will retain $75,548,188.22.

The National Bituminous Coal Commission today unanimously elected as its permanent chairman Commissioner Percy Tetlow of Ohio who has been in temporary charge since March, when Charles F. Hosford resigned. His term will expire in December.

Formation of a committee to solicit proxies to be voted at the annual meeting of the Noma Electric Corporation on June 6 in opposition to the management was announced yesterday by Joseph Block, chairman of the committee. Other members are C. D. Wood and D. B. MacKendrick.

With 10,000 striking fur workers slamming Twenty-ninth Street from Seventh to Eighth Avenue at a mass meeting yesterday noon, the Police Department kept its promise to fur manufacturers to end the "reign of terror" in the strike by having seventy-five officers and patrolmen and five mounted men on hand to keep order.
The ancient half-timbered cottage at Shallowford near Stafford where Izaak Walton lived three centuries ago was destroyed today by a fire that started on the thatched roof.

Wall Street became convinced yesterday that an early end of the controversy between Washington and the utilities was assured, and as a result the entire list generally moved higher on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mrs. J. C. Clark's Irish bay gelding, Little Cottage II, won a leg on the Gardner_ Cassatt Challenge Cup, feature of the Radnor Hunt Club Spring meeting-opening today, before 5.000 spectators.

A pledge that commercially sponscored films will not be played in any theatre controlled by Warner Brothers was made yesterday by Joseph Bernhard, general manager of its theatre circuit, at the annual Eastern and Canadian sales convention of the company, which closed last night at the Hotel Roosevelt.
Edward E. Bruen, first Mayor of this city and dean of real estate men in this area, died last night at his home here after a five months' illness. He was in his seventy-ninth year.

American can Trusteed Funds, Inc., New York City, an investment trust, filed. under the Securities Act 1933 a registration statement ing 500,000 Lexington- Trust share certificates to be offered the market for estimated cash ceeds of $5,000,000. The proceeds will be used for investment.

Two hundred and seventeen planes and more than 3,000 officers and men of the army's General Headquarters Air Force, distributed at eighteen fields in six Northeastern States, were "alerted" last midnight, the "zero hour" for the most intensive and far-flung aerial war game the Army Air Corps has ever played.
