The 23-year-old daughter of the President of Brazil, Alzira Vargas, tonight described vividly how she and her father with five others faced an uprising of Fascist rebels "ready to die with our boots on, as you Americans say."
Now that the Republicans in Congress, encouraged by the- prospect of gaining seats next November, have come out of their storm-cellars, it must be admitted that their artillery tactics are punishing.
Freight rates for the 1938 Great Lakes shipping season announced today are unchanged from last year.
Papers in connection with a suit for divorce, alleging intolerable cruelty, were served today on John B. Wright, who is held under $5,000 bonds on charges of shooting Friday at his. wife.
It seemed as if it were certainly in the Cards today to bring a halt to the madcap dash the Giants have been making ever since they sprang the barrier on this year's National League pennant race.

A moratorium on mortgage foreclosures by the Home Owner s Loan Corporation and other suggestions intended to relieve distress conditions among home owners in New York and New Jersey were proposed to James Roosevelt, White House Secretary, and to John H. Fahey, chairman of the financing agency, by a delegation of nine Representatives today.

WASHINGTON, May 11.--Republicans charged in the House today that President Roosevelt's pump-priming recovery program was a political move to aid Democratic prospects in the coming elections, and declared the President was to blame for the present business recession.

Citing the Senate Lobby Committee's investigation of the farm magazine Rural Progress as a "glaring example of Russian methods" and a threat to the freedom of the press, Frank E. Gannett, Rochester publisher, warned yesterday that any newspaper criticizing the Roosevelt Administration could be subjected to the same treatment.

Mrs. Syiva Annenberg of Fresh Meadow, Long Island match play champion, finally succeeded in breaking into the winning column today as she led home a field of forty-six golfers to win low gross honors in the Long Island one-day tourney with a score of 39, 42-81 at the Women's' National course.

An etching entitled "Dawn" by James McBey, a contemporary Scottish artist, was sold last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries for $1,050. M. Knoedler Co. was the purchaser. The McBey etching was part of a collection of 200, mostly from the portfolios of three private collectors in England. The whole collection netted $13,517.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Rammer in a speech at the annual ..meeting of the Bronx Bar Association last night, admittedly intended for the Constitutional Convention, opposed programs advanced by Mayor La Guardia and the New York Bar Association to consolidate and supervise the Supreme Courts.

The Independent Theatre Owners Association, which last week took exception to the high salaries paid to "has-been" motion picture stars, yesterday charged that the doublefeature system of theatre booking is the root of evils in the industry.

It has long been felt that Autralia's Prime Minister is very inadequately paid at the present salary of 2,250 Australian pounds [the Australian pound is currently quoted at about $3.98] and that the allotment of [Pound]15,679 for the thirteen Federal Ministers and several Whips might reasonably be increased, especially as the law requires Ministers With Portfolios,
A preliminary hearing in what was described as a suit to force seven large New York York City banks to "buy American insurance" was held- here today- before Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley.

Princeton's varsity and freshman tennis teams retained their undefeated status by gaining 9-0 ,victories over Columbia today. Captain Jeff Podesta won easily, 6-4, 6-1, from Chauncey Steele to pace the varsity to its ninth straight victory. The cubs have survived five contests.

Bond values moved forward over a broad front yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, under the leadership of public utility loans. These, as well as stocks of the electric light and power companies, responded to the evidence of conciliation disclosed yesterday in the negotiations between utility executives and Government officials.
The largest influx of monkeys yet recorded in France occurred today with the arrival of the banana steamer Kakoulima at Nantes from Africa.

A Movement is under way in Congress to force Ways and Means Committee hearings on the bill by Representative Towey of New Jersey to lower to $3,000 the base on which Federal social security unemployment compensation taxes are paid.

Max Silverman, industrial racketeer, who has been described by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey as a "front-rank public enemy," was found guilty by a blue ribbon jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court last night of conspiring to obstruct justice by "fixing" the Samuel Drukman murder case.

Introduction in the Constitutional Convention next week of a proposal to establish a tax stabilization reserve fund was forecast today by Abbot Low Moffat, Republican chairman of the committee on State finances and revenues.

A few years after its conversion into a modern structure with suites of the smaller type, the fourteenstory and penthouse apartment building at 929 Park Avenue has been sold by Louis Cowan to the Straight Improvement Company, Inc., for investment.

The United States Steel Corporation filed today under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering the issue of $100,000,000 of ten-year debentures due on June 1, 1948, which recently was authorized. Other details as to the nature of the offering are to be supplied later.

GENEVA, May 11.--Haile Selassie returned here tonight to defend his title as Emperor of Ethiopia against the British Government, on whose word he had staked his empire. He appeared sick and sad, yet so much the King that men almost involuntarily doffed their hats as he passed on the station platform.

In a spectacular and well planned; although weakly executed coup early this morning, Integralistas (Brazilian Fascists) failed in an attempt to kidnap or kill President Getulio Vargas and seize the government.
The conference report on the 1938 Revenue Bill, designed to raise more than $5,300,000,000 in taxes, was approved late today by the House. It now goes to the President for his signature.

The German Foreign Office organ, Diplomatische Korrespondenz, bitterly protests today the Spanish Loyalist. Government's continued resistance to General Francisco Franco, insisting that there is no excuse for such resistance because the issue has now been decided.

Scholars from many field of science and official delegates from twenty-nine colleges and univerities will attend the installation of a chapter of the Society of the Sigma Xi at Wellesley College tomorrow and Friday. Smith is the only other woman's college which has received- a charter from the honorary scientific fraternity.

Behind the erratic but effective hurling of Jack Moller, Columbia turned back the Princeton nine, 7-4, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League contest on University Field today. The Lions had nearly finished their scoring before the Tigers got started in the seventh.
William L. Keating, partner in Miller, Donaldson Co., has been elected president of the New York chapter, National Association of Cost Accountants, it was announced yesterday.

New York City high school students are becoming art-conscious. Since 1927, the number voluntarily electing art has jumped from 2,500 to 20,000, Forest Grant, director of art in the city school system, disclosed yesterday.

While a group of at least fifty adherents of the "Women's Rebellion" against governmental spending planned to go to Washington tonight to appeal personally to their Congressmen to vote against the pump-priming Recovery Bill, Mrs. Charles L. Hulswitt of Suffern,

Mrs. Edwin H. Hess of 'the Weylin Hotel. here and Montclair, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Hess, to Lester V. Noteman, son of Mr. and -Mrs. Norman L. Noteman of New Rochelle, N. Y., and Miami Beach, Fla.
Law rin, winner of the Kentucky Derby, was nominated today for the seventh running. of the $12,000 added Illinois Derby at Aurora on Saturday, May 28.

William Clark Noble, widely known sculptor and painter, died last night of acute asthma at the age of 80. Among Mr. Noble's better known works were the Soldiers and Sailors Monument in Newport, R. I.; the statue of Robert Burns in Providence, the Brooke Memorial in the Church of the Ianarnation, New York, and the statue of General Porter in Van Cortlandt Park, New York.
Joseph H. Nuelle was elected president of the Delaware Hudson Company and its subsidiaries, as of Monday, at an organization meeting of the board yesterday.

Fireman 1st grade Denis Herlihy, of H. L. Co. 154, died May 10. Funeral will take place from McGrath Funeral Parlors, 91-20 37th Ave., Jackson Heights, Queens, at 10:30 A. M., Saturday, May 14. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.
Lefty Grove kept eleven Chicago hits well scattered today and gained his fifth consecutive victory, hurling the Red Sox to a 4-2 triumph over Jimmy Dykes's White Sox.
Ray E. Bauder of Bauder-Baker, financial advertising service, today was elected president of the Chicago Financial Advertisers for a one-year term at a luncheon meeting in the Great Northern Hotel.

J. A. Perkins, Acting Minister of Customs, recently referred to the Common wealth Book Censorship Committee thirty magazines, of which twenty-eight were from the United States, one from the United Kingdom and one from New Zealand.
The two major midoontinent oil States Cut petroleum production drastically today to prevent a price collapse, but revolt was stirred by some independent operators resentful over curtailment orders.

Summer advertising campaigns on several toilet goods products were announced yesterday, and despite the recession, promise to be the largest in many years. Producers in this field have always believed in maintaining schedules,

Passenger service on the new high level tracks of the Long Branch division of the Central Railroad ot New Jersey, between the Elizabethport junction and the Elizabeth Avenue station, was started this morning, when. a special train carl trying city, railroad, Public Utilities Commission and PWA officials passed over the line.

Detectives talked themselves hoarse for nineteen and a half hours in the Flushing precinct yesterday. in an effort to elicit information from Morris Kutler, 53 years old, suspected of many burglaries in Queens in the last year and a half:

Ian Duncan Colvin, author and journalist, died of heart disease here today. His age was 61. As a writer for The Morning Post for many years he had a wide reading public, and his earlier residence in South Africa and India provided plenty of matrial for his facile pen.

With the first of the revised fair is trade contracts on -books scheduled to go into effect a week from tomorrow, a sharp reduction in the number of titles which the department stores will be able to offer as "dividends" in their book clubs was foreseen here yesterday by retail executives.
Great Britain called on Charles Edgar Hare today to bolster her Davis Cup tennis team for the second-round matches against Yugoslavia.
Deportation of aliens swearing allegiance to a foreign country's dictatorship was urged in a resolution passed today by. the Gold Star Mothers at their national. convention.

The International Paper and Power Company and subsidiaries, excluding International Hydro-Electrio System and subsidiaries, reports a net loss of $332,241 for the first quarter of 1938, as compared to a net profit of $1,746,577 in the 1937 period.

About 500 girls arrived at Williams College this afternoon for week-end of gayety, including a play, nine athletic contests and two nights of dancing in the fifteen fraternity houses and the Garfield Club.

The Mount Sinai Hospital, at Fifth Avenue and 100th Street, opened yesterday an exhibition of old photographs, surgical. instruments, documents and charts tracing the history. of the hospital since its foundation in 1855, but with emphasis on the period since 1892, during which George Blumenthal was a member of the board of trustees.

Today, being the feast of SS. Achilleus and Nereus, was Pope Pius's name day, which was officially celebrated in the Vatican. Here at his Summer estate the Pontiff did not grant the customary public audiences.

With only two hours of trading today for the final settlement of May obligations, active covering carried the near month above the July position yesterday and left prices on the New York Cotton Exchange 7 points higher to 4 points lower than on Wednesday.

Retailing, with a record as a "stabilizing influence" even during depression periods, can play a major part in ending the recession by concentrating on doing the best selling job possible and by indicating its desire for cooperation among business, government,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of May 6 Arthur A. Ballantine makes the argument in favor of the proposed automobile compensation plan, authority for which is now being sought by its sponsors before the Constitutional Convention.
Dr. William Eagle Clarke, one of the leading British ornithologists and formerly keeper -of the natural history department of the Royal Scottish Museum in Edinburgh, died here today. His age was 85..

Families on home relief in Orangetown, one of the five townships in Rockland County, are being overwhelmed with foodstuffs furnished by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation, it became known tonight.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has been appointed trustee for Bendix Aviation Corporation Series A ten-year 3 1/2 per cent sinking-fund debentures due on April 1, 1948, and Series B tenyear 2 per cent and 31/2 per cent sinking-fund debentures due on April 1, 1948.
The Census Bureau announced today cottonseed crushed in the ninemonth period, Aug. 1 to April 30, totaled 5,839,749 tons, compared with 4,280,927 in the corresponding period a year ago.

Germany's Ambassadors to Japan and China met here today and informed persons believed they discussed the future of the German military mission that has trained a large part of the Chinese armies now fighting Japan.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today an application by John L. Hugg, E. McLain Watters and Walter E. Kennedy to-serve as used a protective committee for holders Othe of Fort Dodge, Des Moines Southern Railroad Company first mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds, due on Dec. 1, 1938.

William McChesney Martin Jr. will become on Monday acting president of the New York Stock Exchange. This decision was reached yesterday by the board of governors, which is headed by Mr. Martin and which will take office on that day.
Echoes of the days when the United States Treasury actually had a surplus were heard in the Constitutional Convention today.
Scores of communities in New York State would be eligible for new postoffices under a $60,000,000 Federal 'buildings program proposed in the Administration's spending - lending bill.
A. F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, said today his organization would not accept the 15 per cent wage cut proposed by the nation's railroads.
Box and reserved seat tickets for baseball games at Ebbets Field may be obtained at Western Union offices throughout Greater New York, the Brooklyn Dodgers announced yesterday.
The nation's railroads started today the machinery by which they hope to reduce their employes' basic rates of pay 15 per cent.

The sale of securities in odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded purchases by 25,839 shares in the week ended on May 7, reversing the buying trend of several previous weeks, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
Spanish Insurgent commanders reported today a "general offensive" had eliminated stubborn government defenders holding up, their drive toward the Mediterranean in Eastern Spain.

The New York Stock Exchange membership of Harry L. Hoglander was transferred yesterday to Richard Rosenbaum of Richard Rosenbaum Co. On May 26 the Exchange's committee on admissions will vote on the transfer of the seat of Warner J. Banes to Philip W. Wrenn.
Senator Luigi Rava, former Mayor of Rome, died today at the age of. 77. -He was president of the Export Committee and vice president of the Dante Alighieri Society.
Appointment of William F. Logan, varsity lacrosse and soccer coach since 1935, to the newly created post of supervisor of physical education at Princeton was announced today.
Frank Bird Linderman, an authority on Indian life and history, died after a heart attack here today. He was 69 years old. Born in Cleveland, Mr. Linderman passed much of his life in Montana,
Three garden visiting days have been arranged by the Woman's Auxiliary of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey as a benefit for St. Mary's Hall for Girls, this place.

If any one can name an activity more strenuous than that of pollack fishing off Montauk, we'd like to hear about it. After two hours of bringing in fish as rapidly as they could be handled our fingers are all thumbs.

Changes in the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad's collateral for loans from the Reconstruction Fi nance Corporation, required by the RFC when it consented to certain modifications of the terms and coneditions covering the loans, were listed as having been accomplished in a letter dated May 7 from G. R. Cooksey of the RFC, on file with the Interstate Commerce Commission.
One hundred monkeys of assorted species will be shipped from Newark Airport here at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning in a specially chartered plane, bound for the Belle Isle Zoo, Detroit.

Hospitals in a large part of the civilized world celebrated yesterday National Hospital Day, the 118th birthday of the founder of modern nursing and heroine of the Crimean War, Florence Nightingale. In New York City the ninety two member hospitals of the United Hospital Fund observed the day.

The sophomore class, with 33 points, won the third annual Fordham intramural swimming meet yesterday in the university pool. The juniors were runners-up with 15, the freshmen scored 4 and the seniors 1.

How the Bradley-Murphy faction in the Alleghany Corporation's management tried to change its bylaws to negate the control of the holding company held by Robert R. Young and associates was disclosed in a statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Eugene Klapp, consulting engineer and transit expert, a member of the firm of Parsons, Klapp, Brinckerhoff Douglas of New York, died of a heart attack Wednesday night in his home at Sandwich, Mass. He was 70 years old.

Life and the movies have their compensations and such a film as "The Adventures of Robin Hood," which the Warners brought into the Music Hall yesterday, is payment in full for many dull hours of picture-going.
The main barrier to recognition by Britain, France and others of an Italian Emperor of Ethiopia was knocked down today in the council of the League of Nations.

More than 1,500 persons attended a protest meeting tonight at the auditorium of the Great Neck High School here to demonstrate against the action of the Board' of Education in refusing to renew the contracts of four teachers.

Another $5,800,000 gold has been shipped from Japan, consigned to San Francisco, according to word received yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This engagement brings the total of gold sent here by Japan since Feb. 24 to $49,800,000.

Trading in wool goods markets this week was irregular, but prices were firm "despite repeated efforts of buyers to obtain concessions on the strength of recent wage cuts," according to the weekly review issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Four private gardens in Greenwich Village were visited yesterday afternoon by more than 300 persons who went on the second of a threeday series of tours which are being conducted for the benefit of Greenwich House, the Judson Health Center and the Little Gardens Club.

Following is the text of the British note to the Mexican Government demanding payment of special claims. The note was delivered by Owen St. Clair O'Malley, British Minister, to Eduardo Hay, Foreign Minister.

Serious unemployment will always hamper the nation's progress, unless surplus labor is turned to producing new goods or services, which, through advertising, the people come to desire as necessities, Stanley Resor, president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, today told the Harvard School of Business Administration.

THE China that fights with magnificent valor today against the murderous Japanese war lords was partly shaped by the ideas of Master Kung. You may want-to know more about that admirable man. A good way to do that is tread the warm-hearted and informal biography* by Carl Crow--who wrote "400 Million Customers"--that has just appeared.
Tax rates, crime increases and contributions women can make to the decrease of both were leading topics before the triennial confer-. ence of the General Federation of Women's Clubs today.

Stock casualty insurance companies had a combined underwriting gain of $50,263,250 on all lines in 1937, compared with $32,050,134 in 1936, according to the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters.

A joint campaign by variety stores and drug chains, to be promoted in newspaper advertising next month, will undertake to increase sales of milk by 50 to 75 per cent, according to reports yesterday at a meeting of the merchandising committee of the National Association of Drug Chains at the Vanderbilt Hotel.
Secretary Ickes suggested today that Congressional action probably would be necessary before any helium, was sold to Germany.
The five-story walk-up apartment house for forty-eight families at $29 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, has been sold by the Intervale-Boulevard Corporation to a client of Isidor Tankus, attorney.

Although counted out of the 3-year-old championship picture after their, dismal showing in the Kentucky Derby, Fighting Fox and Bull Lea still are the big question marks in Saturday's running of the $70,000 Preakness at Pimlico.

A reduction of 113 cents a bushel on American corn moving from Great Lakes ports to New York for export to England and Europe will be effected soon to offset the low rate quoted on the same freight for movement to Montreal, it became known yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia likes to establish his Summer City Hall at some place that is hard to reach. Be it humor, desire to keep off office-seekers and other bores, the benevolent educational purpose of stimulating the study of local geography and transportation, his official hot-weather site is usually more or less inaccessible.
One of two billsdesig ned to end price wars among retailers of gasoline was signed today by Governor Moore. The other has passed the Assembly and awaits Senate concurrence.

Debate in the Senate today on two measures providing for the creation of a Civil Aeronautics Authority centered upon the question of the President's power to dismiss members of the Authority without cause.

A liberal supply of clipped and Spring lambs was received today. Old crop wooled lambs were limited, suggesting that the Spring lamb crop was about to take the center of the stage. All livestock markets were firm to higher, but strictly good and choice fed steers closed dull, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

William O. Persons, who retired four years ago as head of W. O. Persons Co., a local lumber, coal and masons' material firm, died of a heart attack this evening at his home, 86 Edgemont Road, Montclair. Mr. Persons, who was 54 years old, was stricken as he was walking from his garage to the house.
Joseph D. McGoldrick, Controller, will announce today in the City Record plans for the sale later this month of about $50,000,000 of New York City serial bonds and corporate stock.

Events are moving rapidly to a climax in the great contest between Chinese and Japanese forces along battle fronts embracing Southern Shantung Province, most of Anhwei and sections of Kiangsu and Honan.

Notices to about 250 companies and individuals believed to come under a new State law requiring licenses for virtually all kinds of "free lance" private investigators went sent out yesterday by Abraham S. Wechsler, State Director of Licenses.

Xavier Reiter, retired musician, died here today at his home, 16 Oxford Street, at the age of 83. He had lived here for thirty-five years. Mr. Reiter, who was born in Bavaria, had been a French horn player with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the Metropolitan Opera.
Baron Gottfried von Cramm, Germany's No. 1 tennis player, will be tried here Saturday before an ordinary criminal court on as yet unannounced charges.

THE original intention was to set down here some words about Two-Ton Tony Galento, the heavy weight who is to meet Nathan (That) Mann from New Haven at Madison Square Garden this evening in what should be a rough-andtumble bout, but a letter has arrived--on the first bounce--that demands attention.
The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended May 11 were announced today: COLONELS Clapp, L. A. Quantico, Va.; to headquarters, Marine Corps, Washington, D. C., May 9.

A sale of paintings, owned by H. K. Weele of this city and from the estate of the late Mrs. Stephen A. Powell, together with works of Elihu Vedder, brought a total of $7,277.50 at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 742 Fifth Avenue, last night.
The Rev. Dr. Hugh Latimer Elderdice, a minister for fifty-two years, died to day at his home in Westminster, at the age of 77.

Mrs. William Duncan Herridge of Ottawa, Canada, wife of Major Herridge, former Canadian Minister to the United States, and sister of former Prime Minister Richard Bedford Bennett of Canada, died yesterday morning at the Memorial Hospital here after an illness of a year and a half. Major Herridge was at her bedside.

For the second time within a week English university bowlers failed against Australia's powerful batting array. The visiting cricketers today hit 708 runs for five wickets against Cambridge before declaring, following their huge total of 679 for six wickets, declared, in the match with Oxford.

Business in the Pittsburgh district remained largely unchanged last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The adjusted index stood at 61.7 per cent of the 1923-25 average, compared with 61.8 in the previous week.

Representative of the earliest institution of free public higher education in America, City College celebrated yesterday the ninety-first anniversary of its: founding with formal Charter Day exercises in the Great Hall of the main building, 139th Street and Convent Avenue.

The specific duties and relationships of the principal officers of the United States Steel Corporation of New Jersey are described in new by-laws adopted at a meeting Of the directors on April 5, the day after the annual meeting of stockholders, made public at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday recorded with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The funeral today of former Premier Octavian Goga was attended by leading politicians and diplomats and large deputations from all parts of the country. Before the coffin a peasant delegation carried a floral swastika.
Mr. and Mrs. Erving Pruyn gave a buffet supper last night at their home, 136 East Sixty-fourth Street, and later with the members of their party went roller skating on the Mall at Central Park.

Republican party policymakers told tonight of plans to obtain opinions on national issues at a midsummer meeting from "the most ably qualified minds available," regardless of the politics of such experts.

Hundreds of public officials and friends attended the funeral services for Thomas A. Dempsey yesterday morning in St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church, Rogers Avenue and Carroll Street, Brooklyn Mr. Dempsey,
Miss Mary Hussey, for a half-century a public school teacher of Kingston, died yesterday in the Benedictine Hospital of pneumonia. She resided here.
Excess reserves of all member banks are estimated to have been $2,480,000j000 on Wednesday, a rise of $40,000,000 in the week covered by the statement.

Retail prices declined 0.5 per cent in April, as compared with March, and were 5.25 per cent, below the corresponding month a yaer ago, according to the Fairchild retail price index, issued yesterday.

Mrs. Carita Curtis Bird, wife of Edward Dimon Bird, a director of Tiffany Co., New York jewelers, died last night at the Greenwich Hospital after a brief illness. She had made her home here for twenty-nine years and was prominent in social and civic affairs.

Mount Sinai Hospital and the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews receive bequests of $2,500 each in the will of Emanuel Felsenheld, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mr. Felsenheld died on April 27, leaving an estate formally valued at more than $10,000.
Unexpected rainstorms in many parts of the British Isles promised an end tonight of the country's 101-day $50,000,000 drought.
Some days ago in this space it was related that Vice President Garner had expressed the opinion that the way to recovery was for the President "to let the cattle put on fat."

Despite the presence of several of the nation's outstanding professionals, it was an unsung Long Island wage-earner who supplied whatever thrills there were in the opening round of the thirty-first Metropolitan open golf championship on the Fresh Meadow course in Flushing yesterday.

Manhattan's baseball team- registered its seventh consecutive victory by defeating Seton .Hall, 6-5, at Manhattan Field yesterday. This was the tenth triumph in eleven starts for the Jaspers, as well as the second victory over the Setonians this season..
Sanford Gifford Cable, former special agent for the United States Treasury Department and long a resident of Greenwich Village, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital at the age of 79.

At the demand of Mayor Wilson, the special October grand jury now investigating vice and crime conditions in this city will hear testimony on charges brought against the Mayor in his Democratic Senatorial campaign against Governor Earle.

James Stevens Darcy, a member of the law firm of Darcy, Loughman Bailey, 15 William Street, died Wednesday at his home, Newmarket Road, Garden City, L. I., after an illness of more than two years. He was 70 years old.

The French net against foreign undesirables today - caught Anthony Albani; an American citizen of Italian origin, when he attempted to land from the liner New York. He has been under order of expulsion from France since 1929.
The House of Commons flared into angry debate over Britain's air force today and in the end the government beat down what amounted to a motion of censure by a vote of 299 to 131.

Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines 2 Corporation, New York City, received a total income of $419,926 from the company last year, reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

Sydney A. McAllister, president of the International Harvester Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Hoboken that cumulative domestic sales between Nov. 1, 1937, and May 1, 1938, were about 13 per cent behind the like period of the previous fiscal year.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
Turpentine firm, 23c; Sales, 90 barrels; receipts, 323 barrels; no shipments; stock, 31,298 barrels. Resin firm: sales. 147; receipts, 1,504 shipments, 707 barrels, stock, 94,995 barrels.

The address of Chief Justice Hughes before the American Law Institute today was as follows: When, under the ,Presidency of Mr. Taft, it was suggested that the Supreme Court should have a separate building, Chief Justice White strongly objected.

Elated by the elimination of the 3 per cent fur levy in the House tax bill, spokesmen for the fur industry yesterday said they looked forward to a good. Fail season, despite the labor troubles which have tied up production for many weeks past.

A decline of $47,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities on May was reported for the week ended on Wednesday in the condition statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, issued yesterday. This decline carried the total of brokers' loans down to $468,000,000. The recent low point was $440,000,000, on April 13.
Newsprint production in April in Canada was 200,794 tons, a reduction of 32.3 per cent from the 296,624 tons reported a year ago and 23,810 tons under March's 224,182 tons, it was announced today.

Three of the army's seventeenton sky bombers, the four-motored $250,000 "flying fortresses," roared through line squalls, hail, rain and sunshine today in a 1,300-mile overwater flight, unprecedented in the history of the Army Air Corps.

Mrs. Emmet T. Whalen of Westchester Hills topped a field of sixty-eight players to win low gross honors in the first one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association over the south course of the WestchesterCountry Club today. The pace-setter returned a card of 40, 41-81.

A tentative publication on product labeling, which will contain "check lists" of suggested information to appear on labels for twelve items of consumer merchandise, was approved yesterday at a meeting of the Consumer-Retailer Relations Council held at the Hotel Astor.

The representatives of fifteen nations sat silent yesterday as a little black man, sick and defeated, bowed gently to them all and walked slowly out of the Council room at Geneva. They had listened in silence while the one-time Emperor of the last black empire told the white world what he thought of its morals and its ethics.
With Co-captain George Lenchner leading the way with seven goals, the City College lacrosse team overpowered Lafayette, 17 to 2, at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

The tribute by the Stock Exchange to its president, Charles R. Gay, whose three-year service in that office ends next Monday, recited in its resolution his "calm judgment and steadfastness of purpose" in "a period of profound difficulty," his successful coping "with the new duties and obligations imposed by Federal regulation of securities Exchanges," and his modernizing of the Exchange's administrative organization "to meet the demands of a rapidly changing world."

The Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company, controlled by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has under consideration early issuance of about $30,000,000 in bonds, it was reported in Wall Street yesterday.
William H. Baker, secretary and a director of The Cuba Company and an officer in several associated Cuban railway companies, died on Wednesday at his home in Bronxville at the age of 67.
The Board of Tax Appeals was asked today to determine whether the racing stable of Marion du Pont Scott of Bellevue, Del., was maintained for pleasure or profit in 1934 and 1935.

President Lazaro Cardenas revealed today that he had offered to let United States and British oil companies handle 60 per cent of the Mexican oil production for export over a long period and that he was willing to let the oil companies take a percentage of the oil output in the next ten years to pay for the expropriated holdings.
Lumber production increased last week against a lower seasonal factor and the adjusted index advanced to 58.5 from 54.4. For the week ended May 8, 1937, the figure was 86.8.
Medals of honor for distinguished service in journalism were awarded to two persons-and two newspaperss at the twenty-ninth annual University of Missouri journalism week events today.

Financial editors in this city have been invited to form a reception committee at the dinner which the financial press will give in the Hotel New Yorker on May 18 for Charles R. Gay, retiring president of the New York Stock Exchange.
The American Bible Society distributed during 1937 7,328,550 copies of the Bible, testaments and parts of the Scriptures in 197 languages and dialects, including books for the blind.
Department stores sales in St. Louis last week were 20.5 per cent under the preceding week and 12.5 per cent under a year ago. In the preceding week they had been 5.3 per cent under a year ago.

Gotham Equities Corporation (Joseph K. Alliger and Hyman Ratner) has purchased for cash the two-family dwelling at 2,029 Seventieth Street, Brooklyn. The house is two stories, stands on a plot 30 by 100 feet and is assessed for $10,500. It contains apartments of six and seven rooms.

The Monolith Portland Cement Company of Los Angeles is the apparent low bidder on an invitation from the government for the purchase of 250,000 barrels of cement for use in the next six months, the Treasury procurement division announced today.

Rained out of their final series engagement with the Cardinals, the Giants moved eastward today, riding on the wings of one of the most impressive breaks from the barrier a serious pennant contender has been able to effect in years.
Charges that fascist and Nazi propaganda is being broadcast night and day from Italy and Germany to the nations of South America were made before the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today.

State and municipal financing for the month of April totaled only $47,458,023, as compared with $95,368,325 in April last year. This is the smallest April total for ten years. The total for the first four months of this year was $395,326,946.

The Scripture and the concepts of profane medical history were quoted yesterday by Surrogate James A. Delehanty in support of a deoision in which he upheld the validity of a residual trust established by Jacob Gretzer for the benefit of his three sisters.

The New York Stock Exchange filed a special survey with the Securities and Exchange Commission here today by request, revealing that its former president, E. H. H. Simmons, was right when he said it was the general practice of brokerage houses to use their customers' free balances.

Frederick W. King, honorary president of the American Chamber of-Commerce in Berlin and director general of the German Mergenthaler Linotype Company, died here today at the age of 74, following an apoplectic stroke.

Kingsboro Mortgage Corporation has arranged first mortgage building loans: $130,000 on the six-story apartment under construction on the west side of Morris Avenue, 275 feet north of East 183d Street, the Bronx, for Bio Associates, Inc.
The police disclosed tonight that part of the arms found in raids on himes of Integralista leaders of yesterday's revolt were of German make.

Finding the sloppy track to his liking, C. S. Madison's James N. lasted to win the Statler Purse, Six-furlong feature of today's rainy Suffolk Downs program, by a neck from the Rosedale Stable's Lake View in 1:13 1-5. The winner's price was $24 for $2.

H. E. Morriss's Pasch, winner of the Two Thousand Guineas, tonight was quoted a 2-to-1 favorite for the Derby at Epsom June 1. Sir Abe Bailey's Golden Sovereign, who won the Newmarket stakes in impressive style yesterday, displaced Sir Humphrey de Trafford's Portmarnock as second- favorite.
Long pent-up Czech anger at Henleinist terrorism in the Sudeten areas found expression in an extremely stormy Chamber of Deputies debate today.
The Province of Quebec joined Ontario today in a refusal to consider any further centralization of power in the Federal Government.

Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals signed an order yesterday requiring the National Labor Relations Board to show cause on June 6 why the Association of Western Union Employes should not be permitted to intervene in a proceeding brought by the American Radio Telegraphists Association, a C. I; O.

Marking the first action by any of the leading radio manufacturers on 1939 models, the General Electric Company next week will distribute new "enforceable" fair trade contracts, according to announcement made yesterday by D. W. May, district radio sales manager for the company here.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Y. Eaton have announced from their home in Toronto, Canada, the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nora Eaton, to Paul R. van der Stricht, son of Dr. and Mrs. Nestor van der Stricht of Antwerp, Belgium.
Installation of the newly elected officers of the Hunter College Alumnae Association will take place tomorrow afternoon at the annual Spring reunion of the association at the Hotel Astor.

John L. Lewis disclosed today that the Committee for Industrial Organization is planning an unprecedented campaign of organizing the unorganized millions of American workers as soon as the present depression is over.

St Nicholas Ave, s w cor 157th St, 103.71/2X 144.9: 657 Broadway Realty Co, Inc, Herman Auerbach, press, to Arrow Management Corp, 1,010 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn (corrects deed of last Oct 11). Monroe St, 207, 16.7x49: Fannie Greenberg and five of her family to Central Savings Bank, which holds a mtge for $2,500.
The Petroleum Dealers Chamber of Commerce of New York, an organization of independent retailers, presented three awards of merit for work "in behalf of the petroleum industry"
The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended May 11 were announced today:

Mrs. David de Sola Pool, wife of Rabbi Pool, and Mrs. David Greenberg, both of New York, made a successful appeal before B'nai B'rith's new executive committee here today for funds to extend the work begun two years ago of bringing GermanJewish children out of "countries of persecution" and rehabilitating them in Palestine.

The Board of Elections practiced a "systematic splitting of contracts" for supplies for the. 1937 elections so as to give the contracts to companies as open market orders under $1,000 without public letting, it was charged yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Estimate.
Despite waterfront employers' action in ordering the port of Tacoma reopened tomorrow morning, sailors and firemen walked off a score of ships here tonight, virtually tying up the port of Seattle.

Operations today in the wheat market were devoid of feature. Trading on the Board of Trade here was mainly of a professional character, with some brokers on the buying side on adverse comment on the prospective yield of Winter wheat in Texas and Oklahoma sent in by crop experts.

Trading was generally fair to good. The entire beef market was strong to higher, veal cuts were steady to higher and lamb sold strong to slightly higher. Fresh pork cuts were mostly steady. Kosher business was confined mostly to lamb at stronger prices. Conditions as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey's onslaught in a speech Wednesday night on abuses by shyster lawyers in the criminal courts brought. yesterday what General Sessions Judge Cornelius.F. Collins facetiously called a "sit-down strike" of legal practitioners in his and the Felony Court.

Villiers A. Eacret, for more than twenty years associated with R. L. Polk Co., 354 Fourth Avenue, New York, and a prominent Mason, died suddenly here this morning at his home, 150 Rumsey Road. He was 51 years old.
During the week ended May 11, member bank reserve balances increased $56,000,000.
When 40 per cent of a man is sick the remaining 60 per cent of him is likely to feel below par. The other day the Bank for

Members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of'Electrical Workers, were described yesterday as "vassals of Tammany Hall" at a hearing in the injunction suit brought by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association against the union.

* Winners in the city and State essay and poster contests commemorating National Air Mail Week were announced yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman. The contests, which closed May 1, were open to all grade and high school students in the State.

Paramount today announced the acquisition of J. Edgar Hoover's "Persons in Hiding" to serve as a starring vehicle for Lloyd Nolan. It will be the first in a series of three films fashioned around the activities of the G-men. - Another story.

The general level of wholesale prices continued to decline in the week ended on May 7, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 77.9, compared with 78.3 on April 30 and 87.3 on May 8, 1937.
Intervention by President Roosevelt to prevent the "streamlining" of the "Star-Spangled Banner" was sought in a petition left at the White House today by ten composers, singers and orchestra leaders.

From his study and pulpit at the Roman Catholic Church of. the Nativity in Brooklyn,. Mgr. John L. Belford for more than a quarter of a century has hammered home to American Catholics -his opinions. on almost every question that has stirred religious, political or social interest.
The San Carlo Opera Company last night completed a week at the Center Theatre with a performance of Saint-Saens's "Samson et Dalila" played before a large and responsive audience.
A funeral service for Rear Admiral William Woodward' Phelps, former commandant of the Third Naval District and of the New York Navy..Yard, will be held today at 8 P. M.
Oblivious of the fact that juggling is a lost art, the Yankees went in for juggling in one inning of their game with the Indians at the Stadium yesterday and it cost them a victory.

The University of Chicago has added a second Nobel Prize winner to its physical sciences faculty. President Hutchins today announced the appointment of Dr. James Franck, now of Johns Hopkins University, as Professor of Physical Chemistry, effective Oct. 1.

The need for a heavier volume of residential construction to remove the possibility of a housing shortage which some observers believe is approaching in this. country is emphasized anew in a survey just completed by Lowell J. Chawner, director of the division of economic research of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.
Walter L. Clarkson, city surveyor and city engineer here for most of the last twenty-five years, died at Bayonne Hospital last night after amputation of his right leg. He was 66 years old.
An agent of Germany sought in vain today to look through files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which J. Edgar Hoover heads.

Private capital in large amounts is to be made available to established industries in the Chicago area through funds supplied by a leading life insurance company, Dovenmuehle, Inc., 94-year-old Chicago mortgage company, announced today.
A decrease of $3,655,000 in deposits of chartered banks was reported today by the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday. Dominion Government deposits increased $7,892,000.
The Pierce-Arrow Motor Corporation was sold today at auction when Federal Judge John Knight confirmed a bulk sale of assets for $40,000 subject to liens of $1,349,383.

The fact that Francis V. Goggins, attorney for Simon W. Gerson, Communist aide of Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, in the back rent suit in which the court records were altered to change Gerson's name to Gilson, and that the attorney for the plaintiff in the $150 action, Bertram Sommers, agreed to the change in the records, has been called to the attention of the Bar Association's grievance committee, it developed yesterday.
Jackie Coogan's mother and his stepfather, Arthur L. Bernstein, denied in four legal answers today his claims to the $4,000,000 he says he earned as a child movie star.
Picking up more weight than ever, W. F. Morgan's The Fighter won through' the mud at Belmont Park yesterday for his third consecutive victory since the start of the New York season.

Bruce Boyce, Canadian baritone, gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall. Mr. Boyce received his vocal training at Cornell University, winning a scholarship there that enabled him to concertize extensively in Germany and England.

Bohdan Pavlu, formerly Minister to Moscow and lately Foreign Minister Kamil Krofta's deputy, was drowned with a woman servant today when his automobile plunged into the River San in Northwestern Yugoslavia. His wife jumped from the car and swam ashore.
It is gathered here that Europe wants to know what Poland would do in the event of a German attack on Czechoslovakia. It is something that the Poles themselves do not yet know.
To the complete surprise of every one, including the Czechoslovak Legation, Konrad Henlein, leader of the Sudeten Germans, arrived at Croydon tonight by plane from Prague via Cologne.

Plans for alterations were announced yesterday in connection with sales and leases of houses in Manhattan. A downtown deal involved the five-story tenement at 168 Rivington Street, adjoining the corner of Clinton Street, which was resold by S. Robinson to a client of Herman Koenigsberg, attorney.

AMBERG, MAX W. (Feb. 20, 1937. Gross assets, $119,295; net, $107,665. To Irma H. Amberg, widow. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $83,122. William D. Soriborg, attorney, 219 Westchester Ave., Port Chester.
Backers of Bill Cummings of Indianapolis and Rex Mays of Glendale, Calif., selected today the cars the two will drive in the special match automobile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway Sunday.

Secretary Morgenthau conferred on Lieutenant C. B. Olson of the Coast Guard today the Distinguished Flying Cross. He was the first Coast Guard aviator to receive the award under an act approved by Congress last year.

Princess Beatrix, who was born Jan. 31, was christened today in the Groote Kerk of St. Jacob, where Crown -Princess Juliana and Prince Bernhard, her parents, were married last year. The child wailed lustily when with a quavering voice the Rev. W. L. Welter, 80-year-old former court chaplain, solemnly said:

After combating for two days' the obstinacy of a burglary suspect, who, it was believed, was feigning complete stupidity, including failure to hear, speak or read, the police traced his home address to the Bronx last night and found a cache of miscellaneous articles valued at about $10,000.
Prince Joachim Murat, who represented the exiled Prince Napoleon in France, died today in a Paris clinic of pleurisy at the age of 52.

A bondholders' protective committee headed by Van S. MerleSmith obtained permission yesterday from Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson to intervene in proceedings brought by the Manhattan Railway Company for authority to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

If the good news is true, and the Roosevelt Administration is really moving toward a settlement of its longstanding controversy with the public utility industry, there are various convenient tests by which progress in this direction can be measured.

As a cultural measure the Government of Mexico has decided to exempt the importation of books from duties and stamp taxes, said a report from Mexico City made public today by the Department of Commerce.
Kate Stephens, author,-editor and former college professor, died on Tuesday night at the home of a niece, Mrs. Elizabeth Haughey,. at Concordia, Kan., according to word received here yesterday.

Showing in her accustomed brilliant style, the bay mare Society Barrymore today retired the Flowing Gold Challenge Trophy, one of the feature events of the third day of the seventh annual Atlantic City Horse Show.

For sixteen days, from 8 A. M., May 16. LIEUTENANTS-William V. Judge, from 13th Precinct to Borough Headquarters Squad Brooklyn-Richmond, assigned to duty as Supervisor of Patrol in Uniform. Robert S. Purcell, from 72d Precinct to Juvenile Aid Bureau. James P. Dermody, from 8th Division to office of the Police Commissioner.

Bank clearings for twenty-two leading cities in the United States for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $4,888,388,000, compared with $5,396,292,000 for the corresponding week last year, a drop of 9.4 per cent, according to a compilation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A model kitchen and a basement auditorium for the demonstration of household appliances will be features of the new branch store which Abraham Straus, Brooklyn department store, will open next Monday at Jamaica Avenue at 168th St., Jamaica, L. I.

In perfect health and six pounds heavier than a year ago, Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., American, British and Australian tennis champion, arrived- here yesterday with his Davis Cup doubles partner, Gene Mako of Los Angelegs.

Mrs. Annie R. Henderson, Fuel Administrator during the World War, first director of the White Plains Charities. Department and founder of the White Plains Nursing Association, died today at the home of her daughter,

Herbert W. Schmid, head of H. W. Schmid Co., a bucket shop operated in Savannah, Ga., received a prison sentence of a year and a day yesterday, when he and six others associated with him in a fraud that cost the public between $250,000 and $500,000 pleaded guilty before Federal Judge John W. Clancy.

Plans have been completed' by Miss Lydia S. Ferris, daughter of Mrs. William J. Ferris of Field Point Park, Greenwich, Conn., and the late Judge Ferris, for her marriage to Granville K. Lester, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward O. Lester of Post Road, Stamford, Conn., which will take place on the afternoon of June 11 in the Second Congregational Church, Greenwich. The Rev.

Mayor La Guardia and the Transit Commission hope to negotiate with the representatives of the security holders of the B. M. T., the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company a transit unification plan under which the city will acquire the privately operated properties for not more than $320,000,000, payable in 3 per cent corporate stock or serial bonds, or a combination of the two classes of city obligations.
Through passengers on the New York Central Railroad increased 17.9 per cent in 1937, as compared with 1936, F. E. Williamson, president, said in his annual report to stockholders yesterday.
The romoval of Robert Eikhe from the post of; Commissar of Agriculture was reported today in private circles. Mr. Eikhe was formerly boss of Western Siberia.

A mortgage for $390,000 on the south corner of Riverside Dr and 93d St, 145x117.4 was assigned by Prudence-Bonds Corp and its trustees In a reorganization plan to A. Joseph Geist, as trustee, pursuant to a United States District Court order, and Mr. Geist has agreed with the owner, Amalgamated Properties, Inc, Jerome Thralls, vice president, to extend it to March 31, 1943, at 3 per cent.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 10: REAR ADMIRAL Bagley, D. W., Commander, Mine Craft, Battle Force, to duty as commandant Navy Yard, Mare Island, Calif., in May.
France's champion steeplejack, Jean-Baptiste Mesnard, 56 years old, was killed today when he became dizzy and fell from a 175-foot chimney in a Paris suburb.

Miss Shirley Jane Stone, daughter of Archie R. Stone of the Brittany and the late Mrs. Stone, was married yesterday morning in the chapel of St. Thomas Church to William Henry Warrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Roland Warrick of Mount Holly, N. J.

Miss come Audrey Hammond Madden of the Greenwich, Conn., became the bride here tonight of William Henry Chickering of Piedmont, Calif. The bride is a member of the New York Junior League. The couple will make their home here.

Whether Belgium will have a new government and further depreciation of the belga may be decided at tomorrow afternoon's Cabinet council, which will consider the budgetary crisis. Tomorrow's council replaces the scheduled Chamber of Deputies sitting, which was postponed today.

Any possibility that the United State planned to recognize the Italian conquest of Ethiopia was removed today when Secretary of State Cordell Hull, announced that this governmnent's policy of non-recognition remained unchanged, regardless of developments at Geneva.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 11: BRIGADIER GENERAL Krueger. W. General Staff Corps. three days' leave, May 14.

A plan which will give American designer-craftsmen an opportunity to exhibit their work at the 1939 World's Fair and to "set new standards for American craftsmanship was announced yesterday at a conference in the office of the United States New York World's Fair Commission in the Empire State Building.

Secretary Wallace, in an action said. to be unprecedented, has written a letter to Chief Justice Hughes asserting that the head of the Supreme Court had "shifted his ground" on the question whether the reports of, examiners for quasi-judicial Federal agencies should be made available to parties at issue before final determination.

A prominent issue in the Pennsylvania primary campaign as viewed in the coal fields is: Shall John L. Lewis and his C. I. O. forces become political powers in State politics -and thereby extend their hold over the destinies of the toilers?

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scott Lefebre of 340 East Fifty-seventh Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen LeCount Lefebre, to Hughart Rea Laughlin, son of Mrs. H. Hughart Laughlin of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Laughlin.
Mrs. Henry A. Ingraham, Brook1yn civic leader and for sixteen years president of the Brooklyn Y. W. C. A., was sworn in as a member of the Board of Higher Education by Mayor La Guardia yesterday.

Archduke Albrecht, recently stripped of his royal prerogatives by. Archduke Otto, pretender to the Habsburg throne, for having married a commoner, issued a statement today questioning the validity of this action.

The newly installed organ of the French Church of St. Vincent de Paul was dedicated last night at a formal ceremony in the church at Twenty-third Street near Sixth Avenue. Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, officiated at the blessing of the organ.

Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC is continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: Lt. Walton B. Hinds, 'JG' E-V'G' U. S. N. R.; Nov. 15,'1938. 1st Lt. Bertram L. Levy, Wed.-Res. (2d M. A.); Dec. 3, 1935. 1st Lt. Hendrik Versluls, Vet.-Res. (2d M. A.); Dec. 5, 1938. Capt. Irwin I. Alper, Med.-Res. (2d M. A.); Dec. 10. 1938.

The United States, including Alaska and the Hawaiian Islands, now has an estimated Catholic population of 21,451,460, the Official Catholic Directory for 1938, published by P. J. Kenedy Sons, reported yesterday. The estimate indicates an increase of 492,326 over 3937, 1,762,411 over 1928 and 4,035,157 over 1918.

Opposition to a fusion ticket in the State election next November was expressed by William F. Bleakley, candidate for Governor in 1936, in an address last night before more than 60O Republicans at a dinner at the Hotel Commodore in honor of Joseph A. Levenson, veteran Republican leader of the First Assembly District.

Milburn Shoffner allowed only five hits today, but the Reds, behind the six-hit hurling of Paul Derringer, shut out the Bees, 4 to 0. Shoffner walked only one man and hit a double and a triple, but they went for naught.
A founding member of the Group Theatre and an actor in four of its productions, Franchot Tone will come back from the films to spend the next theatrical season with that organization.

Entrance of more department stores into the buying movement launched during the last two weeks by leading drug chains was indicated here yesterday in the announcement that buyers o The Outlet Company, Providence, will be in the markets here next week to buy for "spot cash" $500,000 worth of seasonal merchandise of "exceptional value."

Decision to raise average commissions by more than 20 per cent was announced yesterday by the New York Curb Exchange. The board of governors adopted an amendment to the constitution which will become effective on June 1 unless disapproved by a majority vote of the membership.

Mrs. Elizabeth C. Riker has purchased the residence of Mrs. Ethel H. Peters, on the east side of Windmill Lane, the north side of Meadow Lane and the south side of Willow Lane, Rumson, N. J., through William H. Hintelmann, broker.

Arthur J. MacSherry, who formerly was associated with the McMeekan interests, and previously with the Manufacturers Trust Company as real estate sales manager, has been appointed sales manager of the real estate division of the Mortgage Corporation of New York.
Japan's refusal to accept naval limitations and increases in the Italian and German Navies will be met by new increases in the French fleet this-year.

Business houses and their employes have contributed $1,021,259 thus far in the effort of the Greater New York Fund to raise $10,000,000 to supplement the finances of private welfare and health agencies, James G. Blaine, chairman of the fund's campaign committee, announced yesterday at the first report luncheon at the Hotel Commodore.
Charity will share in the proceeds of the heavyweight championship fight between Joe Louis and Max Schmeling at the Yankee Stadium June 22.

James R. Crabb of Stamford has purchased about twenty-one acre of land on North Stanwich Road Greenwich, Conn., from the North View Corporation, William Kremer president, for $7,000 above a first mortgage of $14,274.
Tony Lazzeri and Augie Galan batted in nine runs off four Dodger pitchers today, which makes it quite clear why the Cubs won the farewell contest, 9 to 5.
A tentative program for this year's local observance of National Foreign Trade Week, was announced here yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc., in charge of the observance here.

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, chairman of the executive committee of the United Palestine Appeal, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner at the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the Food and Allied Trades Division of the Joint Distribution. Committee and the United Palestine Appeal in commemoration of his "forty years of service to the nation and his people."
Stocks closed fractionally lowerin dull trading; turnover, 596,000 shares. United States Government bonds strong, foreign issues higher, industrial group irregular; transactions, $6,360,700.

Miss Martha Barrows Knowles. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Knowles of Bronxville, N. Y., will be married to Victor John Pollock, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Frank Pollock of Springfield, Mass., on June 3 in the Reformed Church, Bronxville.

An immediate test in the Supreme Court of Errors, the State's highest court, of the legality of the procedure in the Merritt Parkway grand jury investigation that resulted in the indictment of nine persons was asked of Judge Kenneth Wynne in Superior Court today.

About 300 of San Quentin's 4,000 convicts went on a "sit-down" strike today to protest against the discontinuance of a fifteen-minute noon relaxation period, but prison officials said the demonstration lasted only five hours.
A registration statement covering issues of bonds and debentures of not less thank $72,083,195 was filed today under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Commonwealth Edison Company, Chicago.
The Tennessee Valley Authority and the city of Knoxville today offered $7,500,000 for the electric properties of the Tennessee Public Service Company.

The Newark City Commission adopted this afternoon a record-high budget of $58,245,013 for 1938, providing an indicated tax rate of $4.62 for each $100 of assessed valuation contrasted with a $3.69 rate in 1937.
The remaining three brackets in the semi-final round were filled yesterday in the Athletic Associatien of Private Schools tournament at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

Frederick A. Southworth, New York attorney, died of a heart attack Tuesday night at his home here at the age of 65. He attended Columbia University, and was graduated from the New York Law School. He was a member of the Republic Lodge of the Masons in New York.

Magistrate Raphael R. Murphy is not a man to allow court etiquette to interfere with his comfort. So yesterday morning, with the mercury in the low forties, when the magistrate's request for heat in the Bronx Magistrates Court could not be fulfilled, he replaced his judicial robes with a topcoat.

Retired Lieutenant John F. Leary. formerly a member of Engine Co. 250, residing at 1,365 East 23d St., Brooklyn, died May 4. Trial Decision The following member of the Department having been tried before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on April 26, 1938, for violation of Rules and Regulations, 1937, the following decision is rendered by the Fire Chief and Commissioner:

December weather in May caused discomfort to early risers in New York State today, as light snow fell in Buffalo and light frost appeared generally. Buffalo escaped the frost, however. Overnight minimums were 29.1 at Binghamton, where a "heavy to killing" frost was reported; 35 at Rochester, and 37 at Syracuse and Albany.

The country was still reverberating with the horror of the Hindenburg disaster when a Cabinet committee submitted a report on helium in which it was concluded "that the Government should be authorized to make both domestic and export sales for operation of commercial lighter-than-air craft plying between the United States and other countries and for medical, scientific and commercial uses requiring small quantities."

An armed .man held up Jacob Ingber, 45-year-old jeweler of 42 West Forty-eighth Street, on a Sixth Avenue elevated train yesterday and walked out at the Park Place station with a pouch containing $11,000 in unset diamonds.
More than 3,000 volunteers, from 18 to 70. years old, tramped tonight through the forests south of this city in the fast-dying hope -that 4-year-old Marjory West might be found there.
Net income in 1937 of the General Metals Corporation, controlled by the Transamerica Corporation, amounted to $404,682, equal to $1.53 each on 264,460 shares of $2.50 par value capital stock.
Harper reports two new printings in the first ten days since publication of "Rachel's Children," first novel -by Harriet Hassell, University of Alabama student.

Negro spirituals and folk songs were sung tonight in the County Center here at the annual concert of the Westchester Jubilee Singers, comprising 350 Negroes from all parts of. the county. The Westchester County Recreation Commission was the. sponsor.
Charles E. Northup, retired police captain, died on Wednesday at his home, 101-44 Lefferts Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, at the age of 66. Appointed to the department on Aug. 27, 1895,

An action was started yesterday in Supreme Court by the East River Savings Bank on behalf of itself and other investors in whole mortgages guaranteed by the closed New York Title and Mortgage Company to recover alleged excessive fees collected by subsidiaries of the

Miss Elizabeth Newell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Newell, and Richard Hartwell Butler, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Butler of West Hartford, were married this afternoon at the Newell residence here by the Rev. Frederick B. Newell of New York, uncle of the bride.

Business recovery and continued economic health can be achieved by American industry through a program of public education to "counteract the poison of unsound economic doctrine," William R. Kahns, editor of Banking, declared here today at the closing session of the Lithographers National Association convention.

The birth of fifty normal babies to forty-four mothers who had been sterile for periods of one to eighteen years by the administration of mild doses of X-rays was reported yesterday before te closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria

The United States Volunteer Life Saving Corps medal for valor was presented to three members of the New York City Fire Department yesterday afternoon on the pier of the departmental fireboat station, at Battery Park, in recognition of the rescue of a boy from the East River.

Stockholders of the Mission Corporation, a holding company which controls some of the nation's leading oil concerns, acted today to broaden its powers and enable it to enter the "operating business" of oil production.

In the presence of many of his former colleagues in the House of Representatives,. Fred M. Vinson, of Kentucky, former. chairman of the House subcommittee on taxation,. was sworn in this morning as a judge of the' Circuit Court of Appeals of the District of Columbia. He resigned last night from the House.

Surveys to determine the number of titles which will not be subject to price maintenance under the revised fair trade contracts issued by publishers were under way here yesterday as executives sought to shape final policies on the book club plan.

The sentencing of John R. Longo, 24-year-old political opponent of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, was postponed a week in Hudson County Common Pleas Court yesterday to allow Vito Marcantonio, defense counsel, more time to investigate what he said were "suspicious" statements by some of the jurors who found Longo guilty of election fraud.

H. Birchard Taylor of Philadelphia was elected president of the Navy League of the United States at the annual meeting held yesterday at 230 West Forty-first Street. He succeeded N. M. Hubbard Jr., head of the league for two years.
After more than ten hours of grueling conflict, Administration forces today drove through to passage the Relief-Recovery Bill with only one important change.

Weather Curbs Reorders Cooler weather has resulted in some slowing up of reorders on Summer merchandise. Mail volume slackened up somewhat from the pace it followed last week, but expectations were that favorable conditions at the week-end would spur new business next week.
Completion of the first and second rounds of the singles in the' New York State intercollegiate tennis tournament, which commenced today, saw Army qualify three men for the semi-finals.

The award of contracts for construction of the Delaware Aqueduct and for highways in six States boosted the grand total of this week's engineering construction lettings to $70,520,000, a rise of 12 per cent above the 1937 figure of $62,701,000, according to The Engineering News-Record.

The women's Southern golf championship, featured by a spectacular bit of third-round elimination, moved into the semi-finals today, with four favorites surviving the grueling skirmishes over the Birmingham Country Club course.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

The giant airplane, Wings of the Century, took off this morning at 4:55 o'clock from Kisarazu Airport in an another effort to lower the world's endurance record. Favorable weather has been forecast for the next forty-eight hours.

The stock markets here were quiet and generally irregular today. Gilt-edge issues were steady, while among the foreign bonds Austrian loans bead a good tone. Transatlantics registered some gains, but International Nickel closed lower.
Yale's six senior societies at their annual Tap Day exercises, held in the court of Branford College this afternoon, elected their quotas of fifteen members each from the junior class.

Miss Mary Louise Haywood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Holt Haywood of this place, formerly of Montclair, N. J., was married to Archibald K. Davis at historic Home Moravian Church tonight. Bishop J. Kenneth Pfohl and the Rev. Gordon Spaugh officiated.

Edwin J. Jones of 311 Prospect Street, Westfield, N. J., former financial editor of The Financial World and former member of the financial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died at 9:15 A. M. yesterday at Washington and Liberty Streets.

In the presence of many of his former colleagues in the House of Representatives,. Fred M. Vinson, of Kentucky, former. chairman of the House subcommittee on taxation,. was sworn in this morning as a judge of the' Circuit Court of Appeals of the District of Columbia. He resigned last night from the House.

Principal speakers who will address the annual convention of the Pennsylvania State Bankers Assoelation to be held next week in Philadelphia, include former United States Senator George Wharton Pepper; Irland McK. Beckman, Secretary of Banking of Pennsylvania; Upton Close of New York and David J. Leopold of Lebanon, president of the association.
President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of John W. Hanes of North Carolina to be As. sistant Secretary of the Treasury.

A plea for the selection of judges qualified by "training, experience and temperament," and a warning to quasijudicial governmental agencies to act in "the spirit of a just judge," were expressed by Chief Justice Hughes in a speech today to the American Law Institute.

Registering three-run clusters in the third and fourth frames, Georgetown's baseball team shaded N. Y. U., 6 to 5, at Ohio Field yesterday for its fifth straight verdict and its eighth in nine contests this season.

A Boston lawyer, Marcellus Edward Wilde, 48 years old, of Cambridge, tonight entered the studio apartment of a 21-year-old girl acquaintance, Police Sergeant Joseph Fallon said, and ended his life by shooting.
The Republic Steel Corporation was named defendant today in four suits seeking a total of $260,000 for injuries received in last year's Memorial Day steel strike clash at Chicago.
BEGIN No DAY, by Wellinngton Roe. (Putnam, $2.50.) A novel about the Connecticut hat industry. BRAZOS, by Ross McLaury Taylor. (Bobbs-Merrill, $2.) A historical novel of the Southwest.

Tony Galento, stocky, hard-hitting heavyweight from Orange, N. J., who has long been fighting in the outposts of Manhattan, will make his first appearance in Madison Square Garden as a principal in a main bout tonight when he meets Nathan Mann of New Haven, Conn The match is scheduled for ten rounds.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

Charging that two former United States Senators while in office accepted money for helping to protect an alleged "radio monopoly" in 1932, Representative McFarlane of Texas requested the House Rules Committee today to expedite action on a resolution providing for investigation of the radio industry.

For the first time since March 16 The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices has shown a gain. On Wednesday it stood at 80.4, compared with 80.0 in the preceding week and 93.0 a year ago.

The twenty-ninth annual convention of the American Federation of Arts will, be held at the Wardman Park Hotel, Washington, D. C., on May 23, 24 and 25. It will open with a discussion of the New York World's Fair and the 1939 Golden Gate International Exposition.

The list of the Italian liner Rex, due today from Mediterranean ports, includes William Harold White, president of Thomas Cook Son; the Rev. Felix Di Persia, Captain Ugo V. D'Annunzio, J. C. White, United States Consul at Calcutta, with Mrs. White;

Duke's touring baseball team scored its fourteenth victory of the season yesterday when it turned back St. John's, 6 to 1, at Dexter Park. This was the fourth straight triumph for the Blue Devils on their six-game Northern campaign.
Renewed strength and increased activity in United States Government obligations featured trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

President Roosevelt, - believed planning to take an active part in the coming campaign, is expected to open a drive for the renomination and re-election of New Deal supporters by a trip to Kentucky, in advance of the primaries there, to speak in support of Alben W. Barkley, Senate majority leader.
J. Wilton Peters, a New York broker with a home in New Canaan, filed a $3,444,972 petition in bankruptcy today with Referee John Keogh.
Buddy Myer hammered the Senators back to the top of the American League today by connecting for a homer and two singles and driving in four runs for a 7-to-6 victory over the Tigers.

A controversy over the advisability of imposing a floor tax on existing tax-paid stocks of liquor when the $2.25 a gallon impost provided in the new Federal revenue bill becomes effective July 1, took shape here and in Washington yesterday.

By substituting everyday experiences, such as trips to the banks postoffices, telephone and electric light offices, for conventional textbook and disciplined classroom, slow learners were -able to make "remarkable" progress in their studies,
Standard Investing Corp. The Standard Investing Corporation reports a net asset value of $1,839,295, equal to $735.42 per $1,000 on outstanding debentures, as of March 31.

Plans for numerous dwellings in Queens formed the bulk of building projects submitted in the city yesterday. Other operations included plans for a building to cost $104,000 at the College of the City of New York, and alterations to existing structures in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
The Brooklyn College tennis team defeated the Montclair State Teachers College netmen, 6-3, yesterday at the Kings Community Club courts in Brooklyn.

Representative Towey of New Jersey has introduced a bill in Congress to subject to the Federal unemployment insurance tax, paid by the employer, not the entire payroll, as at present, but only the first $3,000 of salary paid to any one individual.

Magistrate Bernard Mogilesky in Traffic Court 'yesterday heard a WPA employee attached to the alcohol tax unit of the Internal Revenue Bureau confess that for the last five months he has used the' confiscated automobile of a man serving a term in the Atlanta Penitentiary and adopted the prisoner's identity on his driver's license.

The marriage of Miss Valerie Lathrop, daughter of Mrs. Paul C. Root of Boston and the late Grayson Farquhar Lathrop, to Bennett Y. Ryan of this city took place yesterday afternoon at the home here of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Charles R. Potter, 151 East Eightieth Street.

An action to obtain a $1,635,000 reduction in the 1938-39' tax valuation of the Pierpont Morgan Library in East. Thirty-sixth Street between Madison and Park Avenues was started yesterday in Supreme Court by trustees of the institution. Similar actions involving the tax valuation for 1935, 1936 and 1937 already are pending.

Labor costs should not be blamed for the low state of construction activity, and organized building mechanics of the nation will continue to oppose any effort to reduce wage rates, leaders of the American Federation of Labor in this field told the New York Building Congress at its seventeenth annual luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

Last week-schools of mackerel darkened the waters off Fire Island. The run was so near the city that fishermen who intercepted it brought their catches here instead of taking them into Boston, as usual.

Whether any butside influence is involved or not, on the face of in it looks very much as if the quickly quelled uprising in Rio was an attempt of one anti-democratic group to oust another. PresidentVargas has had considerable experience with revolts since he seized power eight years ago.

President Roosevelt conferred on the proposed monopoly investigation with Senator O'Mahoney, W. O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission; Garland Ferguson, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, and Thurman - Arnold, Assistant Attorney General.

Junius R. (Chris) Page, brother of Walter Hines Page, wartime Ambassador to Great Britain, died at his home here early today after a heart attack at the age of 72. He was the last of five brothers who made the family name famous.
