St. John Ervine's comedy, "People of Our Class," received a moderate reception at the New Theatre last night. It tackles the favorite theme of conflict between generations and classes.

The United States gunboat Erie, with Commander A. W. Ashbrook, arrived at Callao this morning from Guayaquil. The flagship of the special service squadron will remain at Callao until Tuesday. Aboard the vessel are Rear Admiral V. S. Williams and his staff.

The personnel of ten legislative committees was announced today by John J. Dunnigan, majority leader of the Senate, and Speaker Heck. Three of the committees are new, the others having been continued in existence at the last session of the Legislature.

A suit to recover $1,000,000 from the New York World's Fair 1939, Inc., for-alleged breach of contract, and another $1,000,000 from Swift Co. for allegedly inducing the breach has been instituted by Franham Distributors, Inc., it was disclosed yesterday when the action was transferred from State Supreme Court to the Federal Court for the Southern District.

Mrs. Helen Lowe Fiske, youngest daughter of Mrs. William Lowe Rice of this city, was married to John Guthrie Kilbreth, also of New York, yesterday afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. George Buttrick, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

New York realty is facing a crisis as a result of attempts to break down constitutional safeguards against exseccive taxation and overassessment, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, told the Bronx Real Estate Board at a luncheon meeting yesterday.

In spite of the visible harm that has already been done by Government intervention, and in spite of the growing protest against many phases -of that intervention, it continues to spread, as it were, under its own momentum. The numerous boards and commissions that have been set up, daily hand down new decisions implying new controls, or petition Congress for grants of ever wider powers.

Dr. Charles D. Ripley of this city and St. Landray, Point Pleasant, N. J., formerly of Newark, N. J., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Louise W. Ripley, to Dr. Andrew Jon Valois Klein of East Orange, -N. J.

Shalimar, veteran brown gelding owned by Miss Frances M. Dodge of Rochester, Mich., tonight capturned the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall $1,000 harness horse stake, which carried with it the championship of the harness horse division of the seventh annual Atlantic City horse show.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had:

A new attempt to settle the protracted strike of 15,000 fur workers in this city began yesterday when employers and employes agreed to confer with Dr. Paul Abelson, impartial chairman of the fur industry, in "an earnest and wholehearted effort to reach a mutually acceptable agreementt"

Mr. and Mrs. Jean de Chadenedes of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn de Chadenedes, to Kenneth MacLeish, son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald MacLeish of Conway, Mass.

Department store sales in the week ended May 7 were 13 per cent lower than for the same week in 1937, and for the four weeks ended May 7, 8 per cent lower than for the corresponding period one year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

In an effort "to put a stop" to disturbances in home relief stations, Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio yesterday sentenced a 27-year-old mother of two children to the workhouse for three days after finding her guilty of disorderly conduct.
The Norwegian Foreign Minister, Dr. Halvdan Koht, commenting, said Norway would follow Finland and Sweden and recognize the Italian Empire of Ethiopia.

The military ball tonight brought hundreds of visitors to the Rutgers University campus for a varied two-day program and attracted several thousand to the annual R. O. T. C. field day exercises this afternoon.

Miss Felice H. Rosen was a luncheon hostess yesterday at the Trouville to Miss Virginia French, Miss Nancy Sewall and Mrs. Jorge R. Andre Jr. Luncheon guests of Mrs. John R. Mitchell in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton were Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, Mrs. William Robertson Coe and Mrs. Alfred E. Dieterichs.

John David Houser, industrial personnel and sales market psychologist, died of a heart attack Wednesday night at his home, 80 Brookside Avenue, Darien, Conn. He was the founder and president of the House Associates, Inc., 271 Madison Avenue, market research and personnel consultants. His age was 50. Funeral services and burial will be held in Meadville, Pa., today.

United thrombosis. States Ambassador Joseph P. Ken- Founder of the nedy contrasted "the spirit of tol erance and free inquiry" in the eranee and free inquiry" in the Pennsylvania con United States and Great Britain to "the regimented education" in dictator countries in a speech-tonight Miss Greene M at the annual dinner of the University of London.

The Woman's Hospital in the State of New York cared for 16,088 persons and gave a total of 74,207 days' care in its wards and private rooms in 1937, according to its eighty-second annual 'report. There were 42,080 visits to the out-patient department last year.

Wholesale trade this week showed some gains over the week before, chiefly because of extension of Summer buying and release of Fall commitments by country merchants in districts with. bumper crop prospects, but the decline in volume from the corresponding period last year continued at 8 to 20 per cent, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

" The Festival of Love," an Italian Renaissance tapestry, dated 1600, was bought yesterday for $4,600 by Mrs. Vera Caswell at the auction sale of eighteenth-centnury French furniture, tapestries and decorative objects from the collection of the Marquis de Marnay of Paris at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 742 Fitfh Avenue. The sale brought a total of $22,583.50.

One of the Diesel-powered passenger automobiles of the type which has been successfully used iGermany was -demonstrated here for the first time yesterday. With its four-speed gear box and smokeless exhaust, it negotiated New York street traffic as easily as the automobiles burning gasoline instead of fuel oil.

The Mexican Government announced tonight that it had broken off diplomatic relations with Great Britain by recalling its Minister and other diplomatic representatives in London and advising the British Minister in Mexico City, Owen St. Clair O'Malley, of the step.

The first annual award to be made by the National Bureau for Blind Artists will be granted to Lily Pons, soprano of the .Metropolitan Opera Association, for her work in behalf of the blind, it was announced by a committee of which Mrs. James Roosevelt is honorary chairman.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 13, unless specified: At Sourabaya: Canopus. Pigeon, $-36, 37, 38, 39, 41.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Swift, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Swift of this city, to Lawrence Lowell Reeve, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Stanley Reeve of Haverford, Pa., took place here this afternoon in Trinity Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Spence Burton and the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving.

The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania is expected to announce plans early next week for the sale of $60,000,000 of tax anticipation notes, it was revealed yesterday. The notes are expected to bear a fixed interest rate of 1 1/2 per cent and to mature in about one year.

Wheat prices on the Board of Trade here held within relatively narrow limits in the early trading today, with the outside interest at a minimum, but short covering and commission house buying developed later and prices advanced 1 1/4 cents a bushel from the early low, with the close at net gains of 3/8 to 1 cent.
Funeral services for Rear Admiral William Woodward Phelps, U. S. N., retired, were held today in the Naval Academy chapel by Commander William N. Thomas, chaplain of the academy.

Intervening in the tariff debate in the House of Representatives today, Sir Henry Gullett, former Minister of Trade and Treaties, said Australian manufacturers were being subjected to competition not only by United Kingdom goods, as was intended by the Ottawa treaty, but also by Canadian goods, and argued that this injustice should not be repeated in the new agreement.

The Westchester Division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association inaugurated its annual interclub matches today, when ninety players representing seven Class A and eleven Class B teams competed over the Century Country Club course.
A drum and bugle corps contest will be held tomorrow afternoon and evening in Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the American Legion.

Hammering fourteen hits for twenty-two bases, the Tigers conquered the Browns, 7 to 5, today. George Gill went the route for Detroit and allowed eleven hits as he chalked up his first pitching victory of the season. Jim Walkup started for St. Louis, but retired after allowing twelve hits in five and one-third innings. Julio Bonetti and Howard Mills finished.

Another spirited upswing in local traction issues featured otherwise quiet trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The renewed interest in transit loans was attributed to the reported agreement on a tentative price to be offered for the private rapid transit lines.

Four vessels of the Munson Line's South American fleet, which have been operating since last February at an average loss of $21,000 a round trip, must suspend operation upon the completion of their current voyages on June 21, Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe ruled yesterday,
That Ecuador buy railway materials from Germany instead of from the United States was suggested today by Gabriel Murillo Arzube, manager of the Government Mortgage Bank to the Finance Minister.

Jacob Emil Leltner, Inc, have arranged the following loans: $115,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for five years on the six-story apartment at 4,660 Spuyten Duyvil Parkway for A F Realty Corp with the New York State Teachers Retirement System, Pease Elliman, Inc, acting as co-brokers, and $80,000 on the six-story house under con-. struction on the south side of East 205th. St, 129 feet east of Grand Concourse, for Clarence Campi.

A boy would wait impatiently or The Youth's Companion to come out. If he could get it before his big brother did he would disappear with it until supper time or later. Does any one remember a serial called "Track's End"?

The New York Central Railroad borrowed $10,000,000 from New York banks as of April 30, a statement to the Securities, and Exchange Commission noted yesterday. Recently the Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the road to issue collateral sufficient to secure loans of $20,000,000.
Bursting into flames 3,000 feet above Bristol one of the Air Ministry's secret longrang monoplanes, intended for an attempt at a long-distance record, crashed today in a field and was destroyed.

Retired Fireman Frederick L. Kutzleb, formerly a memberr of H. and L. 4, residing at 384 East 193d St., Bronx, died May 12. Funeral will take place from Cooke's Funeral Parlors, 1 West 190th St., Bronx, at 9:30 A. M., Monday, May 16. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. The Deputy. Chief of the 5th Division shall detail one Captain, one Lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

A group of fifty women from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut trod the corridors of the Capitol today, visiting Senators to register protests against . enactment of the $5,000,000,000 pump-priming program. .
Miss Phyllis Almy Gallatin has chosen the afternoon of June-2 for her marriage to William Appleton Aiken. The ceremony will take place in St. James Church, Seventyfirst Street and Madison Avenue.

The heaviest program of rowing that Easterin waterways have seen in a good many years will be held today, with most of the action centered in the Charles River Basin in Boston and Carnegie Lake in Princeton.
Robert W. Zimmerman, contractor and builder and a former member of the City Council, died yesterday in South Baltimore General Hospital, after a nine-day illness. His age was 64.
Most of the French Atlantic fleet, commanded by Vice Admiral Count Jean de Laborde, arrived at Lisbon today for a four-day courtesy visit.
Dedication of a House of Parliament stone presented to the University of Missouri School of Journalism by Reuters, British news agency, featured today's program of the annual journalism week.
" Madama Butterfly" in the afternoon and, "Carmen" in the evening is today's schedule of the San Carlo Opera Company at the Center Theatre.

The International Mercantile Marine Company issued yesterday a statement of operating conditions and plans to its stockholders and summoned them to a meeting on June 6 at its principal office at 51 Newark Street, Hoboken, to act on proposals affecting the company's future operations.
An exhibition of drawings by Spanish children will be held at Lord Taylor's from Monday through Saturday under the auspices of the Spanish Child Welfare Association.

A test mobilization scheme both for regular forces and volunteer units and designed to examine the possibilities of expanding the local forces on short notice went into effect last night, when an imaginary precautionary period "to a state of war" was announced by the Bermuda command.

Anything that any individual, any public agency or any private interest can do to stop the American motorist from killing or hurting himself or any one else should be encouraged. This is one of the objectives of National Tire Safety Week, which opens today under the auspices of the Rubber Manufacturers Association.

After a warm fight, the Senate today adopted an amendment to the Civil Aero'nautics Bill removing all restrictions upon the President should he desire to remove any of the five members of the proposed Civil Aeronautics Authority.

The Conservatives today presented a bill in the Chamber of Deputies to amend the Constitution to permit only native-born Argentines to vote for Congressmen. The adoption of such an amendment would greatly weaken the Socialist and other Leftist parties, which contain within their ranks many thousand naturalized Europeans of the working classes.

Amid current speculation over the rumored estrangement of President Roosevelt and Senator La Follette of Wisconsin, the latter rested at home with an invitation in his pocket to accompany the President on a week-end cruise down the Potomac River and to bring Mrs. La Follette along.

Thomas J. McMahon, former president of the National Democratic Club, was hailed yesterday afternoon by former Governor Alfred E. Smith as the man who had kept the club "out of the red" while most other clubs in the city were having difficulty in making their income meet their outgo. Mr.
Donald Budge returned to Forest Hills yesterday for the first time since he won the national tennis championship last September by defeating Baron Gottfried Von Cramm of Germany in the final.

Gifts totaling $25,175 to provide for the transfer' and settlement of seventy Jewish children from Austria, Germany and Poland to Palestine were announced yesterday by Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, at its offices, 1,860 Broadway.

Three hundred and twenty Jewish refugees arrived from Europe yesterday on the steamship Manhattan of the United States Lines. Fifty traveled in cabin-class and were doctors, lawyers and business men from Germany who will take up permanent residence in this country and will be cared for by their relatives and friends.

Paced by Jack Sturdy, who hammered out a home run and a triple, the Red Wings defeated Jersey City, 7 to 3, today to run their winning streak to four straight and move into fourth place in the International League race.

The swift, efficient methods of modern science and the ministraions of a young woman interne railed to save the life of John Hara, 20 years old, whole body vas crushed between the floor of freight elevator and the fourthitory level of the J. Bonaparte warehouse at 160 East 126th Street soon after noon yesterday.

Edward B. Boles, through Brown, Wheelock. Harris, Stevens, Inc, in 19 E 72d St; Mrs. F. Hofmann, in 189 E 80th St; Mrs. E. B. Bitler, in 25 E 83d St; Juan K. Serralles, in 400 E 59th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co. Inc. broker.

Ernest Wright Camp, since 1929 assistant general counsel of the American Sugar Refining Company, with offices at 120 Wall Street, Manhattan, died here tonight at Lawrence Hospital following an illness of several months. His age was 50 and he lived in the Southgate apartments here.
Mr. and Mrs. Robcliff V. Jones of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion La Due Jones, to Thomas Harris Hawks, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Haywood Hawks of Rochester.
Thomas R. Manley, landscape art- was ist, etcher and painter of miniatures, died today at his home, 97 Mount Hebron Road, Upper Montclair, after an illness of several weeks. He was 85 years old.

Three Parsees who set out from Bombay, India, in 1933 for a world tour on 'bicycles,. paused yesterday at City Hall to- collect the autograph of Newbold Morris, Acting Mayor, and the 'gold seal of the city in their souvenir book..
A historic church document aimed at the most far-reaching union of Christian churches since the Reformation emerged today from a world conference of churchmen representing 130 denominations.
Henry Abner. Tremaine of 350 West Fifty-fifth Street, an early electrical manufacturer, died on Thursday in Post-Graduate Hospital after a short illness. He was 86 years old.

While the "old guard"' of criminal courts lawyers' reformed its lines yesterday on- the first two benches of Part I, General Sessions, District Attorney Thomas E; Dewey, at a conference in his office across the street, made plans under which, ih the future, "senior" and "junior" panels of outside lawyers will serve from day to day as volunteer counsel at the trials-of -needy defendants.

The State Banking Department's weekly bulletin announced today that approval had been given to the Armour 120 Broadway Credit Union to maintain stations at 42 and 54 Tenth Avenue, Manhattan; 2,286 Twelfth Avenue, and 635 Brook Avenue, the Bronx;

Dr. Hugh R. Monro, banker, of Montclair, N. J., who has just been elected president of the American Tract Society, with headquarters at 7 West Forty-fifth Street, this city, is believed to hold the record of any Protestant layman in the United States for the number of international and national religious organizations of which he is the head, an officer or a director.

The United States Foil Company in its annual report for 1937 issued yesterday shows a net profit of $337,569 after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income and undistributed profits taxes, loss on the sale of securities and $129,014 write-down of New York Eskimo Pie Corporation notes, mortgages and accounts receivable.
A proposal that Luis V. Valiente be admitted as a partner of Lawrence Turnure Co. will be considered by the New York Stock Exchange committee on member firms, on May 26.

Followed into the sanctuary by two bishops and accompanied by fourteen fellow monsignori and several priests, Mgr. John L. Belford, rector since 1905 of the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity, Classon Avenue and Madison Street, Brooklyn, celebrated yesterday morning the fiftieth anniversary of his ordination at a solemn high. mass of thanksgiving. More than 1,200 parishioners attended.
Meeting an old rival, Georgetown. for the first time in eleven years, Fordham's baseball team won by 6 to 4 at Fordham Field yesterday.

Harry A. Reiss, assistant superintendent of agencies of the American Surety Company of New York and the New York Casualty Company, died yesterday morning at his home in St. Albans, Queens, after a brief illness. He was 52 years old.

George F. Johnson, veteran industrialist, said today that "business conditions are looking generally better." Chairman of the board of directors of Endicott Johnson Corporation, Mr. Johnson, in a bulletin issued to the concern's 20,000 employes, said:

Member trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange. in the week ended on April 16 represented 21.64 per cent of total volume, compared with 20.14 per cent in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Many pastors will make a plea in their sermons tomorrow for contributions to the Greater New York Fund. The spiritual leaders of almost 1,500 churches have been asked to dedicate one service tomorrow to the fund, and rabbis of almost 200 synagogues have been asked to do the same today.
Turpentine firm, 23c; sales, 51 barrels; receipts, 417 barrels; no shipments...

Denounced by Mayor S. Davis Wilson for acting almost on the eve of the primary election, the special October grand jury today called for the immediate dismissal of forty-one of the ninety-eight police officers and patrolmen in the central city police district.
Alfred G. Correll, general agent of the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, has been elected president of the Brooklyn Life Managers Association.

Week-end influences set a dull tone for the stock markets today, relieved by only a few bright spots. Gilt-edge issues firstly were overshadowed by the failure of the London County Council's [Pound]10,000,000 loan, but improved later under the lead of the war loan.

More than seventy unions of the American Federation of Labor will parade from Thirtieth Street and Fourth Avenue to Astor Place and thence along Lafayette Street to Foley Square this morning as a preliminary to the observance next week of the A. F. of L. "Union Label Week."

Circuit Judge Michael Feinberg held valid today a suit seeking to recover on behalf of holders of $10,700,000 in unpaid 1929 school tax warrants, the money that holders of other warrants which were paid received in excess of their pro rata share of the tax levy securing the warrants.

Jan. 31 is. recommended as the natural fiscal year closing date for fur coat manufacturers, with Feb. 28 as an alternate date, in a bulletin issued yesterday by the Natural Business Year Council, 135 Cedar Street.

In a decision announced yesterday Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler directed the Department of Hospitals to retain 148 hospital helpers whose dismissal had been ordered by the Municipal Civil Service Commission because they had failed to pass qualifying examinations following a reclassification of their positions.
Walter L. Tobey, retired publisher, died in his suite at the Fountain Square Hotel here today. He was 68 years old. Mr. Tobey had been in ill health for several years.

Delegates to the convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs acclaimed today a report by Mrs. Jefferson D. Atwood of Roswell, N. M., which set forth the advances made in the field of citizenship, and hailed a growing disposition of qualified women to compete for public office.

A search of the cargo of the British freighter Stancroft, which was taken into Gibraltar yesterday with a naval guard aboard, under arrest by the British destroyer Hyperion of the nonintervention patrol on suspicion of carrying arms to Valencia, has thus far failed to reveal-either arms, or munitions.

Orval W. Adams, president of the American Bankers Association and executive vice president of the Utah State National Bank, Salt Lake City, Utah, told delegated to the fifty-first annual convention of the Kansas Bankers Association here today that "we must begin now to save what is left of the country's credit and resources; to tax and economize, and balance our budget."

Only an inning stood between the Indians and a jump back for first place in the American League today, but the White Sox hammered in three runs in the ninth to down the Tribe, 7 to 6, and shove them into a third-place tie with the Yanks.
President Roosevelt was reported today to have restored the Executive Reorganization Bill, recently recommitted in the House, to the "must" list of legislation for this session of Congress.
Former Governor Eugene Talmadge today announced his candidacy for the United States Senate against Senator Walter F. George.

Lawrenceville's champion polo team easily downed the Yale freshmen today, scoring by 14--1, in a one-sided encounter. The yearlings, helpless against a superior attack, rang up their tally when a goal was awarded on a foul directly in front of the Blue goal.

The Texas Corporation has acquired in the open market 267,939 shares of the common stock of the McColl-Frontenac Oil Company, Ltd., according to a report by the former company to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Only one closing this evening"Once Is Enough," which leaves Henry Miller's after playing there 105 times. Louis Schaffer, in high command of the International Garment Workers Union's stage activities, has been making plans for the Summer and Labor Stage. At the moment note:

ALLEN, HENRY (Feb. 14). Estate, $1,400. To Pauline Allen, widow, 35 W. 67th St., executrix. BEATTIE, ROBERT HOWARD (March 26). Estate, not more than $500. To Belle W. Beattie, widow, petitioner, Hotel Plaza, life estate in residue; seven other bequests.

The first national convention of the Communist party ever to be held in the Bronx opened a threeday session last night at the Winter Garden, 1,874 Washington Avenue, with 500 delegates, alternates and guests present.

Dr. Ejnar Hansen, for many years a practicing physician in New York and a specialist in gynecology, died yesterday at his residence, 1,050 Park Avenue, of- a heart ailment. Dr. Hansen, who was 68 years old, had been in poor health for a year.
Dr. Russell W. Tench of New York City became the new president of the Dental Society of the State of New York today at the closing session of the society's seventieth annual convention.

A six-hour celestial spectacle, marking a total eclipse of the moon, was visible throughout most of the United States early this morning. In New York the later phases of the eclipse were to coincide with the rise of the sun at about 5:43 A. M. and for that reason could not be seen.

A renewed attempt by Britain to come to an agreement with Hitler was foreseen in London even at the price of a real sacrifice. Prime Minister Chamberlain was said to favor annexation of the Germanic districts in Czechoslovakia by the Reich, and Hitler was. expected to agree not to. use force in that country, thus opening the way to a general accord.

Charging that it has been swindled out of $22,000 worth of platinum and iridium imported from Soviet Russia, the Amtorg Trading Corporation of 261 Fifth Avenue, official Soviet trading agency here, caused the arrest early today of Louis Rudisch, 36 years.old, of 155 Beach 139th Street, Rockaway, Queens.
The Rev. AlexanderD. Decker, president of the Retired Ministers Association of the Wyoming Methodist Episcopal Conference, died here today. He was TT years old.. Death was due to coronary thrombosis.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday stayed the order of Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May for a meeting late yesterday afternoon of the Queens County Democratic Executive Committee to decide whether it wanted James C. Sheridan to continue as chairman, a position that carries with it the Democratic leadership of Queens.
Charley Grimm and his Cub board of strategy fumbled one today and, as a result, the Pirates gained a 4-to-1 ten-inning victory in the series opener.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 7 amounted to 536,140 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 6,935 cars, or 1.3 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week;

Reviving the junior concerts after a lapse of five years, the Westchester Music Festival Association presented tonight 300 high school singers and 100-instrumentalists as the opening event of the fourteenth annual Westchester Music Festival.

A substantial business recovery this Fall is expected by more than half the members of the National Association of Credit Men, who reported in a survey conducted by the: group's economic credit council, the association announced yesterday.
Newspaper advertising linage suffered its sharpest setback of the year in April, when a decline of 16.1 per cent was registered in papers of fifty-two cities measured by Media Records. As a result,

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Sir Harry Gloster Armstrong, former Consul General in New York, who died last February, has left the Foreign Secretary [Pound]80,000 to be used as an allowance and pension fund for widows and children of members of the British consular service-provided the government finds a similar sum.

President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Harry Slattery to be Under-Secretary of the Interior to succeed Charles West, whose resignation was announced at the White House a few minutes earlier.

Stocks closed lower in dull trading; turnover, 604,950 shares. United States Government issues mostly higher, foreign loans steady, secondary rail and other industrial bonds easier; transactions, $6,043,925.

A movement for formation of a "popular front" or "democratic peace front," combining Left political parties under Laborite leadership to unseat the Chamberlain government, received a setback today when the National Executive Committee of the Labor party vetoed the arrangement as not being in the interest of Great Britain or international peace.
In a civil war now apparently entering its final stage, Nationalist [Insurgent] Spain's achievement on the economic front is hardly less remarkable than on the military front.

Howard Young Galleries, Inc, art gallery, Carolyn Nelson, Ltd, in 1 E 57th St; Payson McL. Merrill Co, Inc, broker. Galban Co, Inc. import and export, in 21 West St; Emanuel Engel, attorney, Samuel Lichterman, real estate and insurance, in 120 Liberty St; A. S. Rosenberg, member Produce Exchange, in 24 Stone St; Cushman Wakefield, Inc, broker.

Immediately after Rabbi Benjamin Plotkin of Congregation Emanu-el, Jersey City, appeared in court there as a character witness for John R. Longo, 24-year-old antiHague Democrat, his congregation was told it must get out within two months, by the Jewish Community Center there, it was disclosed last night.

The Preakness, second of the turf's Spring classics comprising the "triple crown," will be run for the forty-eighth time tomorrow with ten colts primed to test speed and stamina over Pimlico's mile and three-sixteenths for the 3-year-old division's richest pot of gold.

The current exhibition of paintings by Frank Duveneck at the Whitney Museum will close tomorrow evening. A selection of paintings and sculpture from the permanent collection will be placed on view on Tuesday and may be seen through May 27. The museum will close for the Summer on May 28 and will reopen in September.

The building of a large "war chest" was started last January by Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, for legal aid in keeping the union's officers "out of jail," according to testimony yesterday in the injunction suit against the union.

Members of the Cavan and Leix teams from Ireland arrived yesterday aboard the United States liner Manhattan to participate in the three - game international Gaelic football trophy series, slated to start tomorrow at the Polo Grounds. A picked all-New York side also will seek honors in the round-robin competition.
The Red Sox stretched their winning streak to six games today and climbed into second place 'in the American League by walloping the Senators, 10 to 0.

Newsprint production in North America in April showed the sharpest decline for any month this year, but this was attributed to the ?t that in April last year publishers began to store newsprint in anticipation of the advance of $7.50 a ton which became effective in January of this year. April production,

A world congress of Sephardic Jewry opened here this afternoon in the Portuguese Synagogue, ancient center of Sephardic religious culture. [Sephardic Jews are descendants of former Spanish and Portuguese Jews.]

Two of Uncle Sam's Curtis Cup golfers, Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page, national champion, and Miss Marion Miley, Kentucky and Western titleholder, will play tomorrow for the Southern crown Neither has over won.
Judge John M. McCabe refused today to grant a temporary injunction preventing a bondholders committee for the Everglades (Fla.) Drainage District from functioning.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as. supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Captain Claude W. Cole, owner of the Main Ducks Islands, known as "the graveyard of Ontario," and a widely known lake mariner, died of heart attack in his car on the dock at Cape Vincent this morning.
Legislative action on the Administration's $1,156,000,000 Naval Expansion Bill was completed today when the Senate approved the agreement, entered into by the Senate and House conferees.

Adrian Van Sinderen, president of the American Horse Show Association, declined today to comment on the suspension for the year 1938 of the stable of Julius Bliss, broker, from participation in any of the shows under the auspices of the association.

Speaking on "The Current Business and Economic Outlook" before the thirty-eighth annual convention of the New Jersey Bankers Association today, Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, admitted that the government was partly responsible, along with business and organized labor, for the present "depression," which he called by that name.

The spell of Friday the ?? proved too much for Monte Pearson and the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium. Having enjoyed a ten-day rest the Fresno Flinger was out there against Connie Mack's Athletics trying for his third victory in what looked like an easy spot, and the Yankees were striving to launch another winning streak.
Rear Admiral Albert Gleaves Berry, 90 years old, and Commodore Burns Tracy Walling, 83, both retired naval officers, died here within a few hours of each other last night.

Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, is not in favor of beach lifeguards making a career of Summer jobs. He said so yesterday in a letter to John J. Gussak, president of the Greater New York City Lifeguard Association, who had protested a ruling of the Municipal Civil Service Commission that guards on the eligible list must take a re-examination to determine fitness or be dropped from the list.

More than a hundred unemployed men and women, mostly beyond middle age, found work yesterday in a cooperative plant financed by the Neckwear Makers Union, Locals 250 and 253, affiliated with the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America. Some 2,000 members of the union underwrote the enterprise to the extent of $25,000, buying $10 shares.

The report of the United Light and Power Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $4,938,418. This was equal,

An unimproved parcel of land, 50 by 100 feet, directly opposite the proposed entrance to -the World's Fair Grounds, on the southwest corner of 111th Street and Fiftysecond Avenue, Corona, Queens, has been sold to a client of Lee Harris Co. by Rose Sepner for $7,000 cash.

Henry C. Stuart, for fifteen years assistant collector of the Port of New York, died yesterday at his home, 450 Riverside Drive. Mr. Stuart, who was 73 years old, had been in excellent health until being taken ill this week.

Regent Nicholas Horthy today accepted the resignation of Premier Koloman Daranyi and his Cabinet. He then summoned Bela Imredy, former Minister of Commerce, to form a government and after a short series of consultations the following Ministry was announced:...

Trading was active to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were priced fully 50c-$1 higher. Steer cuts sold strong to $1 higher; other classes of traefer meats showed- little change in price Early kosher business indicated all classes to be higher. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

Tully C. Estee, retired vice president of the Washburn-Crosby Company, flour manufacturers,, died today at his Summer home here after a short illness at the age of 69. Mr. Estee had lived during the Winter for thirty years at 203 Summit Avenue, Mount Vernon, N. Y.

Mr. and Mrs. Pierre S. du Pont 3d of Richmond, Va., gave a dance here tonight at the Waterbury Country Club for Mrs. du Pont's sister, Miss Nancy Holcomb, and Ernest A. Anderson Jr., who will be married tomorrow afternoon in St. John's Church here.

Joseph Martin Rising, former owner of the 1922 world's champion trotter, Cora Hal, and owner of other trotting horses for forty-five years, died here yesterday at the home of a son, Carroll Rising. He was a former resident of Pittsburgh.
The touring Australian cricket team defeated Cambridge University by an innings and 425 runs today for its fourth straight innings' victory since the opening match April 30.

John F. Hildemann, for forty years a member of the Hoboken Police Department, died today at his home of a heart ailment at the age of 74. He - was appointed to the police force in 1896 and 'was 'retired in 1936.

The proposal to revise the Neutrality Laws and to permit export of munitions to Loyalist Spain was postponed yesterday by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations at the suggestion of Secretary of State Hull.

Cotton-mill activity increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index spurted five points to 89.7. This compares with 84.2, the revised figure for the preceding week, and 140.4 for the week ended May 8, 1937.

So much of Paragraph 12, Special Orders 37, dated Feb. 14, 1938, as orders 1st Lt. Robert M. Baker, C.A.-Res., to active duty with the CCC, effective Feb. 17, and relieving him, effective Aug. 16, is amended so as to order Lt. Baker to active duty with the CCC, effective Feb. 17, and relieving him, effective May 12.

An announcement that Harold F. McCormick, chairman of the board of directors of the International Harvester Company, and Miss Adah Wilson of Los Angeles would be married soon was made tonight by Mrs. Lillian Martin, secretary to Mr. McCormick.
The significance of the recent abortive revolt in Brazil is discussed here by the President of that country, who, armed with a revolver, helped to defend his family in his besieged palace.
About 160 vigilantes, armed with shotguns, rifles and clubs, drove nine automobile loads of WPA strikers from the municipal gravel pits at Lindenwold, twelve miles southeast of this city, today.

Employes of the vast Cities Service organization throughout the country yesterday celebrated they sixty-eighth birthday of Henry L. Doherty, president and founder of Cities Service Company. Birthday observances were held in 9,000 communities in thirty-eight States and Canada to mark the anniversary.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers, hailed-as "indicating clearly that factionalism is at an end"the unanimous approval today of a twenty-point program by the union's executive board.

A memorial service for Miss Amy Blanche Greene will be held under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street. Miss Greene, who died on March 2, was director of the Youth Department of the Federation.
The Greek Government has increased import quotas allotted to the United States in its group B, F and G, from about $504,000 to about $675,000, the Commerce Department announces.

Viscount Halifax, the British Foreign Secretary, with some effort and more risk got the League of Nations Council tonight to reject by a remarkable vote a resolution proposed by the Spanish Government asking execution of the promise made to it by Britain, France and many others in the League Assembly seven months ago.

President Roosevelt announced today that the question of the sale of helium to Germany would be considered at a meeting of the National Munitions Control Board soon. He indicated agreement with Secretary Ickes's position that the board's previous- authorization of the sale was not according to law in that all members were not present.
Spanish Insurgents occupied the entire length of the Teruel-Albocacer highway today in their drive toward the government's coastal strongholds of Castellon de la Plana and Valencia.

Commander I. Schlossbach, U.S.N., retired, returned to the base of the MacGregor Arctic Expedition this morning at 9 o'clock after flying over the vast unexplored area northwest of Ellesmere Island, Canada. He left here yesterday at 1 P. M. and flew over Bache Peninsula, then over Ellesmere Island and came out over Canon Fiord on the west side.

Paul V. Shields of Shields Co., will be the new chairman of the public relations committee of the New York Stock Exchange, that body decided yesterday in an informal organization meeting. R. Lawrence Oakley of Maynard, Oakley Lawrence will be vice chairman.

There were some surprises in the fourth day of play in the Long Island women's interclub team golf matches at Cherry Valley today when Sound View moved up .from second place to take the lead in Class A.

Miss Ann Richardson of Mamanasco Lake, this place, gave a dinner at the Outpost Inn here tonight for Miss Joan P. Lusk and Charles Henry Tenney, who will be married tomorrow afternoon in St. Stephen's Church here.
Conference of public school superintendents and principals of New York and New Jersey, Horace Mann School, Broadway and 120th Street, 9 A. M. "The Church Looks at the School," Charles H. Morris.

If Winston Churchill has never been Foreign Secretary of great Britain, it is not because he has not a foreign policy, expressed with variations but with unfailing positiveness during a long and versatile career which has touched all the public peaks except the peak of his ambition. Like most Englishmen,
The Federal Trade Commission today issued a complaint against I. J. Fox, Inc., 393 Fifth Avenue, New York, charging -misleading representations in the sale of furs and fur products.

Unable to cope with the budgetary problem, Premier Paul Emile Janson and his Cabinet resigned this afternoon. Foreign Minister Paul Spaak, a Socialist, asked by the King to form a new government, accepted and in a statement to the press he said he hoped to have a Cabinet ready for Parliament's approval Tuesday.
Jose Ramon Gutierrez, Foreign Minister, accompanied by officials of the army, navy and air force, will leave here next Monday for an official visit to Brazil.
Henry Isaacs, president of the Twelfth Street Store, died today in the Michael Reese Hospital following an operation.

Gross assets, $58,929; net, $56,320. To John F. Brunner, sons, and Emma. L. Brunner, daughter, one-fourth residue each, latter also receives $2,000; three specific bequests. Chief assets, real estate, $30,000.

As was threatened, this tourist rambled around the Pimlico track the other day and looked over the Preakness situation as far as it had gone. The nominees, as usual, did no talking. Dauber was munching hay in a contemplative manner. Fighting Fox snubbed this visitor completely; wouldn't even turn around to return a nod of greeting.
Manhattan Alterations Park Ave, 277; to 12-story tenement; 277 Park Avenue Corp, 22 E 40th St, owner; Rosario Candela, architect; cost, $9,000.

Princeton took undisputed possession of first place in the southern division of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf League today by beating a previously undefeated University of Pittsburgh team, 5 to 4. The match was one of three in the first of three elimination rounds for intrasectional play-off berths.

In costumes of milkmaids and farmerettes, rural "sheriffs," "deputies" and farmhands, many members of the Young Women's Organization of the Women's National Republican Club and their husbands and friends attended a barn dance and box supper last night in the clubhouse of the organization at 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Bernard M. Baruch and Dr. Arthur E. Morgan have been named as honorary fellows, of Union College. Their appointments, running for a minimum of three years, will be effective with the next college year.

Chinese reinforcements, which were rushed south from the Lung-Hai Railway yesterday, are battling the Japanese column that has been advancing steadily north through Mengcheng and Yungeheng. The Chinese are fighting desperately to stem the Japanese offensive.

Trailing at 0--3 in the final set, Melvin Schwartzman of Poly Prep, the defending champion, rallied to take six games in a row and defeat Ralph Dawson of Trinity yesterday in the tournament of the Athletic Association of Private Schools at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills. The score was 4--6, 7--5, 6--3.

For the third consecutive period new bond financing this week was restricted to State and municipal offerings. Twelve individual loans in the tax-exempt class were placed on the market for an aggregate amount of $7,018,000, as compared with only $4,515,000 in new issues marketed last week. During this week last year $17,400,000 of new bonds were formally offered.

Plans for expanding one of the leading women's wearing apparel. stores in the city were announced yesterday when Bonwit Teller bought the six-story structure at 7 East-Fifty-sixth Street, in the rear of its twelve-story building at 721 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-sixth Street.

Alfred Rheinstein, Commissioner of Housing and Buildings and chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, believes that the simple six-story apartment structures planned for the vast Queensbridge and Red Hook public housing projects will have a "vital influence" on architecture of the future.
The league-leading Newark Bears reached four Montreal pitchers for sixteen hits today, including eight doubles, to trounce the Royals, 11-1.

The gardens of The Beeches, the home here of Mr. and Mrs. George Williams Seaman, provided the setting for the marriage at noon today of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Hurtin Seaman, to Robert Campbell Barry.

Asserting that a tapering of output earlier than had been expected had been decided upon, Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today this week's assemblies of cars and trucks at 47,415, against 53,385 last week and 139,507 a year ago.

The Roerich Museum, at 310 Riverside Drive. has passed out of existence, it was announced- yesterday by Louis L. Horch, president of the Master Institute of United Arts, Inc., controlling the twentynine-story combination of art galleries and apartment house.

The resignation of the Janson Cabinet in Belgium, after a life of five and one-half months, brought yesterday heavy selling of both spot and forward belgas and plunged the spot quotation-back to its previous lows.

For sixty-two years the Legal Aid Society has been helping poor people who could not buy legal services in the open market. By the end of 1937 it had dealt with 1,274,967 cases of all sorts, not counting those settled out of court.

The long, tapering fingers of Horton Smith, erstwhile Missouri farmboy who has made good on the links in a large way ever since he decided cows and chickens' didn't appeal to him, began to wrap themselves around the stem of the metropolitan open golf championship cup yesterday when he rounded the Fresh Meadow course in Flushing in sixty-nine swings.

Except for the public offering of $2,000,000 of Fall River Electric Light Company 3 1/3 per cent bonds, expected on Monday, little change next week is anticipated in the general character of the market for new issues.

Great Britain won't be able to call on Charles E. Hare for Davis Cup tennis duty after all. Hare agreed yesterday to play for the British in the second-round matches against Yugoslavia but today he informed officials he . would be unable to compete because of the death of his American employer.

Glen Caley, general manager of the New York, Ontario Western Railroad, is to become vice president of the Delaware Hudson Railroad, it was disclosed yesterday. He will succeed J. Taber Loree, who resigned recently from that position.
Benjamin Moore, Mayor of the village of Muttontown since its incorporation in 1931, lawyer and a veteran of the World War, died suddenly today of a heart ailment at Chelsea, his country place, here.

The Rev. James R. Cox was acquitted today on one of thirteen counts against him in connection with the $25,000 Garden Stakes contest. A Federal jury which deliberated twenty-five hours freed him on a charge of conspiracy to defraud by misuse of the mails.

An analysis of the earnings of 100 properties of various types upon which there is an outstanding bonded debt of $213,500,000 reveals an increase in 1937 over the two previous years, according to Burr Co.; Inc.

The United States imported 706,979 ounces of Mexican silver valued at $303,317 in the week ended on May 6, despite the recent suspension of the silver purchase agreement between this country and Mexico, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The Association of American Railroads reported today that preliminary statements from eighty-nine Class I railroads, representing 79.9 per cent of total operating revenues, showed that these roads in April had estimated operating revenues of $212,144,437, compared with $280,840,733 in April, 1937, a decrease of 24.5 per cent. President Roosevelt indicated today that the primary purpose of the proposed anti-monopoly investigation would be the discovery of means for stabilizing production and prices and new methods of preventing economic and business practice from "running away with the ball," which he said had interfered with previous spending programs.

Mrs. Caroline Lena Weil Buttenwieser, wife of Joseph L. Buttenwieser, philanthropist 'and former president of the Federation for Support of Jewish. Philanthropic Societies, died yesterday at her home, 885 Park Avenue, after a long illness. She was 69 years old.

Miss Lucille Louise Brion, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Brion, will be married on June 4 at the home of her parents here to William Juhring Broadhurst, son. of Mrs. William Channing Broadhurst of New Rochelle, N. Y. The Rev. Frank M. Townley will officiate.
Snark, winner in 1937, is the topweighted thoroughbred of the eleven named to run today at Belmont Park in -the forty-fifth renewal of the historic Metropolitan Handicap at a mile.
A $338,750 mortgage on 90 Morningside Dr, held by the Union Dime Savings Bank from the Disney Realty Corp, Sidney R. Jackson, president, was extended to Feb. 1, 1943, 4 1/2 per cent.

An "anti-jinx" party, "debunking" the gloom of old superstitions and omens, was given last night in the roof garden of the Montparnasse under the auspices of the women's social service auxiliary of the Knickerbocker Hospital.

Information emanating from reliable sources indicates that the possibility of foreign connivance in Wednesday's unsuccessful fascist Integralista revolt is daily gaining strength as the police widen their investigations and examine jailed Integralistas.

A sale of art for the garden, part two, assembled and collected by Karl Freund, brought a total of $13,727.50 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

United Artists, recently reorganized by Samuel Goldwyn and Alexander Korda, announced today that Hal Roach had terminated his thirteenyear association with Metro-Gold-. wyn-Mayer and had signed an eightYear agreement with United Artists.

Retirement from active service-of Hugh S. Gibson, veteran diplomat, who is now Ambassador to Belgium, was announced by President Roosevelt today. Mr. Gibson is retiring at his own request, having refused an offer of the Ambassadorship to Germany, Secretary Hull said later.
Germany is already beginning to talk of the commercial advantages she expects as a result of her formal recognition of Manchukuo.
By GEORGE J, KEARNS Rosedale Ave, 1,452, 26x95; Frederick V. Goess, receiver, against Del Gaudio Realty Co; due, $22,021, taxes, etc, $974; to plaintiff for $1,000.

The first annual communion service of the St. George Association of the New York Police Department, an organization of Protestant members of the force, will be held at 8 A. M. tomorrow in St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

Mayor F. H. La Guardia of New York, addressing the Amalgamated Clothing Workers convention, formulated today a platform on which he declared that the nation's progressive forces could stand, farmer and industrial worker.

All classes of livestock sold higher on the week-end market today. The strength on cattle however was more or less a forced affair. Hog supplies were also small and the advance met with no general approval according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

The "pitch and putt" golf course at Jacob Riis Park, Rockaway Beach, has been renovated and will be opened to the public today. A charge of 50 cents a player for one round is imposed, with the Department of Parks providing clubs and balls.
British Empire publication rights of "Village Tale," a novel by John de Meyer, recently published in the United States by J. B. Lippincott, have been bought by Victor Gollanez of London.
The Dale Construction Company sold to Kahn Miller the forty-onefamily apartment house at 2,850-6 Grand Concourse, northeast corner of 190th Street, on a plot 128 by 100 feet. Jacob Slade and L. V.

The National Retail Furniture Association announced today that it would file proof of trade abuses in the courts or with governmental agencies. The proposed action was decided on at a recent closed meeting of the board.

Harvard's nine took sole possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League today by. beating Cornell, 8 to 4. The setback sent the Ithacans, who had been tied for first place with the Crimson, into a deadlock for the runner-up notch with Yale.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The demand for wool this week has continued to drag along and prices are barely steady on the level of a week ago. Sales are mostly of fine and fine medium topmaking types. Activity is spreading out in the West, but is not heavy.
The junior class of the College of New Rochelle will hold its annual tea dance tomorrow afternoon at the Glen Island Casino under the chairmanship of Miss Helen Leddy of White Plains.

Establishment of Summer camps for underprivileged children of this city, to be run by the Board of Education, was proposed yesterday by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, Queens representative and chairman of the board's instructional affairs - committee.
It may have been Friday the Thirteenth, it may have been the wind or it may have been a false report, but the broadbill swordfish were NOT off the New Jersey coast yesterday.
Washington St (15-3934), s w cor of Railroad Ave, 105x108; Purdy-Starling Corp to Matthew F. Walsh, 1,325 Castle Hill Ave; three years, 6 per cent; $12,500.
Tony Galento, who hopes to get into the ring with Joe Louis one day, made a long stride in that direction when he knocked out Nathan Mann of New Haven at Madison Square Garden last night.
Oliver W. Birchead, president of the Peoples National Bank and Trust Company of White, Plains, has been elected a director of James Stewart Co., building contractors.

Mrs. Isaac S. Heller of 375 Howard Avenue, Woodmere, L. I., died on Tuesday of a heart ailment in Hamilton, Bermuda, on her return trip from a visit to South America, according to word received here yesterday.

The American Gas and Electric Service Corporation, New York City, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a declaration for approval of its organization and operation as a subsidiary service company of the American Gas and Electric Company,

President Roosevelt said that the projected anti-monopoly investigation would seek preventive for overproduction and unwarranted high prices, conferred with legislative and administrative aides, signed miscellaneous legislation and nominated Harry Slattery to be UnderSecretary of the Interior.

Army's tennis aces, Caldwell Russell and Albert Rollins, made it an all-cadet final in the New York State intercollegiate tennis championships today for the second straight year and again reached the doubles final as a team.

IT will probably be some time before any family can have a private television set trained on -the nursery so that an alert parent a ozen miles away can see young usan about to smite her brother Spike on the nose-with a cloth. rabbit in time to shout into the microphone.: "Tut! my girl, why not use the croquet mallet?"
The French aviatrix Elizabeth Lion took off from Istres flying field near Marseilles at 10:30 this morning in an attempt to better the woman's distance record held by the late Amelia Earhart.
Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches led a field of eighty-five in a oneday tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Ridgewood Country Club today.

Frances Ciambra, 17 years old, of 2,239 West Seventh Street, in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn, was shot and wounded critically at 10 o'clock last night by an unidentified youth, one of a group with whom she had been playing hideand-seek in the street in front of her home, according to the police.
Charles Dunning, Finance Minister, announced tonight that on next Wednesday subscriptions would be received for a new Dominion of Canada loan up to a

Speedy reorganization of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, a leader in the mbtion-picture industry, which went into equity receivership in January, 1933, and was the first large corporation to file under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, was indicated yesterday as details of the amended plan of reorganization became known. Acting on reported complaints that too much Works Progress Administration money is used to assist "whitecollar workers," Senator King said today on the floor of the Senate that he planned to offer a resolution calling for an investigation of WPA expenditures.

The general construction contract for the new rectory and school of St. Finbar's Roman Catholic Church, at 134-38 Bay Twentieth Street and 1,833-45 Bath Avenue, Brooklyn, has been awarded to S. F. Musselwhite, according to Brown's Letters, Inc.

Despite the failure of Congress to vote this week the additional appropriation required to meet the expenses of administration of the unemployment compensation laws after May 15, officials repeated here that action would be taken and the money made available in ample time for the issuance of the next pay checks, due at the end of May.
Gilda Gray, Milwaukee dancer, today divorced Hector de Briceno, whom she described as a member of the Venezuelan Cabinet. He was her third husband.
Konrad Henlein spent most of today closeted with British political leaders. Almost all he saw are opposed to Nazism and on the side of the ruling government in Czechoslovakia,

Joseph Clark Baldwin modified yesterday previous statements to the effect that he had personal knowledge of "sinister. influences" at work in the Municipal Court. His new statement was made after President Justice Pelham St. George Bissell had caused him to be served with a subpoena requiring. his presence in the justice's chambers at 8 Reade Street.

The new Union Bank of Commerce of Cleveland will open for business on Monday in the banking quarters formerly occupied by the Union Trust Company. Union Trust depositors on the same day will receive by mail checks drawn on the new bank and deposit slips aggregating $38,000,000, representing a 35 per cent dividend on their deposits in the old bank.

Adoption by the Westchester County Village Officials Association of a protest against the removal of top soil from the county for use on the World's Fair grounds and New York's Henry Hudson Parkway was announced here today.
Sit-down strike by convicts in California's State penitentiary at San Quentin in protest against annullment of a recess period.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today: These officers, having qualified, are placed on duty: Mandell, Capt. Rudolph, is to report to the commanding officer, 244th C. A., for assignment to Headquarters Battery and Combat Train, let Battalion.
A Colon theatre audience loudly booed and whistled the suite -from Shostakovich's opera, "The Nose," at last night's symphonic concert directed by Jose Iturbi.
PUNCHER AND SHEARER--$0.756, $0.816 and $0.876 per hour, Navy Yard, Brooklyn, New York. Applications must be on file with the Recorder, Labor Board, NavyYard, Brooklyn, N. Y., not later than May 20.

Despite a rise of 70.8 per cent in industrial production and a drop of 45.8 per cent in unemployment, Federal relief costs increased from $360,000,000 in the fiscal year 1932-33 to $2,467,000,000 in 1936-37, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There were recently published in your columns letters from two distinguished members of. the bar with reference to the proposal for providing a compensation board for negligence cases.

Columbia will polish its attack for the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships three weeks hence in the metropolitan intercollegiate title meet at Randalls Island Stadium today when the Lions defend the honors they won a year ago against the determined bids of Manhattan, N. Y. U., Fordham, City College and St. John's.
Edward P. Simpson, who was convicted of murder by a bullet in his neck, died in the electric chair today for the killing. of two Newton. policemen, Henry G. Bell. and Lawrence P. Murphy.
The Treasury Procurement Division today announced the awards of contracts for a total of 4,242,865 yards of textiles, for delivery July 8. The awards, from bids opened May 6, are as follows:

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase reviewed the. Reserve Officers Training Corps units of New York University yesterday afternoon at the twentieth annual field day held on the uptown campus at University Heights. More than 3,000 persons attended.

Fordham University's tennis team routed Villanova, 5--2,. on the Rams' home courts yesterday. Only one of the contests went into an extra set, Fred Rappleyea of the visitors conquering Gerard Johnson, 2--6, 8--6, 6--3.

Reports that General Juan Yague, described as one of the Spanish Rebels' ablest military leaders, has fallen into disgrace have been confirmed by reports received by the French Foreign Office from informants in Franco territory.

An industrial property in Hoboken, N. J., will be the home of Sperry Products, Inc., of Brooklyn, which will move to a building fronting on Park and Weillow Avenues, between Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets. The building,

Grievances which precipitated a short-lived sit-in strike of 500 students of the Great Neck High School Thursday were ironed out at a meeting of the Great Neck Board of Education and committees representing the students and their parents, held in the auditorium of the Arrandale Elementary School tonight.

Edmund Calvert Lynch, a partnerIn the investment banking firm of Merrill, Lynch Co., 40 Wall Street, a leader in the field of un?erwriting chain-store securities, lied Thursday in London, England, according to word received here yesterday. Mr. Lynch, who resided DR At 570 Park Avenue, also had homes in. Locust Valley, L. I., and Hog Island, Nassau, the Bahamas. He was 52 years old.
Mayor La Guardia will have another try at rapid transit unification, this time in cooperation with the Transit Commission, with which he has been at odds for more than four years.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,196,000 bales, against 1,215,000 a week ago, 1,255,000 two weeks ago; 1,239,000 three weeks ago and- 930,000 a year ago; of which American 800,000 bales, against 820,000 a- week ago, 828,000 two weeks ago, 818,000 three weeks ago and 405,000 a year ago.

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Federal court, Brooklyn, reserved yesterday until June 10 decision on an application by Ralph W. Crolly, representing the Brooklyn Trust Company, for an order directing the distribution of $500,000 by the trustees in reorganization of the Prudence Company, Inc.

Mr. and Mrs. Norman S. Ballantine of Denver have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Ballantine, to Bartlett W. Robinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Boardman Robinson of Colorado Springs.

Mrs. Anna Grabow has purchased for occupancy the eleven-room private residence at 240 Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn, from Elizabeth Cloonan through the Bulkley Horton Company, - brokers. The house, which is of three stories, on a plot 20 by 90 feet,. recently was remodeled b the seller.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 11: COMMANDERS Good, H. H., to Bureau of Navigation, Washington, D. C., instead Naval Operations.

Anthony S. Modleski, 35year-old traffic patrolman with a good record of Police Department service, yesterday shot his wife, three small sons and himself, killing all but one child, who was at the point of death last night in Greenpoint Hospital, Brooklyn.

The United States immigration policy was attacked yesterday by Percy C. Magnus, chairman of the committee for study of criminal alien activities of the American Immigration Conference Board, who asserted that it was contributing to four of the most serious problems of American life today.
Robert Blackburn, 17-year-old Negro student at De Witt Clinton High School, won three first prizes in a national art competition conducted by Scholastic, national high school magazine.

Taking advantage of the return of more than twenty billion francs from abroad since the franc was declared firmly fixed at not more than 179 for the pound sterling, the government will issue for subscription Monday a national defense loan that will be the first of its kind under the separate control of the committee. established to assure its entire disbursement for the purpose for which it is subscribed.

The one-story taxpayer, containing three stores, at 128-132 Main Street, White Plains, Westchester, I as been sold by the Mount Vernon Trust Company to a client of Sam Robinowitz, broker, for cash above a first mortgage of $132,000 held by the Bowery Savings Bank. Jacob I. Berman acted as attorney for the purchaser.

Archie San Romani, Kansan, duplicated his Kansas relay feat of vanquishing Glenn Cunningham, beating the former Kansas University star by two yards tonight in the Crump Invitation Mile of the Memphis, Cotton. Carnival track and field meet.

Responsibility for any oversupply of Federal surplus foodstuffs for home-relief families in Orangetown, Rockland County, was passed down the scale yesterday by Federal, State and county officials and finally laid at the door of the man who made the original charge that oranges, eggs, apples, rice and other commodities, supplied by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation,

Assisted by six other students, Theodore H. Von Laue, Princeton junior whose home is in Berlin, is collecting scraps from the kitchens of seven university eating clubs and distributing them among impoverished families of the town.

Kenneth Richmond, vice president and controller of Abraham Straus, Inc., will discuss "Operating Statements for Selling Departments on the Contribution Method" at the meeting of the Metropolitan Controllers Association to be held next Wednesday evening at the Roger Smith Restaurant.

Class A voting and Class B nonvoting shares of Canadian Industrial Alcohol Company will be stricken from unlisted trading by the New York Curb Exchange if the company, at its meeting of May 20, votes to cancel both issues.

" You must give the lie to the phrase 'Austrian easy-goingness,' for 'easygoing' in work is laziness," Field Marshal Hermann Goering told Linz workers today at the official inauguration of the Four-Year Plan in Austria.

Daniel Frohman, recently voted by the Broadway Association as "the Grand Old Man of Broadway," T was elected president yesterday of the Actors Fund of America for his thirty-fourth consecutive term. The fund held its fifty-sixth annual meeting at the Lyceum Theatre, 149 of West Forty-fifth Street.

Woodley, the historic estate which has been their Washington home since 1929, has been given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Stimson to Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., the deed to take effect at their death.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today an offering at par and accrued interest of $25,000,000 of Series A 2 per cent notes of the Federal National Mortgage Association, dated May 16 and maturing in five years.

Twenty-seven hedge-hopping planes of the army's attack squadrons roared out of the murk in the Newport News area today and bombed an "enemy aerodrome" with more than 100 high-explosive fragmentation bombs.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $7,316,150, consisting of loans of fifty-five municipalities, compared with the revised total of $11,920,359 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $24,562,892.

Jail failed to convince W. L. Tennyson that he should obey a State barber price-fixing law and he emerged under bond today vowing he would continue to be boss in the shop he has run nearly eighteen years.
The Scadta Company's four-seater Junkers plane Darien has not been reported since it left Tumaco for Bunaventura. The company refuses to give out information about passengers aboard.
By B. HOLLANDER SON 38th St, 257-61 W; 16-story loft and store, 54.8x98.9: Empire City Savings Bank against Morton Kulick; due $371,325; to plaintiff for $5,000.

With showers over most of Texas, instead of the warm, dry conditions reported necessary in the weekly weather bulletin, and with more activity in wholesale cotton goods quarters in last week and for some time, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday to the best figures of the month, to end with net gains of 10 to 12 points.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Pratt Jr., who have been at the Madison, will go today to Whitehall, their Summer place in Mill Neck, L. I. Mr. and Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss have come from McLean, Va., and are at the Gotham.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Another totally unfair criticism has been hurled at Bill Terry through the medium of your "Letters" by an apparently narrowminded, o-called Giant fan from Phiiadelphia.

Francis P. Gallagher of Kidder, Peabody Co. has been nominated for president of the Municipal Bond Club of New York for the coming year, it was announced yesterday by Fred W. Reichard, secretary. Others nominated are H. Albert Ascher of R. W. Pressprich Co., for vice president; Thomas F. McEntee. of Adams, McEntee Co., for secretary-treasurer;

Permission to enter a belated defense in the libel suit brought by Mrs. Edith Liggett, widow of Walter Liggett, newspaper editor who was slain near his home in Minneapolis, against the Comprodaily, Inc., publisher of The Daily Worker, Communist party newspaper;

The.Sailors Union of the Pacifio announced yesterday its intention of retaining its contract with the Shepard Steamship Company, intercoastal operators, despite the ruling of the National Labor Relations Board that the union was not qualified to represent a majority of the company's employes.

In a surprise move late today the government demanded that the Supreme Court order the Third Circuit Court of Appeals to allow the National Labor Relations Board to withdraw its order against the Republic Steel Company.
Offerings In the wool auction totaled 7,812 bales today, including 3,367 bales of South American wool at prices ranging from 7 3/4 to 12 pence. Sales amounted to 6.099 bales.

In his address before the American Law Institute Chief Justice Hughes said: I question if there is any greater need at this time than continued respect for the judicial tradition of independence and impartiality.

Two hundred and fifty photographs submitted from all over the United States and Canada were selected yesterday by a reviewing committee for entry in the first Scholastic Salon of Photography, which will be held at the American Museum of Natural History for a week beginning May 22.

Disposal of control of Associated Music Publishers, Inc., to Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., by the North American Company was revealed yesterday by reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission filed by both principals in the deal.
Revised rules covering the telegraphic transfer of funds through the Federal Reserve System were made public yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

At the final session of the adjourned 1937 annual meeting of shareholders of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, held yesterday in Richmond, Va., Morris E. Feiwell, Irwin T. Gilruth, A. L. Jackson, F. Z. Marx, C. A. McDonald, P. B. Shaw and Henry A. Stix were elected directors by unanimous vote of Class B stockholders represented.

Building and engineering contracts for all types of construction awarded in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains during April amounted to $222,016,000, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.

Asserting that the Interstate Commerce Commission acted beyond its powers and invaded the field of management when in April it refused a request that passenger fares on coaches be increased to 2 1/2 cents a mile, the Eastern railroads have filed with the commission a petition asking that the proceedings be reopened.

Rutgers and Lehigh led today in qualifying places for the finals tomorrow in the twenty-sixth annual Middle Atlantic States collegiate track and field meet. Rutgers, last year's runner-up to Haverford, qualified fifteen athletes, and Lehigh the same number.

Even though it was Friday the thirteenth, the inducement of more than $200 in prizes brought 304 artists in Greenwich Village yesterday to Washington Square and adjoining streets with nearly 4,000 works for the opening of the thirteenth semi-annual outdoor art exhibit.
Mrs. Sadie Peirce Wadley Capehart, widow of Captain Edward E. Capehart, U.S.N., retired, died early yesterday of heart disease at her temporary residence in Kent, Conn.

After serving as head cataloguer of the New York Public Library's circulation department since 1900, Miss Emma F. Cragin recorded yesterday the identifying letters on the last of uncounted thousands of books that have passed through her hands-and retired to write a book of her own.

At its eighteenth annual conference opening in Pittsburgh tomorrow and continuing through Friday the Association of Junior Leagues of America will deviate from its usual custom of devoting the major part of its time to reports of league activities.

This liner was driving through spotty fog and smooth seas at twenty-three knots today. This speed, exceeding the expectations of her builders and officers, should enable her to complete her maiden voyage on Monday afternoon instead of Tuesday morning.

The marriage of Miss Mary Dugas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Edward Dugas of Flushing, Queens, to Franklin William Richardson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Richardson of Flushing, took place yesterday afternoon in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church there. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Herbert C. Benjamin. the rector.

Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia headed a large list of Roman Catholic clerics sailing on the Italian liner Rex yesterday for the International Eucharistic Congress to be held at Budapest May 25-29.
EXHIBTIONS of American primitive paintings and wood sculpture serve to throw a significant sidelight on the antique furnishings sought by the collector.

THE National Council of the Boy Scouts, which each year since 1926 has awarded silver buffaloes for "distinguished service to boyhood," made eight such awards last night at the annual banquet marking the close of its twentyeighth annual meeting in Cleveland, Ohio.
THE increasing interest on the part of the general public in the problems relating to physical blindness will receive fresh stimulation in H. Randolph Latimer's "The Conquest of Blindness."
Sales of "lots ready for building" in subdivisions throughout the nation appear to have swung noticeably upward this Spring, after having started the year in sluggish fashion.

A discussion of "Culture Patterns and Their Effect on Personality" will be a feature of the luncheon to be held by the NewYork Council of the Girls Service League at the clubhouse, 138 East Nineteenth Street, on Wednesday. Dr. Frank Lloyd of New York University will lead the forum.

The annual communion breakfast of the Bishop Molloy Laymen's Retreat League will be held Sunday morning, May 22, at the Mary Louis Academy, 86-44 178th Street, Jamaica, Queens. About 1,000 persons are expected to attend.

Before they start criticizing the kind of motion picture or type of radio program that children enjoy, teachers should attend a Wild Western thriller themselves occasionally, or spend a few hours listening to a popular blood-and-thunder story coming over the air, educators attending the tenth-conference of elementary school workers at Teachers College, Columbia University, were advised yesterday.

TO Jerry a drummer in a band was about the most enviable person in the world. When his fingers. feeling their way with a pair of home-whittled pine sticks, rolled out a "daddy - mammy - daddy mammy" on a tin pail, his ambition began to take firm shape.

Our government is representative of individuals, and "unless the government, by its policies and actions, encourages character and exemplifies honesty and justice, character in private life will be weakened also," Alf M. Landon said in an address tonight at a high school commencement.

Once a year New York's capital awakes early whether the Albany burghers and their neighbors over in Rensselaer like it or not. There's no sleeping when almost a hundred speed boats, mufflers left behind, tear downstream to the tune of 5,000 explosions a minute.

THE new 1938-39 radios are beginning to move down the production belts, and the volume is expected to increase between now and September. June will see many of the new sets introduced at wholesale-retail meetings throughout the country.

Max Zaritsky, president of the United Hat, Cap and Millinery Workers Union, and mediator for William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in the factional fight in the International Pocketbook and Luggage Workers Union, installed nineteen officers of the latter union last night at the closing session of its convention at the Center Hotel, Forty-third Street near Sixth Avenue.

A new St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church is rising rapidly in the shadow of the Municipal Building. Workmen have completed about half of the new Georgian Colonial structure that will rise on the site of the tiny wooden building where the first night mass for printers and newspaper men was held about the turn of the century.
