Coming from apparently nowhere, a 15-to-1 outsider, J. D. Norris's Danger Point, surprised a crowd of 15,000 at Belmont Park yesterday when he captured the forty-fifth running of the $11,000 Metropolitan Handicap at a mile, and defeated some of the best handicap horses in the country.

" The greatest step forward in the emancipation of women" is the enthusiastic description of the study of the legal status of women undertaken by the League of Nationsas given by the American member of the committee, Miss Dorothy Kenyon.
Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti will speak on the Constitutional Convention at a meeting of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs on Friday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
EVER since the start of the depression, building construction has been depicted as one of the chief vil lains of the business decline and as a potential hero of recovery.

Rain and a low ceiling forced the postponement this afternoon of all but one of the events scheduled for the first day of the third annual meeting of the New England Intercollegiate Air Conference at Hampton Airport, near here.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., May 14.--The manoeuvres of the army's general headquarters air force, which were officially halted at midnight tonight for a Sunday armistice, have demonstrated a great improvement in the army's aerial efficiency, but have also revealed considerable weaknesses, in the opinions of officers here.

WE are tired of being called a grouch. If you must have the truth, we are victims of environment. THE TIMES'S motion-picture department is bounded on the east by the morgue (its official title is the biographical index) and on the west by a church.

THIS is a season of activity along the waterfront. Ships are sailing to far distant ports and arriving from the other side of the world. Trawlers racing in from Georges Banks with holds overflowing with pop-eyed cod and haddock steam up-river beside palatial cruise ships from the Caribbean.

BREEZES may yet be too chill for one's ball and chain to abandon wintry satin and velvet for the flowered chiffon and mousseline de sole of Summer, but the keepers of our town's hotel rooftops are a forearmed lot and they have already exposed considerable entertainment above the street level.
The annual death toll of beautiful shade trees exacted by lightning cannot be accurately estimated, yet that it is high is quite obvious to any one driving thrbugh the country.

A DEEP voice throbbing in song sounds across the desert as the waning moon lifts above the cloud bars to wash the shapes of cattle with pale light. It is the song of the night rider as he circles the herd.

" To save peace and your liberties - subscribe!" reads the slogan on posters being plastered tonight throughout Paris advertising the new defense loan.
Arrests of Integralistas, both civilians and navy men, are continuing in Brazil in the wake of their unsuccessful uprising last Wdnesday.

Each of the following Medical Department Reserve Officers is assigned to the organization indicated: 22D STATION HOSPITAL (R.A.L.) Capt. Albert L. Eisner, Med.-Res., 10 Mt. Morris Park. New York, N. Y.
The British Minister to Mexico informed the Mexican Foreign Office that he had been ordered by his government to withdraw from Mexico. He said he would leave as soon as he could pack his belongings.

PROFESSOR WRONG, who has to his credit, as author or editor, a long list of scholarly contributions to Canadian history has here undertaken to tell, for the general reader, the whole story of Canada and its people.

Mrs. Arthur B. Walsh of this city and Green Valley Farm, Princeton, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Vivien Rodgers Walsh, to Armand London Fell, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Henry Fell of Trenton, N. J.

The following is the chart showing how the Preakness Stakes was run at Pimlico today: FIFTH RACE--The Preakness; $50,000 added; 3-year-olds; one mile and three-sixteenths. Start good; won handily; place driving. Went to post 5:551/2 (New York time), off 5:59. Winner, ch. o., by Pennant-Ship o' War. Trainer, R. E. Handlen. Net value to winner, $51,875; second, $10,000; third, $5,000; fourth, $2,000. Time--1:59 4-5. Weather raining; track sloppy.

The St. John's team, composed of James Fishbach and Alan Merkle, captured the New York State intercollegiate tennis doubles championship today, defeating Cadets Caldwell Russell and Albert Rolling, Army's 1937 champions, 1-6, 9-7, -4.

A document signed by Thomas Lynch Jr., signer of the Declaration of Independence from South Carolina, whose autograph is among the rarest of those of American Revolutionary figures, will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Gallerie?? Inc. on Thursday afternoon.

Harvard's smooth-stroking varsity crew today sprinted from behind in the last quarter mile and outdistanced Cornell's powerful and heavier eight by a length and a quarter in a quadrangular race with Syracuse and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on the Charles River.

British authorities were reported today to be preparing a protest to Japan against rough treatment suffered by E. S. Wilkinson, a British naturalist living here, who was detained twelve hours by Japanese.

The marriage of Miss Thora Anna Bird, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Viggo E. Bird of West Hartford, to Gordon Chase Streeter, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward C. Streeter of Red Brook, Stonington, took place here this afternoon in the Trinity College chapel.
General Miguel Cabanellas died here early this morning. He had been tricken with a cerebral hemorrhage. At the outbreak of the civil war General Cabanellas immediately joined the Insurgents.

Preparations are being completed by J. J. Shubert and Fol??e Gallo for the presentation of "Three Waltzes" at the Jones Beach Marine Stadium beginning Saturday, June 25, according to an announcement today.

In observance of the silver jubilee of Jewish National Fund Flower Day, Zionist volunteers will sell "Palestine flowers" here and in many communities throughout the United States today, it was- announced yesterday by the Jewish National Fund of America.
THE GARDEN: MORE COLOR FOR LATE SUMMER

The State Constitutional Convention this week became a forum of debate on proposals to remove from the organic law the existing prohibition against lotteries and other forms of gambling. Advocates and opponents warmly pleaded for acceptance of their views.

What has most impressed even the experienced observer regarding the present business reaction has been not so much its occurrence at this distance from the beginning of after-depression recovery in 1932-in that respect the setback has conformed to past experience--as the severity of last Autumn's reaction and the fact that there has as yet seemed to be no recovery from it.

Ideas picked up on a trip to Scandinavia are being used in' the reconstruction of the twelve-story apartment house at 320-30 Park Avenue. An apartment in Swedish modern style, a spacious suite and a traditional apartment for the traveled family feature the model apartments just opened for inspection in the building.

Mr. and Mrs. John L. Gray of Piping Glen Farm, Stanwich Road, gave a tea there this afternoon for Mr. and Mrs. Eric Archdeacon of Berlin, who have been visiting Mrs. Archdeacon's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Edwin Hall of Old Church Road, Greenwich.

For a year or two plants of the tube-flowered Kalanchoe have been growing commoner, but in the young stage mostly. They-are interesting in that stage, with their odd tubular- leaves, gray- green, spotted or streaked with wine-purple. They are also cheap. Few people have taken the trouble to grow the older ones.

Bonds called for redemption before maturity last week aggregated the smallest volume in many weeks, with only two fair-sized calls among the announcements. Aside from several Land Bank redemptions, the new notices were principally in the municipal and industrial fields.

The Great Northern Railway today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to pledge and repledge $15,000,000 principal amount of the road general mortgage 6 per cent gold bonds, Series F, now held in the Treasury, as collateral for short-term notes in the current year.
Dispatches from the town of Santiago Tezontlale, Hidalgo, reported today that seven peasants had been killed and fifteen wounded in an attack by armed agrarians.

The Dodgers still are no bargain for Casey Stengel. Yesterday they came home to Ebbets Field and, while 8,259 Flatbush fans sat contentedly throughout an afternoon of drizzling rain, trounced Casey's Boston Bees, 10 to 2.

British Board of Trade figures for April as follows: Total imports, [Pound]84,870,000; exports of British products, [Pound]42,150,000; re-exports, ??5,460,000; total exports, ??47,610,000; excess of imports, [pound]37,260,000.

IN the long-forgotten era before the World War when the old Emperor Francis Joseph still reigned in Vienna, and Austria was a great power, it used to be noted that the double-headed eagle of Austria-Hungary faced in two directions-westward toward the Germanspeaking world and eastward toward the Balkans.

In the following article-the third of a series-the organizer of the Asiatic Primate Expedition sums up its field work, which recently came to an end. The first and second articles appeared in The Times Magazine on Aug. 1 and 8, 1937.

The Accurate Brass Company's new building at Eighty-eighth Street and Seventy-third Avenue, Glendale, L. I., is nearing completion and is expected to be ready for occupancy about June 15. It is being erected to take care of expanding business.

Curtis W. McGraw, '19, of New York was elected alumni representative on the University Council on Athletics and Robert M. Green, '13, of Newark, N. J., alumni representative on the board of directors of The Princeton Alumni Weekly, at the annual Spring meeting of the graduate council of the National Alumni Association of Princeton University this week. Both will take office in August.

The creation of an undergraduate committee on academic problems to promote closer relationship between students and faculty in matters of study and academic standings was announced today by Dan D. Coyle, '38, of Centreville, Md., chairman of the undergraduate council of Princeton University.
The National Action Committee of the Socialtst party charged in a statement today that the new La Follette-led National Progressives of America, Inc., "moves toward fascism."

A special meeting of the Board of Education will be held at 2 P. M. Wednesday at 500 Park Avenue. Action will be taken on the by-laws pertaining to the reorganization of the board's bureau of construction and maintenance.

A charge that co-leaders of the Philadelphia Democratic organization were making "frantic, unscrupulous efforts" to "steal" next Tuesday's Pennsylvania primary election in this city was made today by Senator Joseph F. Guffey.

Recently in this column reference was made to the new colloidal form of lead arsenate for the treatment of lawn areas infested with grubs of the Japanese beetle and the Asiatic beetle. The advantages of this new form, as compared to the old, are several.
EVEN the men who have employed Mr. Tolefree to investigate the death of William Limpenny are extremely cautious about giving him any information upon which to work.

Harvard's rugby team closed its season today by beating Hofstra College, 9 to 5. Harvard scored first on a try, missed the conversion and then the visitors went ahead on Connors's try - and conversion. Cohen and Osgood made tries for Harvard in the second- half, during which the Crimson was at-its best.

The annual Spring meeting of the department of teachers of subnormal children, New Jersey Teachers Association, will be held in the Essex House here next Saturday at 10:30 A. M. Industrial work by subnormal children throughout the State will be displayed.
Solar activity and ultraviolet radiation are related. Ultraviolet radiation causes microscopic organisms to grow in water reservoirs. To kill them copper sulphate or chlorine gas is used.

ANELANYTE-Mr. and Mrs. William J., announce birth of a daughter, May 8, 1938, at Polyclinic Hospital. BERMAN-Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bennet (nee Janet Frankenthaler), announce the arrival of a son, Robert Edward, on Mother's Day, Sunday, May 8.

Miss Ruth Shively, daughter of Mrs. Sarah Shively of Batesville, Ohio, and the Rev. Lee E. Walker, son of Mrs. Minnie Walker of Delhi, N. Y., were married here tonight at the home of the Rev. Mr. Walker's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond E. Walker.

The wedding of Miss Sara Pickett Woolsey, daughter of Mrs. Theodore Salisbury Woolsey, to Kenneth MacLean, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles Chalmers MacLean of Batavia, N. Y., took place this afternoon at the Woolsey residence here.

THE most stimulating bit of news that has come out of Hollywood this season is Samuel Goldwyn's announcement that he will undertake production of "The Exiles," a topical story dealing with political oppression in European countries.

A strike of roustabouts and maintenance men, the second in just over a month, bogged down the circus at Utica and East New York Avenues, Brooklyn, for two hours early today until an agreement was reached between the American Federation of Actors and the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Company, the operators.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am a member of the House of Representatives of the Imperial Diet of Japan. In 1930, after having finished six years' study of economics and law at university, I made a tour of over a year through the United States and the European countries for the purpose of obtaining actual first-hand knowledge of those countries.

The newspaper Matin today quotes the Air Ministry as having received a radiogram from the French aviatrix Elizabeth Lion annbuncing that she had landed at Abandan, twelve miles east of Basra, on the Persian Gulf, breaking the late Amelia Earhart's non-stop mark by covering approximately 4,300 kilometers [about 2,670 miles].

A gift of $25,000 from the alumnae of the University of Pennsylvania to the university's bicentennial fund was announced today by Miss Althea Kratz, directress of women, at the annual meeting of the alumnae association.
A NEW type of signal lens to control high-speed traffic on the open road has been installed in the traffic lights on the highways of Maryland.
Dr. Julio J. De Poo charged in a divorce suit on file today that his wife's jealous nagging made him "a menace to the safety of the public" when he drove an automobile.

The Cloisters, the new branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Fort Tryon Park, was opened to the public yesterday for the first time. In the seven hours it was open it -was visited by 4,473 persons.

LONDON, May 14.--Konrad Henlein, leader of the German minority in Czechoslovakia, left for home by plane tonight by way of Berlin after. Britons said he had assured them that he was willing to make concessions to settle the minority problem.

THE DIAL PRESS, founded in 1924 by Lincoln MacVeagh, has been purchased by Burton C. Hoffman, formerly president of Knight Publishers, and new offices for the organization have been opened at 432 Fourth Avenue, New York City.

A little more than twelve years after he made the first commercial air mail flight in an 86-mile-anhour monoplane, Captain L. G. (Larry) Fritz, now superintendent of the Eastern region of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., will take off from Los Angeles at 1 P. M. (E. D. T.) today in one of T. W. A.'s twin-motored, 200-mile-an-hour transports for New York.
Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., won the Southern golf championship today in a thrilling match with Mrs. Estelle Lawson Page ot Chapel Hill, N. C., the national titleholder. The score was 1 up.

An illuminated, colored diorama or architectural mOdel of New York City, almost a city block in length and more than a three-story building in height, will be the principal exhibit of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and affiliated companies at the New York World's Fair in 1939, according to an announcement yesterday by Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board.

Jimmy Foxx topped off a wild-hitting ball game today with a long-range homer into the center-field bleachers in the eleventh inning that gave the Red Sox a 10-to-9 triumph over the Senators and boosted the Sox into first place in the American League.

Miss Elisabeth Mills Fawcett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred L. Fawcett of Brooklyn, has completed plans for her marriage to William Elder Robertson of Baltimore, which will take place here June 4 in St. Bartholomew's Church.

It is grim irony that the country whose generous indignation put it in the forefront of the League crusade in behalf of Ethiopia should have taken the lead at Geneva this week both in abandoning sanctions against the aggressor and in setting the seal of legality upon his successful aggression.
The Cuban Government will not impose additional taxes on the sugar industry, according to a palace communique issued following a Cabinet meeting.
Princeton's golf team captured the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf League's Southern Division today by defeating Cornell, 8 to 1.

WITH the production of "Washington Jitters" the Theatre Guild is just concluding its twentieth season. Although twenty years is a long time in the history of any theatre organization, it does not seem much longer than the past two years that have represented the Guild's private depression.
THE total of the new Civil List pensions granted during the year ended March 31 is f2,500.

New York State's elevation to first rank in the adoption of-nursing legislation has been selected by the registered nurses of the State as an occasion for a celebration which will honor Assemblywoman Jane Todd and Senator A. Spencer Feld, sponsors of the bill which becomes operative as a law on July 1.
LAST year Charles Edward Crane showed us Vermont, in a lively volume with an introduction by Dorothy Canfield Fisher.

MORE than 1,000 invitations to a television demonstration for the press on Tuesday afternoon and evening at Radio City have been issued by the National Broadcasting Company. There will be a continuous performance of a twenty-five-minute variety show, including films and live talent.

WHEN the Washington atmosphere was sizzling and crackling not long ago with Capitol rumors and White House denials of a rift between President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner over recovery policies, the wise old Texan pulled one of his favorite tricks. He relaxed.

The President of Cornell University and Mrs. Edmund Ezra Day of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Louise Day, to Frederick Cleveland Copeland, son of Professor and Mrs. Nanton Copeland of Brunswick, Me., and Woods Hole, Mass.

Miss Jane Elizabeth Herrmann, daughter of Mrs. Charles Edward Herrmann of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to William Edwin Hill, son of Mrs. William Edwin Hill of Mamaroneck, which will take place at noon on June 4 in the garden of the home of the prospective bride's mother, 5 Heathcote Road.
MOUNTIES are traditionally reputed to get their men, but here is an obviously veracious history of their organization that tells of several cases in which the criminals got the Mounties.

Howard P. Vermilya, director of the FHA technical division, declares that building codes now in effect in the majority of cities have been outmoded by recent technical developments and should be redrafted to allow the introduction of approved new materials and building practices.

A registration statement covering issuance of common stock for estimated gross cash proceeds of $24,099,639 has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act-of 1933 by Quarterly Income Shares, Inc. Jersey City, an investment trust, of which Ross Beason is president.

If opponents of the New Deal Administration are hoping to see President Roosevelt's party leadership jolted in the coming Kentucky primary this Summer, present indications are that they will be just as disappointed as they were by the results of the Florida primary a few days ago.

Persons conducting business under an assumed trade name must now meet four requirements in addition to the mere filing of a certificate, the Commercial Credit Council pointed out yesterday in a statement 'outlining the provisions of four amendments sponsored by the council which were passed at the last session of the Legislature and approved by Governor Lehman.

The Anvil Chorus, a Brooklyn organization of professional, business and newspaper men, held its twenty-ninth annual dinner last night in the grand -ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Nearly a thousand persons at the dinner applauded skits satirizing the New Deal, New York State politics and city Fusion.
Crashing through a wooden fence surrounding an excavation near the Triborough Bridge approach at 135th Street and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, a sedan driven by Miss Doris Foote, 21 years old,

Seldom has a new "type" of an old flower won such immediate and widespread popularity as has been accorded the Dwarf Hardy Asters. Much as gardeners loved the tallergrowing types, the height and more or less weedy growth made them, under many conditions, impracticable.
Four boys from the upper West Side met Friday afternoon on Riverside Drive, carved crosses on their left forearms with a penknife and decided to embark on careers of crime.

MUSICAL MAYOR: Fiorello H.La Guardia likes to experience the city's activities at first hand. He answers police radio calls, attends fires, encamps for the Summer in distant boroughs; last week he served as musical commentator on the city's own radio station.
THE saccharine cycle is on the way to being revived by the screen, this time with an eye to aggressive nobility. Warners are making "In Every Woman's Life,"
Representatives of the National Council of State Garden Clubs, coming from nearly forty States, will be guests this week of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State.

A drum and bugle corps contest for American Legion teams, under the auspices of President Borough of Manhattan Post-84, will be held today in Madison Square Garden. Juniors will compete in the afternoon, beginning at 2 o'clock, and seniors at night, beginning at 8:15 o'clock.

Thirty-five craft were out today in the first regatta of the season on Long Island Sound, a non-championship affair held by the Larchmont Yacht Club. A number of ocean-going yachts, several of which are going to Bermuda in the race from Newport next month, had their first trials in competition:

Bernard F. Hogan, president of the Greater New York Savings Bank of Brooklyn and recently appointed chairman of the Mayor's committee on property improvement, declares that several thousand buildings in the five city boroughs, including both residential and business structures could be profitably renovated.

THE tobacco weed has taken on something of a national character, thanks to the enterprise of the Library of Congress. The famous collection of books, manuscripts and drawings formed by George Arents Jr. is now being handsomely displayed in the public galleries in Washington.

Bayside (71)-Fred H. Korff made a holein-one on the 150-yard fourteenth hole with a No. 6 iron while playing with Steve Hall and Ray Murphy. Brookville (72)-Match Play 'Handicap Against Par, Class A; M. J. Kramer, all even. Class B: L. M. Bonnewell, all even.

Precooling vegetables and fruit keeps them in good condition for market. Improvements in the process have been introduced in California and Florida to treat green peas, celery, broccoli, cabbage, asparagus and other vegetables.

Election of new executives for student publications at Lehigh University was approved by. the Board of Publications this week. Willet Weeks Jr. of Ridgewood, N. J., has been chosen editor-inchief of the Brown and White, student semi-weekly newspaper.

Mrs. Nancy R. Bradsby of Miami Beach, Fla., widow of Frank W. Bradsby, was married yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church to Walter Reed Emmons of 2 East Eighty-sixth Street, by the rector, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent.
Miss Mary Jeanne Stourton and the Hon. Ralph Robert Watts Sherman Stonor, whose engagement was announced this month, will be married on July 14 at Brompton Oratory.
A new decree forbids German film actors and actresses to accept commissions abroad without the express permission of the Propaganda Ministry.

After setting a competitive course record in winning the qualifying round this morning with a 69, Edmund H. Driggs Jr. of Cherry Valley won his first-round match this afternoon in the annual Morris County Golf Club invitation tournament, He defeated John D. Ames of Chicago, 2 and 1.

Representative Bruce Barton will be the principal speaker at the annual convention of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers to be held at the Greenbrier, White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., May 25, to 27.

Although defeated in one of his nine games in the recent international chessmasters' tournament at Margate, England, Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris, champion of the world, nevertheless carried off the first prize, with Rudolph Spielmann of Vienna as the runner-up.

WITH the first week in May bringing no pronounced increase in new and used car sales, dealers generally are preparing for a sharp increase in service operations during the next six weeks to two months.

Becoming somewhat "fed up" with the dire predictions in' business and other circles about economic conditions, Henry G. Weaver, director of consumer research for General Motors, last week published a booklet at his own expense, in which he announced an "individual moratorium" on discussing the economic situation.
The 101st Council session, all here agree, marks a new high for balance-ofpower politics and a new low for the League.

Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, announced on his departure for Europe last week that he had given orders for the erection of a new machine shop, three stories high, on a plot 160 by 450 feet, adjoining the firm's plant at Endicott, near Binghamton, N. Y. ?he new structure will cost $750,?00.

A bill to provide increased pay for the enlisted man of the army has apparently received short shrift at the hands of the War Department, which approves the legislation in principle but feels itself obliged to oppose it in actuality.
Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School captured the city C. H. S. A. A. novice track team championship for the third straight time at McCarren Park in Brooklyn yesterday.

The NashKelvinator Corporation will make Lincoln, Neb., a "proving ground" this week for a national salesmen's "Crusade Movement" to "prove in Lincoln and surrounding territory that sound, persistent selling methods are effective today, as they always have been," George W. Mason, president, announced today.

Professor Morris Raphael Cohen, who retired from the Department of Philosophy at City College in ebruary, was guest of honor at a dinner given by the - associate alumni of the college in the Hotel Roosevelt last night.
NOBODY has ever accused Fanchon Royer, Hollywood's only woman producer, of making sissy pictures.

The Mary Paul Collins Scholarship for foreign women, one of the highest honors offered by Bryn Mawr College, has been awarded for 1938-39 in the Department of Geology to Miss Anna Hietanen of Finland.

In the garden of London Terrace another Chelsea Jamboree, patterned after last year's event, will be -held on the night of June 9 under the auspices of Chelsea Charities to raise funds to.'send neighborhood children to Sumer camps.

Jules Eckert Goodman's dramatization of "Treasure Island" was presented yesterday afternoon at the Hippodrome, Forty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, by the WPA Federal Theatre Project. Matinee performances will also be given next Saturday and on May 29.

High as are the barriers that most countries have erected to protect what they conceive to be their economic integrity, the outlook today is international. The rapid interchange of scientific ideas and goods has made it so. Science has made the interchange possible. It is an international force.

Japanese exports of cotton piece goods, which slumped sharply in January and February increased substantially in March, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today. March exports were placed at 229,572,000 square yards, compared with 235,640,000 in the same month last year.

The board of directors of the New York County Criminal Courts Bar Association announced yesterday its opposition to the proposed plan of District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, under which in the future "senior" and "junior" panels of outside lawyers will serve as volunteer counsel when needy defendants are placed on trial.
Bela Imredy, the new Premier, said in a warmly applauded speech in Parliament today that the would continue the foreign policy of Koloman Daranyi, his predecessor.

Chugging monotonously round a 400 - kilometer nearly triangular course at a steady 110 miles an hour, the Japanese plane trying for closed-circuit distance record is completing fifty-three hours in the air as this is written.
The first criminal prosecution under the Wagner Act is to begin in Federal District Court here Monday, with 200 witnesses called by the government.

The marriage of Mrs. Evelyn Fahnestock Steele of Seabright, N. J., and this city, to William Greenough Wendell took place at noon yesterday in the first-floor suite of the Ritz-Carlton. The Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, performed the ceremony.

Declaring that seven or eight million of the world's 17,000,000 Jews are living under dictatorships, William Weiss, president of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, last night asserted that the future of Jewry rests with the Jewish community in America.

The average residential property valued at $7,305 in 1928 was worth only $5,000 in 1938 in the northeastern portion of the country, according to a survey made recently by the Society of Residential Appraisers, of which Frank D. Hall is president of the Greater New York Chapter.

As the Norton Wages and Hours Bill apparently heads for enactment in Congress, there is much doubt as to the number of wage earners who stand to get increased wages and more leisure from its provisions.

Keuka College is having its annual week of powwow, an old Indian tradition which dates to the beginning of the college's existence. As the ancient tribes had their powwows ;around campfires, so the juniors have theirs in a secret place three and a half miles from the college.

MOHANDAS K. GANDHI, who recently was in retirement in the small and inaccessible village of Shegaon, whither he had taken himself to recover his health, has again become active in the politics of India, though he is so far from well that he feels he is "not likely to live very long-perhaps a year or a little more."

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

An annual report issued yesterday by Clare Tree Major's Children's Theatre showed that four companies employed by Mrs. Major had traveled a total of 100,000 miles during the last year and had played to a total audience of approximately 1,500,000 children.
TRAVELERS in Europe this Summer will have the opportunity of seeing two airports Le Bourget near Paris and Tempelhof in Berlin-which dwarf America's sky terminals.

The stock market moved narrowly and closed irregular yesterday in the slowest trading since April 30. The same was true of the bond market. The turnover in stocks on the "Big Board was 233,000 shares, and the volume in the listed bond market was $2,689,000.

Hank Borowy, Fordham University sophomore pitching star who has attracted the interest of major league scouts, has decided to finish his college career before turning pro, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
The New York State Merchant Marine Academy will dedicate historic Fort Schuyler in the Bronx as its land base on Saturday at 2:30 P. M., according to an announcement made yesterday.

The most comprehensive program ever developed by an American community to provide medical scare for the needy sick in their own homes is being extended to supply health protection for the impoverished aged and blind, as well as the 550,000 men, women and children on home relief in this city, Edmond B. Butler, chairman of the citizens' advisory committee of the Department of Welfare, disclosed yesterday.

A dove of peace and good-will bearing a figurative olive branch and an actual note reading, in effect, "Let's get together on these expositions and make 1939 an allAmerican World's Fair year," is expected to arrive at the office of Mayor La Guardia about noon today.

All danger of the pilot forgetting to lower the retractable landing wheels prior to landing can now be eliminated, it is asserted, provided the airplane is equipped with the "robot" landing gear described in a patent (No. 2,115,701) just granted to Howard Baer of Jersey City, and Martin T. Finnegan of New York City.

First in importance among New Jersey women to head their organizations during the ensuing club terms is Mrs. Patrick Henry Adams of Maplewood, uncontested candidate for-president of the State Federation of Women's Clubs.

Freddie Wolcott took the iron-man role today as Rice Institute won the annual Southwest Conference track and field meet. He won three first places, breaking records with two of his performances, and anchored the Owls in their 440-yard relay victory.
A student poll has disclosed that Harvard's ten-million-dollar house plan is solving one of the pressing problems here-how to enlist the mass of students in activities other than studies.

THE growing interest in the motor world among high school students is reflected by the heavy enrollment of teachers of automotive -mechanics for the 1938 Summer training courses at the General Motors Institute in Flint,

Joseph W. Catharine, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, will inaugurate on Tuesday a three-month series of conferences with real estate groups which will take him across the United States twice and to Hawaii.

VAL GIELGUD, director of dramatic production for the British Broadcasting Corporation, en route to London after a month in Hollywood, stopped on Manhattan Island long enough to direct two dramatic broadcasts.

A local boy made doubly good in the metropolitan open golf championship at the Fresh Meadow Club, near Flushing, yesterday when Jimmy Hines of Lakeville won the event for the second year in succession. He was the first to repeat a victory in the tournament since Walter Hagen turned the trick in 1920.

The text of those parts of Premier Mussolini's speech here today dealing with foreign affairs follows: You won't be surprised, comrades, if as on all these occasions of memorable gatherings of Fascist people I speak to you about certain questions of an international character.
FOR several weeks I have been reading and analyzing the debates in your columns of THE TIMES anent the American Filmplay vs. the Foreign Filmplay.

ONE seldom comes across a novel more immediately satisfying than "My Son, My Son!" Built along solid Victorian lines, well timbered and four-square, generous in action and character drawing, there is none of the nervous striving for new effects and originality that has taken so many contemporary writers into dark byways.

A sixyear experiment in progressive education comes to an end this semester at Temple University. It has revolved about the "X" group, composed of flexible and adaptable students preparing to become teachers in progressive high schools.

Paintings and drawings made by Spanish children familiar with war will be shown at Lord Taylor's during the week beginning tomorrow. Half the proceeds will go to the young painters in the form of food packages and half to the Spanish Child Welfare Association of America, the honorary chairman of which is Ambassador Claude e Bowers.

OF none of the peoples of the ancient world has the average reader so utterly mistaken an idea as of the Egyptians. Confronted with pictures of obelisks and pyramids, gigantic statues and immense sarcophagi, he imagines them a gloomy, solemn people, given to cruelty and a generally kill-joy attitude toward life.

Peddie School, Lower Merion High and Perth Amboy High carried off the titles in their respective divisions today as 500 athletes competed in a driving rain in the fourteenth annual Lafayette interscholastic track and field games.

The St. Mary's Celtics of Brooklyn, national soccer cup finalists, took a one-point lead yesterday in the first game of the home and home series with the Irish-Americans of Kearny, N. J. Playing at Celtic Park in South Brooklyn the home team defeated the Jerseymen, 1-0.

Stocks closed irregular in the dullest trading so far this month; turnover, 233,220 shares. United States Government bonds lower in featureless transactions; foreign and domestic issues irregular: total turnover. $2,689,800.
There's reason for the brilliance and bright coloring of the buildings that rise over Biscayne Bay in contrast to the more subdued colors usually used on houses in the North.

Rolling up a total of 69 points, six more than they made last year, the athletes representing Frederick Douglass Junior High of Harlem captured the team championship for the seventh year in a row at the annual Public Schools Athletic League junior high outdoor track and field games at the General George W. Wingate Athletic Field in Brooklyn yesterday morning.

The above clause was written into the Empire State's basic code in 1894, and it is still there. Nevertheless, open book-making goes on at the horse race tracks; the pari-mutuel system, in use in all other States that have horse race tracks, remains forbidden here, although at the last session the Legislature proposed a constitutional amendment to legalize it.

Among the thousands of boys and girls who will get their high school diplomas here next month will be a group of 140 student electricians, members of the first graduating class of Samuel Gompers Industrial High School. Trained in the intricacies of neon lights, wireless, television, traffic signals, ignition and cable-splicing, they will stand ready to enter the electrical engineering field.

CORK-COVERED photographic albums are now competing with fabric-covered albums in popularity. Made from thinly rolled sheet cork, the first-named albums are constructed with a special ring binder that permits refilling.

The destruction of Austria's independence-the first open move in Germany's "Drang nach Osten"--and the methods whereby it was brought about throw valuable light on what is afoot in all the States that in one way or another she would have to master in a march toward the oil fields of Rumania and Mosul.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 14.--President Roosevelt, in a telegram read at the convention of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America today, reaffirmed his "pledge to continue the great work which so many Americans have undertaken together."
Miss Jane Porter Boomer, daughter of Mrs. George A. Boomer of Waterbury, has chosen June 4 for her marriage to Lawrence Begelow Barnard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Barnard of Worcester, Mass.

WITH the writing of history so largely taken over by the biographers in recent years, it was inevitable that sooner or later some one would turn to the first Stuart sovereign of England, James VI of Scotland, Elizabeth's successor on the southern throne, under whom the two kingdoms were united.

There is to be no camouflage at the reopening of the public campaign for the destruction of Catholicism and Protestantism at the Sportspalast here May 28. The following declaration has been issued by the National Church movement leaders who will speak at the meeting:

Rhode Island is witnessing a -sensational increase in the registered vote of the State. As of April 30; 1936, a Presidential year, the total registration was 45,795. This year on the corresponding date the total was 82,800, an increase of 37,085, or almost exactly 80 per cent.

Cooperating with the Transit Commission for the first time sinc he took office in 1934, Mayor La Guardia is preparing to complete negotiations, started by the commission last August, for the city's purchase of the rapid-transit properties of the B. M. T., the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company, and their inclusion in a unification plan.

Persistent reports that the foreign service of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Commerce Department might be transferred to the State Department and that if this were done Secretary Roper would resign led to a denial today by Mr. Roper and a White House spokesman that anything of the kind was in prospect.

Toolbox, gray gelding owned by Richard K. Mellon, today won his first leg on the Billy Barton Steeplechase trophy in the feature of the Radnor Hunt Club meet on the Chesterbrook Farm estate of Mrs. J. Packard Laird.

Yale and Princeton were tied at six matches apiece when rain and darkness halted their annual tennis battle today. The Tigers took six of the ten singles matches, and Yale won the only two doubles played.
Mrs. Lizzie Beal, widow of George Carleton Beal, who in' her childhood was a neighbor of Abraham Lincoln, with whom she romped and played, died early yesterday in the Home for Incurables,

Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Smith Proudfoot of Kew Gardens, Queens, gave a luncheon yesterday in the Terrace Restaurant of Sherry's at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Proudfoot, to Maxwell Sheridan Palmer, son of Sheridan B. Palmer of Forest Hills, Queens, and Greenville, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Palmer.
DESPITE the distance of several hundred miles, the annual Canadian - American tournament at Niagara Falls attracts nearly as many New Yorkers each year as a tournament of national championship rank.

A continuous celebration in the next school year, to be climaxed by a large-scale pageant and a symposium on education, is being planned by Columbia Grammar School to mark its 175th anniversary, Frederick Alden, Columbia headmaster, announced yesterday.

The city and the Transit Commission, cooperating along lines laid out in the last two weeks, will seek an early agreement with spokesmen for the B. M. T., and later with representatives of the Interborough-Manhattan system, on a plan of rapid-transit unification, Mayor La Guardia announced at City Hall yesterday.

IN discussing the films of Victor Sjostrom, MM. Bardoche and Brasinach remark that he was "a man really interested in what he was doing, loving the film as though it were one of the noble arts and realizing that it is, above all, the child of light."

Miss Margaret Roseanne Shepard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hubbard Shepard of this place, and Robert Fink Way, son of Dr. and Mrs. Abner Pugh Way of Larchmont, N. Y., and Buck Hill Falls, Pa., were married this morning in Christ Episcopal Church, here.

(Equals championship record, old record made by Johnson in 1937). 220-Yard Dash-Won by Ben Johnson, Columbia; Nat Buchstein, N. Y. U., second; Dick Lundell, Manhattan, third: Ker Dodge, N. Y. U., fourth. Time--0:21.?? (Equals championship record, old record made by George Weinstein, N. Y. U., in 1933).
Cornell students are preparing to "do as the Romans do" on Spring Day, which will be celebrated next Saturday as a Roman holiday.

BRISK bookings for Alaska trips are reported by rail and steamship lines. In addition, many tourists anxious to procure good accommodations on specific dates made their reservations more than a month ago.
OUR novelists, both first novelists and established ones, are going back (in the face of a crumbling civilization in Europe) to their own family pasts. They express both apology and defiance.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Low Pierrepont and Miss Ruth S. Dunning will sail next Saturday on the Nieuw Amsterdam for Rotterdam. Mr. and Mrs. William A. Slater have come from Santa Barbara, Calif., to the Savoy-Plaza.

Some 600 schoolboy athletes, unmindful of a cold, driving rain, participated today in Villanova College's eleventh annual interscholastic track and field meet, with Ambler and West Catholic High of Philadelphia and De La Salle of New York winning top honors in their respective classes. Despite the rain, three records were broken.

The World Ecumenical Council closed a four-day session here today. It was attended by delegates from thirty churches in twenty-one countries, who attained their main object, since all seventy-five representatives agreed on the creation of a world council of churches that will embrace a majority of Protestant Christian creeds and will provide a center for action and study.
Charles B. Durborow, a Philadelphia bank clerk who became widely known as a distance swimmer in pre-war days, died of a heart attack at his home here Thursday.

Mayor La Guardia signed yesterday the contract between the city and the. New York City Housing Authority required by the stipulations under which the United States housing Authority will lend the authority $30,000,000 for the construction of the Red Hook and Queensbridge low-cost apartments to house 5,748 families.

The yucca, in one of its many forms, is native to nearly every section of the United States. This strikingly handsome plant, with its showy panicles of waxen, bellshaped flowers and its stiletto-like leaves, in appearance subtropical and remindful of the desert, occurs in high mountain altitudes or in lowlands, in rocky areas or in clayey or sandy soils.
After a year's work by its education committee, the National Association of Purchasing Agents has just-completed the first in a series of "handbooks for purchasing executives."

To the Radio Editor: I am writing to protest against a custom that is becoming too prevalent on the air. I refer to the habit of interrupting established programs for the insertion of socalled "spot news" items.

His former pupils, many of them gray-haired, and his associates in the public school system gave a farewell party at. the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night for Dr. William A. Kottman, principal. of Charles Sumner Junior High School, 46 Forsyth Street, who is retiring at 70 after fifty-four years as- a New York City teacher.

The Savage School women's tennis team scored an impressive 4-1 victory over the Hofstra College representatives today for its second triumph in three matches. Miss Louise Edelmann gave the home outfit its only point when she conquered Miss Betty Connor, 6--3, 6-2. in the opening singles test.

A moderate increase in State expenditures for varying forms of social service from the building and operation of rest homes to the care of expectant mothers was announced in the 1938 social insurance budget made public today.

With only the miscellaneous carloadings and steel series lower for the week ended May 7, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has advanced to 76.4 from 75.7 (revised). The- increase followed a nominal rise in the previous week. The figure was 108.2 for the comparable week a year ago.

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income after provision for operating expenses, taxes and charges, of $13,629,263.

Dr. William David Ross, provost of Oriel College, Oxford University, will be Visiting Professor of Philosophy in Columbia University next year, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia, announced yesterday.

Here is the loveliness that would not die, The bright unangered peace that yet endures. The lonely shepherd staring at the sky Had such a quiet countenance as yours; The girls that hushed their dancing with the dew:

While Premier Mussolini of Italy today was denouncing anti-Fascist speeches in this country, Senator Walsh, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, attacked the Italian conquest of Ethiopia and pledged the United States to build an independent navy which would not need England's support against "any foreign power or combination of foreign powers."

The United Automobile Workers . of America's international executive board will take up again next week the problem of "preferred lists" of employes in General Motors plants, determined to utilize to the fullest extent the grievance procedure provided by the union's contract with the corporation.
The Silver King Coalition Mines Company reported yesterday for the year ended on March 31 a net profit of $1,077,830 after taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before depletion.

THE author is an important figure in the fine arts and antique business in Europe, member of the firm of J. M. Duveen of London and cousin to the Lord Duveen of Milbank who helped form the Frick, Mellon, Bache and Huntington collections of Old Masters.

WEATHER conditions last week checked trade gains in various parts of the country, cooler temperatures cutting down on the demand that had appeared for Summer merchandise. Sales totals dipped under those of the previous week.

The Mortgage Moratorium Act, in the opinion of David D. Sierson, vice president of the Morgenthau Corporation, has undoubtedly helped many owners to save their properties, but, he adds, there are many owners who are taking advantage of the act to their financial disadvantage.

HEMPSTEAD, Nassau County, L. I., was pictured as one of the bright spots in the present real estate market in a statement issued yesterday by I. Jerome Riker, president of Riker Co., Inc., broker, who recently completed a number of large business property transactions in that section.

Winning three individual titles virtually to clinch the men's allaround championship for the second straight year, George Wheeler, Pittsburgh, tonight dominated the national A. A. U. gymnastic meet. A crowd of 5,000 at Convention Hall vigorously applauded Wheeler, representing Pittsburgh's first United Presbyterian Community House, as he captured the calisthenics with 28.3 points, the long horse with 55 and side horse, 55.1.

PROPAGANDA is a mighty big word, covering a lot of territory-most of which is under a darkish cloud. Immediately the label is slapped upon any form of expression, persons of social awareness generally shy away as from a barrel of powder.
The Osservatore Romano seizes the occasion offered by the publication in Italian, under the title, "National Socialist Press Policy,"

The New Friends of Music Orchestra, which is being organized and which will begin performances next season, will present a series of six consecutive late Sunday afternoon concerts at Carnegie Hall beginning Feb. 23, it is announced by I. A. Hirschmann, president and founder.

A graphic and tragic story of the last hours of Amelia Earhart's frantic search for tiny Howland Island on the broad expanse of the Pacific on July 2 of last year was unfolded here today in the confidential files of the Coast Guard Cutter Itasca, assigned to lie off the island and guide her in by radio.

The President, refreshed by his triumph in the Florida Democratic primaries and the success of the subsequent House movement to bring the Labor Standards Bill from a Rules Committee pigeonhole to the floor, has gone to work in earnest to regain his control over Congress.

New wealth created by the harvesting of a Winter crop estimated at 754,000,000 bushels by the Department of Agriculture will start to flow into genoral trade channels within thirty days and supplement the stream of new money which has been pouring into the Corn Belt in the last few months as a result of the largest European demand for corn in sixteen years.

WITH greater persistence than ever, thousands of Sunday bicycle fans are swarming over metropolitan byways this Spring determined to justify the cycle-club slogan, "Bring Back the Happy Days of 1890."

In celebration of his recent election to the presidency of the Delaware Hudson Railroad Company, a dinner was tendered last night to Joseph H. Nuelle at the New York Athletic Club. Until his election to the presidency of the railroad, Mr. Nuelle was president of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company, Inc.
Mrs. Lena Goldberg, Gold Star mother, died yesterday at her home here at the age of 79. She was one of the mothers who visited the war graves in France seven years ago.

Probably the whole story behind the difference between leaders in the United Automobile Workers Union will never be told, and just what the result of these differences will lead to in the future still remains to be seen.

A NEW approach to the old problem of providing more adequate illumination for night driving-without the bugaboo of worse glare to oncoming drivers-is receiving the attention of automotive lighting engineers.

The group of six five-story tenement buildings comprising the northwest corner of Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street, known as 20 to 26 Columbus Avenue and 101105 West Sixtieth- Street, will be offered at auction May 26 in the Vesey Street salesrooms.
With its three great powers presenting their only solid front of this week the Council of the League of Nations ended its 101st session tonight by a general if moderate stiffening.

Calling attention to the fact that actual home sales present a more significant object lesson of the progress of the national housing program than the number of plans filed for new residential construction, Thomas G. Grace, New York State FHA director,

Two large estate sales in the Rumson section of Monmouth County, N. J., were made last week by the Joseph G. McCue Agency of Rumson. One- was the nine-acre property at Fair Haven fronting 35,373 feet on the North Shrewsbury River and extending to River Road, which was sold to a client for Harry C. Perrine.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Barnes of this place of the engagement of their niece, Miss LaVonne Plastow, to Robert Edsall Reid, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Reid of Babylon and of Montclair, N. J.

Local college baseball teams met interference from rain yesterday, even though several contests were begun. Among the games not completed were N. Y. U.-L. I. U., Fordham-Boston College and Manhattan-C. C. N. Y. Brooklyn College and the Columbus Council, K. of C. were completely rained out.

Joey Fontana, 131 1/2, East Side, earned a decision over Young Chappie, 136, Albany, in the eight-round feature contest last night at the Ridgewood Grove before 3,000 spectators. In the eight-round semifinal Dom Colon, 135 1/2, West Side, fought a draw with Joe Marciente, 132 1/2 Brownsville.
The Columbia freshman baseball team ended its season by bowing to Cheshire (Conn.) Academy, 5-0, yesterday at Baker Field. The yearlings' seven errors proved costly.
Twenty-two degrees and diplomas will be presented next Thursday at 8 P. M. at the sixty-fourth annual commencement exercises of Bloomfield College and Seminary in the First Presbyterian Church here.

Miss Helen M. Farrelly, daughter of James Tully Farrelly of this place and the late Mrs. Farrelly, was married to S. Richard Hall of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Hall, this morning in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection here.

The Automobile Club of New York announces that it will go to court Tuesday to challenge the right of the police to issue summonses to drivers for trespassing over pedestrian crosswalk stripes in cases where no traffic patrolmen or governing lights are visible. The city's traffic code defines.
Welfare Commissioner John E. Cook of Rockland County had some unpalatable reflections on relief served with his luncheon at the county almshouse here today.

Gordon Leavitt of Scarsdale, N. Y., obtained a divorce today from Margaret Stewart Leavitt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. A. Alexander MacLeay. Mr. Leavitt charged cruelty and received custody of their only child. The marriage was Feb. 23, 1925, at Manchester, N. H.

Dictatorships and democracy will be discussed at the annual meeting of the Connecticut branch of the American Association of University Women, to be held Saturday at the Institute of Human Relations, Yale University, New Haven.

Outhit, 11 to 4, the Jersey City Giants, with Manager Travis Jackson in the line-up for the first time in a year, took advantage of the wildness of Herb Moore to beat the Rochester Red Wings today, 5-3.

Ten large German cities lost more than 40 per cent of their Jewish population and many smaller Jewish communities disappeared entirely in the-last five years, according to a report yesterday by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee.

The Civil Service Commission will meet Monday with deputy attorneys general conducting a grand jury investigation of gambling to determine what action should be taken on the grand jury's recommendations against policemen.

BERLIN.--Marshal Hermann W. Goering, Adolf Hitler's man of many jobs, has lately been devoting himself almost exclusively to the multitudinous problems posed by the Reich's four-year plan for conservation of the German national economy.

Whether it is a result of the increased interest of the average citizen in his government or of the program of education for responsible citizenship at Hobart, students of the college in recent months have shown a larger and more understanding interest in the problems of government on their own campus.

A Spanish army captain who has just been repatriated from Portugal revealed to your correspondent today, that some twenty thousand Spanish refugees from the Insurgent camp have been in Portugal since the beginning of the war and are in a most difficult plight because of the hostility of the Portuguese authorities.

Yale defeated the Harvard varsity and freshmen in the annual dual track and field meets on Soldiers Field today. The Eli varsity finished with 715-6 points to 631-6 points for the Crimson, while the Bulldog yearlings won by 77 to 58.

Dr. William Frederick Lloyd, former royal physician, whose strange hobby of making crayon drawings on walls and sidewalks for many years attracted the attention of visi-. tors to this royal borough, died today at the age of 85.

An exhibition home containing six rooms will be opened today for insection in a low-cost housing project planned by the builder, Herbert Silman, in Astoria, Queens, on a large tract at Thirty-third Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

John Spencer Francis of Orange, a retired lawyer, died today at his home after a year's illness. He was 61 years old. One of his daughters, the former Miss Alice Francis, was tenth ranking woman tennis star in 1928.

Yale conquered Princeton's polo four today, 13--5. Leading the Yale attack was Alan Corey, who tallied four goals. He was ably assisted by Mott Woolley, captain Johnson and Chisholm. Robert Eisner was outstanding for the Tigers with three tallies.

Approximately 80 per cent of the 10,000 feet of exhibition space at the thirty-first annual convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers to be held in Milwaukee, June 20 to 23, has been contracted for and tentative reservations have been made for practically all of the remaining space, the association announced yesterday.

If the Man from Mars were to visit the shops full of Summer play clothes in the department stores now he would undoubtedly conclude, from the functional informality and the imaginative gayety of the clothes, that modern Americans know how to play.

Twenty-five hundred students representing twenty-seven Catholic elementary and high schools of the Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn will participate this week in the preliminaries of the contests being held by the Music Education League in the five boroughs of the city.

The Citizens Housing Council, the Merchants Association and the New York Building Congress are sponsoring a luncheon tomorrow in the Hotel Commodore at which Sir Harold Bellman, British housing expert and head of one of London's largest building societies, will be the guest and chief speaker.

Dean John W. Withers of New York University was hailed yesterday as a "dependable counselor, wise administrator and a personal friend" by more than 1,000 students, former students and faculty members at a "friendship luncheon" at the Hotel Astor.

SINCE there is apparently some thing in the air at this time of year that induces an irresistible tendency to awarding prizes, pecuniary 'and otherwise, for this, that and the other achievement in the arts, this department has duly called itself into conference and made its decisions as to what brows best merit the season's choreographic laurels (strictly nonpecuniary).

Possible clues to the kidnapping of 12year-old Peter Levine, son of Murray Levine, New York attorney, from his New Rochelle home on Feb. 24, were found yesterday and Friday in a wooded section near. Rockaway, N. J.

IN an address made recently before the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, in Boston, and here quoted with the Academy's permission, Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, made pertinent and provocative observations upon the art of interpretation as affecting music and poetry.

HUTCHINSON, Kan., May 14.--Harry H. Woodring, Secretary of War, speaking at the convention of the Kansas Bankers Association yesterday, asserted that the great nations were again engaged in the creation of gigantic military machines.

Princeton's track and field team closed its dual meet season undefeated by downing Cornell, 77-58, in Palmer Stadium today and established itself as the major contender for Ivy League honors when the annual Heptagonal games take place here next week.

THE very great debt all students of the drama and the theatre owe to Professor Allardyce Nicoll of Yale is considerably increased by the appearance of his scholarly exposition of the stage techniques employed in the presentation of English masques. Nowhere else can be found the material he painstakingly brings together in this volume.
Princeton's powerful lacrosse team defeated Yale, 5-2, today. The Tigers held the upper hand throughout, Mueller and Marter leading the attack with two goals each.

M. I. Cowen of the paint machinery division of the Consolidated Products Company, Inc., declares that a vast market exists for paint contractors in the small-home field, provided payment terms can be made easy enough.

Mrs. H. Harriet Richardson Bleakley, A widow of Orrin D. Bleakley, Franklin banker, died today at the age of 80. Mrs. Bleakley was noted for her A philanthropies and interest in civic matters, continuing- this activity until taken ill early this year.

Three-quarters of the city's young men and women did not finish high school and one-tenth did not get beyond elementary school, according to a survey submitted to the Greater New York Fund yesterday by the Welfare Council.

Mr. and Mrs. Dean Emerson of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Charlotte Emerson, to Josiah Macy Jr., son of Mrs. Josiah Macy of Morristown, N. J., and the late Mr. Macy.
A last-period rally enabled C. V. Whitney's Blues to defeat G. H. (Pete) Bostwick's Whites in the opening intraclub polo matches of the Meadow Brook Club season today, 10-9.
When the Neutrality Act was passed a year ago there was a general feeling--or at least a hope-that the United States had successfully isolated itself from foreign embroglios.
Members of the graduating class of Bard College are hastening to complete their "senior projects" in time for the commencement.
The Third Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in an opinion today ruled that the "blue blade" patent of the Gillette Safety Razor Company of Boston is invalid.
Strong sentiment developed in the Senate Appropriations Committee today to give President Roosevelt unrestricted control over the $3,154,000,000 relief public works program.

Construction of crude rubber in the United States by manufacturers in April amounted to 27,984 long tons, compared with 30,487 March and 51,589 in April, 1937, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Imports were 30,807 tons, against 35,967 in and 35,850 in April, 1937.

The likelihood that France's latest devaluation of the franc has opened up a new round of currency upsets appeared last week in the foreign exchange market when the pressure of rumor, fear and'speculation shifted from the French unit to that of Belgium.

A bridge party will be held at Hi-Esmaro, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward Manville- here on Tuesday afternoon for the benefit of the Church Mission- of Help, which maintains a Youth Consultation- Service for Westchester girls in heed.

Summing up realty conditions in Brooklyn, Arthur J. Horton, vice president of the Bulkley Horton Company, states that there is a fair volume of sales of used homes in that borough to investors for reconditioning and resale, but the construction of new private houses is comparatively slight.

On the assumption that industry was really apprehensive about the undistributed profits tax, the new revenue measure passed by the House of Representatives last week will go far toward restoring confidence among business men and encouraging additional outlays for expansion of facilities, according to opinions of tax authorities, credit executives and association leaders last week.

Evening graduate courses in engineering subjects, leading to the degree of Master of Science, will be introduced into the curriculum of Stevens Institute of Technology, according to an announcement today by President Harvey N. Davis.

For four hours yesterday afternoon onlookers in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, heard the roll of snare drums and the. pound of bases as junior bands of the Catholic Youth Organization competed for metropolitan honors.

The Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Britain, first of three liners scheduled to return this month from world cruises, will dock here tomorrow after a trip of 128 days. On board are 400 passengers, many of whom were with the vessel when she left New York on Jan. 8, en route to the Mediterranean, ports in India, Australia, New Zealand and the Hawaiian Islands.

During the first quarter of the present year forty-four new institutions were added to the Federal Home Loan Bank System, Preston Delano, governor of the system, announced yesterday. The forty-four new member organizations have assets of approximately $50,000,000.

Charges that politics played a part in Pennsylvania WPA discharges "are for the major part untrue" Harry L. Hopkins, administrator, reported. In cases where the charges were substantiated, disciplinary action had been taken, Mr. Hopkins stated in a telegram to John B. Kelly, Democratic city chairman of Philadelphia.

Wild Bill Cummings of Indianapolis and Rex Mays of Glendale, Calif., put finishing touches today on the power-jammed speedsters which they will pilot in their match race on the Indianapolis motor speedway tomorrow.

Share prices, on the average, ended the week just about where they started. Although a few industries showed some improvement, the general business situation did not help the Stock Market. Bonds gained on the week, and commodities were generally steady.
Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday to about 10,000 American Federation of Labor trade unionists here to end with all speed the division in the ranks of the American labor movement.
Pinkcoated hunting folk and colorfully gowned women were in the throng that attended in the Fifth Regiment Armory tonight the Preakness Ball and the annual coronation in connection with it.

PRESENTED with characteristic unobtrusiveness by Mr. Rockefeller-who remarked at the first of a series of previews last week that his contribution, "being largely financial," must, therefore, be esteemed "relatively unimportant"-The Cloisters, in Fort Tryon Park, was opened to the public yesterday.

ASIATIC "polar" short-wave signals, which are seldom heard clearly in this area, sometimes climb over the North Pole and reach down into America with "local" volume when tuned in between 9 and 11 A. M., E. D. S. T., in May.

After Al Wilson scored two tries for the Yale rugby team early in today's game with-the New York Rugby Club, the visitors rallied and although Yale led, 6-3, at intermission the New Yorkers finally triumphed, 12-6. The line-up:

WHILE this May lacks an American Theatre Council convention to air-condition the academic pro and con of Hollywood and/or Broadway, statistics are ever with us, and so it is that this department once again ventures to detail the facts and figures of the "picture money" situation and a few reasonable conclusions to be drawn therefrom.

Among unusual, delightful and serviceable garden features which may be obtained at small expense the mint pool ranks high. Such a pool was part of the gardens of cloisters- in. England before the Henry VIII period.

Indiana limestone and architectural bronze will be used on the front and side of the first two floors of the eleven-story building at 417 Fifth Avenue under a modernization plan for this property which has been started, according to H. Adams Ashforth, president of Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., agent.
D. Duffy Lane, formerly in the building and contracting field, has joined the firm of Frank O'Hara, Inc., in Jackson Heights, to specialize in appraisals and investment properties.

Miss Joan P. Lusk, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. William B. Lusk, and Charles Henry Tenney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Gleason Tenney of New York, had twenty attendants at their marriage which took place here today.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 14.--Miss Isabel Katherine Bower, daughter of Councilman Frank W. Bower and Mrs. Bower of East Orange, was married to William B. Dickinson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dickinson of Newark, this afternoon in Trinity Congregational Church by the Rev. Dascomb E. Forbush.

The Athletics announced today they had obtained Richard Siebert, left-handed first baseman, from the Columbus Club of the American Association. The deal involved the exchange of Paul Easterling, Gene Hasson, George Turbeville and an unannounced sum.
Consumer response to the revival of ombre types of women's fullfashioned hosiery has been moderate to date, it was reported yesterday by manufacturers.
" EUROPE'S latest storm center," some one has christened this lovely old city, with its dreamy baroque palaces and its bustling Vaclavske Namesti--"the Piccadilly of Prague"

TIME was when peoples could do nothing better than adjust themselves to their monarchs and if the monarch was a bad one, then, as Bishop Bossuet said, they should dutifully accept him as a chastisement for their sins. Now, Jonathan Scott sums up the present situation, "monarchs have to adjust themselves painfully to their peoples."

It's high time New York's cruising skippers began overhauling their off-shore charts. The season's getting on. They can't prolong their shake-downs in landlocked harbors forever. Not when the bluer ocean calls.

The concert of the NBC Symphony Orchestra, broadcast last night from Radio City under the direction- of Sir Adrian Boult, conductor and musical director of the British Broadcasting Company, was one of the most rewarding of this weekly series.
WASHINGTON, May 14.--Senator Glass said today that he would return soon to his Lynchburg, Va., home and stay there for the rest of the session.

James Monroe High School players strengthened their lead in the annual championship series of the Interscholastic Chess League yesterday when they defeated Theodore Roosevelt High by 3-1 in the third round at the Manhattan C. C.

With sales of cotton goods thus far this year, well under the "normal" rate, Fall buying is likely to get under way earlier than in recent years, in the opinion of W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, who declared yesterday that prices are at "bargain" levels.

Although Manhattan foreclosures have shown monthly increases since January, totals for the first four months of 1938 show improvement over the comparable period of 1937 both as to the number of actions and the total dollar volume of liens foreclosed, according to the monthly report of the Real Estate Board of New York.
Mrs. Lurleane B. Harriss of Roselea, this city, formerly of Forest Hills, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Susan B. Harriss, to Malcolm McDowell.Manning of Greenville.
With the first five weeks of the Constitutional Convention over, the Republicans have yet to agree on a policy for reapportioning either legislative or Congressional districts within the State.

" Making a Democracy Work" Is the theme of the eighteenth annual convention of the New Jersey League of Women Voters, meeting Wednesday and Thursday at the Berkley-Carteret Hotel, Asbury Park. Variations on the topic, covering "Living Costs," "Women in Industry," "Vocational Training"

The Hotel Buckingham, sixteenstory residential hostelry at the northwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, has been leased by the Bowery Savings Bank to the Hotel Buckingham, Inc., of which S. Gregory Taylor is president and Charles G. Taylor vice president and treasurer.

After gunplay today authorities tied up the water taxi service to the gambling ship Rex, which was raided last night by squads from the District Attorney's and Sheriff's offices and Santa Monica police.

Back in the administrations of Presidents Harding and Coolidge, Washington indulged a great deal in giving unasked advice to the rest of the world. When this program of international action was begun by the United States, the memory of the important role this country had played in the World War was fresh in the minds of men and we were, for a time, taken seriously.
THE Canterbury pilgrimage of Chaucer's tales has a Chinese counterpart in the annual pilgrimage held this month up the slopes of Miao Feng Shan, some seventeen miles north of Peiping.
The nation's oldest Federal judge gave up his post today. Judge Joseph Buffington, 83, retired from the bench in the Circuit Court of
X-ray tubes operate on direct current-a steady flow in one direction, like that of water in a pipe. Most of our current is alternatinga flow first in one direction and then in the opposite.
Mr. and Mrs. Snowden Fahnestock entertained tonight with a dance at their home in honor of their daughter, Miss Fontaine Fahnestock, who was making her debut.
