As the finale of a week of brilliant triumph, DiXie Maid tonight annexed he grand championship of the three-gaited saddle horses at the final session of the seventh annual Atlantic City horse show.
Glenn B. Watts and M. Zilinski each broke 48 out of 50 in a skeet event at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. As Zilinski shot for targets only, the high scratch cup went to the first-named gunner.

In celebration of Air-Mail Week, May 15 to 21, a special postal cachet of the World's Fair will be stamped upon envelopes deposited in the Flushing Postoffice district beginning today and continuing through next Saturday.

The man without a job is growing into a major political issue today, just in time for this Fall's national elections. He looms almost as big as he did in the Presidential fight six years ago, and the problem is still the same-how to feed him.

Miss Cecile Bausman Dunlap, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Dunlap, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to Edwin A. McAlpin 3d of New York, son of Mrs. Edwin, A. McAlpin of Madison, N. J., and the late Rev. Dr. McAlpin.
DURING the Civil War Samuel Clemens went West with his brother, Orian, who had been appointed secretary to the new Governor of Nevada Territory.
Transfer by Great Britain of $12,500,000 gold to Canada in a single consignment, with intimation that more may follow, is not explainable by the ordinary movement of foreign exchange.

To the Drama Editor: It seems to me unfortunate, if not indeed lamentable, that such a purposeful and interesting experiment as the Federal Theatre's "Trojan Incident" should have been greeted with such a chorus of deprecatory incomprehension mingled with sneers and abuse as characterized the comments of professional critics on the first performance,

This week has seen the clearest signs yet visible of a truce between the utilities and the government. Such a development- on this major front gives more promise of peace between business and the Federal Government than has appeared in the past five years.

A plot to ship airplanes to Spain by way of Mexico was disclosed yesterday with the arraignment of Cloyd Peart Clevenger, a commercial pilot, before United States Commissioner Garret W. Cotter for removal to Houston, Texas, where, it was reported, nine or ten pilots are being sought as airplane smugglers.

In addition to arguing the appeal of the commission men in the Kansas City Stock Yards case, decided recently by the Supreme Court, the writer of the following letter also was leading counsel in the O'Fallon, Schechter, Carter and gold clause cases before the high court.
Despite the rapid growth of population in other sections, the Fulton Street district of downtown Brooklyn continues to retain its supremacy as the mecca of the borough's bargain hunters.

Holy Cross chalked up a 9-to-4 victory over Yale at Fitten Field today in a slow ball game. Art Kenney, Crusader southpaw, allowed seven scattered hits and struck out eleven. Mo Jubitz, his rival, was nicked for eleven solid safeties and walked six.
RESPONSE from listeners has encouraged WNYC to extend its series of symphony concerts of the Federal Music Project of the WPA on Sunday afternoons from 1:30 to 3 o'clock.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are May 14 unless specified: San Diego to Cristobal via Balboa: Brooks, Childs, Dallas, Fox, Gilmer, Williamston. At Norfolk: Leary, Raleigh, Roper, Schenck. Antares, Navy Yard, Philadelphia, to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk.
GENERAL CROZIER is one of Britain's bad boys. He speaks his mind as freely and as frequently as General Smedley D. Butler does in this country.

Beginning tomorrow the School Nature League will open its ninth annual series of garden visits, Landscaped backyard gardens and penthouse terraces in the city, as well as a few Long Island country estates are to be opened to the public in the interest of the league's work in association with the Amer?? of Natural History.
Police Judge J. J. N. Quinlan ruled here that it is the "inalienable right" of a baseball player to "get mad and have a fight with the umpire."
A HISTORY OF WOMEN IN MEDICINE, From the Earliest Times to the Beginning of the Nineteenth Century. By Kate Campbell Hurd-Mead, M. D. 569 pp. 30 Illustrations. Haddam, Conn.: The Haddam Press. $6.

Bridge tables will be placed in seven cottages on the Bonnie Brae Farm Home for Boys here-Tuesday and Wednesday afternoons for the fifth annual bridge series in aid of the home. More than 2,000 persons are expected to attend and the lawns surrounding the buildings may be utilized.

Plans for reorganizing the Druggists Research Bureau are being developed by the National Wholesale Druggists Association, which launched it in 1927 to make factual studies on retail drug store operation, it was stated yesterday by Dr. E. L. Newcomb, executive vice president.

Garden tours and garden teas, all benefit entertainments for charitable or educational causes, are the outstanding activity this month in the colonies of the North Shore, and today three pilgrimages are being made to notable gardens, with a tea at Ryntwood, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Agar Salvage on Cedar Swamp Road,. Glen Head.

In one of the largest realty deals negotiated in Dutchess County in recent months, Lawrence P. Bosworth of New York has signed a contract to purchase 1,025 acres near Pawling, through Irving Lachenbruch, broker.

Miss Caroline MacFadden, a descendant of Benjamin Franklin, and Robert Innes Center, a descendant of Robert Livingston, First Lord of Livingston Manor, were married yesterday afternoon in Trinity Chapel by the Rev. Dr. J. Wilson Sutton. No announcement had been made of their engagement.
Representative O'Connor of New York said today that any effort by President Roosevelt to revive the government reorganization bill would "be as difficult as reviving a dead fish."

THE latest issues of the Friends of Recorded Music are devoted to the piano playing of Arthur Loesser in three sonatas, by Brahms (F sharp, Op. 2), Clementi (G minor, Op. 50, No. 3), and Haydn (F, No. 20 in the Peters Edition).

In probably the longest match on record in the 23-year-old tournament, Melvin Schwartzman of Poly Prep defeated Edward Reid of St. John's Prep yesterday to win the championship of the Athletic Association for Private Schools for the second year in a row at the West Side Tennis Club. Forest Hills.

THE crash of the bombshell dropped by the Independent Theatre Owners Association into the motion picture field is echoing through radio, since broadcasting has established quite an alliance with the film lots in the past year, Huge, modernistic studios have been built in Hollywood.
Fifty members of the American Rock Garden Society from Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Ohio, New York and other States will hold their annual meeting tomorrow at the New York Botanical Garden.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended May 11 aggregated $7,193,000,000, or 16 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 17 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

LONDON.-British newspapers are taken severely to task for their failure to "cover" the United States properly and for giving undue prominence to the trivial and sensational by Political and Economic Planning, a nonpartisan research organization similar to the Brookings Institution, in a special report issued recently.

Spring flowers, white roses and dogwood decorated Christ Episcopal Church here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Frances Godfrey to John Scott Walker. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. C. Kenneth Ackerman.

Davis Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it had concluded a contract with the Mexican Government for the purchase daily of approximately 40,000 barrels of oil not derived from expropriated properties. Payment will be made partly. in cash and partly in materials and supplies.

An attempt to standardize trade practices among furniture manufacturers' representatives and improve their relations with producers is being made through a code of ethics drawn up by a special committee of the Furniture Manufacturers Representatives of New York, Inc., it was learned yesterday.
One man was drowned and two others were missing early today after the sixty-foot auxiliary schooner Quita overturned and sank in the East River, about a mile off City Island.
If provision dealers listen to Hjorth Hansen of Bergen, Norway, they will pay more attention to the age of the ice which they use to keep fish fresh.

Modern water systems for farm and suburban homes located "beyond the water mains" are entirely automatic, states the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau. An upto-date electric water system, it is explained, will automatically maintain pressure at the faucets, will start and stop automatically, and will lubricate itself automatically.

If you were to design a college for the youth of America, what would be its essential characteristics? This in substance is the question which was asked many individuals by the sponsors of Goddard College which is to open its doors in the little village of Plainfield in the Green Mountains of Vermont next September.

The draft of a proposed new constitution for the Communist party in the United States was made public yesterday by the party's central committee through Earl Browder, its general secretary and the last Communist nominee for President. It will be acted upon at the party's tenth national convention in Madison Square Garden, May 26 to 31.

Miss Nancy Holcomb and Ernest A. Anderson Jr. were married here this afternoon in St. John's Church by the Rev. Dr. John N. Lewis. A week of entertaining in honor of the couple was culminated last night by a large dance given at the Waterbury Country Club by the bride's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Pierre S. du Pont 3d of Richmond, Va.

Annual communion breakfast of Mystic Rose Council, 268, Knights of Columbus, Ambassador Hotel, 9:15 A. M. Speakers: the Rev. Ignatius W. Cox, John E. McAniff, the Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge, John A. Saunders, Richard C. Timothy.

I MENTIONED recently, without discussing it at length, John Gielgud's appearance as Shylock. His production of "The Merchant of Venice" is the last of his present season at the Queen's Theatre, a season that has included three other plays-Chekhov's "Three Sisters,"

With a cold rain drenching the few hardy hundreds who huddled on the banks of Lake Carnegie, light and heavyweight oarsmen spent today racing over the placid waters. Records were shattered in the morning and, when the gray day crew to its close, the heavyweight versity of Pennsylvania and the 150-pound varsity of Yale shared the major honors.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 12: CAPTAIN Friedell, W. L.. Chief of Staff. Command dent, 14th Naval District, to duty as Commander Mine Craft, Battle Force, in May.

Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Monday Du Pont (E. I.) de Nemours Co. General Cigar Co., Inc. Public Service Electric Gas Co. Sutherland Paper Co.

More than 25,000 fans are expected to visit the Polo Grounds today to see the Cavan team from Ireland meet an all-New York fifteen in the opening match of a three-game international Gaelic football trophy series.
Chinese today pressed desperate counterattacks to break the lines of Japanese columns which are steadily tightening a trap on China's central front in the drive for Suchow and the Lung-Hai Railway.
RAJPUTANA, the largest and richest of the Indian Agencies, is a vast storehouse of exotic commodities. Peacocks, emerald and sapphire, stru? proudly along the sun-drenched roads.

Dr. Frederick Gardner Cottrell of Washington, prominent research chemist and metallurgist, was presented with a gold medal, annual award of the American Institute of Chemists, at its sixteenth annual meeting in the Hotel Claridge tonight.

The Canadian Retail Coal Association of Toronto and several chambers of commerce along the Great Lakes have asked Finance Minister Dunning to have United States anthracite returned to the free tariff list.
Mrs. John H. Woolley of this place has announced the engagement of her granddaughter, Miss Ella Deininger, to Richard Boyce, son of Mrs. James E. Boyce of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Boyce.

The New York Chapter, American Red Cross, has been urged by Norman H. Davis, national Red Cross chairman, to raise at least $100,000 toward the nation-wide fund for relief of civilian sufferers in China, it was announced yesterday. To date, the chapter has received and transmitted contributions totaling $29,041.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announces that representatives of virtually all the ninetyfour bookmakers operating at the Jamaica and Aqueduct race tracks have agreed to "cooperate" in paying an emergency relief tax on their business since 1934.

INSPECTOR-George F. Bishop, from Borough Headquarters Squad, BrooklynRichmond, to 12th Division, from 8 A. M., May 14, during the absence of inspector on vacation and with leave. SERGEANT-Henry Emde, from 122d Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office. Richmond, for 2 days, from 4 P. M., May 10.

RECENT news from the office of the Assistant Post master General in Washington that postmasters have been seeing snakes in the mails is a reminder that parcel post is used to a considerable extent for the shipping of live freight.

Accused by the police of being implicated in a swindle in which the Amtorg Trading Corporation, trade representative of the Soviet Government in this country, lost six bars of platinum and 100 ounces of iridium, valued at $22,000, Louis Budisch, 36 years old, of 145 Beach 139th Street, Rockaway, Queens, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Rothenberg in the Felony Court on charges of larceny and forgery.

A Novo??birsk newspaper today reported hat nine men were sentenced to ??eath in Western Siberia for a fa-?? ??al mine explosion said to have been ??et off in revenge for Moscow's last big treason trial in which eighteen 'Trotskyists" were sentenced to ??leath. Four workmen were killed ??n the blast.

Trustees of the Roerich Museum will not permit it to pass out of existence when the galleries at 310 Riverside' Drive are reopened on June 4 as the Riverside Museum, it was announced yesterday by Miss Frances R. Grant, vice president of the Roerich Museum. .

Announcement has been made here and in Paris, France, by Mrs. John Oliver Montignani of Rochester, N. Y., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anne Montignani, to Sven-Gunnar Lindstrand, son of Harald Lindstrand of Stockholm, Sweden.
THE Philadelphia Orchestra will give ten concerts in Carnegie Hall next season, be ginning Oct. 18 and concluding April 26. All of the concerts but the last will be given on Tuesday nights.

Expressing optimism for the future of Liberia, Lester-A. Walton, United States Minister to Liberia, declared yesterday that despite unrest in various parts of the world the Negro republic was making rapid progress.

The National Association of Manufacturers in a letter to Secretary of State Cordell Hull today urged modification of the reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and France because the action of the French Government in devaluing the franc. was likely to "be farreaching." The request was taken under consideration.
Baron Gottfried von Cramm, greatest German tennis player and a leading potential contender in this year's Davis Cup matches, was sentenced today to one year in prison on charges of homosexuality.

More than 700' members of the staffs at the four municipal colleges, Brooklyn, Hunter, City and Queens, and officials of the national, State, and local governments will attend the testimonial dinner to be given by the Board of Higher Education in honor of Mark Eisner, retiring chairman of the board, tomorrow evening at the Hotel Astor.

Another notable victory in his enviable chain of best-in-show successes was recorded by the smoothhaired foxterrier Ch. Nornay Saddler from the Wissaboo Kennels of Old Westbury, L. I., today to climax the Orange Kennel Club's fifth annual all-breed exhibition at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

Mrs. J. Sergeant Cram is reported to be planning the erection of a nine-story and penthouse cooperative apartment building on the site of her home property at 9 East Sixty-fourth Street, now occupied by her interesting two-story private dwelling.

Mayor Hugh J. Ryan declared today that the search for Marjory West would be continued "until we can reach some logical decision as to what happened to her." The girl disappeared Sunday afternoon while picking violets with her family.

A public hearing on President Rooseovelt's "pump-priming" bill was asked yesterday by the New York Board of Trade in a telegram to Senator Alva B. Adams, chairman of the subcommittee on appropriations.

A Federal bureau of city-planning experts to aid municipalities in revising their zoning and building regulations is suggested by Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, as a means of paving the way for large-scale housing operations throughout the country.

LENGTHY conferences with the five-man British air commission which spent a week in the Southern California area recently have presented serious problems to the aviation industry here, including the questions of American public opinion, possibility of fulfilling rush orders, and the likelihood of permitting the Britons to manufacture United States equipment in Canada.

The government news agency issued today a semi-official comment on the United States Government's formal protest against the decree of Field Marshal Hermann Goering by which he reserves the right to employ the property of foreign Jews as well as that of German Jews for purposes of the Four-Year Plan.

Mail requisitions increased last week, but there was no real quantity of merchandise requested, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

Aided by nine Choate errors and a four-run drive in the ninth, Milford downed the home nine today, 9-2. Milford collected thirteen hits, while the Choate batters were held to four hits by Barnum. Pepper connected for a homer in the third with one on to lead the. Milford attack.

Within 100 days after its opening for settlement, Van Houten Fields, the new commuters' homestead association at West Nyack, N. Y., has disposed of one-half its available memberships. The twentieth reservation for a homestead was accepted last week by Mrs. Wharton Clay of Nyack, chairwoman of the local committee, and Homer T. Bogle of Suffern, field manager. The land is divided into forty sites from one to five acres.

Mr. and Mrs. Barent L. Vistscher of this community have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Visscher, to Warren D. Starrett, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Everett Starrett of Providence, R. I. .

Wendell L. Willkie, president of the $1,194,000,000 Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, in his 1937 annual report to shareholders, released today, disclosed that he has been negotiating with the Tennessee Valley Authority in recent weeks in an effort to solve the competitive power problem between the TVA and Commonwealth and Southern subsidiaries operating in the Tennessee Valley.

In an effort to insure the future welfare of real estate, sons who are following in their fathers' footsteps In that business will receive special invitations to the annual convention of the Real Estate Association of New York Sept. 15, 16 and 17 in Syracuse, Frank S. O'Hara of Jackson Heights, president of the association, announced yesterday.

The Arabs' opposition to the partition scheme in addition to their boycott of the British partition commission, which recently arrived here, is now unanimous. Even those Arabs who in their hearts welcomed partitionbecause it would have provided lucrative positions-have now joined the out-and-out oppositionists.
The pennon of victory went to the Pennant colt Dauber, whose dam is Ship o' War, as 25,000 huddled in the wind and rain to see the fortyeighth Preakness Stakes at historic Pimlico today.

AERO-PHILATELY will attain its "majority" on Tuesday, which will be the twenty-first anniversary of the world's first authorized air mail stamp-forerunner of an avalanche of such postal items, which today number more than 3,600 varieties.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., filed suit in Federal Court yesterday to recover $134,134 from the government as overpaid in its 1930 income tax return. The company, formerly known as the Paramount Publix Corporation,

Out of the curiously twisted economy of a depression era, the farm woman of New York has emergedan entity to be reckoned with in the business world, according to officers of the New York State Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs.

The Yale freshman second heavyweight eight today defeated Tabor Academy and Brown and Nichols School of Boston in a mile race on the Housatonic by two and a half lengths. The time was 5 minutes 30.5 seconds.
A "workshop for English teachers" will be added to the curriculum of the University of Pittsburgh Summer session, starting July 6.

THE Postoffice Department will issue two commemorative stamps this Summer and is contemplating a third, it was learned from authoritative sources last week. Definitely assured are another Constitution "sesqui" item,

A four-way contest for moderator of the Presbyterian General Assembly, opening its annual meeting here May 24, was under way today. Friends planned to nominate for the highest Presbyterian honor the Rev. Dr. Robert Freeman of Pasadena, the Rev. D. S. Willis McKelvey of Kansas City, the Rev. Dr. Ezra Allen Van Nuys of San Francisco and the Rev. Dr. Charles W. Welch of Louisville.

Two policemen and two firemen were injured and severall persons Were burned as a fire of undetermined origin destroyed a night club here early today. Chateau Monterey, owned and operated by Mrs. Louisa Booth at 419 West Nineteenth Avenue, was razed with a loss estimated at $200,000.
England defeated Germany, 6-3, at the Olympic Stadium today in a soccer match before more than 100,000 persons, including Minister of Propaganda Goebbels. The Englishmen led, 4-2, at half-time.
President Roosevelt and a small group of Congressional friends boarded the Presidential yacht Potomac soon after noon for a week-end cruise on the Potomac River and Chesapeake Bay.

Although there is a tendency toward more closely integrated health programs in American colleges, there are still some startling deficiencies, according to a preliminary report to the American Youth Commission on a survey of the health of college students.
During late May and early June, when most house plants can advantageously be transferred from indoors to the open, is an excellent time for repotting many of them.

Operations in wheat futures in world markets were greatly restricted today. Buying of the May delivery on the Board of Trade here and at Winnipeg, attributed to export interests, featured an otherwise dull session.

Capitalizing on Mitchell's wildness, Boston University scored a 4-to-2 baseball triumph over Amherst at Nickerson Field today. Bob Di Guglielmo, outstanding B. U. pitcher, held the Lord Jeffs to five scattered singles, two of which, however. were responsible for the visitors' runs in the first inning.

Expressing fear that Leftists may attempt to put obstacles in the way ??f his presence at the opening session of Congress May 21, where, in accordance with tradition, the President reads his annual message, President Arturo Alessandri de??lared yesterday that such action by the opposition would be openly revolutionary. .

Scoring a total of thirty-one points, Fieldston School retained its team title at the second annual Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools championship track and field meet at Fieldston yesterday.

Establishment of community forests by American towns and cities is advised by E. W. Tinker, assistant chief of the Federal Forest Service. He points out that the idea has been practiced successfully in European cities for many years but that, although growing, it is comparatively new in this country.
Mr. and Mrs. Julian Rice of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Rice, to Robert Kidder Bodensten, son of Mrs. Frederick Bodensten of Staatsburg, N. Y.
Miss Anna L. Dawes, who lives at White Tree Inn, was 87 years old today, and a group of friends gave a luncheon in her honor at Yellow Aster Tea Room, Lenox Road.

Thirteen out of thirty-seven sections of local department stores had gains in advertising linage in April over the same month last year, according to the breakdown issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc.

" Eat cheese and keep well," the government suggested today--with smell effects. Floats loaded with cheeses from the most pungent limburger to the mildest cream wound their odoriferous way through Berlin's residential streets with the "eat cheese" banners.
THIS report of Dr. Gesell and Dr. Thompson marks the continuation of the valuable research that has been carried on uninterruptedly at the Yale Clinic of Child DeVelopment since 1927.
In anticipation of a large crowd of female hikers from New York over the week-end, the Yonkers police today restored the so-called antishorts squad to inspect costumes.

Both in Congress and out last week the drive to put the nation back on its economic feet gathered momentum. Congress, as if spurred to action by the return to Washington of a Chief Executive tanned and refreshed from a Spring vacation -in the Caribbean, expedited President Roosevelt's $2,500,000,000 program for relief and public works.

One of the longest radio telephone hook-ups on record for a public meeting will feature the World Trade Dinner of the National Foreign Trade Council at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Wednesday evening, May 25, according to an announcement by the council yesterday.

Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General; Jay Allen, journalist, and Professor Jose Castillejo, director of the Students International Union in Geneva, will discuss "Order in World Affairs" at the annual meeting of the union on Tuesday at 4 P. M. in the Hotel Plaza, according to an announcement yesterday.

SARATOGA battlefield, where in 1777 "Gentleman Johnny" Burgoyne's invasion of the Hudson Valley collapsed under the fire of the Continentals' muskets, will, if the bill pending in Congress is enacted into law, be set apart by the government as a national memorial park.

If Dr. Russell W. ?aunting of the University of Michigan's School of Dentistry had his way, the American people would be consuming considerably less sugar than they do. He shakes his head at the 2,000,000,000 pounds of candy that we eat annually.

NO LAUGHTER IN HEAVEN-This evening at the Play Room Club. The first of eight performances of a play by - Martha Pittenger, with a cast including James Todd, Gordon Peters, Ross Matthew, Jackie Grimes, Elizabeth Morrison and Sylvia Leigh. ON BORROWED TIME-This evening at the Longacre Theatre. For the Stage Relief Fund.

Commencement plans for three divisions of Rutgers University were made public today by President Robert C. Clothier. Dr. James L. McConaughy, president of Wesleyan University, will deliver the commencement address at the 172d anniversary graduation exercises of the men's college Sunday afternoon, June 12.
The Supreme Court considered today whether to review litigation involving constitutionality of the government's-Tennessee Valley Authority power program.
From the White House today came a chilling denial that President Roosevelt had in effect endorsed Charles H. Martin, Conservative Democrat, for re-election as Governor.

Earlier in the year this department duly recorded the fact that Dr.- Irving Langmuir, Nobel prizeman, had debunked the tale that the deer botfly (it's like a horsefly but a little smaller) can travel at a speed of 818 miles an hour, almost twice as fast as the airplane record (440 miles an hour).

Miss Ellen Eddy Shaw, curator of elementary instruction at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, received a medal from the School Garden Association of New York yesterday in recognition of her work in teaching children about gardens.

The glamour and romance of the fast-vanishing sailing ships of old, the memory of storied windjammers and the excitement of clipper races-each was revived for a day yesterday as youthful yachtsmen from all parts of the city gathered in Central Park for a model boat regatta.

Modern technical research has provided a vast storehouse of important data to guide municipal officials in the proper preparation of building codes to met today's needs and at the same time effect justifiable economies in construction and design, particularly with respect to the problem of fire, points out D. Knickerbocker Boyd of the American Institute of Architects.

Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, and Norman H. Davis, Ambassador at'Large and former Under-Secretary of State, were appointed by the State Department today as representatives of the United States on the Panel of Mediators created by the Inter-American Treaty on Good Offices and Mediation, signed at Buenos Aires on Dec. 23, 1986.

The United States Golf Association's selection of the personnel of the 1938 Curtis Cup team is an exemplification of its belief in safety first and its desire to preserve the unbeaten record of this team, which, like the Walker Cup squad that sailed recently for England, has yet to lose possession of its trophy.

In its latest monthly building cost index the Federal Home Loan Bank announces that the cost of building a standard six-room house in the average American city increased during the last two years by $476. Data for the bank review were collated from reports from ninety-two representative communities.

A project for the making of simple toys and the repair of donated toys and nursery furniture was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator. The toys will be distributed to needy families and accredited social agencies without cost.

Several sales of properties in Westchester County were reported yesterday by brokers. Frank Zaccaro negotiated the sale to a client for the Midfield Realty Corporation of three buildings and a small cottage on the northeast corner of Main and Astor Streets, Irvington;

THE Ernest Bloch Society, Albert Einstein honorary president, has just issued its annual report. Its principal features comprise lists of the composer's major works performed in this country and in Europe during the 1937-38 season,

The marriage of Miss Anne Marvin Frothingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William I. Frothingham of the Nassau County Club colony here, and Henry G. Bradlee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradlee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradlee of Brookline, Mass., took place this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown at Locust Valley.

Confronted by a rising tide of unemployment and a declining trend in general business, the Roosevelt Administration has proposed a new recovery program, which has produced the most widely, and wildly, varying descriptions of its scope, cost and probable results in work and business.

In a bleak, dismal setting at the Randalls Island Stadium Columbia won the metropolitan track and field championship yesterday with its five wheelhorses-Ben Johnson, Herb Weast, Frank Ryan, Dick Ganslen and Mike Pappas-supplying more than two-thirds of its points.

A stabilized return of good business conditions is impossible until the building industry shows material improvement, N. Max Dunning of Washington, D. C., told the delegates at the convention of the American Institute of Architects in New Orleans last week.

Probably the first submarine mail service in history is operating between Catalonia and the rest of Loyalist Spain. The extraordinary transportation means is necessary because Catalonia has been severed from the rest of Government territory by the Insurgent push to the Mediterranean.

Calling attention to the urgency of combating the recommendations to the Constitutional Convention by the New York State Conference of Mayors, which proposes exemptions from the debt limit as well as suspension of the right of certriorari proceedings on assessed valuations,

One minute of silence will be observed at all meetings of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, Department of New York, on May 21, the twentieth anniversary of the death of the first drafted man to be killed in action in the World War.
Columbia broke even in its doubleheader with Harvard today, winning the opener, 6 to 4, then losing, 12 to 7, when Pitcher Ed Ingalls added a victory to that registered against Cornell yesterday.

The National Labor Relations Board, irked at a wave of what it considers unjustified attacks, following the Morgan Stock Yards decision of April 25 in the Supreme Court, is planning to take its case direct to the public in an effort to clarify its position.

Ohio's industrial centers, particularly Cleveland, are in the midst of- their fourth and most serious relief crisis within two years, because the State government has been unable to set up a permanent welfare program, a failure blamed on rural domination of the Legislature.
There have been recent reports from the farming areas of the country concerning a "revolt" of the farmers against the crop restrictions laid down under the Agricultural Act.

Cooler weather, hailed by farmers in many sections, slowed the movement of seasonal merchandise in retail stores over wide sections last week, and trade for the country as a whole probably declined at least 10 per cent.
Edward Hymes of 420 West End Avenue, a lawyer with offices at 198 Broadway, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital of pneumonia, after a month's illness, at the age of 67.
Harry Burton Leary Sr., an organizer of the General Baking Company, died last night at his home, Clean Drinking Manor, in North Chevy Chase, after a long illness. His age was 74.

The Board of Education is opposed to the proposed home-rule amendment as it affects the New York City schools. Passage of this constitutional amendment would effectively destroy the efficiency and break the morale of the school system, the board charges.

Following conference in Washington last week with Federal Housing Administrator Stewart McDonaid and Deputy Administrator Clyde L. Powell, Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade and chairman of the Bronx Better Housing Committee, predicted yesterday that the stringent requirements of the FHA with respect to ground coverage on multifamily housing projects will be modified in the near-future.

One of the most interesting features of the Spring dog show season this year is the unusual number of separate specialty shows that will be given in addition to those held in connection with regular all-breed events.

Using the World's Fair traffic as an added inducement, James J. it, Lyons Bronx Borough President; Park Commissioner Robert Moses and the Corporation Counsel's office have joined forces in an effort to end a 25-year-old feud between the city and the New. York Central Railroad by attempting to persuade the railroad to construct a terminal at 149th Street and the Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

A photoflash bomb used for night aerial photography which failed to function in the air and exploded when it struck the ground, blew all the glass out of the windows of Paul -Bosarup's farmhouse on Fulton Street, East Hempstead, last night.

The blind faith which the British for generations have placed in their public officials to "muddle through somehow" has been well-nigh shattered by the failure of the Air Ministry after two years of concentrated effort and regardless of expense to match Germany's aircraft construction.

A military court yesterday convicted Sergeant Samuel B. Edgeman of the Thirtieh Infantry, office attache at the Presidio of San Francisco, of removing official and confidential records from the office files.

With Jockey Freddy Scheih outriding the veteran Charley Stevenson in a thrilling stretch duel, Be Blue came on again today after losing the lead to defeat J. W. Y. Martin's Battle Jack by a head and win the $5,000 added Commonwealth Handicap, six-furlong feature of the day's program at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 30,000.

Many home owners are taking advantage of the property improvement credit plan of the FHA to improve dining room alcoves, which for many years were known as the most unattractive spots in a great number of homes.
The war Department released the following orders today dated May 13: COLONEL Reed, W. L. Inf., Reno, Nev., to home and await retirement.

Objection registered by Monmouth County shell fishermen to a bill sponsored by Assemblyman Anthony E. Wickham, Republican, of Ocean County, permitting the taking of clams without-a license, caused Governor Moore to veto the measure today.
Brig. Gen. Aaron Simon Daggett, oldest United States army officer, died today at his home, 31 Linnett Street, West Roxbury. He would have been 101 years old on June 14.
Dartmouth triumphed over Columbia University, 3-2, in a tennis match called on account of rain with a singles and three doubles matches remaining to be contested yesterday on the South Field courts.

Loans granted by savings, building and loan associations throughout the country during March amounted to $86,810,600, a new high record for the year and 35 per cent more than the total of $66,501,800 for February, the United States Building and Loan. League - announced yesterday.
Behind the two-hit pitching of Harold Wonson, sophomore right-hander, Dartmouth won another Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball game today, defeating Cornell, 11-2.

Several thousand varieties of tulips from Holland, including the new "Princess Beatrix," named in honor of Princess Juliana's and Prince Bernhard's daughter, will be exhibited in an unusual flower show to be held on .board the new flagship of-the Holland-America Line, the Nieuw Amsterdam, on Friday afternoon from 2 to 6 o'clock.
The House Flood Control Committee recommended today that a billiondollar program be started under its five-year plan of flood control. It Incidentally criticized "professional planning."
With Bill Bowers placing first in both the 100 and 220 yard events, Oceanside won the Long Island South Shore High Schools Class B track
Drastic changes in the organization of the executive and legislative branches of the State government were recommended yesterday by the Citizens Union to the Constitutional Convention.

A new six-cent air mail stamp, commemorating the first air mall flight twenty years ago, was sold here today in advance of sales at all other cities except Dayton, Ohio, cradle of the air mail service.

With an attendance of 200 educators from all parts of the country, the thirteenth annual meeting of the American Association for Adult Education will be held at the Berkeley-Carteret Hotel on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.

Estate, more than $20,000. To Helen H. Waterman, widows executrix, 655 Park Ave., personal effects, household goods, life estate in residue; Frank D. Waterman Jr., Summit, N. J., remainder interest in one-half residue:
Regulations for conduct of trailer camps that may be established by business men in the vicinity of the World's Fair were issued yesterday by the Board of Health.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Hubbard Wood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra B. Wood of this city, to Alfred G. Bagg, son of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Bagg of Mount Vernon. N. Y., took place this afternoon in the Church of the Messiah.

With cries of "Onward, Spinsters, Onward!" more than 10,000 of Britain's unmarried women marched on London today with banners flying for a rally of their National Spinsters' Pensions Association. They demanded "State pensions at 55."

An economic study-of the dairy industry in Dutchess County presented in the Vassar College Social Museum by students of an economics course in the rise of American industry, a physiology class in nutrition, and an English class dealing with public discussion demonstrates the project method of learning on the college level.
For the first time in history a woman is under serious consideration for appointment as ambassador to a major diplomatic post.

STARTING today, on the twentieth anniversary of the United States-air mail service, and during the nation-wide celebration of Air Mail Week for the next six days, many claims of "first" probably will be heard, judging by the advance programs.
A group of Cleveland's unemployed today threatened a sit-down at City Hall as Mayor Burton and his aides met to hunt for relief funds for the latter half of May.

FOUR old stern-wheelers, veterans of steam packet days on the Sacramento River, will soon be pulled to pieces by the shipwrecker and their machinery salvaged for scrap. Ranging from thirty to over fifty years old, -the boats include the T. C. Walker, built in Stockton in 1885; the J. D. Peters, Stockton-built in 1889; the Reform, launched at Wood Island in 1898, and the Nav?jo, whose keel was laid along the ?akland estuary in 1909.

A valuable collection of 500 volumes on the writings of Dante has been receivd by Manhattan College from the estate of the late Mgr. John T. Slattery of T?oy, N. Y., it was announced yesterday by the college authorities.

Professor Reginald A. Daly, Harvard's distinguished geophysicist, has a new theory about volcanoes. Or rather he revives an old one. Just like his supposedly old-fashioned predecessors he thinks that volcanoes are the chimneys that they seem to be and that they go right down to something like a molten interior.
The government has prohibited popular manifestations of any sort because of student demonstrations against entrance requirements for the universities.
Marius Russo, Newark left-hander, pitched two-hit ball for six innings, but the Royals fell on him in the seventh and eighth for half a dozen blows and a 3-2 victory over the Bears today.

Now that diplomatic relations between Mexico -and Great Britain have been suspended, a firmer interposition by the British Government is expected in the controversy over the seizure of the foreignowned oil properties in Mexico.

AN unusual home of the colonial type utilizing stone-and shin gles for the exterior has been completed by the Harmon National Real Estate Corporation in its community known as Nassau Shores, Amityville, L. I., from plans by Randolph Evans, and has been purchased by Joseph Ginoris, manufacturer of artificial flowers.
The Phillips Exeter nine won from Hebron Academy, 6 to 5, today, making the deciding run in the ninth after the losers had tallied three times to deadlock the score.

Rutgers fell victim to a fiverun first-inning assault by the Williams College nine on Weston Field today, Pitchers Coe and Gels being Victims before. a large holiday crowd, and the New Brunswick team bowed by a 9-2 score.

Miss Elinor Constantinides, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles L. Constantinides, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to Harold Thayer of Passaic, son of Dr. Helen Thayer of Rochester, N. Y., and the late Dr. Herbert Thayer, by the Rev. Percy T. Olton, rector of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Newark.

The American Federation of Labor's Weekly News Service said in an editorial today that the United States Chamber of Commerce had "utterly failed to grasp its opportunity" to help end strife between labor and industry.

The situation in Loyalist Spain remains critical, but at present at only one point-toward the Sagunto Road. The Loyalists' chances of holding up there are good, and the next two or three weeks will tell.

Rain, which seems to be about the only element stopping the Giants these days, held Colonel Bill Terry's whirlwind pace-setters in check again today when it caused a postponement of the opening clash of a three-game series with the Phils.
THERE is a great difference, as Carl Crow points out, between Confucius and Master Kung. And. the title, "Analects of Confucius," the reader may add, seems immeasurably removed from the simple

KIRSTEN FLAGSTAD appears in Honolulu, May 27. She gives recitals in Australia and New Zealand from June 13 to Sept. 10, and in October will make her Parisian debut. Her Paris schedule includes two appearances at the Grand Opera and a recital. Later she sings in recital in London, returning to America in' October.
ENTRANCE to the Suez Canal, Threshold of the East, Gateway to the Indies. A horrible little harbor town, thickly populated by Arabs, Greeks, Negroes,

The Greater New York Taxpayers Association, which originally brought the test case to determine the legality of the so-called bathtub charge by the city, expressed satisfaction yesterday over the decision handed down last week by the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court which affirmed the prior decision of Justice Lester Lazarus, who had found the bathtub charge illegal.

Calling attention to the benefits of proper planning and zoning for group housing and multi-housing projects, the Federal Housing Administration points out that in 1922 there were only 185 planning and coning boards in operation, whereas the close of 1936 found 1,201 cities reporting such agencies.

PAUL WING, spelling master of the wave lengths, who has conducted fifty-six regular "bees" over WJZ's hook-up has made the most of his opportunity to study words and the spellers who spell them into space.. He-says that first and foremost a good speller is picture-minded.

John P. Smith, former owner of Nyack's largest shipyard, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 79. He was born in Nyack on Aug. 18, 1858. His father, the late James E. Smith, a river man of the sailing days, bought a long-established shipyard here in 1867. John Smith took the yard over in 1889.
More Summer residents will spend the season this year on the shores of Lake Mohawk, at Sparta, Sussex County, N. J., than in any previous year, announces the Arthur D. Crane Company, developers.

Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago publisher, told the State convention of Young Republicans of Wisconsin tonight that the uncompromising knife of economic law has whittled down the New Dealers to their natural size."

A "folded- arms" strike of convicts, San Quentin's second within a week, ended today when the participants voted 111 to 62 to accept Warden Court Smith's compromise offer on their demand for restoration of midday rest periods.

Miss Ellen Chandler Bruyn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles De Witt Bruyn of 250 Lincoln Street, was married to Preston Ira Carnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Baldwin Carnes, also this place, this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Carl H.
The Rev. John A. Hlebik, assistant pastor of the St. Joseph's Catholic Church, died last night at the rectory. His age was 77.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--The fish have arrived early in Atlantic City waters and already the visiting anglers are returning home with full baskets. It will be another month, however, before the tuna and other game fish are here to take the hook.
William C. Duell, supervisor of the town of Greenburgh, Westchester County, announces that all of the vacant properties held by the town will be sold at auction in June.

As a special service to prospective June brides, the WPA adult education program of the New York City Board of Education established a new course last week offering the brides practical consumer knowledge in the quality and prices of many standard products.
Canadian gold production in March amounted to 369,000 fine ounces, compared with 341,000 in February and 361,000 in January, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.
Rutgers today won for the second straight year the track and field championship of the Middle Atlantic States Collegiate Athletic Associtation.

Recent publication by President Roosevelt of several thousand words of excerpts from stenographic notes of White House press conferences has served to place an official stamp on what heretofore has been considered the private forum of a man in a highly responsible position.
Thomas Albert Douglas, owner of a plumbing and heating business here from 1892 to 1928, died today at his home after a year's illness. His age was 69.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Mary Whitwell Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Whitwell Wilson of Spuyten Duyvil, this city, to George Davidson White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howell North White of Lakeville, Conn., took place yesterday afternoon in the Riverdale Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George M. Duff, the pastor.

Mrs. William Lord Littlefield of this city has announced the engagement of tionher daughter, Miss Lorraine Littlefield, to George Anderton. Burke, son of Mrs. Julian T. Burke of Alexandria, Va., and the late Mr. Burke.
THE left hand telephone rang on the desk of Harllee Branch, Second Assistant Postmaster General, among whose duties is the supervision of the air mail.

WITH a clear, unprejudiced vision and in chatty, humorous style, Gay MacLaren records her own history as an entertainer on Chautauqua programs along with the story of the whole movement from proud beginning to ignominious end.

The Census Bureau reported today cotton consumed during April totaled 414,392 bales of lint and 57,852 of linters, compared with 510,941 and 60,443 during March this year, and 718,975 and 73,715 during April last year.
Bill Farnsworth, owned by Mrs. M. Cassidy of New York, raced to a two-and-a-half-length upset victory over Sir Oracle in the $2,500 added Woodside Handicap

Aimed at reducing the number of highway accidents and at the same time stimulating the rubber industry, National Tire Safety Week was opened yesterday with the endorsement of many motor vehicle commissioners throughout the country and the heads of many safety organizations.

With grants from the Rockefeller and Josiah Macy Jr. Foundations of New York, Drs. Gordon H. Scott, J. H. McMillen and D. M. Packer of the Department of Anatomy, Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, Mo.,
FAYETTEVILLE, N. C.--Conservation is beginning to show results in North Carolina, and from the mountains to the sea Tar Heel fishermen new are enjoying a highly successful season.

THE series which Algeria will issue, as mentioned in these columns on May 1, to mark the centenary of the death of Rene Caille (1799-1838), a French explorer in Africa, will present also portraits of three other men identified with French penetration of the Sahara.
Business was quiet in the foreign exchange market here today and chief interest centered in forward belgas, which recovered to 120 and 175 centimes discount for one and three months, respectively.

A bullet fired by an assailant in a hotel taproom tonight terminated the mysterious career of Isaiah Leebove, wealthy Michigan oil operator and political figure. Police Chief William Dunlop said that William Livingstone, an oil man and former associate of Leebove, admitted firing the fatal shot.

Bitter strife among..Pennsylvania Democratic leaders and candidates, which Governor Earle two months ago called "just a family argument," showed no signs of abating as the last full week. of the primary campaign drew toward a close.

We had word yesterday that Tommy Gifford, one of the best big-game boat captains on the coast, opened the tuna season at Bimini by taking the first of this year's blue-fins. One of the tuna weighed. .396 and the other 402 pounds.

The Rev. John Bernard Kelly, spiritual director of the Catholic Writers Guild, will be guest of honor next Friday night at the Waldorf-Astoria at a special meeting to commemorate his silver jubilee. The poet-priest is a representative of Cardinal Hayes among Catholic writers for the press, stage, screen and radio.

The role of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America as the possible peacemaker in the relations between the Ameripan Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization was developed significantly, here this week during the union's biennial convention.

Vincent Moran turned in a magnificent performance on the mound as Barnard School's baseball team blanked Woodmere Academy, 7-0, yesterday at Fieldston in a play-off for the Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools championship.

IN these sunlit weeks that usher in midsummer, the Arctic North comes again into its own. As Lauge Koch is off once more to Greenland for further Polar research, some of the findings of his recent expedition, by far the largest ever sent out from Denmark, are brought together in popular form,

James L. Dougherty, assistant general counsel of the RFC and a director of the recently organized National Mortgage Association of Washington, D. C., told the delegates at the recent conference in Washington called by the National Association of Real Estate Boards that the mortgage association will purchase all FHA insured mortgages on new structures begun on or after Jan. 1, 1937.

THE recent visit of Adolf Hitler to Italy revealed anew the methods used by dictators in handling crowds Premier Mussolini, as stage manager, put on popular demonstrations that rivaled those in Germany when the Fuehrer was the host and the Duce the guest. The crowd has become a tool of dictators.

Led by Don Bradman the touring Australian test cricket team today compiled 428 runs for five wickets at the close of the first day's play against the Marylebone C. C. The Aussie- skipper scored 257 not out before a capacity crowd of 32,000 at Lord's.

A proposal involving the eventual acquisition of about $81,000,000 in private power properties in Nebraska and presenting squarely to the government the question of its policy concerning competition with private utilities was outlined today to Secretary Ickes.

William du Pont's Dauber, 3-to-2 favorite, came from far off the pace to win by seven lengths in the forty-eighth Preakness at Pimlico. Townsend B. Martin's Cravat, an outsider in the betting, was second, a nose in advance of Hal Price Headley's Menow.
Bill Knickerbocker got -his first hit in five games yesterday at the Yankee Stadium, a significant triple after fourteen fruitless trips to the plate.

K. Lee Hyder of Milwaukee, president of the Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, declares that proper regulations should be drawn up by the Securities and Exchange Commission whereby the value behind securities may be measured on the indicated effective productivity of the future.

New cases of foreclogure on properties coming within the purview of the State Mortgage Commission currently amount to less than 10 per cent of the volume arising in 1935 and 1936, according to Lewis F. X. Cotignola, attorney in charge of the commission's foreclosure department.

Mexico and Great Britain appeared last week to have reached the parting of the ways. Mexico suddenly recalled her Minister from London and announced that because of the "not very friendly attitude of the British Government" diplomatic relations had been severed.
New officers of the Hunter College Associate Alumnae were installed yesterday afternoon at the annual Spring reunion at the Hotel Astor. Mrs. Theodore Simis, former treasurer, was elected president.

Army won from Georgetown at baseball today, 6 to 1. Cadet Tom Davis held the Hoyas to four hits and shut them out until the ninth. Smith, Georgetown starting pitcher, walked three cadets in the first inning and all scored when Yeager smashed a triple to right field.

Miss Katharine Stanley Howland, daughter of Mrs. Daniel Howland of East Greenwich, R. I., and the late Mr. Howland, was married to Lieutenant Alfred Allen Maybach, United States Army, of Fort Devens, Mass., son of the late Colonel and Mrs. Alfred A. Maybach of Providence, this afternoon in St. Luke's Church in East Greenwich.

The National Council of State Garden Clubs, of which Mrs. O. W. Dynes is president, will open its convention: here tomorrow as the guest of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, according to an announcement yesterday.
Tribute was paid yesterday to the work of Sir Patrick Manson and Sir Ronald Ross in the prevention and cure of malaria, which, it was contended, had revolutionized life in the tropics.

James L. Dougherty, assistant general counsel of the RFC and a director of the recently organized National Mortgage Association of Washington, D. C., told the delegates at the recent conference in Washington called by the National Association of Real Estate Boards that the mortgage association will purchase all FHA insured mortgages on new structures begun on or after Jan. 1, 1937.

HER first-solo show in several years brings together several of Lauren Ford's oils and a score of colored crayon drawings. Among the oils is that huge panorama called "The Country Doctor," the title character spotted with bullseye accuracy at the center of the web of rural activities.
The suspension by Mexico of diplomatic relations with Britain has occasioned grave concern here because

The railroads of this country have reached a grave crisis and it is time to give the industry, its owners and executives a chance to see what they can do with fair and proper supervision, according to Theodore Prince, economic consultant.

Shipments of merchandise out of this port for Mexico have risen 20 per cent since May 1, when Mexico reduced the temporary tariff rates imposed in January, according to officials at the office of the Mexican Consuul General here.
To create a new Salzburg in America, Max Reinhardt, noted producer, will move his entire "workshop" to Hollywood and will stage three elaborate fantasies here this Summer.

It seemed for a while this morning as if one more bobble had been made in the bookings for Kansas City's new municipal auditorium, where the General Federation of Women's Clubs has been holding forth in its triennial convention.

ABRAMSON--MINTZ--Mr. and Mrs. Aaron G. Mintz of Ithaca, N. Y., announce the engagement of their daughter. Frances Annette, to Mr. Jacob Abramson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Abramson of Rochester, N. Y.

Bonds on the New York Stock Exchange moved lower yesterday in the dullest trading this month. Sales aggregated only $2,689,800, compared with $3,786,675 a week before. Trends were mixed and only a few issues were able to show sizable gains.

Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Education Commissioner, appealed today to the Phi Beta Kappa society to create and select leaders "who will courageously lead the forces undertaking to ameliorate existent confused social, political and economic conditions."
What will be known as the Revenue Act of 1938 has been passed by both houses of Congress and is now awaiting the signature of the President, of which it is reasonably assured.

This year's great Spring drought, with no equal in England and Wales at any season of the year since 1785, was virtually. ended tonight with a steady downpour in London and showers elsewhere,with the wind set in the wet south quarter.

Two resolutions designed to make a kind of city-State of the national capital, with full right of -franchise for its residents, will be the subject of public hearings before the House Judiciary Committee next Wednesday and Thursday.

Approximately 1,000 persons are expected to sail on the "mystery cruise" to be conducted aboard the S. S. Westchester on Friday night as a benefit for the Summer camp of the Stryker's Lane Community Center of this city.

A SWEDISH countess, the wife of a Czech painter, long resident in Italy, obviously dowered by nature with musical gifts and social charm, the author of "Sardi-nian Sideshow" has plenty of interesting recollections to put into a new book.

Participation in the New York World's Fair will have particular significance for the New York State Federation of Music Clubs because it will be combined with the celebration of the twentieth anniversary of the founding of the organization.
GRETCHEN SCHMIDT is a German Hausfrau. Her job is to cook five meals a day - breakfast, lunch, dinner, "Kaffee" and supper-for her husband, children and herself.
MAY is here again, bringing in its train, if not warmth and sunshine, the London season with all that follows-races, tennis tournaments, cricket, regattas for the sportsman;
Trailing in the ninth inning and again in the tenth, the Cardinals fought to an uphill. 7-to-6 victory over the Reds today. Rookie Enos Slaughter's home run with Joe Stripp on base decided the issue.

THOUGH the Critics Circle and Pulitzer drama prizes have confronted each other three times, box-office students have had no chance until now to study the relative financial effect of the two; this because, on the occasion of the Circle's first two awards, the Pulitzer committee hung its garland on shows that were already selling out ("Idiot's Delight" and "You Can't Take It With You").

The May Day celebration of Marymount College here will be held tomorrow on the campus. Miss Mary Brophy, president of the Student Council, will be crowned "Queen of the May" by Miss Joan Lalley, and the program will include a pageant, "May Dawning."

Among otner things which might puzzle a visitor from Mars, should he descend upon Canada to observe its phenomena, would be the question of whether Premier W. C. Aberhart of Alberta is a great political success or a flat political failure.

Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota has generally been regarded as the father of the controversial Neutrality Act, for it was his committee's investigation of the munitions industry that gave the spur to the legislation. The committee attempted to show a relationship between American entrance into the World War and American loans and munitions sales to the warring powers before our entry.

Miss Lorena Brooks Rowe, daughter of Mrs. James Gordon Rowe Jr. of this place, has completed plans for her marriage on June 9 to James A. Corroon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Corroon of Massapequa Manor, Massapequa, L.I.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday that attempts were being made by it and by persons prominent in medical circles to obtain the 1940 annual meeting of the American Medical Association for New York City.

George Letterhouse, trust officer of the Commercial Trust Company of New Jersey at Jersey City, who was elected president of the New Jersey Bankers Association at the closing session of the thirty-fifth annual convention today, attacked the Federal. Government's new "pump-priming" program in an ad-. dress to the convention.
Representative Mead, Buffalo Democrat, today urged the House--Wage and Hour Bill as a means-of protecting working standards in New York industries against competition from low-pay areas.

Increases of more than 100 per cent in three activities sponsored by the Westchester County Recreation Commission were listed in the commission's annual report covering 1937, filed this week with the Board of Supervisors.

James R. Cavanaugh, Federal engineer in charge, announced today that the subterranean fire which has been eating away the heart of this coal district for fiftyfour years had been turned back on the first of three fronts.

The aggregate profit of $5,029,264 for eight leading automotive companies in the first quarter of 1938 was $53,984,604 or 90 per cent, below that for the corresponding period of 1937, with five companies showing losses for this year's period, whereas only one operated in the red in the first three months of 1937.

Four Group Shows-In the current group exhibition at the Midtown Galleries are characteristic paintings by Waldo and Alzira Peirce, Paul Mommer (his darkly moody "Inlet, Long Island"), Philip Evergood ("Pink Dismissal Slip"), Frederic Taubes (a classic nostalgia with deeper color than of old), Jacob Getlar Smith ("Manhattan Nocturne") and a dozen others. A welldiversified show.

LET'S declare a holiday and pretend military flourishes did not head the World's Fair parade while flags in shops flanking it brandished the motto: "Art of the Future"; pretend that the parade passed through streets bordered by sensible architecture;

In a speech dealing almost exclusively with foreign politics, Premier Mussolini this morning speaking to a crowd of many thousands served notice on the world's great democracies that in the case of war the "totalitarian States will immediately form a bloc and march together to the end."
Philadelphia at New York--Thomas vs. Sundra. Washington at Boston--Weaver vs. Grove. Chicago at Cleveland--Dietrich vs. Whitehill. St. Louis at Detroit--Hildebrand vs. Auker.

THIS collection will be seized upon eagerly by every addict of Americana, for here will be found reprinted many and many a deep-water piece no longer to be come upon except as an "item" obtainable only at great expense.

A plea for a principle of superiority in the warships and weapons of the United States was made by Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary -of the Navy, here today in addressing the graduate class of seventy-four officers at the Naval War College.

The engagement of MissFrances Barnes Van Every, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Brock Van Every of this place, to William Blunt Sher man, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Leighton Sherman of Dobbs Ferry, has been announced by her parents.

WASHINGTON.-Congress has moved to change the name of Water Street to Maine Avenue, and in so doing has removed Maine from the small list of States not at present honored by a street. or avenue in the nation's capital.
It was announced today that Premier Paul Henri Spaak's Cabinet would comprise four Socialists, four Catholics, two Liberals and the nonpartisan General Henri Denis, Minister for National Defense.

New York's foreign trade zone, conducted for more than a year by the city, will pass under the control of private operators tomorrow morning when Harry C. Shanks, head of the Manhattan Lighterage Corporation and president of the newly formed New York Foreign Trade Zone Operators, Inc., lessees, formally takes over the Staten Island property.
The Milbank estate in Greenwich, Conn., will be the setting on June 11 for a large outdoor fashion show to be presented for the benefit of the Greenwich Time Children's Camp and Educational Fund.

Every year more and more city people find it possible to run away from their cities for a day, a week-end or a whole vacation. Escape is cheaper and easier than it used to be. But in escaping from the pavements we do not always leave our city ideas behind.

A government spokesman said today that Vienna's coronation insignia of Germanic emperors, dating back to the eleventh century, had been declared the property of the greater German Reich following the March 13 Austro-German Anschluss.

THE fourteenth annual Westchester Festival wil end Friday and Saturday at the County Center, White Plains. Hugh Ross, conductor of the festival, and Eugene Ormandy will direct. The Westchester Festival Chorus will appear in the Saturday night concert. The Philadelphia Orchestra will play both evenings.

Prospects of reopening the Allen-A Company's plant here under the direction of a corporation formed by a citizens' committee were bright today with the promise of aid from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Hugo Eckener told Secretary Ickes today he did not consider 10,000,000 cubic feet of helium to be of "military importance" and said he hoped the latter would reconsider his determination not to sell non-explosive gas to Germany.

FOR the next step in its campaign aimed at the adoption by the Constitutional Convention of an amendment allocating all motor vehicle registration fees and fuel taxes solely to highway purposes, the convention committee of the New York State Automobile Association will meet tomorrow night in Albany.
The new fluorescent lamps which were described on this page a few weeks ago are to be used for the first time in large-scale outdoor illumination at California's International Exposition in 1939.
A sudden stiffening of Spanish Government resistance along the front from Teruel eastward to the Mediterranean tonight slowed the pace of the Insurgents' offensive toward Valencia.
SECRETARIES have been busily sending out announcements that the beach clubs are about to open their doors. Decoration Day sets the season in motion. Play toes are the order of the day.

Mr. and Mrs. Perry D. Frazer gave a tea today at their home here at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Dorothea Frazer, to William Cairns Banta Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Banta, also of Ridgewood.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, prestdent of City College, announced yesterday that the twenty-second annual Summer semester would open on Tuesday, July 5, for an eight-week term, which will close on Monday, Aug. 29.

While bands played and a cordon of police surrounded the Federal Building, patrolling the A. F. of L. union parade in Foley Square, Louis Galvani, an alleged narcotic addict, escaped from the United States Attorney's office while awaiting arraignment. It was the fourth time a narcotic, prisoner had fled in recent months.

In order to deport Mohammed di Koresa, 27 years old, an Ethiopian with a criminal record, the United States Government, through the Department of Labor, had to pay $196 for his journey back to Addis Ababa, where he was born.

Sir Harry Lauder, famous Scotch comedian, was admitted into the McAlpine Hospital here this morning suffering from injuries of the face and thigh sustained when he slipped in the bathroom of his home today.
Today Alpha Omicron Pi Alumnae-Tea, Beekman Tower. Catholic Young Women's ClubAnnual congress of religious discussion grouns. 4:30 P. M.

The University of Southern California team bettered the world record for the 440-yard relay tonight in the West Coast relays, chalking up a time of 0:40.5 seconds. The former mark of 0:40.7 was established by another U. S. C. team in 1936.

Five youths who had been thrown into the waters of Eastchester Bay, 500 feet off the foot of Cross Street, City Island, when their canoe overturned in the storm just before 5 P. M. yesterday, were rescued and taken ashore in a passing motorboat, the Lucky Ann, operated by Buddy Martin of City Island.
Supply contracts valued at $4,695,644 were awarded in the week ended on May 12 by ten F deal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Schultz of Wellesley Hills, Mass., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice De Haven Schultz, to Roger Ransom Valkenburgh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Valkenburgh of Middletown, N. Y.

Primo Villa Michel, the Mexican Minister to London, called at the Foreign Office today, and in the absence of Viscount Halifax, the Foreign Secretary, who is in Geneva, informed Sir Alexander Cadogan, the permanent Under-Secretary, of his instructions to close his legation and leave the country.
Boys representing high schools throughout Delaware "governed" the State today. They elected William Price of Newark as "Governor" and organized a Senate and House of Representatives.
Charles S. Snyder, this boro's oldest resident and voter, died early today at the home of his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. R. W. Mitchell. He was 98 years old last Dec. 26.

Despite lower foreign markets and beneficial rainfall in the Mississippi Valley and Eastern States, prices on the Cotton Exchange held within an unusually narrow range yesterday and ended with. losses of l to 4 points.

Six automatic computing machines as large as pianos, operating for two years in Columbia University's astronomical laboratories, have verified the modern theory of the motions of the moon, which was developed after third years of lunar research and calculations by Professor Ernest W. Brown, Yale University astronomer and mathmatician, it was announced yesterday.

The Boy Scouts of America honored eight men tonight with. the Silver Buffalo award, given for "distinguished service to boyhood." The awards, announced at thee closing dinner of the National Scout Council's twenty-eighth annual meeting, went to:

Seventy-one grants for study and research in the social sciences here and abroad, representing an expenditure of more than $85,000, have been awarded to scholars in all parts of the United States for 19381939 by the Social Science Research Council, 230 Park Avenue, it was announced yesterday.
Three blasts on the Farmingdale Fire Department's siren tomorrow night will herald the first "black-out' ever to be tried in the United States,

Plans have been completed by Miss Margaret Tucker, daughter of Captain William B. Tucker of 44 Bellwood Place, and the late Mrs. Tucker, for her marriage to Dr. Lewis E. Bodenweiser of Springfield, son of Dr. and Mrs. Elias Bodenweiser of Irvington.

Irving Moses of the St. Anselm's Athletic Club defeated his teammate, George La Torre, in a keen ten-mile handicap walk sponsored by the Walkers Club of America at Macombs Dam Park in the Bronx yesterday despite intermittent showers.

B. Altman Co. is launching plans for an expansion program to cost at least $1,000,000, according to an announcement issued for publication today by John S. Burke, president of the Fifth Avenue store. Construction work will begin this week and Will be completed by Oct.
The salt water fishing seems to be getting better and better, and the reports from Connecticut to North Carolina are the best in years.

Walter N. Rothschild's yawl Avanti, winner of the Gibson Island ocean race last year, swept through sixteen miles of cold and wet going out on Long Island Sound today to triumph in the Larchmont Yacht Club regatta.

It is difficult to discern any real reason for Wall Street's return to a condition of mild optimism. Little in the immediate outlook justifies higher security prices and Wall Street evidently is doing its best to produce an atmosphere in which views more favorable to the future will be able to develop.

Alexander Pope, the English poet who in his time was accused by his contemporaries of abusing "Almighty God," "the King," "the established church" and "both houses of Parliament," was born in London on May 21, 1688, and, to celebrate the 250th anniversary of his birth, Columbia University will open today in South Hall an exhibition devoted to his works.
Weather, cold and damp, again held the Giants in a firm grip today, and for the second successive afternoon a game with the Phillies was washed on to the postponed calendar.

All conditions now appear favorable for the production this year of the biggest grain crop in Russian history, larger than last year's record-breaking harvest, estimated at slightly under 7,000,000 poods La pood is thirty-six pounds] and thus within sight of the- goal of 7,000,000 to 8,000,000 poods set by Joseph Stalin in 1935 for attainment within three or four years.

Hassan a Rifaat Pasha, Under-Secretary of the Interior, will summon tomorrow Palestinian Arab leaders now residing here as political refugees and will warn them that unless they refrain from political activities here, particularly concerning Palestine, the Egyptian Government will be forced to withdraw its hospitality and to deport them.
Mrs. Roberta Campbell Lawson, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, abandoned the rostrum for the pulpit this morning, speaking at services in the First Baptist Church.
The principal financial event of the last week was the sharp repercussion on the money market made by the repatriation of French capital.

First place has been awarded to the Long Island Railroad among Group C railroads in the national safety contest conducted in 1937 by the committee of railroad employes of the National Safety Council, it was announced yesterday by George Le Boutillier, vice president.

Francis Seon Colt. died yesterday. at his residence, 1,158 Fifth Avenue, after two years of ill health, at' the age of 78. He retired from business some years ago, having been a partner in Collins Co., manufacturers of edged tools.

Tomorrow is primary day in Pennsylvania. The campaign has been a witches' Sabbath on the Democratic side, and some of the Republican brethren have had a high temperature. It is hard to make any sense out of the daily outpouring of accusations,
The San Carlo Opera Company closed its local season with Verdi's "Il Trovatore" last night at the Center Theatre. Again a capacity audience was on hand.

Increases in enrollment in three of the colleges of Fordham University and continued insistence upon higher standards throughout the university were announced by the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham, in his annual report at the convocation of the fa-ulties of the university yesterday.

If wage scales, coal costs, the prices of materials and supplies and taxes had been the same in 1937 as in 1933, the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad's net operating return in 1937 would have been $4,122,200 greater, Wilson McCarthy and Henry Swan, trustees in bankruptcy, asserted in their annual report.
