Dr. Arthur M. Howe, chairman of the Brooklyn College Administrative Committee of the Board of Higher Education, said yesterday that the committee had adopted a resolution recommending to the board that an R. O. T. C. club be permitted to meet as an official organization at the college.

David George Jr., 24 years old, of Philadelphia, was killed and three Vineland men were injured early this morning when Mr. George's automobile crashed into a telephone pole on a curve of West Boulevard in Franklin Township.

Columbian Carbon Company and Assoc Subsidiaries-Three months ended Balfo March 31: Net profit, $707,155, after depreciation and depletion, minority interest charges and profit on the sale of securities,

Shelley Braverman of 149-50 Roosevelt Avenue, Queens, New York, and three corporations in Which he is said to own all or a majority of the stock, were named today in a complaint by the Federal Trade Commission charging unfair competition in the sale of a medicinal product called Retardo, an alleged remedy for overweight.
Twelve traveling fellowships for study abroad during the next academic year were awarded at Harvard University today. They carry a total cash value of $14,800. The prizes were granted as follows:
After a sensational "upswing without prosperity" that carried it to the peak of capacity production and put all able-bodied Germans to work, German business is apparently entering a new phase.
The Browns defeated the Tigers, 4 to 1, today in the final game of their series, which lasted only five innings because of rain.
Tobacco growers in Pittsylvania County were in a state of virtual revolt today over the recently announced acreage allocations promulgated by the Department of Agriculture under the Crop Control Act.

" Zip." a big, black "mystery" frog from Stockton, shattered the "world's" record today with a leap of 15 feet 10 inches at the annual international frog jumping jubilee commemorating Mark Twain's famous story of the Calaveras County leaping 'croaker.

A mass meeting of 30,000 World War veterans here today ended with an appeal for a Christian Hungary and the maintenance of law and order. A group of young Fascists attempted to break up a subsequent procession by throwing petards, but these, however, failed to explode. The veterans almost lynched the youths, ten of whom were arrested.

The American Tobacco Company's building at the New York World's Fair will feature a full-size manufacturing unit showing how cigarettes are made and packaged, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation. Cost of the exhibit,

For the first time in forty-one years St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, has called a minister. He is the Rev. W. John Villaume, 24 years old, of Summit, N. J., but a native of this city. He will be the assistant to the Rev. Dr. Alfred B. Moldenke, who is in his sixty-seventh year.
The rise on the Bourse last week was due chiefly to purchases of professional speculators who discounted the improvement of the market through the repatriation of exported capital.

The eleventh annual parade and church service of the Knights Templar of Greater New York were held yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The attendance and marching were curtailed in comparison with former years by cold w?ads and a threatening sky.
The observer of developments in Central Europe should not overlook or underestimate the importance of the change of government in Hungary. This is an event both symptomatic and significant.
On Wednesday international stocks had a brief fillip from the official intimation ers to the bankers' congress that the veto on private capital issues might be relaxed.

The modern boy would probably rather be an aviator than anything else. The boy of about thirty years ago wanted to be a locomotive engineer. So this suggests a way to solve a part of the railroad problem.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Livesey of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Marie Livesey, to Curtis Campaigne Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Campaign, also of Montclair, and of New York. Miss Livesey is a graduate of the Kimberley School here.
Bill Cummings of Indianapolis and Rex Mays of Glendale, Calif., each won a heat in their match race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today, but the weather man took the final decision,

Obedience to the Creator is safer and better than obedience to creation, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.
Here in this little town of 1,900 in Southern Kentucky a trial fraught with significance to all the nation's employ; ers of labor opens tomorrow.

The rise in total cost of public relief in the nation, which has continued for the past five months, mounted by $18,000,000, or 8 per cent, from February to March, reaching $234,800,000 for the latter month, the Social Security Board reported today.

Mr. and Mrs. Martin von Dehn of 510 Park Avenue will sail Wednesday on the Europa. They will pass some time in London. Mrs. Henry Arthur Hutchins of Wilmette, Ill., is visiting her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Charles Gilmore Kerley, at 10 East Eighty-first Street.

Bertha Kalich, retired tragedienne of the English and Yiddish stages, will be honored tonight at the Public Theatre with a testimonial performance of "Brothers Ashkenazi." The production has been brought from Boston by Maurice Schwartz and his Yiddish Art Theatre company, who earlier in the season played an engagement at their own theatre here.

The British Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices for April, based on 1930 as 100, is 103.1, compared with 104.1 in March and 108.9 in April, 1937. Last year's high was 111.5, established in July.

Mankind has failed to realize some of its most cherished ideals because it has lacked the motivating power of a mighty affection, the Rev. Leon Merle Flanders, pastor of the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse at 178th Street, said at his morning service yesterday.

Little interest was shown in -the oats, rye and soy bean markets here last week. Oats closed. 3/8 cent higher to 1/8 cent line lower for the week, with May showing the most strength, being quoted will on Saturday at 29 cents, with July 27 1/2 cents and September at 27 1/2 cents a bushel.

Miss Louise Quigley of the Convent of the Sacred Heart was elected president yesterday of the National Federation of Catholic College Students at the annual meeting held at the Manhattanville college, Convent Avenue and 133d Street.
Two of army fliers descended at 7:18 Guil o'clock last night after having completed twenty-nine laps in their plane, Wings of the Century, over a closed course and claimed two world records.

Miss Hope Tyler Kiesewetter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Helmuth von Moltke Kiesewetter of South Orange, will be married June- 16 in Grace .Episcopal Church,. Orange, to Standish Forde Medina, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Medina of New York and Westhampton Beach, L. I.

Jimmy Hines, home club pro, who retained the Metropolitan open championship yesterday, paired with Vic Ghezzi, the North and South champion, today to conquer Ralph Guldahl, national open ruler, and Sam Snead in a benefit foursome at the Lakeville Golf and Country Club. The score was 1 up.

FOLLOWING the Introductory prayer, the opening item on the agenda of the International Union of Book Reviewers, when and if it is organized and holds its first annual congress in Rio de Janeiro, should be a vote of thanks and congratulation to Comrade Howard Spring for having given the lie, in the space of a-mere 649 pages, to those carping outsiders who assert that book reviewers are book reviewers simply because they won't write books.

To fill its rightful place in life today, the church must recover its self-respect, which has suffered in the face of the world's indifference, the Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.
After being questioned by Federal Bureau of Investigation men and police of Rockaway, N. J., for nearly twenty hours, John Skonc, 52-year-old rag-picker, was set free late yesterday afternoon.
The Position of the belga, made worse by veto that cabinet crisis in Brussels, naturally is creating concern here.

Leo Leo Schnepel of the Polish Falcons of Elizabeth, N. J., won the National A. A. U. 50,000-meter walking championship today in 5 hours 18 minutes 50.2 seconds. John Abate of Cincinnati was second, 5 minutes and 50 seconds behind the victor.

G. Hilmer Lundbeck, managing director of the Swedish American Line in the United States and Canada, will sail Wednesday on the French liner Normandie on his way to Trieste, Italy, to attend the launching' of the company's new 28,000 ton motorship Stockholm.

A vacant plot, 105 by 108 feet, at the southwest corner of Starling Avenue and Purdy Street was sold by Matthew F. Walsh to the PurdyStarling Corporation, Simon Kaplan, president. It is assessed at $19,

Barney Ross, working hard for the defense of his welterweight title, was cheered today when Bow-Tie Jimmy Bronson flatly predicted he would knock out Challenger Henry Armstrong in Madison Square Garden Bowl, May 26.
In drum and bugle corps contests at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon and evening, participated in-by 800 men and boys and witnessed by approximately 7,000 spectators, East Orange (N. J.)

A protest against the failure of the United States to lift its arms embargo against Spain was made yesterday by members of the Bronx County Communist party through a resolution adopted by delegates to the party's convention at the Winter Garden, 1,874 Washington Avenue.

Increasing consumption of iron and steel products in Norway in 1937, with active demand for United States products, including stainless and galvanized steel plates, was noted in a report issued today by the metals and minerals division of the Department of Commerce.

Neither the government report indicating a prospective Winter wheat crop of 754,000,00 bushels, the second largest on record, nor an almost unprecedented export demand served to increase speculative interest in the grain markets last week.

The warfare in Anhwei, Shantung and Kiangsu, where the Japanese have almost completed a wide encirclement of Suchow, is likely to develop into isolated engagements without a well-defined front and with the opposing forces attacking each other from all directions.

Even though one peace conference between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization failed to bring about a reunited labor movement that does not mean that conferences are bound to fail, Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, declared today.

The Rebels, who for a fortnight had been trying to hammer through the government lines in the Aliaga sector, northeast of Teruel, found their efforts frustrated and now have turned to seeking their main objective from another direction.
Guy Gayler Clark, executive art director of the National Process Company, has been appointed art director of Cooper Union, it was announced yesterday by the union's director, Dr. Edwin S. Burdell.

The Stadium Concerts this Summer will be broadcast every Sunday from 8:30 to 10 P. M., beginning June 26, over the nation-wide WABC-Columbia networks, according to a statement released yesterday by Stadium Concerts, Inc.

Miss Jeanne, Jackson Kennard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Mortimer Kennard of this place, will be married on June. 18 to A. Gardiner Layng, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Montague Layng of Montclair. The Rev. John Kirkpatrick will perform the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church of Glen Ridge and Bloomfield. A reception will follow at the Kennard home.

Applications are now open for the following positions in the City Service. Details are available at the office of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, Municipal Building, or in the City Record. Positions include pension, fair sick leave. There are physical and residence requirements.

This week dividend announcements were excellent. Westdeutsche Kaufhof resumed payment at the rate of 5 per cent, signalizing the final abandonment of the Nazi party's policy of suppressing department stores.

The Manhattan parks horseshoe pitching championships for doubles teams and singles were decided yesterday afternoon on Circle Lawn Playground, Central Park, at 106th Street, after rain had prolonged the borough play-offs scheduled for Saturday.
Joseph Brasler, curtains, In 455 Broadway; Lionel Shirt Co in 486 Broadway; Arthur Forsberg and Lyman G. Pickrum, repairing of electric motors, in 415 W Broadway; Charles F. Noyes Co, broker.

A Spring festival under the auspieces of the Woman's Board of the Church Charity Foundation of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will be held May 25 at the Home for the Aged, 452 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn. Both luncheon and dinner will be served.

Former Mayor Walter G. C. Otto of this city announced today that he would call upon President Roosevelt in Washington tomorrow to present to him a specially prepared invitation to the celebration next month of the 250th anniversary of the founding of this city.

Inclement weather curtailed the scheduled air show over New York City yesterday, which was to have ushered in the celebration of National Air Mail Week, marking the twentieth anniversary of the first air-mail flight.

France's intention of making the fullest use of her colonial troops in the event of war appeared clearly today in a decree of the Ministry of Colonies that offers special inducements for African enlistments in the French armed forces.

A supremely religious man or woman is one who believes deeply and consistently in the veracity of his highest experiences, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside 'Church, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

Mrs. Charles H. Derr, a missionary of the Presbyterian Church of the United States at Chenchow (Chenhsien), China, died on Thursday at the La Vina (Calif.) Sanatorium, according to an announcement yesterday by the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America. She was 64 years old.

The Economist's index number of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 73.2 on May 11, compared with 73.3 a fortnight, before, 71 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustee, is inviting tenders for the sale to it for retirement of the Third Avenue Railroad Company first-mortgage 5 per cent fifty-year gold bonds dated July 1, 1887, in an amount sufficient to exhaust the sum of $350,000.
The market for equities shows little more life than that for bonds and the drift is downward, thanks to the accumulating evidence of trade recession.

The Monday holiday bill, which would cause every legal holiday to be observed in New Jersey on the nearest Monday, will face strong opposition from war veterans, fraternal orders, patriotic societies and some business interests if it reaches the floor of the State Senate, its opponents declared today.

The cotton market was comparatively dull last week, with traders disposed to hold off until the situation cleared in Washington and something more definite was known concerning the probable size of the new crop.

In an exciting final which was not decided until the nineteenth hole, Jarvis S. Hicks, brother of Miss Helen Hicks, former women's national champion,today defeated Edmund H. Driggs Jr. of Cherry Valley to win the seventeenth annual Morris County Golf Club invitation tournament.

The need for a true aristocracy in our society was emphasized yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, in his morning sermon.

Loans for new homes by building and loan associations in the United States in March amounted to $23,877,109, an increase of 34 per cent over February, E. G. Baltz, president of the United States Building and Loan League, said today.

A proposal to establish a group of cadets to receive military instruction in the Liceum of Costa Rica has aroused much public interest and discussion and has resulted in the announcement that there is no intention to militarize the youth of this country.

The 1937 annual report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries, which is being forwarded to shareholders today, shows a consolidated net income for the year, after all operating expenses and charges, of $9,136,015.

Miss Grace Wallace Means, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Means of this place, will be .married to Walter Arthur Arnold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Arnold of Kew Gardens, L. I, on May 27, in the Glen Ridge Congregational Church by the Rev. Dr. William Weston Patton.
Despite favorable business reports, the financial markets here have been dull this Week. International developments had no visible influence on them.

Dr. John H. Mackay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary, delivered the baccalaureate sermon in Miller Chapel on the seminary campus this afternoon, opening the three-day program of the institution's 126th commencement.
The Rome conversations between leaders of the Rome-Berlin axis elicited little comment in Dutch financial quartets.

Better accustomed than their rivals to the miserable weather and to the uncertain underfooting, Cavan defeated an all-New York selected fifteen, 9 to 4, in the opening match of the round-robin Gaelic football series at the Polo Grounds yesterday before a gathering of A 12.000.

John A. Brown, chairman of the committee of employes of the Greater New York Fund, announced yesterday that contributions were at present being solicited from employes of 1,309 business concerns. George- A. Sloan, chairman of the- committee on firms, also announced that 12,613 corporations had been assigned to fund workers as "prospects" for firm gifts.

Miss Mary Howard Bruce and H. Alexander Smith Jr. will be married here on the afternoon of June 11- in St. Paul's Church. The ceremony will be performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Arthur B. Kinsolving; Mr. Smith's brother-in-law, the Rev.

Miss Peggy K. Minder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Minder of South Orange, will be married to Cadet Paul C. Davis of West Point, son of Mrs. G. C. Davis of Chatham and R. J. Davis of North Arlington, the afternoon of June 18 in the chapel at the United States Military Academy.

The first of a series of strikes that the union says will affect ultimately 9,000 barbers employed in 6,000 shops in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan, will begin tomorrow morning, it was announced yesterday by John Tartamella, general director of the Greater New York Joint Board of the Barbers and Beauty Culturists Union of America, C. I. O. affiliate.

The Women's Auxiliary of the National Maritime Union made public yesterday a letter signed -by its e chairman, Dorothy Gavin, and addressed to Mrs. C. H. Pearsall, president of the Women's Organization for the Merchant Marine, replying to recent proposals by the matter organization for training of unlicensed union -maritime workers and compulsory arbitration of labor disputes.
Lewis B. Traver, president of the American Booksellers Association, attacked yesterday what he termed the "mechanized reading of books," which he said was forced on the public by the book clubs.

Cotton prices stayed within a narrow range last week, but the trend was to slightly higher levels. On the New York Cotton Exchange future contracts showed net gains of 5 to 9 points. Trading was fairly small.

The ability to shoulder responsibilities without breaking under the strain and without becoming conceitedlyy self-important" comes to persons who have genuine faith in God, the Rev. Big Casey Boyle,-his once red hair gone white after forty years of pushing railroad locomotives for the Union Pacific: Railroad out of his home town of Pocatello, Idaho, settled down comfortably and said to the waiter, "I want a Sim Col1ins. "

Herman Schoolmeester, 26-yearold jewelry salesman who left New York in March with his wife and child after, it is charged, he pawned $2,600 worth of jewelry temporarily lent to him on consignment by three Manhattan concerns, was arrested in Los Angeles early yesterday by Acting Lieutenant Grover Brown of the New York Police Department, according to word received here last night.

V. S. McClatchy, a member of the pioneer California newspaper famly, died today at the age of 80. A son of James McClatchy, founder of The Sacramento Bee, Mr. McClatchy became half owner of that newspaper, and The Fresno Bee. He served as publisher of The Sacramento Bee from 1884 until 1923.

Motoring to Gibraltar from Seville by way of Jerez, one passes places conspicuous in naval history, such as Cadiz and Cape Trafalgar, whose name is immortalized on so many British street maps. But the scene has more than merely historical interest.

A registration statement covering 1,000,000 shares of common stock of Chemical Fund, Inc., an investment company of the management type, was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington on Saturday, according to an announcement made here yesterday by the sponsors of the company.

Group and one-man exhibitions continue to give a lively appearance to the art world as the third week of May opens. The Whitney Museum, having closed its Duveneck show, the last of its special exhibitions of the season, will open a brief show tomorrow with paintings and sculpture from the permanent collection.

Dr. Glenn Frank, editor. of Rural Progress, said today that the National Broadcasting Company had given him fifteen minutes over its blue network from Chicago Wednesday to answer a radio speech by Senator Minton, - chairman of the Senate lobby committee.

Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Brush of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Brush, to George David Forney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip W. Forney of Hanover, Pa.

Rayon fabric loom activity during the week ended May 7 showed virtually no change from the subnormal production of the preceding week, according to the report issued for publication today by the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc.
The Red Sox Swept their three-game series with the Senators by taking the finale today, 4 to 3, and rode westward on the crest of an eight-game winning streak.

Mis Jane Luce of Kansas City, Mo., today won the r advanced horsemanship cup at the Skidmore College horse show, final event of the week-end May Day festivities.

Riverside Dr, n cor of 88th St, 103.7x122.11: Vanderbilt Estates, Inc, Louis Schleifer. president, to Stern-Green Realty Co, Inc. 250 W 57th St ($3). Hudson St, a w cor of Horatio St, 76.1x 98.2; U. S. Trust Co to Six Thirty-One Hudson Street Corp. 45 Wall St ($44).
Five home-run balls went sailing through the drizzling rain at Ebbets Field yesterday, but the most devastating blow was a long twobagger by Tony Cuccinello off Max Butcher in the eighth inning.
MotorIsts and other operators of gasolinepropelled vehicles paid State taxes on fuel amounting to $761,998,000 in 1937, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

Discovery and excavation of King Solomon's seaport on the shore of the Red Sea by Nelson Glueck, director of the American School of Oriental Research in Jerusalem, was announced here today by Professor Millar Burrows of Yale University.

Lard futures declined early last week to within a small fraction of a cent of the lowest level of the season and since early in 1934, but short covering and investment buying developed and a strong rally followed..
New stock corporations, formed in this State in the first four months of this year, showed a decrease of 1,448, as compared to a similar period in 1937. There were 6,990 in 1937 and 5,542 this year.

William Livingston, 41, held in the Clare County jail in connection with the barroom shooting last night of Isaiah Leebove, 41, oil promoter and former "mystery man" of Michigan politics, today alleged a "double-cross" by his victim, a one-time associate.

Corn futures held within relatively narrow limits on the Board of Trade last week. While there was an aggressive foreign - demand, the country sold heavily, resulting in an even balance between supply and demand.

The Federal Trade Commission issued a complaint today against Linwood Sales Company, Inc., 101 Prince Street, New York, charging unfair competition through use of a lottery plan in the sale of various articles.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel Lamont, Professor of Apologetics at the University of Edinburgh, arrived here yesterday on the steamship Caledonia of the Anchor Line to represent the Church of Scotland at the: general assembly of the Presbyterian Church of America to be held in Philadelphia May 26.

The Federal Symphony Orchestra, under Fritz Mahler, gave a concert yesterday afternoon with Herta Glatz, mezzo-soprano, as soloist. Irving Kolodin, associate music critic of The New York Sun, who was scheduled as the commentator, was unable to appear, but the script he had prepared was read by Paul Reese, former program director of radio station KFI in Los Angeles.
Konrad Henlein, chief of Czechoslovakia's Sudeten German minority, returned from London today, saying his two-day talks with British leaders had had "very satisfactory results."
George S. Kaufman was saying yesterday that his and Moss Hart's new play will be finished "within a few weeks," that it is due in a Broadway house (not the Music Box) the first week of October.

Mme. Virginie Schildge-Bianchini, French organist, will give her first American recital tonight at 8:30 o'clock in the Church of St. Mary the Virgin. She will offer a program of modern French compositions.

The retiring United States Ambassador, Joseph E. Davies, accompanied by Mrs. Davies, left Moscow tonight for a three-weeks inspection tour of Southern Russia which will supplement the journey that he made in January, 1987.
Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd left a sick bed in Boston to come here today to dedicate the Babylon seaplane base on the bay at the foot of. the midway. Despite stormy weather,

President Roosevelt's $3,154,000,000 Relief-Recovery Bill, which passed the House in a night session on Thursday. will be started on its way through the Senate tomorrow with hearings before a Senate subcommittee on Appropriations.

Miss Margarita Noble, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Noble of Round Hill Road, Greenwich, has completed plans for her marriage to Dr. Howard P. Serrell of Montvale, N. J., on June 2 in the Round Hill Community Church here. The Rev. Harold E. Wilson will officiate.
The city government, which contributed virtually nothing to WPA costs in 1936, has voted contributions of more than $20,000,000 in the first twenty weeks of this year, it was learned yesterday.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition LADIES' EMPIRE, INC., retailers of women's apparel. 56 E. 14th St.-Involuntary proceeding filed by creditors to effect a reorganization under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Law. The petition states the liabilities amount to .$27,356 and assets $41,682.

Purchasing in the wholesale market last week was only fair, although an increase was registered in volume of mail orders over the previous week. Better dress manufacturers concentrated on such successful reorder items as rayon Jerseys, Summer-weight satins, dark chiffons with lingerie trim and black - and - white prints.

Suffering is necessary for salvation, the Rev. Dr. George Drach, general secretary of the Board of Suffering Missions of the United Lutheran Church of America, said ih his sermon yesterday at the Christ Lutheran Church, 406 East Nineteenth Street.

While Washington waited for crystallization of an official United States attitude on the situation created by suspension of diplomatic relations between Great Britain and Mexico, Senator William E. Borah of Idaho, veteran member of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations,

A single question instead of the four originally proposed will be submitted in the plebiscite of the News of America to be held on June 25, 26 and 27 to create a united front against anti-semitism in Eastern and Central Europe, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Stephen S.Wise, president of the American Jewish Congress. A poll tax of 10 cents is planned in connection with the plebiscite.

The Jersey City Low Rent Housing Conference, organized three weeks ago by representatives of union labor, civic groups and fraternal organizations, announced after a meeting this afternoon that it would propose the naming of at least one representative of union labor to the Jersey City Housing Authority.
University Ave (12-3249), s e cor of 197th St, 159x100; 2,800 University, Inc. to Sally B. Titelbaum, 211 Central Park West; extends mtg to Feb. 10, 1941, at 6 per cent; $16,500.
Miss Elizabeth Buckridge, daughter of Lighthouse Captain Thomas A. Buckridge and Mrs. Buckridge, was married in the Montauk Point Lighthouse today to Albert S. Santi, postmaster at Ivoryton,
A daughter was born to Mr. and and Mrs. E. Nobles Lowe of 55 West of Eleventh Street on Friday at the Presbyterian Hospital, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. Mrs.
The Reich's railroads, in their returns for 1937, showed gross receipts of 4,420,000,000 marks, against 3,905,000,000 in 1936. Operating surplus was 295,
There is as yet only a little confidence among Dutch financial circles for an early and permanent recovery in securities in the United States.

By defeating the Irish Americans, 2 to 1, at Scots Field today, the St. Mary's Celtics of Brooklyn swept the home and home series between the teams and qualified to meet the ScotsAmericans in the final series for the championship of the American Soccer League next Saturday and Sunday.

The existence of a contest for the position of Class A director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York was disclosed yesterday when the Reserve Bank sent out to its members the names of three bankers who have been nominated for the post.
Lou Salica, bantamweight from Brooklyn, knocked out Fillo Echeverria:in the ninth round of their tenround bout last night. Salica weighed 117, the Spaniard 119.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's,-Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's,. Macy's, Scribner's and Womrath's:
About 1,500 WPA workers on Camden County projects who went on strike on May 7 held a meeting here tonight and voted unanimously to return to their jobs tomorrow.

Robert F. Black, president of the White Motor Company, has been appointed chairman of the motor truck committee of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, accord- ing to an announcement by Alvin Macauley, president of the association.

Paul Spaak has formed a ministry and done so in record time for Belgium, it was announced today. The threat of a dissolution of Parliament probably had its effect in the emergency, as King Leopold had declared Belgium could not be without a government in this critical moment.

The regular weekly clay target shoot of the North Jersey Gun Club today was held in honor of Andrew Best of Netcong on the occasion of his birthday and his retirement er more than fifty years of railroad service. The club gave him a souvenir commemorating the event.

Miss Mary E. Dohoney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Dohoney of 20 Raymond Terrace, has chosen May 28 as the date of her marriage to William J. Malone, son of Mrs. Mary Malone, also of this city, and the late Michael Malone.

Louis Sobel Park, a small triangular area bounded by Division and Lee Avenues and Roebling Street, Brooklyn, said to be the first park in this State named for a Jewish war veteran, was dedicated yesterday afternoon.

The Rev. Arthur M. Crawford at Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims,. Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, warned against overconfidence in human contributions to recorded writings in the Bible and against ascribing divine sanction to human institutions such as the Federal Constitution or the "gospel of private property."
George W. Harris, president, has announced the dissolution of Harris, Ayers Co., Inc., which was founded in 1919. F. A. Brewer Co., Inc., of Chicago, are voluntarily discontinuing business today.

The Committee for Religious Peace established here a few week ago with the aim of furthering cooperation between the Catholic Church and National Socialists has been collecting signatures of prominent Catholics throughout Austria on a resolution thanking Cardinal Innitzer for his gesture toward the Nazis immediately after Anschluss and expressing their loyalty to him.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt opened National Air Mail Week here today by accepting a sheet of the new sixcent air mail stamps from Vincent Burke, Washington postmaster. The presentation was made at an airliner set up on a plaza across from the Commerce Department Building.

Fred Arrington Wolcott of Rice Institute need bar only ill fortune to assure himself a tourist's view of Japan in 1940 with the United States Olympic team. No other eligible American hurdler can boast the record he owns for 1938.

Miss Helen McKee, Philadelphia Turners' gymnast, shared national A. A. U. championship honors with George Wheeler of the First United Presbyterian Community House, Pittsburgh, and the Hudson County, N. J., Swiss Turn Verein in a title meet which ended today.

Traditional methods of preaching, teaching and relieving the poor, when unworkable, ought to give place to new ways of doing these things, declared Bishop Emmet M. Walsh of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Charleston, 'S. C., in a sermon yesterday morning at the Church of St. John the Baptist, Lewis and Willoughby Avenues, Brooklyn.

Stephen Parrish, father of Max- men field Parrish, internationally-known artist, died today,at the age of 93. A native of Philadelphia, he came to Plainfield in 1895. An etcher, he was associated in his younger years with Joseph Pennell and Charles Platt.

The tragedies of our time, for the most part, are the result of power and influence used selfishly, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

C. Richard Offringa, 31-year-old former school teacher and college graduate, became a member of the Ridgewood police force at midnight tonight. Tomorrow he will patrol his. first "beat," which will be in this village's business district.

The next important piece of legislation which the House still has before it is the Wages and Hours Bill. One principal question which must be asked regarding that measure is: Will it benefit on net balance the particular group that it is intended to benefit?

A schedule of forty feature pictures, sixteen "Westerns," 126 short subjects and four serials will be released by Columbia Pictures during the season of 1938-39, according to an announcement released here yesterday following the first of the company's annual sales conventions held at the Hotel Warwick.

A wire-haired foxterrier, Champion Boarzell Brilliance, owned by Mrs. H. H. Swann of Santa Barbara, Calif., captured best-in-show honors at the fifteenth annual exhibition of the Huntingdon Valley Kennel Club, on the estate of Peter A. B. Widener of Lynnwood Hall, near Elkins Park, today.
The preachings of John Wesley, founder of the Methodist Society, "practicing universal righteousness and placing the spirit of God into everything we do,"

" Making the world safe for democracy" is not a legitimate cause for one nation to join in conflict with another, the Rev. Ignatius W. Cox, Professor. of Ethics at Fordham University, said yesterdayat the annual communion breakfast of the Catholic Club of New York City at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Stagehand, Dauber and Lawrin stand out as the. leaders in the 3year-old division as the result of the Winter racing and such early Spring specials as the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes.

The five-story flats at 46-50 W 111th St, were sold by the Fifty Central Park West Corp, Bernard F. Martin, president, to Jerome Simon at a valuation shown as $7,500 over the lien of a mortgage of $51.500, and Mr. Simon conveyed the premises to Centrapar Holding CorP.

That British trade is declining, despite the offsetting influence of rearmament, admits of no doubt. With a further fall of [Pound]327,000 in railway receipts last week, the whole of the [Pound]1,000,000 increase shown only two months ago has now disappeared.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,242,683,650. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills.

Miss Leonore Kathryn Pell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Pell of Richmond Hill, Queens, has selected June 25 as the date for her marriage to Arthur G. Coyle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert G. Coyle of Brooklyn. The ceremony will take place in the Hanson Place Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, and will be performed by the Rev. J. Lane Miller.

Prospects of a burdensome supply of wheat in the 1938-39 season have affected the world market in recent weeks and developments last week were regarded as substantiating the gneral trade belief that North America at least would harvest a bumper crop.

A Lewiston journalist and a New York sculptor, hoping to thread their way in their 18-foot canoe through inland waterways from New York to Alaska, rested here today after completing 500 miles of the projected trip.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Wednesday at her Winter home in Miami, Fla., of Rose Beaumont Phillips, former partner of her sister, Nellie, in the well-known vaudeville team, the Beaumont Sisters.
The index of French wholesale prices for May 7 was 638 compared with 619 a week before and 620 two weeks before.
Mayor La Guardia, answering critics who have termed him "radical," declared yesterday that he had done no more than guide his actions by the Lord's Prayer.

Charles E. Gill, at 7 Ridgeway, White Plains, from Leonard H. Gaetz; Robert E Farley Organization, broker. Arthur O'Neill, cottage on, Croton River at Ossining, from Margaret Mayo; the Houghton Co. and Paul Moffitt. brokers.
Neither to industry nor finance did last week bring any noticeable change. Rate of production in the principal industries remained where it stood at the month's beginning.

Across Manhattan, from the North River to the East, booms the deep bass of the liner's whistle. Objects on desks vibrate to it. One feels it in one's bones. The old sorrow to be going somewhere comes again. One ought to know better.
A bill to set up an emergency organization to deal with the railroad problem is to be introduced by Representative Drew of Pennsylvania.

Charles Tiberghien, president and founder of the French Worsted Company of Woonsocket, one of the largest spinning plants of French system worsted sales yarns in the country, died today at Tourcoing, France, according to a cablegram received by plant officials here tonight. His age was 79.

Samuel F. Swinburne of 122 Elm Street, who retired from the bench in 1928 after serving as a city court judge here for eighteen years, died today in the New Rochelle Hospital, where he had been a patient for a year. He was 70 years old.

There is now a possibility that George Bernard Shaw's latest play, "Geneva," will be finished in time for production at the Malvern Festival in August. Mr. Shaw's "Saint Joan" also is to be presented, and Elisabeth Bergner is to appear in it.

Lucie Stern, concert pianist, who made her debut here as a child to prodigy at the age of 11, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital of a streptococcus infection. She was 24 years old. Her home was at 46 West Eighty-second Street.

Earthquakes shook Central Turkey today for the third time within a month, sending the populace fleeing into fields in terror. An official government report announced there had been three severe shocks but gave no estimate of casualties.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 32 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the two preceding weeks.
An Extension at 4 per cent of a $25,000 mortgage on 50 East Fiftieth Street has been arranged by the Charles F. Noyes Company for Joseph E. Gilbert.

Norman Taurog, discoverer of Jackie Cooper and director of several outstanding films about children, has been placed under a fiveyear contract by Metro. His first assignment will involve Spencer Tracy and Mickey Rooney in "Boys' Town," and this will be followed by the "Wizard of Oz." "Boys' Town"

Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of the American Social Hygiene Association, announced yesterday that women have contributed $68,939, or nearly 49 per cent of the $141,456 raised to date by national, State and city anti-syphilis committees for the 1938 program to stamp out syphilis.

The Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam will arrive this afternoon on her maiden voyage from Rotterdam via Boulogne and Southampton. Among her 529 passengers are Viscount Almoceden, Sir William and Lady Isherwood, Baroness Cornelia van Ruxleben, Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Towle, Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Wason, William C. Bryant, Guthrie McClintic, A. H. keys, Dr. and Mrs. Johannes E. Feisser.

A ceremony to open the fifteenth annual Cuban Week, so named by the Comite Pro-Cuba, was held yesterday by the society at 1 P. M. in front 'of the Church of Our Lady of Esperanza in 156th Street, west of Broadway.

Performing consistently through a long day of competition, Camp, 4year-old Texas-bred son of Swope and Champion belonging to Mrs. Norman K. Toerge of Locust Valley, won major honors in the hunter classes at the fifth annual Oaks Hunt horse show today.
Shooting in adverse weather coneditions, S. M. (Steve) Crothers of Chestnut Hill, Pa., carried off high amateur gun honors in the Spring shoot of the Atlantic Indians today.

A million-dollar program for Jewish educationn in America was an nounced yesterday by William Weiss, president of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations, at the second day of the organization's annual convention at the Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 West Seventy-third Street.

Thomas H. Powers Farr, founder and president of the First National Bank of West Orange, died this morning at his home on Prospect Avenue after a week's illness following a heart attack. He would have been 77 years old on Thursday.
After holding a commanding seven-run lead in the fourth, the Cardinals had to resort to the pinch hitting of Pepper Martin to beat the Reds, 12 to 11, in the tenth inning for the second straight day.

Senator Norris of Nebraska entered the fight for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination in Oregon today with an endorsement of the candidacy of Henry Hess and an attack on Governor Charles H. Martin, who seeks Re-election.

The Plrates won their second successive extra-inning battle with the Cubs today, 4 to 3, in eleven innings although the Cubs pounded three pitchers for. thirteen hits and received eight bases on balls.

Reception and luncheon, Citizens Housing Council of New York, New York Building Congress and Merchants Association of New York in honor of Sir Harold Bellman, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. Speakers: Commissioner Albert Rheinstein, Louis K., Comstock, Thomas S. Holden, Harold S. Buttenheim.

Many of the colleges and universities in this country have become "hotbeds of paganism, materialism, atheism and immorality," Mgr. Michael A. Reilly, pastor of St. Barnabas Roman Catholic Church, in the Woodlawn section of the Bronx, declared yesterday in a sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Premier Edouard Daladier's courageous action, first in dealing with the strike movement in France and with the labor situation generally, and second, in having devalued the franc with the approval of the United States and Great Britain--that is,

A former member of the board of directors of the Jewish Community Center of Jersey City issued a statement last night defending the ouster from the center of Rabbi Benjamin Plotkin and the Congregation Emanu-El, declaring that the action was the culmination of many years of growing resentment against the rabbi's teachings.

The new Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam is maintaining a speed of- more than twenty-two knots and will dock at Fifth Street, Hoboken, N. J., at 5:30 P. M. today, according to a radio message received yesterday afternoon from Captain Johannes Bijl, the master of the ship .

Individual and doubles competitors in the New York State bowling tournament today staged the final heavy-pin assault of the month-long meet, but failed to produce a single change in the standings. The tournament, which opened last April 12, ends tomorrow night.

The Federal Trade Commission's hearings this week in New York were announced by the commission as follows: E. B. Muller Co., Port Huron, Mich., et al., May 16, 9 A. M., Room 500, 45 Broadway-alleged violation of the Robinson-Patman act in the sale of granulated chicory.

Operators of all American flagships have. been requested by Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission, to make "dress ship" the order of the day on National Maritime Day, Monday, May 23, as part of the national celebration-of this event.

Transit unification negotiations between the spokesmen for the privately operated lines and the group representing the city and the Transit Commission are expected to make speedier progress because of "spade work" started by the commission as long ago as last August, it was indicated yesterday..
The money market here has been dull this week, with day loans quoted today at 2 1/2 and 2 3/4per cent. The Reichsbank's reports continue to indicate rapid expansion.
Haile Selassie, Ethiopia's exiled Emperor, was described as "too sick in mind and body" today to attend a meeting that he was scheduled to address here.

An issue of $2,000,000 of Fall River Electric Light Company firstmortgage bonds, Series A, is to be. offered to the public today by the First Boston Corporation and a group of dealers at a price of 104.
Sam Rabinowitz defeated Abe Grinker, 31 to 13, for the national Y. M. H. A. four-wall handball championship at the Ninety-second Street clubhouse yesterday.

Newell Coleridge Fitzpatrick, baritone, director of the School of Music at Knoxville College, Knoxville, Tenn., gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, under the auspices of the Knoxville College Club, the Virginia Seminary and College Club and the Georgia Club of Williams Institutional Church.

Edward G. Seubert, president of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, has made a special report to employes on the company's 1937 operations in the May issue of The Stanolind Record, company publication, to be issued tomorrow.

The United States basketball team, made up of stars from Eastern colleges and clubs and representing the Amateur Athletic Union, lost its final game in Peru last night to a local combi- t nation, 36 to 29.

Financial circles here realize that the money that has been reintroduced into France as a consequence of the new devaluation of the franc consists chiefly of floating capital. It has almost all been left on deposit in banks, thus giving exceptional ease to the money market.

The question of greatest interest just now to French financiers is whether the redundance of money on the market, resulting from capital repatriation, will be invested for longer term, particularly in the new defense loan to be issued at the beginning of next week.

Three thousand persons heard Jessica Dragonette sing at Georgian Court College this afternoon at the school's fourteenth annual musicale in the Casino auditorium. In keeping with the tradition of honoring a renowned composer each year, the musical was dedicated to the eighty-eighth anniversary of the death of Chopin.

Foreclosures of non-farm real estate in the United States in the first quarter of 1938 were 23 per cent below a year ago, Corwin A. Fergus of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's Division of Research and Statistics reported today.
It is agreed in financial circles that the devaluation of the franc has had a favorable effect on the money and foreign-exchange markets.

It is "inexplicable" why almost none of the many ships that pass through e the Panama Canal replenish their supplies in the ports of Panama, Dr. Don Augusto S. Boyd, Minister of Pana, declared today in a radio speech on "economic cooperation in the Americas."
Rapid progress is being made in the negotiations for a Cuban-Mexican commercial treaty, according to information obtained today.
The Yankees left on their first long tour-of the championship season last night after rain prevented even the opening of the gates in the Stadium for the last game of the series with the Athletics.

The University of Southern California, on the basis of its latest smashing track and field triumph, appeared today to have clinched the role of favorite to win the 1938 National.Collegiate A. A. team title, a feat it has accomplished for the last three years.
Rapid progress is being made in the negotiations for a Cuban-Mexican commercial treaty, according to information obtained today.

Although immunizations of children against diphtheria in this city totaled 2,487 more in the first quarter of this year than in the corresponding period of 1937, the number was less than 40 per cent of what it should be if the disease is to be eradicated, Dr. John L, Rice,

George H. Sutton, billiard and pocket-billiard expert despite a handicap imposed early in life when he lost both hands in a sawmill accident, died of a heart attack here today in 'his camp car. His age was 68. During the last year he toured the country, lecturing and appearing in exhibitions as an employee of a Chicago billiard company.

Charles Gilmore Maphis, Professor of Secondary Education and dean of the Summer quarter, University of Virginia, died suddenly last night at the age of 73. He had been in ill health for the last two years, following a paralytic stroke.
Announcement has been made by Colonel Frederick C. Test, U. S. A., of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Jo Janelene Test, to Howard Earl McCurdy, son of Mrs. A. E. Patrick of Portland.

Mrs. Edith Bishop Taylor, widow of Moses Taylor, New York financier, was married this morning to G. J. Guthrie Nicholson of Jasper, Ala., formerly of New York, in the Independent Presbyterian Church in Birmingham, Ala., according to an announcement made by the bride's secretary here tonight.
British authorities announced today the death of twenty-three Arabs in a sharp engagement with British troops in Northern Palestine.
A sports event so punishing and gruelling to the contestants that they were objects of sympathy, the eleventh annual speed-boat race of outboard marathoners, down the Hudson from Albany,

The Federal Trade Commission charged twenty-four manufacturers today with conspiring to fix prices of hardwood lumber produced in Northern Michigan and Northern Wisconsin. The commission alleged that the producers and their trade association, the Hardwood Institute, fixed and maintained uniform maximum discounts and terms of sale.

Perhaps the most serious defect in the government's recovery program is that it entirely overlooks the crisis conditions that have developed in the railroad industry, Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, says in the current issue of the bank's business bulletin.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 80.8, which compares with 80.5 a week ago, 80.6 two weeks ago, 81 three weeks ago and 81.1 four weeks ago.

Michael Delfino, building and construction contractor, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 62. After acting as a foreman in building the big Cornell Dam in Croton for the New York City waterworks, he entered the contracting business.
The seven small nations linked by The Hague convention today announced they would discontinue their mutual trade agreement July 1 "because of world conditions."
The horrible discovery has been made in London that the famous woolsack, the crimson cushion from which the Lord Chancellor
Herbert Howard, for many years connected with the woolen business in this city, died yesterday at his home, 4 Forest Avenue, Old Greenwhich, Conn. He was 74 years old.

Former Senator Joseph R. Grundy, once the Republican leader of Pennsylvania and now sharing leadership with Joseph N.-Pew Jr., vice president of the Sun Oil Company, may desert Judge Arthur James, the Pew candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor.

In ancient times cities and civilizations could be destroyed by cutting off their water supply. Sometimes human enemies did this, for a limited period. Sometimes Nature did it, as in Arabia and Northern Africa, permanently.

A fashion show including costumes for all occasions will be held Wednesday at the Nearly New Shop, 917 Eighth Avenue. Proceeds will aid the various charitable institutions supported by the shop, one of the oldest enterprises of its kind in the-city.
Leaders of the vast group of women who guide America's children through the-formative years opened here today the annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.
Realty deals in Manhattan announced over the week-end included sales by savings banks of houses in scattered sections.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Asa J. Harris of this M place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Stewart Harris, to Carl M. Pedersen of Cranford, son of Mrs. C. M. Pedersen and the late Captain Pedersen.
Pig iron production in Germany in April amounted to 1,442,400 tons; for the first four months the total was 5,749,800, against 5,093,000 in the corresponding period of 1937.

What stands out most strikingly from the recent session of the League Council is the success of Britain in overcoming the opposition and in gaining majority support for her new role of arbiter in Continental Europe, which her leaders themselves have admitted must be a transition policy.

Assertions in Congress and elsewhere that a return to local administration of work relief funds would result in economy in public expenditures were challenged today by Lester W. Herzog, WPA Administrator, so far as New York State, exclusive of New York City, is concerned.
The police have learned in their investigation of the Integralista uprising on last Wednesday that the
The index of German wholesale prices on May 4 was 105.5, unchanged from a week ago. The cost-of-living index for April was 125.6, against 125.5 in March.

The important military developments on the Suchow front, which Japanese army vanguard columns precipitatedthrough their spectacular advances from nearly all points of the cqmpass, are causing grave concern in Shanghai.

The Firestone Local of the United Rubber Workers of America today voted almost unanimously to accept .a year's contract with the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, which is almost identical with the expiring contract.
United States consuls at Mexican ports will refuse to certify that shipments of Mexican oil come only from non-expropriated properties, Consul General James B. Stewart declared today.

A proposal that judges and justices of the State courts, except justices of the peace, be placed on the bench under a new system of qualified Gubernatorial appointment, instead of by election as at present, is contained in a report prepared for the Constitutional Convention. by a committee of the New York County Lawyers Association, it was announced yesterday.

Governor Hurley assailed the Roosevelt Administration for interfering with business and creating a fear which had stifled private enterprise, when he spoke this morning before 500 members of the Holy Name Society of St. Mary's Church, at a communion breakfast in Knights of Columbus Hall.
The United States speed-skating committee for the 1940 Olympic Games announced today it had adopted a $15,000 budget for financing -its entries in the Winter events at Sapporo, Japan.
A brassie shot by Carl Fricki of AItadena today landed in the pocket of H. P. Eastman of San Gabriel. Eastman said later he felt a slight blow, but had no idea it was caused by a flying golf ball.

With even greater circumspection than he showed himself in his reference to the Franco-Italian negotiations, the French press today commented sparingly on Premier Mussolini's speech. There is one point of fact, however, that has been taken- up and replied -to vigorously.

George W. Burpee, engineering accountant, testified yesterday in Federal court that the Sixth Avenue elevated line, which the city is trying to acquire for about $12,500,000, including about $9,000,000 in back taxes, is worth-$11,346,000.

The principle of the undistributed-profits tax, a keystone of the Administration's tax policy, was sustained today when the Supreme Court by a 5-to-2 vote upheld a deficiency levy of $477,360 upon the 1931 income of the National Grocery Company on the ground that the concern had been used by the late Henry Kohl, sole owner, to prevent payment of surtaxes.
The Sheriff's office reported tonight that a new fourteen-passenger plane, being flown from the factory here to St. Paul, Minn., with nine persons aboard, was missing between here and Las Vegas, Nev.

Miss Faith Fahnestock, daughter of Harris Fahnestock of 15 East Sixty-sixth Street and Lenox, Mass., and of the late Mrs. Mabel Metcalf Fahnestock, was married to John Fiske Paine Jr. of this city yesterday at noon in the. marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.
Discovery of paying quantities of platinum-bearing ores in Southwestern Colorado was reported today by the Geological Survey.
The new Union Bank of Commerce opened today and at the same time the liquidated Union Trust Company, which it superseded, began payment of $38,000,000 to depositors.

Miss Mary Blair McKee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. R. Blair Jr. of Sewickley Heights, Pa., was married to Edward Donnan Wardrop this afternoon in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Sewickley, by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Louis M. Hirshon.

Fourteen youths who described themselves as members of the sophomore class at the College of the City of New York were locked up in the West Forty-seventh Street station on disorderly conduct charges shortly after 2 o'clock this horning, when policemen in radio cars broke up a "snake dance" of

Activity in the wool textile industry, after increasing seasonally in February, decreased at a much greater than seasonal rate in March, according to figures issued yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

Supreme Court Justice Abram Zoller, here from the up-State village of Herkimer for two weeks to preside at the trial of damage suits, et a fashion note for women jurors of the Ninth Judicial District today when he decreed that hats could not be worn in the jury box of his court beginning tomorrow. Ten women are on his first jury.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will open its general subscription sale of seats for next season today at 9 A. M. All places not resubscribed by last year's patrons will be placed at the disposal of the public.

The Century Country Club women's golf team gained a two-point lead over the field in Class A of the Westchester division of the Women's Metropolitan - interclub matches as play was resumed today over the Quaker Ridge course.

The uncertainty hitherto existing regarding the precise status of relations between the Holy See and Nationalist [Insurgent] Spain was removed today when an exchange of duly accredited permanent diplomatic representatives was decided upon.

A suit challenging the validity 6f the Lyons Residence Law, which requires all municipal employes to live within the city and all new appointees to have been city residents for three years, was filed yesterday in Supreme Court.

The Senate, by a voice vote, today passed the McCarran bill to establish a Civil Aeronautics Authority which would combine the jurisdictions over aviation now exercised by the Bureau of Air Commerce, the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Postoffice Department.
With the so-called "third season" definitely taking hold, large-scale advertising of men's Summer wear is scheduled to start this week, several weeks earlier than usual.
Tax rates for twenty-one of twenty-two municipalities in Essex County for 1938 were set here today by the County Tax Board.
Plans for dinghy races on Lake Ontario this Summer between teams representing Canada and England were announced today by officials of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club.

The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill by Representative Barry, Democrat of Brooklyn, providing a two-cent postal rate for all mail originating in Queens County for delivery within the county.

All telephone connections between Rikers Island in the East River and the rest of the city were disconnected suddenly yesterday afternoon. Because the island has 2,000 prisoners in the new city penitentiary, the police hurriedly rigged up a two-way radio for communication with the city in the emergency.

Sholem Asch, Jewish author, who wrote "Three Cities" and other books, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie to confer with fellow members of the Jewish Joint Distribution Committee on plans to find a place where Jews of Central Europe can emigrate.

Marion Etta Turpie, New York State women's golf champion, was married today to Harry McNaughton, the Bottle of the Phil Baker radio program, in Trinity Episcopal Church. The Rev. Randall W. Conklin officiated.

Philip Murray, a leader of the C. I. O., declared tonight that President Roosevelt today "had announced his endorsement of Thomas Kennedy for Governor" of Pennsylvania "through our National Chairman, Jim Farley."

Miss Barbara Hope Smith, daughter of Mrs. Ernest Walker Smith of Mountain Spring Road, has completed arrangements for her marriage to Jarrett H. Folley, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Frederick Folley of Syracuse, which is to take place on June 3, in the First Congregational Church.

The private construction industry, which "remains pretty much in the doldrums," was encouraged yesterday to emulate British home building achievement by putting to work the "idle millions of private capital now available" in a large scale low-cost housing program.

The list of the North German Lloyd liner Europa, arriving today from the Channel ports, includes Robert C. Stanley, president of the International Nickel Company; Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Pearce, Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Reed, Lloyd N. Hamilton, James Bowcock, United States Vice Consul at Munich, and Mrs. Bowcock;

The purpose of fair-trade legislation is to get more merchandise to the public at lower prices and the legislation cannot succeed unless this objective is achieved, Morris L. Ernst, attorney and author, warned 400 booksellers and a large number of publishers at a "Fair-Trade Forum" luncheon at the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday, sponsored by the American Booksellers Association in connection with its annual convention.
The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania yesterday set June 1 as the date on which the State Treasurer, F. Clair Ross, will consider tenders for an issue of $60,000,000 of tax anticipation notes.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Moclair of Jackson Heights, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Marie Moclair, to Henry J. Kennedy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Kennedy of this city.

Senator La Follette led an attack today on the railroads' proposal to reduce wages 15 per cent on July 1. Their difficulties are due to their overloaded debt structure, not to high wages, the Senator told the Senate.
More than 800 high school pupils of the Roslyn and Manhasset schools took part today in a celebration of the seventieth anniversary of the birth of Mme. Marie Curie and the
The board of the Association of Junior Leagues of America completed today the program for the national conference of the association to begin here tomorrow.
European industrialists are predicting an early revival of business in the United States, Max Epstein, chairman of the board of General American Transportation Corporation, said today.

UNITED STATES MEDICAL TECHNICIAN (FIELD ROENTGENOLOGY), $1,800 a year, U. S. Public Health Service, Treasury Department. Applications must be on file not later than June 16 if received from Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming, and not later than June 13 from all other States.

Charting a gain of more than 25 per cent over 1937, Southern California aviation manufacturing companies will produce more than $63,000,000 worth of ships this year, according to a forecast today by the Los Angeles Board of Supervisors and the Chamber of Commerce.

Receipt of the United States note protesting the application to United. States citi-zens of the German decree requiring Jews to declare their property holdings in Germany will be acknowledged to the State Department tomorrow, it was learned today.

The State Department made public today the text of a telegram from President Roosevelt to President Getulio Vargas of Brazil congratulating him upon his escape from death at the hands of revolutionaries, and the Brazilian President's reply.
Marvin Duke, southpaw who pitched twenty-one victories for Montreal in the International League last year, headed. back here today, complaining the Pirates did not give him a "square shake."

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved toddy an application by the Fall River Electric Light Company -for exemption from the provisions of the Holding Company Act regarding the issue and sale of $2,000,000 of first-mortgage I bonds, Series A. dated May 1, 1938, and bearing 3 1/8 per cent interest.

A new mortgage for $16.000 was given by the Hadeli Realty Corp, Eli Haddad, president, to the Mutual Life Insurance Co, and this has been consolidated with four prior mortgages to form one lien for $40,000 on 51-53 Orchard St, 49.9x88, payable according'to the bonds.
Mrs. Zittella Flynn, an old-time circus and vaudeville strong woman, died in the Englewood Hospital today at the age of 87.

Buddy, the original "Seeing Eye" dog, came home yesterday to die after ten years of faithful work. She flew from Chicago to Newark in' a regular United Air Lines passenger plane. Although it was her first airplane trip, she passed most of the four hours sleeping soundly at the feet of her master. Morris S.. Frank, vice president of the "Seeing Eye" training school at Morristown. N. J.
The farm mortgage debt of the United States on Jan. 1, 1937, was $7,254,821,000, a decline of 5.1 per cent from Jan. 1, 1935, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics announced today.

Mrs. Fannie Kochaniewicz, 47 years old, of 1,535 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, returned yesterday to Bronx Magistrate's Court to report to Magistrate Peter A. Abeles that she had been unable to raise $50 to pay a fine imposed on her last Thursday, when she was found guilty of having permitted her German police dog to go unmuzzled and without a leash.

The annual dinner dance and entertainment of the Lenox Hill Hospital Ladies' Auxiliary will take place tonight in the Hotel Astor Roof Garden. It will be a preview opening of the roof garden for the season.

Disregarding party lines, the French have once more hastened to aid their country by oversubscribing a national de fense loan of 5,000,000,000 france ir a few hours after the- list opened this morning.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Color in Painting," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; American Wing (general tour), noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Design in Lace," Grace Cornell. 3 P. M.; "Chinese and European Chinawares," Mabel Harrison Duncan, 4 P. M.
Charles M. Wood Jr., tennis professional, was reported missing last night by the Somerset Hill Country Club of Bernardsville, N. J., where he is an instructor. A police alarm was sent out for him.

The body of Baron Wilhelm von Ketteler, former private secretary to Colonel Franz von Papen, German Ambassador to Austria, was recovered. from the Danube three days ago near Hainburg, about twenty miles from Vienna. Identification was possible only today.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Bloomfield, an employee of the New Rochelle Board of Education since 1899, and principal of the.Washington school for twenty-nine years, died here yesterday at her home after an illness of two weeks.
The annual Spring dance for members of the senior class of the Scud-der School will be held Friday night in the Embassy and Trianon Rooms of the Ambassador.

With the increasing public interest in the surveys made by the American Institute of Public Opinion, many persons have asked for information on the way the institute conducts its surveys, the accuracy of its findings and the social value of its work. I should like to attempt to answer these questions.

Having swept through their respective divisions with five victories in as many starts each, the Harvard and Princeton squads will meet in the thirty-six hole intersectional final of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf League at the Woodway Country Club in Springdale, Conn., on Saturday.

Three coveted fellowships of the American Academy in Rome, each valued at more than $4,000 and enabling the winner to study two years in Rome, were awarded yesterday at the Grand Central Art Galleries after national competitions.

Miss Louise Carnegie Miller, daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. Roswell Miller and granddaughter of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie of this city and the late Mr. Carnegie, steel manufacturer and philanthropist, has chosen July 27 as the date for her marriage to J. F. Gordon Thomson of Edinburgh, Scotland.
Henry Armstrong was the recipient of two trophies presented by Nat fleischer, publisher of the boxing magazine Ring today.

In answer to charges that families on home relief in Orangetown and other townships of Rockland County were being overwhelmed with perishable foodstuffs by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation, County Welfare Commissioner John E. Cook gave out figures today to show that the oversupply was not the fault of the corporation but was the result of improper distribution in two of the townships.
Vernon Kennedy, who came to Detroit in the trade with the White Sox last Winter, registered his fifth straight pitching triumph as the Tigers hammered out a 13-to-7 victory over the Senators today.

Louis Palermo, 30 years old, suspected of having been a killer for the old Dutch Schultz gang in the policy racket of a few years ago, was sentenced to eight and a half to eighteen years in prison yesterday by Judge James Garrett Wallace in General Sessions.
A twenty-five-minute television demonstration including films and live actors will be on view at Radio City today, with several showings scheduled in the afternoon and evening.

Eddie Mayo, former third baseman of the Bees, tonight had the choice of quitting organized baseball or playing with Los Angeles of the Pacific Coast League--the club to which he refused to report after his sale by Bostop Saturday.

British Columbia Power Corporation, Ltd.-Ten months to April 30: Net profit after taxes and charges, $1,822,831, equal to $1.82 a share on the outstanding Class A stock, compared with $1,753,885, or $1.75 a share, in the ten months to April 30, 1937.
ANDREWS--At Norwalk, Conn., May 14, 1938, Pauline J. Andrews. Services at her late home, 9 Bettswood Road, Norwalk, Tuesday afternoon, May 17, at 3:30 o'clock, daylight-saving time.

Six hits were all that the Dodgers collected off Deacon Danny MacFayden yesterday at Ebbets Field, yet they finished a surprisingly close second to the Bees, dropping a 5-4 game in which they were indeed lucky to score at all. The bespectacled veteran should have won by a shutout.

Mrs. David Hunter McAlpin 2d of 69 Madison Avenue, Morristown, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Madeleine Evans McAlpin, to Wynant Davis Vanderpool Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wynant Davis Vanderpool, also of Morristown.
A sitdown demonstration, which leaders said would continue until "drastic action is taken by the State Legislature in the Cleveland relief situation," was organized in City Council chambers tonight.

The 27-foot cruiser Spray, with five persons aboard, which had not been heard from for twenty-four hours after leaving on a fishing trip early Sunday, was found aground on a mud flat in Reynolds Channel, near here, by a Coast Guard picket boat this morning.
John Padden, 33 years, a longshoreman of 507 West Forty-ninth Street, was killed in. pre-repeal gangster fashion on Columbus Avenue near Eighty-sedond Street at 11:20 o'clock last night.

Supporters of Pennsylvania's war-torn Democratic factions will go to the polls tomorrow, startled by an eleventh-hour admonition from James A. Farley, national chairman, to split their primary election tickets and nominate a leader of each slate as the only way of assuring a Democratic victory in November.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 13: CAPTAINS Allen, E. G., to duty as budget officer, Navy Department, Washington, D. C., instead of Naval Operations. Mecleary, H. B., to duty as chief of staff and aide to the commandant of the 14th. Naval Dist., Pearl Harbor, T. H.; orders of Jan. 21 revoked.

By transforming their diminutive theatre into the cocktail lounge of a New York hotel the gamekeepers of the Play Room Club in Twentieth Street have given "No Laughter in Heaven" an inviting appearance. Seated within hailing and sniffing distance of the bar, the audience is virtually part of the stage setting.
Field Marshal Hermann Goering presided today at the start of work for Germany's greatest electric power works at Kaprun in the Tauern range.
William Lyon Phelps last week delivered to the Oxford University Press the manuscript of his autobiography. It is scheduled for publication in October.

Mexico City police, led by Chief Federico Montes, succeeded today in ousting a group of Socialist youths who between 2 and 3 o'clock this morining had seized control of the Commerce and Law Schools of the National University and the National Pre paratory School.

Harry Schenker, president of Lenart Import, Ltd., has just returned from abroad, where he negotiated agreements to act as American representative for the glassware of Luigi Fontana Co., Milan, Italy, and of James Powell Sons, Ltd., London.

Conflicting price movements characterized quiet trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. While local traction securities featured the day's trading with another spirited upswing to new high levels of the year, other groups of domestic corporation bonds drifted to moderately lower levels.

The Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam, the largest ship ever built in Holland and by far the fastest liner in the Netherlands-New York service, arrived yesterday on her maiden transatlantic voyage.

Mrs. Jessie Wallace Joraan, grayhaired member of a German spy ring declared to have been operated simultaneously in Great Britain and the United 'States, was sentenced today to four years at hard labor for having violated the British Official Secrets Act.
The will of Dan Fellows Platt, former Mayor of Englewood, who died on May 5, was filed today for probate by his wife, Mrs. Ethel Bliss Platt, who is chief beneficiary and executrix.

Julius Lynch Piland, a graduate of the United States Military Academy and of the Massachusetts In-. stitute of Technology, was installed yesterday as a deputy commissioner of hospitals in charge of construction, engineering and architecture.

Professor Jacob S. Worm-Muller, who holds the Chair of Modern History at the University of Oslo, Norway, arrived yesterday on the Canadian Pacific liner, Empress of Britain from a four months' world cruise.
Congressional leaders tried today to dissuade President Roosevelt from pressing for further action -on his executive reorganization legislation at this session of Congress.

Archaeological records that 'our expedition has discovered in Burma and others that we have just finished studying in Java all point to Southeastern Asia as the probable center of dispersal for the most ancient tool-making races of the Stone Age man in Asia.

Delegates to the convention of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America today unanimously approved the efforts of their Officers "to bring about unity between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization" and directed them to continue their efforts "to the end that unity may be brought about when a satisfactory basis can be found."

Supreme Court Justice Edward R. Koch sustained yesterday a $116,000 verdict against Irving T. Bush, chairman of the board and president of the Bush Terminal Company, in a libel suit by James C. Van Siclen and C. Walter Randall, former reorganization trustees for the company.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended on May 11:

A group of seventy-seven onefamily houses are planned for Laurelton, Queens, according to the plans submitted to the Department of Housing and Buildings there yesterday. This project is estimated to cost about $231,000.
The St. Peter's High nine continued its unbeaten stride in the Manhattan-Richmond C. H. S. A. A. by conquering St. Ann's Academy. 7-5, yesterday at Central Park.

A renewed drive throughout the nation to raise $1,000,000 for the aid of Chinese civilians was pledged here yesterday by Norman H. Davis, newly chosen national chairman of the American Red Cross, on his first official visit to the New York Chapter of the Red Cross at 315 Lexington Avenue.

The War Department recommended to Congress today adoption of the report of the army engineers proposing modification of the project for improvement of Huntington Harbor, New York, a shallow tidal inlet on the north side of Long Island, forty miles northeast of the Battery.

LAPLAND JOURNEY, by Halliday Sutherland. (Dodd, Mead, $3.) An account of a journey through Finland to Norway and Sweden. MINGLED YARN, by Willie Snow Ethridge. (Macmillan, $2.50.) A novel about a girl brought up in a Georgia textile city.

Abraham Straus, Brooklyn department store, opened a new branch at 168-04 Jamaica Avenue, in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday with ceremonies that began at noon when Ralph Halpern, executive examiner for Borough President Harvey of Queens, cut a ribbon that extended across the front door.

Lieutenant Joseph P. Murray, assigned to the Yankee Stadium for many years and reputed to know more big-league baseball players than any other member of the police force, has filed an application for retirement, to become effective this midnight, according to an announcement at police headquarters yesterday.

The Spring Bridge Festival for the benefit of the West Side Hospital and Dispensary will take place Thursday afternoon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Varied divertissements, including a group of dances by professionals, will be presented.
No American quarrels with a Good Neighbor policy that produces confidence and cooperation among the nations of this hemisphere.
