Domestic retail deliveries of Buick motor cars during April totaled 18,150 units, compared with 15,435 in the previous month, a gain of 17.6 per cent, according to figures made public yesterday by W. F. Hufstader, general sales manager. Dealers reported 4,464 sales in the first ten days of the month 5,962 during the second period and 7,724, during the last ten days.
The President's Advisory Committee on Political Refugees held an organization meeting today at the State Department and elected as chairman James G. McDonald. .

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Coast Artillery Corps Reserve officers, assigned or attached to the 607th Coast Artillery, is ordered to active /duty, effective June 12, at Fort Hancock, N. J.: Lt. Col. Allan B. Campfield, 119-17 114th St., South Ozone Park, N. Y. Major George L. Clarke, 214 Kneeland Ave., Yonkers, N. Y. Capt. Stanley E. Karp. 56 Fort Washington Ave., New York City.

Dollar volume of retail grocery sales was off an average of 10 per cent last week compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the weekly survey of conditions in the grocery industry by the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.
Lord Leigh, Lord Lieutenant of Warwickshire and major landowner, died at his home in London today at the age of 82.
In a Saragossa hotel one night a Spanish officer announced the capture of the town of Caspe. A German, evincing little interest, remarked: "Ah! But we have just taken Vienna."

The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, Los Angeles, and the National City Bank of New York commenced delivery on May 9 in permanent form of Department of Water and Power of Los Angeles electric plant revenue bonds, 2 and 3 per cent, in exchange for interim receipts.
America's Walker Cup team arrived today and joked with British golf writers who told them "You're going to leave that cup here this time."

After an inspection tour yesterday afternoon to four of the several hundred agencies to be aided through the Greater New York Fund's campaign for $10,000,000, Paul Felix Warburg, Winthrop Rockefeller and Byrnes MacDonald, campaign leaders, pronounced the visits "a grand education."
A home on Archer Drive, Bronxville, has been purchased by Oliver A. Westfall Jr. through August M. Blomberg, broker, who also sold a six-room house on Lockwood Avenue to Arthur J. Maus.

A constitutional amendment .to give the Legislature power to declare the State's $2,000,000,000 milk industry a public utility, subject to regulation and control by the State, was offered to the Constitutional Convention tonight by Charles Poletti, Supreme Court justice.

A comprehensive scheme to re-plan London on a scale far more elaborate than ever dreamed of by Sir Christopher Wren when he sought to rebuild the city following the great fire in 1666 is described in a report of the Ministry of Transport which was made public today.

William Henry Hastie, the first Negro judge of the District Court here, has protested the admission of German naval officers and cadets of the training ship Horst Wessel, which included the Virgin Islands in its itinerary, to a benefit party at the Grand Hotel sponsored by colored residents.

Investments in companies owned 90 per cent or more by the Missouri Pacific Railroad and carried at $46,902,376, included $32,231,606 covering concerns in bankruptcy, the road's report for 1937, issued yesterday, disclosed.
Sir Evan Gwynne Gwynne-Evans, Bart., and Lady Gwynne-Evans of Oaklands Park, Gloucestershire, England, are at the Gladstone.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates May 15, unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Chaumont, May 16; Antares. Sourabaya to Batavia: Canopus, Pigeon, S-36, 37, 38, 39, 41. At Norfolk: Herbert, J. F. Talbott, Texas. Bagley, at Guantanamo. California, San Pedro to San Diego, May 16. Clark, at Navy Yard, Mare Island.
Visitors to the spacious exhibition gallery on the tenth floor of The Times Annex, dedicated to the History of the Recorded Word,

President Roosevelt presented the $500 first prize in the annual Gorgas essay competition to Frances Babin of South Side High School, Memphis, Tenn., today for the best composition on "The Achievements of William Crawford Gorgas and Their Relation to Our Health."

Authorization by the Legislature of a Board of Tax Review, which would take over from the State Supreme Court appeals by property-owners allegingexcessive real estate assessments, was asked tonight in a proposal sent to the Constitutional Convention by the Real Estate Board of New York.

Colonel Edward E. McCammon, chief of staff of the Ninety-eighth Division, Organized Reserves, who rose from the ranks in the army, died at his home here today of a coronary thrombosis. His age was 59.
Charges were made yesterday of vandalism on advertising signs in subway cars and subway stations following a strike of more than 100 billboard workers called last Friday.

Freeman St, 903 to 913 (11-2976); Reo Holding Co, Inc, to I. H. L. Realty Corp, 2,040 Bronxdale Ave. Harvard Ave (14-3778), w s, 275 ft s of 172d St. 50x100; Constance Marinelli to Frank Scattareggia, 437 4th Ave, North Pelham. N. Y.

The colors of J. D. Norris, Chicago sportsman, are becoming prominent at Belmont Park. Following on the heels of the victory of his Danger Point in the Metropolitan Saturday he sent out another winner yesterday in Camisado, who captured the Shoreham Handicap at six furlongs in a field of six good sprinters.

Two Negroes, who pleaded guilty recently in General Sessions in the hold-up killing of Patrolman Isadore Astel, were sentenced yesterday to terms in State prison by Judge James Garrett Wallace. Joseph Nelson, 22 years old, an exconvict,

Stockholders of the Gruen Watch Company will vote on May 27 on a proposal to authorize the directors to sell 165,000 shares of common stock to retire the Class A preferred stock and to increase the working capital. Such authorization would be effective until May 1, 1939.
Stocks eased in final hour and closed lower in second slowest trading of the month; turnover, 395,920 shares. Traction bonds strong, other groups lower; transactions, $4,423,325.

Mexico's ability to find a ready market for her silver and for expropriated oil within the coming ninety days will decide the future of that country and its government, in the opinion of export executives of proprietary companies who met yesterday at the first day's session of the fifty-sixth annual convention of the Proprietary Association in the Hotel Biltmore.

Trading was good to fair. The markets were strong to higher with steer beef showing largest advance. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb to be steady with recent advance and other classes strong to higher. Condition, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follows:

Dr. Charles Wortsman, a member of the editorial staff of The Jewish Morning Journal for the last five years and well known in Zionist circles, died yesterday morning at Bellevue Hospital at the age of 60.

A charge by Dean George C. Sellery of the University of Wisconsin College of Letters and Science that the removal of Richard J. Davis of New York City as executive editor of The Daily Cardinal, student newspaper, was motivated by antiSemitism as denied tonight by Clarence A. Dykstra, president of the university.

More than seventy-five alumni of New York University who hold Alumni Meritorious Service Awards for "distinguished service to the university" will pay tribute tonight at a dinner at the Hotel Lafayette to seven alumni who are to receive the awards at the university's 160th commencement June 8.
The Right Rev. Alfred Berkeley, retired Bishop of the Windward Islands, died today at the age of 76. He had lived in London since 1930.
James Leland Thompson, one of this city's leading citizens and a founder of the Troy Cohoes Shirt Company, died yesterday at his home at the age of 90.

Michigan State College of East Lansing will be represented by a formidable team of twenty men in the sixty-second -annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field games scheduled for Randalls Island Stadium on June 3-4, it was announced yesterday.
Claude S. Reeder, automobile dealer, disclosed today that he and Guy C. Myers, New York broker, were negotiating for the purchase of the Knoxville, Nashville and Chattanooga Street Railway systems.

An indictment accusing a Queens County contracting concern and ten individuals with defrauding and conspiring to defraud the government of about $25,000 in the delivery of materials used in the WPA road projects, in Queens between May, 1936, and August, 1937, was handed up yesterday to Judge Marcus B. Campbell in Brooklyn Federal Court.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the issuance of an analysis of the deficiencies commonly cited by the commission in connection with financial statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

Jimmy Hines, who won the metropolitan open golf championship on Saturday for the second successive year, proved today he also could be a champion on his home course. With capable partners, he accounted for the principal honors in the Long Island P. G. A. one-day tournament at Lakeville.

The United States is fast becoming one of the greatest champagne markets in the world, the Marquis de Saures d'Aulan, vice president of the Association f Champagne Makers in France, declared yesterday, after completing an extensive tour of the country.

After years of litigation in lower courts, the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority program will be reviewed at the next term of the Supreme Court, according to an order issued by the highest tribunal today.
Victoria Gray, in 51 E 97th St; Mrs. B. Chesner, in 25 E 99th St; Walter Samuels, Inc, broker. Paul and Grace Hartman, in Hotel Plaza, Fifth Ave and 59th St.
Driving Nick Strincevich to cover with a four-run assault in theseventh inning, the Red Wings defeated the Bears in the opening game of the series today, 7 to 5.

Sales in the city reported yesterday principally involved multiple dwellings in various sections. The five-story house at 122 East Sixty-first Street was sold by the Frances Canfield estate to Raoul Fernandez, prominent Cuban athlete, through Louis F. Hines, broker.
As it had been hinted he would; George Abbott is now doctoring the musical "You Never Know." He went to Chicago last Saturday to go to work on it, both book and staging. Back late this week.
The undefeated Fordham golf team gained its seventh victory of the season by downing St. John's University, 5 to 4, at the Hillcrest G. C. in Jamaica yesterday.
Owners of the missing British freighter Anglo Australian informed Lloyds today that the ship's hatch covers had been sighted off Panama by the steamer Dalhanna, which arrived at Cristobal yesterday.

The Supreme Court upheld the National Labor Relations Board in its order growing out of the Mackay Radio strike. It ordered the Circuit Court judges of Philadelphia to show cause why the board should not be allowed to withdraw its order against the Republic Steel Corporation.

Wheat futures declined 1 3/8 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade here today. The decline was based on continued favorable reports on the outlook for the Winter wheat crop, good rains over the week-end in the dry areas in the' Texas Panhandle and parts of western Oklahoma, easiness in securities and absence of foreign demand.

The number of industrial and commercial failures in the United States for the week ended May 12 was 231, the same as in the preceding week, but an increase over the corresponding week last year, when there were 190, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

We confess to a little disappointment in the Queen of Sheba. Professor Burrows of Yale thinks it probable that she made her celebrated visit to Solomon after he had built his fleet because she was afraid that his new merchant marine would lower the receipts of her caravan trade.

Dr. William F. Dunlop, a dentist died yesterday at his home, 201 East Seventy-first Street, after a long illness. He was 71 years old. Dr. Dunlop, who maintained offices at 424 Madison Avenue, was the originator of the Dunlop oxygen treatment for pyorrhea.

The Appellate Division, First. Department, appointed yesterday Theodore Kiendl, law partner of John W. Davis, as referee to investigate the circumstances surrounding the change of the name of Simon W. Gerson, Communist aide to Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs, to Samuel W. Gilson, in the records of a $150 back rent suit in M??nicipal Court.

Six hundred members of the Actors Equity Association now employed on the WPA Federal Theatre Project have been. suspended from Equity for failure to restore themselves to good standing by May 1, according to an editorial in the current issue of the Equity magazine.
Two more of Richard Whitney's five partners in the bankrupt firm of Richard Whitney Co. were questioned yesterday in the Federal search for assets to repay the $2,655,000 deficit of the firm.

Lawrence Hunt, an attorney for the National Labor Relations Board, arguing today in the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals on the appeal of the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation of North Chicago from a board ruling ordering the company to reinstate ninety-three employes, declared that the sit-down strike is "foolish and illegal."

After advancing sharply last week, fat cattle prices continued active at the advance, showing further upturn on light heifer and mixed yearlings. Both hogs and lambs also reflected strength, livestock markets in general suggesting temporary activity in the dressed markets.

Allan Hatch held Harvard So seven hits today as the Tufts College Jumbos beat the Crimson, 13 to 4. Harvard scored three times in the first inning on four passes, two hits and an error, but Hatch settled down after that.

The Chinese have begun a general retreat, according to the Tokyo Asahi's correspondent with frontline Japanese troops in the Lung-Hai Railway region. Heretofore no large Chinese troop movements had been observed during daylight, he reports, but since yesterday morning "the enemy has been fleeing westward like an avalanche."

With more than 1,000. officials and employes of the United States customs service attending, funeral services were held yesterday afternoon at St.. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street, for Henry, C. Stuart, former assistant collector of the port of New York, who died on Friday at the age of 73 years in his home at 450 Riverside Drive.
Athletic Director W. J. Bingham of Harvard announced today that the athletic committee would allow its varsity baseball men to play outside ball this Summer, although not in professional leagues.

The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today a motion f6r dismissal of a proceeding against Gerald M. Loeb and Gordon B. Crary, individually and as partners of E. F. Hutton Co., and H. Terry Morrison, individually.

Delegates were arriving here tonight for the opening tomorrow of the 172d annual meeting of the Medical Society of New Jersey. Dr. Chevalier L. Jackson of Philadelphia heads the list of scheduled speakers.

Miss Elizabeth Dickert, daughter, of Mrs. John Dickert of Overbrook, has chosen June 25 for her marriage to G. Maitland Chambers, son of Mrs. G. Maitland Chambers of South Orange, N. J. The ceremony will be performed in the Chapel of the Mediators, Philadelphia.

The Peddle School baseball team defeated Rutgers Prep by a score of 9 to 3 today in a five-inning game. Peddle scored six runs in the first inning, while Rutgers tallied in the second, fourth and fifth frames. Rutgers made more hits than Peddle.

The amended plan of reorganization for the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, which. was made public last week, was submitted yesterday by Hamilton C. Rickaby, attorney for the Atlas Corporation, proponent of the plan, to Federal Judge William Bondy, who indicated that he would refer it to George W. Alger Jr., special master, for hearings.

The Public Works Administration has on file 2,700 approved projects, 80 per cent still classified as "alive," Secretary Ickes told a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today at a hearing on President Roosevelt's recovery-relief bill.

Kenesaw Mountain Landis, Commissioner of Baseball, today questioned Frankie Frisch, manager of the Cardinals, about the release of Pitchers Roy Henshaw and Si Johnson to Rochester of the International League. Both Henshaw and Johnson appealed to Landis to prevent St. Louis from returning them to the minors.

Although rain fell over parts of Texas where it was not especially needed, beneficial moisture in the Mississippi Valley and the Eastern States served to increase pressure on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.

The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company reported yesterday for the March quarter a net profit of $1,403,649 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes, excess profits taxes and other charges, but before any provision for surtax on undistributed earnings.

Business was brisk yesterday In Paddy's Market, along Ninth Avenue between Forty-second and Thirty-seventh Streets. Hundreds of peddlers stood beside their pushcarts hawking their wares and ignoring the Police and Market Department signs which prohibited pushcarts "after March 19, 1938."

What is belived to be the first move in a Japanese plan to assume control of the International Settlement's Chinese court estabiished in 1928 by the foreign consular body under the Mixed Court Rendition Agreement, was seen late this morning when three Japanese officials visited the court compound and all nine court-rooms where cases involving Chinese are simultaneously heard.
There has been much wind on the mountain. On its arrival at Rongbuk the expedition made its base at Camp No. 1 at an altitude of 18,000 feet, near the snout of the East Rongbuk Glacier.

Henry Holden Huss, pianist-composer, and some of his pupils will present a program of his own compositions in the new Music Chamber Hall in the Academic Building of Brooklyn College today at 2 P. M., under the auspices of the students' music group of the school.

Suggestions of changes in the Constitution reported by a committee of the New York County Lawyers Association are worth study. They embody the conclusions arrived at after long pondering by able lawyers. The everrecurrent question of appointive or elective judges is resumed.

The nominations for the Supreme Soviets of the constituent republics of the Soviet Union-the elections for which will be held this Summerare faithfully following the pattern used in the nominations and elections of members of the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union, held last December, when Joseph Stalin was unanimously nominated in every electoral district of the Soviet Union.
Soviet Russian authorities . today announced the rejection of a Japanese. protest against a May Day speech by Navy Commissar Peter Alexandrovich Smirnoff.
Mrs. F. Vance Pawson de Revere, writer and character analyst, died 'here yesterday in St. John's Hospital after a long illness. Her age was 52 years.

A committee of the younger members of the bar in the nine judicial districts of the State to study various phases of administrative law was announced today by Judge Joseph Roach, president of the New York State Bar Association, following a conference with the executive committee.
Bill Cummings of Indianapolis and Rex Mays of Glendale, Calif., will settle their match race in the qualification trials Saturday for the Memorial Day 500-mile speedway race.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 14: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Matthews, A. P., Dental Corps, promoted to colonel. Bayley, A. J., Med. Corps, Presidio of San Francisco. to University of California, San Francisco about Aug. 1. Weir, B. G., ordered to office of Chief of Air Corps, Washington, D, C., Instead March Field, Calif.
There is a notion in some quarters abroad that National Socialism and fascism are really capitalist conspiracies to control the masses and smash the labor unions.

Alexander Lax, 27 years old, of 389 Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn, a home relief recipient, was. sentenced to ten days in jail yesterday by Magistrate Folwell in the Pennsylvania Avenue court, Brooklyn, for creating a disturbance in the home relief bureau at 269 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn.
Rear Admiral Richard Morgan Watt, who retired from the navy in 1936 after forty-nine years of service, died yesterday of pneumonnia at the age of 65.

A trial by court-martial of Captain Herbert L. Berry, Quartermaster Corps, United States Army, on charges involving embezzlement began yesterday at Governors Island. The court met in the Sixteenth Infantry area. Colonel Arthur S. Cowan of the Signal Corps is President of the court.

Inability to read English prevented 8,664 persons from obtaining drivers' licenses in this State in the first quarter of this year, according to Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles. The number of English failures has risen steadily since the test was inaugurated two yearn ago.
Automobile output declined more than. seasonally last week and the adjusted index receded to 44.5 from 50.1. The-figure was 131.8 for the week ended May 15, 1937.
Allie Stolz, 128, Newark, stopped Chang Collura, 124, also of Newark, in the fourth round of a scheduled eight-round boxing bout tonight. Both are former New-Jersey amateur champions.

Some excitement has been caused in New Jersey by what is described as a "vicious, uncalled-for invasion of patriotic principles." So far as can be learned, this situation is in no way connected with Mayor Hague or Jersey City.

A group of Conservatives killed four Liberals, tried to set fire to two houses and then fled in the town of Villacaro in the State of North Santander last Friday night. The Espectador reports the occurrence as word of it was received from a report of the Circuit Judge of Villacaro to the Minister of Government.

There was no school yesterday for more than 1,100 Brooklyn high school freshmen who left South Ferry on the municipal ferryboat Queens for morning and afternoon trips that started, for 1938, the warm-weather civics cruises begun last Fall by the Department of Education.

Miles Mander, English director and writer, today was assigned to the role of Disraeli in. Twentieth Century-Fox's "Suez"; George Arliss was sought for the part but he declined to play a supporting role. Three additions were made to the cast of "Ellis Island" with Marjory Gateson, Gilbert Roland and Marta Bamattre assigned; shooting started today.

The principal European exchanges continued yesterday to decline in terms of the dollar in the foreign exchange market. In spite of general approval of the new Belgian Cabinet, the belga sold off 3 points to 16.82 1/2 cents.

BYCK. AUGUSTA (May 3). Estate, less than $10,000. To Rita Benjamin, daughter, Bluefield, Va., and Amie Byck, daughter, executrix, 820 West End Ave., onehalf residue each. HESS, STEPHEN G. (May 12). Estate, more than $10,000. To Marcel H. Stiegliz, nephew, 1,125 Park Ave., and Arthur M. Hess, brother, executor, 45 E. 80th St., one-half residue each.

Authors, publishers, booksellers and educators agree that Americans ought to buy and read more books. Whenever the American Booksellers Association convenes, as it has been doing in this city this week, the subject naturally comes up and every one has ideas about

The prospects for a "friendly" settlement between the Czechoslovak Government and the Sudeten Germans are "far better than I had expected," Winston Churchill, who had a long talk with Konrad Henlein, Sudeten Nazi leader, said in the second speech in his campaign for "peace and freedom" at Bristol tonight.

Ginger Foran, British Empire featherweight champion, will tackle Johnny-Cabello of Harlem in the star bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, tonight. Murray Brandt of Long Island City and Joe Pennino, South Brooklyn welterweight, will clash in the semi-final, also slated for eight rounds.

Charging that assets of the investment trust had been diverted and wasted, Arthur A. Ballantine, trustee for the Continental Securities Corporation, entered suit yesterday in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York to recover more than $3,300,000 from ninety-one defendants.

Edward T. Stotesbury, one of the nation's outstanding financiers, who headed the Philadelphia banking firm of Drexel Co. and was a partner of J. H. Morgan Co. of New York, died at 9:20 o'clock tonight at his Chestnut Hill home, Whitemarsh Hall. He was 89 years old on Feb. 26.

In the Supreme Court of the United States today Samuel K. Beier, Aaron Frank, James Abell Mills and John B. Sheerin of New York City were admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had: 453--General Electric Company, petr., V. Wabash Appliance Corporation, Abe Adler and Abe M. Parker.

The stock markets here were quiet and generally weaker today. Gilt-edge issues showed small declines, while among the foreign bonds German and Czechoslovak loans were weak. Transatlantic shares generally were firm and United States Steel advanced.

While commemorative and special flights were being made yesterday in various parts of the country in celebration of National Air Mail Week, which opened on Sunday, essay and contest winners of New York State and the New York City postal district received awards from Postmaster Albert Goldman.

Epsom Derby odds against H. E. Morriss's colt Pasch shortened to 15 to 8 in today's Victoria Club call-over. The Two Thousand Guineas winner previously had been quoted at 2 to 1 for the classic June 1.
The international stock market indices for May 14, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:
Proponents of a State system of mortgage indemnity and debenture corporations are preparing to revive their program at the next session of the New York Legislature.

Through the cooperation of leading European museums as well as outstanding private collectors here and abroad, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has arranged what is believed to be the most important exhibition of rare antique French silver ever brought together in this country and rarely surpassed in France.
The American Viscountess Charles Benoist d'Any was disclosed today to have risked her life to save her dog,-Ramby, who was thrown into a lake in the Bois de Bouloine by a group of hoodlums.

Five members of the crew of the American steamer City of.Norfolk of. the Baltimore Mail Steamship Company died at dusk Saturday as the result of a stabbing in the cook's galley, it. was disclosed when the vessel docked here today.

The Westinghouse and. Electric Manufacturing Company, which operated an old-age pension system between 1929 and 1935, plans to reestablish a new system to supplement present Federal security plans, it was reported yesterday by W. G. Marshall, vice president.
Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General in New York, has been appointed to the position of High Commissioner in Canada for .the United Kingdom, according to an official announcement.

Gross assets, $1,275; net, $503. To Lillian McClintic, Dorothy McClintic, Eleanore Cross and Lillian M. Call, specific bequests and one-seventh residue each; Cecil C. Baldwin, Beryl C. Gale and Lucie C. Nixon, one-seventh residue each. Chief assets, miscellaneous property, $735. William DeForest Manice, attorney, 20 Exchange Pl.
Revenue Minister J. L. Ilsley announced today that eleven magazines had been banned from in Canada. Importation into Canada of the following magazines will be prohibited:
Joseph Baermann Strauss, the engineer whose genius brought into reality the world's longest suspension structure, San Francisco's famed Golden Gate Bridge, died here today at the age of 68.

A home-run barrage by Jersey City defeated the Bisons, 10 to 3, today in an International League game. Circuit clouts by Hal Lee, Tom Winsett and Joiner accounted for six of the Little Giants' markers.
Ninety-five students will receive degrees this evening at the Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street. The class is the largest in the seminary's history.

Although the deadline is still a week off, the Dodgers yesterday went one below the twenty-threeplayer limit as Larry MacPhail announced the severance from the Brooklyn payroll of Waite Hoyt, Heinie Manush, Roy Spencer and George Jeffcoat.

An investing client of Friedman, Marx Handler, attorneys, purchased from the Hudson City Savings Bank two apartment houses in Jersey City. One is at 114-16 Virginia Avenue and the other at 158-60 Bergen Avehue. Fred W.

George Browne Post, banker and broker and a founder of the brokerage firm of Post Flagg, left a net restate of $1,549,590 when he died last May 25, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.
Operations in the steel industry. for this week beginning yesterday are scheduled at 30.7 per cent of capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Miss Edith Emily Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Wilson of this place, has chosen June 25 as the date for her marriage to Robert L. Andrus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred L.' Andrus of Bloomfield.

The securities business and investment supervisory service of Lawrence Stern Co., Inc., Chicago, will be conducted, after May 31, by a new firm of Stern, Wampler Co., Inc., it was announced yesterday by Lawrence Stern, president of Lawrence Stern Co., Inc.
The week-end saw a lot of fishing, but not many fish, salt and fresh water alike, according to the reports we received from Long Island, New York and New Jersey.

The Indians tied the Athletics, 3-3, in the seventh today and then won, 4-3, in the tenth on successive doubles by Odell Hale and Jeff Heath. With the Yankees idle, the victory sent Cleveland into undisputed possession of second place.
Norfolk St, 145, 5-story tenement, 25x100; Fifth Avenue Bank of New York, trustee, against Kelln Realty Co; due, $20,253; taxes, etc, $976; to plaintiff for S12.000.

A nation-wide..campaign against venereal disease was outlined by Public Health- Service officials - today after the House passed a Senate bill calling for the expenditure of from $3,000,000 to $7,000,000 a year for the activity.

A new dividend policy, regarded as important in view of the development of department-store book clubs and the revision of publishers' fair-trade contracts, was announced by the Book-of-the-Month Club, Inc., in a bulletin sent to subscribers at the week-end.

Rivington St, ?? s, 25 ft e of Lewis St, 25x 80; Benjamin Mellman to Ida Landset and Gertrude Mellman, 1,746 President St, Brooklyn; mtg $2,000 ($2). 80th St, 218-20 E, 50x102.2; Katherine Grogan to 218-220 E 80th St Corp, 21 E 40th St, care Ornstein Silverman.

Directors of the National Power and Light Company met yesterday afternoon to decide whether to accept the offer of Knoxville officials and the TVA to buy the electric properties of the Tennessee Public Service Company, a subsidiary of National Power and Light.

France turned to the United States for war planes today in her rush to rearm. The Air Ministry announced that 100. airplanes had . been ordered from American manufacturers to fill a gap caused by failure of French industry to meet the government's urgent orders.
Admiral Sir Lewis Bayly, in charge of the coordinated American and British naval forces operating at Cobh, Ireland, against German submarines during the World War, died today at the age of 80.

Although devoting a large part of his day to the candidates and their representatives, President Roosevelt's attention was riveted on preprimary developments in Pennsylvania as he watched for the reaction to Postmaster General Farley's statement from New York endorsing a split Democratic harmony ticket.
Members of the New York State Chamber of Commerce will hear on Thursday afternoon a lecture on "How to Detect Counterfeit Money" by Harry Cooper of the Treasury Department.

Representatives of the largest producers among the nation's life insurance agents urged today the managements of the life insurance companies to spend $10,000,000 a year as part of a permanent public relations and sales promotion program.

Two hundred educators gathered here today at the thirteenth annual meeting of the American Association for Adult Education and heard the association's director, Dr. Morse A. Cartwright, question the advisability of subsidizing a nationwide program of adult education with Federal funds.

The charges against Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, Iron Guard [Fascist] leader, were made public today. The trial will open in the next few days. The charges are, first, high treason, based on his possession of secret State documents; secondly, complicity with foreign organizations,

Landing safely at his King's Bay Base this morning. after an eleven and one-half-hour flight, Dr. Lauge Koch was able to state definitely that there is no land between Spitsbergen and Peary Land, the supposed location of the mysterious Fata Morgana Islands.

A scarcity of trained domestic servants from the Scandinavian countries and the British Isles is perplexing householders here, it was reported yesterday by - some of the private employment agencies, although agencies generally decleared that experienced help was more plentiful, because of the recession, than a year ago.

En route to St. Louis and their first invasion of the West, the Yankees stopped off here today long enough to smother their Class D Butler Yankees of the Pennsylvania State Association, in an exhibition game that attracted an overflow crowd of 3,000 and was halted abruptly after the first half of the seventh inning, when autograph seekers swarmed all over the field.

SUPPOSE this were the Spring of 1838 instead of 1938 and you, a New York City business man, wanted to get to Buffalo as quickly as possible. How would you go? By steam boat, steam cars or stage coach?
Don Skene, sports writer, foreign correspondent and author, died yesterday in New York Hospital after an illness of several months. His age was 40.

Premier Bela Imredy's first acts are causing a considerable feeling of relief and an increasing confidence in political and economic circles. The Budapest Stock Exchange reaction has sent up all quotations nearly 10 per-cent.

With full ecclesiastical ceremonial in the presence of prelates and distinguished laymen of the New York archdiocese, Alfred E. Smith, John S. Burke and John T. Smith were invested with the rank of Papal Chamberlains of the Cape and Sword last night in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Dr. John MacKay, principal of Manitoba College since 1919 and a leading educator of the United Church of Canada, died here today at the age of 67 years.

Miss Patricia Williams O'Donoghue, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. O'Donoghue of 27 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, has completed plans for her marriage to Joseph John Ryan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ryan of Brooklyn and Bayport, L. I., which will take place on the morning of June 22 in the Church of Our Lady of Refuge, Brooklyn.

The madcap dash of the Giants, who were suffering from four days of inactivity, which apparently permitted some damaging rust to gather in the machinery, ended with a thud against the Phillies' famed right-field wall today.

A $360,000 mortgage at 4 1/2 per cent for ten years on the n w cor of Broadway and 74th St has been arranged for William Hull Browning, owner, by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc, broker. The property is known as 2,121-27 Broadway.

The two four-story apartment house buildings at 300-302 Quincy Street, Brooklyn, containing thirtytwo apartments each, on a combined plot 66 by 100 feet, were sold by the Jacbar Realty Corporation to an investing client of Hy and D. Agar, Inc., brokers in the transaction.

At the shrill screech of a fire siren at 10:32 o'clock tonight an area covering almost twenty square miles of Long Island was plunged into darkness as the army completed its four-day mimic aerial. war with a bombing "raid" on the Seversky aircraft factory here.
A fire before dawn today turned the 30year-old Terminal Hotel into a flaming horror in ten minutes, killed twenty-seven persons and left a score more missing or injured.

Mayor La Guardia is scheduled to lay the cornerstone of the new Lafayette High School at 3:30 P. M. today at Benson Avenue and Fortythird Street, Bensonburst. At 2 P. M. the Mayor will participate in the-dedication of the new elementary Public School 254, Avenue Y and East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn.

Officials of this Administration who deal with international matters seem to have every hope that our present difficulties with Mexico will be adjusted, and the "good neighbor" policy in this hemisphere proceed without fracture, unless one thing happens.

Lily Pons, French operatic soprano, returned yesterday on the liner Normandie from a five week concert tour of Europe and was met at Quarantine by Andre Kostelanetz, orchestra conductor, to whom she will be married in New York in June before leaving for Buenos Aires to sing at the Colon Theatre.

Albert S. McGrover, 34 years old, of 1,019 St. John's Place, and John F. Crotty, 47, of 7,915 Colonial Road, both Brooklyn, were sworn in yesterday as opinion clerks of the Kings County Supreme Court.

It was candidates' day at the White House as Democratic hopefuls or their emissaries from as far South as Georgia and South Carolina and as far West as the Pacific Coast descended on the Executive Offices today to seek the blessing of President Roosevelt.

This normally quiet village almost in the center of Long Island became the first American community tonight to participate in air raid manoeuvres, so common to Europe, and it enjoyed them with the spontaneous spirit of a carnival.
John Relyea Schermerhorn, formerly an executive of the Thomas E. Edison Industries in West Orange, died today at his home after an illness of several months. His age was 75.
Determined to wrest her newly acquired non-stop mark from Elizabeth Lion, French aviatrix, Madame Dupeyron took off today for Basra, Iraq, in a Caudron-Aiglon plane.

Although unfavorable weather put a damper on retail trade Friday and Saturday of last week, most sections of the country reporting rain and cold, mail orders coming into the local merchandise markets yesterday were numerous but individual orders were confined to small lots.
Private broadcasting interests opposed today before the House Naval Affairs Committee a proposal to build a radio station in California to broadcast "good-will" programs to Central and South America.

The first annual meeting of the Senior Margin Clerks Section of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, at which officers and members of the executive committee will be elected, is to be held on Tuesday, May 24, at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.
Five alleged Nazis charged with violation of the State's Civil Rights Law, were held for the Suffolk County Grand Jury here tonight at a court hearing attended by nearly 1,500 persons.

Automobile traffic fatalities, accidents and injuries again declined last week as compared to those of the corresponding week last year, the safety bureau of the Police Department announced yesterday. Despite increases in accidents and injuries over the two-day weekend deaths also declined.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded in on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

During the last five years the Roosevelt -Administration has spent forty billion dollars, which is a larger sum of money than was spent by all the Administrations that governed this country from the days of George Washington to the days of Woodrow Wilson.

Clyde C. (Newton) Newkirk, humorist and columnist for The Boston Post for thirty-three years, died yesterday at the age of 67. He was forced to give up his journalistic work three years ago, when he suffered a nervous breakdown.

A missing. defendant in the trial of mine operators and a score of former peace officers of Harlan County, which opened here today in Federal Court, was caught by G-men in Dominion, Va., 125 miles away, fifteen minutes After his disappearance was revealed at the trial.
Twenty persons were arrested last night when a plot was discovered to overthrow the Lebanese Government and establish a dictatorship here.
The Rev. Dr. Stuart N. Hutchison of Pittsburgh was elected president of the National Alumni Association of Princeton Theological Seminary at the association's annual dinner here tonight.

Domestic stocks of refined copper on April 30, exclusive of consumers' stocks at their plants or warehouses, amount to 355,663 tons, compared with 342,785 on March 31, an increase of 12,878, according to the Copper Institute.

A large official delegation left this morning by air for Mendoza, Argentina. Headed by the Chilean Foreign Minister, Jose Ramon Gutierrez, the group will visit Brazil also and stop at Buneos Aires a second time on the return trip.
Ernest S. Davis died today at his home in Portland, Conn., at the age of 61 years. He was president of the Rogers Hubbard Company of Portland, treasurer of the L. O. E. S.

Switzerland's return to unconditional neutrality with the permission of the League of-Nations is greeted here with undisguised enthusiasm. The League is. spoken of with the customary bitter contempt, ;while Switzerland is congratulated on having accomplished much in ridding itself of League responsibility.

The Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, in the closing session of its annual convention at the Riverside Plaza Hotel yesterday, adopted a resolution: opposing the proposal of the.American Jewish Congress for a referendum of the Jewish population of the United States on "the desirability of their. being one' organization as the sole representative of all Jews in the United States."

Automobile lights on the highways prevented a complete "blackout" of Farmingdale, which was still a comparatively easy target for the planes of the General Headquarters Air Force after the street lights were turned off, it was observed during a flight over the besieged city between 10:10 and 11 o'clock tonight.

American automobiles are still universally the most popular in South America, and will continue so for many years, according to James D. Mooney, president of the General Motors Export Corporation, returned yesterday in the steamship Santa Lucia of the Grace Line from a four-month vacation in South America, accompanied by Mrs. Mooney and their daughter, Martha.

Notice Members of the Department who will attend the Communion Mass and Breakfast of the Fire Department Holy Name Society, Boroughs of Brooklyn and Queens, on Sunday, May 22, shall report, not later than 8:15 A. M., at Grand Army Plaza (Prospect Park), between Vanderbilt and Flatbush Aves., Brooklyn. Regulation Summer uniform (officers, white caps), white gloves shall be worn.

Several Fifth Avenue units were listed among the store rentals announced yesterday by brokers. A store in the building at 580 Fifth Avenue was taken by Arnold Hansen, who will open a restaurant, to be known as Arnold's Luncheonette, at that location.
James H. Lockhart, a director of the Mellon.National Bank and prominent in many other Pittsburgh industries, died today after a long illness at his home, 5,601 Fifth Avenue, at the age of 74.

Mike Belloise, 128 1/2, of the Bronx, formerly recognized as the world's featherweight champion by the New York State Athletic Commission, hammered out a-decision over Paul Lee, 126 1/2, Indianapolis, in the eight-round main event at St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Miss Polly Samuels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Gurney Samuels of Maplewood, will be married May 27 to Robert Niebling, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Niebling of South Orange, in Morrow Memorial Church here.
The special stockholders' meeting of the Federal Mining and Smelting Company, called to consider the reduction in the preferred stock and adjourned last Wednesday, is scheduled to be held on May 27.

With the professional member of each firm contributing the low score, the team of Tony Penna of Dayton, Ohio, and Ray O'Brien of Bonnie Briar tied the combination of Paul Runyan and Howard Schanzer of Metropolis for bestball honors at the wind-swept Bonnie Briar Country Club today in the one-day tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association.

Finland's pride in her army was manifested more impressively than ever today. in. the twentieth anniversary celebration of the triumphal entry-into the capital of the White army under the command of General, now Field Marshal, Carl Gustaf Emil Mannerheim, following his victory over. the Red Finno-Russian forces.

Sixteen hours ahead of schedule, Mrs. Saidie Orr Dunbar, career woman and non-knitting grandmother from Portland, Ore, was announced this afternoon as the new president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.
Stephen Fairbairn, internationally known rowing coach and inventor of the "Fairbairn style," died here today at the age of 75. Born in Australia, Mr. Fairbairn spent most of his life in England.
Leaders of the Republican majorities in the Senate and Assembly suddenly. convened the Legislature in joint session tonight and elected a State treasurer, controller and auditor.

An integrated. bar, making mandatory. the membership .of New Jersey's 7,000 practicing lawyers and jurists, was debated before the Supreme Court here today on an application filed by the State Bar Association for a rule requiring its creation.
Mrs. J. Bertram Lippincott, wife of the chairman of the board of directors of the J. B. Lippincott Company, publishers, died at Abington Memorial Hospital today after a short illness.

Three thousand persons attended a solemn requiem mass yesterday at St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church, North Henry and Herbert Streets, Brooklyn, for Patrolman Anthony S. Modleski, 35 years old, and his wife, Antoinette, 27.
Viscount Swinton, Secretary for Air, resigned from the Cabinet today and was replaced by Sir Kingsley Wood.

Turpentine firm, 23c; sales, 93 barrels; receipts, 402 barrels; shipments, 124 barrels; stock, 32,367 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 292 barrels; receipts, 1,973 barrels; shipments, 1,754 barrels; stock, 99,182 barrels. Quote: B, $3.55; D, $3.70; E, $3.75; F, $4.15; G, $4.47 1/2; H, I, K, M, $4.55; N, $5.05; WG, $5.75; WW, X,$6.20.

Transmutable, I. C. Little's gelding, came from behind today to win the Maywood Purse. Transmutable surprised the largest week-day crowd of the meeting by catching the pace-setting favorite, Gold Mesh, in the stretch and going on to score by two. lengths.

Declaring at Saturday's closing score of 491 runs for eight wickets, Lancashire dismissed Essex for 119 and 195 to win by an innings and 177 runs today. It was the northern county's third victory this season.

Under the auspices of the Spanish Child Welfare Association, an organization formed to support the relief efforts carried on in Spain by the American Friends Service Committee, an exhibition of drawings by Spanish school children opened yesterday at Lord Taylor's.

To take effect 8 A. M., May 17: LIEUTENANT --Alexander P. Lilley, 6th Division, assignment changed from desk duty to supervisor of patrol in uniform. PATROLMEN James Bute, from 63d Precinct to Harbor Precinct. Robert E. Martin, from 76th Precinct to Police Academy, for duty In Technical Research Laboratory. Frank A. Texter, from Harbor Precinct to 75th Precinct.

A protective committee for holders of first mortgage bonds of the Mountain States Power Company has filed an application under the Holding Company Act for approval of a plan of reorganization for the company, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Leo Dandurand, part owner of two Montreal race tracks and an official of the Quebec Racing Association, said today there would be no horse-racing in Quebec Province this Summer because of increased provincial government taxation of the tracks. Dandurand said this would apply to Connaught Park, near Ottawa, which is in Quebec Province.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES editorial "The Issue of Political Power" deals with the very important subject of unemployment and relief, with particular reference to the relief and; recovery .measure now being debated by the Congress.

The unusually low rate of 0.029 per cent received last week on the Treasury's weekly bill issue was bettered this week with an average rate of 0.027 per cent, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight. This represents a new low interest rate for Treasury bills, he said.

Dropping all diplomatic niceties, the German press launched today a new attack against President Getulio Vargas of Brazil, and in obviously inspired utterances issued a warning that Great Germany would not tolerate further "annoyances and chicanery in connection with Germans, German business and the German press" in Brazil.

Duncan MacInnes, deputy city treasurer, received yesterday in the presence of Mayor La Guardia the second annual award of the City Club of New York in token of his unstintedd contributions to the fiscal administration of the city."
The sharpest advance since last January took place in the general level of wholesale commodity prices last week, according to the index compiled by the National Fertilizer Association.

As the delegates to the Constitutional Convention opened the sixth week of sessions tonight it became clear that strong sentiment exists against any radical changes in the present provisions dealing with the State's judicial system.
The new regime of the New York Stock Exchange took office yesterday quietly. At 3 P. M. Charles R. Gay, ending his third term as president, appeared on the rostrum overlooking the trading floor.

Turpentine firm, 23c; sales, 93 barrels; receipts, 402 barrels; shipments, 124 barrels; stock, 32,367 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 292 barrels; receipts, 1,973 barrels; shipments, 1,754 barrels; stock, 99,182 barrels. Quote: B, $3.55; D, $3.70; E, $3.75; F, $4.15; G, $4.47 1/2; H, I, K, M, $4.55; N, $5.05; WG, $5.75; WW, X,$6.20.

Transmutable, I. C. Little's gelding, came from behind today to win the Maywood Purse. Transmutable surprised the largest week-day crowd of the meeting by catching the pace-setting favorite, Gold Mesh, in the stretch and going on to score by two. lengths.

Declaring at Saturday's closing score of 491 runs for eight wickets, Lancashire dismissed Essex for 119 and 195 to win by an innings and 177 runs today. It was the northern county's third victory this season.

Under the auspices of the Spanish Child Welfare Association, an organization formed to support the relief efforts carried on in Spain by the American Friends Service Committee, an exhibition of drawings by Spanish school children opened yesterday at Lord Taylor's.

To take effect 8 A. M., May 17: LIEUTENANT --Alexander P. Lilley, 6th Division, assignment changed from desk duty to supervisor of patrol in uniform. PATROLMEN James Bute, from 63d Precinct to Harbor Precinct. Robert E. Martin, from 76th Precinct to Police Academy, for duty In Technical Research Laboratory. Frank A. Texter, from Harbor Precinct to 75th Precinct.

A protective committee for holders of first mortgage bonds of the Mountain States Power Company has filed an application under the Holding Company Act for approval of a plan of reorganization for the company, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Leo Dandurand, part owner of two Montreal race tracks and an official of the Quebec Racing Association, said today there would be no horse-racing in Quebec Province this Summer because of increased provincial government taxation of the tracks. Dandurand said this would apply to Connaught Park, near Ottawa, which is in Quebec Province.

Facts and figures concerning the developing spread between the decreased cost of ingredients and the "rigidity" of bread prices have been transmitted by Secretary Wallace to the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission for their consideration.

The second day of the trial through which the government is seeking to expose the feudal social and economic philosophy of Harlan County, scene of years of bitter mine warfare, and to set a precedent for punishing employers who conspire to deny the workers the right to organize in unions, failed today to produce a jury to try the sixty-six defendants who occupy half the seats in Judge W. Church Ford's Federal District Court.

Hary L. Hopkins, Administrator of the Works Progress Administration, told a Senate subcommittee today that the amount carried in the relief-recovery measure would enable WPA to care for about 3,000,000 persons next Winter.

Mrs. Emily Amelia Cole Lurcott, who lived for seventy years in New York in happy obscurity as the wife of George Lurcott until 1936, when they were honored as "ideal parents," died on Monday of pneumonia at her home, 1,160 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, after an illness of two weeks. She would have been 93 years old on May 31.
Betting on Maryland's race tracks slumped $1,440,395 this Spring from the $13,383,968 shoved through the pari-mutuel windows a year ago.

The thirty-two buyers representing the Outlet Company, Providence, who are here to purchase $500,000 worth of merchandise for a "mammoth promotional event," devoted their-attention yesterday to visiting the showrooms of manufacturers.

Warren A. Dow of the Salle Santelli retired the Greco Trophy last night as he won the Greco Fencing Academy's open foils competition for the third straight year. Dow, in superb form, came through an intensive evening of competition in which thirty candidates started.

The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, opened yesterday an exhibition of oils and sculpture from the permanent collection. It will be current for but a scant fortnight, through Friday of next week, and on the following day the museum will close for the Summer, not to reopen until some time in September.

The marriage of Miss Florence Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Allen of Dongan Hills, S. I., to Lieut. Comdr. Francis Gaffney, U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Joseph Gaffney of Charleston, S. C., took place here yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in West Seventy-first Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James T. Ryan.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in a message to the institution's 100,000 graduates, urged support yesterday for the Columbia Alumni Fund's initial drive to raise the $50,000,000 he estimated in March as the university's immediate need.

Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, announced yesterday that his department had started a drive to license all theatrical agencies in the city. The license fee will be $25, plus $10 for a $1,000 bond.

Pensions were granted to 193 employes of the Western Union Telegraph Company in 1937, bringing the number of pensioners to 1,771, of which 1,276 are men and 495 are women, according to the twentyfifth annual report of the Employes Benefit Fund Committee, issued yesterday.

The agony of the Sweepstakes is the burden of "Mazal Darf Men" ("You Need Luck"), a dramatizatior by Mark Schweid of a story by S. Yushkewitch which was presented at the Neighborhood Playhouse last night.
The era of easily obtained bank charters which resulted in too many banks is gone forever, Marshall R. Diggs, Acting Controller of the Currency, said at the State Bankers Convention here today.

MANHATTAN CONDARDO, ANNA, also known as Anna Krippendorf (May 9). Estate, $1,000. To Arnold Krippendorf, husband, executor, 345 W. 70th St. GRENTHAL, MICHAEL (April 30). Estate, more than $20,000. To Bertha Levine, 842 E. 9th St. Martha Siegal, 160 Riverside Dr.; Benjamin Grenthal, executor, 535 W. 110th St., and Abraham Grenthal, executor, 225 Central Park West, children, residue equally.

The sale of tax stamps for cigarette packages has been so heavy that the supply of 101,000,000 stamps, which was expected to last until June 30, is nearing exhaustion and a new contract for a like amount will be let soon, Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer, announced yesterday.

The Central Republic Trust Company on May 3 owed the Reconstruction Finance Corporation $44,291,546 of the original $90,000,000 loan made to the old "Dawes Bank"-Central Republic Bank and Trust Company-in 1932 shortly before it closed.

Taking cognizance of the existing business depression, Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman denied yesterday an application made by Joseph Rosenthal, Kings County Court librarian, for an order directing the city to pay him at the rate of $8,000 instead of $6,750 a year. In a formal opinion,
Mrs. Carolyn Morrell Griswold, widow of Dr. William L. Griswold, physician and surgeon here for many years, died at the Greenwich Hospital this afternoon. She underwent an operation on Friday.
Cubans today honored Domingo Rosillo, 61-yearold flier, who, twenty-five years ago, flew from Key West to Havana on the first flight between the United States and Cuba.

It is probably best not to mention the name of the 13-year-old New York boy who has made three ocean trips as a stowaway during the past three months. He has had more publicity than is good for him. It is also probably best not to compare him with Huck Finn.

Those members of Local 117 of the Cloak Operators Union, affiliated with the International Ladies Garment Workers, who since January have received not more than $300 in wages because of unemployment, will receive, for the first time in the fifty-two-year history of the organization, unemployment payments totaling $75,000, it was announced yesterday. Some 1,400 members are to receive- the checks.

The Brazilian Ambassador Moniz de Aragao called on the Foreign Office today to talk about charges against Germany made in Brazil in connection with the recent futile uprising. The resentment that the German press has expressed as well as the state of German feeling were probably discussed.
Mr. and Mrs. Emerson Whithorne of 1,120 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of Mrs. Whithorne's daughter, Mrs. Jane I Harvey Nilson, to William Erskine MacKay of this city.

The newly organized American Palestine Securities Company, which was registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, has opened offices at 63 Wall Street to deal generally in securities originating in the Holy Land.
Arthur W. Ramsdell, director of sales of the Borden Company, was elected president of the Sales Executives Club of New York at its annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Ninety-five members of the graduating class received degrees last night at the 102d annual commencement exercises of Union Theological Seminary. Thatcher M. Brown, president of the board of directors, awarded the degrees in the chapel of the seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.
A jury before Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadien Jr. in Queens exonerated Commissioner of Correction Austin H. MacCormick yesterday in a suit for $100,000 for false arrest.

A national center for safety education, said to be the first of its kind in the United States, will be established by New York University on July 1, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university.
Earl Whitehill turned back the Athletics with four hits today to give Cleveland a 5-1 victory which put the Indians within a half-game of the league-leading Red Sox, who were rained out.

The government decreed today that the RhineDanube Canal via the Main River should be completed by 1945. Simultaneously the Danube will be developed as a "Reich waterway" up to the new German border below Vienna.

Joseph D'Addario of 2,141 Sixtyfourth Street, Brooklyn, a thirdyear. student at Brooklyn Law School, who was expelled on May 5, has been reinstated, according to an announcement yesterday by Dean William Payson Richardson.

A resolution opposing any change in the State Constitution that would legalize gambling or permit a lottery was defeated by a vote of .150 to 123 this afternoon at the seventyfirst annual .convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island at the Cathedral of the Incarnation here.

Mayor La Guardia "strongly recommended" to the City Council yesterday the re-enactment of all existing emergency relief tax laws "plus a compensatory tax which would in a measure stop leaks to existing law." A compensatory tax bill,

A notice in the obituary column of the newspaper Voelkischer Beobachter of the death of Albert Kallweit, a Storm Trooper who "on May 13 was the victim of cowardly attack during the performance of his duty at a lonely post in the Thuringian Forest," is taken here as confirming a report of the first known outbreak .of violence in a German concentration camp.

Friends and former colleagues from the newspaper, sports and theatrical worlds yesterday afternoon attended funeral services for Don Skene at the Funeral Church, Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street. Mr. Skene, sports writer, foreign correspondent and author, died on Monday at New York Hospital.

An agreement is being considered between Chile and Argentina for air navigation between the southern Chilean territories of Aysen and Magallanes, permitting free flight over Argentine territory without frontier control.

The speech delivered recently at Burgos to an audience of soldiers at a theatre by General Juan Yague, one of the leading Nationalist [Insurgent] commanders, that brought rebuke from Generalissimo Francisco Franco, has caused much perturbation in those limited circles that are permitted to know what is going on.
A letter has been sent to holders of Porto Rican American Tobacco Company 6 per cent convertible bonds due in 1942, asking them to consent to waive sinking-fund requirements of $585,000 annually.

Estimated national consumption of lumber for the fist half of 1938 will be 9,800,000,000 feet, a decrease of 24 per cent from the record of the first half of 1937 and 12 per cent under the same period of 1936, but appreciably above the first half of the four preceding years,

Five officials of the Toledo Guaranty Corporation who were convicted last week of fraud and issuing fraudulent checks were sentenced today to penitentiary terms ranging from five to thirty-eight years.
The State of Oregon has invited bankers to submit bids on June 15 for a new issue of $750,000

Mrs. Margaret J. Perrine, eldest daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand W. Roebling Sr. and mother-in-law of Robert T. Bowman, president of the State Chamber of Commerce, died here today in Mercer Hospital, where she underwent an operation yesterday.

The National Labor Relations Board has won a substantial victory in the Supreme Court's decision in the Mackay case. The question at issue was the constitutionality of an order of the board directing the employer to reinstate five employes who had gone on strike.

Miss Hazel M. McDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. McDonald of this place, was married to George F. Hamill, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George J. Hamill of Flushing, this morning at the Church of St. Anastasia in Douglaston. The Rev. George A. Dawson officiated.

Declaring that he was "against naming anything after a politician," B. Charney Vladeck. coalition leader, yesterday fought a proposal in the City Council to honor the late Louis A. Cuvillier, who died in May, 1935,
Stockholders of the American Investment Company of Illinois approved yesterday an increase in the authorized stock to be used in the acquisition of the Ideal Financing Association, Inc., of Boston.

A sweeping investigation of the entire structure of the Municipal Courts of New York City was presaged yesterday on the eve of the opening today by the McNaboe Legislative Committee of its inquiry into the rent case involving Simon W. Gerson, Communist aide to Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Kings County told a Brooklyn audience last night (sotto voce, incidentally) that Brooklyn criminals have him worried again, not because of a new crime wave, but because they don't seem to be committing crimes any more.

SOME of the older inhabitants will remember Banjo Charley. He used to play a great game at first base for the Pittsburgh Pirates. He really could tickle the banjo, too. But the Pirates ran into some sad years and Banjo Charley stopped his music at the source.

A supplementary summary of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations in March, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed that Walter Seligman, a director,

Huntington Adams, mining engineer, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness. Mr. Adams, who was 58 years old, had been active in mining operations in Mexico and South America, and later as a consultant in this city. His home was at Block House, Greenwich, Conn.

An unusually large police detail of 140 uniformed men and eighty-five detectives, under high ranking officers, was distributed in and around the Turnhalle at Eightyfifth Street and Lexington Avenue last night for the regular fortnightly meeting of the German American Bund, a Nazi organization, whose celebration of Adolf Hitler's birthday on April 20 ended in a riot.

A proposal to merge the Allegheny Steel Company of Brackenridge, Pa., and the Ludlum Steel Company of Watervliet, N. Y., was approved yesterday at separate meetings of the boards of directors of the two companies.

While the Pennsylvania Democrats were huddling into the polling places yesterday Democrats and Democratic politicians in two other States had their own coming troubles or hopes to ponder. The Keystone Democrats were all quarreling New Dealers.

The Red Wings drove Atley Donald out of the box today and collected a total of twelve hits off three Newark pitchers for a 7-2 verdict. It was Rochester's second conquest of the Bears in two days and stretched the visitors' losing streak to three games, equaling their longest string of losses in two seasons.
President Roosevelt signed today the bill authorizing a $1,090,656,000 expansion of the navy during the next ten years.

Wells W. Cheney, retired silk manufacturer of South Manchester, Conn., died here today after a long illness at the age of 80 years. Survivors include a brother, Louis R. Cheney, retired silk manufacturer of Hartford, Conn.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York urged Mayor La Guardia and the other members of the Board of Estimate yesterday to delay construction of the proposed $4,000,000 Appellate Division court house on Park Avenue at Thirtyninth Street because it would "not be productive of any return" and was "not immediately necessary."

G. William Magly, prominent Queens real estate operator and former chairman of the New York State Budget Advisory Board, died on Monday night, after being ill for several months of heart disease, at his home, 85-01 168th Place, Jamaica, L. I. He was 59 years old.

President Roosevelt today heeded complaints that business, industry and private individuals were being inconvenience by the increase of requests from various government agencies for statistical reports and called on the Central Statistical

The Lone Ranger, famed on radio and more recently in the movies, is entering a new field, with sponsorship of products for boys and girls between the ages of 8 and 14, it was announced yesterday by Raymond Spector, merchandising and advertising counsel, who will direct this activity.

Employes of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company will divide approximately $180,000 of extra income on May 31, representing 3 per cent adjusted compensation in addition to their regular earnings for the month, A. W. Robertson, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

Bob Riddle, veteran right-hander, hurled three-hit ball and led Princeton at bat to turn back the Rutgers nine, 8-2, in a battle of pitchers on University Field today. Both teams were held scoreless until the eighth inning, when the Scarlet tallied once and the Tigers came back with an eight-run deluge.

Violence broke out- anew in the fur district yesterday as efforts were continued by Dr. Paul Abelson, impartial chairman of the industry, to settle the strike of 15,000 workers members of the International Fur Workers Union.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES has performed a service to the public by opening its columns to discussion of the desirability of establishing an automobile accident compensation plan on the lines of the workmen's compensation acts.

Dr. David H. Shelling of 3,035 Brighton Sixth Street, Brooklyn, pediatrician and research worker, who made many contributions to medical science on the subject of bone diseases, died yesterday in the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn after a long illness. His age was 39 years.
The plot of 6,500 square feet at the northeast corner of Northern Boulevard and 146th Street, Flushing, Queens, has been sold by Katherine E. Willis to the Southpore Realty Company of Ossining,

Decreases in both passenger and freight revenues were shown in consolidated returns by 141 Class I railroads in March and the first three months of the year to the Interstate Commerce Commission. The statement follows:

Today's major events: Ensemble Chorale Society, Town Hall, 8:15 P. M.; Federal Opera Chorus and Greenwich Orchestra, Federal Music Theatre, 8:45 P. M.; Composers' Forum-Laboratory, Carnegie Chamber Hall, 8:45 P. M., free to the public; Josef and Rosina Lhevinne,
Six young lawyers, the first of the "junior" panel of attorneys who volunteered last week to aid without compensation needy defendants in the criminal courts, reported yesterday for duty to Edward T.

Julius A. Moses, for forty-three years a member of the law firm of Kennedy, Stein Bachrach-, died today in his home here at the age of 66. Mr. Moses was an authority on the amended Federal Bankruptcy Act.
The midtown and downtown areas shared the bulk of the contracts for commercial space announced by brokers yesterday. Among the firms reported to have taken space were the Interior Wireways, Ind.,

Police Captains Bernard W. Rorke of the Sheriff Street station and Joseph A. Murray of the Clinton Street station applied yesterday for retirement, having reached the mandatory age of 63. They will receive pensions of $2,750 annually. Both men have served in the department for more than 35 years.

Awards for meritorious art work by students of the New York School of Applied Design for Women were announced yesterday at a luncheon and private view of the forty-sixth annual exhibition of students' work in the school galleries, 160 Lexington Avenue.

Legislation for construction and operation of a "good-will" broadcasting service to South and Central America,. the station to be owned and operated- by the-- government, apparently died today when the House Committee on Naval Affairs postponed indefinitely further hearings on the Celler bill.

A man resembling the composite picture of the kidnapper of Charles F. Mattson at Tacoma, Wash., was arrested by Detective George Swander of the homicide squad yesterday near the city Parole Commission office at 139 Center Street.

The House approved today and sent to the President a bill amending the Federal Reserve Act so as to elimninate a large part of the double liability on stockholders of certain State banks which are members of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corportion.

John T. Madden, dean of the School of Commerce of New York University, who was selected as arbitrator to adjudicate demands made upon the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations by Local 32B of the Building Service Employes Union,

A bill authorizing the British Government to carry out the provisions of the Anglo-Irish agreement became law tonight when the King's assent was given by the Royal Commission after its final passage this afternoon by the House of Lords without a division.
The unusual publicity of a world-wide short wave broadcast will be given to President Arturo Alessandri's annual message to Congress 'Saturday.

Projects were filed in Brooklyn yesterday for two groups of homes, one of fifteen in the Ridgewood section and the other of ten in Sheepshead Bay. All of the onefamily type, the former will cost $4,000 each and the latter $5,000 each.
Dr. Harold L. Van Nostrand, a specialist in children's diseases, died on Sunday night at the Benedictine Hospital here after an illness of several weeks.

Paul Treadway, welfare director for the United Automobile Workers of America in Flint, has been dismissed by the union. The announcement was contained in a letter from Homer Martin, international union president, to George F. Granger, acting State Relief Administrator in Lansing.
Pat Malone, a cast-off from the Yankees missed a no-hit, no-run game in his second International League start today by the margin of a scratch single as Baltimore scored a 3-0 shutout over Montreal.

Motor and Pump Operators The following members having satisfactorily completed the course in the care and operation of motors and pumps used in the department, are designated as motor and pump operators, and they are therefore qualified to be assigned to that duty in their companies or in any company to which they may be transferred, in preference to all other members who have not previously qualified:

Plans for reorganizing the Prudence-Bonds Corporation have been declared operative in orders signed by United States District Judge Robert A. Inch and the new company has been organized under the laws of New York, it was announced formally yesterday by Thomas W. Streeter, president.

One of the largest lists of entries in the history of the national open golf championship was assured for this year's tournament when the United States Golf Association estimated that 1,160 had been received when the deadline fell late yesterday, according to the Associated Press.

Red tape in the New York Stock Exchange appeared yesterday to be a thing of the past as the new administration headed by William McC. Martin Jr., chairman and acting president, settled down to the serious task of reorganizing the institution.
Representative Patrick J. Boland, Democratic whip of the House, appeared certain of renomination tonight in his quest for a fifth term.

A Board of Taxicabs, which would take over complete jurisdiction of the licensing, operation and control of taxicabs in the city from the Police Department, was proposed in a report submitted to the City Council yesterday.

A duel between Augustin Parla, veteran aviator, and Jesus Ganzalez Scarpeta of the editorial staff of the morning newspaper, the Mundo, was held today on a farm near Santa Maria del Rosario, twentyfive miles from Havana.

The first line of America's national defense should be spiritual, Stanley K. Hornbeck, political adviser to Secretary Hull, said tonight in an address before the annual meeting of the Chaplains Association of the Army of the United States.

Miss is Tasha Tudor Burgess, daughter of Mrs. Rosamond Tudor Burgess of this place and Boston and of W. Starling Burgess of Wiscasset, Me., racing yacht designer, has chosen May 28 as the date for her marriage to Thomas Leighton McCready Jr. of New York and Redding.
Questioned in the House of Commons today on the progress of the Anglo-American trade negotiations, Oliver Stanley, President of the Board of Trade, refused to make any comment.
Visiting the home of Dr. Sigmund Freud, the father of psychoanalysis, today, the writer learned that Dr. Freud and his family would soon leave for England.
A proposal that Congress ask a.pardon for Tom Mooney, convicted in the San Francisco preparedness day bombing in 1916, won today the approval of a House Judiciary subcommittee.

Passage of President Roosevelt's pump-priming bill without the $3,000,000,000 appropriation being earmarked will "Tammanyize" the country, Amos Pinchot declared yesterday in a letter to the President opposing the measure.

Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company-Three months to March 31: Net income after taxes and charges, $1,398,072; for the twelve months to March 31, net income was $4,351,386. No provision was made for surtax on undistributed profits for the first three months of 1938.

President Roosevelt signed the $1,156,000,000 Naval Expansion Bill, the Legislative Appropriation Bill and a measure authorizing Federal participation in the celebration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg.
Barney Ross spent a lazy day today before resuming training for his fifteen-round welterweight title defense against Henry Armstrong in Madison Square Garden Bowl May 26.

The "black-out" and air raid staged by army fliers on Monday night over Farmingdale, L. I., were sharply criticized in a resolution adopted yesterday by 300 pastors at the opening of the New York East annual conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in the Central Methodist Episcopal Church, Hanson Place and St. Felix Street, Brooklyn.
Many dinner parties were given last night at the dinner dance arranged by members of the Ladies Auxiliary of the Lenox Hill Hospital, which was held at a preopening of the Roof Garden of the Astor.
Placements by offices of the United States Employment Service during April increased by 30 per cent over March, but applications for jobs continued near peak levels, Secretary Perkins reported today.

Sun glinted from scores of "props" and wing tips, and drumming motors roared a song of power above New York yesterday as the army's General Headquarters Air Force passed in aerial review at Mitchel Field and flashed past the city in a triumphant parades of power.
Dominican election returns today put a 92 per cent stamp of approval on President Rafael Trujillo's choice of Dr. Jacinto B. Peynado as his successor.
Alpheu Winter, seven-time Connecticut senior champion, won the first one-day tournament of the season conducted by the Connecticut Seniors Golf Association at the Woodway Country Club today.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday numbered less than in the preceding week and in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

The New York Curb Exchange has been notified that 4,950 shares of Sherwin-Williams Company cumulative preferred stock, Series AAA, par value $100, have been drawn for redemption on June 1 at $105 and accrued dividend. The committee on securities has ruled that the drawn certificates ceased to be a delivery after April 30.

" The Junior League's contribution to the Community" was the subject of an address at the annual conference of the Association of - the Junior Leagues of America here today, by Mrs. DeForest Van Slyck of New York, executive secretary of the association.

Jurisdiction over chorus groups in grand opera companies has been taken from the Grand Opera Choral Alliance and awarded to the American Guild of Musical Artists, it was announced yesterday by the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, the American Federation of Labor's parent body of all entertainers' unions.

In an article appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Tuesday, May 17, 1938, describing the suit which Arthur A. Ballantine, as trustee of Continental Securities Corporation, was authorized by Judge Robert P. Patterson of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York to institute
