The government today prohibited civil servants from participation in any secret organization, particularly the taking of secret oaths to "leaders." Those violating this order will lose positions and pensions.

Only a few weeks after the resumption of diplomatic and commercial relations between Poland and Lithuania after a lapse of eighteen years, a new dispute has arisen over the status of Vilna, original cause of the long estrangement.
One hundred members of the New York branch of the - English-Speaking Union and their guests visited the gardens of Welwyn, home of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt, this afternoon.
The four-story brownstone dwelling at 891 Union Street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn was purchased by Catharlne Vinci through the John Pullman Real Estate Company, Inc., broker.

The fat-cattle trade continued active today, all classes selling strong to higher, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture. Shippers and order buyers as well as local killers bought freely. In the hog trade big killers played a part in a 20c advance. Lambs sold strong.

Judge Maurice Tetreau debided today that there was enough evidence to order three former employes of the Montreal branch of Jenks, Gwynne Co. of New York, a brokerage firm, committed for trial before the next term of the Criminal Assizes on charges of conspiracy to steal $97,954 from the firm.

While university officials refused to comment, it is learned from an authoritative source that Joseph P. Kennedy, Amabassador to Great, Britain, will receive an honorary degree from Harvard at the commencement exercises next month.
The estate at 45 Runyon Avenue, Deal, N. J., formerly owned by the late Mayor Sidney Rhodes, has been purchased by William Bernstein, secretary and treasurer of the Wilmark Service of New York.

Three Fordham winning streaks of considerable length were in jeopardy yesterday at Fordham Field until the Rams staged an eighthinning uprising, which brought them a 3-2 victory over St. John's of Brooklyn in a thrilling encounter, which required only 1 hour 46 minutes.
It is a common reproach that in the matter of building homes for people our construction industry has not moved very far

The ruling of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court that mortgage certificates held by title companies ranked equally with those held by others was upheld today by the Court of Appeals in the action involving liquidation of the New York

Apparently aware that he was marked for death, John Padden, 33-year-old ex-convict, recently had converted all of his surplus cash into $1,400 worth of life insurance policies with double indemnity clauses, the police made known yesterday.

Justices DeLuca, Kozicke and Brady acquitted yesterday five members of Local 155 of the Knitgoods Workers Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, on coercion and conspiracy charges in a strike in 1936.

The fourteen students of the City College School of Business who were arrested early yesterday morning on charges of disorderly conduct after they obstructed traffic in the Times Square area and raced through the Hotel Astor will meet Magistrate August Dreyer in West Side Court today with their parents to discuss suitable punishment.
Six persons were killed and more than forty were injured, many of them seriously, today in a rear-end collision between two crowded subway trains.

That America is fighing against time to develop its democratic processes through education in the face of world conditions was one of many opinions expressed today at the thirteenth annual meeting of the American Association for Adult Education.
Spanish Government reinforcements, aided by fresh Spring rains, tonight blocked again the Insurgents' attack along the coast toward Valencia.

The Naval Academy, fighting to retain its Eastern sprint championship, will send an orthodox portstroked varsity crew, capable of pulling a fast beat, into the Adams Cup race here Saturday against Harvard and Pennsylvania.

Two large buildings were among the seven Manhattan properties in scattered parts of the city sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. Included was the ten-story loft and store building on a plot 97.6 by 100.5 feet at 71-79 West Forty-fifth

Frank C. Lynch of Kansas City, Mo., has been awarded- the Navy Athletic Association Sword as the best athlete of the year at the Naval Academy. Six feet four inches tall, and weighing 218 pounds, Lynch was a tackle on the eleven, center of the basketball five and holds academy records for the shot-put and discus throw.

The charge that the Roosevelt Administration and, in particular, the immigration authorities are being "very lax" in permitting many European Communists to enter this country in the guise of German refugees was made yesterday at a meeting of the New York State Women's Republican Club at the Hotel Plaza.

Officials of the Holland-America Line entertained members of the press at a luncheon on the steamship Nieuw Amsterdam yesterday, and expressed appreciation of the reception accorded the vessel at the end of her maiden voyage.
The Medallion Alumni Organization of New York University last night elected officers for next year at its annual dinner meeting at the Hotel Lafayette.
With 110 members and guests present, the New York A. C. opened its twenty-sixth golf season and its seventieth year of Summer athletic competition over the course of the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

J. M. B. Hoxsey, executive director of the stock list committee of the New York Stock Exchange, indicated yesterday his intention to retire on a pension before the end of the year. Now nearing his seventieth year and past the retirement age, Mr. Hoxsey is expected to inform officials of the Exchange formally of his desire within a few weeks.

A shake-up was effected today by Coach Fred Spuhn to inject more power into the Princeton crew that clashes with Yale and Cornell in the Carnegie Cup race on Lake Cayuga Friday. Captain Phil Le Boutillier, at stroke, and Jack Pitney, No. 6 sweep, will be the only varsity men on their usual slides.

The continued weakening of the Chinese dollar as a result of China's unfavorable trade balance and the heavy demand for foreign exchange, especially in treaty ports such as Shanghai, is causing increasingly serious concern among foreign and Chinese bankers and merchants.
The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a bill increasing pensions of certain aged and disabled veterans of the Spanish War, the Philippine Insurrection and the China Relief Expedition.

Resorting to a varied assortment of tactics, which at times resembled a combination of chess and checkers, with just a dash of baseball on the side, our sagacious Colonel Bill Terry outfoxed charming Cholly Grimm at the Polo Grounds yesterday and the result, as one might well imagine, was almost inevitable.

FIRST MILITARY AREA The following reserve officers recently released to the First Military Area are assigned as indicated: 514th Coast Artillery (AA)-Captain Irvine H. Marshall, C.A.-Res., 365 State St., Albany, N. Y. 391st Infantry-2d Lt. Alfred G. Fry, Inf.Res., Sheldon Court, Ithaca, N. Y.

Nineteen major automobile convoycompanies, which deliver new cars to dealers in the Northeastern United States, petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission today to make ineffective a new Pennsylvania statute which, they say, virtually prohibits operation of the convoys in that State.

Both sides prepared today for a parliamentary struggle next Monday when the Wages and Hours Bill will come up in the House under a petition discharging the Rules Committee from further consideration of the measure.

Dr. John M. Kessler, 55 years old, of 100 Forest Hill Road, West Orange, N. J., who was a chemist associated with the Kessler Chemical Company; Philadelphia, was found dead late today in' a room at the Orange Hotel here, Dr. George Olcott,
Count Valiant, 3-year-old son of Reigh Count and French Duchess, showed a liking for Aurora's deep, muddy track today by running away with the best offering on the card by six lengths.

The name of the Brooklyn Home for Consumptives, 240 Kingston Avenue, Brooklyn, will be changed to the Brooklyn Thoracic Hospital, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Oscar W. Swift, president of the board of trustees of the home.

Johnny Cabello, 131, Puerto Rico, outpointed Ginger Foran, 131, Ireland, in the feature eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena last night before 3,500 fans. It was the closing boxing show of the season in the arena.
Henry Travers, the original Grandpa Vanderhof of "You Can't Take It With You," departs from the cast at the Booth a week from next Saturday night, bound for Hollywood and a film.

Wheat futures declined more than 1 cent a bushel at the extreme today to the lowest levels since April, 1934, after showing relative steadiness in the early trading when there was buying said to have been to remove hedges against export sales.

America's Walker Cup golfers went through their initial workouts at Sunningdale today. Johnny Fischer of Cincinnati, who lost ten pounds during the exceptionally rough crossing,- nevertheless scored a 69, four under par.
Dr. Otto Vollbahr, book and manuscript collector of Washington, returned from Denmark yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa after a- visit to the Royal Library in Copenhagen.

A seven-year-old suit brought by the government to compel the National City Bank, as trustee of the estate of the late Alice G. Vanderbilt, to pay an income tax on net profits of $3,000,000 made in 1926 and 1927 in the sale of the old Cornelius Vanderbilt house on Fifth Avenue was settled yesterday for $600,000.

A resolution calling for the creation of a nonsalaried, nonpartisan State Council of Fish and Game within the present State Conservation Department has been adopted by the Southern New York Fish and Game Association and forwarded for introduction in the Constitutional Convention.

Harvard and Army will play in the opening game of the college polo championship next- month at the Burnt Mills Polo Club in New Jersey, according to the draw made public yesterday by the officials of the club and of the Intercollegiate Polo Association.

Roger W. Babson of Wellesley, National Moderator of the Congregational Church, led several hundred ministers and church leaders today in a bolt from the State Congregational Convention in Allin Church, here, to the Dedham Unitarian Church, across the street, which Mr. Babson hired for the purpose.

J. Edward Davey, chief of the section of finance of the Bureau of Motor Carriers of the Interstate Commerce Commisssion, has recommended a prohibition of the merger of the Burlington Trailways, a subsidiary of the Chicago,
Thomas Carbone, John Adams High School athlete, was restored to good standing at the monthly meeting of the Games Committee of the Public Schools Athletic League at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

Twenty acres on Dobbs Ferry Road, in Greenburgh, Westchester County, have been sold by the trustees of Series 2-4136 to M. Wadley of Bronxville, who Will develop the property as a nursery. Prince Ripley, Inc., negotiated the deal.

Either interest in golf is greater this year or else golfers have more time on their hands than they've had in the past. Whichever is the case the fact remains that the turnout for the first one-day tournament of the season at the North Hempstead Country Club today, sponsored by the Metropolitan Golf Association, was the largest in several years.

Miss Valentine Porter of Carmel, Calif., won first prize in the third Prix de Paris annual career contest for senior college women conducted by Vogue magazine, it was an- which nounced yesterday by Edna Woolman Chase, editor-in-chief. Miss Helen Hartman of Lancaster, Pa., received second prize.
Nine runs in the third inning gave Buffalo a 12-to-6 victory over Jersey City today. Fourteen Bison batsmen faced three pitchers in the third. Woody Abernathy poled a homer with two aboard.

A bill to abolish "block-booking" of motion pictures and to require film distributors to furnish exhibitors with a "true synopsis" of each picture offered to them was passed by the Senate today without a record vote.

The five-story apartment house on a plot 141 by 105 feet at 3,155 Godwin Terrace, the Bronx, which last week was purchased by David S. Meister, operator, has again been sold. The latest buyer is an investing client of Isidore Nassau, attorney.

The stock market here was quiet on the whole today and the lack of business caused most sections to sag. Gilt edge issues showed fractional losses, but among the foreign bonds Chinese and Brazilian loans did well.

Since Jan. 1, Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., have been appointed renting and managing agents of about 100 properties, principally in Manhattan. They include the fourteen-story office building at 176 Broadway,
Henry Burck, violinist, concertmaster, composer and music teacher, long a resident of New York, died here on Sunday at the home of a friend, William Asmus, after a short illness. His are was 77.
The municipal commissions elected in nine New Jersey communities on May 10 held their organization meetings yesterday, electing Mayors and assigning directorates to the other commission members.

Mrs. Herman Metz has leased a duplex apartment of thirteen rooms and five baths in 720 Park Avenue, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers, who also report leasing of suites in 277 Park Avenue to Charles J. Mulligan

With more than 150 buyers attending, including many representing large department stores, a quantity of towels, toweling, bath mats, washcloths, sheets, pillow cases, napkins, drapery materials and luggage cloths was sold at auction yesterday by Edward Jacobs,
Claiming they were still in telephone communication with Suchow, Chinese Army leaders denied today that the city had been abandoned or that the defenders had been routed.

Robert L. Tudor, Acting City Clerk, whose election by the City Council is still awaiting determination in the courts, has not drawn any salary since the first of the year and has not had any payments from the city pension which he had been drawing at the rate of $171 a month since 1934, it was disclosed yesterday.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt last night told 300 booksellers in convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania of the influence books have had on her life and incidentally some of the troubles of a President's wife trying to catch up with her reading.

W. V. Mcgrath's Peligroso II became the first of the $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap nominees to score at Suffolk Downs when he won the six furlong co-feature today to pay $9.60 for $2. Peligroso II was four lengths in front of Mrs.
Henlein terrorism against German Democrats and other anti-Fascists in the Sudeten area increases daily, according to the Czech press, as the first municipal elections, scheduled for Sunday, approach.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A. M., May 18: THIRD-GRADE DETECTIVE --Leonard W. Parkes, from 18th Division, 11th Detective District, to 77th Precinct, designation as third-grade detective revoked.

The foreign exchange market recovered yesterday from its weakness of the previous day. The pound sterling was 1/2 cent higher at $4.96 3/4, the franc up 1/4 point at 2.79 1/2 cents, the belga up 1 3/4 points to 16.84 1/4 cents, the guilder up 3
Henry Fisher, a former director of the Standard Oil Company, who was a veteran of more than sixty years in the oil industry when he retired on Jan. 1, 1936, died yesterday at the age of 79.
Arcadio Gomez Palkencia, commander of Loyalist carabineers at Figueras, Catalonia, was shot this morning by his own men as he was passing over the frontier into France.

Premier Paul Spaak hinted in his Ministerial statement in the Chamber of Deputies today that the Constitution might have to be revamped to conform to the changed conditions facing a democratic regime.

The New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, 200 West Seventy-second Street, aided more than 1,600 blind persons at a cost of more than $135,000 last year, according to the annual report made public yesterday by the president, Leonard. M. Wallstein.

Alf M. Landon, 1936 Republican Presidential nominee, who championed free speech and a free press in an address today before the Inland Daily Press Association convention in Chicago, was the principal guest at the annual Gridiron Dinner at the Ulen Country Club here tonight.

The fare of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad between New Jersey stations and downtown Manhattan should not be increased from six to ten cents, as proposed by the railroad, but an increase to eight cents would not be unreasonable,

Prices yesterday continued to show a firmer undertone at the fur sale being conducted here by the New York Auction Company. The levels were described by officials of the company as showing a "slight recovery" from the quotations earlier in the year, reflecting the need for goods in some quarters and the somewhat better feeling which has developed in the industry during the last ten days.
The Italian Line's ships on the New York run will henceforth call at Cannes instead of Villefranche, their Riviera agency announced today.

A vigorous upswing in the issues of Hudson Manhattan Railroad, in response to the Interstate Commerce Commission examiner's recommendation of an eight-cent fare in its downtown service, stood out as the only feature of another drab session yesterday in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange.

The number of commercial and industrial failures during the week ended May 12 increased in four out of five trade groups compared with the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
What is believed to be the biggest real estate deal in British history was completed today with the, sale by the Marquess of Bute of half the city of Cardiff, in South Wales.
County Judge Thomas Downs declared a mistrial yesterday in Long Island City in the case of Michael Alex, 27 years old, who was being tried for the fifth time on a firstdegree murder indictment.

The Court of Errors and Appeals reversed today the action of the Court of Chancery in dismissing a suit brought by Schenley Products Company against Franklin Stores Company of Newark for allegedly selling branded whiskey a a price less than fixed under the provisions of the State Fair Trade Act.
The Mayor and Common Council of Englewood announced tonight they had decided to permit the erection of a sixty-eight-family garden apartment house at East Palisade Avenue and Lydecker Street,

Paul Dullzell, executive secretary of the Actors Equity Association, issued a statement yesterday correcting an\ article in the current issue of the union's magazine, Equity, in which it is said that 600 Equity members employed on the WPA Federal Theatre Project have been suspended for non-payment of dues.

Directors of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey voted yesterday to declare a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock for the second quarter of this year. In the first quarter of 1938 and last year the quarterly rate was 65 cents.

The General American Transporstation Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year a net profit of $845,372 after depreciation, interest and Federal income taxes, but before surtax on undistributed earnings.
Dr. Simon Fraser Maclennan, Professor Emeritus of Philosophy and Comparative Religion at Oberlin College, died here this morning.

Hampered by high winds, the first New Jersey one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association neverthl-ss found Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches in a low scoring mood when she took low gross honors with 41,38-79 over the third and fourth nines of the Montclair links in a field of fifty-six today.

Congress was asked by President Roosevelt today to provide $70,672,407 in deficiency and supplemental appropriations for the Treasury Department. The sum includes $56,170,000 for refunds on processing and related taxes during the present fiscal year.

Teachers cannot estimate with any degree of accuracy the intelligence or industry of their pupils merely through classroom observation, according to a survey conducted in the New York City schools, made public yesterday. Any attempt by the teacher to classify members of a class as "bright" or "dumb" is decidedly unfair, it was found.

The board of directors of the Anchor Hocking Glass Corporation, formerly the Anchor Cap Corporation, was reduced from fifteen mem- S bers to eleven at the annual meeting held yesterday at Lancaster, Ohio. Herman Krannert, L. B.

The marriage of Miss Mary Anne Vietor, daughter of Mrs. Thomas F. Vietor of 791 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Vietor, to George D. Arthur Jr., also of this city, will take place on the afternoon of June 16 in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. Bishop John T. Dallas of New Hampshire will perform the ceremony.

The organization of a labor system that employed spies and carried on a reign- of 'intimidation, fear, violence and oppression," in which politicians took their share of "easy money," all under the "full protection of city officials, was attributed yesterday to Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.
Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne received a warm welcome tonight when they revisited London after a long absence, appearing in "Amphitryon 38" at the Lyric Theatre.

Nineteen honor awards to students of Cooper Union for distinction in extracurricular activities were announced yesterday by Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, director of the Union. The awards included three silver "C's," the highest honor, and sixteen gold "C's."

The first drawn match of the Australians' cricket tour of England this year was posted today, rain canceling the last day's play against Marylebone at Lord's. The invaders have won all four previous matches by wide margins.
Princess M. Caetani di Bassanio and her daughter, Donna Lelia Caetani, have returned from Washington to the Carlyle, where they have joined Miss Cornelia Van Auken Chapin, sister of the Princess.

The University of Southern California squad, twenty-six strong, will compete in the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships at Randalls Island Stadium, June 3 and 4, once again. The Trojans' entry was received yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell, executive director of the association.

With only seventy-one deaths of pneumonia reported in the week ended last Saturday, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday that a new low record for this year had been set in the city.

The writing of new life insurance last month was 26 per cent less than in April a year ago, while the total for the first four months this year was 21.2 per cent below the same period in 1937, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in a report to the United States Department of Cbmmerce.

A miniature Coney Island, with side shows and amusement features typical of the resort a few decades ago, was set up last night at Le Coq Rouge for the Coney Island Carnival of 1910, a fate given to aid the building fund of the West Side Hospital and Dispensary.

Heavy rains in parts of Texas, where last week's official report reflected need of dry weather, exerted a steadying influence on prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and the list ended with gains of 1 to 4 points. After an early decline which carried foreign quotations to the lowest levels of the year,

More than 1,500 little girls danced around twenty-five Maypoles yesterday afternoon in the Sheep Meadow of Central Park. The fete was conducted by the girls' branch of the Public Schools Athletic League, and the girls who danced were members of afterschool athletic clubs in twenty-five Manhattan schools. Such Spring festivals have been held by the league every May since 1907.

Resenting a scattering of hisses at his declaration that he was from Jersey City, William George, and assistant Prosecutor of Hudson County, retaliated last night with an attack on the New York judiciary that caused Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag to get up from a seat in the front row and leave the room.

An order signed last Monday by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson authorizing Arthur A. Ballantine, --trustee in reorganization of theContinental Securities Corporation, to bring an action in State Supreme Court- for $3,300,000 against ninety-one defendants, was filed yesterday in the United States District Court.

Professor E. Adelaide Hahn, head of the Classics Department at Hunter College, will be the speaker at the formal chapel to be attended by Hunter College juniors and seniors this afternoon at the Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Mrs. William Litchfield McKee of Rye, N. Y., gave a luncheon here yesterday in the Garden of the Ambassador, at which she announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy E. McKee, to Vincenzo de Luca of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlo de Luca of Naples, Italy.

More than 800 persons attended tonight a dinner given by the alumni of Seton Hall in honor of Archbishop Thomas J. Walsh of Newark. Mgr. William F. Lawler, the principal speaker, gave Archbishop Walsh a silver plaque on behalf

Completion of the north tube of the Lincoln Tunnel will be deferred, partly because New Jersey has failed to construct connecting highways to supply sufficient traffic to require two tubes and partly because of "present unsatisfactory economic conditions," Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the board of the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday.
The shake-up of Britain's military planemaking machine widened today with the resignation of Lord Weir, unofficial adviser to the government on aircraft expansion since 1935.

The weather gods are piling up a lot of doubleheaders for the Yankees. Today's scheduled opener against the Browns on the first Western tour of the year for the champions was washed out, providing a doubleheader for a later visit here and the sixth twin bill on the Yankee calendar.

The detailed program sent yesterday to members of the Bond Club of New York regarding the club's eighteenth annual Field Day, to be held on June 10 at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, promises "the most delectable assortment of sense and nonsense ever assembled to tempt the jaded palates of the redink brigade."

Chairman Eccles of the Federal Reserve Board is one of the most influential advisers on economic policies in the Administration, and for that reason his talk before the New Jersey Bankers Association deserves study.

As a first move in the Independent Theatre Owners Association's drive against "double features," Harry Brandt, president of the association and head of the Brandt theatre chain in the metropolitan area, announced yesterday that on and after Aug. 15, he would install vaudeville in twenty of his houses to alternate with a single-feature film program.

Amateur boxing is expected to draw a capacity crowd of 21,000 spectators to the Chicago Stadium tomorrow night to watch the champions of Europe battle the Golden Gloves titleholders of Chicago in the seventh series of international bouts.
Lloyd Waner struck base-running Elbie Fletcher on the back today to ruin big Russ Bauers's splendid one-hit pitching performance and give the Bees a 1-to-0 victory over the Pirates.
The old Roman city of London, like the old Dutch city of New York, has increasing difficulty with traffic. Streets that served well enough a generation ago will not do now.

The capture of more than a dozen rare spiders of a species that for seventy-five years was regarded as extinct and of which only six speci.mens had been found since 1912 was announced yesterday by the American Museum of Natural History.
Steel ingot production held steady last week in face of a downward seasonal trend, and the adjusted index rose to 40.4 from 40.0. The figure for the week ended May 15, 1937, was 121.3.

Owners of King's Park here have decided not to operate this year under the present provincial taxation, Leo Dandurand said tonight. Dandurand announced last night that unless taxes were lowered the two Montreal tracks

Francis A. Donnelly, member of the executive committee of the Mercantile Exchange of New York, died last night at his home here after a two-week illness. His age was 54. Mr. Donnelly, who was born in Newark, was employed for twenty years with the commission firm of M. Augenblick Co. there.
There is cause for both hope and misgiving on the part of the air transport industry in the McCarran bill to establish a Civil Aeronautics Authority.
Minnie Dupree, Broadway character actress, was engaged by Selznick-International today for the role of Ellen Fortune; for which Maude Adams and Dorothy Gish were tested, in "The Young in Heart."
Shabbily dressed reliefers" sat hour after hour today in Cleveland's City Council chamber, applauding pleas for restoration of full food orders and reading-newspapers.

J. Edgar Hoover analyzed the economics of crime protection for the several hundred delegates at the closing session of the triennial convention of the General Federation of Women's Clubs here tonight. He gave statistics from the records of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which he directs.

The New York Public Library has reopened for the fourth season the Open-Air Reading Room in Bryant Park. The outdoor library is a cooperative effort of the Park Department, New York Public Library, WPA and the National Youth Administration.

Criticism of Police Commissioner Valentine of New York City for failure to take action on all forms of bingo playing in the city was expressed by George D. Egbert, president of the Society for the Prevention of Crime,

President Roosevelt served notice on Washington correspondents today that he would have nothing to say publicly on developments in State primary contests or candidates' claims of his support, even if that course led to erroneous interpretation of the White House attitude.

Physicians here attending the 172nd annual meeting of the Medical Society of New Jersey in the Hotel Ambassador are agreed that organized medicine must take the lead in working out medical care which the public can afford or the government will take over the work.
Alexander D. Snow of this city has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Margaret Ann Snow, to Robert W. Cambreleng, son of Mrs. Gaston P. Cambreleng of Orange and the late Mr. Cambreleng.

Continuing his gibes at the Board of Education's Bureau of Construction and Maintenance, Mayor La Guardia, in dedicating two new schools in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, declared he was not at all satisfied with the way the schools were maintained.

Manhattan's millions turned eyes aloft yesterday morning as the units of the Army Air Corps roared overhead in a mighty demonstration of the equipment and personnel, which for the last few days have been repelling an imaginary enemy.

Bill McGee, who plays first (and only) violin for Pepper Martin's Musical Mudcats, pulled some mournful notes from his fiddle strings, in spite of the Cardinals' 2-1 triumph at Ebbets Field, when he took part in a radio broadcast last night.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,362,300 barrels, compared with 3,382,350 in the previous week, a decline of 20,050, according to the -American- Petroleum Institute. Production was. 44,200 barrels more than the calculation

China will win its war against Japan, Dr. Chenting T. Wang, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, predicted last night at a dinner at the Hotel Pierre commemorating China's "Democracy Day"the twenty-fifth anniversary of the recognition of the Republic of China in the United States.

Major Robert A. Greenfield, architect and engineer, died here Sunday night at his home after a short illness. As an architect he had done work on the Custom House and General Postoffice in New York and the Postoffice in Pittsburgh.

The Justice Department, a spokesman said today,' will propose "in the very near future" a second grand jury investigation of the country's three largest automobile manufacturers and their associated finance companies.

Mrs. Caroline Deckinger Siegler, who was 94 years old last Sunday, died yesterday morning at her home, 15 West Eleventh Street, where she lived with her daughter, Mrs. Amelia Abrams. On her ninetieth birthday she received letters of congratulation from President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia.
Mrs. Catherine Una Macpherson MacNeil Merriam, widow of Major Gen. Henry Clay Merriam, U. S. A., died yesterday morning at her residence, 530 East Eighty-sixth Street.

Trading in traefer meats was fair to good and prices steady to higher. Early trading in kosher meats was fairly dependable for veal and lamb, though common and medium veal moved rather slowly at some points, beef generally slow.

Labor's share of the sales dollar of the steel industry last year was five times as large as the share of stockholders plus the amount added to surplus, whereas in 1929 labor's share was only 2 1/2 times as large as that of stockholders, according to a survey of the American Iron

William McC. Martin Jr., 31-yearold chairman of the board of governors and acting president of the New York Stock Exchange, plunged yesterday into the task of reorganizing the Exchange along the lines set down by the new constitution.

Max Schmeling, en route to Speculator, N. Y., to begin training for his heavyweight championship fight with Joe Louis on June 22, stepped off a train here tonight and confidently predicted that he would repeat his 1936 victory over the Brown Bomber.

No settlement on a financing plan was reached yesterday at a meeting between the Board of Commissioners of the Everglades Drainage District, Florida; representatives of nine of the leading landowners of the district, and the Florida Everglades Bondholders Protective Committee, it was announced by H. C. Rorick, chairman of the bondholders' committee.
Owing to the falling birth rate the Pilgrim Trust is assisting Queen Charlotte's Maternity Hospital in research on puerperal fever, according to the trustees' annual report, issued tonight.

The Chinese and Japanese today charged each other with duplicity in the air. The Chinese said three Japanese planes, painted with Chinese colors, bombed Liuling, on the Hupeh-Honan border, killing thirty persons.

Efforts that have been made in the United States to fix minimum prices in order to prevent unfair competition have proved ineffective, the 1937 annual report of Sofina (Societe Financiere de Transports et d'Entreprises Industrielles), released yesterday, sets forth.

Bobby Stap, 13 years old, was placed in the shelter of the Queens Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children in Jamaica yesterday after his return from Southern ports on the City of Chattanooga, on which he had stowed away.
Combining effective hitting with Paul Derringer's four-hit pitching, Cincinnati today scored an easy 13-1 victory over the Phillies. It was Derringer's fourth victory of the season.

Mrs. J. Francis A. Clark gave a dinner last night in the Roof Garden of the Pierre for Mr. and Mrs. Ogden H. Hammond, Mrs. Leonard M. Thomas, Mr. and Mrs. Jorge R. Andre, Williams Burden and Joseph Earle Stevens.
Governor George H. Earle, who campaigned for the Democratic Senatorial nomination with the reputed political ambitions of John L. Lewis as the chief target

F. E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, was selected yesterday to be chairman of the Eastern Presidents Conference in succession to L. F. Loree, who held the position many years.

Starting a movement for closer trade and cultural relations between Brazil and the United States, Diario de Noticias, one of the leading morning newspapers of Rio de Janeiro, will publish twenty-four special editions, beginning July 4, devoted to United States affairs.

Opposition on patriotic grounds to the reported plan of the Texas Corporation to capture control of the McCollFrontenac Oil Company was launched tonight by Nesbitt, Thomson Co., who have financed the oil company since its inception.

A Senate Naval Affairs subcommittee today listened for an hour to a plea that Congress enact a law restoring a former midshipman to the class of 1938 at the Naval Academy, with "all the rights, privileges and benefits to which he would have been entitled had he not resigned."

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Federal Court, Brooklyn, signed an order yesterday directing United States Attorney Michael F. Walsh and William E. Collins; special assistant to the United States Attorney, to serve notice on the officials of the Munson Steamship Company and officers of the steamship Southern Cross of that line that the government has filed a foreclosure suit of a preferred mortgage of $769,500 against the vessel.

Donald Symington, president of the Baltimore Mail Line, announced today that the company would cease transatlantic steamship operations on May 26 unless its Federal operating subsidy was increased to $1,000,000 a year.

Following a two-day trial by a general court-martial on Governors Island, Captain Herbert L. Berry, Quartermaster Corps, United States Army, who had worked his way up from the ranks of the National Guard, was sentenced yesterday afternoon to dismissal from the service. He was found guilty of embezzling about $2,000.

At the closing session of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers convention today President Sidney Hillman called on the delegates to unite in making the labor movement represented by the Committee for Industrial Organization as strong as possible for the sake of labor as a whole.

A funeral service for Edward T. Stotesbury, the Philadelphia financier, who died of a heart attack last night, will be held at 2:30 P. M. on Thursday at Whitemarsh Hall, the Stotesbury estate in Chestnut
The Senate today passed and sent to the White House a bill by Senator La Follette providing for a long-term study of venereal diseases and establishment of a program to control them.

Mariano Fanti, 37-year-old feather exporter, was convicted of firstdegree manslaughter by a blue-ribbon jury in Kings County Court last night in the slaying of his secretary and business partner, Mrs. Bertha Nolan, while they were in his parked car at Eighty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, Brooklyn, on Dec. 5.

When Chancellor Adolf Hitler came to power Germany's public debt amounted in round figures to 24,000,000,000 marks and her foreign debt to 20,000,000,000 marks. Now her public debt is estimated at more than 55,000,000,000 marks, while her foreign debt has been reduced to, roughly, 9,000,000,000 marks.
Many high-goal polo players swung into action for the first time this season as two Meadow Brook Club members' matches took place at the Phipps Estate today. William Post's Red four turned back

Professional golfers will find $27,000 prize money in California's tournaments next Winter. Clifford L. Rawson, chairman of the California Association of Open Golf Tournament Sponsors, announced today the following schedule:

The list of the French liner Normandie, leaving today for Havre via Southampton, includes Dr. Diogenes Escalante, Minister of Venezuela to the United States; Jules S. Bache, S. Hilmer Lundbeck, Miss Diana Barrymore, Mr. and Mrs. Max Gordon, Marquis de Suarez d'Aulan and the Marquise, G. Russell Allen, P. Durand-Ruel, Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Pannill, Joseph Upton, Tilly Losch, Brian Aherne and Aiden Roark.
The Brooklyn College tennis team crushed Manhattan, 8-1, yesterday at the Culver courts in Brooklyn. The Kingsmen took every set but one in the singles and took two of the three doubles matches.

William Ward Willett, an early operator in the coal fields of West Virginia,. who until recently was actively identified with coal and shipping concerns in New York and Boston, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

The suggestion that Great Britain join with the United States in raising the embargo on the export of arms to the Spanish Government was firmly rejected today by a government spokesman in the House of Commons.
A rather perplexed Senate has just dumped back onto the lap of its Judiciary Committee a measure that raises the issue of the excessive Federalizing of the United States, all forty-eight of them.

A $100,000 check, the gift of the estate of the late Jacob Fox, former president of the Owners and Tenants Electric Company, Inc., was presented yesterday to the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and the National Coordinating Committee for Aid to Refugees and Emigrants Coming From Germany.

Leading a field of eight, of which six are eligible for the Kentucky Oaks, Cross Keys, 3-year-old filly from the stable of Midkiff and Wells, captured the feature event today at Churchill Downs. The favorite, Shining Heels,

Strict application of the provisions of the Wheeler-Lea law, governing advertising, to those few companies "who choose to disregard their responsibilities" was promised yesterday by R. E. Freer of the Federal Trade Commission in an address before the annual convention of the Proprietary Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

Italy, facing the poorest wheat harvest in years, took steps today to increase the percentage of wheat substitutes in flour. In conformity with the program of the Ministry of Corporations, a number of regional wheat councils, including that of Milan,

The silver cup for athletics at the College of Mount St. Vincent has been won by the class of 1940 for the second year in succession, it was announced yesterday. The sophomore class scored a total of 149 points during the scholastic year and received its prize at the field day held on the campus at Riverdale.

Depression conditions make imperative the expansion of all private health and welfare agencies, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, commissioner of hospitals, declared yesterday in a statement issued through the Greater New York Fund, which is seeking $10,000,000 to supplement the finances of the city's private charities.

Senate and House today accepted a conference report creating sixteen new Federal judgeships in addition to providing for the appointment of three judges for districts in which the first vacancies to follow their confirmation shall not be filled.
Curtis High's nine clinched the Richmond Division P. S. A. L. championship yesterday by topping Port Richmond, 3 to 2, at Curtis Field. The victory was Curtis's fifth in a row in the tournament.

Miss Hephzibah Menuhin, who at the age of 18 is already a brilliant pianist and has given joint recitals with her older brother, the violinist, Yehudi Menuhin, announced her engagement today to Lindsay George Nicholas of Melbourne, Australia, whose sister, Miss Nola Nicholas, will soon be married to Yehudi.

A source close to Premier Edouard Daladier said today that Jules Blondel, French Charge d'Affaires in Rome, had been instructed to convey to the Italian Government an expression of "French surprise" over Premier Benito Mussolini's remarks at Genoa Saturday.
The Maritime Commission opened bids today for the construction of four steel cargo steamships, to be among the fastest of their class afloat.
Efforts by the railroads to cut basic wage rates 15 per cent threatened today to block legislation to authorize further loans to the carriers by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
The Federal Housing Administration now. has extended its mortgage-insurance operations to include rural properties as well as city and suburban homes.
California Institute of Technology has received a $300,000 grant from the Rockefeller Foundation for studying substances that link living and non-living things.

Eight witnesses, either directors or producer-members of the Metropolitan Cooperative Milk Bargaining Agency, declared their approval of a proposed Federal-State milk-marketing agreement at a hearing here today.

IT is exactly one hundred years since John Muir, that peculiar combination of sentimentality and hardheadedness, was born in Scotland, and nearly twenty-four years since he died in California. Out of the combination came sound scientific work, a series of fine books, and a great public service.

James Lavin, 31-year-old ex-convict, who had boasted frequently during his fifteen months' confinement in the Tombs Prison that he would be acquitted of the slaying of another former felon, only to find himself convicted yesterday afternoon of second-degree murder, committed suicide last night in his Tombs cell.

Nine suits to enjoin retail packaged liquor dealers from cutting the prices of trade mark brands were instituted yesterday in Supreme Court. In eight of the actions Schenley Distributors, Inc., and Schenley Import Corporation were plaintiffs.

The Maryland Hunt Cup committee announced today it would campaign for the training of a larger number of jumping horses to offset the small entry lists in important society races during the recent season.
Manhattan journeyed to Brooklyn College yesterday to repeat the victory it had scored over the Kingsmen on the Jasper diamond in April.

Driving past her opposition in the last furlong, Handcuff, bred by C. V. Whitney but yesterday carrying the colors of Mrs. Dodge Sloane, captured the $12,900 Acorn Stakes by half a length at Belmont Park. Made the favorite at 11 to 10,

E. O. DeCamp, vice president of the Williamson Heater Company, died at Good Samaritan Hospital today after a long illness. His age was 63. Mr. DeCamp had served with the heater company more than thirtyfive years. Before entering the business world he was a school

American public sentiment is almost evenly divided on the question, now being debated in the New York Constitutional Assembly, whether States should conduct lotteries to help pay the cost of government.

That he had seen General Saturnino Cedillo, the weakened war lord of San Luis Potosi, at his home on his ranch of Las Palomas today was reported by a correspondent of El Universal, Enrique Torres Quniga, who asserted General Cedillo had said:

The District Attorneys of New York City, Kings, Bronx and Queens Counties have started a series of conferences aimed at evolving a collective position on proposed reforms before the State Constitutional Convention concerning the work and structure of the city's criminal courts and prosecuting agencies, it was learned yesterday.

In a report in THE NEW YORK TIMES on May 14 concerning the illness of Bernard Devine, one of the judges of the outdoor art exhibit, it was said that a wait of twenty minutes occurred before the arrival of an ambulance.

Miss Jean Macintyre, actress, who appeared with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne in "Idiot's Delight," and Jo Mielziner, scenic designer, will be married at the end of this month, it was announced yesterday. After their marriage the couple expect to go abroad.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 16: BRIGADIER GENERAL Krueger, W., relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corps, Washington, D. C., June 30, and assigned to command the 16th Inf. Brigade, Fort George G. Meade, Md.

Mr. and Mrs. Roscoe C. E. Brown of 164 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Stanley Brown, to Alfred Milton Payne Amey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Amey, also of Brooklyn Heights.

W. R. Bull, a trustee of the American Founders Corporation, testified today that the company, established in 1922 with $500 paid-in capital, had issued $828,000 of capital securities by the end of 1924. He was a witness at a hearing of the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with its general study of investment companies.

Buildings on both sides of Manhattan, from Greenwich Village to Harlem, figured in the realty trading announced yesterday. The twenty-family tenement at 316 East Sixty-second Street, a fivestory building on a plot 25 by 100.5 feet, was sold by the Bank of New York and Trust Company to the Lakeland Developing Corporation through George F. Meyer Co., Inc., brokers.

A country only a fortnight ago in the depths of financial crisis has oversubscribed a huge new defense loan in a single morning. Its Minister of Finance had planned to go on the air at noon to launch an appeal to patriotic sentiment in behalf of the loan, but by the time he reached the microphone the entire issue had been absorbed.
Pressure from within the Republican party, from the down-State leaders whose districts would gain under a reapportionment,...

The colorful gardens and rolling woodlands of some of Westchester's most beautiful estates were visited yesterday by 300 women members of the National Council of State Garden Clubs as the group, representing forty States, opened its ninth annual convention. Sessions will be held until tomorrow evening at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Mr. and Mrs. Huntington Choate Atwater of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Trumbull Atwater, to Dr. Walter Lynwood Heaver, son of Mrs. Maude Blackford Heaver of Oakland, Calif.

More than 400 new subscriptions for the 1938-39 season of the Metropolitan Opera Association were made yesterday from 9 A. M., when the box office opened for general seat sale, to the afternoon, it was reported by Earle Lewis, treasurer and assistant general manager of the Metropolitan.

Bertram M. Campbell, 51 years old, a former associate member of several stock brokerage concerns, was found guilty yesterday by a General Sessions jury of being the "front" for a clever gang of forgers, the leaders of which thus far have not been uncovered. Campbell, who said his home is at Baldwin, L. I., was remanded to the Tombs by Judge Charles C. Nott for sentence on May 26.

In the first general television demonstration for the press in seven months, the National Broadcasting Company was host yesterday to 1,000 representatives of newspapers in a series of twenty-five-minute programs that ran throughout the afternoon and evening.
The Book-of-the-Month Club has chosen as its July book "Fanny Kemble: a Passionate Victorian," by Margaret Armstrong. The biography will be published by Macmillan on June 28.

At the twenty-second annual meeting of the Women's City Club, held last night at the clubhouse in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, Mrs. Samuel Sloan Duryee was re-elected president for a two-year term.

The Republican attitude on the problem of labor relations was clarified today as the Constitutional Convention's committee on the bill of rights killed four proposals regarded as too broad in scope, and a Republican-sponsored joint legislative committee,

President Roosevelt said today he had turned over to Attorney General Cummings for his consideration complaints made against Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President in 1936, and Representative Jerry J. O'Connell of Montana.
Seven adults and two children were feared dead tonight in a giant airliner unreported since 2 P.M. (P. S. T.) yesterday. A dense fog blocked land and air searchers.

Stock Exchange Stocks closed at irregularly higher levels after a slightly lower opening; turnover, 416,060 shares. Hudson Manhattan Railroad bonds strong, United States Government and other issues irregularly lower; transactions, $5,189,900.

John Urie, 84 years old, who was associated with Thomas A. Edison in the early development of the motion picture, died yesterday afternoon at the Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge. Mr. Urie, long a resident of Bayonne, N. J., came here a month ago to visit his son, Albert. He was taken to the hospital three weeks ago.

Lowered waistlines, a tendency toward "portrait" fashions of historic inspiration, and a preference for mat-surfaced fabrics were among the Fall style trends stressed in a showing of twenty-three costumes by American designers, held yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Savoy-Plaza before an audience of 300 stylists, merchandising executives and fashion writers under the sponsorship of A. Wimpfheimer Bro., Inc.

The Court of Appeals today ruled against the presentation in this State of a motion picture, "Tomorrow's Children," which deals with sterilization of the unfit. Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane and Judge Irving Lehman dissented.

New York State bowlers had an entire new set of champions and two new all-time records to shoot at today. With the Marksonz Furniture team of Syracuse formally crowned five-man champions at the tourney wound up last night,
Out where the lights are shining, out where the people shout, the mighty Casey himself-remember?-goes tomorrow night to show the prankish Orioles how he struck out.
There is no sign of modification in the Henleinists' anti-Czech campaign despite well-substantiated reports of grave warnings given in London to Konrad Henlein, their leader, against its continuance.

The manager of a local motionpicture theatre is scheduled to appear tomorrow before Police Recorder Albert L. Vreeland here to answer a charge that he violated a New Jersey statute by showing "The Birth of a Nation, D. W. Griffith's film classic of more than two decades ago.

Dismissal of the complaint of the city of Philadelphia that the rates of railroads to Philadelphia were prejudicial to that port and preferential to other ports of the Eastern seaboard was recommended today to the Interstate Commerce Commission in a report by Charles M. Bardwell, examiner.

Spanish Insurgent shock troops today smashed through government defense lines in Castellon and Teruel Provinces. Mountain units on Generalissimo Francisco Franco's right wing fought through the hills around Penarroya Peak, east of Teruel.

Republicans and Democrats alike polled close to two-thirds of their total registered strength at yesterday's primary, but the edge was with the Republicans as they turned out in unexpected numbers to back Judge Arthur H. James for Governor against former Governor Gifford Pinchot, attacked as a "New Dealer" and "pro-Lewis candidate."

Lambs and hogs sold considerably higher in an active trade today, the United States Department of Agriculture reported. California springers sold up to $9.80 and the bog top moved up to $8.75. The fed steer and yearling trade softened up a bit, following a set of higher markets late last week and early this week.

A few minutes before the scheduled opening of a trial of two men on charges of forcing three women into compulsory prostitution, one defendant tried to end his life with a razor yesterday in a restaurant across the street from the Criminal Courts Building, at Lafayette and Franklin Streets.

Alf M. Landon, Republican Presidential nominee in 1936, expressed the opinion this afternoon that the big Republican primary vote in Pennsylvania augured a Republican victory in that State in November.

Ordway Tead, author and teacher, who was appointed to the Board of Higher Education last October, was elected chairman of the board last night at its annual election meeting at the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

Major Ferenc Szalasi, leader of the most outspoken branch of the Hungarian Nazis, is ready to withdraw from political life. A statement to this effect was made in Parliament today by an extreme Right Deputy,

Several backyard gardens and solaria in this city will be opened to the public today for the second in the series of garden visits arranged in the interests of the School Nature League. Mrs. Howard S. Cullman is chairman of the garden days committee.

Buyers for a number of Southern dry goods wholesale houses were in the market yesterday, seeking offprice merchandise. While they did little buying, most of them were expected to remain through the week and to make moderate purchases.
Gerald M. Loeb and Gordon B. Crary have resigned from the New York Stock Exchange firm of E. F. Hutton Co., the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
Both chambers of Parliament today passed a law legalizing abortion in a number of cases in which it was not previously permitted. Apart from medical reasons, abortion will be allowed for

The largest crowd ever to witness amateur boxing indoors, 22,234 spectators, saw the Chicago Golden Gloves championship team triumph over the European champions, 5 bouts to 3, in the Chicago Stadium tonight.

Appointment of Forest H. Akers as vice president in charge of sales of the Dodge Division of the Chrysler Corporation and of Frank J. Timmens as general sales manager was announced yesterday by W. J. O'Neil, vice president and general manager of the company.
Dr. Martha M. Eliot, assistant chief of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor, declared here yesterday that 60 to 75 per cent of the maternity deaths in this country were preventable.

Fires in four different sections of. Brooklyn yesterday caused injuries to seven men, drove fourteen families from their homes and routed sixty persons, mostly women and children, from a theatre. Three of the fires resulted in extra alarms.
More than 350 pianists from 4 to 24 years old will compete in the New York section of the fifth annual national piano-playing tournament at the Hotel Biltmore from June 1-4.

A cooperative effort by the drug industry to simplify and modernize the regulatory control of the manufacture and sale of its products throughout the country was urged by James F. Hoge, counsel to the Proprietary Association, at the organization's annual convention, which closed yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.

Five airplane pilots on their way from Newark airport to Floyd Bennett Field were rescued from Jamaica Bay yesterday afternoon after their cabin monoplane had fallen into a spin at 500 feet and dived into the bay, trapping them in twenty feet of water.

Mrs. Harriet Stewart Dawson, 57-year-old widow of a wealthy Australian business man, gave notice at the London registry office today of her intention to marry Prince Michael Radziwill, elderly Polish descendant of the Hohenzollerns.

A feeling of confidence in the future has been created in Southern Spain by General Francisco Franco's new decree acknowledging the liabilities of the treasury's public bonds and promising that all interest accruing after next July 1 will be met by the Insurgent government.

Fair-trade contracts of the Philco Radio and Television Corporation for the 1939 season have been completed and will be issued early in June, it was said yesterday by H. R. Sheer, general manager of the company here.

At least forty of the city's most eminent lawyers, whose private court fees reach up to $1,000 daily, will be among those on the "senior" panel of volunteer defense counsel to appear henceforth in General Sessions trials of defendants unable to engage counsel.

Cardinal Hayes, assisted by high church officials, dedicated yesterday Mary Moran Hall, a $250,000 classroom and residence building at Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, Convent Avenue and 133d Street.

A nation-wide campaign was opened yesterday by the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, to enlist the support of other bar associations and civic bodies for a bill introduced by Representative Emmanuel Celler to create a permanent commission to study and advise on constitutional amendments.

Ransom Cooper Jr., through Brown, Wheelock, Hairis, Stevens, Inc, in 142 E 7st St; J. Taylor Woodward, in 530 E 88th St; Ruth Banta, Katherine Brown and Margaret Halt, in 192 E 75th St: Harry S. Gels. In 49 E 86th St; Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc. broker.

A gift of $25,000 from the Charles Hayden Foundation to Stevens Institute of Technology, to be expended in scholarships for boys of the New York and Boston metropolitan districts, was announced tonight by Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of the school, at an alumni dinner in' his honor at Jacobus Hall, here. Dr.

Claire Murray, a Barnard College senior, has received a fellowship for study in Italy from the college, in cooperation with the American-Italian Student Exchange. Miss Murray is a resident student from Atlantic City, N. J. She will enter the University of Rome this Fall with the fellowship, which provides tuition and maintenance for her there.

The first of the explanations which the Department of Justice has promised to make regarding its reason for anti-trust prosecutions came today when Attorney General Cummings stated that new prosecutions of the three major automobile financing companies would be attempted next week at South Bend, Ind.
The Brooklyn campaign of the American ORT Federation was started last night at a testimonial dinner in the Jewish Center, 667 Eastern Parkway, to Max Herzfeld, chairman of the Brooklyn drive.
Trouble aboard Britain's 9,975-ton cruiser. Dorsetshire was disclosed today in a guarded announcement by the Admiralty that eight seamen. had deserted at Sydney, Australia.
A Federal grand jury indicted today seven persons, three of them former Hot Springs officials, on charges of harboring Alvin Karpis, once Public Enemy No. 1.

The first United States Government air mail flight, made from Nassau Boulevard here to Mineola as a "stunt" on Sept. 23, 1911, will be re-enacted tomorrow in conjunction with the Air Mail Week celebration.

The advantages to property owners of the five-year tax exemption offered by this city and the finencing available through the FHA and the Prior Lien Law will be explained in a speaking campaign covering the five boroughs of the city, Bernard F. Hogan, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Property Improvement, annourled yesterday.

Luther Martin 3d, a trustee of the University of Pennsylvania and president of the General Alumni Society, was the guest of honor last night at the fiftieth annual dinner of the University of Pennsylvania Club at 37 East Thirty-sixth Street.

Miss Priscilla Minor Allen, daughter of Mrs. Mabel Burlingame Allen of this place, was married this afternoon in the First Congregational Church to Charles Bertus Lauren, son of Bertus C. Lauren of Oneonta, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Roy C. Houghton.

Chinese military leaders here contend the main Japanese forces attacking the Lung-Hai Railway are still held by the defense lines forty-five miles north and forty-five miles south of the railway and that the small raiding parties which had been attacking points on the railway from the main Japanese positions had been repulsed.

The conference of the National Missionary Organization of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America opened here tonight, attended by 500 women, with Mrs. William L. Darby of Washington, D. C., presiding. She was assisted by Mrs. Vincent T. Shipley of Philadelphia.

Thomas Mann, exiled German novelist and Nobel Prize winner, and Mayor La Guardia will take part this afternoon in the laying of the cornerstone for the Palestine Pavilion at the 1939 World's Fair, Meyer W. Weisgal, director of the exhibit, announced yesterday.

Netiations have almost been completed between the British Exports Credit Department and the commission of Turkish bankers who arrived in London in February for a credits agreement with Turkey involving the sum of [Pound]16,000,000.

Editorial comment gathered from key cities in the United States indicated a general impression that the outcome of the Pennsylvania primaries was a rebuke to both the New Deal leaders and John L. Lewis. These comments were as follows:

Reports of the release of Baron Louis Rothschild, financier and former president of the Credit Anstalt, prove baseless. The writer learns that he is still held for questioning about alleged irregularities connected with his financial support of the former regime.
Victor Morawetz, New York and Baltimore lawyer, died here early today at the age of 79. He was stricken with a heart attack a week ago.

Municipal Court Justice Arthur P. McNulty was held in contempt of the State Legislature yesterday when he refused to testify in regard to the Gerson name-changing case at a public hearing of the McNaboe Joint Legislative Committee at the County Court House.

Women's organizations were aroused here tonight as Joseph Bauer, Civil War veteran and long-time G. A. R. marshal of the city's Memorial Day parades, renewed a stand taken last year inwhich he refused to permit women in the parade.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months to April 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all operating expenses, taxes and charges of $23,275,320.

The marriage of Miss Helen Newbold Trotter, daughter of Mrs. Theodore Van Antwerp Trotter and the late Mr. Trotter, to Colonel Albert Gilmor, U. S. A., son of the late Judge and Mrs. Robert Gilmor of Baltimore, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, 136 East Thirty-seventh Street.

John Howes Burton, chairman of the East River-Thirty-eighth Street Tunnel committee, made public yesterday a letter he had written to Mayor La Guardia asking support for a direct roadway connection from the Queens end of the QueensMidtown Tunnel to the Junction of Horace Harding Boulevard and Queens Boulevard.
The big weakfish are in Peconia Bay. This isn't just an idle rumor, it's an actual fact, so if you don't take any big ones this week-end mark it down to the weather or the wrong location.

BACHRACH FLORA (Sept. 21, 1935). Gross assets, $108,588; net, $70,670. ToWilliam Bachrach, husband, household effects and life estate in one-half residue; Marion B. Fisch, daughter, silver, jewelry, wearing apparel and life estate in onehalf residue and remainder in other onehalf of residue. Chief assets, real estate, $48,533. Arnstein Levy, attorneys, 30 Broad St.

A. Thornton Baker, a Princeton, N. J., business man who turned skipper, brought his 72-foot schooner So Fong into port here yesterday after a voyage that lasted thirteen months and took him and his crew into some of the most exotic ports on the globe.

Julius Gerber, 22 years old, of 60 West' Ninety-second Street, Manhattan, was held in $50,000 bail for trial when he pleaded not guilty yesterday before Kings County Judge John J. Fitzgerald to an indictment charging robbery, grand larceny and assault in the first degree.

Finance Minister Paolo Thaon di Revel, speaking before the Chamber today at the conclusion of the debate on his Ministry's budget, indicated that Italy's rearmament program was approaching completion for he foresaw that no further appropriations on this score would be necessary after June 30, 1941.
Only 92 per cent of the vote was cast in the Dominican Republic election for President Trujillo's candidate to succeed

Thomas McKelvey's chestnut gelding Arapal beat Mrs. J. W. Y. Martin's Comonhome by a nose in the grueling three and a half mile Bayard Taylor Plate Steeplechase at the opening of the Rose Tree hunts meeting today. Mrs. Martin's Dartforth was third. The finish, one of the closest seen here in years, thrilled 2,500 spectators.

The services of eight United States Army aviators as technical instructors of the Argentine Air Corps were provided today in an arrangement concluded by the State Department and Argentina, with the approval of the War Department.

Albert Marinelli, former New York County Clerk and Tammany leader of the Second Assembly District, was placed on trial yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, before Judge Marcus B. Campbell and a jury on an indictment charging him with harboring Charles Falci while the latter was a fugitive from justice under Federal indictment for election frauds.

A bullet fired by an unknown person passed through the body of a woman walking near her home in East 114th Street shortly after 10 o'clock last night and then wounded two men who were chatting on the sidewalk a few feet away. Mrs.

The marriage of Miss Josephine Percy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Percy of this city, to Philip Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Carson Smith of St. Louis, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Church of the. Incarnation. The ceremony was performed by the assistant rector, the Rev. Frederick W. Golden-Howse.

Fifth Avenue's celebrated retail district soon will have a new row of modern shops. Plans for a group of five stores in the well-known Hotel Gotham, built a generation ago at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street as a quiet residential hotel, will mean the end of the Renaissance room there.

The first disqualification of the metropolitan acing season occurred yesterday at Belmont Park and gave Magic Hour the victory in the Pillory Purse after he had finished a head behind Efface, carrying T. H. Somerville's colors.

Officers of the Reynolds Investing Company, Inc., were ordered yesterday to show cause on May 25 why a creditors' petition seeking reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act should not be approved.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Attorney General Cummings said today the Justice Department "very shortly" would file a $3,000,000 suit against New York City, as a result of Mayor La Guardia's failure to recognize a government claim in connection with the purchase of a postoffice site.

Payson Nicholas singled in the ninth to score Al Cox with the winning run as the Lehigh baseball team downed Rutgers, 5 to 4, before 200 fans on Neilson Field today. The victory was Lehigh's first over the Scarlet since 1936 and evened the series this year, Rutgers having triumphed previously, 8 to 4.

The Washington Square College Alumni Association, at a meeting held last night at the college, 32 Waverly Place, voted to return to membership in the New York University Alumni Federation, after having left it three years ago.

The export copper markets' were erratic yesterday. After some sales had been made as low as 9.30 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, a new low for this year, prices recovered to around 9.425 cents. Some sales were made early as high as 9.50 cents.
A Senate appropriations subcommittee completed today its executive hearings on the 1938 relief-recovery bill. The measure is expected to be before the Senate for debate by Monday.

Mr. and Mrs. A. D. Lawrence Jewett 2d of Nyack, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna deBaun Foss Jewett, to Thomas Howard Wolf, son of Mrs. Louis Ellinger of Valley Cottage, N. Y., and James Stanley Wolf of this city.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, third largest C. I. O. affiliate, with a membership of 250,000, yesterday attributed the defeat of the C. I. O. in the Pennsylvania primary to the war between the A. F. of L. and the C. I. O. and declared that the primary result made peace between the two labor factions more imperative.
Rear Admiral Charles Philip Snyder, U.S.N., president of the Naval War College, and Mrs. Snyder have come from Newport to the Vanderbilt.

Now that the dust has cleared away, it is evident that another C. I. 0. campaign has come a cropper. In Pennsylvania on Tuesday, as in Detroit last Fall and more recently in Seattle, the attempt to use industrial unionism as a means of acquiring political power has failed ingloriously.

W. R. Bull, a trustee of the American Founders Corporation, testified today that, but for the taking up of optioned shares of an affiliate at a valuation in excess of costs, the company would have been unable to pay dividends from 1922 to 1924.

After an acrimonious session which ended in a threat of court action, the Board of Education at a special meeting yesterday afternoon ousted Walter C. Martin, Superintendent of School Buildings for the last ten years, from his $25,000 a year post.

Although absence of rain and higher temperatures yesterday brought improved weather conditions in the Southwest, trading on the Cotton Exchange again reflected a demand for contracts that sustained -prices and left the list with gains of 1 to 3 points.

Declaring that stockholders should not be divested lightly of their control of a corporation's policies, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora dismissed yesterday injunction proceedings brought by three small shareholders in the Bethlehem Steel Corporation to restrain officers and directors of the company from submitting for consideration at a stockholders' meeting today a proposal to revoke the management stock ownership plan promulgated in 1930.
Director control of the Illinois Central Railroad was shifted from New York to Chicago today when members of the board held their first meeting at the railroad's general offices here.
Sales of real estate announced yesterday in Manhattan included deals for tenement houses which will be renovated by the purchasers.

Interest in the bond section on the New York Stock Exchange failed to hold up yesterday, as the entire list, with the exception of the Treasury issues and some scattered. loans, gave a highly uneven performance. Sales aggregated $4,632,900, compared with $5,189,900 on Tuesday.
Franco-Italian ngotiations were said to have approached a breakdown today for two reasons-Italian pressure on Tunisia and Soviet Russia's pressure on France to let supplies pass to government Spain.

The four-story structure at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 113th Street, formerly occupiedd by Beth David Hospital, vas sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. It was Ought in by the West Side Savings Bank for $30,000.

Senator Lucien Hubert, former French delegate to the League of Nations and Minister of Justice in Andr6 Tardieu's first Cabinet, formed Nov. 2, 1929, died yesterday. He was 70 years old and had been a member of Parliament since 1897.
The Treasury Procurement Division today announced awards of contracts for 2,726,185 yards of textiles for delivery July 8 from bids opened May 11. The awards follow:

The United States Steel Company petitioned the United States Circuit Court of Appeals today to forestall any penalties which might be inflicted because of noncompliance with an order issued in 1924 by the Federal Trade Commission against what the commission termed the "Pittsburgh plus practice."
Anton Lang, who played the Christ three times in the Oberammergau Passion Play, died in a private clinic here tonight at the age of 63. He had been operated upon for a stomach ailment.

Notman Lila Estates, Inc., operators, bought from the builder the five-and-one-half-story - apartment house at 2,332 Walton Avenue in the West Bronx. They paid cash over a first mortgage of $37,500 at 4 1/2 per cent. Nehring Bros., Inc., negotiated the sale,, and Jesse H. Barkin represented the buyers.

Two Army varsity teams recorded triumphs today, the Cadet nine gaining a 3-2 decision over Amherst in a thrilling baseball game, while the West Point tennis players vanquished Yale, 6--2, with one of the doubles matches being unfinished. The Army plebes were turned back by the strong Lawrenceville School polo unit, 7-3, in a fast game on Howze Field.
A third romance in the musical Menuhin family became known today with the announcement of the engagement of Yehudi's 16-year-old sister, Yaltah, to William Stix of St. Louis.

To Probationary School The following members shall be directed to report at the Probationary Firemen's School, Manhattan, from 8:50 A. M., Monday, May 23, for thirty school days, to complete their required course of training.
A mortgage for $12,000 on 1,952 Park Ave, held by the trustees of the will of Robert J. Armstrong, from Jacob Chaimowitz, was extended to May 1, 1943; 4 per cent.

Astronomers describe a place, Seen through a crack in the vault of Space, So dark, so absolute, so far, No light wave from the oldest star Nor even the thought of God can reach And, fainting, fall on that far beach: Abhorrent and inhuman this,' Chinese call, "The Great Abyss."
A rally to protest against Nazi organization in this country was held last night at Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street, by the United Anti-Nazi Council.

Only thirty miles from its starting point at Union Air Terminal, Burbank, the wreckage of the airliner which crashed into a mountainside Monday, exploded and burned to death its nine occupants, was discovered today after being shrouded by dense fog for forty hours.

A client of Milton Buchsbaum, attorney, has purchased the threestory building at 80-82 Church Street, Montclair, N. J., for cash above a first mortgage of $86,400. The structure contains eight apartments and two stores and occupies a plot 86 by 125 feet.

After his second pitched ball went for a homer, Milkman Jim Turner, who revels in midsummer heat, braved the cold today and gained a fourteen-inning 2-1 decision over the Pirates to give the Bees their fourth successive victory.

Seton Hall defeated C. C. N. Y. today, 6-2, for its eighth victory of the baseball season. Kilcommons's single drove in two runs in the first and his double added another in the fourth. Finnerty's single pushed over the final brace of runs in the eighth.

Following closely upon the "death" in a House committee yesterday of a bill for establishment of a government "good-will" broadcasting service to Latin America, the Department of Commerce made public a report from the commercial attache at Rome, telling of current expansion of the Italian Government's international broadcasting facilities.

The men's and boys' clothing industry is receiving a steadily declining portion of the consumer's retail dollar, a trend posing several questions for both manufacturers and retailers which are unanswerable without more data on operations in the industry, Irwin M. Heine of the marketing division, Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce, told clothing credit men last night.

Frederick Innis Allen, retired patent lawyer, former United States Commissioner of Patents and a noted mineralogist, died Tuesday night of a heart ailment at his home, 55 East Sixty-fifth Street, after a few weeks' illness.

Lieut. Col. Walter Lloyd Bender, U. S. A. Air Corps, and Mrs. Bender of Langley Field, Va., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Truth Cornelia Bender, to Lieutenant William Pleasant Ragsdale Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ragsdale of McAllen, Texas.
The use of soybeans as a grain crop is attracting the attention of many New Jersey farmers, reports Dr. Howard B. Sprague, agronomist of the State Agricultural Experiment Station, Rutgers University.
Two funeral services were held yesterday afternoon for Dr. David H. Shelling, pediatrician and research worker, prominently identified with the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn, who died there on Tuesday.
Alfred Huger of Charleston, S. C., national authority on maritime law, d died here today. His age was 61 e years.

The passenger list of the Italian motorship Saturnia, arriving today from Mediterranean ports, includes Mr. and Mrs. L. T. Benant, Mrs. J. H. Burtenshaw, Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Morgan, Mrs. Frank A. Calderone, Miss M. B. Gower, Mr. and Mrs. Frederic H. Curtiss. Mrs. Robert B. Livingston, Mr. and Mrs. Melvin L. Rivard, John G. Robinson, Mrs. Douglas V. Wallace and Mr. and Mrs. Addison G. Brooks.

All relief stations in Chicago were closed today, and were expected to remain shut for the rest of the month.
