The 34,000 families, or 91,000 persons, who will get no cash assistance during May because of depletion of the city's relief funds will receive only surplus foods distributed by the Federal Government.

The Senate passed today without a record vote a bill legalizing wiretapping by government law-enforcement agencies. The measure would make proper a means of collecting evidence which, in the absence of specific legislation, was necessitated by a Supreme Court decision, handed down Dec. 20 in the Nardone case.

United States exports to China in the first quarter of the current year increased slightly because of indirect shipments through Hong Kong and Kwantung, while exports to Japan declined by $14,750,000, according to preliminary statistics made public today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

The first step to develop the East River Drive below Fourteenth Street as a recreation area was taken this week by Commissioner Robert Moses when the Park Department filed plans for the construction of four buildings and an addition to a one-story bandstand. The cost of these projects will be more than $200,000.
Wheat fluctuated in an erratic manner within a range of around 1 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade here today.

The entry lists from four more colleges for the sixty-second annual Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championships, at Randalls Island on June 3 and 4 were announced yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell. Dartmouth, with 36;

The bill increasing authorizations for the United States Housing Authority by $300,000,000 was reported favorably today by the House Banking and Currency Committee, after a situation had developed which may lead to the unusual procedure of a majority of the committee signing a minority report.

Charles J. Pannill, president of the Radiomarine Corporation of America, sailed yesterday on the French liner Normandie to attend the annual meeting of the International Radio Maritime Committee on June 13 in Paris.

The United States Steel Corporation's principal subsidiary has acted to stabilize present steel prices to the end of September, at which time the present price structure will have been in effect eighteen consecutive months.

President Roosevelt devoted his attention to routine business. The White House announced that he would attend the Navy-Harvard boat race at Annapolis on Saturday and would leave May 26 to spend a few days at Hyde Park.
Appointment of Rudelph. Reese as acting director of labor relations for the WPA Federal Theatre Project in this city was announced yesterday by George Kondolf, director of the project here.

President Lazaro Cardenas, in personal command of heavy contingents of Federal troops in the capital of the State of San Luis Potosi, last night charged General Saturnino Cedillo, broken war lord of the State, with having "carried on rebellious activities."

The St. Joseph Water Company, St. Joseph, Mo., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 7,000 shares of $100par value 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock, to be offered for the accounts of its parent American Water Works and Electric Cornpany, Inc. W. C. Langley Co. and others later to be named will be the underwriters.

The Senate today passed a bill to award gold medals to Mrs. Richard Aldrich, the former Margaret Livingston Chanler, widow of Richard Aldrich, music critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and posthumously to Miss Anna Boligny of New York for their services during the SpanishAmerican War.
Mrs. Adele Le Bourgeois Chapin, wife of Robert W. Chapin, a member of the American bar, died today at Ringham, Oxford. Her age was 76.

Three infants, grandchildren of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. and great-grandchildren of the late Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller, were born here within the last two days, it was revealed yesterday. Two are girls and the other is a boy.

A plaque commemorating the 300year military occupancy of Governors Island under three flags was presented to the War Department yesterday at ceremonies on the island. The plaque was the gift of the Military Intelligence Reserve Society of the Second Corps Area.

Miss Marie Margaret Gerety, daughter of Mrs. John Joseph Gerety of Silver Lake, S. I., and the late Mr. Gerety, was married to Edward Corbett Wallace, son of Mrs; William T. Wallace of the Bronx and the late Mr. Wallace, yesterday morning in the Church of the Sacred Heart, West New Brighton, S. I. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Thomas J. McLaughlin.

American prestige in South America 'will be impaired and American business will suffer if regular American ship service to Brazil and Argentina is withdrawn, it was freely predicted today by American business interests here at a meeting held at the American Chamber of Commerce.

Cornell scored its first lacrosse victory today after four defeats when it vanquished Colgate, 9-6, with the aid of a fourth-period rally. The teams went into the final frame tied at 5--5, but some fine playing on the part of Bob Brennan and Bob Babson carried the Ithacans to the fore.

Four Canadian officials of the. McCollFrontenac Oil Company who have been cooperating with the Texas Corporation to enable it to get an interest in. the Canadian company denied today allegations that they were trying to transfer complete control to American hands.

Trading in traefer meats was uneven: some classes met with a good demand, others sold slowly. The market was slightly irregular, hinds and ribs mostly steady, veal hindsaddles higher, lamb lower, pork steady to higher. Early trading in kosher meats generally slow and opening market weak to lower. Conditions, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Miss Julia Lane Alexander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Alexander of this place, was married here tonight in her parents' home to Robert Bogue Bell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus L. Bell of Noroton. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Brocklebank of St. Marks-in-the-Bouwerie, New York.

Dr. Ignatz T. Griebl, first lieutenant in the-Medical Reserve, United States Army, one-time national leader of American Nazis and an important but shadowy background figure in the government's greatest spy hunt in peace-time history, vanished last week, it was learned yesterday, only a few days before the Federal grand jury began hearing evidence of a German spy ring.

Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan called the political agitation in Jersey City "the greatest threat to American democracy" yesterday in addressing 1,000 delegates of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations at a meeting in the Community House of Congregation Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

George Zengaras, 135, East Side, scored a knockout victory over Frankie Terranova, 132 1/4, Harlem, last night at the first outdoor show of the season at the Queensboro Arena in Long Island City before a crowd of 2,000 persons. The end came in 37 seconds of the seventh of a listed eight-rounder when Terranova's seconds indicated to Referee Young Otto that the bout be halted.
The new $140,000,000 Dominion of Canada loan which went on the market today was oversubscribed half an hour after the books opened, the Finance Department announced.

Mayor La Guardia will deliver an address of welcome at the annual meeting of the State Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs tomorrow and Saturday at the Hotel Biltmore, according to an announcement yesterday.

There is never a dull moment in Brooklyn and yesterday proved no exception at Ebbets Field, where the Dodgers found themselves in the wrong again. For in the course of events, which brought the Cardinals a 12-4 victory and at the same time boosted Brooklyn's losing streak to four, a number of the talented local men suffered untold indignities and humiliation.

BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions CAROL-LEE SHOP, INC., coats and dresses, 1,658 Broadway.-Voluntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $5,605 and assets of S9,530.

With White House approval, Secretary Wallace today fired the opening gun in "another battle" involving the judicial branch of the government. What he termed as proposals "to have the courts invade the administrative field by taking over the rate-making and. regulatory functions of administrative agencies" were attacked.

Pennsylvania's Democratic State Committee hoisted victory signals today all along the primary election front, having fought off successfully John L. Lewis's bid for political power in every contest waged yesterday.

James Breath, retired general manager of the Seaboard branch of the New York Life Insurance Company, who died on April 23 last, left his residuary estate of undetermined value to the New York Community Trust. This was learned yesterday when his will was filed for' probate in Surrogate's Court. The estate was formally valued at "more than $20,000."

National Republican leaders contended today that the outcome of the Pennsylvania primaries indicated major gains for their party in November, but their predictions promptly were challenged by Democrats.

Banking partners and friends active in civic and industrial fields wilt serve as honorary pallbearers at the funeral service tomorrow for Edward T. Stotesbury, who died Monday night in his ninetieth year.

A May party for the benefit of Five Points Mission, which is at 69 Madison Street, will be given tomorrow at 2 P. M. in the parish house of the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.
Henry Bernstein, playwright, has challenged Edouard Bourdet, director of the Comedie Francaise, to a duel, according to friends.

The-iirst of the two international twelve-meter yachts to be built in this country this year was launched yesterday from the Nevins shipyard in City Island. She is the Nyala, for F. T. Bedford of the Pequot Yacht Club of Southport, Conn. Sparkman and Stephens designed her, along with the other twelve.

The first composite foreign trade balance for Great Germany, issued today for April, has proved something of a blow to the high hopes entertained here that Anschluss and the consequent ready access to the Danube region and the Balkans-would bring immediate expansion of that trade.
The Senate Commerce Committee took under consideration today a proposal by Chairman Copeland for an eighteen-mile bridge across Long Island Sound connecting New York and Connecticut.

Charles R. Hook, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, addressing the annual meeting of the American Foundrymen's Association today, offered a seven-point program, which he said would restore business activity in America if it received the necessary support.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation reaffirmed yesterday for the third quarter of 1938 its present prices on products for delivery and consumption in the United States, with the exception of quotations for certain flat-rolled products.
The Anaconda Copper Mining Company in the first three months of this year had a consolidated net income of $2,385,516 after all charges and taxes except depletion of metal mines.

The five-story building at 203 Montague Street, Brooklyn, once occupied by the-American Trust Company and later by the New York Title and Mortgage Company, has been leased for the BowerySavings Bank to the National Surety Corporation, which will rebuild the structure and occupy it as the main Brooklyn office of the company.

The reason for the removal of all tenants recently from the Theodore Roosevelt apartments in the Bronx--one of the largest projects of its kind in the country when erected in 1922-was revealed yesterday when plans were announced for the rehabilitation of the fourteen units into modern suites.

Whittlesey House announces for Fall publication "America Begins Again: The Conquest of Waste in Our National Resources," by Katharine Clover. Stuart Chase is writing an introduction to this book, which is an outgrowth of his own "Rich Land, Poor Land."

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for June 7 on an application by the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing the 5 per cent serial gold notes of the New York Dock Company due on April 1, 1938,

Kenesaw M. Landis grumbled a bit about the weather today and announced that each American and National League manager would have a voice in naming his circuit's team for baseball's big show, the July 6 allstar game at Cincinnati.

Alla Nazimova, who abandoned the screen thirteen years ago to return to the stage in her Ibsen repertoire, has joined the Paramount production staff as a consultant on "Zaza." The actress was starred in the stage version of the piece in 1901 in Russia and later came to this country, where she toured with it while Mrs. Leslie Carter was appearing in the English version.

Led by Woody Abernathy, who drove in four runs, Buffalo pounded out a 10-to-4 victory over the Jersey City Giants today. The Bisons scored five runs in the first. Abernathy collected his eighth home run of the season and two singles.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 18, unless specified: At-San Diego: Nitro, Kanawha, May 13. At Norfolk: Owl, Schenck, May 13. Navy Yard, Mare Island, to San Diego, via San_ Pedro: Chandler, Hovey, Long, Southard.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 16: REAR ADMIRAL Sadler, F. H., Commander Cruiser Division 6, to duty as member general board, Navy Department, about July 16.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum held in the United States at the close of the week ?? May 7 totaled 305,748,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.
ALBANY-Richard Healy Co.: J. R. Healy, ready-to-wear; 1,441 Bway (Specialty Stores Assn.). ALTOONA, Pa.--Smmond's; G. B. Simmond, ready-to-wear; 101 W. 31st (Wm. Loweth Co.).

The Securities and Exchange Commission amended its rules today to provide that applications for approval by it of the maximum amount of fees and expenses in connection with reorganizations of registered holding companies and subsidiaries in the Federal courts must be filed with it before a petition for fees or expenses is filed with the court, and also that the applicant must include a copy of the commission's findings in its petition to the court.

On the assumption that the World's Fair will definitely affect business here six months before it opens, as happened at the Chicago Fair, New York newspapers, stores and other business elements here are looking for a sharp upturn in the Fall, according to comment by executives yesterday.
The Peddie School nine downed the Horace Mann School for Boys, 6 to 5, in an Eastern Private Schools League game on the Horace Mann diamond yesterday.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and its affiliated companies were accused yesterday in State Supreme Court of illegally fostering the efforts of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, to organize their 40,000 employes.
Retail credit collections decreased 1.88 per cent in April, according to the index covering twenty local stores, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York.
The Red Navy today celebrated the fifth anniversary of the founding of the Northern Fleet, which, based near Murmansk, operates in Europe's northernmost waters.

Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Shiman of the Hotel Bradford, New York, and Naples, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adele Shiman, to Jacob L. Trobe, son of Mrs. Julius Trobe and' the late Mr. Trobe of Beaver Falls, Pa.

President Roosevelt, Secretary Perkins and Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, sent greetings today to the 300 delegates to the convention of the United Office and Professional Workers of America.

The Mendel Medal for 1938 was presented tonight at Villanova College to Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, for having given "practical demonstration of the fact that between true science and true religion there is no real conflict."

A syndicate which has been acquiring properties in Manhattan in the last seven months added to its holdings yesterday by leasing the six-story house containing twentysix apartments and six stores at 203 West 103d Street, northwest cornet of Amsterdam Avenue, from the Wilzur Realty Company. Inc.

Miss Hilda Kronman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Kronman of this city, was married this afternoon at her home to Joseph A. Lieberman, son of Mrs. Isaac Lieberman of this city and the late Mr. Lieberman. The Rev. Jacob L. Katzin officiated.

Acting under a sixty-eight-year-old statute, the Department of Justice is making an investigation to see if the regime of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City has conspired to violate basic Constitutional rights in the case of Norman Thomas and other individuals.

With the banks overstuffed with excess reserves as a result of the government's extremely easymoney policy, the offering of $25,000,000 of 2 per cent five-year notes of the Federal National Mortgage Association, made last Friday by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has brought in subscriptions of more than $1,000,000,000.

Continuing his practice in preparation for his quest of the French and British titles, Donald Budge faced the stiffest opposition he has met with in his workouts at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

Grote St (11-3100), s s, 143 feet e of Prospect Ave. 52x134; 1,531 Grote St., Inc., to Crescent Realty Co., Inc., 17 E 42d St. Poplar St (15-4082), s w cor of Jarrett Pl, 31x77; August C. Eschenback to Agnes C. Kunzelman, 1,616 Poplar St.

A judgment for $15,290 was entered in Circuit Court here today against the Jewish Community Center by the Ravegno-Hall Company, as assignee, for debts allegedly due since the construction- of the building at Bergen and Belmont Avenues in 1929.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a six-story apartment on Gramercy Park South to cost $300,000. Details of the plans follow:

Two promotions within its ranks were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission: the appointment of Francis T. Greene of Warrenton, Va., as an assistant director of the Trading and Exchange Division and that of Walter C. Louchheim Jr. of New York as assistant to the division's director, Ganson Purcell.

Mrs. Selina C. Cornish, widow of Edward Joel Cornish, former chairman of the board of the National Lead Company, died yesterday morning in her apartment in the Hotel Savoy-Plaza, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, at the age of 88.

Apparently unaware that Mayor La Guardia and Fusion have ruled New York for nearly five years, Mrs. Nora E. Dooley, an anxious mother of 501 Maple Boulevard, Kansas City, wrote to the "Democratic Precinct Captain in the district for the address 249 Sullivan Street," asking for information of her twin daughters, Nora and Cora, and enclosed a $1 bill "for the Democratic fund."

Premier Paul Spaak's new government received a vote of confidence in Parliament today by 132 votes to 38 on the basis of yesterday's Ministerial declaration in favor of budgetary economies and a form of democracy that might mean fundamental changes in the Belgian Constitution.

Dr. Jacob Oshlag, retired physician, who-had specialized in general diagnosis and psychiatry, died yesterday at his home, 300 Central Park West, after a short illness. Dr. Oshlag, who also had a home at Lake Mahopac, N. Y., had an office at 29 East Eightieth Street until his retirement in 1936. His age was 72 years.

Dr. Glenn Frank said in a prepared speech today that a "reckless misuse of governmental powers and misstatement of fact" marked the "attack" made recently by Senator Sherman Minton, Democrat of Indiana, on Rural Progress Magazine.

Formal announcement of his appointment as chairman of the newly created New York Joint Liquor Committee was made here yesterday by Gerald F. Dunne, president of the Metropolitan Council of Retail Package Store Associations, Inc.
Readjustment of prices on merchandise to Mexico was in prospect here yesterday among exporters following word that the Mexican. Government has lifted the 3 per cent tax on foreign shipments.

Trading was dull and price changes were small in the security and commodity markets yesterday. The stock market drifted higher and closed around the best levels of the day. The volume on the Stock Exchange was 398,000 shares, compared with 416,000 the day before.

Patrolman David K. Eisinger, safety man of the Thirtieth Precinct, Amsterdam Avenue and 152d Street, had an inspiration three months ago that a traffic sign on which a simple parody of a nursery rhyme was printed would be an excellent means of instilling vividly in the minds of children the importance of crossing streets at corners, with the traffic lights.

Leo C. Levin, vice president and controller of Emily Shops, Inc., was elected chairman of the Metropolitan Controllers Association at a meeting last night at the Roger Smith Restaurant, 40 East Fortyfirst Street.
Striking textile workers at the plant of Atlantic Mills, Inc., "carried on" today with the aid of a check they said was donated by a daughter of a former part owner of the mills.

British hopes for a settlement of the Spanish question struck a bad snag today, and there is serious concern over a hitch in the negotiations for a meeting of the Non-Intervention Committee for a final settlement of intervention issue.
The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company announced today a 10 per cent reduction in the pay of 13,000 salaried employes, including executives, effective on June 1.

Mrs. Emma T. Brenack McQuade, long a leader among Roman Catholic women locally, in the State and nationally, died on Monday at St. Mary's Hospital, Brooklyn, after a ten-day illness. Mrs. McQuade, the wife of George T. McQuade, president of the McQuade Stevedoring Company, Manhattan, resided at 941 St. John's Place, Brooklyn. Her age was 58.
The reorganization of the Naval Reserve forces was urged before the House Committee on Naval Affairs today by Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, chief of the Bureau of Navigation.
An elevator in the Queens Borough Hall fell from the third floor to the basement yesterday morning, injuring the operator and fourteen passengers, four of them seriously.

Deputy Mayor Henry H. Curran, crusader against noise, disclosed yesterday that he had turned over to, Police Commissioner Valentine an anonymous complaint about roosters at 920 East 220th Street, as too delicate for him to handle.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is considerable misunderstanding concerning present and past policies in the relief administration that affect the relation between landlords and certain of their tenants who happen to be receiving relief grants.

The showing this correspondent the admirably equipped and efficient headquarters of the social auxiliary of the Falangists at Valladolidbright neat nurseries with animals painted on the walls, spacious kitchens for feeding the poor, wireless for giving orders to branches throughout Insurgent Spain and elaborate card index records-the charming upper-class woman who is largely responsible for this achievement said:

Sentiment in the stock market here today was bolstered by yesterday's improvement in Wall Street, and although business was small, most sections were firm. Gilt-edge issues were steady, while among the foreign bonds Brazilian loans declined further.

IF the debates become too bitter over the coming Barney Ross-Henry Armstrong bout or the Schmeling-Louis affair, a diplomat can always lighten the trend of the conversation by dragging in Two-Ton Tony Galento.

In referring to the battle for Suchow as "the Tannenberg of the Far East," the Japanese imply that the hoped-for capture of this strategic railway junction, since January the military capital of the defenders of East China, will be a decisive victory.

The Fine Arts Federation of New York has adopted a resolution in commemoration of George Grey Barnard, the sculptor, who died on April 24. Prepared by Arthur A. and Charles W. Stoughton, the resolution says:

German Ambassador Karl Ritter, nine of whose countrymen have been held in connection with the short-lived Fascist uprising of May 11, was disclosed today to have called at the Brazilian Foreign Office.
The Society of Professional Musicians will give a concert of music written by its composer-members tonight at the society's auditorium, 1,347 Sixth Avenue.
Prime Minister J. B. M. Hertzog's United party sprang far into the lead as counting progressed early today in yesterday's general election in the Union of South Africa.

A protest against the exploitation of young Negro women engaged for wages of $1 a day or 15 cents an hour for domestic work at "slave markets" in Bronx and Brooklyn thoroughfares was made yesterday by Miss Dorothy Height, Negro representative of the Harlem branch of the Y. W. C. A.

9th St, 743 E, 25x92.3; Henry M. T. Beekman to Dry Dock Savings Institution; consideration $1,000; foreclosure. Horatio St, 46, 20x58,lxirreg; Francis X. Hennessy 2d to New York Savings Bank; consideration $3,000: foreclosure.

Bishop William T. Manning and Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler were the principal speakers last night at exercises held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the Training School for Nurses of St. Luke's Hospital. Nearly 1,000 persons, including several hundred nurses, were present.
Fordham's track and field team competed in its only dual meet of the Spring. season yesterday and vanquished City College at Lewisohn Stadium by 102 to 24.

Ernest T. Weir, steel manufacturer and prominent Republican, said tonight that he viewed results of the Pennsylvania primary as showing "clearly we will triumph next November with a united party." The chairman of the National
There were sixty-seven strikes involving 8,516 workers in New York State in March, the Division of Industrial Relations of the State Labor Department reported yesterday.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 17: BRIGADIER GENERALS Chaney, J. E. (Colonel), Air Corps, on expiration of appointment as Assistant to Chief of Air Corps, July 16, from Air Corps Training Center, Randolph Field, Texas, to Mitchel Field, L. I., and assume Command.

The marriage of Miss Sarah Adams Whiting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Butler Whiting of Sutton Manor, this place, to James Robert Baylis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Baylis of Scarsdale and Noank, Conn., will take place on the afternoon of June 10 in Christ Church, Pelham Manor.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, today added his voice to that of the Senate bloc that favors reconsideration of proposed new Federal credits for the railroads in the light of announced plans by the roads to reduce basic wage rates by 15 per cent.

When Hitler came into power the Communists here and elsewhere, having recovered from their initial shock, were all ready with their neat "classstruggle" theory to explain it. Fascism (including the Nazi brand) was "the last effort of a desperate capitalism to keep itself in power."

LeRoy C. Palmer, president of Franklin Simon's, last night presented awards to winning employes in the storewide sales contest staged for the two weeks ending May 14. The cosmetic department, with the greatest increase over its quota, 130 per cent, won the first prize.

In the Paramount's "Doctor Rhythm," Bing Crosby, Bea Lillie Co. are wooing the comic muse as though they had a $5 bet on its surrender. Maybe a $3. bet. Nothing quite so grim as their pursuit of the elfin guffaw has been seen in these parts since Martha Raye fell down the incinerator chute.

THE problem of Puerto Rico doesn't bother most of us, who find we have enough to worry about without worrying about a West Indian isle. But that doesn't make it any the less acute or its solution any the less desirable. For an objective and fairly up-to-date survey of the situation, see Trumbull White's "Puerto Rico and Its People,"* published today.

J. Warren Madden, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, in a radio address over the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight declared that the board would not modify its policy of vigorous enforcement of the National Labor Relations Act.

After an all-day debate devoted principally to the labor provisions, the House today passed the Lea Bill, under which a three-man Authority would be created having jurisdiction over all civil aviation. The Senate passed a similar measure

Resolutions assailing gambling and liquor advertising in newspapers and magazines were adopted yesterday at the second day's sessions of the New York East Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at the Hanson Place Central Church, Hanson Place and St. Felix Street, Brooklyn. More than 200 pastors were present.
Clifford Odets's "Golden Boy" will cease appearing at the Belasco Theatre on Saturday night, June 4, at which time it will have compiled a stout record. It opened on Nov. 6.
Brilliant running catches by Captain Crowley and John Martin, Providence College outfielders, marked today's 5-to-1 victory over Yale before 800 chilled spectators.

To the music of the Sixty-second Coast Artillery Band from Fort Totten, Fordham University's Reserve Officers Training Corps-350 strong--held its eleventh annual military demonstration yesterday afternoon before more than 1,500 spectators at Fordham Field.

Charges of disorderly conduct against fourteen students of City College were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate August Dreyer in the West Side Court. The students were arrested early Tuesday morning in

A sentence of five to ten years in the Bedford Hills State Prison for Women was imposed by General Sessions Judge Freschi yesterday on Mrs. Marie Rodriquez, 27 years old, of 1,650 Madison Avenue. The sentence was imposed on her

The Philadelphia Inquirer will say tomorrow morning in. a copyrighted story that the cruiser Philadelphia, the navy's newest $15,000,000 warship,: "sprang a leak" and shipped more than thirty tons of water while President Roosevelt was aboard her for a fishing trip ten days ago.

Electric power production showed a larger increase last week than looked for on the basis of seasonal and long-term trends, and the'adjusted index advanced to 90.6 from 90.1. It was 106.1 for the week ended May 15, 1937.

The outcome of yesterday's primary election in Pennsylvania was widely interpreted in Washington today as the most important political development since the beginning of the Democratic ground swell in 1930.

Annual tour of the Bronx park system conducted by the Bronx Board of Trade, leaving from 349 East 149th Street 11:30 A. M. Luncheon, Concourse Plaza Hotel, 161st Street and Grand Concourse, noon. Speakers; Borough President James J. Lyons, Edward O. Seiffert.

Miss Abbie Adaline Rollins, daughter of Mrs. Ellsworth H. Rollins of this place and the late State Senator Rollins of Laconia and Alton, was married here this afternoon in the Congregational Church to Gardner Arthur Caverly, son of Mrs. Arthur L. Caverly of Laconia and the late Mr. Caverly. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George Dahl of New Haven, Conn.

At the final business session of the thirteenth annual meeting of the American Association for Adult Education here today a resolution recommending that attention be given to safeguarding' adult education against Federal and State control was withdrawn by the resolutions committee in the face of opposition lead by Carl Milam, secretary of the American Library Association.

ON THEIR OWN APPLICATIONS-To take effect 12 midnight, May 17: Lieutenant Joseph P. Murray, -7th Division, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed Jan. 30, 1907. Patrolman Thomas J. Barrett, 88th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 1, 1904.

Lord Robert Crichton-Stuart, son of the Marquess of Bute, who yesterday sold real estate embracing half the city of Cardiff, Wales, sailed for New York today on the liner Queen Mary. It was reported that Lord Robert planned to invest part of the proceeds of the sale in the United States, but he denied this strenuously.

Stock market closed firm and mixed in quiet trading; industrial shares slightly higher; turnover, 398,370 shares. United States Government bonds steady and slightly higher, other groups irregular; transactions, $4,632,900.
Herman Schulte's fumble on Crabtree's grounder with the bases loaded and one away in the ninth enabled the Red Wings to triumph, 1 to 0, today and sweep their threegame series with the Bears.

The board of directors of the Holland-America Line gave a dinner to a group of distinguished representatives of The Netherlands and this country last night on board the flagship Nieuw Amsterdam, on the occasion of the ship's first visit to the United States.
The marriage of Prince Antonius of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha and Luise Josepha Meyerhofer, daughter of a Steyr postal official, was reported today.

H. E. Morriss's Pasch, winner of the Two Thousand Guineas, went back to 2 to 1 today in the betting for the Derby at Epsom Downs, June 1. In the call-over of odds at the Victoria Club, the colt was strongly backed at that figure as compared with 15-8 on Monday.
Turpentine firm, 23c; sales 56 barrels; receipts 480 barrels; shipments 10 barrels; stock 33,315 barrels. Resin firm; sales 561; receipts 2,400: shipments 319; stock 103,919.

Allowing only six hits, Wesley Ferrell pitched the Senators to a 5-to-1 victory over the Tigers today. Ferrell aided his own cause with a homer with the bases empty in the fifth. He was deprived of a shut-out when Chester Laabs hit for the circuit for Detroit in the seventh.

Cumbersome as the German economic system may look, with its official controls over all business and labor activities, there is the undeniable fact that it has worked so far and that all classes have shared in the financial benefits resulting from the upswing.
Business leasing yesterday was brisk along Fifth and Madison Avenues and included several contracts for store locations.
Stockholders of the Taggart Corporation will be asked on June 8 to consider a proposal that the company acquire the properties of subsidiaries and assume their funded debt.

The Congressional committee investigating the Tennessee Valley Authority voted today to hear Dr. Arthur E. Morgan, recently removed by President Roosevelt as chairman of the Authority, as its first witness, and then to hear Dr. Harcourt A. Morgan, the new chairman, and David E. Lilienthal, the other member of the board of directors.

A plea for better educational op portunities for sailors to make the sea attractive as a permanent ca- W reer was expressed last night at a dinner of about fifty representatives of the shipping industry at the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

Jules Sassani, member of the executive board of the Grand Opera Choral Alliance, announced yesterday that the union would appeal Monday's decision of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, governing body of American Federation of Labor entertainer unions, under which it lost its jurisdiction over chorus groups in grand opera to the American Guild of Musical Artists, headed by Lawrence -Tibbett.

Since the 131/4 per cent reduction on April 16 of reserve requirements, surplus reserves of member banks have risen in four weeks $750,000,000, but commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the same banks have decreased $138,000,000.
The dispute between the management of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and the Guaranty Trust Company, trustee for Alleghany Corporation bonds, was compromised yesterday.

You may put us among victims of "retardation" and thick-headedness in school, if you like, but we can't help being pleased by the experiment of Dr. Harry Eisner, head mathematics man of Manual Training School.

The trial of the sixty-six wealthy coal operators and well-paid peace officers indicted for conspiracy to flout the Wagner act in Harlan County made progress backward today as peremptory government challenges, exhaustive examination of talesmen and confession reduced the number of jurors tentatively selected.
Mayor La Guardia assailed yesterday the high salaries paid to court clerks and contrasted them with the lower salaries paid to the Park and Police Commissioners.

Bob Feller scattered six hits among the Athletics today, had only one bad inning and won his fifth game of the season, 7 to 2. The victory pulled Cleveland within 13 percentage points of the idle first-place Red Sox and even with Boston in the games won and lost column.

Miss Isabel Gibson, daughter of Mrs. Hugh F. Gibson of Bennington, Vt., and the late Mr. Gibson, was married here yesterday afternoon in Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, to Wilson Derr Sked, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman S. Sked of Pennington, N. J. The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

An injury suffered by Ellis H. Parker Jr. earlier in the day forced the postponement today of a scheduled appearance of Mr. Parker and his father in Federal Court here to file an appeal from an order for their removal to Brooklyn for trial on indictments accusing them of the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel. Judge William Clark postponed the hearing until next Wednesday.

Prizes and certificates of honorable mention -were awarded yesterda. to 111 pupils of art-in the city's elementary and junior and senior high schools for posters embodying the spirit of the $10,000,000 campaign of the Greater New York Fund to supplement the finances of private welfare and health agencies.

The 154th annual commencement of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary will be held at Kirkpatrick Chapel, Rutgers University, tomorrow morning, with the degree of Bachelor of Divinity to be conferred upon seven students. The speaker will be Dr.

Governor Lehman returned to the Capitol today, after three weeks of fishing off the coast of Florida, looking rested and tanned, but completely silent on the subject of politics. He expects to remain here until after Memorial Day.
The State Department is seeking permission for Americans in China to return to cities from which they were driven by Japan's advance, officials said today.

The twelve-family dwelling at 90 Ongley Street, Rockville Center, L. I., has been purchased by Gotham Equitles Corporation (Joseph K. Alliger and Hyman Ratner) for cash, J. Holmes Swezey acting as broker.

The Royal Society of Medicine today informed Dr. W. J. McNally, oto-laryngologist at Royal Victoria Hospital, that the Dalby prize for the best work in his field during the past five years had been awarded to him.

During the last decade an average of more than $150,000,000 annually has been spent by communities in the United States in extension and improvement of waterworks facilities, according to the American Water Works Association.
A milkprice war which has dropped retail prices to low levels brought a demand today from Western New York farmers for a State investigatibn.

Julian C. Smith, president of the Shawingan Water and Power Company, announced yesterday that a special meeting of shareholders of the company had been called for June 15 for the purpose of considering a by-law enacted by the directors calling for a reduction of Capital and simplification of the company's balance sheet.

Up-State Republican leaders, confronted today with an assertion by leaders from the metropolitan area that the Constitutional Convention must do something about reapportionment, prepared to press for recognizing territory as well as population in any redistricting of the State's legislative seats.

The leading European exchanges made further recovery in terms of the dollar in yesterday's foreign ex change market. Sterling rose 1/8 cent to $4.96 7/8, the franc advanced 3/8 point to 2.79 7/8 cents, the guilder was up 3 points to 55.36 cents and the Swiss franc up 3 3/4 points to 22.84 1/2 cents.
The law of averages and the Cubs caught up with the Giants all on the one bounce at the Polo Grounds yesterday and not even the gifted talents of Carl Hubbell could do anything about it.

Ellesworth A. Hawthorne, 71 years old, a retired business man, and his wife, Eliza, 70, were found dead in their gas-filled residence at 51 Alred Avenue by their married son, Stuart Hawthorne, a builder, of 82 Lewis Place, shortly after 7 o'clock tonight.
Several charitable organizations, beneficiaries of the twenty-fourth Rittenhouse Flower Market, as well as prominent garden clubs, will maintain booths at the market tomorrow in Rittenhouse Square.

Financial newspaper men of this city assembled last night in the Hotel New Yorker and paid tribute to Charles R. Gay, who on Monday closed his third successive term as president of- the New York Stock Exchange.

An issue of $2,150,000 Department of Water and Power of the City of Los Angeles 2 1/4 and 2 1/2 per cent water works revenue bonds, first of 1938, was awarded yesterday to a banking group headed by Lehman Brothers on its bid of 100.04 for the combination.
The business depression was attributed today by David J. Leopold, president of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association, to the "hostility manifested by those in high places to business profits."

The earnings of the Consolidated Oil Corporation are running below those of the corresponding period last year, according to H. F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee, who presided at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday. He said, however, that the company Was earning its dividends.

Three men accused of holding up a girl and her escort while they were in a parked car in Rayside, Queens, early yesterday were held in bail totaling $160,000 by Magistrate Anthony Savarese in the Queens Felory Court.

The Democrats of Pennsylvania have declined to turn over the State government to a single economic group. They have refused to exchange Pennsylvania for the political and financial support given the President by John L. Lewis and his C. I. O. in the past and for assurance of this support in the future.

Former President Hoover talked in Milwaukee tonight but not about politics, except as he described the problems of training American youth in general as one of the major political problems to insure the future of democracy.

Residents of the St. Mark's Garth apartments will hold their. annual garden party and entertainment on Saturday afternoon- at 111 East Tenth Street. The historic gardens and church grounds will be opened to visitors as well as some of the studios of resident artists.
The 1938 revenue bill, now awaiting the signature of President Roosevelt, contains a provision which would eliminate the present penalty on cut-rate theatre tickets, it was learned today.

Miss Judith Black, daughter of Mrs. H. Clifford Black of Pelham Manor, N. Y., and Broadmoor, Col-. orado Springs, has completed plans for her marriage on July 9 to Farish Alston Jenkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Edgar Jenkins of St. Louis.

Officers of the National Power and Light Company received an additional twenty-four hours yesterday from officials of the city of Knoxville and the Tennessee Valley Authority in which to answer on the "yes or no" offer. made last week to buy for $7,500,000 the Tennessee Public Service Company, a National Power subsidiary operating in Knoxville.

The Daladier government today set a restrictive quota for importation of motor trucks, truck parts and chassis. These items, which previously have come chiefly from the United States, had not been under quota before.

BREATH JAMES (April 23). Estate, more than $20,000. To Grace K. Glasby, 16 Pearl Ave., Verona, N. J.; Fanny Hoover, Ramsey, N. J.; Elizabeth W. Ayrault, 380 Beacon' St., Boston, Mass.; Charles A. Breath, Bay St. Louis, Mo.; Eugenie V. Cologne, 4,734 St. Peter St., New Orleans La. : Ann W. Dunbar, 80 Park St., Montclair, N. J.; Charlotte E. Hopper, 145 E. 60th St., and Helen Wilkin, 1 University PI., $2,500 each: Eloise Wood.

A large whale, estimated by members of the Rockaway Point Coast Guard station to have been at least 50 feet long, romped briefly yesterday in the shallow water by the jetty that extends from the point out to sea.

Full opportunity of employment for professional women musicians was proclaimed as a right yesterday morning at Steinway Hall at the first mass meeting- of the sixweeks-old committee for the recognition of women in the musical profession.

Close of play scores in English first-class cricket matches started today, follow: Lancashire 280 (Paynter 63, Oldfield 54, Lister 54, Philipson 51, Smith four for 47); Middelesex 81 for two, at Lord's.
President and Mrs. Roosevelt will visit their Hyde Park home over the Decoration Day week-end, according to tentative plans announced at the White House today.
To the derisive jeers of a partisan crowd in Sportsman's Park today, Joe DiMaggio gave the only response at his command.
